column2: SIDNEY, N.S.W., Sept. 30. -- It is not improbable that an American offer to establish iron works in New South Wales will be accepted by the Government of that State, which has caused the following letter to be published:

Everything was in shipshape order yesterday at the Baltusrol Golf Club for the women's amateur golf championship, which will begin Tuesday morning and be continued through the week. The course never looked better and the fair green, where once there was roughness of turf and cuppy lies, will bear comparison on the score of perfectness with any links in the country.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Charles H. Allen, ex-Assistant Secretary of the Navy and ex-Governor of Porto Rico, was a witness to-day before the Senate Military Affairs Committee in the Heistand investigation. He declared in the most emphatic manner that he never had had any connection with the proposed hemp company.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 5. -- 1 The State College football team scored on Pennsylvania at Franklin Field this afternoon during the only lapse the Quakers had in their fast and good game. The score --23 to 6-- does not show the real character of the work of the Red and Blue, who, gathering strength as the game progressed, played all around the State College men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Medical expert testimony has heretofore been looked upon almost with jocularity, but after the revelations in President McKinley's case what Judge or jury will hereafter pay any serious heed to it?

The tract of about 275 acres, known as Echo Hills, near Chauncey Station, on the New York and Putnam Railroad, has been bought by the New York Juvenile Asylum, and after the necessary buildings have been erected, that institution will abandon its present home on Washington Heights.

FOR the three hundredth anniversary of the death of Tycho Brahe, the Scandinavian astronomer, on Oct. 24, an elaborate celebration in honor of the occasion is to take place on the Island of Hven, or Hveen, in the sound between the Kattegat and the Baltic, where Brahe lived and worked for many years.

The proverbial good luck of the New York Athletic Club in the matter of good weather for its games was unbroken yesterday, and the throng of about seven thousand fashionably attired people who made the uncomfortable trip in crowded cars to the beautiful Summer home of the club on Travers Island had a delightful outing in one of the most attractive suburbs of the city.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A large party of the friends of Sir Henry Irving, Ellen Terry, and other members of the Irving company lunched with them and bid them farewell to-day on board the Atlantic Transport Line steamer Minnehaha, which sailed from London to-day for New York.

A WELL-DRESSED and generally dapper man, with an elastic step and a pervading air of well-preservedness, visited a prominent oculist a few days ago. As he tripped up the front steps of the physician's house he smiled deprecatingly, as who should say: "I am on a fool's errand, and if any one supposes that I am here because it is necessary that I should come, he may disabuse his mind of that impression."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 5. -- Harvard defeated Bates in their annual football game on Soldiers' Field this afternoon by a score of 16 to 6, the visitors' score being made owing to a fumble by Swann on Harvard's twenty-five-yard line and quick work of Blake of Bates, aided by the good interference of Ailen.

The new series of black and white prints in the upper corridor at the Lenox Library consists of etched work by Rembrandt van Ryn. While some of the famous prints are there, such as the Good Samaritan and the Angel Appearing to the Shepherds, and the Ecce Homo, a number of portraits etched by Rembrandt from the looking-glass form the most interesting part of the exhibit.

OUGHT a man to have a better right to the name of some one else than to his own name in his own business? This is the question which a good many manufacturers and solicitors are trying to answer. The sharp reversal of the policy which had prevailed for nearly twenty years in the registration of trademarks in the patent office at Washington is responsible for the discussion.

THEY are Brooklyn girls and were spending the Summer at Mendham, N. J. Each day they took long drives through the country, stopping at the farm houses along the roads to buy old mahogany furniture, brass andirons or colonial china.

AN agent for a large apartment hotel on West Thirtieth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was approached the other day in his office by a young man who desired to look at an apartment with a view to leasing it. The agent and the stranger spent an hour or more in the building, and finally the young man agreed that the suite on the very top floor was just what he wanted.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- A special dispatch from Rome says that the construction of the new tunnel beneath the Quirinal has so seriously weakened the foundation that the palace is endangered.

Oscar Hammerstein will open the Victoria Theatre Thursday evening next with a new spectacular musical comedy, entitled "Sweet Marie." The book is by R. Jackson and the music by S. Brown. Jacksons and Browns are plentiful in the theatrical profession, but the librettist and composer in this instance are more than likely myths.
OS. STEVENS, who is a clerk in a feed store on Chenango Street, Bingbamton, N.Y., once refused to buy for a saddle horse and $100 what is now known as the Comstock Silver Lode, in Colorado.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- Copies of general orders from the Department of Cuba just received at the War Department contain the records of an interesting court-martial trial.

ROBERT CARR of Edenville, Orange County, N.Y., had a thirty-two-dollar set or harness. One night his parn was broken into by some one who stole the harness. Not long before that a horse belonging to Farmer Edsall, near by, was stolen from the lot where it was pasturing.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 5. -- An effort was made here to obtain from Marquis Ito a statement regarding the announcement from London that Japan is about to procure a loan of 50,000,000 yen, equal to $25,000,000, in gold in the United States. Of this sum it was asserted that 5,000,000 yen was to be expended in Formosa.

AS I sat before my fire lale one stormy December night, I was startied by a Knocking at the outer door, and, when I opened it, there entered one who asked for shelter at my hearth from the snow and sleet which raged in a whirling blizzard against the earth.

From London Truth. The courtyard and the facade looking on it remind one of the Palais Royal on the Rue de Rivoli side, where Prince Napoleon lived. One ascends to the grand apartments by magnificent stairs that convey the idea so dear to Matthew Arnold of sweetness and light.

-- Reflection convinces us that the hymnologist of the Democratic Club, whose curious contribution to organization poesy we were privileged to publish Friday, would have done better had he stuck closer to SCOTT and left POPE alone, or at least have paraphrased the two, not in a single breath, but in separate ones.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Gov. Odell was present at the Goshen horse show to-day, which marked the sixth annual show of the Orange County Horse Show Association. He had a vital interest in the exhibits, for his daughter, Miss Estelle Odell, had an entry in the class for the most attractive and stylish pony turnout.

A boy ran into the Madison Street Police Station about 9 o'clock last night and told the Sergeant at the desk that murder was being committed in a synagogue at Madison and Clinton Streets. Capt. Fitzpatrick, who was in the station house, heard the report, and with six patrolmen went to the place.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much impressed by a letter in a late number of THE TIMES signed "D.," and treating of the subject of the "Aged Poor."

FALL, RIVER, Mass., Oct. 5. -- The strike threatened by the cotton mill operatives here, to be begun next Monday morning, to enforce a demand for a 5 per cent, increase in wages, has been declared off for two weeks by the Textile Council.

The Republican and Citizens' Union campaign books will be issued to-day. The books will be the same, except for the proceedings of the conventions of the two organizations. Many statements are made in regard to the administration of the City Government under Tammany rule.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- A correspondent of The Times, wiring from Dundee, Natal, says that during the progress of a big movement such as is now being conducted by Gen. Lyttelton in the southeast corner of the Transvaal, the news consists mostly of a record of the movements of the Boers from farm to farm in their attempt to escape the cordon which is being drawn around them by the British troops.

Under the charter that will go into effect at the opening of the term of the Mayor elected this Fall the powers of that office will be Confined within a somewhat narrower range, but Within that range will be far greater than at present. The Mayor will cease to have the appointment of the Commissioners of Public Improvements, and all the functions of that department will be transferred to the several Borough Presidents.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The rapid Recline of the native population of the Aleutian chain of islands is told in a report just received by the Marine Hospital Service from F.J. Thornbury, the Assistant Surgeon at Dutch Harbor, Alaska. The report says that formerly there were 120 villages on the islands, with a native population variously estimated at from 1,500 to 2,500.

There are those who will remember with ourselves the not distant past when American railroads were thought so peculiarly the enemy of ail except themselves that legislation was advocated by Populists and Grangerites to curb their extortion. The truth, of course, was and is that American railroads are the best friends in America, or in the world, of anybody who has anything which he wishes carried to or from the American market.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Sixty lodgers in the Planters Hotel, a cheap lodging house for men on Mulberry Street, opposite Centre Market, narrowly escaped suffocation in a fire which started early this morning on the second floor. The men were asleep on the two floors above.

The Committee of Fifteen, following out its expressed purpose to publish from time to time the results of investigations in order to put the public in possession of facts, and to bring about the adoption of such corrective measures as may be needed, yesterday gave out a partial report of its work in so far as this work relates to the expulsion of vice from tenement houses.

MANILA, Oct. 6. -- Considerable interest attaches to the case of Oakley Brooks, a military prisoner ordered to be deported. The Insular Supreme Court recently issued a writ of habeas corpus directing the production of the prisoner, but the military authorities refused to produce him on the ground that the only tribunal having jurisdiction of a militatry prisoner is the Federal Court.

MANILA, Oct. 6. -- Major Morris C. Foote of the Ninth United States Infantry, who has returned here from the Island of Samar, was in Balangiga the day before the disaster to Company C. He says that Capt. Connell had been fully warned and had taken what he (Major Foote) considered every necessary precaution.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- The week ended with money so cheap in the open market that balances were with difficulty tent until Monday at 1 per cent. The market was giving indications of this coming ease all the week. Much less than usual was borrowed by it from the Bank at the end of the quarter, so that yesterday's glut of dividend payments left it after these borrowings had been repaid flush with funds.

Sheltered from the wind by the high bluff that overlooks the west side of the Harlem River Speedway, New York City's road drivers spent a couple of very enjoyable hours yesterday morning stepping their crack trotters and pacers. The company was fast, and all classes were well represented, so that there was no lack of exciting brushes, close finishes marking the majority of them.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The Times's financial article to-day says money was very abundant on Saturday owing to the release of Government dividends. At the close balances could not be placed at all in many cases. Only a small amount fell due at the bank. In the discount market rates were unchanged, the tendency being weak.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Edward M Shepard, the Democratic nominee for Mayor of New York, arrived here shortly after midnight; after traveling seventy miles from his Summer home in Caldwell by trolley car. While refusing to talk upon the subject of his candidacy, he made this statement:

The meeting of the Citizens union on Saturday night was an appropriate opening of the anti-Tammany campaign. It gave to the candidates, who did nearly all the speaking, an opportunity, which they seized eagerly, to show that they all stand fairly and firmly on the principles of the union.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6. -- Four men are under arrest here charged with kidnapping a woman, holding her a prisoner for four days, robbing her of jewels worth over $2,000, and compelling her to sign checks for large sums.

BELOIT, Wis., Oct. 6. -- George F. Stock-well, a student in the preparatory department of Beloit College, was enticed from his room in the house of President Eaton to-day by members of the middle preparatory class. He was overpowered, divested of all his clothing, and compelled to walk ahead of a score of howling students, who tormented their victim with switches.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 23. -- The universities have resumed work quietly. There are no present indications of fermentation, though the more stringent enforcement of the exceptional restriction of the attendance of Jewish youths in the intermediate schools, the universities and the other, higher educational institutions is causing much heartburning.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 6. -- A stir was created among the politicians this evening by State Chairman Jones issuing a card withdrawing from the United States Senatorial race and suggesting a plan through which a bitter political campaign may be avoided by sending Gen. Wade Hampton back to the Senate after an absence of about eleven years.

The favor and commendation with which the report of the United States Steel Corporation for the first six months of its business existence has been received give proof of the public disposition to welcome the policy of publicity in the management of great corporations whose shares are offered on the investment market.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- Just how much money has been given to the fund for the ransom of Miss Ellen M. Stone, the American Board missionary held captive by brigands, is not known to-night. Those directing the effort in her behalf hope that the response throughout the country to-day has been very liberal, and that the figure is fully $100,000, if not the necessary amount which is $10,000 more.

NEWARK, N. J., Oct. 6. -- This was "handicap day" at the Vailsburg cycle track, even the quarter-mile dash for professionals, being handicapped. The principal event of the day was the ten-mile professional race, which was fast from the start. The back-mark men caught the leaders in the fourth mile, and from that point to the finish the struggle was close and exciting.

There were four fires yesterday in the four-story tenement house at 554 Third Avenue. Three were on the ground floor, which is occupied as a branch office of the Postal Telegraph Company. The other was in the cellar among some newspapers. Three families reside in the house. They suspect the fires are of incendiary origin and threaten to move out of the building.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 6. -- The law firm of Bailey Vorhees of this city, lawyers for Fred Gebhard, have filed in the State Circuit Court here a suit in which Mr. Gebhard asks for absolute divorce from his wife, Mrs. Louise Morris Gebhard.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 6. -- Congressman John F. Shafroth, who has been traveling in China and the Philippines for the past four months, has reached home. Speaking of the conditions in the Philippines he said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- At a memorial meeting of the Ohio residents of Washington, held under the auspices of the Ohio Republican Association to-day, a letter from Dr. M.D. Mann, one of the President's physicians, to T.M. Sullivan, the Secretary of the association, was read. It was as follows:

Edward M. Grout has sent the following letter of acceptance of the nomination for Controller, tendered him by the Republican, Citizens' Union, and other anti-Tammany organizations to the various fusion bodies:

The Republican and Citizens' Union Assembly District Conventions will be held to-night for the purpose of nominating candidates for the Assembly and for Aldermen. In nearly all of the districts complete fusion upon the Assembly and Aldermanic contests has been attained. The candidates for the Assembly who have been agreed upon by these two organizations are as follows:
Patrick A. McMamus, a lawyer, whose offices are in the New York Life Building, in a light wagon drawn by a spirited brown horse had been having a spin on the Speedway yesterday Afternoon.

Kyrle Bellew, the English actor, arrived in New York yesterday on the Umbria. With his manager, George Tyler, he drove directly from the pier to a photographer's studio. He spent four hours before the camera.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 6. -- All the evidence to be offered by the Judge Advocate in the Schley Court of Inquiry is almost in. His case will be finished some time this week, and Rear Admiral Schley will then begin to put his own witnesses on the stand. A number of facts have already been established by the inquiry, and the state of the case is now about as follows:

--Perhaps it was the inclination, shared with most of humanity, to believe interesting stories not intrinsically improbable, that led us to accept as true a yarn which reached us the other day about the recovery of 10,000 sovereigns from an old wreck in Lake champlain; perhaps we did it because we found that The Springfield Republican.

Archbishop Corrigan, at the 11 o'clock high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, yesterday begain a series of sermons on Socialism, in the first at which he took the position that Socialism, using the popular definition of the word, is wrong, since Christ's views of political economy were in keeping with the ideas upon which all present government is based.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- This was a day of oratory in the House of Deputies of the triennial Episcopal Convention. The debate, which began last Saturday on the proposed addition to Article X. of the Constitution, prescribing the form of worship, was continued all day, and resulted in its adoption. As adopted it is as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not like to leave America without thanking the numerous friends who have made my short stay there so pleasant.
BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. New Yord funds sold at par and 5 and 10 cents premium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The features of the day at the Schley court were a graphic and thrilling story of the Santiago fight by Lieut. Commander Hodgson and a defense of Schley's bombardment of the Colon by Capt. Folger, who was described by the Judge Advocate as an expert in ordnance matters.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 7 -- Capt. Bosanquet's team of English cricketers met with a crushing defeat to-day on the grounds of the Germantown Cricket Club at Manheim, near here, it being the third day of the second and last test match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and the visitors.

Over seventy, and probably as many as seventy-five, competitors of the eighty-five who are entered for the women's golf championship of America are expected to start in the qualifying round this morning on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N.J. The name of Mrs. Lewis of Philadelphia has been added as a late entry omitted from the original list, and that makes an even eighty-five contestants.

The Right Rev. Knute Henning Gazelius von Scheele, Bishop of Wisby, Sweden, and a member of the Second Chamber of the Swedish Diet, was the guest of honor at a dinner tendered to him last night at the Hotel Manhattan by representative Swedes.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The speech of H. Kelly of New York at the Anarchist meeting held in London on Sunday has led to a revival of the demand for the extirpation of Anarchists.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 7 -- The steamer Duke of Fife, which sailed from Yokohama on Sept. 21, brings a story of the public suicide of a Chinese woman at Foo-Chow. She resolved on the deed after the death of her husband, and informed the public of her intention.

YORK LODGE, Lake Manitoba, via Poplar Point, Northwest Territory, Oct. 7 -- Yesterday and to-day were probably the most informal spent by the Duke of Cornwall and his party since they began their tour through Canada. The arrangements made by Senator Kirchhoffer for the entertainment of his guests were perfect in every detail.

Yachtsmen who had feared that the defeat of the Shamrock II. would so discourage foreign contestants that it might be years before another aquatic struggle were delighted to learn last night that Sir Thomas Lipton has decided to leave his boat in America for the Winter. Unless there is some change in his plans he will race her next season against the Columbia and the Constitution.

President Seth Low bade formal adieu to the students and Faculty of Columbia yesterday morning in the auditorium of the newly completed story of University Hall. In the afternoon the Trustees received and accepted Mr. Low's resignation and named Prof. Nicholas Murray Butler as the Acting President of the university, to hold office until some one is chosen to fill the office permanently.

The report of the engineers employed by the District Attorney to examine the condition and, incidentally, the management of the East River suspension bridge adds very little to the knowledge already possessed by those for whom the sub- ject has interest. In the discussion which followed the fracture of the suspender rods last Summer all the facts discovered by Messrs.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The villagers at Penns Grove, a few miles below this city on the Delaware River, were scared badly this morning by a fire which for a time threatened to destroy the most thickly settled portion of the village. The flames started in the property wall between the stores occupied by F.J. Layton as a butcher's shop and by George Justice, a tobacconist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many frequenters of the Park bridle paths and drives must deplore the loss of Policeman Hoey of the mounted squad, who on Thursday was crushed to death while in discharge of the duty he had for years performed so well -- "killed in action," we may say as truly of him as of any other brave soldier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Statistics compiled by the Marine Hospital Service for 1,190 cities and towns in the United States having a population of 1,000 or more, indicate for the United States an annuar mortality for the last calendar year of 17.47 per 1,000 of population, according to the census of 1900.

Mayor Van Wyck talked public business arid politics at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday. The three departmental estimates considered were those of the Department of Water Supply, Bridges, and the Department of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The Court of Appeals has affirmed the decree of Surrogate Silkman of Westchester County in the matter of the ascounting of other executors of James Russell deceased.

Richard Croker received a copy of Mr. Shepard's speech at the Democratic Club within a short time after its delivery, and before the members of the Manhattan delegation had returned from Brooklyn. There was but a small attendance at the club at the time. Soon afterward Mr. Croker retired to his room.

Edward M. Shepard announced his campaign principles and made his pledges to the voters in an address delivered last evening to the Notification Committee of the Democratic City Convention, when he formally accepted the nomination for Mayor. There was little formality about the proceedings.

CROKER must disclaim SHEPARD and SHEPARD must disclaim CROKER. Each must repudiate the other with emphasis and specification. That is the only way in which both can fool the people, as both are trying to fool the people in this campaign.

It was evident that the theatregoing public regarded the first appearance in this country of Charles Hawtrey, the English comedian, as an event of no little importance, for the audience at the Garrick Theatre last night was one of large size, interested mood, and plentiful demonstrativeness.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 7 -- The Worcester Traction Company, which has owned street railways in the Massachusetts city from which it is named, at a special stockholders' meeting to-day voted to retire and cancel 19,600 shares of its preferred stock. The company recently sold its system to a syndicate, and may go out of business.

-- Possibly a canary bird story will be safer than stories about submerged gold, particularly as we find the canary bird story in The Christian Register, the contributors to which, we fondly assume, keep imagination well within bounds, and carefully discriminate between fact and fiction. The canary bird in question, we read, had long grieved its owner, by utterly refusing to take a bath.

One of the most mysterious crimes in the history of the Police Department was discovered yesterday morning shortly before 6 o'clock, when the body of Albert Robertson, a little mulatto boy of five years, living at 300 West Twenty-first Street, was found mutilated and stuffed in a burlap bag on a grass patch in front of the basement area of the apartment house at 361 West Twenty-second Street.
WALTER D. DAVIDGE, for fifty years a practitioner at the Washington (D.C.) bar, founder of the District of Columbia Bar Association, died in Washington yesterday aged seventy-eight years.

The Court of Appeals recently gave an important decision in a suit by John H. Bosworth, as receiver of the Genesee National Savings and Loan Association, against Charles M. Allen and others, which was an action against the Directors of the defunct corporation for an accounting by them for loss or waste of assets and undue gain to themselves resulting from a breach of their trust.
Richard Croker spent yesterday listening to statements by leaders and friends as to candidates for the Supreme Court Justiceships. The convention will be held on Thursday in Tammany Hall.

BEAUMONT, Texas, Oct. 7 -- The oil wells in the Beaumont fields have caused new wonder in the last few days, and an investigation of the principal cause of the strange action of these former gushers is to be made by a geological survey, of which Dr. William B. Phelps is at the head.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Robert, E. Burke, under two indictments charging embezzlement of city funds, resigned his position as oil inspector to-day. The resignation was acccepted at once by Mayor Harrison, who will name Burke's successor next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- "If I can't find Republicans I am going to appoint Democrats," said the President to-day to Representative C.W. Thompson of Alabama. "I am going to make such appointments as will make every Southerner respect the Republican Party."
LONDON, Oct 8 -- No confirmation has been received at the Foreign Office of the report of the death of the Ameer, but the accuracy of the report is not doubted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Schley court of inquiry to-day entered upon the third straight week of the investigation of Admiral Schley's conduct in the Spanish war. It had been expected that the Navy Department would be able to complete its presentation of the case by the close of last week, but when the court opened today Capt. Lemly's list of witnesses still contained almost a dozen names.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Money was in moderate demand to-day and the market was flooded with unanticipated Government dividends. The tenders for local loans Oct. 9 and the consols installment Oct. 10 are expected to remove some of this surplus.
BOSTON, Oct. 7 -- Nearly half the money needed to ransom Miss Ellen M. Stone, the missionary, from the Bulgarian brigands, has been placed in the hands of Messrs, Kidder, Peabody Co.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The Union College football team to-day defeated the Hobart eleven by the score of 35 to 0. The contest was a walk-over for the local collegians, who outplayed the visitors at every point and won on their merits.

A long line of anxious taxpayers of both sexes stood on Chambers Street yesterday from 9:30 o'clock in the morning until after 4 o'clock in the afternoon, anxious to pay money to Collector of Taxes Austen's 400 assistants. It was the first day on which cash in payment of taxes for 1901 could be received.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The Marconi Company and Lloyd's Shipping Agency have entered into an agreement whereby the stations of the agency throughout the world are to be equipped with wireless apparatus.

All exchange of passes and free transportation between railroads for officials and employes of the same will be stopped if a report formulated yesterday at a committee meeting of railroad Presidents, held in this city, is adopted by the various passenger organizations in the Unites States.

With the last of the great prizes of the turf season, the Matron Produce Stakes, as the chief attraction, the last great meeting of the Eastern racing year will open to-day at Morris Park. The race will be the third running of the Matron Stakes, for two-year-olds, at six furlongs, over the Eclipse Course.

Collector Bidwell yesterday gave out a decision declining to seize the Japanese Silks imported by A.S. Rosenthal Co., the invoice of which was returned last month by Appraiser Wakeman as fraudulent. After a very thorough investigation of this case it is the opinion of the Collector and the experts in his office that the charge of fraudulent intent cannot be sustained.

Argument upon the writ of habeas corpus issued by United States District Court Judge Adams in the case of the wardman, George Bissert, convicted of bribery, was yesterday heard by Judge E. Henry Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 7 -- It was announced at a meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Association to-night that Boralma was too sick to meet The Abbott in the proposed $30,000 race Wednesday. He has congestion of the lungs. The Directors then attempted to have Cresceus substituted, and offered $5,000.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Dispatches from Simla received here last evening state that the Ameer of Afghanistan died at Kabul on Oct. 3.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 -- The only stocks that attracted much attention on the Stock Exchange to-day were Consolidated Lake Superior and Choctaw common. There was a rise in the latter stock caused by the declaration of an increased dividend, in addition to a 10 per cent, stock dividend, but nearly all the gain was lost before the close, as the action of the board had been pretty generally foreshadowed.

Prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday moved with much irregularity, now up, now down, with the close showing a fair degree of strength in a number of the more active issues, notably the Vanderbilts, the copper stocks, Atchison, Union Pacific, and Southern Pacific, while in inactive stocks and some of the industrials there was continued heaviness.
P.L. Crovat, who already owned 138 to 144 West Forty-fifth Street, has acquired the adjoining property, No. 136, from Jefferson M. Levy. An apartment house will be erected on the plot.

The Municipal Council transacted more public business at the session yesterday than has been accomplished at the last five sessions of the board. Chairman Oakley of the Railroad Committee reported in favor of granting a franchise to the Union Railway Company to run tracks over the Central Bridge and the Viaduct connecting the tracks of the Union Railway Company with those of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

Continued strength in some of the copper stocks and an increase in activity in the Seaboard issues were the chief features of the outside market yesterday. The list as a whole continued its irregular course, with transactions, showing totals not above the recent average. The heaviest loss of the day was recorded in Standard Oil, which was weak and somewhat more active than usual.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Between the leaves of a book bought yesterday at a second-hand store in Boston has been found the will of Samuel Welch of Strafford, N.H., who died in 1890, and whose estate of about $8,000 was subsequently eaten up by litigation.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 8. -- Mrs. John Clinton Gray, Mrs. J.F. Stone, and Mrs. C. C. Pomeroy returned from New York today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An old Roman historian tells how a vindictive General once spent his rage on a captured foe. His victim was stretched at full length on the ground. Ropes tied to the ankles were then tied to horses, which, being driven in opposite directions, the body was thus torn in two.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of those who believe that under public ownership of public utilities the consumer or passenger pays less charges than under the system of private ownership, I erave a little space to reply to your leader of Sept. 18 on "The Government and the Telegraph."

MELBOURNE, Oct. 8. -- In the Federal House of Representatives to-day the Commonthwealth Tariff bill was introduced by the Right Hon. Charles Cameron Kingston, Minister of Trade and Commerce, who congratulated the House on the fact that free trade now existed among the States of the Commonwealth.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- More than 200 delegates from boards of trade and commercial bodies in twenty-five cities in the United States gathered here to-day for the purpose of dismissing the propriety of appropriating public moneys for the Improvement of rivers and harbors in the United States.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell to a much smaller total than on the day previous, little over 5,000,000 shares being dealt in. But though the market was less active it was much stronger, under the continued leadership of the Vanderbilt stocks and such shares as St. Paul, Union Pacific, Delaware and Hudson, Erie, and Southern Railway.

The Fusion nominees for borough and county offices were yesterday notified of their nomination. The notification took place at the headquarters of the Republican County Committee in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building on Madison Square. All of the nominees of the County Convention were present, with the exception of those for the Supreme Court Justiceships.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- Money was abundant and easy to-day. The demand was moderate.

In her excitement over the discovery that her pocketbook containing $4 was missing, Mrs. Louise Atkins of 414 West Fifty-third Street, a shopper in a Sixth Avenue department store, yesterday accused the first person she turned to of taking it. This proved to be Jessie Pierpoint, seventeen years old, who was accompanied by her older sister, May Pierpoint.
Seth Low, when asked yesterday what he had to say in reply to Edward M. Shepard's speech of acceptance, said that he did not care to refer to it informally.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The indictment of Robert E. Burke for the embezzlement of public funds has started a shaking up at the City Hall, which seems to have no end Mayor Harrison to-day came out with the following statement:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- The feature of to-day's sessions of the Triennial Episcopal Convention was the reconsideration and defeat of what is known as the Huntingrton amendment to the Constitution, which was adopted by the House of Deputies yesterday, providing for the use of modified forms of worship by congregations willing to accept the spiritual oversight of a Bishop, although not in full communion with the Church.

LEXINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The three opening events of the ten days' meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Association, which began here to-day, were won in straight heats, though each was hard fought to the wire. In the Kentucky Futurity, value $16,000, Walnut Hall, the favorite, could do no better than lap with Peter Stirling, the winner, around the circle and finish a half length behind.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- The Rev. Jere K. Cooke, curate of Grace Episcopal Church, this city, has accepted a call to the rectorship of St. George's Church at Hempstead, L.I. Mr. Belmont and two other of the Vestrymen of St. George's came to Baltimore a few Sundays ago to hear Mr. Cooke preach, and they invited him to preach at St. George's. The call followed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Judge Advocate Lemly of the Schley inquiry is now engaged in putting in cumulative evidence. His witnesses are testifying to things already proved or disproved, and hence no new facts about the Santiago campaign were developed in to-day's session.

Fire Chief Edward F. Croker had occasion at a destructive early morning fire yesterday, for the third time in three days, to severely censure the police for negligence in turning in alarms during the last tour between midnight and dawn.

The long-delayed annual report of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company for the year ended June 30 last was issued in Wall Street yesterday. It shows total receipts of $12,185,559, total expenses of $7,210,008, and net earnings of $4,919,551, as compared with net earnings last year of $4,662,177.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8. -- Another aggressive move has been made by the American Sugar Refining Company in the campaign which it has begun against the beetsugar industry. The cut in the price of granulated sugar to all Missouri River points, which was announced last week, has been followed by a reduction in the price of beet and cane sugar in all States from Colorado to California.
John J. Townsend, Referee in Bankruptcy, has just filed a decision which gives a bankrupt the privilege to do business in a new concern, without liability for individual indebtedness.

The New York Yacht Club gave a reception and dinner to Sir Thomas Lipton last night at the clubhouse, on Forty-fourth Street, and nearly three hundred members of the club were present. Commodore Lewis Cass Ledyard received the guest of the evening and his party and acted as toastmaster at the dinner.

With the exception of Columbia, all the prominent college football elevens have games today. Harvard plays Amherst, and as Amherst held Yale down to one touch-down a week ago, the contest will furnish a comparison of the strength of the two elevens at present. As the other games are with teams that have not as yet contested with the big elevens, no comparison can be made.

Spoken by the honest candidate of a reputable party, the words uttered by Mr. SHEPARD in accepting the nomination of Tammany would command the assent and win the support of thousands of men unselfishly devoted to the cause of good government who will not now vote for him because his candidacy does not fulfill both the expressed conditions.
Seven caribou were added to the animals in the New York Zoological Park yesterday. They came from Newfoundland by way of Bangor, Me., in charge of R.L. Mayer.

Patrick Divver and association in the Second Assembly District, after some wordy disputes, last night came out regularly for Edward M. Shepard. Fritz Lindinger, who had been on the committee of Germans to notify Seth Low, protested against this and left the meeting.

Motormen and conductors on the Metropolitan Street Railway system are in full dress, and are to be paragons of neatness for three days. The number plates on the caps, and badges and buttons on the uniform are all polished until they shine. Shoes are shlned. Dust accumulated on many rides through the streets is brushed away.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The wedding of John Appleton Havens Hopkins of New York and Miss Alison Low Turnbull, daughter of Lieut. Frank Turnbull, United States Navy, retired, was celebrated at 12:30 to-day in the Church of the Redeemer by the Rev. Dr. E.E. Butler of Madison, N.J. The bride, who entered the church on the arm of her father, was gowned in white crepe de chine, trimmed with old point lace.

In the Brooklyn Royal Arcanium bottling tournament, on the Elephant Club alleys last night, the Empire State Council team, though in Class B of the tournament, rolled in Class A form, making a high score of 924. Buck made 234, which is the highest individual score of the tournament so far. Empire Council won two games; Washington Irving Council won one game and lost one, and De Witt Clinton Council lost two games.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- The stock market was brighter all around to-day, and prices were higher for nearly all the leaders. The trading was of a wider range than had been the rule recently. Consolidated Lake Superior common rose three-quarters and the preferred a point, on the settlement of the equity suit against the company, but later the common receded to last night's figure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent article on the annual appropriation to the City College appears to me to overlook the fact that there can no more be primary education without, the higher education than there can be a child without parents. The training of teachers has come to be recognized as a function of the State.
The work of the Committee of Fifteen in cleaning prostitution from tenement houses is simply invaluable.

F.B. Brill has sold for the estate of Mary A. Redfield for $60,000 the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 40 West Twentieth Street, 25 by 92. The buyer, J.A. Stevens, will erect a store and loft building on the lot.

Samuel Fay, General Superintendent of the London and Southwestern Railway, and J.W. Jacomb Hood, Chief Engineer of the same company, who have been spending several weeks in this country traveling over the principal railroads for the purpose of examining their methods of operation, traffic arrangements, and other important subjects of railroad management, talked of the general results of their investigations to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

Mayor Van Wyck and President Miles M. O'Brien of the Board of Education carried on a lively discussion before the Board of Estimate yesterday when the educational budget for 1902 was under consideration. President O'Brien asked for $20,465,016.67 to run the schools next year, which is an increase of $1,952,198 over the amount allowed by the Board of Estimate for this year.

Edward M. Shepard, the Democratic candiate for Mayor, remained in his home, in Congress Street, Brooklyn, yesterday. He was not feeling well, and denied himself to all but a very few visitors. When Mr. Shepard was seen in the afternoon he said that he had determined not to discuss the political issues during the campaign at his home.

As a resurt of the ruling of Commissioner of Internal Revenue Yerkes regarding the matter of taxation of collateral pledged as security for loans, a number of Clearing House bankers yesterday sent a request to Washington for the exact wording of the ruling. As it now stands, the ruling admits of several meanings, and a plain statement of it may do away with any discussion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The proceeding's of the day began by the recall of Capt. W.M. Folger for the purpose of correcting his testimony of yesterday. Advantage was taken of his presence to ask him further questions concerning the blockade of Santiago. Among other questions, he was asked by Capt. Lemly if he had had any conversation with Commodore Schley during the blockade.

It is settled that the Shamrock II. is to stay in American waters this Winter, and next Summer she will probably be seen in races on Long Island Sound and elsewhere. Sir Thomas Lipton said yesterday that the yacht would be laid up at Erie Basin, and not at New London, as originally intended.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter with this caption in THE TIMES of Sept. 27 from a clergyman, signed "W. B.," while inviting attention" to the humilitating attitude and utterances of Christian ministers in connection with the murder of President McKinley, concludes by falling into the same shocking attitude -- attributes the act to God! "If God rules the world."

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says the difference between Emperor William and the Municipal Council of the capital regarding the appointment of Herr Kaufmann as Second Burgomaster is still the main topic of discussion in the press.

We had something to say, when the trial Judges in this judicial department struck work for their Summer vacation, about the unseemliness of a three nonths' vacation in the face of two fears' arrears. Further investigation has convinced us that we were in the wrong in assailing the administration of justice in New York upon that ground.
Congratulations for THE NEW YORK TIMES on account of its Jubilee Number, issued on Sept. 25, still come in dally. Among those received are the following:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see by the papers that his Grace the Archbishop of York has put forth the suggestion that a day of national humiliation and prayer should be appointed for the purpose of entreating the Almighty to grant greater success to the British arms in South Africa.

There were many friends of Richard Croker who openly avowed yesterday that the Tammany leader did riot like the emphatic manner in which Edward M. Shepard stated repeatedly in his speech of acceptance that he stood by all his political utterances of the past. Mr. Shepard, in the Mayoralty campaign of four years ago said that Tammany Hall was a corrupt organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- The list of casualties sustained by the rank and file of the ill-fated Company C, Ninth Infantry, in the massacre in the Philippine Island of Samar, is given in the following cablegram from Gen. Chaffee, received at the War Department late this afternoon:

COLON, Colombia, Oct. 8 -- (Previous cabling of this matter prevented.) -- A force of Liberals numbering at least 250 attacked Morro Island, commanding the entrance to the port of Tumaco, Sept. 24. The island had all along been garrisoned with fewer than a hundred troops, well supplied with arms, ammunition, and commissary stores, including more than 150 head of cattle and other provisions in proportion.

The first production of Ernst von Wolzogen's play, "Ein Unbeschriebenes Blatt" ("A Blank Page") at the Irving Place Theatre last night proved a felicitous occasion for everybody concerned. Curiosity was manifest in regard to Fraulein Gerthe Kupfer, from the Neuen Theatre, Berlin, who made her debut with Mr. Conried's company, and incidentally scored a pronounced success.

There have been few more remarkable deliverances from the bench of New York than the opinion by which Judge GIEGERICH supports his decision that Capt. DIAMOND is entitled to a change of venue, since he cannot get a fair trial in this county. Everybody, says the learned Judge in effect, and almost in terms, believes that any policeman accused of taking bribes is guilty.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- Miss Kate Spencer Ellis was married to Thomas Horlor Truslow of Guantanamo, Cuba, formerly of New York, at Trinity Church this evening. The bride is the only daughter of Major and Mrs. Eugene A. Ellis. Major Ellis is Collector of Customs at Guantanamo.

Fire broke out in the hold of the bark Criffel, lying at Pier 12, East River, last night, and as it contained a cargo of gunpowder, cartridges, and kerosene oil, the firemen worked in peril of their lives.
According to Galveston dispatches, the export business of that port for September shows, a remarkable increase, cotton and wheat leading, but lumber falling off greatly.
BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds were in good demand at 5 and 10c premium. Exchanges, $26,214,530; balances, $2,744,384.

Yesterday was delightful in both town and suburbs and the opening of the Women's National Championship Golf Tournament at Baltusrol with the tea and reception at the clubhouse of the Baltusrol Club was the chief event of the day. To-day will be marked by the occurrence of several important weddings, all of them out of town.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 8. -- An interesting feature of the evening session of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, which is holding its annual meeting here, was the official report of the board concerning the captivity and ransom of Miss Ellen M. Stone. The report was as follows:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 8. -- The marriage of Miss Louise Green Fisk and Lewis Edmund Waring was celebrated yesterday. The wedding was the most brilliant society event that has taken place in this city this Fall. Invitations had been issued to more than 2,500 persons in this city, New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Newport, Washington, and various other cities in this and adjacent States.
LONDON, Oct. 8. -- At the meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Grand Trunk Railway the report of the President, Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, was unanimously adopted.

The fusionist campaign opened on the Bowery last night with a largely attended meeting at the hall of the Republican Club known as Annex No. 1, at 274 Bowery, and practically the first campaign gun on that historic thoroughfare was fired by Frank Moss.

Another so-called Tammany tip went wrong at Morris Park race track yesterday, and Mr. Croker and his friends lost heavily on it. The tip was De Reszke, a horse in the stable of Frank Farrell, which it was said by Mr. Farrell could not lose.
According to Philadelphia dispatches, the limit for the sale of Bethlehem Steel Company minority stock at $24 a share has been extended to Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- For the first time since the Schley court opened a witness has been found willing to directly charge Rear Admiral Schley with cowardice. The charge was made to-day in explicit terms by Lieut. Commander Templin M. Potts, who was the navigator of the Massachusetts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- The action of the greatest importance taken to-day by the triennial Episcopal Convention was the adoption by the House of Bishops, by a vote of 37 to 21, of Cannon 36, which relates to the solemnization of marriage. All of its provisions had previously been argued, except those contained in Section 4, which forbade the marriage of persons divorced for any cause not existing before marriage.

The long-distance coaching trip from New York to Philadelphia and return, on the French four-in-hand vehicle Tantivy, began in this city at 6A.M. yesterday and ended at the Holland House at 1:32 this morning.

The stock market yesterday was one of the dullest in recent weeks, with trading falling to what now is considered insignificant proportions. Approximately 370,000 shares were dealt in during the entire session, with only eight stocks traded in to the extent of more than 10,000 shares each.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- The United States Circuit Court to-day took under advisement the famous case involving the levy of a countervailing duty on Russian sugar imported into this country, argument in behalf of the National Association of Manufacturers, who had entered a protest against the duty, being completed by E.H. Bigelow of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the magazine supplement of yesterday's TIMES is a paragraph concerning the alleged petering out of a movement in 1881 to build a large church in Washington by the "sect" called the Christiana, the movement having, it is alleged, had its rise in the desire to provide a more imposing edifice in which the President -- Garfield -- might worship.

Madison Square Garden resounded yesterday with the ringing of every imaginable sort of street car gong and fare register and with the hum of an electric plant that furnished power for the moving exhibits of the exposition that supplements the twentieth annual convention of the American Street Railway Association.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- Father T. McGrady of St. Anthony's Church of Bellevue, Ky., wishes to debate on socialism with Archbishop Corrigan. The cause of the challenge is the Archbishop's recent warning against socialistic doctrines being spread among the members of the Catholic Church.

There were some good poker players among the 660 cabin passengers who landed in New York from the White Star liner Oceanic at noon yesterday. At least that is the opinion of a young Englishman -- A. C. Burnley -- who on Tuesday morning as the Oceanic neared the American shore, sought Capt. Cameron and told him that he had been inveigled into a stateroom and lost u20 in cash and u82 in I.O.Us.

Secretary Thomas A. Fulton of the Citizens' Union yesterday made public a letter which he received from George Foster Peabody, in which Mr. Peabody explains the reasons that led him to resign from the Union and espouse the cause of Edward M. Shepard, the Democratic nominee for Mayor.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- A resolution of confidence in President Roosevelt was ruled out of order in the National Rivers and Harbors Congress to-day. It was not that the greater number of the representative business men from twenty-eight States have not confidence in the President, but an unfortunate incident and the expression of a New Orleans delegate forced the Chairman to bar the resolution.

With singular unanimity foreign military attaches who have been following the British arms in the field in South Africa have agreed that the British officer was as conspicuous for his recklessness in exposing himself as he was in his supreme ignorance of the methods of modern warfare.

Good golf, but no sensational surprises, marked the day's play yesterday in the first match play rounds for the women's National championship on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N.J. For a weeding-out day, the gallery was unusually large early in the morning, and a long line of enthusiasts left the tee in the wake of each pair.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- A dispatch from Durban to The Times says there has been silence lately regarding Gen. Lyttleton's operations on the border of Natal, which have been directed against the desperate attempt of the Boers to extricate themselves from the critical corner in which, their bold dash on Zululand placed them.

It may or it may not be a significant star of the times that the theatres at which the largest crowds of people at the present time are to be found are those in which frivolity reigns. All the serious dramas on exhibition in New York at the present are receiving only a modicum of the patronage which they deserve.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9 -- Miss Abby Green Aldrich, second daughter of Senator Nelson W. Aldrich, senior Republican Senator from Rhode Island, and John Davidson Rockefeller, Jr., of New York, only son of John D. Rockefeller, were married at noon to-day at the Summer residence of Senator Aldrich at Warwick Neck.
A municipal campaign costs money. Where, for each side, is the money coming from in this campaign?

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- The Philadelphia market opened strong, but there was not enough business to maintain the gains of the start, and, except for a few arbitrage stocks, the market dragged through the rest of the day. Most of the business was in Reading and United States Steel.
All of the evidences in lower Wall Street point to a war to the end in the Missouri River Valley between the cane and beet sugar interests.

Practice of the Columbia football team yesterday was far ahead of the best form the team had previously shown this season The 'Varsity, with excellent dash, scored twice on a scrub that included five line men who have at one time or another played on the 'Varsity. The quintet were Wolff of the '99 'Varsity, Neidlinger of the 1900 'Varsity, and Duden, Martin, and Shaw, who have been on the present first team.

The marriage of Miss Jennie Gertrude Cohen, daughter of Simon Cohen, to Dr. Zama Feldstein, formerly of Calcutta, India, was celebrated last evening at the Tuxedo. The pride was attended by her two sisters, Florence Hilda and Harriet Cohen. The flower maids were the bride's two cousins, Florence Cohen and Miriam Gizang.

Commissioner MURPHY owes Commissioner SEXTON a letter. That in which Commissioner SEXTON assures Commissioner MURPHY of the zeal and intelligence of the police in their co-operation with the movement of the Committee of Fifteen and the Health Department to purify the tenement houses is very pleasant and creates an obligation which should not be overlooked.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Money and discounts were easy to-day. Apart from the settlement, operators on the Stock Exchange were nearly idle. Consols improved. Indians were steady, a reaction after yesterday's gloomy forebodings. The South African news was considered encouraging.

Practically the only event of special interest in the outside market yesterday was a sharp break in Standard Oil, followed by as sharp a recovery. Elsewhere the list moved in about the same course which it has followed for some time past, price movements being irregular, but for the most part unimportant.

The independent Democrats who met at the home of School Commissioner Herman A. Metz, 253 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, Tuesday night and pledged their support to Edward M. Shepard, began active work yesterday by hiring headquarters at 361 Fulton Street.

-- Delightful proof of how extremely funny our cousins across the water can be, and still remain utterly unconscious of it. and also of the amazing seriousness with which they take their people with titles, even though the wearer of the title may be of American birth, is given by a little news paragraph which we find in a copy of The London News just arrived by mail.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Notwithstanding to-day marks an important turning point in the career of Rear Admiral Schley, being nothing less than the date of his transfer from the active to the retired list of the navy, he was in his accustomed seat within the railing of the Sehley court of inquiry and gave his usual attention to the proceedings of the court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Frank D. Hill, United States Consul at Amsterdam, in a communication to the State Department, says: "The necessity for United States manufacturers to adopt the metric system in foreign trade becomes daily more imperative. A firm in Holland received this week a cable offer from New York for 2,000 barrels of potatoes.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 9. -- Harvard defeated Amherst on Soldiers Field to-day by a score of 11 to 0 in a game that was full of the keenest excitement. Amherst held Yale down to a single touch-down a week ago, but the crimson scored twice through good, steady, hard rushing. On the whole, Amherst considers Harvard stronger than Yale in the back field and nearly as good in the line, only not quite so heavy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Ex-Gov. W.C. Oates of Alabama directs attention to the fact that the President's recent appointee to the District Judgeshlp in Alabama will probably have to pass upon the validity of the suffrage clause in the amended Constitution. Ex-Gov. Jones was ex-Gov. Oates's predecessor in office, and he characterizes him as "an honest and capable gentleman."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9 -- The market to-day was dull and easier. The most active features were the United Railways bonds, which were under a slight selling pressure, as a result of which the fours lost 1/2 and the incomes 5/8. The number of gains was limited to three -- a gain of 3 points for Commercial and Farmers' Bank, 1/4 for Georgia, Carolina and Northern 5s, and 1/4 for Georgia and Alabama consol 5s.

It is late for picnics, but there is something that may be a convenience to a traveeler and it is not a bad thing to have on hand. It is in silver, plated, the size of an ordinary pocketknife, the plated blade being useful as a fruitknife or for other practical use, and combined with this is a spoon and a salt spoon.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- State Excise Commissioner Cullinan to-day issued a statement making a comparative showing of the number of licenses issued and net receipts under Excise Boards for the year ended April 30, 1896, the last year under the old law, together with the number of tax certificates in force and net receipts for the year ended April 30, 1901, under the new law, by boroughs, in Greater New York, as follows:

Robert L. Martin and Henry Veltheusen, President and Secretary of the Delaware Surety Company, who were arrested on Tuesday night by Detectives Farrington and Feeney of the Centre Street Court squad on warrants issued by Magistrate Olmsted, were arraigned in the police court yesterday, charged with, perjury, and after an informal hearing held in $10,000 bail each.
BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- Money loaned between banks at the Clearing Hous'e to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $24,309,326; balances, $2,300,171.

Edward M. Grout, the fusion candidate for Controller, addressed the Public Ownership Union last night at its regular meeting in Civic Hall, 128 East Twenty-eighth Street. The subject was, "What Can Be Done Now on Lines of Public Ownership in New York City."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- New York State Day at the Pan-American Exposition was observed to-day. At 9 o'clock this morning the Reception Committee assembled at the City Hall to receive the specially invited guests. These included the Governor and members of the Governor's staff, their wives, and members of the Legislatures of 1899, 1900, and 1901.

Certain persons, representing themselves to be connected with various New York newspapers, including THE NEW YORK TIMES, have of late been soliciting subscriptions among financiers, politicians, lawyers, and others for the ostensible purpose of endowing a hospital bed for newspaper artists and actors.

A text book has been issued by the regular Democratic organization in Brooklyn for the use of campaign speakers. Bridge Commissioner John L. Shea, as Chairman of the Democratic Campaign Committee, at a meeting of speakers for instruction last night in the Thomas Jefferson Building, called attention to the book.

Mr. SHEPARD professes two sets of principles, quite unlike, wholly antagonistic. He addresses the voters as a partisan, a Democrat, nominated by Democrats, appealing to Democrats for support, and presenting as the sole objection to his opponent the fact that he is a Republican whose nomination "was dictated by the Republican organization."
There were developments at the Citizens' Union Convention in the Thirty-first Assembly District last night that indicate that there will be ill-feeling among the fusionists of the district.

RIVERDALE, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The wedding of Eugene Pintard Bicknell and Miss Edith Babcock took place here to-day at 3 o'clock in Christ Church. The bride, who entered the church on the arm of her brother, William Evelyn Babcock, wore the conventional white satin gown and veil, both trimmed with rare old lace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- Senator Cullom of Illinois evidently has concluded that there is so much sentiment in the West in favor of reciprocity and so much belief that the tariff may be amended without danger to any substantial interest, that reciprocity will have to be supported as a policy to avoid entering upon a tariff-reducing session of Congress.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The Almada Sugar Refineries Company of New York City was incorporated to-day, with a capital of $3,500,000. The company will operate in Mexico. The Directors are Jorge E. Almada and Jesus Almada of Navototo, Mexico. E.J. Johnson of Twinsburg, Ohio, Santiago Smithers, George Nordenholt, and Charles W. Mackey of New York City, and G.V. A. Conger of Belleville, N.J.

The golf at Baltusrol, the various suburban weddings, the restaurants, and theatres divided the attention of society yesterday. At Meadow Brook there was a hunt in the afternoon. At Morristown to-day the horse show begins. This is an event in its social history.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9. -- Yale scored 24 to 0 against Wesleyan this afternoon. The game was slow, but abounded in individual plays of real brilliancy. Capt. Gould made Hogan and Goss distinguish themselves, while De Saulies did some very clever running back of kick-offs and Glass did some powerful interferance.

STURGEON BAY, Wis., Oct. 9 -- The whaleback steamship Thomas Wilson, belonging to the United States Steel Corporation, went on the reef at Bailey's Harbor about 9 o'clock last night during a heavy storm and dense fog, and word was received here at 10 o'clock to-day that she has broken in two and is a total loss.

LIABILITY OF RAILROADS TO EMPLOYES. -- The Fourth Appellate Division has affirmed a judgment dismissing the complaint in an action brought, by Joseph Rager against the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company to recover damages for injuries sustained by him while employed as a car repairer in the defendant's repair shop.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 9 -- To-day's sessions of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions were devoted to reports of officers and addresses. Dr. Judson Smith, Corresponding Secretary, stated that in the eleven missions under his supervision there are 208 missionaries, of whom 13 have gone out for the first time, and 2,092 native laborers, of whom 82 are pastors of mission churches.

Mrs. Lucy Carroll, daughter of Charles Kornder, a wealthy retired dry goods merchant of Brooklyn, and wife of Charles Carroll, formerly a Brooklyn hat manufacturer, but now in the Philippines, was shot twice at the home of her father, at 26 South Elliott Place, Brooklyn early yesterday morning, by Capt. John Nelson, 31 years old, until recently engaged in the Government transport service.

-- Commenting on the report of the engineers appointed to investigate the condition of the Brooklyn Bridge, Engineering News says that if, to laymen, the report in some passages seems to hint that the bridge is unsafe, and in others to assert that its strength is adequate to meet present demands, this is due to the fact that the word "safety" is a relative term, and the experts recognized two of its degrees or meanings.

MINING AND METALLURGY, (New York City.) -- Mining and Metallurgy felicitates with THE TIMES upon its success and wishes it continued prosperity and increasing power for good in the community. The Jubilee Number just issued by THE TIMES presents in attractive form the history of the sheet, and embodies many other features of special interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- Substantial advances in the Readings and Lehigh Valley gave the Philadelphia market the most of its business to-day. The upward turn in Wall Street was responded to quickly on small transactions. New York took all the Reading common and second preferred that was offered, the common rising 13-10 and the second preferred 11-16.

Capitalists with holdings in Mexican mines read with concern in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the arrest of W.H. Meahly at Monterey, Mexico. Mr. Meahly is known to have large interests in the neighboring republic. He has been a miner there for fifteen years. The fact that he is held incommunicado is regarded as very serious.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Oct. 10. -- The British Royal Mail steamer Eden arrived here to-day from Laguayra, Venezuela, and brought the following story: Last Sunday night about fifty sailors from the German cruiser Vineta became engaged in a street row, at Porto Cabello, with the local populace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The killing of Policeman Hoey by an automobile in Central Park the other day prompts me to say a word which I have long wanted an opportunity to say upon a subject of vital importance to the citizens of New York who use the Park highways on horseback or in carriages.
McVickar Co. have sold for the estate of Charles Tisch the plot of three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 194.4 feet east of Riverside Drive.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The Southampton Horse Association of Southampton, Suffolk County, was incorporated to-day to hold horse shows, improve the breed of horses, and to maintain grounds for polo playing and other sports. The Directors are F. Gaillard Thomas, Thomas H. Barber, Charles Coster, Henry W. McVickar, Stephen Peabody, and George R. Schieffelin of New York City, and George A. Dixon of Southampton.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10 -- Edward Browning and a number of well-known Philadelphians will attempt to break the record for the coaching trip made yesterday by Alfred G. Vanderbilt and party between New York and Philadelphia. After the Vanderbilt coach left the Bellevue yesterday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 10. -- The idea of a peaceful and conclusive arrangement between Venezuela and Colombia of the existing trouble is not repulsive to Venezuela, it being always understood that Venezuela's national honor will in no way suffer thereby. During the past fortnight this idea has grown and has secured increased following in Caracas.

BUFFALO, Oct. 10 -- The seventh annual meeting of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs ended to-day. The color question, which, it was expected, would be disposed of at to-day's meeting, was once more left unsettled, so far as this federation is concerned.

The annual report of the Reading Company for the year ended June 30, 1901, was made public yesterday. The report says that the surplus is increasing, but that it is not now available for distribution without weakening the company. All the improvements have been charged to expenses. Notwithstanding the heavy loss of traffic during the coal strike, the net earnings of the company increased $1,066,297.75.

LIMA, Ohio, Oct. 10 -- In the discussions this afternoon of the Grand Council of the Evangelical Church of North America, which is holding its biennial session here, interest centred on the theme, "Marriage in Its Relation to Divorce." The position was taken that marriage is indissoluble for life, divorce by divine authority being legitimate only when the marriage covenant has been broken, either by husband or wife.

CLEVELAND, O., Oct. 10. -- At a meeting to-day of the trustees of the McKinley Memorial Association, officers were elected as follows: President, William R. Day, Canton, Ohio; Vice President, Marcus A. Hanna, Cleveland; Treasurer, Col. Myron T. Herrick, Cleveland; Secretary. Ryerson Ritchie, Cleveland.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Executive officers of the Western roads were in session in Chicago to-day, considering measures for securing a better maintenance of rates east-bound from the Missouri River. The Auxiliary Committee of financial interests, of which E.H. Harriman is the Chairman, had a conference with the Presidents of the Western roads in the early part of the week, and told them in unmistakable terms that the tariff rates hereafter must be firmly maintained.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Justice William Travers Jerome was the guest of honor at a dinner at Sherry's last night Tammany Hall men, Independent Democrats, and Republicans were included in the group of about thirty who gave the dinner.

JUSTICE MORGAN J. O'BRIEN, who was renominated for Supreme Court Justice, was born in New York City in 1852. He received his first education at the public schools, and later attended the Christian Brothers' School, from which he was graduated. In 1889 he received the degree of Doctor of Laws from St. John's College, and he afterward entered Columbia College Law School.
LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Money was in increased demand to-day in connection with the consols installment. Discounts were sympathetically firmer.

In the Harlem Bowling League tournament on the Harlem Palace alleys lost night the Hyperion team won two games, the Washington Heights bowlers won one game and lost one, and the Knickerbocker five lost two games. The scores:
August Rebhan has been elected President of the Milwaukee Board of Fire Underwriters.

It seems that much "political significance" is attributed in Washington to the appointment by the President of one of the conspicuous opponents of ADDICKS to the vacant Postmastership of Wilmington, Del. We should say that the significance was not so much political as personal.

Among the rehabilitations of historical characters that have been one of the results of historical research within the last generation, none is more curious or more instructive than the attempted rehabilitation of "the pirate KIDD." For nearly two centuries he was commonly regarded as the chief of all pirates.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 10 -- At the evening session of the American Board to-night, after President Capen had given the annual address on "A Million Dollars for Foreign Missions," the Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman of Brooklyn. N.Y., began an effort to raise $102,000 to wipe out the debt of the board.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Following is the monthly report of crop conditions issued by the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture:

The plans submitted by the Engineers' Department of the New York Central Railroad to President SEXTON of the Board of Health, for approval, show very clearly a settled purpose on the part of the management of that corporation to continue the nuisance while making a pretense of measures for minimizing the discomfort and danger resulting therefrom to passengers by the tunnel route.

Brilliant, and to some extent sensational, golf marked the career of the women's national championship tournament yesterday on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, N.J. All of the contests were unusually close, suggestive more of semi-final competitions than the round previous to that critical stage of the game.

The Tammany County and Borough Convention was held last evening in Tammany Hall. There was only one break in the slate as announced by the leaders several days ago. Col. Asa Bird Gardiner was a few hours before the time fixed to make the nominations withdrawn from the race for the District Attorneyship.
BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $26,252,649; balances, $2,110,523.

Former automobile records were literally blown out of sight yesterday on the Empire City track, near Yonkers, with the same ease that a stiff wind carries the Autumn leaves from the trees at this time of the year. Albert C. Bostwick and the French champion, Henri Fournier, were the record-breakers, but when the speed tests were over Fournier had gathered all records from one to six miles to himself.
AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 10 -- A dispatch from Monterey, Mexico, says:

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says that neither Anatole France, the famous novelist and critic; Jose de Heredia, the poet, nor Sebastian Faure, the Anarchist, appeared, as it was expected they would do, as witnesses for the defense in the trial of Laurent Tailhade, charged with inciting to murder in an article in the Anarchist newspaper Libertaire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- Some time ago Secretary Long received a letter from G. L. Duval of the Flint, Eddy and American Trading Company, dated New York, which stated that the officers of the Chilian training ship Bauquedano, shortly due in United States waters, were desirous of affixing a bronze plate to the Washington monument in this city, as a tribute of respect from their country to the first American President.

For the woman who does not care for large pearls and who likes variety there Is the heavy rope made of many twisted strands of small pearls. These ropes, finished with tassels of the pearls at the ends, are very charming.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 10 -- Six thousand people at the Grosse Pointe track this afternoon saw Alexander Winton of Cleveland drive his heavy racing automobile a mile in 1:12 2-5, lowering the previous world's track record for that distance nearly four-fifths of a second. The time was made during a three-mile exhibition at the first meet of the Detroit Automobile Association, and the entire distance was covered in 3:42 2-5.

Jacob Reefes, a jeweler, who lives at 223 Sixth Street, was arrested yesterday at his store, 14 Chrystie Street, by Detective Sergeant Wakefield on a charge of receiving stolen goods. He was arraigned in the Centre Street Court before Magistrate Olmsted, who committed him to the Tombs to await extradition papers from New Jersey, where he is wanted by the Newark authorities.

An unusual suit to recover life insurance is now on trial before Justice Fitzgerald, in the Supreme Court. By the accidental discovery of a picture of an "unknown man" which had been kept on file at the Morgue for two years a woman discovered that she was entitled to $2,000 of life insurance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read a letter in your issue of to-day which caused me some regret and more surprise. Your correspondent speaks against mission work, in Turkey, calling it a farce, and ends with the strange remark "Let the benighted heathen live in peace and happiness."

Stimulated by the strength of the Stock Exchange market, prices in the outside market yesterday made some substantial recoveries. In parts of the list declines occurred, but these were far less numerous than they had been for some days past. Standard Oil was again active at higher prices, and it closed at the top price of the day.

Among the diversions for the delegates of the American Street Railway Association yesterday was an inspection of Fire Headquarters. In the school of instruction Chief Henry McAdams showed them a fire drill, and then they went to the house of Engine Company No. 39, where an alarm was turned on for their benefit.
ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 10. -- The papers here are harmonious in their views concerning the situation in Afghanistan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your efficient services in calling attention to the wretched condition of the New York Central tunnel and to the wholly inadequate "improvements" proposed to be made have elicited my admiration.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The fourth annual horse show of the Morristown Field Club was opened here to-day with a large and fashionable attendance and under perfect weather conditions. The show will continue to-morrow and Saturday. Much interest was shown in the competition to-day and the awards were well distributed.
MANCHESTER, Iowa, Oct. 10 -- D.B. Henderson, Speaker of the House of Represetatives in the last Congress, made one of the principal addresses at a Republican meeting here to-night. He said in part:

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 10. -- Lorenzo Snow, Fifth President of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, better known as the Mormon Church, died unexpectedly at his private residence, the historic Bee Hive House, this afternoon, after an illness that had been serious only since yesterday.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 10 -- The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall reached Toronto to-day and their entry to the city was marked by a great popular demonstration of welcome. A storm swept over the city at the time, but wind and rain had no appreciable effect upon the throngs that turned out to aid in the welcome.
