In his address at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, Mr. Low took up the question, which the Tammany candidate has raised, that the present election should be decided by a party vote, and that the candidates should be supported or opposed because they are nominated by one or the other party.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17. -- The market today was fairly active, well distributed in trading, and with an upward tendency. Trust company stocks came into prominence as the leaders on the bull side, the advances running as follows: Continental, 1 point; Maryland, 2 points; Fidelity and Deposit, 2 1/2 points; Mercantile, 5 points.

Frank Moss led a raid against the Little Eo-Peep Social Club, 207 West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, last night. He was accompanied by Superintendent MacClinton of the Society for the Provention of Vice and Detectives Hammond, McClelland, and Dillon. In the early evening Mr. Moss had been speaking at a political meeting in Avenue C.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would add greatly to the interest of your very interesting, campaign if Mr. Low could be induced to tell the newspaper reporters, who are cross-examining Mr. Shepard, whether Mr. Low's opinion of Mr. Platt and the Republican organization is the same as when he ran for Mayor before.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 17. -- The postponed meeting of the shareholders of the Central Pacific, which was scheduled to take place to-day, was again adjourned for two weeks, until Oct. 31. It is thought that the long-deferred action of the stockholders in electing a Harriman board will be taken, however, at the next meeting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- The first new witness called before the Schley Court of Inquiry to-day was Lieut. Commander T. D. Griffin, who, as Lieutenant, was the senior watch officer on the Brooklyn during the war with Spain. As usual, before any of the new witnesses were summoned, a number of former witnesses were called for the purpose of correcting their former testimony.

Frotitable Advertising, Boston, October, 1901. THE NEW YORK TIMES celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of its founding on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 1901. It issued a Jubilee Number that was unique and worthy of permanent record as the story of a type of the ideal school in journalism.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The dominating influence on the money market to-day was the condition of French exchange, the in- creasing probability of gold exports to Paris, and the prospect of the withdrawal of a considerable portion of the exceptional amount of French capital invested in London, owing to the financial situation in Paris being disquieting.
BOSTON, Oct. 17. -- A bulletin was posted to-day by Mr. Lawson, in his office, in which, with his old-time characteristic confidence, he grave utterance to these predictions:

BOSTON. Oct. 17. -- Rain interfered with the racing programme at Old Saugus track this afternoon, and only one event was finished, that being the 2:18 trot, which was unfinished yesterday. Limerick made quick work of the race to-day.

Walter J. Travis, America's champion golfer, put all former records on the Westbrook golf links out of sight yesterday when he played the course twice in 77 strokes. That establishes new records for both eighteen and thirty-six holes, a total of 154 for the latter. The former record was 171, made last year by Louis Livingston, Jr., when he won the gold medal in the opening round.

The first big handball match of the season was played yesterday on Michael Egan's Jersey City Handball Club court, when "Phil" Casey and James Dunne of Brooklyn opposed Michael Egan and P. Flaherty in the first of a series of nine games, four of which were decided yesterday with honors even, while the remainins five will be played on Casey's court in Brooklyn on next Wednesday.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 17. -- The National Congregational Council, which has been in triennial session here since last Friday, succeeded in clearing up all its business this afternoon and final adjournment was taken to-night. The next meeting will be held in Dcs Moines, Iowa, in 1904.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Thomas Nichols, formerly pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Milford, Penn., died yesterday of heart disease at his home, in Germantown, Penn. He moved to Germantown after resigning his Milford charge, Sept. 10, 1901, because of ill-health.

Friday is generally a dull day in society. Although there are no entertainments arranged in town or the suburbs, except the musicale which is to be given by Mrs. Speyer at Scarborough, many plans are being made for house parties, and among these there will be a large one given by Dr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb at Shelburne Farms, and another by Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sloane at Elm Court, Lenox.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17. -- The triennial convention of the Episcopal Church of America has adjourned sine die. The next convention is to be held in Boston in 1904. The day was a busy one in both houses, most of the time, however, being taken up in the discussion of matters which were not definitely decided.

BURLINGTON, Iowa., Oct. 17. -- What is believed to be the first tangible move in the Hill-Morgan deal for the consolidation of Northwestern roads was taken here when the articles of incorporation for the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railway Company were filed in the County Auditor's office yesterday.

Racegoers at the Morris Park track yesterday enjoyed or not the most remarkable variety of wealth than the season has producede damp and gloom predominated, howaver, but with no appreciable effect on the attendance. The track was fairly good, and the racing was thoroughly interesting from start to finish, with an abundance of surprises, in the shape of winning long chances.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- It is understood that President Roosevelt, following out the policy of President McKinley, will urge the ratification of the reciprocity treaties with France and the West Indian and South American countries, which failed of ratification in the Senate last year.

As a result of Wednesday's football games the practice on most of the college gridirons yesterday was light. As Columbia played no game on Wednesday, snap and energy characterized their work yesterday, and new recruits to the squad brightened the outlook. Among these new recruits was a man with one hand named Angel, who played a guard on the scrub, opposing the giant Lancon.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 23cent stamps shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value excceds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Apparently Mr. SHEPARD is unable to distinguish between Tammany as a historic political organization, in which many good men have in the past had part, and Mr. CROKER'S Tammany of today. He can see in the effort to destroy Tammany nothing but "factional" politics, and he refuses with much emphasis to make any such effort.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Frank W. Hackett, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, will ask to be relieved from that office shortly, and will resume his law practice in Washington. He had intended to do so on Oct. 1, but remained at the request of Secretary Long, who on account of the death of President McKinley and domestic afflictions has been obliged to be away from the department.
The Sub-Treasury yesterday transferred $275,000 in currency to New Orleans for crop-moving purposes.

BOYERTOWN, Penn., Oct. 18. -- Shortly before noon to-day, the doors of the National Bank of Boyertown, situated here, were closed. A notice posted on the bank's door stated that it was done because of the disappearance of Milton A. Mory, the cashier, who has not been seen for a week. A committee of bank officials went to Philadelphia to-day to investigate his alleged doings there.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of to-day, Gertrude Atherton writes concerning Alexander Hamilton as follows:

There is an obiter dictum in one of the recent essays of Mr. Andrew Lang which is calculated to attract attention, all the more because it is an obiter dictum. It is to the effect that the drama in English being dead, and biography and "memoirs" uncultivated, "Fiction is Literature."

Melvin A. Rice, a bookkeeper in the offices of the Board of Education, and Arthur P. Sanborn. who describes himself as a salesman, living at the Astor House, were yesterday arraigned in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, charged with having attempted to tamper with witnesses in a suit brought against Rice by his wife for an absolute divorce.

AN admirable secondary function of this reissue of Prof. David Masson's "Chatterton" -- it was originally published forty odd years ago as a chapter in a volume of collected essays, has very long been out of print, and is now given to the public in a greatly expanded form -- will be served if it shall happily revive the study, for their own sake of the altogether unique antique poems of the "Marvelous Boy."

A writer in The Fortnightly Review discusses the popularity of criticism and sums up his conclusions by saying that it is due to the fact that it purveys to the appetite for personal gossip. In other words, criticism occupies precisely the same place in the general plan of things as personal journalism does, and it is liked for that reason.

PARIS, Oct. I8. -- The Premier, M. Waldeck-Rousseau, has replied to the inquiry of the Secretary of the Miners' Federation ns to the Government's intentions in regard to the demands of the miners for an eighthour day, a minimum wage, and a pension of 21, a day after twenty-five years' work. The miners threaten to strike on Nov. 1 if their requests are not granted.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Does not Cyrus Townsend Brady draw rather too liberally upon his imagination in the October number of McClure's Magazine in an article under the name of "Frontenac the Savior of Canada?" Mr. Brady describes the commander of the American land forces.

The Fusion forces, with the exception of the Republican organization, are sorely in need of funds with which to carry on their campaign. The following announcement was put out yesterday by authority of the Citizens' Union:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Miss Agnes Montgomery Gill is acting as Governor of New Jersey this week owing to the absence of Gov. Voorhees, his private secretary. Hobart Tuttle, and Executive Clerk Fox, all of whom arc at Buffalo because of Jersey Day at the Pan-American. Miss Gill disposes of all the Governor's mail, answers all inquiries directed to the department, and attends to other official duties.

The returns in the registration yesterday show that Manhattan and the Bronx had 69,090 voters registered for the third day of this year, or 3,000 less than in 1900, 1,500 more than in 1898, 14,000 less than in 1897, and a little over 2,000 less than in 1896.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- "Kim" is out in book form. As has been evident to the readers of the book as it appeared in Cassell's Magazine and also in McClure's. it has absolutely no plot. It is merely the record of the adventures of a boy and his companions, young and old.

ONE could scarcely name a book of this season which has been more anxiously awaited than the present memoir. At the same time, inasmuch as the Stevenson letters had been so admirably edited, it was with some feelings of dread that the memoir was awaited, especially as Mr. Graham Balfour's personality and his literary ability hare been more or less unknown quantities.

Mr. William Robert's article on "Book Collecting as an Investment," which appeared in the September Fortnightly Review, has attracted a Rood deal of attention. He points out the late Earl of Ashburnhum's unique opportunities in collection, (the article, in fact, is hardly more than a resume of the Ashburnham sales,) and declares that collecting for the end was decidedly a good Investment.
Olga Salomea Heitz, the sole legatee under the will of Eugene Guido Cruger, gave out the following interview yesterday:

STUDENTS of American manners and history, and of the early days of Yale and Harvard, Princeton and Dartmouth have long known of the existence of this remarkable collection of memoranda, correspondence, and daily records of life in the latter part of the eighteenth century, but no attempt has been made until now to put it within the reach of students unable to examine it in its original form.

Railroad and financial circles continue to show the greatest interest in the developments of the railroad situation in the Northwest. The Wall Street news bureaus sent out various and conflicting stories yesterday regarding these developments, and especially regarding the pending negotiations for a readjustment of the capital stock of the Northern Pacific Railway.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The annual report of Major Gen. Henry C. Corbin, Adjutant General of the army, comprehensively reviews the work, condition, and needs of the military establishment.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The suit of Mrs. Dora Thompson, wife of Alexander Thompson, against her father. Charles H. Stebbins, a retired broker and millionaire of Hartsdale. Westchester County, has been decided in favor of the daughter, and she sets her share in property belonging to the three children and which is valued at $25,500.

MR. ROOSEVELT is commonly spoken of as the most literary of American Presidents since Jefferson. Those who use this formula must either have forgotten John Quincy Adams, or confounded him with his father -- Jefferson's immediate predecessor: for the younger Adams, who followed the author of the Declaration of Independence In the White Rouse after an interval of sixteen years, was even more of a man of letters than Jefferson himself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Another long conference was held to-day by Rear Admiral Walker of the Isthmian Canal Commission and M. Hutin, President of the Panama Canal Company. Rear Admiral Walker will not report the details of the conversation, nor the probability of the offer of transfer to the United States of the French concession and property, and M. Hutin remains dumb to all who approach him on the subject.

TWIXT Sirdar and Meneilk, by the late Capt. Montagu Sinclair Wellby, Eighteenth Hussars, is the simple and straightforward record of a seven months' journey made by him in 1898 through unexplored parts of Abyssinia lying between the town of Addis Abeba, on the east, and the Sobat River, one of the Nile's tributaries, on the west, and extending as far south as the lower end of Lake Rudolf.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Dispatches from many points in the South contain opinions of the press and politicians on President Roosevelt's action in entertaining Booker T. Washington at dinner. Democrats condemn the President and Republicans say that his action will redound to the credit of the party.

Some increase in activity occurred yesterday in the outside market, but the market followed the same irregular course noted on Thursday. Several of the issues which recently were advanced sharply on very light purchases of stock receded from the figures thus temporarily established, and with these there occurred in other parts of the list smaller net losses.

Preparing for a Life of Burr. Mr. Pidgin, author of "Blennerhasnett." has sent to his publishers a unique letter which, while declaring his intention to write a life of Aaron Burr, incidentally reveals the way in which he purposes to get his material together.

Folks are more important than words, and to rear a child well is better than to write a novel. Therefore, while "The Century Book for Mothers" can scarcely be called literatur, it is more worthy of bringing before the notice of the public than ninety-nine one-hundredths of the fiction that fills the eye and the mind of the multitudes who read.

Gertrude Atherton, the novelist, gave an interesting historical souvenir to the New York Historical Society at Its last annual meeting. It was a photograph of half a page from the church records of Chrtsttansted, on the Island of St. Croix, in the Danish West Indies, containing the Interment notice of the mother of Alexander Hamilton.

OF "Mexico As I Saw It," writes Mrs. Alec Tweedle, author of "Through Finland in Carts," in a now book, which will be published immediately by the Macmillan Company. The book will contain over 100 Illustrations taken on the spot, besides water color sketches by the writer.

Trading was somewhat more active in the stock market yesterday than on the day previous, though transactions were not well distributed, five stocks -- Sugar, St. Baul, Northern Pacific preferred, Southern Pacific, and Amalgabated Copper -- contributing more than one-third of the entire market transactions.

Memories of the Metropolitan championship last Spring will be revived to-day in the final round for the chief trophy in the Westbrook Golf Club's invitation tournament on the club's links, near Islip, L.I. The contestants for the Westbrook cup will be Walter J. Travis and Charles H. seeley.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday affirmed the decision of Justice Blanchard, given last June, refusing to continue a preliminary injunction which Frederick Gerken had secured, restraining Charles Ward Hall, the owner of the Morse Building, at Nassau and Beekman Streets, from erecting and maintaining a wooden bridge in front of Mr. Gerken's cafe on the first floor of the building.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Vice Chancellor Stevens gave a hearing to-day in the suit of the Standard Rope and Twine Company against Vincent P. Travers, Charles Efros, and the Charles Efros Company, to prevent the using of a secret process to which the Standard Company claims exclusive rights.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The following cablegram from Gen. Chaffee reporting the fight of the Ninth Infantry in Samar Wednesday was received at the War Department this afternoon.

Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh said late last night that from one of three men arrested by him, charged with conspiring to colonize the Sixth Election District of the Third Assembly District, he had secured valuable information. The men arrested are Ignatius Dugan, James Wilson, and James Dunn.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18 -- The market today was rather strong in tone, with a preponderance of good gains, but the trading did not include as many different issues as on the preceding two days. The speculative securities figured most prominently with the exception of Seaboard stocks, which, strange to relate, did not record a single sale.

LAKE MOHONK, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The nineteenth annual session of the Lake Mohonk Indian Conference adjourned to-day after adopting a platform, congratulating the country upon a Federal school system for the education of 25,000 Indian children, the allotment of over 3,500,000 acres of land to over 55,000 Indians, with a secure individual title, and other evidences of progress in the education and elevation of the Indian.

The Executive Committee of the Bryan Democratic League of New York held a meeting last evening at the Astor House and adopted resolutions opposing the candidacy of Edward M. Shepard for Mayor. Charles Campbell, President of the league and ex-officio Chairman of the Executive Committee, presided, and A.C. McNulty, a lawyer, of 132 Nassau Street, acted as Secretary.

Helena G. French, widow of the popular comedian, William Hoey, better known as "Old Hoss," died yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, Mrs. H.M. French, 207 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, from Bright's disease, from which she had long suffered. She was born thirty-seven years ago in Lee.

This little volume, which does not claim to rank among the legal works of reference, has a distinct and almost unique plain in its department of literature. It is a gnition of the awakening consciousness of American women of their heritage in the common law as amplified and modified by statute, and of the gradual and generally favorable change which is taking place in their legal condition.

Much of the whole burden of Mr. SHEPARD'S speech at Tammany Hall was devoted to an attempt to expose the partisanship of Mr. Low's candidacy, and the factitious, if not fraudulent, character of the Democratic support promised to him.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- The new Russian battleship Retvizan, built by the Cramps of Philadelphia, arrived here to-day from New York after an all night run, in course of which, for twelve consecutive hours, she was driven at top speed, and, in spite of storm and darkness, she attained an average speed of 18.8 knots, breaking all records for that number of hours and showing herself to be the fastest first-class battleship in the world.

E pur si muove Is as true to-day as when the historical romancer of the eighteenth century put these words into the mouth of the old astronomer, Galileo. With perhaps the single exception of electrical science, there has been no more rapid and wonderful growth and development than that of the library movement.

THE fourteenth season of the free lectures in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx began on Tuesday evening, Oct. 1. Last season the total attendance upon the 1,963 lectures that made up the course was 553,558, or an increase of more than 25,000 over the previous year.

In Messrs. Maxfield, Parrish and others we have our own varieties of poster artists, but it is amusing now and then to see what is done by the French provider for advertisements in the same line, the more so as the taste for owning posters is on the increase, and especially country houses are apt to be decorated with them.

The new buildings for the west side work of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church will be opened to the public Tuesday evening. Oct. abd when appropriate exercises will be held, addresses being made by the Rev. Dr. W. H.P. Faunce, President of Brown University, and the pastor of the Fifth Avenue Church, the Rev. Dr. R.P. Johnston.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The Cologne Gazette, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times publishes an "unctuous" article in regard to the Bagdad Railway, in which, it says, French, German, and Russian capital is interested.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Picking up THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for Sept. 28, 1901, my eye falls on the recent article on the recent meeting of the New York Library Association at Lake Placid, by "F.W.H." There is a paragraph about the "literary associations" of Adirondack Lodge which fixes my attention.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18. -- The 2:18 trot to-day, three heats of which were held Thursday, proved to be the biggest trotting race of the meeting being held here. There were four heat winners when, at the end of the fifth heat, the others were sent to their stables.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The Newburg Citizens' Protection Party has filed with the County Clerk a list of 550 voters of Newburg City, with a municipal ticket to be supported at the polls in November. Its emblem will be a horseshoe, and the prime movers are Darwin W. Esmond and James McCord.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- The Committee on Arrangements of the National Association of Manufacturers met here to-day to perfect arrangements for the holding of a National Reciprocity Convention at Washington, beginning Nov. 19. The convention will probably last three days.
NEWPORT, Oct. 18. -- Hawthorne Villa, which for many years was occupied by the family of Dr. E.S. Arnold, has been sold to the Rev. Braddin Hamilton.

In the Columbia League tournament on Schlusing's Columbia Alleys last night J. Koehler of the Standard team rolled a total of 245 and made a new high individual score for the tournament. All three teams tied in this series. The Knickerbocker Athletic Club team won three games in the National tournament and the Corinthians won two in the Harlem League series.

It is not easily to be perceived that the General Convention of "the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States of America" has left that body, in any important respect, different from what it found it. And that, considering the great and growing influence of the Church in this country, is not by any means necessarily to be regretted.

MR. CASTLE is a romancer by temperament, predilection, and intention. In talking with him I had somewhat the feeling as though talking with Dumas pere. To be sure, I have never conversed with the creator of D'Artagnan, but I feel certain that he would have given me the same sense of freshness, vitality, and joy of living.

The cool, crisp air of Autumn invites to the sports of country life this week and there are many entertainments and house parties. The Marquise de Tallyrand Perigord will entertain at Chatsworth the Prince del Drago. There will be a musicale and a dance at Tuxedo this evening, and a drag hunt at Meadowbrook and informal dancing at Ardsley.

Has Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD any possible chance to be elected Mayor of New York? Is he not already defeated by the great silent vote, by the fixed resolution of the decent people of this community not to put up any longer with the nastiness and thievery of Tammany government? Have the revelations of the evil and vileness of Crokerism been wholly lost, altogether without effect upon the minds of right-thinking men?

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Judge Kohlsaat, sitting in the united States Circuit Court, today granted a temporary injunction restraining Reliable Lodge No. 253 of the International Association of Machinists, its members, and others from picketing the works of the Allis-Chalmers Company or in any way intimidating the workmen of the company.

Mark Twain on Thursday evening of this week, at the Waldorf Astoria, read a magazine article prepared by himself in which he called attention to points of similarity between the career of Warren Hastings, as set forth by Edmund Burke in the famous impeachment proceedings before the British House of Commons, and Richard Croker.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Commenting upon the statement of the Politische Correspondenz regarding the letter from M. Saratoff, the Bulgarian Minister, to Mr. Dickinson, the Vienna correspondent of The Standard says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- That there has been retrogression rather than an advance along engineering lines in the navy during the past two years is the most significant statement contained in the annual report of Admiral George Melville, Engineer in Chief of the navy.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18. -- John Sargent Pillsbury, ex-Governor of Minnesota and one of the State's foremost citizens, died early to-day of Bright's disease. His illness was comparatively brief, owing to his advanced age.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- The two events of the literary world here during the fortnight last past have been the appearance of Richard Mansfield in Booth Tarkington's "Beaucaire" and the placing in the hands of the public of Dr. Weir Mitchell's "Circumstance."

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- Money was easy today and the supplies were augmented in spite of the continued nervousness regarding the possible outflow of gold. Discounts were easier, though there was little inclination to take bills, in view of the uncertainty as to foreign exchanges.

It was the plan of the late George Murray Smith, when he planned the great "Dictionary of National Biography," fifteen odd years ago, to have no name which the ruthless discriminator. Time, had not deemed worthy. This necessarily precluded many names borne by men who, although reasonably assured of eminence by their contemporaries, were still alive.

Beyond doubt Justice JEROME is the most picturesque and popular figure of the present municipal canvass. Crowds go to look at him and to hear him wherever he speaks, and the applause for him is always enthusiastic.

Copyright, 1901, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Oct. 18. -- "The Lepers" is the the title of the latest novel from the pen of E.F. Benson, which, however, has not yet found an American publisher. As is usual with the novels of this author, who, it will be recalled, wrote "Dodo," the theme deals with the high life of modern London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- At the Schley court to-day Mr. Rayner put on the stand J.L. Hunley, who was chief machinist on the Texas at Santiago. Hunley was at the throttle of the port engine during the battle. He testified not only that the Texas did not back her engines at the time of the Brooklyn's loop, but that she did not even stop them.

Collegiate football games will hold sway once more to-day. Of the big games the most important is that between Cornell and the Carlisle Indians, to be played in the Stadium of the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo. Another contest of more than ordinary importance is to be played at West Point between the cadets and Harvard.

A block of rock weighing nearly 130 tons crashed from the ceiling and the wall of the Rapid Transit tunnel yesterday morning in Section 14, corner One Hundred and Sixty-fourth Street and Eleventh Avenue, without an instant's warning, into the midst of a gans of seventeen muckers, who were at work loading cars and smashing rock that had been blasted.

Seth Low made his first speech before the Greater New York Democracy last evening at a big meeting held by that organization in the Borough of the Bronx as Zeltner's Hall, corner of One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue. The hall was crowded to the doors, fully 2,000 people being present.

The W.A. Wilde Company has always been intent upon publishing for the new girl and for the new boy; not for the ill-bred and selfish, but for the refined and considerate, differing from old-fashioned good children only in seeing the opportunities of the present time.

This is not a horticultural treatise upon the raising of table greenery. In educational and charitable circles in New York City and cities upon other continents also, it is well understood that kitchen gardening is akin to kindergartening, and that the harvest is in the training of little hands and budding intelligences.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- At the Clearing House money between the banks was quoted at 3 and 21/2 per cent. Some bankers doubted, however, if any loans were actually made. There is certainly no demand. Leading banks say there is little reason for dropping the rate, because no more money could be loaned at 2 per cent, than at 21/2 or 3 per cent.
A combination sale of race horses in training, the property of a half dozen different owners, was held in the saddling paddock of the Morris Park race track yesterday, by the Fasig-Tipton Company.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Sir Thomas Lipton to-day declared himself in favor of a change in the construction of challengers and defenders of the America's Cup.

The letters of hearty good-will and compliment that have come to THE TIMES, upon the occasion of its fiftieth birthday and in praise of its Jubilee Number, issued yesterday, are most gratifying in their expressions and their number. Appreciation is about the most pleasant thing on earth.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Prof. Fedor de Maartens, of the Foreign Office of Russia, called upon the President to-day. He was presented by Chief Justice Fuller, who gives a dinner in his honor this evening. Prof. De Maartens was one of Russia's representatives at The Hague Conference. He is understood to be urging a meeting of the permanent Court of Arbitration, which has never assembled.

A resolution adopted by the Grand Army of the Republic at its encampment this year in Cleveland, Ohio, suggesting that the United States purchase two islands to which all Anarchists may be banished for life was the main topic of conversation at the twenty-fourth annual dinner of the veterans of the Fifth Regiment of Heavy New York Artillery, held at the St. Denis Hotel last night.
Birds Start Southward. THE annual Fall migration of the birds has begun and is now well under way.

To the Editor of The New Yort Times: Referring to your editorial of yesterday, every one must agree with you that one of the best methods of punishing and discourage Anarchists is to deprive them, as far as possible, of the notoriety which seems to be one of their chief ambitions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with sorrow and surprise the letters of some of your correspondents summoning us to follow Mr. Shepard into the Tammany camp. We might "Walk backward with averted gaze To hide the shame." did we not believe in his entire sincerity; we may pity him for his coming disillusionment; but follow him we may not.

The doors of Madison Square Garden will be opened at 2 o'clock to-morrow afternoon upon the Horticultural Exhibition and Flower Show, given under the auspices of the New York Florists' Club. There will be exhibits of fruits, vegetables, and flowers. The arrangement of the exhibits will make the Garden very attractive.

District Attorney John F. Clarke of Kings County yesterday said that he had not yet received notice from the attorneys of Willlam F. Miller of the Franklin Syndicate that they intended to apply for Miller's admission to ball, pending a new trial. Mr. Clarke said that he would oppose any attempt to have Miller released on ball.

Tammany Hall, the Democracy, Republicanism, and the Citizens' Union, as well as anarchy and the "capitalistic class," were unsparingly denounced at the ratification meeting of the city ticket of the SocialistLabor Party last night before a crowd which filled Cooper Union to the floors and gathered at overflow meetings in the street.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 19. -- Prof. C. C. Georgeson, special agent in charge of the investigation in agriculture in Alaska, has returned after a two months' tour. Having visited the experiment station at Kenai in the Spring, Prof. Georgeson left for the Yukon basin, July 19, going in by way of White Pass.

An important corporation event of the past week -- on Wednesday last -- appeared in the action of the stockholders of the Illinois Central Railroad Company, who at their annual meeting approved the recommendation of their Board of Directors, that the company's share capital be increased from 600,000 shares to 792,000 shares, the increase, of course, representing $13,200,000 added to the outstanding volume of capital stock.
Boston's registration this year is the largest in the history of the city, being 108,240. The total at the Presidential election last year was 106,329.

With the ball on Columbia's ten-yard line, the football contest between Hamilton and Columbia on the Polo Grounds yesterday ended in favor of Columbia by a score of 12 to 0. Two sensational runs had carried it to that spot from Hamilton's fifty-yard line, and it was due to a magnificent tackle by Weekes that the first of these runs failed to net a touchdown.

Games were rolled last night in three of the local bowling tournaments. The Wholesale Drug Trade Association began its season on Reid's alleys and the Bank Clerks also bowled at the same place, while three games in the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum series were decided on the Elephant Club alleys, Brooklyn. The scores:

IN finding ways and means of defraying athletic expenses some of the expedients adopted at the larger universities during the past few years have shown great ingenuity on the part of the managers of the teams and the prominent upper classmen, upon whom the responsibility has chiefly fallen of seeing that the various branches of athletics had funds sufficient to warrant their continuation.

THERE had not been an alarm all evening, and the men of Hook and Ladder Company, No 3. at 108 East Thirteenth Street, had stopped their games of dominoes and checkers. They were gossiping about this, that, and the other, and, incidentally, talking shop, as men of all callings will do.

One of the humors of the campaign from the Republican standpoint is a letter sent out by a supporter of Mayor Van Wyck for the Supreme Bench, and the reply which it elicited from William Bruce Mann. The letters were given out last night at the Republican County Committee Headquarters and are as follows:

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The Merchants' National Bank opened and closed its doors at the usual hours to-day and nothing out of the ordinary developed to interfere with its business, despite the surprising absence of the teller, Albert G. Smith, and the bookkeeper, Lewis K. Swift.

The tenth supplementary practice day of the season for National Guardsmen was held at Creedmoor yesterday for the sharpshooters' class at 500 and 600 yards, it being the last opportunity this season to practice in the sharpshooters' class. The remaining days for practice are for the marksmen and expert classes.

At the fourth matinee race meeting of the Bay Ridge Driving Club, held at the Parkway Driving Club track. King's Highway and Ocean Boulevard, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, there was so much scoring in the starts and so much breaking in the heats that, although there were only two races, it was dark when the final heat was concluded.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read THE TIMES for many years with general satisfaction as to its policy, management, and opinions.

Edward M. Grout, fusion candidate for Controller, at a big meeting held last night in McKinley Hall, at Greenpoint, asserted that Devery, Sexton, Carroll, and Farrell are four of the five members of the gambling syndicate which the Committee of Fifteen has been seeking to reach. He also declared that Croker was compelled to stand by Devery, being afraid to remove him.

From The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, Sept. 3. Our valued contemporary THE NEW YORK TIMES had an uncommonly interesting and gratifying piece of news for its readers yesterday. It has made a business arrangement -- " an alliance." to use its own phrase -- with The London Times. Under this arrangement it acquires the exclusive right (for this continent) to the entire news service of the famous English journal -- a service of unrivaled excellence.

That the railroads of the country, speaking generally, are in a much improved physical condition as compared with a few years ago, every intelligent observer recognizes; but it is just possible that some railroad properties are conceded to be in a better state than really is warranted, owing to impressions which have gained ground that the vast amount of improvement work done of late has materially raised a physical standard already at a satisfactory level.

Intimately connected with the local money market situation at present, because foreshadowing that recently expected Bold imports may not be forthcoming now for some time, is the course of the foreign exchange market. In Paris, exchange has declined sharply to below the point where gold can profitably be imported from London.

Grain trade conditions continue much discussed, with scant reflection of the "arguments" in the market. Dullness reigns there. Yet in large majority the professional authorities are forecasting activity of consequence -- and some of the calculators have it that the betterment is close at hand.

IT is the habit of the public to accept without question the conclusions of qualified and reputable experts on every subject which is necessarily outside of popular knowledge. The engineer builds a bridge and the people cross it with rarely a thought as to its stability. They assume that it is strong enough for the purpose for which it is designed.

"OF course I believe that honesty is the best policy," said the young man who smokes. "It is a rule of ethics that if I find anything lying around loose it is my duty to restore it to the owner, whenever possible. I used to observe that principle religiously, but I doubt if I should now be so conscientious.

James Watson, who had been known a number of years in Wall Street as a speculator on a small scale, and who, according to his own statement, was a brother of William Watson, the English poet once spoken of for the Laureateship, was discovered to have committed suicide by inhaling gas at the Morton House about noon yesterday.

The Democrats of the Twenty-first Assembly District charge that a large number of students of Columbia College -- perhaps as many as 300 -- had registered illegally in their zeal to vote for their former President, Seth Low. Twenty students will be called upon to appear in the Harlem Police Court to-morrow morning, and justify their registration, provided summonses for their appearance, which were obtained yesterday, can be served.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 19. -- Neither W.W. Peet, Treasurer of the American Bible House, nor Spencer Eddy, Secretary of the United States Legation, had received any news up to noon to-day from the missionaries who are searching for the brigands who kidnapped Miss Ellen M. Stone and her companion, Mme. Tsilka, Messrs. Peet and Eddy had a long conference today as to the advisability of reinforcing the searchers, but decided that the present arrangements sufficed.

It is needless to say that society is on the wing. It is almost impossible to locate any one. There are a few -- and this is not relapsing into the popular refrain of a comic opera -- who are in town, and yet others who are in the country, and others again who combine the two. Meadow Brook never was as gay, and there are ever so many house parties there this week.

BARICK MARSTON and several other Ogunqult politicians who are tremendously interested in the New York City campaign called on Mr. Silas Larrabee this morning and begged him to light up the situation a little.

Profitable Advertising, Boston, October, 1901. THE NEW YORK TIMES celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of its founding on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 1901. It issued a Jubilee Number that was unique and worthy of permanent record as the story of a type of the ideal school in journalism.

In the following list "mtg" stands for martgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The Southern papers are not well advised in their severe criticism of the President for inviting Dr. BOOKER WASHINGTON to dinner at the White House. There sat down together on that occasion two gentlemen, one white and the other colored, who are two of the truest Americans born on our soil, and two of the best and most intelligent and influential friends of the South now living.

ALBANY, N. Y., Oct. 19. -- Rumors of resignations in the Department of Public Safety, which have been rife for several weeks, partly culminated to-day in the resignation of Howard P. Foster as Chief of Police at the request of Mayor James H. Blessing.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- Hall Caine has consented to become a candidate for the Isle of Man Parliament in behalf of the town of Ramsay. His opponent is a local lawyer. Mr. Caine's address has created consternation even among his own supporters, for he advocates sweeping changes that might well be planks in a national platform of some great reform party.

THERE are many reasons why we are on better terms with the squirrels than with most of our other wild creatures, and perhaps the principal reason is that they are among the very few that will allow us to become acquainted with them. In the first place most of the others are nocturnal in their habits, and few earn to take the trouble to call on them in the dark.

NEW YORK COMMERCIAL. -- Interest in New York newspaperdom is centred this morning in the appearance of the Jubilee Number of THE NEW YORK TIMES, a special issue to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of its founding. The publishers of "All the news that's fit to print" have devoted a great deal of time and attention to this historical edition, professing to have found an excuse for it in the Book of Leviticus, xxv., 10:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Why all this ascription of "high character" to Mr. Shepard, as well as of the special gifts that have made him a keen and successful lawyer?

EVERY ship that comes into the port of New York, or leaves here for distant countries, carries on board creatures whose presence is never clearly known until the vessel has been duly inspected froin truck to keel. Rats inhabit nearly all vessels, whether built of wood or iron, and they come and go with the freedom of passengers with tickets prepaid through to distant ports.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Oct. 19. -- The Spectator to-day has a leading article which seems to be an attempt to express in plain prose the meaning of Rudyard Kipling's latest poem, which was printed in The Times this week. Poems have been described by one irate critic as the attempt to translate four intelligible lines of prose into fourteen unintelligible stanzas of verse.
"THERE is no hand," said the manicure, "like the Irish hand. It is the most beautiful hand which comes to me for care."

BATH, Me., Oct. 19. -- Shipbuilding in this city for 1901 shows a large increase over recent years, and the prospect for next year is of great promise. During the past year there have been completed in Bath shipyards the following:

A GROCERY keeper near Morristown, N.J., is bemoaning the loss of a large tomcat of which he was particularly fond. At the same time a nearby farmer is boasting of having the smartest pair of Scotch collies in the world. The sorrow of the one and the joy of the other are due to a tragedy in which the two dogs and the cat were the actors.
Miss Carroll Badham has returned to her home, 65 Central Park West, after four months on the Continent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19, 1901. -- Enrique M. Barretto, chief translator for the Provost Marshal General of Manila, is in Washington, on leave of absence. He is a graduate of schools in England and Hongkong, and speaks Spanish, English, French, Italian, Portuguese, and Tagalog. He has been a prominent business man in Manila as a member of the firm of B. A. Barretto Co., headed by his father, and was also a manufacturer.

BOYERTOWN, Penn., Oct. 19 -- An official of the First National Bank admitted this evening that some of the bank's assets are still missing. The shortage is due to the operations of Cashier Milton A. Mory, who disappeared on Monday last.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Oct. 19 -- The Republicans formally opened their State campaign here to-day with a parade, in which clubs of the leading cities and organizations of the different counties participated. The speakers were Congressman Warnock of Urbana, who presided; Senator Carl L. Nippert, candidate for Lieutenant Governor; Gov. Nash, candidate for re-election; Senator Foraker, candidate for re-election, and Senator Hanna, who is regarded as a candidate for re-election two years hence.

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 19 -- The prosperous and thriving town of Sydney was almost destroyed to-day by a fire which started about 2 o'clock. The flames, fanned by a forty-five-mile gale, swept through the business part of the town. Four blocks of the finest business buildings are in ashes.

Last week's business, furnishing as it did several transactions of substantial magnitude in various sections of the city, was in many respects gratifying to those who have expressed confidence in the present condition of the market, and who were not satisfied to regard the dealings of the first two weeks in October as any fair indication of the outlook.

MONTREAL, Oct. 19. -- Sir Christopher Furness has left for Sault Ste. Marie to look into F. H. Clergue's enterprises. He is accompanied by a number of Canadian gentlemen interested therein, and by M. Genesral, President of the Franco-Canadian Line and an ironmaster of France, who is interested in promoting trade between France and Canada.

A man was beaten and robbed by thugs late last night within a few steps on Frankfort Street and Park Row, and another man who tried to rescue him from his assailants was knocked down by them. The thieves, who numbered three, escaped. The man who was robbed was taken to the Hudson Street Hospital unconscious.

BERLIN, Oct. 19 -- On the Boerse to-day prices opened fairly firm. The feature was the buoyancy of Northern Pacifics, which advanced on a rumor of favorable dividend news. Canadian Pacifics improved. Later the tendency became dull, on Vienna advices. Banks, coal and iron shares reacted slightly.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- The Innis Arden golf team visited the links of the Hillanda'e Golf Club to-day, and was beaten in a match by 23 holes to 12. Seven men played on each team, the scores being:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- Trading in the Philadelphia market to-day was in very small volume. Cambria Steel was the most active stock. Choetaw improved 3/4. There was a heavy shrinkage in the Readings, less than 400 shares being recorded. Pennsylvania and Northwestern, which figured prominently early in the week, dropped to 34 1/4 on a sale of a hundred shares.

It would be a strange turn of the wheel of fortune if France, under the republic, as under the First and the Second Empires, should become again the object of wooing by rival European Powers. Mr. POULTNEY BIGELOW, writing from Rheims alter the review at which the Czar was honored, says, in the current number of The Independent:

The closing golf contest of the season was begun yesterday on the links of the Crescent Athletic Club, near Bay Ridge. Twenty-five members qualified during the monthly handicaps for competition for the President's cup, and these met in a medal play match in the forenoon. This event was a handicap, and the cup was won by H.S. Bowns, who made both the best gross and net scores.

Twelve races, to establish, if possible, straightaway mile records, have been arranged by the Long Island Automobile Club for Saturday, Nov. 16, on the Coney Island Boulevard. Consent for this meeting has been obtained from Park Commissioner George V. Brower, and the officers of the Parkway Driving Club and the Pleasure Driving Association have also consented to assist in making the affair a success.

Tristan C. Backelman, a merchant who lives with his wife in a boarding house at 132 West Ninety-eighth Street, was removed to the J. Hood Wright Hospital last night with a bullet wound in his right breast. He is a prisoner of the police of the West One Hundreth Street Station, who charge him with attempting suicide.
The total registration of the City of New York for 1901 is 604,727, 38,000 less than 1900, 44,000 more than 1898 and 37,000 more than 1897.

Walter J. Travis had his revenge on Charles H. Seeley yesterday in the final round for the Westbrook Cup in the invitation golf tournament of the Westbrook Golf Club, near Islip, L.I. The National champion beat the young Connecticut champion in a thirty-six hole round by the unlocked far score of 7 up and 6 to play.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The submarine boat Shark was successfully launched at the Crescent Shipyards this afternoon before a distinguished company. The vessel was christened by Miss Wainwright, daughter of Commodore Richard Wainwright. The christening party came on a special train from Washington this morning and included naval officers from Washington and Annapolis.

THREE men stood on the platform of a Second Avenue car, which was crowded with persons on their way back from the Morris Park race track. It was 5 o'clock in the afternoon, and the tenements and flats along the route made an interesting picture. Out of every four in eight windows leaned either a man, woman, or child, while in some there were all three.

IF ANY one wants to have a whole lot of fun and at the same time to study human nature in one of its most curious phases, there is no place that is better adapted to the purpose than the lower east side at the present time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial. "The Old Shepard and the New." you have presented an unanswerable argument why independent Democrats should, oppose the election of the Tammany candidate. There is no escape from the conclusion that Mr. Shepard has grossly deceived himself, or is attempting to deceive his former associates.

(On Its Fiftieth Anniversary.) By the Rev. Daniel H. Overton, Pastor. Greene Avenue Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The public owes you honor for your aim. Steadfast and sure, for half a century. To print "All of, the news that's fit to print."

An alliance for mutual interest and advantage has been concluded between THE NEW YORK TIMES and The London Times which secures to this journal the exclusive right to the entire news service of its London namesake for the Continent of America.
Dr. HENRY RAYMOND ROGERS died yesterday, aged eighty years, at Dunkirk, N.Y. Dr. Rogers held membership in many scientific associations.

Prof. Bashford Dean of the Department of Zoology in Columbia University has returned from a stay of fifteen months in the Far East, where he has spent his vacation, on leave from the university, engaged in research work in zoology. He has succeeded in securing some wonderful specimens of rare fish and animal life, as well as other important relics of the civilization of Japan and the Philippines.
Justice William Travers Jerome, the Fusion candidate for District Attorney, made a noonday speech yesterday at Broadway and Leonard Street. He said in the course of his remarks:

George Armitage, the twenty-year-old messenger of the New Amsterdam Bank of Manhattan, who disappeared on Tuesday last with over $5,000 in money and $20,000 in securities belonging to the bank, is perhaps the most penitent prisoner in the Tombs. His family and friends believe that his mind has been clouded and his moral perceptions contorted by constant cigarette smoking.

Further testimony to the efficient methods of railroad administration in the United States is offered by indications in England that railway owners there are beginning to look toward alliance -- and it may end even in actual amalgamation -- of kindred systems, what has come to be known as the community of interest idea.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an old and regular subscriber to your valuable paper, may I ask the courtesy of your columns to explain why, as a former member of Tammany Hall, I find myself compelled to vote against the party with which I have been allied for the past five years?

Much attention has recently been fixed in our security market upon the shares of street railways, and there has been heavy fluctuation, mostly in a downward direction, in the market value of properties like those of Philadelphia and Chicago, while within the past few weeks there have been continual severe attacks upon the local New York traction systems.

Mme. CLARA BRINKERHOFF, 268 West Forty-third Street. -- In addressing you I would recall Judge Dykman's remarks in THE TIMES of Sept. 27, as to how many persons having taken THE NEW YORK TIMES from the first number up to date, 1851 to 1901, are living. It is rather hard on a professional lady to own up to half a century, but I will do so.

James A. Daly, an Inspector in the Water Department, living at 262 William Street, with John H. Irwin of 235 Front Street, the Captain of the Third Election District of the Second Assembly District, were arrested last night by deputies of State Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh charged with conspiring to colonize this district.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Oct. 19. -- We have had what may be called an incipient scare this week in our money market. Owing to the mid-monthly Bourse settlement in Paris a demand arose here for remittances on the French account. This sent the Paris cheque down on Wednesday to a figure that would just permit bar gold to be drawn from the Bank of England without loss.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 10. -- The guests of the university began to arrive last evening, and to-day the social part of the bi-centennial is under full swing. All of the professors of the university have distinguished housefuls, and in some homes are gathered a half-dozen Presidents of the leading universities of the country.

A number of persons interested in the progress of Young Men's Christian Association worte assembled yesterday afternoon at 153 East Eighty-sixth Street to witness the laying of the cornerstone of the new building, which is to be connected with the present branch on East Eighty-seventh Street.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 19. -- The greatest week in the history of Yale University will open to-morrow morning, when the bi-centennial celebration is ushered in with services in Battell Chapel. The colleges and the city are to-day waving with blue streamers and gala bunting, and every street in the middle of the city and around the campuses is hung with festoons of evergreen and Japanese lanterns.

From The Boston Watchman. No paper ever rendered a more conspicuous public service than THE NEW YORK TIMES -- which has just celebrated its fiftieth anniversary -- in its attack on the Tweed ring. The other day the Chicago Congregational ministers adopted a resolution practically recommending that public journals should not be "permitted to continue to speak evil of the men to whom the suffrages of the people have given high office."

The football team of Maryland University of Baltimore was defeated yesterday in an exciting scrimmage by the Robert Davis Athletic Association of Jersey City on the St. George Cricket Grounds, Hoboken, by the score of 23 to 0.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Rear Admiral Francis Marvin Bunce, United States Navy, retired, died this morning at his home here. Admiral Bunce's death, while sudden, was not unexpected, and his family had been warned to expect the worst. Last May cancer of the tongue developed, and an operation in Boston resulted in the removal of the Admiral's tongue.

The first Ions-distance race of the Fall season at the Morris Park track -- the Municipal Handicap at one mile and three-quarters over the famous Westchester Hill -- was the feature and the attraction of the half holiday yesterday, and as a spectacle fully justified the interest that it aroused.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 -- The market to-day was exceedingly quiet and featureless. There was no noteworthy change but the decline of one point in Cotton Duck. That was due to the pressed sale of a marginal account. The shares met firm resistance at 15 and hardened perceptibly. The Brewing issues were still leaders.

To the Editior of The New York Times: About a week ago we saw Mayor Van Wyck quoted in one of the evening sheets that Shepard would win by a majority of about 60,000, and two days later the same, paper shows us Mr. Croker's estimate to be only 50,000 majority.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Fortification Board at its meeting just ended at Sandy Hook witnessed the preparations making for the approaching trial of field guns for the artillery. Several such guns were already on the grounds and were undergoing private tests preliminary to the official trials which will begin next week, and probably last three weeks.

Golf at the Englewood Club yesterday drew out one of the largest fields of competitors that has been seen on the links this Fall. The occasion was the closing match of the three qualifying championship series, members playing in two of the rounds and turning in a thirty-six-hole score.

"MY busmess is full of vanity," said the photographer. He was net located on the east side, nor down town, but on ultra-fashionable Fifth Avenue. "But for the vanity of men and women, and principally women, I could not live."

The insurance on the property of S. Baumann in the two buildings, 229 to 233 and 235 to 245 Sixth Avenue, amounted to $175,000. Of this aggregate $59,000 was covered on contents of the corner building, $111,000 on contents in 233 to 245 Sixth Avenue, which was gutted, and $5,000 on fixtures in the two buildings.

To the Editor of the New York Times: When Mr. Shepard was bluntly asked whether he, like Mr. Low, would promise the removal of Devery, he answered, in effect, that pre-election promises were in bad taste and were made only to gain votes.

The National Convention of the American Bankers' Association, which has just completed its session at Milwaukee, will long remain one of the most notable in the history of that eminently useful institution, so powerful for good and so capable of giving a wholesome trend to public opinion and to State and Federal legislation.

A document was given out at the City Hall yesterday purporting to show that during Mayor Van Wyck's administration the various departments of the municipal service have been filled with officials holding political sinecures. The parson who gave out the document for publication claimed that it has received the indorsement of the Republican County Committee.

"I'M through with freak advertising," said the young dentist. "I've had my fling at trade secured through illegitimate tricks, and I've sworn off from further cultivation of the public in ways that are dark.

FEW people know anything of the animals which furnish the furs most commonly used for articles of wearing apparel. Investigation discovers unsuspected and close family relations in the furs which absolutely refuse, according to canons of good taste, to be near neighbors in coats.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 19. -- The twenty-ninth meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association closed to-day. It was characterized by the largest average attendance and the heaviest pooling in the history of the association. It is also declared to have been the cleanest trotting meet.

"TOUGH ships," said my much-wanring friend Bill; "why, sure. Sir, I've shipped in a many of them; but the toughest. I guess, was a Norwegian. You might say that there's three kind of tough craft. The treat-you-hard-and-feed-you-well ship, she's generally American. The treat-you-well-and-feed-you-hard, that's the 'lime-juicer,' or Englishman.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- According to the most reliable information obtainable, there is no foundation for the report that Chancellor von Bulow has agreed to drop the minimum duties on cereals, and it seems quite certain that the Bundesrath will, apart from minor changes, consent to the adoption of the tariff in its present form.

FRANK MOORE JEFFERY, 52 Broadway -- In your Jubilee period permit me to add a word, of commendation to the good work of THE TIMES. Its high moral tone, literary excellence, and justice to the news, combine the fundamental qualities of a perfect newspaper, which, with its supplements, cover the sum of information of the commercial, political, and fine art world.

THE TIMES is sensible of the fact that in addressing a greater audience a newspaper wields a greater influence and assumes a high responsibility. The duty to use power sanely and well is correlative to the right to use it at all. It appears to be possible for newspapers of large circulation to disregard this duty every day and flagrantly without loss of standing in the class to which they appeal.
BOSTON, Oct. 19. -- The twenty-first season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra began this evening at Symphony Hall. The programme was as follows

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 19. -- A distressing accident happened near here this afternoon which resulted in the almost instant death of Frederick H. Benedict, son of E. C. Benedict, the banker, and perhaps the fatal injury of Grenville Kane, a guest of Mr. Benedict.

An interesting feature of current railroad development is the continuous, steady building of new lines. There is of course, no great new projections of building enterprises, but the construction which follows the normal development of the country goes on steadily, unobtrusively, and amounts year by year to an important total.

PRINCETON, Oct. 19. -- Princeton easily defeated Brown here this afternoon by the score of 35 to 0. The Orange and Black put up by far the best game they have played this season, concerted work by the backs making the large score possible. Foulke, a freshman, was the star of the game.

William Faversham will begin the third month of his engagement at the Criterion Theatre Tuesday. In addition to "A Royal Rival,' he will give as a curtain raiser "Prince Charlle," a new fifty-minute play by Robert Marshall, which later Mr. and Mrs. Kendall will play in England.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The Orange County Hunt had the best sport of the year this afternoon. Ten members followed the pack in a fox hunt over nine miles of beautiful country. The country was open and the going excellent, although in some places stony. The fencing was mainly of stone, and the jumps were close and stiff.

Seth Low, Edward M. Grout, Charles V. Fernes, Jacob A. Cantor, Justice William Travers Jerome, Thomas L. Hamilton, and Samuel Seabury, were introduced yesterday afternoon to the members of the Campaign and Executive Committees of the GermanAmerican Reform Union and also to the district leaders of that organization at its headquarters in Terrace Garden, Fiftyeighth Street, near Third Avenue.

THERE is a great deal of work done in a political campaign, such as the City of New York is now going through, that the casual observer does not see or read about. That work is what may be called the strictly practical part of the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Louisiana will be opposed to the extension of a reciprocal arrangement to Cuba, if such an arrangement is to afford Cuba opportunity to send to the United States her leading productions, sugar, tobacco, and fruits, with advantages in tariff rates that will permit Cuban competition with American producers of the same articles.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- At the Clearing House to-day all the money that was loaned was put out at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,114,226. Balances, $2,087,588. Call money is quoted at from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent., with a plentiful supply at the former figure to the right borrowers.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 19 -- George Gould and a party of railroad officials, representing the Missouri Pacific, Denver and Rio Grande, and Rio Grande Western systems, spent the greater part of to-day in viewing the sights. At 10 o'clock they attended a special orgarirecital in the Tabernacle, after which they called upon Joseph P. Smith, the newly elected President of the Mormon Church.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- R.G. Dyrenforth, who has been conspicuous as a promoter of the fight against Pension Commissioner Evans and who is Commander in Chief of the "Union Veterans' Union of Battlemen Soldiers," visited the President to-day prior to the departure of a delegation of the "Battlemen" for Chicago, to attend a convention to be held in that city.

To, the Editor of The New York Times: The hosts of renders of THE NEW YORK DAILY TIMES are proud of its reaching its fiftieth (golden) anniversary, if expressed or not. It has come to the lead of the most famous political journals, giving the fullest and latest news, with the sermon and Sunday school lesson, as well as reports of lectures in literature and science and ablest party speeches.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Fire to-night destroyed the New England building at the Pan-American Exposition.

The security market of the past week was of shifting and evasive character, with strength and weakness alternating in fitful succession. Speculation, without aggressive leadership, was restricted mainly to professional scalping, indifferent to business tendencies or conditions, seeking to snatch hasty profits in either direction.

From The Wilkesbarre (Penn.) Times. THE NEW YORK TIMES has entered upon an alliance with its London namesake that is quite unique, in the history of international journalism. It has secured the exclusive use of the entire news service of The London Times and also the exclusive use of its special articles contributed by eminent writers and which have a permanent value and wide interest.

At the Knickerbocker Theatre to-morrow evening Henry Irving, Ellen Terry, and the London Lyceum Theatre Company will begin an engagement of three weeks. Mr. Irving will appear in "King Charles I." This play has not been presented in this country since Mr. Irving appeared in it at the Star Theatre in 1883.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the campaign advances there is a noticeable change in the tone of your editorials. You are surely drifting away from the spirit of fairness you earlier manifested toward Mr. Shepard. and from the past expressed policy of your paper to deal impartially with public questions.

Plans are shortly to be announced where-by the American Syndicate, representing the new interests in Mexican Central, now, in control of that property, will disclose far-reaching-purposes not only for the development of Mexican Central proper, but for its extension into a system even greater than it has been as the foremost railroad of the country.

The long-expected transfer of the Pike extate, consisting of 3,000 acres of meadow land in Hudson County and 800 acres in Bergen County, has at last been made, and the deeds were yesterday filed in the Register's offices of the two counties, at Jersey City and Hackensack. The only change to be noted is that the property is conveyed to John R. Ferrier instead of Henry L. Sprague, who originally represented the purchasing syndicate.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- The Santos-Dumont airship ascended at St. Cloud at 2:42 o'clock this afternoon, and five minutes afterward began to round the Eiffel Tower. Santos-Dumont completed his trip successfully, but a question arose as to whether it was done within the time limit. M. Deutsch, who offered the prize, said the aeronaut won.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- One of the questions that will require the prompt and serious consideration of Secretary Root on his return to this city next week will be the military situation in the Philippines.
PARIS, Ky., Oct. 19 -- The courthouse here was destroyed by fire to-day, leaving only the crumbling walls. The fire was confined to the courthouse. Loss, $130,000; insurance, .$60,000.
DURBAN, Natal, Oct. 19. -- Gen. De Wet's recent inactivity has produced the Impression among military men that he is either dead or incapacitated through illness or wounds.

The just issued report of the Distilling Company of America for the fiscal year ended June 30 last is highly encouraging -- and this is saying a good deal for the statement of a concern whose prior history, at least as to some of its parts, has covered all kinds of bankruptcy and reorganization.

IT is possible, though it is not extremely probable, that Mr. Sothern's appearance as Francois Villon in Mr. Justin Huntly McCarthy's "If I Were King," may arouse some new interest in the history of that remarkable blackguard. The hero of the drama is no other than the famous French poet, who was brother to the dregs of Paris, a loafer, a drunkard, a thief.
THIS is a story about Toomey of Jersey, a yelow pup, a tailor-made miss, and a hand-brushed Boston terrier.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- As a result of Lester Reiff's expulsion from the English turf, an important withdrawal of American trainers and jockeys from the turf here is likely to occur in 1902. Enoch Wishard immediately canceled all his English engagements after Reiff's expulsion and turned Richard Croker's and John A. Drake's horses out of training, declaring they would not enter an English race till Reiff was reinstated.

Joseph H. Choate, Ambassador from the United States to the Court of St. James's was a passenger on the Philadelphia, which arrived yesterday from Southampton. Mr. Choate, apparently in the best of health, was one of the first to land, and, having the courtesies of the port, spent very little time on the dock.
The Merchants' Association yesterday received a letter signed by the secretary to the Mayor, which is as follows:

Beyond the trading at advancing prices in Amalgamated Copper, some transfers of Union Pacific and St. Paul, and a little activity in Northern Pacific preferred stock, though on a smaller scale than in recent days, there was little or no life to the stock market yesterday. Barely 200,000 shares were traded in throughout the session, with copper contributing one-half of the entire total.

Seth Low received three delegations at the Fusion headquarters, 41 East Twentythird Street, yesterday afternoon. The delegations came to tender him their indorsement. One was that representing the Bohemians of the Twenty-sixth Assembly District. This delegation was introduced to Mr. Low by John C. Sheehan, the leader of the Greater New York Democracy.

CONCORD (N.H.) PEOPLE AND PATRIOT. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES observed the fiftieth anniversary of its birth by issuing the handsomest supplement that ever came from a newspaper office. By the rule "Handsome is that handsome does." THE TIMES is a very handsome newspaper every day in the year, living well up to its motto: "All the news that's fit to print."

Seth Low received three delegations at the Fusion headquarters, 41 East Twentythird Street, yesterday afternoon. The delegations came to tender him their indorsement. One was that representing the Bohemians of the Twenty-sixth Assembly District. This delegation was introduced to Mr. Low by John C. Sheehan, the leader of the Greater New York Democracy.

CONCORD (N.H.) PEOPLE AND PATRIOT. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES observed the fiftieth anniversary of its birth by issuing the handsomest supplement that ever came from a newspaper office. By the rule "Handsome is that handsome does." THE TIMES is a very handsome newspaper every day in the year, living well up to its motto: "All the news that's fit to print."

Printers' Ink, New York. In a handsome thirty-six page supplement with gilt cover THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 25 commemorated the fiftieth anniversary of its founding and takes occasion to tell the story of its life-an exceedingly pithy story, giving much interesting national, local, and newspaper history, and many side-lights on famous mortals generally.

In one of his straight-from-the-shoulder speeches, which are the joy of the campaign and the delight of his audiences, Mr. JEROME said the other night that there was a large number of persons in this city who would rather fight than pay, meaning that they would rather fight Tammany than pay blackmail to Tammany.

The third week of the football season has proved as barren in decisive results as the two which preceded it, and though the larger colleges have gone on rolling up large scores against weaker opponents, there has been little to indicate the comparative strength or the real standing of the teams.

Fishing in ash barrels for rags and old tin cans, although the pockets of his tattered clothes were filled with money, a little, bent man was found yesterday aftternoon and taken to Bellevue Hospital for examination as to his sanity. There he gave his name as Oscar Reis of 106 East Houston Street, and the man who accompanied him, John McGee of 426 East Seventy-seventh Street, asked that he be committed to an institution.

The annual report of the British Board of Trade on the working of British railways during the past year will spread little sunshine in investment circles abroad. For the first time in six years there was an increase in the receipts from passenger traffic, notably of third class travel, the gain for the year being something over 3 per cent. in numbers, with about the same percentage in receipts.
