Mr. Blackwell, who was seventy-eight years old, came to New York from England when nine years of age. His father established the first sugar refinery in this city, but removed to Cincinnati.

Washington R. Vermilye, James E. Carter, and George F. Newcomb, who compose the firm of W.R. Vermilye Co., stock brokers, at 52 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Daniel O. Hulse, without preference. Mr. Vermilye resides in Bayonne, N.J., Mr. Carter at 20 Morningside Avenue, New York City, and Mr. Newcomb at the Criterion Hotel, New York City.

As Richard Croker, John F. Carroll, Rogister Isaac Fromme, Health Commissioner John B. Sexton, and one or two minor Tammany leaders were walking up Fourth Avenue yesterday afternoon on their way from Tammany Hall to the Hoffman House, they espied several billposters at work near Twenty-first Street industriously placarding the boards alongside the subway with Citizens Union posters.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Money was in good inquiry to-day and very firm, in expectation of an advance of the bank rate Thursday next. Discounts were harder, influenced by money and foreign exchanges. The reports of the floating of a French loan of 270,000,000 francs early in November have not been confirmed.

Though the season for light harness racing is still nearly two months from its end in the Southern States, the period for record-breaking performances has about passed, and trotting turfmen generally accept the new records made through the season of 1901 as figures that will stand with small danger of being disturbed until the next year of the sport has come.

We observe, with interest, that the attitude of the clergy of this municipality toward the municipal campaign was the topic that seemed chiefly to interest Mr. SHEPARD in his Monday allocution to the reporters. It was, indeed, calculated to arrest his attention, or that of any other intelligent and reflective reader of newspapers.
BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $18,271,558; balances, $1,575,795.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- At the resumption of the sittings of the South African Compensation Commission yesterday. Major Gen. Sir John C. Ardagh, on behalf of the Government, announced that all claims of foreign countries, with the exception of France and the Netherlands, had been settled diplomatically, as follows:

It is an old maid's kitchen, and really one might take up the profession of old maid or girl bachelor just for an opportunity to play at housekeeping with it. It looks when it is closed, like nothing so much as an old-fashioned box washstand closed in, top and all. This top is in several pieces, connected by hinges, and folds back, leaving the little kitchen open.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says the German activity at the Yildiz Kiosk last week and the Sultan's compliant mood have apparently brought the Bagdad Railway Convention nearer to a conclusion.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The pertinacity with which society discusses the rumors regarding the health of King Edward has had a serious effect on the business of the Court dressmakers, who expected ere now to be busily engaged on the Coronation robes, They are keeping large staffs in almost complete idleness.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Krueser Auditorium was filled to-night with the largest political gathering Newark has seen this year. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Republican City organization and was addressed by former Attorney General John W. Griggs, Franklin Murphy, the Republican nominee for Governor, and by United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew in the order named.

Under the unfavorable influence of the weak Stock Exchange market prices in the outside market yesterday were again irregular, with the majority of changes on the side of declines. Transactions assumed large proportions in only two or three stocks, the balance of the list being dealt in to a very limited extent.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $300 of consideration over $3,000.

At the Knickerbocker Theatre last night Sir Henry Irving and Miss Ellen Terry acted together in Victorian Sardou and Emile Morcau's drama, "Madame Sans-Gene." There was an audience of large size, and its applause betokened an interest both deep and wide. Nothing else could well be the case in the presence of such admirable acting as that seen last evening.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- A letter from Michael Davitt appears in The Times to-day, protesting against its correspondent's description of New York, which he characterized as "a libel upon that city as gross and grotesque as ever was printed in a public journal."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many of your most faithful readers are surprised at your course in the Mayoralty election. With that, however, I have nothing to do, but knowing how liberal and fair you are I ask leave to present some arguments why I think the election of Mr. Shepard would be far more hopeful of reform than that of Mr. Low.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a few hours the soul of Czolgosz will stand before the judgment seat of God, and that God, laying His fingers on the lips of all of earth, will say, "Judge not." Christ said, "They know not what they do." President McKinley said, "Let no one hurt him."
BALTIMORE, Oct. 28 -- The stock market to-day was dull and featureless. There were a few more gains than losses, but except in two instances changes were only fractional.

This is not a scratchers campaign. The election will not be decided by scratching. The bulk of the vote will be cast by marks in the circle under the emblems of Fusion or Tammany. If Mr. Low is elected Tammany may save some of the other places in this county and the Borough of Manhattan.

One hundred and fifteen thousand dollars has been raised by the Citizens' Union so far. It was announced after a meeting of the Finance Committee yesterday afternoon that $135,000 more is imperatively required to meet the legitimate demands of the campaign to the time the polls close on election day.

-- In an article contributed to The Electrical Review by Mr. ROBERT McCULLOCH, the writer, after telling with almost lyrical enthusiasm how the conditions of modern life, especially in cities, have been bettered by the trolley car, touches upon the question of municipal ownership and declares that under that system the marvelously rapid changes -- all of them improvements -- in street car service made during the last few years would have been impossible.

L.M. Goldberger, who is a Royal Privy Councilor of Commerce and Member of the Imperial German Consulting Board for Commercial Measures, and who arrived in this city a few days ago from Berlin, talked last night to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES about the objects and purposes of his mission.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- The Stock Exchange is still lifeless, and business is as near to a standstill as it very well could be without actual suspension. Brokers on every hand are complaining. Hopes of a change for the better were stimulated last week by a rise in Tidewater Steel to 9, especially as it was attended by some activity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the burning issues of the city campaign, questions of political method deserve to be put in the background. But as a lover of liberty, I cannot fail to be interested in the strange argument of Mr. Shepard and his admirers about "reform from within."

Methods of a nature more radical than have been adopted for years were enacted last night by the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union. The Board of Managers of the local association, which was elected at the recent annual meeting, held its first meeting for organization in the Astor House.
DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 28 -- At the first annual meeting to-day of the stockholders of the Detroit Southern Railway the following Directors were elected:

The Brown segmental wire tube ten-inch gun, which is over 37 feet long, weighs 26 1/4 tons, and has a range of 15 miles, burst while being tested with smokeless powder charges at the Sandy Hook proving ground yesterday afternoon.

A banquet to commemorate the millenary of King Alfred the Great was held at Delmonico's last night under the auspices of the Societies of St. George, St. Andrew, St. David, and the Historical Society, in accordance with the suggestion of the Society of American Authors.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- Tennis on the indoor courts in the new tennis and racquet club at Tuxedo is now very popular among the Tuxedo colonists. To-day the galleries were crowded with many well-known New Yorkers to witness an exhibition match between the French professional, Broquedis, of the Tuxedo Court, and Alfred Tompkins, professional of the New York Racquet and Tennis Court.
BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- It is characteristic of the Kaiser to surprise his subjects by unexpectedly taking the initiative in some matter of public importance.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 28 -- The bloodiest race war the South has known since the early eighties began last night at Balltown, Washington Parish, La. The hostilities were opened by the blacks, and in the first engagement three whites and eleven negroes were killed. The conflict raged on to-day, and the death roll has been increased by the killing of twenty more blacks.

Republicans and members of the Citizens' Union joined forces last night for a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall. The crowd was large, but did not quite fill the hall. The Fusion organization of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District arranged the gathering, and Senator N.A. Elsberg was the Chairman.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The wife of Robert Vauley was attacked last night in her home, at Oakley, a village five miles from here, by a masked negro, who beat her into a state of insensibility and then robbed the house. Her husband arrived home soon afterward and gave the alarm. Neighbors answered his call.

Edward M. Shepard left the Windsor Theatre, in Manhattan, in a carriage with Sheriff Walton to drive to the Academy of Music in Brooklyn, where he was to deliver a speech before the Brooklyn Democratic Club. A special invitation has been extended to school teachers to attend and hear what the Democratic candidate for Mayor had to say on the educational problems of the city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Spalding Co., jewelers, offer, through an advertisement, to pay $500 for the return of a diamond brooch. Investigation proves that its value is $18,000; that it was recently purchased at the Buffalo Exposition from a New York firm, and is the property of the wife of a Chicagoan.

AUBURN, N.Y. Oct. 28 -- The Leon Czolgosz, the murder of Pr McKinley, will not be removed from Auburn. Superintendent of State Prisons Cornelius V. Collins and Warden J. Warren Mead, after hours of controversy with Czolgosz's brother, succeeded in obtaining from him the following relinquishment of the family claims to the body when the executioner shall have finished his work:

To the Editor of The New Tork Times: It is now a proved fact that a corn crop can be made with success in the three months from the middle of July to the end of October. It became apparent in July that the Western corp crop was going to suffer terribly from the drought of June and early July.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The cross-examination of Rear Admiral Schley, which will last at least two days, and perhaps three, was begun to-day by Judge Advocate Lemly. The questions were drafted chiefly by Lieut. Ward of the Bureau of Navigation, Capt. Lemly's assistant. They were all in typewriting, and Capt. Lemly rarely departed from the questions as arranged, which were before him in a great pile.

The question whether the Surrogate, last May, in his order correctly fixed the transfer tax upon the estate of Cornelius Vanderbilt, was before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday, on appeal by State Controller Knight. Cross appeals taken by the executors of Mr. Vanderbilt's will and by Alfred G. Vanderbilt, individually, from the same order, were heard at the same time.

Mrs. Virginia Weir, a widow, 43 year old, was found dead in bed at 8:30 o'clock last evening at her home 706 East One Hundred and Forty-third Street and the circumstances of her death are involved in the deepest mystery. There was one bullet wound over her right ear, but no deeper than, the scalp, but another bullet appears to have gone directly through her heart.

Surrogate Thomas heard testimony yesterday in the contest over the will of the late Mrs. Charlotte Miller of 64 West Fortieth Street, who died on March 6 last, leaving almost all her property, valued at about $100,000 to Mrs. Margaret Louise Schultz, the wife of Police Capt. Schultz, to the exclusion of her nieces and nephews, the children of Capt. Schultz's first wife, who was a sister of the testatrix.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue Tuesday, the 22d, there is reference to the case of one James Jackson, who, because he swore allegiance to the Constitution, was suspended by the Session of the Reformed Presbyterian Church, Boston, which suspension was confirmed by the New York Presbytery at a late meeting.

Within the past few days great interest has been excited by reports of wonderful results in wireless telegraphy, telephony, torpedo guidance, and other important things, by English electricians. While it is not likely that these reports have been consciously exaggerated by the reputable journals which have given them currency, it is quite probable that the visions of scientific miracles to which they have given rise are to a great extent purely fanciful.

Edward M. Shepard was late in appearing at the Hoffman House headquarters yesterday. Richard Croker, John F. Carroll, Register Isaac Fromme, Health Commissioner John Sexton, James Shevlin Deputy Police Commissioner York, and a score of other politicians waited until nearly 6 o'clock before Mr. Shepard arrived.
Edward M. Shepard went to the Bowery last evening and made a speech in the Windsor Theatre. The place was crowded with the followers of Senator Timothy D. Sullivan.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for James Carlew the five-story American basement dwelling 14 West Seventy-sixth Street, 25 by 70 by 102.2. This is the sixth house sold out of a row of seven recently erected by Mr. Carlew.

Invitations for country house parties still continue to pour in and as the weather has a great deal to do with this state of things, it is probable that as long as the glorious Indian Summer lasts there will be entertaining, and this probably will be until after Thanksgiving. For this week there is the usual schedule of hunts and other affairs and informal dances and dinners.

In The Springfield Republican of yesterday morning there was a letter from the New York correspondent of that journal, dealing with the pending canvass. The writer is in evident sympathy with the anti-Tammany movement, and is intimately informed as to the history of the past four years, and the increasing audacity and depravity of the leaders of Tammany.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Lieut. Gen. Miles in his annual report gives the total strength of the army at the present time as 84,513, of which number 33,874 are in the United States, 43,289 in the Philippines, 4,914 in Cuba, the remainder, in small detachments, being in Porto Rico, Hawaii, China, and Alaska.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- The number of cases of typhus officially reported in Bochum thus far is 1,329. There have been twenty-seven deaths, while only 192 persons have completely recovered. The epidemic has now spread to Ludenscheid.

Some ill-feeling sems to have been engendered as a result, of the Columbia-Yale game last Saturday. Since then reports have come from New Haven that the Columbia players used the roughest kind of tactics, that some of the men playing were not elgible, and that concerted action is being taken to cut the Columbia game oft Yale's list.

One handsome Persian muff has flare ends of chinchilla, those ends which are supposed to turn back over the muff when the wearer is walking and to flare out over the wrists when driving. That is for extra warmth undoubtedly, though, for a truth, furs as a matter of protection are a joke on Fifth Avenue the greater part of the Winter.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Fall River is the centre of a remarkable boom in print cloths. When McKinley died M.C.D. Borden shipped from his print works in this city everything that was black and white in cloth, and his works in some departments were kept in operation as long as the Massachusetts laws would allow.

An audience which filled every part of Carnegie Hall assembled last night to hear Edward M. Shepard and John B. Stanchfield discuss the issues of the municipal campaign. Bourke Cockran was also to have been one of the speakers of the evening, but was prevented from appearing by an accident which befell him during the afternoon at his home on Long Island.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Far the last thirty-one years two things I have done with never-failing regularity. One is to read THE NEW YORK TIMES and the other is at every election to vote the Republican ticket from top to bottom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- When the Schley court of inquiry adjourned to-day Judge Advocate Lemly had not appreciably decreased the size of his pile of typewritten questions, and it is questionable whether the cross-examination of Rear Admiral Schley will be finished by Thursday. It is understood that, in addition to Lieut. Ward's work, a large number of the questions have been prepared by an outsider, who is a lawyer.

Athletic warfare against the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, which has been simmering ever since the annual meeting of the local association in September, has been cleverly evaded, but at the same time appearances indicate that the flames of discord between the Metropolitan Association and the Pastime Athletic Club may break out more fiercely than ever.

There was a good-sized gathering at Athenaeum Hall, corner of Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, last night when the Fusion managers abdicated the management of the campaign in that district for a few hours and turned it over to the women of the Brooklyn Woman's Republican League, assisted for the occasion only by the Citizens' Union.

New high scores were made in the Commercial Bowling League tournament last night, Gallussere of the F. Vietor Achelis team rolling 238, which is the highest individual score, and bringing the team score up to 897, which is the team record of the tournament to date. In the National League series the Knickerbocker Athletic Club won three games from the Defender team.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Considerable surprise was expressed by politicians and friends of Mayor Fiske here today when they learned that he had suspended City Clerk Hoyt. It is alleged that Clerk Hoyt had deposited in the First National Bank of this city the city's funds, together with his personal account.
LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Money was in strong demand to-day for over the month end, and supplies were augmented. Discounts were firm. Opinions regarding a rise in the bank rate are divided.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Beyond the breaking of a track record by Lennep in the fourth race and the disqualification of Hermeneia, the odds-on favorite in the third event, the racing at Lakeside was featureless to-day. The card was an ordinary one. Lennep ran a mile and fifty yards in 1:44 4-5, the former record for the distance on the Lakeside track being 1:45 2-5.

It will be remembered that under the rule of Aegius, the boss of the city of Elis, (who was accused of aggravating his despotic and dirty management by absenteeism.) some thousands of cattle had been allowed to live in the official stables for a matter of four years, without any attempt at the removal of the filth which it was their nature to produce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tammany Hall, led by a man who has hitherto denounced it in unmeasured terms, is seeking an indorsement of its incompetent and corrupt rule at the hands of the voters of New York. While the impending election concerns the city first of all, yet the issues involved make it a matter of National importance as well.
L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Cornelius W. Luyster the six-story American basement dwelling 39 West Eighty-sixth Street, 32.6 by 100. This house was only recently completed by Mr. Luyster.

Justice Jercme created three distinct sensations on his speech-making tour beginning at Madison Square Garden, passing through the middle district of the borough, and ending on Amsterdam Avenue in the heart of Health Commissioner Sexton's district, in the rear room of a saloon.

One of the largest Fusion meetings since the present municipal campaign began was held last evening in the great hall at Prohibition Park, on Staten Island, where Seth Low and Edward M. Grout were among the speakers. The building, which has a seating capacity on the floor of 4,000, was filled to the doors, in addition to which its two galleries were crammed with eager listeners to the harangues from the platform.

AUBURN, Oct. 29. -- Czolgosz was a carefully secluded prisoner in Auburn Penitentiary. State Superintendent of Prisons Cornelius V. Collins was determined that the prisoner, despite the enormity of his crime, should gain no undue notoriety, and issued strict orders for his complete seclusion.

As we have heretofore remarked, in whatever the Anarchist assassins may differ, they have this in common, that they have a morbid and exaggerated appetite for notoriety. Consequently it behooves society to see that their fate, when they are caught and punished, shall not minister to this perverted and diseased ambition.

To-day will be one of weddings. There are more than the usual number at the different churches in town and in the suburbs. One of the most notable church marriages will be that of Miss Fanny Walton Ogden to Joel Nott Allen at the Church of the Ascension. The usual hunt meets at Meadow Brook and Westchester will take place.
BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent, and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents Premium. Exchanges, $22,155,507; balances, $2,426,294.

The racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday was remarkable in one way at least, and that the extraordinary lack of either quality or class among the horses that made up the six races on the programme for the afternoon. Racegoers wondered what had become of the fair horses that ran last week at Morris Park, for the fields of yesterday were made up of the very poorest of the beaten animals of the greater tracks.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29. -- While there as an all-around improvement in the stock market to-day, the dealings were chiefly in the Reading group. The decision of the Union Traction employes not to strike stimulated the price of that stock it to 27 1/2. Philadelphia Traction rose 1/4, to 1 3/4.

The move of the Seth Low Democrats in Brooklyn on Monday in raising a big Low banner in Willoughby Street, almost directly in front of the auction room where-in Hugh McLaughlin and his lieutenants gather daily, yesterday led to a counter-move on the part of the Democratic campaign managers which precipitated a merry war.

The only important football contest scheduled for to-day is that between Columbia and Haverford, and Columbia expects to win this game easily.The practice at Columbia yesterday was lively, although the Varsity was weakened somewhat by the absence of several players. At Harvard a most rousing football meeting was held, at which several new songs were practiced to help along the eleven in the Pennsylvania and Yale contests.

Around the hotels and other places where political betting is done a strong tendency was noticed yesterday on the part of men who wanted to bet on Shepard to demand even money. Some bettors who have been talking for Shepard and betting on him were offering to bet on Low, and this led to the circulation of the report that the Shepard bettors were hedging.

Passers-by in upper Seventh Avenue yesterday morning were treated to the spectacle of an exciting race between Louis Iselin, son of Columbus Iselin and nephew of C. Oliver Iselin, in an automobile, and Mounted Policeman Charles W. Sturges, who had hailed the young man at One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, as the machine was coming down the avenue at a greater speed than the law allows.
A Prohibition mass meeting was held last night at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street. Many women were present. W.T. Warwell presided.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 29. -- President Jeffery of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway to-day announced the appointment of J.H. Herbert as General Manager of the entire Rio Grande system, to succeed J.H. Metcalfe, who will retire on Nov. 1.

Mrs. Susan Boyce of 131 Washington Street, Hoboken, swore out a warrant before Justice of the Peace George F. Seymour of that city yesterday for the arrest of her husband, James Boyce, for assault. When Mr. Boyce appeared before the Judge his mother was with him, and said that his wife had assaulted him with a piece of furniture and cut his hand, and as he was a cooper he was unable to work.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 29. -- One hundred and ten of the ring horses of Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show were crushed to death in a railroad wreck near Lexington at 3 o'clock this morning. Among the horses killed was "Old Pap," Col. Cody's favorite saddle horse. "Old Eagle," the star ring horse, was killed and his mangled body fell on top of one of the wrecked engines.

W. Bourke Cockran met with a painful, if not serious accident while riding yesterday afternoon at Sands Point, L.I. Mr. Cockran was thrown, or fell from his horse on his face. He was found unconscious by a labcrer on his place, and was taken to his home in a wagon. The horse, riderless, returning to the stable, was the first intimation that Mr. Cockran had been hurt.

For the first time since the death of President McKinley his autograph was sold at public auction in this city yesterday. It was included in a lot of Americana and scarce miscellaneous work sold by Bangs Co. at 91 Fifth Avenue. The autograph consisted just of the President's name written in full, "William McKinley," across an original cabinet photograph of him by Sarony.

Columbia oarsmen will hold their annual Fall regatta from the university boathouse, on the Hudson River, on Friday. The chief event Will be a race between the eight-oared crews of the college and Science. In previous years the eight-oared contest has lacked interest because a freshman crew has been matched against an experienced crew.

Mark Twain and Seth Low were the attractions at the noon meeting yesterday in the hall on the ground floor of 350 Broadway. A crowd of more than 2,000 jammed into the place, and was so thick that several times the management had to interrupt the speakers to prevent surging, and injury to many in the audience.

A controlling interest in the Ninth National Bank has been acquired by interests identified with the Hanover National Bank, and other financial interests. It is not the intention to make many radical changes in the management of the Ninth National, but there will be some gradual changes in the directory.

Two widows and the daughter of one of them comprise a stock company that transacts a large business with this and many foreign Governments. It is the Coston Signal Company, just incorporated at Albany by Mrs. Martha J. Coston, Mrs. A.L. Coston, and Miss Aline H. Coston. Mrs. M.J. Coston is the President and Miss A.H. Coston the Secretary and Treasurer.

The British Board of Trade has just published a memorandum which will give pleasure or pain, according to the point of view of the person for whom the figures have interest. They show as accurately as possible, from the averages of five to ten years, the per capita consumption of wine, malt liquor, and spirits in the principal countries of the world.

On Nov. 16 the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the battle of Fort Washington, the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, with the co-operation of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, will dedicate a memorial marking the site of the old Revolutionary fort.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 29. -- Thoroughbred breeders, owners, and trainers of the Blue Grass region and Central Kentucky met here to-day to take action on the moving of the three-eighths pole at the Kentucky Association track last Thursday in order to "speed up" a yearling that Clarence H. Mackay of New York was negotiating for.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Another attempt soon will be made to establish an amusement enterprise in the ill-starred Acelphia Theatre, at Wabash Avenue and Seventeenth Street. Negotiations between a real estate firm and the owners of the property resulted to-day in the transfer of the theatre and hotel to David B. Weber and his brother Max for a considerations of $125,000.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Messrs. August Belmont, John B. McDonald, Bryan, Deyo, Van Vleck, and Stillwell, having completed their survey of the underground railroads of Europe, start on their return to New York tomorrow on the White Star liner Oceanic. They have obtained much useful information for the benefit of New York City's underground road.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- That an agreement between the leading horse racing bodies of England and the United States of America will be made, whereby the authorities of the turf will have control of all racing affairs, has been settled beyond the shadow of a doubt by the statement made here today by August Belmont, one of the organizers of The Jockey Club of America, and for several terms President of that organization.
The following resolutions have been passed by the Board of Managers of the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital:

The declaration of Gen. MILES in his annual report concerning the canteen will undoubtedly carry weight with the country and with Congress. What the commanding General says is in effect that the anti-canteen law has not had a conclusive trial, and should not be condemned or repealed in advance of such a trial.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Most elaborate plans have been made for the reception of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and Tork at Portsmouth and London. It is not generally felt that their tour has been a success, as, on the whole, comparatively little interest has been taken in it, the war and other events having completely overshadowed the royal journey.

We have no idea when the admirable paper on "Commercialism in Politics," contributed by Controller COLER to The Independent of Oct. 30, was written, but its appearance is peculiarly timely and is a more vigorous arraignment of Crokerism as a principle, and in practice, than we should expect from one resting under what he deems a party obligation to support Mr. SHEPARD'S candidacy.

A long Washington dispatch to The Sun is published under the headlines "Reciprocity Treaties Dead," "The President Will Not Recommend Ratification." If the dispatch agreed with the head lines and sustained them it would be interesting and important. It doesn't.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were relatively small, but prices were firmer than they were on Monday. Recoveries occurred in several stocks that had been under pressure the previous day, and closing prices showed the larger part of the changes to be on the side of net gains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Judge Advocate Lemly lost no time in beginning his interrogations of Admiral Schley after the Schley Court of Inquiry convened to-day. As on yesterday, Admiral Schley was calm in his demeanor and deliberate in his answers, apparently weighing all questions carefully before replying.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29. -- The market today was a shade more active in the stock apartment, but it was at the cost of prices. The whole market was easier. There were only three gains against fourteen losses. The liquidating of some tired speculative holdings of Seaboard caused that group to tp fractionally, though the closing found the tone there better than it was during the earlier trading.

SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 30. -- General Manager Thomas E. Clarke of the Lackawanna system was injured slightly and a fireman was hurt badly in a collision seven miles west of this point at noon to-day. Mr. Clarke, in company with Superintendent Ketcham of the Morris and Essex Division, Chief Engineer MacFarland, and Chief Electrician Rudd, were on a tour of inspection.
BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- Loans were offered freely at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $22,062,495; balances, $2,057,385.

Many persons in the neighborhood bounded by Ninth and Tenth Avenues and Forty-third and Forty-ninth Streets, were poisoned yesterday by eating crullers and doughnuts. All day long physicians were kept busy attending women and children. The ambulance at Roosevelt Hospital was kept on the go from morning until night, and the surgeons at the hospital had the busiest day on record.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- The Colgate University football team to-day engaged Mason, the Cornell football coach. He will be here Monday.

From the meagre accounts which have reached us, it does not seem probable that the race riot in Washington Parish, La., was in any respect necessary. That the negro LOTT was operating a restaurant in a colored church in connection with a camp meeting is probable enough.

There was trouble at a meeting of Fusionists of the Nineteenth Assembly District last evening at the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street. Eggs were thrown and one of the speakers was struck by one and water was dashed over those on the outskirts of the small crowd.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 30. -- Charles Francis Adams, in an address before the American Antiquarian Society to-day, reviewed the history of Lee's surrender, and compared the struggle of the South with the present war in South Africa. What he said was new, and included a hitherto unpublished chapter of American history.

Seth Low during the two hours which he spent at Fusion headquarters late yesterday afternoon received a greater number of visitors than on any day since the headquarters opened. A landslide for the Fusion ticket was generally predicted by those who talked with Mr. Low. Upon leaving the headquarters, Mr. Low said:

Columbia's football team, though lacking the services of Kingdon and Berrien, yesterday continued the fast pace set in the Yale game by rolling up a score of 29 to 6 in the game with Haverford. Twenty-three of Columbia's points were made in the first half. In the second period scrub players were substituted and only one touch-down was made, on a 95-yard run by Weekes.

Betting in Wall Street on the Mayoralty contest was brisk yesterday and underwent a decided change. While on Tuesday the odds were 10 to 9, and the only even money bets were those of smaller size, yesterday even money was the rule all day, and toward the close the supply of Low money far exceeded that of the Shepard bettors.

The abolition of the Reading Committe of the Theatre Fruncais has made a stir in Paris. The committee was established by the "decree of Moscow" under Napoleon I., though the decree was really made in Paris. But the theatric Emperor liked to have people believe that in the heat of a fatal campaign in the heart of Russia he could still think of the drama.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- After having been upon the witness stand before the Court of Inquiry for four and one-half days Hear Admiral Schley this afternoon Concluded his testimony. For three days be was under cross-examination.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The annual report of Inspector Gen. J. C. Breckenridge says of the post exchange:
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Charles T. Yerkes has purchased Turner's celebrated painting "Rockets and Blue Lights," at the record price of L15,750.

The tax budget for 1902 was approved by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday. A reduction in city and county expenses of $125,871.60 was made as compared with the allowances for the city and county departments for 1901. The total budget for 1902 is $97,074,541.83, which includes the cost of conducting the business of the city and counties of the Greater New York, and also State taxes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- With the opening of the Schley Court of Inquiry to-day Admiral Schley began the fifth day of his testimony, and the third day of his cross-examination. The first question Capt. Lemly asked was whether the Iowa was with the Flying Squadron at Hampton Roads when he gave the Captains of the ships their verbal orders as to attacking the enemy's fleet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the language of a letter to you by S. Edmund Seaman, I am "a steadfast, but not fanatical, opponent of Tammany Hall. I had hoped at this election to help, by my ballot at least, in a vigorous, sincere, and successful campaign against it."

Two or three days before the Tammany convention met. Mr. George Foster Peabody called upon me to say that Croker was willing to take Edward M. Shepard as the Tammany nominee for Mayor and that Shepard was considering the suggestion. Peabody told me that he and Mr. Orr had advised Shepard to accept the nomination, because, whether he or President Low Should be elected, the city would be sure to have an honest administration.

John F. Carroll, the lieutenant of Richard Croker, is building a new town house for himself, according to reports which were freely circulated yesterday, and in which anti-Tammany campaigners seemed to place considerable credence. The residence, which is supposed to be intended for Mr. Carroll, is in process of construction on the Lot 8 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The Pan-American Exposition and the Pan-American Congress are steps in the education of our people regarding the nations to the south of us Half a century ago the United States thought more and really knew more of South America than to-day. At that time our merchant marine visited South American ports, and many of the merchants in our Atlantic cities had direct dealings with merchants of South America.

Announcement was made yesterday that Edwin Gould will become President of the Seventh National Bank, which suspended last June. The other officers will be Edward R. Thomas and William H. Taylor, Vice Presidents, and K. W. Jones, Jr. Vice President and cashier.

PORT WASHINGTON, L,. I., Oct. 30. -- W. Bourke Cockran of Sands Point, who was injured yesterday afternoon by a fall from his horse while out riding, is improving rapidly. The doctors who have been in attendance upon him say there is no danger from the injury to the head, and that a quick recovery is looked for.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Money was in active demand to-day in connection with the installment of the New South Wales loan. The supplies were increased largely by a large discount business, at 3 per cent., at the Bank of England during the last day or two, giving rise to the belief that the rate will not be raised to-morrow.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The National Review recently published the alleged essential terms of the "spatch-cooked" dispatch of Gen. Sir Redvers Buller to Gen. Sir George White, when the latter was in command of the beleaguered British garrison at Ladysmith. According to this authority, the message ran as follows:

-- Intimate knowledge of local conditions and characteristics as they exist in Greenwich would be necessary, of course, for reaching any conclusive opinion as to the motives of the name-concealing persons who have of late been sending to the tradesmen of that town letters containing banknotes of denominations running all the way from $2 to $20.

Argument on the motion to quash the indictment for murder against Roland B. Molineux was adjourned until next Thursday afternoon by Judge McMahon in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, after two hearings. Molineux was not in court, but ex-Gov. Black, who recently entered the case, appeared in his behalf, and Gen. Molineux watched the proceedings with his usual close attention.

Justice Jerome sprang the greatest surprise of the campaign last night in Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street, when he declared that Thomas C. Platt, William C. Whitney, Thomas F. Ryan, and H. H. Vroeland met yesterday afternoon in a conference in Mr. Whitney's office to discuss the District Attorneyship of the County of New York.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Joseph Herrings, the war correspondent, who was present at the battle of Taku, has been ordered to leave Prussia on the ground of evasion of military service a number of years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This is a campaign in which straight voting would seem to be peculiarly appropriate. When Tammany was beaten in 1894 the force of the defeat was materially lessened by the fact that that "ancient organization," as Mr. Shepard calls it, still retained possession of most of the county offices, with the power and patronage connected therewith.

Andrew Carnegie, who is expected home from Europe on Saturday, has, so it is said on excellent authority, planned the construction of a great polytechnic institute in Pittsburg which, with the necessary endowment fund, will cost something like $33,000,000.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 30. -- A collision occurred here to-day between a motor vehicle run by Henri Pournier, the famous French chauffeur, and a wildcat engine on the Long Island Railroad. Besides Mr. Fournier there were five persons in the automobile, and all were more or less injured, three of them being severely hurt The party was composed as follows:
Three commercial offices of the Reading Company and the Jersey Central to be consolidated to-morrow.

Allen -- Ogden. Joel Nott Allen, a son of the late Rev. Edward Brown Alien, and Miss Fanny Walton Ogden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Ogden, were married at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension, on lower Fifth Avenue. The Right Rev. Henry C. Potter, Bishop of New York, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Octavius Flagg and the Rev. Percy S. Grant, rector of the church.

A vastly improved card at the Aqueduct race track yesterday amply justified the large attendance, and further made amends for the poor racing of the day before by furnishing such a day of sport as has been witnessed on few occasions since the Fall season began.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30. -- The market to-day lacked activity, but was greatly improved in tone. While there was a large sprinkling of losses, the gains were in the majority. This result marked a complete swing in sentiment, for the feeling at yesterday's close was decidedly easy. The chief sufferer to-day was Atlantic Transport, which broke 5 points, to 225.

We rejoice at and applaud the action of the National Live Stock Association in preparing a bill declaring that "shoddy" shall no longer masquerade in the guise of honest all-wool goods. The principle of the bill is fundamentally righteous, and public policy demands its enactment.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- New York exchange was at 20 cents discount to-day. Rates for call and time loans, 4 1/2 to D per cent.

Dennis McAvoy, the proprietor of the hotel on the second floor of which Justice Jerome has his campaign headquarters was attacked by four men yesterday. He was in his saloon, just under Mr. Jerome's headquarters, and was assorting the mail which the postman had just left for the Justice when assaulted.

Within a limited range prices in the outside market yesterday showed considerable irregularity. Closing quotations showed some substantial declines, while elsewhere in the list appeared net gains even larger than the losses, but transactions were so small that little significance could be attached to the price movements of the day.

In a decision handed down by Judge Wallace yesterday the United States Circuit Court of Appeals reverses the decree of the United States Circuit Court, which was in favor of holders of the Brickill patent for apparatus for keeping the boilers of steam fire engines hot while not in actual service, in their suit against the city to recover $1,800,000 damages for alleged infringement of their rights.

William F. Miller of the defunct Franklin Syndicate and his attorney, Col. Robert A. Ammon, were on the witness stand yesterday in the Federal Building, Brooklyn, where Robert L. Tilney, a referee in bankruptcy, is holding an investigation for the benefit of creditors, who charge that Miller and his agents have concealed $115,000 to be used when Miller regains his freedom.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 -- The committee of thoroughbred breeders formed here yesterday at a mass meeting for the purpose of investigating the charges of the moving of the three-eighths pole, on the Kentucky Association track, for the purpose of selling Clarence H. Mackay the yearling bay colt by imp.
Sonn Brothers have sold the southwest corner of Waverley Place and Mercer Street, 25 by 82.9, to Goerlitz Benjes, who will erect on the lot a ten-story store and loft building.

NEWMARKET, Oct. 31 -- The first important step toward the breaking up of William C. Whitney's English racing establishment at Heath House was the sale today of ten of Mr. Whitney's racers. The Mount Vernon filly brought the best price, $16,000.

Controller Coler in a speech advocating the election of Edward M. Shepard, and mentioning the name of no other candidate, paid his respects to those who are in politics "for their pockets all the time" at the Grand Central Palace last night. Mr. Coler said that the rank and file of Democracy in this city was all right, but that there were troubles at the top.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The Ophir and the escorting warships encountered the full force of the severe easterly gale blowing yesterday over the Channel, and were obliged to abandon their intention of putting into Portland Roads.

George W. Freeborn, an undertaker, of 167 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, who was arrested Wednesday on an unsatisfied judgment of $10,000, was admitted to $20,000 bail by the Sheriff yesterday. The judgment was obtained against him in a suit for conspiracy, in which he was charged with the spiriting away of the body of the plaintiff's husband.

The statement made by Justice Jerome at Lyric Hall on Wednesday evening that Thomas C. Platt, William C. Whitney, Thomas P. Ryan, and H.H. Vreeland had met earlier in the day in Mr. Whitney's private office and discussed the District Attorneyship was much discussed in political circles yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While preparing a sermon upon the life and character of Alfred the Great for next Sunday morning, I naturally thought of that other personage who is the present most distinguished citizen of Wantage, a contribution from Greater New York. How does our Richard compare with England's Alfred?

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 -- The Grau Opera Company opened its engagement in New Orleans to-night under the most favorable auspices. The French Opera House was packed to the doors. Considering the season, the showing made by society was remarkable. The opera to-night was "Lohengrin."

Conditions in the outside market yesterday were practically a repetition of those of the previous day. Prices continued to show considerable irregularity, and there was no appreciable increase in the volume of transactions. Not more than three or four stocks were sufficiently active to attract attention, and all of these were numbered among the few issues which recently have been the most prominent.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The President to-day denied six applications for pardons, granted one, and restored three applicants to citizenship.

Edward M. Shepard waged his part of the Democratic Mayoralty campaign in the Borough of Richmond last evening. The "ancient and honorable ferryboats" plying between Manhattan and Staten Island were made an issue in Mr. Sheparu's speech, and he also paid attention to the remarks of Seth Low, made recently, concerning the record of Tammany Hall.

In the bowling tournament of the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island, on Thum Ehlers' Palace Alleys, Brooklyn, last night, Hermann Ehler of the Greater New York Wheelmen, made a new high individual score of 256, with seven strikes and three spares. The Greater New Yorkers' score of 982 in the second game was a new high team score.

An unusual demonstration took place yesterday afternoon on the pier of the White Star Line, following the arrival of the steamship Majestic. The big pier echoed with the cheers of a large crowd of Irish-Americans, who were there to greet John Redmond, Patrick A. McHugh, and Thomas O'Donnell, all members of the British Parliament, and at the present time the most conspicuous Irish Nationalists.

There is a delightful collection of flowers and plants to be seen at the Central Park conservatories. One Hundred and Fifth Street und Fifth Avenue, at the annual Fall exhibition which opened yesterday. The chrysanthemum in the north greenhouse, form the chief floral feature of the show, and they are even more beautiful this year than last.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As our brief civic campaign enters its final tumultuous week, it seems fitting that onlookers, who, though not unsympathetic, have taken no part in the activities, should make their comments.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The seventh annual meeting of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs, representing 7,300 women and ninety-five clubs, assembled in Trinity Congregational Church of East Orange this morning. The church was decorated with flowers and plants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer has observed that in a number of instances campaign speakers who are engaged in the struggle for the overthrow of "Crokerism" have made haste to assure their audiences that their remarks were not intended as a reflection upon Mr. Croker's personal character.

It has been long since the betting patrons of the turf, and none but bettors patronize the turf at Aqueduct, had so disastrous an afternoon as that of yesterday. On the other hand, the men in the ring, who now are known as "layers," have been waiting a similar length of time for such an inning as they then had.

"He [SHEPARD] tells us that he is running upon a partisan platform and that he has no faith in any kind of municipal government which is not conducted by the representatives of party organizations. The distinction between my position in 1901 and SHEPARD'S in 1901 is therefore fundamental.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After your generosity in giving so much space to a presentation by Dr. Edward F. Barnes of my claims to the support of voters in the Twenty-seventh Assembly District, it is with much reluctance that I now impose upon you a reply to your editorial observations concerning my candidacy.

A charming girl was out yesterday wearing a simple black corduroy suit, the skirt made plainly, the placket hole fastened in the back in two points, each finished with a black button. There was a short jacket, a flat black hat, and one of the big, flimsy, much-beruffled muffs of chiffon was carried with it.

A certain number of Southern papers and Southern politicians continue to scold about the incident of Mr. BOOKER T. WASHINGTON at the table of Mr. ROOSEVELT. Though we could bray them in a mortar of advice, we suppose that they would hardly cease from their folly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day (Oct. 29) there appears a reference to the declination of a title from his Royal Highness the Duke of Cornwall and York by the Lieutenant Governor of Nova Scotia, the Hon. A.G. Jones.

Justice Clarke in the Supreme Court yesterday heard argument on the application of Lawyer Meyer J. Stein, Chairman of the Greater New York Democracy, to prohibit Magistrate Brann from hearing a charge against him and his client Isaac Gutenstein, for placing a banner over a registration place.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- When the Schley Court opened to-day Capt. T.S. Borden was called as the first witness of the day, and as the last witness who was to testify in Admiral Schley's behalf. It had been expected that Admiral Barker would be called, but it has been decided that his testimony if given would not be material, and it is not now expected that he will testify.

-- when grievances for which, it real, redress can be obtained from the constituted authorities are industriously and prematurely exploited through newspaper and other unofficial channels in the shape of unproved suspicions and unsupported charges, the result can hardly fail to be the creation in discriminative minds of an impression that the complainant is not quite confident of his ability to make out a case in the regular way.

Surrogate Thomas yesterday admitted to probate the will of Archy A. Field, who died last February at 1,659 Monroe Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, leaving an estate valued at $50,000 to his second wife, who, with her six children, live in the Monroe Avenue house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the letter signed Richard Dickinson in your issue of Oct. 27 on the change of American sentiment from the British to the Boer side in the South African war and ask the favor of a few words in reply.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 -- The market to-day was very dull in the department of stocks, but showed more interest and activity among investment bonds. The two most noteworthy changes were three-point gains for Consolidation Coal and Atlantic Coast Line of Connecticut. Seaboard common was an eighth lower.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a citizen of this city I protest against the publication in your issue of Oct. 27 of a notice wherein the members of the so-called Woman's Campaign Committee charge the members of the Tammany Society as follows: "Tammany Hall is using its control of the City Government to encourage the business of ruining young girls for gain."

In town it was a dull day, although the Avenue and Park were crowded during the afternoon with carriages, and there were many new faces of people who have returned for the season seen at the restaurants. It was gay in the country and at Tuxedo and Meadow Brook and other colonies All Halloween was celebrated with enthusiasm by the young people.

As most of the colleges are to meet teams of an almost equal calibre Saturday, the practice yesterday in nearly every case was secret. Instead of practicing on South Field, the Columbia football squad journeyed up to the Polo Grounds and put in a hard afternoon's work there, the 'Varsity, made up chiefly of first substitute material, proving too much for the scrub.

When Mr. SHEPARD undertakes to show that the Fusion ticket was not made in heaven, nor even in Arcadia, he always adduces Mr. CANTOR. He did it again, night before last, as if the nomination of Mr. CANTOR to be President of the Borough of Manhattan were some kind of proof that the Fusion ticket Was a ticket of false pretenses.

CREEDMOOR, Oct. 31 -- The last practice day of the season was held here to-day for the expert class at 700 and 800 yards. The attendance was light. The weather was foggy in the morning, but cleared off and became favorable with light 5 o'clock wind. The shooting and issuing of decorations were under the supervision of Lieut. Cov. N.B. Thurston, Ordnance Officer, N.G. N.Y. Scores follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent TIMES editorial begins in this way: "There is a class of men in every community which profess to believe, and most of them do believe, that the reform of great and firmly rooted evils is practically impossible," and then you argue against their conclusion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The calling of witnesses in rebuttal was begun to-day in the Schley court. Rear Admiral Schley's last witness, Capt. Borden, of the Marine Corps, testified in the forenoon and the rest of the morning session was given up to arguments between counsel about the admisibility of evidence.

The second annual team match of the Philadelphia and the Metropolitan Women's Golf Associations for the Clement A. Griscom cup was played yesterday on the links of the Morris County Golf Club, near Morristown, N.J. The home team won by the totally unexpected score of 91 holes to 5, winning the match and the cup by the unusual margin of 86 holes.
CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- New York exchange was at 20 cents discount to-day. Time and call loans. 4 1/2@5 per cent.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- Late last night the following dispatch was received from Toulon:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having long regarded THE TIMES as one of the few newspapers whose editorial columns a man of mature mind may forgive himself for reading, it is with deep regret that I yield to the conclusion that the spirit of fairness has evaporated from its pages in the heat of the present political struggle.

While reiterating that there was a conference on Wednesday afternoon between Senator Thomas C. Platt and William C. Whitney, Justice Jerome asserted at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night that he had been assured by a gentleman in a position to know that no question of politics was discussed at the meeting.

Yesterday's stock market was narrow and professional throughout the entire day, with traders disposed to do very little on either side of the market. What little was done reflected merely the contrary opinions held as to the probable course of prices in the immediate future, and hence it was that while some issues advanced others declined.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So far as I have seen, you have not defined what you mean by "non-partisanship" in municipal politics; but I take it you mean a movement toward city administration without regard to the policies of the two great National parties. And you conceive that Mr. Shepard has struck a heavy blow against good government by appealing for support on the ground that he is a Democrat.

A.P. DUTTON, a pioneer of Wisconsin, died at Racine yesterday. Mr. Dutton built the first piers and elevators in Racine, and was in early years prominently identified with the grain handling and shipping interests. He was born in New York State in 1822 and came to Wisconsin in 1841.
Details will be found in another column regarding the sale of a plot on Pine Street to Kean. Van Cortlandt Co. and the City Real Property Investing Company.

MINEOLA, L.I., Oct. 31 -- H.B. Fullerton, J.H. Gerrie, and A.G. Batchelder, who were hurt yesterday at Westbury, L. I., in the crash between Henri Fournier's automobile and an engine on the Long Island Railroad, and who are being cared for in the Nassau Hospital here, were reported this evening to be doing well.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In all the election talk the main thing is not brought out as plainly as it seems to me it should be. There is no reasonable doubt that either Mr. Shepard or Mr. Low would make an excellent Mayor so far as either is free to do his best, and both appear to be unusually free so far as pledges and party obligations go.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold from 5c premium to 5@10c discount. Exchanges, $23,053,780; balances, $2,677,979.
LONDON, Oct. 31 -- The Lancet says it has official authority to announce that the rumors regarding the health of King Edward are entirely without truth or foundation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to Mr. Aiken's letter in to-day's paper, entitled "The City Election in Its National Aspects," permit me to say that, while agreeing with him in the main, I cannot agree with, him in his assertion that "Tammany stands for an idea wholly unAmerican." Tammany rule is essentially American, an outgrowth of our peculiar election machinery.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 31 -- When President Charles M. Schwab of the United States Steel Corporation was in Joliet he ran up against an employe of his big company who was no respecter of persons, and denied to the president of the Steel Corporation the right to enter one of his own plants.

The decision of the Appellate term of the Supreme Court of Illinois that married women in that State are liable for debts contracted by their husbands rests upon a statute and is not along the line of development of the common law. For this reason it lacks something of the interest which would otherwise attach to it.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Franklin Murphy, Republican Gubernatorial candidate, made his first appearance in this city this evening. He was accompanied by United States Senator John Kean and Edmund Wilson of Red Bank.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 1 -- The affidavits of Cecil Rhodes, repudiating notes aggregating L23,000, drawn in favor of the Princess Catherine Radziwill; (of the German branch of the Radziwill family,) and purporting to have been signed by Mr. Rhodes, have arrived here.

Edward M. Shepard has filed in the Queens County Clerk's office, a deed transferring to the Palmer Waterfront Land and Improvement Company and Lowell M. Palmer, Henry O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, and H.U. Palmer, a tract of land on Newtown Creek, north of Grand Street and between Newtown Creek and the Long Island Railroad tracks in Long Island City.

The private sale of the magnificent Sunderland library to Mrs. John Rylands was a good thing for the City of Manchester, and, in fact, for the world. The private sale of the Lefferts library to a rare book dealer is a good thing for the purchaser alone.

Miss Genevieve Hecker, America's champion woman golfer, encountered her second defeat yesterday within less than two weeks of her National championship victory. On Thursday, in the inter-city match at Morris County, Miss Hecker was beaten by Mrs. Caleb F. Fox of Philadelphia, and yesterday she went down before Mrs. Edward A. Manice by 3 up and 1 to play.

IT is said that Henry B. Fuller's new book, which D. Appleton Co. will shortly publish, with the title "Under the Skylights," is a satire on certain art and literary circles in Chicago which can hardly pass without remonstrance from the Windy City.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- John Rohr, thirty-eight years of age, living at Great Falls, two miles north of this village, is in the hospital here suffering from a gashed throat. He tried to kill himself this afternoon with a bread knife. Last night he attempted to kill his wife. She was awakened by being struck, with a club.

With the end of the week come the various meets of the different hunts, which generally give an extra run on Saturday afternoons. Apawamis and Ardsley will have golf matches, and at the latter place there will be an informal dance. At Tuxedo, there will be the afternoon musicale, followed by dinners at the club and a dance.

The meeting held last night at Durland's Riding Academy under the auspices of the West Side Republican Club was attended by a scene which bordered upon a serious panic. The crowds began to gather in front of the academy, on Sixty-sixth Street, near Eighth Avenue, as early as 7 o'clock.

Justice Clarke in the Supreme Court yeserday listened to argument on an application made by the Atlantic Telephone Company for a writ of mandamus to compel Henry S. Kearny, Commissioner of Public Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies, to permit the company to use the subways of the Empire City Electrical Subway Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most important civic obligations, one all men have to perform, is the duty of voting. Only a small portion of the voting population has the advantage of higher studies, and the subject of exercising the right to vote is scarcely touched upon in the common schools.

At the request of the Postmasters' Association of the United States, Postmaster E.R. Monfort of this city has prepared a paper on the subject of "Misdirected Mail." It has been ordered printed, and is to be sent to all the Post Offices of the country as the opening move in arousing the people generally on this matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Secretary Hay to-day presented to the President Senor Don Jorge Munoz as a Special Minister and Plenipotentiary from Guatemala. Senor Munoz was accompanied by Dr. Yela, the Secretary of the Guatemalan Legation here. The former came in a special capacity, as the bearer of the condolences of the Guatemalan Government upon the death of President McKinley.
LONDON, Nov. 2 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, Nov. 1:

Last Wednesday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre Mme. Sarah Grand, author of "The Heavenly Twins," spoke to an interested audience on the subject of "Mere Man." A noticeable feature of the afternoon, however, was the conspicuous absence of "mere man," there being scarcely more than a dozen in the entire auditorium; but these did their best to make a showing, and laughed heartily at Mme. Grand's wit.

A careful reading of Mr. Graham Balfour's biography of his cousin and friend, Robert Louis Stevenson, tends to confirm the old saying that all good biography is autobiography. Not that Mr. Balfour's book is not good reading. On the contrary, it is very good reading. The more the reader of it knows about Stevenson, the more interesting it is.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Walker Breese Smith and George Griswold, well-known members of the Tuxedo Park colony, are candidates for the office of Highway Commissioner, the election to occur Nov. 5. They have been nominated on both the Democratic and Republican tickets, consequently their election is assured.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Schley inqruiry is practically closed. On Monday Rear Admiral Schley will take the stand to correct his testimony, and an officer of the Castine, Lieut. Strauss, may be called. After that, unless the Judge Advocate in the meantime discovers some more witnesses, Mr. Hanna will begin the argument.

Capt. F. Norton Goddard stated yesterday that he had been told by an employe of the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company, occupying a position of responsibility, that the men of at least one department had been instructed to vote against Justice Jerome for District Attorney at the coming election.

By way of such explanation as may avert confusion of mind. The Springfield Republican has thought it well, in its issue of Oct. 20, to devote half a column of space to an explanation of the meaning of academic costumes, in the matter of stuffs, colors, forms, facings, linings, and the like.

Betting is a practice not to be commended, and very properly discouraged by the new Constitution, and also by the Penal Code, of the State of New York. The only thing that is to be said in its favor, so far as we know, is that it does afford a test of sincerity. When a man tells you incredible things, it is well that you should have some ready criterion of his credulity.

-- Laboring under the curious delusion that "the subject of vivisection *** is one of the most weighty before the public to-day," the Boston publication which calls itself The Animals' Defender -- presumably because of a subliminal consciousness that man delights it not nor woman neither -- has recently taken a lot of trouble to find out how the candidates for office in Massachusetts this Fall stand on the question.
Army. Capt. Wilds P. Richardson, Eighth Infantry, will join his company.
PORTSMOUTH, Nov. 1 -- To-day's pageant in honor of the return of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York was almost a reproduction of that attending their departure.

The last Tammany cheers of greeting to Edward M. Shepard before election were given by over 20,000 people who crowded the five halls in which he spoke in the Borough of Manhattan last evening. Another gathering estimated at 10,000 people tried to hear some of Mr. Shepard's words uttered at the first outdoor meeting he has attended during the campaign, but his voice was drowned by cheers.

Richard M. Montgomery has sold for William P. Douglas to R. Amsinck the four-story building 78 Beaver Street, running through to 125 Pearl Street, adjoining the corner of Hanover Street, 18 by 96.5 by 22 by 93.6.

Seth Low addressed 14,000 persons during the four speeches which he made last night, a larger number than has heard him upon any single evening since the present municipal campaign commenced. He spoke to 1,800 persons at the Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, on Bleecker Street, to 7,000 at Durland's Riding Academy, to 3,000 at the Lenox Lyceum, and 2,000 persons heard him at Maennerchor Hall, at Fifty-sixth Street, near Third Avenue.

Carl Schurz, John Harsen Rhoades, Job B. Hedges, Edward M. Grout, George V. Von Skal, and others addressed a mass meeting attended by over 2,000 persons at Arion Hall, Brooklyn, last evening. The meeting was held under the auspices of the German-American Union, Dr. W. John Schildge, President of the German-American Municipal League, presiding.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In Mr. Stoddard's reminiscences of Edmund Clarence Stedman, printed in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Oct. 26, appears a reference to me and my mission to Charles Dickens, in 1859, having in view a second visit from him to this coun- try, which is so offensive that I approach it with reluctance, even for the purpose of its correction.

With the fondness and fullness of a true enthusiast, Dr. Mortimer has made a book of nearly 600 big pages upon a single plant. But he tells us that it is the most wonderful plant in the world in its beneficent properties, and that the whole story of the career of the Incas and the fabric of Peru clusters about it.

There has been this year a considerable falling off in the value of our exports of manufactures. There has also been a perceptible increase in the amounts of our imports generally. The two facts have been taken as having some connection and as indicating forces at work to check the recent extraordinary prosperity of our foreign trade.

The business men of the country will cordially approve the arrangements of United States Treasurer ROBERTS, as described in his annual report just made public, to increase the proportion of bills of small denomination annually issued. With the approval of Congress, more than $140,000,000 of Treasury and National bank notes of denominations above ten dollars will be reissued in denominations below that figure.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 -- Representatives of the Northern and Southern Synods of the Presbyterian Church are in session here to-day for the purpose of taking steps toward establishing a great Presbyterian college for the higher education of women, to cost probably $500,000. The hope is to make it a bond of union between the two contending branches of the Church in the United States.

Who is to decide when doctors disagree? Hero are two learned professors, one of New York and the other of Boston, who hold entirely different views about the delicate art of writing the English language. Both of them have high standing in the world of letters, and both should know not a little about their subject.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Will you kindly publish in your columns the following statement: In the recently published "Life of Poe," by Col. John A. Joyce, a mistake is made which should be corrected. Reference is made to the literary contest of 1833, in which premiums were offered by The Baltimore Saturday.

The Monarch team won two games in the American National series last night, scoring 978 in the first. In the Columbia League tournament the Corinthians won two more victories, while the Knickerbockers were the double winners in the Harlem League series, making an average of 938 1/2 in the two games. The scores follow:

Stocks in delicate colors, pink and blue and heliotrope velvet, are made in the forn of a deep turn-over collar, the edges of the collar finished with a narrow edge of cream lace. The tie is long and with broad ends finished with cream lace. It is tied in a small four-in-hand knot.
MADRID, Nov. 1 -- The name of "Sackville" is figuring in strange investigations which are occupying the attention of the courts here.

Secretary Gage's action in ordering the resumption of bond purchases resulted yesterday in much larger offerings than anticipated by bankers. All of the leading bond brokers were represented in the early offerings, one of them by a lot of $600,000.

Surrounded by text books on various sciences, Louis Schapiro, a young Russian Anarchist, commited suicide by swallowing carbolic acid at his home, at 105 Avenue B, yesterday morning and called in a neighbor to see him die. He left brief writings of his own, some blasphemous in the extreme, others reviling society.

President Feitner sent to Mayor Van Wyck yesterday a report of the work of the Department of Taxes and Assessments for the three months ending Sept. 30, 1901. The report contains an analysis of the assessment rolls for 1901, and a synopsis shows that the taxpayers of the city will pay $88,241,852.75, of which real estate will bear $75,632,266.44 of the burden, and personal estates pay $12,609,586.31.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- In addition to the four warships which Congress has directed him to prepare plans for, as a basis for appropriation at the next session of Congress, Secretary Long has before him the recommendations of the Board of Naval Construction, looking to authorization by Congress of the building of forty more naval vessels of all classes, from battleships down to tugboats.

The author of "The Man With the Hoe" has put forth another volume of versus, of which the title, "Lincoln," is taken from the poem read at the New York Republican Club's Lincoln birthday dinner last year. This poem is conspicuous for its dignified simplicity, its breadth of style, and its conciseness.

Robert Louis Stevenson is certainly not without honor in his own country. Leading Stevenson features are issued by English and Scottish papers, while of other good articles about him there seem to be no end. One of the most charming -- a long paper of three or four thousand words -- will be found in a late number of The Scotsman -- "In a Colinton Garden."

Football will be thoroughly alive to-day in every part of the country where collegiate interest and athletic rivalry are to be found. It will be a day of many big gaines, and they are all bound to be interesting because the well-known teams have been whipped nicely into shape during the contests of the last three or four weeks.

Doubtless few persons trouble themselves about the number of books published in a year, or the kinds. It might, however, be instructive to such persons to inquire what classes of works of literature seem to be the most popular. No one would hesitate to accord the leading place to fiction, for it is an undeniable fact that the great majority of readers read for amusement and not for information.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Appended to the annual report of Commissioner, General Weston, which was made public to-day, is an account of the proceedings of a board of officers convened to report on a new emergency ration and of the way in which, after selecting it, they tried it on a detachment of soldiers ordered out for the purpose.

What gives to Boston its peculiar mental atmosphere, with which the visitor, though a wayfaring man, sojourning there but a few days, even a few hours, cannot fail to be impressed, especially if he be a visitor from New York?

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 1 -- Dr. J.E. Gilman, Senior Professor of Materia Medica in the Hahnemann Medical College of Chicago, who through the agency of X-rays is said to have affected a permanent cure of cancer of the breast from which Mrs. Orrin W. Potter of this city had been a sufferer for years, described his treatment to-day.

"Joseph Henry Shorthouse, manufacturer of sulphuric acid, author of 'John Inglesant,' 'Countess Eve,' 'Sir Percival,' c." In this manner a well-known biographical dictionary sums up the novelist of Birmingham, whose books are known one may almost say wherever the English language is spoken.

ROME, Oct. 7 -- A superficial reading of "The Eternal City" produced in certain circles here a rather unfavorable impression of the author's picture of Italian political men and life. From information received, for the accuracy of which I can vouch. I learn that even at Court the book was read and keenly discussed.

Mr. Stone's book is limited to 350 numbered copies and is printed on a good quality of handmade paper, in well-selected type, being rubricated throughout. The running titles are set in a well-designed font of small capitals, separated from the body of the page by two red lines, one much heavier than the other, which renders the page unusually effective.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 1 -- George C. Bennett's crack two-year-old thoroughbred Abe Frank and the three-year-old race mare Miss Bennett are suffering from lung fever. To-night a veterinary surgeon in attendance pronounces the condition of both horses as hopeless. Abe Frank won many of the two-year-old classics on the Chicago tracks this season, and it is said Mr. Bennett at one time refused an offer of $25,000 for the colt.

Justice Jerome at each of the six meetings he addressed last night said he was confident that the entire Fusion ticket would be elected. He declared that he had hoped up to the present time, but now from information he had received hope had become almost certainty.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The book of the week in Paris is Jules Simon's "The Evening of My Life." It is a the volume of reminiscences of the great French statesman and writer, who in early life was known as Jules Francois Simon Suisse.

THIS timely work by a cultivated and fair-minded American, the greater part of his life resident at Constantinople, merits respectful attention. The first part covers ground often described by travelers' narratives, the "people and customs" of the Orient. The second part relates to the condition of the multiform religions and the progress of reform in the superb capital of the Grand Turk.

MR. LLOYD, in "Warwick of the Knobs," again gives us a powerful novel, of which the scene is laid in Northern Kentucky. The central figure is old Warwick, a "hardshell" Baptist preacher. The peculiar tenets of this sect and the type of manhood which they foster are set forth in the preface, which should, by all means, be read as a preparation for the story.
GENEVA, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- The football team of Colgate University defeated Hobart College here to-day in one of the championship games of the New York State League by the close score of 11 to 10.

The Episcopal Church authorities have sent out a letter to the various Church and charitable organizations of the city calling their attention to a proposed amendment to Section 18 of Article III. of the Constitution, which amendment is to be voted upon at the election to be held next Tuesday.
