BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5 and 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $23,113,943; balances, $2,514,632.

THE wisdom of republishing in a volume that which has already appeared in the form of journalism is often doubtful, especially when this journalism is mere reporting. An exception must be made, however, when the "news" thus revived is 200 years old.

Mr. SHEPARD appeals to Democratic voters to help on the rehabilitation of their party by voting the Tammany ticket -- that is, by voting for FROMME, UNGER, and VAN HOESEN as well as for EDWARD M. SHEPARD; by voting for all of CROKER'S candidates, by voting to give the victory to CROKER.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Nov. 1 -- John F. Reilly, a young sportsman, shot himself to-day while out hunting. He stumbled under some underbrush and his gun went off, the charge entering his right leg. He is quite seriously hurt.

The passing on of William Carey is a sorrow to an unusually large circle. Indeed. It is given to few mortals to win as many stanch friends as he won. He possessed a genius for friendship -- the power of attaching men and women to him as by hooks of steel. Yet he never seemed to study to please.

More than 1,000 persons attended the ratification meeting last night of the Carondelet Club, in Madison Avenue, near One Hundred and Eighteenth Street. The clubhouse was crowded, and an overflow meeting was held in the street. A week ago last Tuesday a score of members met at the clubhouse and indorsed Seth Low and all the rest of the Fusion ticket.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read Shepard's reply to my communicatlon with increasing pain. It is, I am sorry to say, a tissue of misstatements. I have nowhere said that he had been "seduced by the contagion of office," but I urged him to decline the Tammany nomination because others, not I, would think that he had sold out to the enemy.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- The market today was better in tone than it has been for more than a week. There was an abundance of gains and only one decline. Seaboards were better, the common being 1/8 higher, the preferred 1/4, and the 4 per cent, bonds 1/2. United States Fidelity Trust, one of the constituent units of the rumored bonding companies' consolidation, was a full point better.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to congratulate you on your admirable editorial in to-day's issue on "Gen. Miles and the Canteen."

At his Brooklyn headquarters yesterday, Edward M. Shepard made public replies he had prepared in answer to the latest criticisms of him by ex-Mayor Abrarn S. Hewitt and R. Fulton Cutting, Mr. Shepard's reply to Mr. Hewitt is as follows:

Edward S. Stokes died at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the home of his sister, Mrs. Mary McNutt, 73 St. Nicholas Avenue. He had been unconscious for three days, and his death was expected at any hour. This fact was concealed from all inquirers. At 2:45 o'clock his nurse and valet attempted to turn him in bed.

From this day (May 17) we were not to see the sun again for two months. At the begining. we did not dread the prospect of this long polar night before us, but before the sun had been gone many days one of us became very ill. Danco lacked the constitution to hold out, and on June 5 he died. It is useless to dwell on sad recollections.

From St. Nicholas. If you turn over some of the stones quickly you sometimes find nothing at all; often an ants' nest, occasionally a colony of snails, or sometimes a tiny snake coiled in a ball like a marble.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The first official statement of any kind made for a month in relation to the Nicaragua Canal confirms the report that Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador to the United States, when he lands in New York to-day, will have with him the draft of a new treaty, abrogating the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Americans on the English turf, trainers and jockeys, wound up the racing season at Newmarket in such a glorious style as to cause a general reversion of opinion on the part of racegoers. To-day no word is too good for the Americans. Such a high authority as The Field says:

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- With the thundering of the Royal salute rending the air and the totem poles holding aloft the national colors along his roundabout path from the Victoria Station to Marlborough House, the homecoming of the heir apparent to the British throne has been appropriately and vigorously welcomed.

A memorial fountain is speedily to be erected near the union railway passenger station in Waycross, Ga., in honor of the late Henry B. Plant. It is to be in the centre of a memorial park and so placed that all passengers on the railroad trains may see this memorial of the great railroad builder of Florida.

It is not often that so many conflicting and contrary developments appear in the money market as those which in the last week have come to occasion so much speculation and uncertainty in the financial district and to set at naught all predictions based upon the assumption that only normal conditions would rule.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "The Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States," a visible ecclesiastical association, organized a hundred odd years ago, and the inheritor of certain things (and some things uncertain) from Scotch as well as English ancestry of prior existing visible ecclesiastical organizations, does not stand in need of any defense from one of its humblest members.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Thursday last appears a communication signed "S.E.R.," in which the writer states the opinion that Tammany Hall is deceiving the public by displaying the inscription "Regular Democratic Republican Nominees" upon its banner at Broadway and Twenty-third Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 2. -- Gov. W. T. Durbin, in a lengthy communication addressed to-night to Gov. J.C.W. Beckham of Kentucky, refused to grant the requisition for the extradition of ex-Gov. William S. Taylor and Charles W. Finley, who have been indicted by Kentucky courts for complicity in the murder of Gov. William Goebel. Gov. Durbin says in part:

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- At the headquarters of the Republican State Committee, returns of the registration in the cities and towns of the State have been received from the city and town committees, and an attempt has been made to base a prediction on the total vote of Massachusetts next Tuesday, and the Republican plurality.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Four hundred employes of the Illinois Central Railroad working in the shops at Burnside, near Chicago, have been laid off. Out of a force of 186 machinists and helpers, 128 were included in the lay-off. Boilenmakers, blacksmiths, and their helpers and roundhouse men make up the balance of the number.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 2. -- The investigating committee appointed by Kentucky breeders and trainers at a mass meeting last Monday completed its work to-day and will report its findings at another meeting Monday noon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One would think that the Davis law, stating explicitly what each teacher should receive under certain conditions, could not be evaded even by the Board of Education, but that is not the case. The fate of the teachers depends wholly upon the interpretation by the board ou the word "meritorious."

Trading in the market for outside securities was almost at a standstill yesterday by reason of the large amount of attention devoted to betting on the Mayoralty contest. What little dealing there was developed weakness in the prevailing prices in most instances.

There has been for long in the United States a belief that Russia was a genuine, sympathetic friend, moved by admiration for the American people and their institutions. This has grown up chiefly, I suppose, from the apocryphal narratives of the readiness of Russia, to intervene on the side of right during the war of the rebellion.

Germany in Asia Minor. Some confusion has been betrayed in the cable dispatches dealing with the bearing of the Turko-German railway question upon the affair at Koweit. Some of the confusion arises from the fact that there are two distinct lines, each of which has been called "the Bagdad Railway."

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- The Matin last Sunday published three letters from Gen. Voyron, who commanded the French troops in China, dated Dec. 30, Nov. 16, and Dec. 10, 1900, respectively, in reply to communications from Field Marshal Count von Waldersee, the commander of the allied forces, the tenor of which only is given.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems that none of the inner ring of Tammany take the accusations of Justice Jerome so much to heart as Senator Sullivan, and it is pitiful to watch him appealing to the substratum of ignorance and prejudice, which has carried him, Croker, and all the rest so long.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The Orange Athletic Club football team took the Yale Law School team into camp this afternoon on the Orange Oval, defeating them by the score of 22 to 0. The Orange team was much heavier than the Yale eleven, and the latter were not up to the mark in team work, while Orange had its team work and interference down fine.

The experiences which we have had in this country with municipal governments have been far from satisfactory to the lovers of free institutions. They are less so each year, And, meanwhile, we are quietly drifting away from the principles of Democracy -- a government of the people, by the people, and for the people.

Last week's business, although still following somewhat restricted lines, contained a number of transactions of such size and character as to brighten materially the outlook for the Winter and Spring months of active real estate trading.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 2. -- Col. Reginald Norman has had plans drawn for a country house on his farm at Black Point, in Portsmouth, about five and a half miles from Newport. The house will be an example of the English style of the Tudor period. It will be 92 by 55 feet and contain twenty-five rooms.

The Fusion campaign managers all expressed themselves yesterday as more than sanguine of the outcome of the election. They predicted a sweeping victory for Low and the whole Fusion ticket. During the day Mr. Low received reports from the leaders of the various organizations which are supporting the Fusion cause. Following are some of the opinions expressed:
The stork market is slothful. Speculative transactions are insignificant. Commission house business has become wholly unimportant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I regret to see that an eminent minister of the Gospel in his sermon yesterday morning "argued for the abolition of capital punishment." Many wise and good persons believe that the only way to lessen the number of murders is to follow each case with its due and proper punishment.

The following is the programme for the second concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, on Saturday afternoon, Nov. 9: Volkmann, overture, "Richard III.:" Lalo. concerto for violoncello and orchestra: Liszt. symphonic poem. "Festklaenge:" Beethoven, Symphony No. 7. soloist, Mr. Jean Gerardy.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Nov. 2. -- At this morning's meeting of the Pan-American Congress Gen, Raffael Reyes, delegate of Colombia, in a speech full of praise for the United States, proposed that H.G. Davis, Chairman of the United States delegation, be elected Permanent President of the Pan-American Conference.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- President Roosevelt to-day issued his proclamation fixing Thursday. Nov. 28, as a day of National thanksgiving. It is as follows:

Justice William Travers Jerome, looking thoroughly worn out from the labors of the campaign, appeared on the platform last night for his final speech before election day. He talked slowly, taking long breaths, as if laboring to hold up under a strain. It was at the meeting of the united German societies of the city, held in the Grand Central Palace.

WITH the first concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, which takes place at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, the musical season of 1901-2 will formally open. The advance gun was fired a week ago by the recital of S.M. Fabian, a pianist of respectable abilities, at Mendelssohn Hall, but the series of entertainments which is to flow unbrokenly from November till May really begins on Thursday night.

THE bridal gown worn by Miss Leila Wotherspoon at the lime of her marriage to Col. Asser was unlike anything that has been seen thus far this Autumn. The skirt's train was moderately long, and at its edge were tucks of chiffon. The foundation of the dress was white satin, but this was almost completely concealed by the long tunic of white crepe de thine.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The indifference of New Yorkers to their deprivations of the rights accorded them, (in the streets of their city, by the laws, not only of the city but of the State as well,) and their consequent inconvenience and annoyance, has long been a surprise to citizens of other places.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Robert B. Roosevelt and others object to Low as largely the candidate of Platt and the Republican machine. I would like to remind these gentlemen that Low is the candidate of a free parliament in which they were or could have been represented, or at worst he is the candidate of King Platt and Parliament.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Nov. 2. -- There have been no new plays lately except an exceedingly clever burlesque of William Gillette's "Sherlock Holmes" at Terry's Theatre, in which, of course, the astute detective is proved always in the wrong, and the remarks of Dr. Watson's unseen wife, whenever the door is opened in the last scene, are positively disgraceful.

Almira C. Lawton, wife of Frank H. Lawton, a pianist of this city, has brought suit in the Supreme Court against her husband for a separation on the ground of cruelty, and in the course of her charges the plaintiff states that her husband compelled her to act as Captain, mate, boatswain, cook, and cabin-boy of a houseboat on which they spent their Summers on Lake Champlain.

RULE IN SHELLEY'S CASE. -- "The rule in Shelley's case," which was first propounded in the English courts in the reign of the second Edward, and was afterward more definitely expressed in the days of Lord Coke, and which was abrogated by statute in this State in 1830, has very seldom for many years figured here as an element in legal controversy.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 2. -- Lafayette and Lehigh, old rivals, met here on the gridiron to-day, the former being victorious by the score of 29 to 0. Most of the scoring was done in the first half, when Lafayette made 23 points on touch-downs by Cure, Platt, Pritchard, and E. Haldman. Bachman kicked 3 out of 4 goals.

Justice Jerome practically ended his campaign yesterday after delivering, a series of eight speeches along the east side and the Bowery. Crowds, cheering and shouting his name, followed him through the streets of that district whenever he walked, and crowded around his carriage and followed it from place to place as he rode.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- The Military Academy cadets are jubilant to-night over the splendid showing made by their football team against Yale to-day. The tie score, 5 to 5, shows how well the soldiers fought against Eli's giants. Weight, strength, and age were in favor of the visitors, but for all that they made no headway against the cadets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All now concede, I think, that the mental and moral qualifications of Mr. Shepard to be Mayor would be exceptionally high were it not for his political ambition. Is that a defect in him? We do not wish those in high public places who seek them merely for a livelihood, and are indifferent to honorable fame.

ELECTIONEERING on the east side is an occupation not always fraught with pleasure and success, and men who go in for the work from a purely impersonal motive and only in the desire to see good government, deserve more credit than they often get. There is hard work and little glory in it.

UTICA, Nov. 2. -- The election of the Democratic city ticket on Tuesday is certain. Charles A. Talcott, Democratic candidate for Mayor to succeed Richard W. Sherman, is a leading member of the Oneida County bar, and a few years agro carried Utica for County Judge by about 900 majority. Mr. Talcott cut the big Republican majority in the county down to about 500.

From The Conservative Review. The taste which is catered to by lengthy, detailed, and elaborate illustrated descriptions of murders, suicides, and all sorts of blood-curdling catastrophes is the same in essence (and even more unmitigated in its depravity) as that which reveled in the gladiator and wild-beast contests of the ancient Roman amphitheatres, and which in some countries keeps alive the bullfight in its most hideous forms.

Shepard will have a plurality of 47,233 in New York County, and when Secretary Smith announced this official prediction of the Wigwam he said:

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 2. -- The University of Michigan defeated the Carlisle Indian School football team at Bennett Park this afternoon before 8,000 people, by the score of 22 to 0. Wu Ting-Fang, Chinese Minister to the United States, occupied one of the boxes with former Secretary of War Alger, who, at the close of the game, in response to the demands of the spectators, addressed them, congratulating Michigan on its victory.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 2. -- A captive balloon, in which were seven men and one woman, broke loose from its fastening this afternoon as the rope was being drawn in, and floated away. It was seen by thousands as it soared up to the height of a mile or more, and then drifted southwest toward Santa Clara County.

WHEN a young man named Oscar Parviainen passed through this city a few days ago, he attracted considerable attention, partly because he was a Finn and partly because he was in the middle of a 6,000-mile journey to get a bride. His destination was Decorah, Iowa, for there lives the lady of his choice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, Mr. K. Oakley Baldwin, advocates the rejection of a proposed amendment to Section 18, Article III., of the State Constitution. He quotes the amendment correctly, as follows: "The Legislature shall not pass a private or local bill in any of the following cases: * * * Granting to any person, association, firm, or corporation an exemption from taxation on real or personal property."

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Lloyd Carpenter Griscom, United States Minister to Persia, was married at 1 o'clock this afternoon in St. Margaret's-Church. Westminster, to Miss Elizabeth Duer Bronson, daughter of the late Frederick Bronson of New York, before a fashionable assemblage. Canon Henson performed the ceremony.

From The Fortnightly Review. India is the land of reports. There is a monthly, quarterly, half-yearly, annual plague of them. There is no country, probably, in which so many useless reports are written and so few read. In one province I have heard it said the chief business of the Local Government consists in dunning its officers for statistics and reports, and in compiling from them volumes for the delusion of the supreme Government.
Money on call, 3@3 1/2 per cent. Time money, 4 1/2 per cent. for high-grade loans, 49 3/4@3 per cent. on mixed collateral for all periods.

Edward M. Shepard made his last speeches in the campaign for the Mayoralty in Brooklyn last evening. He went from South Brooklyn to the Clermont Avenue Rink and made three speeches according to schedule and one not on the programme arranged for him by his campaign managers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Commissioner General Powderly of the Immigration Bureau has entered into an agreement with the principal steamship and railroad lines of Canada for the regulation of immigration to the United States through Canada.

George H. Bowly won the championship of the Jersey City Golf Club yesterday for the second time, and he will hold the title for the coming six months. The championship is played for twice a year at medal and match play, and the competitions for the present honor have been in progress nearly a month. In the thirty-six hole final round, Bowly beat B.H. Pelzer by three up and two to play.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you, in the interest of justice, ask Mr. Henry Boland, who criticises in your columns so many of our noblest and best New York women, if he will kindly read the pamphlet which they are causing to be distributed, under the head of "Facts for Fathers and Mothers"?
No Hope for Bald Heads. "IS there a cure for baldness? If there was, do you suppose there would be any bald-headed doctors ?"
To the Edilor of The New York Times: I often enjoy letters from the correspondents of your clean and valuable paper, and hope that some of your readers may be interested in a few words from me.

IT COSTS the City of New York one dollar and eleven and some fractions of a cent for every vote cast at a Mayoralty election. That is the money actually expended by the Bureau of Elections for the Greater New York in rent of booths, places for the Board of Registry to sit, polling places, and the general expenses incidental to the collecting of votes of the greater city.

Another horse has been added to the list of animals who have achieved at least temporary fame by the accomplishment of some marvelous feat in the way of accidents without getting hurt, and without using a barrel for protection, either. The trick which this quadruped did yesterday was worthy of the best tumbler on the variety stage.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Cheers greeted the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York to-day as they passed on their triumphal return from their world tour through the crowded streets of London, intermingled with the shrill cries of the newsboys shouting: "Terrible disaster in South Africa." Beneath the sporadic jubilation on the safe j arrival of the heir apparent there existed a keen undercurrent of grief and anger over the defeat of Col. Benson's column.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would appear from the correspondence columns of your last Sunday's edition that the doctrinal position of the Episcopal Church is very uncertain. This is doubtless due to the fact that even otherwise thoughtful men do not always make a distinction between the Church's teaching and that of some of her otherwise faithful clergy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is about the only newspaper in Manhattan to which one may turn for fair play in the present political contest. May one of its constant readers ask that it set forth truthfully the essential facts as to the relations of the Mayor and the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to the city "budget."

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $30,660,406; balances, $2,715,908. Call money is loaning at from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent., with the latter figure the more general rate. Time money is a trifle firmer. The market for business paper is quiet, with 4 1/2 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent who asks that Mr. Low say something positive respecting the City College forgets that Mr. Low on the 18th of October published a letter in which he says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to call attention in your columns to the contest for Alderman in the Twenty-first District, where Mr. Armitage Mathews (the present Alderman,) is the Republican, Mr. John Stewart the Citizens' Union, and Mr. M.H. Dalberg the Tammany candidate.

The anti-Tammany Fusion mass meeting in Cooper Union last night, at which Seth Low and Justice Jerome spoke, attracted an audience that packed every inch of available space in the hall, and the police were compelled to refuse admittance to hundreds of men and women, who lingered for a time and finally went away disappointed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Princeton scored a hard-fought football victory over Cornell this afternoon by the narrow margin of 2 points, the final score being 8 to 6. Princeton won on a safety allowed by Referee Wrightington, which was vigorously protested by Cornell. It resulted from a trial for a goal from the field by right tackle De Witt.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 2. -- Commencing this year Washington has entered the list of States which will hereafter supply the world's markets with apples. Dozens of carloads of apples are being shipped to Eastern cities from the appleraising districts of Eastern Washington. The crop is no better than that of last year and previous years, but is larger, because of the increased acreage of orchards that have come into bearing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The utterances of Mr. Shepard in the interview from which you quote this morning in your editorial entitled "Moral Issues," are the most illuminating that he has ventured to give to the public since his nomination. They throw a sort of X-ray into at least one corner of his mind, and enable us to see the direction his thoughts are taking since his new political birth.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- The chief incident in the Philadelphia market to-day was the development of renewed heaviness in the asphalt securities, but, as heretofore, the list collectively ignored the weakness, and nearly all the local favorites closed with an improvement. Of the steam roads, Lehigh Valley possessed the strongest pulse, advanceing close to 35, while Cambria Steel, Choctaw, Consolidated Lake Superior, and United Gas Improvement all closed higher.

TO many foreigners, accustomed to national codes and centralized administration. It seems strange enough that the murderer of the President of the United States at Buffalo should net have been tried and punished in a Federal Court. It seems hardly less anomalous to many Americans.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Croker has a little lamb, Its name stood very bright; And everything that Croker asks The lamb replies -- all right.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- Past conditions suggesting a reasonable doubt as to the result of next Tuesday's Gubernatorial election have been neutralized by the activities of Chairman Dick, and the indications are that Gov. Nash will be re-elected by a plurality quite as large as that which he received two years ago when John R. McLean ran against him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Minister Wu-Ting-Fang is at Ann Arbor. It is said at the Chinese Legation that no surprise would be felt if he should be recalled. He has already been here for more than four years, and it is not customary for the Chinese Government to keep a Minister in one place more than three.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Harvard doubled Pennsylvania's tally against Brown's football team to-day when she defeated the Rhode Islanders by the decisive score of 48 to 0. It was a fast, hard game, marked by long runs by the Crimson backs and crushing mass plays on centre and between tackles and ends.

With November the season begins. In a fortnight there will be the Horse Show, followed by the series of debutantes' teas. In three weeks the dancing classes will commence their sessions, and by the end of the month the Winter's gayeties will be in full swing. One season's history is very much like that of another.

Martin Engel and his friends in the Eighth Assembly District were again defeated in the Supreme Court yesterday, when Justice Bischoff granted a writ of mandamus directing the names of David Blaustein for Alderman and Max Franklin for Assembly to be stricken from a ticket known as the Citizens' Union of the Eighth Assembly District.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- Money was easier today and discounts were steady and quiet. On the Stock Exchange the attendance was meagre and was believed to be the smallest of the year, due to the royal procession and the determination of many operators to extend yesterday's holiday over the week end.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whoever wins in this election, we must all admit, Republicans and Democrats alike, that E.M. Shepard as a candidate has shone with a particular lustre. Not only has he always been the gentleman, but he has been the man of charity par excellence.

"Apart altogether from the increase dividend on Pennsylvania and the enormous earnings of the various railroads of the country as reported from day to day," said the President of a leading Western Railroad system yesterday, "a further and very substantial evidence of the remarkable prosperity of the railways of the country has appeared in the last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter issued by the City College Shepard Club on Oct. 26 seems to be an attack on President Low and Columbia more than an argument for Shepard. In it are many assertions that come perilously near to being misstatements, and there is one which is absolutely without foundation and against which this letter is a protest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have in to-day's issue largely quoted the clergy on behalf of the anti-Tammany movement, and have given good and sufficient reasons why they cannot properly be in favor of any other. Let me call attention to certain things that have been the means of changing the opinion of at least one clergyman as to the honesty and sincerity of Mr. Shepard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposed amendment to the Constitution to be voted upon in the approaching election: A careful consideration of the proposed amendment will show that its adoption is not so menacing to philanthropic, charitable, and church interests as a cursory reading would seem to indicate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much newspaper space has been utilized of late, particularly in the Southern press, in condemnation of the act of our President, the Hon. Theodore Roosevelt, in allowing a colored man in the person of one Booker Washington to sit at his (the President's) table.

It was announced yesterday that John T. Meehan of the firm of Dolan Nephew, the Park Row restaurant proprietors, had been appointed a School Commissioner. Nephew Meehan was sworn in to take the place of William T. Emmet, who resigned.

Only within the past fortnight have the subway contractors begun to recover from the effects of the recent steel strike. Not much was said about their difficulties at the time of that labor trouble, for they say they have enough "kicks" anyway, without calling the public's attention to every new cause of delay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may be true, as stated in your special Washington dispatch of the 25th inst., that there has been some talk among the friends of reciprocity about dropping the treaty with the Argentine Republic. But it scarcely seems that such a proposal can come from any well-informed friends of reciprocity.

MR. WILLIAMS had written but six lines of his essay on "Concentration of Thought" when the dog commenced to howl. Williams didn't know what dog, it was that howled. It wasn't easy to specify dogs in the Wiltshire. The Wiltshire sheltered twenty-four families. each of which owned a dog, and none but an expert could differentiate the various canine war cries.
AN interesting collection of totems has just been added to the exhibits of the American Museum of Natural tory.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Autumn theatrical term in London has not been thus far rich in promise or brilliant in performance. Excepting Mr. Pinero's cruel dramatic study of the downfall of a selfish, pampered woman, called "Iris," no new play making the slightest appeal to one's intellect has been produced.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A number of golfers were out on the links of the Merris County Golf Club to-day, but the only match of importance that was finished was the semi-final round for the Captain's Cup, given by W. Allston Flagg. W.D. Vanderpool, the new club champion, beat George J. Little by 2 up, and Alfred Macy won his match by default.

THE advertisement of the sale of Battle Abbey, the church and appendages which mark the spot where fell the "last of the Saxons," and where the sword of the Norman carved out the beginnings of modern English history, has moved many writers to refer incidentally to the traditions and associations connected with this historic foundation.

MINISTER CONGER has transmitted to the State Department at Washington the detailed plan published by the Board of National Administration for the reform of the Chinese Government, a task for which the board was brought into existence. This document is especially interesting because of the odd and painstaking method by which It seeks to bring home to the Chinese mind the objects it has in view.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The more I read your most excellent paper the more I like it. It has become an indispensable part of our household. It does not only print all the news that's fit to print, but it has the couragre of its convictions in that it speaks out in unmistakable tones on all matters of public policy.
From The Cincinnati Commercial Tribune. A goldfish farm in a suburb of Cincinnati is the largest in the United States. From there goldfish are shipped all over the country.

THE other day a crowd of sailors and a few civilians who had assembled in a South Street saloon heard a remarkable talk on the trouble in the Philippines from the standpoint of an American sailor who had just arrived on a ship that had touched at Manila on the way to New York from the Orient.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- "The obvious and sustained friendliness of the United States Government to Cuba, the impending increase of sugar production in Porto Rico, Hawaii, and the Philippines, added to the steady and rapid development of the beet sugar industry throughout a large area of the United States, all point to an inevitable and definite decline in European sugar exports to our country."

Thousands of families with three small rooms for each family; tens of thousands with two small rooms; a hundred thousand with one room. And such rooms -- better call them boxes. Dining room and bedroom, kitchen and scullery, coal house and drawing room, workshop and wash house, all in one.

Herbert H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, last night said that Capt. Goddard lied khowingly when he declared that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was coercing its men to vote against Justice Jerome.

From The Empire Review. Cyrus, King of Persia, possessed a regular riding Dost, stations and men with horses that were always in readiness when required. The speed of his horses was such, according to Herodotus, as nothing mortal surpassed, and varied on the road from Susa to Sardis from 60 to 120 miles a day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me strange that so easy-going a public sentiment exists in regard to Mr. Shepard's candidacy. Perhaps it is because his action so bewildered people that they have been unable to think straight. But now that the first period of astonishment is over, the facts ought to be discerned.

RICHMOND, Nov. 2. -- The campaign in Virginia this year has been in many respects a remarkable one. The election Tuesday is for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, one-half of the Senate, composed of forty members, and members of the House of Delegates. The Democrats will, as usual, win on their general ticket, as well as both branches of the Legislature.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The financial week has developed many features of interest far London, but not many directly concerning American investors. Still, the scramble for gold goes on in Continental centres and prudent New York operators are scarcely indifferent to that.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- Drs. Fowler, Crego, and Putnam, the specialists who were requested by District Attorney Penney to examine into the mental condition of Leon F. Czolgosz, the assassin of the President, have made public their report, in which they say that he was sane.

THE myriads of insects which creep and crawl around in the Summer time, greatly to the discomfort of vacationists at seashore and mountain, disappear in the Autumn of the year when the leaves of the trees begin to take on the brilliant colors which make the glory of our American Autumns.

From The Savannah (Ga.) News. The Florida orange season is now fairly open. The height of the season will not be reached for several weeks, when the oranges will be in their perfection. Up to this time there has been greenness and immaturity in most of the fruit shipped, but henceforth ripe and luscious oranges will find their way into the markets.

A word of caution to those who may have opportunities offered them to make large and immediate profits from investments in systems of wireless telegraphy may not be Wholly outside the province of the conservative engineer sufficiently familiar with the facts of the case to warrant him in expressing an opinion.
The following personal appeal to voters was issued yesterday by Mayoralty Candidate Edward M. Shepard:

Less money, politicians said, was bet at the hotels yesterday than on any Saturday immediately preceding an election for years past. There were many rumors of an immense Tammany Hall fund variously estimated at from $150,000 to $250,000. But if there was any such sum of Shepard money ready for takers the supporters of Mr. Low could not find it.

A FINNISH immigrant had just landed in New York, apparently more generously supplied, with stupidity than money. He had relatives in Paterson, who had promised to meet him at the landing place. They neglected to show up, however, and the Finn; walking dolefully about, was approached by a representative of one of the first-class immigrant homes, who offered to find his friends for him.

THE camera is making deep inroads in the market of the artist whose greatest source of income was at one time the field of illustrating. The average illustrator is looking on the improvements in camera work with consternation. The extras printed by the illustrated weekly papers, after the assassination of President McKinley, made a climax to a condition the average artist knew was coming but which he did not know was so close at hand.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 2. -- The Naval Cadet football team won from Dickinson College this afternoon by a score of 12 to 6. It was not, however, a game to be proud of, for though the navy eleven scored all their points in the first half, Dickinson decidedly outplayed them in the second, and scored a touchdown and a goal, while the Cadets could not reach their opponents goal line.

From The Los Angeles (Cal.) Herald. A.G. Park, formerly of Hanford and now of Los Angeles, has received from the Supreme Court an opinion that is of general interest to attorneys, and that involves a story of two children that reads like a chapter of fiction.

The Aqueduct race track yesterday surpessed itself in the matter of providing good and exciting sport. Aided by a fast and safe track, the six events of the programme made an afternoon of sport that eclipsed all that had preceded it on the Queens County course.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2. -- The Pan-American Exposition ended to-night at midnight, when President John G. Milburn pressed an electric button and the lights in the electric tower grew dim for the last time. A corps of bugles standing in the tower sounded "taps," and one of the grlories of the exposition, the electrical illumination, passed away, and the exposition was ended.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The platform of the recent City Convention which nominated Mr. Shepard for Mayor contains the following clause:

From The Savannah (Ga.) News. Savannah will be without a Mormon elder after to-day. Elder I.W. Clagg of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints will leave for Atlanta, and it is not at all likely that any more elders will appear in Savannah for some time to come.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement of Mr. Shepard that the majority of the clergy heartily indorse his mesalliance with Tammany Hall in this present momentous contest would seem to render it desirable that the ministers should stand up and be counted. I, for one, am unwilling to permit my silence to afford any ground for a misunderstanding as to my position.

Four new plays will be presented this week at the different theatres. Clyde Fitch's "The Way of the World," with Elsie De Wolfe as the principal player, will be performed for the first time to-morrow night at the Victoria Theatre, and the Broadway Theatre will furnish a production of the Drury Lane extravaganza.

SILAS LARRABEE received yesterday a Boston paper containing United States Senator Tillman's statesmanlike remarks about the dinner Booker T. Washington ate at the President's table. A blue ring was drawn about this paragraph:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prince Chun of China recently paid a visit of expiation to the Emperor of Germany. The German Ambassador had been assassinated at Peking and the Chinese Government sent a Prince of the blood to disavow any complicity with the assassins. The Chinese Prince was treated, as if he belonged to civilisation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is plain from a common sense view of our municipal campaign that Mr. Shepard will be defeated along with the entire Tammany ticket because be makes his canvass not as a citizen but as a Democrat in the face of the fixed and fast growing belief of the people that New York can not be honestly and properly governed by party.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unfortunately "T.L.N." does not (of course, he could not,) state the kind of baldness he has, whether alopecia areata, atrophiante en clarieres, congenita, fere totalis, or pityrodes. However, I beg to inform him that the following are all efficient remedies, and none will hurt him:

Andrew Carnegie arrived in New York or the American Line steamship St. Louis yesterday afternoon, off the Quarantine Station a score of reporters boarded the vessel. Mr. Carnegie was in the dining saloon making his declaration to a Deputy Surveyor when they greeted him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your reply to the question of J.A.D. in to-day's issue of your paper, stating that a National guardsman who became a United States volunteer during the late war with Spain, but who failed to re-enlist in the guard after his discharge from the volunteers, had no legal military standing whatever, gives rise to serious possibilities.

That lawyers are "timid" when it is a question of good or bad Judges, is a familiar saying. They are no more timid, in the face of Tammany oppression, than the common business man. But that they are expected, and that the common business man is not expected, to brave injury to their business in the public cause is a compliment to their profession.

By The Associated Press. LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The copyrighting of "Monsieur Beaucaire" in England, which threatened to develop into a dramatic fight, has resolved itself into a comic chapter of cross-purposes and errors. The rival claimants for the copyright met for the first time this week and discovered, to their mutual surprise, that they were both actuated by the same motive and acting practically for the same parties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The greatest service rendered by King Alfred to the English or, rather, to the British people and to mankind was the work he did in building up a strong, centralized, national government out of a number of petty kingdoms, each too small and weak in itself to make either a strong defense against foreign invasion, or to accomplish much in the development of a higher civilization.

It is admitted that Justice JEROME has made a mistake in the gallant, picturesque, and stirring canvass he has made for the District Attorneyship of this county. He has admitted it himself. It is always a mistake to charge publicly what you cannot publicly substantiate.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Do the people of New York understand what the Health Board and the New York Central propose to do with Fourth Avenue?

Alone in her richly appointed home Mrs. Lillian Gilbert, long a sufferer from Bright's disease killed herself by inhaling gas some time yesterday afternoon. She lived with her mother, Mrs. Polly Hopkins, in the house 999 Mott Avenue.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- The unique campaign that closed in Maryland to-night was conducted strictly on the educational plan -- the teaching of illiterates how to mark the worst mixed-up ballot that the voters in this State have ever tackled. In some of the counties, the ballots are nearly two feet long, and the name of each candidate voted for must be marked separately by the voter.

There was little life to yesterday's market and practically no significance in the dealings until the last fifteen minutes, when substantial strength developed under the lead of Union Pacific, which was bought by interests identified with the property. Elsewhere, the Vanderbilt group excepted, professionals were almost wholly in control, and they were apparently not disposed to do much one way or the other.

An extraordinary rise -- approximating two-score points -- has been suddenly scored in the market quotation of Michigan Central stock; and the price has reached a figure where purchases of it, if made for investment purposes, yield less than 3 per cent, on the present dividend basis.

The campaigns and battles of the civil war were on a scale of surpassing magnitude. There were more than a score of single battles, sometimes extending over several days, in each of which the losses in killed and wounded on the Federal side were greater than the aggregate of all our losses in all our other wars combined.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The publication in Paris this week of three letters written by Gen. Voyron, who commanded the French troops in China, to Field Marshal Count von Waldersee, showing among other things that the relations between the French General and the Field Marshal were strained during the entire period of the foreign occupation, caused but little excitement here.

PARIS, Nov. 2. -- The dispatch of Admiral Caillard's squadron from Toulon to Turkish waters has already had its effect. The French Foreign Office this morning received a telegram from M. Bapst, Councillor of the French Legation at Constantinople, announcing that the Sultan yesterday sent him a message accepting all the French claims, including the Lorando claim.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Play for the Golf Committee Cup was continued this afternoon on the links of the Hillside Golf Club. Dr. Endicott carried off the honors. The players and scores are:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Human life is held altogether too cheap and it seems that no number of horrible happenings such as the recent holocaust in Philadelphia will make any impression upon the property class, whose only thought is interest and profit. This immeasurable greed in this so-called civilization is simply hellish.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The Government of Nicaragua has terminated the treaty under which the United States was empowered to construct an interoceanic canal across the territory of Nicaragua. This action has been conveyed to the State Department by the Nicaraguan Minister for Foreign Affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The exact terms in which Gen. Buller. who continues to monopolize conversation in England, advised Gen. White to surrender Ladysmith, are not yet published, nor are they likely to be published in the near future. The National Review's version of the message, while correct in substance, is incorrect textually.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of your editorial this morning on "The South and Mr. Roosevelt," I would suggest that the best possible cure for such narrow, sectional prejudice as has been manifested in connection with the Booker T. Washington episode would be to distribute widely, as a tract, with a view to the enlightenment of Mr. Roosevelt's critics, the autobiography of Booker T. Washington, entitled "Up from Slavery."

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the purpose of defining my position as one of those Independent Democrats whose motives are aspersed and whose ideals are ridiculed because we support Mr. Shepard in the present campaign, I venture once again to trespass upon the hospitality of THE TIMES.

The Financier hag compiled figures showing that for the fiscal year ended June 30 the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company charged against earnings $1,157,593 for the payment of damage claims, and for the preceding year $800,000 for the same purpose. From this it appears that in two years the liquidation of damage verdicts and the expenses incident thereto have absorbed an amount about equal to a dividend of 4 per cent. upon the company's capital.

WINSTED, Conn., Nov. 3. -- Judge William Travers Jerome, whose Summer home is at Lakeville, this county, has accepted an invitation to be the guest of honor at the annual banquet of the Litchfield County Bar Association, to be held here, Nov. 22. He is down for a speech, but the subject is not known.

Daniel Yung, a German tailor, fifty years old, who lived in a lodging house at 108 Debevoise Street, Brooklyn, was murdered early yesterday morning by John Vath, while two other lodgers -- Herman Liebermann, fifty-six years old, and Charles Liebacher, fifty-two years old -- were injured. Vath used a baseball bat. Yung's head was crushed to pulp.

MANILA, Nov. 3 -- There was a public discussion before the Philippine Commission to-day of the draft of the act against treason and sedition. Many prominent Filipinos were present. Vice Gov. Wright explained the object of the bill, saying that the Spanish code was unsatisfactory.

At the annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union on Nov. 18 many important topics will be discussed, among them some which have an international bearing. At the recent Canadian meeting Dr. George McK. Hall of the Young Men's Christian Association of Buffalo competed in and won the pole vaulting contest.

The "big four" in the college football world had a hard time of it Saturday. To begin with. Pennsylvania was beaten in rather handy fashion by Columbia, while the best that Yale could do against West Point was to play a tie game. Princeton too, had her hands full, for Cornell was not considered as strong as she proved to be by the Orange and Black.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- The Boerse last week showed the same pessimistic symptoms displayed during several weeks previous. "It is nearly a lifeless body," says the Vossische Zeitung, "and no longer able to respond to outside influences." Business has grown so stagnant that many first-class shares could not be quoted at the first make-up list on some days.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 3 -- After being quiet for two months, the strikers from the Southern Railroad machine shops, whose fight was lost long ago, formed a lynching party this morning and committed murder. William Seaver and Walter Binder, young machinists, who were brought down here by the Southern from Newton, Mass., were living about a mile from the shops, and felt perfectly secure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial commenting on the speech of Mr. Gage in a recent edition of THE TIMES. I would like to ask, however, if we are to understand that all the young men who do not succeed in "crowding themselves to the top" and landing $25,000 positions are incapable of filling such positions -- have not the ability to earn that amount?

More than three thousand persons in Carnegie Hall shouted themselves hoarse last night over the principles of the Irish Nationalist cause as presented by John E. Redmond. M.P.; Patrick McHugh, and Thomas O'Donnell, the envoys of the Irish United League to the United States. Every one who was there paid for his admission, and several hundreds unable to obtain tickets were turned away.

From nearly every church in the city, regardless of creed, an announcement was read yesterday regarding the proposed amendment to the Constitution of the State, which contemplates that hereafter churches and benevolent institutions shall be taxed. It is one of the questions which the voters on Tuesday next will have to pass upon.

The Central Federated Union had another stormy meeting yesterday, arising chiefly out of personal grievances of the delegates and the excitement which always marks the close of an election campaign. The first part of the meeting was taken up with reports pf committees which had waited upon city officials with various labor complaints.

Tammany Hall, the headquarters of Edward M. Shepard at the Hoffman House, and the Tammany County Headquarters at the Rossmore Hotel, were practically deserted yesterday. The day was not an Idle one, however, for Tammany. At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the election district captains of each Assembly district met their district leaders and received final instructions as to how to get out every Democratic vote to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- There was an intensely dramatic scene in Holy Name Cathedral to-day, when, in the presence of fully 1,000 parishioners. Jeremiah J. Crowley, the excommunicated Roman Catholic priest, was humiliated publicly by order of the authorities of the church.
Senator T.C. Platt, when asked last night for an expression of opinion on the outlook of the campaign, said:

It is certainly a most extraordinary personal appeal that Mr. SHEPARD makes on the eve of the election, and it is not without a touch of pathos. Practically it is an appeal to his former associates in the Democratic Party to support him in spite of the source of his nomination, and because he thinks that this is the only way in which the organization behind him can be reduced to relative harmlessness.

The Citizens' Union yesterday gave out a letter which was sent by Joseph L. Hance to Edward M. Shepard. Mr. Hance was secretary to Samuel J. Tilden when Mr. Tilden was Governor of New York. He remained in close intimacy with Mr. Tilden until his death. He was Deputy State Treasurer during Gov. Robinson's administration, and United States Consul at Cardenas, Cuba, until the beginning of the war with Spain.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Albert Champion, the French motor cyclist, who was injured in an accident to his motor cycle near Mount Vernon last week, had sufficiently recovered from his injuries to give a ten-mile exhibition at the Vailsburg track to-day, in the course of which he broke previous records for everv mile except the first.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After close perusal of THE TIMES'S editorials, "The Moral Issues," "Of Interest to Democrats," and Abram S. Hewitt's letter, I beg to say that, as an interested Democrat, I wish enough others may take advantage of the information these articles contain and vote the Greater Democracy ticket.

To-morrow's election was the theme of sermons yesterday in many churches that embraced practically every denomination. All those addresses of which reports were obtained denounced Tammany Hall, and appealed for support for the Fusion ticket. Some of the ministers referred to Edward M. Shepard, and deplored his acceptance of the Mayoralty nomination at the hands of Tammany.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It always grieves me somewhat to see a conservative and thoughtful person or newspaper advocate legislation to prohibit a thing which is no crime, on the principle that what sometimes furnishes material for a crime is a good thing to wipe out, innocent though it be of itself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To hear all this prating about Shepard's "character," one would think he had a monopoly of the article. What about his ambition and his method of gratifying it? He knows that there is no leading Democrat in New York to-day in line for the Presidency except David B. Hill.

Alarmed by reports received from district leaders, the Democratic campaign managers in Brooklyn yesterday made hasty arrangements to continue to-day the work which it had been planned should wind up with the big meeting held, at the Clermont Avenue Rink last Saturday night. The reports which caused alarm to the campaign managers came from the Eastern District.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Miss Neva M. Vail, to whom Mr. Neville is engaged to be married, received a message this afternoon at her home in the Hotel Windermere announcing his safe arrival in New York on the Umbria. The message contained nothing concerning the difficulty into which he had fallen, and Miss Vail was surprised to-night when informed of his arrest.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 3. -- Wu Ting-Fans, Minister from China to the United States, witnessed his first football game yesterday. It was the clash between the elevens of the University of Michigan and the Carlisle Indian School, at the American League baseball park.
PARIS, Nov. 4 -- According to dispatches from Toulon, all the officers and men of the garrison now on leave of absence have been ordered to rejoin their respective commands immediately.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Dr. Austin Scott, President of Rutgers College, this evening made a statement relative to the granting of a leave of absence to Dr. Jacob Cooper, Vice President of the college. He says that the leave was granted as a mark of esteem and to show the appreciation of the college for the very valuable services which have been rendered to it by Dr. Cooper as an officer and instructor.
Tammany Hall mass meetings were held in various theatres of the city last night.

BATH, N.Y., Nov 3. -- Frank Campbell, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, who has been conducting the Democratic Aaaembly campaign, with headquarters located here, said to-night that all indications point to large Democratic gains in the next Assembly, and that the Democratic Party is in better shape in the country than it has been in years.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 -- The nine occupants of the captive balloon which escaped from this city yesterday afternoon returned safely to San Francisco to-day, having been rescued after being In the air two hours.

MANCHESTER, Nov. 3 -- Although last week's market was a shade firmer, the turnover was disappointing. There was a little increase in transactions at the end of the week, although the continued decline in cotton and the heavy movement generally influenced buyers to delay operations.

Buffalo has had her days of glory and her day of mourning. She has been spoken of wherever the news of the Pan-American has penetrated and her civic pride has been flattered and strengthened, not, indeed, without cost to her public-spirited citizens, on whom have fallen the burden of the festival and the losses financial that seem inseparable from such enterprises.

With a mob of a thousand persons surrounding him in front of the Marlborough Hotel, Broadway and Thirty-seventh Street, several hundred of whom were attempting to wrest a prisoner from him, Policeman Quinn of the West Thirtieth Street Station last night drew his revolver and threatened to shoot.

HAVANA, Nov. 3 -- Mgr. Dona to Sbarretti, whom the Pope has appointed Apostolic Delegate Extraordinary to the Philippines, has issued a farewell pastoral letter to the Diocese of Havana, in the course of which he says:

In Australia, as in this country, the first difficulty that the Federal Government has been called on to deal with after its organization is that of revenue, and as the Australian Government is obliged under the Federal Constitution to raise in part the revenues of the separate States, the difficulty is somewhat greater than it was with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The annual report of Second Assistant Postmaster General William S. Shallenberger, made public to-day, urges regular, direct fast mall service between the Pacific Coast and the Orient, the re-establishment of pneumatic tube service generally, and the closer separation of city mail by postal clerks on railway trains, rather than by clerks of the mailing division after its arrival in the general office.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- A fog such as the United Kingdom had not experienced for years enveloped London and half the country yesterday, blockading shipping, deranging railways, and throwing business in London, Birmingham, and other provincial cities into confusion.

In the outside market yesterday prices showed more strength than they have at any time within a week. With the exception of the Can stocks nearly all the active issues showed advances, and the number of stocks to which some attention was given was much larger than at the close of last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plain people are tired of being told how respectable Edward M. Shepard is. His past is before them; his speeches echo in their ears and declare what his future will be. They are capable of judging him for themselves. His persistent iteration of his own virtue and his clamoring for the broom of Hercules and a chance at Tammany refuse will not save him.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 4 -- In the United States Court to-day answers and demurrers were filed by the defendants in the case of the United States versus Oberlin M. Carter and others. This is the case in which the Government has proceeded to hold up certain securities and other property held in the name of Carter or those closely associated with him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4 -- State officers and members of the Legislature will be elected in Ohio to-morrow. There is perhaps greater interest in the result of the legislative contests than in the Gubernatorial election, from the fact that the Legislature to be chosen to-morrow will elect a successor to United States Senator Joseph B. Foraker.

At all elevated railroad stations and Brooklyn ferry docks last evening men were stationed distributing Tammany circulars. The circular most extensively distributed was headed "Thou Shalt Not Bear False Witness."

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- According to the Athens correspondent of the Journal, a French dispatch boat arrived yesterday (Monday) at Syra, (Hermoupolis.) capital of the Island of Syra, to get a number of dispatches that were waiting at the telegraph office. In the Chamber of Deputies yesterday Marcel Sembat (Radical Socialist) interpellated the Government on the Franco-Turkish dispute.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The committee of the Aero Club by a vote of 12 to 9 yesterday proclaimed M. Santos-Dumont, the Brazilian aeronaut, the winner of the prize of 100,000f. offered by M. Deutsch for a dirigible balloon.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times, after reviewing and commenting upon Great Britain's policy toward Germany, favors a direct agreement between Great Britain and Russia in regard to certain international matters.

The Tuskegee News is the only paper published by the white people in the town of Tuskegee and in Macon County. Ala., where the Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute is located, and of which Booker T. Washington is Principal. This is the first time that this paper has referred to the White House dinner which has created so much discussion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Schley Court of Inquiry reached the argument stage at the beginning of the afternoon session to-day. The morning was devoted to listening to Admiral Schley and Capt. Sigsbee in making corrections of their testimony, which had been given previously, and the introduction by Judge Advocate Lemly of numerous documents bearing upon different phases of the inquiry.

-- Our recent comment on the curious fact that the loser of the cup races secured much more of the glory which takes the form of popular attention than did the men whose boat defeated his has moved The St. Paul Pioneer Press to attempt an explanation of what we complalningly called "the apotheosis of failure."

Miss Helen Miller Gould was yesterday elected President of the Woman's Advisory Board of New York University to succeed Mrs. Henry Draper, who had been President for several years. Miss Gould has consented to accept the position. She has been Vice President for a considerable period. Mrs. Edward C. Bodman was chosen Vice President and Mrs. Eugene Smith Secretary of the woman's organization.

PORT HURON, Mich., Nov. 4 -- Fire tonight destroyed two large adjoining grain elevators owned by the Botsford Elevator Company here, entailing a loss of $300,000. There were 171,000 bushels of wheat, 90,000 bushels of corn, and 14,000 bushels of oats in the buildings, and the grain was all destroyed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Erie Train No. 17 pulled into Rochester to-night with a new engineer in the cab and with Alexander Thompson, the regrular driver, unconscious on a cot in the baggage car. For miles the train, loaded with passengers, had sped with no slacking speed and with no guiding hand at the throttle.

Election day is a general holiday with the fashionable sot in New York. The men who vote in town do so early and then go out to the country. Others vote from their respective boroughs in the suburbs. The programme to-day is quite attractive. The Meadow Brook Club will have a hunt and breakfast at William Hazard's, at Far Rockaway, and the National Beagle Association has its, trials at the farm of William C. Whitney.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- After the performance at Her Majesty's Theatre last night it is easy to guess why John Drew preferred not to accept Clyde Fitch's play called "The Last of the Dandies, "originally designed for him, and why Charles Frohman hesitated to give the piece an early production in New York.
VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- A singular tragedy has taken place in connection with a financial collapse in Western Hungary.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt arrived in this city soon after 6 o'clock last evening on the Pennsylvania Road. The President was bound for Oyster Bay to cast his vote. The party arrived late, an accident on the Philadelphia. Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad having delayed the train on which he left Washington at 1 o'clock in the afternoon.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's report of yesterday's pulpit you say:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The certificate of incorporation of "The Robins' Nest" was filed to-day in the County Clerk's office. It was organized for the purpose of providing a temporary home in the country for children between the ages of two and twelve years, from New York, who need fresh air and good food.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- "Maid Marian," the latest effort of Reginald De Koven and Harry B Smith, had its first production at the Chestnut Street Opera House to-night, the presentation being made by the Bostonians. The audience was large, and the reception accorded the opera placed the seal of success upon the work."

BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Honey at the Clearing House was marked up to-day to 3 per cent., and several loans were made at that figure, though most of the loans were placed at 2 1/2, per cent. New York funds sold at 5 and 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $28,695,183; balances, $2,483,488.

The interest and dividend payments scheduled for November at banks and trust companies acting as transfer offices of the large corporations, represent the considerable amount of $60,217,000. This is roughly made up as follows: Government interest payments, $2,500,000; railroad dividends, $13,500,000; interest on railroad bonds, $17,390,000; industrial and miscellaneous dividends, $17,000,000; other classifications, $10,000,000, more or less.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 4 -- It has been announced that the control of the Detroit Baseball Club has passed from Messrs. Burns and Stallings to S.F. Angus, a local capitalist. The Peninsular Savings Bank has accepted a check for $13,60O for the stock that institution held as collateral for a loan made Burns Stallings early in the past season.

It is likely that Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE will accomplish most for the education of the people through his latest gift -- if it is ever safe in his case to speak of a latest gift, lest he may have made another overnight -- to be specific, then, his gift of eight millions to Pittsburg for a Polytechnic, with twenty-five millions added as an endowment.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leader of last Saturday contains statements and questions which really are, as you affirm, "of interest to Democrats."

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Money was in increased demand to-day in connection, with the consols settlement and the payment of u1,000,000 of London County Council bills. The consols installment due Nov. 7 will diminish the supply. It is anticipated that the bank may find it necessary to borrow soon, in order to further reduce the supply. Discounts were steadier.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- The Times states that it has reason to believe that Sir William H. White, Director of Naval Construction, who may be said to have created the British fleet as it exists today, has decided to resign, owing to his failing health and the long-continued strain of official responsibility.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Frank B. Richards of New York, the newspaper correspondent, who was excluded from the witness stand at the Schley court to-day, made the following statement to-night:

Edward M. Shepard closed his campaign last night with a speech at Cooper Hall, East Brooklyn. Immediately upon the close of the meeting he was driven to his home in Congress Street, Brooklyn, reaching there at a little before 11 o'clock. As he bade Controller Coler and Sheriff Walton, who accompanied him, good-night, he appeared to be in excellent spirits and was to all appearances confident of victory at the polls to-day.

HORSE CAVE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- A library of 500 selected volumes and valued at 51,000 was presented to the Horse Cave Graded School to-day by Miss Helen Miller Gould. A committee was appointed to draft resolution of gratitude to Miss Gould for the gift.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 -- Fire in the business centre of Jennlngs, La., destroyed a score of buildings this morning.

As a result of Saturday's games most of the players on the college football elevens were stiff and sore yesterday. Despite the hard game against West Point, Yale had a fast day's work, punting taking up a considerable part of the practice. A shift, too, was made in the eleven, Capt. Gould himself going in as full back on the Varsity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- To-morrow being an off day caused a large amount of stock to change hands on the Stock Exchange to-day. The continued decline of American Asphalt 5s and National Asphalt 5s was the feature of the day. The bonds of the former company made a new low record -- 47 1/2.
Another large American manufacturing concern is seeking a foothold in this country, and will within a few months establish a branch plant here.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 4 -- At this morning's session of the Pan-American Congress a note was read from the Spanish Minister, Marquis de Prat, conveying the thanks of the Chamber of Deputies of Madrid, for the friendly sentiments of the conference toward Spain, as wired by Gen. Reyes, delegate of Colombia, and expressed at the municipal banquet.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The active campaign urged by certain ecclesiastical bodies and the representatives of schools and charities against the amendment proposed to Section 18 of Article III. of the Constitution of the State is rather discouraging to those who have been in the habit of looking to persons active in such institutions for intelligent and unselfish action in public affairs.
Richard Croker at midnight at the Democratic Club declared that he was confident of the success of the Democratic city and county tickets. He said:
Vote Early ! The hours are from 6 A.M. to 5 P.M.

Several more sales of high-priced automobiles were reported yesterday at the Automobile Show, which is now in progress in Madison Square Garden. William L. Stow purchased a four-cylinder gasoline machine similar to the six-cylinder one purchased on Saturday by Clifford V. Brokaw for $8,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- It appears to-night that the special feature of the election in Louisville to-morrow, when a Mayor and full city and county legislative tickets will be voted for will be the attempt of the Republicans to challenge Democratic voters whom they suspect of being illegally registered.

Betting in Wall Street yesterday was heavy both on the Stock Exchange and on the "curb." It was estimated that more than $300,000 was wagered on the Mayoralty contest during the day. At the majority of the principal hotels at night, however, little betting was done, few backers of Shepard being in evidence.

Men ordinarily clear-headed sometimes get confused in the voting booth, and in attempting to vote with intelligence and discrimination invalidate their ballots by forbidden marking, and so fail to vote at all.

When James Walsbe, a bank clerk who has a furnished room at 155 West Fifteenth Street, started for home last night after attending a political meeting, he went into No. 157, the house adjoining, by mistake. He did not notice that he was in the wrong house, and wending his way up stairs to the top floor, he opened the door of a room which he thought was his, and entered.

To-day there will be submitted to each voter for his approval or disapproval an amendment to the eighteenth section of the third article of the Constitution of the State. If adopted, the section will read as follows: "The Legislature shall not pass a private or local bill * * * granting to any person, association, firm, or corporation an exemption from taxation on real or personal property.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 4 -- A local paper will say to-morrow: "Local railway and financial circles were stirred yesterday by an announcement coming from an official and thoroughly reliable source, that at last the air of Wall Street and the Western traffic world was to be clarified by a settlement of the differences between the Burlington, Great Northern, Northern Pacific, and Union Pacific Companies.

Gen. Russell A. Alger's reply to Richard Harding Davis in their controversy over the courage of the correspondents who accompanied the American forces in the Santiago campaign, started by a paragraph in Gen. Alger's book, is made public by Harper Brothers, the publishers. Gen. Alger denies that he made any imputation of cowardice against Mr. Davis.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 4 -- The death of Monsignor Murphy, one of the most prominent Roman Catholic clergymen in Lower Canada, and rector of St. Mary's Cathedral in this city, occurred to-day. He was a native of Cork, reland, and was fifty-eight years of age. He was ordained in 1867, received the degree of D.D. in 1892, and was appointed Pronotary about three years ago.

ROSLYN, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The annual trials of the National Beagle Club of America were begun to-day on the estate of William C. Whitney at Wheatley Hills, near Roslyn, and will be continued daily this week until concluded. The entry list is the largest in the history of the club, and unusual interest in the trials is being manifested.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 -- On the eve of election both parties claim to have the better of the situation. A State Controller and a Clerk of the Court of Appeals are the only State officers to be chosen, and most interest attaches to the election of a Legislature, which will choose a United States Senator to succeed George L. Wellington.

Negotiations for the purchase of 41 and 43 Wall Street, running through to 45 and 47 Exchange Place, by Charles W. Morse and his associates from W.K. Aston, have been closed. The Wall Street end of the plot, now covered by a nine-story building, measures 30.6 by 124.11 by 40.1 by 116.9, while the Exchange Place parcel consists of old five-story structures on a plot 50.2 by 96.2 by 49.4 by 93.6.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Consul Benjamin H. Ridgely, United States Consul at Malaga, Spain, has just made a report on the exportation of Malaga raisins to this country. He says:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4 --The market today was very dull except at one or two points, and the trend was undecided. The only real point of strength was the Seaboard group. Both stocks and bonds were bought more freely on the September statement of earnings, the common gaining the preferred 3/8, the 4 per cent, bonds 1 1/8, and the ten-year 5s 1/8.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The State Department has been informed by the Legation at Constantinople that the Turkish Government has issued an exequatur to Dr. Thomas Herbert Norton, United States Consul at Harput, Turkey, who was appointed to that post in June, 1900. Dr. Norton has been without the authority of the Porte to perform his functions as United States Consul at Harput, for nearly a year and a half.

Columbia's annual Fall regatta, postponed from Friday, will be held this afternoon from the university boathouse, at One Hundred and Fifteenth Street and the Hudson River. The races will be for single shells, fours, and eights, in which the following entries have been announced:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The Republicans carried this State to-day, electing Franklin Murphy Governor by at least 8,000 over James M. Seymour, his Democratic opponent. Murphy's majority may go several thousand higher, and his friends are claiming from 10,000 to 13,500.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent, "Alpha," in to-day's TIMES, commends your recent editorial on "Numbers and the Army Canteen." I should like to ask you and him a few questions.
CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- New York exchange to-day was at 10 cents discount. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent.

Seth Low as Mayor will have a salary of $15,000. He will, in the first place, have the privilege of appointing such clerks and assistants in the Mayor's office as he may choose. The first of the appointments in his disposition is that of a private secretary at a salary of $5,000.

Society did its duty yesterday. The men voted early and went to the country. Others remained in town, expectant of the result. There were anxious crowds around the tickers in the clubs during the entire evening. At the Union, the Metropolitan, the Calumet, the Knickerbocker, the University, and the other Fifth Avenue clubs Election Day is always an occasion on which many of the members who only come around once or twice a year meet.

OYSTER BAY, Nov. 5. -- President Roosevelt cast his ballot at 10 o'clock to-day, and it took him just one minute to do it. His special train arrived here from New York at a few minutes before 10, and the President drove immediately to the polling place of the Fifth District, in Fisher's Hall. He voted Ballot No. 125.

The voting machine, which was used for the first time in Brooklyn, in the Eighteenth Election District of the First Assembly District yesterday, proved a pronounced success in one respect at least -- in the promptness with which it made known the total vote cast in the district. The entire result of the voting was known two minutes after the polls closed at 5 o'clock.
