Daniel Chauncey won the championship of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club, near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday, by defeating in the final thirty-six hole round Alfred L. Norris by 8 up and 7 to play. Norris was the title holder at the time, but he was badly off his game, while Chauncey never played better golf in his life.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- In an exceptionally interesting contest the Lafayette College football team lost its second game of the season here to-day at the Philadelphia Ball Park, being defeated by the Philadelphia Professionals by the score of 23 to 0.

Elections yesterday in the States in which tickets were in the field resulted as follows: PENNSYLVANIA. -- Indications are that the Republicans have carried the State, but by a greatly reduced plurality. Returns came slowly, but at midnight the Fusion leaders in Philadelphia admitted that their ticket both in the State and county had been beaten.

Conrad Bahnmiller, alias "Bigfoot Jack, the Coal Miner," a former private in the Eighth United States Infantry, is the latest military prisoner to make his escape from Castle Williams, the military prison on Governors Island. He got away Sunday night. Like "Matchhead" Henderson, the dusky prisoner who escaped in female attire two weeks ago, "Bigfoot Jack" also managed to procure a civilian outfit.

The following tables show the result of the election in this city, the figures being as complete as possible at 2 A.M. to-day. The vote for Mayor is shown with 135 election districts missing, and with these out the plurality for Mr. Low is 29,656.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to "J.L.N.," who wants a remedy for baldness, please find my experience. There is no remedy for baldness, but there is, I believe, a preventive. The stiff bristles of a brush are the cause of baldness, where it is not caused by disease. At the root of every hair there is a little cell or blood vessel which nourishes it.

Columbia defeated Georgetown yesterday in a spirited game of football on the Polo Grounds by a score of 18 to 0. Berrien made the first touch-down in the first half, while Weekes carried the ball over the goal line twice in the second half, Morley kicking all three goals.

On the 1st of January next Mr. VAN WYCK will pass from the Mayor's office to such obscurity as his character deserves, or permits, and his place will be taken by Mr. Low. An able and upright man, of wide experience and trained judgment, who has already rendered distinguished service in positions of great importance and difficulty, will assume powers hitherto unprecedented in the organization of any great American city.
By The Associated Press. PARIS, Nov. 6. -- The following dispatch has been received from Admiral Caillard:

To the Editor of The New York times: Some few weeks ago I had occasion to rise in my seat and give utterance to a protest at what I termed your neglect in allowing Deacon Larrabee to absent himself from our Sunday meeting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Mr. Hanna resumed his argument when the Schley court of inquiry convened at 11 o'clock this morning. He began where he had left off yesterday. As on yesterday he spoke in calm and dispassionate tones, and generally contented himself with outlining his conception of the purport of the testimony.

Richard Croker told a friend last evening at the Democratic Club that he had gone through his last campaign as the leader of Tammany Hall. The robes of the leadership will fall on the shoulders of John F. Carroll, according to an amicable arrangement said to have been made at a conference between Senator Timothy D. Sullivan and Mr. Croker.
"I've nothing to say whatever." This was the only answer Deputy Commissioner Devery would give to the many questions put to him last night, after the returns began to show the election of Mr. Low.

The Fusion forces carried the city yesterday, as well as electing the Presidents of the Boroughs of Manhattan, Richmond, and Brooklyn, the District Attorney of New York County, four Justices of the Supreme Court, and a Judge of the City Court.

The field trials of the National Beagle Club of America were continued on the estate of William C. Whitney, at Wheatley Hills, L.I., yesterday. The first class, for dogs over 13 and under 15 inches, which was begun on Monday, was completed, and a beginning was made in the second class, for bitches of the same height, which will be continued this morning.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A new and astonishing fact in connection with the Schley inquiry was brought out to-day by Capt. Parker in his summing up for the applicant. It was so surprising that both Admiral Schley and Mr. Rayner thought Parker must be mistaken, and attempted to stop and correct him.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Early unofficial figures based upon scattering returns indicate the re-election of Gov. Nash by a plurality much larger than that of two years ago, when he received 49,023 more votes than John R. McLean. There are 3,234 precincts in the State, and in order to win the Democrats would have to gain about sixteen to a precinct.

Practice was continued by all of the "big four" football teams yesterday, but the poor showing that has been made by the Pennsylvanians has almost eliminated the term "big" from their name. Although the practice of the Quakers was secret yesterday, it was discouraging, and no ray of hope for a lively contest with Harvard appeared.

Seth Low received the returns of the election last night at his house, 30 East Sixty-fourth Street, where they were sent over a private wire from Police Headquarters. At 10:30, when assured of the result, he issued the following statement:

The fact that M. SANTOS-DUMONT has been declared entitled to the 100,000f. prize offered by M. DEUTSCH to any one who would circumnavigate the Eiffel Tower under certain conditions will give pleasure to a great many people who have no interest in the matter, one way on the other.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 5. -- There seems to be no doubt that the Republican plurality in this State will be at least 85,000. What makes the Republican victory the greater is the fact that there is a conslderable decrease in the vote from that of 1899, when Gov. Shaw received a plurality of 56,000, a plurality greater than had been received by any Governor that preceded him.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- William Goss, caretaker on the Lodge estate at Galloupe's Point, Swamscott, was gored by a bull last evening and seriously injured. Had it not been for the assistance of another workman. Goss probably would have been killed. The bull was shot.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 5. -- Many of Newport's Summer residents are enrolled as voters here, and always on hand to cast their ballots in the municipal and State elections. To-day, for the first time, both elections occurred on the same day, and a good number appeared at the polls to vote. Ex-Cpmmodore Elbridge T. Gerry and his two sons.

The various Police Magistrates were largely employed yesterday in disposing of cases involving alleged illegal registration or assaults growing out of disputes among partisans at the polls, and large crowds were drawn to the police courts to experience whatever excitement could be gotten out of the hearing of the cases.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial to-day, "The Health Department," in which you express surprise that the bill of indictment against Tammany Hall does not include sanitary misgovernment, prompts me to observe that public opinion should arraign it for its gross violation of the mandates of the Berlin Lepra Conference.

-- That the inhabitants of New Jersey are in some mysterious way unlike the rest of the country's population is a fact which was noticed long ago and has been the occasion of innumerable comments, mostly of a derisive nature; but nobody, so far as we remember, has ever made a serious effort to ascertain the cause of the queerness observed by all.

Negligees are quite short this year, reaching only a little below the waist many of them. One garment shows something new in the way of trimming. This is in ribbonedged lace. A narrow edge of Valenciennes lace is used to trim bands of heavier lace, to finish the garment down the front and around the sleeves, and a pretty effect is given to it by stitching on the under side a narrow baby ribbon.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Despite the cheerless weather, with the strong gusts of wind that blew across the links of the Morris County Golf Club to-day, there was an excellent turnout of members to take part in the mixed foursome handicap arranged by the Handicap Committee for special election day cups.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The transport McClellan has arrived at Colombo on her way from Manila to New York with the Engineer Battalion.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 5. -- Returns are slow in coming in. The vote was light over the State, only Circuit Judges being elected. At midnight the indications, are that the Republicans elected all eight Judges, but the Democrats claim the election of Bennett in the Third and MeGee in the Seventh District, but returns from these districts are too meagre to base definite estimates upon.

New York has been delivered, from its shame and bondage by the intelligence and the moral sense of its voting population. Had the intelligence of the voters been less keen they would have been hoodwinked by CROKER'S audacious and desperately skillful trick of nominating SHEPARD.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6. -- The count in Maryland and Baltimore City was seriously delayed by the intricacies of the new ballot law, frauds in printing the ballots, and the determination of Democrats to carry everything with a high hand, as in the old ring days.
LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 5. -- News of his victory was received here by Justice William Travers Jerome, surrounded by his family and Lakeville neighbors.
MANILA, Nov. 5. -- A plot to massacre the American garrison at Moncada, Province of Tarlac, Island of Luzon, has been revealed by the wife of one of the conspirators.

Nothing in the election is more satisfactory to the instinct of common decency than the defeat of ROBERT A. VAN WYCK. When a meeting of the Bar Association described him as "conspicuously unfit for judicial office" and omitted to give any reasons it branded him as effectually by the omission as the description.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 5. -- Kentucky's total vote to-day will show a Democratic majority of about 20,000, as compared with 8,000 for Bryan for President and 4,000 for Beckam, (Dem.,) for Governor last year. There was no general election, the candidates voted for being municipal and legislative.

Edward M. Shepard, when he was seen at his Brooklyn home yesterday, gave no expression of personal disappointment at the result of the election. He said that he intended to leave for his country home, at Lake George, to rest. Some time before the end of December he will take a trip to Europe and remain there for some time.

The estate of Frederick Benedict has sold the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 6 West Fifty-second Street, 25 by 100.5. The properly is immediately at the rear of the W.D. Sloane mansion, at the southwest corner of Filth Avenue and Fifty-second Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 6 -- The Democratic primaries which resulted in sending contesting delegates to the convention are to be investigated by the Grand Jury. This afternoon Justice Skinner called that body before him and charged it to investigate the matter thoroughly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- In his annual report the Commissioner of Pensions discusses at length the faults of the present system of pensioning and the difficulties in the way of determining the merits of claims for pension and increase.

Prices in the outside market yesterday showed considerable strength in sympathy with the advances on the Stock Exchange, but for the most part the gains were made on small transactions. The general feeling seemed to be one of confidence, and all the active issues, as well as some of the less active ones, closed above the final prices of last Monday.

Gloom and darkness, occasionally broken with a few glaring flashes of high lights -- such is the atmosphere in which move the characters of Hermann Sudermann's new drama in if our acts, entitled "Johannisfeuer," (St. John's Fire.) In this respect, therefore, the latest work of this German poet is not much different from his-previous efforts.
Anthony Eickhoff, aged seventy-four, exFire Commissioner and ex-Coroner, who lived at 118 West Ninety-fourth Street, died Tuesday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Miehling, 854 West End Avenue.

Buoyancy such as has not often been seen since the May panic developed in the stock market yesterday under the stimulus of very heavy buying by the largest financial interests in the Street, these purchases, once their source traced, being promptly followed by not a few purchases by the professional element, who for the most part have lately been espousing the short side.

"The Acorns," whom Richard Croker designated as "The Popcorns," held a boisterous triumph yesterday, which extended from their headquarters in the old Jaffray Building, in Broadway, through many streets to Forty-second Street, in which not less than 5,000 people participated before it was all over.

The majority of Franklin Murphy, the Republican candidate for Governor, grows in New Jersey as the detailed returns are filed with the various County Clerks throughout the State. His plurality over James M. Seymour exceeds the highest figure set in the predictions of the Republican leaders before the election.

Col. Robert A. Ammon was the witness of the day before Referee John Straley yesterday in the inquiry into the assets of the defunct brokerage firm of Seymour, of Seymour, Johnson Co., with which Goslin and Miller of Franklin Syndicate fame were closely identified. It is hoped that the hearings will reveal where a considerable portion of the syndicate's stealings went.

The mysterious "Prince Ranjit of Baluchistan," who recently excited and baffled curiosity as to his identity in London, arrived in New York yesterday morning with his retainers and his Nautch girl, Bahar Bux, and promptly disappeared.

Every New Yorker who knows how things are done in other cities ought to take some personal shame to himself from the attitude of the N.Y.C. H. R.R.R. about the tunnel from Fortysecond Street to Harlem. Every other railroad, run in competition, attempts, at least, to find out what its patrons want, and to do it.

That Tammany man who complained that his organization could not get its case before the public except upon the backs of perambulating, "sandwich" men unconsciously paid a very high tribute to the newspapers of New York. His statement of the facts was incorrect, since the case of Tammany as it was presented in the able speeches of Mr. SHEPARD was very fully given in the newspapers, notably so in THE TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- In the stock market to-day, practically everything gave way to the Asphalt securities, and for the first time since the recent descent began, support was manifest, appearing when a new low record was made. The bulk of the trading was in the 5s of the American Asphalt Company.
ALBANY, Nov. 6 -- Gov. Odell to-day issued his first Thanksgiving Pay proclamation, as follows:

We believe that Mr. HEWITT, in the face of the returns, will be inclined to retract, or at least seriously to modify, that disbelief in universal suffrage, as a means for the government of cities, which he expressed on the eve of the election, and which Tammany vainly endeavored to turn to demagogic account.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Money was in fair demand to-day, apprehensions being felt that it would be more stringent after tomorrow's consols payment. Uncertainty as to the future hardened discounts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In looking over a late file of your excellent journal I came across a communication on Socialism, signed "A Layman," which amused me considerably. I presume you will accord the same privilege to a woman to express her views, provided she be reasonably brief.

Two victories by two-year-olds over fairclass old horses at the Aqueduct race track yesterday served to round out a season of remarkable performances by the younger horses, those successes, beginning in August with the victory of the stout Western colt Otis at Saratoga over one of the fastest sprinters of the American turf, Isidor, having been so frequent as to constitute a feature of the racing season.

Interest in automobiles showed a decided increase in attendance yesterday at the Madison Square Garden, where the Automobile Show is now in progress. The largest number of spectators of any day since the opening was present, and the novelties were all closely inspected. The crowd this year shows marked improvement in automobile intelligence over last year, and this fact is encouraging to dealers, as it illustrates a steady growth of the desire for motor vehicles.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 6 -- The police have in custody a man and a woman suspected of complicity in the robbery of an express car on the Great Northern Railroad, near Wagner, Mont., July 3 last, when the safe was blown open and a consignment of unsigned notes for the National Bank of Helena, Mont., amounting to between $50,000 and $100,000, was stolen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Adjt. Gen. Henry C Corbin. United States Army, and Miss Edythe Agnes Patten were married today at the home of Miss Patten, 2,122 Massachusetts Avenue. Cardinal Gibons performed the ceremony.

Deputy Sheriff Radley has received an attachment against Samuel Schenkein and Martin A. Coney of Buffalo in favor of Emmett McConnell on a claim for $92,250. The attachment was granted by Judge White of Buffalo and was served on a trust company here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I marvel at "Lutheran" in this morning's TIMES and the author of the sermon from which he quotes in denunciation of "secular" preaching. Surely they must have forgotten the Old Testament propeets who were nothing if not "secular" preachers.

The White Star liner Oceanic, which passed the bar Tuesday night, after having made a record passage of the Atlantic, came up to her pier on North River yesterday. At Quarantine the Oceanic was detained several hours by the medical authorities for a thorough inspection, owing to the presence in Liverpool, the Oceanic's homo port, of a few cases of the bubonic plague.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The climax of the Schley court of inquiry came this afternoon, when Mr. Rayner, the chief counsel for Admiral Schley, concluded a brilliant argument of over three hours with a peroration so eloquent and impassioned that all within the sound of his voice were profoundly touched.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- "The Enigma," a new play by Paul Hervieu, was produced at the Theatre Francais last evening, says the Paris correspondent of The Times. It was acted by the best of the Comedie Francaise company, but is a disappointment, considering the fame of the author as an Academician and a thinker.

-- Easy, and indeed, necessary, as it is to suspect that more than a few of the enormous bets on the election so solemnly recorded and reported -- especially reported -- last week were either of a nature strictly conversational or else reckless exaggerations of the financial arrangement really made, it is beyond question that the inhabitants of the greater city in innumerable cases backed their hopes or their opinions with money or money's worth.

Reduction of half a cent in posted rates for long sterling exchange. Company composed of New York, Detroit, and Chicago capitalists organized with $7,000,000 capital to build interurban railroads in Central Kentucky.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Reginald W. Rives, the New York clubman and coaching expert, who is President of the Dutchess County Agricultural Society, was beaten for re-election as Supervisor on Tuesday. His home is in New Hamburg, and he ran as Democratic nominee from the town of Wappingers.
BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 10 and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $23.380,074; balances, $1,981,279.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- The election for Mayor of this city will it is pretty certain be carried into the courts. The step was practically decided upon tonight at a conference of the Republican leaders with Dr. Edward S. Brush, who was the party's nominee for Mayor, and Senator Isaac N. Mills as counsel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6.-- Oberlin M. Carter, now a convict in the Federal prison at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., and once a Captain in the Engineer Corps, is to have an opportunity to be heard in a civil court upon the matters which led to his conviction by court-martial.

LOND0N, Nov. 7 -- The morning papers vie yith yesterday's evening journals in expressions of rejoicing over the defeat of Tammany Hall, in the achievement of which Mr. Roosevelt's strong influence is regarded as the mainspring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Messrs. Edwin Gould, President, and William Nelson Cromwell, counsel, of New York, with Forrest Rayner, receiver of the Seventh National Bank of New York, met Controller Ridgely by appointment at his office today. They submitted the final papers for the resumption of the Seventh National Bank.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The result of the election in Philadelphia is a decisive victory for the Republican "organization." It has given the candidates on its State and city ticket pluralities ranging from 32,000 to 47,000, the lowest plurality being recorded for Justice Potter of the Supreme Court.

The main points in the settlement of the Northern Pacific have at last been agreed upon. This statement was made yesterday by a number of the Harriman syndicate, and also by James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The entire time of the Schley court of inquiry to-day was devoted to argument in Admiral Schley's behalf. Immediately after the court convened at 11 o'clock this morning, Capt. Parker proceeded with his address. Capt. Parker talked for twenty-five minutes, and was followed by Mr. Rayner.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 6 -- Thanks to the election law which he himself had passed by the last Legislature, ex-Senator German will again become a member of the United States Senate. According to present indications the next Legislature will have a Democratic majority. Certainly the official figures will give the Democrats enough votes to elect a successor to Senator Wellington, and Mr. German is the only candidate.

Yale and Princeton are apparently making strenuous efforts to stir up enthusiasm for their football elevens. Each university held a mass meeting last night, and speeches were made by former graduates and football players urging hearty support of the elevens, and, also calling upon the undergraduates to march to the fields in bodies, so as to encourage the players with cheers.
One of the results of the election of the Fusion ticket will be the immediate attempt of the Democratic anti-Tammany forces to rehabilitate the party in this section.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Senator Platt, when asked to-night for his views about the elections, said:

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Nov. 6 -- Resting in the quiet of his country place on the shores of Lake Wononsco, Justice Jerome to-day declared that when he took office on Jan. 1 next there would "immediately be a great shake-down" in the present composition of the staff of the District Attorney's office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have watched the election closed in New York yesterday with scarcely less interest than I should have done had it been a Presidential campaign. It was an election not only of city, but of State and National importance, and the result one of which the whole country may be proud.
PEKING, Nov. 7 -- Li-Hung-Chang died at 11 o'clock this morning. His condition had been hopeless since early yesterday (Wednesday) morning.

Entries will close to-day at 2 o'clock at the Aqueduct track for the Creedmoor Handicap, five and a half furlongs, for two-year-olds, and the Farmingdale Handicap, one mile and a sixteenth, for all ages, which races will be the features of the Saturday card at Aqueduct, the last day of racing in New York for the present season.

Richard Croker was at the Democratic Club last evening, and he told stories about the peculiarities of race horses. He also denied the report that he would go abroad before the holidays, and that John F. Carroll would take his place as the leader of Tammany Hall.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6 -- This morning the Pan-American Congress decided to go into secret session to hear the project of the arbitration treaty proposed by the Mexican delegation. The votes against the secret session were those of Paraguay and Argentine Republic, Bolivia and Peru, 4 against 15.

The corrected figures of the local election as tabulated yesterday, made a few minor changes in the results at first announced. With 135 election districts missing, Mr. Low's plurality for Mayor over Mr. Shepard was put at 29,656. Allowing a similar proportion to the missing districts would have brought Mr. Low's plurality up to about 33,000.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 -- The market today was more active and firmer. Seaboard bonds and stocks were all higher, with the Street alive with bull tips. The 4s advanced a full point, the common 1/2, and the preferred 3/8. The ten-year 5s also were an eighth better. The whole list firmed up sympathetically, though there were some losses recorded.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I trust you will allow me space in your columns for a reply to "G.H.S.," who has criticised my letter contained in your issue of Oct. 27.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES, in its issue of yesterday, in the article "The Real Free Trade of Australasia," says: "At prsent, as near as can be estimated, the Intercolonial trade is not less than $2,000,000,000, and is probably nearer $300,000,000. The foreign import trade is rather more than the higher estimate of the domestic trade."

Another "Message from Mars" was delivered to the New York theatre-going public last night. Exactly what this message was it is hard to tell, but of its effect there can be little doubt. It made a few people in the audience laugh from time to time. It caused mild amusement with a larger number at more frequent intervals, while to many others it had no more meaning than would the "message to Garcia."

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- M. Bouquet, Director in Chief of the Department of Technical Instruction of the Ministry of Commerce, today confirmed the statement that the Minister of Commerce, M. Millerand, proposes to appoint a committee to elaborate a plan for the establishment of a French school in the United States devoted to the study of American industrial methods.

LA GUAYRA, Venezuela, Nov. 7 -- Senor Herbost, the Minister of Chile at Bogota, with the authorization of his Government, has cabled to President Castro offering the good offices of Chile in order to arrange the differences between Venezuela and Colombia, stipulating the acceptation of Colombia.

The New York art season opens with the exhibition of the Water Color Club at the Fine Arts, in West Fifty-seventh Street, and opens well, in view of the fact that water colors and colored crayons, pastels, and miniatures are things that appeal to a wider circle than do any other works of art.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R3" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

A record-breaking run from Philadelphia to this city, terminating at the Madison Square Garden, gave the racing sharps at the automobile show yesterday an element of more than usual interest for discussion. Louis Clark of the Quaker City made the journey from that place to the Garden by way of Camden, Trenton, Perth Amboy, and Staten Island in 6 hours and 5 seconds.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to take issue with your editorial of Nov. 4, "Suits Against Common Carriers." It must, indeed be gratifying to every one who has the public interest at heart to read that within two years the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company has been made to pay $2,000,000 for personal injuries, which amounts to an annual oss of 4 per cent, in dividends.

While the majority of the men employed by the Republican and Citizens' Union organizations have been laid off. It is recognized by the managers of both those bodies that each will have to keep up a better organization in the future than was necessary in the past, owing to the fact that under the new charter the city election will occur every two years instead of every four.

Through the arraignment in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday of a man who had been arrested in Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon, it became public that a robbery of gems worth $4,000 had been committed on Saturday last at the home of Charles A. Hoyt, at 15 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn.
The Venezuelan Consul in this city, Mr. Gonzales, has given out a statement received from his Government. It bears the date Oct. 28, and is in part as follows:

Yesterday the principal event was the Dyer-Scott wedding, a full account of which appears in another column. The sale of boxes for the Horse Show has ceased to be a society event, and there were only a few well-known people present. Neither this afternoon nor to-morrow are there many events of importance.

Boehm Coon yesterday through L.J. Phillips Co., sold the northwest corner of Twenty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, a building leased for a term of years to the Hecker-Jones Restaurant Company, to Henry G. Lytton, a wholesale clothing dealer of Chicago. Mr. Lytton gives in part payment of the purchase price a plot 85 feet front on West Eleventh Street, at Nos. 323, 325, and 327.

The first tangible evidence of the settlement of the Northwestern Railroad situation became known yesterday, when it leaked out that E.H. Harriman, James Stillman, Jacob H. Schiff, Norman B. Ream, Robert Bacon, and H. McK. Twombly had been elected into the Board of Directors of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad at the stockholders' annual meeting, held on Wednesday last in Chicago.

While the body of Li-Hung-Chang, the great Chinese statesman, lies ready for burial and the courtyard of the yamen is filled with life-size paper horses that are to be buried with his body to carry his soul to heaven, the American friends of the famous old statesman are looking around for stories and incidents connected with the Oriental who was known all over the world.

Samuel L. Clemens, ("Mark Twain,") and Patrick H. Coakley, a paperhanger, met last night on the little stage of the Good Citizenship Association of the East Side Settlement House, Seventy-sixth Street and East River. Both were there to entertain a large audience by telling stories. Mr. Coakley was not embarrassed by his distinguished rival, and Mr. Clemens acknowledged that the paperhanger received the lion's share of the applause.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A cablegram received at the War Department to-day from Gen. Chaffee, at Manila, announces the death, from pneumonia, of Capt. Robert H. Anderson of the Ninth Infantry. Capt. Anderson was appointed to the army in 1884 from civil life, being credited to Georgia.

The Stewards of the Jockey Club held a meeting yesterday afternoon in the office of the club with James R. Keene. F.R. Hitchcock, H.K. Knapp, and Andrew Miller in attendance. The meeting authorized the Secretary to accept, under the rules for registering and naming horses, the following: Valentine, for the chestnut gelding, three years old, by Valante-Jessie B.; Elorad, for the bay gelding, three years, by Florist-Addie Warren, and the bay mare unnamed by Richelieu-Caramita.

PEKING, Nov. 7 -- The end of Li-Hung-Chang was peaceful. His vitality slowly ebbed. For a time he lost consciousness; but he showed great tenacity, rallied at midnight, became semi-conscious, partook of nourishment, and appeared to recognize his relatives.

During a fire in the three-story frame building at 431 West Thirty-sixth Street, yesterday evening at about 6:30 o'clock, Policeman Trojan of the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station, and Frank Matthews, who lives across the street from the building which was ablaze, were nearly suffocated in rescuing Mrs. Saral McKnight, a cripple, sixty years old, who lived on the top floor.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 7 -- The Savannah Football Club eleven defeated the Jacksonville Rifle Club football team here to-day by a score of 18 to 0. The Florida men were heavier, but the activity and dash of the local players more than made up for weight deficiency.

The Harvard football squad left for Philadelphia yesterday, where they are to play the University of Pennsylvania to-morrow. The eleven is not especially confident of victory, as Pennsylvania always plays strongly against Harvard. Pennsylvania, however, has apparently given up hope of winning the game, but as Harvard is considered to be over-confident, the practice yesterday seemed to have the object in view of devising some plan to profit by this supposed over-confidence.
Housebreakers invaded at least three Harlem homes early last evening, and in one place got a gold watch and chain, some stick pins, and $40 in money. The thieves were not caught.

Robert A. Ammon was arrested by Detective McConville yesterday at the hearing before Referee John A. Straley, charged with criminally receiving $100,000 on Nov. 23, 1899, from William P. Miller of Franklin Syndicate notoriety. The hearing was being held to determine definitely the facts relating to the $140,000 Ammon says he put into the bankrupt firm of Seymour, Johnson Co.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7 -- Federal warrants charging forgery of signatures to banknotes were issued this afternoon against Laura Bullion, alias Clara Hayes, alias Laura Coxey, alias Della Rose, who, masquerading as Mrs. Nellie Rose, was arrested at the Laclede Hotel Wednesday when about to depart with a grip containing approximately banknotes to the value of $8,500, which were stolen in the Great Northern train robbery.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra gave the first of its series of concerts at Carnegie Hall last night. Whether it was because this was the opening entertainment of the musical Winter, or because the magic name of Wagner headed the programme, the audience was one of the largest ever seen at these concerts.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 -- It leaked out late to-night that a meeting of the Breeders' Investigating Committee has been called for noon to-morrow and that Trainer Dan O'Brien, who last week declared that he assumed the responsibility for the moving of the three-eights pole at the Kentucky Association track for the purpose of selling a colt to Clarence H. Mackay on a false trial, is to appear before it for a further statement.
Martin Engel, Tammany leader of the Eighth Assembly District, had a long conversation with Richard Croker yesterday. Then he talked of the defeat of the Tammany candidates, and said:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- David B. Hill arrived from New York this evening and was asked if he had given an interview on the subject of the reorganization of the Democracy of New York and had made comments on Tammany's defeat. Mr. Hill said:

Already, and before the publication of the full details of the vote, we have some curious and trustworthy indications of the amounts which the National parties, respectively, contributed to the cause of municipal reform. No Republican would be willing to admit that "the vote under the Eagle" is the measure of the strength of his party.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a fundamental proposition with some publicists that government on a universal franchise basis must be run by a machine -- good or bad. If the party machine is bad, as it was under Walpole in England, they advocate the entrance of a large number of good men in the party in order to accomplish its reform and the overthrow of its bad leader.

Few more wearisome and unprofitable discussions have occupied the newspapers during recent years than that which has grown out of the effort of British engineers to discredit American locomotives. The points of difference between our engines and those of English build are sufficiently important to interest the student of the refinements of mechanics, but that is about all that can be said of them.

Active as was Wednesday's stock market, yesterday's was still more active, dealings for the day running up to the no insignificant total of 1,200,000 shares. What is more, the buying was at advancing prices, as a glance at the list of net changes will show. Here and there appear declines, but they are few and far between as compared with the advances, some of which were not unsubstantial.

A resolution, asking the United States Government to grant permission for an American cable company, which wishes to establish a transpacific cable, to land cables at Hawaii and the Philippines, was adopted yesterday by the Chamber of Commerce at its regular monthly meeting, upon motion of Gustav H. Schwab, as Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Commerce and Revenue Laws.

"To be the ablest man among four hundred millions is surely something," an English writer, evidently very well informed about China, wrote of LI-HUNG-CHANG, when that already aged statesman was making his tour of the world. But the accuracy of the praise may very justly be questioned.

Bishop Potter was the principal speaker at the annual meeting of the Sisterhood of Shearith Israel, held last night in the assembly room of the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, Seventieth Street and Central Park West. His address was applauded by a very large assemblage of the members of the congregation.

The declaration made by Mr. Low as to his appointments to office is precisely what was to have been expected of him. It is not only in strict accordance with the principles and the practice he has observed in the public service heretofore, but it is in accordance with the accepted ideas of municipal administration among the great body of intelligent and honest men of the day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission was told to-day by witnesses for the American Hay Association that the rates charged by the railroads will make it possible for Canadian hay to crowd the product of the Middle West out of the New England States. Dealers from various points of Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois gave testimony.
LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Money was in strong demand to-day. The uncertainty as to the future made discounts firmer.

DETROIT, Nov. 7 -- President Ban Johnson of the American Baseball League was in conference here to-day with James Burns and his attorney, Mr. McNamara, concerning the affairs of the Detroit Club. The conference extended into the night, and when it was concluded Mr. Johnson stated that the affairs of the club were in a somewhat mixed state, especially so far as its financial condition was concerned.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 7 -- William Hale Thompson has been appointed Chairman of the committee on local and preliminary athletics in connection with the Olympian games for 1904. This means that Mr. Thompson will be at the head and front of local athletics, and indeed of athletics in the West and to a great measure of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 7 -- The exercises celebrating Founders' Day at the Carnegie Institute were held this afternoon. Aside from the natural interest attaching to the opening of the institute's Winter season of art and music, the presence of ex-President Cleveland as orator of the day, and of Mrs. Cleveland, as honor guest, served to augment the desire of the people to participiate in the exercises.

At attempt was made yesterday to file the petition for the probate of the will of Edward S. Stokes, which was filed on Wednesday, but as the petition failed to include statements that the testator had or had not left a widow or children, the probate clerk of the Surrogates office would not receive it.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Miss Kate Greenaway, the artist, is dead.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 7 -- The sudden and so far unaccountable increase of cases of smallpox in the city has so overcrowded the Isolated Hospital that Health Officer Chandler to-day made arrangements to have a large tent erected close to the institution, and this will be used to accommodate the convalescent patients, and thus relieve the congestion.

PORT HURON, Mich., Nov. 7 -- By his own written confession, Charles D. Thompson, Supreme Finance Keeper of the Supreme Tent, Knights of the Maccabees, and a prominent vessel and tug owner of this city, is a defaulter in the sum of $57,000. Mr. Thompson, however, was heavily bonded in the National Surety Company of New York and the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Baltimore, and the order, therefore, is protected from loss.

The economic and industrial disturbances caused by the present shortage of cars are sufficiently serious to merit notice. The great internal freight movement has its periods of annual congestion which correspond to those of the "rush hours" of city and suburban travel.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- Latest returns from Maryland, partly official, show about 360 plurality for Hering, Democrat, for Controller, who headed the State ticket. The House will be composed of 50 Democrats and 44 Republicans, with the election of one member still in doubt. The Senate stands 17 Democrats and 9 Republicans, a Democratic majority of 14 on joint ballot.

ALBANY, Nov. 7 -- The Rochester, Syracuse and Eastern Railroad Company was incorporated to-day with a capital of $3,500,000, to operate a street surface electric line between Syracuse and Rochester, a distance of 100 miles. The road will connect those cities and other places in Onondaga, Cayuga, Wayne, Ontario, and Monroe Counties.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 -- The market to-day was considerably stronger and notably more active. The trading broadened out somewhat, and embraced a wide range of securities, but the bulk of the buying circled around the Seaboard group. The 4 per cent. bonds reached the highest point to-day ever recorded on the local Exchange.
CHRISTIANIA, Nov. 7 -- Petrified tropical fruits have been found in some Spitzbergen coal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A cablegram received at the State Department to-day from Minister Conger confirms the press report of the death of Li-Hung-Chang. Mr. Conger's message simply states that Earl Li died at 11:15 o'clock this morning.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Dr. C.N. Spalter of West Eighty-second Street, Manhattan, was shot and killed accidentally this afternoon while with Dr. Edward E. Tull of 119 West Eightieth Street, Manhattan. The accident occurred off the residence of C. Oliver Iselin, at Premium Point, while the two men were out duck shooting.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Nov. 8 -- John T. Hayes, charged with murdering his former sweetheart, Miss Winnifred Cooke, was this morning found guilty of murder in the second degree. The prisoner was immediately sentenced to imprisonment for life.
The fortieth meeting of the George Peabody Education Fund, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday was attended by eleven of the twelve surviving Trustees.

The delegation of the Merchants' Association of New York which visited Texas last Spring in response to an official invitation tendered by the Governor and Legislature of that State has prepared its report. It comprises about 125 pages, with sectional maps showing resources of the State.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- A dispatch from Admiral Caillard has just been received, announcing that he landed marines on the Island of Mitylene this morning and occupied the Customs at Midilli without resistance.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 7 -- James Hagan, who was a General in the Confederate Army, died at his home here to-day at the age of eighty years. He was a Mexican war veteran, joining Col. Hay's Texas Rangers and taking part in the storming of Monterey. At the beginning of the civil war he was commissioned a Captain, and after the battle of Shiloh he was made Colonel of the Third Alabama Cavalry.

The sale of boxes by auction for the coming exhibition in Madison Square Garden of the National Horse Show Association of America was held at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Garden Theatre, when a crowd of nearly 200 well-known people gathered in the auditorium of the theatre and competed sharply for the choicest of the arena boxes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- When the Sehley court convened at 2 o'clock there were no formalities, and Judge Advocate-General Lemly at once began his closing argument for the Department. He read his speech from manuscript. He said at the outset that his plan contemplated, first, a response to criticisms of Admiral Schley's counsel, and then a presentation of the subject in hand on an independent basis.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 7 -- The most successful prison mutiny ever attempted in this section was put in execution at the new United States Penitentiary site on the Fort Leaven worth Reservation this afternoon. There was a regular pitched battle between guards and rebellious convicts, and one guard was killed and three wounded, while one convict was killed and another fatally wounded.

-- We all like to believe that our British cousins some time ago came to the conclusion that we and our doings were worth their careful study, and the London papers have certainly shown of late a much more accurate knowledge of American affairs than they did when the new appreciation of our National importance began to develop.

The happenings at the Aqueduct race-track yesterday all tended to one end, the emptying of the pockets of the bettors, the very horses seeming to have entered into conspiracy with the betting ring to make the selection of winners difficult. Five times in six races the public went wrong, the single choice which got home first being one that furnished little relief, for that one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that you are wasting a great deal of valuable space in discussing the Tammany misrepresentation of my views in regard to the best kind of government for cities. I am not opposed to universal suffrage as the proper foundation for free government.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Judge Neely, in the Circuit Court to-day, denied the petition of the Board of Education of the City of Chicago, asking that the injunction be dissolved which restrained that body from furnishing free text books to children of the first four grades of the Chicago public schools.

The marriage of Col. George Rathbone Dyer, son of ex-Gov. Elisha Dyer of Rhode Island, to Miss Grace Gurnee Scott, granddaughter of Walter S. Gurnee, Sr., took place at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest. The Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan read the service.

The new hotel to be erected by the SubTray Realty Company on the block front on Park Avenue, between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets, will be known as the Hotel Terminus, and will be nineteen stories in height. The structure will rise 253 feet above the curb level, and will cost $2,500,000, according to the estimate of Architects Warren, Wetmore Morgan, by whom the plans were filed yesterday at the Building Department.

The statement by Dr. Harry Pratt Judson, Dean of the University of Chicago, of the decay of oratory, in addressing the seniors the other day, leaves a good deal to be desired. We expect from such a quarter on that or any other subject to have not only its unsatisfactory condition pointed out, but something in the utterance which will leave the matter not where it finds it.

The West Side Republican Club entertained members who were successful candidates at the election Tuesday at a dinner last evening at the clubhouse of the organization, at 2,307 Broadway. There were about 160 men present. They cheered nearly every man who had anything to do with the recent Fusion victory, whether he was in the hall or not.

Transactions in yesterday's stock market, though somewhat smaller than on the day previous, nevertheless reached the no inconsiderable total of 950,000 shares, while so far as prices were concerned, the upward movement begun several days ago was generally continued -- and this in the face of lower prices sent over by London at the opening, followed by selling orders, on balance, of fully 60,000 shares.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Among the honors bestowed on the occasion of King Edward's birthday, which occurs to-morrow, are a Baronetcy upon the retiring Lord Mayor of London. Frank Green, and knighthoods for Chief Justices Little of Newfoundland and Gray of Bermuda: G.A. Critchett. Oculist to the King, and George Hussey, Mayor of Southampton.

An association has been formed to promote the erection of a National monument to the memory of the late President MCKINLEY in Washington. It is intended that the monument shall be in the form of a memorial arch connected with the famous bridge across the Potomac. The officers of the association are: President -- HENRY B.F. MACFARLAND; Secretary -- THOMAS F. WALSH; Treasurer -- LYMAN J. GAGE.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- The torrent of new books that is just now issuing from the press suggests the question why they are all published at one time instead of being published at intervals during the year. Why should there be an Autumn and a Spring publishing season, and why is it the firm belief of publishers that it is worse than useless to publish books in Winter and Summer?

Lieut. Col. George G. Greenough, Artillery Corps, is detailed as a member of the retiring board, appointed Aug. 20, to meet at Manila, vice Lieut. Col. Stephen C. Mills, Inspector General, relieved as a member of that board during the examination of Capt. Joseph B. Batchelor, Jr., Twenty-fourth infantry, only, Lieut. Col. Greenough is relieved as a member of the board, to take effect upon the completion of the examination of Capt. Batchelor.

People passing at Broadway and Thirty-sixth Street yesterday afternoon were horrified to see an elderly woman, who was crossing toward the Marlborough Hotel, become suddenly confused in front of a cab that was being driven rapidly down town, and which struck her, hurling her down on the trolley tracks, along which a car was rapidly approaching.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Consul General Patterson writes from Calcutta, Sept. 26, 1901: "In answer to inquiries of the various railway companies in India regarding the comparative original cost of American and English locomotives, and the compara- tive working capacity and expense of run- ning them.

True humor of the unconscious type is never out of date, so The Century Company need not apologize for republishing its treasury of examination answers first collected fourteen years ago by Miss Car oline B. Le Row and then published under the sponsorship of Mark Twain. "English as She Is Taught" is as natvely diverting as its Portuguese forerunner "English as She Is Spoke."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The report of Mr. Chamberlain, the United States Commissioner of Navigation, says that the past fiscal year has been the third successive year of notable prosperity and growth in American shipping, exceeding the two previous years. The extent and nature of work under way or projected in shipyards promises an even greater growth for the current fiscal year.

The Colorado-Mojave Desert offers, cer- tainly a fresh field for a writer of Mr. Van Dyke's predilections, and if any fault is to be found with the present volume it is that the novelty of impression and suggestion has proved a little overpowering and has led to surplusage. The mere facts recorded, however, are numerous, and much of the description is poetic and vivid.

The nearest prototype of the camps of concentration established by Lord KITCHENER in South Africa were those established by Gen. WEYLER in Cuba. The condition of those reconcentrados was one of the moving causes of our war with Spain, although, with the con- nivance of Gen. BLANCO, we should doubtless have gone on feeding them for an indefinite time if the Maine had not been destroyed and the war thus precipitated.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The recent recovery of parts of Arnold's flag vessel, the Royal Savage, sunk and burned by the British at Valcour Island, recalls one of the most memorable naval fights of the Revolution. It also has interest now in connection with your review to-day of Mr. Codman's book on "Arnold's Expedition to Quebec," and the attention you have called to Arnold's services before he became a traitor.

The contest for the Vice Chairmanship of the Board of Aldermen, which carries with it the majority leadership, was started yesterday. Three or four candidates entered the field, and there was a rapid lining up of forces. The Vice Chairman during the next two years will have the greatest power of any official in the legislative department of the city except the President of the Board of Aldermen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- In a letter to the Navy Department, dated at Colon, Oct. 29, Lieut. Commander McCrea, who is in command of the Machias, says:

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- When Erastus C. Knight asumes the office of Mayor of Buffalo on January 1, there will be a vacancy in the office of State Controller. No one has been picked out yet for Controller, nor will there be until the conference is held next week with Mr. Platt in New York City.
BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. and New York funds sold at par.

The tactical advantages which the United States possesses over other countries with regard to Eastern Asia is much more than a question of geography; it has to do with our style of government, our methods in diplomacy, and the fact that we can point to the vast areas unfilled by our population as warrant that we shall not act in an aggressive way.

We do not know whether Houghton, Mifflin Co. intend to publish any more French texts, but the quality of their first effort in this direction is such a great realization that it would be a pity if it were not a promise as well. They have appropriately reproduced a little work by one of the most distinguished literary amateurs of the eighteenth century, Xavier de Maistre.

The Editor's Drawer" in Harper's. The development of humor in a serious magazine is often as funny as the point which it has most recently made, while a comparison with its first funny effort is not altogether devoid of pathos.

According to The Sun, Tammany Hall has discovered that the present Tammany incumbents of offices under the City Government are pretty safe, thanks to the protection of the civil service law. It seems, according to this authority, that there are only three ways in which office holders can be removed.

Methodists of Manhattan and the Bronx, including that part of the New York East Conference which skirts the East River on the Manhattan side, have raised $400,000 of the $1,000,000 which they started out to get as their part of the $20,000,000 thank offering fund. This is considerably more than one-half the amount needed to pay the debts on all Methodist churches within the district named.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Mention was recently made in this letter of a forthcoming book by Charles Heber dark (Max Adeler) soon to be published by Henry T. Coates Company. "Captain Bluitt" has attracted attention even from the advance notices, and the sales have already been large.

Last Summer Prof. Nicholas Murray Butler -- as he then was, now President Butler -- of Columbia University delivered an address to the undergraduates of Vas- sar College on the subject of "Five Evi- dences of an Education." A part of it was printed at that time in THE SATURDAY REVIEW.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8. -- Eliminating the Asphalt bonds, which sold at a new low range, the trend of the stock market was upward to-day. New points of interest developed, and the highest prices reached for weeks were made by United Gas Improvement and Choctaw common, the former crossing 118 1/4, a net advance of 4 points.

Following Police Commissioner Murphy's promotion of a number of Roundsman and patrolmen to Detective Sergenteies this week, on notice from Chief Examiner Ireland of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, Col. Kipp. chief clerk of the Police Department, notified 214 Sergeants to appear for mental examination and 2,000 patrolmen to appear for physical examination at the office of the Civil Service Commission.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 8. -- Among the contributions to the Teachers' Retirement Fund in Newport are the following from the Summer residents: Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, $100; J.N.A. Griswold, $100; Mrs. Victor Sorchan, $50; Mr. John Carter Brown, $50; Mrs. Robert Goelet, $50; Mrs. Joseph Howland, $50; Theodore K. Gibbs, $25 Elbridge T. Gerry, $25; Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss, $25; Mrs. Harold Brown, $15: the Misses E. and M.K. Wetmore, $15, and W. Morgan, $10.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Nov. 8. -- Nine of the twenty-six convicts who escaped from the stockade of the new Federal prison here yesterday afternoon have been accounted for. Two of them are dead. These are James Hoffman, aged twenty, white, and J. J. Poffenholm, aged twenty-five, white, a soldier convict.

WE have already mentioned certain facts concerning Capt. Alfred T. Mahan's forthcoming volume. "Types of Naval Officers," which Little, Brown Company will publish toward the end of the month. The six British Admirals discussed -- Lord Hawke, Lord Rodney, Earl Howe, Earl St. Vincent, Lord De Saumarez, and Lord Exmouth -- are those who raised themselves to their rank in the peerage by their distinguished professional services.

Desperate at being held up by three men who he said tried to rob him, Jacob Wen- dell, a cook on board the steamboat Co- lumbia, drew a revolver last night and fired six shots at his assailants, putting them to flight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Minister Wu-Ting-Fang is expecting early official advices of the appointment of Earl Li's successor. Apart from the press dispatches upon this point he has had no information as yet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8. -- The control of the Market Street Railway Company has passed to a Baltimore syndicate, represented by G.R. Webb, who has departed for Baltimore in possession of the papers necessary to complete the transaction. Securities representing a value of $250,000 were deposited by Mr. Webb as a guarantee on the part of the purchasers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 8. -- Responding to a request by a local paper for an expression of his views regarding the Roosevelt-Washington dinner and the edu- eated negro and social equality, Prof. W. H. Council, President of the Agricultural and Mechanical College for Negroes at Normal, Ala., to-day sent a reply.

The country still exercised fascinations for the fashionable world. There will be a hunt at Goshen this afternoon; the WestChester hounds will meet at Blind Brook farm, and the Meadow Brook Hunt assembles at 2 in the afternoon at Wheatley. Besides these events there will be any number of house parties.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Sister Superior Agnes of the Academy of St. Mary of the Lake, who is well known and very popular in Lakewood, was shot in the left shoulder to-day by John Lawler, a former employe of the academy, who had been discharged for drunkenness. The bullet was extracted by Dr. C.L. Lindley soon after the wound was inflicted, and Sister Agnes's condition is not serious.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- At Bow Street Police Court to-day H. St. John Dix was charged, on a provisional warrant, with larceny committed in the United States. It is alleged that in 1900 he obtained control of three banks in the State of Washington, and that he subsequently wrecked the Scandinavian-American Bank at Whatcom, Washington, and disappeared with over $8,000.

A CORRESPONDENT sends to The London Times the letter printed below from Thomas Carlyle on the statue of Oliver Cromwell which it was proposed to set up at St. Ives in 1849, St. Ives being the place where Cromwell spent five years of his life as a farmer.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Vice Chancellor and Principal Donaldson of the University of St. Andrew's this morning announced the unanimous election of Andrew Carnegie as Lord Rector. The students greeted the announcement with prolonged cheering and the singing of "He's a Jolly Good Fellow." The Vice Chancellor remarked that Mr. Carnegie's election would meet with the approval of the whole nation.

We have here a very notable series of papers and addresses embodying such ideas and ideals as should, if President Hadley has an equal faculty for formulating and carrying out a system of education, afford a very substantial basis of congratu- lation to the sons of Yale who have so recently come together for the celebration of the two hundredth anniversary of the founding of their university.
Discussing the movement of currency during the week, Messrs. Dow, Jones Co; say:
PEKING, Nov. 8. -- A violent dispute with Paul Lessar (Russian Minister to China) over the Manchurian treaty appears to have been the immediate cause of the death of Li-Hung-Chang.

IT IS impossible to read Mr. Brownell's reflections upon these half-dozen "Victorian prose masters" without a feeling of selt-congratulation that, while the writers discussed are still of our own time, we should be led to see them so surrounded by their atmosphere, and with such a sense of space between ourselves and them.

In the presence of nearly 100 prominent members of the Chamber of Commerce of New York State, the corner stone of the new Chamber of Commerce Building, between Nassau Street and Broadway, on Liberty Street, was laid yesterday afternoon. The Chamber was founded 133 years ago, and when this building is completed it will be the first permanent home of the organization.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I wish to thank you and the gentleman who wrote the editorial article in this morning's SATURDAY REVIEW, entitled "The Mental Atmosphere of Boston." I consider it the most kind and just article on Boston that I have ever seen in a New York paper.

The twelfth annual meeting of the New Jersey Library Association was held at the Newark Public Library Wednesday, Oct. 30, 1901. The morning session opened with an address of welcome by Miss Beatrice Winser, acting librarian of the Newark Library. Mr. Arthur E. Bostwick, Vice President of the association, responded briefly.

This novel is written, we are told, by a young Anglo-Japanese girl whose opportunities for observing her countrywomen have been exceptional and whose mind has been trained to the European point of view. It has thus an interest apart from its literary merit, which is considerable, but not, perhaps, extraordinary.

In Prof. Sloane's volume we have to announce the publication of a very substantial and original contribution to our knowledge of what has been hitherto a very vague and unfamiliar phase of the French Revolution. The richness of the material accessible to the student of this point in the ecclesiastical history of France is only equaled by the scarcity of any comprehensive or satisfactory sifting and summing up of this vast quantity of unconnected facts.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- James Bryce, having completed a revised and enlarged edition of his "Impressions of South Africa," is soon to publish, through the Oxford Press, two volumes made up of studies of the history of jurisprudence.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The Russian press, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, does not receive with enthusiasm the praise of Russia in Hungarian papers apropos of the visit of the Grand Duke Michael to Budapest.

Dr. Horner's book represents much study and investigation of modern discoveries and research, the result being an attempt to reconcile apparent historical difficulties. Its preparation has evidently been a labor of love, Mr. Horner referring to the study and investigation of which it is the result as his "luxury through many otherwise very busy and laborious years."

N.P. Willis, the poet, and, with George P. Morris, one of the founders of The Home Journal, died at his country home, Idlewild, on the Hudson, in February, 1867, more than thirty-four years ago. His widow still lives, and, while not so strong, physically, at fourscore, as she was two score years ago, her mind is perfectly clear, and her general health is good.

To a notable gathering of men a comprehensive plan for the promulgation of education among both the white and negro races was enunciated at a dinner given by Robert C. Ogden to the Southern Education Board and other invited guests at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The plan is an outgrowth of the Southern educational conferences which have been held at Capon Springs and Salem-Winston for the past two years.

MR. STEPHEN explains in his preface the circumstances which have delayed the publication of this book for eighteen years. Green, born in 1837, having died in 1883. The main obstruction was his lack of personal intimacy with the historian, especially as he felt that he must do something more than give his letters without note or comment.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- Though the pressure was relaxed to-day, the demand for money was good, supplies were reduced, and the price was nominally easier. Discounts were quiet and had an easier tendency.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The weekly papers have a good deal to say about the defeat of Tammany Hall.

AT the last annual meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, Dr. S. S. Wheeler presented to its council and members the magnificent collection of works on the early sciences, lately belonging to Latimer Clark, who was one of the founders of the English Society of Telegraph Engineers, and its President during 1875.

CHINESE exclusiveness has been matched in the past by our contented ignorance of Chinese ideas and Chinese ways. We have complacently accepted the most mistaken notions concerning the yellow men refusing to look for correct information or to give it proper weight when brought to our attention.

W.E. Baker, the electrical engineer, who has charge of the electrical equipment of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad, said last night that in less than two months the stations and station platforms of the Second Avenue branch of the road will be illuminated by electricity. Each station will have fifty lights of twelve candle power each, and the lights will be kept burning from sundown until dawn.

After being in session for five hours at the Hotel Manhattan yesterday, the Trustees of Williams College adjourned indefinitely without selecting a President to succeed Franklin Carter, who resigned some time ago. When the board dispersed Edward Herrick Griffin, Dean of Johns Hopkins University, led in the voting.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- The market today continued the activity begun Thursday, and held strong, as well as broadening out in range. The Street heard many rumors of deals, the most persistently circulated being the probable sale by the United Railways Company of its holdings of Light and Power stock, on expectation of a deal involving the latter company and Consolidated Gas.

One of the advantages of such an arena as exists in the department of "Letters to the Editor" in this journal, is that the contributors answer each other. One man's sense counterbalances and exposes another's want of reflection.

Mr. Louis Harman Peet has presented a little volume under the title of "Who's the Author?" which anybody who has occasion to look up American writers, speakers, and composers, their novels, stories, speeches, songs, and general writings, will find most convenient, and, in some cases, invaluable.

The New York Realty Corporation is the buyer of the two lots on the west side of Fifth Avenue, 61.9 feet north of Thirtyfourth Street, to the sale of which by Charles T. Barney and his associates reference was made in this column yesterday. The negotiations were conducted by Richard M. Montgomery.

Frank H. Lawton, whose wife has instituted proceedings against him for a separation on the ground of cruelty, filed in the Supreme Court yesterday his answer to the suit, in which he alleges that his wife neglected him and made him the household drudge of the family.

An analysis of the extent and causes of the shrinkage of our manufactured exports during the past year, as made by Mr. O.P. AUSTIN, Chief of the United States Bureau of Statistics, and lately commented on in these columns, shows that the shrinkage has occurred chiefly in three lines of products, all of which are more or less perfectly controlled by so-called trusts.

What is regarded as the most important legal contest in the history of poolroom gambling will be started in the United States Circuit Court to-day before Judge Lacombe. A secret combination of the poolroom interests formed months ago has made every arrangement for the fight and raised large sums of money.

Many of the qualities which made the "German Garden" and the "Solitary Summer" so peculiarly fascinating are discernible in "The Benefactress." There is the same enthusiasm for nature, the same dominance of a captivating personality, the same whimsical humor, the same swift shafts of irony and wit, the same deft way of putting things.

In this volume of adventure the author depicts the lives of certain humble modern heroes whose unconscious courage ordinarily goes unnoticed. Mr. Moffett has chosen ten unusual and picturesque careers, and has offered dramatic scenes from the lives of the steeple climber, the diver, the lion tamer, the balloonist, and others.

Some remarks were made in this place last week about the large popularity of historical works. Under this head were included books of biography. But it may be worth while to note that these have a special ground of their own for being widely read. Emerson said that the search after heroes was one of the delights of youth which did not lose its zest in maturity.

The twenty-fifth service of song will be given at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church. Forty-eighth Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock by the quartet and chorus of twenty-five voices under the direction of the choirmaster, William H. Johns.

James Stillman, President of the National City Bank, was elected a Director of the National Citizens' Bank yesterday, and it is understood that a considerable block of the stock of the latter bank has been purchased by interests identified with the National City Bank.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Before the Merchants' Club of Chicago, at its banquet here this evening, James B. Dill of New York made the principal address. It was on trusts and their uses and abuses and excited much interest. Mr. Dill described a trust as a "dominant combination of money, property, business, or commercial power or energy."

Four speakers representing different branches of learning addressed the regular monthly meeting of the Schoolmasters' Association, at 17 West Forty-fourth Street, yesterday, when the topic was "The Examination Question of the College Entrance Board of the Middle States and Maryland."

According to a "Dictionary of the Varieties of Life" published early in the last century, "a general uppishness to things, and being down to the ordinary transactions of life, is known as 'gumption.'" This is a fairly exact description of the qualities for which Sam Weller might be cited as a shining example.

From The London Mail. Within the walls of the royal castle of Furstenried -- a majestic building, standing out with vivid whiteness against a sombre background of hill and forest-there is being enacted a drama which has few parallels in the history of the world.

After the uncertainty of Friday, the outside market yesterday resumed an upward course. Practically all the stocks which showed activity were somewhat higher at the end of the day than they were on Friday, and in some instances the gains were notable. The market, too, was more active than of late, the transactions being the largest recorded on a Saturday for a long time past.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 9 -- Armed guards, aided at many points by farmers, to-day kept up an unceasing search in the woods and on the highways in the country between Leavenworth, Kansas City, and the Kansas River for the convicts fleeing from the Federal prison at Fort Leavenworth.

THE COURTS of Li-Hung-Chang's rainbling Peking Yamen are resounding to-day with the shrieks and screams of professional white-robed mourners, hired to reinforce the lamentations of the women of his household.

The snapping of a rope in one and the breaking of a plank in the second caused the death of a man and the injury of two others who were employed in the new buildings at the northeast and northwest corners of Wall and Water Streets, yesterday afternoon.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 9 -- The Temple Coal and Iron Company averted a strike at their eight mines to-night by granting the demands of their men and agreeing to reinstate the fifty men discharged from the Forty Port and Harry E. collieries.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- An exceptionally large number of members of the Middlesex Club attended the dinner of the club at Young'c Hotel this afternoon, the prospective address by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge proving an irresistible magnet. The Hon. Edgar R. Champlin presided, and the gathering included many of the Massachusetts delegation in Congress, State, and National officers and other prominent Republicans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the slender Fusion majority of perhaps one vote in the Board of Aldermen, I deem it proper to recur to the triagonal contest in the Twenty-first District hereat, concerning which I wrote you last week. There Mr. Armitage Mathews was the Republican candidate for re-election, and Mr. John Stewart and Mr. M.H. Dalberg were respectively the Citizens' Union and the Tammany nominee in opposition.
Final arrangements for the annual debate between Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania have been completed, and it will be held here Dec. 13.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 9 -- George Patterson, the ten-year-old son of James Patterson, is believed, to be dying at Muhlenberg Hospital of injuries received in a scrimmage while playing football in the west end of the city several weeks ago.

Shortly before midnight last night Patrolman Patrick McCarthy of the Old Slip Station heard cries coming from the end of the pier at the foot of Coenties Slip, and on going there found a man struggling in the water.

After running over and fatally injuring a child at Park and Kent Avenues, Brooklyn, last evening, the motorman of a trolley car fled to escape the anger of a crowd which had gathered and threatened him.

From The London Telegraph. Piccadilly has its Bachelors' Club, New York has -- or had -- its "Suicides' Club." The establishment of the former was, at its inception, looked upon in certain quarters as somewhat of an eccentricity, while nobody surely could regard the latter otherwise than as at the best a very grim joke.

MANILA, Nov. 9 -- Advices from Catbalogan, capital of Samar Island, report that Major Waller attacked a force of insurgents occupying a strong position at Sojton, two three-inch guns being used to shell the rebel stronghold. Throughout the first day the insurgents held the place, but yesterday Major Waller renewed the attack, and, after a desperate engagement, carried the position.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- The Post will say to-morrow: "There is a well-defined report in yachting circles that Lawson's yacht Independence has not seen her last day and will probably appear in races as trial horse next year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 9 -- A.S. Pitt won the championship of the Wee Burn Golf Club to-day after a match with W.B. Wheeler, by 4 up and 3 to play in thirty-six holes. In the finals for the Consolation Cup M.R. Pitt and J.T. Williams, Jr., were pitted against each other.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to say that Dr. Doty's conclusions in favor of relaxing quarantine restrictions are entitled to general and generous support. Among the many abuses to which mankind is subject all over the world, quarantines are unquestionably of the worst. They are harsh, unreasonable, arbitrary, onerous, and often a risk to life. This is particularly the case in South America.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Lord Mayor's banquet at the Guildhall to-night was spectacular. The historic building was the scene of a brilliant pageant, in which modern and mediaeval sights were strangely mingled.

Buried in the heart of a civilized, powerful, and progressive foreign people a little handful of Indians have lived for three hundred years, and have contrived to keep, during all that time, their national characteristics, their traditions, and their individuality. If you seek them you will find them in Amatlan de los Reyes, a village in the State of Vera Cruz, Mexico.

THE boy in blue cloth and buttons approached the cashier with a valiant swagger and thrust a paper under the very nib of the scratchy pen. The man with money transfixed the corner of the document with his inky weapon.
Pearce Phillips have been appointed District of Columbia agents of the Westchester Fire Insurance Company.

Gov. Chester B. Jordan of New Hampshire, in his proclamation appointing Thursday, Nov. 28, as a day of thanksgiving in his State, says: "Ever since the golden Autumn of 1621 dawned upon our forefathers at Plymouth for various reasons and at sundry times, thanksgiving days have been observed.

DURBAN, Oct. 28 -- Lord Milner arrived here at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon. His Excellency was received with enthusiasm by the Ultlanders and townspeople and was presented with an address of welcome by the Mayor at the Town Hall. In reply Lord Milner thanked the residents of Durban for the great services they had rendered during the great crisis.

The crowds of people passing at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street at half-past 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon were terrified by a loud crash on the elevated structure overhead. From the end of the Sixth Avenue elevated track facing Central Park there came a storm of flying splinters and iron.
Letter to the Editor of The London Times. Sir: I find the following in a recent scientific publication:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that the election is over, and the battle for good government has been won, it is well to consider some of the agencies that have contributed toward making a successful fight possible. To my mind no factor has been more powerful than the editorial page of your paper.

Interesting facts are developed by a comparison, herewith appended, of the prices which prevailed on the Stock Exchange on the day succeeding the election of 1000 and those of last Wednesday, together with the highest and lowest figures that have meantime been recorded.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly allow me space, as a communicant of thirty-seven years' standing in the Protestant Episcopal Church, a former Vestryman, and Assistant Superintendent of Sunday schools, to reply to Mr. Clarence M. Lindsay's communication which appeared in yesterday's TIMES relative to the seven sacraments?

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 9 -- At the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company Nov. 18, plans will be laid before them bearing upon the dividends and the financing of new properties. As the voting trust has been dissolved, the stockholders for the first time since the receivership have an opportunity to participate in the annual meeting.
