ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 9 -- An official dispatch from Chabarovsk says that seven Tungese leaders and 3,000 men have surrendered. Of these 1,300 have been enrolled as Chinese police, and the rest have been dismissed.

During the past week there have met in this city the managers of the Peabody fund and of the Slater fund for the promotion of education in the South, and there has been perfected the organization of the Southern Educational Conference, of which Mr. ROBERT C. OGDEN is the President.

A new hotel has opened up for business in Washington. It rises twelve stories from the street and towers high above any other building in the neighborhood. In appointments, equipment, and style it rivals the famous Waldorf-Astoria of New York. The lobby is a thing of magnificence. Huge onyx columns, shining marble, and glistening metal work form a combination of splendor and elegance that is hard to beat.

Columbia was surprised, beaten, and outplayed at the Polo Grounds yesterday at football by Syracuse, and it was not until the first half was well under way that Columbia realized the fact that she had held Syracuse too cheaply. The score was 11 to 5.

"THERE is no one, I believe," said the Philosopher, with the air of imparting important information, "who has not some petty economy which amounts almost to stinginess and which is also, as a rule, along the line of his or her greatest extravagances. Every one will deny this at first, but let them give the matter a moment's thought and if they are frank they will admit that I am right.

"I HAVE just discovered a new advantage in the ownership of the name Smith," said the talkative stationer. "The gain derived from this possession is particularly marked if the surname happens to be John. And John Smith's wife profits from the combination even more than John himself.

WHAT name to give to a new apartment house -- that is a question that puzzles every extensive builder and real estate operator in New York City. Any one of them will tell you, if you get to talking to them about their doings, that all the names are gone, appropriated.

NOW that the tropical heats of an unprecedentedly hot Summer have ended, the season of badly damaged livers is on, and the family doctor is about to commence. We who were compelled to remain in our own country are thankful to an unknown power which enabled us to exist through the inevitable ills of the location and period, and finally saw us through to the end in comparative safety.

Astronomers all over the world will watch with deep interest for the November showers of meteors. They are expected between the 13th and 16th of the month. Scientists, however, are by no means confident that they will witness the brilliant displays of 1833 and 1866. They figure that the November meteors have been diverted several millions of miles from their former course, and are in a path between the earth and the sun.

Though there were some additions to the scores, there were few changes in the leaders in the principal local bowling league tournaments the past week. The Metropolitan team still leads the American National tournament with the remarkable record of ten consecutive victories and no defeats, the Corinthians lead in the Columbia series, the Lafayette and the Phoenix fives are tied in the Harlem League tournament, and the Metropolitans lead in the National League.

The new French liner La Savoie, the rebuilt American liner Philadelphia, (formerly the Paris,) and the Cunarder Lucania, three of the swiftest transatlantic liners afloat, came into port yesterday morning in one, two, three order. When they steamed up the bay a story that there had been a three-cornered race across the Atlantic immediately started the rounds.

When the passengers of the Leyland liner Canadian disembarked yesterday they were profuse in their praise of four Shetland ponies that had been brought across on the vessel. The little animals are prize winners on the other side and are to be exhibited at the coming Horse Show. They are the property of Mrs. W. Hope-Johnstone of Tunbridge-Wells, England.
"NOW let's begin at the beginning." The assistant counsel at the seamen's branch of the Legal Aid Society checked an applicant in the midst of a burst of voluble dialect.

Senator Horace White of Syracuse is a sportsman of high rank. He has hunted and fished through the Adirondacks for twenty years, and he is not yet forty. Of late years he has aspired for larger same and rougher life than can he found in the Adirondack woods, and pursues the moose in the wilds of Canada.

Football in the Navy Yard. TO SEE a game of football of really stirring interest: one where the mass play does not make the struggle tedious, take a Flushing-Graham Avenue trolley car at the Brooklyn Bridge and set off at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, in front of the Parade Ground.

ITHACA, Nov. 9 -- The trophies of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association for the four and eight oared crews are now on exhibition at Cornell University Library. They were won by Cornell at Poughkeepsie in July of this year.
Col. E.P. Kinnaird, a retired United States Army officer, living at the Gilsey House, was the victim of a series of accidents yesterday, and finally went to bed in order to escape further injury.

Under the heading, "For a Freer Sunday," yesterday's Evening Post published some valuable and interesting opinions of persons who by their relations as members of the New England Society might be supposed to hold Puritanical views about the observance of the Sabbath, and who were asked to express their views about the propriety of opening the beer saloons and the beer gardens on Sunday afternoons.

To The Editor of The New York Times: After the good work accomplished by last Tuesday's election some people of more or less prominence have become affected within throat irritation or palpitation of the heart to such an extent that all they can say is that they have nothing to say.
WOMEN who sew in families have troubles of their own. Sometimes it is one thing that bothers them and then again it is something else. Most often it is the machine.

William West Durant, son of Thomas C. Durant, who was the President of the Credit Mobilier, which built the Central Pacific Railroad across the continent, will be called upon to defend a suit for contempt of court which has, been brought through his sister, Heloise D. Rose, on Tuesday next.

The phenomenal advances in the local railway shares were easily the feature of the market. Metropolitan at one time rising 7 points, Brooklyn 4, and Manhattan 2. It is a known fact that there has been a very heavy short interest in both Metropolitan and Brooklyn, and much of yesterday's buying of these securities was attributed to precipitate covering by these shorts.

AGAIN the thick fog is settling down-over London. We have had day after day of perilous getting about this month or October, and the beginning of the season of fogs thus early is regarded as a bad omen by weatherwise Londoners. St. Stephen's and Victoria towers and the spires of the Abbey can now be seen faintly through a yellowish mist, and the houses on the south bank or the river, are invisible.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The North American to-morrow will say: " A new fifty-milllon-dollar steel corporation is being formed for the purpose of uniting in one powerful combination the plate mills of the country. Ten or more plants, including Pennsylvania companies that are now doing a large business, are to be absorbed by the new concern.
THE one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the capture of Fort Wash ington, which will be observed on Saturday next, was a particularly heroic and gallant struggle, marked by unusual episodes.

HELENA, Montana, Nov. 9 -- The indications are that the United States Government has struck a splendid gold mine at the site of its new building in this city. As announced yesterday a vein of free-milling gold ore was encountered while excavating which showed as high as $100 a ton by the panning process.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "A noble duty nobly done." These words aptly describe the work accomplished in the late election by the ever-increasing body of independent voters who co-operated with members of the Republican and other formal party organizations. Among the large and influential bodies that contributed to the result was the Citizens' Union.
THERE lives in a small town in Western New York, not far from Buffalo, an estimable lady with matrimonial proclivities. She has married three times and is yet barely past middle age.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Miss Isabel McKenna gave a tea this afternoon at the residence of her parents, on Rhode Island Avenue, where the guests were invited to meet Miss Evelyn Sloane of New York, who has been the guest of Justice McKenria's family for the past week. The young hostess and her guest received in the first drawing room.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondents "G.H.S." and "Reader," who have written in reply to Mr. Clarence Y. Lindsay's reference to the number of the sacraments as taught by the Protestant Episcopal Church have strangely misunderstood the Church Catuchism to which they refer as conclusively restricting the number of the sacraments to two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Consul General Dickinson from Sofia, reports to the State Department by cable the receipt by him of another letter from Miss Stone, as already noted in the press dispatches of last night. He quotes Miss Stone as saying:

A STRANGE personality, strange even for the golf course, has been invading the links of Van Courtlandt Park and other neighboring playgrounds during the past few weeks. This individual calls himself Charley.

COLUMBUS, Nov. 9 -- The strong Michigan team ran up only 21 points, their smallest score of the year, against the crippled Ohio State University eleven here to-day. Three touch-downs were made in the latter part of the first half, after Ohio had successfully defended her goal line for nearly twenty minutes.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 9 -- The Naval Cadets played good football on the offensive this afternoon, and defeated, the Carlisle Indians by a score of 16 to 5. The Navy opened the game by Belknap kicking to Johnson, who ran back twenty yards before he was tackled. At once the Indians began the attack on the Navy line, and rarely failed to gain.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Six to six was the score in the Princeton-West Point football game to-day. It was a battle of giants, and the result shows how evenly the teams were matched. Princeton had more weight and strength than the Cadets, but the soldiers, under Daly's generalship, held down the big men and tied the game.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- President Roosevelt, in making appointments of Postmasters for Fort Worth, Texas; Clarksdale, Miss., and Decatur and Union Springs, Ala., to-day disregarded the recommendations of the Republican organizations in three States. In these cases the organization candidates were found not to meet all the requirements.

With nine hours to spare, the Australian-London mail, rushed across the continent by fast mail trains, arrived in this city yesterday morning at 4 o'clock, and three hours later was on board the steamship Umbria long before that vessel's sailing time. The Australian mails left Melbourne on Oct. 14 last on the steamship Ventura.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have not been reading the various letters which have been written by Mr. Clarence M. Lindsay, "G.H.S.," and others that have been published recently in your paper, so do not know exactly what the controversy is about. But a statement in Mr. Lindsay's letter printed in this morning's issue attracted my attention, concerning which I trust you will permit me to make the following observations.

Columbia and Princeton played their annual chess match yesterday afternoon at the Columbia team's rooms, in University Hall. Ten boards were played, nine of which resulted in a score of 4 1/2 games for each team. The ninth board, however, was not finished, but was left over for adjudication.
Announcement was made yesterday of plans for the merger of the Ninth National Bank with the National Citizens' Bank.
THE three green lights cast uncertain shadows about the street doorway. In the office, just inside, the Sergeant is busily writing reports.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The appointment of the Rev. Charles Gore, the Canon of Westminster, to be Bishop of Worcester, has raised both a political and an ecclesiastic storm. Only a few days previous to the annoucement of his appointment Mr. Gore came out in The Times with a strong letter condemning the concentration camps and other severe measures in South africa.

Copyright, 1901. Via French Telegraph Cable Company. LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Although we have had another broken financial week, the celebration of the anniversary of the King's birth closing the Stock Exchange to-day, it is unlikely that the volume of business would have been larger if the week had been full.

The officers of the Republican County Committee are obtaining copies of the tally sheets in all the election districts for the purpose of satisfying themselves as to the vote cast under the different emblems.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- A complimentary dinner was tendered to Luther R. Marsh at the Russell House in this city to-night in honor of his ninetieth birthday. Singularly enough, there were just ninety persons present, although the fact was not known until noses were counted. Many prominent men who were friends of the aged lawyer in the days when his life was more strenuous were present.

MILLBURN, N.J., Nov. 9 -- The first case of smallpox ever reported in this place was discovered to-day in an Italian tenement house containing about forty persons. One portion of the building is used as a church by the colored people of the town. The house was immediately quarantined. To-night the Board of Health held a special meeting and decided to move the patient to a pest house on the Millburn poor farm.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- With the entire undergraduate body present, Williams won from Wesleyan to-day in the most exciting game of football played on Andrus Field in many years. The victory, while not so decisive as Wesleyan's victory of last year, is sufficient to give Williams hope for the game next Saturday against Amherst.

Some unexplained circumstances surround the death of Emerich Kiss, an aged cabinetmaker, whose body was found on the first floor of 109 Mercer Street yesterday, with the large artery of his right arm severed near the elbow and the left arm cut. A razor was lying near him. All of the front entrances to the building, which was owned by Kiss, were padlocked on the outside.

A pile driver fell on a gang of Italian laborers who were working on a new bridge across at Hackensack River at Secaucus yesterday, killing one of the men and injuring four others. The bridge is being constructed for the Henderson County Board of Freeholders by John R. Long.
THE Ogunquit Board of Trade, at its regular monthly meeting yesterday, refused to adopt a resolution indorsing Senator Frye's ship subsidy scheme. Clim Bascom presented the resolution.

SYDNEY, Oct. 15 -- As expected, the Australian Ministry has framed the Federal tariff on a protectionist basis, but in a manner suggestive of attempting to sit on two stools at the same time. It is too high to please the free traders and tarfif for revenue men, as they now prefer to call themselves, and too low to satisfy the ultra-protectionists.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 9 -- Ripping the light Pennsylvania line as though it had been so much paper, the Harvard football team tore to victory this afternoon on Franklin Field by the score of 33 to 6. These six points for Pennsylvania were so many drops of sweetness in the cup of bitterness to the 18,000 Quakers who witnessed the struggle.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- Yale won easily from Orange Athletic Club this afternoon at Yale Field, rushing the ball over the goal line five times, in the first half, then putting in substitutes and contenting herself with a single goal from the field in the second. The final score was 35 to 0.

When the Rev. Charles Wing, now in Brooklyn, was a young man he was called to a church in a small country village. Mrs. Wing kept no servant in those days, and so, when she found that the parsonage needed cleaning, just after their arrival, she asked Mr. Wing to find a woman to help her in the work.

THERE has been a stir among women all over the country since the absurd story was promulgated that Mrs. Roosevelt had said that $300 was a sufficient allowance for the average society woman to dress upon. Of course she made no such statement. Dressmakers have been interviewed, society women have talked, and women who do not make a pretense of going "into society" have given their opinions.

Verona, N.J., Nov. 7, 1901. Lesson of a Fatal Accident. To the Editor of The New York Times: The horrible accident resulting in the death of Dr. C.N. Spaulter in Dr. E.E. Tull's naphtha launch while duck shooting in Long Island Sound, off Premium Point, near New Rochelle, is to be greatly deplored.

SEVERAL days ago a number of laborers, who were excavating near one of the big oil tanks of the Standard Oil Company, on Constable Hook, Bayonne, N.J., came upon a quantity of arrowheads, tomahawks, and wampum beads, about six feet below the surface. Digging further down their picks laid bare a scattered heap of fragments of what, to all appearances were human bones.
From The London Standard. PARIS, Oct. 23 -- M. Sarafoff, ex-President of the Macedonian Committee, has addressed from Paris the following letter to the Temps:

Yesterday was another day of remarkable strength and activity on the Stock Exchange. More than 500,000 shares were traded in in the two hours of business -- by far the most active Saturday on the Exchange in months -- while some very substantial gains were recorded throughout the list.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- During the lengthy Cabinet conferences this week, a representative of The Associated Press learns, the question of re-enforcing the old ballot laws came up for discussion. Many of the Cabinet Ministers were strongly in favor of putting in practice this form of conscription, for which certain obsolete laws already provide.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The most exciting and dramatic attempt by M. Santos Dumont to win the Deutsch Prize took place yesterday at Les Coteaux, near St. Cloud, in the sight of vast crowds.

George Bissert, the "wardman," convicted of bribery, has been informed by the authorities that he will be treated with leniency if he will disclose what he knows of the reception of protection money by the police. He has been told that a full confesion may even lead to his unconditional release under his sentence, which calls for five and a half years of imprisonment and the payment of a fine of $1,000.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Nov. 9 -- The birthday of King Edward was celebrated in Newfoundland to-day with general enthusiasm, which was intensified when it was learned that his Majesty had conferred the honor of Knighthood upon Chief Justice Little, the Deputy Governor. It is understood that this compliment is a further recognition of the King's gratitude for the cordial welcome given to the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York in St. John's last month.

John Proctor Clarke, who was elected to the Supreme Court bench on the Fusion ticket, filed a certificate with the County Clerk yesterday in which he declared "that no moneys were contributed or expended by me directly or indirectly either by myself or by any other person in aid of my election."
To the Editor of The New York Times: "A Physician," in his letter on "the question of capital punishment," published in your issue of Nov. 3, makes some statements which I desire to notice.

Mr. Hall Caine, I observe, by 458 votes to 191, has become a "Key." The author of "The Deemster" is predestinate, no doubt. It is not quite so easy to determine why the twenty-four who form the executive branch of the Legislature of the Isle of Man are called "Keys."

With this week the social season may be said to have begun in New York. As yet there are no entertainments of any magnitude nor are there likely to be until after the Horse Show. There is a promise of an impromptu dance during the show, but nothing definite has been decided. This coming week will be passed greatly in getting houses in order.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 9 -- Chairman Murray Van Diver of the Democratic State Central Committee in an interview to-day said:

"There are two very substantial reasons why the net revenues of the railroads of the country will not fall off even should general business not continue as good as at present," says the President of a Western railroad.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 9 -- The total easterns receipts for the month of October are $96,858, against $97,344 in October, 1900. This was when the tariff between Porto Rico and the United States was in force.

TWO notable entertainments opened the musical season. The Wagner concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Thursday, night and the song recital of Lilli Lehmann on Friday afternoon were things to be treasured in the memory, of the true lover of music. It was especially fortunate that the first notes of the vocal season were those of a song recital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Mrs. Roosevelt, through her Secretary, Miss Isabel Hagner, has requested the local papers to announce that she will discontinue her informal Friday afternoon receptions, this course having been adopted to avoid embarrassment caused by the large number of uninvited guests, who have made their way into the White House on these occasions, even before the expiration of the thirty days' official mourning for President McKinley.

Jan Kubelik has finished his Continental tour and reaches London during the coming week, appearing in Brighton Nov. 16. The farewell London concert is advertised for the Queen's Hall Nov. 19, and the following day he sails for New York. Already announcements are made of his London dates for next year with Richter and the Philharmonics, May 15, the opening of the season, and July 2, when he plays Young Randegger's new violin concerto.

To The Editor of The New York Times: If there is one set of men more than any other who are responsible for the present shameful system of bossism in American politics they are the individuals who pride themselves upon the fact that they always vote the "straight ticket," no matter whose name may be upon it.
The first afternoon concert of the sixteenth season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The programme was as follows:

George Willing, a clerk, living at 207 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, would have drowned in the Harlem River at One Hundred and Sixtieth Street yesterday afternoon had it not been, for John Shults, the champion sculler of the Harlem River Rowing Club. Shults now has a record of saving four persons from death by drowning.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 9 -- Sheriff Frank Reedy performed a most unpleasant task to-day in the public flogging of William H. Decker, horse thief. Decker has been ill, and is subject to violent attacks of heart trouble.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- At its meeting tonight at the Copley Square Hotel the New England Free Trade League voted to change its name to the "American Free Trade League," and to accept the invitation of the National Association of Manufacturers to send a delegation to attend the coming reciprocity convention in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Advances of 3 per cent, in the work on the battleships Maine and Missouri and good starts on the new battleships Georgia, New Jersey, and Rhode Island are shown in the report of the Naval Bureau of Construction and Repair, just made public, showing the state of the work on the vessels building for the navy.

The feature of the week in sterling exchange has been not so much the continued strength as the fact that rates are now almost up to the point where cold shipments direct to London may be profitably made, while a triangular operation such as that under which recent exports have been made to Paris would no longer show a profit because of an advance in Paris exchange.

CONSIDERING that nearly everybody is praising the rapid strides ahead in everything which makes for greater speed in local transit, it seems weird that there are people who live right here in New York who are opposed to it. They are doomed to be swept out of current history soon, because their peculiarity depends mainly on the length of life of the Seventh Avenue horse car line which is fast fading away.

A novel step in the direction of educating cash girls and boys and the other children forced to work throughout the day in the large department stores was recently introduced by James A. Hearn Co. So many children at work from morning till night in the big stores are unable to get the time for an education that the firm decided to open a school of its own.

Dr. George A. Williams, a physician of the Bedford section of Brooklyn, living at 449 Hancock Street, yesterday asked the police to search for his sixteen-year-old daughter, Augusta K. Williams, who has been strangely missing since Friday morning.

The managers of the six-day bicycle race to be held at Madison Square Garden were notified by Floyd McFarland yesterday that the cyclists who will compete in this year's struggle have sailed for New York on the St. Paul. The teams that left Europe to come here are as follows: Gougoltz and Simar, France; Chevallier and Fisher, Switzerland; Muller and Le Poutre, De Roeck and Kerff, Belgium, and Frederick and Jaak, Germany.

WHEN there is a stickler that puzzles lawyers and doctors, when there are mysteries that thrill the land, in tact whenever, to use a slang phrase, everybody is "strictly up against it," the analytical chemist is called in to solve the problems and to shed light upon that which without his skill must remain a hidden riddle to the public, layman, and professional alike.

"MANY years ago I learned that it was never safe to bet on another man's game," remarked William A. Brady to several theatrical men. "I was riding on a train and struck up a convorsation with a drummer. We discussed the speed of the train and differed on it. Finally he offered to bet that he could tell the time made between two mile posts nearer than I could.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par. Call loans, 3 1/2 to 4. Time money, 4 to 5. Clearing House exchanges, $25,159,930; balances, $1,848,2 There was greater breadth, strength, and activity to the two hours' stock trading than have been the case in many weeks.
Miss Florence Ranstead, a young American singer, will make her first appearance here next Friday at 3 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria in a song recital.

Albert F. Harris, fifty-five years of age, who says he lives at 365 West Fifty-fifth Street, was a prisoner in the West Side Court yesterday morning, charged with having given a worthless check to Nicholas Bryan of 228 East Eleventh Street, a driver for the firm of Arnold, Constable Co.

We entirely distrust the dispatch which purports to come from Peking and to set forth that the Japanese Government has been discouraged by the failure of the Governments of Great Britain and of the United States to back up with sufficient energy its protest against the Russian procedures in Manchuria, which amount to the virtual annexation of that province.
ON Monday morning Mr. Judson made a startling announcement.

PEKING, Nov. 9 -- The Foreign Ministers this afternoon went in a body, wearing plain mourning, to the late Li-Hung-Chang's yamen and presented their condolences, according to Chinese custom. Chinese soldiers lined the streets near the yamen, and the great crowds which gathered in the streets and about the yamen were perfectly orderly.

Dressing Room Comedy. THERE are often two performances going on at Weber Fields's Music Hall nightly. One is that the audience enjoys, and the other takes place in the dressing room of John T. Kelly and Sam Bernard, and is a special entertainment given only before the friends of the two actors who happen in.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 19th ult. you publish an extract from a paper read by Charles Francis Adams before the Historical Society of the State of Massachusetts in which he says that but for Gen. Robert E. Lee the civil war, after the surrender, would have been prolonged in the South as is now the war in South Africa by the Boers.

The belief that the thing to do for a man or a nation behindhand in his or its accounts is to "save face" has been brought up to account for many things otherwise unaccountable in the politics of the Far East. But it is equally efficacious in the politics of the Near East.

Two boys were killed and another was dangerously injured yesterday afternoon through the collapse of an overhanging bank of earth about 100 feet high in Hausmann Street, near Norman Avenue, Greenpoint. Three other boys who were playing with them had narrow escapes. The dead are James Cunard, nine years old, of 255 Nassau Avenue and Edward Fagan, eleven years old of Sutton Street and Nassau Avenue.

THERE has just been completed a strange memorial which will recall to posterity a remarkable chapter of religious history in this country. It is the testimonial of the Universalist Church and a tribute to the memory of Thomas Potter, the Prophet of the Jersey wilderness, and Thomas Murray, the Sailor Apostle, who was called to his life work down in Ocean County, just beyond Toms River.

Now, since the election, the main question in the minds of reflective and patriotic New Yorkers must be the question how that victory is to be made permanent, how we are to get the full fruits of it. How, in a word, is the reign of decency and honesty to be established.

BANGOR, Me., Nov. 8 -- At 1:30 o'clock this morning the night police of Bangor were startled at the sight of a big buck deer racing through the business streets of the city -- so startled, in fact, that they forgot to shoot, although the animal passed very close to several officers and nearly knocked one through a window.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 or consideration over $3,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thanks of all who helped by their votes to elect the Fusion ticket are due to you for the various articles that have appeared in your valuable paper during the past month on behalf of moral and political decency, and as a humble subscriber I therefore most heartily thank you for the same.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 9 -- A dispatch from Guayamas, Mexico, says: The lost Tayapa mines, celebrated in Spanish annals as having produced $80,000,000 in sliver and gold in the seventeenth century, which are described on Spanish maps as being situated in Northwestern Mexico, about fifty leagues from the sea, near Dos Pilares, have been found.

MOST people get alarmed when they read the statistics of immigration, and their apprehension leads them to some conclusions which cannot be substantiated by an analysis of the figures. In 1775, according to Mr. Bancroft, the historian, one-fifth of all the people in the colonies had for their mother tongue some other language than the English.

Fire Risks of Electricity. A RECENT report of the Electrical Bureau of the National Board of Fire Underwriters contains a number of curious and interesting instances of fires resulting from misdirected electrical currents, which should convince those who use electricity that it requires careful watching to restrict its incendiary tendencies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- While Commander Benjamin F. Tilley, Commandant of the United States Naval Station at Tutuila, Samoa, was in Washington recently, he submitted to Secretary Long his annual report upon affairs and conditions in this island possession. Commander Tilley says that the inhabitants are a gentle, kindly, simple-minded people, and that the form of government instituted by the United States has proved very popular with them.

The officials of the Department of Water Supply in Brooklyn are being criticised because of a proposition that has been made by them to purchase a tract of land near Bensonhurst for a driven-well pumping station. It is claimed that this land is unfit for the purpose, as it has been used for years as a dumping ground for garbage and offal.
"DID you ever see a skirling match?" queried the Latest Recruit a few weeks from the wilds.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Robert C. Gordon, manager of the Princeton University Football Association, has defined Princeton's stand in reference to the eligibility of Glass, the Yale guard, in a letter to The Alumni Weekly. The following is the substance of the letter:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Government Lighthouse Board is to make an experiment of great interest to shipping and to the lighthouse system of the world. This will be made on the Diamond Shoal Lightship next month. The officers of the board expect to project a great thirteen-inch stream of light from the sea to the sky which will be visible to mariners up to forty miles away.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Gold nuggets and fine gold dust worth $7,000 were found a few days ago by Henry Freeshe, a farm hand, in the attic of an old shanty on the Barker Road, north of Royalton. The building was being remodeled to be used as a barn. The gold was stored in an old wooden box about two feet square.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9 -- The Yale freshmen easily won from the Princeton freshmen this afternoon at Yale Field, in a prettily contested football game by a score of 11 to 0.

"THE fashion and etiquette writers in some of the English journals are making a big ado over the matter of calling by proxy," said the woman who prides herself on doing things in the right way, "but there is really no cause for all the fuss and feathers. The idea is by no means new.

James W. Godfrey, manager of the Habirshaw Wire Company, at 15 Cortlandt Street, was thrown from a light wagon drawn by his trotter Fake, a well-known Speedway horse, at St. Nicholas Avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-third Street, soon after 6 o'clock last evening. His skull was fractured, and he died two hours later in the J. Hood Wright Hospital without recovering consciousness.

A judgment secured by Dr. Edward A. Ayers against the Western Union Telegraph Company for damages for its failure to transmit promptly to the addressee a message delivered by him to its messenger, was yesterday reversed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The death of Lillian Bailey Henschel, who was very popular here, has caused much sorrow; she and her husband were inseparable throughout her long musical career. Their daughter, Helen Henschel, has just made a successful debut on the concert stage.

Sweden and Denmark are competing in friendly rivalry to do honor to the tercentenary, of Tycho Brahe. Just three centuries have passed since that fine old astronomer, whose quaint personality and brilliant achievements fill so-large a page in the early history of science, died on a sickbed at Prague, Oct. 24, 1601.
Senator M.A. Hanna of Ohio, who arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening, has every confidence that President Roosevelt will give the country an excellent Administration.

Members of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club, near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, had an unusually interesting day on the links yesterday, the programme comprising a larger number of important matches than is usually seen at one club for a single day's competition. The chief feature was the defeat of Findlay S. Douglas, the former National champion and the present metropolitan champion, by Daniel Chauncey.

SIMLA, India; Oct. 10 -- The events at Kabul have overshadowed everything else. But there is no denying the fact that the agricultural outlook in certain parts of India is anything but pleasant. The monsoon rains this year started late, not setting in properly until July. This in itself was not a very serious matter, provided that, once started, the downfall was well continued.
The law of New Hampshire requires that town lines shall be resurveyed and marked at least once in seven years.

Several interested persons who chanced to be passing through the Parc Monceau Saturday were witnesses of a very pretty scene, when Mile. Toutain, who was that evening to create the role of Yvette at the Vaudeville, visited the monument of its author, Guy de Maupassant, and placed on the marble seat beneath his bust her tribute of flowers.

An increase in activity, gains in market value, and a disclosed new hopefulness -- almost aggressive confidence -- have marked the Stock Exchange week. Many securities have advanced. A vast deal of entertaining "argument" has been in evidence -- argument to induce public favor for the market.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The Tammany of Naples, the Camorra, seems likely to have the same fate awaiting it as its brother bandit organization in New York lately met. If the local reformers fail in the work they have undertaken, a royal decree will intervene.

ST. LOUIS. Mo., Nov. 9 -- Fragments of letters stolen from the mails which were found on the sidewalk near the home of Samuel Seelig caused his arrest late Friday night. Seelig was detailed temporarily as foreman in the distributing department of the St. Louis Post Office. He is charged with peculations estimated at $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Representative Landis of Indiana said to-day: "We will have to wrestle with the surplus; that will be one of the important matters to come before Congress at its next session. We have not always such a problem to deal with, but now that it is confronting us, we will have to solve it, and I have no doubt that we will be able to do so.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- At the fifth annual convention of the National Live Stock Association, commencing here Dec. 3, it is estimated that 8,000,000 Americans who are in one way or another interested in the business, will be represented. The live stock of the country if converted into cash would, it is said, take every dollar in circulation in the United States, and that in addition $2,225,000,000 would be needed to liquidate the bill.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 17 -- Ever since the establishment of the Australian Commonwealth the question which has occupied the foremost place in the interest and in the speculations of both New Zealand and Australia has been the tariff. That "free trade" was out of the question was early made manifest, the protectionists of Victoria and their followers in the other States being too strong for the New South Wales "free traders."

Tennyson once told his neighbor, Mrs. Cameron, the famous amateur photographer, that he believed that every vice and every crime in the world were connected with the passion for allographs and anecdotes and records. In his biography there is a rather cryptic stanza, written for an American lady who had asked for his autograph:

CHARLES BELLAMY, a brother of the late Edward Bellamy of "Looking Backward" fame, and also proprietor or The Springfield (Mass.) Daily News, in the way of recreation is fond of playing practical jokes on his friends. Here is one which he was responsible for, and of which Samuel Bowles, the editor of The Springfield Republicans was the victim.
The first concert of this, the tenth season in New York, of the Kneisel Quartet will be given on Tuesday evening, Nov. 12, at 8:15 o'clock, in Mendelssohn Hall. The programme will be as follows:

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 9 -- "Neither our courts, our Legislatures, nor our churches have improved and grained greater hold on the people in the last thirty years," said President Eliot of Harvard in the course of an address on "A Survey of the Conditions of American Education with Some Accounts of Its Successes and Its Failures," before the Twentieth Century Club to-day.

Salem S. Sarkis, editor of the Syrian paper, Almoushir, appeared in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning as complainant against David Widower of 81 Washington Street and Antonio Saur of 63 Washington Street, charging them with assault. The men were paroled until Monday in the custody of Lawyer Trainor, who represented them.

Those who expected a poor showing from the real estate market during electon week have been happily disappointed. Not only have a number of transactions come to light, the figures in which would be sufficient to attract attention, but the announcement of important building operations in connection with several of the deals furnished an additional element of interest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The State Department has received from Consul General Frank Mason, at Berlin, a long report upon the commerce and industries of Germany. Mr. Mason handles his subject in a comprehensive way.

A large attendance of automobile enthusiasts saw the second annual automobile show come to a successful close last night in Madison Square Garden. For an exhibit that has been more, thoroughly a trade show than was the first one last year, the attendance has been a surprise to the manufacturing community, and it has made all classes realize more accurately the strong hold that the motor vehicle industry has taken upon the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The President to-day appointed William F. Willoughby of the District of Columbia Treasurer of the Island of Porto Rico. Mr. Willoughby will succeed Jacob Hollander, of Maryland, who resigned some time ago.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Nov. 9 -- The cruel absurdities of what is called discipline and honor in the German Army were never more revoltingly shown than in the positive murder of poor young Kurt Blaskowitz a Lieutenant of artillery who was killed in a duel this week.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Supreme Court Justice Dykman to-day made an order allowing the rector and wardens of St. John's Church, Yonkers, to carry out a certain proposition to mortgage its property, as follows:

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Cornell easily vanquished Lehigh University to-day, and when the contestants left the field the score stood 30 to 0 in favor of the Ithacans. Neither team played fast, and Cornell was able to win handily more because, of the weakness of her opponents than by reason of her own strength.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter in this morning's TIMES Mr. Frederick W. Pangborn states that with the exception of a few cities and towns, the people of New Jersey are "sadly deficient in a genuine pride in themselves and their localities," and among the cities condemned he places Hoboken, Trenton, and Elizabeth, where he asserts "the public pride is also low and seldom asserts itself."

THE wedding gown of Mrs. Joel Nott Allen (Miss Fanny Walton Ogden) departed from the usual conventional satin, and was of crepe de chine with satin dots scattered over its shimmering surface. It was simple, too. The long plain skirt had a deep, square-cut train and a full gathered flounce of old point lace some ten inches in depth, which went all around the train, as well as around the skirt of the costume.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The Philadelphia market partook of the betterment shown in Wall Street, nearly the whole list closing with some improvement. The only exception was that of the Asphalt group, both the National and American 5s declining to the lowest ebb ever reached. The strength of Choctaw and the spirited recovery in Consolidated Lake Superior excited a favorable influence and a revival was seen in Philadelphia Electric, over 1,800 shares being dealt in.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The Boerse has grown more stagnant, although values generally have been maintained. Some coal and iron shares improved several points last week, but others fell off. All other industrials were weaker.

CURACAO, Nov. 10. -- Dr. Eduardo Blanco, Venezuelan Minister of Foreign Affairs, has resigned his portfolio. He will be succeeded by Dr. Pachano. The cause of the resignation was a disagreement regarding the Colombian question, particularly the answer of President Castro to the Pan-American Congress in the City of Mexico, which was sent without Dr. Blanco's knowledge.

The compassion of Magistrate Pool was aroused yesterday morning, when, in the Harlem Police Court he saw before him a decrepit, poorly clad, old man, whose flowing white hair touched his shoulders. The old prisoner was Louis Martin, sixty-eight years old, who last lived in a lodging house at 2,317 Third Avenue, and who was charged with being a vagrant.

A wave of reform has swept over East Harlem since the election of the Fusion ticket, and that portion of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street between Park and Third Avenues known to Harlemites as "Leadville," which has for years been the haunt of gamblers and bookmakers, is completely deserted by them.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- There were no services to-day in the French Catholic Church here, which was organized about two years ago by the Rev. Father Alphonse Laroque. The priest is greatly incensed against the action of Bishop O'Connor in having the edifice dismantled yesterday while its rector was in Washington protesting against such action.

In the large hall of Cooper Union last night the Winter season of the People's Institute was opened with ethical talks and music. There was a large and interested audience. Those who spoke were Howard Mansfield, Dr. Rudolph Grossman, Carl A. Mead, and Charles Frederic Adams. Charles Sprague Smith introduced the speakers.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 10. -- Sheriff Cook arrived from Pauline at 10 o'clock to-night. He was somewhat disfigured, and his clothes were ragged, but he had lost none of his nerve by his usage at the hands of the convicts. He said that when he and Deputy Williams reached the scene in the afternoon a farmer boy, a lad of eighteen, who had been chasing the convicts was

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A striking illustrarion of the growth of the American Navy is presented in the single statement in the annual report of Rear Admiral Bradford. Chief of the Equipment Bureau of the Navy, that he spent $2,273,111 last fiscal year for 324,108 tons of coal at an average cost of S7,01 a ton.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 10. -- Sheriff Cook and Deputy Sheriff Williams of this county were captured by two escaped convicts from the Fort Leavenworth military prison this afternoon at Pauline, five miles south of Topeka, and held prisoners in the farmhouse of a man named wooster for several hours.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For more than fifty years I have lived in Brooklyn. I not only voted for Seth Low, but spent half a day getting out the laggards to the polls, in my anxiety to see him elected. For a man of my years this means something more than expectation of office.

The Adams Street Police Station, in Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday with prisoners taken in a raid on a room in a building at the corner of Wilolughby and Adams Streets, in which, it was alleged, gambling was being carried on. The raid was made early yesterday morning by Capt. James Reynolds, the head of the Brooklyn Central Office, and a score of his detectives.

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., Nov. 10. -- A high northwest gale developed here this morning, and continues. A large fleet of steamships, tows, and tugs was caught off here, and is being severely handled by the wind and sea. A loaded barge, believed to belong to the Jersey Central Railroad, and in tow of the tug Plymouth, was discovered at anchor, and on fire off Wellfleet to-day.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Nov. 10. -- Augusta K. Williams, daughter of Dr. Williams of Brooklyn, has been at the home of Mrs. Ella Stiles since her sudden departure from her home last Friday.

HAVANA, Nov. 10. -- The Municipal Council of Havana has decided by a vote of 10 to 8 to accept the bid of S.P. McGivney and R.T. Rockeby of Jersey City, which is $10,393,015,99, for the Havana sewering and paving contract. Considerable feeling was manifested during the session over the circulation of a pamphlet insinuating that the McGivney-Rockeby bid was really the bid of the Engineer's Department.

Peter Gilsey, oldest son of the late founder of the hotel of that name at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, died suddenly last night. He fell unconscious at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-first Street, was taken into a neighboring drug store, and was then taken to his home at 80 Madison Avenue in a cab.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- In an editorial article on the speech delivered by Lord Salisbury at the Guildhall banquet on Saturday The Times says the Premier must know that Great Britain went to war in South Africa very imperfectly equipped with knowledge. The urgent representations of many who knew the country and the Boer people were put aside as not worth listening to by the official advisers, who subsequently found everything to learn.
The Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Slicer, at the Church of All Souls' yesterday morning preached on the recent election, his theme being the "Responsibility of the Victor." He said in part:

Everett Bodine Latham, twenty-seven years of age, living at 4 West Forty-seventh Street, was arrested yesterday afternoon on a charge of forgery. He was taken into custody as he was entering his home by Detectives Weaton and Murtha. With the detectives he went to the West Thirtieth Street Station and was held there for examination to-morrow in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

A special service was held in St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoo.i to unveil a Carrara marble bust of the late rector of the church, the Rev. Dr. John Wesley Brown. The edifice was well filled by parishioners. As usual, music predominated in the services, which were conducted by the rector, the Rev. Ernest M. Stires, D.D.
Senator T.C. Platt was asked last night what he thought of Justice Jerome's proposition with regard to a change in the excise law.

Theodore Deranzy, a salesman, thirty-five years old, of 47 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg was badly injured yesterday afternoon by being run down by a coach belonging to Sherman Rader of 33 Boerum Street, in which was a bridal party on its way to a hall at Pitkins Avenue and Watkins Street, Brownsville, where the friends of the bride and bridegroom were awaiting them to celebrate the wedding.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Jonathan Lyon, seventy-six years of age of 204 Vanderpool Street, watchman in Cawley Clark's paint works at the corner of Vanderpool Street and Avenue C, was found in the works this morning unconscious with several ugly wounds on his head, his skull fractured, and his pockets turned inside out.

An appeal "To the people and press of New England" relative to the employment of children in the cotton mills of the South controlled by Northern capital has been printed in the Boston and other New England papers, and appears to have been well received. The most significant paragraph of this appeal is that which we quote below:

PARIS, Nov. 11. -- The Foreign Office yesterday announced that the Sultan had signed an irade for the execution of his engagements with the French Government, and that the Franco-Turkish dispute was at an end.

Familiarity with the only passenger in his car and disobedience of the rule forbidding conductors to converse with a passenger last night cost Conductor William Fitzgerald of the Union Railway Company $18 in fares and his gold watch. Incidentally the conductor had the experience of his life he says.

Notwithstanding the fact that Saturdays' bank statement showed a material loss in cash and a further reduction in the surplus reserve account, the statement itself was one of the most assuring and encouraging the Street has had in some time -- this, because of the substantial decrease in loans, the first of such decreases shown in some weeks.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 10. -- Dr. J.W. Smart, Commissioner of Public Works of Cape Colony, in the course of a letter to the papers here dealing with the mission of the General Manager of the Cape Government Railways, Charles Bletterman Elliott, and his correspondence with the British press, says Mr. Elliott has cabled that his total purchases and orders for the Cape railways placed in America do not exceed u600.

Sheriff-elect William J. O'Brien was received with three rousing cheers when he appeared at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday in his capacity of delegate for the Granite Cutters' Union.

There is evidently a considerable sentiment in the Republican Party in the direction of legislation to improve the currency. As this sentiment is strong also among the gold Democrats, as it has had Mr. GAGE for its leader for some years, and as it is spreading among the business men of the country, it is pretty certain that a movement will be undertaken to accomplish something in the next Congress.

PEEKSKILI, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- Senator Depew has shown the ruins of his Opera House. Short after the fire which gutted the handsom building on Jan. 29, 1900, Senator Depew caused a big sign of "For Sale" to be acted on the ruins.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The fall in consols, which is partially attributable to the speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, foreshadowing increased war taxes, caused everything to be dull during the early part of last week, but owing to the brisk revival in American railway securities all the markets closed better.

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- Under the title "The Russians and the French in the Levant." says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, the Deutsche Zeitung publishes an instructive letter regarding the causes of Russo-French friction in the near East.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The persistent efforts of a small minority in the Episcopal Church to assimilate her doctrinal system to that of the Church of Rome are likely to prejudice her, as a Protestant body, in the minds of the uninformed. She has declared in her catechism that there are two sacraments only ordained by Christ "as generally necessary for salvation," meaning, of course, necessary where they can be had.

Highway robbery as practiced on Fifth Avenue might make a good theme for a prisoner who calls himself Max Wiess, and who is now locked up in the West Fortyseventh Street Police Station. In broad daylight he held up two men at the point of a pistol yesterday afternoon on the corner just opposite Sherry's and almost in front of Delmonico's

The discussion of trusts by Mr. JAMES B. DILL of this city at Chicago on Saturday evening has a special interest from the well-known ability of that gentleman in the line of practice connected with this class of corporations and his wide experience. It is fair to assume that there is very little to be learned from the outside or the inside that Mr. DILL does not know on this subject.

The outdoor season of sport and recreation which is now drawing to a close has been marked by an interesting change in the character of the pleasure travel on the popular roads in and about New York. This change has been a noticeable yielding of the bicycle to the newer machine -- the automobile.

For nearly two years John A. Doherty, a young man of this city, has been missing from his home, 488 Seventh Avenue, and his relatives have evidence now that leads them to believe him a prisoner of the British authorities in Cape Town. His place of confinement, they say, is the Island of Ceylon, and they contend that he is detained wrongfully.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- In as close a finish as any racing event of the meeting is likely to produce, the work on the improvements on the Bennings race track was so nearly completed Saturday night that all now is in readiness for the Fall racing, the last meet of the Eastern season, which will begin to-morrow to continue for three weeks.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The new chapel of St. Joseph, attached to St. Joseph's Hospital here, was dedicated this morning by the Right Rev. Bishop O'Connor of Newark, assisted by a large numoer of prominent clergymen of the diocese.

Chain Shot, the Grand Circuit trotter, vrith a mark of 2:06 1/2, and the crack pacing mare, Helen D., 2:09, who figured prominently on Western tracks and won the circuit events at Windsor, Ontario, and Cleveland, Ohio, were the star performers on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- C.T. Durnell, the American jockey and trainer, has been disqualified for life by the Jockey Club on the ground that he deliberately remained at the post at St. Cloud Oct. 28, when he rode Londres in the Prix de Marly-Je-Roi.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The Exchange Telegraph Company has received a dispatch from Lisbon announcing that a Portuguese gunboat has seized the American schooner Nettie and Lottie at Horta, Island of Fayol, Azores, for clandestinely conveying twenty-six emigrants who were trying to avoid military service.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10. -- After traveling all over the world in a vain effort to still the twinges of conscience and avoid a man and a woman who he believed were proclaiming him everywhere as a murderer, Edward Rogers, aged thirty-five years, who killed James Hoban in a quarrel in a saloon here Nov. 24, 1897, surrendered to the police at Erie, Penn., and was brought to Baltimore to-day.

SOFIA, Nov. 10. -- Information has been received here from Doubnitza that the band of brigands holding captive Miss Ellen M. Stone, the American missionary, called about a fortnight ago at the village of Smetchevo and subsequently proceeded to the monastery of Rilo; but the movements of the troops compelled the brigands to flee toward the frontier, where they are now in hiding.

According to the police of the West Forty-seventh Street Station four arrests made Saturday night may prove to be important ones. The four prisoners who were arraigned in the West Side Court yesterday morning as suspicious persons gave their names as Lillie Walker of Boston, Edward Jackson, Margaret Hawes, and Walter Hawes.

-- We do not share the indignation expressed by Mr. R.L. EDWARDS, in a letter which we published on Saturday, against the organization which with quite unnecessary caution he described as "the so-called Order of Acorns." It is true, as he said, that their jollification over the Fusion victory was "boisterous," but what of that?

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- On account of the cold weather the attendance at the final cycle rages of the season at the Vailsburg track was very small, numbering less than 1,000 persons. There were only four events, of which but two proved of interest -- a half-mile open professional race, won by Frank Kramer of East Orange, and a ten-mile handicap, won by John King of this city from the 580-yard mark.

UTICA, Nov. 10. -- Michael Stepanik, employed by John W. Owens as a farm laborer at New York Mills, went out to round up some stray cattle Tuesday night. He did not return, and the following morning search was instituted for him.

The banquet hall of the Sturtevant House, Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, was filled last evening with young people. They were members of the Marble Collegiate Church, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, and had come to celebrate the tenth anniversary of the founding in that church of the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor.

People are beginning slowly to come back to town, and there were many new faces on the avenue yesterday. Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry and the Misses Gerry are among those who have returned. Mrs. Ogden Mills was also in town for the day. Before the end of the week nearly every one will be in town.

The State Railroad Commission, in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday continued the hearing on the application of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company for a certificate authorizing the construction of a four-track electric railroad with terminus in this city and at the Connecticut State line in Port Chester.

In Detroit there is at present a conflict of a triangular nature between the old gas company, a new gas company, and the city. Practically, it is much the same sort of a quarrel which has arisen wherever a local monopoly furnishes gas at a relatively high price and resists efforts to improve the quality and cheapen the cost of the light furnished to consumers.

Like most other editors, I have received a great deal of correspondence in reference to the Buller case. I select the following letter from the rest because I know that the writer is, as he says, in a position to know much that goes on behind the scenes:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 11 -- Alabama voted to-day on the question of the adoption or ratification of the Constitution formed by the recent convention, and from the returns so far received it is evident that the instrument has carried by a majority ranging between 25,000 and 35,000.

The midyear assembly of the Eastern Methodist Episcopal Conference was opened at Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, 323 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. The Rev. James Montgomery, Presiding Elder, Brooklyn North District, acted as Chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Ansley Wilcox of Buffalo is a guest of the White House for a few days. The President took the oath of office at Mr. Wilcox's residence, in Buffalo.

QUALIFICATIONS OF NOTARIES PUBLIC. -- The objection that has been raised of late in the case of a notary public who has filed a duplicate certificate of his appointment in a county adjoining that of his residence against his acting in such adjoining county because the certificate so filed did not state that he had qualified was passed upon on Friday by the Appellate Division in this city in favor of the notary.

Sol. Berliner, United States Consul to the Canary Islands, who came home on a vacation last Summer and filed a petition in bankruptcy on July 13, has been granted a discharge in bankruptcy by Judge Adams of the United States District Court. Goldfogle, Cohn Land, his attorneys, made a motion for his discharge yesterday, and as there was no opposition by creditors it was immediately granted.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The following crop report was issued this afternoon by the Department of Agriculture:

BERLIN. Nov. 11 -- Referring to the meetings held throughout Germany to denounce the reflections recently cast by Mr. Chamberlain upon the conduct of the German troops in the war with France, the Cologne Volks Zeitung excuses the demonstrations by pointing out that no German Government organ has printed a semi-official repudiation of Mr. Chamberlain's sentiment, and that, in the absence of such repudiation, public opinion must find expression in other ways.

Not within several months have the transactions in the outside market showed as large a total as they did yesterday. The bulk of the trading was supplied by the copper stocks, but in other parts of the list as well considerable life appeared, and a number of stocks showed fairly large totals.

A second will executed by Edward S. Stokes on March 22, 1894, was filed in the Surrogates' office yesterday. In this will the testator directs that after all his lawful debts have been paid his mother. Nancy Stokes, was to receive all of his estate of whatsoever kind and nature he was possessed at the time of his death for her use and benefit forever.

The upward movement in prices which has been a feature of the stock market for a week past was continued yesterday under the stimulus of heavy and well distributed buying which carried the total transactions for the day beyond the million mark. The continuing strength was in evidence at the very opening of the market, notwithstanding the irregular prices sent over by London, followed by some selling orders from that quarter.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 6 -- The announcement that Secretary Root will ask Congress to appropriate more than two million dollars for harbor improvements and the erection of a dry dock in San Juan has caused a deal of excitement here. The expenditure of such an amount of money will do much to relieve the present depression.

It is a pity that the dwellers on the opposite side of the Atlantic Ocean never read the American newspapers. They would learn some things about this country which they need very much to know. But as it stands they are still laboring under the pleasing delusion that we are a very young and innocent Nation, and that we are ready to accept with acclamations anything that receives toleration from the British nobility.

Controller Coler deniid yesterday the stories that there have been transfers made by the Board of Estimate by which several thousand Tammany employes were to be held in office in 1902. He declared such stories "were absurd and nonsense." Continuing, he said:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 11 -- The leading news here to-day is that M.C.D. Borden has withdrawn completely from this market, his brokers saying they have no goods to sell and none to buy. He did not succeed in unloading any of his cut-rate contracts, so far as is known here, and it is known that his best offer from printers was on a very much lower basis than 2 15-16 cents.

The United States Steel Corporation has now reached what would appear to be a crisis in its history. When it was formed it was generally believed that this crisis would be reached only when reaction from prosperity had changed the conditions and brought it what, in the familiar language of the trade, is known as "hard sledding."

Dr. John A. Irwin, President of the British Schools and Universities Club, received yesterday the following cablegram from King Edward's secretary in response to a congratulatory message sent on Saturday, the King's birthday and the occasion of the club's annual dinner at Delmonico's. The message was dated Sandringham:

Columbia's fencing men have begun an agitation for the formation of an intercollegiate association. Harvard, Pennsylvania, Cornell, Yale, and Annapolis are the others said to be interested in the scheme.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The programme for the National Reciprocity Convention at Washington next week was made public to-day by President Theodore C. Search of the National Association of Manufacturers, who is Chairman of the Committee on Arrangements for the convention. The programme is subject to such changes as might suggest themselves during the progress of the meeting.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 11 -- Two more of the twenty-six convicts who escaped from the Federal Prison at Fort Leavenworth Thursday last were recaptured to-day. One is Frank Thompson, a negro, who was the leader of the mutiny. The other convict is Lawrence Lewis, a white boy, twenty years of age.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Sir Franklin Lushington, Chief Police Magistrate for London, died yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11.-- The Census Office to-day issued a statement, giving the status of the manufacturing industries of the State of Connecticut for the census year of 1900, and making comparisons extending back to 1850. The table shows a steady growth for all those years.

Richard Mayo Smith, forty-seven years old, of 305 West Seventy-seventh Street, a professor of political economy in Columbia University, was killed last night on the stone flagging in the rear of his residence after a fan of four stories. Prof. Smith fell or jumped from one of his study windows. Whether it was suicide or accident no one can tell.

Mrs. Vencedora Chartrand of Hoboken, who is still held at the Hudson County Jail, Jersey City, on charge of murdering her husband, John Chartrand, whom she contends she shot accidentally on Oct. 30, was yesterday identified by William Noelte, the Hoboken gunsmith, as the woman to whom he sold the pistol used by Mrs. Chartrand.

Invitations to the number of 750 have been sent out for the dinner to be given on Thursday evening at the Madison Square Concert Hall by the City Club in honor of the successful Fusion candidates for city, county, and borough offices.

If it is possible to maintain in this city a municipal political organization not based upon any idea of "graft," the attempt is to be made by the Citizens' Union. This was decided upon at a full meeting of the City Committee of the union held at tho organization's headquarters in Union Square last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- The more cheerful feeling in New York found reflection in the market here, particularly for the coal stocks. Enormous absorptions of all the Readings emanating from Wall Street acted as a tonic and braced the whole list. Lehigh Valley followed closely. The most important advance, however, was in the Choctaws, the common rising 2 3/4 and the preferred 2 1/4.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Your reply this morning to my canteen inquiries hardly covers the questions at issue. It may be impracticable to shut the men up in camp, but this only brings up again the point I raised, whether the canteen did not really offer all the "fire water," whisky, and the rest, that the soldiers crave.

Justice O'Gormman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, denied the application made by counsel for Deputy Police Commissioner Devery for a permanent writ of prohibition restraining Justice Jerome from hearing the charges of neglect of duty and oppression preferred against him by the District Attorney upon the complaint of Policeman Edward O'Neill.

In the effort to secure a reasonable Sunday opening law for this city, it will be well to proceed carefully and considerately, recognizing the numerous difficulties in the way, and the perfectly honest and conscientious opposition which it will be necessary to overcome. The only way in which opposition of that character can be met is by demonstrating that the measure we advocate will actually lessen the evils which the opponents fear and condemn.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Nov. 11 -- The following facts have been ascertained, regarding the case of Newell C. Rathbun, whose alleged sudden and mysterious death here are being investigate by life insurance representatives and the authorities at Little Rock. Ark.:

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 11 -- Gov. Beckham to-night addressed to Gov. Durbin of Indiana, a letter replying to the criticism by that Executive, of the courts and officials of Kentucky in his recent letter refusing to honor the requisition for Taylor and Finley, wanted for alleged complicity in the assassination of William Goebel.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent., and was in good supply. New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $18,133,556; balances, $1,372,395.

Casimir, the old, white-mustached waiter of the Maison d'Or, has left, after forty years' service. He entered contemporaneously with the extension of the privileges of the Corps Legislatif in 1861, and heard all the fine people who came to dine and sup speak of that measure as the beginning of the end of imperial France, which, perhaps, it was.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 -- The market was less active to-day, but was fairly firm. Seaboard common and preferred were both higher, while the 4s lost an 1/8, though the tone on this was better at the close. Knoxville tractions made a bound of 5 3/4, being a legitimate recovery from an abnormally depressed price.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 11 -- The body shipped here from Jeffersonville, Ind., as that of Newell C. Rathbun was to have been buried yesterday at Oakland Cemetery, but S.M. Powell, State agent for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who declared that it was not that of Rathbun, induced the undertaker to wait until to-day, and last night placed in the hands of the Sheriff his proof.

In the American National bowling tournament last night, the Rosedale Bowling Club team made a score of 1,050, Hahnenfeldt making 241. In the second game, Westberg of the Newburg Wheelmen rolled 277, which is within one pin of the highest score recorded on the alley. The scores:

To the Editor of The New York Times. Your editorial on the "District Leader" is wise and opportune in its warning that reformers can retain power permanently only by "showing kindness to many people." The Tammany henchman must be supplanted as "the friend of all the world."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 11 -- The company is formed by the John W. Gates syndicate, and will control railroad lines in Missouri and Kansas. J. W. Gates and associates bought the old Kansas City Northern connecting line from Kansas City to Pattonsburg, Mo., when it was sold under foreclosure of mortgage recently.

One of the chief improvements incident to the installment of electricity on the Manhattan Elevated Railroad's system will be the new One Hundred and Tenth Street station, which will be at Manhattan Avenue, on the great curve from Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Ninth Street to Eighth Avenue and One Hundred and Eleventh Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The experience of one signing herself "A Practical Woman," as related in the people's column of THE TIMES of the 7th inst. is an interesting contribution to the literature of Socialism.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 11 -- Delivering his annual address before the Wardens' Association at the annual congress here to-day of the National Prison Assocation, Otis Fuller, President of the association and Superintendent of the Michigan Reformatory, said:

Such delightful enameled steelware is to be found that it is almost a shame to waste money upon china. One can hardly object to having an enameled coffee pot upon the table when it is in this soft blue enamel on the outside and a beautiful clean white on the inside. It is all imported ware, made without seams.

There is something peculiarly interesting and significant in the fact that in Boston last Saturday the subject of our trade relations was discussed before the free trade organization and before the Middlesex Club by two Republicans and protectionists, and in both cases reciprocity in principle was strongly sus- tamed.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Nov. 11 -- Santiago Iglesias was arrested here last Thursday on landing from the Red "D" Line steamer Philadelphia from New York. His detention was due to his non-appearance after having been thrice summoned by the local courts to appear in a case against him and seven others brought in July of last year when the currency was changed.

The Phi Delta Phi Club celebrated its annual dinner last night at the Hotel Marlborough. The feature of the evening was the speech of Prof. Isaac Franklin Russell. At its conclusion Charles Thaddeus Terry of Columbia University, the President of the club, stated that he believed the professor had been perhaps pointing more particularly to certain truths, rather than stating a belief in the impossibility of any betterment in the world.

Mayor-elect Seth Low arrived in this city yesterday morning from Great Barrington. Mass., where he had been playing golf and otherwise seeking recreation since the day following the election. He said he had had a fine rest, and that he felt in good shape to take up the work of preparing for the new administration of the city's affairs.

The police have discovered that an organized gang of robbers is making a specialty of stealing trunks and baggage in this city. They know little more than this, although every police station in the city has on its books the instructions for the men to watch for trunk robbers.

BANGOR, Nov. 11 -- Several large transactions in Maine timber lands within the past few months illustrate how that class of property is increasing in value. Liewellyn Powers of Houlton, ex-Governor of Maine, and now Representative in Congress for the Fourth District of the State, owned until recently 137,000 acres of timber lands.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,5OO and is under $3,OOO. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,OOO.

The monthly conference of the Episcopal Clergy of the city was held yesterday afternoon, in the Church Missions House, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. E. Walpole Warren presided during the first part of the meeting, and the Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Parks followed him later, the former having been called away.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit an old reader of THE TIMES a small space in your valued columus to reply to Mr. C.M. Lindsay's communication in yesterday's edition, in which he seems more solicitous of the name of the Protestant Episcopal Church than what it stands for and really is.

SOFIA, Nov. 11.-- From another letter that has been received from Miss Ellen M. Stone, the abducted American missionary, it appears that she is enduring the trials or her hard experience with fortitude, forgetting herself in her anxiety for her companion, Mme. Tsilka.

"Jake" Schaefer, George Slosson, and Barutel, the Frenchman, all played matches yesterday to get in form for the billiard championship tournament at eighteen-inch balk line. In his game with the Spanish player, Ortiz, at Slosson Wheelock's Academy, in the afternoon, Schaefer made a run of 126 and averaged 23 1-13.

A fire which was productive of much more than the usual amount of excitement occurred at 9 o'clock yesterday morning in the Planet Mills, which occupy the greater part of the block bounded by Carroll, President, Hoyt, and Smith Streets, Brooklyn. Four firemen were overcome by smoke and a number of girls who were at work on the top floor were thrown into a panic.

The Fox Hills Club of Staten Island has announced that it will hold its annual tournament for the championship of the club on Thanksgiving Day. The match will be thirty-six holes, medal play, and the winner will hold the gold medal given a few years ago by George E. Armstrong.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The campaign of the Fusionists just over lacked nothing in eulogy, but possibly a good deal in discrimination. The cry of "Vice, vice!" (limiting the word to one particular kind of vice,) has been repeated in speech and writing by orator and pamphleteer from the pulpit and cart, by missionaries, male and female, with iteration almost wearisome.

In St. Chrysostom's Chapel, Trinity Parish, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, last night, there was a meeting of the Church Association for the Advancement of the Interests of Labor. Vigorous action in seeing that the law providing light and air through the reconstruction of tenements, no matter what the cost to the owners; municipal ownership of tenements and the end of child labor in the South were urged by the speakers.

Edward Louis Donaldson, Assistant Treasurer, and by inheritance, part owner of the London Theatre, and a well-known character along the Bowery where that playhouse is situated, died yesterday at his home, 47 Seventh Street, of pneumonia, after more adventures than fall to the ordinary lot in his lifetime of thirty-four years.

Pretty little corset covers are made of entre deux, lingerie ribbon which will wash, an inch wide and with lace of the same wilth. These waists come in pretty shades of pale blue, pink, and lavender. They cost $6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- All the favorites were beaten at to-day's races at Bennings. The track was fast, despite a heavy rain that fell through the day.
