Jockey Martin, who rode O'Hagan in the fourth event, was suspended a week for having 4 1/2 pounds overweight, but his horse, the winner of the race, was not disqualified, under a recent ruling of the Jockey Club.

H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, said last night that there was no truth in the recent persistent rumors connecting the rise in Metropolitan stocks with a revival of the story that it had secured control of Brooklyn Rapid Transit, but that the rise was directly due to the result of the election.

Aurel Batonyi, the whip and owner of the coach Good Times, has brought suit against James W. Bell, the tailor, of 372 Fifth Avenue, to recover $2,000 for damages which he claims were inflicted upon his coach and two horses in a collision on April 14 last In Central Park, between the Good Times and a team driven by Mr. Bell.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The report of the Board of Visitors to West Point devotes some space to the painful features of life at the Academy. In recommending the building of a new chapel the board says:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12 -- Yale has decided not to play her giant freshman guard, Glass, because of his ineligibility according to the strict wording of the Yale rules. Announcement of this was made to-night by Manager Francis for Capt. Gould:

Edward B. Amend, the Chairman of the Executive Committee of the German-American Reform Union, is the candidate of that organization for Corporation Counsel. Mr. Amend is a brother-in-law of Herman Ridder. The Republican organization is urging Julius M. Mayer, the head of the Law Committee of the Republican County Committee, for the place.

PRINCETON, Nov. 12 -- The Princeton University basket ball schedule for this Winter has been completed. The plans of the team are more extensive than ever before. Candidates for places on the team will be called out immediately after the closing of the football season, and will be in good shape for the opening games.

With the Post-Brown wedding and several others, with the dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. R.T. Wilson for their daughter, Mrs. Michael Herbert, who soon sails for Europe, and several lesser town events, and with the suburban affairs at Meadow Brook and Tuxedo, there was a great deal of gayety yesterday.

Nichols Lummis have sold for the Somerset Land Company a tract of land on Mine Mountain, at Bernardsville, N.J., upon which the buyer will erect a country mansion. The site sold is nearly 1,000 feet above sea level, and contains about 100 acres of land overlooking the Somerset Inn and the homes of the Stevens family of Hoboken.

WASHINGTOIN, Nov. 12 -- The President to-day announced the following appointments: Joseph A. Craft to be Internal Revenue Collector in the Fifth District, Kentucky, and of George W. Lieberth to be Internal Revenue Collector in the Sixth District of the same State.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 12 -- At the Douglas Park race, track to-day Bad Penny, a colt represented to be three years old, by Tenny-Lizzie Flynn, and to be owned by F.L. Schleith of Asbury Park, N.J., was the medium of the most sensational betting coup of the season in the West. Bad Penny, trained by "Bill" Spirling, was ridden to-day by Jockey Charlie Murphy.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- Emperor William has acceded to the oft-repeated request of Count von Hatzfeidt-Wildenburg, the German Ambassador to Great Britain, that he be allowed to retire from the diplomatic service because of ill-health.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12 -- The sale of St. Maxim and the extraordinary number of mares purchased by the Breeders' Protective Association were the features of the closing day of the Fasig-Tipton thoroughbred sales. The average was low, as the Breeders' Association bought thirty-six of the seventy-nine head offered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The death of Col. John W. French, which occurred at Atlanta yesterday, will promote Lieut. Col. James Miller to be Colonel, Major F.W. Mansfield to be Lieutenant Colonel, and Capt. James B. Jackson to be Major.

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 12 -- All the leading ship owners who do business by the St. Lawrence route waited on the members of the Canadian Government to-day in the Premier's office and presented a petition asking for the improvement of the channel so that insurance rates might be lowered. It was pointed out by Mr. Reford that it cost $5,000 more a vessel for insurance by the St. Lawrence than by New York or Boston.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The conference to discuss the abolition of the sugar bounties, says the Brussels correspondent of The Times, has been definitely fixed for Dec. 15.

One of the laborers in the Rapid Transit Tunnel, while at work near Duane and Centre Streets yesterday afternoon, fell from a brace to the bottom of the tunnel, breaking his back. The man was alive after the fall, and did not seem to be dangerously hurt.

Mayor-elect Seth Low will go to Albany to-day to pay his respects to Gov. Odell and to talk over with the Governor many of the questions of policy with which he will have to deal during his administration. Mr. Low said last evening that he expected to take the train which leaves the Grand Central Station at 8:30 and return by the Empire State Express in the evening.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of to-day on the United States Steel Corporation and prices is interesting, but in one respect it is difficult to understand.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- On a charge of contempt of court Judge Hanecy to-day sentenced Andrew M. Lawrence, managing editor of Hearst's Chicago American, to forty days in the County jail. The sentence of H.S. Canfield, who wrote the article objectionable to the court, was fixed at thirty days in jail.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 12 -- A letter, 200 years old, from Capt. Kidd, the pirate chief, to John Bailey, Esq., of New York, which, from evidence contained in it, is believed to be genuine by those to whom it has become an heirloom, has been deposited for safe keeping in the office of the Record Commissioners of this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Charles N. Wilkinson, a member of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange of New York, whose home is at Westfield, is the defendant in a suit for limited divorce brought by his wife, Edith K. Wilkinson, who also claims alimony and the custody of their two-and-a-half-year-old boy.

The thirtieth annual meeting of St. John's Guild was held last evening at the Berkeley Lyceum, in West Forty-fourth Street. A general review of the work of the past year appeared in the reports of the various officers.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Wiring from Han-Kow, the Peking correspondent of The Times says the normal peaceful conditions have been resumed in the Yang-tse Valley.

Business in the outside market yesterday continued active and transactions were fairly well distributed throughout the list. The sales in the copper stocks were once more unusually heavy, although the total was not quite as large as on Monday. To some extent the reactionary movement which occurred on the Stock Exchange was felt also in the outside market, but in few cases were the declines sufficiently heavy to suggest weakness.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- Justice Gummere of the Supreme Court has given a decision which affects the exemption of property used by churches. It has additional interest because the property concerned is Bonaparte Park, the home during his period of exile of Joseph Bonaparte, King of Naples and of Spain.

Imagine a gun forty-four feet long, a foot and a half Interior diameter, and weighing sixty tons, the largest modern gun ever built, and which will hurl a mass of metal seven feet long and a ton in weight through the air at the enormous velocity of 2,000 feet a second, or more than twenty times the speed of the swiftest railway train in existence to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Terrific storms, attended with much loss of life and resulting in a great number of disasters to shipping, are reported from all parts of the United Kingdom Various coast towns have been badly damaged. The gale is still raging this morning unabated. Reports of shipping casualties are continually arriving.

The State Railroad Commission yesterday resumed the hearing at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on the application of the New York and Portchester Railway Company for permission to construct a four-track electric railroad between New York and Portchester.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 12 -- To-night at Jacob's Theatre, Kathryn Kidder produced Glen MacDonough's new comedy drama, "Molly Pitcher," in the presence of a large audience that included Gov. Voorhees and the Governor-elect, Franklin Murphy. The story of the play takes Molly Pitcher from Carlisle to Philadelphia, while the British occupied that city, and ends with the battle at Monmouth, N.J.

At a midnight meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club at Sherry's last night, Mrs. Minnie Maddern Fiske delivered an address on "The Influence of the So-called Theatrical Trust Upon the American Drama."

The will of William Jauncey Cruger, nephew of the late S. Van Rensselaer Cruger, who died in France, by which he left a large estate to his wife, Mary Fambrough Cruger, with the exception of a number of ten-dollar bequests to his brother, James Pendleton Cruger, and to a number of nephews and nieces, was admitted to probate yesterday by Surrogate Thomas.

A team of big gray horses, attached to a heavy delivery wagon, last night ran uncontrolled down Fifth Avenue from Thirty-ninth Street to Thirty-fourth Street, upsetting in their mad flight two hansom cabs and running into a Thirty-fourth Street crosstown street car before they were stopped in front of the Waldorf-Astoria by Bicycle Policeman Shea.
The Charity Organization Society appeals for assistance in the following cases:

On Third Avenue, one of the most populous thoroughfares of this city, at a little after 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon -- a time of day when the streets are usually filled with people -- two thieves locked the front door of a jewelry store, broke a plate glass window, and attempted to get away with a tray containing diamonds said to be worth more than $2,000.

Concentration is the order of the day in commerce and trade, while politics itself appears to stand in the sign of fusion, so that it is not unnatural for the artists to draw together, waive old rancors, and debate the question whether co-operation would not in the long run help their cause.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A consignment of trotting-bred horses from the Caton Stock Farm, at Joltet, Ill., was sold at Dexter Park pavilion to-day. The sales included:

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Money was in good demand to-day, owing to the preparations for the settlement and as a result of the Treasury bills' allotment. The firmness of Continental exchanges weakened discounts.

State Game Protector John E. Overton has seized two packages of partridges which he says were being illegally shipped to New York in an express car of the Long Island Railroad. He says that one was from Wading River and the other from Smithtown. He says he also seized three partridges that were being taken to the city over the main line of the road by a newsboy named Anderson.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The President to-day made the following naval appointments: John H. Shipley, Lieutenant Commander; Robert M. Kennedy, Surgeon, and Rudolph C. Mehrtens, boatswain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the note from Greenwich on "Cause for Thanksgiving," "F.M.B." is probably in error in suggesting that Tammany smiled over the stupidity of anti-Tammany in presenting two candidates against Van Wyck four years ago. Without a doubt Tammany smiled, but not at the stupidity of its enemies.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $25,060,980; balances, $2,033,211.

A debate regarding reforms to be accomplished by the incoming municipal administration took place last evening between members of the Social Reform Club at its rooms, 128 East Twenty-eighth Street. The principal speaker of the evening was James W. Pryor, who said that there had recently grown up in New York "a certain political sub-consciousness" which made the success of the Fusion ticket in the late election more timely than it otherwise would have been.
New York and Southern capital has undertaken a plan for the establishment of a large shipbuilding plant and the construction of a dry dock on the Gulf coast.

ALBANY, Nov. 12 -- Edward M. Shepard, Democratic candidate for Mayor of Greater New York, to-day certified to the Secretary of State that his expenses in the late municipal contest were $3,309.06. The expenses included the following:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- In the stock market to-day Union Traction made a sharp advance on heavy buying, reaching 29 1/2. Philadelphia Traction, in sympathy, was fractionally higher. The Readings were up on good buying by interests that for some time have been taking the stock. Reading general mortgage fours were especially strong, going to within a quarter of par.

Practically the first reaction that the stock market has had since the upward movement in prices began more than a week ago manifested itself in the final hour of trading yesterday when, under the pressure of heavy realizing and selling for the short account, prices sagged off quite generally, with declines for from one to two points the rule rather than the exception.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 12 -- There is a quiet movement on foot among military men in the State to have Gov. Murphy, when he assumes office in January, order a reorganization of the National Guard in this State.

SOFIA, Nov. 12 -- Consul General Dickinson of Constantinople to-day supplemented his verbal representations to the Bulgarian Government by a note in which he recapitulated the history of the abduction of Miss Ellen M. Stone and her companion and the steps taken to obtain their release, and reminded the Foreign Minister of his promise to give every assistance.

Secret practice on wet fields constituted most of the football activity yesterday by those teams upon which the major portion of attention will be concentrated next Saturday. The coaches of both the Yale and Princeton elevens kept the practice hour carefully guarded and no one who was not intimately connected with the team was allowed within the gates.

It looks now as if the policy adopted by the late President McKINLEY and Secretary HAY of consulting the members of the Senate in regard to the important canal treaty would be crowned with success. The tone of the remarks of Senator CABOT LODGE at Boston on Saturday clearly indicated this result.

Alice Washington Fairchild, who is about sixty-five years old, and a third cousin once removed of George Washington, appeared yesterday as a pauper before Superintendent George Blair of the Outdoor Poor Department of the Department of Public Charities, and was sent to the almshouse.

The first meeting of the Board of Aldermen since election resulted in the clashing of factions several times. Tammany Hall members were arrayed against the Republican and Citizens' Union men, and the latter, although in the minority, won. Notice was served by the Republican leaders of the board that all plans for appropriating large sums of money would be obstructed until Mayor Low's appointees have a chance to pass on such matters.

The first meeting of the Board of Aldermen since election resulted in the clashing of factions several times. Tammany Hall members were arrayed against the Republican and Citizens' Union men, and the latter, although in the minority, won. Notice was served by the Republican leaders of the board that all plans for appropriating large sums of money would be obstructed until Mayor Low's appointees have a chance to pass on such matters.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- On the eve of the trial of the action to recover $10,000 damages for slander, brought by Superintendent of Schools Edwin S. Harris against Mrs. Emily Collins, wife of School Commissioner Collins, the announcement is made that the suit has been discontinued, Mrs. Collins having signed a statement retracting all that she said.
The Warren Wheelmen have taken the place of the Twenty-sixth Ward Wheelmen in the bowline tournament of the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island.

Bernard H. Kroger, who made a fortune in Cincinnati selling bread at half the regular price a loaf, is in New York planning to cut the rate for the standard loaf in half and at a profit to himself. Mr. Kroger was seen at the Waldorf Astoria last night, and said to a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES:
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Money was in increased demand to-day in connection with the settlement. The short supply hardened discounts. The bank apparently was borrowing.

The incorporation of the Northern Securities Company yesterday is the closing chapter in one of the most extraordinary contests in the history of the financial world. From what has been made public from time to time by the parties themselves and from what has leaked out, the events which led to yesterday's treaty of peace appear to have been something like this:

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Much alarm has been caused here by the fact that a number of cases of lockjaw have been reported which are said to have resulted from vaccination. T.B. Hazelton, eighteen years old, died this morning, and Lillian Carty, eighteen years old, and Walter Bower, fifteen years old, are reported to be in a critical condition.

The fifth annual session of the National Founders' Association began at the Gilsey House yesterday, and will be continued to-day. The body has a membership of about 400, and more than 300 were present.

Deputy Sheriff Murray has received three executions aggregating $1,437 against James H. Havens, who did business as James H. Havens Sons, builders and lumber dealers at Fifty-sixth Street and Eleventh Avenue, in favor of the following creditors: L. Thomson Co., $783; Shepard Morse Lumber Company, $334, and R.R. Sizer, $320.

Mayor-elect Seth Low returned to the city last night from his visit to Albany, whither he went to pay his respects to Gov. Odell and have a general talk with the Governor about city affairs. Mr. Low arrived at the Grand Central Station at 9 o'clock on the Chicago Limited. His train was half an hour late.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Miss Vanderbilt Wackerman of New York was taken to St. Giles's Infirmary yesterday as a wandering lunatic. She will probably be examined to-day.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, Secretary of State for War, speaking last evening at a banquet given in London in his honor by the City Carlton Club, declared that the Boers were hiding their tracks by murdering Kafirs behind them. He said:

The State Railroad Commission, in session at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, continued the consideration of the application of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company for a certificate authorizing the construction of a four-track electric railway between this city and Port Chester, a distance of about thirty miles.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is repaired for each $300 consideration over $3,000.

Ten delegates from the New York Board of Trade and Transportation are to go to the Commercial Reciprocity Convention, which will be held in Washington on Nov. 19 and will be composed of "manufacturers properly accredited as delegates by trade and commercial organizations."

SOFIA, Nov. 13 -- The Bulgarian officials disclaim any intention of interfering with Consul General Dickinson's private negotiations for the release of Miss Ellen M. Stone. They decline, however, to become a party to an agreement allowing brigands or the emissaries of brigands to come into Bulgarian territory to treat for the ransom of persons captured in a neighboring State.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Mrs. William F. Acker of 77 Lincoln Park, this city, wife of a New York business man, plunged down an elevator shaft in a department store this afternoon to death. Mrs. Acker was a handsome young blonde. She went out shopping this afternoon and spent the time in the stores along Broad Street.

-- Domestic fowls being excellent food n the opinion of all except the vegetarian and otherwise negligible fraction of humanity, it is necessary that the first tragical operation in the series that ends at the table should be performed, and therefore the people who as a mater of business take the lives of poultry are not, and should not be, either derided or scorned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Orders were issued by the War Department to-day directing seven troops of the Fifteenth Cavalry, now in the Department of California, to sail for the Philippines on the Hancock about Dec. 10.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 -- Renewed reports in financial circles attribute to the Standard Oil group the purpose to establish a large trust company here, which will do a banking business and provide means for financing large American undertakings, these being continually growing in importance.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Columbus Gottschalk, a lawyer, died some time last night at the Continental Hotel, Broad Street, this city Manager Charles J. Coon of the hotel notified County Physician Washington, who made a thorough examination of the body and the room, which failed to reveal any cause for death.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed own a decision to-day in favor of Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, N.G.N.Y., in the legal proceedings, which he instituted to prevent the carrying out of the order ousting him from the National Guard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Three favorites, Cousin Jess, Royal Sterling, and Satire, won at Bennings to-day. In the fifth race Knight of Rhodes, with Burns up, was a strongly played favorite. When the start was made Wonderly, who was on Carbuncle, and Burns were both caught in the barrier and, lashed together as they were, raced in this manner for some distance.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13 -- Ex-Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge, in a speech made here Tuesday night, aroused the anger of delegates to the Kentucky Federation of Labor now assembled in convention in this city, by the sentimens he expressed. At a turbulent meeting held this afternoon the federation adopted resolutions denouncing Col. Breckinridge.

Guests of the Astor House were last evening much alarmed when several pieces of fire apparatus drew up alongside of the Barclay Street entrance to the hotel. The pungent odor of burning paper and wood added to their alarm, until Policeman Ryan of the Church Street Station informed the patrons that the fire was not in the hotel.

BOSTON, Nov. 13, -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 per cent., and was in good supply at that figure. Exchanges, $24,373,628; balances, $2,043,453. New York funds were in good demand, with sales at par and 5 cents premium for cash, mostly 5 cents premium.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Bishop William Croswell Doane, in his address to the annual convention of his diocese this morning, took occasion to summarize the recommendations of the Triennial Conference and urges the preaching in public of these things:

The poolrooms in Queens Borough were deserted yesterday. The crap games had no players last night. It had become known that Borough President Bowley had constituted himself a vice committee of one, and private detectives had been gathering evidence against the various places which have been violating the law.
Discussing the iron and steel situation, The Iron Age will to-day say:

Major J.B. Pond, the industrious manager of lecturers, has a musical attraction which he expects will arouse much interest here. This is a musical prodigy, a lad of nine years, named Plorizel Reuter. He is a native of Davenport, Iowa, and is a protege of Secretary Gage of the Treasury. The boy studied for a year or so with Sauret and is now under the capable guidance of Henri Marteau.

Billiardists had more than one game of interest to watch last night, and the increased number of spectators in the different billiard academies where the masters of the cue are practicing in preparation for the coming championship tourney in Madison Square Garden, illustrates the firm hold that good billiards has upon its devotees when there is an opportunity of seeing it exemplified.

ITHACA, Nov. 13 -- The attention of the members of the Faculty of Cornell University was directed to-day to the publication of a special dispatch from Ithaca in to-day's NEW YORK TIMES relative to the appointment by President Schurman or a committee on student conduct. The correspondent stated in the dispatch that "frequent cases of intoxication and immorality among the students" had forced the Faculty to take action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A distinguished body representing the commercial organizations of New York, Boston, Buffalo, Pittsburg, Cleveland, Indianapolis, and Cincinnati called upon the President to-day to urge the importance of reciprocity with Canada.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The report that the famous Hope blue diamond is going to New York is correct. It is in the possession of a member of a New York firm now on his way to America from London. The heirloom was sold by order of the Master in Chancery.

At a meeting of the Park Avenue Property Owners' Association held last night at 700 Park Avenue, war was declared on the New York Central Railroad and a motion was passed to compel the railroad to make the tunnel alterations as the residents on the avenue demand, namely, to substitute electric power for steam power in its tunnel.
The proposed change in the present excise law has aroused considerable discussion in Brooklyn.

Nine converts to the teachings of the "Holy Ghost and Us" Society were received in the new order yesterday afternoon. They were baptized in the waters of the New York Bay at the foot of Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn. At the time of the baptism of the converts a strong northwest wind was blowing and the temperature of the water was but little above freezing.
C.R. Stouffer has been appointed Chicago manager of the Royal Insurance Company.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The big whistle on the Sing Sing State prison sounded this evening, about 8 o'clock, and the alarm caused a general rush to the prison walls in expectation of witnessing a fire. The alarm was for a prisoner who had escaped. It is some time now since a prisoner got away, and the sound of the whistle for this purpose had become unusual.

Henry Corn has bought from the Van Rensselaer estate, through Frederick Southack and Alwyn Ball, Jr., for about $300,000, the five-story buildings 476 Broadway, running through to 38 Crosby Street, about 123 feet south of Broome Street. The property has frontages of 50 feet on Broadway and 23 feet on Crosby Street, and will be improved by Mr. Corn with a twelve-story store and loft building, costing in the neighborhood of $400,000.

The dream of all who have delved into the romances of the astronomers "touchin' on and appertainin' to" the wonderful planet Mars, of establishing communication with it by means of luminous or other signals and getting replies, does not receive much encouragement from those who take astronomy seriously and are more practical than imaginative.

At the annual meeting of stockholders of the Manhattan Railway Company yesterday the annual report for the year ended Sept. 30 last was submitted. The report is one of the most favorable ever issued. The statement of earnings shows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The team of horses purchased for President Roosevelt in Baltimore yesterday has arrived at the White House stables. The President is much pleased with their appearance. They are fine, high-stepping, stylish-looking animals, and fulfill the President's idea of a carriage team.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 13 -- The mystery of two murders near this city yesterday remains unsolved. The fact that both of the victims were women, that both were killed in the same manner, and evidently by the same person, adds to the mystery. What possible motive existed for either crime no one is able to explain.

INJURED BY ELECTRIC SHOCK. -- A judgment for the plaintiff in an action brought by Mary A. Buckbee against the Third Avenue Railroad Company to recover damages for personal injuries which Mrs. Buckbee claimed she sustained in consequence of an electric shock has been affirmed by the Second Appellate Division.

With the incorporation in Trenton yesterday of a four-hundred-million-dollar security-holding company the famous Northern Pacific fight has at last come to an end. The effect of this arrangement will be felt in London, Paris, and Berlin scarcely less than in this country. The interests involved are of almost unparalleled magnitude.
White silk linings of black long coats for women have rows of black velvet ribbon stitched down the front edges for ornamentation.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 7 -- The following are details of the capture by the insurgents of the steamship Darien, belonging to the Government, which was recently purchased from the Darien Gold Mining Company at Panama:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Colombian Government is making an earnest effort, and in an interesting way, to solve the troubles which have arisen in its executive branch. The first official act of a new Colombian Congress is to appoint a "designado," an official who succeeds to the Presidency upon the retirement of both the President and Vice President.

The question of the Manhattan approach to the new East River Bridge was the subject of a spirited discussion before the Board of Public Improvements yesterday. Controller-elect Edward M. Grout and Commissioner of Bridges John L. Shea exchanged compliments during the discussion. A report was presented by Commissioner Shea recommending the widening of Delancey Street, from the present terminal of the bridge to the Bowery.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The demoralization of the ticker service, caused by yesterday's conduit explosion, placed brokers in a quandary to-day and somewhat affected business on the stock market. The movement of business was small. Changes were all of a fractional order, some stocks higher and others below those of yesterday.

It should not be difficult to settle beyond opportunity for dispute the question now agitating the officials of Brooklyn, as to whether the representatives of the Health Department in that borough properly performed or utterly neglected their duty in the matter of the disinfection of the classroom of the Hancock Street public school in which diphtheria brought down one victim after another in quick succession.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The gale which has been sweeping over the United Kingdom for the past two days continues unabated at many coast points. Over the Welsh lowlands the torrential rains are increasing, causing disastrous floods. Reports of wrecks and casualties continue to flow in.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The Schenectady Baseball Association to-day signed Lew Whistler of St. Louis to manage and Captain its 1902 State League team for this city.

ROLLIN M. DAGGETT, a pioneer journalist of the Pacific Coast, ex-member of Congress from Nevada, and United States Minister to Hawaii under the Garfield Administration, is dead in San Francisco. He was seventy years old.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The Schenectady Baseball Association to-day signed Lew Whistler of St. Louis to manage and Captain its 1902 State League team for this city.

-- Those who are always right about everything -- we can speak for them confidently, having learned only too well that infallibility and happiness are not interchangeable terms -- will read with feelings of bitter and hopeless envy some editorial remarks made by Harper's Weekly in regard to the conduct of the Schley inquiry.

The Woman's Art Club of New York is holding its annual exhibition in Autumn, as it did two years ago, and in the same place, by courtesy of the Arts Club, in the galleries, 37 and 39 West Thirty-fourth Street. About sixty oils, pastels, and water colors comprise the show, together with some leather and burned wood pieces by Miss Harriet Keith Fobes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago, in the course of conversation with a lady connected with several well-known families of the South, I alluded to the remarkable fact in connection with the civil war that while Southern men were away from home at the field of strife the women and children were left to the care and protection of those in bondage.

Horgan Slattery, Tammany architects, are having a hard job trying to superintend the work of Contractor John Pierce on the new Hall of Records. Mayor Van Wyck forced through the Board of Estimate the resolution appointing Horgan Slattery architects a few days after the death of John R. Thomas, who spent the last years of his life in the work of making the Hall of Records a monument of his architectural ability.

BASIC CITY, Va., Nov. 14 -- The most important social event in Virginia for many years was the marriage to-day of Miss Phyllis Langhorne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chiswell Dabney Langhorne of Mirado, Albemarle County, to Reginald Brooks of New York City. The Brandon, in this city, was the scene of this wedding, as Mirado, the home of the bride's parents, was inadequate to accommodate the hundreds of guests.

Billiards continued lively last night in the various academies, where practice games are in progress for the coming billlard championship, which will open in Madison Square Garden on Dec. 2. There were some surprises among the big men, for some of the lesser lights who have been acting as runners-up for the last few nights ceased to remain at second best and came out on top.

SCHENECTADY, Nov. 14 -- There is a deadlock in the Common Council of this city and from present appearances it may last until the first of the year, when the Republican administration will assume the reins of municipal government.

Judge Adams of the United States District Court has granted discharges in bankruptcy to Samuel J. Hart of 7 West Ninety-second Street and to Helen H. Hart, his sister, on the application of Hays Hershfield, their attorneys. The case is the only one of its kind filed in this city under the present Bankruptcy act.

The excise pot was boiling at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. At the close of the day the consensus of opinion among the Republican loaders seemed, to be summed up in the sententious remark of one of them: "The people of New York may get up as much steam as they want over this proposition, but its power will not be felt above the Harlem River."
Not only were there politicians of all parties at the City Club's dinner, as well as clergymen, but the society representation in the boxes was large.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- The Philadelphia National League Baseball Club has appealed to the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania to review the record of the lower court and set aside on reverse the verdict of the latter court in the case of Napoleon Lajoie. The case was decided in Lajoie's favor in May last.

The National Founders' Association at their session at the Gilsey House yesterday first discussed the question, "Have contracts with individual employes proved of value?" This was debated by W.B. Butterworth of Moline, Ill., J.W. Adams of Minneapolis, and others, and the consensus of opinion was that the proposition was exceedingly desirable.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Republican here are somewhat exercised on account of the Postmastership. Quay adherents express confidence that Postmaster Hicks, whose term expires soon, will be succeeded by a man of Senator Quay's selection. On the other hand, insurgent Republicans believe that President Roosevelt will allow Postmaster General Smith a voice in naming the man.

The residence of J.A. Burden, Jr., 8 East Sixty-ninth Street, a four-story stone-front dwelling, has been sold through S. Osgood Pell. The house is one of the finest in the upper Fifth Avenue section, having a frontage of 55 feet, the lot being 100 feet deep on the easterly side and 145 feet on the westerly side.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- The chief interest in the stock market to-day was in Reading common. There were large dealings, both for local and New York account, but the weakness in Wall Street told upon the shares, which gradually eased off 7 1-16, regaining the loss in the last half hour.

From The Troy Press, Nov. 6. A clean and incorruptible standard bearer, Seymour Van Santvoord's character is undimmed by defeat. Brilliantly he exemplified an oratorical power and a mastery of logic equaled by few men even in this great and populous Commonwealth, and his political opponents as well as supporters give him credit for a high order of ability.

Mayor Van Wyck made a statement yesterday at the meeting of the Board of Estimate about the action of the city officials in making up the budget and transferring city employes in the different departments. After Deputy Controller Levey had read the section of the charter authorizing the transfers, Mayor Van Wyck said:

Golf on local links will show considerable activity to-morrow. The day will be one of the last big competitive days of the season, although with good weather Thanksgiving Day will witness the customary large outpouring of devotees of the game to metropolitan links. Already most of the clubs are getting up special attractions for Thanksgiving, and its golf features will, in great part, be similar to the Election Day events.

The demand of Street Cleaning Commissioner NAGLE for an additional appropriation of $180,000, to be expended for steel carts, horses, whips, cart covers, garbage crematories, and the like, is a characteristic impertinence on the part of an official with an unexpended credit of $72,000 available for purposes actually necessary, and only about forty-five days probable tenure of the office in which he has done much harm and little good.

There were several weddings yesterday of note. The nuptials of Miss Phyllis Langhorne and Reginald Brooks, at Basic City, Va., were witnessed by a number of New Yorkers. Miss Leonie De Bary and George Dillwyn Cross were married at Summit, in the presence of a large and fashionable gathering.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says a private letter received from Tabriz, Persia, points out the increasing weakness of British influence in Persia. This, says the writer, comes at a time when Russia is making use of every opportunity to further her political and economic interests in that region.

KANKAKEE, Ill., Nov. 14 -- A few years ago there was but little farm land in Illinois that was valued at more than $50 or $75 an acre. A few days ago a farm, near Manteni, this county, was sold at $112.50 an acre, and this price has been the rule rather than the exception in that locality within the last year. Land in other parts of Kankakee is proportionally high.

Prince ton and Yale, the two football elevens which are to meet in the most important same to be played to-morrow, about completed their work yesterday, although both teams will devote some time to-day to running through signals. Princeton's eleven is in fair shape for the game, and all the regular 'Varsity players will at least play in the game at the start.

Mayor-elect Seth Low will go to Washington to-day to visit President Roosevelt. He will leave at 12:53 over the Pennsylvania Road. Mr. Low's trip is made upon an invitation extended to him by President Roosevelt at the time Mr. Low received his nomination from the Fusion forces. Mr. Low will spend the night at the White House, returning to New York on one of the trains which leave Saturday morning.

Funeral services over the body of Prof. Richmond Mayo-Smith of Columbia University were held yesterday morning in Christ Church, at Seventy-first Street and Broadway. They were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Newton N. Perkins of the City Missions Society, in which Prof. MayoSmith took a great interest.
Calendars for 1902 are out. Mary Mannering is represented on an attractive one.

In answer to the questionings of the reporters, Count CASSINI said, upon his arrival here to resume his duties in Washington: "Every promise made by Russia will be kept. Everything is quiet in Manchuria now, and there is no danger of any difficulty arising."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note a letter in your paper in which the writer takes exception to the fact that the heroine of "Under Southern Skies" suspects her mother's blood was tainted by a negro strain. The writer of the letter declares that no Southern girl of good family would entertain such a thought.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The authorities are searching for two women who witnessed the crushing death of Mrs. W. F. Asker of 77 Lincoln Park yesterday afternoon in Hahne Co.'s department store through the elevator being started upward as she was in the act of stepping from it on to the basement floor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Representative Babcock of Wisconsin has by no means given up his determination to insist on tariff revision. He said to-day:

It seems that the army in general, and the Ordnance Department in particular, are agitated by the rumor that it is the intention of the President to appoint a Captain thirty places from the top of the list of officers of the department to be Chief of the Corps, in place of Gen. BUFFINGTON, retired.

The decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court that Major Clinton H. Smith. Seventy-first Regiment, was wrongfully dismissed the service on the recommendation of the board of examination appointed by Gov. Roosevelt, and the latter's approval of the same, will have legal result in a few days.

Mme. Lilli Lehmann gave the second of her song recitals last night in Carnegie Hall. That there was deep public interest in the return of this eminent singer was demonstrated by the welcome which was accorded her at her first recital last week, but that was a matinee entertainment and could hardly be expected to draw as large an audience as an evening concert.

FISHKILL, LANDING, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The Eastman Business College football eleven, composed of Spaniards and Porto Ricans, defeated the Mount Beacon Military Academy team here to-day by the score of 5 to 0.

In the outside market yesterday stocks were duller and at the same time inclined to weakness. In some cases substantial declines resulted from the day's transactions, and most issues were at least fractionally lower than at the close of the previous day. It is true that some issues advanced in spite of the general unfavorable conditions, but such gains were entirely exceptional.

The formation of the Northern Securities Company, with the powers described in its comprehensive charter, and with the objects avowed by the parties to it or attributed to them by those best informed, is the longest step in the practical consolidation of railroad properties that has yet taken place.

James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway, was yesterday elected President of the Northern Securities Company, the new four-hundred-million-dollar corporation, through the medium of which the late financial unpleasantness in the Northwestern Railway field has been definitely disposed of.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A receiver has been appointed to settle the affairs of "The Whirl of the Town" theatrical company.

A romance in which Secretary of War Elihu Root, Gov. Stone of Pennsylvania, the military authorities on Governors Isl- and, a prisoner in Castle Williams, and a demure little Irish maid from Philadelphia played the principal parts, had a happy ending in the little chapel on Governors Island Sunday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was much impressed by the article in to-day's issue headed "Growth of Connecticut Industries in Fifty Years," in which it was stated that in 1900, 176,694 wage earners produced $352,824,106, say, $2,000 each. That salaried officials earned an average income of about $1,200 per annum, as compared with the wages paid in the producers or workers, averaging, say, $460.

EARLINGTON, Ky., Nov. 14 -- Adjt. Gen. David J. Murray, who has been in Madisonvine for two days looking into the mining situation, this afternoon telephoned to the Governor recommending that troops again be sent to Hopkins County.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 -- The wedding of Miss Florence Maragaret Foraker, daughter, of Senator Foraker, and Randolph Matthews occurred to-day in the Church of the Advent, Walnut Hills, near the Sen- ator's residence, and was followed by a brilliant reception at the bride's home.

READING, Penn., Nov. 14 -- The wedding of Miss Emily Baer, second daughter of President George F. Baer of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, to Frank Leavenworth Connard, occurred at the Second Reformed Church, this evening, the Rev. Dr. S.R. Bridenbaugh officiating. The church was magnificently decorated and the affair was the most brilliant ever seen here.

Wanderers from all points on the Bowery are expected to be present at the funeral of Capt. William H. Baker, founder and President of the Hoboes' Club, which is set for this afternoon at Bacigalupo's Chapel, in Mulberry Street. He died Wednesday in Hudson Street Hospital from injuries resulting from being run down by a Third Avenue trolley car.

OMAHA, Nov. 14 -- Spring is always a dangerous season along the Missouri River, and much money has been expended, for the improvement of that stream, which has almost been so much money thrown away, so erratic is it. The fickle Missouri, when full to its banks in the Spring, has a habit of cutting across lots in any and every direction, demolishing whole farms in a day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Chauveau of Paris, in 1890, made three experiments to show the identity of tuberculosis of man and that of the ox. First, he caused the oxen to ingest products of human tuberculosis; second, he made intravenous injections of the same product, and in the third, sub-cutaneous injections.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Commissioner Cullinan to-night issued a statement showing the operation of the State liquor tax law in New York City during the last excise year. The statement of the Commissioner is as follows:

Two ex-Governors of the State of New York, both eminent lawyers, met in a great legal struggle yesterday before Judge Newburger in the Court of General Sessions for the freedom of Roland Burnham Molineux, the convicted murderer of Mrs. Kate J. Adams, now in the Tombs awaiting a new trial granted by the Court of Appeals.

L.J. Jurgens of 377 Court Street, Brooklyn, contemplates bringing a suit for damages against the city. Mr. Jurgens ovens or did own a two-story basement and attic frame dwelling at 27 Little Street, opposite John, near the navy yard. At present all that remains of the house is the skeleton.

After addressing slim houses in Brooklyn for three days, the Rev. Frank L. Sandford and his "Holy Ghost and Us" fraternity from Shiloh, Me., have abandoned their effort to prepare the people of that borough for the "great tribulation." Announcement to this effect was made at the meeting of the band in Grand Union Hall, on Court Street, last night.

Nearly six hundred persons sat down last night at the City Club dinner in honor of Seth Low, Charles V. Fornes, Edward M. Grout, William Travers Jerome, "and the Fusion forces uniting in their election." The long tables, arranged as closely together as the space permitted, crowded the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 14 -- Fully half a million dollars' damage has been done in Utah by a series of earthquakes, beginning last night and lasting until this afternoon. Buildings were wrecked, and in one place a chasm was opened in the earth and a number of persons had narrow escapes from death.

William C. Gotshall, President of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company, gave some interesting figures to the State Railroad Commission at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday relative to the probable earnings and operating expenses of the projected railroad.

JEFF ERSONVILLE, Ind., Nov. 14 -- Newell C. Rathbun, suspected of killing Charles Goodman in a hotel here by poison, was to-day positively identified by an officer and an acquaintance of the prisoner from Little Rock, Ark., where he lived for a time. Later, Rathbun was arraigned before Mayor Rader, in the police station on a charge of murder.
Army. Major Frank H. Titus, Surgeon United States Volunteers, will proceed to San Francisco for transportation to the Philippine Islands.

A meeting of the special commission appointed to inquire into the extension of the Rapid Transit tunnel under the East River to Brooklyn was held in the rooms of the Rapid Transit Commissioners at 320 Broadway yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- First choice horses had their best day since the opening of the meet at Bennings to-day, four favorites, a weil played second choice, and an outsider capturing the money. In the third race Pigeon Post, backed from 30 to 1 to 12 to 1, easily beat the 9 to 10 favorite, Lady of the Valley.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- After two days and two nights of exposure Carl Odell, nineteen years old, of 75 Pelham Road, and Herman Wickerloff, thirty-five years old, of Residence Park, reached home to-night after their families and friends had given them up for dead. On Tuesday afternoon they set out in the sailboat Rosie from Keefer's wharf to shoot ducks.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Representative H.S. Boutell of Illinois, one of the leading Republican members of the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures in the last House, said to-day:

Deputy Commissioner Devery, presiding as judge at the trials of delinquent policemen at Headquarters yesterday, grave the first intimation that he has seen the shadow of his official doom. Twoscore or more were before him charged with failure to pay their debts, and in most instances confessed their fault.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- With the completion of the settlement the demand for money lessened Monday, though it was fairly active and not materially easier. The condition of the short-loan market justifies the opinion that the Bank of England is quietly reducing supplies. Discounts were steady.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Col. J.H. Mapleson, the operatic impresario, died in London to-day from blood poisoning supervening on Bright's disease. He had been seriously ill about a fortnight.
BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $23,800,907; balances, $1,702,205.

The medical profession is disturbed over the recent fatalities in St. Louis resulting from the injection of antitoxine for the cure of diphtheria. Twenty cases of tetanus, or lockjaw, developed among patients who had been treated with diphtheria antitoxine, manufactured by the Health Department of the City of St. Louis, which has been engaged in its production since 1895.

The medical profession is disturbed over the recent fatalities in St. Louis resulting from the injection of antitoxine for the cure of diphtheria. Twenty cases of tetanus, or lockjaw, developed among patients who had been treated with diphtheria antitoxine, manufactured by the Health Department of the City of St. Louis, which has been engaged in its production since 1895.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It gives me pleasure to note that THE TIMES has a large and growing circulation here. I find the passengers on the Brighton Beach trains appear to take more copies of yours than of any other morning daily, and the count of votes, in this district, indicates that you had a good influence.

To those who have anything to do with books of importance and value, accurate cataloguing is an indispensable thing. It is not so rare to-day as it was half a century ago. The influence of Stevens, Philes, Sabin, and other distinguished bibliographers has been widely felt.

-- A veteran of the "P. O." service, commenting in The Shipping World of London on the Admiralty Court's recent decision with regard to the collision between the Oceanic and the coasting steamer Kincora, condenses the long document into the statement that "in a dense fog a horse may as well go at a full gallop over a precipice as to proceed at a three-miles-an-hour pace."

To-day being the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the so-called battle of Port Washington, the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, with the co-operation of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society, will dedicate a memorial given by James Gordon Bennett to mark the site of Fort Washington, which, as every New Yorker should know, stood on what is now Fort Washington Avenue, near One Hundred and Eighty-first Street.
BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,539,170; balances, $2,020,366.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15. -- The Philadelphia market to-day was broad and buoyant, and many issues attained their highest prices in weeks, some the highest prices in years. Union Traction was eagerly sought around 30 1/4, and went to 30 1/2. It had not been so high before since last August.

George Slosson played a grand game of billiards last night at his Broadway academy with the Spanish billiardist, Jose Ortiz. It was at eighteen-inch balk line, and 400 points were placed as the limit. A large crowd of spectators watched the sport and saw Slosson run out his 400 points in thirty-three innings, while Ortiz only made 174.

Edmund Clarence Stedman. Houghton, Mifflin Co. have in preparation a most attractive little volume containing "Mater Coronata," the poem composed and recited by Mr. Stedman at the bicentennial celebration of Yale University on the 23d of last October.

There is no decent citizen of this municipality who will not rejoice in the disappearance from its councils of Mr. WHALEN. There is no educated citizen who will not rejoice that he is supplanted by Mr. RIVES. The Tammany appointments to places of trust under the Municipal Government were, almost without exception, insults to the people of New York.

After a ten-years' test Mr. Brownell's book on French art reappears in a form suitable to work destined to survive. It is reset, printed on handsome paper, enriched by forty-eight illustrations, and has one new chapter on "Rodin and the Institute," all that the development of French art within the decade requires, the author thinks, in addition to what was written ten years ago.
LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Money was in less demand to-day, and the price was maintained fairly. The supply of money was not plentiful. Discounts were firm.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The talk of an Aaron Burr revival again arouses interest in the mysterious fate of Theodosia. Burr's fair and brilliant daughter. The uncertainty about her death forms one of those curious lapses of history which are rich in rumor but seemingly lacking in authenticated fact.

In his annual report to the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade, just rendered, President C.C. Shayne discusses at length the results on customs revenues of the operation of the one-hundred-dollar limitation law.
The first public rehearsal of the sixtieth season of the Philharmonic Society of New York took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The programme was as follows:

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 15. -- A Butte dispatch says: "Recent developments lead many well-informed persons to believe that mining litigation involving $100,000,000 or more, which has kept the Courts of the State busy for many years, will be practically ended before the close of the year. From an inside source, information comes that Heinze has made up his mind to accept the Amalgamated Company's terms for the purchase of his properties.

This little volume of fairy stories and illustrations is typically American. In that it is fully worthy of its title. The stories which relate the adventures of little girls and boys of to-day in the land of the mysterious and among fantastic surroundings, have also an underlying current of irony which will not be lost upon adult readers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Senator Nevada N. Stranahan, picked out to succeed Collector Bidwell, is understood to have started for Washington with Col. John T. Mott for an interview with the President.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- It was announced at the War Department to-day that the names of the officers to fill the vacancies In the grade of Brigadier General will not be announced until Congress meets, as it is not deemed desirable to make ad interim appointments. In addition to this statement, and in view of the great pressure that has been brought to bear, it has been deemed proper to make the following declaration:

Dr. William Mason of New York is regarded by many as the father of the musical profession in the United States, though there are some older musicians than he. But he has a patriarchal manner, and he has memories of every one. He is a son of Lowell Mason, who was a pioneer in American music.

Given a wonderful statue which, without the conscious intention of the sculptor, closely resembles a girl of whose photograph the sculptor has had one glimpse, whose voice he has once heard; and given all Rome, whispering that the girl has been the model for the statue, what shall the sculptor do?

Considering Dante's subject matter, it is difficult for a criticism of his entire work to be otherwise than religious, but his politics, his personal references, Beatrice, and queries as to his affections, occupy so much space in the minds of many critics that it is agreeable to find one to whom only the deepest and highest things in the poet's word seem of much value.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- There is a revelation in the new Life of Stevenson which is extremely interesting. It is Mr. Lloyd Osbourne's explanation of the method and extent of his collaboration with Stevenson.
The first edition of this book was published in 1899, and was a large quarto volume with ninety-one illustrations.

The impression of force and insight made by Mr. White's stories as they appeared at intervals in the magazines is not weakened by considering them as a whole. They bear remarkably well the test of one uninterrupted reading; partly, perhaps, because the same motive and the same persons re-appear in different aspects and in different relations in almost every story.

Daniel Birdsall Co. and E.A. Cruikshank Co. have sold for the United Status Trust Company, as trustee, for about $135,000, the four-story brick building 1.146 Broadway, adjoining the Victoria Hotel, 26.5 by 81.8 by 21.8 by 91.2.

The display of extra bindings in Charles Scribner's Sons' annual exhibition this year is more comprehensive than ever before attempted by the house. Typical examples from thirteen countries appear. Many of the European and a few of the American binders are seen for the first time in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Representative Loudenslager of New Jersey, the Secretary of the Republican Congressional Committee, was at the White House to-day. He says he has been in Washington for several days trying to ascertain the strength of the sentiment in favor of a revision of the tariff, and thus far he had not, he said, found the existence of any movement worthy of note in that direction.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- When Mrs. W.H. Kuhlthau, the Postmaster's wife at Milltown, went out to the woodshed this morning she found somebody holding on to the door from the inside. She kept pulling until a voice from inside remonstrated:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 15. -- The greater part of the third day's session of the General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Episcopal Church was devoted to the subject of appropriations, but the burning question came up late in the afternoon, when the "negro question" was precipitated by a motion made by Bishop Foss when an application from Alabama Conferences for missionary aid came up.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The high praise which you justly give to Mr. Edwin Markham's "Lincoln and Other Poems" in your recent review of that book reminds me of something in the same strain that some of us had the good fortune, a few evenings ago, to hear at Mr. Hamilton Mable's lecture on modern American poetry before the Brooklyn Institute.

Justice O'Gorman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday set aside upon his own motion a verdict for $300 in favor of Julius Willsen. who sued the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for $13,000 damages for the death of his five-year-old son Lawrence. Justice O'Gonnan, in his decision setting aside the verdict, said that it was inadequate, and the amount of damages awarded was a shock to the moral sense.

Germany of To-day. A book of interesting facts by a well-known fact gatherer is Ray Stannard Baker's "Seen in Germany," announced by McClure. Phillips Co. He treats a host of subjects suggested by a close observation of Germany's military and civil life.

The Gathmann gun, a piece of ordnance that its inventor, Louis Gathmann, claims is the most destructive engine of war ever constructed, was fired at 2:15 P.M. yesterday at the Government proving grounds on Sandy Hook. A specially constructed target, which was said to be of sufficient strength to represent the resisting force of a modern battleship, received the impact of the projectile.

BARON DE SANTA-ANNA NERY, the author of this work, which was first published in Paris in 1884, and lately reissued in France in a second edition, contributes an interesting preface to the present volume, in which he says:
Mayor-elect Low announced yesterday the appointment of George L. Rives as Corporation Counsel. In making the announcement Mr. Low said:
George R. Bidwell of this city will be superseded as Collector of Customs at the Port of New York on or about April 1, 1902, by State Senator Nevada N. Stranahan of Fulton, Oswego County, this State.

Capt. William H. Baker, professional "hobo" and founder and President of the Hobo Club of Mulberry Street, who died Wednesday in the Hudson Street Hospital, was buried yesterday afternoon in the Government plot in Cypress Hill Cemetery, where old soldiers arc given free lodging pending the sounding of the last bugle call.

Too poor to pay a physician and too proud to accept his services without paying for them, Malcolm Van Alstine, about thirty-five years old, of 2,077 Crotona Avenue, was seized with a Hemorrhage of the lungs in Nassau Street precisely at noon yesterday, as a result of a lack of medical attention, and died almost instantly.

Five interesting competitions were finished last night in the monthly gymnasium games of the St. George Athletic Club, held in the gymnasium at. 207 East Sixteenth Street. C.A. Shindler carried off the individual honors, winning two of the events, the twelve-pound shot put and the potato race.

Few library habitues, although many of them may have marveled at the celerity with which they have received the books called for, probably comprehend the intricate system of classification which enables them not only to find the number of the book they are in search of in the shortest possible time, but also makes it possible for the librarian to place his hand directly upon the book.

Possibly no structure in the world is so filled with the memories of great historical events as the Tower of London. Here Princes, Kings, and Queens have been imprisoned; traitors and witches tortured; while the best and the worst blood of England has commingled upon its stone pavements. The Bayard Tower, the Traitors Gate, the Bloody Tower have all played their part in the making of English history in the Middle Ages.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Court of Errors and Appeals this afternoon declared unconstitutional the Stokes school law of 1900, which was passed for the purpose of governing all the school districts of the State. By reason of this decision, the District School Boards throughout the State will go back to the laws that prevailed previous to the passage of the Stokes act.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a very pleasing article about his brother Edward, published in your issue of to-day, Mr. George Gary Eggleston very properly observes that he feels under no obligation whatever to apologize for having written it. Of course not; no one will question his taste in the matter.

There was a complete reversal of speculative sentiment on the Stock Exchange yesterday, due probably to the disclosure early in the day that the liquidation of the day previous had run its course and that the larger banking interests in the Street were inclined to buy rather aggressively, this being particularly true in the case of the local railway shares, notably Metropolitan and Manhattan, which advanced substantially.

A charming book of verses entitled "Anni Fugaces," has come from the pen of no less a personage than our old friend, R.C. Lehmann. Mr. Lehmann is not our old friend in literature, for this seems to be a debut in that field, but he has been with us in the world of athletics, and we are not likely soon to forget him.

NAGASAKI, Japan, Nov. 15. -- Still another one of the country's vessels has come to grief off the coast of Japan. The transport Hancock is ashore on the south side of the Straits of Shimonoseki, grounded on a sandy bottom. A German gunboat is assisting her. This is the third time within a month that a United States transport has met with misfortune in Japanese waters.

VINELAND, N.J., Nov. 15. -- An attempt was made last night to kidnap Miss Emma M. Veale, seventeen years of age, daughter of Charles Veale, Superintendent of the Agricultural Department of the New Jersey Traning School for Feeble-Minded Children. Miss Veale to-day is confined to her father's home as a result of her experience.

DICKENS began public readings from his works in 1837. The experiment was found to be, from every point of view, completely successful. Its money returns were large; his dignity was not compromised, as some of his friends thought it might be; he showed himself a master in his new art, as he had proved himself in his old one.

Louis Alexander Robertson is the name of a young poet who has just risen to notice on the Western coast. His book, "The Dead Calypso and Other Poems," has already called forth praise from the critics of San Francisco. This praise is deserved, for, while Mr. Robertson will not at once claim a place among the prominent singers of this country, he takes a comfortable position among the minor poets.

A gentleman connected with the new organization of railway interests is reported in our columns as saying: "Some people have made the point that the Government of the United States should take over all the railroads after they had been brought as closely together as possible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Forty yards from the finish in the Fall club regatta of graded crews at Harvard to-day, Philip Adams, who rowed No. 2 in the fourth Weld lost his oar and plunged overboard into the cold and icy waters of the Charles River. The action was well meant, but it proved disastrous.

Since the success of Paul Laurence Dunbar has become distinctive and generally admitted, others of his race have not hesitated to place their efforts in verse before the public. In most cases, however, the verses thus put forth have been marred by an elementary point of view and by the lack of a knowledge of prosody which has hardly been replaced by the natural gift of versification, except in pure and simple negro lyrics.

By The Associated Press. DUBLIN, Nov. 15. -- The Parliamentary contest in Galway is being marked by a succession of fights. All the constabulary of the neighborhood are needed to keep the contestants within bounds. Horace Plunkett, Unionist, an ex-Member of Parliament for the South Division of Dublin County, is opposing Col. Arthur Lynch.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Commissioner of Internal Revenue to-day rendered a decision in which he holds that beer, whisky, and other articles of domestic manufacture subject to internal revenue tax when consumed in the United States, are subject to this tax when shipped to the Philippine Islands.

Prompted, it is believed, by the knowledge that the death two weeks ago of Harry E. Corbett, for eighteen years paying teller of the Williamsburg Savings Bank, whom he involves as his accomplice, would lead to discovery, George Zollinhofer, for thirty-three years receiving teller of the same bank, has confessed to embezzlements estimated to total more than $60,000, and which it is thought may be found to amount to nearly $100,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The Chronicle will say to-morrow:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15. -- The stock market to-day was more active and higher. There were no special influences at work other than bullish rumors on Seaboard. It is said an early payment of dividends on the preferred is likely. January, 1903, which is a little more than a year hence, is marked down as the probable date for the move.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 15. -- The astronomers at Harvard observed about 400 leonids in the early hours of this morning and took numerous photographs. This planet, earth, must have fallen in with a particularly numerous swarm soon after 4 o'clock, for during a half hour nearly a hundred flashed across the dusky sky.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Some of the witnesses in the Schley inquiry, both for and against Admiral Schley, have received orders transferring them from their present positions. The latest orders relating to any of them were given out to-day.

Four new books have been added to the Century Classics -- "Franklin's Autobiography," Kingsley's "Hypatia," Poe's "Tales," and "Sesame and Lilies" and "A Crown of Wild Olive," by John Ruskin. Suffice to repeat at this day that these volumes, which are presented with valuable introductions and in durable, stamped green cloth bindings, and printed from clear type upon heavy English-made paper, are intended to combine both cheapness of price with appropriate literary form.

Under the title of "The Art of Building a Home" Mr. Barry Parker and Mr. Raymond Unwin have collated, with interesting and appropriate illustrations, a number of popular lectures and contributions to British architectural journals, so arranged as to form a consecutive series of chapters relating especially to small and economical middle-class houses.

The Park Avenue Property Owners' Association, which took up at a meeting Wednesday night the subject of nuisances connected with the New York Central tunnel in Park Avenue, is already at work. The declared object of the association is to compel the substitution of electricity for steam as the motive power of New York Central trains passing through the tunnel.

This book by the well-known scientists and engineers, MM. Neuburger and Noalhat, and translated by Prof. Melntosh, late Lecturer on Geology and Mineralogy, People's Palace, London, is a wonderful work. The general reader knows little about the history, geography, and geology of the great oil fields of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Mayor-elect Seth Low of New York was the guest of President Roosevelt to-night. Accompanied by Philip Roosevelt, a cousin of the President, Mr. Low arrived here shortly after 6 o'clock this evening. He was met at the Pennsylvania station by Secretary Cortelyou, and went immediately to the White House, where he took dinner and remained over night.

The blanks prepared for the monthly pay rolls of the city departments have at the bottom a certificate to which the President or Chief Commissioner has to subscribe. By so subscribing he becomes responsible for the correctness of the pay roll, and on such certification payment is made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- A fast track and a well-filled card drew to Bennings today one of the largest crowds of the week. Three favorites, Barouche, Tyrshena, and Potente, won. In the fifth race Tyrshena, opening at 15 to 1, was backed off the boards of most of the bookmakers. Jockey H. Cochran for the second time this week was thrown from his horse, but again escaped uninjured. Summary:

By the time it is completed the series of "Real Conversations" which William Archer is contributing month by month to an American and an English magazine will include expressions of opinion on nearly all the possible problems of contemporary literature. Its index will suggest topics enough to keep a diligent essay writer going for a twelvemonth.

Of the permanent value of Mr. Wyckoff's self-sacrificing study of the laborer and the labor problem there are a variety of opinions. His own frank admission is that "scarcely a generalization with the least claim to value can be drawn from my superficial contact with the world of labor in America," leads to the query whether his study has been a mere quixotic windmill encounter, ending fn confessed failure.

POVIDENTIALLY or otherwise, simultaneously with the visit of J.E. Redmond, M.P. to this country is the appearance of a volume dealing in a scholarly manner with the subject which he has so much to heart. "Ireland and the Empire," by T.W. Russell, also a member of the House of Commons, is believed to be a disinterested attempt to throw full light upon the wrongs Ireland has suffered during the last hundred years.

It requires some extended observation of German hyperaesthesia to understand the resentment that has been caused in Berlin by the publication of the letters of Gen. VOYRON, commanding the French detachment in China, to Count VON WALDERSEE, the "Commander in Chief of the allied forces."

The first case ever presented to a jury in the New York courts under the new law that went into effect on Sept. 1, 1899, whereby a co-respondent in a divorce suit is allowed to frame issues in the suit and defend the action so far as the issues affect him or her, was tried yesterday before Justice Fitzgerald in the Supreme Court, and the co-respondent named was exonerated of all wrongdoing.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 15. -- It is announced here to-day that Anson Phelps Stokes of New York has purchased twelve acres of choice shore-front property at Collender's Point, Noroton, a part of the Collender estate. It is understood that Mr. Stokes will erect a fine Summer residence before next season.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 consideration over $3,000.

In an attractively made little volume, bound uniformly with the Thistle Edition of Stevenson's works, will be found an essay on "Stevenson's Attitude to Life, with Readings from His Essays and Letters," by John Franklin Genung. Prof. Genung prepared his book in lecture form for delivery at Amherst, where the attention it awakened led him to issue it in book form.

Mr. Gledstone issued in 1871 a much longer and fuller biography of the great field preacher, which has long been out of print. The attention it attracted, and the increasing demand for a life which should be full, but without too great detail, has led to the preparation of the present volume, the main idea of both works being, Mr. Gledstone says:

The present conductors of The Evening Post are entirely justified in celebrating the hundredth anniversary of the foundation of that paper in a way to call attention to the character and career of the journal. It is a most unusual and important heritage that has come down to them.

Kate Greenaway, whose death was announced a week ago, was so long and so violently the fashion that the public has fallen into the habit of thinking less about her art than about the effect it produced; less about what she did than about what other people did in imitation of her.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- New York exchange, 15 cents' premium. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2 per cent.

As the Winter season approaches plans are being formed for entertainments of all kinds, and each day one takes place. This week-end is very gay for the fashionable world. This afternoon at Meadow Brook Harry W. Bull, acting Master of the Hounds, will give a breakfast to the members of the hunt.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15. -- In one of the most unsatisfactory prizefights ever witnessed in this country, James J. Jeffries proved the victor to-night over "Gus" Ruhlin, the Akron giant. In the fifth round of what was to have been a twenty-round struggle, Ruhlin wilted and then surrendered to his peer, to the utter amazement and disgust of the assembled thousands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Winter cruise of the North Atlantic Squadron, which begins on the 25th of this month, will be a notable one, for the vessels of the squadron will stop at Charleston for four days during the exposition, and visit Cuba, Porto Rico, the Isthmus of Panama, Colombia, Trinidad Island, on the north-east coast of Venezuela, and the Danish West Indies.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Such demonstrations as the celebration of the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the capture of Fort Washington and the erection of a beautiful and unique memorial to mark the site of the nobly-defended work are evidences of New York's awakening to its historic treasures and of a wide-spreading sentiment of civic pride and patriotic appreciation of local landmarks.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I trust that none of the readers of THE REVIEW was tempted to omit careful perusal of Mr. S.G.W. Benjamin's informing article on Dr. Dwight's "Constantinople and Its Problems" in your issue of Nov. 2. Mr. Benjamin knows much regarding many subjects.

IRREGULARITIES "WAIVED. -- James L. Weeks was in 1857 the owner of an undivided one-half interest in certain real estate. On Sept. 23 of that year a judgment was secured against him, on which execution was issued and returned unsatisfied. Seventeen years later a second execution was issued upon the judgment, under which the Sheriff sold Weeks's interest in the premises to Anna R. Gerding.

Following the course of the Stock Exchange market, prices in the outside market yesterday recovered from the low figures of Thursday. The gains were in few cases accompanied by much activity, only a few stocks being dealt in to the extent of 1,000 shares. New interest appeared in certain parts of the list, and some stocks which have been in no way prominent recently figured among the issues showing advances.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Attention has recently been called by Andrew Lang to Dr. Chivers, the eccentric poet who died in Decatur, Ga., in 1858 and whose verse, it has been asserted from time to time, suggested to Poe the peculiar nomenclature and rhythm which the latter made so effective.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Union County Trust Company filed articles of incorporation in the office of County Clerk Howard to-day. The President of the new company, it is said, is Gov. Foster M. Voorhees, who retires from the office of Governor at the close of the year. The capital of the concern is given as $100,000.

BIRD lovers and bird students divide themselves into special classes, just as do doctors and lawyers.
