Some devote their time to studying the eggs alone, and to them that bird is only worth knowing which produces the prettiest eggs; others study the plumage and see beauty in the dark dirty brown streaks of the sparrow.

PADUCAH, Ky., Nov. 16. -- The Paducah, Cairo and Northwestern Railroad Company to-day filed articles of incorporation with the County Clerk. The incorporators are E.W. Smith, B.H. Scott, Joseph, L. Friedman, S.T. Payne, George O. Hart, George C. Wallace, and Lloyd Bloomfield, all of Paducah.

LAKEWOOD, Nov. 16. -- New Yorkers are flocking to this resort much earlier than, usual, and in much larger numbers. The Lakewood Hotel opened its doors last Thursday, and is fast filling up. The correspondence which Manager James N. Berry has had during the last week promises a house full of guests by Thanksgiving.

For several weeks past counsel for Annie Meyer of 200 West One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, the complainant in a criminal action against Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Fieroe, who was a well-known society woman of Cincinnati and who in the last year, it is said, has spent a fortune in Wall Street, have been unable to serve papers on her in a civil action in the Supreme Court for conversion.
The Hon. Robert S. Rantoul has accepted a citizens' nomination for Mayor of Salem, Mass. The municipal election will be held in December.

Senator Platt and Gov. Odell took breakfast together yesterday. When the Governor was seen later and asked what he thought about Senator Stranahan's selection to succeed George R. Bidwell, Collector of the Port, he said:

The football season has almost reached its close, but two games of real importance in the world of the gridiron now remaining to be played. These are the meeting of Harvard and Yale, one of the chief events of the year, and the struggle for supremacy between the elevens of West Point and Annapolis, a contest that will furnish the great sporting feature of the season for the army and navy.

The light harness racing season of 1901 was prolific of new fast performances and reductions of records by horses that before had achieved low marks. To the 2:10 list there were added eleven trotters and thirty-nine pacers, while four trotters and twenty-seven pacers which at the close of the season of 1900 had places on the roll of honor, improved on their former marks.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 16. -- It was only by the close score of 10 to 14 that Pennsylvania secured a victory over the Carlisle Indians this afternoon, and the result was due not so much to the Quakers' playing as to the fumbling by the Indians, the ready with of Reynolds, and the pugnaciousness of Mitchell.

"It may seem a most ridiculous statement to make," says the member of a leading Stock Exchange house, "but nevertheless I believe that before we are six months older we will see days when transactions on the Stock Exchange will run up to a total of four and five million shares a day -- and at advancing prices.

From The International Monthly. When, writes a missionary of the tribes of the remote part of Victoria, a native is able to imitate the peculiarities of some absent member of the tribe, it is very common to hear all in the camp convulsed with laughter. The Indians of Brazil hold the peculiarities (the beard, for example) of other tribes up to laughter in the shape of a lively pantomime.

From Ainslee's Magazine. A tornado that was remarkable both in appearance and in action was one that traveled from Texas across Oklahoma and Indian Territory in May, 1896. A man in Sherman, Oklahoma Territory, who had exceptional opportunities for observing the storm, inasmuch as he was caught up in it and carried several hundred yards before descending to earth again, is certain that it was not funnel-shaped.

YORK, Penn., Nov. 16. -- While running at the rate of forty-five miles an hour, the Southwestern express of the Northern Central Railway, due in this city at 10:44 P.M., was wrecked last night by a charge of dynamite placed under the track near the Black Bridge, a short distance north of York.

Games of all sorts were freely indulged in in camp, including cricket, football, quoits, lawn tennis, besides which there were several clubs established and maintained, one, the German Club, where concerts and sing-songs were held at least once a fortnight; another, the Hollander Club, where similar entertainments were given; there was also a sports club and a boxing saloon.

From The National Review. Every lapse in thought from the Christian standard spells degradation for multitudes. But it spells misery, too. The experiment of life, reduced to a play of molecular forces, does not correspond to the nature of things; it is a dream upon which reality is always breaking in, and the dreamer cannot sleep in peace.
AMERICANS make some curious discoveries in London, often unearthing things of interest and importance that the Londoners themselves had not been aware of.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- Harvard played a team of substitutes against Dartmouth's football team to-day and won by the score of 24 to 12. Both the visitors' scores were made as the result of blocked kicks, the ball in each instance being picked up by a Dartmouth man and carried over the goal line.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been very much interested in the attitude of THE TIMES toward the canteen question. Perhaps a few remarks from one who has served many years in the army and has had charge of the canteen or post exchange, may be of interest to those who have followed the discussion.

The scarcity of cars recently reported by so many prominent roads has been surpassed by the more deplorable shortage in motive power. It is more natural for cars to run short at certain centres of activity than for locomotives to grow scarce, for the reason that the cars of one or more companies may be seattered and not under immediate control when most needed to meet a pressing requirement.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- One outcome of the recent anti-monastic legislation in France seems to be the revival of Nationalism, or, as it is called, "Gallicanism," among a certain section of the French priesthood, who were largely and ably represented at the recent Catholic congress at Lille.

A men's foursome tournament called forth a large delegation of players to the links of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club, near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, yesterday. The prizes were offered by J. Duncan Dithridge and Henry Crossley, and the conditions were that the first eight pairs should qualify to continue at match play on succeeding Saturdays.

WITH the blare of bands and the blaze of fireworks, which died out at election time, the two old parties practically abandoned, until the next campaign, organized efforts to spread their political gospel. This is not true of the earnest believers in a co-operative Commonwealth, who mate up the Socialist Labor and Social Democratic Parties.

The Democratic members of Congress from New York City would have found much of interest in a map which was being prepared yesterday under the direction of certain of the Fusion leaders in the recent campaign. The map in question was designed to show the Fusion vote in the election districts composing the various Congressional districts of Greater New York.

New world's records were made yesterday in the mile straightaway races arranged by the Long Island Automobile Club on the Coney Island Boulevard. Henri Fournier, the French champion, carried off the record-holding honors of the day, making a mile with his forty horse power foreign machine in the unprecedented time of 51 4-5 seconds.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Out of seven victims of lockjaw following vaccination in Camden, five have died. The fifth victim, Lillian Carty, sixteen years old, of 742 Berkley Street, died early this morning.

The foreign cycle racers who are to compete in the annual international six-day race in Madison Square Garden arrived on the steamer St. Paul yesterday. The teams who come to ride for American gold are Jean Gougoltz and Cesar Simar of France; Albin Chevallier and Jean Fischer of Switzerland; Rudolph Muller and Oscar Lepoutre of Italy; Alphonse de Roeck and Charles Korff of Belgium, and Hans Jaak and Michel Fredricks of Germany.

With her players much the worse for Wear, her football aspirations trampled upon, the Columbia team finished the game with Cornell yesterday on the Polo Grounds, having been beaten by a score of 24 to 0. The teams appeared to be evenly matched in the first half, and Cornell's touchdown in this half was the result of a long run by Schoellkopf, who, when tackled, fumbled the ball.

The only theatrical offering or importance the coming week will be to-morrow night at Wallack's Theatre, when Augustus Thomas's latest play, "Colorado," will have its first presentation on any stage. The scenes of the play are laid in the Rocky Mountains, the first showing a cabin in the gap on the trail of the Happy Strike Mine, which is owned by Frank Austin, who is in love with Kitty Doyle, the daughter of his foreman.

Madison Square Garden presented a lively appearance yesterday. All was bustle and confusion resulting from the arrangements preliminary to the National Horse Show Association exhibition, which opens to-morrow morning at 8 o'clock and will continue until midnight Saturday.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- All the old favorites at the London theatres are doing pnenomenal business. "San Toy," at Daly's Theatre, promises to reach its one thousanth performance. "William Gillette keeps the Lyceum Theatre packed with "Sherlock Holmes," and "The Last of the Dandies," at Her Majesty's Theatre, is equally popular.

Joseph Laguttuta, a truckman, who kept his truck and horses at a livery and boarding stable maintained by Robert Wilson, on premises in East Eleventh Street owned by George E. Chisolm, sent his nine-year-old son, Andrew, with his driver, who did not speak English, to act as interpreter in getting the team and truck.

THE gown worn by Miss Grace Gurnee Scott, now Mrs. George Rathbone Dyer, at her wedding a fortnight ago was noticeably elegant and simple. The sat'n used was of the heaviest, its tint was creamy, and the lace that formed the deep flounce running around the foot of the skirt and train was of exquisitely beautiful old point.

IT MIGHT be interesting to have expert opinion from architects on the scene used for three acts of "Quality Street" at the Knickerbocker Theatre. The picture shown is "the blue and white room in the house of Miss Susan and Miss Phoebe Throssel." The artist has designed a scene calculated to please the eye greatly; the coloring is subdued, and bis mantelpiece and open fireplace add frank, cheerful touches.

HERBERT SPENCER'S theory of wave-like ups and downs in the history of nations and their literature applies to many other things. Families start in obscurity and cheerful poverty, rise gradually to wealth, luxury, and ostentatious extravagance; too often the third generation sinks into the effeminate, worthless, leisure class and soon disappears.

It was a foregone conclusion when the racing year was half over that either William C. Whitney or John E. Madden would lead the list of winning owners on the American turf. The end of the season found these two turfmen so far in advance of all others that the winnings of the two combined about equaled the combined winnings of the next five stables on the list of winners in 1901.

The observer with no especial interest in the automobile, and not a partisan of one or another variety, genus, or species -- whichever is the proper term -- who simply looks on and watches the results reached by richer people who are spending much money in the encouragement of invention and experiment connected with motor vehicles, has probably noticed that the horseless carriage is gradually assuming a form peculiarly and distinctively its own.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 16. -- Mrs. C.F. Sprague, widow of the Congressman, expects to spend $150,000 in remodeling, improving, and enlarging her country house. in Brookline. A feature of the extension to the mansion will be a magnificent ballroom ornamented with rare works and carving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Secretary Hitchcock has disbarred William C. Buderus, an attorney of Sturgis, S.D., from practicing before the Interior Department, because of criticisms said to have been made by the latter on the late President McKinley. The Secretary explains in a letter to the man the reason for the disbarment. He says:

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 16. -- Thomas P. Watts, sanitary plumber, is in for a rare treat and must eat his last season's straw hat. He is game and says he will do it. A hot political debate resulted in the following agreement:

LONDON. Nov. 16. -- Money was in fair inquiry to-day and discounts had an easier tendency, on the firmness of foreign exchanges and the scarcity of bills. Business on the Stock Exchange was dull and the attendance was poor. Transactions were restricted, the fog proving a hindrance. First-class securities were steady.

From The Geographical Journal. Reaching Great Bear Lake on June 23, we were disappointed to find that the ice of the lake was still as continuous as in mid-winter. This was anything but an encouraging outlook to greet our arrival, and it was made the worse by the news which the Indians brought in a few days afterward.

TOLEDO, Nov. 16. -- Officers representing three States -- Ohio, Michigan, and Massachusetts -- clashed at the Union Station to-day and engaged in a brisk struggle for the possession of a woman prisoner, who has attained considerable fame. The woman in the case is a pickpocket, Anna Evans, alias Tessie Hamilton, alias Miss Graham.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16. -- The annual football game between the Varsity teams of Tale and Princeton was played to-day under ideal conditions on Yale Field, and was won by Yale by a score of 12 to 0. These figures, according to the views of experts who witnessed the game, represent accurately the superiority of the sons of Eli over the Tigers of Old Nassau.

One of the most daring attempts at highway robbery ever made in the upper part of the city occurred yesterday morning, when at 11 o'clock three men attacked George W. Reinhardt, a wealthy feed dealer, living at 1,346 Franklin Avenue, in a crowded Third Avenue trolley car at One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and relieved him of $1,000 in bills which he had just drawn from the Twenty-third Ward Bank to pay his employes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal to open the saloons during certain hours Sundays for the sale of the lighter alcoholic drinks such as beer and claret, which is indorsed by THE TIMES and by all level-headed and liberal-minded people generally, is an interesting proposition. It has more than one side, this proposition; more, even, than two.

At a few minutes after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, while the excitement attending the second half of the Cornell-Columbia football game at the Polo Grounds was at its height, Albert Mendoza, who had charge of the sale of tickets at the Eighth Avenue entrance, put on his hat and overcoat and stepped out of the box office, closing and locking its door behind him and disappeared.

DOVER, Del., Nov. 16. -- A move in the big copper war in the New York Courts was blocked to-day by the decision of Chancellor Nicholson that Secretary of State Caleb R. Layton cannot take to New York with him the certificate of the Delaware Surety (Heinze) Company made under oath to the effect that the paid in capital stock of the company is $1,000,000.

From Good Words. In 1810 foolish questions put by a Mr. Fuller were ignored by the Chairman, Sir John Anstruther, and after the Earl had retired. Fuller rose in a great heat and claimed that he had a Tight to have his questions attended to. "G -- d -- me." he cried, "I have as much right to be heard as the Chancellor of the Exchequer."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Nov. 16. -- "Windy Barn," the beautiful country residence here of Charles T. Barney, President of the Knickerbocker Trust Company, with all its contents, including rare bric-a-brac and paintings of great value, by European artists, was totally destroyed by fire last night.

Notwithstanding some irregular price movements here and there, decided strength, almost general to the list, developed in yesterday's stock market under the lead of the Readings, the local railway shares, American Locomotive issues, and certain of the Western railroad stocks.

Mayor-elect Seth Low returned to the city from Washington last evening. Mr. Low went to Washington at the invitation of President Roosevelt and spent Friday night at the White House. When seen last night at his residence, 30 East Sixty-fourth Street. Mr. Low said there was really very little to say about his visit to the President.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 16. -- Leonids were seen in great numbers here just before daybreak, the showers of them having been almost continuous since 1 o'clock. One watcher counted 385 between 4 and 5 o'clock, while the total number seen is estimated at a thousand. Some of the meteors were very beautiful, leaving brilliant trails of green and red.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- When asked about the work before the Fifty-seventh Congress at its opening session. Senator J.C. Burrows of Michigan said to-day:

From The Gentleman's Magazine. At least one-half of the entire inscriptions are the graffits or scratching, a habit accounted for by the temptation to use the sharp-pointed stylus on the polished stucco of the walls or pillars. Such scratching are of all kinds; names, catchwords from poems, amatory couplets, rough sketches, such as the profile of a face or a ship.

Golfers who have played over the Baltusrol Club course near Short Hills, N.J., have often asked, "Where did the name of this club come from?" Beyond the fact that the high hill back of the clubhouse had been called Baltusrol Mountain ever since the first inhabitant began to exercise his memory, no further explanation has ever been offered.

Now that excavations have been made in a great majority of the blocks through which the rapid transit subway is to pass, not many new discoveries of underground curiosities or unexpected complications are to be chronicled. The engineers are well acquainted by this lime with "what they are up against."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under your issue of Wednesday, Nov. 13, is a long article headed, "Washington's Cousin in the Almshouse," and it further gives the name of "Mrs. Alice Washington Fairchild, referred to as being the daughter of Lawrence Washington, son of John Augustine Washington, who inherited Mount Vernon."

SPOONER, Wis., Nov. 16. -- Conductor H. C. Schultze and his entire crew of a freight train on the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway were attacked at Superior Junction last night by a gang of trumps. Schultze received probably fatal knife wounds. Brakeman Ferguson was stabbed in the arm and is in a critical condition from loss of blood.

The continued growing demand for American railroad appliances throughout the world is little short of marvelous. This story of progress reads like a chapter from the Arabian Nights and the work of genii, but the plan facts are even more eloquent than any flights of the imagination. We have become a world power, as our rapidly increasing foreign exports show.

Capt. Titus yesterday caused the arrest of a man who says that he is Azner B. Wheeler, but who the detectives say is O.B. Wheeler, Jr., on a charge of having attempted to negotiate worthless notes with Wall Street and other brokers. The notes which were found upon the man after his arrest, and those which he was alleged to have tried to pass, aggregate about $103,000 in value.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see that your columns are open for opinions on various subjects. You publish in Monday's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES an article on the Sunday saloon question. I believe in absolute personal freedom; besides this, I am a temperance man. This temperance question must be presented in entirely new form, else people will not read of it.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16. -- The first successful experiments in photographing the spectrum of lightning -- the divisions of color which combine to produce the white glare of the lightning flash and offer the physicist his opportunity to analyze the elements that compose it -- is announced in a circular sent out to-day by Prof. E.C. Pickering, the director of the Harvard Observatory.

HAD those persons who consider that Justice Jerome established a precedent by prosecuting the anti-vice crusade in person and bringing his judicial presence to bear wherever there was necessity to urge the true law, inspected the records of the General Quarter Sessions Court of old New York, they would have found that there was full precedent for his action.

THERE is one pecuilar democracy which has no constitution and no country, and which recongnizes no social distinctions, yet its laws are absolute, and no man would dare to violate them. That is the democracy of smokers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most encouraging signs of the post-election period is the appearance even at this early day of a real vital issue, for which the people of this city can unite, irrespective of party lines. I refer to the proposition to do away with the "Raines law hotel" disgrace and promulgate in place thereof a sensible system of Sunday opening.

As sufficient causes usually cited for the intervention of law are infidelity, nonsupport, "gross neglect of duty," and "extreme cruelty." In regard to the first, the injured party, whether man or woman, must keenly feel the personal indignity offered by infidelity, as such a plea for divorce is an open recognition of the basis of marriage which many a woman had rather endure wrong than acknowledge in public.

A deficit of $577,945,73 was incurred by the Pan-American Exposition Company for unpaid accounts, according to the statement of its accounts, which were published yesterday. The difference between the assets and liabilities, however, according to the statement is $1,183,240.44. In addition to this there are contingent liabilities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sunday, Nov. 10, 1901, the writer visited such a saloon twice -- afternoon and in the early evening. Possibly it was a "sandwich" hotel. He did not visit it as a city official or as a missionary. He simply went in. He went in the side door because the front doors were fastened.

With the Horse Show, which begins to-morrow, and which has every promise of brilliant success, the season -- with a very big S -- in New York is supposed to be launched. A few years ago this was true, but conditions have changed, and the show has been likened some several Winters to a prelude, after which there is a Slight pause before the rising of the curtain.

From The Fortnightly Review. I know of no parallel to the difficulty the Government of the Czar has recently experienced, in disposing of the thousands upon thousands of laborers and artisans thrown out of work by the closing of industrial undertakings in every part of the empire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has denied the application of Jesse D. Carr for an order restraining the United States Marshal in Oregon from tearing down a stone fence around what is known as the Clear Lake Ranch, on the Oregon and California boundary.

Copyright, 1901. Via French Telegraph Cable Company. LONDON, Nov. 16. -- London is inclined to take a conservative, even an insular, view concerning the American railroad trust. To begin with, all last week reports came from New York that Northern Pacific preferreds were to be retired at 115. When news was received that they were to be retired at par there was great disappointment -- whether justifiable or not, it makes no difference.
IN certain households in New York there are special subjects whose discussion is under a boycott.

George L. Rives, the incoming Corporation Counsel, spoke yesterday morning before the members of the League for Political Education at 23 West Forty-fourth Street on "The Revised Charter of New York City." Mr. Rives was Chairman of the Charter Revision Committee. When the hour for the lecture, 11 o'clock, arrived, there were 250 -- members of the league present.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- At a conference to-day between friends of James S. Wight and the Perth Amboy Mutual Loan. Homestead and Building Association, the former arranged to pay over the sum of $9,400, which is alleged to be due the association from Mr. Wight, the former Secretary.

CAMBRIDGE., Mass., Nov. 16. -- The Harvard freshmen football players; surprised their most loyal supporters this afternoon by taking the Yale freshmen into camp by a score of 35 to 6. As the score indicates, the game was very one-sided and an easy victory for the Crimson youngsters. The Eli team was unable to stop the onslaught of the Crimson backs, only twice holding them for downs.

IT is a queer place to look for humor, the advertising columns of a newspaper, and one that at first glance would seem a barren field; yet a close inspection of these columns, both in the papers of other days and in those of our own, really affords a rich harvest of amusing expression and thought.

"The position of England in the Far East," said the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Nevin, "is very different to-day from what it was. Six years ago, when I was in Japan, there was no one quite so respectfully regarded as the British Ambassador. Now the representative of England in China or Japan occupies the unenviable position of a man whose word hardly counts.
Many prominent individualities which commanded attention in the Legislature of 1901 will be missing from the Legislature which meets on Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- State Senator N.H. Stranahan of Oswego, N.Y., after his call upon the President, to-day made the following statement:

A very important convention of business men will meet in Washington on Tuesday. It is called by the American Manufacturers' Association, the largest and most representative organization of manufacturers in the country. Its object is to discuss and to formulate views with reference to the promotion of foreign trade by means of reciprocity and to the form that reciprocity should take.

The Commercial and Financial Chronicle compiles statistics showing that the shortage of this year's harvests is somewhat greater in the aggregate than was at first supposed. The most trustworthy returns now available indicate that the total of corn, wheat, oats, barley, and rye falls about 700,000,000 bushels below the total for 1900.

The Evening Post commemorated yesterday its one hundredth anniversary by issuing a jubilee edition and entertaining its entire staff of 180 persons at a dinner at the Hardware Club, at which the souvenir was a special Birthday Extra. The offices of the newspaper, at Fulton Street and Broadway, were decorated with evergreens, flags, and drapings, and these were at night illuminated with electricity in golden bulbs.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- The centre of the town is full of new art shows, some of unusual interest, such as the Gainsborough Exhibition and the choice selection of portraits by Raeburn, a small part of last Summer's show in Edinburgh, where sixty odd portraits by the Scotch master were shown in one room of the Greek temple on Princes Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from "A.T.T." awakens pleasant recollections about how Mr. Platt saved his face. During the recent canvass for the Fusion ticket I was asked by a person in the audience how I could work with Platt and his tools, whom we had previously denounced as the aiders and abettors of Crokerism and Whitney and the traction interests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Commissioner General Powderly of the Immigration Bureau shows in his annual report, just issued, that the total steerage arrivals in the United States during the year have been 487,918, an increase over the preceding year of 39,346, or approximately 9 per cent. Of this increase 2,020 came through Canada, and the remainder through ports of this country.

CONSCIENTIOUS contributors to funds for the support of parish houses where the philanthropic work of the large churches is carried on show an intelligent interest in the moral training of the children who flock to these houses, by studying the individuality of each child in their circle of acquaintance, and by listening patiently to its criticisms and its complaints.

Grosvenor Atterbury, Secretary of the United Fine Arts Building Committee, yesterday afternoon gave out a report of the Friday night meeting of the Executive Committee of the fine arts federation of New York. The meeting was held in the Arts Club, 37 West Thirty-fourth Street, and was composed of members of the various art associations of the city.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 16. -- All of the Siberian peninsula extending into Bering sea and the Arctic east of the one hundred and eightieth meridian, comprising about 67.800 square miles of territory, equal in area to Washington State, will be thrown open for public mining operations next Spring.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Officers of Relief Council, American Mechanics, are still trying to locate William R. Durham, the absent Treasurer of the council. Durham left town on Wednesday, and it is thought in some quarters that his departure was due to the fact that at a meeting of the council to be held Thursday night an examination of his accounts was to be made.

"The Lotos Club vs. Joseph H. Choate," was the formal looking document, wrapped in a legal blue cover and tied with a legal red string that stared the American Ambassador to England in the face when he took his place as the guest of honor at the Lotos Club dinner last night. It was the menu.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Nov. 16. -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy HacKett, representing the navy, accepted the gift of a silver service for the battleship Illinois to-day in the presence of a large crowd.

Athletics in the Hawaiian Islands are going to be fostered by the Amateur Athletic Union, and one of the interesting features of the annual meeting of the National athletic body to-morrow will be the granting of that distant territory of the United States to the Pacific Coast Athletic Association.

The football team of New York University on Ohio Field yesterday defeated the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute eleven by a score of 46 to 5, in a one-sided and rather tame game. The first half was a practical walk-over for New York University, 29 points being rolled up. The first touchdown was made in four minutes, others being made at about similar intervals through the period.

Or course, nobody will pretend that the appointment of Mr. STRANAHAN to succeed Mr. BIDWELL as Collector of the Port is in the least "ideal." On the contrary, it is evidently a matter of the most "practical politics." The President baa taken the candidate for the place of the Republican organization in this State, having first ascertained that there was nothing personally objectionable about the candidate.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The only official report so far received at the War Department of the result of yesterday's test of the Gathmann gun at Sandy Hook is comprised in the following brief telegram to Gen. Buffington, the Chief of Ordnance, from Major Babbitt, the senior officer representing that department at Sandy Hook:

Of the subjects to be dealt with by the Catholic Archbishops at their meeting this week in Baltimore, that of widest interest to Catholics throughout the country is undoubtedly the question of the Federation of the Catholic Societies of America.

IT IS a clergyman's story, and he was one of the chief actors in what he considered at the time a small tragedy, but which proved eventually to be "one on him." He tells the story himself and vouches for it, so while it is one of the most remarkable cat stories on record, it must be believed.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The Orange County Hunt had the largest run of the season to-day. Seventeen riders rode the entire eight-miles course in forty minutes, and all were close up at then finish. The pack cast in at Prospect Lake and went over hill and valley to Glenmere, doubling on its trail and coming back from the outgoing direction.

The dedication of the memorial which marks the site of Port Washington, which was constructed by the Continental troops in the Summer of 1776, and which was taken by the British after a heroic defense on Nov. 16, 1770, took place yesterday, with appropriate religious and military exercises.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- If it be true, as asserted this week, that King Edward refuses to be crowned until the war is over there may be a great disappointment in store for the shopkeepers of London, for the war is no nearer a finish now, according to all surface indications, than it was a year ago.

Saturday is usually a quiet day on the Harlem River Speedway, but yesterday was an exception to the rule. For a couple of hours before sunset there was some lively sport between trotters and pacers with fast marks. Page, 2:09 3/4, driven by Dr. Moore, trotted two fast heats with Swift, 2:15 3/4, driven by J.F. Cockerill, Page winning the first by a nose after a hard race, and the second by a length.

STRANGE and curious are some of the habits of the newly-Christianized natives of New Britain and New Ireland, who have recently been visited by a New Yorker, the Rev. John H. Denison, pastor of the Church of the Sea and Land, at Market and Henry Streets. Mr. Denison says the islands, which are a port of call for regular steamers running between Sydney and Singapore, now contain 13,000 church-goers.

Mrs. Fannie Bloomfield-Zeisler, the most distinguished of American women players of the piano forte, gave a recital yesterday afternoon in Mendelssohn Hall. There was a large audience, a fact which needs to be mentioned, because it is not the rule at piano recitals, and an abundance of applause, which is not at all usual where music is performed by a soloist.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to say a few words regarding the Fourth Avenue tunnel nuisance. There are exactly 3,729 houses affected by it, inhabited by 93,386 human beings. Some of these get noise, smoke, gas, and vibration; some noise and vibration, to say nothing about the loss in rental values and necessarily taxable values.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I should like to reply to some of the questions which "H.D.C." asks in his letter, printed in THE TIMES of the 6th inst., in regard to the canteen.

The eighteen-inch Gathmann gun was tested at Sandy Hook again yesterday. Two shots were fired at the target used on the previous day, and, though this target was somewhat battered, it was not injured to any serious extent, and the test, as on the first trial, was pronounced very unsatisfactory

TO the lovers of the beautiful for its own sake there is no season of the year in which the city parks afford such a rich harvest of delights as in the Autumn, that season called by the sinister name of "Fall." It is true that it is the beginning of death, the last "flurry" of the dying Summer, so to speak, and, perhaps.
OGUNQUIT was pale with excitement yesterday as the news ran about that Silas Larrabee was going to New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The Bridgeport Yacht Club, of Black Rock Harbor, acting on, the acceptance by the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club of Montreal, Canada, of the challenge for the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup for small yachts, has issued a circular announcing the conditions that are to govern the challenge race and the trials for the selection of a representative yacht for the cup event.

THE death of Li-Hung-Chang brought the Chinese question to the front in the Army and Navy Club the other evening. Dr. Louis Livingston Seaman, but recently returned from China, who was an intimate friend of the dead statesman and a surgeon in the army throughout the Philippine and the China campaigns, said in defense of China and its people:

From The Harrisburg (Penn.) Patriot. "One of our constables last week had $88.44 as his profit for one Sunday's work in arresting violaters of the game laws, and what he did could be readily duplicated by other constables, if they were only willing to keep their eyes open and do a little hustling."
Why Gambters "Fell Out." THE sporting men are whispering a story of tragic interest which occurred recently (to use the expression) "in their midst."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Japanese Minister has just received telegraphic advices from his Government which show that statements recently published concerning; a financial panic in Japan are unfounded. There have been some fluctuations in the stock market, but nothing of an alarming nature, and the publication of the Government's new financial scheme has checked effectually the downward movement.

ALONG the Bowery are dozens of windows where are displayed unredeemed pledges, trinkets or valuables that have strayed from all quarters into these, eddies of commerce. Sometimes a melancholy interest attaches to these things, but the pawnbroker, to a foe to melancholy. Therefore he puts humorous placards upon his wares, to catch the eye and evoke a smile, for a good-humored man is a better customer than a gloomy one.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- The sealed verdict of the jury, rendered last night, in the contest over the will of Mrs. Letitia Robinson, was opened to-day by Judge Johnson in the Delaware County Court at Media, Penn. The jury found that the will should be broken, on the ground of undue influence.

To the Edito of The New York Times: I was present at the police trials yesterday, and to-day read the story of them published in at least four daily papers, and was surprised to see that there was no correct report of the conditions relative to the dismissing by Devery of the debt complaints referred to in the trials.

THERE was once a young fellow who prided himself on being the champion long-distance author of the world. It was his proud boast that he had once written two complete and hair-raising novels of about 200,000 words each within the space of six working days, and he was wont to aver with confidence that he could repeat the performance with one hand tied behind him.

THE negrot problem is not the sole property of the South. To be sure, it is there most complicated and pressing. Yet north of Mason and Dixon's line there live to-day three-quarters of a million men of negro lineage. Nearly 400,000 of these live in New Kngland and the Middle Atlantic States, and it is this population that I wish especially to study in a series of papers.

The Committee on Dependent Children, organized by the Charity Organization Society, publishes a full report on its operations. Its existence came of proposed legislation aimed at protecting those of tender age from taint through commitment to institutions by association with other children depraved before commitment.

The week's market has been feverish. Transactions have risen in volume beyond recent averages; but there has been no actual tendency one way or the other. A variety of important business developments have been recorded. The danger of grave and protracted Western railway war has disappeared, official promulgation of "settlement" issuing during the week; and this is, naturally enough, accounted a factor making for lasting betterment.

The flotation of companies owning lands in Texas and other States to which attention has recently been drawn by the discovery of oil has of late been a profitable field for that class of promoters whose sole object is to sell stock irrespective of the future of the companies the securities of which they place in the hands of the public.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It strikes me as strange to see the names of certain well-known Christian ministers attached to paragraphs in me papers recommending an open saloon for certain hours on the Christian day of rest. These gentlemen know, possibly, better than I do, that the weekly day of rest is of divine origin.

The Brooklyn police are investigating what they regard as a remarkable story of robbery told by Mrs. George W. Smith of 104 Fifty-fifth Street, South Brooklyn. Mrs. Smith declares that on Wednesday last she was bound and gagged by a thief, who had visited her apartments on the pretense that he had been sent to inspect her piano.

Mrs. Saelma Haebe, seventy-four years old, died yesterday at her home, 335 South Third Street, Williamsburg, and twenty minutes later her husband expired. The death of both came suddenly. It had always been their wish that when death claimed one, it would claim the other, and their request was granted.

In the following list "mtg" Stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WEDNESDAY, NOV. 20. -- By Bryan L. Kennelly Co., administrator's sale. One Hundred and First Street, north side, 100 feet west of Third Avenue, nine lots, each 25 by 100.11, and one lot, 15 by 100.11.

Our London correspondent gives us in his cable letter a glimpse of the conditions surrounding university education in Ireland which is at once amusing and instructive. The chronic grievance of the Irish and the chronic resistance of the English upon this subject are alike unintelligible to an American.

As usual, the athletes of Company E of the Thirteenth Regiment almost made a clean sweep of the honors at the annual Fall games of the regiment, held at the armory, corner of Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, last night, winning first place in six of the ten events, second place in seven of them, and taking three of eight thirds as well.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Electric locomotives to propel trains through the Park Avenue tunnel would provide the best and most economical remedy for existing evils, disposing at once of the question of ventilation, eliminating the noise from the exhaust of powerful steam locomotives, and materially diminishing the vibration due to passing trains.

THE young woman had roughly sketched a wicket, a flea, a hen, a man, a purse, and a lion. These miscellaneous specimens of animate and inanimate nature were separated by wide blank spaces which the illustrator was vainly endeavoring to fill in to her satisfaction.

The last horse show of the season and a most important one, both socially and otherwise, will be that which will take place at the Riding and Driving Club, Orange, N.J., during the evenings of Nov. 28, 29, and 30. A special feature will be a matinee during the last day of the exhibition. The committee in charge of affairs is presided over by Ira A. Kip, Jr.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Scratches in the Second District Special reduced the field to three starters at the Bennings track to-day. In this race Knight of Rhodes, at the prohibitive price of 1 to 20 in the first heat and 1 to 10 in the second heat, proved the only winning favorite of the day, second choices winning three of the four other races.

Few people realize the difficulties which have to be overcome by Mr. Sam Franko before he can arrange the concerts which are rendered so smoothly at the Lyceum Theatre. For example, Mr. Franko determined to play the overture to "Oedipe a Colone," by Sacchini, an Italian composer who died in 1786.

Hiram Mabie. Hiram Mabie, the oldest citizen of Peekskill, died on Friday in his ninety-sixth year. He learned the wheelwright trade there, and followed it for many years. In 1850 he began pattern-making in Peekskill, which he followed until 1890, working at the bench until he was eighty-four years old.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe THE TIMES is quite as strong an opponent of intemperance as I am and that it recognizes as clearly as any one the heartrending evils that flow therefrom, and that when it advocates the opening of the liquor saloons on Sunday I am pretty sure it thinks that drunkenness would not be increased thereby.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- On the eve of the departure of Mrs. Patrick Campbell for the United States her admirers, who comprise probably the larger proportion of Londoners who frequent the higher-priced theatres, and many Americans and other foreigners who know the contemporary stage well, find themselves wondering what sort of a reception she will have.

When an overwhelming majority of the voters of a city of 75,000 inhabitants decide that for two years they wish to have as the chief, executive officer of their municipality an untutored laboring man, there must be something about that particular Individual which makes him stand out from the usual order of men.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16. -- In the midst of the Princeton game this noon fire broke out in the Hutchinson student dormitory, and in three hours had destroyed the interior of the handsome six-story structure, entailing a loss of $75,000, uninsured, oil the building and over $30,000 in personal effects of the 200 student roomers.

"THAT Consul," remarked my forecastle-head companion, "was a queer-looking fellow. He bad fishy, light blue eyes, a long dropping sandy mustache, and the soberest face ever saw on a man. He was new to his job, and wanted to do everything just right.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were not very large, but trading was fairly well diversified, and the market showed some signs of improvement. A few sharp advances resulted from the day's operations, and scattered throughout the list were a number of smaller gains. The few stocks that declined were considerably out-numbered by those that advanced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 15th, Lottie Blair Parker defends her story, "Under Southern Skies," assuming that there is nothing inconsistent in her plot, which presupposes a taint of negro blood in the heroine. She is correct. Such a suspicion might be assumed reasonably vague, uncertain, and indefinite, but still natural.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent wide comment over the entertainment by President Roosevelt at the White House of the talented negro President of the Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, recalls to my mind an interesting incident in which Mr. Washington figured last Summer.

THE man who frequents barber shops is willing to admit that if there is any place where he cannot say his soul is his own it is in the average city barber shop. A well-known rounder who has been shaved so many times since youth that he can't remember the date of beginning, was standing in front of a barber's shop the other afternoon looking sour and rubbins his freshly shaven chin.

Seven men, carrying lighted lanterns, one of them bearing a leg of mutton, and all being accompanied by dogs had the residents of One Hundred and Seventy-fourth Street, near Clinton Avenue, in an uproar at 2 o'clock yesterday morning. The men were looking for a family which on Suturday morning had ordered the mutton from Richard Webber's butcher shop at One Hundred find Twentieth Street and Third Avenue.

Women in West One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street are frightened by reports to the police of the daring of a woman footpad." They do not feel safe after dark unless accompanied by escorts. The police of the One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station learned to-day of an attack made Saturday night by the woman footpad on Mary Monaghan.

Golf during the coming week will be somewhat quieter than has been the case since Labor Day. Every week from that time has been well filled with competitions of many sorts on all of the metropolitan links. Winter preparations are being made by some clubs, for while the competitive season closes for nearly all of the local clubs, the links are not entirely closed except in a few cases.

Several of the much-talked-of and postponed trotting and pacing races on the Harlem River Speedway wore held yesterday morning under somewhat unfavorable circumstances. The threatening weather and cold wind that swept the entire course kept hundreds of spectators away, and the footing in the upper stretch was not as good as it might have been.

Not the happiest society woman in Brooklyn just now is Mrs. Harriet Burton of 1,037 Fulton Street. Mrs. Burton is in fear of nervous prostration because of the many troubles she is experiencing as a result or the strenuous wind-up of a big progressive euchre party which she managed a few nights ago. The euchre was held in the Johnston Building, on Nevins Street, and was attended by about 300 women.

O.B. Wheeler. Jr., who was arrested Saturday charged with attempting to negotiate $103,000 in forged notes in Wall Street, was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday mornings Magistrate Cornell remanded him until this morning, when Henry J. McCormick, Wheeler's counsel, will endeavor to show that he is mentally irresponsible, and will ask that he be committed to Bellevue.

WICHITA, Kan:, Nov. 17. -- News of the death of Anna Green, a pupil of the Mount Hope (Oklahoma) School, who was shot by six drunken huntsmen Friday afternoon, has just been received here. A boy named John Williams was shot through the hand, and other pupils were more or less injured by flying bullets and broken glass in their mad rush to get out of the building. The men are now locked in jail.

The Metropolitan Bowling Club still leads the list in the local bowling records with its remarkable score of ten victories and no defeats in the American National tournament. The first team of the Prudential Life Insurance Company makes the next best showing, with nine straight victories in the Life Insurance League tournament, while the Prosperity team in the Grand Central tournament in Brooklyn has a record of eight wins and no defeats.

William Sleaman was thrown from the seat of his cab and dragged for half a block along Fifth Avenue yesterday by his runaway horse. He held to the reins until the animal was stopped after crashing into a trolley car. Sleaman, who is twenty-six years of age, was driving along Broadway when his horse became frightened and started to run.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- Discussing the possibility of an Anglo-Russian understanding, the Paris Journal des Debats, quoted by the Paris correspondent of The Times, says two conditions are indispensable: First, Great Britain must cease to thwart Russian policy; secondly, she must cease to thwart French policy where the two powers are destined to live side by side.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- Charles A. Conant, Special Commissioner of the War Department on Coinage and Banking in the Philippines, and D.R. Williams, Secretary of the Philippine Commission, left here for Washington to-night. They are carrying with them the annual report of the Philippine Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By all means let us have "Sunday opening." Many experiments have been tried, and the results have not been all that was desired. Surely a saloon proprietor who is able to keep his place respectable on Monday should be able to do the same on Sunday. The house or place of business should be licensed, not the proprietor.

The Emanu-El Sisterhood of Personal Service of Temple Emanu-El showed their new house for carrying on their philanthropic work at 318-320 East Eighty-second Street, yesterday, during a reception which was held for the purpose of making acquainted those who are interested in the charitable work which is being done there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The persons in the Episcopal Church who claim to be Protestants point to the legal name as a proof of their claim. But we say that the Episcopal Church is not entitled to bear the epithet, because having much more in common with Catholic Churches than Protestants we should be classed rather with the former.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will place orders for the following equipment for delivery in 1902: Thirty-eight locomotives, 10 six-wheel shifters, 2 four-wheel shifters, 25 passenger coaches, 11 baggage cars, 1 combined baggage and coach, 1 combined mail and baggage car, 1,300 80,000 pounds' capacity box cars, 4,000 100,000 pounds' capacity steel hoppers, and 700 flat cars, a total of 50 locomotives, 38 passenger equipment cars, and 6,000 freight equipment cars.

Policeman Ford of the East Fifty-first Street Station distinguished himself Saturday afternoon last by arresting one automobile which he found loitering in a suspicious manner at the corner of Forty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue. The machine was an aristocratic $4,000 one, and after considerable difficulty the officer got it to the station house.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- Ex-Queen Liliuokalani of Hawaii, who arrived here yesterday, is combining business and pleasure. Besides seeking the recovery of her health, she has come to consult the Federal authorities relating to the Crown Islands in Hawaii. These were sequestered by the Revolutionary Government at the time the monarchy was overthrown, and she has not been reimbursed for the loss of the Crown revenues, amounting to about $100,000 a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17. -- A story is published here to-day from Skagway, Alaska, under date of Nov. 6, telling of the discovery of what is alleged to be a huge conspiracy existing in Dawson and ramifying to Skagway, Victoria, Vancouver, and Seattle for the overthrow of the local govvernment of the Northwest Territory and the establishing of a republic, with Dawson as its capital.

MADISONVILLE, Ky., Nov. 17. -- Mining troubles in this district caused more blood-shed this morning. James H. Smith, a negro striker, is dead; George Crouch, another striker, is fatally wounded, while John West, Hut Dawson, and Nathan Bush, all guards, are wounded, none of them dangerously.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The only duty which is seriously detrimental to producers of leather and manufacturers of the articles into which it enters, is that upon hides. This duty was framed, ostensibly, as a benefit to the cattle raising industry. But as hides are a by-product, and as their prices have fluctuated entirely at variance with those of leather, the fallacy of this policy has been apparent to all.

Senator Nevada N. Stranahan, who has been appointed Collector of the Port of New York to succeed George R. Bidwell, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon and registered at the Murray Hill Hotel, Senator Stranahan came from Washington, where on Saturday he had a conference with President Roosevelt with regard to his appointment.

An open Sunday law was the topic discussed by the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur in his sermon at Calvary Baptist Church last night. As a preface to his discourse Dr. MacArthur said that during the day no had spent an hour looking among the saoens in the neighborhood of the church.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- The discussion at the triennial council of the Episcopal Church in San Francisco on the proposition to call the Episcopal Church the Catholic Church in America caused Bishop Burke, in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, to preach a sermon at to-day's mass on the growth of the Catholic Church in the United States.

HOSLYN, L.I., Nov. 17. -- Mrs. Clarence Mackay has almost doubled in size and greatly improved the William Cullen Bryant Library of this village. One result of her work has been the finding of several rare old books, formerly a part of Mr. Bryant's Cedarmere library. These books are first editions, and were given to the poet by the authors, and bear the signatures of famous men and women, and also Mr. Bryant's autograph.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- An election bet with some collateral issues will come before Judge Lewis in the District Court on Tuesday next. George Pierce has a saloon on Park Avenue. Some time ago he purchased some whisky from Henry Hollander of New York City and subsequently a judgment was rendered for Hollander because the whisky was not paid for.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- The redemption of Northern Pacific stock by the Northern Securities Company and the iron report, both American matters, were subjects of foremost interest on the Boerse during the last week.

It is time to sound a note of warning against the failure of Legislatures in failing so generally to surround with proper safeguards the production of vaccine virus and the several varieties of the animal serums for trade distribution. The business has become large and temptingly profitable.
In a sermon on Christian Science in the Thirty-fourth Street Reformed Church yesterday the Rev. Dr. John H. Elliott said:
Senator Platt, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening, was asked:

Alexander Long, said to be an actor, living at the Rossmore Hotel, was arrested last evening by Post Office Inspector Michael Boyle on the charge of sending green goods circulars through the mails. He was locked up at the West Forty-seventh Street Station. It was denied at the Rossmore Hotel that anything was known there of Long.

While Mrs. Anne Strobel, thirty-seven years old, lay writhing in agony on the kitchen floor of her home, 308 Ellery Street, Williamsburg, yesterday from the effects of carbolic acid which she had taken to end her life, and her three children stood weeping beside her, her husband, Charles Strobel, it is alleged, looked on with a grin.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Z.M. Ward, as counsel, yesterday issued summons and declaration in a suit for $20,000 damages brought in the New Jersey Supreme Court by Isaiah L. Bambers, Jr., against William Walker and Abram M. Rittenberg. The suit is to recover damages for injuries received in the explosion on upper Main Street just before July 4 last, in the tenement owned by Walker.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- There is an impression abroad that the "mossback" protectionists are fronted with the fight of their lives.

There is a significant note in the comments of the Republican press as to the appointments made by President ROOSEVELT and the methods of selection he has so far pursued. The feeling is very apparent that the President has a well-defined standard of fitness which must first be satisfied before any other claims are considered.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 17. -- John R. Montgomery, Deputy United States Marshal pro tem., a respected citizen of Oxford, and Deputy United States Marshal Hush Montgomery of Pontotoc left here yesterday for the purpose of arresting Will Mathis, an alleged counterfeiter and moonshiner, who lives twelve miles east of this place.

Dr. Albert Leary Gihon, seventy years old, a retired surgeon of the United States Navy, who came to this city from the South three weeks ago, to meet his wife, who had been in Europe, and who is expected back on Tuesday, died in Roosevelt Hospital early Sunday morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The subject to which you are to give publicity through the columns of your very popular paper I feel is one that at the present time is receiving more than ordinary consideration by the business men of this country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mindful of the part which THE TIMES took some years ago in pointing out the misdirected zeal of the New York Board of Health, in connection with the manufacture, distribution, and sale of antitoxins and vaccine virus, and incidentally the waste of public funds, unfair competition with legitimate manufacturers and practitioners of medicine, and suspicions of favoritism and jobbery which were involved.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 17. -- "Truth Dexter," the new novel of American life, is, according to the divorced wife of Ernest Fenollosa, formerly of the Boston Art Museum, a work of collaboration by Mr. Fenollosa and May Ledyard Scott of Mobile, Ala., who was the co-respondent in-the divorce proceedings.

Would-be depressors of market values found little consolation in the exhibits made by the Clearing House banks in the weekly statement made public on Saturday. In the face of gold exports during the week approximating five millions of dollars, the banks actually increased their cash holdings, while the surplus reserve account was bettered $1,413,900, and loans decreased $4,427,600.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Replying to your letter of the 31st ult: While the removal of tariffs on certain commodities would probably aid my particular business, that of shipbuilding, by increasing the ocean trade, particularly if a system of ship subsidies is adopted, I cannot but "view with alarm" any disturbance of the existing tariff conditions.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 17. -- William Brannon, who for ten years has suffered ostracism from the American turf, has bean reinstated at Latonia. The offeuse which made Brannon an outlaw was the alleged "ringing" of the noted horse Tanner under the name of Polk Badget at Latonia, on which he won something like $30,000.

SOFIA, Nov. 17. -- The brigands who abducted Miss Ellen M. Stone and Mme. Tsilka have not yet replied to the latest proposals of Mr. Dickinson, Diplomatic Agent of the United States in Sofia. This is believed to be due to the fact that the band has many leaders, and that they are unable to agree among themselves.

At the Mariners' Church, Madison and Catharine Streets, yesterday the New York Port Society celebrated with religious services the eighty-third anniversary of its founding. Sailors of various nationalities told in sailor fashion how "the scuppers of their hearts had been washed clear and clean of sins and Christ had been brought aboard in a heavy gale to pilot them over the bar into the calm waters of sheltered harbors."
To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES I read an article on the much-talked-of but evidently little understood canteen question.

The strategy of Policeman Patrick Cox of the West Thirtieth Street Station last night to stop and arrest a motor vehicle chauffeur whom he believed to be violating a city ordinance took the form of a cordon of policemen stretched across Seventh Avenue and Thirty-third Street. Policeman Cox got his man.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 17. -- Dennis Mulvihill,, the coal shoveler, who was elected Mayor of this city last week, announced to-night that he would begin his administration of reform by causing the abolition of the office of Fire Marshal and by preventing the consummation of the plans of the previous administration to erect a new City Hall at a cost of $500,000.

The twenty-second annual meeting of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, held yesterday morning at the institution, One Hundred and Fiftieth Street and Broadway, will ever remain a memorable one in the history of the society from the fact that $47,500 was subscribed by nine gentlemen prominent in Hebrew charities.

A. Mendoza, one of Andrew Freedman's ticket sellers at the Polo Grounds, for whom a general alarm was sent out by the police after the close of Saturday's football game between Cornell and Columbia on account of his disappearance with almost the entire receipts of one of the ticket windows for the game Saturday, has not been located yet, as far as the police of the city know.

BOSTON, Nov. 17. -- Prof. E.C. Pickering, Director of the Harvard Observatory, has made a discovery that, in his own words, "opens up possibilities of a very great future and bids fair to revolutionize all chemical and physical theories of the final composition of matter.

With the games this week the football season will be practically over, although several matches remain to be played. Of these the most important contests are those between Carlisle and Columbia and Pennsylvania and Cornell on Thanksgiving Day, while the army, as represented by West Point, and the navy by Annapolis, will contest on the Saturday following Thanksgiving on neutral grounds -- Franklin Field in Philadelphla.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- In spite of various happenings following which a rise in Stock Exchange quotations was confidently predicted, the condition of affairs at the end of the week has not materially improved. Neither the Northern Pacific nor the Franco-Turkish settlements, the cheerful speeches of Lord Salisbury and Mr. Brodrick, nor the lack of serious news from South Africa served to impart the promised upward movement on the Exchange.

There are no smoking rooms and no observation windows, but to all intents and purposes the new woman's club opened at 9 East Forty-sixth Street yesterday will be on a par with the average man's club. It is intended for the comfort and convenience of its members without a thought of self-improvement or the emancipation of woman from the cares of home life.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- In an informal, almost casual manner, the treaty which there is every reason to believe will end the long dead-lock over the Nicaragua Canal was signed to-day by Secretary Hay and Lord Pauncefote. Those who imagined that the signing of a treaty destined to become historic is a matter of ceremonious pomp were disappointed by the severely business-like manner in which the negotiation was completed.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Constantinople correspondent of The Times says that Abdur Rahman Pasha, when the Grand Vizierate was offered to him, made the removal of two of the Ministers a condition of his acceptance.

Gregory Hast, an English tenor, made his first appearance in this country yesterday afternoon, when he gave a song recital in Mendelssohn Hall. He was heard by a large and attentive audience, which seemed to be pleased with his singing. His programme was as follows:

Justice Jerome announced yesterday that he would not hear the charges of oppression and neglect of duty against Deputy Police Commissioner Devery, though the Supreme Court had decided that he could do so.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 18. -- In an interview to-day Senator Hanna, Vice President of the McKinley National Memorial Association, said that he did not approve the plan to use the surplus of $8,000 in the hands of the Grand Army people to erect a bronze statue to McKinley in Cleveland. He thinks these local monuments will detract from the funds necessary for the National monument at Canton.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 18 -- A Fall River special to The Transcript gives the quarterly dividend list, which, shows a distribution of $230,800 on a capitalization of $21,301,000 in the cloth mills, or 1.08 per cent. Nine out of thirty-six corporations listed paid no dividends, as compared with ten in the preceding quarter.

Panic prevailed in Proctor's Pleasure Palace, or Fifty-eighth Street Theatre, on Third Avenue, last night, when the technoscope, or moving picture machine, apparently exploded. An alarm of fire was turned in, and half the audience rushed to the street. Most of them were persuaded to return to the theatre by a force of policeman and some cool-headed persons, but a number of women whose nerves were shaken by the excitement, hastened to their homes.

Business in the outside market yesterday was very light, and prices showed considerable irregularity. Under the same influences which governed the Stock Exchange market trading on the curb was confined within narrow limits, and the lack of any general support resulted in a number of declines.

The Horse Show is the one event which crowns all others in the social world. There is a full account of it elsewhere. There have been many dinners and small entertainments given at the various hotels and restaurants between the afternoon and evening hours and after the show. The corridors of several of the hotels were crowded all day.

While op her way to the Horse Show last night Mrs. F.S. Alen, who lives at 687 West End Avenue, had a narrow escape when her coach came in collision with a cab on Fifth Avenue, between Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets. With her in the coach was William H. Cann, who lives at 232 East Sixty-ninth Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 -- The market today was quiet but steady. Though the buying crowd seemed somewhat reluctant in the face of the engaged gold shipments from New York, it was sufficiently confident to make the day's results a record mostly of gains.

A statement was issued by Secretary George McAneny of the Civil Service Reform Association yesterday showing the patronage at the disposal of the incoming city administration. The laws in refereence to the removal of officials and the appointment of men to fill their places are set forth.

As the contest between Harvard and Yale draws near, the winning of which will decide the football championship, there is talk of professionalism, and the men accused are members of the Harvard eleven. There is no likelihood, however, that Yale will protest any member of the Harvard eleven, although campus talk at New Haven has for some time connected the names of Capt. Campbell, Cutts, and Kernan with professionalism.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- The Readings, Union Traction, Tidewater, and Cambria Steel and Lehigh Valley were the leaders in strength in the Philadelphia market. All of these stocks advanced in response to good demand. Union Traction went above 31 and found many purchasers at that point as a result of the announcement that along with the extra assessment on the stock, to pay for recent improvements, would be declared a dividend.

An accident on the Fifth Avenue Elevated line not far beyond the Brooklyn end of the bridge, and just at the rush hour, caused a serious blockade in travel from Manhattan to Brooklyn last evening. It resulted especially in a great crush at the New York terminus, where one man was quite severely injured and many women fainted.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- Dr. William Fisher Norris, a widely known oculist, died at his home here to-day, aged sixty-three years. Death was due to pneumonia. Dr. Norris was graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1861. He was appointed an Assistant Surgeon in the Union Army and was in charge of the Douglas Hospital at Washington in 1864.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- President Woodford of the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad received a dispatch to-day from the attorneys of the road in New York, advising him that the negotiations were closed in that city to-day whereby the Cincinnati, Hamilton and Dayton Railroad purchased the Findlay, Fort Wayne and Western Road.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article entitled "A Model Saloon for Sunday," in THE TIMES of Nov. 17, the question of the Sunday saloon has been treated in a manner idealistic, and consequently impracticable. Opposition to the Sunday opening of any saloon where only men congregate is suggested.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Harry Kundell, nee Lillian Bullard, will inherit almost all of the late Lyman Bullard's estate, in spite of the fact that she was disinherited about two years ago, when she married Mr. Rundell of Beach Ridge against Mr. Bullard's wishes. The estate is valued at $500,000.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- In spite of the Government disbursements, there was considerable demand for money to-day, chiefly in connection with the repayment of u2, 000,000 borrowed from the Bank of England Nov. 13. Discounts had an easier tendency owing to the scarcity of bills.

The disposition of the Government of Great Britain to agree to an Isthmian Canal treaty which the Senate of the United States would be willing to accept was affirmed many months ago on the authority of statements made by Lord PAUNCEFOTE in London. Reports to that effect have been often repeated of late, and with increasing precision as to the substance and terms of the treaty, indicating the progress of the negotiations toward complete agreement.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 18 -- Warren Brandriff, twenty-five years old, was arrested at 229 First Avenue to-day by Police Lieutenant George B. McClelland and James P. Rutledge, a Delaware detective, charged with having stolen $700 and jewelry valued at $500 from the home of his fiancee in Wilmington, Del., while she was dressing for the wedding ceremony, which was to have been held in a church in this city on last Monday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 18 -- Nathaniel Baxter, Jr., has resigned the Presidency of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway Company for the purpose of accepting a similar position with the Cumberland Coal and Coke Company. The resignation becomes effective Dec. 1. The new company has large capital behind it, and is fathered by St. Louis financiers, whose faith in the resources of Tennessee has been shown before.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The creditors of the late William H. Clark met to-day and organized to protect themselves. There were seventy-five persons present at the meeting, which was held at the Empire City track. This property of the Clark estate is to be sold at public auction on Thursday next at the Manor Hall in this city.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- Emperor William to- day took part in a debate by the Society of Naval Engineers on the subject of the plac- ing of heavy guns on battleships and its effect upon their design and construction.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- When a college football coach denounces the work of his team publicly over his own signature, as did George Woodruff, the University of Pennsylvania, it is little wonder the report which emanated at Ann Arbor, Mich., which reached here this afternoon, that there was a likelihood of "Mike" Murphy returning to Pennsylvania and acting in the dual capacity of football coach and trainer, was hailed with delight by the undergraduate body.

Mayor-elect Seth Low had a very busy time yesterday, while his private secretary, Mr. Clark, was so much occupied that when the headquarters were closed last evening he had not had the opportunity to digest the morning mail, to say nothing of the letters that came in later deliveries.

Advance of half a cent in posted rates for sterling exchange. Shipments of 495,000 ounces of silver to Europe by to-day's steamer. Bondholders of the Electric Vehicle Company said to have assented to the proposition to issue $575,000 additional 6 per cent, bonds for developing the business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The cold, threatening weather held down the attendance at Bennings to-day, but there was little diminution in speculation. Favorites again had a bad day, only two -- Tour and Andy Williams -- winning. The latter, a 1 to 2 proposition, won by a nose after the most exciting finish of the meet.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18 -- Coroner Funkhouser has rendered a verdict finding the St. Louis Health Department negligent in the preparation of diphtheria antitoxin, the administration of which recently caused the deaths of seven children by lockjaw.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Herr Von Holleben, the German Ambassador to the United States, has just returned to Washington from his Summer vacation in Europe. When asked about the existing relations between Germany and the United States, His Excellency said:

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Except as affording a chance for the Opposition journals to attack the Government and the Foreign Secretary. Lord Lansdowne, the signing of the new Isthmian Canal Convention does not excite strong interest in Great Britain. It is generally admitted that the British have nothing to gain by a retention of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, while they have much to gain by the construction of the canal.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Delegates to the primary convention of the newly established Protestant Episcopal diocese of Western Massachusetts, in a preliminary meeting to-night, declared unanimously for the Rev. Dr. D.H. Greer of St. Bartholomew's Church, New York City, for Bishop, and his election in the convention to-morrow will be made unanimously.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 18 -- Money at the Clearing House to-day loaned at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par, 5 cents, and 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $20,539,815; balances, $2,029,243. Call money is in better demand, and some of the beat borrowers are now paying 4 1/2 and 5 per cent., and only the very choicest collateral and specially favored borrowers are now able to shade the first-named figure.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 18 -- Gov. J.K. Toole, when seen to-day, declined for the present to state what his policy would be in regard to the absorption of the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railroads by the Northern Securities Company.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 18 -- It is a foregone conclusion that a special session of the Legislature will be called within a few days to enact laws to prevent any change in the operation or management of the Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railroads. Gov. Van Sant received advices from Montana, North Dakota, and Washington to-day, saying that those States would follow the lead of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Col Henry E. Noyes, Second Cavalry, to-day was retired on account of age. He was appointed to West Point from Maine in 1857. His retirement will promote Lieut. Col. Eli L. Huggins, Third Cavalry, now in the philippines, to be Colonel of the Second Cavalry, and Major Earl D. Thomas, Inspector General at Fort Myer, Virginia, to be Lieutenant at Fort Myer, Virginia, to be Lieutenant Colonel of the Third Cavalry.

All the aspirants for the billiard championship at eighteen-inch balk line practiced yesterday. Barutel, the French expert, varied the monotony of practice, however, by starting a match with "Willie" Hoppe, the juvenile exponent of the game, which will be contested every afternoon and evening this week at Daly's Academy.

The letters from representative business men on the general subject of tariff revision, now appearing in the columns of this journal, are of unusual interest, and will be so regarded by the thoughtful reader. Our correspondents are by no means in agreement, either as to the principle of tariff revision or as to details of a safe economic policy, but represent widely divergent views from widely different standpoints.

"Coon" songs have brought the "coon" into many things and usually with attractive results. Snapping mottoes have the wrappings for the fancy caps inside of crepe paper this year, and some of the quaintest have coon decorations and a bar from a coon song on the paper.

Over $7,080,000 in gold bars, the largest withdrawal from the Assay Office in one day on record, and the largest shipment to be consigned to one transatlantic steamship, will leave New York to-day on board the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse for Europe. Of this shipment, about $1,000,000 is consigned to Berlin and the remainder will go to Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The annual report of Gov. William M. Jenkins of the Territory of Oklahoma was made public today by the Secretary of the Interior. Gov. Jenkins makes a strong plea for statehood, saying that the past rapid development of the material interests of the Territory insure its future.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A dispatch to the Daily Chronicle from Rome says:

MADISONVILLE, Ky., Nov. 18 -- The militia is now in control of the mining situation in Hopkihs and Webster Counties. Two companies of the Third Regiment are on duty under the personal direction of Adjt. Gen. Murray, and more will be called out if necessary.
