BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The court-martial appointed to inquire into the duel between Lieut. Blaskowitz and Lieut. Hildebrand, both army officers, at Insterburg, East Prussia, in which the former' was killed, has sentenced Lieut. Hildebrand to two years' imprisonment.

The James D. Hale estate has sold the old Hale piano factory site of about fifteen lots on Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues. The property has a frontage of 350 feet on Thirty-fifth Street, from 517 to 527, and extends through to 512 to 520 West Thirty-sixth Street.

The deeds of daring of the men who protect the lives and property of the citizens of this municipality from the dangers of fire and accident and the depredations of the criminal, together with the acts of courage of the surfmen who risk their lives to save the wrecked voyager from the waves, were recounted in stirring terms to appreciative members of the Congregational Club, at the St. Denis, last night.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In a recent issue of THE TIMES an editorial note expressed surprise that the friends of Mr. Richard Croker selected such an article as a jardiniere to present to the head of Tammany Hall as a sort of parting gift. The feeling of surprise originated through the writer of the article having received a defective education concerning the habits of well-to-do Englishmen.

NEWS FERRY, Va., Nov. 18 -- Miss Frances Coleman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Coleman, was married here to-day in the Episcopal Church to Roger Williams of New York. The bride was pronounced by the late President McKinley to be the most beautiful girl he saw in the Old Dominion.

Among the clergymen who last Sunday opposed the proposition to relax the stringency of the existing excise law by procuring the amendment of it as regards selling on Sunday were Dr. MACARTHUR, Dr. BANKS, and Dr. PATTERSON, of the Baptist, Methodist, and Universalist Churches, respectively.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- An uproarious incident occurred yesterday in the Chamber of Deputies in the course of the discussion on the bill authorizing a loan of 265,000,000 in 3 per cent, perpetual rentes, to reimburse the Treasury for its outlay as a result of the Chinese Expedition and to pay indemnities to French sufferers in China.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 18 -- For failing to attend school regularly Mrs. Emanuel Smallstreet of this city punished her thirteen-year-old stepson, Hal, at noon to-day. The boy resented the action of his step-mother and said she would have cause to regret it.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The Board of Health met this afternoon and passed a resolution forbidding all physicians to resort to vaccination until the board has an opportunity to investigate the fatal results which have followed it in several cases here. The board further advised the Board of Education to refrain from enforcing the law for the time being.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Surgeon General of the Marine Hospital Service has been advised of the death of Acting Assistant Surgeon Stuart Eldridge, who was on duty in the office of the United States Consul General at the Port of Yokohama, Japan. Dr. Eldridge was a native of New York State, but had resided in Japan for many years.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

National athletics in many phases were considered yesterday by the magnates of the Amateur Athletic Union in their annual meeting held in the Astor House. The delegates were in continuous session from 12 o'clock until 10 o'clock last night, long discussions over proposed changes of rules and other matters of importance to the athletic community making a prolonged and active meeting.

Because the Rev. Dr. Octavus Flagg, ex-professor of Yale and a friend to Bishop Potter, declared that Emma Bowker of Inwood, L.I., the young daughter of a poor painter of that village had a "heavenly voice," Mrs. Russell Sage, Mrs. Daniel Lord, Mrs. James R. Keene, and Miss Helen Gould have planned to send her to Europe to have her voice cultivated.
We owe to the researched of our esteemed contemporary, the Courier des Etats Unis, a most interesting account of a German military plan for the invasion and subjugation of the United States.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 18 -- A.F. Lowenthal, a diamond broker, of New York, arrived here Saturday evening and registered at the Portland Hotel. He was assigned a room on the ground floor of the hotel and placed a trunk containing diamonds valued at $10,000 and $200 in gold in the room.

-- There still lingers in many lands, and in the minds of not a few people apparently sane, the belief that a forked hazel twig, if called a "divining rod" and manipulated in peculiar ways by persons peculiarly gifted, will reveal the position of hidden treasures, such as subterranean water courses and deposits of metal, native or minted.

In the hearing on the motion for alimony and counsel fees made before Justice Leventritt in the Supreme Court yesterday by counsel for Mrs. John G. Gilmore in the suit for annulment of marriage brought against her by her husband, a rather extraordinary state of affairs was revealed.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 18 -- Numerous business men and friends of Gov. Rogers an Tacoma, Spokane, and Seattle have been urging him to take action similar to that proposed by Gov. Van Sant of Minnesota, by calling the Legislature together in extra session to enact anti-trust laws such as will prevent the consolidation of the Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railways under one management.

A situation of more than ordinary intensity in the second act, and a melodramatic climax of no especial originality but not without theatric value, served to relieve the somewhat tardy and unconvincing movement of Augustus Thomas's play, "Colorado," which was produced at Wallack's last night.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Prompted by the announcement of the naval estimate to be submitted to Congress in December, involving the expenditure during the next fiscal year of $100,000,000 and "a larger increase programme than was ever presented to Congress," a remonstrance prepared by a number of citizens, chiefly members of the American Peace Society, of which Secretary Long is a member, was put in circulation for signatures in this city to-day.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Gov. Odell said to-night relative to the statement that he would discuss the Sunday excise question in New York City to-morrow:

After a rough pasage of twenty-five days, during which time she was on three different occasions in sight of the Highlands Light, the brig Sunlight, from Jamaica, got in yesterday. Tuesday night of last week the skipper, whose name is Wright, said that he had sighted the light for the second time, the first time having been on the Sunday before.

J. Romaine Brown Co. have sold for Robert H. Benary to Andrew J. Connick the plot 75 by 100 at the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and Two Hundred and Fourth Street. Mr. Connick is also the purchaser of the three lots on the north side of One Hundred and Eishty-first Street, 100 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.
New England Free Trade League, Boston, Nov. 2, 1901. To the Editor of The New York Times: Speaking for myself individually, and not for the Free Trade League, I answer your inquiries as follows:

A bad man struggling with adversity is a spectacle so grateful to the moralist that it is the moralist's public duty to call attention to it whenever he encounters it. And we observe, with great pleasure, in the news columns of yesterday's Evening Post, that RICHARD CROKER is such a man.

PASSAIC, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Peter Reid of the Reid Barry Mills has given $50,000 to the City of Passaic for a public library. The site of the library will be in the Dundee section of the city. The building is to be a memorial to Jane Watson Reid. Mr. Reid is reputed to be a millionaire. The offer has been accepted.

Every foot of ground around this town is full of legends. Stories of Indians, stories of Bienville and Iberville, and all the rest of the gentlemanly adventurers, and some adventurers who were not gentlemen, can be had here for the asking Something of the dreamy charm which these ancient oaks cast over the wanderers from France and Spain and other countries is with them still.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 19 -- Miss Patti Ellison of Louisville and Sir Charles Ross were married to-day at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Ellison. On account of a business engagement of Sir Charles in New York the wedding was advanced a day, having been planned for to-morrow.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 19 -- The new Diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church composed of Hampden, Hampshire. Franklin, and Berkshire Counties and all of Worcester County, except Southbridge, was formally organized in the primary convention of the parochial delegates held in Christ Church to-day.

Running expenses of first-class automobiles are rather high as well as their first cost, according to testimony adduced in the trial of a suit brought by Frangois Engeidinger, an imported French chauffeur, against Talbot J. Taylor, a banker, to recover $100.72 for alleged breach of contract, in the Tenth District Municipal Court before Judge Murray yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The prospect of increased importations from the United States into Austria-Hungary is not viewed with complacency in the latter country, according to a report to the State Department from Consul General Hurst at Vienna dated Oct. 28. Austrian manufacturers and agriculturists, he says, are making an organized effort to stem the inflow of American products, which last year amounted to about $30,500,000.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and abundant. It is believed the Government has been disbursing freely lately. The large exports of gold from New York have caused an easier tendency in discounts. Though the gold is going to the Continent, the market is confident that it will soon find its way here.

Mayor-elect Seth Low and Senator T.C. Platt are to confer. The conference will be held at Mr. Low's residence, 30 East Sixty-fourth Street, to-morrow morning. Mr. Low made the announcement of the conference at his headquarters last evening in a written statement, which he first read to the assembled reporters and then handed to them to be copied.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19. -- The market today was more active and higher. The initial strength was imparted by the demand for Cotton Duck, which put the stock up 1 1/4, and the income bonds the same amount. The Street heard favorable rumors of encouraging developments and of an immediate dividend on the stocks of the new company.
BUFFALO, Nov. 19. -- Mayor Diehl suspended City Treasurer Philip Gerst to-day, charging him with misconduct in office and with having kept inaccurate and false accounts.
Columbia's hockey team began practice in the St. Nicholas Rink yesterday afternoon in preparation for the coming season. The team will practice twice a week from now on.

John J. Delany tendered his resignation yesterday as Assistant District Attorney, and Samuel H. Ordway was appointed in his stead, while Mr. Delany was made a Deputy Assistant District Attorney. The reason for the change, Mr. Philbin said, was to make it possible for Mr. Ordway to appear before the Grand Jury and present to them the evidence against Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell and Contractor William L. Marks.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company desires to abandon seven stations now existing on the elevated road in that city, but yesterday, when the subject was discussed before a meeting of the State Railroad Commission, reduced the number to six.
Army. Major Henry I. Raymond; Surgeon, is ordered to the Philippines, sailing on the transport Buford from New York about Jan. 15.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis, leaving London for New York next Thursday, will have among her passengers E. Wishard and John Huggins, trainer for W.C. Whitney. It is doubted if either will return here, although in each case a return to Great Britain is contingent upon arrangements that may be made in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Signor F. Mayor des Planches, who succeeds Baron Feva as Italian Ambassador to the United States, was formally received by Presidept Roosevelt at the White House Just prior to the meeting of the Cabinet to-day. He was accompanied by Secretary Hay, who presented him to the President.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- The densest fog ever experienced in Chicago caused numerous collisions between trains early to-day. In these collisions one man was killed, two were so badly injured that they probably will die, and fifteen others were seriously hurt. Scores of others, the police say, were injured in minor accidents due to the fog, but as they were able to assist themselves no official reports were made.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- Henry Martin, publisher and editor of The Daily News, died to-day at the University Hospital of hydrostatic pneumonia, following a surgical operation. He was thirty-eight years of age, and was President of the Fellowship Club, a member of the Clover Club, and President and Secretary of the Pen and Pencil Club for several years.

President Guggenheimer started on its passage through the Municipal Assembly yesterday an ordinance which if passed will relieve the smoke nuisance in the New York Central tunnel from Forty-second Street to the Harlem River, Mr. Guggenheimer told the members of the Municipal Council that there should be no delay in this matter, and that the people demanded that this improvement be made by the railroad companies as soon as possible.

Again the Horse Show eclipses all other forms of social amusement. There is a great deal, however, going on quietly. Little dinners and luncheons and all that sort of thing. There was also one wedding yesterday, that of Miss Caroline Schell Giilender, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus T. Gillender, and William M. Fliess. Jr. To-day Miss Edith Slater Mills, the daughter of Mrs. Abraham Mills, will marry W. Wilson Drake.

Prominent charity workers from all parts of the State, together with those of this city, gathered last night in Association Hall, in East Twenty-third Street, to attend the opening of the second New York State Conference of Charities and Corrections. Gov. Odell. Archbishop Corrigan. Robert W. De Forest, and R. Fulton Cutting made addresses.

Positive confirmation was given in Brooklyn last night to the report that Postmaster Francis H Wilson had, tendered his. resignation to President Roosevelt. The resignation, however, has not yet been accepted by the President. Mr. Wilson expects to leave the Brooklyn Post Office in about three weeks.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- At the recent election William G. Barren of Katonah was elected Register of the County of Westchester.

" Colonel" Robert A. Ammon, the Miller syndicate lawyer, who placed $140,000 of the syndicate money in the defunct firm of Seymour, Johnson Co., went on the stand in the bankruptcy hearing before Referee John A. Straley yesterday and declined to tell of the $140,000.

A fairly large number of stocks were dealt in in the outside market yesterday, but in none were the transactions large. Prices showed much irregularity, some issues declining, while others advanced. It happened, though, in several cases of stocks that declined during the morning that the afternoon trading brought about substantial recovery.

PATERSON, Nov. 19. -- Under the new and exceedingly strict pure food law of New Jersey, which went into effect Nov. 1, a large force of State Inspectors swooped flown on the milk dealers of this city early to-day, with disastrous consequences to the dealers. Supplies of the fluid which came in on trains were tested, as well as that which local dairymen and neighboring farmers were peddling in wagons.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- A fresh outburst of liquidation in the Asphalt securities overshadowed everything else in the Philadelphia market and brought about the most violent shrinkage in the price of those bonds since the beginning of the Asphalt scare. The market in other directions moved oblivious of this sensational fall, prices in most instances showing fractional appreciation, the Reading common being an exception.

COLON, Nov. 19 -- Gen. Alban, with a force of 1,100 men, well armed and having cannon and modern quick-firing guns with them, has started to attack the insurgent forces, which are strongly intrenched at Cborrera.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Four favorites were among the winners at Bennings to-day -- Sadducee, Extinguisher, The Puritan, and McMeekin, the last two at the prohibitive prices of 1 to 15 and 1 to 8, respectively. Seventeen horses faced the barrier in the second event. It resulted in an exciting dead heat between Trauer and Succasunna.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The three burglars who broke into the little Post Office at Englishtown last night mode easy work of the Job and as much noise about it as if they weren't afraid of the whole town.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Persons who staid away from the National Reciprocity Convention through fear it would be captured by free traders will read the story of the opening sessions, held to-day, with mingled gratification and amusement. If the outcome of the convention was indicated by what was said and done to-day its declarations will be a long way removed from such a pronouncement as a body of free traders would put forth.

Richard Croker made two announcements yesterday. One was in an interview in which he challenged and defied the Republicans to show that he ever obtained a dollar dishonestly in his life. His defiance was delivered at the Democratic Club and for the first time since election day he showed by his actions that he intended to remain for some time at the head of Tammany Hall and try to fight back into power.

VINCENNES, Ind., Nov. 19. -- Three hundred union miners from Washington, Princeton, Petersburg, Linton, Sullivan, and Bicknell came here during the night and early to-day marched to the shaft of the Protest Hill Coal Mine Company, where non-union miners are employed, and closed the shaft.

In the following list " mtg " stands for mortgage and " R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Nearly four hundred guests filled the great banquet hall of Delmonico's last evening, the occasion being the one hundred and thirty-third annual banquet of the New York Chamber of Commerce. The room was crowded to the doors, and more than one member of the organization who was late in applying for a ticket was unable to recure a seat.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 19 -- Frank Brown, ex-Postmaster of Baltimore, and ex-Governor of Maryland, the wealthiest Democrat in the State, has been criticising the leaders of the German organization and advocating reorganization of his party, To-day he announced his desire to undertake the task.

One football team left the city yesterday and another one entered it. The Columbia Kickers. accompanied by Coach Sanford, with trainers, to the number of twenty men in all, left last night shortly after 9 o'clock over the Pennsylvania Railroad for Annapolis, where they will line up to-day agninst the naval cadets.

Another brilliant day at the Horse Show. If anything, it was more crowded, more representative than Monday. At both afternoon and evening sessions there were many well-known fashionable people -- in fact, the entire set was present. Not only were the boxes filled, but many of the seats.

Too much approval cannot be expressed of the plan of the managers of the Louisiana purchase Exposition in 1903, to be held in St. Louis, to make it in every detail a demonstration of the fact that the burning of bituminous coal can be effected without the usual accompaniment of sulphurous and tormenting smoke.

SANTIAGO, Cuba, Nov. 19 -- To-day Gov. Gen. Wood and Mrs. Wood entertained Mayor Bacardi, Adjt. Gen. McGunnegle, and several prominent Cuban officials at luncheon on the Government yacht Kanawha. Major Barbour, Chief of the Sanitary Department, took Collector Bliss and the other members of Gen. Wood's party to El Cobre, where they inspected the mines and looked at the famous shrine.

Presbyterian clergymen and laymen met last night in the home of Constant A. Andrews, at 737 Madison Avenue, for a conference as to the civic, moral, and religious relations of the white Kb the colored people, living in "Little Africa," or that part of the city extending west of Sixth Avenue to the Hudson River, and north of Twenty-sixth Street to Fifty-second Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- A well-dressed individual made himself at home in the house of L. de F. Munger, President of the Munger Tire Company, on Bayard Street, yesterday. He called about noon. The maid opened the hall door and informed him that the family had just, gone out for the day in an automobile.
Emeline Dale, a six-year old child, died early yesterday morning at Busch's Hotel, Hoboken, from poisoning.
TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 19 -- As a result of a run brought about by a misunderstanding the Metropolitan Bank, of which P.V. Ceasar was President, closed its doors to-day.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Some time ago Journeay Burnham, a New Jersey corporation doing business in Brooklyn, N.Y., was dissolved by the Directors as Trustees, with the consent of 92 per cent, of the stockholders, and the assets were subsequently sold under advertised sale to William F. Irish, a clerk of the Williamsburg Trust Company.

Mayor-elect Low's first official visit to the City Hall will be made to-day. In answer to a letter sent by Mayor Van Wyck, Mr. Low said that he would be at the City Hall to-day, and Mayor Van Wyck then invited his successor to be present at the meetings of the Board of Estimate and the Sinking Fund Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Having finished his labors with the Kentucky politiclans. President Roosevelt is now up to his neck in Missouri politics, and is being besieged by representatives of the rival factions in that State. Richard C. Kerens, the head of one faction, was at the White House to-day with W.S. Dickey and E.L. Morse, and they are to have another conference with the President to-morrow.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Joseph L. Fornachon, faultlessly dressed and appearing like a prosperous business man, with his pretty young wife, were arraigned in the First Precinct Court this morning, charged with violating the city ordinance prohibiting begging. Fornachen wore immaculate linen and undressed kid gloves, while his trousers were neatly creased.

The report of the British Board of Trade of proceedings under the Conciliation act of 1896, just issued, covering the two years-ended with June last, seems to indicate that progress is being made in the direction of adjusting differences without recourse to strikes. The net results have probably failed to realize the expectations of those who have been instrumental in organizing and maintaining the machinery of voluntary arbitration, but that was to be expected.

The trial by court-martial of Col. Robert L. Meade, Commandant of the Marine Barracks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, charged with drunkenness on duty and scandalous conduct tending to the destruction of good morals in the service, was begun at 10 o'clock yesterday morning in the assembly room over the Paymaster's office in the navy yard.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The annual report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue shows that the total receipts for the year ended June 30, 1901, were $306,871,069, or $11,555,561 in excess of the estimates, about the same amount in excess of the receipts for the year ended June 30, 1900, and $33,000,000 in excess of the receipts for 1899.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- This evening at the Episcopal Church of the Annunciation Miss Mary Reynolds Lyle, daughter of Mrs. Clara Oram Lyle, was married to Morton Mackay Lyon of New York. The Rev. Father Odell, rector of the parish, performed the ceremony. The ceremony was followed by a small dinner at the home of the bride's uncle, W.R. Oram, 2,130 North Fifteenth Street.

Irregularity characterized the trading in the outside market yesterday. The same uncertain conditions which prevailed on Tuesday were continued and a number of stocks declined, while elsewhere in the list substantial advances were recorded. An event of special interest was the trading in Pocahontas Coal subscriptions, which until Tuesday had not been publicly dealt in.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The Appeal Court today rendered a decision sustaining the decision of the lower court that the late W. L. Winans, formerly of Baltimore, Md., was domiciled in England, and that the Crown, therefore, is entitled to legacy duty.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 20. -- Gov. Savage will take a hand in the fight against railroad combinations in the West. Attorney General Prout has promised to aid him. The State Constitution makes the following provision against the consolidation of parallel railroad lines:

Columbia's football team just about escaped from Annapolis with a victory yesterday, and there was no time for easy breathing, for the New York collegians, owing to Bruce's good right foot, earned a point that the embryo Deweys and Schleys failed in procuring after a similar trial, and turned a victory by the narrowest margin possible in football.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- In a game of two twenty-seven-minute halves the football team of West Point defeated the University of Pennsylvania eleven by a score of 24 to 0 here to-day. The visitors were clearly outclassed. They averaged more weight than the soldiers, but in spite of this failed to shatter the latter's strong line.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The action of an Anglo-American syndicate in applying to the London County Council for a 999 years' lease of a site on the north side of the Strand, for the erection of an office building on American lines, has caused much, comment and interest.

"Jake" Schaefer was the star in the billiard world yesterday, and his average of 22 4-18 in a 400-point game is the best he has done of late in a contest of this length at eighteen-inch balk line. Ortiz, the Spaniard, played against him at Slosson Wheelock's Academy. It was not until the fourth inning that Schaefer found conditions to suit him.

The numbers of the office seekers and their friends who have besieged Mr. Low's headquarters, 10 West Twenty-third Street, have become so large that Mr. Low has felt compelled to abandon his general receptions after this week. Yesterday he made the following formal announcement on the subject:

Aside from the Horse Show the day was not very gay, except in the matter of dinners and luncheons, all of which depended on the show for inspiration. There are to be a great many house parties this week. Some of them are to begin to-morrow and many of them will last over Thanksgiving William K. Vanderbilt has still a number of guests at Id e Hour who will remain over Sunday.

Quite a little dash of excitement was injected into the proceedings of the first business meeting of the Second New York State Conference of Charities and Correction, held yesterday in the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building.

John J. Manley was arrested late Tuesday night by Detective Sergeants Cuff and McNaught of the District Attorney's Office. He was arraigned before Police Magistrate Cornell in the Centre Market Police Court on a charge of grand larceny. Later in the day he was released in $2,500 bail.

Mrs. Elizabeth Dale, the mother of five-year-old Emiline Dale, who died at Busch's Hotel, Hoboken, Tuesday night, was arrested shortly after 9 o'clock last night upon a charge of murder. Edward Waller, the man who stopped at Busch's Hotel and occupied the next room to Mrs. Dale and her child, was arrested a few minutes before, and is now locked up.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- The market was dull and about steady, with a mixture of net changes. The buying was mostly of an investment character, the speculative demand being at a minimum, owing to uncertainties surrounding the sold movement. The day, however, showed some good advances.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 20. -- Secretary of state Laylin's report to the Governor shows that 1,851 new companies were chartered in Ohio in the year closing Nov. 15, 1901, and that 1,808 miscellaneous certificates were filed. The total capital involved was $204,977,890, as compared with $113,040,099 for 1900, a gain of $91,932,791.

The first row over the canvass of the vote of New York County occurred last evening, just before the official count was completed. For a time the dispute between the representatives of the two contesting political parties became bitter and then the Chairman of the Board of Canvassers, Councilman Owens, threatened to have all the Republican lawyers who were watching the canvass ejected from the City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Roosevelt gave out to-day for publication a memorial from the Tariff Reform Committee of the Reform Club of New York objecting to the passage of ship subsidy bills pending in Congress.

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 5, 8, and 10 cents discount. Exchange, $22,427,752; balances, $1,553,670. On call, new money is mostly 4 1/2 per cent. Some loans are still outstanding at 4 per cent., and a few borrowers are paying as high as 5 per cent.

The Corn Exchange Bank has bought the old five-story building 13, 17, and 19 William Street, adjoining its eleven-story structure at the northwest corner of William and Beaver Streets. The sellers of the property are the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company, and the consideration is said to have been about $375,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- A wide movement to secure the release of old Libbla Garribrant, the oldest life convict in the State Prison, has been begun. Libble is one of the most interesting prisoners the State has ever had. She is sixty years old, and has been in the State Prison since she was sixteen years old.

Champions at both the trotting and pacing gait were very much in evidence on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon, when there was a crowd of drivers and onlookers on the course during almost the entire afternoon. The famous trotter Lord Derby, 2:06 1/2, driven by Ed. Geers, and the crack pacer Shadow Chimes, 2:06 1/2, handled by a trainer, were among the participants of the sport.

That was a very straight, unmistakable, and categorical deliverance that the German Ambassador made to the reporters at Washington about Germany and the Monroe Doctrine. " You are without doubt aware that at regular intervals reports appear in the newspapers to the effect that Germany is trying to acquire coaling stations, or a foothold of some kind, in South America or in the West Indian waters.

Designs of Street Cleaning Commissioner Percival E. Nagle to sell the famous garbage dumping steam scows Cinderella, Asenenbroedel. and Cenerentola were blocked yesterday by an injunction granted by Justice Maddox of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, at the instance of Frederick P. Bellamy of that borough, who acted at the instance of the City Club.

By The Associated Press. LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and the price was irregular, though less stringent. Discounts were easier, owing to the state of the Continental exchanges and the prospect of further shipments of gold from New York.
By The Associated Press. LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The speech of Secretary Hay at the banquet of the New York Chamber of Commerce has aroused keen discussion in the London papers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Not a favorite showed in front at Bennings to-day, five second choices and the rank outsider Handicapper, quoted at 20 to 1, in the last event, winning. Cousin Jess won the steeplechase after a hard drive in the stretch, lowering the best previous trade time of 4:09 by 7 seconds.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 20 -- Mrs. Emily S. Ladenburg. a prominent society woman and reputed to be the finest cross country rider of her sex in the country. is to be made the defendant in a suit for $15.000 damages.

Mayor-elect Seth Low called at the City Hall yesterday and attended a meeting of the Board of Estimate. The meeting between Mayor-elect Low and Mayor Van Wyck was very cordial. There was a crowd at the City Hall to greet Mr. Low, who arrived at 11:15 in an automobile. He was not recognized until he had almost reached the Mayor's office.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 20. -- Major William Wayne died to-day at the old Anthony Wayne Mansion, near Paoli, this county. He was President of the Society of the Cincinnati, and had been President of the Sons of the Revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Mr. Fitchio says there is no foundation for the report that the charges were held up by Mr. Powderly. The charges are now before the Secretary of the Treasury. The New York Commissioner says his presence in "Washington has nothing to do with the Ellis Island cases, but that he is here with others helping to frame a new immigration law.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The confirmation of the reported capture of Colon by the Colombian Liberals caused a decided commotion in the State and Navy Departments to-day. There were long conferences between Secretary Long and Admiral Crowninshield, and between the Admiral and Acting Secretary of State Hill.
According to Sharon, Penn., dispatches, two new steel plants are to be built there which will employ 1,000 men.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 20. -- This town has fallen into the hands of the Liberals. Their attacking force was first commanded by Gen. Patino, but he was killed, and Col. Frederico Barrera succeeded him. The Government forces made little resistance. The attack was made unexpectedly at 8 o'clock last night, and the casualties included twelve or more men killed and about thirty wounded.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 20. -- A postponed wedding took place this evening at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mead, next to William G. Rockefeller's Summer home, the bride being the only daughter, Miss Tillie Augusta Mead, and the bridegroom, Robert Mead Wilcox, an official in the Fourth National Bank of New York City.

Lieut, Commander Lucien Young of the United States Navy arrived here Tuesday from Havana on leave of absence. He is Captain of the Port at that city, and has charge of all marine matters in Cuba. Last night, at the Hotel Victoria, in discussing the relations between Cuba and the United States, he expressed himself in favor of annexation, saying:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Renewed pressure against the Asphalt securities adversely affected the stock market to-day. The Asphalts dropped below all previous low records, but there was a vigorous recovery toward the close. The selling today was in smaller lots than since the break started less than a month ago.

IRVINE DEPOT, Ky., Nov. 20. -- The second day of the National Association of Fox Hunters brought no better results than the first. The Derby, which was not finished yesterday, was started early to-day, all of the seventeen entries remaining in. Big Sand Hill, on the west side of the river, was selected for the trial, and the puppies were cast three miles from this place.

That Russia should seriously consider the old plan to utilize the waterways between Riga on the Baltic and Odessa on the Black Sea and connect the northward flowing rivers with those flowing southward is hardly subject for surprise. The line of the proposed Baltic-Black Sea Canal is one of the traditional and prehistoric highways between the great northern and greater southern indentation of Europe.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

The second half of the foursome begun last Thursday at the Dyker Meadow Golf Club was completed yesterday at the Fox Hills links. As in the first meeting, George Low, the Dyker Meadow professional, and James L. Taylor, a well-known Dyker amateur, were pitted against Isaac Mackie, professional at Fox Hills, and Mortimer M. Singer, Captain of the Fox Hills team.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 -- Sir Christopher Furness of London, the largest owner and builder of ships in the world, arrived in New Orleans to-night in a private car from the West. The purpose of his coming is to inspect the facilities of the port, with a view to the erection of a large copper smelter and refinery.

The strike in the local yards of the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company had last night tied up its general freight buslness, but its local passenger service was not affected, nor its Colonial and Federal expiesses. The company had handled much of its perishable freight, and its Sound business was reported as unaffected.

Justice Clarke, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, signed an order allowing Dr. Charles P. MacDonald, committee of the person of Ida A. Flagler, formerly the wife of Henry M. Flagler, $25,000 a year for her care and maintenance, on the ground that the present allowance of a little more than $1,000 a month is not sufficient to support her in the luxury that her former mode of living justifies.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 21. -- The clerical and lay delegates to the special convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diccese of Long Island called to elect a successor to Bishop Littlejohn adjourned this morning, after balloting all night. The result after ten ballots was the election of the Rev. Dr. Frederick Burgess of Grace Church Brooklyn.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 20. -- The Columbia University football team beat the Annapolis cadets to-day, but by a very narrow margin. The game, which was closely fought from beginning to end, resulted in a score of 6 to 5 in favor of the New Yorkers, but was in doubt until the last minute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Missouri faction fight is at its height, and President Roosevelt is giving a large share of his time to the arguments of the rival factions. The Kerens element have now thrown off all disguise and are openly making their fight against Secretary Hitchcock. They are denouncing him in plain language, and offer no objection to the inference that they want his official scalp.

Mr. THEODORE C. SEARCH, who is the Permanent Chairman of the Reciprocity Convention now in session at Washington, must have been deeply gratified by the immediate response to his appeal for a "better understanding" between the advocates and the opponents of the policy of tariff revision by reciprocity treaties. The tone of Mr. SEARCH'S address was hopeful, but not optimistic.

Of the two sessions at the Horse Show yesterday, that of the evening was more brilliant socially, although during the afternoon many strolled in and remained for a little time. Indeed, between 4 and 5 o'clock the people of fashion were greatly in evidence. It was rather difficult, however, to place them, as they were first in one and then in another part of the Garden.

The testimony given yesterday at the second session of the trial by court-martial of Col. Robert L. Meade, Commandant of the Marine Barracks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, on charges of intoxication while on duty and conduct tending to the destruction of good, morals in the service, bore largely upon the number of glasses of whisky a naval officer can refresh himself with and still be able to fulfill the duties connected With his command.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Gen. Corbin received a dispatch from Col. Mills, Superintendent of the Military Academy, to-day, saying that the managers of the New York horse show had invited the first class of cadets to be their guests one day this week. Col. Mills recommended that permission be granted, and Gen. Corbin telegraphed the Superintendent approval of his recommendation.

With the arrest of a young colored man yesterday the police say they have solved the mystery of the numerous trunk thefts that were reported by express companies all over the city during the past two months.

TELLURIDE, Col., Nov. 20. -- What is likely to prove the most disastrous accident that has ever occurred in a metallic mine in Colorado, resulted to-day from a fire which burned the buildings at the mouth of the Bullion Tunnel, through which the Smuggler-Union Mine is worked, and which filled the mine with deadly gas and smoke.

The New York Lumber Trade Journal, New York, Nov. 2, 1901. To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to your question: My own judgment would be that tariff on any material which is controlled, manufactured, or sold by a trust, or concerning which there exists among merchants any combination or agreement to govern its price, should be put on the free list.

Prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday again moved very irregularly, strength appearing in some issues and heaviness in others. As has been the case for several days, the operations were largely professional and reflected little more than the varying moods of the trading element.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The National Reciprocity Convention adjourned sine die to-night. The night session was devoted mainly to speech-making. The day session was of a more businesslike nature.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- There is every reason to believe that a fight will be made against Rear Admiral Crowninshield's confirmation as a Rear Admiral unless the Navy Department abandons its present intention to place him in charge of the European station and let him represent the United States at the coronation of King Edward.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The National Reciprocity Convention adjourned sine die to-night. The night session was devoted mainly to speech-making. The day session was of a more businesslike nature.
TORONTO, Nov. 20. -- A special dispatch from Vancouver, published here, says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Mayor-elect Low, on his recent visit to Washington, is alleged to have tendered the Police Commissionership of New York City to Adjt. Gen. Corbin. The offer was declined. Mr. to get an army officer as Police Commis-Low is anxious to get an army officer as Police Commisisoner, and is now considering the names of Gen. Wesley Merritt and Gen. J. Ford Kent, retired.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Simon W. Hanauer, Deputy Consul General, writing from Frankfort under date of Oct. 26, says:
Mme. Sembrich sang Elsa in German in Los Angeles on Nov. 9, and Mr. E.F. Kubel contributed an uncommonly good piece of criticism to The Herald of that city. He said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to yours of Oct. 31 I would say I am well aware of the fact that my views on the tariff question are too radical, too extreme, to meet with favorable consideration on the part of your readers and of the general public, and yet I have not reached my present standpoint without many years of careful study and consideration of the subject.
DUBLIN, Nov. 21 -- The result of the Parliamentary election in Galway to-day was as follows:

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Money loaned at the local Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 10, 8, and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $21,086,537; balances, $1,632,905. Locally, money is moderately firm. Banks are generally asking 4 1/2 per cent. for new call loans. A considerable amount of money is still, however, outstanding at 4 per cent.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Tickets for the Yale-Harvard football game on Saturday are selling to-night at a higher premium than was ever known before, two days before the championship game. Every one of the 35,000 seats on Soldiers' Field has been taken, and persons who are anxious to see the game are offering fabulous prices for entrance slips.

Russell Sage and Miss Helen M. Gould sat side by side at the seventh annual banquet of the Society of Mayflower Descendants at Delmonico's last night. Throughout the elaborate dinner and the speaking that followed and until the Sage-Gould party departed, the aged financier paid marked attention to Miss Gould.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration of value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Everett P. Wheeler, at his home, 731 Park Avenue, last night expressed the belief that at last the property owners along the New York Central Railroad tunnel, from Forty-second Street to the Harlem River, have the prospect of freedom from the noise and smoke nuisance of passing trains.

MORRIS PLAINS, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The new wing of the State Hospital for the Insane was opened to-day. The new building, which provides sleeping room for about 1,000 persons and will be used as a dormitory solely, has cost to date about $325,000. The Board of Managers and the medical staff received the invited guests.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- The State Fair Commission, at its meeting in this city, decided to hold its next fair at Syracuse during the week commencing Aug. 25, 1902. While a two-weeks' fair has been under consideration, it was deemed advisable to hold it but for one week. The Treasurer reported that there would be a deficiency resulting from the fair held, in September last of $20,000 to $24,000.

Four dismissed policemen took steps to secure reinstatements at the close of the trials of delinquent members of the force, over which Deputy Commissioner Devery presided at Headquarters yesterday afternoon, and their unexpected appearance caused a stir in the trial room, especially among a number of policemen under suspension, there as spectators.

Improvement showed in many parts of the outside market yesterday, and closing quotations indicated a number of net gains over the previous day's figures. There was more than usual activity in several stocks which seldom figure prominently in outside transactions, so that the total for the day was fairly large.

The Society for the Study of Life held its annual banquet last evening at the Tuxedo, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, Mrs. Almon Hensley, the President, presiding. There were about one hundred and thirty diners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is so surprising and unusual to see anything in THE TIMES unfit to print that I respectfully beg leave to protest against the communication in to-day's (Nov. 18) issue under the displayed heading, "Municipal Socialism of a Dangerous Kind," and your editorial, apparently sustaining it.

That is a very well-meant "Conference of Charities and Correction" that was opened the other day in the United Charities Building. It ought to be very useful by the comparison of news and views of people from various parts who are interested in the same good work.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Samuel B. Huey, President of the Philadelphia Board of Education, and one of the leading lawyers of the city, died at his home here to-day after a short illness. He was fifty-eight years old and was born in Pittsburg. He was graduated from Princeton College in the class of 1863 and from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1868.

The report was circulated yesterday that the Board of Estimate at the next meeting was going to put through a plan for the building of an elevated structure from the present terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge down Park Row to Vesey Street, across to the Hudson River, and by a long loop up Centre Street to Canal Street, connecting with the terminals of East River Bridges Nos. 2 and 3.

A decision regarding evidence was given yesterday afternoon by the court-martial sitting in the case of Col. Robert L. Meade, commandant of the marine barracks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, which is re- garded as establishing a precedent of ex- treme importance in the conduct of naval courts-martial in the future.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Jim Megibben in the hurdle race teas the only winning favorite at Bennings to-day, the remaining events going to good-priced horses. In the jumping race Jockey Brazil on Salesman had a miraculous escape from being killed. While taking one of the jumps in the midst of the bunch his horse fell and broke his neck and rolled over his rider.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 21 -- Colon was perfectly quiet all yesterday and last night. Foreigners are being protected and transit across the Isthmus is uninterrupted. The Post Office, Prefecture, all the other Government offices, and nearly all the commercial houses are closed.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 21 -- A number of parishioners of the East Washington Baptist Church resigned their membership to-day because the Rev. Elmer E. Loux of Richmond Hill, N.Y., had been called to fill the pulpit for one year. The church has had no permanent pastor for a year, the Rev. George D. Reid having resigned on account of friction in his congregation.

To shift a dead weight of 1,200,000 pounds is not an easy matter even in these days of improved mechanical appliances, as the contractors who are doing the lifting of that much steel at 6 East Eighteenth Street will testify. Few people who pass the above address see anything extraordinary about the half-finished eight-story steel building there or imagine that one side of it is being shifted bodily.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Representatives of the various clubs in the Illinois, Iowa, and Indiana Baseball League met here to-day and perfected plans for next season.

Ex-Gov. Frank S. Black and Weeks, Battle Marshall, as attorneys for Roland B. Molineux, who is charged with the murder of Katherine J. Adams on Dec. 28, 1898, served upon the District Attorney yesterday their brief in the argument made last week for the dismissal of the indictment against Molineux and an inspection of the minutes of the Grand Jury which found the indictment against him.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick Burgess, rector of Grace Church, on the Heights, Brooklyn, who has been elected Bishop of the Long Island Diocese of the Episcopal Church, said yesterday that he would accept the Bishopric.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 21 -- While being loaded with fruit for New York, the British steamship Ethelred, Capt. Nickerson, which sailed from New York on Nov. 15 for West Indian ports, grounded this morning on the north side of the island. She will probably become a total wreck. Her crew was landed safely.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The candidates for the Princeton University gymnasium team reported for practice to-day. The squad is composed of about thirty men. All except one of the members of last year's team are still in the university, and indications point to a strong team. An exhibition will be given early in January to determine the all-around champion of the team.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 -- The market to-day was exceptionally dull and featureless, but steady. The general undertone was a shade better than on Wednesday. This improvement developed late in the day, when it was seen that New York would escape all weakness and would better its position before the close.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21 -- The New Jersey McKinley Memorial Fund Association was organized at a meeting in the Board of Trade rooms to-day. John F. Dryden was elected President, Frank Bergen of Elizabeth and Edgar J. Rappleve of Jersey City Vice Presidents; John S. Gibson, Secretary, and Major Gen. Joseph W. Plume, Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A delegation from the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange of New York, consisting of Frank D. Pavey, George C. Thomas, Robert M. Jarvis, and Mortimer Wagar, Presiident of the Exchange, called on the President to-day to protest against the further continuation of the war revenue tax, upon stock transactions.
On simple shirt waists of flannel the most satisfactory buttons, as far as looks are concerned, are those covered with the material.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Mrs. Alice Kent Robertson, the well-known disciple of Browning, was married to Trueman Lee Quimby to-day at her home, 25 Monument Square. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philo W. Sprague, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Philip S. Moxom of Springfield.

On the face of it the reciprocity convention in Washington was a melancholy failure as to its avowed object. That object was to secure from a body of representatives of the manufacturers of the country united action in the direction of extending our foreign markets through reciprocal reductions of tariff barriers to that trade.

Senator Thomas C. Platt called by appointment at the residence of Mayor-elect Low yesterday morning at 9:30 o'clock to discuss, with Mr. Low appointments and other matters incident to the new administration. The Senator remained with the Mayor-elect over an hour. At the conclusion of the conference the Senator stepped into his carriage and was driven to his office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There appears to-day in your news columns under the heading, "Sale of City Garbage Scows Stopped," some statements which impugn not only my own integrity, but also that of the late James McCartney, who I believe was an honest man.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The fact that the anti-Chamberlain agitation in Germany has at last extracted a semi-official expression of approval from the North German Ga- zette has had the effect of convincing the British press that the situation is becoming serious. Heretofore there had been a disposition to disregard and belittle the influence of the agitation.

Mrs. Elizabeth Dale, the mother of five-year-old Emeline, whose death, in Busch's Hotel in Hoboken on Tuesday was caused, according to Mrs. Dale, by strychnine tablets which the child mistook for peppermint candies, was arraigned before Recorder Stanton yesterday and formally accused of murder. Upon hearing the charge she fainted.

Congressman Nicholas Muller of the Borough of Richmond has resigned as a member of the House of Representatives and a special election will have to be held to elect a successor. Congressman Muller is the Democratic leader of the Borough of Richmond, and was a candidate for President of the Borough at the last election.

A flash around the bend preceded by a flurry of dust, a steady, hard drive through the straight, and one of the best matches on the Speedway was decided yesterday. The Monk, owned by Fred Gerken, once more disposing of a contender for the title of champion trotter of the Speedway. His competitor was the trotter Alves, 2:09 1/2, owned by Nathan Straus, the conditions toeing two heats of one-half mile each.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 21 -- General Superintendent Sumner J. Collins of the Wisconsin Central Railroad has resigned, to take effect Nov. 25. He will be succeeded by E.F. Potter, the present General Superintendent of the Davenport, Rock Island and Northwestern Railroad, at Davenport, Iowa.

Mrs. John Gerhardt, twenty-eight years old, according to the police, attempted last night to kill herself and little girl, Jennie, six years of age, at her home, 407 Hart Street, Brooklyn. They are now lying in a critical state in St. Mary's Hospital. Mrs. Gerhardt says that she was deserted last week by her husband, who was employed by a New York wholesale liquor house.

After a long series of negotiations the Consolidated Tobacco Company, which controls the American and the Continental Tobacco Companies, has acquired control of the tobacco properties of D.H. McAlpin Co. The actual change in management will probably be effected on or about Jan. 1, and the purchase price is reported to be in the neighborhood of $2,500,000.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 26 1-16d per ounce and in New York at 56 5/8 c. Mexican silver dollars at 45c.

Senator John Raines, the author of the Raines law, is expected to arrive in the city to-day. Senator Raines is coming here to confer with the Republican leaders and others with regard to the proposed changes in the excise law. Senator Raines was in Albany yesterday and had an interview with Gov. Odell.

The ordinance introduced by President GUGGENHEIMER of the Municipal Council, directing the company owning and operating the Park Avenue tunnel to change the motive power employed in the movement of trains through it from steam to electricity, possesses none of the characteristics of a "bluff."

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 21 -- Governor General Wood and his party left last night on the Government yacht Kanawha for Guantanamo, where Gen. Wood inspected the troops to-day. The Kanawha was compelled to return to the harbor on account of the rough sea outside, but left a few hours later.

Four tracks will be impracticable in the extension of the rapid transit road through lower Broadway, according to Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons, who took the stand at yesterday's meeting of the Special Commission on the East River Tunnel at the rooms of the Rapid Transit Commission at 320 Broadway.

Guests and hosts vied with each other in entertaining the large assemblage gathered yesterday from 4 P.M. until 10 P.M. at 211 Clinton Street, in the heart of the red light district. The occasion was a reception given by the Gospel Settlement to the clergymen of New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The excise laws which govern the liquor business in this State are a survival of the unfittest. They have come to us as an inheritance from the epoch which enacted legislation for the punishment of witches and imposed a sentence of banishment upon theological heresy.

With the football contest to-morrow at Cambridge between the Yale and Harvard elevens will go the championship of the year, and the weeks of hard practice and trials attendant on the training for a big football eleven will be considered as nothing by the victors, compared to the more satisfactory conditions generated by the feeling that a dangerous and worthy foe has been disposed of.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 -- The rioting resulting from the agitation against the proposal to translate the Gospels into modern Greek was continued to-day. Seven persons were killed, thirty were severely injured, and many others were slightly injured.

LYNN, Mass., Nov. 21 -- After lasting for seven days, the morocco strike, affecting several factories and more than 1,000 men, appears within measurable distance of settlement. Judge Reed of Brockton, Chairman of the State Board of Arbitration and Conciliation, said to-night that he thought the trouble would end soon.
DOVER, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Buildings of the Forcite Powder Works near Landing were badly damaged to-night by two explosions. One blew up a storehouse and the other the freezing house.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- One man insane, one broken in health, and half a dozen under a regular course of treatment is the price paid for the examination and attempted balacing of the tangled accounts of the City of Chicago. Men who began the work four months ago are suffering from failing eyesight, or, worn out from the constant strain upon their nerves, are on the verge of a collapse.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- President John M. Hall of the New York and New Haven Road said at midnight:

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The situation in the mining centres of France is again approaching a climax. The next day or two will see a definite decision upon the question of a general strike. The result of the recent referendum, while it gave a majority in favor of a strike on the actual number who voted, actually indicated that a very considerable number of the miners were either opposed to a strike or not enthusiastic.

The undefeated players in the fourteen-inch balk-line amateur billiard tournament which was contested at the Metropolitan Academy last week met last night in the deciding contest, Dr. Walter G. Douglas, the champion of the New York Athletic Club, winning from E.O. Presby by a score of 200 to 168.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Money was scarce to-day, in comparison to the demand, and consequently discounts hardened. Business on the Stock Exchange opened quiet and generally unfavorable. Consols were fairly steady. Home rails were dull. Brighton was weak on the remote prospect of electric railroad competition.

The strike of the yardmen employed by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was not settled yesterday. A committee of the strikers met C.H. Platt, General Superintendent of the Consolidated, at the Willis Avenue office of the company, and renewed the demand, as a basis of settlement, for the resignation of Superintendent Wardrop, Assistant General Yardmaster Smith, and Detective O'Brien.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Harvard is enjoying an unusual number of football games this week. This afternoon the juniors won the class championship from the sophomores in a well-contested game by a score of 11 to 5. To-morrow the Harvard and Yale Law School teams will play at Soldiers' Field in the first of a probable series.

The strike of the yardmen employed by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was not settled yesterday. A committee of the strikers met C.H. Platt, General Superintendent of the Consolidated, at the Willis Avenue office of the company, and renewed the demand, as a basis of settlement, for the resignation of Superintendent Wardrop, Assistant General Yardmaster Smith, and Detective O'Brien.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Harvard is enjoying an unusual number of football games this week. This afternoon the juniors won the class championship from the sophomores in a well-contested game by a score of 11 to 5. To-morrow the Harvard and Yale Law School teams will play at Soldiers' Field in the first of a probable series.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Pedro Ospina and Gen. Holguin, the former Minister of War of Colombia and the latter ex-Finance Minister, have arrived here to confer with Gen. Reyes, a member of the Pan-American Congress. It is understood that they will offer him the Presidency of Colombia, assuring him that his taking the office will bring peace to his country.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Considerable attention is being paid here to the landing of the force of American marines at Colon, particularly in view of Secretary Hay's recent speech. La Patrie publishes a New York dispatch announcing that the French Consul at Colon has protested against the American action, and that he has cabled to his Government for instructions.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Mrs. Ann O'Neil Miner, widow of Henry C. Miner, the five-story American basement dwelling at the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and Seventy-sixth Street. The purchaser is Alan W. Wood of Pittsburg. The brokers report the price at something over $100,000.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 21 -- Gov. Stone removed Recorder A.M. Brown of Pittsburg to-day and appointed in his place ex-Director of Public Safety J.O. Brown. The Second-Class City Charter bill, passed by the last Legislature and known as the "Pittsburg Ripper bill," struck out the office of Mayor and gave the Governor power to appoint a Recorder who would be the chief executive officer of the city.

A new company, the purpose of which is told by its name -- the Title Insurance Company of New York -- has just been organized, with a capital of $1,000,000, and identified with it are some of the most influential, and best-known men in the city's real estate and financial circles.

The examination into the affairs of the bankrupt stock brokerage firm of G. Edward Graft Co. was continued yesterday in the United States Court, Brooklyn, before Referee in Bankruptcy R.F. Tilney G. Edward Graff was the only witness heard during the day. James Shevlin and ex-Senator John McCarty, who are alleged, to have been interested with members of the firm in a so-called blind pool, were present.

If his own account be true, no small boy ever met with a much stranger adventure than that which befel Cyrus Cromwell, thirteen years old, of Hicksville, L.I., who had been missing from home since Sunday until yesterday, when he walked into the home of his aunt, Mrs. Barton, at 4,100 Park Avenue.
PUEBLO, Col., Nov. 21 -- Cresceus, the champion trotter, failed to lower his record to-day on Pueblo's half-mile track. Paced by his runing mate, he made the mile in 2:10 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Navy Department is informed that the monitor Florida, building at the shipyard of Lewis Nixon at Flizabethport, N.J., will be launched on the 27th inst., instead of a month later as was intended originally. Mrs. Nixon, wife of the contractor, will christen the vessel.

If his own account be true, no small boy ever met with a much stranger adventure than that which befel Cyrus Cromwell, thirteen years old, of Hicksville, L.I., who had been missing from home since Sunday until yesterday, when he walked into the home of his aunt, Mrs. Barton, at 4,100 Park Avenue.
PUEBLO, Col., Nov. 21 -- Cresceus, the champion trotter, failed to lower his record to-day on Pueblo's half-mile track. Paced by his runing mate, he made the mile in 2:10 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Navy Department is informed that the monitor Florida, building at the shipyard of Lewis Nixon at Flizabethport, N.J., will be launched on the 27th inst., instead of a month later as was intended originally. Mrs. Nixon, wife of the contractor, will christen the vessel.
Thursday is always considered the banner day at the Horse Show. It has for years attracted the largest assemblage of the week, and yesterday was no exception to the rule.

The annual football game to-day at Cambridge between Yale and Harvard is looked on by all conversant with the sport as the great game of the year. Not only will the winning eleven be the champion team of the year, but the absolute uncertainty as to the result of the contest lends just that color to the affair to make lovers of athletic sport anxious to see the struggle.

In view of the continued agitation in the Northwestern States against the new Northern Securities Company and all the plans of the various financial interests to secure stable rates and effect a saving in operation much discussion has been had among the chief organizers of the new company regarding the advisability of retaining on one Board of Directors a man who already is a Director in another railroad.

AN "Anthology of Russian Literature," by Prof. Leo Wiener, is to be published early in 1902 by G.P. Putnam's Sons. This is the first work of its kind to be under-taken in English. It will, give extracts, but more often complete productions, from all writers who have had an important part in the development of Russian letters, from the period preceding the nineteenth century up to the present time.

MANILA, Nov. 22 -- It has been officially reported to Gen. Chaffee that the insurgent leader Caballos has 500 fully armea men, including a number of American negroes, under his command in Laguna Province, Luzon. An insurgent officer has just been captured, carrying papers dated Mauban, Laguna Province, Nov. 18, and signed by Caballos.

It is a hard fate to be born and brought up in a village of the newer and rawer parts of our country, in the Far West, or even in the Middle West. That is the moral of "Jack Racer." It is also the moral of Mr. Howe's "Story of a Country Town." This latter is almost a classic, though it never attained any wide popularity, and has now dropped out of notice.

W.H. Baldwin, Jr., President of the Long Island Railroad and Chairman of the Committee of Fifteen and Treasurer of Tuskegee Institute, was the speaker last night before the People's Institute at Cooper Union. He spoke on "Some Present Problems," and at the end of his address was bombarded with questions from the audience, to which he replied to the satisfaction of the majority of his auditors.

The Rev. Dr. Donald Guthrie, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Baltimore, will, according to rumor among the congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, be called to the pastorate. It is said that the pulpit committee has communicated with him and received a favorable reply.

By The Associated Press. LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The increasing stringency of money in conjunction with the character of the Bank return decidedly strengthened rates. Some relief may shortly be afforded by large Government disbursements, but the tendency will be toward hardening until the year-end.

A BIOGRAPHY, other things being equal, is like laughter. He who biographs last usually does it best. I believe the word should be biographize, but that has an awkward sound in a sentence, and as biograph has become associated in the popular mind with a picture that presents one element of life, in that it moves, I let it stand.

-- We observe with regret that Harper's Weekly has observed with regret that last week we observed with regret that it had criticised the conduct of the Schley inquiry and complained that officers of the United States Navy should have been catechised in the presence of self-chosen representatives of the general public.

We have heard something similar to this indictment framed by Mr. Harold E. Gorst in "The Curse of Education," (E. P. Dutton Co.,) as at present organized, have heard it a good many times, but seldom, or never, such a railing accusation on the one hand, and on the other so little in the way of practical suggestion for the betterment of what is held to be so bad.

BELOW will be found outlines of the various features which the editors of the principal magazines in this country have arranged for use during the coming year. These outlines have been prepared from advance sheets of prospectuses end their news value will be obvious to our readers.

Throughout all Europe the industrial situation is becoming very disquieting. Coincident with the unfortunate conditions in Germany, Austria is now suffering from industrial collapse, and, according to latest official advices, affairs in that country are going from bad to worse.

"Boozer," the bull terrier, was the hero of an exciting runaway through the Tenderloin District last night. The runaway started at Sixth Axenue and Thirty-eighth Street where a landau with five persons in it, going west, was run down by a south bound Sixth Avenue car and hurled against an elevated railroad pillar.
Copyright, 1901, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- The Call of Moses -- Exodus, III., 1-12.

The Ledger Monthly for 1902, as in the past, will continue its excellent work. The scope of this publication is a wide one, for, with increasing readers, the demands an its columns have become of the most varied character. The Ledger Monthly is above all a family paper, replete with interesting and instructive matter.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Manager Jones of the Intercollegiate Cross Country Association to-night gave out a list of entries for all the universities that will enter teams at the Morris Park meet, in New York, Nov. 30. The entries are as follows:

It will be interesting news to trap shooters to learn that the Amateur Athletic Union has just passed a resolution to the effect that a trap shooter who shoots for a sweepstake prize shall be declared a professional athlete. This action was occasioned upon receipt of a letter at the recent annual meeting from J.H. Daggett, Captain of the Boston Athletic Association Gun Club.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 22 -- It is reported that the Government has addressed a communication to the United States Consul, stating that it cannot guarantee protection for isthmian transit, which is now uninterrupted and under the Liberals' protection. Two sailing boats which left Panama with Gen. Alban and 75 soldiers aboard, returned to that place at 3 P.M. yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 22 -- About 1,000 shopmen employed by the Louisville and Nashville Railroad have been treated to a surprise in the form of a voluntary increase of 10 per cent, in their pay. The order affects all who formerly drew $1.75 a day or over, and includes carpenters, blacksmiths, painters, machinists, and car builders generally.
The Legal Aid Society held its monthly meeting yesterday at 49 Wall Street, the office of the President, Arthur Von Briesen

To The Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly allow me to voice a feeling which I know is entertained by thousands who have read your editorials on the liquor question, which appeared to-day and yesterday, Nov. 19 and 20? You say:

The thread of the story is so slender upon which Mrs. Champney hangs a sketch of the Court of Ferrara, and the Huguenots in France and Canada, a detailed account of the siege of La Rochelle, and a great deal about de Frontenac and the Five Nations that we wonder she does not frankly admit on the face of "A Daughter of the Huguenots " that its purport and interest are historical, not romantic.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Referring to a remark of the Cologne Gazette that "the present state of feeling in both England and Germany may assume a form of conflagration which cannot be extinguished," the Berlin correspondent of The Times says:

The little bark Ella, which had been forty-one days making the trip from Savanna-la-Mar, Jamaica, was docked at the Erie Basin yesterday morning. After being storm-swept, storm-bound, and having faced starvation, the thirteen souls on board celebrated a joyous thanksgiving on reaching port.

The upward movement in prices which began on Thursday under the stimulus of buying by the largest interests in the Street was continued yesterday, and at the close of the day, inspite of heavy profit taking sales, many substantial net advances appeared. Notable of these were gains of one and two points in Norfolk and Western, Baltimore and Ohio.
Perry Belmont, asked whether he was a candidate for the position made vacant by Congressman Muller's resignation, said:

In a compass of slightly over three hundred pages, Mr. Arthur Walpole has told the history of Greece in a remarkably clever fashion. So convincingly has his work been done, with such understanding of the tastes of young readers, that it would seem the "Little Arthur" for whom the book was ostensibly prepared must be a bona fide child.

Although Friday is supposed to be one of the dull days of the Horse Show, yesterday gave no sign of decreased attendance either in the boxes or among the spectators. There was a large crowd present during the day and evening. There was possibly not as much variety in the audience, as many box holders who were there early in the week, were seen again last evening.

Discussing trade conditions hi Canada Dun's report says that a better feeling prevails at St. John. Jobbers report a brisker movement in all staple lines and retail trade is more encouraging than for some weeks. Produce shipments are large and retail clothing is active at Halifax, but footwears moves slowly.
The Medico-Legal Society at its last meeting adopted resolutions upon the death of Simon Sterne. They were introduced by Henry Wollman, and are as follows:

In the National Bowling League tournament last night, the Knickerbocker Athletic Club bowlers won two of their three games with the National team, scoring over 900 in the second and the third games. Ross made a score of 242 in the second game. The Royal Arcanum Wheelmen made a new high team score of 990 in the Columbia League series, though the Rosedales proved the double winners.

ATHENS, Nov. 22 -- The turbulent demonstrations here, growing out of the proposal to translate the Gospels into modern Greek, were continued in the early part of to-day in the streets, especially in front of the Chamber of Deputies and before the university. There were many ugly rushes.

Mr. E.T. Cook, a journalist and editor of The London Daily News until January of the present year, when, for some reason, he retired from that position, has given the world what appears to be a premature history of the Boor war regarded from the British point of view. In this he has tried to be fair and judicial, but the effort has been only partially successful.

The feature of yesterday's proceeding's at the court-martial of Col. Robert L. Meade, commander of the Marine Barracks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was the testimony given by Capt. B.H. Fuller, assistant to the Judge Advocate in the trial. Capt. Fuller was recalled to the stand by the prosecution, to whom his testimony proved surprising.
Judge John A. Blair, sitting in the Court of General Sessions in Jersey City yesterday, decided that there is no law in New Jersey forbidding theatrical performances on Sunday.

Dr. DE COSTA strangely misconceives the nature and meaning of the argument for more liberal Sunday laws. "The real question," THE TIMES has said and many others have said, "is not whether men shall drink on Sunday, but whether they shall drink in defiance of the law or by permission of the law."

Frank Leslie's Popular Monthly now enters on the second quarter-century of its career, and with a perfected organization, its intention is to give readers a magazine that shall be both entertaining and healthful, not overlooking that practical side which is of such signal benefit to readers. Frank Leslie's Popular Monthly, as its title designates, is written for all classes, and not alone for the fathers and the mothers, but for the younger generation.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 22 -- The application of the Chicago Union Traction Company and the Consolidated Traction Company for an injunction restraining the State Board of Equalization from assessing the capital stock of these companies for 1900, was denied at 12:30 this afternoon by Judges Grosscup and Humphrey, in the United States Circuit Court.

Work will not be stopped on the new Custom House now building in this city notwithstanding the rather disquieting report received here yesterday that Secretary Gage had reported to the Controller of the Currency that an extra million dollars would be required to complete the structure.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- New York exchange was quoted at 15c discount to-day. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent. Although the trading in street railway stocks on the local Exchange to-day was only moderately active, the market for about all of them continued to show weakness. Sentiment on Union Traction and its allied stocks seems to be particularly bearish.

The recognition of Country Life in America has been as spontaneous as it has been general. The publishers of this handsome monthly, to use a trite expression, seem to have felt that there was a want and to have supplied it. The first issue for this month, November, was certainly as fine a specimen of American typography as has been heretofore presented.

Every one who has had the happy fortune to loiter along footpaths and among green hills with Mr. Torrey knows what to expect from his companionship -- what alertness of eye and ear, what comprehensiveness of observation, what deftness of description, what charm of literary allusion, what ripe wisdom, sweetened by the sunshine in which the writer's spirit seems always to walk.

Two well-known Western crooks were arrested yesterday after they had stolen a gold watch and chain from a contractor on a Second Avenue electric car.
