TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 24 -- Twelve mountain rivers in Western Washington are overflowing their banks in consequence of the heavy rains of the last four days. Three inches of rain have fallen since last night.

A new steel company with a capitalization of $200,000,000 is being projected, according to the statement of Frederick H. Clarke of the law firm of Blymer, Hobbs Stover, who are the promoters of the new combination of steel interests, and the organization of the giant company, he says, is now well under way.

Although it is asserted by the officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad that the strike in the freight yards is at an end and things are once more running smoothly, the men say that but 100 out of the 300 men who struck were back at work yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Mr. Frye proposes to bring the ship subsidy scheme before Congress again in the shape of a new bill, but if the sentiment of the members toward the fundamental idea remains unchanged, nothing will be done with the bill. It will just "lie in state."
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- A Thanksgiving precedent of more than twenty years' standing has been set aside by the Rev. Dr. Frank Crane and the Trustees of the People's Church.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 24 -- More damage has been done along the coasts of Connecticut by the storm of the last twenty-four hours than was ever wrought by a single siege of wind and wave In the State's history. The losses will aggregate $50,000.

An entertainment that drew an audience which filled every seat in Carnegie Hall was presented yesetrday afternoon under the auspices of the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. The New York Festival Chorus, under the direction of Conductor Tali Esen Morgan, rendered "The Holy City," by Alfred P. Gaul.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think that in my reply to Mr. Lindsay's communication in your issue of Nov. 8 his statement that, "the Protestant Episcopal Church is not Protestant (is not and never has been)" was conclusively disproved.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Industrial Commission to-day published a special report explanatory of what is styled the "Kartell." The report covers much the same grounds as recent German cablegrams with reference to the workings of this organization. The Kartell, it is stated, guarantees producers of raw sugar a certain minimum price, any difference between this price and an actually lower price in the world's markets being made up by the refiners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- William Gwyn, the negro who was for thirty years chief messenger to the Secretary of State, is dead. He had been in feeble health for some time, But persisted in sticking to his work, and was at his post last Saturday. He died last night from a chronic stomach complaint.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 25. -- Mayor Mulvihill presided for the first time over the Board of Aldermen to-night and succeeded in blocking the scheme to build a new City Hall. There is a question, however, whether the action of the Aldermen will stand in law.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 25. -- William C. McMillan of Detroit has been chosen to succeed the late David Carter as General Manager of the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company. He is a son of United States Senator McMillan of Michigan, and has been connected with the Detroit and Cleveland.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Thomas J. Diamond, the first Captain of the New York police to be brought to trial upon a criminal charge since the days of Lexow, faced to-day a jury of Albany County farmers and business men before Justice D. Cady Herrick, in the Supreme Court, to answer an accusation of wilful neglect of duty in failing to suppress Lena Schmitt's disorderly house at 27 Stuyvesant Street.

COLON, Nov. 25. -- An armed guard of marines from the United States battleship Iowa has re-established transit across the Isthmus, and details from the marines are now protecting each passenger train.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- In the Supreme Court to-day a motion was made to dismiss or affirm the decree of the District Court for the Southern District of New York in the habeas corpus case of George Bissert, the New York City patrolman under sentence for receiving bribes.

The formal terms for the retirement of the Northern Pacific preferred stock were made public yesterday in a circular addressed to the limited number of Northern Pacific common stockholders by the Secretary of the company, George H. Earl. The circular reads in part as follows:

Justice McAdam in the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision in the action brought by School Commissioner Miles M. O'Brien, as trustee in bankruptcy of the property of Grahams Policy, formerly treasurer of the Hoffman House, lately adjudged a bankrupt. The Justice set aside the conveyance of a house made by Mr. Polley to a woman as fraudulent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- A delegation of Cubans called upon the President to-day and presented a petition adopted by the industrial organizations of the island, urging upon his attention the necessity of reduction in the American tariff upon Cuban products, particularly upon sugar and tobacco.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- Pennsylvania was the most active stock in the market to-day, and in the first hour over 1,100 shares were traded in at prices ranging from 74 1/2 to 75 5-16. Its activity was in sympathy with its course in the New York markets. The Readings continued to make a large part of the business here.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- At the first meeting of the Boston and Worcester Street Railway Company, held here to-day, officers were elected and contracts aggregating more than $1,500,000 for the construction of a new street railway line from Boston to Worcester were awarded. The new officers are:
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- Telegraphing from Vienna, the correspondent of The Times quotes the Neue Freie Press in explanation of the remarkable troubles now agitating the Greek Government.

The will of Henry Hart, who held a controlling interest in the Third Avenue Railroad Company until it was absorbed by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, was filed yesterday with Probate Cleric Washburn in the Surrogates' office.

Deputy Police Commissioner William S. Devery, with Commissioner Murphy and a number of detectives, appeared in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday afternoon before Justice Holbrook to answer to the charges of neglect of duty and oppression. After some argument between Abram I. Elkus, who appeared for Deputy Commissioner Devery, and Assistant District Attorney Cans, the hearing was again adjourned until next Monday afternoon.

The Old Glory sale of trotting bred horses, the largest offering ever made, was begun in Madison Square Garden yesterday morning by the Fasig-Tipton Company before a huge attendance of racing men and patrons of the light-harness horse, prospective buyers having gathered from all parts of the United States and Canada for the occasion, while agents were present to represent a number of foreign firms.

The remarkable feature of yesterday's stools market was not the live-point break in Amalgamated Copper -- for blind pool stocks may be expected to collapse at any time -- but the decided strength of the standard railway shares, such as New York Central and Pennsylvania, and of the so-called "minor " railway properties, in which group may be included Nickel Plate, Lake Brie and Western, Southern Railway, Chesapeake and Ohio, and Norfolk and Western.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- This has been a day of developments on the Isthmus of Panama. A battle was fought at Empire City and the Liberals were driven back. The fighting was later resumed, and is still going on. American marines and bluejackets are now being spread over the Isthmus at different points to protect the traffic.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- "Should no one else challenge, I am willing seriously to consider making another attempt to lift the cup."

Fourteen regular contests and one exhibition event comprised the athletic games decided last night in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, at Columbus Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street, under the auspices of the Regimental Athletic Association. They were all closed events, interest centring in the points secured by each company.

Deputy Commissioner Devery announced the transfer of eleven Police Captains late yesterday afternoon, but he refused to assign any reason for the changes except the stereotyped one, "for the good of the service."

A new apartment hotel, costing $500,000, similar to the Touraine, recently completed at 9 and 11 East Thirty-ninth Street, will be erected on the plot 71 by 100.5, at 59 to 63 West Forty-fourth Street. This property, acquired within the last few weeks by the Century Realty Company, has been resold to the Puritan Realty Company through James L. Libby Son, for about $180,000.

When WILLIAM H. SEWARD thirty-four years ago negotiated with Russia the treaty for the purchase of Alaska for $7,000,000 he provoked an outburst of sarcastic mirth throughout the land. As well pay seven millions for the north pole, men said; there was nothing in Alaska but ice and mountains, some seals, and a few tribes of very dirty Indians.

Discussing the recently published cables from London regarding the German sugar kartell, Privy Councillor Goldberger, member of the Imperial German Consultative Board for Commercial Measures, who is in this city, said yesterday:

The writ of habeas corpus sued out by David M. Neuberger on behalf of Isidore Hein and Joseph Bower, who were convicted and fined 52 each by Magistrate Mayo for selling tickets for the opening performance of "Miranda of the Balcony," at the Manhattan Theatre, on Sept. 24 last, was dismissed by Justice Clarke in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The General Board of Appraisers has decided when sausage is not sausage, and the distinction is set forth in an opinion written by General Appraiser Fischer, in the case of H. Hackfeld Co., who protested against the decision of the Collector of Customs at Honolulu.

The November meeting of the Congregational Club of Brooklyn took place last night in Pouch Gallery, 345 Clinton Avenue, with a number of distinguished speakers among those listed for the after dinner speeches. The meeting was an exceptionally large one, 230 members and guests being present.

The proceedings taken by the Law Department to compel the taking down of the portico of the Pabst Hotel, in Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, were advanced yesterday to a final stage. Supreme Court Justice David McAdam decided last week in favor of the city, in its suit to compel the restoration to the public of the sidewalk incumbered by the portico.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 25. -- The Court of Errors and Appeals heard argument to-day on the appeal taken by the North Jersey Street Railway Company from the decision of the Supreme Court concerning the assessment made for taxes of 1900 against the company by the Tax Board of the City of Newark.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 25. -- A party of six Western League baseball magnates held a meeting at Council Bluffs yesterday to form a plan of opposition to the programme that President Hickey and Manager Tebeau are said to have mapped out, and to consider the advisability of retaining President Hickey's service longer.

That the apparatus combining the X-ray tube and the fluoroscope has failed to realize the promise of its inception is due to the limitations of its scope of vision to one dimension. It gave Only shadows, liable to distortion and, especially in surgery, apt to be misleading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article which appeared in the editorial columns of your paper, under the caption "A Yellow Clergyman," in reference to a paper which the writer read at the Conference of Charities and Correction, was written. I think, in all justice to your paper, by one who has never seen the paper there criticised.

BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- The Foreign Office to-day declared the announcement to the effect that the countries party to the Triple Alliance were making a concentrated demonstration in South American waters to be false.

The report of the committee appointed to draw up a plan for developing the Citizens' Union was presented last night at a meeting of the City Committee of that organization. It was announced to reporters that the character of the report would not be made public until it had been printed and revised.

Letters and telegrams have been received during the last four days by Andrew G. Cropsey, a lawyer of 3 Chambers Street, giving details of a hunt which has been going on since last Wednesday night for his niece, Miss Helen Crospsey, who mysteriously disappeared from her home in Elizabeth City, N. C.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Blanche Herman and Extinguisher were the only winning favorites at Bennings to-day. One side of the barrier refused to work promptly in the third race, and Wonderly on Bessie McCarthy and Slack on Tyrshena were caught in the tape and left at the post Lamp o' Lee ran second in the fifth race, but was disqualified.

Misty rain that fell intermittently and a chilly wind that blew in fitful gusts succeeded yesterday to the driving downpour and fierce northeast gale which for thirty-six hours had deluged and buffeted the city and its vicinity.

At the Manhattan Theatre last night the second production was made under the management of Harrison Grey Fiske. The play offered for public delectation and reflection was "The Unwelcome Mrs. Hatch," described on the house bills as "an everyday drama," by Mrs. Burton Harrison. The four acts of this play were watched with close attention by a considerate audience, and the efforts of the actors and actresses were encouraged by the customary demonstrations.

There is nothing more beautiful in the way of muffs and boas this year than those of ostrich, feathers. Those in delicate colors for evening wear are particularly beautiful. Among those in pale blue and pink are some having the part of the boa going around the neck made into quite a wide collar and of many short plumes put together with a charming fluffy effect, while the ends are long and round.

The Meade court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard resumed its sittings yesterday. Col. Frank Denny of the Marine Corps, one of the officers preferring charges of drunkenness and false swearing against Col. Meade, was the chief witness of the day.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 25. -- Joseph Flscher of New York City, the well-known music dealer of 7 Bible House, died suddenly at 10 o'clock to-night at the home of his brother, the Rev. A. J. Fischer, at 26 Lagonda Avenue, this city. The cause of his death was the trimming of a troublesome corn on the small toe of the right foot.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Nov. 25. -- What was only intimated about the Reciprocity Convention the day it adjourned -- that it had turned out precisely as its managers designed it should turn out -- is openly charged now by persons who say they know what they are talking about. A member of the House Ways and Means Committee said yesterday that the programme of the convention was cut and dried from beginning to end.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revsnue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Senator VEST shares the general incredulity about the reciprocity treaties. He has no faith whatever in the intentions of the Republican Party to remove or lower any of the customs duties either by reciprocity arrangements or general revision. "Some of them may talk reciprocity," he says," but they mean, protection all the while.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The damage to buildings in this city during the storm of Saturday night and Sunday morning was far greater than was supposed yesterday. Hardly a building but suffered more or less. The damage ranged all the way from the roof being carried away, as was the case at the United States Hotel, down to the breaking of window panes and the smashing of shutters.

The Committee on Railroads of the Municlpal Council listened yesterday to arguments why the local Legislature should pass the ordinance offered by President Guggenheimer compelling the New York Central and allied railroad companies to install electric power for the propulsion of cars through the tunnel from Forty-second Street to the Harlem River.

NEWPORT, R. I., Nov. 25. -- Rear Commodore and Mrs. C. L. F. Robinson, accompanied by a number of friends, will start on an extended cruise on board their English-built steam yacht Barbara from New York Dec. 7, and will go direct to the "West Indies and Cuba, afterward crossing the Atlantic to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day an opinion was banded down in the case of Getting and Higginson against A. A. Godard, Attorney General of the State of Kansas, and the Kansas City Stock Yards Company, involving the validity of the State law of Kansas, empowering the State authorities to fix rates of charges on stock in the stock yards.

Last week we commented upon the fact that three preachers had on the previous Sunday expressed themselves as strongly opposed to the legalized opening of any saloons during any hours on Sunday. We pointed out to these clergymen that experience indicated that the saloons would in any case be open in the sense of being accessible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The monthly, statement of the collections of internal revenue shows that for October, 1901, the receipts from all sources amounted to $24,359,907, a decrease of $3,104,672, as compared with October of last year. The collections from the several sources of revenue are given as follows:

Controller Coler yesterday denied the story that Mayor Low would have no money to spend on new improvements during his term of office. Also, in denying the sensational story ahout the debt limit, he said:

An alleged consumptive child Has been the cause of some alarm among the parents of children attending Public School No. 108, at Arlington Avenue and Linwood Street, in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $17,025,879. Balances, $1,513,462. On call the banks are generally asking 4 1/2 per cent., though a few loans are made to special borrowers at 4 per cent., and there is considerable money outstanding at 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Third Assistant Postmaster General Edwin C. Madden. in his annual report, says: The total postal revenues for the year from all sources were $111,631,193, being $3,923,727 less than the expenditures. This is exclusive of the cost of transporting the mails over the subsidized Pacific railroads that have not yet settled their bonded accounts with the Government.

Our position at Colon is interesting and delicate. As between the Colombian Government and its citizens who are in revolt against it we must be and are strictly neutral. But by treaty agreement we not only enjoy the right, but have assumed the obligation, to protect from interruption the traffic and transportation across the isthmus by the Panama Railroad.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 25. -- Marquis Ito, the Japanese statesman, has arrived here.

It seems very curious that a New York Captain of Police should have to be taken to Albany to get a fair trial. For ourselves, we have by no means impeached the justice of the decision of Judge GIEGERICH, which had the effect of sending Capt. DIAMOND there. On the contrary, we believe it to be just.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 25. -- The market was slow to-day, but that was due to New York's irregularity. Before the tone here had time to harden the liquidation of Amalgamated by the Wall Street crowd threw the home traders into a position of doubt. The market met the perplexity, therefore, by lapsing into dullness instead of growing weak.

Schaefer played exceptional billiards yesterday, and made the remarkable run of 144 points in the evening contest under the conditions which Will govern in the coming eighteen-inch balk line championship of the world tournament. While this run is slightly better than the best on record for tournament play under similar conditions, it has been beaten in practice matches.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were fairly large, but prices were irregular, and resulted in no decided movement in either direction. In parts of the list there was considerable weakness, and elsewhere substantial advances resulted from the day's trading. The copper stocks were not very active, and were only slightly affected by the heavy decline in Amalgamated Copper on the Stock Exchange.

Meetings were held yesterday morning at the Grand Central Station by the Boards of Directors of all the New York Central lines, commonly called Vanderbilt roads. While nothing was given out about what was done at the meetings, on the ground that only routine business was transacted, the impression prevailed among men in Wall Street and railroad circles that other matters were discussed, even if nothing definite was decided upon.

Not for some weeks has the German stock company at the Irving Place Theatre had such a chance to display its excellence in "milieu" and character drawing as it did last night, when it produced a three-act comedy by Otto Ernst, entitled "Flachsmann als Erzieher," ("Flachsmann as Educator.")

What was characterized by the defense as an indication of animus on the part of accusers of Col. Robert Meade developed at the close of yesterday afternoon's session of the Meade court-martial, at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Francis A. Palmer, the wealthy banker and philanthropist, yesterday publicly announced his intention of disinheriting a favorite grandniece, whom for twenty years he treated as a daughter and whom since childhood he has looked upon as the apple ot his eye. Mr. Palmer's wife died a number of years ago.

The Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York are planning to erect a building solely for their own use on Fifty-fifth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues. A committee appointed to consider the feasibility of the scheme has reported favorably to the Board of Managers, and the entire subject will be brought up at the annual meeting of the society to be held next Tuesday.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 26 -- Money was in abundant supply at the local Clearing House to-day, and while 3 per cent. was still the general rate, some of the banks made loans at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $22,397,217; balances, $1,561,371. Call money was quoted at 4 and 4 1/2, mostly, however, at the latter figure.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 26 -- Judging from appearances, the switchmen's strike, inaugurated this morning, has proved a failure. The strike was ordered by the Switchmen's Union of North America, and the claim was made early in the day by the union officials that every railroad in the city, with the exception of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago, and the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis, would be tied up completely.

Benjamin S. Church, who originally designed the new Croton Aqueduct, and was chief engineer of the first Aqueduct Commission from 1883 to 1888, is in favor of the plan of construction decided on by the Board of Engineers of which James J.R. Croes was a member. Engineer Church claims that a solid masonry embankment should be built at Croton Dam Instead of the earth embankment and core wall which has been partly constructed.

In the National Bowling League tournament last night the Excelsior team won two of their three matches with the Fidelia five. The Lotus bowlers won their ninth and tenth consecutive victories in the Harlem League, and the Owl team scored a double victory in the Columbia League. In the Fire Insurance League-tournament two of the three scheduled games were postponed on account of the illness of a member of the Home Fire Insurance Company team.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- It has long been one of the aims of Adjt. Gen. Corbin's life to get the army officers in the War Department building to wear uniforms while on duty. They did so during the Spanish war, but after the war was over Secretary Alger allowed them to resume their civilian clothing.

Richard Croker gave out an interview yesterday stating that the Democratic Party in the city, State, and Nation would have no chance for years to come unless the factions in New York State harmonized, Elliot Danforth, who is the only politician in New York having the full confidence of Senator David B. Hill, said last evening to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES:

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Five bodies have now washed ashore from the five barges stranded along the coast. Four of the barges have gone to pieces. The fifth lies out on the bar tossing about and pounding. She will probably break up within a day or two. Only two men have been saved from the five barges, but no one here knows how many have been drowned.

Speaker T. Frederick Nixon consulted yesterday with a number of the Republican Assemblymen-elect from New York City. The Speaker was anxious to ascertain the local sentiment upon various propositions affecting New York City which will come before the Legislature this Winter and was particularly desirous to learn the aspirations of the New York members with regard to committee places.
Army. Major James B. Jackson, recently promoted from Captain subject to examination, will report in person to the examining board at Vancouver Barracks.

Those who love to wander and wonder through the American Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Eighth Avenue, will find many new marvels and new rooms opened to their investigation. Members' Day, yesterday, was made notable by giving the members and their friends the first view of the new exhibits and new collections.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Ruin threatens the Union Traction Company in consequence of Judge Thompson's mandamus, according to a statement made to-day by an attorney who probably knows more about it than any other man.

The rumors of a great steel merger to rival the United States Steel Corporation, which have been industriously circulated for some time past, have excited more interest than the facts of the case would warrant. Primarily, the plants do not exist from which to form a merger which would be in any sense a competitor on equal terms with United States Steel.

The Rev. Herman D. van Broekhuizen of Pretoria, South Africa, who on Sunday addressed the congregation of President Roosevelt's church in Washington, last night made an appeal for aid to the Boer cause in an address at the Assembly Hall of the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street.

COLON, Columbia, Nov. 26 -- With an armed guard of marines on board, the train from Panama that was due at 11:30 A.M. reached here at 4 o'clock this afternoon, bringing the news that Gen. Alban, with about 300 Government troops, had crossed Barbacoa Bridge and was continuing his march toward Colon.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The historic Battle Abbey and the 6,000 -- acre estate surrounding it were sold at public auction yesterday afternoon for L200,000.
Details will be found in another column regarding the sale of a large tract on Washington Heights to a syndicate headed by Alfred G. Vanderbilt.

-- Some remarks which we made a few flays ago on the subject of automobile racing and racers are echoed by The Electrical World and Engineer, which makes the recent contests on the Coney Island Boulevard a text for lament over the "waste of time" involved in the construction and use of machines of no practical value for the purposes either of business or pleasure.

The announcement made yesterday that Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt was a member of a syndicate which had bought a tract of about 127 lots on Washington Heights from the Deaf and Dumb Asylum, came as a surprise to those who have associated the name of that family with nothing but railroads and kindred forms of investment.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- Mrs. J.S. Collins, a bride of less than three months, made temporarily insane, it is supposed, by grief over the death of her mother, took a dose of carbolic acid from which she died at midnight. Mrs. Collins's mother caught cold some days ago, and it was supposed from this cause died last night.

There is little to be said of yesterday's stock market beyond the fact that in spite of the further heaviness of Amalgamated Copper in the early trading, and of uneasiness caused by the Pittsburg Railroad strike, the trend of prices was unmistakably to a higher level under the lead of the railroad group, of Manhattan and Southern Railway preferred, and, in the industrial, of General Electric and Sugar.

An unexpected bomb was thrown into the University of Pennsylvania football camp last night when the graduate and undergraduate members of the Athletic Association received the following communication from Coach George W. Woodruff:

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The course of events in Central America," says The Pall Mall Gazette, "is showing how inevitable it is that the United States should be the principal performer in these isthmian games, and that it is just as well that their Government and ours should have settled outstanding differences and be working amicably together for the preservation of an an open door."

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 26 -- Surrogate Petty will have to read up on hoodooism. He has been called upon to set aside a will because it is claimed the testator was hoodooed, and as a result changed his will. The contestant also thinks he is hoodooed. The will is that of Aaron Cuffee. He was a negro, married into the Shinnecock Indian tribe.

There will, it is declared, be no change in the tariff laws by the next session of Congress. While it is conceded that there is room for improvement, the opinion nevertheless prevails that the business disturbance which would follow any agitation of amendatory tariff legislation would be more harmful than could be compensated by alterations in the law.

MADISONVILLE, Ky., Nov. 26 -- The camp of the striking union miners at Nortonville is again a reality. From Thomas Rooney, a member of the official board of the United Mine Workers of America, it is learned that the new camp was established yesterday with fifty charter members and one large tent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 26 -- The Newport Trust Company, for which a charter was granted by the Legislature last week, was organized this afternoon and will undoubtedly prove one of the most influential financial institutions in the State.

Locked away for safe keeping in the strongbox of the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm, which got in yesterday, is the famous blue stone known as the "Hope Diamond." It was recently purchased in London by Simon Frankel, a jeweler of this city, who, according to report, paid $250,000 for it.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 -- Under the guiding hand of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is to be divided into three grand divisions under a system of complete reorganization. The announcement to-day that $20,000,000 additional common stock would be issued is part of the plan.

The Cuban Commissioners who are in Washington urging the President, in behalf of the business men of Cuba, whom they represent, to recommend to Congress that the tobacco, sugar, and other products of the island be admitted here under rates of duty lower than those of the Dingley tariff, must have discovered by this time the futility of their errand.
Secretary of War Elihu Root has made public his annual report.

Prices averaged high at the second day of the great sale of trotting bred horses in Madison Square Garden yesterday, the Fasig-Tipton Company's "Old Glory" combination offering. The attendance of racing men and breeders from all parts of the country was even larger than on the opening day.

William S. Devery, Deputy Police Commissioner, is now a full-fledged member of the Democratic Club. He was elected at the last meeting of the Board of Governors, and the fact has been kept a secret about which the members of the club were not supposed to speak. Treasurer Theodore F. Hascall has received from Mr. Devery the initiation fee required of all Tammany men who want to become members of the organization.

Joseph Goldman, forty-two years old, of 63 Bainbridge Street, Brooklyn, was arraigned before Judge McMahon in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with burglary, and was sentenced to not less than three years and ten months and not more than five years in State prison.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 26 -- The market to-day was dull to an extreme, with the tone sufficiently easy to admit of a number of fractional recessions without any very big decline being suffered. The local movement was altogether a sympathetic one, the irregularities in Wall Street caused by Amalgamated's wide swings being the principal depressing influence.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 26 -- At a special meeting of the policy holders of the Atlantic Mutual Life Insurance Company held here to-day it was unanimously voted to consolidate with the Boston Mutual Life Insurance Company. It was then unanimously voted to effect the consolidation.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 -- Twenty-six men are dead and twenty-four other men are lying in the various hospitals of the city suffering from terrible cuts, burns, and other injuries, all results of the explosion of one of the boilers in the Penberthy Injector Company's large plant, at the corner of Abbott Street and Brooklyn Avenue, at 9:30 o'clock to-day.

Huge red cards, announcing a children's performance to take place yesterday afternoon in Colonial Hall, One Hundred and First Street and Columbus Avenue, in aid of a children's home, were distributed in the neighborhood of West One Hundredth Street last week. Part of the price of admission was a potato, and 1,200 children, each with a potato, went there yesterday.

Residents and property owners in that section of the Borough of the Bronx lying east of the Bronx River have been considerably disturbed recently by reports that the Standard Oil Company had acquired a large tract on Westchester Creek. Such a purchase has been made, but it is said that the land, which includes some water-front privileges, will merely be the site or a distributing station for Standard Oil products in the Bronx section.

The State of New York is unwittingly vendor of "gold bricks," and the attempt will be made at the coming session of the Legislature to amend certain laws so that innocent purchasers of land sold for unpaid taxes shall no longer be robbed.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 26 -- The marriage of Miss Mary Patterson Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hall Harris, to John Henry Sherburne, Jr., of Boston, took place here to-day. Although the arrangements were very simple, they were characterized by great elegance. Socially, the wedding was the most important in Baltimore in a long time.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 26 -- The Rev. Dr. Joseph Henry Thayer, Bussey Professor Emeritus of New Testament Criticism and Interpretation in the Harvard University Divinity School, died to-day, in his seventy-fourth year. He had been connected with Harvard for many years, but retired last year, retaining his title, as a mark of honor, at the request of the Board of Overseers.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Though money was not much wanted to-day, it was firmer, owing to its scarcity. Discounts were sympathetically firm. Business on the Stock Exchange opened quiet and easier and scarcely anything was done beyond arranging the account, the chief characteristics of which were the depression in home rails, the strength of foreigners, and the irregularity of Americans.

At the annual meeting yesterday at the Chase National Bank of the Children's Aid Society William Church Osborn was elected President, to succeed D. Willis James, who has held the office since 1892. Mr. James continues as Trustee. Charles E. Whitehead, Vice President; A. Barton Hepburn, Treasurer, and Charles Loring Brace, Secretary, were re-elected.

The rapidity with which electric street railways and lines connecting centres of population with suburbs, originally intended to be strictly local, are being consolidated into systems and expanding into interurban lines of communication is extremely significant. Problems with which the steam railroad has been unable to cope profitably are being solved by the electric road naturally and easily.

The Rev. William S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, had something to say yesterday regarding the interview of Senator John Raines, father of the present excise law, which was published a day or two ago. Dr. Rainsford has been out of town for several days, and had net seen the interview during his absence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A newspaper which is trying to find out which officers read the proofs of Maclay's History, and thereby indorsed the criticisms upon Rear Admiral Schley, recently sent a letter to Rear Admiral Taylor asking whether he had read the proofs. Similar letters are being sent by the paper to the other Captains who served in the Santiago campaign.

The United States Board of Classification yesterday issued a decision on the protest in the case of Lucius Beebe Sons of Boston, importers, against the decision of the Collector of Customs at Boston, the decision involving the value of the Indian rupee in cases in which, merchandise from foreign countries is invoiced in rupees.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A reduction of the United States tariff on Canadian productions or a fair reciprocity treaty between this country and the United States would have been hailed with great satisfaction for many years after the abrogation of the old treaty which the United States declined to renew.

Despite adverse winds and mountainous seas that buffeted her all the way across the Atlantic, the new North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm got into port yesterday with a new transatlantic record for her westward passage to her credit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The assurances which Senor Infante, Chilean Charge, has given to the State Department relative to the continued cordial relations between Chile and Argentina are based upon dispatches received by Senor Infante from his Government.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- That part of the National Party which is supporting Gen. Bartolome Maso, the Democratic candidate for the Presidency of Cuba, has voted to send a cablegram to President Roosevelt asking him to recommend that the representatives of the United States in Cuba observe the strictest impartiality in the approaching election for a President.

Despite adverse winds and mountainous seas that buffeted her all the way across the Atlantic, the new North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm got into port yesterday with a new transatlantic record for her westward passage to her credit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Miss Dorothy Rockhill of this city and Joseph Clarke Hoppin of Boston were married at noon to-day in St. John's Episcopal Church. The bride is the eldest daughter of W.W. Rockhill, ex-Assistant Secretary of State and lately Special Envoy to China, and the bridegroom is the son of the late Courtland Hoppin of Boston and is a professor at Bryn Mawr College.

Duane -- Carpender. Many New Yorkers went to New Brunswick yesterday to attend the wedding of Miss Catherine Neilson Carpender, oldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nellson Carpender of that city, to Franklin Duane of Dover, Del., which took place at the Church of St. John the Evangelist.
REDWOOD CITY, Cal., Nov. 27. -- George M. Pullman is ill with acute pneumonia at San Mateo. His mother has been summoned.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 27. -- The announcement of the violation of the customs laws by Canadian fur dealers is of considerable interest here, as one of the cases is to come up before the United States District Court, which will meet in Rutland next Monday afternoon. The case involves a seizure of 107 Copper Island sealskins at Swanton, near the Canadian line, by Olin Merrill, Collector of Customs for that district, on Sept. 30 last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Of a card of seven events at Bennings to-day five favorites, Ohnet, Honolulu, Wellesley, Extinguisher, and Lady Teazle won. The extra event, a match race between Sir Ellerslie and Lady Teazle, was won by the latter. Track fast and attendance large Summary:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Secretary Long received the following cablegram from Capt. Perry of the battleship Iowa to-day:

It is notorious that for many years, with brief intervals of improvement. New York has had a police force in many respects far below a decent standard of honest efficiency. Yesterday for the first time in the history of the force an officer of high rank has been convicted and punished for willful neglect of duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The general expectation here is that Congress will enact a law for the further exclusion of Chinese, and that the law will not be any more favorable to the Chinese than that now in force. In fact it is said to be the programme to make a law that shall be more difficult of evasion than the present law.

In every place of worship in our land where the people are assembled to-day after the honored custom of their forefathers, and in the quiet of their homes, their thoughts will turn first to the terrible tragedy of the past year, to the shock and loss and danger that came to us in the assassination of our Chief Magistrate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Secretary Hay received a dispatch from Constantinople to-day repeating a rumor that has reached there that Miss Ellen M. Stone and Mme. Tsilka are dead. The report lacks confirmation, and is not credited by either Spencer Eddy, the American Charge at Constantinople, or by Mr. Dickinson, the Consul General there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Of a card of seven events at Bennings to-day five favorites, Ohnet, Honolulu, Wellesley, Extinguisher, and Lady Teazle won. The extra event, a match race between Sir Ellerslie and Lady Teazle, was won by the latter. Track fast and attendance large Summary:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The National Capitol is taking its annual bath. A large force of men, equipped with scrubbing brushes and scouring soap, started this morning to wash and scrub the great structure from dome to foundations. They will finish the work to-morrow night.

The Board of Building Commissioners, on Oct. 14 last, granted to the builders of the skyscrapers at Broadway and Maiden Lane and at Broadway and Twenty-third Street exemption from compliance with the provisions of Section 105 of the Building Code. This section requires that in all structures over 150 feet in height all materials used in construction shall be fireproof, of metal or metal-covered wood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Secretary Hay received a dispatch from Constantinople to-day repeating a rumor that has reached there that Miss Ellen M. Stone and Mme. Tsilka are dead. The report lacks confirmation, and is not credited by either Spencer Eddy, the American Charge at Constantinople, or by Mr. Dickinson, the Consul General there.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a favorite trick with that type of clergyman whom you aptly styled "yellow" to have a flint? at the women when other topics fail to draw a crowd. Women have borne with this kind of insults, and have submitted to be lectured from the pulpit upon their duties as women with a patience worthy of a better cause.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 27. -- After reading in an evening newspaper that his books were under examination by expert accountants, Stuart R. Young, City Treasurer of Louisville, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself behind the right ear with a pistol. It is stated that the shortage in the accounts will reach $50,000 and that the stealing had been systematic during the whole four years he held office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a favorite trick with that type of clergyman whom you aptly styled "yellow" to have a flint? at the women when other topics fail to draw a crowd. Women have borne with this kind of insults, and have submitted to be lectured from the pulpit upon their duties as women with a patience worthy of a better cause.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Naval, Board of Construction to-day completed its recommendations called for by Congress relative to two new battleships and two armored cruisers, and also covering many technical questions which have arisen as to naval architecture, armor, batteries, and turrets.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The suit by which Mme. Henry, widow of Col. Henry, who committed suicide as a result of the Dreyfus investigations, and her son are seeking to recover 200,000f. damages from Joseph Reinach, the Dreyfus supporter, and the newspaper the Siecle, was called yesterday.

The Board of Building Commissioners, on Oct. 14 last, granted to the builders of the skyscrapers at Broadway and Maiden Lane and at Broadway and Twenty-third Street exemption from compliance with the provisions of Section 105 of the Building Code. This section requires that in all structures over 150 feet in height all materials used in construction shall be fireproof, of metal or metal-covered wood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The general expectation here is that Congress will enact a law for the further exclusion of Chinese, and that the law will not be any more favorable to the Chinese than that now in force. In fact it is said to be the programme to make a law that shall be more difficult of evasion than the present law.
REDWOOD CITY, Cal., Nov. 27. -- George M. Pullman is ill with acute pneumonia at San Mateo. His mother has been summoned.

The mine owners of Colorado are just now much excited by the fear that Prof. C.W. WYNNE of Denver has made a discovery which will disturb the financial system of the world. Just what the discovery is no one except the inventor seems to know. Its results, however, are sufficient to justify the wildest kind of excitement-provided, of course, the facts are as believed.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27. -- The coaching squad of the naval cadets' football team was augmented to-day by Jesse Riggs, the former Princeton guard. The best scrub that ever played against the cadets was in the field to-day. Some of the players were Riggs, Edwards, Hillebrand, and Cochran of Princeton, and Irwin, Karns, and Izard of former naval teams.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith made public his annual report for the year ended June 30, 1901. Half of it is devoted to the abuses of second-class mail matter and the other half to rural free delivery, increase of revenue, service in Cuba and the Philippines, ocean mail service, pneumatic-tube service, parcels post, money-order department, service in Alaska, automobile tests, electric-car service, registry division, suppression of fraud, and the legislation needed.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 27. -- An American named Murphy corroborates the report that the Colombian gunboat General Pinzon fired on Porto Bello. On Monday morning he was in an open boat bound for Playadonna on a mining excursion. Besides himself there were three Chinese and a Colombian negro in the boat, which was commanded by the colored man.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Times to-day quotes an interview in a Nantes newspaper with a man named Sandberg, who is described as an aide de camp of the Boer Commandant General, Louis Botha. Sandberg has been, lecturing on the Continent to collect Boer funds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Naval, Board of Construction to-day completed its recommendations called for by Congress relative to two new battleships and two armored cruisers, and also covering many technical questions which have arisen as to naval architecture, armor, batteries, and turrets.

The session of the Meade court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday was enlivened by a spirited protest made by Architect William A. Boring against his being called before the court to testify. Mr. Boring is a member of the firm of Boring Tilton, the architects in charge of the work on the marine barracks in the yard.

Detective Christopher Grosel, who is attached to the Vernon Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, was murderously assaulted at an early hour yesterday morning by three men at Marcy and De Kalb Avenues and is now lying at his home, 207 Stockton Street, in a critical condition, suffering from a fracture of the skull and internal injuries.

DETROIT, Nov. 27. -- As the result of a head-on collision on the Wabash Railroad one mile from Seneca, Mich., at 6:45 o'clock this evening, 100 passengers, most of whom were immigrants, lost their lives. The list of the injured will probably reach 50.

DETROIT, Nov. 27. -- As the result of a head-on collision on the Wabash Railroad one mile from Seneca, Mich., at 6:45 o'clock this evening, 100 passengers, most of whom were immigrants, lost their lives. The list of the injured will probably reach 50.

The $25,000,000 paid in by the banking syndicate which financed the United States Steel Corporation has been returned to the members of the syndicate. The profits of the syndicate, however, which are variously estimated at from 25 to 37 1/2 per cent, of the amount of their original subscriptions, have not been returned and the syndicate has not been dissolved.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Rev. Wallace Radcliffe of this city, and the Rev. Dr. Crissey, Chairman of the Presbyterian Synodical Committee on Religious Work in the Army, called upon the President to-day to discuss the subject.

The Board of Education will ask the Board of Estimate and Apportionment for $12,495,200 for school buildings and sites. The Educational Board decided on this request last night and passed a resolution asking that the Board of Estimate approve the issue o corporate stock to an amount not to exceed the sum mentioned.

The protest of Charles R. Lamb against the levying of duty on parts of an altar imported by him on the steamship British King on Nov. 14, 1900, is overruled in a decision filed yesterday by the United States Board of General Appraisers.

The $25,000,000 paid in by the banking syndicate which financed the United States Steel Corporation has been returned to the members of the syndicate. The profits of the syndicate, however, which are variously estimated at from 25 to 37 1/2 per cent, of the amount of their original subscriptions, have not been returned and the syndicate has not been dissolved.

The protest of Charles R. Lamb against the levying of duty on parts of an altar imported by him on the steamship British King on Nov. 14, 1900, is overruled in a decision filed yesterday by the United States Board of General Appraisers.

Handel London, who is also known as T. Sack, was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday, charged with stealing merchandise from about forty wholesale furnishing goods houses. Complaints were taken in three cases, and he was held in $1,000 bail on each charge for further examination.

Directum, the trotting stallion, was sold in Madison Square Garden yesterday morning to Henry M. Savage, representing the International Stock Farm of Minneapolis, for $12.100. Directum was the head of the stud of the Suburban Stock Farm of Glens Falls, N.Y., belonging to the estate or the late William E. Spier, and the sale of the famous stallion was the feature of the sale now in progress in Madison Sqare Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27. -- Judge McCarthy of the Common Pleas Court has issued an injunction in which he denies the right of the Council of the Allied Building Trades, or its agents, to instigate strikes at buildings where contractors employ labor that is not affiliated with the organization.

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 27. -- An American named Murphy corroborates the report that the Colombian gunboat General Pinzon fired on Porto Bello. On Monday morning he was in an open boat bound for Playadonna on a mining excursion. Besides himself there were three Chinese and a Colombian negro in the boat, which was commanded by the colored man.

ANTWERP, Nov. 27. -- The British steamer Ban High, which was detained at the Victoria Docks, London, by customs officials under suspicion that she had on board arms and ammunition intended for the Boere, has arrived here. She carries a large cargo of munitions of war for the Colombian Liberals, including 4,000 cases of cartridges, 1,000 cases of rifles, machineguns, and chemicals.

ANTWERP, Nov. 27. -- The British steamer Ban High, which was detained at the Victoria Docks, London, by customs officials under suspicion that she had on board arms and ammunition intended for the Boere, has arrived here. She carries a large cargo of munitions of war for the Colombian Liberals, including 4,000 cases of cartridges, 1,000 cases of rifles, machineguns, and chemicals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The engagement was announced to-day of Miss Helen Hay, eldest daughter of the Secretary of State, to Payne Whitney, second son of William C. Whitney, ex-Secretary of the Navy.

ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- Police Captain Thomas J. Diamond of New York was convicted to-day by a jury composed chiefly of Albany County farmers of willful neglect of duty while in command of the Eleventh Precinct in failing to suppress the disorderly house of Lena Schmitt, at 27 Stuyvesant Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith made public his annual report for the year ended June 30, 1901. Half of it is devoted to the abuses of second-class mail matter and the other half to rural free delivery, increase of revenue, service in Cuba and the Philippines, ocean mail service, pneumatic-tube service, parcels post, money-order department, service in Alaska, automobile tests, electric-car service, registry division, suppression of fraud, and the legislation needed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Republican leaders in Congress, as a rule, have not been affected very much by Secretary Root's plea for commercial reciprocity for the Cubans. Nor is there any expectation that what the President is to say in his message in support of Mr. Root's plea will result in any considerable gain to the number of those who favor giving the Cubans what they ask.

In the pain of defeat Mr. RICHARD CROKER lifts up his voice for harmony in the Democratic Party. A divided party can accomplish nothing, he says; the Democracy must get together. The Democrats of New York City and the Democrats up the State must be one in purpose and in leadership.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The Marquis of Lansdowne, Secretary of State for 'Foreign Affairs, speaking at Darlington last night, referred to the extraordinary keenness of the competition for the world's markets as affording the greatest preoccupation in questions of foreign policy.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 14. -- That the death of Li-Hung-Chang should be regarded as a loss to Russia is only natural, seeing that Russia negotiated through him the Manchuria treaties. It is also looked upon here as a loss to China and the whole world.

Handel London, who is also known as T. Sack, was arraigned in the Centre Street Court yesterday, charged with stealing merchandise from about forty wholesale furnishing goods houses. Complaints were taken in three cases, and he was held in $1,000 bail on each charge for further examination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- "I take pleasure in reporting the success attendant upon the first serious experiment in introducing American cotton fabrics into this market, where hitherto English wares have held undisputed sway," says Consul Norton, at Harput, in a report to the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The annual report of Secretary of War Elihu Root for 1901 includes a report on the government of the Philippines, and he transmits with it all the enactments of the Commission to Oct. 11, so that the National Legisla ture will be in possession of the entire body of legislative acts under which civil government in the Philippine Islands is proceeding.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In his address, "Disease and Sin," before the Wisconsin State Medical Society, Dr. George M. Gould, one of our best statisticians in this country, says:

The cars, cabs, and carriages on Broadway, about 8 o'clock last evening, were stopped for ten minutes by the Thanksgiving theatre crowd which collected in front of the Sturtevant House and Proctor's Theatre to see a dogfight.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 28. -- When night fell over the scene of yesterday evening's awful calamity on the Wabash Railroad near Seneca, Mich., those who had been investigating the disaster had found nothing to alter their estimate of about eighty lives lost as a result of the collision. Superintendent George M. Burns, of the division on which the wreck occurred, insists that the estimates are top high.

Henry Clews, Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Clews, and Mrs. Louise Morris Gebhard, daughter of Mrs. John Morris, were married in Christ Presbyterian Church, in West Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday morning at 10:30 o'clock by the Rev. Dr. James M. Farr of that church.
Senator William A. Clark of Montana arrived on the Majestic from Europe yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Wisconsin 35, Chicago 0 was the result of the football game to-day between the Universities of Wisconsin and Chicago. Wisconsin's goal only twice was in the least danger. Straight football won the day and the team work on the part of the victors was clever, though in nearly every case the scores were made by star plays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The President expects to have a fine time at the West Point-Annapolis football game in Philadelphia Saturday. He will leave here at 10 o'clock Saturday morning, and get back in the evening. Mrs. Roosevelt will accompany the President, and among others who will be in the party are Commander and Mrs. Cowles, Col. and Mrs. Theodore Bingham, Secretary and Mrs. Cortelyou, Dr. and Mrs. Rixey, Assistant Secretary Loeb, and probably others.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Here is a suggestion for the creation of an insurance fund, in the foundation and maintenance of which no profit, except to its eventual beneficiaries, is contemplated. The crude idea that may perhaps be elaborated and reduced to a working basis is this:

Traffic on all surface car lines in the lower portion of the city, south of Eighth Street, was paralyzed completely from halfpast 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon until 11 o'clock last night by an explosion of gas in the subway of the Bowling Green section of the up town Broadway track, opposite the Produce Exchange.

BRICK CHURCH, Nov. 28. -- The annual horse show of the Oranges opened to-night at the Riding and Driving Club, in Halsted Street, East Orange. The clubhouse was filled with a large assemblage of the fashionable people of the Oranges. All the boxes have been sold for the entire three days of the show.

OSSINING, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- This was a holiday at Sing Sing Prison, and the convicts enjoyed a respite from work. They had, as usual, breakfast and dinner only, this belngr the Sunday and holiday plan. Breakfast, instead of being served early in the morning, was not served until 8 o'clock, and occupied an hour.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Thanksgiving Day card of seven events, including a hurdle, a steeplechase, and a race on the flat at two and a quarter miles for the Washington Cup to-day drew to the Bennings race track one of the largest crowds that ever witnessed a day's racing on that track.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to your inquiries, I can only speak for the tobacco trade and industries.

Thanksgiving services in the churches were, as a rule, so largely attended as to almost mark a revival of public interest in the religious aspect of the festival. In numerous instances congregations combined in union services. In all the sermons the memory of President McKinley occupied a leading part, and many eloquent eulogies were spoken.

PARIS, Nov. 29. -- The Chamber of Deputies, by a vote of 333 to 213, yesterday, adopted the Chinese loan bill, after rejecting two paragraphs of the final article, which the commission had inserted against the wish of the Government. These paragraphs excluded religious congregations from the benefits of the loan, and provided that indemnities be distributed to private claimants only, as China paid the installments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Preliminary work on the revision of the Creed of the Presbyterian Church, so as to make it more popularly understood, was inaugurated here to-day at a meeting of a section of the Committee of Twenty appointed at the last Presbyterian Assembly to accomplish this result.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team ended its disastrous season to-day with a crushing defeat at the hands of the Cornell eleven, the Ithaca boys scoring 24 points to the Quakers' 6. It was the first time since the two universities have played football together that Cornell has been able to conquer Pennsylvania.

The question of the loss of the free use of a finger and thumb, and its effect upon the plaintiff's employment of the sign language as a deaf-mute, was one of the points sharply contested in a suit brought by Moritz Swelig of 13 West One Hundred and Fifteenth Street. Swelig sues to recover $2,000 from the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for personal injuries.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- Sixteen reporters and six business men gathered yesterday afternoon, in response to the general invitation of the London Chamber of Commerce, to hear Seymour Bell, the Commercial Agent of Great Britain in the United States, expound his views on American trade competition.
BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The Vossische Zeitung announces that the German Plate Syndicate has reduced its prices on boiler plate from 180 to 160 marks, and on other plates from 100 to 140 marks.

To the Editor of The Now York Times: I am glad to see attention called in your paper this morning to the construction of the principal building or the City College, at Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. As a graduate of the college, with a practical interest in the problems of fire prevention, the condition of the building has been for many years a question of grave concern to me.

Thanksgivind Day did not stay the "Old Glory" horse sale at Madison Square Garden for a moment. Matters went on as steadily as if the turkey was unknown and the only business of the world was the buying and selling of horses.

A clear and cold Thanksgiving gave zest to the many entertainments out of town. It was a day for sports in the open, and the entire country responded. At Meadow Brook it was a gala occasion. The hunt met in the forenoon, and there was a breakfast at Mrs. Adolph Ladenburg's which was very jolly and picturesque.

Only the annual game between West Point and Annapolis remains to be played in order to conclude the football season of 1901, as yesterday's games completed the college schedules. Michigan completes her season with the remarkable and probably unprecedented total of 501 points to none for her opponents; Cornell comes next, with 334 to 14; Harvard has 255 to 24, Yale, 256 to 37; Princeton, 247 to 24, and Lafayette 230 to 94.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- John Krause, who kept a little cigar store on Lincoln Avenue, where he lived alone, was murdered this evening in his apartments in the rear of the store. The police are look- ing for Frank Williams, who, according to statements made by his wife, committed the crime.

Barutel, the French billiard player, who is to be one of the competitors in the world's championship next week in the Madison Square Garden, began the second series of contests with Willie Hoppe, the boy billiardist, last night in Maurice Daly's academy. Three games will be played, and the total is to be 1,100 for the Frenchman and 825 for Hoppe.

There was no end of good sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday, when the best of New York city's trotting and pacing horses turned out in force and furnished a continuous performance to the thousands of spectators that lined the curbs of the upper stretch. The footing was especially suited to pacers, who carried off the majority of the fast heats during the day.

Bears on the stock market have had little solace thus far this week -- and this in the face of a collapse in the price of Amalgamated Copper which, because Standard Oil interests are identified with that property, afforded excuse for every bear operator to declare with emphasis that "Standard Oil interests are opposed to the market."

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Three hundred guests assembled this evening for the Thanksgiving Day dinner given under the auspices of the American Society in London. John Morgan Richards was in the chair. Paul Cambon, the French Ambassador to Great Britain, proposed the health of President Roosevelt.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 28. -- Knocked out in the second round," of which one minute and forty-four seconds had elapsed, was the referee's verdict of the prizefight between "Young Corbett" (William Rothwell) of Denver, Col., and "Terry" McGovern of Brooklyn, who has held the featherweight championship since he won it from George Dixon eighteen months ago.

An investigation into Custom House affairs by special Treasury agents is said to have disclosed evidences of fraudulent entry aided by collusion by which importers in some cases might profit. This relates to the manner of selecting samples of imported goods to be sent to the Appraisers' Stores for the determination of their value and classification.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says a subscription on behalf of the Polish children concerned in the Wreschen school scandals has been started by an appeal issued by Henryk Sienkiewicz, the novelist.

Postmaster General SMITH returns in his annual report to the attack on the abuses connected with the second class mail matter, the matter sent out to subscribers at one cent a pound. This time, however, he has the very great advantage that he points to steps taken under his direction to correct the abuses, steps which he thinks will go far toward accomplishing his aim, whether or not there is additional legislation.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Henry S. Teinson, who is connected with the National Biscuit Company, was among the Chicagoans on the ill-fated Wabash train. He was in the third coach from the rear.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 28. -- American residents celebrated Thanksgiving Day by a special ball. President Diaz was among the invited guests. Many members of the Pan-American Congress with their ladies were present. The decorative scheme embraced a display of the flags of all American republics.

A fierce fire which caused damage estimated by Chief Croker at nearly $1,000,000 started last evening in the seven-story cigar box and veneer factory of William Uptegrove Brother, extending from 457 to 467 East Tenth Street, near Avenue D. The factory was totally destroyed, and the flames spread to property of the Mutual Gas Company, the Standard Oil Company, and two lumber concerns.

We make no apology for transferring to our news columns all that we can make room for of the concluding part of the report of the Secretary of War. It is virtually independent of or supplementary to the main body of the report, and deals exclusively with the Government of the Philippines.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28. -- George M. Pullman, son of the late millionaire car builder, died at his country home in San Mateo this morning. He had been ill several weeks with pneumonia, but until Tuesday his condition was not considered serious. On that day he suffered a relapse, and grew steadily weaker.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- The unbeaten Michigan football team met the University of Iowa eleven on the gridiron in the National League Baseball Park to-day. Michigan scored almost at will, making 50 points to the Hawkeyes' 0. Thus Michigan closes the regular football season with a total record of 501 points, while not one of the teams she has met has been able to score a single point against her.

Thanksgiving was celebrated in a very jolly way yesterday evening in the rooms of the New Era Club, at 287 Henry Street. The club has a membership of nearly 300 young men, and when the majority arrived last evening, each accompanied by a sweetheart or a sister, the snug little club-house was filled almost to overflowing.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 28. -- Beyond the statement made last night to Mayor Granger by one of the expert accountants, that discrepancies amounting to $23,000 had been found in the books of the former city Treasurer, Stuart R. Young, who committed suicide last evening, nothing definite is known as to how the accounts stand betwen the city and its former treasurer.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- Although the requirements for the conclusion of the settlement are trifling, the scantiness of supplies stiffens money, in view of the month-end and in spite of the borrowings from the bank, which have relieved the pressure somewhat. Consequently, with the weakness of French exchange, discounts were beyond the completion of the account.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Over 100 golfers drove off from the first tee of the Lakewood Golf Club to-day in the opening medal play round of the annual Thanksgiving tournament of the club. The actual number of starters was 108, a recordbreaking number for a club that has always been able to command a large field for its open golf events.

The estate of George Bancroft, the historian, worth over $600,000, which has been tied up for ten years, will be distributed within a few days. When the historian died in Washington on Jan. 17, 1891, he left a will, executed April 13, 1887, in which he tied up the bulk of his estate until Nov. 1, 1901. This will was filed for probate on March 3, 1891.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 28. -- George W. Youmans of this city was killed in the Wabash Railroad wreck near Seneca, Mich. Mr. Youmans was a well-known building and paving contractor and a member of the Board of Public Works of Kansas City. He erected many of the large buildings in Kansas City and has held heavy contracts throughout the Southwest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If cleanliness is next to godliness, then the amount of water a people consume measures their civilization. Because Boston is a great civilization she has taken possession of hundreds of square miles of water area, and not only has a neverfailing quantity for herself, but enough to supply seventeen neighboring towns.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Georgetown University football team closed its season to-day by defeating Lehigh University, 22 to 0. The visitors were never seriously in the contest. Both teams were weak on the defensive. At times Lehigh played an aggressively offensive game, but for the most part the work of the team was featureless.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- With the restoration of order and open traffic on the Isthmus of Panama it is expected that the Navy Department will be able to withdraw some of the United States warships now on duty in that quarter, and it is now probable that one ship will be withdrawn on either side of the Isthmus.

District Attorney Philbin wrote a letter yesterday to Building Commissioner James G. Wallace in reference to alleged violations of the Building Code. The letter was the outcome of many complaints that violations of the law were being committed by certain builders.

It is one of the most beautiful of hair ornaments. There is a good-sized pin representing a spray of holly, made of brilliants, with a dot of red here and there. From the pin rises a miniature ostrich plume 3 or 4 inches high, perhaps, and the prettiest ostrich plume ever used for such a purpose.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 -- Mrs. Lottie Wiethop, eighteen years old, a bride of less than three months, who is one of the heirs to an English estate, passed Thanksgiving Day and night in prison with a charge of burglary and larceny against her. She freely admitted that the charge was deserved.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 29 -- Thomas E. Moran, Deputy Customs Collector at this port, agrees with the estimate that at least seventy-five lives were lost in Wednesday night's collision on the Wabash Railroad near Seneca. Deputy Moran visited the train in his official capacity when it crossed the Detroit River Wednesday afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on making criminals I consider very timely and to the point. You may not be an expert on criminology, but you are in earnest, and you are certainly applying the rules of good common sense to the solution of this problem of vital importance.

In the outside market yesterday prices were irregular, some parts of the list showing material improvement, while in others there was a decided downward tendency. As a whole the market was more active than it has been recently, several stocks being traded in to the extent of about 5,000 shares, although the majority of issues naturally showed much smaller totals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question of city taxation is a tremendous problem. Ninety-odd millions is the amount required for next year, and a rate of about $2.30 on every $100 of assessed value is fixed, and real estate will have to bear about the whole of it. Do property owners kick?

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The exhibition of four-in-hand driving by Mau- rice Hewlett, the noted French whip, was a feature of the second night of the Orangre Horse Show. Although this was the last number on the programme, practically the entire audience awaited the exhibit.

The recent revival, at a large private reception given at Hampstead, England, of Milton's masque of "Comus" was an event of literary interest. The masque was produced by Savage Cooper, the artist, who painted the three scenes and played the part of Comus.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 29 -- A special from Newton, N.C., to The Observer says:
S. CHURCHILL CONDE -- S. Churchill Conde of Oswego filed a petition in bankruptcy at Utica yesterday. There are $26,446 in liabilities and no assets. Most of the creditors are citizens of Oswego.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Englishmen are now so used to untruths with regard to the Boer war that their constant reappearance provokes nothing but contempt at the futile attempts of our enemies. But when an individual like Herman D. Van Broekhuizen (who writes "Rev." in front of his name) utters such libels as he did on Tuesday evening they should not go unnoticed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The football warriors of the West Point and Annapolis Academies arrived here to-day for their annual contest on the University of Pennsylvania's athletic field to-morrow. Nearly every train from the North, South, and West that came in during the afternoon and evening brought scores of persons who, with the President of the United States, will watch the cadets do battle on the gridiron.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's issue, Mr. Kohler gives an interesting discourse on the Chinese Exclusion act. There are, however, two sides to this question. The atrocities and outrages alleged by Mr. Kohler to have been perpetrated upon the poor, ignorant Chinese are more apparent than real.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- On the close of the settlement money was cheaper to-day, though with a good demand and a short supply it is not likely to decline much. Discounts were correspondingly easier.

We hope Mr. BABCOCK and all the tariff reform Republicans of the East and West will read and ponder the utterances of the unyielding Republican defenders of Dingleyism. Their speech shows with what manner of thoughts their minds are occupied.

Winter gave a gentle warning that he was here for another visit yesterday. His notice was in the shape of a whirl and a rush of snowflakes which peppered the throngs in the streets on their way to work during the early morning hours, and finally enveloped the roofs and roadways in mantles of glistening white.

Among the shivering passengers who arrived yesterday on the steamer Monterey from the palm shaded precincts of Havana to be greeted by the falling snows of New York was Gen. Leonard Wood. Military Governor of Cuba. Gen. Wood was accompanied by Mrs. Wood, his Secretary, William A. Varty; Lieut. McCoy of the Tenth Cavalry, his aide, and by Gonzalo de Queseda, as special Commissioner from Cuba to Washington.

ERIE, Penn., Nov. 29 -- The east-bound Lake Shore limited, carrying over 400 pouches of Australian mail to catch Saturday's steamer for Queenstown, arrived in this city at 1:45 o'clock P.M. and left for the East on schedule time, having made up fourteen minutes between here and Cleveland.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Two books issued by Philadelphia houses during the past fortnight have met with very marked success "The True Thomas Jefferson," by William Eleroy Curtis, and "Captain Bluitt," by Max Adeler, have both been met by such considerable orders that the editions have been exhausted.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 -- Secretary Hester's statement of the world's visible supply of cotton, issued to-day, shows a total of 3,456,193 bales, against 3,325,990 bales last week and 3,363,456 bales last year. Of this the total of American cotton is 3,003,193 bales, against 2,907,990 bales last week and 2,839,456 bales last year, and of all other kinds, including Egypt, Brazil, India, , 453,000 bales, against 418,000 bales last week and 524,000 bales last year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The transport Buford, en route from the Philippines with two battalions of the Twenty-third Infantry aboard to New York, is several days overdue. No apprehension is felt at the War Department, however, as the severe northwest gales which have prevailed for some days past over the North Atlantic naturally would retard her progress.
VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- Herr Wolf. German Nationalist member of the Lower House of the Reichsrath, who has been so prominent in riotous scenes in the House, has resigned his seat.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The American Association of Professional Baseball Clubs, with Thomas J. Hickey as President, was launched to-day. The circuit and owners of the franchises were announced as follows: Indianapolis, W.H. Watkins and J. Rauschkaup; Milwaukee, H.D. Quinn and C.S. Havenor: St. Paul, George Lennon; Columbus, T.J. Bryce; Toledo, Charles Strobel; Minneapolis, A.B. Beall; Omaha, W.A. Rourke, and Kansas City, George Tebeau.

Following is a statement of books which have sold best in regular book and department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Washington, Cincinnati, Chicago, San Francisco, St. Louis, Boston, Minneapolis, and Baltimore between Oct. 27 and Nov. 27 of this year. The statement is based on the reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES of those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, through its Prudential Committee, has just sent out a circular to the Congregational churches of the country asking for more liberal support. The board was a little over $100,000 in debt, but at the annual meeting in Hartford a few weeks ago the entire amount was subscribed by about 500 persons.

IN these papers, which strive to record the vanishing memories of nearly half a centruy freedom of souvenirs which I have already printed here and there in magazines and newspapers, some of them a score and more years ago when my remembrance of the events and persons described was naturally fresher than it can now be expected to be.
