ROME, Nov. 29 -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day passed a bill appropriating 3,500,000 lire ($675,500) for the purchase of the Borghese collection of pictures, the estimated value of which is 10,000,000 lire, ($1,930,000.)

MR. FITZGERALD MOLLOY'S gossipy volumes are much more than a chronicle of the fortunes of the Churchills, interesting as is the story of the rise of that family. It is in reality a record of the history, the scandals, political intrigues, and other happenings, both public and private, in England during the long period covered by the reigns of Charles II., James II., William and Mary, Queen Anne, and the first of the Georges.

Fire Chief Croker said yesterday that the Standard Oil Company had violated the laws governing the storage of explosives and combustibles and that but for this the big fire which started in the Uptegrove cigar-box factory, in East Tenth Street, on Thursday evening, could have been held in check with ease.

The teaching of English was discussed in its various aspects by the New England Association of Teachers of English, in the City of Boston on Nov. 16. It is an educational subject of the first importance, and the subject and its importance are alike perpetual.

Florida has a crop of oranges this year that makes the orange growers of that State think the time is near at hand when the annual shipment of oranges will approximate that immediately before the great freeze of 1895. It will be recalled that during the season before the freeze pretty nearly 5,000,000 boxes were shipped out of the State.
D.F. STEVENS, for twenty-one years a Police Judge of Lockport, N.Y., died yesterday, aged sixty-eight years.

The schedule committee of the Amateur Hockey League of America yesterday adopted the schedule of games for the season of 1901-1902. With only the New York Athletic Club, St. Nicholas Skating Club, Crescent Athletic Club, and Hockey Club of New York in the association, the schedule is considerably shorter this year than last.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A step toward the abolition of professionalism from college athletics was taken to-day by the Faculty representatives of the intercollegiate college conference, who had an all-day session here to-day.

FROM the Knickerbocker Press comes this beautifully printed and elaborately illustrated book of 455 pages. The author is a distinguished citizen of Amsterdam, N.Y. Mr. Reid frankly confesses that his subject is his hobby, and always has been.

Mr. Alexander Del Mar's "History of the Precious Metals" was begun by him in 1858, and completed in 1879. The edition now just issued has been carefully revised by the author and much material of additional interest has been added. During the last few years Mr. Del Mar's time has been occupied with practical mining, and he has thus been able to study in person the subject of the precious metals in many different countries.

The case for the prosecution was closed and that of the defense opened at yesterday's session of the Meade court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Mr. Semple of Col. Meade'a counsel, opening the defense, took up the first charge made against Col. Meade, that of drunkenness. He called to the stand in the order named Lieuts. of Marines J.S. Hooker, J.C. Beaumont, Raymond P. Sullivan, O.H. Rask, Fryer, and Dikeman.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 29 -- City Counsel Thomas A. Davis announced to-day that the entire shortage of David J. Quinlan, the suspended Water Clerk, has been made up. Between $13,500 and $14,000 is now deposited in the Orange National Bank to the city's credit. Quinlan is still in hiding, and the evidence in connection with his defalcation is ready for the Grand Jury.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just been reading Levermore's "Republic of New Haven," and desire to cite two brief quotations which, I believe, will be of interest to you and to many of your readers apropos of the recent election in New York:

Deputy Controller Edgar J. Levey retires from the Department of Finance to-day, to become the Vice President and General Manager of the Title Insurance Company of New York. James W. Stevenson of 847 Greens Avenue, Brooklyn, who has been private secretary to President Grout of the Borough of Brooklyn, was yesterday appointed Second Deputy Controller.

During the last two years five distinct howls of wrath have arisen in this country, chiefly swelled by the voice of the half-educated, but in part produced by others, and the five causes, Prof. Hugo Munsterberg's three Atlantic and two International Review articles, are to appear in a volume entitled "American Traits from the Point of View of a German."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Secretary Root to-day addressed a communication to Eligio Bonachea, President of the convention at Havana, Cuba, that nominated Bartholomew Maso for President, relative to complaints that United States authorities were interfering in the Cuban elections. A press dispatch from Havana stated that Maso complained that the interference of United States officers was being exerted in favor of Estrada Palma, and a dispatch from Bonachea to the Secretary implied the same thing.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The Evening Telegraph says:

The eighteen-inch balk line handicap billiard match between "Willie" Hoppe and Barutel was continued yesterday afternoon at Maurice Daly's Academy. Hoppe, who was in excellent form, gradually wore down his opponent's lead, and at the end of the game had a comfortable lead with which to complete his string to-night.

The Executive Committee of the Greater New York Democracy met last night at the headquarters of the organization, 180 Broadway. Every member of the committee was present, as also were many members of the organization who are not members of the Executive Committee. Among the notables present were John C. Sheehan, the leader of the organization, Sheriff-elect O'Brien, Register-elect Ronner, and E. Ellery Anderson.

Glancing over last week's Magazine number of this paper many readers must have been impressed by the methods of display in the matter of large type used by the publishers in their advertise- ments. The type was often about an inch in length and its face was a quarter of an inch wide -- solid black masses of ink.
Senator Joseph W. Bailey of Texas favors the nomination by the Democrats of ex-Senator German of Maryland for the Presidency in 1904.

"Colonial Fights and Fighters" is second to "American Fights and Fighters" in the series in which Mr. Brady means to complete "a Battle History of America, in which the stories of all the conflicts, wars, and adventures, which have taken place on the continent, will eventually find a place."

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Mrs. Humphry Ward has nearly finished a new novel, as yet unnamed, which will begin its serial run in Harper's Magazine next Spring. Possibly no woman novelist of to-day writes in such an aggressive, and at the same time wholesome, manner.

A half dozen painters of the French landscape school, 1830-1870, are among those whose pictures greet one in the galleries of Mr. Julius Oehme -- pictures that may be new to this country, but have a respectable number of years behind them; pictures of the kind that grow rarer and rarer as the big private collections as well as the public art museums absorb their fellows.

The present experience of the German Government in Prussian Poland illustrates anew the difficulty that always besets the attempt of one race to govern another which does not acquiesce in the assumption that it is "inferior" or "subject." That assumption of white men is commonly acquiesced in by black or yellow men after a brief season of experiment.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Among the many interesting articles in your ever interesting NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS none has pleased me more than those of your symposium on criticism. What you have said has been so well said, it would seem there is nothing more to be added save a word in commendation of your leaders and one from the individual point of view.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the name of common decency I desire to enter my protest against the opening of saloons on the Sabbath. If the traffic in liquor is a legitimate business put it on the same basis and accord it no more nor less privileges than are granted to legitimate and immeasurably more decent lines of business.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circut Court, yesterday handed down an order finding Anson R. Flower, a Director of the Boston Montana Consolidated Copper and Silver Mining Company, guilty of con- tempt of court, and committing him to the custody of United States Marshal Henkel until he shall consent to appear and testify in an action brought against the company in the Montana courts.

Another batch of house parties for the country over the week end and quite a number of teas and receptions in town. In fact, this will be a field day for the early debutantes. The snow and frost may interfere with the drag hunts to-day. There is a meet at Goshan in the afternoon at which the Tuxedo contingent will assist, and Howard Willets has called one of the Westchester Hounds at Rye.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of to-day (Nov. 27.) you give some prominence to statements made under above heading, and, as a matter of ordinary fair play, I feel confident you will give me, as an Englishman, equal opportunity to reply -- especially as it is but fair to the American people that they should have the other side of the question also before them.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The Times, in its financial article to-day, says copper was again flat yesterday. Considerable excitement was caused in the City by a cablegram from New York, signed "Casek," received by a number of important houses. It alleged that more than 20,000 tons of copper had been sold at a decline by the United Metals Company.

Justice Clarke, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, upon the application of Lawyer George G. MacLaughlin, issued a writ of habeas corpus directing George Blair, Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, to produce in court Ellen Duff, seventy-eight years old, whom, it is alleged, Mr. Blair has restrained of her liberty.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The complete figures of the attendance at Cornell University were given out by President Schurman this evening. Excluding the Summer session, which was attended by 501 students, there are at present 2,792 regularly enrolled students at Cornell, as against 2,458 last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Representative Swanson of Virginia has prepared the following amendment to the rules of the House which he proposes to offer if an opportunity presents itself:

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In the privately printed of "After-Dinner Speeches at the Lotos Club," issued this year, the first speech, that of Charles Kingsley, is assigned the date Feb. 15, 1872. It is followed by the speech of Kingsley's intimate friend, James Anthony Froude, Oct. 12, 1872 and Wilkie Collins, Sept. 27, 1873.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- The fifteenth annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland convened in this city this morning with a good attendance. The delegates were received by the Faculty of Syracuse University, where the convention is being held, and shown about the different colleges.

VERY few men have been able to live long enough to master highly more than one trade. S. Weir Mitchell may be regarded as the marked exception to prove the rule. Not so many years ago he was spoken of as a famous physician who was also an author.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Twelve Persons were injured in a rear-end collision between a special and a freight on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad near Tully Station early this morning. The special was bringing home from Cortland a large party of Syracuse Knights of Columbia, who had been attending lodge festivities there.

The telling and retelling of old tales, from parent to child, down the long generations, have made Europe the home of "the Little People" -- pixie and kobold and brownie and gnome -- until now the Gothic style of folkstories is a part of the permanent furnishing of the literary consciousness of the world.

Mayor-elect Seth Low formally announced yesterday morning his appointment of Col. John M. Partridge to be Commissioner of Police. THE NEW YORK TIMES, in yesterday's issue, made public the fact that Col. Partridge had been chosen, and that his successor as State Superintendent of Public Works had been selected.

HERE in a elever and interesting volume is discussed the wonderful mission of the Jesuits in Paraguay. The average man in this country knows little, and cares less, about Paraguay. He remembers it as a spot on the map of which he heard in school days.

Just at present, when the matter of library establishment is receiving general attention, owing to the constant activity of Mr. Andrew Carnegie, it would be well to bear in mind that no town or city, or even village, in this State need await the pleasure of the industrious philanthropist to acquire a good library at a small expense.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 29 -- The State Board of Canvassers, who passed on the validity of the New Jersey election and authorized the issuing of a commission to Franklin Murphy that he is the Governor-elect of New Jersey, is not a reviewing committee, as is the popular impression, but an interesting relic of the days of the old New Jersey Council, and it sits with fixed statutory powers that are judicial.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- The new Public Library Commission of New Jersey has just completed its first annual report, which is particularly valuable because it gives fresh statistics on the libraries in the State, there being an active movement in the construction of libraries at present.

The seventeen-story building at the northwest corner of William and Cedar Streets has been sold by the Queen Insurance Company to Dumont Clarke, President of the American Exchange National Bank, through William A. White Sons.

WANDERINGS in Three Continents," by the late Capt. Sir Richard F. Burton, scholar and adventurer, comes from the press of Dodd, Mead Co. this week. It is intended to supplement, and not to replace, the biographical material about Burton already published.

The little book on Maude Adams, which is in uniform size and binding with Mir. E.A. Dithmar's volume on John Drew, published last year should be attractive to lovers of the stage, and especially in admirers of this gifted young actress. It is itself, a eulogy rather than a critism. Its author, under whose management Miss Adams played for several years, is frankly an admires of her work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 24th inst., under the heading of "The W.C.T.U. on Sunday Opening," you say: "He [Roosevelt as Police Commissioner] did succeed in making it, if not impossible, at least difficult, for any New Yorker to get a glass of beer on Sunday.

Continuations are not always successful, but Barbara Yechton in "Young Mrs. Teddy," has followed out the fortunes of the heroine of "A Young Savage" in the happiest manner. Perhaps the story might appeal more to women than to men, but for all that the method and the manner of the writing are of the best.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- New York exchange was quoted at par to-day. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. There was a lively trade in Tin Can, but the rest of the market was rather slow. Generally speaking, prices were steady. The bulk of the early dealings in Can were at 10 1/2 to 18 3/4 for the common and 63 to 65 1/2 for the preferred.

Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, heard argument and reserved decision on an application to set aside the attachment issued against the property of Mrs. Mary Reynolds, in the suit brought against her by Miss Harriet A. Haines, who alleged that Mrs. Reynolds had failed to keep her promise to her as to the payment of certain money, and that she was about to elope and go to England to reside.

A man does not need to be very old before he begins to talk of his schooldays in a tender reminiscent tone, or rather to talk about his school -- for it is the man who has been bred in a single school whom one finds prattling about comrade and mentor -- or, if he happens to be a writer, prattling about them in print.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Nov. 29 -- Henry H. Terwilliger, for twenty years a private banker at Montague, has gone and he says he will not return. According to an investigation by experts the Montague Bank has $15,000 more assets than liabilities. Terwilliger went to Detroit Nov. 21, and wrote back from there.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Metropolitan dog fanciers to-day, as on the two previous days, succeeded in capturing their share of prizes and ribbons at the international show of the Philadelphia Dog Show Association. H.T. Foote of New Rochelle, N.Y., managed to capture a bulk of the prizes in the class for black and tan terriers, also winning the special prize for the best team in the show.

FOR me there were two Stevensons: the Stevenson who went to America in 1887; and the Stevenson who never came back. The first I knew and loved; the other I lost touch with, and, though I admired him, did not greatly esteem.

Gwendolyn in her boudoir and Biddy in her kitchen know how necessary for their existences is a dream book. Gwendolyn in her slumbers smells the fragrance of violets, and Biddy the reek of onions. Both at once fly to the printed oracle for some interpretation. Acording to the volume under notice, violets presage a future husband, and onions (cooked) "placidity and small gains in business."
MADRID, Nov. 29 -- Francisco Pi y Margall, Chief of the Republican Federal Party, died to-day.

Mr. Andrew Lang's preface to "A Diary of the Siege of the Legations in Peking" gives this volume the nicest of send-offs. When you launch a craft there ought to be the regulation dedication, and a bottle of champagne answers all the purposes. Mr. Nigel Oliphant comes from a fighting stock, which from the time of David I. (1141) were never so entirely at home as when besieged.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Walter J. Travis succeeded this afternoon, amid conditions not the best for high-class golf, in making a record for the 5,800-yard Lakewood course of 75 strokes. If made on a mild Autumn day, with the smoothest turf for the putting greens it would be heralded as a typical championship play.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- There is an obvious tendency to "return to Nature" in the books of the last twelve months. That is to say, there has been published a very considerable number of books dealing with gardens, life in the open air, and the manners and customs of animals.

Mayor-elect Seth Low and District Attorney-elect William Travers Jerome have conferred since the election. At their conference the responsibilities of the new administration to probe thoroughly into the methods of the Tammany administration was discussed. Mr. Low and Mr. Jerome are agreed that no man found guilty of wrong-doing should escape.

Our contemporary The Evening Post was much toasted and praised and mildly criticised at the noteworthy luncheon recently given in honor of the achievements of those now or in the past responsible for the paper. Among the qualities that received most recognition was the "independence" of the gentlemen who have followed in long succession in the direction and the making of that venerable and lusty journal.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with keen interest the late articles in your paper on Sunday opening of the saloons.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- There is every probability that the motive power of the New York Central Railroad in its city and suburban service in and around New York will shortly be changed from steam to electricity, as a result of the tests that have taken place in this city during the past few weeks.

The usual tranquility of the gatherings of the Ohio Society was somewhat disturbed last night at the Hotel Manhattan at the annual meeting for the election of officers. The regular ticket put up by the Nominating Committee had been read when Col. H.H. Adams sprang a complete surprise on the majority of the members present by nominating a new set of Vice Presidents and two new Trustees.

Mary E. Wilkins has flingered so many keys since she struck the delicate, vibrating note of "A Humble Romance" and "A New England Nun," that when we take up her latest book, having attuned our car to a minor third, we hold ourselves in readiness for new chords and unexpected resolutions.

Borough President Jacob A. Cantor has tendered the appointment of Superintendent of Buildings to ex-Assemblyman Perez M. Stewart, who has accepted the place, and of Consulting Architect in the Borough of Manhattan to William Martin Aiken, who has also accepted. The two selections, it is said, will be formally announced by Mr. Cantor within the next two or three days.

The New York State Anti-Saloon League, of which the Rev. Theodore R. Cuyler is Honorary President, and Truman H. Baldwin President, has addressed an open letter to the members of the Legislature, in which it makes clear its position on the present agitation for Sunday opening of saloons.

THIS work is a continuation of the famous collection of original drawings by Rembrandt, published from 1888 to 1892 by F. Lippmann in four folios, which contain 200 drawings. This supplement is composed of 100 piates, to be published in two parts, in a limited edition of 150 copies. The first part is now read; the second part will be issued in the Autumn.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,176,812 balances, $1.914,343. Money on call rules at from 4 to 5 per cent. Time money is quoted at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, for six months, according to the character of the collateral, and for a year from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A sensational outline of the State's contention in the case wherein Alexander Sullivan, a lawyer, is charged with conspiring to keep out of the State James J. Lynch, a former bailiff, chargred with jury bribing, was given to a jury in Judge Smith's court here to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 29 -- Traffic was not interrupted in a marked degree to-day on any of the railroads, save on the Allegheny Valley. This road is still badly crippled, and as a consequence several industrial plants along the Allegheny River were compelled to temporarily suspend operations owing to their supply of coal being exhausted.

With such personifications of the things of the forest as the "Jungle Book," and such careful picture of natural life as Mr. Seton has given us, it is hard to give full credit to an animal book that does not come up to the standard already set, and it is hard to know just how valuable it would seem if it was the first book of its kind.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Annual Return of the Foreign Trade of the Empire of Japan for the Year 1900" is a document which has just reached the Treasury Bureau of Statistics. It shows that the growth in American imports into Japan during the decade has been far greater than that of any other nation's imports.

An attempt is being made by many city officials who are Commissioners of Deeds to put through the Controller's office claims amounting to more than $200,000 for acknowledgments and affidavits taken during the last few years. The claimants are officials of the Building Department as well as many other departments of the city.

ADRIAN, Mich., Nov. 29 -- Just before the Coroner's inquest on the Wabash railroad wreck adjourned to-day, Conductor Trowl of No. 13 train testified. According to his statement there were 190 passengers on board.

District Attorney Philbin said yesterday morning that he intended taking steps toward the indictment of a prominent Tammany official. He said that he thought he had about enough facts to warrant the finding of an indictment, but he was not sure that he could do so before his term of office expired.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 -- The market again was dull to-day, with the net changes about evenly balanced on both sides. The larger fluctuations, however, were chiefly on the side of gains. The trading was dull and the buying reluctant, owing to the uncertainties overhanging New York. The Street listened to bull rumors on Seaboards, based on expectations of greater activity when listed on the New York Exchange.

This is a book which tells what a commonplace girl did during a commonplace Summer. The thread of the story runs through it. Its groundwork might have been taken from the journal of any young person of fifteen. To enliven her youthful readers Miss Reed has given many pages to dialogue as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask what your valued reporter meant by stating in Friday's issue that, "owing to the fact that the divorce was obtained in Dakota, the bride [Mrs. Gebhard] could not be married in an Episcopal church"?

The scene now brought before us is a judgment scene. It is the judgment of God upon His enemies and the enemies of His people. Moses and Aaron -- the representatives of His law and of His atonement -- stand before Pharaoh -- the representative of the world and all worldliness, and they condemn him and it to a complete overthrow.
A number of Jhe best and fastest trotters and pacers were disposed of yesterday at the "Old Glory" sale of horses now being conducted by the Fasig-Tipton Company at Madison Square Garden.

The first town meeting in Ludlow, Vt., was held on March 31, 1792, and the town was organized by the election of the following officers: Jesse Fletcher, Jonas Hadley, and Elihu Ives, Selectmen; Josiah Fletcher, Town Treasurer. In the extreme southeast corner of the village cemetery, a burial lot is inclosed with an iron fence and sagging marble posts after the fashion of a bygone day.

Complete Works of Edmund FitzGerald. The forthcoming publication of "The Variorum and Deflnitive Edition of the Poetical and Prose Writings of Edward FitzGerald" in seven volumes as arranged by George Bentham with a preface by Edmund Gosse, is a literary event of no small importance.

DOUBTLESS the most happy and fortunate of men is the journalist, for to him each dawn heralds a novel day, but next in the ranks of the blest is the archaeologist in contemporary Rome, for whom each setting sun gilds some ancient relic fresh plucked from darkness and the grave.

COLON, Nov. 30. -- The town is full of troops from Barranquilla. Over 700 soldiers landed from the gunboat General Pinzon last night. These belong in the interior of Colombia, and are fine, able-bodied men and veteran troops, having taken part in many previous engagements. Among them are a few of the female relatives of the soldiers.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Sunday issue you give considerable space to English attempts at justification of their cause against the Boers; now let a German-American speak.

The Prussian Prosecution of Polcs. Although the cable dispatches have announced the result of the Polish trials in Posen, East Prussia, six students and one lawyer having been sentenced to terms of imprisonment varying from three weeks to four months, the real interest of the prosecution was the extraordinary circumstance that the State secured the convictions on grounds which pertained more to Russia than they did to Germany.

MEMBERS of the New York Historical Society are now looking forward with interest to celebrating the centennial of that organization in its fine new home, which is to occupy the entire block on Central Park West, between Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Streets. The sum of $100,000 has been raised for building purposes, and as the society has owned the land for several years, there is nothing to pay for real estate.

IN NO SETTLEMENT in the City of New York are the ancestral habits and manners of a foreign race more perfectly retained than in the little colony of William's Bridge weavers. The visitor who happens there upon a Sunday or a holiday is impressed by the prevalence of French customs.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The feature of the financial week was the big stir in copper, with its attendant mysteries, including the now-famous manifolded dispatch from New York signed "Casey," which caused much excitement until a statement was cabled on the authority of the Amalgamated managers late on Friday in answer to an inquiry that "Casey " was surely a falsifier.

What are security market prospects? Is the public to come in? Are business conditions warranting renewed buoyancy? Is there to be a Merry Christmas? Or are pools overloaded, must there be liquidation, is there occasion to apprehend disturbance and disaster? How representative conservatives in Wall Street regard the situation is to be gathered from the following views:
Beginning to-morrow, night the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx will be patrolled by Detective Sergeants, especially assigned for the work by Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau.

A gratifying feature of the current situation is the equanimity with which financial circles regard the convening of Congress. It is within the memory of even the younger Wall Street element that Congressional sessions were uniformly looked forward to with alarm, and their approach was a powerful weapon in the hands of the speculative bear party.

Numerous transactions of the first magnitude, involving properties in many widely separated sections combined to make last week's dealings of unusual interest. Seldom, indeed, even in the busiest seasons, has a more interesting group of sales and projected improvements come to light than during the last few days.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 30. -- An enormous reptile, more like the extinct brontosaurus or fabled sea serpent than any living creature, has just been killed by a hunter in this lower Everglades. He means to send the skeleton to the Smithsonian institution at Washington.

Breathing hard, but running steadily, D. W. Franchot of Yale was the first man to run through the narrow lane formed by spectators at the finish line of the third annual cross country run of the Intercollegiate Association held yesterday at Morris Park. Tale was also the first to finish a quartette of runners, and she therefore secured first place in the team contest.

FH. HITCHCOCK of Washington, one of the sub-chiefs of the Department of Agriculture, lately returned from a seventeen-thousand-mile trip down the Atlantic Coast, into Mexico, up the Pacific Coast, and finally home across the northern part of the United States.

SOMETHING more than Mrs. Burton Harrison's play is on trial at the Manhattan Theatre -- something broader, more far-reaching, and of deeper significance than the fate of any one production designed for public entertainment. And that something is the attitude of women toward life in general, as exemplified by their reception of plays in particular.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a long and labored letter recently published by you in THE TIMES, your correspondent, much after the fashion of the Hon. J. Porter, seeks to prove municipal ownership of public service corporations too expensive to be undertaken by the public.

A Little Too Previous. SO MANY blockades had occurred that it had taken over an hour to go from Warren Street to Twenty-eighth. By that time patience had ceased to be a virtue and the irate passengers glared at each other as if the only thing that could afford relief to mind and body was to mob the first person who gave the slightest provocation for a general uprising.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 30. -- The Government is taking steps toward reclaiming a hundred miles of sand dunes along the Columbia River between The Dalles and Umatilla. The sand has been shifting for years, gradually changing its location from the plains above the mouth of the Umatilla River to the banks of the Columbia.

The task of the appraisers of the Custom House in drawing nice distinctions between the work of the artist and that of the artisan, and deciding for purposes of valuation what is art and what is not, often leads to results reminding one of the dictum of the English railway guard in enforcing the company's rules: " Cats is dogs and must go to the luggage van; turtles is insects and may stay."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to say how fully I indorse the views expressed in your editorial of the 12th inst, entitled, "The W.C.T.U. on Sunday Opening." While not presuming to believe that I can in any way strengthern the expression of these views. yet I will venture to send a few thoughts suggested by its perusal.

THE song recital and the piano recital are abroad in the land. It was Liszt who adopted the term "recital" for the solo performance of a number of piano pieces, and his first announcement caused some curious critic to ask how one could recite on the piano. Now we find that in the Standard Dictionary the second definition of "recital" is: "The recitation or repetition, especially in public, of something previously memorized or prepared."
BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- At the Boston Athletic Club to-night there were many interesting boxing contests in the semi-final, final, special local, and intercity bouts between Boston and New York boxers.

The last day of the first week of the "Old Glory" sale of horses, conducted by the Fasig-Tipton Company at Madison Square Garden, might properly be called a bargain day, for the catalogue called for the disposal of a large number of horses which, while well brede, had not distinguished themselves particularly as race horses.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 30. -- It is a hard struggle for existence that the infant heiress, who was born a week or two ago, to Mrs. Irving E. Raymond of Strawberry Hill Avenue, is having. If she lives she will inherit some of the Raymond and Baker millions. She has known no existence outside of the incubator thus far in her little life.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 30. -- The home of Thomas Crawley, on New Street, was destroyed by fire this morning, and his daughter. Miss Sally Crawley, was rescued with difficulty by her brother Joseph.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your reply, in the editorial of the 19th inst., to the question of the clergymen who ask why the public sale of intoxicating drink should be allowed on Sunday when the law prohibits a general traffic in food on that day suggests, as it appears to me, the first sound basis for the agitation for relaxation of the present excise law.

The taking of testimony at the Meade court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard was concluded yesterday afternoon. Col. Meade, the accused officer, was the last witness placed on the stand. When the court adjourned he was congratulated by his friends upon what they declared appeared to be a victory for him to the trial.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- The Seventh District Police Station House, at Third Street and Fairmount Avenue, has been placed under quarantine by the Board of Health, and as a result more than forty policeman, including a House Sergeant and turnkey, are prisoners in the building.

For the first time in the history of the city an administration will assume control on the first of January required by law and determined on principle to make appointments and employment in the great body of the city service on the merit and fitness of those selected and not for partisan considerations.
ANEW YORK woman, who had returned from a visit to some friends in the West, was telling some funny experiences the other day.

MRS. BURTON HARRISON, whose play. "The Unwelcome Mrs. Hatch," is now being played by Minnie Madern Fiske and her company, is not a successful authoress and playwright only, but a notable housewife, again disproving the old-fashioned theory that to write-or, to use the now almost obsolete term, to be a bluestocking -- was the corollary of a lack of all housewifely qualities, and even of proper pride in one's own appearance.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The pressure of money was lessened to-day, and there were indications of an increase in the supply, partly attributed to Government reimbursements. Discounts were easy.

Traders and professional market operators generally took advantage yesterday of the further break in Amalgamated Copper and a rather disappointing bank statement to hammer the general list, selecting such representative stocks as St. Paul, Pennsylvania, and Union Pacific as special targets.

Robert Rowan, thirty-eight years old, of 1,510 Park Avenue,7 was caged last night in a money wagon of the Adams Express Company, where he could see the approach of an electric car, knew that a collision was inevitable, yet could not escape being locked in. He is a messenger in the employ of the company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- New York was heard from emphatically in the Democratic House caucus to-day. The Empire State delegation served notice that it wanted the minority party in the House to adopt sound and sensible policy. It marked out what it conceived to be a course of use fulness to the country, and asked a declaration from the caucus that that course would be followed.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The great theatrical topic this week was the first "royal command " performance since King Edward's accession, at Sandringham, in which Seymour Hicks and Ellaline Terriss were honored and Dan Leno stepped into the chronicles of history as the first music hall performer ever distinguished by so great a mark of the royal favor.
ON an up-town thoroughfare is a certain window which seems able at all hours to hold about it a group of interested pedestrians. Behind the glass sit two darkeyed maidens dressed in Turkish costumes.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House this morning at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $25,104,980; balances, $2,883,522. The stock market was moderately active all day, with a tendency to weakness. The feeling at the close regarding all the Coppers was somewhat improved and a good-sized rally was predicted for early in the week.

PITTSBURGH, Penn., Nov. 30. -- Railroad officials of all the roads affected by the strike except the Allegheny Valley report to-night that the strike is over. The Valley officials say the worst is over and by Monday or Tuesday their road will be in normal condition.

The greatest number of men ever employed at the Boston and Montana Copper Works in this city was 1,680. Within less than a year there will be employed in the plant at least 2,000 men. The increase will be commenced before the first of the year. -- Great Falls Tribune.

THE sun enters the sign Capricornus on the 22d, and astronomical Winter begins on the same date. The point in the sun's path reached at that time is known as the solstice, which word means a standing still. At this point in his course the sun moves very slowly, so that when his face is first turned toward us we find his motion about as slow as at any time during the year.

There were no important developments in the money market during the past week, and, much to the chagrin of those pessimists in the Street who have been hoping against hope that their predictions of tight money might come true, rates showed no disposition to harden, but rather tended to greater ease.

It will be agreed that Mr. CANTOR has made two excellent appointments in those announced, of Mr. STEWART to be Superintendent of the Department of Buildings and of Mr. AIKEN to be Chief Inspector and " Consulting Architect" of the department. For the secondary title there is no warrant that we can find in the revised charter, though we quite agree that there ought to be.

SHE had been spending her Summers in Cape Cod, and was expatiating upon the peculiarities of that neighborhood. "I can't imagine," said she, "anything more incongruous than a murder trial on Cape Cod. Barnstable County, which is all the cape, is the most law-abiding community on earth. It's the only place I know where the Summer visitor has no need to tear tramps.
NEARLY everybody has heard of and wondered at the mango-growing trick of the Hindu, by which he makes a seed sprout before the astonished eyes of the European and reach maturity in a very short time.

From The International Munthly. Several of the loaders of the first crusade had decided before leaving their homos to remain in the land which they expected to conquer Rohemond, son of Robert Guiscard, had failed to secure his father's principality, in Southern Italy, and used the crusade as an opportunity to obtain a new dominien for himself.

Three arrests made by Capt. Titus are believed to have broken up a set of men who operated in at least four places as dealers in stocks and bonds, and then, by setting up as a collection agency, obtained possession of most of the legal evidense of their operations. This evidence, naturally enough, was destroyed.

Sons of Scotland who claim America as their adopted country gathered to the number of 500 in Delmonico's banquet hall last night, to celebrate the one hundred and forty-fifth annual dinner of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York.

From The Saturday Review. Posting was expensive and exciting if you traveled without a courier and were not at home in the Italian patois and coinage. Starting from Rome, you hired a light phaeton which went through to your destination; you paid in advance at the Portifical bureau, and the officials so far smoothed the way that the coppers for positions at each successive stage were made up in separate parcels.
The second concert of the Philharmonic Society will take place on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hail, preceded by the customary rehearsal on Friday afternoon. The programme is as follows:

HUNTINGTON, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Lawrence Gildersleeve, a member of the Huntington football team, is critically ill as a result of injuries received in a game of football played on Thanksgiving Day at Mineola between the local eleven and a team of the Mineola Athletic Club. Gildersleeve was somewhat hurt in the first half of the game, but insisted on continuing playing.
Discussing the report that a pool had been formed in Wall Street to "protect" Amalgamated Copper stock, the head of a leading Stock Exchange house says:

ONE cold January evening in 1807 I was on a railroad train, returning to Boston from Springfield, Mass., where I had been attending a convention of Associated Charity Workers. Soon after we passed the town of Palmer my attention was drawn to the sounds of loud, angry voices near one of the doors.

MANY a worthy citizen finds himself half awake at that hour in the morning when it is impossible to make any approximate guess at the time, judging from the quality of sunlight that creeps through his drawn curtains. What shall he do? Turn over and doze again, thus to run the risk of oversleeping, or get up, look at the clock, and so destroy all further prospect of repose?

The sale of the "House of Lords," the saloon at Crosby and Houston Streets, and within a stone's throw of Police Headquarters, was the subject of a spirited argument before Surrogate Thomas in the Surrogate's Court yesterday on an application by Mrs. Rose Cogan, a sister of the late Lawrence B. Lynch, for the removal of John Henry Murphy, a lawyer, of 52 Broadway, and her nephew, as executors of Mr. Lynch's estate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- President Roosevelt left on a special train of three cars over the Pennsylvania Railroad at 10:00 o'clock. With the President were Mrs. Roosevelt and two children. Commander and Mrs. Cowles, Secretary and Mrs. Cortelyou, Assistant Secretary Loeb. Mrs. Douglas Robinson and daughter. Dr. and Mrs. Rixey, Col. Bingham, and Mrs. Richardson.

From The Contemporary Review. Every Spring from the mountain villages of Roumania a throng of dancers invades the towns and cities. Their dancing is noisy, as they wear bells on their belts, sleeves, and trousers, and shout and stamp their feet on the ground as they dance: but they are unable to explain the meaning of the words they say.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- A new point of interest in the Philadelphia market was a spirited advance of 4 points in Electric Storage Battery, the stock rising 3 1/2 points without an intervening transaction. There was a rumor of a deal with the General Electric. The bulk of the business on the local Exchange was in the Readings.

The three fires on Thanksgiving Day, the large ones in East Tenth Street and in Williamsburg, and the considerable blaze in the Harrison Street hay storage place, together with the Prince Street fire of yesterday morning, have completely upset the expectations of local fire underwriters that the record of fire losses for November, unlike October, would prove to be well within conservative bounds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question of Sunday closing of saloons is one of the greatest importance on account of the far-reaching consequences attending whatever action is taken by the coming city administration.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in a recent issue relative to " Commercial Virus and Antitoxin" comes in a very opportune time.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Ex-Bailiff James J. Lynch, the confessed Jury briber, on whose testimony Alexander Sullivan, an attorney, was indicted for conspiracy, took the stand in Judge Smith's court here to-day, and immediately launched into a story of juries which he said he had bribed in behalf of Sullivan.

New York has seen few more enthusiastic gaherings than that which, occurred at Seminole Hall, 414 Grand Street, last night, under the auspices of the Manhattan Democracy to commemorate the great Fusion victory.

Price movements in the outside market yesterday were again decidedly irregular. The copper stocks suffered further losses in sympathy with the decline in Amalgamated on the Stock Exchange, and the weakness in these issues was shared by some other parts of the list. Elsewhere, however, substantial advances were made, and in some cases the net gains were noteworthy.

In response to a communication from the Rev. Alexander P. Doyle of the Paulist Fathers, editor of The Catholic World Magazine, Mgr. Adolph Favler, Bishop of the Vicariate Apostolic of Peking, China, has made emphatic denial of charges of looting which appeared in the public press at the time of the Boxers' outbreak.
Capt. J. B. Prescott is about to retire from the Boston Fire Department after forty-seven years' serivce in It. He will receive a pension.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 30. -- Frank W. Conard, proprietor of a hotel at Perth Amboy, ate his Thanksgiving dinner on Thursday with a sneak thief, whom he captured in his house one night last August. The effrontery of the man, who had just completed his sentence for the offense, overawed Mr. Conard and won for the man a well-cooked turkey feast.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- A quarrel over a borrowed book was followed by a murder here late last night, when George Johnson shot and killed Robert Newitt, a lifelong friend. Mrs. Johnson is authority for the statement that the shooting came on the heels of the quarrel over the book, which was owned by Johnson.
THERE is an all-consuming desire on the part of many persons who read from day to day about those who are conspicuous in the world to know just what they say and how they say it.

Few people in the East have any idea of the magnitude of the independent telephone movement in this country. The history of the independent companies since 1895, when the more important patents of the Bell Company expired, has been most interesting, showing as it does the great advance made in both the number of instruments used, as well as in the cheapening of rates to the subscriber.

From Pearson's Magazine. The discovery of the nests and eggs of the magnificent rifle bird of Paradise in New South Wales was the chief event in the world of Australian naturalists a few years ago. The bird inhabits the dense scrubs and has been known to science some seventy years.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. David Post, believed here to be the oldest married couple in the United States, will celebrated Monday the seventy-first anniversary of their wedding day in their home, near Pine Island, Orange County. On Dec. 2, 1830, David Post, then a youth of twenty, and Mary Ann Wood at the age of sixteen, were united in matrimony and set out upon their Journey through the world together.

HENRY PITZ ALAN HOWARD, Duke of Norfolk, Earl Marshal of England, and many other things too numerous to mention is not a man much given to laughter; on the contrary, he is somewhat of the saturnine type of Englishman, doing things from a sense of duty, and inclined to take life gravely.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 30. -- F. X. Beaudet of this place has brought from the Klondike evidence that prehistoric man used solid-silver nails in his shoes. He exhibits nine shoenails exactly similar to the modern product, except that they are made of pure silver. These were taken out of a claim on Hunker Creek, where they were found on the bedrock at a depth of 110 feet under the surface.

From The Westminster Review. At the Council of Clermout, Urban the Second proclaimed a plenary indulgence to those who should enlist under the banner of the cross, the absolution of all their sins, and a full receipt for all that might be due of canonical penance. In the age of earnest faith the effect of this decree was far reaching and electrical.
The course of the stock market during December has ever been of more interest than perhaps that of any other month of the year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: About four years ago when the Woodward Lawn Cemetery, near Detroit, Mich., was laid out, the Superintendent, Mr. Eurich was almost in despair about not finding Water. Repeated borings at several places gave no results, and he was obliged to buy his water for household purposes.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30. -- About a year ago robbers entered the house of an elderly woman named Vasquez and her widowed daughter, Senora Campello. They were said to have stolen $50,000. The police arrested five men, who were tried and sentenced to prison for long terms.

Michael Stoska is the name of a man from Shamokin, Penn., who tried to catch the steamship Ryndam, the Holland-America's fastest ocean liner, by swimming after her in the waters of the Hudson yesterday morning. Stoska intended sailing on the Ryndam, and was on the ferryboat Hamburg on his way to the pier when he spied the liner on her way to sea.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Just as the cocks began to crow in the pale yellow moonlight, John Walter Rone and Elinor Pauline Quackenbush, each aged twenty-one years, Were married at 2 o'clock this morning by the Rev. William Ackroid in the Methodist parsonage. John came some years ago from Lomza, Russia, and located at Warwick.

BACHELOR girls in New York are always interesting in the way they live, one reason being that they cannot avail themselves in this great city of such perfect accommodations as it affords the male bachelor. The bachelor girl apartment house has yet to come.
The team of Dodge Olcott increased their lead in the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association tournament by winning two games yesterday evening. The scores follow:

From The Nineteenth Century. Three great economic developments have taken place in Argentina during the last few years which are largely responsible for the increase of its wealth. The first is the enormous increase in the cultivation and export of wheat. It is difficult to believe that twenty years ago the country did not produce enough of this cereal for its own consumption, and that it actually imported in 1890 177,000 tons.

From The Cornhill. Let me just jot down, with no pretense of scientific accuracy, a few of the leading genera and larger species, a few of the most noticeable instances which met even the cursory gaze. First there were dignitaries, and dignitaries of many types. There were dignitaries with gaiters and dignitaries with trousers, dignitaries with pectoral crosses, and dignitaries with gold pince-nez, dignitaries with corded hats, and dignitaries with hats amorphous but not corded.

The reported discovery in England that the modest violet is a cure for cancer, whether or not it shall be 'established by experience to be an addition to the still extremely small list of specifics recognized in materia medica, is of enough interest to have started an exciting discussion.

IN the United States Navy pets are allowed on board ship at the discretion of the commanding officer, and he is in most cases liberal in his permission to the sailors, so long as they take care that the cleanliness of the decks is not impaired. Moreover, he usually has at least one pet of his own.

From The Syracuse Post-Standard. This is the season of the year when the Boards of Supervisors are in session throughout the State, and that always means a considerable degree of attention to the very important question of good roads. This has grown to be one of the most important matters with which Supervisors have to deal.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 30. -- The Homestead football eleven won a second victory from Philadelphia to-day by a score of 6 to 5. In the first half Homestead fumbled repeatedly, and this enabled Philadelphia to retain possession of the ball a goodly part of the time. Roller finally carrying the ball over for a touch-down. The goal was missed.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 30. -- Reports here that W. P. Clough has resigned as First Vice President of the Great Northern Railway, and that J. N. Hill will succeed him are confirmed here.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest your editorial in THE TIMES on friars in the Philippines and your plan for the distribution of small farms to the Filipinos.

THE "Exposition" business promises to become a "continuous performance" in these United States. The Pan-American is almost immediately succeeded by the South Carolina Inter-State and West Indian Exposition, which is to-be "inaugurated " at Charleston, with ceremonies including an oration by Senator Depew.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- To-day closed the most disastrous meeting experienced by favorites at Bennings for a long time. Ideal weather conditions and the feature of the card, the Second Maximum, a race on the flat of three miles, drew one of the largest crowds of the meet. Carbuncle, who was easily the best of the field, took this event.

Edwin A. Abbey, R. A., the American artist who has been commissioned by King Edward to paint the coronation ceremony, was an arrival on the American liner Philadelphia yesterday. Mr. Abbey comes to America at this time in order to supervise the hanging of the nine remaining panels of the "Quest of the Holy Grail," which will complete the mural decorations in the delivery room of the Boston Public Library.

The members of the Kings County Republican Executive Committee, met yessterday afternpon and made selections for the Chairmanshipps of the General and Executive Committees. The officers are to be formally elected next Tuesday night.

Clyde Fitch on Wednesday night will offer a new play, "The Girl and the Judge," at the Lyceum Theatre, interpreted by Annie Russell and her company, which gave their last performance of "A Royal Family" last night. The theatre will be closed to-morrow and Tuesday night. Richard Mansfield returns to town at the Herald Square Theatre in "Beaucaire."
One of the first matters to which Jacob A. Cartor, President-elect of the Borough of Manhattan, will give his attention when he takes office will be to provide proper street signs for the city.

From The Ninteenth Century. I am not in the secrets of the Russian Government, but a little reasoning will partly permit us to discover the limits of its designs with regard to the Middle Kingdom. Of Chinese territory proper Russia may be safely said to have obtained as much as she cares for, now that she has annexed Manchuria.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- A combination of a number of the most important school apparatus dealers of the country has been effected, it is said, by the American syndicate corporation, James H. Teller of this city, a brother of United States Senator Teller, and a writer against trusts, is mentioned as the leader of the movement.

From The Spectator. The policy which dictates the " Milan decrees " never succeeds, and Napoleon when he tried it was not hampered by the question of food, and had almost absolute power in his own hand. Four or fivo Courts, and four or five Parliaments, not to mention four or five peoples, will not hold together long enough to work America serious mischief.

GOSHEN, N. Y., Nov. 30. -- Just as the cocks began to crow in the pale yellow moonlight. John Walter Rone and Elinor Pauline Quarkenbush, each aged twenty-one years, were married at 2 o'clock this morning by the Rev. William Ackroid in the Methodist parsonage. John came some years ago from Lomza, Russia, and located at Warwick.
LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The Foreign Office confirms a report that the Russo-Chinese Manchurian negotiations are broken off.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- It was chaimpion's day at the International Dog Show to-day, the competition being chiefly for special prizes, between the week's winners.

MENLO PARK, N. J., Nov. 30. -- After being practically abandoned for a number of years, the Menlo Park copper mines are to be worked to their utmost capacity. The New Jersey Copper Mining Company, the owner of the mines and 300 acres of land surrounding them, held a meeting here to-day.

President Jacob L. Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday made known a scheme which he has in mind for connecting the present East River Bridge and the one now building with a loop in Manhattan; on which to operate the cars of his company.

Prosecutor James S. Erwin of Jersey City yesterday announced that he had been informed by the Grand Jury that they had decided not to Indict Eugene Sullivan, who was charged by the police with maintaining a poolroom. Justice Collins refused to talk of the matter or say what course he would take, but he had summarily discharged the previous Grand Jury in the middle of the term for refusing to indict Sullivan.

"IT WOULD not be possible. I believe." said Miss Maud Hoffman, speaking of the English stage the other day, "for a girl to go over on the other side and make her way professionally without letters of introduction and enough money to last for a considerable time while she is waiting for an engagement."

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The latest outburst of German Anglophobia seems to nt its fury, or else some powerful influence has compelled the German pass to cease attacking England. For a moment there is no uppermost political epic and although Count von Bu- may yet make that threatened antiEnglish speech in the Reichstag, the seems remote.

In England, whore many of the underlying securities are held for investment, the Northern Securities Company proposition does not meet with unanimous approval. Some of the foremost financial journals of London give indorsement, while some are non-committal, and still others are outspoken in opposition.
Barting in and out among the fashionable equipages on Fifth Avenue yesterday a large cow that had escaped from its keeper caused some excitement on that thoroughfare.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the column of the "Topics of the Times" in your issue of the 26th inst. is an article commencing with: "Much light on the way in which myths are perpetuated and in which beliefs get along, even among intelligent and educated people, without a single fact for basis, was cast by a letter which we published on Sunday."

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- The wedding of Lord Tweedmouth's son, the Hon. Dudley Churchill Marjoribanks, to Muriel, daughter of the War Secretary, Mr. Brodrick, at St. George's Church, Hanover Square, took place this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Republican members of the House held their caucus in the Hall of Representatives this afternoon, and it lasted about three hours. Speaker Henderson and the old officers of the House were made the unanimous choice of the caucus, and the major portion of the time was devoted to an effort, led by Representative Hepburn of lowa, to effect some changes in the rules of the last House.

ANOTHER sign has come to the surface to indicate that a great impending change in men's fashions may be close at hand, that the tyranny so long exercised by hatters and tailors is being assailed, and that the wearers of clothes may rise in their might and exclaim "We defy them!" The hat war rages in London.

"It seems to me," said an officer of a National bank yesterday, "that the best reason for confidence in the future of the stock market appears on the very surface in the form of the new high records recently made by such stocks as New York Central in the Vanderbilt group, Southern Railway preferred in the Morgan stocks, and Norfolk and Western in the Pennsylvania list.

THE great arch fills the vista and scorns to invite approach. Twilight is lingering in the ripen spaces of the square: there is still a faint, rosy reflection where a broken roof-line permits a glimpse of a more distant horizon; and, seen through the arch, where its great curve cuts into the depths of blue, a slender, pale new moon slowly climbs the sky.

MENLO PARK, N. J., Nov. 30. -- After being practically abandoned for a number of years, the Menlo Park copper mines are to be worked to their utmost capacity. The New Jersey Copper Mining Company, the owner of the mines, and 300 acres of land surrounding them, held a meeting here to-day.

Dense, smoke made hard and dangerous work for firemen early yesterday morning at the six-story building, 117 and 119 Prince Street between Greene and Wooster Streets, which is occupied by a number of garment and dry goods firms. Before they finally triimphed the three upper stories were entirely burned out and the lower part of the building was flooded, the total loss, according to Chief Croker, amounting to about $40,000.

A suit for damages has been, brought in the Supreme Court against the Caramel and Chocolate Cream. Trust, otherwise known as the New York Confectionery Jobbers' Protective Association, by Morris Kivowits, a retail dealer in candles, of 269 Second Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the "Topics of the Times" should try and ridicule statements which are based on facts, and with one stroke of a pen make millions of Americans insane is, indeed, very amusing.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The project of founding a new Roman Catholic seminary, a main feature of whose scope will be the education under American auspices of clergy for the Philippine Islands, was one of the matters taken up by the Catholic Archbishops of the country at their recent meeting in Baltimore. It received their hearty approval.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The impulse to say a word in reference to "Women Ph. D's." can no longer be resisted. The point really is, shall women be educated? for the number of women Ph. D's. is too small to be considered at all. Your correspondent, " Mother of Four," discusses admirably certain aspects of the case, but there are others that she did not mention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The President to-day appointed Thomas B. Fergruson Governor of Oklahoma in the place of William M. Jenklns, removed. In taking this action the President attached to the papers the following memorandum:

SILAS LARRABEE of Ogunquit had a most exciting ten minutes this evening in the dining room of one of the Nantueket hotels. We came to Nantucket in order to have repairs made to the rudder of the "Sewsan" E. Nash, which early this morning ran afoul of some half-sunken thing.

VINELAND, N. J., Nov. 30. -- Herbert V. Halters, who was arrested at Salem last night for forcing his attentions on Miss Alice Stonickson, a society belle, to whom Halters sent many love letters, was arraigned here to-day. He was held for further examination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing the several letters in THE NEW YORK TIMES in reference to the use of the "divining rod " in searching for water, I give you my experience in reference to same.

The marine engineers of this city, who are organized as Local No. 33 of the Marine Engineers' Benevolent Association, were greatly exercised yesterday over a circular issued by George Uhler, President of the association, which takes in the marine engineers of the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts and of the great lakes.

COLON, Dec. 1 -- Yesterday and to-day passed uneventfully at Colon and Panama. Both Liberals and Conservatives are gradually resuming their customary intercourse and fraternizing the one with the other. There is no undue boasting on the part of the victors nor ill-concealed hatred on the part of those who sympathize with the vanquished.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The Rev. George C. Betts, rector of St. James's Episcopal Church, died suddenly last night. He fell ill with heart disease a year ago, but the attack had passed away and he was apparently in excellent health late yesterday. He remained until 10:45 o'clock in his study and then went into the bathroom to shave himself, so that he would be ready for an early service.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Dec. 1 -- "Send warships instead of money, and the United States will secure the speedy release of my sister," said Perlay A. Stone of this city, brother of Miss Ellen M. Stone, the missionary, to-day. He added:

MANILA, Dec. 1 -- The financial situation in the Philippine Islands is causing considerable alarm. In an interview published in Manila, Henry C. Ide, Chief of the Department of Finance and Justice, referred to the probable enforcement of an alteration, in the immediate future, of the present Government parity of two Mexican dollars for one gold dollar.

A great crowd of spectators gathered on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning in the hope of seeing some of the crack trotters and pacers purchased at last week's sale by prominent New York horsemen step with the favorites of the road. They were not disappointed, for several animals whose qualities had been heralded far and wide put in an appearance on the upper stretch bright and early.

The purpose for which Speaker Nixon and other leaders of the Legislature have visited New York during the past ten days was made known last night by New York City members of the Legislature with whom they conferred.

A terrific explosion that was heard for blocks startled the guests of the Hotel Belvedere, at Eighteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday morning, shaking the hotel and throwing them into a panic. It seemed as if the building was about to fall. Every glass in every window up to the fourth story was broken by the force of the explosion.

Arthur W. Soper, President of the Pintsch Compressing Company, the Safety Car Heating and Lighting Company, and a prominent figure in many corporations, clubs, and other organizations, died after a month's illness early yesterday morning at his home, 150 Central Park South. Mr. Soper had suffered from a complication of stomach troubles, which took an acute turn last Wednesday.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 1 -- Reports from the managers and operators of the different railroads affected by the switchmen's strike are to the effect that they have the situation well in hand and that the new men who have taken strikers' places are now working to good advantage. Sunday being a day when little new freight is received, considerable work was accomplished in the way of clearing the yards of their accumulated stores.

ALTOONA, Penn., Dec. 1 -- Shortly after 2 o'clock this morning Mrs. Mary C. Burk and her four children were burned to death at Gwin Station, on the Wopsononock Railroad, three miles north of this city. Carl W. Burk, the husband, escaped with severe injuries. The ages of the children, two of whom were girls, were between eight and sixteen years.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- During the past week the Stock Exchange has been anything but a cheerful resort. Money has been decidedly tight, forcing borrowers to have recourse to the bank. Fortunately the Government disbursements have been larger for this week. France also shows a disposition to increase her balances in London, while the hope is expressed that further gold will be forthcoming from New York.
The Rev. Dr. Samuel Schulman, rabbi of the Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, preached a sermon on Sunday observance yesterday morning. He said:

Col. John N. Partridge, the new Commissioner of Police, left last night for Albany. He will remain at the State capital until Wednesday clearing up accumulated business in the Department of Public Works and preparing for his leave-taking as the head of that department.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- A.H. Mueller, the man arrested Saturday evening at Broad and Chestnut Streets, charged with having declared that "President Roosevelt should be served the same as McKinley," was held in $800 bail to-day for disturbing the peace.

Bears on the stock market may be tempted to make a demonstration against market values and endeavor to depress prices because of the fact that gold exports are to be resumed this week -- this, of course, suggesting to the pessimist that the local money market may be affected as a result of these new shipments.

The occupants of the three-story double frame tenement house at 250 Wallabout Street, Willlamsburg, were thrown into a panic at an early hour yesterday morning by an incendiary fire which had been started in the lower hallway. The building is owned by George Dorring, who occupies the second floor with his family.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- Increased confidence and further gains were noticeable on the Boerse/during the last week. It was the best week in many months, all departments scoring advances. Foreign rentes, especially Spanish and Chinese, led the interest. The latter were exceedingly strong yesterday, with heavy transactions.

Discussing the financial affairs of the city yesterday, Controller-elect Edward M. Grout said that, for reasons which he set forth, he did not favor a proposition which has been made to take out of the city debt what the city has spent or is spending for certain improvements. To thus greatly expand the city's borrowing capacity, Mr. Grout said, would offer great opportunity for municipal extravagance.

Spain is one of the most picturesque countries at Europe, yet the least visited, although neither writers nor artists have stinted their praise since the days of Washington Irving. When Theophile Gautier and Gustave Dore made their celebrated trip to Spain in search of the picturesque half a century ago there happened to them an incident which did not find its way into their reports.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 1 -- The Right Rev. Thomas J. Conaty, titular Bishop of Samos and President of the Catholic University, officiated to-day for the first time at solemn pontifical services in his old church, that of the Sacred Heart, where he labored for seventeen years as a priest before his appointment as President of the university.

Messrs. Henry R. Towne, W.A. Marble, and Charles R. Lamb, the committee appointed by the Merchants' Association of New York to attend the convention of the National Association of Manufacturers, held at Washington from the 19th to the 21st of November last, have made their report as to what was done at the convention to the Merchants' Association.

A beautiful dark brown velvet turban, absolutely simple, the velvet draped upon the frame, with crown and rim in one, has painted around the front of the hat an ostrich feather in dark bronze green gold. This is in the heavy free-hand painting which is seen upon the painted buttons used on coats and hats.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- In the October Summary of Domestic Trade Movements, just issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, are statements of withdrawals of staple commodities from the internal commerce of the country. The domestic movements for the first ten months of this year are compared with those of the corresponding period a year ago.

Jeremiah Brennan, Assistant Superintendent of the Yellow Pine Lumber Company at the foot of East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, is a prisoner in the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station, charged with having shot John Williams in the right leg. Brennan was arrested yesterday afternoon by Policeman Hart.

Acting Captain Churchill continued his labors of trying to suppress vice of all kinds in the Fifteenth Precinet early yesterday morning by raiding an alleged gambling house at 141 Second Avenue. Capt. Churchill led the raid in person, and he and his detectives gathered in twenty-three men, only one of whom was held by the Captain.

The United States transport Buford arrived yesterday from Manila, bringing eight companies of the Twenty-third Infantry, consisting of 901 enlisted men, non-commissioned staff and band, and 37 officers, under the command of Col. J. Milton Thompson. There were in addition 115 discharged soldiers of various regiments, Government employes, wives and children of officers of the Twenty-third, and a few civilians not attached to the Government service.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 7 -- The biggest battle of the present Parliamentary session in New Zealand was that which waged round the question of renewing the San Francisco mall contracts with the J.D. Spreckels Company. The account of that debate will not be pleasant reading for the Messrs. Spreckels, for it is not too much to say the advocates of the service succeeded in maintaining it just "by the skin of their teeth."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 1 -- Although the managers of the San Rafael Ferry Line declare that not more than three lives were lost in the collision last night with the ferryboat Sausalito, it is plain from the accounts of several cool-headed men who were on board that from ten to twenty persons perished in the thick fog.

The opening match for the world's championship at eighteen-inch balk-line billiards, no shot in, will be played to-night at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, between Louis Barutel, the French expert, and George Sutton. Both men have practiced assiduously for the tournament, the Frenchman devoting most of his time to match play at Maurice Daly's Academy and Sutton doing the bulk of his work in Chicago.

The pro-British sentiments of Major Gen. John R. Brooke. commanding the Department of the East, as expressed by him at the birthday dinner given in honor of King Edward, brought down upon him last night the denunciation of an Irish orator and the hisses of a large audience of Irishmen.

St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, yesterday celebrated its seventy-first anniversary by raising over $40,000, thereby canceling the mortgage, paying all debts, and providing a fund with which to meet current expenses.

Gov. Odell's appointment of Charles Spencer Boyd as State Superintendent of Public Works to succeed Col. John N. Partridge, who has just been named by Mayor-elect Low as his Police Commissioner, gave the Republican leaders the greatest surprise they have had in some time. No question is made of his qualifications for the important place to which he has been named, but he is unknown to the politicians.

An appeal arising from a novel case in the Municipal Court is down for hearing and argument to-day in the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court. The appeal was taken through the law firm of Peckham, Warner Strong by the King-McLeod Company of Newport, R.I., from a judgment rendered by Judge Martin in Municipal Court in October in favor of Henry T. Sloane, the defendant in a suit brought by the Newport firm.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 1 -- It is announced that an appeal to the United States Supreme Court will be taken in the case of Solomon Hotema, the Choctaw Indian who has just been tried and convicted in the Federal court of the Northern District of Texas of the crime of killing two alleged witches and a man near his home at Cold Springs, Indian Territory.

TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- Trenton is making extensive plans to celebrate the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the Battle of Trenton on Dec. 26. The State of New Jersey is to assist the local committee so that the affair has a State significance. Gov. Voorhees has issued a proclamation commending it to the interest of the people of the State.

"The greatest evil that theatregoers in this city have to contend with is the ticket speculator," said Magistrate Crane in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning. "Their conduct is outrageous and they should be suppressed. They are practically highwaymen and hold up everybody that goes to a place of amusement."

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- "Buller Sunday" passed without serious incident. The Government had taken every precaution to prevent disturbances. This included the reading at three parades last week of a special order in the military regulations, which prohibits officers or soldiers from "taking part in any meetings, demonstrations, or processions for party of political purposes."

"Why We Need a Minister of Commerce" is the title of an article by A. Barton Hepburn, ex-Controller of the Currency, in the current issue of Leslie's Weekly. Mr. Hepburn refers to the recent advocacy of the creation of such a portfolio by the New York Chamber of Commerce and to the power of Congress to regulate commerce derived from the framers of the Constitution.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 1 -- The Woodward Shanklin midwinter sale of thoroughbred horses begins here to-morrow. Among the consigners are W.C. Whitney, James R. and F.P. Keene, Mrs. Byron McClelland, W.F. Schulte, J.V. Ship, Frank B. Harper, L. Tarlton. United States Senator J.C.S. Blackburn, and Col. Barnes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Fifty-Seventh Congress came into existence to-day. There was nothing to be done in the Senate to prepare it for work, but the House had a good deal to do in the way of organization, and it was late this afternoon before it could be said that the Congress was ready for business.
The new City Central Committee of theCltlzens' Union met last night, C.C. Nadal presiding.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2. -- The annual meeting of the Cook County Democratic Central Committee to-day resulted in a split and two committees were organized. One organized under the auspices of Chairman Thomas Gahan in the Sherman House. The other organized under the direction of Robert E. Burke at Democratic Headquarters, 145 Randolph Street.

Deputy Police Commissioner Devery was arraigned yesterday before Justice Holbrook to answer to charges of oppression and neglect. The charges are the result of the Deputy Commissioner's action in the case of Policeman O'Neill.
