The attorneys Interested In claims growing out of the collision off the Battery last June of the ferryboats Northfleld of the Staten Island line and the Mauch Chunk of the Central Railroad of New Jersey which resulted In the sinking of the North field, the loss of three lives, and injury to a number of passengers, have found an obstacle in the United States statutes which makes recovery for the loss practically impossible.

The mills of Edward E. Rose, dramatizer, are not like those of the famous proverb, for they grind rapidly and not exceeding fine. The latest sample of their grinding powers was submitted to the taste of the public at the Garden Theatre last night when Virginia Harned appeared in the title part of a dramatization of Maurice Thompson's novel "Alice of Old Vincennes."

After winning eight straight games, the Prosperity bowlers met their first defeat in the Grand Central tournament last night at the hands of the Echo team, which stands nineteenth in the record of the tournament. The Prosperity team still holds first place in the series, however, in spite of its single defeat.

No change occurred yesterday in the general conditions prevailing in the outside market: in parts of the list prices still moved downward while a somewhat larger number of issues ended the day at figures above those of last Saturday.

The Hoboken authorities are mystified over a man who made a fifteen-day trip across the ocean in a case in the hold of the Hamburg-American liner Palatia, which arrived on Sunday. He was discovered yesterday and lies unconscious in St. Mary's Hospital. Whether he will recover the physicians are unable to say.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Representative Grosvenor of Ohio apparently subscribes to the dual doctrine of a "Hanna bounty on ships and a Dingley embargo on foreign trade." A few days ago he declared stoutly against tariff concessions in the interest of the eport trade of the country. In an interview to-day he makes an argument in favor of ship subsidies.

A meeting of about 175 prominent New York dry goods merchants was held yesterday morning at the Broadway Central Hotel, and there were also in attendance several representatives of out-of-town houses. The occasion was the first meeting of the creditors of "The Metropolitan," a large concern doing a department store business at Binghamton, this State, and which began its career a little over a month ago.

PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 2. -- The Rev. John Gaston, D.F., died here late last night at his home 236 Lexington Avenue. He had been a sufferer from heart trouble for several years. He was seventy-six years old. He was born in Somerville in 1825 and was ordained a clergyman of the Reformed Church in New Brunswick.

In charging the Grand Jury yesterday, Recorder Goff outlined the duties of a Grand Juror and said that they had been chosen out of a list of 40,000 petit jurors on account of their high standing for integrity.
The Puritan Realty Company of New York City; capital, $1,300,000. Directors -- Charles A. Baker, L.J. Morton and D.H. Babbitt of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The biographies published in the new Congressional Directory, out to-day, show some curious contrasts. Most of the old members have written short autobiographies. As a general thing the new members have the longest autobiographies, although Senator Depew still continues to hold the record as the author of the longest autobiography in the whole directory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The House of Representatives went through, its cut-and-dried programme, but there was one event that was not scheduled, and that was a short "scrap" between Democrats and Republicans over the rules, followed by a vengeful filibuster of an hour and more headed by Mr. Richardson, the Democratic leader.

Jan Kubelik, the young Bohemian violinist, whose advent has been heralded in the most excited language by cable and mail, arrived in this city a few days ago and made his first appearance last night in a concert given at Carnegie Hall. That there was a large audience goes without saying. That there was also enthusiasm of the most voluminous and vigorous sort is a matter of course.

The outcome of the agitation for a postal telephone system for London seems to be attended with some public disappointment. The terms are said to have been "received with surprise " by the City Council. The particular Stem which appears to have excited the most evident signs of disapprobation is the charge of u17 for the use of an instrument with an unlimited number of calls.

It is to be hoped that no timid Briton will be any more alarmed than is any well-informed American by the truculence of the speeches made in New York on Sunday evening, upon the occasion of the commemoration of the "Manchester martyrs." Seeing that the meeting was held under the auspices of the Clan-na-Gael, a good deal of truculence was to be expected.
By The Associated Press. LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Money to-day tended to be easier. Three million pounds in dividend and intrest payments were disbursed. Discounts were steady.

Mayor-elect Low, ex-President of Columbia University, attended the monthly meeting yesterday of the Board of Trustees of the university, of which he is a member. Acting President Nicholas Murray Butler presided at the meeting. No action was taken toward the election of a President in Mr. Low's place.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day transmitted to Congress the estimates of appropriations required for the Government service for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1903, as furnished by the heads of the several executive departments. The total appropriations asked for are $610,827,688, which is $16,000,000 less than the estimates for 1902, and $4,000,000 more than the appropriations for that year.

A stowaway dressed in a fine black cutaway suit, wearing a silk hat of recent make, patent leather shoes, and with the rest of his garb proportionately elegant, landed at New York from the French liner La Gascogne Sunday. He gave his name as Leo von Carstenn, a citizen of Berlin, and twenty-five years of age.

Mr. and Mrs. Marshall C. Lefferts are to give a dinner and dance early in January -- probably during the first week -- at Sherry's, at which they will introduce their daughter. Miss Mollie Cozine Lefferts. Mrs. Lefferts will also give two receptions on the last two Thursdays in January.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. -- Count von Bulow, the Imperial Chancellor, in inaugurating today the greatest Parliamentary struggle that Germany has ever faced -- that in regard to the Tariff bill -- counseled the members of the Reichstag to moderation of language, declaring that the eyes of the world were upon them.

The case of Col. Robert L. Meade, commander of the marine barracks, who has been on trial by court-martial at the Brooklyn Navy Yard for the past two weeks, was closed yesterday afternoon, when the summing up by the prosecution and defense was completed. The courtroom was cleared, and the court, of which Rear Admiral Sumner is the President, went into executive session to consider the testimony adduced.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- The market today was again dull and backward, the demand showing decided reluctance when it was learned that gold had been engaged for export to Euripe, Prices held rather steady because the local level is believed to be already as low as it ought to go. Holders, therefore, pressed little for sale, thereby maintaining prices very well despite the dull trading.

In accordance with the writ of habeas corpus issued by Justice Clarke last week on the application of Lawyer George C. MacLaughlin, to compel George Blair, Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, to produce Ellen Duff, seventy-two years old, in the Supreme Court, before Justice Beach, now sitting in Special Term, Part I., the woman was brought down to court yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 2. -- It was announced here to-day that Frederick Weyerhauser had been elected to the Directorate of the Great Northern Railway, vice Col. W.P. Clough, resigned. The latter is to manage the Northern Securities Company.

The Willoughby Street leaders are taking steps to effect a reorganization of the Democratic Party in Brooklyn, and with that end in view an attempt is being made to enlist the sympathy and support of the independent Democratic element in the borough. It is known that overtures have been made to several of the independent leaders and that Edward M. Shepard is a prominent factor in the plan for reorganization.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Thomas Peterson Goudie, the bookkeeper of the Bank of Liverpool, who disappeared at the time of the discovery that the bank had been robbed of about u170,000, was captured this morning at Bootie, near Liverpool, where he had been in hiding. Goudie had u300 in his pocket when arrested.

Chief Engineer C.C. Martin's report on the plans to relieve the congestion of passenger traffic at the Manhattan terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge was turned over yesterday afternoon to Bridge Commissioner Shea, who approved it and will submit it for further action at the next meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

It is a fair inference from recent publications of the views of Secretary GAGE, his emphatic paper read and discussed at the Bankers' Convention at Milwaukee and others of like character, that he intends to bring before Congress the subject of the completion of the reform of our currency and finance.

While Heinrich Conried, manager of the Irving Place Theatre, was eating dinner at 7:30 o'clock last night with Mrs. Conried and Master Gonried, at their home, 65 West Seventy-first Street, sneak thieves entered the house and stole jewelry valued at $6,000. Mr. Conried had left the house for the theatre when Mrs. Conried went up stairs to her room and found boxes scattered on the bed.

Edward M. Shepard yesterday denied that he was the author of the resolutions presented at the caucus of Democratic Congressmen in Washington on Saturday. Mr. Shepard admitted, however, that he was consulted with regard to the resolutions and that he was in accord with the sentiments which they expressed.
Pretty things in hat pins are made of coral beads, strings of them twisted into a knot. They cost something over $2 apiece.

Charged with stealing a five-dollar bill from a room in the boarding house 42 West Twenty-seventh Street, Henry Clay Harp, a well-known horseman of Lexington, Ky., where he owns a stock farm adjoining Elmendorf, the famous farm of J. B. Haggln, and who is a friend of Garret D. Wilson and Edward Tipton, was locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station House last night.

The demonstration of Sunday in London, extraordinary as it was, was characteristically British. A Hyde Park meeting on Sunday is necessarily a meeting of the populace, of what is known in London as the " residuum." It is many years since such a meeting has been, so largely attended, or has commanded such general attention.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Two new cases of smallpox are reported in the old Constable Hook section of Bayonne, N.J. by Dr. Archibald C. Forman, the city's Health Physician. This makes five cases in a densely populated tenement section, one of which has proved fatal.

The billiard tournament for the championship of the world at eighteen-inch balk line was started last night at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall with George Sutton of Chicago and Louis Barutel of France as the contestants, and Barutel won after an interesting game of forty-six innings by a score of 400 to 389.

COPENHAGEN, Dec. 2. -- A full agreement has been reached between Denmark and the United States for the sale of the Danish West Indies. The treaty will probably be signed this week at Washington. The price fixed is between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000.

The decision, of the Supreme Court holding that duties were unlawfully collected in the case of the fourteen diamond rings brought into the United States by a returning soldier establishes the fact that the Philippine Islands are a part of our territory, but requiring, like Porto Rico, a special act of tariff legislation by Congress to make legal and collectible duties on merchandise passing between the islands and this country.
Mrs. Margaret E. Crocker died at her home, 41 East Forty-ninth Street, yesterday, aged seventy-seven years. She was the widow of Edwin B. Crocker, the California millionaire, who died in 1875.

The Commissioners of Taxes and Assessments in assessing the property of the Society of the Free Church of St. Mary the Virgin, a religious and charitable corporation, while exempting the church edifice under the provision of the general tax law exempting from taxation the property of religious and other similar corporations, assessed the mission house at $10,000, the clergy house at $12,000, and the rectory at $8,000.

Max Hochstim, the lieutenant of Martin Engel, was placed on trial yesterday before Judge Cowing in Part IV. of General Sessions, on an indictment charging him with interfering with an officer in the discharge of his duty. The officer is William M. Chapman, a deputy of Superintendent McCullagh's staff.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- Local stocks were strong to-day in the Philadelphia market, while issues having a collateral interest in the Wall Street market were comparatively weak. The interest was dividend between Reading common and Union Traction. The former closed at its lowest and the latter reached its highest for the present movement.
According to Berlin cables a $6,000,000 American bank's projected there.

Miss Helen Margaret Kelly, the daughter of the late Edward Kelly and granddaughter of the late Eugene Kelly, the banker, was married yesterday afternoon to Frank J. Gould, the youngest son of the late Jay Gould.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- Capt. John H. Brinckerhoff, who was injured in a runaway several days ago, died this morning from his injuries, which consisted of a fracture at the base of the brain.

To those who may have supposed that Booth Tarkington's story "Monsieur Beaucaire" would lend itself readily to dramatization and prove of more than usual effectiveness in its translation to the stage, the result of author's and actors' efforts at the Herald Square Theatre last night was somewhat disappointing.

George C. Boldt has bought, through Folsom Brothers, from Mrs. K.P. Walker, for $100,000, the property 41 West Thirty-third Street, a four-story dwelling, which has been altered for business purposes. This parcel abuts upon 36 West Thirty-fourth Street, which has also been acquired by Mr. Boldt.

The Woman's National Sabbath Alliance registered its, protest yesterday against, the proposed plan to open the saloons of New York on Sundays. It was the seventh annual meeting of the organization, the session being held in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 2. -- The South Carolina and West Indian Exposition was formally opened to the world to-day with words of greeting from the President of the United States. An imposing parade of military and civic bodies formed down town, and escorted the guests of honor to the exposition grounds, where they took part in an appropriate programme of exercises.

Heavy trading and great excitement prevailed on the Cotton Exchange shortly after the noon hour yesterday, when it was announced that the Government estimate of the cotton crop was but 9,674,000 bales and is far short of all private and professional estimates.

ELIZABETH CITY, N. C., Dec. 3. -- The preliminary hearing of James Wilcox, charged with the abduction of Nellie Cropsey on the night of Nov. 20, resulted in the defendant being held for the Grand Jury in $1,000 bail. Although more than twenty witnesses had been subpoenaed, only four were examined.

Eugene B. Sanger, the members of the November Grand Jury, who is alleged by counsel for Fire Commissioner Scannell to be a non-resident of this county, yesterday told District Attorney Philbin that he had voted in Larchmont, Westchester County, for the past seven or eight years. Mr. Sanger, however, declared that he regarded this city as his residence.

BERLIN, Dec. 3. -- The message of President Roosevelt caused mild excitement in Germany. On the Boerse, where it was eagerly awaited, it was received with uncommon interest, and the market generally was slightly stimulated upon the posting of a bulletin containing Mr. Roosevelt's utterances about trusts.

Johann Beck, who was brought to this port in a box in the hold of the steamship Palatia of the Hamburg-American Line and was discovered on Monday, when the hatches were opened at Hoboken, will recover.

Slawson Hobbs have sold for Gunn Grant to John Butler, for about $200,000 the seven-story apartment house at the northeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 50.11 by 95 by 100.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- In the Senate the reading of the President's message consumed two and a half hours. The first portion, dealing with the Buffalo tragedy, excited the most profound interest.

The recent large purchases of real estate on Thirty-first, Thirty-second, and Thirty-third Streets west of Seventh Avenue have been made by the Stuyvesant Real Estate Company, which is now in process of organization, and the incorporation papers of which were forwarded to Albany last week.

Two games were played in the world's championship billiard tournament at eighteen-inch balk line yesterday, the afternoon contest going to Sutton, after thirty-eight innings of play, and the evening to Slosson, who ran out the 400 points necessary to win in thirty-nine, innings. Opposed to them were Howison and Morningstar, each man a novice at a world's championship tourney, and naturally very nervous on that account.
NEWPORT, Dec. 3. -- The condition of J. Neilson Howard is very critical this evening, and his physician expresses the opinion that death may come at any time.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 3. -- The Woodard Shanklin horse sales closed here to-day, 107 horses bringing $18,000. During the sales 250 horses were sold for $55,885, an average of about $215 per head.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The financial editor of The Times, in discussing the foreign credit of the United States, dwells on the fact that, in spite of the large apparent balance of trade in favor of the United States against Europe, the balance has really been the other way, because of the borrowing operations necessitated by the enormous consolidation and other schemes in process of execution by American capitalists.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 3. -- President Zelaya officially received the Chilean Minister in the Hall of Congress to-day. A large assemblage was present, and speeches were made expressing the intimate relations between Chile and Nicaragua.

Richard Croker declared last evening that he was tired of doing the actual work of the leadership of Tammany Hall "all the year round," and that he could not stay in New York more than a "part of each year." When seen last evening at the Democratic Club Mr. Croker said:
Ellen Byrne Fox, wife of John Fox, ex-State Senator and President of the Democratic Club, died last night at her home, 10 East Fiftieth Street, after a week's illness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- There was a very good attendance in the galleries of the House during the reading of the message. The members gathered early, chatting and discussing prospective legislation. As the hands of the clock pointed to 12 Speaker Henderson called the House to order. After the Journal had been read Mr. Cooper (Texas) and Mr. Wood, (Cal.,) who were not present yesterday, appeared at the bar and were sworn in.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Dec. 3. -- The First National Bank of Ballston Spa failed to open its doors this morning. Edward J. Graham of Albany, a National Bank Examiner, posted on the main entrance an official notice stating that "this bank is closed pending an investigation by the Controller of the Currency."

Trading in the outside market yesterday was very light. As a whole, prices were firm, and more net gains resulted from the day's operations than declines. The further weakening of Amalgamated Copper on the Exchange was practically without effect on the outside copper stocks, trading in which was smaller than at any time for the past ten days.

MANILA, Dec. 3. -- The newspapers here published extras when they received the news of the United States Supreme Court's decision in the "fourteen diamond rings" case that the Philippines are American territory, and that the imposition of duty on articles imported into the United States from the Philippines is improper.

In a pouring rain, which did not deter several hundred spectators, and accompanied by the strains of "The Star-Spangled Banner" played by the Twenty-third Regiment Band, the first spadeful of earth in the work of depressing the Atlantic Avenue tracks of the Long Island Railroad, in Brooklyn, was turned at Atlantic and Bedford Avenues yesterday.

A couple of hundred members of the New York Credit Men's Association, who discussed the bankruptcy law after a dinner at 100 William Street last evening, nearly all seemed in favor of appealing to Congress during the present session for, an amendment of Section 57 -- G, which now construes payments made in due course of trade as preferences.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- At the meeting of stockholders of the Cleveland and Buffalo transit line to-day the capital stock was increased from $760,000 to $1,000,000, and the additional stock was immediately subscribed by the present stock-holders. A regular quarterly dividend of 1 1/4 per cent. and an additional dividend to distribute the large surplus which had been earned on account of the Pan-American Exposition travel was declared.

Mayor-elect Seth Low left for Washington last night on the midnight train. He will take luncheon to-day, with President Roosevelt. Senators Platt and Depew and Ambassador Choate will also be of the party at the President's table. Mr. Low said yesterday afternoon, that his visit to Washington was purely social; that no political significance whatever could be attached to it He will return to New York this evening.
Deputy Police Commissioner William S. Devery was again arraigned before Justice Holbrook yesterday to answer to charges of oppression preferred by ex-Policeman Edward O'Neill.
Baldwin Frick have been appointed Baltimore agents of the Reading Fire Insurance Company.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 3. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 3 per discount. Exchanges, $26,924,111; balances, $2,650,410. On call money rules from 4 to 5 per cent., mostly at 4 1/2 per cent. Time money ranges from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, for four to six months and 4 to 4 1/2 per cent, for a year.

HELENA, Mon., Dec. 3. -- The Supreme Court has Just handed down an important decision in the litigation between the Boston and Montana Mining Company and the Montana Ore Purchasing Company. Some time ago Judge Clancy of Butte denied a motion of the Boston and Montana for an injunction to restrain the Montana Ore Purchasing Company from working the Pennsylvania Mine, pending a decision on the ownership of the mine by the Supreme Court.

MANILA, Dec. 3. -- Advices from Catbalogan, capital of the Island of Samar, report that the insurgent General, Lukban, has offered to negotiate terms of surrender with Gen. Smith. To this offer the American commander replied that the time for negotiations had passed.

The text of the brief submitted by the United States Attorney General on the motion to dismiss the claims against this Government growing out of the destruction of the battleship Maine in Havana Harbor in February, 1898, was received in this city yesterday by the law firms representing the claimants.
LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Sidney Lee sends to The Times a letter which he has received from King Edward congratulating him on the final completion of that great work, "The Dictionary of National Biography."

The largest blaze on Staten Island in years almost destroyed the plaster mills of Jerome B. King Company at New Brighton yesterday morning. The main building, a brick structure, five stories high, was entirely consumed and the wooden wings at either end were partly destroyed. The loss is estimated at $150,000 on which there is full insurance.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Charles Brown, one of the murderers of Washington Hunter, paid the penalty of his share of the crime in the jail yard this morning. A short time before he died he made a desperate attempt to escape. In doing so he wounded a constable, but not seriously. He succeeded only in getting into the jail yard, where he was cowed into surrender.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Dec. 3. -- Two of the oldest residents of Dunellen died in that place to-day.

Chickering Hall, at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, has been purchased by the Alliance Realty Company, of which Frederick Southack Is President. The price paid for the property could not be learned yesterday from any of the parties interested in the deal, but it is understood that the owners of the property, the estate of Sidney Mason, have held it at about $575,000.

The Democratic General Committee of Kings County met last night in the Thomas Jefferson, Court Square, Brooklyn, and took the first step toward carrying out the plan for a reorganization of the party in the borough. The meeting was held for the purpose of effecting a permanent organization for the ensuing year.

HONOLULU, Nov. 26, via San Francisco, Cal., Dec. 3. -- Old Afong and his son, Anthony, are in trouble in China and have had to claim protection of the American Consulate in Hongkong. Anthony is a brother of the wife of Capt. Whiting of the United States Navy and of the wife of Lieut. Commander Dougherty.

The strong box in the Fifth Avenue Safe Deposit Company's vaults at 190 Fifth Avenue, in which Alfred Hallenbeck, known as the "honest gambler," and who died last February, deposited his superfluous wealth, was opened yesterday. Instead of being filled with worthless paper, as was expected, the box contained $1,000 in bank notes, numerous jewels, bonds and securities said to be worth at least $150,000.

The conservative and altogether assuring attitude taken by President Roosevelt in this message to Congress was promptly reflected in a substantial advance in prices on the Stock Exchange, following a period of hesitancy and market inactivity because of a vague fear that for some cause or other the message might prove disappointing, and mayhap even disturbing.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 3. -- Col. Richard Wootton, for many years a leader of the Democratic Party in Maryland, died here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Miss Edith Harlan Child was presented to society this afternoon at a tea at the residence of her grandfather, Justice Harlan. The entire drawing room floor was adorned in chrysanthemums and roses sent by friends of the debutante. Miss Harlan and Miss Ruth Harlan received the guests.

Yesterday was a dull, fitful, disagreeable day with every, one in town. The afternoon was employed in luncheons and some Very small affairs. There was one tea given by Francis Sherwoed Kinney for his daughter, Miss Kinndy, at 13 West Fifty-fourth Street. In the evening there were several dances, the more Important being the Junior Cotillion at Sherry's and the meeting of the class which was organized by Mrs. John Rockefeller, Jr.

President ROOSEVELT has not only communicated to Congress and the country much information about public business, but he has done it with a directness and vigor of expression that make the reading of his message not a labor but a pleasure. No other President has ever had Mr. ROOSEVELT'S experience with the pen, and none, we think, has surpassed him in respect to skill in the use of it.

The run of Clyde Fitch's play "The Way of the World," which has been the attraction at Hammer stein's Victoria Theatre for the past four weeks, came to a sudden end yesterday. Last evening the patrons who had purchased tickets were informed upon arrival at the theatre that there would be no performance.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- The annual meeting of the United States Spirits Association here to-day was attended by about fifty representatives of the distributors in this country.

By This Associated Press. LONDON, Dec. 3. -- The demand for money to-day was good, and supplies were limited. The competition for bills, for Continental account, weakened discounts. Business on the Stock exchange was fairly cheerful, and prices were occasionally irregular. A sharp reaction in Americans proved a rather general dampener.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- Money was plentiful to-day, and had an easier tendency, though it was much wanted in connection with repayments to the Bank of England and preparations for to-morrow's installment of consols. Discounts were maintained, notwithstanding the ease of money.

Henry D. Winans May have sold for the estate of Chauncey Kilmer the fourstory brownstone-front dwelling 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, 28 by 100; also, for the estate of Stephen Barker to John H. Glover the four-story business building 19 East Twenty-first Street, 28 by 98.9.

PARIS, Dec. 5. -- The recent revival of interest in the Dreyfus affair has given rise to several incidents which, while not affecting the question of the innocence of Dreyfus, throw light on the subsequent relations of the chief Dreyfusards with each other.

TRENTON, Dec. 4. -- The State Board of Health makes the statement that Trenton has not had a case of smallpox this year, but that cancer is the most dangerous and fatal disease in this locality. There were 34 deaths in the city and 44 in the county from cancer.

BOSTON, Dec. 4. -- Money loaned at the local Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 6, 10, and 12 1/2 cents discount. Exchanges, $24,683,192; balances, $1,754,791. Money on call is loaned mostly at 4 1/2, with some loans, however, made both sides of this figure. The choicest commercial paper now passes at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Speculation on the Board of trade to-day was such as to recall the great transactions of Hutchinson, Cudahy, Kent, Ream, and the other giants who ruled the pits and swung prices for fortunes every session. Bull enthusiasm such as has not been seen often in late years had possession of the markets, and in spite of heavy selling for profits every pit closed strong.

Slow billiards was characteristic of both games in the world's championship series yesterday in the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden. The games were at eighteen-inch balk line, and the feature of the evening was the first appearance of "Jake" Schaefer, who shares with Slosson in favoritism for the championship.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Gen. A.D. Hazen, who served as Third Assistant Postmaster General for many years, died last night at his home here. He was sixty-one years old.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday announced a decision regarding a statue representing the Immaculate Conception, which was imported from Italy and presented to the Cathedral of Baltimore. The statue, which was invoiced at 3,500 lire, was consigned to the Rev. C.G. Thomas; but it was in part the gift of the Misses Andrews to the cathedral.

What interest has Mayor VAN WYCK in endeavoring to "Jam through" the Board of Estimate a contract whereby the notorious HORGAN SLATTERY are to be saddled upon the city as architects of the Hall of Records until the completion of that building? This is the question which everybody who is informed about the matter must be asking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Practically the entire session of the Senate to-day was devoted to the introduction of bills and resolutions. Two of these measures, relating to the suppression of anarchy and the dealing with Anarchists, were allowed to lie on the table, so that their authors, Mr. McComas of Maryland and Mr. Vest of Missouri, might bring them to the early attention of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Secretary Gage does not consider it a matter of great moment whether The London Times is right or wrong in saying the United States is still a debtor Nation in spite of the country's enormous wealth and its great trade balances. Referring to the matter in an interview to-day the Secretary said:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 4. -- Geraldo Maiorano, who, in addition to being a Deputy Sheriff, is the Postmaster of Silver Lake, to-day had his badge and revolver taken from him in the Sheriff's office and his license as deputy revoked. Further steps against him may be taken by the Prosecutor.

A gathering of representative Irishmen from all parts of the United States had a five hours' conference at the Hoffman House yesterday with Delegates John E. Redmond, P.A. McHugh, and Thomas O'Donnell, sent here from Ireland to promote the organization in this country of branches of the United Irish League, the association succeeding the Land League made famous under the leadership of the late Charles S. Parnell.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- New York, instead of sending gold to Germany, is returning the German Treasury bills floated in September, 1900. The Tageblatt learns that fully half of this loan has been returned.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The quarrel between Queen Wilhelmina and Prince Henry, her husband, excites great interest here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Mayor-elect Seth Low at 1:30 o'clock took luncheon with the President. The guests included Attorney General Knox, Secretary Root, Secretary Hay, Senators Platt and Depew of New York, Ambassador Choate, Senators Frye and Spooner, Representatives Payne and Littauer, Mr. Tyler, Mr. Adams, and Secretary Cortelyou.

BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Internationals were firm on the Boerse to-day, especially Spanish 4s and Turks. Transvaal Dynamite Trust was harder on the alleged exhaustion of Gen. Botha's troops. Anatolian Railroad advanced sharply, and, consequently, Deutsche Bank was in active demand.

The stock market yesterday continued to reflect the stimulus given to it on Tuesday by the encouraging and conservative character of President Roosevelt's message to Congress -- a stimulus that made itself manifest immediately following the publication of the message, when prices quite generally advanced, and, despite a sharp and unsettling break in Amalgamated Copper, held a material part of their gain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day issued the following circular of instructions to collectors of customs regarding the refund of duties collected from imports from the Philippine Islands:

TRENTON, Dec. 4. -- For the first time New Jersey has compiled complete figures of the railroad interests of this State. The Bureau of Statistics has completed a valuable report, which has been submitted to Gov. Voorhees. It Is valuable because it gives the number of men employed, and some idea of the number of accidents during the year on the various lines having their terminals within the State.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The Court of Claims, which is dealing with the rights and privileges relating to the coronation of King Edward, sat yesterday in solemn state, in the council chamber in Whitehall, to adjudicate between nobles and others who are wrangling for ancient but generally empty and often ludicrous honors.

Commander S.A. Staunton of the United States Navy was interviewed at the Albemarle Hotel last night on the need of the United States for a better navy as recommended in the President's message. Looking at the matter from a commercial view point he said a larger and better navy was an absolute necessity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The report of the Isthmian Canal Commission was sent to Congress to-day. As anticipated several weeks ago, the commission favors the Nicaragua route, and makes an estimate of $189,864,062 as the total cost of construction of the canal through Nicaragua. The estimated cost of the Panama route la $144,233,338, but, the report says, it would cost $109,141,000 to obtain the Panama concession.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The two wounded men from Virginia reached this city tonight at 7:30 o'clock, and were at once taken to the Emergency Hospital. It was soon seen that Heflin's wound was fatal, and he died in about an hour after reaching the hospital. Stiff is paralyzed from the neck down, but there is a remote, possibility of his recovery.

Why does the Secretary of the Treasury accord to the subject of the excessive Federal taxes such gingerly and inadequate treatment? There is before him no other Treasury problem so grave or so urgent. The Federal laws will take from the people in the current fiscal year $100,000,000 more than is required for the expenditures of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Senator Hale today reintroduced the Pacific Cable bill as it passed al the last session of Congress, it provides for the construction by the Government of ft cable from the western coast of the United States to Hawaii.
William C. Whitney has sent out invitations for the ball to be given for Miss Adelaide Randolph, the daughter of the late Mrs. Whitney, on the evening of Tuesday, Dec. 17.

Mr. GROUT is sure that Controller COLER'S plan of deducting from the total of the city's debt bonds representing profitable assets which are not only taking care of their fixed charges but providing for additions to the sinking fund which will permit their extinction at maturity, is "too radical." His own plan, which he regards as much more conservative, is to capitalize such public improvements on a 4 per cent.

All sorts of jewelry in gun metal is set with amethysts, and very pretty it is, too. Large brooches are to be looked at a little askance, but long pins, a serpent, perhaps, the entire length of its body set with the purple stones, are very attractive.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Senator Lodge to-day introduced a bill to provide revenues for the Philippine Islands. It provides that the tariff passed by the Philippine commission Sept. 17, 1901, and approved by the Secretary of War, shall remain in full force and effect. This covers goods going into the islands.

President Bowley of the Borough of Queens created a sensation at the meeting of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday by declaring that the map of the proposed canal from Flushing Bay to Newtown Creek was not in accordance with the resolutions passed by the board. The resolutions, President Bowley claimed, called for a strip of land 150 feet wide on each side of the canal to be used as bulkheads and for docking purposes.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Buying of Union Traction stock was a feature of the local market to-day and the price reached the highest of the present advance, one block of 3,000 shares going at 34 and smaller lots at 34 3/8. Some of the local specialties, however, made new low records, while the arbitrage stocks were advancing.

Members of the grain trade of the New York Produce Exchange were considerably disturbed by the reports from the interior of the State that forty-six canalboats, containing an equal number of loads of grain and flaxseed, have been frozen in in the Erie Canal and will in all probability not reach this city until the early Spring of next year.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4. -- The local market was quiet to-day so far as the volume of trading counted, but it was better in tone and generally higher in prices. The somewhat more favorable conditions in Wall Street had a very perceptible influence here. The pressure on United Railways relaxed sufficently, or rather the buying, of the issues improved sufficiently, to make possible a fractional net gain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Two bills looking to the construction of an Isthmian canal via the Nicaragua route were introduced to-day in the Senate. The first of these, presented by Senator Morgan, is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4. -- Dr. Isaac Newton Evans of Hatboro, Penn., who was a member of the Forty-fifth, Forty-eighth, and Forty-ninth Congresses, from the Seventh District of Pennsylvania, died suddenly of heart disease at his home last night, aged seventy-four years. He was born in Chester County, Penn., and was graduated in medicine from Bowdoin College, Maine, and Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia.

With many well-known people on board the White Star liner Oceanic got in from Liverpool yesterday morning. Among them were Gilbert Parker, M.P., the novelist and dramatist; A.W. Maconochie, another M. P., and Horace Plunkett, who was recently defeated by Arthur Lynch, of the Boer forces, for Member of Parliament from County Galway.

PEKING, Dec. 4. -- Native papers say that Yuan-Shi-Kai, the Governor of Pe-chi-Li, proposes to reorganize the Pei-Yang naval forces under British and American instructors, and that he will consolidate the military forces of Pe-chi-Li into an army corps, numbering 100,000 men, under foreign instructors.

In the outside market yesterday prices were generally strong in sympathy with the upward movement in Stock Exchange quotations. The issues which during the past few days had shown continued firmness made some further gains, and a number of other issues joined in this upward movement.

"The Girl and the Judge," produced at the Lyceum Theatre last evening, is chiefly remarkable for the feeling of vague uncertainty which it must instill into the mind of one who seeks to define it. It tells an improbable story, in an impossible way. introduces people who do improbable things, through following instincts and mental processes that to the ordinarily balanced mentality would likewise seem impossible.

The present procedures of Tammany in several departments must recall to the people of New York the words of Scripture: "The devil is come down unto you, having great wrath, because he knoweth that he hath but a short time."

The last day of the Fasig-Tipton "Old Glory" sale of light harness horses was reached yesterday, after eight days of sensational horse selling. The total of the sales, both in the number of animals sold and the aggregate amount of money realized, has never been approached. With resales, sales of wagons, harness, , the total amounted to a full half-million dollars.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage sent the annual report of the Treasury Department to the Speaker of the House of Representatives to-day.

BALLSTON SPA, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- Bank Examiner Graham was busy all day examining deposit certificates presented to the First National Bank. There are 400 interest-bearing certificates, and it will be several days before all can be brought in and verified. Next will be examined the depositors' books subject to sight checks.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Dec. 4. -- The news from Wilson, N.C., of the detention there of a woman partially identified as Miss Nellie Cropsey has created little interest here among the girl's family or officials of the town. This same woman and her companion were examined at Speed, N.C., by an agent of Chief of Police Dawson several days ago.

Over 300 men and women employed in the six-story factory building occupied by S. M. Bixby Co., dealers in shoe blacking and polish, at 194 Hester Street, were panic-stricken yesterday evening by a fire which occurred on the top floor. As soon as the cry of fire was raised the employes, without waiting to see which floor the fire was on, made a rush for the fire escapes and stairways, crowding and blocking them.

TRENTON, Dec. 4. -- The fifteen Judges of the Court of Errors and Appeals of New Jersey are to sit in solemn judicial conclave to decide in effect what should constitute the, proper treatment of a cat.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The reappointment of Cornelius Van Cott as Postmaster of New York City was announced to-day at the White House. It also was announced that Dwight H. Bruce had been reappointed Postmaster at Syracuse, and that W.H. Smyth was to run another term as Postmaster at Owego, Senator Platt's home.

The steamship Finance of the Panama Line, the officers, crew, and passengers of which vessel were at Colon during the fighting at that port, arrived at New York yesterday. The vessel was a day late owing to the fact that the transisthmian train which connects with the vessels of the Panama Line was some six or seven hours behind time in reaching Colon.

B. Howard Martin and Miss Elizabeth, Agmew, daughter of the late John T. Agnew, were married at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Old First Presbyterian Church, on lower Fifth Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, pastor of the church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Jefferson of the Broadway Tabernacle and the Rev. Percy S. Grant of the Church of the Ascension

Sheriff-elect William J. O'Brien has been seeking legal advice in regard to his right to discharge the Deputies and Assistant Deputies in the Sheriff's office. It has been the general impression that these men were under the Civil Service, but Mr. O'Brien received information which led him to think otherwise, and he has been investigating the extent of his power of appointment.

The unexpected ending Tuesday night of "The Way of the World," running at Hammerstein's Victoria Theatre, appears to have brought about fresh troubles in the shape of a many-sided controversy, in which producer, manager, principal actress, and playwright are engaged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The Cuban Commission on Tariff Concession spent yesterday and to-day in Washington, accompanied by their counsel, State Senator Frank D. Pavey of New York. They held conferences yesterday and to-day with Gov. Wood and others Gen. Wood took luncheon to-day with the commission at the New Willard.

In total darkness, due to a shifting belt in the dynamo room, Acting President Nicholas Murray Butler of Columbia University, addressed yesterday the patrons and friends of the University and Teachers College, who gathered in the auditorium of the new Horace Mann School Building to take part in its dedication exercises.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Roosevelt at "San Juan Hill " is to be the subject of a painting by Vassill Verestchagin, the painter of battle scenes. The famous Russian artist arrived here to-day, to conduct an exhibition of his paintings at the Art Institute.

A new Bible, authorized by the late general convention in San Francisco to be read in all Episcopal churches in the United States, has been in process of completion by the Committee on Marginal Readings, which has sat at the Episcopal General Seminary in this city since last Tuesday, and will conclude its work to-morrow.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5. -- George B. Chadwick, a junior at Yale University, was to-night elected Captain of the football team, for next year, to succeed Charles Gould, who graduates in June next.

Trotting decisions in more than a score of cases were announced by the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association after an all-day session at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. The morning was spent in taking testimony and the afternoon in executive session, after which the decisions were announced.

The first hockey match of the present season was played last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, in West Sixty-sixth Street, between teams representing the St. Nicholas Skating Club and Yale University, Yale winning by a score of 4 to 2.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Rev. John W. Leekines, a colored minister, of this place, is about to forward a petition to Congress asserting that he saved the Cities of Washington and Baltimore from capture by the Confederate Army during the civil war, and thereby saved the Union. Dr. Leekines says he had to leave Baltimore to escape the enemies he made by his disclosures.

CLEVELAND, O., Dec. 5. -- Judge William R. Day of Canton, President of the McKinley National Memorial Association, has called a special meeting of the Board of Trustees, of that body to be held at the Arlington Hotel, Washington, on Saturday, Dec. 7. Reports will be submitted showing the progress of organization throughout the entire country.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Rev. Dr. P.T. Pockman, pastor of the First Reformed Church of New Brunswick and President of the Rutgers Chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa Braternity Alpha, of New Jersey, called by appointment upon President Roosevelt at the White House to-day.

All New England is excited over the actions of Mayor Stephen Charters of Ansonia, Conn. He professes that he is anything other than a revolutionist, and states that his modest home in Church Street has always flown the American flag on holidays and made it conspicuous, particularly on St. Patrick's Day, by a contrast of colors where the red, white, and blue floated side by side with the green flag and the golden harp.

CENTRALI., Ill., Dec. 5. -- Thomas W. Haymond, a New York foundling, who came to Illinois about fifty years ago and made a fortune, committed suicide last night by jumping into a well. The action is attributed to mental derangement, resulting from overwork and grief for his foster father and partner.

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- Clerk Archie Baxter has completed his roll of members of the new State Assembly, which will organize in January. Of the 150 members, 96 have had previous service in the Assembly. This number includes 41 who sat for the first time in the session of 1901, and 18 who began their service in 1900 and were reelected last year and this year.

BOSTON, Dec. 5. -- Money loaned at the local Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 10, 8, and 5, cents discount. Exchanges, $22,396,212. Balance, $1,560.427. Money at call rules from 4 to 5 per cent. Time money is quoted from 41/2 to 5 per cent for four to six months, and 4 to 41/2 per cent for a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Representative Crumpacker, (Rep., Ind.,) one of the original movers of the proposition to reduce the representation of the Southern States in the House, is circulating a petition for the calling of a Republican caucus to determine whether the dominant party in the House shall take up as a definite policy some plan of action against the alleged "over-representation."

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The City entertained the Prince and Princess of Wales yesterday at a luncheon in the Guildhall, and presented to them an address of congratulation on their successful tour of the British Empire.

The city officials, as the result of over one thousand lawsuits, have found that street cleaners cannot be "laid off" for a day now and then. This victory of the "men behind the broom" came as a surprise to Corporation Counsel Whalen, Street Cleaning Commissioner Nagle, and many other Tammany officials.

De Lancey Nicoll, W. N. Coler, Jr., G. Creighton Webb, and J. Wesley. Allison, It was announced yesterday, are, among others, on the Board of Directors of the Montreal and Boston Copper Company, Limited, which has been formed under the laws of the Province of Nova Scotia, District of Canada, with a capital stock of $3,000,000.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 5. -- Senator W. J. Sewall of New Jersey, ho has been in Asheville for several months on account of ill-health, will leave for home to-morrow.

GREENCASTLE, Ind., Dec. 5. -- Harry Crawford, President of the Midland Railroad, is making a hard fight in the Putnam County Circuit Court for the retention of the control of his property. Charles Kenney and others are suing the road for a receivership. The plaintiffs hold 177 claims, which they have bought from the employes, aggregating between five and six thousand dollars.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Senator McComas (Rep.) of Maryland made a long speech in the Senate to-day on the subject of Anarchy. This was followed by some brief remarks by Mr. Hoar (Rep.) of Massachusetts, who talked about the difficulties in the way of dealing with Anarchist assassins.

Mayor Van Wyck gave a public hearing yesterday to a delegation of members of the Brooklyn League. J. Hampden Dougherty was the spokesman for the delegation. Mr. Dougherty called the Mayor's attention to the alleged failure of the contractor to complete the work on the Miliburn conduit, which was undertaken to increase the water supply of Brooklyn.

The New York Church Choir Company, an organization numbering seventy-five singers who were recruited by Junius Howe and William Parry from the choirs of New York and Brooklyn churches, will render "Martha" as the matinee offering and "Faust" on the evening of Saturday, the 14th of December, at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn.

Benjamin Steinhardt, counsel for Mrs. Hallenbeck, widow of Alfred Hallenbeck, who for many years was known as the "honest gambler," examined Owen G. Parr, who had been Mr. Hallenbeck's secretary and in whose name he held a strong box in the vaults of the Fifth Avenue Safe Deposit Company, before Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, as to the nature of the contents of the box.

Acting Captain Churchill, accompanied by three detectives and nine policemen in plain clothes, whom he had called from their beds for special duty, last night raided an alleged gambling house at 148 East Fourteenth Street, directly opposite Tammany Hall. The raiders were equipped with portable electric lights, in addition to axes.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday were on a more limited scale than for some time past, aggregating something less than 650,000 shares. This decrease and the irregular price movements of the day -- strength appearing in some issues and heaviness in otherswere no doubt due to the disposition on the part of traders and operators generally not to extend their market commitments until after the Amalgamated Copper dividend meeting next week.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The new Hay-Pauncefote treaty, providing for the construction of an isthmian canal, which was sent to the Senate yesterday, is as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- Another article by the financial editor of The Times on the credit relations of the United States and Europe appears to-day. He infers that the views he expressed in, The Times on Wednesday are not disputed by the best judges in the United States.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Booming bull enthusiasm, the heaviest transactions in over a year in all pits, record prices in grains, and heavy profits for the fortunate sellersthese were the characteristic features of business on the Board of Trade to-day. The craze for much buying, which began to show itself yesterday, was present again at the opening, and was augmented on every hand as the session advanced.

The principle laid down in the Taaff Vale, Belfast Butcher, and other cases involving demands for damages against trades unions for injury inflicted upon employers, seems to have been embodied into the jurisprudence of the United Kingdom. The latest case of record is instructive as involving the question of individual liability for injurious concerted action.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- Gov. Odell held a conference to-day with the leaders of the Republican Party in the State Legislature. There were present Col. George W. Dunn, Chairman of the Republican State Committee; Senator Ellsworth, President pro tem, of the Senate; Senator Higgins, Chairman of the Finance Committee, and Senator Stranahan, Krum, Malby, and Raines, Speaker of the Assembly Nixon, Leader Allds, and Assemblyman Kelsey.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- The market was again dull to-day, the buying demand still holding back to await a definite signal from New York. The record to-day showed little change. It was inclined upward,but later eased off somewhat, closing about the same as Wednesday's level. Seaboard common was one-quarter higher, while Georgia Southern and Florida second preferred advanced 11/2.

At the December meeting yesterday of the Chamber of Commerce, at which Morris K. Jesup presided, the resolutions offered by Gustav H. Schwab, as Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Commerce and the Revenue Laws, on the action of the National Reciprocity Convention were after much debate referred back to the committee.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 5. -- The British ship Nelson, which was reported lost off the Columbia River yesterday, was towed into Puget Sound to-day by the steamer Walla Walla, bound from San Francisco to Seattle. The hull of the Nelson is practically intact, but her bulwarks are smashed, lifeboats and fore rigging carried away, and cabins damaged.

George Slosson and Ora C. Morningstar, the latter being the Indiana billiardist, were the victors yesterday in the billiard tournament for the championship of the world, which is now in progress in the Concert Hall of the Madison Square Garden. Morningstar won his game in the afternoon, beating the Chicago entry, George Sutton, in a game well worth watching, by 25 points.

The Hamburg-American liner Deutschland arrived yesterday after a stormy voyage across the Atlantic. The big ship had to slow down several times owing to the rough weather, a fact which caused her to be several hours late in making port.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 5. -- Prof. Ira N. Hollis, Chairman of the Athletic Committee of Harvard, gave out an important statement to-night, answering a pertinent question as to what the yearly athletic surplus at Harvard is used for, and incidentally touching upon a matter which is of vital interest to every member of the university.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 5. -- Herbert Marx, the principal in the Westmoreland County shooting affair, arrived in Fredericksburg late last night, having boarded the Weems Line steamboat Northumberland down the river yesterday evening. He was met by his brother, Ernest Marx, who arrived from New York, and together they spent the night at the Hotel Dannehl.

The amended and revised Hay-Pauncefote treaty is a very simple instrument. If reads like a convention negotiated for the purpose of facilitating the construction not of a military canal, but of a waterway intended primarily for peaceful commerce. For that reason it will commend itself to the approval of men of sense.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 5. -- Because he remained by his wife's side when commanded by a conductor to move forward in the aisle of a crowded Olive Street car, L. D. Cabanne became involved in a fight, which ended by his receiving a stunning blow from a motorman's controller.

A large number of soldiers' wives, sweethearts, and friends filled the Army Pier on the East River yesterday afternoon, watching the United States transport Crook slide out into the stream to start for Manila by way of the Mediterranean with over a thousand troops on board.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- The man who is declared to be the most insignificant looking in the Reichstag, Herr Bebel, broke the monotony of the House to-day and lifted the tariff debate to emotional levels. Herr Bebel often provoked his opponents, but sometimes he enthralled even them. The galleries followed his address breathlessly.

A monument to Robert Fulton, the inventor of the steamboat, was unveiled yesterday afternoon in Trinity Churchyard after a memorial service that crowded the main body of the old church. The services were attended by many prominent engineers and naval men. The monument was erected by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, who have been holding their annual convention in this city for the last two days.

Resolved, That this Chamber hereby expresses its disapproval of the action taken by the National Reciprocity Convention at Washington on the 20th ultimo, as subversive of all attempts to bring about closer trade relations with our sister nations, and to open new and wider markets for our products; and be it further

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- The People's Traction Company of New York City has leased its property and franchises to the Interurban Street Railway Company for a term of 999 years, according to a certificate filed to-day with the Secretary of State.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- A joint committee representing all the labor unions of the city visited the office of President John B. Parsons of the Union Traction Company to-day in the interest of the company's employes, some of whom have been endeavoring to secure an adjustment of grievances.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5. -- The Philadelphia market was very dull to-day. A wavering course in the afternoon wiped out most of the grains of a strong tone in the morning, leaving the list at the close at about where It stood last night. There was a steady demand for Union Traction and for a while this braced the list, but when the Readings began to fall off the general tone became weaker.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5. -- Nebraska's prairie "volcano" is again in a state of eruption, after resting quietly since 1879. This very peculiar freak of nature was seen first by white men when Lewis and Clark made their famous trip across the Continent in the early part of the nineteenth century.

The Rev. Dr. Henry Lubeck, rector of the Church of Zion and St. Timothy, Fifty-seventh Street near Eighth Avenue, was on Wednesday elected to the chair of pastoral theology in the Episcopal General Seminary in this city. The election takes effect September, 1902, and Trustees of the Seminary express the hope that by that time the rector of Zion and St. Timothy may decide to accept the position.

-- Is the State Commission of Lunacy the deadly enemy of the Pathological Institute, instead of its protecting and sustaining friend, as it is supposed to be, and are the members of the commission so dealing with an undertaking which it dares not destroy outright that there will soon be nothing left of it except a name?

Daniel S. McElroy. who already owned 328 Lexington Avenue, has bought, through James Bailey, the adjoining properties, Nos. 330 and 332, giving him control of a plot 59.2 by 75 at the southwest corner of Thirty-ninth Street. It is reported that negotiations are pending for the resale of the property to Irons Todd, who will erect thereon a twelve-story apartment hotel.

Mayor-elect Seth Low gave a dinner last night at his residence, at which his guests were Col. John N. Partridge, the new Police Commissioner; Justice Jerome, the District Attorney-elect; Robert C. Morris, the President of the Republican County Com- mittee, and Robert Grier Monroe, the attorney for the Citizen's Union.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Rev. Dr. Henry van Dyke, head of the English department of Princeton University, has accepted the call from the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York to become minister in charge during the vacancy of its pastorate.
The quarterly meeting of the Association of Civil Employes in the State of New York was held last night in the Brooklyn Borough Hall. The meeting was largely attended.

Yesterday was a busy day with its receptions and teas, the Cinderella cotillions, and other dances. The Thursday Evening Club was the principal entertainment for the set which does not dance and which prefers music and intellectual pursuits.
LONDON, Dec. 5. -- The demand for money increased to-day, owing to the payment of the financial consols instalment, estimated approximately at u3,750,000. Discounts were firm and inactive.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: As the only one of a committee of two of the Directors of the Lotos Club appointed to welcome the Rev. Charles Kingsley to these shores who reached the steamer, I am able to confirm the surmise or your correspondent, Mr. Charles Tilden Sempers, that the distinguished and beloved author landed here on the 11th or 12th of February, 1874.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The following named persons were entertained by the President at dinner this evening: Secretary Long, Senators Pettus, (Dem., Ala.,) Gallinger, (Rep., N.H.,) ,Nelson, (Rep., Minn.,) Dolliver, (Rep., Iowa,) McComas, (Rep., Md.,) Clark, (Rep., Wy.,) Mallory, (Dem., Fla.,) Foster, (Dem., La.,) Clay, (Dem., Ga.,) Bard, (Rep., Cal.,) Burton, (Rep., Kan.,) Dillingham, (Rep., Vt.,) and Burnham, (Rep., N.H.,) and Mr. Paul Morton.

Expectations of an unfavorable bank statement to-day, as indicated by a loss of over $5,500,000 by the banks during the week; suggestions that large gold exports are to be made next week, and the rumor current that a further reduction is probable in the Amalgamated Copper dividend were the factors inducing to the rather general selling in yesterday's stock market which forced some sharp declines throughout the list.

Filippo Brunelleschi is one of the most interesting figures of the early Renaissance. His biographer complains of the lack of data upon which to build an authentic life of him, but from such data as exist one gains a singularly vivid picture. Ugly in person and proud of spirit, he begins his artistic life with a strong bias toward sculpture.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. S.G.W. Benjamin's minute historical research that resulted in unearthing the imitative exploit of a Jersey Committee of Public Safety in the obscure little landing of Greenwich certainly merits the thanks of many students of American history who have failed of his diligence.

What a superbly brutal period it was when the Crusades flourished! Fanaticism and superstition are apparently those two human traits never to be eradicated. What oceans of blood were spilled in the darker ages, but as for that we are not sparing of life to-day. Mr. William Stearns Davis in his "God Wills It" presents a striking picture of the First Crusade.

Berlin Letter to Chicago Record-Herald. Only three women have taken degrees at the University of Berlin. Two are American and one a Jewess. The latter was one of the first women to enter the university and the first to win a degree. Her name is Bertha Neumann, and her father keeps a music store on Potsdamer Strasse in Berlin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Joseph Coleman of 158 Rush Street gave a dinner this evening in honor of Mrs. W.H. Truesdale of New York, who is in the city for a short visit to her daughter, Mrs. Richard Bissell. This dinner was the second in a series of social functions of much interest to the North Side "smart set."

The new Immigration bill, drawn by Commissioner General of Immigration T. V. Powderly and introduced into the Senate Thursday by Senator Penrose of Pennsylvania, will be vigorously opposed by representatives of the transatlantic steamship lines at this port. This decision was reached by those who informally discussed the proposed legislation yesterday.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 6 -- Divergent stories come from Westmoreland County in connection with the tragedy in which Herbert Marx of New York played such a conspicuous part. The latest dispatch from Warsaw says that Marx admitted at the Coroner's inquest that he had kissed Miss Rosa Taylor, but had said nothing wrong.

Jacob Schaefer and Louis Barutel were the victors yesterday in the billiard games for the world's championship, which is being played in the Concert Hall of the Madison Square Garden, at eighteen-inch balk line. Schaefer beat George Sutton, the Chicago entry, last evening, by 57 points, while Barutel beat the Canadian, Leonard Howison, in the afternoon by 76 points.

BELOW will be found our regular annual list of selected books suitable for holiday presents. This feature is in line with the lists which THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS has offered each year since the supplement was started.

In some remarks in THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW on one of Hugo Munsterberg's ar- ticles, I find the following: "He believes in the broadest possible education as a foundation for all specialized study, and he denies the value of electives, even on utilitarian grounds, and as to interesting the dear little boys, he dryly says that 'the platform is no variety show; the boys must be inspired, but not aroused.'"
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Sarah Klee and her little daughter were burned to death and seven other members of the same family were injured in a fire at Carnegie, Penn., this morning.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Can you tell me how it happens that there are still a few American editors who persist in sticking pins through unavailable manuscripts? A manuscript of twelve typewritten pages now lies on my desk punctured twice through and through with a pin, the mutilation done by a New York editor.

LADY DILKE'S volume is illustrated by a dozen photogravure plates and about fifty half-tone prints, sometimes of one, sometimes of several objects. The list of illustrations shows that a few additional illustrations, partly photogravures, and partly half-tones, are published with the large paper edition, and with that only.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Ex-Secretary of State John W. Foster and Mrs. Foster gave another large dinner party this evening at their Eighteenth Street home. As on Tuesday evening, the dinner was in honor of distinguished Presbyterians of the Creed Revision Committee.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Does the Russian language present such hard problems to the translator that it is impossible to render the writings of a Russian into English without destroying the author's style and without making the most patent blunders? Or is it true that our translators differ from the Germans, the French, or others in the matter of thoroughness and fidelity?

Recorder Goff's decision sustaining the demurrer of Police Captain John D. Herlihy to the indictment charging him with the crime of willfully omitting to perform a duty enjoined by law upon him as a public officer has been unanimously reversed by the Appellate Division in an opinion by Justice Chester B. McLaughlin.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- John Frazer Mills, one of the wealthiest residents of Port Chester, died at his home Thursday night, aged fifty-seven. He was born in Jersey City, where his father, Benjamin Mills, was a prominent manufacturer. Mr. Mills fell ill with liver disease on Nov. 25, after he had been attending a meeting of the Sons of the Revolution in New York City.

When a man publishes his autobiography he deliberately opens to the public doors usually kept locked and barred. It is an invitation to criticism of himself as well as criticism of his book. A review of "The Making of an American" must, therefore, in a large measure, be a review of the author as seen in it, for the making of a man means necessarily the man himself.

Gov. Odell came to the city yesterday from Newburg to attend a dinner given in his honor last evening by G.K. Clark of the Produce Exchange. When the Governor's attention was called to a statement published in a Philadelphia paper that a break between him and Senator Platt was imminent, he said: ...

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 -- L.H. Jones, Superintendent of the Cleveland Public Schools, has devised a plan for receiving contributions from pupils for the McKinley National Memorial Fund that has received the hearty approval of the officals of the National Association. It is pointed out that in the schools attended alike by the children of the rich and poor public offerings often cause suffering to sensitive pupils.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The effacement of a monument is always a melancholy spectacle. When that monument is a literary landmark, the proceedings are doubly sad. One by one the idols of the past to whom we have looked up are shaken from their pedestals.

St. Francis Xavier's Church, in West Sixteenth Street, near Sixth Avenue, now the most important Jesuit foundation in America, is fifty years old, and its semi-centennial will be commemorated by a three days' celebration, beginning with a pontifical high mass to-morrow morning, the Feast of the Immaculate Conception.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Exportation of manufactures from the United States continues to show a healthy growth in nearly all important articles except copper and iron and steel. The export figures just made public by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics show that in the ten months ending with October exports of copper have fallen about $23,000,000 and exports of iron and steel about $23,000,000, making a total reduction in these two classes of $40,445,685.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One doubtless cannot expect that the writers of our latter-day popular novels should possess anything which could fairly be called literary style, or that they should pay much atttention to the subtier points of good writing; but is it unreasonable to demand that they shall at least observe the simpler rules of grammar?

The Board of Estimate held a long session yesterday and heard arguments for and against the plans of experts to relieve the crush at the New York terminal of the Brooklyn Bridge. There was talk outside of the meeting that an attempt might be made by Mayor Van Wyck, Corporation Counsel Whalen, and President Feitner of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, to "jam through" the plans before Jan. 1.

Brooklyn politicians last night were discussing an interesting story involving the appointment of ex-Assemblyman William L. Sandford as Under Sheriff, which was announced yesterday by Sheriff-elect Guden. Mr. Sandford is dangerously ill with typhoid fever at his home, 332 Dean Street, and his appointment was made because it was believed that such action was necessary to save his life or prevent him from going insane.

District Attorney John B. Merrill of Queens County has served notice upon Coroners Samuel S. Guy, Jr., Philip T. Cronin, and Leonard Rouff, Jr., that an investigation has disclosed the fact that Martin Mager, Jr., received more votes for Coroner at the last month's election than Rouff, who received the certificate of election from the County Board of Canvassers, and that they must be careful in the matter of appointments.

-- "Family extravagance" is the excuse, or explanation, given by Mr. CHARLES E. FITCHAM for robbing the First National Bank of Ballston Spa of several thousand dollars. Just what he means by "family extravagance" is not explained in the dispatches, but apparently he intended merely to admit that he had lived beyond his income, and was not trying to shift the responsibility for his thefts upon his wife and children.

When Col. Partridge was asked yesterday if he had decided upon Robert Grier Monroe as his first deputy he replied that he had no announcement of appointments to make as yet, and might not be ready to make any before the first of the year. Mr. Monroe was equally evasive. To a question as to whether he was to be the Deputy Commissioner he laughingly responded:

ANEW edition of Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" is being issued by D.C. Heath Co. It is illustrated by the English artist, C.E. Brock. Edward Everett Hale contributes a preface, and it contains some curious features in connection with the work which have hitherto not been pointed out.

Rosa Bonheur loved animals, and the animals loved her. In fact, she exercised a magnetic power over them. The fierce watchdogs of the house at By were like lambs in her presence. Tame lions she had about her, too, those majestic creatures that she so loved to paint, and whose manes she would smilingly caress with her delicate hand.

The confession, "I know I 'ought' to like such and such a book or author, but I do not," is not infrequently heard from the lips of persons who value the possession of good taste in literature, and concerning authors of accepted standing, and the same confession would be heard oftener if all readers were equally frank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Now that the ratification of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty is practically accomplished, speculation has drifted to the question of routes. There seems to be no doubt that a large majority in each House of Congress favors the building of a canal and prompt legislative action to start the construction.

George Sand's Correspondence Mme. Maurice Sand just before her death had completed the arrangement of the letters of her celebrated mother-in-law, who corresponded with Victor Hugo, Sainte Beuve, Paul Meurice, and other illustrious and eminent men of her time, and they will be published shortly in Paris.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A communication from "Lector" appears in this day's TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, referring to J.F. Smith, the popular novelist of London of nearly sixty years ago. I for the first time hear that he rivaled Thackeray or Dickens. His works were read by more people, without doubt because they were published in a popular-priced journal.

Judge Newburger rendered a decision yesterday afternoon adverse to the interests of Roland B. Molineux. The attorneys for Molineux filed a motion for the inspection of the minutes of the Grand Jury which returned the indictment and to quash the indictment for murder. The arguments on the motion were made before Judge Newburger, ex-Senator David B. Hill appearing for the District Attorney's office and ex-Gov. Frank P. Black for the accused man.

The chief interest of this handsome volume is to be found in the illustrations, which give an excellent idea of the range and quality of the artists represented. These are Matthys Maris, Theophile de Bock, August Allebe, Johannes Warnardus Bilders, Willy Martens, Mrs. Mesdag-van Houten, Alexander Hugo. Bakker Korff, George Poggenbeek, J.H. Wysmuller, J.Voerman, Tony Offermans, and John van Essen, all of them painters of reputation and ability, but Maris only touched with genius.

from The London Standard of Nov. 12. Sir Clements Markham presided over a crowded meeting of members of the Royal Geographical Society, held in the Theatre, Burlington Gardens, last night, on the occasion of a paper being read by Sir Harry Johnston on his travels through the Uganda Protectorate.

From The London Academy. Having read Mr. Graham Balfour's "Life of Robert Louis Stevenson," Mr. Henley finds himself "discontented, dissatisfied, still looking for more." That "more" he gives to the world in the pages of the Pall Mall Magazine, being, as he says, "oppressed by the thought" that in Mr. Balfour's Life Stevenson is shown only as he "may well have wanted to be."

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Loans were made at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5 cents dis- count. Exchanges, $22,453,446; balances, $1,817,446. Money on call rules from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent, to the best borrowers. Time money ranges from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent., according to names and collateral.

ONE od the most fascinating of recent books, which should make a strong appeal to allsorts and conditions of readers, is William Dean Howells's Heroines of Fiction." It makes little difference whether we entirely agree with Mr. Howells's: verdicts, as few of his readers thoroughly familiar with the wide range of fiction he has covered will probably do.

Evidently the time anticipated by J.K. Stephen when "the Haggards ride no more," has not yet arrived, for only last year the popular South African novelist was engaged on a considerable pilgrimage.
