This record ol his Journey will scarcely make its author remembered, as he seems to hope, with Sir John Mandeville, and Chateaubriand.

LIVERPOOL, Dec. 6 -- The fire in the Liverpool Exchange buildings, which broke out this morning as the result of an explosion, was subdued after two and a half hours' work by the firemen. The Chamber of Commerce offices and the Exchange newsroom were chiefly affected. The damage is considerable.

Idyls! Yes; there are the glimpses of that sun God gives to all mankind, but there are many shadows, dark and gloomy ones, and they come not from the Almighty, but from "bigotry, corruption, ignorance, envy, and hate." And the victims, who are they? The Jews, those unfortunate ones who are forced to live in countries where religious freedom is unknown, not understandable.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Sugden, first choice in the closing event at Oakland today, crossed his legs after passing the halfmile post and fell, interfering with Dunblane. Sugden, who is blind in one eye, then ran away three and a half miles. J. Mathews, who rode the winner in the fourth race, was fined $50 for rough riding.

Secretary GAGE'S article in The North American Review on the "Customs Inspection of Baggage" has inspired in advance an interest which it scarcely justifies. By carefully limiting the scope of his paper the Secretary is enabled to make out a very good case for the actual enforcement of the law by the Inspectors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations voted to-day to report favorably the new Hay-Pauncetots treaty providing for the construction of an isthmian canal.

Our esteemed friends of the management of the railroads having their New York terminal in the Grand Central Station may be interested in the views of Mr. LANGDON of the Midland Railway, a very respectable English corporation engaged in operating a line between London and some other towns of local importance.

Lowell and Mr. Watts-Dunton. In an entertaining article entitled "At the Pines," in the current number of The Critic, in which Mr. William Armstrong writes about the life of Swinburne and Watts-Dunton passed as cotenants at that estate in Putney, is found a passage which will have particular interest for Americans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Major Gen. Adna R. Chaffee's annual report, as Military Governor of the Philippine Islands, has been made public. He states that the Provinces of Batangas and Laguna, in Luzon, and the Islands of Samar, Mindoro, Cebu, and Bohol constitute the area disturbed by insurgents.

Senator N.B. Scott of West Virginia, who is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, last night expressed the opinion that all maters relative to the tariff would be referred to a joint commission to be apointed by Congress.

The New York Times Saturday Review of BOOKS: The letter of your Atlanta correspondent Mrs. Bacont published in your issue of the 16th inst., concerning (and giving specimens of) "Dr. Chivers's High-Sounding Verse," causes me to recall the extended review which appeared in your columns early in 1900, under, the caption "Poe and Chivers," of Mr. Joel Benton's volume "In the Poe Circle," (Mansfield Wessels, New York, 1900.)

The Mount Sinai Hospital and Training School properties, on the east side of Lexington Avenue, Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets, have been sold, through Brokers Henry D. Winans May, to David H. Hyman.

IN THIS part of the world we are well acquainted with Mr. Harry Furniss. Long ago as an illustrator he attracted attention, for we are uncommonly sharp in the United States in the appreciation of the pictorial side of a magazine or a weekly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- There was a large attendance on the floor when the House met to-day, but there were only a few spectators in the galleries. After the reading and approval of the Journal Speaker Henderson announced the appointment of the following committees:

Controller COLER rendered a useful public service on Thursday in his informal address before the Chamber of Commerce on the relation which the assets of the City of New York bear to its liabilities. The membership of the Chamber of Commerce includes many of those likely to be influential in shaping public opinion and directing legislation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The local stock market was affected by a fresh outburst of Asphalt securities, which sold at the lowest yet recorded. This depressing influence, coming on top of weakness in New York, caused prices to shade off all round. The losses, however, were trivial, except in Union Traction, which was affected by revived talk of labor troubles.

GIOVANNI SEGANTINI is an an artist of whom we have heard comparatively little in this country. This monument to his memory will attract attention not only from its novelty, but because the life of the artist was interesting and romantic, and especially because his pictures, even as shown in black and white reproduction, are remarkably expressive and have a personal distinction.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 6 -- John Hunter, who is connected with the freight department of the Pennsylvania Railroad at Pier 4 in New York City, was late in getting to his home at Metuchen on Wednesday night. His carriage had been to the station twice to convey him to his home on Middlesex Avenue, three-quarters of a mile distant, and when he failed to appear the family had dinner without the head of the house.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The comment of the weekly journals on President Roosevelt's message to Congress is not generally sofriendly as that of the dailies.

The tenth annual exhibition of fine bindings at the Bonaventure Gallery began on Dec. 2 and will continue until Dec. 9. There was the usual preponderance of French bookbindings, but the present exhibition is particularly notable from the fact of its containing many books which were exhibits at the Paris Exposition of last year.

Scores were imperiled and hundreds badly scared when a young horse drawing a delivery wagon of a large clothing store bolted at some sudden noise and ran down Third Avenue from Twenty-fifth Street early last evening, the driver, George Perry, of 876 East One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, being tumbled into the street at the beginning of the excitement.

In our present issue is published a list of a hundred books suitable to the holiday season. It must not be supposed that this list comprises necessarily the best books of the season. Its purpose is to enumerate the books which most people would be likely to select as Christmas gifts.

Mr. Edward Stratemeyer's "American Boys' Lite of William McKinley" must be read with its title always in mind, for its author mokes no pretense, at rhetorical grace or eloquence beyond what is needed to explain the late President's success in such, terms as a boy can understand, a course causing him to appear so entirely great as to give an aspect almost criminal to a vote cast against him.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- During the four weeks of the grand opera season the Grau company gave thirty performances, and the receipts reached $230,000. It is estimated that 80,000 people attended. The season is now over, and the company is on its way to Kansas City.

Mr. JOHN W. FOSTER is a diplomatist of experience and great learning. It is not the habitual weakness of men of his class to be idealists. Whatever temptation they may have in that direction is likely to be checked by the continuous obstacles it encounters, and if it be not, its expression is generally restrained by an acute sense of incongruity.

Some remarks of ours last week on "Book Advertisements" have struck a responsive chord, and in a publishing house. This we learn from a private letter, the parts of which that are not private we take pleasure in publishing:
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Amsterdam says that Major Van Tets died on Thursday evening.

A short-lived strike which was very lively white it lasted took place on the rapid transit tunnel work yesterday morning. The number who quit work was variously estimated from 400 to 2,000, all "unorganized" Italian laborers. They made noise enough for 5,000 and kept the police reserves on the alert for about an hour.

So far we have known Mr. Frank T. Bullen as the writer of short sailor's yarns, all with a peculiar flavor of Jollity. Careless Jaok was his hero. In the volume "The Apostles of the Southeast" the author occupies the highest ground, for he writes of the regeneration of man through the grace of God.

At the Guimet Museum, yesterday M. Gayet, an Egyptologist, provided a novel entertainment for a select company. He gave a lecture on Thais, the notorious beauty of Alexandria, whose adventures have been described by M. Anatole France, and utilized for operatic purposes by M. Massenet.

Discipline against indulgence, reticence against expression, asceticism against development -- these are the opposing methods of life that present themselves constantly to every human being who tries to attain any sort of ethical ideal, who tries even to get at the secret of happiness for himself. In setting forth the claims of one side or the other most writers fall into errors of exaggeration and exclusion.

Frost, Ernest Seton-Thompson, and others, and bearing the imprint of Charles Scrlbner's Sons, is particularly appropriate at this time, as the heroes of the narrative are now represented in portraits upon the new ten-dollar bill.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Eight indictments against Democrats accused of complicity in alleged frauds in the conduct of primaries held on Sept. 27 last for the election of delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which were presented by the Grand Jury late yesterday afternoon, involved more than that number of men.

COULD the gods of merriment and laughter be imagined as dwelling not only in the man in whom they have incarnated themselves, but also in his immediate neighborhood, the picturesque community of Riverdale on the Hudson must be now peopled with the Jolliest crew of imps and sprites that ever joked together since fun began.

The Corinthian bowlers lost two games in the Columbia Bowling League tournament last night, thereby losing the lead they have held since the opening of the season, and leaving the Rosedale and Oriental teams tied for the first two places.

IN stamping Robert Burns a genius it was as though nature had marked for herself her own Court poet; other singers bad been her interpreters to men, this man should be the minstrel of her secret groves, the Tasso of her own Ferrara; to him she would reveal her heart.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A meeting of Senators and members of the House representing the Pacific Coast States was held to-day for the purpose of agreeing, upon a united policy in the prosecution of legislation for the continued exclusion of the Chinese from the United States. Representative Loud was chosen Chairman and Senator Dubois Secretary.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In taking "notice" of Mr. Gorst's book on "The Curse of Education" in your Nov. 23 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS you admit the presence of a shadow across the "path of modern civilization." The monster intruding itself between the true light and the path, in your opinion, is a tendency to mechanical routine in our education.

The institution of "The Lord's Passover" marked a new era in the history of God's people. Before it was instituted they were divided into families and tribes. After it they became a nation. Before it they were many. After it they were one. It was the bond of union between them. Moreover, with it the Patriarchal Church -- distinguished by covenants and promises -- came to an end.

Clara Morris, in her memories of the stage, touches very lightly on her own per- sonal career apart from the theatre. Born of an American mother and a Canadian father in Toronto, the 17th of March, she tells us how on a certain "St. Patrick's day of sunshine, snow, and rain, of riot and blocdshed, in trouble and poverty -- I was born."

Descendants of the stout Dutch patroons and the stanch English colonists who were citizens of old New York when New York was New Amsterdam -- before the year 1785 -- gathered in Delmonico's last night for the seventy-eighth time, to do honor to the memory of good St. Nicholas.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Eastern capitalists are interested in the formation of a large lighting and power combination, which has been organized in this city with a capitalization of $30,000,000. One of the earliest undertakings of the concern, the name of which is the California Gas and Electric Corporation, will be the amalgamation of the local gas companies.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: To say that I am distressed by the attack which you permit Thomas B. Connery to make upon George Cary Eggleston in your last week's issue is to put it mildly; I am more -- I am shocked. Accuse that dear South Carolina cavalier of booming a fish or fishing a boom -- he does not even know what a boom is!

From these eight tales of earlier authorship than "Foma Gordyeeff," one receives, as in the later work, an impression of strength tumultuous, tremendous, almost volcanic. All but two, "Varenka Olesoff " and "The Khan and His Son," deal with the under world of Russia, the world of poverty, of revolt, of degradation.

From the London Mall. THE announcement that Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan has bought one of the Hobbemas at Dorchester House from Capt. Holford for u25,000 is only one more instance of the process by which the best works of art in England are gradually passing into the hands of American collectors.

Since the days when the ancient Hebrews used daily to offer up their prayer of "Blessed art Thou, Oh, Lord, our God, King of the Universe, who hast not made me a heathen, who hast not made me a slave, who hast not made me a woman," women have passed through many stages of development.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Mr. Wells's Anticipations shows much of the ingenuity which charms us in his stories. He pictures the future much as it was described in his book "When the Sleeper Wakes." At least he prophesies that many of the things which he mentioned in that book will become matters of fact.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The pressure for money relaxed to-day, though a considerable amount was required to repay loans to the Bank of England, which caused firmness. Discounts were stagnant.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 6 -- The eastbound passenger train on. the Oregon Railway and Navigation Line which left this city at 9 A.M. was wrecked twelve miles east of The Dalles this afternoon. The engine turned completely over and the mail car left the track. The composite sleeper and diner also left the rails, but remained upright.

Mr. Henderson's volume on "Richard Wagner, His Life and His Dramas," is the latest addition to the rapidly growing list of books upon the life and work of the greatest musical genius of the nineteenth century. The first part of the volume is devoted naturally to the biography of Wagner.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was heavier than on any recent day. The upward movement in prices was to a large extent checked by decided weaknes in one or two prominent issues, which more or less affected the whole list. A few stocks, however, were conspicuously strong and ended the day with substantial gains.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Frederick Greenwood, who of late has written little for publication, although he is still remembered in some quarters as the author of a life of Napoleon III., published nearly half a century ago, has written a letter which appears in this week's Tatler correcting the statement contained in all the obituaries of Frederick Warne that this publisher introduced "Uncle Tom's Cabin" to English readers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- On the subject of the civilian salary list in the Philippines there appears to be a difference of opinion between the military authorities who have had charge of the islands for two years and certain civilian travelers who visited the islands during the last Summer. Among the latter were many Congressmen, and it is said that some of them think the civil service in the Philippines is overpaid.

This new edition of Mr. Mabie's "Norse Stories" has the added feature of illustrations in color from the brush of Mr. Wright. What Hawthorne did with Graeco-Roman mythology in producing "The Tanglewood Tales," Mr. Mable has done with the legends and the traditions of Scandinavia, which at one time dominated the life and culture of all Northwestern Europe.

What was the type of woman the trouveres sang about and the artists painted? M. Armand Dayot tells us that an altar was erected to the blonde. Her skin had to be as white as "fleur de lis," her hair of gold, and to fall in waves to her ankles, and her lips as roseate as the flowers of the peach.

Well dressed and wearing much jewelry, a handsome nineteen-year-old girl was locked up in the Mercer Street Station last night charged with stealing $1,500 worth of silverware and jewelry in Brookline, Mass. She was arrested in the Gilsey House, Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway, where she had been stopping, by Central Office Detectives Backer and Barnett of Capt. Titus's staff.

From The Humanitarian. The gradual decline in the birth rate since the beginning of the nineteenth century is one of the most striking in social economics. The number of births from 1801 to 1810 -- my figures are those of M. Paul Leroy-Beaulieu, than whom there is no more competent authority in France -- was 32.3 per 1,000: from 1811 to 1829, 31.0; and from 1820 to 1830, 30.8.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Frank Maffino, a wealthy Italian, finding himself with two wives on his hands, endeavored to solve the problem by having both reside with him under the same roof, but he was arrested by the police on the charge of bigamy.

Readers of "Along French Byways" and "Among English Hedgerows," which it may be recalled was presented with an introduction by Hamilton W. Mabie, can hardly fail to enjoy this new book by Mr. Johnson, which, although it may lack something of the spirit of modern Ireland as revealed by the speeches of the Irish members in the British House of Commons, attractively presents that Ireland which is of peculiar interest to the student and artist.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The charge, not of inaccuracy or negligence, but of positive unfairness, is so serious an indictment to bring against a historian that Mr. Ulmann's letter in THE REVIEW of Nov. 16 ought not to pass unanswered. Mr. Ulmann accuses Mr. Fiske of "unfairness," "strikingly exhibited" in Fiske's "American Revolution," and again "of something very much akin to prejudice."

WHY cannot loyalty speak a kind word for poor Hale? Such is an indignant reader's penciled remark in a copy of Lossing "Field Book of the Revolution," belonginff to one of our local libraries. This question, written many years ago, was evoked by Lossing's hope that a suitable monument would soma day mark the spot where Andre was hanged.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- I do not think that we in America know enough or think enough of the literary life of France. Nor do we copy enough of what is most worthy in the life of the most intellectual and most literary people.

In response to a call that was sent out Nov. 27 by a number of prominent Irishmen and sympathizers with Ireland, a conference was held last night at Sherry's, Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, at which decisive action was taken. It was decided to appoint a committee which will proceed actively about the work of raising funds to aid the Irish Parliamentary Party, of which John E. Redmond is the leader.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to extend to your paper the appreciation and thanks of the members of the Polish Educational Society of this city for your interest in the condition or the Polish people in Prussian Poland.

Officials of the New York Central Railroad admitted yesterday for the first time the feasibility of running through trains from the Battery over the elevated railroad and then via the Putnam Division of the New York Central to Yonkers and other suburban points.

Former Governor William J. Stone, or "Gum Shoe Bill," as he is familiarly styled in Missouri, and Col. William C. Wetmore are great friends, and never weary of telling or playing jokes on each other. The following is one at the expense of Col. Wetmore which the former Governor is fond of relating:

From The Yale Review. In the United States 4,000,000 feet of pine lumber is used every year for matches, or the equivalent of the product of 400 acres of good virgin forest. About 620,000,000 cross ties are now laid on American railroads, and 90,000,000 new ties are required annually for renewals.

Much interest has centred around the Vanderbilt issues in the recent market, where most of them have held firmly and where in more than one case sharp advances have been scored on varying rumors of consolidation plans, readjustment of relationship, or division of surpluses in some form or other.

Van Cortlandt Park was yesterday afternoon and late into, the evening the Mecca of those who really know how to skate. The ice on the pond had been officially declared sale and sound, except in two places, where the word "Dangerous " in large red letters placed above the thin ice warned the reckless to be careful.

SOMETHING new in the way of afterdinner entertaining was successfully tried last week at a banquet where the "single-tax" friends of Samuel Seabury, City Court Judge-elect, assembled at the Hotel Marlborough.

PRINCETON. N.J., Dec. 7. -- A very valuable and interesting collection of the publi- I cations of Horace Walpole's Press at Strawberry Hill, his famous country seat, has recently been added to the university library. The collection numbers thirty-six items, of which twenty-seven are books and nine broadsides.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7. -- When Nell Cropsey, the missing North Carolina girl, left Norfolk, Va., on Nov. 23, it is thought in police circles that she came to Baltimore on a Bay Line steamer. Detectives have been hunting for her in this city and vicinity for several days. Yesterday the Norfolk Chief of Police said he positively knew the girl to be alive and well.

In view of the incalculable injury which has been done to the cause of progress in preventive medicine by the widespread popular distrust of vaccine virus and antitoxin serums resulting from the occurrence of tetanus and less dangerous diseases in those vaccinated and inoculated, the apparent apathy of the medical profession is difficult to understand.
IN a down-town law office the other day the senior member of the firm was indulging in a few brief reminiscences.

THE New Yorker, who had been at Kyscrike for a week or two hunting, being ready to return home, handed the tavern keeper a one-hundred-dollar note, out of which to take pay for his bill. The landlord could not change the note. Neither could Deacon Blimber, who was by.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- The Tariff bill goes to committee next week, and nobody expects its reappearance for months. Herren Bebel and Richter and other Opposition leaders have agreed to delay the measure as long as possible in committee. They are determined to make a fight on every one of the 946 item.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The fifty-seventh Congress which met on Dec. 2 will have to decide a number of important questions. Foremost among them is the tariff, on account of its effect on the expansion, of our exportation, and our relation with foreign nations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication signed "Interested" in your issue of the 30th presents no new side to the Sunday saloon question. On the contrary, it reveals a woeful lack of feminine grace and womanly dignity on the part of your correspondent which is all the more blamable because of that "college training" of which she boasts.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 7. -- It was an odd find H. W. Reiter came upon while I taking a spin with an iceboat on Lake Calhoun. Near the west shore his attention was attracted by something black which fluttered about on the ice. He found the object to be a large loon. In some unaccountable way one of its wings had frozen in the ice.

A movement has been started on the low er east aide to extend the work of the Young Men's Hebrew Association. A meeting was held in Pleasure Palace Hall, 52 Attorney Street, at which plans were discussed for the organization. Adolph Stern was elected Chairman of a committee to draft a constitution and by-laws.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As to the Sunday opening or closing of saloons, I desire to quote as a general text these words of George Lord Lyttelton: "A wise Government will know where to yield, as well as where to resist; and there is no surer mark of littleness of mind in an administration than obstinacy in trifles.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- M. Lazare Weiller, Councilor of Foreign Commerce, who, with M. Maurice La Gotellerie, an engineer, has been intrusted by the Government with the task of making a special investigation of American trusts, told a representative of the Associated Press to-day that he would also make inquiries in aid of the Government's plan of organizing an industrial college.
WHILE it is a popular belief that every millionaire has his private car, it is a fact that many of them and the wealthiest of all do not own them, but are content to hire one as occasion may require.

To the Editor of The new York: Times: In the belief that THE NEW YORK TIMES is a forum for free discussion of questions affected with a public Interest, I make bold to ask room in your columns for a few remarks on the Amalgamated Copper Company.

THE Judicious may, and doubtless will, grieve over the strengthening of the dramatized novel in the affections of the New York theatrical manager but the dramatizer goes merrily on Last week there were no less than seven "dramatic versions'' of stories of novels presented here for edification of the public.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 7. -- The Railroad Warehouse Commission to-day held an executive session at the close of which the Secretary, A.C. Clausen, sent to the InterState Commerce Commission a letter cancelling the appointment made for a conference of the two commissions for next Tuesday in Washington.

LODON, Dec. 7. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Central News announces the arrest at Sofia, after a violent resistance, of a man named Halju, who is alleged to be the assassin of ex-Premier Stambuloff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Many months ago there was an almost universal outburst of indignation from the residents of the upper west side because of the threatened destruction of the beautiful elms, more than a generation old, that lined the centre of the Boulevard, (Upper Broadway,) the fate of which the construction of the subway had decreed to be inevitable.

YOUNG Mr. Kubelik has already been described as a reincarnation of Nicola Paganini. This is not fortunate for young Mr. Kubelik. because it conveys to the minds of many rersons the impression that the youth is a mere trickster of the fiddle. This is the popular idea of Paganini, an erroneous idea, to be sure, butone that cannot easily be removed.
CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 7. -- At a meeting of the Charleston Racing Association held here to-day it was determined that no foreign book should be made upon the Exposition track.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It does seem singular that this Nation, and that through its Executive head, should still advocate the complete exclusion of the Chinese people. No man of unbiased judgment, who has traveled in other Eastern countries and included China in his observation, but has been deeply impressed by that people.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The rumors about opposition to the Nicaragua Canal from Senators who favor the Panama route till continue, but if there is any considerable number of such Senators they are conducting a still hunt at present. One of those who are mentioned as favoring the Panama route has declared himself openly a Panama man.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Philadelphia, a city supposed to be governed by a bad set of politicians, is in one respect far ahead of New York. Any New Yorker who will take the trouble to observe the deportment of the policemen who patrol the streets of the Quaker City will discover that they are polite, civil, and considerate.

The progress of railroad earnings toward expansion may be said to have started with the beginning of the fiscal year 1897, or nearly four and one-half years ago, during which period the monthly totals, as far as it has been possible to compile them from partial returns made, have shown but two decreases as to gross and five decreases as to net.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Seeing that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company has made application to extend its lines, I am reminded of what was told me in Montreal about six years ago regarding the traction system of that city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I must ask you to pardon my presumption in taking the liberty to intrude upon the limited time you can afford to spare from your manifold duties, your legion of correspondents; but my gratitude is so sincere and heartfelt that I must find vent for it in a letter of thanks,
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 7. -- Syracuse friends of Willie Dineen say he has signed with Collins's American League team.

NOWADAYS, when a baby arrives in one of the homes of the rich or well-to-do in New York, it often happens that a little basket is regularly delivered at the door every day thereafter, containing a number of glass bottles, tightly stopped with sterilized cotton. In each bottle is one meal for the little newcomer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Miss Alice Roosevelt, returned to Washington to-day, entirely recovered from her recent slight illness. In consequence of the illness of Mrs. Roosevelt's secretary, Mrs. Cowles's private secretary will assume charge of Mrs. Roosevelt's correspondence and engagement book for the present.

From The Denver (Col.) Times. A summing up of the recent elections in Colorado shows, that the Republicans elected a majority of the county officers and control the Boards of County Commissioners in a majority of the counties. The returns show beyond a doubt that with a united Republican party in the State there is no doubt of Republican success.

Mr. N. Kanzaki, Japan's Japan's Great special Commissioner of Industrial Foreign Exhibits for the Exposition, fair at Osaka in 1903, will shortly arrive in this country from Germany and exert his efforts to interest American manufacturers in Japan's enterprise.

The annual six-day cycle race will be started in the immense amphitheatre of the Madison Square Garden live minutes past midnight to-night by the flash from a pistol held by "Young Corbett," the new featherweight champion pugilist, and for 142 hours the contest of speed and endurance will continue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have observed in THE TIMES your editorial approval of the course of the Postmaster General with respect to second-class mail mater, which I think has been given without due consideration of this important matter.

Company E of the Seventh Regiment, after winning the Nesbitt trophy for the last four years, added another victory last night which will give it one leg toward holding the cup through the year 1902, as the cup is competed for semi-annually. The cup was won in the fortieth annual regimental games held in the armory of the Seventh Regiment, Park Avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets.

One of State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh's men met with determined resistance one day last week in endeavoring to serve at the Appraiser's Office a subpoena in an election fraud case. The deputy was Robert A. Kelly, who is connected with the Citizens' Union.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present unsettled condition of the money market, and the fact that gold has been going out of the country when, according to all precedents, it should be coming in, must be very confusing to those people who have unbounded faith in the current theory of the disappearance of our trade balances.
IT was the Librarian who was speaking. He studies both books and men.

WHEN he had finished rending his scientific journal the literary man thoughtfully stroked his nose and said it was "funny" to see all the pretty stories of history were being exposed as so many fabrications.

"YOU can always tell a woman's financial status by her coat linings." says a bright girl. "She may have, to all appearances, the smartest of tailormade coats, it may have the trade marks of a fashionable tailor In every seam, apparently, and you will murmur to yourself that it did not cost less than $85 in good hard cash -- that is if you don't know.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- Money rates bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as below: Clearing House rate, 3 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount: call loans, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.; Clearing House exchanges, $22,668,194; balances, $1,860,692.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or valuev exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two articles by "Englishmen" which appeared in your edition of the 30th have been of great interest to me. Especially so were the allegations that the "English were incapable of" committing the outrages with which they have been charged in South Africa. No facts are forthcoming to refute the very definite assertions of gross barbarity.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- The weakness in New York somewhat affected prices here to-day, but the effect was seen more in a heavy contraction of business than in any material inroads upon prices. Interest reverted almost entirely to the arbitrage stocks -- Reading, Pennsylvania, and United States Steel -- which moved closely on a parity with the New York quotations.

Two boys were arrested by the police of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station last night charged with burglary after they had entered a flat house in Harlem, stealing jewelry worth $400 and frightening badly a boy who was alone. The prisoners, are Joseph Albertson, sixteen, of 727 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, and Morris Sachs, thirteen, of 76 East One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street.

WHEN the firm failed every cent owned by the family was gone and the young woman, scarcely within her twenties, had had no practical education. She was an exquisite pianist. Music lessons she decided upon. The only trouble was where to get the scholars.

In a few days the Sub-Treasury will receive a couple of million dollars in newly minted gold, silver, and copper, coins and newly printed greenbacks, which will be exchanged with those desiring them for use as Christmas presents. Each year the demand in the city and the adjacent country grows greater for new money to be used for this purpose.

Lester Reiff, the American jockey who was ruled off the English turf by the Jockey Club, charged with suspicious riding, was among the arrivals on the Cunarder Lucania yesterday. Accompanying him was his brother "Johnnie." who rode the horse that won the race which caused the trouble. Previous to this both boys had been successful, and "Johnnie" finished the season well up in the list of jockeys.

The Central Railroad Company of New Jersey -- Jersey Central as its more popular title goes -- has been a rising and prominent feature in the market lately, the stock, usually a somewhat dormant one, having been actively traded in and the price sharply advanced on what has the appearance of merit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Nov. 18 of an abstract of a sermon preached by Bishop Burke of the Diocese of Albany on the proposition of the Episcopal Church to change its name to the Catholic Church of America has led to considerable discussion, and not a little annoyance to the Bishop.

TO the woman who has spent the best years of her life in a quiet country town in the East a mere suggestion of coming to a frontier country is terrifying. But this is the class that make the best of the wild, unrestrained manners of border life when once they get into it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your recent exposure of the condition of affairs in the Building Department has already done an incalculable amount of good, but the writer, for one, earnestly hopes that you will not relax your efforts, but will follow the matter up to the end.

Staten Island is much interested in a dramatic entertainment which will be given by the Athletic Association of Westerleigh Collegiate Institute Hall next Friday evening. The programme consists of two light comedies, "The Benicia Boy" and "The Box of Monkeys." The Wester- leigh Orchestra, conducted by Prof. L. Llewellyn Griffith, will be one of the features of the evening.

TRENTON, Dec. 7. -- There is a well-organized movement in the capital to give Governor-elect Franklin Murphy an inauguration that will be notable. The plan comprehends not only a civic and political parade but it, is to be dignified by a very generous turn-out of the National Guard of the State.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The general expectation of sensational disclosures in Maitre Labori's explanations of his rupture with Dreyfus has thus far been disappointed, as he announces that his lips are sealed toy professional secrecy from telling the story of the factual breaking of relations with the Dreyfus family.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports at general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of the Rev. H. Lustig, D. D., in Friday's TIMES recalls the experience of a colored preacher in the South. He was a practical man, and endeavored to make the religion which he preached applicable to the everyday life of his people.

The first week in December has come and gone, with its initial preparations for the January disbursements, and yet there has been no disturbance to the money market. Time money has ruled practically unchanged, while, setting aside a momentary flurry in call money on Thursday to 6 per cent., call rates have been no higher than at any time recently, the average figure being 4 1/2 per cent.

JUST how long seeds will live is a question that is attracting much attention among the scientists, gardeners, and horticulturists of Europe at this time. The discussion was started by the publication of a story that a handful of peas found in a sarcophagus of the Pharaohs, who died 3,000 years ago, had been planted and had grown.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from "Interested" on the Sunday opening question in your issue of Nov. 30 arouses sympathy and a desire to help. No doubt there are many cultured wives whose homes are blighted and happiness destroyed by the husband's indulgence in the social glass.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- In an intensely bitter anti-American article The Saturday Review to-day advocates German-English friendship for the purpose of holding the United States in check. Emperor William, it declares, sees in the growing German population, of Chile and Brazil the inevitable necessity for future interference which, "in any form, involves a conflict with the United States."

Police Captain Thomas J. Diamond, now suspended from duty in the Fifteenth Precinct, will next Tuesday morning be tried by Commissioner Murphy in his private office at Police Headquarters for having been convicted of a crime, namely, criminal neglect of duty in not performing aduty enjoined by law on him as a public officer.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The domestic infelicities of European royalties have never come so prominently before the public as have to-day the difficulties of Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherland, the dramatic circumstances of which form one or the chief topics of conversation. The romantic halo surrounding the young Queen and the keen interest taken in her marriage only help to accentuate public curiosity and sympathy.

A number of important changes in the standing of the teams in some of the principal local bowling leagues were made by the games of the past week. The Corinthians, who were leaders in both the Columbia and the American National tournaments, suffered defeats and lost first places in both series, the Mohawks coming to the front in the Columbia League and the Metropolitans in the American National series.
Army. Major William B. Schofield. Paymaster, upon the completion of the payments on muster of Nov. 30, 1901, will proceed to San Francisco for temporary duty.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Postmaster General Smith had a conference with the President to-day, at which the last of a batch of about 500 Post Office appointments were decided upon.

MRS. REGINALD BROOKS (Miss Phyi. lis Langhorne) was seen the other day in a charmingly simple frock of bright yet deep blue serge that set off her petite girlish figure to perfection. The shirt touched all around and was not full, not yet did it outline the figure as so many of the new costumes do, but was just Bracefully scant.

Herr BEBEL, the Socialist leader in the Reichstag, must be a bold man. To our notions of German notions of individual freedom, it seems strange that such a speech as that of which we printed yesterday the cabled summary should have been allowed to be made. It was indeed freely and often outrageously interrupted but only by the individual and irritated junkers who are "behind" the Government measure.

Another play by Clyde Fitch will be the only new offering of the week in theatricals. The controversy between Mr. Fitch and Mr. Nethersole, manager for Miss Sadie Martinot, seems to have been agreeably settled, and "The Marriage Game," it is announced, will open at the Victoria Theatre on Tuesday evening.
THE monkey is entitled to a position or dignity if not of trust.

Yesterday afternoon at Delmonico's a reception was given by the Governors of the Wednesday Cotillions to the patronesses of these dances for the coming season, and who are Mesdames John Burling Lawrence, Edward A. Stevens of Castle Point, Oilyer Livingston, Jones. John C. Calhoun, Thomas Randolph Price, John W. Boothby, and Samuel Spencer.

To The Editor of The New York Times: You have certainly done good public service in permitting your various correspondents to express their opinions on the momentous question of opening the saloon on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- An important conference was held at the War Department to-day in regard to the legislation necessary to meet fiscal conditions in the Philippines as a result of the recent insular decisions of the Supreme Court. There were present Secretary Root. Senators Lodge of Massachusetts and Platt of Connecticut, and Representatives Payne and Dalzell.

The first week in the billiard tournament for the world's championship at eighteen-inch balk line ended with the game last night between Slosson and Barutel, the Frenchman. Slosson won this match by 40 points, while in the afternoon contest Leonard Howison won his only victory in the tournament by defeating Ora Morningstar.

Commissioner of Buildings James G. Wallace will have to appear before Supreme Court Justice Miles Beach on Wednesday next to show why he is allowing alleged violations of the Building Code in the construction of skyscrapers. The order to show cause why a peremptory writ of mandamus should not issue to compel the Commissioner to take such action as will prevent further violations of the Building Code was signed yesterday by Justice Beach.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 7. -- School Superintendent Kindall has instructed eighth grade and high school teachers to insist upon students reading President Roosevelt's message. He considers a close perusal of the document a good opportunity for the study of current history, civics, and English.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- The municipal campaign, with its exciting and enthusiastic rallies on both sides, was billed to close tonight, but there will be Sunday political gatherings and conferences and actual work will not end until the polls close on Tuesday afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 7. -- Among the many improvements at the Westchester Polo Club for next season will be a new clubhouse. The building is about ready. There will be also a new running race track, which will be fifty feet wide and five-eighths of a mile long. The polo field is in excellent condition.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 7. -- There's just a suspiclon of Winter in the breezes that come through the pines these clear sunny days. A few stray snowflakes come to town on Wednesday, and that night a thin coating of ice formed around the shores of Lake Carasaljo. The cottage set and the hotel guests are awaiting with almost as much impatience as the small boys the announcement that the ice is thick enough for skating.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As Secretary of the Committee of One Hundred of the Republicans of New York I receive daily many inquiries about what is meant by direct nominations by the people. As your paper reaches a great number of intelligent voters, the valuable space in your columns is respectfully solicited for a partial explanation.

From The Forum. At Ostende the admission fee is 20f., which operates to exclude nearly all persons excepting those who wish to play, whereas at Monte Carlo the gambling rooms are generally overrun with curious spectators.

Much of an encouraging nature has taken place the past year or two that might be cited in proof of the fact that the Wabash Railroad as a property and as a money earner has greatly improved. Revenues have increased, more than had been possible before has been done to raise the physical condition of the road, and in spite of heavier outlays there has been a steady expansion in net earnings.

THERE is something very ingenuous about President Loubet which attracts almost all foreigners -- a quaint, almost childlike desire to be liked, very evident even to those who merely pass him in the street, and which explains at once why tho Empress of Russia was so drawn to him.

The Brooklyn Health authorities and the Coroner's office of that borough are about to investigate the case of a boy who had been treated at the Long Island College Hospital for a fractured skull and was removed after being there for two weeks to the Kingston Avenue Hospital, suffering from scarlet fever.

A TAIL OF A CAT. A FEW evenings ago a stray cat caused a great deal of trouble for the International Traction Company and the Niagara Falls Power Company. She climbed a trolley pole of the Buffalo and Lockport Electric Railroad at Hoffman, a village just west of Lockport, and undertook to walk along the feed wire, using her tail as the tight-rope walker uses the balancing pole or the Japanese an umbrella.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7. -- After many exciting adventures in Oriental waters, having narrowly escaped foundering, the transport Sheridan is safe in port. With several Congressmen on board and a large number of sick and discharged soldiers, the Sheridan left Manila fifty-one days ago mound for San Francisco.

From the Bulletin of the American Geographical Society. The white men were arbitrary, not only in prices, but in other things also. Doubtless, also, the natives were often exorbitant in their demands. When the differences became extreme the native chiefs called in the aid of Ukuku.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- An ugly fight is probable in the Senate over the confirmation of George Koester, a young Gold Democrat and personal friend of Senator McLaurin whom President Roosevelt recently appointed Collector of Internal Revenue for the District of South Carolina.

The conclusion of the Merchants' Association Committee on the Bankruptcy Law that only necessary amendments, based on actual and definite experience of defects, should be proposed is sound. On the whole, it is generally agreed that the law has worked a great improvement on the condition of things previous to its passage.
Commissioner William Dalton of the Water Supply Department yesterday made public his annual report of the business and operations of the water system for the year ending Sept. 30, 1901.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 7. -- The first formal competition of the season on Country Club links to-day attracted one of the largest handicap crowds which have ever played over the club links. Ventors, the new instructor, had the course in fine condition, and the day was perfect for sport. Twenty-five played the double round, and all but four reported cards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to John E. Hamilton, who writes in to-day's TIMES, the Boer war is once more nearly "over." He says that there are now only a few thousand Boers left, whom the British are gathering in at the rate of 400 a week, while no less than 30,000 are prisoners in the British camps.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- The matter of the application of ex-Police Captain James McLaughlin of the Yonkers police force for a peremptory writ of mandamus directed to the Police Commissioners of the City of Yonkers to reinstate him as Police Captain and Chief on the ground that he was illegally removed was heard by Supreme Court Justice Martin J. Keogh to-day.
Natives of the State of Missouri resident in New York, were well represented at a gathering at the Hoffman House last night when a permanent Missouri Society of New York was organised.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Bravo, Mother of Four!

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The "Cabinet crisis" man was at work last night. He sent out from Washington a story that there was unpleasantness between Secretary Gage and President Roosevelt. "Insiders," he said, believed the President was endeavoring to make Mr. Gage's position so uncomfortable that he would be forced to resign.

Deputy Commissioner of Corrections Fanning called at the Tombs at 10 o'clock last night and asked for "Warden James J. Hagan. He was not there, however, nor were the Deputy Wardens, Flynn and Curran. Mr. Fanning then sat down and wrote the following letter, which he left on the Warden's desk:
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Government disbursements increased the supply of money today, but the inquiry was not extensive. Discounts were easy.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Gage's plan for bank-note issues, as printed in your columns, seems imperfect in certain matters of detail.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 7. -- George Bissert, the convicted "wardman," formerly of Capt. Diamond's precinct in New York, arrived at Sing Sing Prison at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon to begin his sentence of five years and six months for bribery. Bissert was in custody of a Deputy Sheriff, who also had in charge John Williams, convicted of election frauds.

The Cunarder Lucania and the American liner St. Paul, both from English ports, got in yesterday morning, after having for nearly twelve hours engaged in an exciting test of speed on the Atlantic. It was early Friday morning, about 2 o'clock, that the lookout on the bridge of the St. Paul, which at that time was ahead, made out the lights of the Cunarder.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Neither the most conservative nor the most progressive London financiers with whom I have talked this week expressed agreement with the recent utterances of The Times's financial columns in regard to American credit abroad.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Mrs. Anna Zabriskie, wife of John P. Zabriskie, a wealthy poultry farmer of Ridgewood, disappeared from home yesterday. Her husband and family have searched this city all day without result, and the supposition is that the woman has either committed suicide or gone a long distance, as she had considerable money in her possession.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- Edward J. Mathews, President of the American District Telegraph Company, a prominent banker and broker and clubman of this city, was thrown from his horse and instantly killed this afternoon. Mr. Mathews was returning to his country residence at Valley Forge from the Radnor Hunt breakfast at Chesterbrook Farm.

PINEVILLE, Ky., Dec. 7. -- Berry Howard, for two years hunted under indictment charging him with complicity in the murder of William Goebel, Democratic contestant for the office of Governor, and a cousin of Jim Howard, who was sentenced to death for complicity in the same crime, was arrested this afternoon by Sheriff Henry Broughton.
DURING the past few days there has been a good deal of quiet talk among the safe men of New York about the extraordinary occurrences in the office of a manufacturing concern of Lynn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Such a striking phase of history has been manifested during the year 1901 that to the observant mind it suggests a comparison with the year 1776. In 1776 the American Nation was born politically. In 1901 it seems to have begun a process of moral or spiritual birth or rebirth. The elements of the history can be definitely stated as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Pandemonium broke forth afresh on the Board of Trade to-day. Prices for all the grains went skyward, high records for the season were badly broken, and there was more activity and excitement and a greater amount of business transacted than there has been during one session for many months.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7. -- The local market to-day was influenced by the weakness in Wall Street, but the effect was more, in the matter of hesitancy in buying than in any hurry to sell. The volume of business was small and so were the price changes, because holders offered no more than the market was able to absorb at approximately Friday's, prices.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7. -- Hiram Woods, for many years a prominent sugar refiner and largely interested in real estate, died today. He was born in Saco, Me., in 1826, and came to Baltimore when sixteen years old.

From The Era. The bandit is the Macedonian hero. The admiration of him is inbred. Greek independence was won by bandits inured to fighting and marches, not by townsmen. The Greek national costume to-day the resplendent uniform worn by the King's crack regiments of "Euzones" -- is that of the Albanian brigand.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 7. -- Liabilities approximately $1,000,000 and assets of unknown and apparently undiscoverable value is the critical condition in which the Omaha Loan and Trust Company finds itself today. Edward Battle, a Philadelphia bond broker, representing creditors of the institution to the amount of $500,000, is here making an investigation of the affairs of the company.

NEWARK, N.J, Dec. 7. -- Attorney General Gray, representing Commissioner of Banking and insurance Bettle, yesterday obtained an order from Vice Chancellor Reed in Trenton enjoining the Washington Co-operative Bank of New Jersey of this city from further transaction of business pending the determination of an application for the appointment of a receiver for the concern.

Dispossess notices have been served on the tenants of an up-town apartment house because they refused to pay their rent twice over. With the service of the notices, though they stated that the persons served are not required to vacate before the fifteenth of the month, gas, water, and heat were cut off, suffering being thereby caused to several families.

Five of the fifteen wall paintings dealing with the Quest of the Holy Grail took their places in the Boston Public Library some years ago. Mr. Edwin A. Abbey has finished the remaining nine, and after showing them in London at the art gallery of the Guildhall, will exhibit them till the 21st at the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 7. -- No less than 200,000 Russian infantry and cavalry have been quietly mobilized in Manchuria, in other Chinese provinces, and in Southern Siberia, according to statements made today by Capt. I.K. Jacques or the English Army, who arrived yesterday on the steamship Shinano Maru.
Last week's business furnished additional evidence of the substantial character of the present activity in the real estate market.

NEW YORK Chinamen, will be without an official arbiter in any matters they may have under dispute for some time to come: The Chines Consul here, Chow Tsscki obtained leave of absence and left a few days aga for China.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7. -- The past weak has been a particularly gay one in Baltimore, the season having been formally opened by the ball of the Bachelors' Cotillion Club on Monday night. After the cotillion Dr. Thomas Shearer gave a supper at the Stafford in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Jr., and Miss Laura Patterson Swan of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Board of Trustees of the McKinley Memorial Association met here to-day, Judge William R. Day of Canton presiding. Among those present were Cornelius N. Bliss, New York; Senator Hanna, Ohio; Henry C. Payne, Milwaukee; Myron T. Herrick, Cleveland; Alexander H. Revell, Chicago; Gen. Henry M. Duffield, Detroit; George B, Cortelyou, Washington; John G. Milburn, Buffalo; Senator Fairbanks, Indiana; Robert J. Lowry, Atlanta, and Henry T. Scott, San Francisco.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Andrew M. Lawrence, managing editor of the Chicago American, and H.S. Canfield, a reporter, who were sentenced recently by Judge Hanecy to forty and thirty days, respectively, in the county jail for contempt of court, were discharged from custody by Judge Dunne to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Sousa's success here has exceeded all expectations. He has now arranged with Philip York, his present English manager, to return here June 26 for a season of twenty-five weeks. Part of this time will be spent on the Continent.

There was a bad break in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, under the lead of Amalgamated Copper, which has been the bete noire of the stock market for the past few months and has had most depressing and distressing effect. In this Copper break many fortunes have been lost by those who have been forced to part with their holdings in the issue.
The Insurance Company of the State of Pennsylvania has withdrawn from the State of Maryland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to answer Dr. B. S. Talmey. In your issue of Nov. 29 on the question of morality and law Dr. Talmage makes the point that the Prohibitionists are enemies to reform and true progress. Permit me to say in reply that the Prohibitionists as a whole are reasonable and only insist on the enforcement of law as it appears on the statute books.

When Man and Beast Contended. THERE is at the corner of Bushwlck Avenue and Meserole Street. Williamsburg, a saloon where "hunters assernble to tell of their own prowess and of the skill of friends. Ninety-nine pair of antlers adorn the walls, and to each one there is attached a story.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 7. -- Walter E. Brown, a twenty-two-year-old telephone boy in the Milwaukee branch office of Bartlett, Frazier Co. of Chicago, disappeared this morning before it was discovered that he had sold calls on the firm for $5,000 bushels of wheat without reporting the same.
COLON, Colombia, Dec. 7. -- Gen. Alban, the Colombian commander, returned here early this morning on the British cruiser Tribune from Bocas del Toro, and went to Panama at 8 A. M.

FEW things in New York society are less homogeneous than a theatre crowd. The kind of pleasure sought at a dramatic performance varies, one might almost say, with every spectator. Some go there simply to drive away the day's cares, and all they desire is to spend the evening in, the midst of bright surroundings;

Chief Wilkie of the United States Secret Service Bureau, who has been in Boston attending the trial of John Lavigne, a counterfeiter of cents, stopped over here Saturday night on his way to Washington in order to personally extend to Chief Operator Flynn of the local department of the service his congratulations on a capture which the latter had accomplished.

OMAHA, Dec. 8 -- President A.U. Wyman, head of the Omaha Loan and Trust Company, admitted to-day that a conference of Directors had been held to seek means of relieving the company's financial embarrassment. As a result of the meeting it is announced that no receiver's help will be required at this time.

With the rolling of the initial games of the Bronx Royal Arcanum Athletic League and Arcbdiocesan Union tournaments last week the local bowling season reaches its height, and though several important leagues have not yet begun their season, they will, in most cases, take the place of tournaments now in progress.
Dr. Howard Agnew Johnston of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church preached yesterday morning on "Our City's Crisis."

"Mr. and Mrs. Slow" shed their Summer raiment yesterday morning. "Mr. and Mrs. Slow" are the two big rook pythons in the new glass snake ten in the monkey house in Central Park. When the very early visitors to the monkey house arrived they noticed that the two big snakes looked particularly glossy and bright, and undulated about the floor of the den in a very dignified manner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- George E. Roberts, Director of the Mint, has completed his report on the operations of the mint service during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1901. The coinage during the year amounted to 176,999,132 pieces, of the value of $134,340,781. Of this $99,065,715 was in gold, $24,208,850 in silver dollars, $10,966,648 in fractional silver, and $2,009,568 in minor coin.

John B. Merrill District Attorney of Queens County, who secured the conviction of Patrick McCarthy on a charge of keeping a disorderly house, said last night that he had received notification from Gov. Odell that there had been filed with the Executive a petition requesting the Governor to set aside McCarthy's sentence on the ground that the District Attorney had used improper means to convict the man.

In the presence of a record-breaking crowd of 12,000 people, which occupied every seat of Madison Square Garden and filled the vast amphitheatre almost to suffocation and clung to every point affording a view of the track, sixteen professional bicycle riders, representing nine of the principal foreign nations of the earth in addition and a half dozen sections of this country, started last night in the annual six-day cycle race.
BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- Thomas W. Lawson issued to-night the following statement:

-- Superintendents and Principals of the Chicago public schools are much disturbed over a charge by one of their number that they and their teachers use "frightfully" inaccurate language in the class room. He objects especially to such locutions as "Take three from eleven and eight remains."

St. Francis Xavier's Church was yesterday morning the scene of solemn and imposing services, the beginning of a four-day celebration to commemorate the golden jubilee of the dedication of the first church built on this site. In the morning was held pontifical high mass, succeeded by a vesper service for children at 4 o'clock, and finally the day was closed by a solemn benediction at 8 o'clock.

An important review of the history of the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers of the United States is given in The Quarterly Journal of Economics, published for Harvard University. It is written by the Hon. CARROLL D. WRIGHT, United States Commissioner of Labor, who is entirely friendly to what is known as "organized labor" and has a reputation for ability and great candor.

In the discussion which has been waged before and since the recent election about excise legislation, for New York City, which would permit of the Sunday opening of saloons, the statement has been repeatedly made with positiveness that the sentiment up the State was practically unanimous in opposition to any amendment of the Raines law.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 22 -- The Ministry of the Interior yesterday issued another statement about the famine. Five and a half million poods of Winter grain and 3,000,000 poods of Summer grain have been purchased and forwarded to the needy districts. The total grain purchases are given as exceeding 10,000,000 poods, for which 10,000,000 rubles ($3,150,000) has been expended.

The City Club has started a movement to stop the letting of any questionable contracts by the Tammany administration between now and the 1st of January, when the administration of Seth Low will take charge of the Municipal Government. A committee appointed by the Council of the City Club has been in conference with a similar committee of the Independent Club of the Twenty-first Assembly District, and a plan of action has been agreed upon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I regret exceedingly that through your editorial columns the attack made by Prof. Hyslop upon the State Commission in Lunacy in reference to the Pathological Institute should come to the notice of the public. For your comments lend importance to a matter which otherwise would have received but little attention.

The new champion of the Van Courtlandt links is Gilman P. Tiffany, a Columbia freshman and a former champion of the Powelton 'Golf Club at Newburg. He will hold the new Morosini Cup for the first year and receives a gold medal in addition.

Detectives Brady and Manning of Capt. Titus's staff last night asserted that they had arrested Max Goesche, thirty-one years old, who says he lives at 219 Bowery, in the act of robbing a McKinley memorial money box in a saloon at Delancey Street and Bowery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Speeches expressing disapproval of British methods in the South African war were heard with close attention by an immense audience in the Auditorium Theatre here to-night, and resolutions' for the appointment of a committee to bring the sentiments of the meeting before President Roosevelt were adopted.

Financial and railway circles are animated by reports current yesterday that official announcements are about to be made of important developments along "community of interest" lines. One of these -- foreshadowing at least one new and big combination -- is that a new President is about to be elected by the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad.

When the patient and resourceful hunter has labored for hours at the mouth of the cave, continually adding fresh fuel to the fire and seeking by the combustion of strange herbs and unusual substances to impart an acrid and unpleasant quality to the smoke, with what eager-joy he notes the first sounds of uneasiness and discomfort within.

Exercises to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the arrival of Louis Kossuth in America were held in Lenox Lyceum last night by the Hungarian societies of New York. The exercises included music by a Hungarian Gypsy Band, vocal music by Hungarian singing societies, and speeches, and the unveiling of a life-size portrait of the Hungarian patriot.

Meetings of the Association of Naval Militias of the United States were held Saturday afternoon and yesterday morning on board the United States receiving ship New Hampshire, off the foot of East Twenty-fourth Street. At these meetings discussions were held on the bill introduced in Congress by Congressman Foss of Illinois, which provides for the organization of a National Naval Reserve.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The annual report of the Department of Banking and Insurance relating to building and loan associations contains a general statement as to the operation of these organization. The total number of domestic associations in the State is 364, as against 360 last year.

A year ago, when everybody was excited to an unnecessary degree over the question of a vast and profitable increase of the exports of American coal to Europe, the evident demand was sharply checked by the fact that it was much easier to sell coal to European customers than to deliver it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The approaching session of the Legislature promises to bring forth the usual crop of changes in the road laws and of course of proposals of loans of millions to rebuild the roads and of a large appropriation for pieces of roads scattered all over the State as object lessons for next year and beginnings of network of highways for our grandchildren's use.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- The Boerse did not show a uniform tendency during the past week; while there was a bull movement in domestic shares, industrials were exhausted. Foreign rentes continued to rise, and domestic banks likewise made further advances. These latter were supported by Vienna, where the strong demand for rentes enabled the banks of Berlin advantageously to dispose of their holdings in these securities.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass, Dec. 8 -- Harvard men are somewhat out of patience with Yale because of certain reports which it is believed by them have emanated from there recently relative to future athletic relations between the wearers of the crimson and the wearers of the blue. All talk about there being no necessity for Yale to meet Harvard in all branches of athletics is considered absurd.

Alice in Wonderland is outdone nowadays in an up-to-date toy shop. It is not a question of which animals can talk, but which cannot. Small things in papier mache in the shape of animals of all sorts and kinds would startle the beasts in a real zoological garden. Lions, tigers, bears, horses, cows, dogs, cats, mules, ducks, and chickens can each speak in its own language and without an accent.

A general strike is threatened in the Rapid Transit tunnel to-day, on account of complaints made on behalf of the pavers and bluestone cutters employed in the Degnon-McLean Company's sections, at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union. These pavers and bluestone cutters are not employed directly by the Degnon-McLean Company, but by Patrick Costello a sub-contractor.

In the parlor of his brother-in-law's home in Brooklyn last night young Herbert Marx, who shot three men in defending himself from attack on the family plantation in Virginia on Tuesday night, told the story of his trying experience. Marx told his own story of the affair upon the return last evening of his brother-in-law, Abel E. Blackmar, from Virginia.

That Wardman Bissert was allowed special privileges in the Tombs -- that although turkey, chicken, and everything good to eat was sent in to him he was still allowed to eat at the Warden's table -- proved yesterday to be the principal charge against Warden James J. Hagan of the City Prison, for which Deputy Commissioner N.O. Fanning, suspended him on Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The only measure of importance which the Senate has on its calendar for the present week is the new Hay-Pauncefote treaty making provision for the abrogation of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty and opening the way for the construction of an Isthmian canal by the United States.

As was to be expected, a strong opposition was developed before the Board of Estimate to the plans of the appointed experts for relieving the pressure at the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge. What was not to be expected was that much of this opposition should be so recklessly expressed as to discredit it.

Col. George W. Dunn, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee, came to the city last night from his home in Binghamton. He will be at the Republican State Headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel during the week. Col. Dunn's attention was called to a report that Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff was being suggested as Senator Platt's successor in the Senate at the expiration of the Senator's term on March 4, 1903.

The Schwarzschild Sulzberger Company, large meat packers, at Forty-fifth Street and First Avenue, are shortly to reconstruct their plant here on the plan of their Chicago branch which has just been completed.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- The filing of a suit for divorce by Dora S. Mounce against Jesse T. Mounce, her husband, clears up a mystery which has puzzled residents of one section of this city since April.

Bishop N.C. Matz, Roman Catholic Bishop of Denver, Col., who, while in Rome recently, was accused by Father John Gushing, formerly of Denver, of trying to introduce the German language into the Catholic service, was one of the passengers who arrived on the French liner L'Aquitaine from Havre yesterday.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: Intending, of course, to speak with perfect respect of the President, it seems to me that the least strong part of his message, so far as the merits or demerits of the subject are concerned, is that relating to the merchant marine.

Through the arrest of Margaret Thompson, at Mount Vernon on Friday, the Brooklyn police believe they have been able to apprehend the leading members of a gang which for months has been systematically robbing houses in the suburbs of New York.

A correspondent in another column presents some interesting facts in regard to "Highway Law." He represents the views of the Highway Alliance, whose purpose is "to increase the usefulness of highways," and which has a strong and intelligent constituency.

The Presidents of the clubs that compose the National League of Baseball Clubs will hold their annual meeting beginning to-morrow. This is the most important meeting held in years. A new President is to be elected to succeed Nicholas Young, who has held the place for ten years, and who is not a candidate for re-election.

"Sally," the last of the orang-outangs in the New York Zoological Gardens, in the Bronx Park, which were made famous by the human -- like intelligence displayed by Rajah, has fallen a victim to the same disease that carried off the others of the tribe, and is very sick. That she will ever recover is doubted by the garden officials, and Superintendent Hornaday states her malady is incurable.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 8 -- Messrs. Langhenry, Korpf, Thompson, and Brill of the American Bowling Congress conferred today to consider the situation regarding the coming National tournament brought about by the demand of Dr. Timm of New York that, a deposit of all prize money the made by the managers of the Buffalo tournament.

However unpleasant it may have been to holder's of stocks frightened or obliged to sell as a result of Friday's and Saturday's collapse in prices, it is an undeniable fact that the stock market's position, technical and otherwise, has been measurably improved by the liquidation and short selling which were then so much in evidence.

Calling his sisters and brothers angels and saints, Augustin Helm, a portrait artist, twenty-four years old, who lived at 724 East One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street, was removed to Bellevue Hospital last night, where he was placed in the insane ward, hopelessly insane, the physicians say.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Mrs. Roosevelt held a reception this afternoon from 5 to 6 o'clock, for fifty or sixty invited guests. Mrs. Cowles and Miss Alice Roosevelt assisted in the blue parlor, and Miss Root, Miss Knox, and Miss Anne Hitchcock took turns at the tea table in the red room. Among the visitors were the British Ambassador and Lady Pauncefote, Ambassador Choate, Mrs. Choate, and Miss Mabel Choate, and Senator Depew.

The annual Fall meeting of the National League, in many, respects the most important in the history of baseball, will begin to-day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. With the exception of the Philadelphia owners, all the Presidents of the different clubs, were in town yesterday. Col. Rogers and A.J. Reach, representing the Philadelphia Club, will be in town early to-day.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 9. -- Col. John Doniphan, a veteran of the Mexican and civil wars, and for fifty years prominent in the affairs of Missouri, died at his home here to-day. Col. Domiphan was born in Ohio in 1826. He was an Odd Fellow of National reputation, and was the first President of the Kansas City, St. Joseph and Council Bluffs Railroad.

The dispatch from Copenhagen to The London Times, which we published yesterday, assumes that our principal motive, for acquiring the Danish West Indies is the acquisition of the harbor of St. Thomas. The economic situation of the islands, the writer adds, is bad account of the fall in the price of sugar And evidently he regards the islands as a liability rather than an asset.

After a period of depression, due to the early weakness in Amalgamated Copper and a sharp flurry in call money rates to 6 1/2 per cent., the stock market yesterday shortly after noon became decidedly strong under the lead of Copper and the Gould stocks, which on very aggressive buying jumped up in a manner strongly suggestive of the upward movements which were the feature of the bull market following Mr. McKinley's re-election.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- It seemed for about a second this afternoon that there was a possibility that Senators McLaurin and Tillman of South Carolina would resign from the Senate forthwith.

A case involving the disappearance of a defendant in bankruptcy proceedings, who disappeared after the United States Marshal had delayed serving him because of a promise of his lawyer to produce him, the examination by the lawyer in court and the subsequent reappearance of the man, will come shortly before Theodor Aub as referee.

The inquest into the death of little Emiline Dale, whose mother, Elizabeth Howe Dale, has been under arrest in Hoboken under suspicion of having murdered the child on the morning of Nov. 19 in Busch's Hotel, ended last night and resulted in a verdict exonerating the mother.

Michael J. Callahan, formerly an Assemblyman and liquor dealer, who is now manager for James Freeman's saloon, at 12 Chatham Square, has filed a petition in bankruptcy, with liabilities of $24,280 and no assets. The liabilities were contracted in 1896, and include twenty judgments which have been obtained against him since.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was active and prices were stronger than they were at the close of last week. Further gains were made by some stocks which remained strong, while most of the list had been declining, and substantial recoveries occurred in some other issue. The strength of Amalgamated Copper on the Exchange was a favorable influence, and brought about an advance in some of the copper shares on the curb.

The week began well with the Bagby musicale at the Waldorf-Astoria, a meeting of the skaters at the St. Nicholas Rink, and finished with a dance for Miss Newbold at the Metropolitan Club, and the meeting of the Cotillion of Eighty. New York is very full just now, and there are few fashionable people left in the country.

PARIS, Dec. 9. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Minister of Finance, M. Caillaux, replied to criticisms of the Budget proposals, and to the pessimistic predictions of the adversaries of the republic. He said that after 1815 the debt had increased by milliards until the Third Republic, whose finances during the past fifteen years had been flourishing.
BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Mr. Lawson issued a significant statement to-day, just when the Street began to hear favorable rumors regarding a settlement of the copper war. It was this:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-live cents, additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
