WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Chairman Payne (Rep., N.Y.,) of the Ways and Means Committee presented to-day to his Republican colleagues of the committee a revenue tariff bill for the Philippines. The measure had been drawn to meet the conditions of the recent Supreme Court decision.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Though the trading in the Philadelphia market to-day extended over a longer list of stocks than are usually active, the erratic movement in Wall Street restricted business to a low ebb in the morning, and the greater part of the list closed the day with losses. In the last hour the Asphalt issues began to improve, the American fives running 1/2 above Saturday.

The week on which we have just entered promises to be an eventful one for the interests identified with the great speculation in copper. The trouble is all the more serious because the management of the Amalgamated Copper Company has adhered to a policy of silence which leaves it and interests behind it open to charges which discredit them and depress the stock.
LONDON, Dec. 9. -- The supplies of money exceeded the requirements to-day. Discounts were steady.

The State Railroad Commission yesterday resumed at the Fifth Avenue Hotel the hearing on the application of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company for a certificate declaring the construction of the proposed road to be a matter of necessity and convenience.
Educational circles in New York yesterday were surprised and highly pleased at a report that a great National university, lavishly endowed, was to be founded in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- President Roosevelt reappointed Cornelius Van Cott to be Postmaster at New York to-day.

The Rev. William J. O'Kelly, pastor of the Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel, at 230 East Ninetieth Street, died yesterday from the results of blood poisoning at the parsonage adjoining the church. While at Rockaway Beach a number of weeks ago Father O'Kelly carelessly handled a fishhook, which accidentally entered his thumb.

Statements were made yesterday by A.B. Blackmar, brother-in-law of Herbert Marx, the young Brooklyn lawyer who shot three men of a party who had attacked him in his country home in Oak Grove, Va., tending to show that the victims of the young Brooklynite's trusty revolver had come to his home to burn him at the stake.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- A coterie of revivalists by the name of the Portsmouth Campmeeting Association, who have been holding services of an extraordinary character in Park Street Church since Friday, were ordered out of the edifice this afternoon.

The congestion of grain at Buffalo, representing some twenty-five millions of bushels of wheat in elevator or on its way to that point, with an eastward movement of only about a million bushels a day, calls attention to the fact that the trouble at the moment is less a scarcity of cars on which to load it than a scarcity of engines with which to move the cars when loaded.

When the first day of the six-day cycle race in the Madison Square Garden expired at a few minutes past midnight last night four of the sixteen teams which had made the start just twenty-four hours before were already out of the race, leaving but twelve pairs to continue the monotonous grind around the wooden oval.

Only one more day of billiards remains to decide the world's championship, and the final matches will be played this afternoon and evening in the Concert Hall of the Madison Square Garden. Schaefer and Morningstar will meet in the earlier part of the day, and the closing match will be between Slosson and Schaefer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Senator Frye today introduced the new Ship Subsidy bill. It differs in form from the subsidy bill of the past two sessions, and is divided into four titles and fifteen sections.
SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 9. -- The most serious of the many riots that have taken place here in connection with the streetcar strike occurred this afternoon on Luzerne Street.
The Municipal Realty Corporation has bought the five-story American basement dwelling, 20 East Ninety-fifth Street.

-- We do not see why Dr. M. ALLEN STARR should "regret exceedingly," or even at all, the fact that we transferred to this column the substance of certain charges made in The Medical Record by Prof. HYSLOP of Columbia in regard to the treatment of the Pathological Institute by the State Commission in Lunacy.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 9. -- H.J. Fleishman, cashier of the Farmers and Merchants' Bank of this city, has disappeared with a sum of the bank's money, which Vice President H.W. Hellman estimates at $100,000. The shortage was discovered to-day.

About the only feat as yet uncertain of accomplishment in the operation of a submarine torpedo boat will be attempted tomorrow by the recently completed but already famous Fulton, which will start from her anchorage in Peconic Bay, on Long Island Sound, on her 450-mile trip on and under water from New York to Washington.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers announced a decision yesterday regarding an anatomical model of a man, nearly six feet in height, which was imported for the Medical School of Maine, a department of Bowdoin College. The model is made up of about one hundred pieces, which can be taken apart and replaced as desired.

The disclosure of some things which have been happening in the Tombs, and which were first hinted at late on Saturday night when Deputy Commissioner Fanning wrote the note suspending Warden James J. Hagan, was taken up again yesterday, and nearly everybody who really has a knowledge of what has been going on made a statement.

Sympathetic notice of the death of the German Emperor's mother at the annual dinner of the British Schools and Universities Club, at Delmonico's recently, brought the following telegram, received by Dr. John A. Irwin, the President of the organization, yesterday:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Washington Post to-morrow will say:

WARWICK, N.Y., Dec. 9. -- Lewis A. Riley, Vice President of the Lehigh and Hudson River Railroad Company and President of the Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company and of the Lehigh and Lackawanna Railroad Company, has been chosen President of the Lehigh and Hudson Railroad Company, to succeed the late Grinnell Burt of Warwick.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Dec. 9. -- First Lieut. F.W. Altsaetter of the Engineer Corps, stationed at Fort Leavenworth, had some interesting experiences with the negro deserter, David Fagin, who was reported this morning as having been killed by native scouts in the Philippines. Altstaetter's West Point class ring was found on Fagin.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 8 and 10 cents discount. On call money rules at 4@5 per cent. Time money rule from 4 1/2 per cent, Upward. The supply at 4 1/2 is limited and applies only to the very choicest grade of collateral.

Representative BALL of Texas sees in the trusts a monster that to be captured needs but to be cornered. Accordingly, he has introduced three bills heading off the trusts in three different directions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The Western Jockey Club has withdrawn the ban which at the opening of the season it placed upon the tracks in St. Louis. At the annual meeting held here to-day it was decided to admit as members of the club the club department of the St. Louis Fair Association and the Delmar Jockey Club of St. Louis.

How is this for a chinchilla bonnet? The rim of the fur and the crown of dark-green leaves with funny round, green buds. Perhaps a botanist would know what they are intended to represent, usually the milliner does not. Anyhow, they are stylish.

Amalgamated Copper was again yesterday the centre of interest on the Stock Exchange not only because of a curiosity to see how the stock would act, but also because of the many reports bearing upon the copper trade, the Amalgamated Company figuring in some form or other in practically all of these reports.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A bill was introduced to-day by Congressman Arthur S. Tompkins of New York, which the author thinks would provide a uniform, secure, and elastic banknote currency. At cording, to this bill, banks, would receive their charters from the States in which they are located.

The regular monthly meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club was held at Sherry's last evening. Mrs. Hilborne L. Roosevelt and Mrs. Robert Abbe received the guests, of whom there were about 450. Dr. E.R. L. Gould, President of the club welcomrd the National Arts Club, members of which were to speak on the subject of the evening, "Public Art."

Capt Thomas J. Diamond, late of the Fifteenth Precinct, was placed on trial before Police Commissioner Murphy yesterday charged with having been convicted in Albany County of neglect of duty in not suppressing a disorderly house, which, under the Public Officers' act, is a criminal offense.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The North Atlantic Squadron, in its southern cruise, will stop at some Venezuelan port not yet determined, the itinerary being purposely left incomplete. The appearance of a German squadron in Venezuelan waters will have considerable influence in determining the movements of our own.

Most readers will probably be surprised by the announcement that our trade has suffered more than that of any European Power by the disturbances of the past two years in China. Yet that announcement is officially made by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, and there ought to be nothing surprising about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- All the wives of the Cabinet members except Mrs. Hay, who was out of town, called on Mrs. Roosevelt this morning, Tuesday being the established day for what is facetiously termed the "female cabinet meeting."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 10 -- Miss Elsie Gaylord, who is regaided as one of the most beautiful women in Louisville, and John C. Latham, of the firm of Latham, Alexander Co. of New York, were married this evening at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. John H. Brand of 1,405 Third Avenue.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- The ranking committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association has completed a list of the official ranking of the Lawn Tennis players of the country. It follows:
In the tournament of the National Bowling League last night the Fidelia bowlers won three games from the Mutual team The scores:

The bursting of a 48-inch trunk water main at Fifty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue at 9:30 o'clock last night flooded that section of the city between Park and Madison Avenues, and from Fifty-third to Fifty-ninth Street Millions of gallons of water swept through the streets, running to waste and leaving a trail of havoc in its wake.

There was a big spectacular play and a great personal triumph for Director Heinrich Conried, who took the leading part Konig Karl IX., in the play "A Carnival of Blood," at the Irving Place Theatre, last evening. This in the German is "Die Blutnochzeit," a four-act trauerspiel, by Albert Lindner.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- Col. Carroll H. Potter, a veteran of the civil and Spanish wars and a widely known retired officer of the, regular army, died yesterday at a hospital here of apoplexy, after an illness of three weeks, Col. Potter had resided in this city since his retirement last year. He was born, in Rhode Islanad in 1838 and was appointed to the West Point Military Academy from Massachusetts.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- The Democrats completely overwhelmed the Republicans in the city election to-day, Gen. Patrick A. Collins being elected over Mayor Thomas N. Hart by the largest plurality in a quarter of a century. The Democrats also obtained control of both branches of the City Government, elected their Street Commissioner, Salem D. Charles, and practically all their candidates for School Commission.

The Civil Service Reform League, which holds its annual meeting in Boston to-morrow and Friday, is the representative of the movement, for the general adpption in the Federal, State, and Municipal Governments of this country of the principle embodied in the Constitution of New York that all appointments to the civil service shall be made for merit and fitness, the movement for what is generally known as "the merit system."

Jacob Kerskowitz, thirty-five years of age, and Paul Muller, a boy, presumably about seventeen years old, both living at 69 Rivington Street, were arraigned yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Shields on the charge of manufacturing whisky without a license. They were held in $2,500 bail each for exaroination Saturday.

When the meeting of the National League adjourned last night after midnight, practically nothing had been done except the formal award of the pennant to the Pittsburg Club by the Board of Directors. The League's Directors met In the afternoon, and out of courtesy to members who had engagements elsewhere, adjourned until the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Senator Gallinger introduced in the Senate to-day a bill to protect the President, Vice President, persons in the line of succession to the Presidency, and Ambassadors and foreign Ministers. Before presenting it, he explained that the bill was prepared by Edgar Aldrich, United States District Judge of New Hampshire.

Two more teams withdrew from the six days' cycle race In the Madison Square Garden yesterday, reducing the number of the competing pairs to an even ten, but there is every indication that the weaklings are now all weeded out, and that the teams now in the race will stay until the finish.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Andrew Carnegie's proposed gift of $10,000,000 for educational purposes was discussed at to-day's meeting at the Cabinet. It was stated after the meeting that the President had received a communication from Mr. Carnegie on the subject of the creation of a fund for the extension of higher education.

Senator TILLMAN of South Carolina did not appear to advantage in his unseemly Strangle with Senator MCLAURIN, and came very close to having his own right to a seat in the Senate called in question. This was more than he probably expected, and Senator HOAR'S calm analysis of his somewhat equivocal position will be likely to cause him to restrain as much as possible his natural tendency to turbulence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The New York Democratic members of the House are not hopeful that the policy which they outlined in the resolutions they submitted to the Democratic caucus will be adopted by the minority. They have little inclining them to the belief that the Southern and Western Democrats are considering favorably their propositions.

Up to the last half hour of trading yesterday the stock market, though irregular, was inclined to strength un- der the lead of Amalgamated Copper, the Gould, and the Vanderbilt stocks. While, with the exception of Copper, which at one time rose four points, there were no remarkable advances, there was, nevertheless, consistent and persistent firmness resulting from what the Street declared to be buying by the larger banking interests.

Deputy Police Commissioner William S. Devery was again arraigned before Justice Holbrook yesterday. Ex-Policeman Edward O'Neill was again placed on the stand and again underwent a severe cross-examination at the hands of Abram I. Elkus, attorney for Devery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee agreed upon a Philippine tariff measure to-day. Later the entire membership of the committee, Democrats and Republicans, was called together for the first time.

Lyman S. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury, has requested the resignation of Wilbur F. Wakeman, Appraiser for the Port of New York. The request did not come as a surprise. THE NEW YORK TIMES several weeks ago exclusively announced that Mr. Wakeman was to go, and that George W. Whitehead of Niagara County, who has been serving as Collector of Customs at San Juan, Porto Rico, would be his successor.

Net changes in the market for outside securities yesterday, were in few cases important. The general tone of the market was firm, and such variations as did occur were mostly on the side of advances, but these in few cases amounted to as much as 1 point. Trading was not as active as on Monday, but the market was fairly broad, and a good many stocks were dealt in.

The feud between the officials of the Tombs resulted yesterday only in bringing to light what the political strength of Warden Hagan is; a rather hazy suggestion that another prison other than the Tombs -- possibly Jefferson Market -- may be investigated if Deputy Commissioner Fanning's plans do not miscarry, and finally explanations between Mr. Lantry and Mr. Fanning.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 10 -- During the high wind which prevailed this morning the two-story frame factory building, 130 by 50 feet, in course of erection for the Essex Ice Company, at Oakwood Avenue and he Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad tracks collapsed with hardly an instant's warning.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 10, 8, and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $24,272,545. Balances, $2,163,786. Call money rules from 4 to 5 per cent. There is very little demand for time money, borrowers preferring to wait until after Jan. 1.

A cigarette, carelessly, dropped into the recesses of an ancient haircloth sofa, started a blaze, on Broadway near Thirty-first Street, last night which threatened the destruction of the Bijou Theatre and threw thousands of people into a panic that lasted for an hour.

Donald W. MacLeod, head of the firm of D.W. MacLeod Co. of 293 Church Street, Manhattan, died on Sunday at his home, 786 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, of a complication of diseases, after a long illness. Although Mr. MacLeod's death occurred on Sunday, it did not become known to most of his friends until yesterday, when announcement of it was published.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10 -- Charles Selvage, who was local manager of the Niagara Fire Insurance Company of New York, has begun a suit for $200,000 damages against the company.

Secret Service men engaged in running down the daring thieves who stole money and stamps to the amount of $75,000 from the Chicago Post Office, after tunneling under the building and cutting through the steel base of the main stamp safe, yesterday announced the arrest of Charles Stokes of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Routine busineas, such as the presentation of petitions, memorials and bills, monopolized the Sengate's open session to-day; Then there was an executive session, on motion of Senator Lodge, who has charge of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty.

The explanation, which seems to be quite authentic, given by Mr. CARROLL D. WEIGHT of Mr. CARNEGIE'S latest and most remarkable benefaction, again vindicates the shrewdness which attends and regulates the benefactor's benevolence. Sir GEORGE CORNEWALL LEWIS'S famous remark that "Philanthropy is the basest passion of our nature," so far as it had any foundation, was doubtless founded upon observation of the positive mischief done by unregulated benevolence.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The report of Treasurer Packard of the University of Pennsylvania Athletic Association shows the total income from athletics at Pennsylvania during the year ended Sept. 1 to have been $110,201,45. Football was the only paying sport, the profit being $59,012.

W.K. Aston has bought the O'Sullivan estate property at the southeast corner of Wall and Pearl Streets, and will erect thereon a twelve-story office building. The plot, which is now covered by old four-story structures, has frontages of 72.10 feet on Wall Street and 61.7 feet on Pearl Street.

Jacob Schaefer won the world's billiard championship at eighteen-inch balk-line last night in the final game of the tournament played in the Concert. Hall of the Madison Square Garden. He beat George Slosson by 400 points to 335 in a forty-nine inning game. While not as short as some others in the contest, the match was thoroughly worthy of a championship final.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A blow at the Fairbanks organization in Indiana by President Roosevelt was the political sensation here to-day. Senator Fairbanks has been nursing a Presidential boom for the last year. During the McKinley Administration his sway in Indiana was absolute. He could have everything he wanted, and the entire patronage of the State was in his hands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The new members from New York have as a whole, no reason to complain of Speaker Henderson's treatment of them in the matter of committees and some of them seem very well pleased. Three of them, Douglass, Hanbury, and Pugsley, were placed on important committees. Douglass and Pugsley are on the Banking and Currency Committee and Hanbury is on the Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Prince Ferdinand Radziwlll, an aged aristocrat, in whose veins flows the blood of the ancient Kings of Poland, spoke of the wrongs of his people in the Reichstag to-day.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- A railroad company which includes among its Directors officials of the Pennsylvania and Long Island Railroad Companies was incorporated to-day to operate a railroad line through an underground tunnel connecting New Jersey with Long Island. The name of the company is the Pennsylvania-New York Extension Railroad Company and its capital stock is $1,000,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Internationals were quiet on the Boerse to-day, though Spanish 4s attracted some attention. Canadian Pacifics were depressed in spite of the increased traffic returns. Banks were dull. Mines were steady. Navigations were in good demand on rumors that a pool was being formed among the companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Democratic Senators to-day held their first caucus of the present session. Its purpose was to consider committee assignments, but the occasion was more than ordinarily significant because of the general attendance upon the caucus. All the Senators elected as Democrats, with the exception of McLaurin of South Carolina, were present, as were all the Senators who were elected as Silver Republicans or Populists.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- A fashionable choral wedding took place this afternoon in St. Peter's Church, Germantown. The bride was Miss Mary Raymond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Warren Raymond, and a granddaughter of Henry J. Raymond, founder of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the bridegroom, George Thomas Lambert, son of Major William H. Lambert.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Money was much wanted in the market to-day in connection with the Settlement. The payment of a call for L1,000,000 of the New South Wales Ican hardened rates. The weakness of foreign exchanges and the appreciable increase in the number of bills stiffened discounts.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A military correspondent of The Times, in a message sent from Pretoria, declares that the statements that the British troops in South Africa are "stale" are untrue. He says, on the contrary, that the men are in splendid condition, and, though they would be glad to get home, they have not lost their zest for fighting.

Those whose memories are not too short for their own advantage will recall with profit the industry with which speculators having an interest in doing so labored during August and September to create a panic over the partial failure of the corn crop. The evil consequences to follow this calamity were pointed out in language borrowed, or imitated, from the writings of the prophet JEREMIAH.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Considerable progress was made to-day by the Presbyterian Revision Committee, which is preparing a brief doctrinal statement of faith. The important subjects regarding the person and work of Jesus Christ, and regarding also the person and work of the Holy Spirit, were given careful attention and the further subjects of Justification.

Fraley C. Niebuhr. Fraley C. Niebuhr died at his home, 336 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, last Tuesday, in the eighty-second year of his age. Mr. Niebuhr had been in failing health for the last two years. He was born in Philadelphia, Nov. 11, 1820. At an early age he came to New York, and when fourteen years old became connected with Custom House brokerage.

The six-day cycle race in Madison Square Garden now seems to have settled down to a test of the endurance of the ten teams remaining in the competition, each of which seems content to plug along at an easy gait, sprinting only when there seems to be a chance to catch the others napping and quickly slackening the pace when the attempt is seen to be a failure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- At a meeting of the Ways and Means Committee to-day Chairman Payne was directed to report favorably to the House the Philippine Tariff bill, which the Republican members of the committee agreed upon yesterday. The report will be made Friday, and the bill will be considered in House next Tuesday, with a vote at 4 P.M. on Wednesday, instead of on Tuesday, as at first planned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The long-expected report of Special Commissioner W.W. Rockhill to the Secretary of State on the results of his work in connection with the negotiations at Peking has been submitted to Congress, together with the full text of the protocol, which has already been published, and a mass of detailed statements.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- Money was quoted today at the local Clearing House at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 8 and 10 cents discount. Call loans are mostly quoted at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent. Exchanges, $30,733,761; balances, $2,039,984. National banks are not seeking time loans to any extent.
John D. Crimmins, it was learned yesterday on authority deemed reliable, has concluded not to take the appointment of Park Commissioner for Manhattan and Richmond offered to him by Mr. Low.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 11 -- Unusual interest is apparent in the conference of the American Federation of Catholic Societies, which began here yesterday. The interest centred in the framing of the new Constitution and by-laws to render the federation acceptable to all the old societies and also to the hierarchy.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11. -- The market to- day was dull and a shade easier in sympa- thy with the irregular swings in New York, thy the day's declines were limited mostly to fractions. Only four issues scored gains. They were all bonds Georgia and Alabama consols 5s and South Bound 5s both advanced a full point.

Considerable irregularity in prices showed in the outside market yesterday. Transactions were larger in some parts of the list than has been usual of late, but the general total was not above the average of the past few days. The copper stocks as a whole were not active and did not hold an important place in the day's trading.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 11 -- The Right Rev. Thomas F. Gambon, rector of St. Patrick's Catholic Church in this city and Vicar General and Chancellor of the diocese of Louisville, died suddenly at his home to-day of heart disease. He was sixty-four years old and a native of Ireland.

Rumors were current yesterday to the effect that a large parcel in the Wall Street district had changed hands. The deal, as report in financial circles had it, consisted of the purchase of the Imperial Insurance Company's Building, 31 and 33 Pine Street, by Kuhn, Loeb Co., whose twelve-story structure adjoins the Imperial Building on the west.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 11 -- One of the most beautiful as well as important weddings of the season in Baltimore, and one, in which a large proportion of society here and elsewhere was interested, took place to-day, when Miss Elizabeth Anderson Pennington was married to Henry Chapin Halle of Springfield, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Cannibalism has appeared in the varied list of crimes charged against Filipinos by American military courts. According to the record of a court-martial convened in the Department of the Viscayas, Raymundo Fonte, a native, found his working companion, Liberato Benliro, sleeping in his (Fonte's) boat.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- J.W. Spencer of Columbia University again at the Sportsmen's Show compelled E.C. Schaeffer to excel the American record in order to beat him for the five-hundred-yard indoor swimming championship of America. Schaeffer swam the distance in 6 minutes 513-5 seconds.

Justice Jerome was seen last night at the Union Club and asked what he had to say in reply to the statement issued by District Attorney Philbin yesterday, in which Mr. Philbin declared against Sunday opening.

A knock-out blow practically was given to the pet plan of John T. Brush for a Baseball Trust yesterday, when the National League Presidents resumed their session in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. After an executive meeting that did not break up until after midnight Tuesday night, the baseball men were not particularly early in getting around in the morning, and the second day's conferences did not begin yesterday until nearly 3 o'clock in the afternoon.

Major Gen. Leonard A. Wood, Governor General of Cuba, sailed for Havana yesterday afternoon on the Ward Line steamship Yucatan. Gen. Wood came to this city Monday night from Washington, where he had spent several days conferring with President Roosevelt and Congressional leaders.

Capt. Thomas J. Diamond, who was convicted by an Albany jury on Nov. 27 of neglect of duty in falling to suppress a disorderly house, was dismissed from the New York police force yesterday afternoon by order of Commissioner Murphy. Lawyer F.B. House of the ex-Captain's counsel said at once that the order of dismissal would be fought by means of certiorari proceedings in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Dec. 11 -- Andrew Farabaugh, class 1904, nephew of President Charles M. Schwab of the United States Steel Corporation, has been elected Captain of next year's football eleven at Lehigh University. Farabaugh played tackle this Fall.

A.J. Cassatt, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, confirmed yesterday the announcement that the Pennsylvania Railroad would build a tunnel under the Hudson River instead of building a North River bridge in order to secure an entrance into this city and to connect with the Long Island Railroad.

Commissioner NAGLE of the Department of Street Cleaning is very unhappy. If he wanted to sleep o' nights he could not. Probably he has more congenial nocturnal occupations -- but that is beside the fact. He knows the city streets are being neglected and that property owners and taxpayers are after him with uncomfortable insistence.

It is indicative of extremely loose management in the Water Department that it should have needed two hours to locate and close the gate valve controlling the forty-eight inch main which burst on Tuesday evening and did an amount of damage which will probably cost the city a great deal of money in the settlement of judgments.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Lord Kitchener's promised statement, specifying thirty-seven separate instances in which natives have been shot by the Boers, and which involve the loss of eighty-four lives, was issued by the War Office last night.

WINSTED, Conn., Dec. 11 -- Connecticut women holding stock in the Adams Express Company, think that the company is of the opinion that they are in need of some spending money for the holiday season. Many of them in the State have receivcd letters from the company offering to buy their stock at 190, either all or any part of their holdings.

At Calvary Church yesterday there was a double wedding, the first which has taken place in society in a long time. The two daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Beach Turner were married, Miss Mary Esther Beach Turner to W. Nathaniel Foote and Miss Anna Tracy Turner to Carl Christian Lorentzen.

The game of billiards as it is played by experts is so rapidly modified that "the record" is of very little use in estimating the latest performances. All the modifications that have taken place in the American game, within the past twenty years, have had for their object to make the game harder for two ex- perts, SCHAEFER and SLOSSON, and to give other players an opportunity of competing with them on even terms.

District Attorney Philoin has been frequently asked to express himself with regard to the opening of the liquor saloons on Sunday, and yesterday he consented to make a statement. Considerable interest attaches to Mr. Philbin's attitude in this matter, as it is well known that he stands as close, if not closer, to Archbishop Corrigan than any other public official in New York City.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 11 -- A plan conveying hope to thousands afflicted with tuberculosis was approved by the State Board of Health to-day. The board will ask the Legislature for aid. Full details of the plan have not been given out yet, but it is proposed to have a system of sanitariums, to be located in various suitable parts of the State.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Continuing the tariff debate in the Reichstag to-day. Count von Kanitz, the Agrarian leader, declared that "the shaping of Germany's commercial relations with America will be the most important task before the country for the next decade." He further said that the United States, Great Britain, and France were by no means convinced of the expediency of concluding commercial treaties of long duration.

The State Railroad Commission yesterday, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, closed the hearing on the application of the New York and Port Chester Railway Company for a certificate that the construction of a four-track electric railway between this city and Port Chester is a public necessity and a convenience.

With the notable exception of Amalgamated Copper, which closed for the day at a fractional net advance, practically every active security on the Stock Exchange declined yesterday under the pressure of liquidating sales and selling for the short account -- the liquidation either being induced by the higher call money rates, the figure at one time rising as high as 10 per cent., or being forced, as prices went lower, by the exhaustion of margins.

Yesterday was one of receptions, and the only large dance of importance was the Wednesday Cotillion at Delmonico's. The wedding of the day had the novelty of being a double one. There were any number of "at homes," including those of Mrs. Cornelius G. Fellowes, Mrs. Bayard Tuckerman, Mrs. Benjamin Blossom, Mrs. Victor Newcomb, and Mrs. Charles Prentice Kellogg.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- When the Senate met to-day the House's concurrent resolution providing for a holiday adjournment from Dec. 19 until Jan. 6 was referred to the Committee on Appropriations. The Senate then went into executive session to consider the Hay-Pauncefote treaty.

Senator FRYE'S new Ship Subsidy bill appears to be in the main an extension of the policy of mail subsidies adopted ten years ago. It is a very different measure from the Frye Ship Subsidy bill which failed in the last Congress. The former bill provided for the payment of $9,000,000 a year for a period of twenty years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- In the local stock market the tone was much better today and only the depressing influence of New York advices prevented lively bidding up of the local issues. As it was, there was substantial betterment in many stocks, and the trading was over the longest list in many a day.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Much of the mystery concerning the plans of the Trenton and New Brunswick Railway Company, which was incorporated yesterday at Trenton with $1,000,000 capital, has been cleared up. The scheme, as it now appears, is to build a third-rail electric system between New York and Philadelphia, of which the twenty-three miles between Milltown and Trenton, specified in the charter filed yesterday, is an important central part.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 11 -- The organization of the Connecticut Tobacco Producing and Trading Corporation, with a paid-in capital of $115,000, is announced. Under the strict new Connecticut laws the company proposes to begin the shade-growing of Sumatra tobacco on a large scale, as recommended to American capitalists by the Secretary of Agriculture in his recent report to President Roosevelt.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says the physical weakness of the people of Annam and Tohquin is being attributed to the absence of phosphate in their rice diet.

In the National Bowling League tournament last night the team of Our Council, Royal Arcanum, won three straight games from the Caledonian five. In the Greater New York tournament, Carroon's high score of 246 was equaled by Cordes and Mcincken. The scores:

Miss Mary de Peyster Carey of 12 East Forty-first Street, a daughter of the late Samuel T. Carey, appeared yesterday morning in the Jefferson Market Police Court to press a charge of begging against a young woman. The prisoner, who said that her name was Annie Kramer of 169 Orchard Street, was found to be Jennie Gold of 8 Allen Street, at which address she lived with her parents.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 11 -- W. H. Woods and a woman companion called True Johnson, both negroes, were arrested here to-day, charged with having stolen from Alfred B. Lowenthal, a traveling salesman for a New York jewelry firm, in a hotel of Portland, Oregon, diamonds and jewelry worth $15,000.

Fire that started about 1:30 o'clock this morning in the rear of the five-story building at 198 Broadway, occupied by the Dennison Manufacturing Company, did damage estimated at $300,000 in less than an hour's time.
O'Brlon Russell have been appointed Boston agents of the Home Insurance Company of San Francisco.

LOCKPORT DEPOT, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- Miss Estella Morley or Stella Louise Nicholas is heiress to two large estates as a result of a lawyer's mistake in drawing her adoption papers. Miss Nicholas is a Monroe County girl. She was born in Ohio, but spent the greater part of her life in Los Angeles, Cal., where she was educated.

That is a well-meant bill which Senator FORAKER has introduced into the Senate, intended to give the franking privilege to the widow of President McKINLEY. In so far as it is designed to benefit or to honor Mrs. McKINLEY, there will be no opposition to it from any quarter.

It would be dishonorable and in bad faith to attempt to force political opinion in Cuba for the purpose of changing her relative position in reference to the United States by maintaining obstacles to trade relations, which will result in producing a condition of ruin and disorder through failure of her two industries, sugar and tobacco -- Gen. LEONARD WOOD in The Independent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Naval Board of Construction has declined to sanction a request made by the Holland Submarine Boat Company for certain modifications as to speed and other conditions imposed by the existing contracts.

H.H. Vreeland, President of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, said yesterday that William N. Amory, who has asserted in a published interview that the leased lines of the Metropolitan Company are being operated in violation of the Constitution, had been quoting from a Court of Appeals deolsion which that court had since declared to have no application to the Metropolitan leases.

The Governing Committee of the StocK Exchange sat in executive session for almost four hours yesteraay, and made a thorough investigation into a series of complaints preferred against a member of that institution. The nature of these complaints and the name of the broker were not disclosed, but it was stated after the meeting that all the charges had been dismissed.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 12 -- The, American Federation of Catholic Societies, after a session of three days, adjourned this afternoon to meet In Chicago. July 15, 1902. After the adoption, last night of the new constitution and the election of officers this morning the last day was mostly devoted to the consideration of plans for field work.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

There is always a lull after such an event as the Assembly Ball. This afternoon there will again, be many teas and receptions, and this evening the Friday Dancing Class will have its first meeting. Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge. T. Gerry will give a large dinner in the evening. It is the first one of the season and one of a series.

Mayor-elect Seth Low announced yesterday that his appointments would be made public in a few days. It is understood that Mr. Low has made up his mind upon all of his appointments with the exception of Park Commissioner, Bridge Commissioner, and Commissioner of Corrections. He expects to decide upon these before the end of the week.

The Pennsylvania Society of New York save its third annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. Robert C. Ogden, First Vice President of the society, presided. There were about 400 members and guests present.

The Community will study with unusual interest the statement of views upon the question of Sunday opening offered to the press and the public by District Attorney PHILBIN. It is not without good reason that Mr. PHILBIN'S statement is regarded as an expression of the opinions of Archbishop CORRIGAN and the Roman Catholic clergy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- The local list was affected by the depression in New York, though only in the arbitrage stocks were the losses considerable. The steel stocks all declined fractionally, Cambria Steel, Diamond State, and Pennsylvania all falling below yesterday's final figures. Choctaw sought a lower level all day.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 12 -- Much life was infused into to-day's proceeding of the convention of the American Federation of Labor. The negro problem was unexpectedly injected into the proceedings, and the long standing conflict between the Socialists and trade unionists promised at one time to monopolize the attention of the delegates.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Supplies were short to-day and money was in active demand. Borrowers were largely dependent on the Bank of England, to which their indebtedness will probably be considerably increased before the week end. The firmness of money and the weakness of exchanges hardened discounts.

William Raymond Weeks, a prominent club man and member of many exclusive professional and historical societies, and once a leader of the New Jersey bar, was arrested at his home, 315 West One Hundred and Sixth Street, Wednesday afternoon on complaint of Mrs. Emma Plaut, who accuss him of having misappropriated $37,986,16 in the handling of an estate of $157,000, the inheritance of Mrs. Plaut's daughters; Blanche E. and Hortense S. Plaut.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Robert H. McCarter and Chauncey Parker, counsel for Robert P. Lister and his sister. Mrs. William A. Selby, have petitioned Vice Chancellor Stevens for a receiver for the trust fund of $50,000 left by Edwin Lister to his wife and heirs. This is held by William R. Weeks as custodian.

There was a sharp break in prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday, due in part to continued bear pressure, but in much larger measure to liquidation forced by the high rates prevailing for call money, the call figure at one time reaching as high as 10 per cent., with most of the day's loans made at 9 per cent.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 12 -- William A. Eddy says that he is writing to Marconi, inclosing diagrams of an improved tandemkite system for reaching a height of 3,000 feet with Major Baden-Powell's kites. He thinks this system will enable Marconi to send messages at least 1,000 miles, because every increase in height has so far enormously increased the range of wireless telegrams.

The United States Government, through Assistant Attorney General Fuller, has changed its ground in opposing before the Spanish Treaty Commission, claims of survivors of the destruction of the battleship Maine at Havana in February, 1898. The brief, recently submitted in support of a motion to dismiss the claims urged by Butler Harwood of this city, attorneys for about seventy claimants, has been Withdrawn, and a demurrer has been filed in its stead.

CADIZ, Dec. 12 -- This city was in a state of partial revolution practically all night long. Riotous mobs, led by striking bakers, armed with knives and bludgeons, pillaged stores, attacked peaceable people in the streets, injured a number of persons, threw the whole town into a state of panic, and made the night hideous with shouts of "Long live the Social Revolution" and "Down with the Bourgeois."

NATICK, Mass., Dec. 12 -- The death of Edmund M. Wood, proprietor of the Waban Road Conservatory ana a florist of National fame, was announced to-day. Mr. Wood was sixty-five years of age. In his early years he was a prominent paint, manufacturer. In 1890 Mr. Wood was elected President of the National Association of American Florists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Before the Senate's adjournment on next Monday a vote will be taken on the new Hay-Pauncefote Treaty for the construction of a canal across the Isthmus of Panama by the United States. This agreement was reached to-day in executive session after four hours of debate, sufficiently interesting to insure the constant attendance of most of the Senators.

Controller Bird S. Coler caused the leaders of the regular Democratic organization in Brooklyn some disturbance of mind yesterday by declaring, in effect, against the reorganization plan of Willoughby Street. Inquiries made among independent Democrats who declined to support the candidates of the organization in the last election seemed to show that these men were of about the same mind as Mr. Coler.

The Assembly, the last of the great subscription reunions of New York society, surviving in this century, took place last everting at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was a brilliant and a beautiful ball, and was chiefly notable for the many debutantes who were introduced and who made a brave showing.

A game of hockey, between teams representing Princeton University and the St. Nicholas Hockey Club was played on the rink of the latter club in this city last night, resulting in a tie score of one point for each team. Both teams showed a lack of practice. The line up:

In the National Bowling League tournament last night the Metropolitan Bowling Club team lost one of their three games with the National bowlers, and are now tied with the Fidelias for second and third places.

At the Reform Club, 233 Fifth Avenue, last night, the first of a series of dinners to discuss municipal affairs was held, ther being about 150 present Among those present were Wheeler H. Peckham, John De Witt Warner, Seth Sprague Terry, Louis Windmuller, Charles S. Fairchild, William H. Baldwin, Jr., and Lawrence E. Sexton.

The Union League Club of Brooklyn last night grave a dinner in honor of Mayorelect Low. The guests included Edward M. Grout, Charles V. Fornes, J. Edward Swanstrorn Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, ex-Mayor Wurster, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Col. Willis L. Ogden, County Judge Aspin- all, James L. Wells, and Rufus L. Scott.
There was a new "plain clothes" man in Wall Street yesterday, and last night he was a very mad but much wiser man than he had been in the morning.

Last evening it was apparent that the six-day cycle race at Madison Square Garden had developed into a scientific sprinting game. There is no more continuous sprinting, but methods first introduced by French sprinters are used. Last night 10,000 persons were in the Garden at 8 o'clock.

At the meetings of the Board of Directors of the various properties affiliated with the New York Central, which were held at the Grand Central Station yesterday, statements were issued which show continued large increases in gross revenues, although in some cases decreases in net earnings appear which are due to large increases in operating expenses, mainly on account of maintenance of way and equipment.

The plans announced by the management of the Pennsylvania Railroad of running tunnels under the Hudson and East Rivers and across New York, of which the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES have been fully advised in our news columns, suggest vain regrets that the same enterprising people cannot get control of the roads making their terminal in the Grand Central Station, at Forty-second Street.

Any number of useful Christmas gifts are to be found for the children when everything in the line of toys has been bought and there is time to think of something to wear. Small boys and girls are catered to by a specialist with as great care as their papas and mammas. There are many little "grown-up" things for the boys and girls which delight their hearts quite as much as toys.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 12 -- The Chronicle Telegraph says today:

Two trackmen of the Manhattan Railway Company had a fight on the Grand Central Depot branch of the Third Avenue Elevated Road yesterday afternoon while hundreds of people watched from below. One of the men, Martin Linspong, of 518 Third Avenue, was struck on the head with a five-pound hammer by the other, Henry Custer of 001 First Avenue.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Times, in its financial article to-day, says the preparations for the Stock Exchange pay day caused a strong demand for money yesterday, and a large business was done by the Bank of England in loans and discounts. The demand for gold on Austrian account continued, but supplies will not be available until the end of the week.
GENEVA, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- John Boardman Whitney of the Class of 1904 has been elected Captain of the football, eleven of Hobart College for next year. His home is in Buffalo.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 25 7-16d per ounce and in New York at 55c. Mexican silver dollars at 43 3/8 c.

Those who, as experts in various lines, have inspected the plans for the new North River tunnel, which the Pennsylvania Railroad Company proposes to build, declare that the magnitude of the undertaking both as an engineering feat and in its effects upon the growth of the city in the future cannot be overestimated.
Army. Transfers made in the Coast Artillery: First Lieut. George F. Connoly from the Forty-fourth Company to the Thirty-sixth Company.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- The spectacle of a millionaire testifying as the complainant in a grand larceny case involving only $30 caused an interested throng to gather in the dingy chambers of the Jefferson County Court House in this city to-day. The action was that of the People against Capt. Daniel Duclon, indicted for grand larceny, and the facts which led up to his indictment and trial are briefly as follows:

Samuel Goldsticker has sold for a Miss Werner to Meyer Jonasson for $77,000 the property 95 Park Row, 19.5 by 72.11, between North William and Chambers Streets, together with the abutting parcel 233 Willlam Street, 28 by 87.6.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- After an executive session the twenty-first annual meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League was opened at the Hotel Somerset here to- day. Dr. D.C. Gilman of Baltimore presided. The opening session was devoted to the presentation of reports.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- In the trial of the case of the Board of Trade against the Odell Commission Company of Cincinnati to enjoin the latter from using the former's quotations to-day ex-Gov. Boyd of Nebraska, who was on the stand, was asked in cross-examination:

WE learn that Miss Mary Johnson's new story, "Audrey," now running as a serial in The Atlantic Monthly, will be brought out in book form late in February by Houghton, Mifflin Co. As the story approaches its climax, many who are reading the novel have expressed the opinion that in construction, plot, movement, and in delineation of character it is a decided advance over.

Application was made to the Supreme Court yesterday for the voluntary dissolution of Wessell, Nickel Gross, corporation, manufacturers of piano actions at Forty-fifth Street and Tenth Avenue by Adam Nickel and Henry A. Nickel, two of the Directors, and Judge Giegerich appointed Chas. E.F. McCann referee in the matter, and the order to show cause was set down for March 25 next. Mr. McCann is a nephew of Richard Croker.

CHRISTMAS as a great festival has not only filled the world with joy and gladness for 1,000 years, but has added to literature some of its brightest gems. When I speak of Christmas in literature, I do not mean "Christmas books" -- those richly bound., volumes which embellish booksellers' windows and tables during the "holiday season."

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The requirements of the settlement increased the demand for money to-day, and the rates demanded were freely paid. It is hoped that Government disbursements will soon relieve the pressure. Discounts were firm. There was much uncertainty and nervousness regarding the immediate future.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- Daniel C. Gilman of Baltimore, ex-President of Johns Hopkins University, was chosen President of the Civil Service Reform League at its meeting here to-day.

"Before the Dawn" on an altogether higher plane than the great mass of popular fiction of the day. It is one of the few novels that have come into our hands from which we would not well spare a page, and it has the rare merit of informing and enriching the mind as well as exciting the emotions.

"The Passover Feast" marked the completion of God's plan for the deliverance of His people from Egypt, just as "The Crucifixion" marked the completion of His plan of Redemption from sin. "The passing through the Red Sea" marked the beginning of the Israelists' journey to Canaan, just as "The Resurrection" marks the rising from the death of sin in the believer to a new life in Christ.

Some live or six hundred bindings, representing forty or more binders, are now onview at the Putnam book store. Many of the notable American binders are represented as well as some foreign masters whose work is not now to be seen elsewhere. A most interesting feature of the display is, however, the bindings that have been executed by G.P. Putnam's Sons at their own establishment, known as the Knickerbocker Press, at New-Rochelle, N. Y.

The impression made, upon English readers by "The Forest Schoolmaster" assuces a welcome for "The God Seeker." Both are strong in the color, atmosphere, and associations -- legendary and historical -- of the Austrian mountains, both are records of human struggle, and in both a man is the centre of influence and interest.

It will be a relief to many to find the printed sermons and discourses of a Roman Catholic clergyman, which while more or less doctrinal, are far from beiong devoid of general and human interest, and which withal may be taken as suggestive and even inspiring rules of conduct by persons who, while having no particular belief, would nevertjhless live the lives of honest upright citizens and charitable neighbors.

London, Dec. 5 -- Mr. Henley's article in The Pall Mall Magazine on Stevenson has of course, been published in America, and it only remains for me to speak of the manner in which it has been received here.

"Thyra: A Romance of the Polar Pit," by Robert Ames Bennet, belongs to the heroic or aeroplane class of literature. It flies precariously; anon it thumps down, again it whirs aloft into the reaim where pulic readers lie in wait to seize upon passages for delivery from the platform. The story really ought to be presented in sage form, perhaps somewhat in the following manner:

Preparations are making in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, for the celebration of the twenttieth anniversary of the rectorate of the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan, which occurs early in January. The present plans contemplate a four days' celebration, beginning Sunday morning, Jan. 5.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 -- "We ain't afraid," said five-year-old Loraine Struble, as he prepared to take the east-bound train to-night for Mortimer, Ohio, where he and his sister, aged two, are going to live with their grandmother.

The New York Times, Saturday Review of Books: Anent the articl in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of the 23d ult., under the caption. "William Le Queux and the Literary Agent," permit me to relate my experience with the latter gentleman, which may be of some value to literary aspirants in search of a publisher.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- A promlsing effort to popularize the writings of George Borrow will be made by Hodder Stoughton in their Red Leather Series, a forthcoming volume of which contains the Isobel Berners episode, which appears half in "Lavengro" and half in "Romany Rye."

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Critics who complain that the popular fiction of the day lacks the distinction and grace of style necessary to establish it as literature, may observe with cynical enjoyment the series of weekly tales contributed anonymously. By twelve authors whose identity the public is invited to guess.

We have already commended what seem to us the good points of Mr. PHILBIN'S deliverance upon the question of Sunday opening. "We fully agree with him that there is no "political necessity" for opening the doors of saloons on Sundays while the doors of shops that dispense the necessaries of life are required by law to be closed and are, in fact, very generally closed.

From The Boston Herald. The city of Springfield has lost the librarian of its city public library, John Cotton Dana, who goes to Newark, N.J. He has been in Springfield four years, and accomplished a large and important work, not only for that city, but for all that part of the State.

During the thick blanket of fog that hung over the Long Island coast and almost paralyzed river and Sound traffic yesterday morning, the ferryboat College Point ran aground on a reef off North Brother Island, jammed a hole in her hull, and now lies a complete wreck on the rocks. About fifty passengers were aboard.

Good men are often coldly ungrateful for the favors of the wicked. Without a thought in the world save to promote his own ends and the ends of the Tammany organization, Mr. RICHARD CROKER has done for this city a service of considerable magnitude. We for one are resolved to thank him for it.

In its current issue The Electrical Review contains a study of the telephone situation, in which it is shown that the amount invested in the telephone industry in the United States is nearly hall a billion or dollars. This estimate includes both the lines and instruments of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, generally called the Bell Company, and of the opposition or independent companies.

President Roosevelt's Warning to Englang. Volume VI, of "The Royal Navy," by Laird Clowes, which has just made its appearance in London, contains certain chapters dealing with the war of 1812, contributed by President Roosevelt.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 13 -- Capitalists of New York, Baltimore, Washington, and several Eastern cities are interested in the organizing of a new trust company with a capital of $5,000,000 for the development of business interest in the South. The remarkable success of several large trust companies of Baltimore in financing Southern industries and enterprises is bringing a new competition into the field.

The six-day cycle race was continued at Madison Square Garden yesterday by the nine tired teams, the members of which sat upon their wheels with difficulty. Five American teams were in the lead, so all interest of an international character was eliminated from the contest.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The House of Lords to-day unanimously decided the suit for the possession of Daly's Theatre here in favor of the Daly estate.

Shakespeare has here found his way into a historical novel. His appearance had to come, sooner or later, and although the part he plays in the present book is purely that of lending "local color" to an otherwise colorless tale, he can no longer be cited as too exalted for the uses of the modern novelist.

Only a few times in a generation does a writer appear who has the gift of making his readers understand a foreign country. Di Amicis has this gift; he is able to make so real the look of things in strange lands that an imaginative sould could easily persuade himself that he had just come from the country of which he had been reading.

A series of papers, written by the late Sir Richard F. Burton and posthumously published under the title of "Wanderings in Three Continents," may do much to revive popular interest in the celebrated traveler whose earlier works appealed strongly to a generation that is passing away.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One would think that in a time of such, superabundance of fresh fiction as the present there would be little disposition to die into the past for half-forgotten novels, Yet we find publishers groping among the ash heaps of another generation with the hope of fanning the embers into flame again.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

IT can hardly be said that Eugene Field has been entirely fortunate in his biographer. Mr. Slason Thompson's volumes, while containing a great deal of entirely fresh material, much of which is of a very readable nature, are not well constructed, and, while adding materially to our knowledge of his friend, fail to leave upon the mind a well-rounded conception of Field either as man or author.
CLEVER and commercial methods of advertising are responsible in "The House Party" for a collection of stories unworthy of almost every name in the list from which we are asked to select the authors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Secretary of State John Hay will be invited to be the orator when services are held in Washington in memory of President McKinley. This selection was made at the suggestion of Senator Fairbanks (Rep., Ind.,) at to-day's joint meeting of the two committees appointed by the House and Senate to make the necessary arrangements for a memorial service.

With the exception of Amalgamated Copper practically every active stock on the Stock Exchange advanced yesterday as a result of continued buying by some of the larger banking houses. This strength was the more noteworthy in that it came notwithstanding the cut in the price of raw copper and a maintained high rate in money for the greater part of the day.

Johann Beck, who crossed the ocean concealed in a box, which was stored in the hold of the Hamburg-American liner Palatia, and who nearly lost his reason through the privation and horror of his confinement, appeared before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday morning and took out his first papers for American citizenship.

The outside market yesterday was again very irregular, and, although a few substantial advances showed in the closing quotations, the condition of the market as a whole still remained a very uncertain one. Some of the stocks which, during the recent falling off in prices, had shown little or no activity, were traded in yesterday and developed weakness with the rest of the market.

Advance sheets of the forthcoming annual report of the Chamber of Commerce, compiled and furnished by its Secretary, George Wilson, give exhaustive and valuable data in regard to the foreign commerce of this port and comparisons with that of the United States.

"The Real World" is a story difficult to analyze. It is so immature and so mature, in places so hackneyed, in others so fresh; the character drawing is at times so vivid and again so conventional. The book as a whole is very interesting the story powerful and well-sustained, and yet the climax comes as an anti-climax.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- After a session of less than an hour, the House adjourned to-day until Tuesday. The bill to provide temporary revenue for the Philippine Islands was reported by Mr. Payne. (Rep., N.Y.,) Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and by unanimous consent an order for the consideration of this bill next Tuesday and Wednesday was adopted.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Baseball games will be renewed with Harvard this Spring, according to Manager Argersinger of the Princeton Baseball Association. For two years the associations of the two universities have been at loggerheads as to whether two games or three should be played, the Crimson urging the former and the Tigers the latter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The report of the Schley court is as follows:

Mr. Arnold's Second Record. Mr. William Harris Arnold has just issued his "Record of Books and Letters," uniform in appearance, style, and arrangement with his "Record" of American first editions, published in the late Spring.

Each season it is harder than the year before to make a restricted list of the best new book for children. For there is a constantly increasing amount of good literature for youngreader. Sensationalism and sentimentality are found in comparatively few juvenile books, and an attractove outward form seldom belies the value of the contents of the volume.

His volume forms one of a series of Handbooks of Archaeology and Antiquities in course of issue. he systematic arrangement of topics in the table of contents makes it available for the specialist seeking information about Roman law, political organization, and civic administration, for immediate use, while the half dozen pages of bibliography afford the general student of the period an ample store of authorities.

The importance of the plans of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in connection with the construction of a tunnel from New Jersey to Long Island under the city, with a great terminal station on Manhattan Island, grows with a study of the immense advantages to result therefrom.

As to the calendars for the coming year, there never were handsomer ones. From Dutton Co. there come "In Friendship's Nome Calendar" in two forms, "Sweet Blossom Calendar," the prettiest of floral gifts, and the "Heavenly Guidance Calendar," and a superb one, "The Elite Calendar," and therein are presented all the sports and amusements of the day.

Instead of making novels out of history, M. Rene Bazin has been making history with his novels -- quite a different undertaking, and much more difficult; in his case notably much more profitable also. We trust that many of our readers remember the charm and the value of "La Terre qui Meurt," ("the Passing, of the Farm,") noticed in this REVIEW last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The House Committee on Inter-State and Foreign Commerce at its first meeting to-day voted to favorably report the Hepburn bill providing for the construction of the Nicaragua Canal. Representative Fletcher (Rep., Minn.) was the only member voting against reporting the bill.

Coleridge, translating Schiller's "Wallenstein," expanded a couplet into eight or ten of his most beautiful lines. The substance of the couplet was to the effect that "the fabled existences are no more." Miss Sharp knows better. She knows the whole geography of fairyland and all about its people and their ways.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Directors of the Rip Tinto Company have been meeting here dally, though quite informally, since, the copper crisis became acute. It was officially stated after yesterday's meeting that whatever settlement might be arrived at lay entirely with the Amalgamated Company; the Rio Tinto Company had made all the propositions which it intended to make, but so far, had received no indication or the action the Amalgamated Company proposed to take.

"The" Rights of Man" are the Lowell Institute lectures, bound up in a volume. Their purpose is thus stated in the first lecture: "In this course of lectures on the rights of man it will be my purpose to define with some accuracy _what those rights are in State, Church, and society." They are certainly a mirror held up to nature, and if the portrait is not always pleasing or complacently soothing, to American selfconceit.

By the death yesterday of Arthur J. Heaney, politician, pawnbroker, and philanthropist, Brooklyn has lest one of its roost interesting and popular characters. Mr. Heaney died at his home, 170 Amity Street, of pneumonia.

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Premier Zanardelli, in the course of a long statement in the Chamber of Deputies to-day, in which he showed how the efforts of the Government had improved the health and material prosperity of Naples and the southern provinces, announced that he hoped to conclude commercial treaties with Germany and Austria benefiting Italian agriculture.

Probably no sciences are making more rapid progress than medicine and surgery, and although the former is, even yet, by no means "exact," the latter has made such strides within the last few years that the saying has become common that whatever ailment the surgeon's knife can reach can be cured.

The five Borough Presidents-elect who will take office on Jan. 1 received yesterday the schedules of the employes of their departments, as assigned by the direction of Mayor Van Wyck and the Board of Estimate. They show what transfers of officials have been made from the departments abolished or changed by the new charter.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $23,140,444; balances, $2,194,559. Call money is now loaning almost wholly at 5 per ceijt., and nothing even in specially favored cases is obtainable under 4 1/2 per cent.

The year now drawing to a close, which was full of bibliographical surprises in the form of record prices, witnessed none greater than those connected with the name of Shakespeare. The elder Quaritch scoffed at the man who paid L1,700 for a first folio Shakespear in 1899, calling it an "exaggerated" price.

JOSEPH R. SWAN, one of the wealthiest residents of Utica, N.Y., died yesterday morning after a brief illness. He was sixty years of age, and had been attorney for some of the largest corporations of the State.

Fourth and last in a series of volumes on American towns appears: "Historic Towns of the Western States." The preceding volumes were entitled: "Historic Towns of New England," "Historic Towns of the Middle States," and "Historic Towns of the Southern States." Mr. Lyman P. Powell is the editor of the series, and he has exercised a judicious choice in the selection of contributors.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 13 -- Representatives of the frarichised corporations of Omaha, including the Omaha Street Railway, Omaha Gas Company, Omaha and Council Bluffs Bridge and Motor Line and Electric Light Company, are on the way to New York to confer with J.P. Morgan, who is at the head of a syndicate formed to buy these concerns, provided terms can be made.

Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court yesterday, decided that the Tax Commissioners had no right to levy a personal tax upon an part of the money held by the Controller to be paid to contractors upon the fulfillment of their contracts. According to hundreds of agreements between the city and contractors, the latter, upon the completion of their contracts, are to receive 70 per cent. of the contract price.

The reports current yesterday that Cornelius Vanderbilt was to be the Republican candidate in the Seventh Congress District to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Nicholas Muller of Richmond County were without foundation. There was a conference at 1 Madison Avenue, the Republican County Headquarters, yesterday afternoon, but at no time was there any mention of the name of Mr. Vanderbilt as a possible nominee.

In these days there are a great many men and some women engaged in the business of writing what they fondly believe are books suitable for boys and girls. Now, real juvenile books, are scarce. By real juvenile books we do not mean bocks which are juvenile, for they are altogether too numerous; but books which are attractive and suited for the young.

Capt. F. NORTON GODDARD is to be congratulated on the very important step forward he was enabled to take on Thursday in his war on policy gambling, and the city is particularly to be congratulated on its possession of a citizen of his character and energy, willing to devote his time, money, and labor with such disinterested zeal to so good a work.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I beg the liberty of criticising a criticism of Mr. Riis's autobiography in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Dec. 7. The chief characteristic of the autobiography is the sincerity of his delineation of his efforts, successes, and feelings.

Miss Josephine Preston Peabody's "Marlowe" can hardly be supposed to be intended for presentation in spite of its dramatic form and elaborate stage directions, but is rather a series of scenes, each needing its own especial explanation, and separated by a considerable interval of time from the others.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A second installment of schoolboy "howlers" may not lack interest for some of your readers. These are in the domain of Greek and Roman history:

In two hundred and a few more wellwritten and very readable pages Mr. David A Curtis, who is described on his title page as, "the poker expert of The New York sun," has endeavored to convince himself.

The long-deferred sensation in baseball was sprung yesterday afternoon when A.G. Spalding stated in an interview that the only condition under which he would accept the Presidency of the National Baseball League would be that Andrew Freedman should be forced out of baseball.

Various scattered parcels on the south side of Twenty-second Street and the north side of Twenty-first Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues at the rear of Stern Brothers' dry goods establishment, have been the subject of considerable gossip recently -- the supposition being that that firm is acquiring the site for some sort of an addition or annex to its Twenty-third Street store.

MMR. ALLAN FEA, with his large and beautifully cound, printed, and illustrated "King Monmouth," adds one more to the numerous opportunities the public has had of late to become intimately acquainted with the mental deficiencies and moral obliquities of those whose business in this world, it has been to sit upon thrones or to aspire to them.

William B. Hoyt, the employe of the H. B. Claflin Company, who brought suit against the Metropolitan, Street Railway Company for $25,000 for injuries received by being run down by a trolley car on March 22, 1899, was awarded $10,000 yesterday by a jury, which heard the case before Justice Bischoff.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Two passenger trains collided this morning on the Central Railroad at the engine roundhouse near Matawan station. No one was injured, but the passengers were well shaken up. Two trains, one from Freehold and the other from Atlantic Highlands, were late this morning on account of the dense fog.

-- If It he indeed true, as officially reported, that nothing more than "the putting in of a switch and some extra signals" was required to make possible the disuse by practically all loaded passenger trains of the two outside compartments of the Park Avenue tunnel, then does one have a good right to be -- filled with grateful joy?

The test of Christian Science on a rheumatic jaguar in the Chicago Zoo is interesting. If it should be found to restore that amiable creature to good health to receive an "absent treatment," no argument will be needed to establish the fact that the jaguar's imagination had nothing to do with it.

The day after the ball, drizzling and dreary, had the usual number of receptions, and in the evening there was the first of the Friday dances. There will be one wedding to-day, that of Miss Matilda S. Janeway, the daughter of Dr. Edward and Mrs. Edward S. Janeway, and William Talman Wisner.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have read the article in today's issue on Pierpont by Noah Brooks with the interest of one of the "old boys" referred to, and since, while THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS is about it, one mey fine in the face an excuse for correctness, allow me to say that both dates given for the advent of the "American First Class Book" are erroneous.

"Before I Forget --" as a title might make one fancy that there were some more or less heartrending disclosures to be made. When you read, however, the name of the writer you are certain that there will be discoverable in the book much to laugh about. Mr. Albert Chevalier, one of the representatives of English, comedy, is most favorably known in this country, having paid us a professional visit some nine years ago.

It probably does not rest with the editorial management of this literary newspaper to say which is the most interesting or most important item printed in these columns to-day. Few readers perhaps would agree completely either with its judgment on that matter or with the judgment of others.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Lloyd's defense of John Fiske seems to require an answer. Let us adopt Mr. Lloyd's scheme of reasoning and see whither it leads. Fiske devoted liberal space to the Boston tea party and described it in great deal, says your correspondent, because Boston at the time "occupied the centre of the stage."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Talk about a Congressional investigation of the SampsonSchley matter is rife to-night. It has been regarded as a foregone conclusion for some time that there would be one, but it has not cropped up in Congress because those who have been most active in the matter have thought it only decent to wait the action of the court.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Mr. Noah Brooks's article in your last issue on the Rev. John Pierpont makes interesting reading for one who, as in the writer's case, when a schoolboy in Boston in the forties, was also, like Mr. Brooks, practiced in good English through Pierpont's "First Class Reader," and in later life had the additional privilege of acquaintance with him.

According to a decision handed down by Justice Lawrence in a suit brought for the purpose of obtaining a construction of the will of Cornelius Van Shaick Roosevelt, who died in New York in 1887, President Theodore Roosevelt, who is a nephew of the testator of the will, will inherit a fortune of between $100,000 and $150,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- After four weeks of waiting, the result of the Schley court's work was made public to-night. There are two reports. The majority report, embodying the conclusions of Admirals Ramsay and Benham, finds against Admiral Schley on every count and condemns him unsparingly.

THE very name of Mexico bears with it a mysterious breeze of charm. To write entertainingly, even eloquently, of a land which is redolent of tales ancient as the Argonauts, which boasts perhaps the richest civilization of aboriginal America, which bears yet the scars of that heroic, almost legendary, conquest, which has risen out of revolutionary chaos into a prosperous State, seems a task easy of accomplishment.
