While looking over the files of The Freeman's Journal in Cooperstown the writer was interested to find the following, notice in the issue of July 24, 1837:

There is a curious contrast between the jingle of the fiction written in this country and the sombre note that conies to us from nearly every country, by means of various translations. In the Slavic countries there is a continual weeping and gnashing of teeth. The great Russian writers cry aloud over the misery of their people.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Look here, John Paul, this thing of proddine a fellow about his years is bad enough under ordinary circumstances; but when a man like you, born so near the beginning of last century; undertakes to do it, I find it worse even than Esgleston's fish stories. It is far harder to endure.

The Children's Aid Society make a special appeal for funds at this season, not merely that they may give the gifts of the season to the thousands of children under their care in their numerous industrial and other schools, but that their friends shall select this form of Christmas giving.

FOR a fortnight before Christmas Day West Street looks as though a section of the Catskill woods had been miraculously, transferred to New York and was flourishing apace. It is a carefully selected forest, however, that meets the eye of the observer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his answer to my letter Mr. Charles Ribbans claims that the Prohibitionists are reasonable and only insist on the enforcement of law as it appears on the statute books. But the prohibitionists caused that law in question, though not in harmony with the sentiments of the majority of the people in this city, to be on the statute books.
From The Boston Journal. The life story of Gen. Patrick A. Collina. is an interesting one.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- There is a demand on the part of certain Republican Senators that the Senate Committee on Inter-Oceanic Canals be Republicanized. While there was no immediate prospect of the passage of a bill authorizing the holding of an isthmian canal, these Senators did not care much about the make-up of the committee.

Those who read the cable news dispatches from England are probably aware that the enterprising American promoter Mr. CHARLES T. YERKES has accomplished the object of his recent visit to London and secured the rights he sought in connection with rapid transit in that city.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May a mere woman who wears skirts add a few words to the desultory discussion which you graciously permit in your columns about this item of feminine attire?

MR. WILLIAM THOTLESS is a pleasant, amiable, rather absent-minded man, with a chronic tendency toward forgetting to mail his wife's letters. If that was as far as his forgetfulness extended he might have borne it with humility. But when it reached the degree of making him ridiculous he began to despair.

Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken, at a reception given yesterday afternoon at the University Building in "Washington Square by the Women's Advisory Committee of New York University for the purpose of meeting the Faculty of the reorganized School of Pedagogy, announced that the honorary degree of Master of Letters had been conferred on five women for "eminent service to education in a woman's organization auxiliary to the university."

FOR miles along the trail the tepees were deserted and the ashes of the camp fires scattered and browned by age. In silence these told the story plainer than words. The Indian occupants of these tepees had been away more than a week. The fact that their wagons were missing from the barnyards signified that the whole family had gone along, taking sufficient provisions for a long journey.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The borrowings from the Bank of England during the past day or two have considerably relieved the pressure in the money market. Discounts to-day were steady.

AN albino quail was recently presented to the New York Zoological Park by Charles Payne of Wiehita, Kan. There was a white peacock in Central Park. Shortly before its death, a few days ago, this curious creature excited remarks among some would-be naturalists who were looking at it.
LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Col. Sadler, who has been employed in the Consular Service, has been appointed British Commissioner in Uganda, whence Sir Harry H. Johnston recently returned.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Mrs. Roosevelt began, her series of public afternoon receptions to-day. The White House was thrown open from 3 to 5 o'clock. In the two hours of the reception more than a thousand women passed through the Blue Room, and laid their respects to the new mistress of the White House, who extended to each a cordial greeting, but refrained from shaking hands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I trespass upon your valuable space sufficiently to comment on a few of Dr. Starr's remarks in your issue of this morning anent the State Pathological Institute and its recent reorganization?

Yesterday was a record breaker in the foreign mail service of the New York Post Office. The Lucania of the Cunard Line and the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse of the North German Lloyd, which sailed as "Christmas ships," carried' away more mail matter than has ever been sent from New York to Europe on any previous single day.

WE have followed in some detail the history and condition of the colored people in the three chief cities of the Northeast, and there are some manifest conclusions which may here be gathered up and considered.

A FAT MAN, nood-natured looking and apparently well-to-do, strode into a down-town restaurant a day or two ago. Although the weather outside was not warm, and the restaurant was not overheated, he was perspiring.

COUNTLESS stories and legends are told of the semi-mythological character. Nasr-ed-din-Hojah, whom the Turkish children love just as other youngsters delight in Mother Goose. Among the stories told of the Hojah (professor) are the four which follow, favorites with the children at bedtime.

From The London Times. BERLIN, Nov. 28. -- The two new volumes, chiefly consisting of important correspondence of the late Prince Bismarck, which will be published to-morrow, contain letters from and to the Emperor William I., the late Count Andrassy, and other personages. They form a kind of appendix to them. "Reflections and Reminiscences."

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Led by the farmers of Cumberland County, the tomato growers ou South Jersey have started in on a trust of their own to oppose the canners next season. It Is brought about by the very small figures the farmers secured for their crop of last year and the very large figures which the canners are getting for the canned goods.

The one dramatic novelty of the week in New York will be the appearance of Henry Miller at the Savoy Theatre to-morrow night in a new play entitled "D'Arcy of the Guards." Though already having appeared in book form, "D'Arcy of the Guards," it is announced, is not a dramatization of the novel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in last Sunday's TIMES, signed Roger Padden Smith, in which he criticises "Interested" for giving to the public a view of her domestic life, in which a drinking husband is the theme, shows the power of the appetite to dominate the reason, and deaden the kindlier feelings of our nature.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 14. -- Rear Admiral Belknap, United States Navy, (retired,) who is at the head of the Massachusetts Nautical Training School, declined to discuss at any length the finding of the court of inquiry in the case of Rear Admiral Schley, when seen to-day. He did, however, give out a brief statement in writing, which follows:

The series of articles now being presented to the readers of THE TIMES on the subject of "The Black North" are designed to give a clear and somewhat detailed account of the situation of the negro race in the larger cities of the North. The articles are prepared by a writer of that race, Prof. W.E. BURGHARDT DU BOIS of Atlanta University, Ga., where he holds the Chair of Economics and History.
W.C. Boorn of Chicago will resign on Jan. 1 as Agency Superintendent in the Western Department of the London and Lancashire Insurance Company.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law. as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Chicago experienced to-day and to-night one of the most severe cold snaps on record for the early part of the Winter. The Weather Office predicted early in the day that it would prove the most severe weather that the city had felt for twenty-five years In the month of December, and to-night no flaws can be found in the prediction.

Assemblyman John A. Weekes. Jr., in the course of a speech delivered last night at a dinner in the Madison Square Concert Hall declared that at the coming session of the legislature the primary law would be amended. Mr. Weekes was a guest of honor at the dinner as was also Alderman Herbert Parsons, the Madison Square Republican Club having, tendered it to them jointly with the regular Republican organization of the Twenty-fifth Assembly District.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- The bankers of Chicago were given a banquet by the Marquette Club to-night. In addition to speeches by former Controller James H. Eckles, President of the Commercial National Bank, and President James B. Forgan of the First National Bank, there was one by A.B. Stickney, President of the Chicago, Great Western Railway Company, who was the principal guest of the evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One day, only a few Summers ago, I was seated on the campus at the University of Chicago, reading an afternoon paper. On the same bench were several divinity students, personally unknown to me, discussing topics of interest in university life. One was complaining of the conditions at his eating club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article on Wabash to-day has seemed quite interesting. It bears evidence of careful analysis of reports, but lacks so, much that contributes to an understanding of Wabash conditions and consequently of security values that I drop these few lines entirely without any figures.

All the problems incidental to burrowing under a great city seem to have been solved to the satisfaction of New York rapid transit enthusiasts except the one of tunneling under water. While the subway engineers hear fewer and fewer complaints about their work beneath the streets as that work progresses, they are still in receipt of weekly, even daily, abuse because of the results of their labors at making plans for subaqueous interborough trainways.

THE woman who had lately moved over from Brooklyn sighed wearily. "I used to think I had found out everything there was to learn upon the servant Question,'" she said, "but since I began housekeeping in a Harlem flat I have had an entirely new experience in this line -- one which women In any other part of the globe except Harlem never dream of."
Army. Capt. Beverly W. Dunn, Ordnance Department, will make ten visits to the Sandy Hook Proving Ground on business pertaining to meetings of the Ordnance Board.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few years ago I resided on the west side, up in the nineties, and having been unwell, and consequently compelled to relinquish busines for over a year, I occasionally took long walks on the Boulevard and Riverside Drive. During these walks I often wished for a drink of fresh water but I could not find a fountain or hydrant on either of those promenades.

As co-operation in the management of the constituent companies whose securities are to be acquired by the Northern Securities Company involves many new factors, it is not possible to make an exact estimate of the amount that will be available for dividends on its stock. An approximate estimate, however, may be made by a study of the past earnings of the Great Northern, Northern Pacific, and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroads.

On the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse. which sailed for Europe yesterday, were John G. A. Leishman, United States Minister to Turkey; John Wallace Riddle, Secretary of the American Embassy at St. Petersburg; Ludwig Brefeld, Prussian Minister of Commerce, and Lieut. Juan S. Atwell, Naval Attache of the Argentine Legation at Washington.

CAIRO, Nov. 23. -- The Alexandria cotton mills had a fair start and are now hard at work turning out cloth. An average of 130 looms are going daily, and a very good average production of cloth is being turned out, considering that most of the work people are native weavers accustomed to hand looms only.

An air of mystery mingled with feelings of surprise and doubt, pervaded the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday, where the baseball men have been wont to congregate during the last week and discuss the outlook for the coming year.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew, looking wondrously happy, sailed away on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse for France yesterday. The Senator is going to Nice, where he will wed Miss May Palmer. There were flowers galore in his cabin, and presents that weighed in the aggregate several tons, it is said, were hidden away in the big ship's hold.

TROY, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- A span of the Big Four bridge across the Miami River, onehalf mile east of Troy, went down at 5 o'clock this morning as a west-bound freight train was crossing. Fireman W.H. Clifford of Indianapolis was killed and at 11 o'clock to-day his body had not been recovered from the river.

From The London Daily Mail. Henry Cuthbert, a journalist, of Old Broad Street, City, was summoned at North London Court for assaulting Mr. Thomas John Whiting, Managing Director of T.J. Whiting Sons. Limited, of Finsbury. Mr. H.W. Henniker Ranee, LL. D., appeared for the complainant, and Mr. C.V. Young defended.

Following the many previous vicissitudes of the General Carriage Company, announcement has been made within the past few days that the proposed plan of reorganization has been definitely abandoned. It is understood that new interests are ahout to assume control of the company's assets and expect to carry to success a new plan for the re-establishment of the company.

From The London Chronicle, A veteran of Bridport has just received his medal -- such is the indecent haste of the War Office -- for the Crimean War, just as many Canadian Volunteers about two years ago were hurriedly presented with their medals for services of some forty years back.
WHEN the music student had got to the door the girl who paints called her back. "Say," she said, "you don't happen to he in need of a pair of new gloves, do you?"

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- Reading common and Pennsylvania Railroad dominated the local market. These were strong, but in other directions there was little reflection of the feeling in Wall Street. In the whole list the trading was light Diamond State Steel was active, and both the common and preferred made new low records.

"I RECKON I ought to say it in a whisper, or maybe I hadn't ought to say it at all." said a man claiming to be a Marylander, "but It's a fact that before terrapin began to get scarce down in Maryland muskrats were more than abundant."

To the Editor of The New York Times: While I have long had much more than a suspicion that the current "explanations" of the continued excess in value of exports from this country over its imports were for "the home market" only, I have lacked the facts so well set forth by Mr. Allen in Sunday's TIMES under the caption "The Disappearance of Trade Balances."

Rifle practice figures of the National Guard and Naval Militia of New York at out door ranges for the season of 1901, which ended last week, were completed Thursday by Col. W.B. Thurston, Inspector of Small Arms Practice, and show a fine record for the Guard in the important duty of rifle practice.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The latest word from Rome concerning d'Annunzio's play "Francesca da Rimini," which was first acted there this week with Duse as Francesca, is that the piece failed, from the first and was hooted by the galleries. William Archer, who mourns over the brutality of the incident, praises Duse's acting, but at least five other chroniclers say that she was slow and dull.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- A.B. Farquhar of York. Penn., addressed the American Academy of Political and Social Science a the New Century Drawing Room last evening. His subject was "The Need of Reciprocity from the Point of "View of an American Manufacturer."
"A COUPLE of caribou have been the most potent of recent forces in Michigan politics." said a member of Congress from that State, who was in the city last week.

From The Forum This Kursaal at Ostend was erected and is owned and conducted by the city." as is the gambling ball, willed is practically under the same roof. The gambling establishment is nominally controlled and managed by a single individual, who is understood to have a number of Berlin banters as his silent partners.

Very little business was transacted in the outside market yesterday except in the Copper stocks. Outside of this group, very little interest was displayed, and such issues as were traded in generally did not show a larger total than two or three hundred shares. Prices were somewhat irregular, but, except in the copper shares, net changes for the day did not prove important.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your criticisms of Secretary Gage in Saturday's issue on Custom House inspection is unjustifiable from any standard except those who are guilty of the petty business of buying their wardrobes abroad, endeavoring to pay the expense of their pleasure trip across the briny deep in the difference of the cost of material and skilled labor abroad and at home.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14. -- The University of Pennsylvania will send a Varsity crew to compete next year at the Henley regatta, and at Dublin in one of the greatest college boat races that has ever been contested.

IN various parts of the world, generally in those countries in which education is backward, strange superstitions exist with regard to the animal kingdom. Deep students of sociology and religion claim to see in these beliefs a survival of the age when the creator was worshipped in the form of animals, as in ancient Egypt cats were deified and in India a sacred character was and is attributed to cattle.

BOSTON, Dec. 14. -- Money was in plentiful supply at the local-Clearing House-today, and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount and par. Exchanges, $23,464,617: balances, $1,901,450. Call loans are 4 1/2@5 per cent., with more at the latter rate than the former. There is practically, no business doing in time money.

From The Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier. All of those who had the pleasure of meeting Capt. George P. Colvocoresses, United States Navy, commanding the United States training ship Lancaster, regretted the departure from the port of that fine old ship, and hoped that the sturdy, courteous and pleasant sailor and his craft would find this harbor again and often.

Clearly outclassed, Yale was beaten at hockey last night in the St. Nicholas Skating Rink by a score of 4 to 1. Throughout the contest the New York Athletic Club acted on the aggressive, compelling Yale to play a defensive game, which she did splendidly, clever stops by Stern and Ward earning applause.

An action brought by Emory M. Van Tassell against the Greenwich Insurance Company to recover on a policy of insurance on premises at the northeast corner of Thirteenth Avenue and West Eleventh Street, which was tried for the first time in April; 1893, and has been tried four times since, was last week ordered to be tried for the sixth time by the Appellate Division.

Wall Street during the past week has devoted itself largely -- almost exclusively -- to Copper Trust sensationalism. The whole market has been hurt by copper's cavorting. On every side can be heard expressions of belief that but for Copper Trust disturbance the Stock Exchange would now be enjoying buoyant markets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The announcements in to-day's TIMES are of such an import as to demand more than a casual reading. A summary of the events of yesterday speaks more forcibly than words:

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- The question of the American reciprocity treaty, which has, ever since the opening of the discussion, been watched with intense interest by France, is entering into a new phase which may seriously compromise the prospects of the treaty unless the matter is speedily concluded.

The season's oyster crop on the Jersey side of Delaware Bay will have cost the Philadelphia and New York wholesalers $200,000 by the end of April. The people who eat these oysters will pay several millions more. The Jersey Delaware Bay syster grounds cover at the lowest measurement 220 square miles.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14. -- Maryland is aroused over the findings of the Schley court. Regardless of politics, men in every position, State and city officials, clergymen, lawyers, merchants, manufacturers, and politicians denounce the findings of the majority of the court and demand a Congressional investigation.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 14. -- Weather cloudy, track heavy. Uterp was the only successful favorite, and he was well backed. The other winners had but mild support.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Golfers in Lakewood have had a full day's sport, and though a high morning wind prevented low scores and brought rain in the afternoon, the day has been much enjoyed. The Country Club had an entry list of nine for its handicap, eight returning cards.

EDUCATIONAL development in the Philippines interests Americans in two different directions: First, from the purely ethical side, in arousing a sense of the necessities of the Filipinos, and, second, from, the business side, in affording an opportunity to do a profitable business in supplying books and equipment.

Within the past week we have had two most vivid reminders of how much richer rich Americans are growing. One is the gift by Mr. CARNEGIE of ten millions for higher education, but one gift of many. The other is the final transfer to the Stanford University of an estate valued at thirty millions.
MISS ANNIE RUSSELL is delighted with her new play, The Girl and the Judge," and particularly pleased with her part in it.

IT may be a trifle startling to out-of-town visitors as well as to many native New Yorkers whose interest in matters historical has led them to inspect the old tombstones in Trinity churchyard, bearing names of prominence and power in earlier years, to learn that two of the most famous stones there are simply "fakes."

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 14. -- The Young Men's Christian Association basket ball team surprised a big crowd to-night by defeating the strong Yale team by a score of 18 to 15 in a game that was fast and exciting all through. The visitors had the advantage in weight and height, but the defense of the local players was superb and they kept the visitors blocked and covered at every turn.

From The Bangor (Me.) Commercial. The missing picture of Capt. Luke Wilder of Bangor has been found. It is now the property of Mrs. Eliza Wilder Hassard of this city, who is a grandchild of Capt. Wilder. It was left to her by Jacob McGaw, who purchased it from thes painter, and it has been in her possession at the Bruce farm on Kenduskeag Avenue for about twenty-five years.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14. -- Owing to the large number of wealthy young girls recently introduced, the season in Baltimore will be an unusually gay one, and big events are already beginning to crowd each other unpleasantly. On Monday evening several theatre parties occurred, the most important being given by Mr. Walter Lord, son of Sir. Charles K. Lord of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, in honor of his debutante sister, Miss Bessie Lord.

From The New Orleans Times-Democrat. Another effort will be made to secure from Congress an appropriation sufficient to exterminate the water hyacinth, which has of late years spread so rapidly In Louisiana, Mississippi, and Florida streams as seriously to impede their navigation and to harass and injure the logging, timber, and oyster business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in this morning's issue reviewing, the utterances of District Attorney Philbin on the liquor question has naturally provoked much, comment among Roman Catholics who are concerned regarding the attitude of their Church on the problem of Sunday opening of the saloons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I cannot agree with that part of your editorial in to-day's issue regarding the city debt limit which says: "These three items (water, dock, and tunnel bonds) aggregate $66,349,800, and have no place among the liabilities which help to swell the public debt to the legal limit.

William Van Slooten, who became locally famous in the political campaign in Brooklyn in 1893 as "The Mysterious Van Slooten," committed suicide late yesterday afternoon at his home, 52 Sidney Place, Brooklyn Heights, by shooting himself in the head. He killed himself in the presence of his wife and his attending physician, while suffering from temporary derangement of the mind.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 14. -- With the building of the proposed, railroad through the Copper River Valley, the development of Alaska's mineral resources will commence on a scale more vast than anything heretofore attempted in the North. This is the conclusion of Western mining men who base their belief on the immensity of the ore deposits of Southern Alaska and the fact that they must necessarily be developed through large investments of capital.

THE average boy will chew tar wherever he finds it, and when a building in course of erection near a schoolhouse reaches the tar period, there is apt to be trouble at school. This was the case the other day in a school up in the Bronx. Shortly after the opening exercises, the teacher called Joe Welner to the desk, and the following dialogue ensued.

One of the happiest sequels of the Pan-American was the dinner given a day or two ago at the Buffalo Club by the friends of Mr. W.A. Coffin to honor his departure from the field of his labors as Director of Fine Arts at the exposition. Among the givers of the banquet were President Milburn of the exposition.

The Montauk Club of Brooklyn last night gave a complimentary dinner to Edward M. Grout, the Controller-elect of this city. The dinner was attended by a large number of prominent Brooklyn citizens. Among them were William Berri, Justice W.J. Gaynor, Col. John N. Partridge, Justice John Woodward, Thomas H. Troy, Charles A. Moore, Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, ex-Mayor David A. Bobdy, Felix Campbell, Joseph C. Hendrix, and W.J. La Roche.

Seth Low and Col. John N. Patridge. the new Police Commissioner-elect, had an hour's conference yesterday afternoon. At its conclusion it was learned that the selection of a Deputy Police Commissioner for Manhattan is still undecided. In fact, there is at present no man of all those who have been considered for the place within the last ten days who can be set down as even a probability.

Not the least interesting feature in the Erie Railroad report for the late fiscal year is the exhibit made with regard to passenger results. Taking the latter as a whole, viewing them broadly, it is quite evident that traffic development in the freight department has not absorbed official attention to the exclusion of the passenger branch of the service.

Copyright. 1901. LONDON, Dec. 14. -- American rails have had a week's decline, yet in the stock Exchange settlement it was shown that there had been a persistent bull movement all the month, and prices advanced again somewhat as the week closed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The State Board of Canvassers met to-day and canvassed the vote cast for and against the Constitutional amendment and for the candidates for Justice of the Supreme Court in the First, Third, Fourth, Sixth, and Seventh Judicial Districts; for member of Congress, and for State Senator in the Thirtieth and Forty-third Senatorial Districts.

BANGOR, Dec. 14. -- The big game season in Maine closes to-night, with a record of 4,000 deer and 175 moose killed in the country above Bangor and brought to this city on the way to points west. This is but a small part of the game actually killed, as many deer and moose are eaten in the woods and many more left to rot where they fall.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 14. -- David P. Thompson, a well-known capitalist and ex-United States Minister to Turkey, died early this morning. Mr. Thompson was born in Ohio in 1834. He came to Oregon in 1853, walking every step of the way across the continent.

VISITORS to Washington during the past few days have been much interested in the new decorations of the committee rooms of Congress. Artistically the new decorations and furniture are attracting a degree of attention second only to that evoked by the wall paintings and appointments of the library of Congress.

TO most of us, no memory of our childhood is dearer than the tales we used to love -- the stories of Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood, and all the host of fairy folk and goblins that were to us then living realities and friends. But there are thousands of young men and women in New York whose memories of the "evening hour" bring up friends far different from those we knew and loved.

IN THE little musical world of New York Thursday was the significant day of last week. The interest was due to the performance of music by Mr. Richard Strauss of Munich. Musicians are nearly all admirers of the works of this composer, and this would lead critics to believe them great, were it not for one well-known fact, namely, that musicians are, to a man, worshippers of technics.

Charles Bloomfield Hewitt, head of the New York paper firm of C.B. Hewitt Brothers, nephew of ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and brother-in-law of Edward M. Shepard, died yesterday in Cannes, France. With him at the time of his death were his wife and two of his three daughters.

From Chamber's Journal. A story which recently went the rounds related how in the last Parliament a number of Unionists, thinking the policy of the Government might be improved, decided to lay their views before Sir Michael Hicks-Beach. Going to the door of his private room they, chose one of their number to walk inside and speak for all.

Andrew Carnegie's opportunities to continue giving so that he may not die rich were imperilled yesterday afternoon at the laying of the corner stone of the High School of Commerce Building, midway between Broadway and West End Avenue, in Sixty-fifth Street. He delivered the address of the occasion, prefacing it with a plea that he might be allowed to speak with his hat on and his overcoat close buttoned under his throat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bourke Cockran is not the stamp of man that Great Britain takes advice from. He and those Irish M.P.'s who have lately been touring in this country raising money for Irish secret societies might as well save their breath, for they accomplish no good and do not help the Boers.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Internationals were dull on the Boerse to-day, principally Argentines. Chinese were easier. Locals were quiet, but Bochumer shares were in demand toward the close on rumors that the concern had been awarded large orders for rails from Japan.

MRS. WILLIAM DOUGLAS SLOANE has a velvet gown in the sweeping skirt and Eton coat fashion. Topped, as it usually is by a rather flat and small toque of velvet of the same sable shade as the frock, with a feathery aigrette rising at the left. It suits her well. The skirt is not too sweeping.

Many women seem peculiarly unable to appreciate the immorality of smuggling and bribing and to understand that it is as great a crime to swindle the Government as it is to swindle one's neighbor. Not long ago a gentleman and his wife went to Europe for an extended trip. The wife announced before going that she intended to lay in a stock of laces in Europe that would last her the remainder of her life.

ONE may find people around every corner in New York whom they would never suspect of any but the most ordinary experiences, yet whose lives have been full of odd and interesting happenings. Such a one is Mlle. L.D. Odou, a clever and brainly little Frenchwoman, who was the first pupil and for years the intimate friend of Florence Nightingale, in whose family she resided.

The first annual show of the Ladies' Kennel Association will take place at Madison Square Garden this week. The dogs to be benched are all good performers and every breed will be strongly represented. The dogs will be benched, as is the custom at the Westminster Kennel Club show, on the floor and in the galleries, pet dogs being relegated to the latter places.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Lakewood is fairly bubbling over with the spirit of Christmas. Christmas week is the gayest week of the season, and the plans and preparations that have been made for holiday entertainments indicate that society is bent upon extracting the fullest meed of pleasure from this joyous occasion.

ST. JOHN'S. N.F., Dec. 14. -- Guglielmo Marconi announced to-night the most wonderful scientific development of recent times. He stated that he had received electric signals across the Atlantic Ocean from his station in Cornwall, England.

With this week begins a new era in society. It is that of private, dances. The Horse Show has been held, the debutantes have made their bows at teas and receptions, the first meetings, of the different dancing classes have taken place, and the Assembly has passed into history. The preliminaries have all been arranged.

MY FRIEND Silas Larrabec is in Washington. Much to my surprise I met him last night on Pennsylvania Avenue. When I bade him good-bye the day the "Sewsan" E. Nash got into New York my understanding was that he would stay aboard the schooner until it should get back to Ogunquit.

From The Buffalo Commercial. Jacob Durrenberger, Superintendent of Horses of the Fire Department, went out to the stock yards on Monday to look over some horses there. Superintendent Durrenberger is always on the watch for good things in horseflesh. He could tell a sound steed as far as he could, see it, almost. That is the reason why the horses in the Buffalo Fire Department are among the finest in the world of their kind.
Columbia's champions of the year in the various branches of gymnastic work were yesterday announced by Dr. Watson L. Savage, director of gymnastics. They are as follows:

THIS incident of Orinoco life is but one of many such, the stories of which seldom do go beyond the river's mouth, except when we who have lived upon its banks betake ourselves for good to other parts. Overmuch talking is in no way advantageous to one having wherewithal at stake in that land.

The second concert of the season by the Kneisel Quartet -- the first of their two matinees -- to be given at Mendelssohn Hall on Tuesday afternoon at 2:15 o'clocK will be devoted to the music of Beethoven, in remembrance of his birthday, which is Monday. The programme will be as follows:

THERE is no spot in Greenwood Cemetery more closely associated with the New York City of fifty years ago than what is known as the Mexican plot, and yet there is none of which the general public visiting that burial place knows so little; none that has been permitted to fall into a state of such surprising neglect.

-- That an exponent of "osteopathy" should have ventured to sue in a New York court for payment for services rendered is certainly a remarkable fact, suggesting comment, not alone on the plaintiff, but also oh the defendant. "Osteopathy," as everybody knows or ought to know, is quackery, pure and simple.

THE revolution at the Comedie Francaise is still the chief topic of conversation everywhere. The journalists who have played such a part in stirring up the strife against Claretie ever since the days of Le Bargy's revolt two years ago -- at which time the trouble really began -- are already warning the actors to put on brakes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- It is said to be definitely decided that President Roosevelt will not accept the offer of Mr. Andrew Carnegie of $10,000,000 of bonds of the United States Steel Corporation for the purpose of founding an institution for higher education in this city.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I venture to call attention through your columns to the needs of the Boer prisoners in South Africa and Bermuda?

THE dogs of war are rifles, and they go by different names in different countries. In the Argentine Republic and Belgium the name is Mauser, but in Spain and turkey they are Mousers, a title previously conferred on cats.

As in nearly every other branch of the city's activity, so amons real state men, the last few days have been devoted to little else besides the discussion of the Pennsylvania Railroad's announcement of its plans for a North River tunnel and a station on Manhattan Island.

The batting and Welding averages of the Amateur Baseball League for the 1901 season have been complied by the Secretary, M.P. Halpin of the New York Athletic Club. Few men made a batting average of 300 or over this year, and this is accounted for by better pitching.

It was the political campaign of 1896, and it was where the battle raged the fiercest -- even the State of Kentucky. It was one Indian Summer morning, and a Sunday morning, that the elite of social, professional, and political Louisville -- Democrats, Republicans, Palmer and Buckner men, gold -bugs, silver cranks -- were assembled in the big and spacious and sumptuous lobby of the Galt House.

The copper situation daily grows more intricate and perplexing to those who are interested in it and are not close enough to the powers that manipulate the copper game to obtain intelligent information regarding it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- So many attacks have been made lately on the high salaries. alleged to be paid to American officials in the Philippines, and there have been so many rumors of Congressional action, that the War Department has received a number of inquiries asking for the facts of the matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The delegation from Ireland to the United States in behalf of the new League to carry, on the same line of work as the former Land League in that country, is reported as having sailed for home apparently very much satisfied with their mission in this country.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 14. -- Smallpox is en the increase in this city and vicinity, and the entire county is in the throes of a smallpox alarm. The isolation hospital here is taxed to its utmost capacity, and a building to accommodate sixty more patients is being built under hurry orders.

How to Americanize the French Canadian who swarms the streets of the New England cotton towns; how to break up those voluntary Ghettos formed by the strange tongue, the strange customs, and a people willing to forget neither -- this is to-day a serious problem. But one phase, at least, of the problem is a delightful study -- the young French Canadian girl.

Mr. Hall Caine contributes an article on the Pope to the Christmas number of Household Words, which has recently been acquired by his son. In the preparation of "The Eternal City," Mr. Hall Caine had many views, public and private, of his Holiness. Here is a sketch of Leo XIII, in the Basilica of St. Peter's:
SO many cares devolve upon the eldest girl of an east side family that she has earned her name of "Little Mother." Often her mother and her father are both away from the house all day.

Copyright, 1901. (Via French Telesraph-Cable Company.) LONDON, Dec. 14. -- While the public generally takes small interest in the Nicaraguan Canal matter, there is no doubt, of the strong feeling of relief among the few at the assurances cabled that the new treaty will surely be ratified. In other words, so far as there is any feeling here at all about the treaty, its speedy ratification is favored.

The year's cricket in New York was brought to an interesting conclusion by the international match at Bergen Point against B.J.T. Bosanquet's team of English cricketers. The season's games were full of interest, and the championship series of the Metropolitan District Cricket League and New York Cricket Association were followed with enthusiasm by the many votaries of the game in this vicinity.

Announcement made during the past week of a special meeting to be held Dec. 20 by the stockholders of the American Chicle Company draws attention to the large growth of the business represented by this company. Formed about two years ago to take dyer the Adams company and other concerns manufacturing chewing gum, it was incorporated with a capital of $9,000,000, divided into $6,000,000 common and $3,000,000 preferred stock.

From The London Telegraph. A little girl, aged twelve, named Amelia E. Hovell, of Margaret Street, Hadkney, was charged on remand at North London with stealing sausages and condensed milk from the shop of David Vale of Elsdale Street, Hackney. The child said she took the food because her little brothers had had no dinner.
"My views of the stock market are entirely optimistic," declares A.P. Miller of Miller Co.

Edward H. Moeran, senior counsel in New York for the Marconi Wireless Telegraph Company, when seen at his residence, 55 Irvlng Place, last evening, and informed of the dispatch from St. John's to the effect that Signer Marconi had received wireless signals from England, said:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15. -- Of all the peculiar sects which have recently sprung up in the West, St. Louis boasts the most striking -- a community of dirt eaters. William Windsor, native of Wisconsin, some time lawyer, college student, student of natural science, is their Moses. Seventy-five men and women form the community.

"I fully believe, that Marconi succeeded in signaling between the coasts of Newfoundland and Cornwall, England, by his system of wireless telegraphy." said M.I. Pupin, Professor of Electrical Mechanics at Columbia University to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES last evening.

THE TROUBLE ON THE INDIAN FRONTIER. -- Although the Indian Covernment is loath to announce the fact that a field force is operating against the revolting tribes in and about the new Northwest Province of British India, the four columns which have been placed in the field show that the campaign is neither unimportant nor devoid of serious circumstances.

From The London News. BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- Some years ago when the story reached Western Europe of the sect at Tiraspol, in Russia, who buried their relatives alive, an outcry of horror arose. Now we have here, two hours' journey from Berlin, a case which is hardly less astounding.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15. -- For severity and destructiveness the storm which visited Eastern and Central Pennsylvania last night has not been equaled in this State for twenty-five years. It caused almost unprecedented damage and resulted in the loss of at least four lives. The havoc in the coal regions is enormous, and the loss to railroad and mining companies will amount to millions of dollars.

Mayor-elect Low will partially relieve the suspense of the politicians to-day by announcing some of his appointments. It was understood last night that the appointments which Mr. Low would make public to-day are the following:

After a week of haggling and squabbling, the National Baseball League Presidents spent yesterday trying to figure out just "where they were at", and what the ultimate outcome of the situation would be. Andrew Freedman was seen at the Democratic Club and asked if it were true that lawyers had been engaged-to bring the affairs of the League into the courts.

To The Editor of The New York Times: It is not my purpose to discuss the question of the open or closed Sunday from its religious standpoint or aspect. What I have to say on this subject will relate exclusively to Sunday as a rest day. I think it will be agreed that this day of rest is absolutely needed for the physical well-being.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 15. -- Although the situation between the Argentine Republic and Chile has improved, it has not yet been clearly defined. The Council of Argentine Ministers has spent much time in studying the two paragraphs of the Chilean note which form the basis of that country's proposition, an agreement upon which would mean the solution of the pending difficulty.

From The Galveston (Texas) News. "Speaking of unique cases in the law," said a member of the Galveston bar, "I am reminded, of a case which, is often told by lawyers, and the beauty about the story is that it is well authenticated. It really happened. Lawyers have a fund of these things on hand, for some of the most curious happenings in the world happen to the lawyer.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- The holiday festivities at Vassar College began last night with a Christmas german given by the Shakespeare and Dickens Clubs. The spirit suggested by the bespangled tree on the favor table was in the air, and the dance was a great success.

PERCY, Ill., Dec. 15. -- Kaskaskia, the first capital of Illinois, will soon be wiped out of official existence by an order of the Postmaster General, effective on Jan. 1, 1902. Only five families now live in the once flourishing town, and the department has decided to abolish the Post Office and accommodate the residents through the extension of a rural free delivery route from Fort Gage.

In an apartment house in the Bronx three cases of small pox were discovered yesterday and all in the convalescent stage, so that the officers of the Health Department did not think it necessary to remove them from the house, which they quarantined. The discovery led to a great deal of excitement in the neighborhood, which was somewhat quicted by the assurances that the danger of contagion was over.

BERLIN, Dec. 15. -- The chief strength of the Boerse during the past week was again foreign rentes, Spanish fours taking the first place and reaching their highest quotation in a number of years. There were large transactions in Spanish fours, as well as in Portuguese and Chinese rentes, on the invitation of outsiders.

There was a conference yesterday afternoon the headquarters of the Republican County Committee to canvass the Congressional situation in the Seventh Congressional District, in which a special elecition is to be held on Jan. 7 to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Nicholas Muller.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15. -- The rabbis of Baltimore have been discussing the question of Jewish unity. Dr. William Roseman of the Eutaw Place Temple recently said that the need of a united Israel was marked, in view of the conditions by which Israel is surrounded. United Israel, he declared, was the natural resultant of the forces operating in Israel's life.
Commenting on the editorial article in the columns of this journal on Dec. 8 entitled "Vaccine and Antitoxin," The Philadelphia Medical Journal says:

BRUSSELS, Dec. 6. -- At the annual banquet of the Anglo-American Chamber of Commerce in Belgium, held at Antwerp last evening, the United States Minister, Lawrence Townsend, replied to a toast to the President of the United States. After a tribute to Mr. Roosevelt's "unflinching courage and unbending honesty," Mr. Townsend said:
John Swinton, journalist, economist, and orator, died at his home, 658 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, after an illness lasting ten days.

A well-attended meeting of the-Manhattan delegates to the American Bowling Congress, which meets at Buffalo next month, was held, at Thum's White. Elephant alleys yesterday, afternoon, while the Brooklyn delegates met at the Elephant Club in Brooklyn.
GEORGE F. BILL, Chief of Police of Hartford, Conn., for many years, died suddenly at his home in that city early yesterday morning, aged sixty-four. He was a veteran of the civil war.

The predictions of the men who at the behest of the Government of the United States manipulate the weather hereabout, that yesterday was going to be a grand combination of gale and ice, was fulfilled to the letter. Early in the morning the rain was still falling, but it was a different kind of rain from the unpleasant misty affair that made life in the metropolis so miserable Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Very little business beyond the consideration or the HayPauncefote treaty will be transacted in the Senate before the adjournment for the holidays. In accordance with the agreement reached on Friday, the treaty will be voted upon before the Senate adjourns to-morrow. Senator Teller (Silver. Col.) will make the first speech of the day, and will be followed by others with brief talks.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15. -- Rear Admiral W. S. Schley has notified Attorney General Isidor Rayner that he is ready to take any action with reference to his case that Mr. Rayner may advise. Mr. Rayner expects to meet the Admiral in Washington tomorrow or Tuesday. When asked whether he favored a Congressional investigation, Mr. Rayner said:

Physicians throughout the country, and particularly in New York and San Fransisco, are manifesting deep interest in a bill to provide a National leper law, which is likely to be introduced by Senator T.C. Platt in the Senate and by Representative L.P. Wagner of Pennsylvania in the House of Representatives this week.

A writer in The Westminster Review remarks that the attitude of England toward Russia has been "vacillating, absurd, and without result," and that the object of British diplomacy has apparently been to thwart important Russian schemes, in order to obtain unimportant advantages for Great Britain.

In discussing the question of the city's debt limit yesterday, Controller Bird S. Coler said that he had suggested for discussion a proposition that municipal properties which have satisfactorily proved their ability to pay for themselves be exempted from counting against the city's credit.

Price movements in Wall Street this week are not unlikely to show much irregularity and, at times, heaviness -- this because of the condition of the money market and the uncertainty as to the developments likely to come to pass at the dividend meeting of the Amalgamated Copper Company, to toe held on Thursday.

A crowd which filled the large auditorium of the West Side Young Men's Christian Association, 318 West Fifty-seventh Street, to overflowing, was attracted yesterday afternoon by the announcement that speeches would be made at the regular Sunday afternoon meeting by "men of distinction in the football world."

From The Cleveland Leader. The flow of mirth and jollity at the opening ceremonies at the new Ninth Precinct Police Station Wednesday evening was interrupted by a dirty face being pressed against the window of the room where the eatables and good things were displayed.

From The London Standard. BERLIN, Dec. 4. -- In connection with the scientific inquiries as to the possibility of predicting fogs. I may quote a letter from the well-known Prof. Neumayer, head of the Hamburg Naval Observatory, written in reply to a question addressed to him by Herr Kirchoff, the editor of a German technical paper.

Sunday was a day of rest to the sixteen weary riders who finished their six days' grind in Madison Square Garden Saturday night. After the race was over all the contestants took Turkish baths, and then took the first real rest they had had since the race began. They were sent to the Putnam House, just across Fourth 'Avenue from the Garden. Before retiring, however, they dined as liberally as their trainers allowed.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 15. -- Much interest is taken in the expected trip of George B. Cox and other Republican leaders to Washington this week. Owing to the contest between the friends of Senator Foraker and of Senator Hanna over the organization of the Legislature, there is an unusual agitation all over the State.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Miss Maxine Elliott (Mrs. Nat. C. Goodwin) spoke at the ladies' night dinner of the Old Players' Club at the Criterion to-night. Four hundred guests were present. They included William Gillette, Mr. and Mrs. Forbes Robertson, Mr. and Mrs. Holbrook Blinn, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Collins, Miss Marie Tempest, Cecil Raleigh, Henry B. Irving, Paul Arthur, and other American and English players.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I most heartily agree with your editorial of Friday on the subject of park Commissioner. I cannot understand how New Yorkers can be so indifferent to the appearance of their city as to give any one man the right to destroy as he pleases whatever we may have of the beautiful.

MANILA, Dec. 15 -- Gen. J. Franklin Bell has been exceedingly active in Batangas Province, where he intends by every means available to stamp out the insurrection. There are daily small fights between the insurgents and the men of Gen. Bell's command, in which the former are almost invariably routed.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 15. -- Miss Elsie De Wolfe, who is to open in "The Way of the "World" at the Tremont Theatre to-morrow night, brought her pet dog with her when she came to Boston. The rules of the Whipple hotels, Young's, Parker's, and the Touraine, are prohibitive of dogs, as Miss De Wolfe found after domiciling herself in the last-named establishment.

The cold and piercing wind of yesterday daunted even the hardy cross-country runners, and, though some of the scheduled runs were held, the attendance was much less than usual, only the extreme enthusiasts, turning out.

The study of the science of banking, with a view to adapting present methods to the extensive changes now going on rapidly in the business of the country, is, we think, more steadily and vigorously pursued in the West than it is in what we are fond of regarding as the financial centre of the country.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15. -- "One of the greatest floods in the history of Pittsburg was averted only by the sudden drop in the temperature. The rise at the headwater of the Allegheny and Monongahela' Rivers was about stopped at midnight, and the rivers will likely slowly recede."

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- Not since the memorable ice gorge of 1875 has there been such a freshet in the Delaware and Neverslnk. Rivers through this section as there was last night. The Neversink began to rise about 10 o'clock and soon inundated several thousand acres of the Neversink Valley, washing out a considerable portion of the roadbed of the Port Jervis, Monticello and New York Railroad.

From The London Chronicle. The "Peking Colloquial Paper," to give a literal translation of the title of that enterprising journal, has lately been summing up the characteristics of the various nations which are represented in China, and which for a year and more have been represented there in more than usual abundance.

For years David F. Butcher, seventy-eight years old, who once was a wealthy man, lived alone and did his own house-work because he had an unconquerable aversion for women. The last two years he lived almost the life of a hermit in three rooms on the top floor of a rear tenement at 544 West Forty-fifth Street.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 15. -- Congratulations from Newfoundland and abroad are pouring in on Signor Marconi. The inventor is dining to-night with Sir Cavendish Boyle, Governor of Newfoundland, in order more fully to explain the details of his experiments to the Governor, who to-morrow will send a lengthy dispatch on the subject to the British Cabinet.

From The Galyeston News. On last Friday, unlucky day, Col. Dan Henderson received telegraphic advices from friends at Cleveland, Texas, to join them in a deer hunt. If there is anything the Colonel enjoys more than a County Commissioners' meeting, it is a deer hunt, so he accepted the invitation and caught the first train for Cleveland.

The Immense plant of the Brooklyn Cooperage Company, which extends from North Sixth to North Seventh Street, and from Kent Avenue nearly 1,000 feet to the East River, in Williamsburg, was badly damaged by fire yesterday, while many firemen were badly burned while righting the blaze.

Col. PARTRIDGE, the Superintendent of Public Works, indulges in a little mild satisfaction at the showing of the State canals for the year just closed. Owing to a freak of Jack Frost, the season was shorter than last year by about three weeks, the time for an average trip. Despite this curtailment of time, the tonnage carried oh the canals exceeded that of last year by 77,000 tons, and reached the total of 3,420,613 tons.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Mrs. Etta Joseph Swick, wife of a Park Avenue piano manufacturer, died last night. The circumstances surrounding her death caused an official investigation to begin and an autopsy was ordered by County Physician McBride. Dr. Mackintosh and Dr. Pike, the physicians in attendance, refused to grant a death certificate.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 15. -- While the fourth race was being run at New Orleans yesterday Detectives McInerney and Lord raided a poolroom at 100 Market Street, this city. Seven men were taken out of the hundred caught in the place. Upon their arrival at the police station the party was ushered into the big assembly room, while a telephone message was sent to Recorder Senior requesting his immediate attendance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 15. -- Harvard's athletic authorities will probably decline the invitation to row at the Henley and Dublin races next Summer. Prof. Hollis, Chairman of the Athletic Committee, would say nothing about the matter to-day when seen by THE TIMES correspondent, but his attitude in regard to the matter is only too well known by those who remember the question of entering the poughkeepsie regatta last June.

Poorly clad, unshaven, and with a ragged sweater to complete the appearance of poverty, a man was arraigned before Magistrate Brann in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning, and gave his name as Martin Jordan, and said that he had no home. Patrolman Pfeiffer of the Church Stret Station arrested Jordan on West Broadway, near Warren Street, Saturday night for begging.
The results of the weekly, matches of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club are as follows:

CAIRO, Nov. 29. -- North Africa might become a source of trouble between France and Italy, but the departure of the French squadron from Mitylene came just in time to forestall Italian agitation for an expedition to Tripoli.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The correspondent of The Times at Pretoria says the recent British successes occur opportunely, at a moment when the Boers are showing signs of discontent with the life on commando, but the British, instead of congratulating themselves, ought to put forth further efforts, on a bigger scale.

Residents of Manhassett Place, near Rapelye Street, Brooklyn, were aroused from their slumbers shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday morning by the report of a pistol, followed by a scream of pain. Running to their windows they saw a man stagger down the street a short distance, then throw up his hands and drop to the sidewalk, while another man, dressed only in his night clothes, and carrying a revolver, ran up to him.

"The American Sabbath, Especially in Our Large Cities," was the topic of an address delivered by Prof. Felix Adler before the Society of Ethical Culture at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning. From being a believer in keeping the saloons closed on Sunday. Prof. Adler said that he had been brought around to the opposite view.

The discussion now occupying so prominent a place in the colunrms of The London Times of the causes immediately contributory to "The Crisis in British Industry" is in the highest degree educational, but there is reason to fear that those for whom it would contain most instruction are not reached by it.

COLON, Colombia, Dec. 16. -- A schooner which just arrived here from Nombre de Dios, a town on the Caribbean coast, brings the news that the Colombian Government troops, numbering 70, who left Colon a fortnight ago for Viento Frio, had an engagement with the Liberal forces at that town on last Friday.

More than 500 active Republicans attended the complimentary dinner given to the officers of the Republican County Committee at the Waldorf-Astorla last night. Alexander T. Mason, Civil Service Commissioner and Republican leader in the Twenty-ninth District, acted as toastmaster. Having been reappointed by Mayor-elect Low, Mr. Mason was warmly, greeted.

A peremptory writ of mar pel Building Commissioner Wallace to see that the building laws were complied with in the construction of the office building at Broadway and fore Justice Scott, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. The order was issued by Justice Beach and directed Commissioner Wallace to explain why a writ should not be issued compelling him to see that no further violations of the law were allowed on certain structures.

Barutel, the French billiardist, who is matched to meet Schaefer in a 1,200-point contest on the last three nights of this week at the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, corner of Fulton and Jay Streets, Brooklyn, played an exhibition game there yesterday with the former Brooklyn amateur champion, Frank A. Keeney.

The courts have now been called upon to decide the baseball controversy waging between Andrew Freedman and A. G. Spalding. A temporary injunction was served on Mr. Spalding as he was leaving the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, after, a public meeting at which he formally declared Mr. Freedman out of the National League.

Mayor-elect Low yesterday made public the names of twelve more men who have been selected as members of his administration. Three of the most important appointments were announced by Mr. Low at his home, 30 East Sixty-fourth Street, at 6 o'clock last evening. The others were given out earlier in the day.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $19,407,064; balances, $1,865,842. On call money rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. The principal borrowing in Boston is by houses with New York connections. There is very little doing in time money.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 16. -- It appears the resolution offered last week by Senator Clapp (Rep.) of Minnesota in favor of discussing the Hay-Pauncefote treaty in open session was not proposed as a joke. Mr. Clapp told the Senate to-day that he was in earnest in his demand that the public be allowed to listen to the treaty debate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Just before adjourning to-night the Senate confirmed the nomination of Philander C. Knox to be Attorney General of the United States.

PORTLAND. Me., Dec. 16. -- This State to-night is suffering from one of the most severe storms in its history, hourly reports telling of disaster that adds thousands of dollars to the aggregate damage. The three principal rivers and innumerable smaller streams have overflowed their banks, submerging vast areas, washing away bridges, buildings, and great quantities of logs and lumber and flooding factories, mills, and dwellings.

In appointing a distinguished engineer to be Commissioner of Bridges Mr. Low has of course made an innovation. Tammany has no use for experts, except in strictly subordinate capacities, and to the extent to which, experts are a disagreeable political necessity. It may be that the Mayor-elect will find a similar solution in the case of other departments in which technical knowledge is essential, such as the Docks and the Parks.

In a large room at 203 Broadway yesterday morning there took place one of the most remarkable gatherings of representatives of capital and labor in the history of industrial progress. The meeting had been called by the National Civic Federation for the purpose of discussing the relations of capital and labor and, if possible, devising a means for settling strikes.
WICKFOKD, R. I., Dec. 16. -- Gov. William Gregory of Rhode Island died at his home here at 3 o'clock this afternoon. He had been ill for several months.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- The demand for money in the market to-day, was fairly strong, owing to various calls on new issues of capital, including an installment of the Interoceanic Railroad of Mexico second debenture bonds. Discounts were easier, in consequence of larger supplies of cash and inquiries for bills for Continental account.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 16. -- Lord Brazen, a dog, is ill with pneumonia. For the past week he has been confined to his bed, but yesterday there were indications of an early convalescence. The patient is receiving most excellent professional attention. A nurse is with him constantly, night and day, and a skilled surgeon visits him twice daily.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16. -- The cold wave reached a climax this morning when the thermometer registered 24 degrees. The tumble broke the backbone, and to-night it is much warmer. The record of 24 degrees holds good for twenty years for December. Two deaths occurred from freezing last night in New Orleans and one near Bastrop, La.

BOSTON, Dec. 16. -- Dr. Lyman Abbott, at Pilgrim Hall, this morning in his address to Congregational ministers took occasion to reply to the Rev. C. E. Davis, pastor of the Tremont Street Methodist Episcopal Church, who had criticised him in his sermon Sunday.

CARROLLTON, Mo., Dec. 16. -- Dr. Oren Root and Mrs. Anna Quay Quisenbury were married here to-day. The bridegroom is the only brother of Secretary of War Elihu Root. He has been for a long time head of a department in Hamilton College, New York, of which he and his brother Elihu are honor graduates. During his residence in Missouri he took an active part in all important public affairs.

The Junior League is to give a children's carnival, and each member has the right to invite two guests. The entertainment, which is for the benefit of the Messiah Home for Children, will take place on the afternoons of Dec. 30 and 31 at the Carnegie Lyceum. The different circles are rehearsing.

In the Equity Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, before Justice D. Cady Herrick, Edward M. Shepard declared that the civil service examination under which the batch of Police Captains had been appointed in December, 1900, was a hollow farce. The movements of a competitive examination had been gone through with, Mr. Shepard said, but there had been no real competition.

Among the events of to-day will be reeptions by Mrs. H. Duncan Wood and Miss Wood and Mrs. Fraser. This evening will take place the dance given by William C. Whitney for the debut of his stepdaughter. Miss Adelaide Randolph A. double cotillion and two bands will be among the features. The cotillion will be danced before supper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The monthly statement of the exports of domestic products of the United States issued by the Bureau of Statistics, shows that for the month of November. 1001, the exports were as follows: Breadstuffs, $18.901,637: decrease as compared with November, 1900, of $3,000,000.

On dealings involving over 107,000 shares -- one-fifth of the entire market transactions -- Amalgamated Copper yesterday on the Stock Exchange broke 3 5/8 points to 61 7/8, the lowest price on record, where it closed. All through the day the issue was heavy, opening off half a point and rallying but feebly at any time.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The papers this morning express considerable satisfaction at the fact that the United States Senate ratified the Hay-Pauncefote Treaty by such a large majority.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- At a meeting of the creditors of the London, and Globe Finance Corporation to-day the official receiver, Mr. Barnes, announced that the unsecured liabilities of the concern aggregated u1,142,000, with apparently overvalued assets totaling u424,000.

If MARCONI succeeds in his experiments with intercontinental wireless telegraphy his name will stand through, the ages among the very first of the world's great inventors. The thing he is attempting to do would be almost transforming in its effect-upon the social life, the business and political relations of the peoples of the earth.

ACTION AGAINST GUARDIAN'S SURETIES. -- After the death in April, 1897, of Kate Jay Grant, the guardian of Harry G. Van Zandt, a proceeding was begun by Mary A. Van Zandt, the infant's new guardian, against Mrs. Grant's husband, as administrator, for an accounting. The Surrogate's decree adjudged that the balance for which the former guardian was liable to her ward's estate was $2,874.65.

CHESTERFIELD, Dec. 16. -- The long-expected and much-heralded speech by the Earl of Rosebery was delivered here this evening before an immense crowd, and was continually interrupted by prolonged applause. A large range of subjects was discussed, including the war in South Africa, the present position of the Liberal Party, and the commercial development of Great Britain.

At a meeting of the Supreme Court Commissioners of the new East River tunnel, held in the office of the Board of Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners, at 320 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, Albert B. Boardman, one of the counsel to the commission, made the statement that, in his opinion, the tunnel under the East River connecting Brooklyn and Manhattan would be constructed without any cost to the city.

The first thing that strikes an impartial observer in the appointments so far determined, on by Mr. Low -- and the list is nearly complete -- is the singularly high standard of fitness for the duties of the several offices by which he has evidently been guided. There is not a man on the list who is not known to have experience or ability, or both, directly adapted to the work he has to perform.

At a conference composed of twenty-two delegates of local temperance and Sabbath societies, held yesterday under the auspices of the National Temperance Society, and in its rooms, at 3 West Eighteenth Street, resolutions were adopted placing these societies in opposition to the Sunday opening of saloons.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- In an editorial article to-day The Times says the ratification of the Isthmian Canal treaty by such a decisive majority of the United States Senate is a very striking success for President Roosevelt's Administration and for his political friends, who have helped to conciliate and neutralize the hostile elements in the Senate.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- Advices from all sections of the eastern half of Pennsylvania, over which area the storm of Saturday night and Sunday raged furiously, are to the effect that the waters covering the flooded districts are receding and that railroad and telegraphic communication is slowly being restored.

VIENNA, Dec. 16. -- It is officially announced here that, owing to the fact that American shoes are invading the Austrian market, the Ministry of Commerce has bought a number of the latest American shoemaking machines' and will shortly institute a series of lectures and demonstrations for the benefit of the Austrian shoe manufacturers and operatives.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 16. -- The violence of the new Schley controversy which has arisen since the report of the Court of Inquiry far surpasses any phase of the original controversy. Ever since the early days of the court's sessions the anti-Schley men have been asserting that the question of cowardice was not in issue, but now the more extreme among them are asserting that Schley's cowardice has been proved by the court's decision.

Controller-elect Edward M. Grout was the guest of honor at a dinner given by the City Club in the banquet room, of its clubhouse last night. "The Finances of the City of New York" was the subject of the speeches.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- By a vote of 72 to 6 the Senate ratified to-day the HayPauncefote Isthmian Canal Treaty. The vote was reached a few minutes before 5 o'clock, after almost five hours of discussion behind closed doors. There were no sensational incidents during this entire time.

The Alvord estate's property, consisting of a three-story brick dwelling and a stable on a plot 97 by 100, at 4 to 10 West Thirty-first Street, has been bought by the New York Realty Corporation, through John N. Golding. The parcel has been held at about $320,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Mrs. Roosevelt was at home this afternoon from 4 to 6 o'clock, and saw nearly 200 invited visitors who were received in the blue parlor. The occasion was one of a series of at homes through which Mrs. Roosevelt expects to extend hospitality to the large number of persons who have called at the White House since her arrival in Washington.

The two most important and significant speeches made Monday at the conference of the Civic Federation on the relations of labor and capital were those of Mr. PHILLIPS, Secretary of the National Hatters' Union, and of Mr. PFAIILER, stove founder of Philadelphia, who has organized the stove manufacturers.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Money was in good supply at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,324,418; balances, $1,659,391. Money on call rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Time money is quiet. The quick is 5 per cent., though the very choicest collateral loan would probably pass from 4 1/4 to 4 3/4 per cent.

John Kelly, thirty-six years old, a well-known jockey from the South, jumped from a third-story window at Hahn's Hotel, at Brook Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street, at midnight last night. His skull was fractured on the sidewalk and he died soon after his removel to the Harlem Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Developments in the now bitter controversy raised by the conflicting reports of the Schley court are following each other with great rapidity. Rear Admiral Sampson's friends entered the lists to-day and indicated their purpose to fight for the exclusion of Admiral Dewey's report from the record.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 17 -- The Hoyden, Piedrich, and Boomerack were the successful favorites to-day. Jockey H. Wilson was suspended indefinitely for his ride on the filly Leenja yesterday and for his actions on the horse King Tatius in the first race and his ride on the horse Siphon in the third race.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 -- Naval Cadet E.S. Land of Wyoming, who is manager of the crew, is arranging an interesting series of races to take place here next Spring. It is regarded as settled that Yale and the University of Pennsylvania eights will row here, and efforts are being made to bring Harvard also.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 17 -- The local market to-day showed more spirit than at any time since the recent break began in New York last Thursday. Advances were general throughout the list, with Choctaw and Union Traction attaining the greatest distinction. At one period Choctaw common, which closed at 73 3/4 last night, sold at 75, but went back a point in the final dealings.

The meeting of the Board of Aldermen was marked by much excitement before the close of the session yesterday. The Republican minority fought the Tammany majority over an appropriation of $180,000 for the Street Cleaning Department, which would, allow the Street Cleaning Commissioner to purchase Quantities of horses, carts, and other supplies without public bidding.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Money was firm and in active demand to-day. Supplies were inconsiderable, though rather more plentiful than yesterday. No abundance is expected before the New Year, unless the Government disbuses freely. Discounts were depressed by the hardening of foreign exchanges, the small supply of bills, and the continued inquiry from the Continent.

Justice Scott, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, hoard arguments on an application made by certain holders of the preferred stock of the Northern Pacific Railway Company to continue a temporary injunction granted by Justice Beach on Dec. 10, restraining the company from retiring the entire preferred stock of the company (750,000 shares at a par value of $100 a share) on Jan. 1, 1902, pursuant to the resolutions of its Directors adopted on Nov. 13.

-- Analogies and illustrations, much as they help an argument if selected with care and skill, are dangerous, and apt to weaken even a good conclusion, if their relevancy is dubious or deniable. For that reason should the correspondent whose letter in favor of the "American Sunday" in all its traditional strictness we published Monday have refrained from mentioning locomotives and Old clothes as sharing with than the need for rest at stated intervals.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Copper opened to-day at 17s 6d decline, owing to fears of fresh selling in view of the continued break in Amalgamated Copper, but the price hardened on few warrants being available. Seven hundred, tons sold at 49 1/2 to 50 1/4. During the afternoon 200 tons were sold at from 50 1/4 to 51.

Twenty dollars per month per policy shop is believed by ex-Police Commissioner Frank Moss to be the price paid the police for protection by the "Policy King," according to a statement made by him yesterday at the headquarters of the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

The action of the Anglo-American Telegraph Directors in serving on Signor MARCONI papers in a suit for trespass upon the soil of Newfoundland, in which they claim an exclusive monopoly of all telegraphic rights, is an act of folly of which a well-managed corporation should be incapable in this age of general business intelligence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Senator Hale to-day introduced a bill authorizing the enrollment and organization of a United States Naval Reserve.

The German Chancellor is having a bad time with his tariff measure. His rather cynical admission that the rates of duty had been put high to permit the negotiation of commercial treaties with other Governments is resented by Russia and Austria, so far as the official press reflects the views of the Governments, and naturally is criticised by the Opposition.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 17 -- The President entertained at dinner this evening, the guest of honor being the retiring Postmaster General, Charles Emory Smith. There were present the Secretary of the Interior, Senators Spooner, Bate, Foraker, Wetmore, Stewart, Pritchard, Penrose, Mason, Martin, Simon, Foster of Washington, Millard, McCumber, and Kearns, and James R. Sheffield.

Lovers of hockey will be in the heyday of their enjoyment this Winter. An unusually large number of games has been arranged, and beginning with the holiday week, there will be no lack of entertaining competitions until warmer weather calls the young sportsmen to open-air amusements.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The accounts of the executors of the estate Of the late Sheridan Shook were submitted to Surrogate Dorland to-day and approved. At the time of Mr. Shook's death he was supposed to be a millionaire. After the payment of all expenses, however, the total value of his estate is only $51,513,32.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 17 -- T.C. Coleman, a prominent business man, died today at his country home, The Meadows, aged seventy-seven. Mr. Coleman, who came to this country from Cork, Ireland, in 1838, was connected with the steamboat business in its palmy days. It was while engaged in this business that Mr. Coleman, then a steamboat Captain, kidnapped President-elect Zachary Taylor by way of a joke.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 17 -- Harriet P.
