Murphy, prominent in church and society circles and Treasurer of the Kingsley House Fund, was murdered at her home, 6,221 Howe Street, in the East End, by a burglar about 3 o'clock this morning. The murderer made his escape, and although the whole detective and police force of that section was called, the man has not been captured.

The Fifth Avenue Hotel was practically deserted, yesterday as far as the baseball contingent is concerned. A few players and managers came in during the day, but Messrs. Soden and Conant of the Boston Club, who are backing up Andrew Freedman in his fight against A.G. Spalding, left early in the morning.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The banquet of the Chamber of Commerce to-night was largely attended. The Hon. George Raines, in introducing the guest of the evening, Justice William Travers Jerome, facetiously characterized him as the Pan of New York City and proudly spoke of his lineage as being interwoven with the history of Rochester.

As a result of the conferences between representatives of capital and labor which have taken place under the auspices of the National Civic Federation in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation, 203 Broadway, during the present week, there was named last evening a standing committee to take the subject of labor troubles under further consideration and to obviate strikes in the future if possible.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Secretary Root has addressed a letter to Fidel G. Pierra, the representative of the Maso party in Cuba, who is at present in this city, denying his request for a postponement of the Cuban elections. Secretary Roofs letter, which is dated Dec. 16, is as follows:

There were three shifts of authority in the Tombs Prison yesterday, and the day was full of incident for those in authority in the Department of Correction. James J. Hagan was presumably Warden when he arrived at the prison a little before 10 o'clock. There he found that John J. Fallon. Warden of the Blackwell's Island Penitentiary, with a bodyguard of five keepers, in command.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- One of the most important changes in the Senate committees determined in the Republican caucus this morning was the addition of two Senators to the Republican contingent in the Committee on Interoceanic Canal. This action gives the majority party seven members in the committee to the Democrats four, and emphasizes the intention of the majority that whatever canal bill shall be reported shall be recognized as a Republican measure.

Whether or not Lord ROSEBBRT has the stuff in him for a political leader is a question upon which his own countrymen evidently differ widely. But there can be no question that the British need for political leadership is urgent. Lord SALISBURY virtually abdicated some time before he formally resigned the Foreign Secretaryship.

The ball which was given last evening by William C. Whitney for the debut of his stepdaughter. Miss Adelaide Randolph, at his town mansion, 871 Fifth Avenue, was one of the most beautiful entertainments of the kind which New York society has ever enjoyed. The great house was thrown open to a throng of guests, many of them of the younger set.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate to-day confirmed these nominations among others:
ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Adolf Merer of Worcester, Mass., has been appointed Director of the New York State Pathological Institute, at a salary of $5,000 a year.

In compliance with the request of District Attorney Philbin, the trial of Police Captain Cooney, who was to have been arraigned before Commissioner Murphy yesterday, on the charge of neglect of duty in failing to suppress the policy shops of "Al'' Adams which were raided last week, was adjourned sine die.

BUFFALO, Dec. 17 -- In view of the wide discussion incidental to the question of who should pay the physicians who attended President McKinley, Dr. Matthew D. Mann consented to make a statement to-day, setting forth the attitude of himself and his associates. Dr. Mann, in reply to questions by a reporter, said:

Trading in the outside market yesterday showed a little more life than on the first day of the week, and although prices were somewhat irregular, the general tendency of quotations was toward improvement. Net changes that amounted to as much as a point were not numerous, some early advances being later followed by reactions.

CORK, Dec. 17 -- When John E. Redmond, M.P., arrived here he was escorted to his hotel by an enthusiastic and demonstrative crowd, burning tar barrels, carrying torches, and accompanied by bands of music.
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The Times says Commandant Kruitzinger is believed to be the son of British subjects residing near Grahamstown.

The block front on Battery Place, between Washington and West Streets, has been sold by the Hemenway estate of Boston to the Century Realty Company, and resold by the latter to the Battery Place Realty Company, which corporation will erect a sixteen-story office structure on the site. The plot has a frontage of 180 feet on Battery Place, and an average depth of about 41 feet.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Oliver Harriman, Sr., who has a country seat here and is said to be worth at least $5,000,000, was declared insane and incompetent to manage his estate by commission and a Sheriff's jury to-day. He is seventy years old. The petition was made by his eight children, including Oliver Harriman, Jr., and J. Borden Harriman.

Inspired by what she thought was the will of heaven, Miss Sarah R. Mangam, only daughter and heiress of a late resident of Brooklyn, and prominent among the local charity and church workers in that borough, was married last Thursday to an ex-convict, whom she says she has converted to the Baptist Church.

The first of the afternoon concerts of the season of the Kneisel Quartet in this city took place yesterday afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall. The music of the day was taken entirely from the works of Beethoven, for Monday was the anniversary of his birth, and Mr. Kneisel elected to commemorate a fact of so much significance in the history of chamber music.

With her cabins and decks crowded with men and women, teams and trucks, the ferryboat Princeton of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, while steaming out of her slip at the foot of Desbrosses Street on her 5:20 trip to Jersey City last night, crashed into her sister boat, the Hudson City, stayjng a large hole in her on the port side, just aft of the wheelbox, and severely injuring two of the passengers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Postmaster General Smith resigned his office to-day, and the announcement was made that Henry C. Payne of Wisconsin would succeed him. There is not the slightest question that Mr. Smith's resignation was purely a personal matter. There was no question of politics in it.

Mayor-elect Seth Low served notice last evening upon politicians of all the Fusion elements at the dinner of the Republican Club in his honor that if the success of his administration was to depend upon a skillful distribution of the patronage at his disposal it would be a failure. He said that his appointments as well as his actions were to be based upon non-partisan considerations alone, and that this policy would not be altered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The House Committee on Foreign Affairs had an informal hearing to-day on the subject of Chinese exclusion, prominent members of the Asiatic Association being heard in favor of liberal treatment to Chinese merchants, travelers, and students, while Representative Kahn, who represents the San Francisco district, including Chinatown, and Herman Gutstadt, representing the Federation of Labor, spoke for rigid exclusion of the Chinese.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 18. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,127,004; balances, $2,136,372. Money on call rules at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.; the former to strongest borrowers. Time money is nominally 5 per cent. on the mixed collateral which is generally offering.

That John D. Rockefeller is annoyed and embarrassed over the confusion of his name with the stock jobbery in Copper Trust shares is attested in a variety of ways. He is not one of the Amalgamated Copper Company's Directors, is not responsible for its policy, and is not involved in the series of stock market sensations which hosts of critics in Wall Street regard as a scandal.

District Attorney Philbin has assigned assistants to prepare evidence which may lead to the indictment of two Tammany officials and their prosecution by Justice Jerome when he comes into the District Attorney's office on Jan. 1. Three city departments are involved in the investigation.
All but two flint glass bottle manufacturers said to have approved a $30,000,000 consolidation, to be known as the Continental Glass Company.
W.F. PERRYN, who was a Brigadier General in the Confecterate Army during the civil war, died yesterday at his home, in Bowling Green, Ky., from pneumonia, after a brief illness.

Dogs of high degree that have won scores of prizes both in this country and abroad made the Madison Square Garden an interesting and fashionable, attraction yesterday. Over a thousand dogs were barking and yelping merrily on the floor of the Garden by 10 o'clock in the morning when the first show of the Ladies Kennel Association of America officially began.

Columbia's weakness rather than her opponent's strength gave the Hockey Club of New York a decisive victory over the Blue and White seven at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The score was 9 to 0. Columbia's aggregation showed a decided lack of practice, manifested in failure to mass well or shoot accurately.

Hearty indorsement coupled with a pledge of practical support was given to the excise views of Justice William Travers Jerome by the Trustees of the New York State Association of Brewers and Malsters at a meeting of that body in the Brewers Exchange, at 109 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday afternoon.

Trolley Car No. 168 of the Broadway line, loaded to the doors with passengers, suddenly burst into flames shortly before 5 o'clock last evening just as the car was opposite the Hotel Marlborough, Thirtyseventh Street and Broadway. There was a panic among the passengers and a crush of frightened men and hysterical women before the fire could be gotten under control.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The bill to provide revenue temporarily for the Philippine Islands passed the House to-day by a vote of 163 to 128. Five Republicans -- Messrs. McCall of Massachusetts, Littlefield of Maine, and Heatwole, Eddy, and Stevens of Minnesota -- voted with the Democrats against the bill, and three Democrats -- Messrs.

At the annual meeting of the Columbia University Rowing Club yesterday afternoon Edward Hanlan, the coach, predicted that Columbia's 'Varsity crew, at the next intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie, will lower the present record of the four-mile course by 30 seconds. He also said that it was not unlikely that Columbia will have a boathouse of her own on the Harlem River next year, if sufficient subscriptions can be raised.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The correspondent of The Times at Pretoria says the progress of the war is eminently satisfactory, but care should be taken not to imagine that more has been done than is actually the case, in order to avoid subsequent disappointments.

The only important news development in Wall Street yesterday was the announced further cut in the price of raw copper, made by the Amalgamated Company. This, singularly enough, was followed, after some slight recession, by a sharp upward movement in the quotation for Amalgamated Copper, an extreme gain of 4 points being recorded.

Lieut. Fred Fuchs of Engine Company No. 40 and Fireman John Fay of the same company last evening rescued a man, two women, and two children from the five-story apartment house at 372 Columbus Avenue, near Seventy-eighth Street.

A further cut in the price of copper was made by the United Metals Selling Company yesterday. The price is now 14 cents a pound for Lake copper, 13 7/8 cents for electrolytic, and 13 cents for castings.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 18. -- Cotton Duck incomes were the dominating factor in to-day's trading, the break, as a result of the doubt about interest, extending 4 1/2 points further, though the closing was a full point above the lowest. Sentiment was better at the close as the result of some buying that developed.
Dr. George William Shera and Miss May Finlay Bishop, both of Jersey City, were married at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- When the Senate to-day acted upon nominations, it did not pass upon those of Capt. William Crozier to be Chief of the Ordnance Bureau, with the rank of Brigadier General; Col. George L. Gillespie, to be Chief of Engineers, and Gen. George B. Davis, to be Judge Advocate General, and other nominations dependent upon these three.
The Phoenix National Bank denies that it is to be absorbed, sold, or otherwise changed from its present form.

Miss Metcalfe's name is all but unknown in New York, but it is safe to prophesy that more will be heard of her. At her song recital in Mendelssohn Hall yesterday afternoon her programme, if not altogether judiciously selected, showed a wide range in styles and emotional expression, containing such names as Mozart, Scarlatti, Weckerlin, (an arrangement of a seventeenth century pastorale,) Orlando di Lasso, Handel, Haydn, Schubert.

The City Real Property Investing Company is the buyer of the dwellings 27 and 29 East Sixty-second Street. It is said that purchases by the same company cover several adjoining parcels, although the brokers who have been conducting the negotiations would neither confirm nor deny this report yesterday.

The new map of the Borough of the Bronx, which, according to Controller Coler, will involve the city in expenditures of between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000, was passed at a meeting of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday. The plan for the approach to the new East River Bridge was also adopted.

Seven men and a big Newfoundland dog were brought to New York by the Panama liner Advance yesterday, having been rescued from what remained afloat of the three-masted schooner Edward M. Young off Cape Hatteras, at 7 o'clock Monday morning. The men were without water and nearly frozen to death when the Advance sighted them.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 18. -- The University of Nebraska Athletic Board announced this afternoon the re-election of Walter C. Booth of Princeton as football coach for next year, with the privilege of remaining three years.

The more the incident of the proceedings of the Anglo-American Cable Company against Signer MARCONI is considered, the more evident it becomes that the management of that company is in the hands of short-sighted, narrow-minded, unprogressive persons who are much in need of supplementing the Lord's Prayer with a petition to be taught to know their daily bread when they see it.

Not so large an audience listened to Kubelik in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon as was present at his first two concerts, but it was characterized by the same indiscriminate applause that has been noted before. This seems to show that the sensation seekers still constitute the greater part of his hearers, and that he has not yet made a strong appeal to the truly musical public.

And American girls are coming to this! It is a pretty little ornament for the hair. There is a narrow bow of white velvet and a spray of green leaves with whitish berries, and no one would doubt for an instant what it is -- mistletoe. To be sure, it is only an imitation, but to think of what might happen with that sham!

When the curtain fell on the third and last act of "The Marriage Mart," ("Der Heirathsmarkt,") a farce, by one George Okonkpwski, seven happy maidens and seven happy men stood, united in as many happy couples, artistically arranged in groups, which covered all that part of the stage which was not taken up by the furniture.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- A call for L 750,000 for local loans and repayments to the Bank of England to-day increased the demand for money. The supplies were not abundant, owing to the absence of disbursements. Discounts were sympathetically firm.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 18, 1901. -- Regarding the statement given out by the solicitors of the Anglo-American Telegraph Company, Signor Marconi explains that the letter from the company to himself, which is referred to, was only its second letter to him, and was written after the substance of the first letter had been made public.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 18. -- Announcement was made to-day by officials of the Carnegie Company of the organization of the Andrew Carnegie Relief Fund, and the plan of its operation. Prior to his retirement last Spring, Mr. Carnegie tendered to the Board of Directors of the company $4,000,000, to be held in trust, and the income to be used as a pension and relief fund for old employes.

Leading teams met with defeat in two of the local bowling tournaments last night. In the Commercial League the team of H.A. Caesar Co. met with their first defeat of the season at the hands of the Hackett, Carhart Co. bowlers, and in the Greater New York Tournament the Bushwick Council team lost in a similar manner to the Templeton five.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The selection of Henry C. Payne to succeed Mr. Smith as Postmaster General has occasioned a vast amount of political gossip. Some of the politicians profess to see in the appointment a good deal more than the apparently natural choice by the President of one of his closest personal and political friends as a member of his Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- Provision for a permanent civil government and for much important legislation regarding the industrial development of the Philippines is embodied in the annual report of the Philippine Commission.

To-day at 2 o'clock the Fire Committee of the Board of Aldermen go through the form of granting a public hearing to those who desire to be heard, pro or con, on the subject of amending or rescinding Section 105 of the existing code of building laws for New York, which reads as follows:

Final steps were taken yesterday in organizing the work of the Industrial Department of the National Civic Federation, and it is now prepared to avert strikes and to settle labor troubles when called upon.

Superintendent of Buildings Perez M. Stewart and Consulting Architect William Martin Aiken called at the Building Department yesterday afternoon and spent two hours looking over the ground and becoming familiar with the workings of the department. Mr. Stewart said last night that with Mr. Aiken he would spend much of the time up to Jan. 1 in learning the routine of the department.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- David Lloyd-George, M.P., tried to speak in Birmingham Town Hall to-night, and precipitated a scene unprecedented in that city since the Aston Park riots.

The upper half of the six-story carriage factory of Burr Co. on the northwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street and the adjoining property of the Diamond Rubber Company, were nearly destroyed last night by a spectacular fire which raged over an hour before it was gotten under control.

Herman Nutt, eighteen years old, clerk in a Fulton Street liquor store, who was found dead in bed Tuesday morning in his furnished room in the house of Mrs. Elizabeth Lewis, at 8 Bedford Street, is believed now to have been murdered. It was supposed that he had died from natural causes, and the body was removed to the undertaking establishment of Henry E. Howe, 5 Seventh Avenue, on a Coroner's permit.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The big hotel at the Schuetzen Park, Broadway and Steinway Avenue, Long Island City, the hall, pavilion adjoining, and stable were destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The loss is about $30,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- It was announced at the White House to-day that the President has decided to send to the Senate to-morrow the nominations of Charles F. Gallenkamp of Union, Mo., to be Surveyor of the Port of St. Louis, in place of Charles H. Smith, and Charles F. Wenneker of St. Louis to be Collector of Internal Revenue.

-- An agent of the Dominion Coal and Iron Company has been down in Alabama after men to work in the big mills that have turned a little Cape Breton village almost in a night to a fairly accurate imitation of Pittsburg. He has lured enough negroes from the Birmingham works to fill three cars, and they have started on their way North.

There is something admirably modern and enlightened in the spirit and in the result of the conference between the representatives of labor and of capital brought about by the National Civic Federation. War is waste and the avoidance of waste is one of the most notable characteristics of intelligent business methods in the present day.

Conditions in the outside market yesterday showed little or no change, prices remaining firm and transactions being about as large as those of Tuesday. A number of issues were in fairly good demand, with the result that closing quotations were in many cases somewhat above the final prices of the previous day.

The Lorillard dance at Sherry's was the most notable entertainment of last evening. Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry gave a dinner of forty covers, many of the guests of which afterward went to the Lorillard dance. There was also the Christmas festival for the benefit of the Stony Wold Sanatorium at the Waldorf-Astoria, with its representation of the dances given in Newport at Mrs. Cowley's assembly room.

From his own point of view as Chancellor, VON BUELOW does well to meet the complaints of the Poles of Prussia with a brazen front. That Prince FERDINAND RADZIWILI, should be the spokesman for the Polish-speaking sections of Eastern Prussia is a little awkward, owing to the close connections in the past between the Hohenzollerns and Radziwills; but the Prince in question is not likely to prove a very formidable agitator.

Ex-Judge William Scott of Paterson yesterday applied to Vice Chancellor Pitney, at Jersey City, for an order construing the will of George Beesley, who died in Paterson in 1890. Beesley was supposed to be a poor man, and the surprise was great when it was discovered that he had left an estate valued at $150,000.

This may be an interesting and very important day for the warring baseball factions. The argument on the injunction obtained by Andrew Freedman restraining A. G. Spalding from acting as President of the National League, will be heard in Part I. of the Supreme Court, before Justice Scott. The result is of the utmost importance to each side, and it was stated yesterday that the opposing factions are anxious for a quick decision.

The first of the Thursday evening dinner dances for this season took place at Delmonico's last night. This series of dances was organized last Winter by Mrs. Frederic J. de Peyster and J. Montgomery Strong.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 19. -- By an explosion of gas in the Soho furnace of Jones Laughlin, near Brady Street, this city, at 6:20 o'clock this morning, nine men were burned to death, three injured so badly that they are not expected to live, and two others dangerously hurt. The damage to the plant will amount to $20,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- A representative of the Foreign Office says that the law requiring the inspection of foreign meat at German ports of entry has neither been decreed nor is in force, nor has the date of its promulgation been determined.

A public hearing was held yesterday on the proposed amendment to the Building Code which will allow the builders of skyscrapers over twelve stories in height to use non-fireproof material in many important parts of the structures. The present building law requires that every part of buildings over 150 feet in height shall be fireproof.

The following expression of the views of Postmaster General SMITH was cited in our Washington dispatches of Wednesday. It is so sensible and fits so well the facts as they have been brought out in the experience of many years that it is worth while to call especial attention to them:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- The attempt to sell to-day at public auction the old United States Mint building, Chestnut and Juniper Streets, proved a failure. The Government has fixed a minimum price of $2,000,000 for the property, and consequently the highest bid received, $1,500,000, was not entertained.

PRINCETON, Dec. 19. -- The prospects for a good gymnasium team this season are so bright that an unusually large schedule has been arranged. The candidates have been practicing daily, and are showing up excellently. All of last year's team but one are in college, and several good men have been found in the entering class who can fill the vacancy.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Supplies of money were limited to-day owing mainly to trifling Government disbursements. The market was entirely controlled by the Bank of England. The firmness of rates sustained discounts.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 19. -- Reliable information from a Cincinnati man, who is in a position to know, is to the effect that Judge William H. Taft, Governor of the Philippines, is returning to this country upon the request of the President, who, the informant says, has tendered to him the Secretaryship of State.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- J. Spencer Van Cleef, one of the most prominent lawyers in this city and county, died at his home suddenly this evening. He had been in ill-health for some time, but was able to attend to his business at his home and was not considered in a serious condition.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- A telegram from Dublin to The Times says the absolute authority which the United Irish League demands and secures, not only in regard to the disposal of lands by private persons, but also in regard to the allocation of public appointments and contracts, is constantly being illustrated.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- "History affords no parallel of a whole people thus practically turning war traitors, and in the genius of no other people was ever found such masterful powers of secrecy and dissimulation; but it is needless to say that no powerful state was ever erected, or ever can be erected, on such immoral and unenlightoned foundations."

The Republican County Committee held its annual meeting last evening and organized for the year 1902, re-electing the officers who are serving this year and the present Executive Committee as well. The meeting was held in the assembly hall of the United Charities Building.

During a fire in the studio of Louis Proudfoot Son on the second floor of 1,695 Broadway, at 5:30 yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Mary Ferris, seventy years old, was about to jump from the top floor window when she was prevented by Policemen J.T. Conway and Henrich Stool and carried to the roof.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner has completed his statistical tables for the school year ended July 31, 1901.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Chicago is staring a coal famine in the face, and 15 degrees betow zero is predicted by the Weather Bureau within twenty-four hours. Throughout the entire city big consumers of hard and soft coal are begging shippers to supply them, but without avail. The severe weather and the floods throughout the coal mining districts have tied up railroads to such an extent that shipment is almost impossible.

Jan Kubelik's Stradlvarius sang the song of his people last night in the Bohemian National Hall, 321 to 325 East Seventy-third Street. There were seventy-one notes to the song, ten two beat, thirteen one beat, and forty-six half beat notes. He played the Bohemian National air and used the G string only.

The medical fraternity of the entire city discussed yesterday the paper read Wednesday night before the Medico Legal Society by Dr. John Duncan Quackenbos, emeritus Professor of Psychology in Columbia University, in which he told of a young actress who a few months ago won fame in a single night while under the spell of hypnotic, suggestion.

The week draws to a close, but the dances are still on. Last evening there were two, and society practically was divided in its allegiance. This evening the dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Poor for Miss Edith Poor will take place. Miss Elsie Waterbury will also make her debut at a theatre party to be given to-night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James M. Waterbury.

The Authors' Club gave a reception to Mayor-elect Seth Low last evening in the club rooms in the Carnegie Building. About 200 men, including members and a score or so invited guests, were present. George Cary Eggleston, President of the Council of the club, introduced the members and their friends to Mr. Low.
BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 19. -- There is no change in the international situation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hitchcock entertained at dinner this evening. Their guests were Chief Justice Fuller and Mrs. Fuller, Attorney General Knox and Mrs. Knox. Assistant Secretary of State Hill and Mrs. Hill, Senator and Mrs. A.H. Platt, Surgeon General Sternberg and Mrs. Sternberg, Col. Bingham and Mrs. Bingham, Judge and Mrs. Vandeventer, Miss Hitchcock, and Dr. Charles Clinton Swisher.

In the Columbia Bowling League tournament on Schlusing's Columbia alleys last night the, Belvidere Bowling Club team rolled scores of 1,003 and 998, an average of 1,000 1/2. The first total is a new high-team score for the tournament. In the American National tournament the Monarch team scored 1,048, of which Walters made 257.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the reading of the majority report of the Schley court of inquiry and from the light of surrounding circumstances and the testimony I am led to the following suggestions:

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 19. -- Sir Cavendish Boyle, Governor of Newfoundland, gave a large luncheon in honor of Signor Marconi to-day. Among those present were Premier Bond, the Cabinet Ministers, and the heads of departments. The affair was practically a State function.
Details will be found in another column regarding the sale of the Broadway Tabernacle property, at Broadway and Thirtyfourth Street, as the site for a twentystory hotel.

Charles P. Chipp, who for a score of years was a trusted official in the Finance Department, was arrested last evening. He will have to answer to charges of abstracting from the cash drawer of a department of the Controller's office during the past seven years the sum of $30,000.

Recorder Goff, before whom Wardman Edward Glennon of the "Tenderloin" station, is on trial, created something of a sensation yesterday afternoon when, at the close of the hearing for the day, he announced that the jury would not be allowed to separate until the case was concluded and a verdict rendered, and that, beginning with to-day, he would hold night sessions.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Dec. 19. -- Nearly all the 2,500 men employed by the American Car and Foundry Company are idle because of the cold weather. The steam pipes all over the plant have been frozen for several days, and at Howard's Shipyard not a wheel is turning, more than 300 employes being temporarily idle.

Yesterday's stock market was essentially a "waiting" market, nearly all speculative activity, save and except in Copper itself, coming to a halt during the day because of the uncertainty in respect to the probable action of the Amalgamated Directors at their meeting scheduled for the afternoon.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 19. -- The renewed stirring up on the old controversy over the length of the course for a 'Varsity crew race is interesting Yale men. Yale crew men have always held that a four crew course is the only proper distance in which the merits of two crews can be decided, but there is a general sentiment among.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Dec. 10. -- The steamship Kanawha Bell, which runs between Charleston and Montgomery, went over lock No. 3 at Pant Creek on her down trip to-night, broke in two and is a total wreck.
The first concert of the ninth season of the Musical Art Society took place last night at Carnegie Hall. The programme was as follows:

John D. Rockefeller, Jr., made the address of welcome last evening at The Club, 11 West Forty-fifth Street. The occasion was an informal reception given by the Young Men's Bible Class of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, of which class Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., is the leader, to the honorary members of the class.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says the ceremony, of unveiling the Baudin monument is to take place next Sunday, and will assume a disproportionate importance, because of the attitude of the Municipal Council, which is controlled by Nationalists.

The cable has transmitted to us a remarkable suggestion of a Berlin newspaper, though less remarkable than it would be if the cable had not already familiarized us with the ways of looking at things of the Berlin press in general, and of this newspaper, the Kreuz Zeltung, in particular.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- Stagnation prevailed in the local stock market to-day. Reading being the only issue of which over 1,000 shares were sold. Price variations were trivial, and at the close the list stood about where it started this morning. There was a demand for Union Traction at a fraction below the market, and Lehigh Valley reflected a stronger tone.
Army. Capt. Wilbur E. Dove, Twelfth Infantry, having been found physically disqualified to perform the duties of a Captain of infantry, his retirement is announced, to date from Dec. 17.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The smoke of battle has cleared away; the glorious victory over Tammany, has been celebrated; our chieftain and his elected associates have prepared themselves for entrance upon their duties, and soon we shall be in enjoyment of pure and upright government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Observing, at a trifle long range, the good work your paper is doing in the attempt to restore to the army the right to have beer with other mild drinks sold at the post exchange, I have thought that the following facts in the history of one man of my command might be pertinent:

Dog fanciers thronged the Madison Square Garden yesterday in greater numbers than on the previous day, when the bench show of the Ladies' Kennel Association of America was opened. The judge's were hard at work all day, and they succeeded in cleaning up nearly all the classes, and all that remains for to-day is the award of the special cups.

Mrs. Sallie M. Blanchard, wife of supreme Court Justice James A. Blanchard of 17 East Eightieth Street, was crossing Fifth Avenue at Twentieth Street yesterday afternoon when she was run down by a livery coupe driven by James Cavanaugh of 1,009 Sixth Avenue, which was going north and carrying Mrs. J.A. Montant of 30 West Forty-ninth Street.

The Rev. Dr. CUYLBR, who has earned a right to advise as to public questions, and especially questions involving moral considerations, by long years of conscientious devotion to civic duty, writes in this week's Evangelist on "GOD'S Day and the German's Beer." His general position is thus defined in his opening sentences:

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Presidents and executive officers of various railroads met today at the Great Northern Building to put a stop to the indiscriminate rate cutting that has been going on west of the Missouri River. It was deemed inadvisable to take any concerted action that might be construed as a violation of the anti-trust law, so each road pledged itself individually to strictly maintain tariff rates after Jan. 1.

-- Our recent assertion that the Nova Scotians in particular, and the inhabitants of the Maritime Provinces in general, are "practically Americans," was criticised with some fierceness by a few people who, though finding it convenient to live in the United States, like to preserve the belief that our northern boundary line is something more than a mark on the map.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 19. -- The H.B. Claflin Company of New York has closed a deal with Samuel Posner for the purchase of his big department store in this city, and will assume charge Jan. 1. The transaction involves over $500,000.

Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage was the first speaker at the annual dinner of the bankers of the City of New York, comprising Group VIII. of the New York State Banking Association, which was held last night in the ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. The Secretary urged the federation of the individual National banks in one central institution, and the currency reforms recommended in his recent annual report to Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Before the House adjourned to-day for the holiday recess, a special order was made for the consideration of the Nicaragua Canal Bill to begin on Tuesday, Jan. 7, and to continue until the measure is disposed of. The order, however, is not to interfere with revenue or appropriation bills.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19. -- The Committee on Commerce and Reciprocity of the Pan-American Congress has agreed substantially on Its report, which has been prepared by Pablo Macedo of the Mexican delegation.

There has been an undercurrent of rumor in banking circles for the past few weeks to the effect that Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage was to resign. Many other rumors concerning the future actions of Mr. Gage and the probability of his accepting a position in one of the financial institutions in this city have kept company with the one concerning his probable retirement.

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- The Rev. Dr. Charles Henry Brent of St. Stephen's Church, in this city, was to-day consecrated as the first Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the Philippine Islands. The consecration ceremonies took place in Emmanuel Church, and were attended by eleven Bishops and 140 clergymen of the Episcopal denomination.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 19. -- Favorites won four of the races on to-day's card. Garter Ban won the third race at the long price of 50 to 1 without backing. The stable attributed the win to the running of the horse without blinkers. The Waldo boys, Jed and Willie, who accompanied the Corrigan stable to England, arrived to-day, and probably will ride during the meeting.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- A romantic story was disclosed in the trial here to-day in the Orphans' Court of an action by which Miss Allenia C.W. Sharpe of Salisbury, Conn., a woman of thirty, seeks to set aside the will of her grandfather, who was an eccentric retired New York merchant.

Of the proposed appointments announced by Mr. Low last evening, that of Mr. WELLS as Tax Commissioner will generally be recognized as excellent. He was one of the not too many appointees of Mr. STRONG who made a good record and whose intimate knowledge of the subject matter of his work Inspires confidence.

A somewhat better tone prevailed in the outside market yesterday, and at the close quotations were as a rule above those of the previous day. Transactions were not unusually large in any part of the list, al though the total exceeded that of Thurs day. The termination of the uncertainty about the dividend on Amalgamated Copper favorably influenced the copper shares and resulted in some net advances in this group.

The week closes with a spurt of gayety. Last evening there were two notable entertainments. One of these was the debut of Miss Edith Poor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Poor, and the other the theatre party and dance for Miss Elsie Waterbury, another debutante, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Waterbury.

A.G. Spalding, through his counsel, Alfred Kiddle, consented yesterday before Justice Scott in the Supreme Court to a continuance of the temporary injunction obtained by Andrew Fredman form Justice Leventritt on Monday restraining Spalding from exercising any of the powers of President, Secretary, or Treasurer of the National Baseball League until such time as the action instituted by Mr. Freedman be brought to trial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Cabinet situation was cleared up to a considerable extent to-day. It was made known that Secretary Gage has decided to leave the Cabinet, and that Secretary Hay is to remain. The latter fact was announced positively and authoritatively, and the former is known to be equally correct.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial to-day entitled "Dr. Cuyler on God's Day," you quote the preamble of my article in The New York Evangelist, but you do not quote any of the subsequent arguments which I give in favor of closing the dramshops on the Sabbath.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The local stock market feature to-day was the declaration of a 2 per cent. Philadelphia and Erie dividend, the first distribution since 1894. Following the announcement the stock went up to 46 1/2 bid, the highest in its history. The highest sale was at 46, at which the stock closed.
PEKING, Dec. 20 -- Yuan-Shi-Kai, the new Viceroy of Pe-Chi-Li has enganged Japanese officers to train the Chinese Army.

Harry Furniss and Lewis Carroll. In his "Confessions of a Caricaturist," just published by Harper Brothers, Harry Furniss tells some anecdotes of Lewis Carroll of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" fame.
The third public rehearsal of the sixtieth season of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall The programme was as follows:

Preparations have been completed for the Christmas music in the churches of New York. The Christmas music is designed to cover several services in each church. These will begin with the Christmas Eve celebrations for children in some of the churches and finish with the evening services the following day.

At the reception to Mayor-elect Low given by the Authors Club on Thursday evening of this week Mr. Stedman, in the course of his address of welcome remarked that "there can be no world of letters apart from the world of life." He illustrated this truism in its newer application, now becoming better understood than in former times, by citing several men who, in late years, have risen from authorship to public service.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 -- The advance in United Railways issues was the feature to-day. The strong opposition that has been excited against the projecting of a new railway company was the cause, inasmuch as the prospect of such a company operating here was the chief depressing influence that carried the securities lower.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I am deeply impressed with a sense of the favor that has been done to me in the review of my work on "The Science of Draw Poker," but after the manner of thin-skinned authors, I am impelled to register a protest on one or two points.

Mr. Carpenter has prepared for The Beacon Biographies Series a critical estimate of Longfellow. Abundant material is found in Longfellow's published journal, and in his brother's "Life," which contains extracts from his correspondence. Shorter biographies, notably those of Underwood, Austin, and Kennedy, all published in 1882, were superseded by the authorized "Life."
THE Authors Club turned out in large force last Thursday evening when it welcomed to its rooms in the Carnegie Building Mr. Seth Low, the Mayor-elect of Greater New York.

Aroused from their sleep by smoke and flames which threatened to destroy the Baroness de Hirsch Institute building, on East Sixty-third Street, near Third Avenue, last night 100 girls clad only in their night, robes tumbled out of their beds and fled to the top floor. Crowding in one of the rooms, the girls struggled to get out on the window sill to jump to the street.

An informal set of mounted games, followed by a smoker, was given last night by Squadron A in its armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. The most skillful horsemen of the three troops competed in a series of events which embodied a number of difficult and clever manoeuvres on horseback, and the non-contestants lined in the balcony seats and shouted their applause at every successful move.

The article which we print to-day in conjunction with Literature, under our special arrangement with The London Times, calls up the general subject of the illustration of works of fiction. Dickens was more fortunate than most novelists, perhaps, in the selection of his illustrators.

The merit of the objections raised by the counsel of Admiral SAMPSON to the minority opinion of Admiral DEWEY, giving to SCHLEY the credit of the victory at Santiago as the officer in command, may be judged from the single specimen of statements and reasoning.

An appeal for the aid of starving and destitute Boer women and children has just been sent out by several well-known philanthropic women, a few of them Americans, to which is added also the appeal of the Rev. Herman D. von Broekhuizen of Pretoria.

Solid silver makes one of the gifts which is generally welcome, and all sorts of presents, big and little, can be found in it. There are a number of things that are absolutely new this year, some of them coming out within the last few days.

The return of Forefathers' Day and the perennial comment upon the significance of the Puritan movement in English and American history is a wholesome fact in our National life, for it induces comparisons between the past and the present which are always useful, and it serves to keep before our people certain ideals which in their essence are needful for healthy National life.

From 10 o'clock yesterday morning until 12:25 o'clock this morning Recorder Goff held court in General Sessions to try Edward G. Glennon on the charge of a misdemeanor in failing to suppress a disorderly house at 148 West Thirty-third Street when he was a precinct detective, or wardman, in the Tenderloin.

"LETTERS to Washington" to be read in the volume under notice comprise the correspondence addressed to the Father of his Country between the years 1770 and 1774. In 1770 Washington was thirty-eight years of age.

Foxhall P. Keene acted as judge of a decidedly picturesque feature of the dog snow in the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. It was judging two sets of foxhounds, and the novelty proved to be one of the most entertaining attractions, from the spectacular viewpoint of the entire show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The objection of Admiral W.T. Sampson to that portion of Admiral Dewey's report of the Schley court of inquiry in which he says Admiral Schley was in command at the battle off Santiago and entitled to the credit for the victory, was filed with Secretary Long today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Hamlin Garland and Richard Harding Davis spent a few days in Philadelphia recently, the latter telling of a trip he is now planning to make which will take him across the continent of South America. It is somewhat characteristic of the man that he speaks regretfully of the recent political developments there, which may cheat him out of a personal view of the revolution of the past few weeks.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20 -- That a railroad from Omaha to Emporia, Kan., backed by the Missouri, Kansas and Texas, with the Santa Fe as a possible lessee, is in active hands, and good capital backing it, is a certainty. Richard Nevin, Jr., of St. Louis has been in this city for two weeks interesting local capital for the project, which comprehends as a basis of immediate profit the packing house products now sent eastward.

Mrs. Earle's "Old Time Gardens" is a most welcome book. It is replete with memories of old days and old flowers, and when these pleasures are restored, accompanied by a wealth of floral and garden lore, one cannot but acknowledge the potency of the spell that arouses yearnings for old village gardens and flowers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The United States Philippine Commission In its report to the Secretary of War urges that such slavery as exists In the Philippines at the present time be not Interfered with forcibly by the United States Government at this time. It is argued that if the present system be prevented from spreading, the institution of slavery will be killed without serlous difficulty or embitterment.

Within a week the Corn Exchange Bank of this city will have added probably one of Brooklyn's most substantial institutions to the number it already controls. The bank in question is the Mechanics and Traders', situated at Franklin and Green-point Avenues.

The issue of a new edition of the lyrics and epistles of Q. Horatius Fiaccus in the early days of the twentieth century and in the City of New York, commented on elsewhere in this issue by Mr. Bocock, may seem to some minds an anomalous proceeding. But it is not. To be sure, New York is a long way from the Rome of the Augustan age in its attitude toward art and literature.

-- Even of the people who have never been particularly worried over what is known as "unearned Increment," not a few must have found cause for disquieting thoughts and uneasy questionings when they read about the sale of the Broadway Tabernacle. Here Is a piece of property that In 1857 cost the organization which has just disposed of It the sum of $78,500.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have been much interested in your discussion of the manners of book advertising. It is somewhat wearying to contemplate the book advertisements of the present time, each screaming at the top of its voice to drown out what every other publisher has to say, but in this disagreeable hubbub blackness and largeness of type are not the only objectionable features.
Dr. George Bayles. Dr. George Bayles died at his residence, in Orange, N.J., yesterday morning. His illness was brief and his death sudden, as until Wednesday he had been able to attend his practice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- It is stated by persons believed to be well-informed that Thomas Fitchie will not remain long in the office of Commissioner of Immigration for the Port of New York. The President is said to be dissatisfied with conditions existing on the island, and with methods prevalent there.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Money at the Clearing House was in good supply at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $20,375,438; balances, $1,143,772. On call, money rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Time money is nominally 5 per cent., though exceptions are noted on both sides of this figure.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The certificate of incorporation of the American Lumber Company, capital $8,000,000, was filed here to-day. The articles set forth the objects to be to acquire and sell timber, farming, grazing, mineral. and other lands, to mine coal, ores, stone, and to construct bridges, buildings, machinery, ships, railroads, docks, water works, gas works, electric works,
NO MORE beautiful gift book for man or boy could have been devised than Doubleday, Page Co. have magnificently made of Mr. Wallihan's photographic pictures of the game of the Rocky Mountains.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Schley case is moving rapidly toward a climax. This afternoon Judge Advocate General Lemly handed to Secretary Long a paper signed by himself and his assistant, Mr. Hanna, in which they reply to Admiral Schley's bill of exceptions and sharply assail the Admiral and his counsel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Judge Advocate Lemly and Solicitor Hanna of the Navy Department to-day filed with Secretary Long their joint reply to the bill of exceptions already filed by Admiral Schley and his counsel.

THE relations which existed between Dickens and the artists who illustrated his books were most intimate. To-day it is the publisher who chooses the artist and approves or disapproves of his work. But Dickens was more particular and superintended the choice of subject for illustrations and the manner of the treatment of it in his books.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20 -- The ball given to-night by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Brown at their Cathedral Street residence in honor of their debutante daughter, Miss Harriet Brown, was the most brilliant event that has occurred in Baltimore in a number of years.

INTERSTICES of a fog-soaked ' Summer I filled with a few books, some of which were sent to me and others on which I drifted. It is not my intention to review them but I would like to say how they impressed me and to compare my impressions with those of others.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 20 -- Meme Wastell, Bristol, and Alard were the winning favorites to-day. Weather clear and cold. Track hard. Summary:

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The "Theocratic Unity" trial was ended to-day. A verdict of guilty was found against Theodore and Laura Jackson, (Ann O'Delia Diss Debar,) who were sentenced, respectively, to fifteen years and seven years' penal servitude. The defendants heard the sentences with astonishment, but in silence.

We have just received the official report of the celebration of "Founder's Day" last month at the Carnegie institute, at Pittsburg. It contains, among other things, a very vigorous protest, in the form of a speech by Mr. J.W. ALEXANDER, the well-known painter, against the continuance of the tariff tax on works of foreign art.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Booker T. Washington addressed the Outlook Club here to-night, and pleased a big audience, who applauded heartly his remarks. His subject was "The Citizenship of the American Negro."

ASSESSMENT NOT INVALID -- John Havens and another, in July, 1895, when assessed $5,600 on their four lots in Dyckman Street for its improvement from the Hudson River to Exterior Street, paid the amount to the city under protest, claiming the assessment was wholly illegal. Then then sued the city to recover back the amount paid.

ARECENT volume of the Century Company's Thumbnail Series gives English readers an interesting selection from famous translations of the lyrics of Horace. A more ambitious production is to come from Boston on behalf of the Bibliophile Society, to whose Horatian enterprise -- its first -- the aid of a Latin professor in Harvard and an English professor in Columbia has been invited.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Owing to the unsettled state of the copper situation, the shares of that metal in the Boston stock market to-day bordered on a state of demoralization, although the business transacted was not heavy. Calumet and Hecla slumped violently from 580 to 535, rallying to 550 later.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Admiral Sampson's family and friends are annoyed by the persistency with which reports that he Is in a dying condition are circulated whenever the Schley controversy takes a new turn. When the Schley court was convened, and efforts were made to make him a party to it, these reports were industriously circulated.

Broadway, near Forty-eighth Street, was treated to an unexpected bath last night by the bursting of a twenty-inch high pressure water main that lay under the sidewalk at the northeast corner. The break first made itself evident at thirty minutes past 10 o'clock, when a column of water shot into the air-twenty feet.

After an experience on a wrecked schooner in mid ocean for more than two weeks, Capt. Frank H. Lowell, his wife, sister-in-law, and his crew of three men of the schooner W.H. Card of Bucksport, Me., arrived here yesterday on the North German Liovd liner Barbarossa from Bremen, Germany.

THE man who since the death of Dr. J.G. Holland has conducted one of the greatest monthly magazines, and long before that sad event was the editor of Hours at Home and associate editor of scribner's Magazine, predecessor of The Century, is naturally a person who rouses curiosity us to his methods of work.

The disclaimer by the German Ambassador at Washington of any purpose on the part of his Government of acquiring a naval station or other "foothold" in the West Indies, or In any part of Central or South America, was so frank, full, and explicit that it was received and recognized throughout the United States as entirely satisfactory.
"FINANCIAL CRISES." together with "Periods of Industrial and Commercial Depression," by Theodore E. Burton, is the title of an important book which D. Appleton Co. will publish early in the new year.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 20 -- The Black Diamond Steel Works of Park Brothers, on Thirtieth Street, was the scene this morning of an accident in which at least five workmen lost their lives and twelve were injured by the explosion of the four large boilers in the building. The boiler works of James McNeil, adjoining, were also destroyed.

This is a practical, not a poetical age, and yet there was probably never a time in the history of literature when so much new verse found its way into print. But, despite this fact, very few of those engaged in the pleasant occupation of versemaking could earn a respectable living at that pursuit alone.

Everything that Mr. GAGE said to the bankers on Thursday evening in regard to the advantages of a central bank on the federative principle probably received the assent of a large part of his hearers. What undoubtedly they would have been glad to hear from him is the specific plan by which such an institution can be established so as to secure the advantages generally perceived without incurring countervailing disadvantages.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The communication by Mr. James M. Lee, published in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of this week, relating to "Mr. Cooper's quarrel with his neighbors over Three Mile Point," in which reference is made in a very pleasant manner to myself, prompts a brief comment on the same.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In "Topics of the Week," in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Nov. 23 is a paragraph noting that "The readers of The London Academy have decided that the following are the twelve best 'novels' published in the first ten months of the year."

McVickar Co. have sold for William Hall's Sons the plot, 50 by 100, on the north side of Fifty-first Street, 100 feet east of Madison-Avenue. It is understood that the buyer will erect a handsome dwelling on the lots.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Appraiser Wakeman sent a letter to Secretary Gage declining to comply with the Secretary's request for his resignation. It was received yesterday in Mr. Gage's absence in New York, and at the same time President Roosevelt received from Mr. Wakeman a letter attacking Mr. Gage.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 20 -- The Novosti, in a long article to-day on the Russian export trade, oeclares that the Russian Government is making a strong effort, in view of the probability of a tariff war with Germany, to bring about an Anglo-Russian alliance.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- There is nothing quite equal to the gentle serenity of a publisher who has come to the close of the season's issues and has nothing to do but to order new editions now and then, and this season the Boston publisher is uncommonly tranquil, for every house has at least one book which is surprisingly successful.
One day last week the following letter was referred to the editorial department of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS.
PEKING, Dec. 20 -- William N. Pethick, an American, who had been private secretary and diplomatic adviser to Li-Hung-Chang for thirty years, died here to-day.

By The Associated Press. LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Money was in active demand to-day, and its scarcity hardened rates. A large indebtedness to the Bank of England is likely to remain until the distribution of the January dividends.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 --Marvin Hughitt, Jr., Freight Traffic Manager of the Chicago and Northwestern left in his private car for his headquarters this morning, after a week's hunt on Little Lake which broke all records. Mr. Hughitt was accompanied by R.M. Cox of Chicago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This is not intended to salve over the feelings of anybody, but just to ask a few plain questions. I have been reading your editorial In to-day's TIMES, "The War on Policy," and wish to ask If something cannot be done to repeal the laws against gambling.

Frightened by the whistle of an elevated train, a horse attached to a wagon belonging to Davis Isaacs, wholesale liquor dealers of 1,493 Broadway, ran away last night on Second Avenue, near One Hundred and Tenth Street. The driver was thrown to the street, the wagon smashed against pillars.

C.F. Libbie Co. sold in Boston Dec. 5 and 6 a number of American first editions, together with other literary items of much interest. The highest price of the sale was the $393.75 given for a complete set, as far as published, on large paper, of Sabin's "Dictionary of Books Relating to America," New York.

Almost everybody one meets is afflicted with that trivial but annoying ailment a "cold." This is one of the minor troubles of life, hut it is a singularly perverse affection all the same, and one decidedly obtsinate as regards its tendencies toward cure. Perhaps the "cold in the head" is one of the most troublesome forms of the ailment.

WHEN Charles Dickens wrote of his doll milliner, and again of his articulator of human bones, it seemed as though he were drawing upon his imagination in his desire to furnish to the world of letters some new types, but right here in New York are to be found trades that are very nearly as strange as those two.

The Aldermanic fight over the proposed amendments to the Building Code will be started to-morrow at a meeting of the Fire Committee of the Board of Aldermen. The plan of a few of the Tammany Aldermen is to wipe out the provisions of the building laws in reference to the proper protection of buildings over 150 feet in height by the use of fireproof materials.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 21. -- Gov. Hunt, upon his return here late Thursday night, was received enthusiastically by a large crowd which had gathered upon the wharf. Yesterday a banquet was given to him by one hundred of the most prominent residents of the city.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent writes to THE SUNDAY TIMES applauding the generosity of certain millionaires for their large gifts to educational institutions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The report from Paris that the Panama Canal Company has expressed a willingness to sell-its property at a fair price to the United States Was read with great interest by such members of Congress as are in Washington. If subsequent proceedings shall indicate that the Frenchmen really mean what they say there is they believe, no doubt that due consideration will be given to their offer.

In view of the topic so frequently broached of the possible increase of dividends, and the periodical hints and hopes of larger returns to stockholders as the various meetings of Directors approach, it may be of general interest to determine the tendency of the rate of dividends as shown by official statistics.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Joseph Case, of this city, a member of the International Paper Company of New York, is just recovering from an experience that gave him a terrible scare one day last week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- It is reported here that President Roosevelt has offered the Secretaryship of the Treasury to Gov. William M. Crane of Massachusetts. Gov. Crane arrived in Washington early yesterday, and after a conference with the President, lasting about an hour, left for Boston.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 21. -- The railroads of the West have formed a plan to reseed the worn-out cattle ranges of the entire West. The scheme involves a large experimental farm through which a seed suited to the country may be discovered. It is the purpose of those at the head of the plan to establish this farm in the early Spring at some central range point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been a reader of THE TIMES, and an occasional correspondent, almost from the day of Its first publication by its founder, Henry J. Raymond, with whom I had the pleasure of a personal acquaintance, and have always admired its spirit of fair play, as well as its other many good qualities.

There was little life to yesterday's stock market, though the undertone was decidedly strong, until after the publication of the weekly bank statement showing a slight increase in surplus reserves and a very substantial decrease of over $13,000,000 in loans. The exhibit was regarded as so altogether favorable and encouraging that the stock market promptly responded with a display of activity and strength that carried prices up appreciably all through the list.

From The Columbia Literary Monthly. It is upon this one comedy "Mercadet'' that Balzac can lay any claims as a dramatic artist. This was first presented at the Theatre do Gymnase Dramatique on Aug. 24, 1851. In 1869, in a-three-act version, it was added to the repertoire of theComedie Francaise -- "the proud and severe guardian of "Gallic stage traditions."

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 21. -- Ohio, particularly Central Ohio, is now experiencing the worst coal famine ever known here. It has been growing worse from day to day, until now it has paralyzed industry, caused untold suffering, imperiled this city's water supply, disarranged interurban road schedules, threatened street-car traffic, jeopardized city lighting, and generally upset all the plans of man, and that, too, with the mercury at sun-up this morning 17 degrees below zero.

A WOMAN has discovered another reason for carrying, when shopping, one of those open-work cord bags the omnibus-like qualifications of which have made them popular. Every package in them is in plain sight, she says, and there is not the slightest danger of being arrested on suspicion, in holiday time, as a shoplifter.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you allow me to state a few facts -- not arguments -- mainly bearing upon the present criticisms of Admiral Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Sugar imports into the United States in the calendar year 1901 will exceed those of any preceding year by about 250,000,000 pounds, and the cost will be greater than any preceding year except 1893, when prices were unusually high. The total importations of sugar in the year about to end will, according to the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, aggregate 4,670,000,000 pounds, and the cost about $115,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Mrs. Roosevelt, who has revived the public afternoon reception at the White House, was at home to-day from 3 to 5 o'clock, being assisted in receiving by the wives of members of the Cabinet. Although the intensely cold weather reduced the number of would-be visitors, fully 600 women paid their respects.

The Sugar Conference in Brussels. Although, as has been represented in a cable dispatch, the delegates to the International Sugar Conference now assembled in Brussels doubtless desire the total abolition of sugar bounties, the absence of Russia and the United States from the convention signifies to students of this subject that little more than a one-sided expression of European sentiment will be the result.

Stage animals are very proud of the organs they can move. If they can roll an eye, they never cease to roll it so long as they think any one is looking; and if they can switch a tall, they, switch it. This weakness for showing off gets them into trouble sometimes, just as weaknesses in general get real animals into trouble.

"WE have been hearing a grood deal lately about the so-called under World.' and the World of Graft.' said a Wall Street man the other day, "but there is one particular kind of 'grafting' and a certain coterie of 'grafters' that I have never seen described in print. Only the very wealthy men and the most prominent business houses of the city are familiar with this class, and their methods.

The regular season of opera will open at the Metropolitan Opera House to-morrow night with "Tristan and Isolde." The principal singers will be Mmes. Ternina and Schumann-Heink, Mr. Van Dyck, Mr. Bispham, and Mr. E. de Reszke. The programme for the rest of the week is as follows:

THERE is an interesting and unique part or this city, almost unknown to the average citizen. The phrase Vaudeville Land carries little meaning to the mind or the layman, and what little it does carry is almost certain to be erroneous. He thinks of the dazzling stage, the tinsel and glitter of gaudy costuming, the crash of orchestras, the glare of colored lights, fantastic acting.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 21. -- A peculiar phase in frontier life is to be seen in Nebraska this week, caused by the restoration of Burlington Railroad lands to the public domain, and resulting in valuable farms being sold for a mere song.

The Hon. Hannis Taylor of Mobile, Ala., ex-United States Minister to Spain, is to deliver an address before the Buffalo (N.Y.) Century Club on "Federal Relations With the New Possessions of the United-States."

THE week which has just ended was one of no small interest in the musical world. It opened with a concert of uncommon beauty given by the Kneisel Quartet of Boston. This concert was devoted to the honor of Beethoven's memory. a memory which is certain to be revered among lovers of chamber music for many years to come.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Count Tolstoi once said that the rich would do anything for the poor except get off their backs. So with these reformers, they will do anything for the workingmen except let them alone and mind their own business. The fact that their intentions are good doesn't mitigate the matter in the least, for they say the infernal regions are beautifully paved with good intentions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not always agree with the editorial views of THE TIMES on the perplexing problem of the right relations between capital and labor, but the tone of your article entitled "Industrial Peace" in your issue of Dec. 19 meets with my warm approval.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 21 -- Miss Wilhelmina Pepper, granddaughter of Millionaire Christian Pepper, St. Louis tobacco merchant, and known on the Stage as Jane Oaker, was married to-day at the home of her father, Christian Pepper, Jr., to Hale Rice Hamilton. The wedding was the result of a sudden determination.

According to one of the speakers at the dinner in honor of Justice Morgan J. O'Brien, given at the Lotos Club last night, there was entirely too much justice, as there were present Justices of the Supreme Court and of the Appellate Division to burn. Justice was not, however, blind to the fun that was furious or deaf to the jests, that were continuous.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 21. -- The Portland (Oregon) Chamber of Commerce has just issued in pamphlet form resolutions passed by it on Dec. 3, which demand that Congress make an appropriation for the opening to navigation of the Columbia and Snake Rivers and their tributaries.

OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 21. -- John J. Valentine, President of the Wells, Fargo Co.'s Express, died at 1:30 o'clock this morning. He had been ill for some time, and his death had been expected for several days.

In the "gold room" of the Metropolitan Museum of Art there has recently been placed one of the most celebrated collections of watches in the world. Most of them are ancient and were once the property of royalty. Unique in design and rich in ornamentation, they are attracting a great deal of attention.

Many people in this country and in America are wondering who is the companion of Miss Stone in captivity and peril. The name of Mme. Tsilka has become familiar enough, but details of her life and character are not generally known.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Christmas has already reached the theatres, and a new holiday fairy piece at the Vaudeville, called "Bluebell in Fairyland," is really a charming and beautiful thing, of a simple, reminiscent kind, with capital music by Walter Slaughter and fine scenery.

Wheat, long much neglected, seems at last to have found some friends. It seems that a number of men who have successfully followed the advance in corn and oats have abandoned those articles and turned their attention to wheat, for the reason that it is now the cheapest article on the list.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The solemn vow, "Until death do us part," has not yet been really taken, but it is much talked of as a coming event. It is being discussed, favorably and unfavorably, in the entire press of the city, and even throughout the State. Indications point to its becoming an affair of National and possibly international importance.

By a new system of leasing the restaurant privileges in the parks of the city, New York has secured without expense to the municipality, improvements in the two most important of these restaurants, which make them by for the most elaborate institutions of their kind in this country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- One of the most important subjects dealt with by the United States Philippine Commission is that of a constabulary system for the islands. The commission says that after a year of observation it is more than ever convinced that the best kind of a constabulary for the Philippines must be largely constituted of natives.

GLANCING over the advertising columns of a newspaper that reaches the middle classes here in New York one finds advertisements of concerns that loan money on salaries, "without security, "money on chattel mortgages, and, money to merchants in any kind of business."

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Lord Rosebery is neither a Gladstone nor a Boulanger, and yet he combines unmistakably certain qualities of both. Except Gladstone there is not an English statesman of this era who has so closely held the attention of his contemporaries and so interested them.

It is a strange fact that the game which holds the record for the largest attendance at a sporting event, with the exception of racing, is little known in this country. This is Association football, which attracted a crowd of 110,000 spectators to a match which was played in London last year for the final cup tie of the championship series.
It would have been interesting, not knowing how great the popularity of Senator Mark Hanna is, to have seen him one night during the past week holding court in the corridor of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THESE days of early Winter, when the rigors of the season are beginning to be felt, afford epecial interest to the man who likes to study the animals of the various zoological collections of New York. There is so great a variety, from such far divergent countries, climates, and temperatures, that it would seem a great problem to properly house and care for the expatriates.

Russia has been suffering form a crisis due partly to the fact that the Government is, to a large extent, the only great buyer. It has in its own hands such as immense proportion of the moving spirit in everything. And when the Government is unable to place orders to the full extent required every industry suffers.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 21. -- George Vanderbilt this afternoon wired Charles McNamee, his business adviser, who came here two weeks ago, that he and his Brothers in New York to-day advanced the sum of $509,000 with which to immediately payoff depositors of the Metropolitan Bank, which failed Nov. 19, after paying out $90,000 during a two days' run.

GUTHRIE, -- Oklahoma, Dec. 21. -- James Wilson, a farmer living ten miles west of this place, was arrested to-day upon a requisition from the Governor of Missouri. He is charged with having murdered Orville Lyons at Arno, Douglass County, Mo., thirty-two years ago. Wilson is now more than sixty-years old.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 21. -- It appeared this evening that "the Chilean incident," as the trouble between Argentina and Chile is referred to here, has, unexpectedly, assumed a more serious aspect. The Tribuna, the official organ of the Government, admits that the Ultima Esperanza question, instead of approaching a settlement, is becoming graver, and that the Chilean Government is now in danger of allowing itself to be influenced by a group of doctrinaires.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By principle and practice I have always been in cordial sympathy with any movement or platform, which had for its object the maintenance of the sanctity of the first day of the week, commonly called Sunday, tout more appropriately and correctly the Lord's Day.

SOME time ago, and even now to a less degree, it was the complaint of American artists that the rich of this country refused to buy canvases signed by sturdy home-lovers at New York or Boston or Philadelphia. The magic words that loosed their purse strings were "Paris" and "London."

The new book depleting Georgia historically and industrially, prepared under the supervision of the State Department of Agriculture, has just been issued from the press of the State Printer. It is an exceedingly handsome volume.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21. -- The Crescent City Handicap, at a mile and a quarter, worth $1,500, furnished the best-contested race of the meeting, Felix Bard and Beana sharing first honors in the betting, opening at threes and closing at a slight advance. With the others it was 6 to 1. Meade took Nitrate to the front at once and held the lead until they swung around the stretch turn.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 21. -- A prominent society wedding which took place here to-day was that of Miss Margaret Guest Blackwell and Mr. Roland Jessup Mulford. The bride is a daughter of the late George Guest of Philadelphia and a stepdaughter of Mr. Josiah Low Blackwell of Baltimore.

HAVANA, Dec. 21. -- The supporters of Gen. Maso in his candidacy for the Presidency of the republic have decided to take no part in the coming elections fixed for Dec. 31; all the candidates of the party have withdrawn, and the Maso members of the provincial boards have been requested to resign.

Legends About Trees. CHRISTMAS is the only holiday identified with certain vegetable growths -- the holly, the mistletoe, and the Christmas tree. The veneration in which these are held goes back to a remote antiquity. There are, however, some strange and curious legends attaching to other products of the vegetable kingdom.

We certainly did not wish to do any-injustice to Dr. CUYLER in regard to his opposition to all liquor selling on Sunday. We find that he did not specifically object to the proposition that Germans "shall have orderly places in which they can consume beer on Sunday"; neither do we find, however, that he approves it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The conflict of testimony in the Schley court of inquiry as regards time, distances, , has recalled an episode that occurred in 1884 at Maldonado Bay, Uruguay. The Nipsic had gone there in order to have small-arm target practice on Lobos Island, at the entrance to the bay.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An almost unnoticed paragraph in Friday's papers "Ioints a moral and adorns a tale," the tale or the last compaign:
