IN all the discussion that has been going on in the European papers as well as in those of the United States concerning "the American, invasion" of foreign countries with industrial products that are driving the native wares out of the market, one important point has, in the opinion of some experts here, been entirely overlooked.

A man well versed in the mysteries of the copper situation said yesterday that the Amalgamated Copper Company has considerably over a hundred million pounds of copper on hand that it is prepared to unload on the market at any kind of prices that will be under the prices quoted by independent companies in secret contract.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to say a word relative to an editorial remark of yours in THE TIMES of Dec. 13. In the leading editorial of that date you remark that "we do not recall any occasion upon which the (Catholic) church authorities, whose views he (Mr. Philbin) is believed to reflect, have taken a definite and announced position in respect to Tammany police corruption."

MEXICO has commenced its Christmas celebration. But any foreigner would have to be told of the fact, for the style of jollification that is going on bears not the slightest resemblance to the holiday season of either the United States or Europe. The American small boy would feel lost down there at this time of the year.

Call money rates again last week touched 10 per cent., but only for so brief a time that the incident is scarcely worth mentioning unless, indeed, it be to point out that the rate was made on Friday afternoon in the last hour, loans made on that day carrying over until Monday.

At a conference between Senator Platt, Chairman George W. Dunn of the Republican State Committee, and Speaker of the Assembly S. Fred Nixon, which lasted for nearly two hours at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon, it was decided that there will be no excise legislation at Albany during the coming session of the Legislature.

Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage was entertained at the Metropolitan Club last night at an elaborate dinner given by Frank A. Vanderlip, Vice President of the National City Bank and ex-Assistant Secretary of the Treasury.

SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 21. --L.C. Dillman has returned from New York, where he sold 28 copper mining claims located in the interior oil Alaska for $1,200,000. He says the London syndicate, to which he sold the claims, has definitely decided to build a railroad from Valdes, Alaska, to the locations of the claims, a distance of 140 miles.
MR. RAYMOND HARRINGTON of the American Museum of Natural History is about to give to a waiting world the first and last of the Mohicans.

There will be a number of important changes in the coming week in theatricals. John Drew closed his long and successful engagement at the Empire Theatre last night, and to-morrow evening the Empire Theatre Stock Company will return to New York for its annual stay, presenting for the first tune in this country H.V. Esmond's play, "The Wilderness."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The first of the series of Cabinet dinners in honor of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt will be given Jan. 11 by Secretary of War and Mrs. Root.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whatever opinions may be held by your various readers, and A.E.G. in particular, in regard to the "origin" of the Sabbath, it is certain (nothwithstanding A.E.G.'s statement) that the State regards Sunday as the Christian rest day, which is (as God well knew) so necessary to man's best welfare.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 21. -- Judge John A. Chandler of St. Paul has been forty-eight years in continuous railroad service in the employ of one road, the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, and in this respect is said to be the dean of railroad men in this country.

FISH have furnished more material for Ananias than any other creatures since the world began, but the man who makes fishes a study learns so much grotesque fact that he is prepared to believe anything. No lie about a fish can be told but that truth can make more of a sensation with one hand tied behind it.

Kaiser WILHELM'S view of the relation of the artists to the throne does not surprise one so much as the estimate he puts on German art and especially on German sculpture. It argues poorly for his knowledge. No country is more industrious in erecting monuments than Germany.

In regard to the head of the bureau in the Controller's office in which the stealing by the man CHIPP took, place, some curious statements are made by Controller COLER. Mr. COLER said: "This bureau has been in a deplorable condition for many years. Former Controllers tried to correct the evils, but failed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Gen. Miles found it necessary to write two letters to the War Department regarding the interview sent out from Cincinnati, and even then there was no expression of satisfaction on the Secretary's part at the second explanation. However, Secretary Root himself regards the incident as closed.

Bridge Commissioner John L. Shea and Chief Engineer C.C. Martin of the Brooklyn Bridge held a long consultation, in the bridge office in Brooklyn yesterday over the presentment handed down on Friday by the Grand Jury, in which the management of the bridge was criticised. After the talk with Mr. Shea, Engineer Martin went to his private office and later gave out the following report, which he said had been indorsed by Commissioner Shea:

AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 21. -- The Mexican Petroleum Company, which was organized under the laws of California several months ago and which has a capital stock of $10,000,000, may become a rival of the Standard Oil Company in the production of oil and the ownership of railway properties.

IT is not everywhere that Santa Claus is a fat, jolly, bearded old fellow, drawn over snow-covered roofs by his faithful reindeer team. In some lands the being that takes his place is a different creature altogether, even to being a woman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorials on the Sunday sale of intoxicants you frequently use the argument that if the Sabbatarians oppose the Low idea of an open Sunday to a successful issue they will alienate the votes of the respectable beer-drinking element, and at the next election the terrible Tammany will creep back into power.

The week which closed last evening with the dance of the Junior Cotillion was one of the most notable in the history of New York society. It was a constant succession of brilliant entertainments, some given at private residences and others at the fash- ionable restaurants, and any one of which would have been an event of major importance, it it had happened in a dull season.

Morris and Charles Greenberg, comprising the firm of Charles Greenberg Son, formerly doing business in white goods and linens at 128 Wooster Street, were yesterday discharged by Judge Adams in the United States District Court as bankrupts.

Senator George F. Hoar of Massachusetts, responding to the toast "Forefather's Day." at the dinner of the New England Society of Brooklyn last evening, called Brooklyn "the salt of New York," and added that judging by what has happened of late the salt had not lost its flavor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- President Roosevelt is said to have knocked a man down on Thursday night last. There are two versions given of the alleged encounter.

"My watch had developed a most annoying irregularity," remarked a very, businesslike woman. "It lost and gained time by turns until I conceived the disagreeable impression of having paid a first-class price for a third-class article. Full of resentment, I posted off to the dealer in chronometers from whom the watch had been purchased and accused him of having treated me unfairly.
OTTAWA, Dec. 21. -- Lord Selkirk offered to sell more than half the land in the present Province of Manitoba for $50,000 in 1811 "owing to its remoteness."

"I have no official knowledge that I am to be superseded or retained," remarked Thomas Fitchie, United States Commissioner of Immigration, yesterday, when his attention was called to a published dispatch that President Roosevelt would shortly remove him. "My term does not expire until March 21, 1902, and about six months ago I tiled an application with the then President for my reappointment.

Paris for some days has been talking of an extraordinary child who has recently become a member, with full member's rights, of the Society of French Dramatic Authors, of which M. Victorien Sardou is President.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- There is every indication that there will be the usual number of amendments to the game laws presented to the Legislature at the coming session. One of the most important of these will propose a tax of $2 a head on every deer killed in the State of New York during the open season.
JOHN DOBBS stood reading the notice which had just been placed in the prompt entrance:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Had Admiral Sampson fought and won the battle of Santiago not one word of the charges upon which the majority of the court based its verdict of condemnation of Admiral Schley would have been heard of. The glory of that day would have settled all scores, amnestied as it were all jealousies, and Admiral Sampson would have been the healthiest man in the navy.
The fall in the value of British, Government, railway and industrial securities during the past two years amounts in the aggregate to hundreds of millions sterling.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The following order was made public this afternoon by Secretary of War Root:

A meeting of representatives of firms interested in trade with the United States, was held at the offices of the London Chamber of Commerce, Eastcheap, when Mr. E. Seymour Bell was present to answer any Questions in reference to the experience acquired by him since his appointment as British Commercial Agent in the United States.

The regulation dress which must be worn by each peeress on the occasion of the coronation of the King and Queen is to be very imposing. Models of the robes have been shown at the Earl Marshal's residence, and no misconception can possibly arise. The dress must be of red velvet of a deep, rich shade, much more ruby in tone than scarlet.

The two cuts in the price of copper made during the past week reducing the price of lake copper to 13 cents brings the price of the metal back to the price prevailing about three years ago. At 13 cents the quotation is 3 7-10 cents under the average price of last year and 4 3/4 cents below the average price of 1899.

Prof. Allen E. Read of the Institution for the Deaf in this city, has just finished for the Census Department, at Washington, a collection of acts and statistics concerning the children who have, since 1890, been in attendance at the institution. The work has occupied him for several weeks, and the compilation is voluminous.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is partly amusing and very annoying to an Englishman to read your cabled report of Lord Rosebery's speech, made yesterday, and to find that there are sufficient people in England to make a "crowded audience" to listen to him, at this stage of the Boer war.

Few changes of importance were made in the standing of the clubs in the principal local bowling tournaments by the games of the past week. The Metropolitan Bowling Club still holds first place in the American National tournament, with twelve games won and only two lost, an excellent showing in view of the strength of most of the clubs in this tournament.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 2. -- The new Louisville Jockey Club has announced its lists of stakes, which close on Monday, Feb. 8. 1902, to be run at the Spring Meeting of 1902 and the Derby, Oaks, and Nursery Stakes for 1903. There will be twenty-one days' racing in the Spring, and nine stakes are to be run, including the Derby, Clark, and Oaks, besides the Nursery, a new $6,000 event for two-yearolds.

SAID the linen man: "There is no limit to the amount of money which can be spent in handkerchiefs. One nay pay ten cents for a handkerchief or $100. The latter will be a lace-trimmed handkerchief, in Duchesse or Point de Veilice, done in floral designs or scrolls.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some two or three weeks ago there appeared in THE TIMES the report of a sermon by Archbisfiop Corrigan on Socialism. That report had every appearance of toeing a verbatim copy of the Archbishop's manuscript -- the paragraphs being inclosed in quotation marks.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Panama Canal Company held last Thursday, President Hutin, who recently returned here from the United States, and M. Choron, the Director of Works, resigned their offices.

The term "freak menu" is applied by caterers to menus drawn up otherwise than in the orthodox style, whether as regards spelling, diction, form, or external or internal embellishment or adornment. A good example of the latter class was placed upon the table at a Judge's dinner party not long ago.

Our special London correspondent's view of the political situation in England, as given in his cable letter to-day, corresponds with that of every other observer in finding the whole field covered by Lord ROSEBERY'S speeh at Chesterfield. The commotion the speech has excited seems, at the first glance, to be quite out of proportion to its intrinsic importance.

THERE cannot be gathered together anywhere a brighter set of men than gentlemanly bred, well-equipped, allthey have finished their day's "details," and the last copy has gone up, and the monster pressed from their cavernous depths are beginning to give out their thunderous roar, that they are at their best.

The eighty-second birthday anniversary of William Morris was celebrated in a most unique way at the home of his son, David Morris, of western Marion County, last Saturday. To make the affair memorable, an octogenarian surprise on the old gentleman was arranged by his son and the son's wife, and invitations to some seventy octogenarians were issued.

Residents of Fordham Heights, a handsome residential section of the Borough of the Bronx, are grieved and angry at the neglected condition in which the ancient burying ground situated at the southeast corner of Sedgwick Avenue and Fordham Landing Road has been allowed to remain for years by the public authorities.

Only a very small amount of business was transacted in the outside market yesterday. In only one or two cases did the trading in any stock amount to as much as 1,000 shares, and by far the larger portion of the list showed totals very much below this figure. In fact the market presented the usual half holiday appearance with trading if anything even duller than usual.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Friday evening last I was one of many who enjoyed "Quality Street." On coming from the theatre to Thirty-eighth (or is it Thirty-seventh?) Street I was witness to a noisy scene. Two hansom drivers were striving for mastery of position next the curb, the space not being sufficient for both.

The following table showing the length of the railways open for traffic in each European country on the 1st of January, 1901, as compared with the figures for Jan. 1, 1900, is taken from statistics compiled by the French Ministry of Public Works.

From The Contemporary Review. The Karpathian shepherd is a regular savage -- tales innumerable are afloat as to his kinship with the fairies and the mountain winds. Twice a year only, in Autumn and in Spring, he is to be seen leading his white herd, assisted by a few hounds, who look like wolves, and are almost as mysterious as their master.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial in one of your morning contemporaries of this date mention is made of the decision of Mr. Cantor and his colaborers in the effort to provide this city with a rational system of street signs, to utilize the lamp posts.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 21. -- The correspondence relating to the John Brown raid and his execution found in the garret of the old Virginia State House was given out to-day. These letters made a great budget and were written to Brown and some of his leaders from all parts of the North and West.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Chicago has passed the most serious aspect of the coal shortage, and after Monday manufacturing establishments and big down-town buildings will be in a better position to fight the possibility of anything approaching a famine.

Golf during the coming week promises to be livelier than usual in the metropolitan district for this time of the year. Of course, the success of all the projected matches depends entirely upon the condition of the weather, a snow fall being the most feared evil to the golfer's mind. The point of greatest activity will be Lakewood.

Because of a strenuous demand which is being made by the Republicans of the Bronx to have a straightout Republican named for Park Commissioner of that borough, Mr. Low did not announce his remaining important appointments yesterday, as had been generally anticipated. Mr. Low has voluntarily pledged himself to name a Park Board composed of two Republicans and one Democrat.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The fall in the securities of cable companies, which commenced with the announcement of the success of Marconi's experiments in having signals transmitted across the ocean by his wireless system of telegraphy, has been continuous throughout the week. Since Dec. 14 Anglo-American preferred has dropped 7 points, and ordinary shares have dropped 4 points, while Eastern Telegraph was a close second, with a fall of 5 1/2 points.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21. -- A heavy demand from New York for Reading common was the point of greatest interest in the Philadelphia market, but its strength was without influence on the balance of the list. The little alteration in prices otherwise was mostly on the side of improvement.

"I SUPPOSE you think you're some careful about the way you handle your guns, don't you?" demanded one old hunter of another, as they sat in the back office of a down-town sporting goods store the other day.

CANTON, S.D., Dec. 21. -- The United States has just completed at tills place the first asylum for the insane Indians in America. When the furniture and furnishings are in place it will then be ready for seventy-five occupants. At least this number of insane redskins is now waiting for admission.
I ASKED Silas Larrabee what had impressed him most as he had watched the operations of the National House of Representatives from his seat in the gallery.

The New York City Teachers' Association, of which Magmus Gross is President, has adopted a report by the Committed on School Work on the Course of Study. The committee met a committee appointed by the Male Principals' Association Dec. 5, and a sub-committee was appointed to formulate a questionnaire to be submitted to the members of the joint committee.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Lakewood's holiday visitors have begun to throng in, and if they continue to come at the present rate the population of the village will be trebled during Christmas week. But there is plenty of room and a hearty welcome for all who come. The cottagers are to entertain house parties galore, and the hotels are sure to have pretty nearly all the people they can accommodate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To-day's TIMES reports Capt. Hobson as saying in his lecture at Cincinnati on the "Needs of the Navy," that "there were only two ships in the squadron off Santiago which had anything near the speed of the Spanish vessels, while the rest were a motley crew, which, with the exception of the Oregon, had a speed average of only about half that of the Spanish ships.

The tentative presentment of the officers of the East River Bridge, Commissioner SHEA, Chief Engineer MARTIN, and Assistant Engineer PROBASCO, by the Grand Jury draws a nice distinction between official negligence and a "willful" betrayal of a grave public trust, which the average citizen will find it difficult to understand.

MANY and very pleasing are the mythical and poetical associations of the mistletoe plant and Christmastide. These have stimulated deep research into the obscure origin of customs whose generic roots and significance are present to us now in vague and nebulous suggestiveness, and their true meaning is.

"THE Germans have the brains, the industry, and are not hampered by the engrossing task of bringing an almost limitless tract of land into subjection so as to have it yield its occupants a living. They made their land productive centuries ago and can now turn their attention to a cultivation and development of the powers that are within themselves," said a Columbia Professor of History in contrasting the German with the American people.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- In a speech to-night before the Bankers' Club, Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, declared that "the trust is a dead business proposition, built on a trinity that would wreck anything the restriction of trade, the increase of prices, and the throttling of competition."

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The Earl Marshal's order, changing the peeresses' coronation robes, while generally commended, has created no little consternation among those who had already ordered these costly garments.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 21. -- The buying of United Railways incomes was the leading, feature in to-day's market. All pressure against them has been lifted since it is found that public sentiment is not behind the projected new company. There is a readier buying of the incomes now, based on the known earning capacity of the company and the regularity with which it has been paying interest.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The Bible Teachers' College located here will be removed to New York after the holidays. The headquarters for the Winter will be in Broadway Tabernacle, and a permanent place will be found near Herald Square. The students to the college come from all over the world, and include foreign missionaries, ministers on a furlough, Secretaries of the National and international Young Men's Christian Associations, Bible students, and Sunday school teachers.

They made their land productive centuries ago and can now turn their attention to a cultivation and development of the powers that are within themselves," said a Columbia Professor of History in contrasting the German with the American people.

From The Fortnightly Review. The word guerrilla is Spanish, and first came into common use in this country during the time of the Peninsular War. But Spain throughout her long history has always been recognized as the country most ideally suited for guerrilla tactics. There is no region in Europe in which it is more difficult to wage successful war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Vice Consul General Murphy sends from Frankfort, Nov. 23, 1901, translation from the Frankfurter Journal relative to a new method of hardening steel in Germany, as follows:

TIME was when teaching was thought to be the only eminently respectable employment for an educated woman of refinement and culture. The result was the familiar one -- a lot of poor teachers and ill-taught scholars, the joy and beauty of knowledge being denied the one and the other.

MONTEREY, Mexico, Dec. 21. -- The Board of Directors of the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railway Company will hold a meeting in St. Louis, Mo., between the 23d and 27th of this month for the purpose of considering a number of important matters relative to the future management of this property, which recently passed into the hands of the H. Clay Pierce syndicate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is proposed to adopt some plan by which the names of the streets shall be more clearly indicated. This is necessary. But should not the improvement be more radical?

A report has been made to Congress by the Executive Committee of the National Association of Referees in Bankruptcy regarding its investigation of the sentiment of representative business houses and associations throughout the country in relation to the Act of Bankruptcy of 1898.

"Jake" Schaefer required but nineteen innings to complete the 400 points necessary to win the 1,200-point billiard match with the French player, Louis Barutel, at 18inch balk line, two shots in, last night at the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, in Brooklyn. He, therefore, made an average of 21 1-19, which is considerably better than the averages made in the first two evenings of play.

"IF the person who goes out after that swift-footed, little, gray cottontail beast we call the rabbit, and sees only the stupid things it does only knew how smart it can really be and is on occasion, he would refer to the shy little fellow's stupidity not with jocularity but regret," said a veteran sportsman, who, from a boy up has taken careful note of the animal in question.

THIS first social organization of any kind in New York was a club established during the Winter of 1668-9 under the distinguished auspices of Gov. Francis Lovelace, a man of refinement and elegance, who by this moans hoped to render more tolerable the exile to which his appointment to this outpost of civilization had condemned him.

A member of one of the most dangerous bands of burglars that, according to Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau, ever worked in the East, Frank Ward, forty-two years old, of Boston, known in criminal annals as "Dublin Ned," was captured at Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street Friday night by Detective Sergts.

ITHACA, Dec. 21. -- The authorities of Cornell, who are directly interested and in charge of the forestry department, are anxious to make their position clear relative to the Adirondack forest reserve tract. They regard the recent petition of the Attorney General as a needless proceeding, and have no fear whatever that they can justify their use and care of the tract in question.

Clarence Kenyon of this city recently attracted attention in Washington, D.C., as "a man from Indiana who did not want anything." With Senator Beveridge, a personal friend, he called on the President, to whom he was presented by the Senator.

In the problem of navigating the air, there is imposed a minimum limit by the weight of the man to be carried. Certain phenomena, such as the frictional resistance of the air, make for a larger size, but the simpler and more important relations of mass and energy call for a small size.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 21. -- The local board of United States Steamboat Inspectors were congratulating themselves on having completed the year's work when word reached them that a steamboat was in operation on Poplar Lake, a small sheet of water far up in the woods of Aroostook, a place of which they had never heard, much less of the steamboat.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The war between the two factions of our protected manufacturers goes merrily on. One faction believes that the Hawaiian Islanders became full-fledged Americans as soon as we annexed Hawaii, and that they should be charged full American prices for all goods ordered from our manufacturers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 21. -- Noah Raby, the old man at Piscataway, whose claims to being 120 years of age have not been successfully disputed, is now losing his wrinkles and taking on an appearance of youth again. To some people who went to see Noah at the Piscataway Township Poor Farm yesterday to give him some presents, he made the statement that he will live to be 150.

Perry Belmont was nominated for Congress on the Democratic ticket in the Seventh District last evening after a most exciting convention. The delegates opposed to the nomination of Mr. Belmont, headed by Police. Commissioner Murphy, shouted and howled and tried to have the convention adjourn without naming a candidate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives has passed a Philippine Tariff bill, and Mr. Payne, the Chairman of the Committee, stated that the bill is designed to raise revenue for the government and benefit of the Philippine archipelago.

In the problem of navigating the air, there is imposed a minimum limit by the weight of the man to be carried. Certain phenomena, such as the frictional resistance of the air, make for a larger size, but the simpler and more important relations of mass and energy call for a small size.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 21. -- The local board of United States Steamboat Inspectors were congratulating themselves on having completed the year's work when word reached them that a steamboat was in operation on Poplar Lake, a small sheet of water far up in the woods of Aroostook, a place of which they had never heard, much less of the steamboat.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Money at local Clearing House to-day loaned at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Exchanges $21,223,081. Balances, $1,433,670. On call, money is in fair supply, at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Time money at nominally 5 per cent. for four to six months, with exceptions on both sides of this figure.
THEY were six in number, and were telling each other stories of life on the ocean, such as only men can tell who for many years have been following the great briny deep.

Nobody doubted that the Secretary of the Navy would approve the findings of the majority of the court of inquiry condemning Admiral SCHLEY and disapprove of the dissenting opinions of the presiding member of the court exculpating SCHLEY from certain charges of the precept. Nobody doubted that he would decline to consider Admiral DEWEY'S expression of opinion that SCHLEY was in command at the battle of Santiago and entitled to the credit of the victory.

MRS. MARSHALL J. DODGE wore at a recent morning musicale a black tailor-made gown, with a white liberty satin blouse. The Eton coat and skirt were of black Venetian cloth, the skirt being simple, and having an applied flounce. The jacket had a turned down collar and cuffs of dull tan velvet, relieved by black.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Secretary Long, by acting on the findings and conclusions of the Court of Inquiry, has disposed finally of the Schley case so far as the Navy Department is concerned, and ordered that the court be dissolved.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Late this afternoon the police raided an alleged poolroom at 7 Warburton Avenue, known as the Manhattan Hotel. About 240 men and boys, including the proprietor, were arrested. Among the prisoners were eight men who said they were New York policemen.

During a quarrel early yesterday morning in the saloon of George May at 240 Franklin Street, Greenpoint, John Gill of 47 Huron Street and Michael Condon of 156 Huron Street were shot. They were removed to St. Catharine's Hospital, where their condition was said last night to be critical.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- State Labor Commissioner John McMackin says in his quarterly bulletin that during the third quarter of the year 1899 only 2.3 per cent, of the trades unionists were continuously idle, last year 3.4 per cent., and this year 3.1 per cent. The proportion of unionists idle at the end of September was 4.7 per cent, in 1899, 13.3 per cent, in 1900, and 6.9 per cent, in 1901.
One man dead and six other persons more or less seriously injured is the casualty list of a fire that destroyed a sweatshop in the rear of the tenement house at 17 Clinton Street early last evening.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 22 -- A gang of forgers of railroad tickets has been operating here successfully during the last few weeks, according to H.C. Townsend of St. Louis, General Passenger Agent of the Missouri Pacific Railroad.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 -- Because he had played the races and lost, a man who gave his name as Walter F. Leighton, Jr., of New York, tried to commit suicide yesterday evening. He jumped from the ferryboat Nathalie Hamilton when the boat was in midstream. Had it not been for the prompt work of the Captain in reversing the engines and lowering a lifeboat he would have succeeded in his purpose.

Policeman John Hussey of the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station early yesterday morning found the body of a young man lying on the north side of West One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, about 100 feet west of Eighth Avenue and about a hundred feet from the foot of the stairway to the elevated railroad station.

The City Club's agitation of the matter of city contracts has resulted in deferring several contracts until after the 1st of January. The contracts are all either matters which should be left to the incoming administration, in the club's opinion, or those which show in the manner of receiving bids such disregard of the city's interests as to call for reconsideration of the specifications under which bids are called for.

Reade Street was the scene of all the excitement that the intricate machinery of the New York Fire Department can arouse at a dangerous conflagration yesterday afternoon. The building at 22, 24, and 26 was completely gutted from its sub-cellar to its roof. Chief Edward F. Croker estimated the losses to be at least $75,000, and the police said that the damage would not be far short of $100,000.

Two days before Christmas and still heaps of Christmas presents to be bought How will a fountain pen in silver do? There are any number of them to be found in all sizes, and they will cost from $2 up. Any man or woman either would be glad to have one of these.

PENNINGTON, N.J., Dec. 22 -- A. Lorison Holcombe, a prosperous farmer living near Hopewell, and President of the Hopewell National Bank, received a letter recently from unknown parties demanding $300. The letter ordered that he put the money in a box and at a certain time take it to a designated place in his lane and leave it.

Justice Jerome, when asked last night if the announcement of the Republican leaders that no modification of the excise law permitting Sunday opening in this city would be tolerated at the coming session of the Legislature would influence him in his attempt to secure such an amendment said:
Ex-Judge James Clark Spencer died last night at his home, 56 West Forty-seventh Street, from old age and general debility. He had been sick for several weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- It is confidently expected by those interested in the subject of immigration that a new law relating to the admission of aliens will be enacted in this session of Congress. A bill representing the views of Commissioner General Powderly and his subordinate Commissioners has been introduced in the House and referred to the Committee on Immigration and Navigation, and the committee has drawn up a report favorable to the bill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Alexander Sullivan, the lawyer who has been on trial before Judge Abner Smith for conspiracy to abet a fugitive from justice, was found guilty today. As punishment the jury imposed a fine of $2,000, which carries with it no prison sentence. Assistant State's Attorney Barnes demanded that Sullivan be taken to jail, but the court declined to accede, and Sullivan was permitted to leave with his attorneys.

-- Discussing the Pennsylvania Railroad's announced intention to enter New York through a tunnel under the Hudson. The Electrical Review suggests, somewhat cruelly, that so far at least as transportation problems are concerned, Philadelphia may properly enough be considered a suburb of this city.

There were in the Madison Avenue Baptist Church, Madison Avenue and Thirty-first Street, special services last night for Forefather's Day. The New England Society was represented by many of its members, and the church was crowded. After prayer and the singing by the congregation, standing, of the National anthem, the Rev. Dr. George C. Lorimer, chose for his text First Samuel, xxiii., 4: "Then David inquired of the Lord again.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The fact that the Uganda Railway has reached the Victoria Nyanza, says the Berlin correspondent of The Times, provides the National Zeitung with food for melancholy reflections. It says Great Britain must again be congratulated on the completion of a colossal undertaking, of which the political and commercial significance can hardly be overestimated.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- President Loubet inaugurated to-day in the Faubourg St. Antoine a statue to the memory of Baudin, the member of the Chamber of Deputies who was killed on the barricade of the Faubourg St. Antoine on Dec. 3, 1851, the day following the coup d'etat of Louis Napoleon.
Senator Simmons of North Carolina knows Cheatham, who has just resigned his position as Recorder of Deeds for this district. "He is the smartest negro I ever saw," says Simmons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- Improvements in the Harbor of Manila are occupying a large share of the attention of the Philippine Commission, as indicated by their report to the Secretary of War. The report calls attention to the fact that just before the American possession began the Spanish Government had prepared elaborate plans for improving the harbor, and had partially carried them into execution.

When we last spoke of the retirement of Secretary GAGE he had not only given no intimation that it was about to occur, but he had denied the reports made from time to time to that effect. Rather suddenly he informs the public that the latest report is correct and that he will resign his place as soon as the President has completed his arrangements for a successor therein.

Edgar Stanton Maclay, the "historian," whose resignation as a "special laborer" in the General Storekeeper's Department at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, President Roosevelt has directed Secretary of the Navy Long to ask for, said last night that he had not yet received any official word with regard to the matter.

Veryl Preston of 532 Fifth Avenue and two ladies who were with him are lying badly hurt in St. John's Riverside Hospital, at Yonkers, as the result of an automobile accident. The party was on its way from the Ardsley Club to New York late Saturday evening when the accident happened.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 22 -- Joseph Novella of Roselle was sentenced six months ago to serve six months in the county jail for attempting to assault a fourteen-year-old girl. He was released to-day and went directly back to Roselle. A few hours later Rosa Putte, mother of the girl, was brought to the county jail under commitment to await the result of injuries she inflicted with a stiletto upon Novella.

DUBOIS, Penn., Dec. 22 -- Two sons, a daughter, and a brother of John Ashbaugh, a farmer living near Summerville, were burned to death early yesterday morning, Another son was so badly injured that he will probably die, and the mother, father, and two little children were seriously hurt.

The mailing platform on the Mail Street side of the Post Office Building was packed yesterday afternoon with sacks and pouches designed for dispatching on outgoing trains. Most of this was mail in transit -- that is, mail received from incoming trains or from branch offices in this city. None of it was foreign mail matter.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22 -- "Willie" Keeler, the clever baseball player, has three engagements open to him. Manager Hanlon of the Brooklyns realizes that "Joe" Kelley will more than likely play with Baltimore next season, and for this reason he is anxious to keep Keeler. Hanlon says that Dwyer of the Detroit Club has offered Keeler $3,000, but that the Brooklyn owners are prepared to make an effort to keep the little fielder.

The footing on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday was first-class for the first time in several weeks, and as a result there was a large turn-out of road drivers and their fast steppers. From Washington Bridge north to Dyckman Street the roadbed was all that could be desired for this season of the year.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 23 -- It is reported from Busra, Asiatic Turkey, that the commander of a British gunboat has removed the Turkish flag from the residence of Mabaruk, the Sheikh of Koweit, and replaced it by Mabaruk's own flag, in token of his independence.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 22 -- Twenty-three of the three hundred men captured in the raid on a poolroom here yesterday by Chief Woodruff are still locked up, being unable to obtain the needed $1,000 security for their appearance. The remainder of the men caught have been paroled or have obtaind bondsmen.

BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- The Boerse has already begun to assume its holiday aspect, dealers being inclined to close their engagements before the holidays. The volume of business during the past week, excepting transactions in Government funds, was extremely light. The public shows a strong disinclination for all speculative securities, but an increased appetite, however, for fixed interest bearers, in which during the week there were large transactions.

After pleasant voyages, two transatlantic liners, both from English ports, got in yesterday. The vessels, which were the White Star liner Celtic, from Liverpool, and the Minnehaha of the Atlantic Transport Line, from London, brought across a large number of passengers for the Winter season, among whom were many people well known on one or both sides of the Atlantic.

CAIRO, Dec. 8 -- An interesting discovery has been lately made regarding the Egyptian ancestry of West African races, a problem which is of great interest to anthropologists. According to Leo, intercourse was established between Egypt and Negro-land -- that is, the Western Soudan -- in A.D. 990, but it has long been thought that relationship existed long prior to those days.

Supreme Court Justice David McAdam died unexpectedly at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. He had been operated on for a cancerous affection of the mouth at the private sanitarium of Dr. William. T. Bull at 33 West Thirty-third Street last Monday. He had passed through the critical phases following such an operation, and was supposed to be out of danger.

The conviction of "Wardman" GLENNON for willful neglect of duty is the third that has been secured by District Attorney PHILBIN within a few weeks. These convictions and the effect they are bound to have on the morals and conduct of the police are things of which Mr. PHILBIN may well be proud and fully justify, if any justification were needed, his choice as successor to the amazing Mr. GARDINER.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The stock market generally was more cheerful during the last week, chiefly owing to the growing belief here and on the Continent that the war in South Africa is really winding up at last. Speculators drew additional encouragement from the better outlook in the United States, the revival of confidence in France, and the belief that the worst of the German crisis is past.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial this morning, "Mr. Gage on Bank Evolution," you say that a practical financier has remarked that New York will not become the world's financial centre until this market is relieved from the sudden and violent fluctuations in the interest rate to which it is now so frequently exposed.

Mutterings of discontent are still heard in Metropolitan Association athletics, the old trouble of representation by every club having broken put again. This was one of the points insisted on by the ten protesting clubs which virtually forced the Metropolitan Association less than two months ago to throw down some of its arbitrary barriers and permit more than fifteen clubs to have a voice in the management.

MANILA, Dec. 22 -- Gen. George W. Davis, commanding at Zamboanga, Island of Mindanao, has requested that the Province of Misamis, Mindanao, again be placed under military control. He has proof that the recently elected President and Vice Councilors and the leading men of Cagayan de Misamis are guilty of treason in furnishing ammunition to the insurgents within the past month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a tea this afternoon in honor of her sister, Miss Carew, who is visiting at the White House. Three hundred invited guests were present. Contrary to her usual custom Mrs. Roosevelt did not call upon all the ladies of the Cabinet to aid in receiving her guests, but summoned to her assistance Mrs. Root, Miss Knox, and the Misses Hitchcock, who received with her and Miss Carew.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The British Government is watching with considerable anxiety the progress of the dispute between the Chilean and Argentine Republics. It was stated at a late hour yesterday that neither side had yet approached the British Foreign Office. If both Chile and Argentina request Great Britain to arbitrate the matters in dispute, Lord Lansdowne, the Foreign Secretary, will promptly acquiesce.

Mrs. Jennie C. Croly, ("Jennie June,") the best-known woman journalist in America and the originator of women's clubs, died in this city yesterday. Funeral services will be held Thursday morning at 10:30 in the Church of the Transfiguration, on East Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- It is said that if the Frenchmen of the Panama Canal Company wish to sell their property to the United States they will do well to dismiss from their minds all thoughts of "jockeying." If they come to Washington prepared to trade according to American methods and really offer this country a bargain, it is the prevailing opinion here that there will be a possibility of a sale.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Money was firm today. Discounts were easy. Business on the Stock Exchange was poor. The most prominent feature was the weakness of Argentines and Chileans, which ranged from 4 1/2 to 6 points. Other South American securities acted sympathetically.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 23 -- After forty years of waiting and years after they had given up all hope, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Klein of 220 Ruling Street are to-day rejoicing in being parents. Mrs. Klein, the mother, is sixty-five years of age, and her husband has reached the allotted age of threescore and ten.
PEKING, Dec. 23 -- The Chinese Court arrived yesterday at Tzu-Chow, within the boundary of Pe-chi-Li Province, where it was welcomed by numerous officials.

The United States Army transport McClellan, looking spick and span after her 12,000-mile voyage from Manila and with uniformed soldiers looking hungrily over the rail at the island which is the metropolis of their native land, arrived yesterday morning flying the flag over her taffrail at halfmast, and threw anchor off St. George, where she lay all day awaiting the night high tide, at which hour she was scheduled to dock in Communipaw.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 23 -- Clever ruses secured the escape of the eight New York policemen who were among the 300 prisoners arrested in a raid upon a poolroom in Warburton Avenue Saturday night, when they were arraigned to-day before Judge Kellogg with the batch of 101 held for examination after their capture.

Secretary William A. Hamilton of the Lakewood Country Club, after a conference with the Golf Committee, has called off the mixed foursome tournament arranged for the three last days of this week. It has been merely postponed for one week, in hopes of better conditions for a good test of golf, the Lakewood links being covered with snow and in no condition for golf beyond a little practice in knocking the ball around.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- Activity in Reading common was the only feature on the local market to-day. The buying was equally divided between New York and local interests. With this stimulus, the price rose within a fraction of its record figure, advancing to 25 1/2 on extensive purchases.

The order demanding the resignation of Edgar Stanton Maclay, the "naval historian," as a "special laborer" in the General Storekeeper's Department at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was transmitted to him yesterday by Rear Admiral Barker, Commandant of the yard. In his message to Maclay, the Commandant merely stated that he was directed by President Roosevelt to call for the designation.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 23 -- Cadet, W.B. Gates, and Donator were the winning favorites to-day. The Rush won the fifth race at the liberal odds of 6 to 1, and the Stewards promptly suspended E. Trotter, the horse's trainer, pending an investigation. The horse has started four times previously at this meeting, and his performances on those occasions were such that the Stewards felt that an inquiry was demanded.

With the contest for the world's billiard championship decided, and the match between Sehaefer and Barutel played, everything is quiet among the professionals about whom the news has centered for the last month or so. Schaefer, Barutel, Ortiz, Howison, and Moulds all sail for Paris Thursday, while "Willie" Hoppe, the juvenile expert, is to make a trip also, his destination being undecided as yet.
Charles W. Keogh, the theatrical manager, who has been seriously ill, was yesterday pronounced to be convalescing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The studious civilian public are not disconcerted by the report of the naval "sharps" in the Sehley inquiry, and we are grateful to Admiral Dewey for his keener appreciation of our point of view.

The Central Realty Bond and Trust Company has bought, through Samuel Goldsticker, the block front on the west side of Seventh Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-fifth and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Streets, fronting 201.10 feeet on the avenue and 125 feet on either street.

An eight-and-one-half-per cent, call money rate and a decline of nearly 7 points in a stock such as American Sugar, with which -- though to a lesser extent than in Amalgamated Copper -- Standard Oil interests are identified, are not encouraging or hopeful developments in the stock market, and certainly do not tend to inspire active bullish enthusiasm.

Councilman Joseph F. O'Grady was nominated for Congress from the Seventh District in a convention held in the Battery Park Music Hall last evening. According to the Officials who counted the delegates present, 158 answered to their names. The previous convention was held on Saturday evening and nominated Perry Belmont.

We print all we can make room for of Lord ROSEBERY'S speech at Chesterfield, which seems to be acknowledged on all hands in England to be the most important deliverance that has been made since the beginning of the war in South Africa. The whole speech occupied two hours in the delivery.

A certificate of reasonable doubt was yesterday granted by Justice William J. Gaynor in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, in the case of Max Hochstim, recently convicted in Manhattan of a charge of interfering with a deputy of State Superintendent of Elections McCullagh on election day. This deputy was arresting a man that he asserted had no right to vote.

Quick work was done by Central Office detectives in capturing an old-time criminal, who is alleged to have entered the house of Hamilton W. Cary, at 801 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon in the guise of an "inspector" and stolen a breastpin valued at $350.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Recent reports of the inauguration of "kommers" at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, having aroused the clergymen of various denominations, the matter was considered formally by the Baptist, Methodist, and Congrega- tionalist ministers to-day.

Surrounded by flags and flowers, 350 members of the New England Society assembled last night in the large ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria at the annual festival of the society, and reviewed the history of the people who founded the Nation and helped to make it great.

BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Money was quoted at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Call money is loaning at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Out of town banks are fair buyers of commercial paper at 5 per cent. City banks are doing little beyond taking care of their regular customers.

BUENOS AYRES, Dec. 23 -- In the course of a long conference between President Roca and Sir W.A.C. Barrington, the British Minister here, last evening, the President explained to the Minister the provoking circumstances which led to the present difficulty between Argentine and Chile.

RICHMOND, Dec. 23 -- Major Robert Temple, one of the best-known engineers in the South, died suddenly yesterday at his home here. He commenced his career as a rodman on the New Orleans, Jackson and Great Northern Railway in 1852. Since that time he has been engaged in some of the most important railway construction in the South.

Deputy Sheriff Radley has received an attachment for $6,991 against Fleteher S. Heath, which was obtained by Lawrence Hughes for Henry Frohwitter on a note made by Mr. Heath at Hamilton. Ohio, on Feb. 1, 1900, to the order of the Miami Valley National Bank of Hamilton, payable at that bank thirty days from date, which note was transferred by the bank to Mr. Frohwitter on Dec. 16, 1901.

Detectives and expert accountants are continuing their investigation of the affairs of the Bureau for the Collection of Assessments and Arrears of the Controller's office. The statement was made yesterday by an official that evidence had been obtained against another clerk, who knew of the defalcations of Deputy Collector Charles P. Chipp, and also took a hand in the signing of receipts for tax arrears by which the city's money was stolen.

Frederic P. Olcott. the President of the Central Trust Company, yesterday received a present or $50,000 from the Directors of the company for faithful services and as an expression of good will and appreciation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- Nearly 400 members and guests attended the twenty-first annual banquet of the New England Society of Pennsylvania to-night in Horticultural Hall. Guests were present from New York, Baltimore, Washington, Boston, and other cities, and the principal speakers were Assistant United States Attorney General James M. Beck, President of the society; Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court and Assistant Secretary of State David J. Hill.

CONCORD, Mass., Dec. 23 -- William Ellery Charming, the last of the brotherhood of literary men which included Thoreau, Hawthorne, and Emerson and which made Concord famous, died to-day. He was born in Boston Nov. 29. 1818.

Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, had at breakfast several months ago a guest who cost him $1,250. The guest was H.C. Stuart, the Secretary of Collector of Customs Bidwell, who had called on Mr. Schwab to ask him about a little matter of $12,500 worth of diamonds that Mr. Schwab had purchased from a Pittsburg importing house.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Edward Onslow Ford, Royal Academy, the sculptor, is dead.

There can be no question that Lieut. Gen. MILES by his public comment upon the findings of the Schley court exposed himself to the censure which the Secretary of War has pronounced against him. It may be said, that the reprimand was much too severe. Exceptions may be taken to the form of the letter in which it was administered.

The dinners which H. O'Neill Co. have been giving to their 1,800 employes daily since the holiday rush began are to be ended this evening with a bounteous Christmas feast. The dinners have been served in the restaurant with the patrons of the store, and it is there that the Christmas table will be spread this evening.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 -- Gov. Crane gave out the following statement here this afternoon:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Col. John N. Partridge, who is to succeed Col. Murphy as Police Commissioner of New York City, lunched with President Roosevelt to-day and returned to New York this afternoon.

-- Our expectation that an immediate and satisfactory reply would be made by the Cornell authorities to the complaint of the Upper Saranac residents in regard to the destruction of the Adirondack forests, is not as confident as it was before we read the statement of Prof. FERNOW, the head of the Forestry College.

The speech of Lord Rosebery at Chesterfield has attracted great attention among Englishmen of all sorts, conditions, and parties. It was delivered in the trainshed of the station, to an audience which filled it, and was estimated at 4,000, on the evening of Dec. 16. The full report occupies seven columns of The London Times.
Emil L. Boas, general agent of the Hamburg-American Line, arrived from Europe yesterday, where he had been to make arrangements for a new transatlantic service.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Lord Kitchener, in a dispatch from Johannesburg, dated Dec. 21, sends reports of sharp fighting in the Orange River and Transvaal Colonies. The engagements took place Dec. 18, 19, and 20, at points widely apart.

The recent revelations of peculations on a considerable scale by an employe of the Controller's office, and the fact that these peculations were carried on for a number of years by a person not officially intrusted with the handling of money, and not held to the responsibility that goes with such duty, suggest a condition of the municipal bookkeeping far from safe and satisfactory.

Justice Jerome last night announced the staff which he has selected for his administration as District Attorney, from Jan. 1. In all, he named six assistants and seventeen deputy assistants. George W. Schurman of Mr. Philbin's staff was retained, and will be chief of staff, acting as District Attorney in Mr. Jerome's absence.

Mayor-elect Low announced yesterday afternoon nearly all the important appointments which remained in his gift. During the holidays he will endeavor to throw off the burden connected with the distribution of patronage, and no more appointments are expected for several days.

The last of the three great events which mark the opening of the social season in New York took place last evening at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was the first night of the opera, and boxes and orchestra and every available space was filled with a fashionable and representative audience. The Horse Show has passed into history and the Assembly ball has followed.

Complaint is often made against trade unions that they are too disposed to look solely at the individual interests of the worker, without regard to the conditions of the economic situation, and especially of suet factors therein as foreign competition and the results that competition must have upon the prices of the goods on which the worker is engaged.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 24 -- The car shortage in the Pittsburg district is worse than ever before, and as a result many mills are shut down, or only in partial operation.

The President-elect of the Borough of Manhattan is quoted as having said that he had not yet been able to find a satisfactory man to take the head of the Department of Public Works. Mr. CANTOR adds that he means to live up to the platform of non-partisanship by dividing his patronage among representatives of the Republicans, the Greater New York Democracy, and the Citizens' Union.

Capt. Michael Sheehan, sent to the Tenderloin Monday, began work yesterday by raiding an alleged poolroom located on the second floor of the building at 108 West Eighteenth Street shortly after 3 o'clock in the afternoon. A crowd was found in the room, six men were captured, and a quantity of furniture was seized.

The funeral services over the body of Justice David McAdam were held last night at his late residence, 354 West Thirty-third Street, in the presence of a representative gathering of his colleagues and friends.

The New York Winter Garden, which is the cold weather name for the roof of the New York Theatre, opened last night to a fair-sized audience, offering as the stage attraction a musical comedy by Sydney Rosenfeld, called "The Supper Club."

FRAUD PRACTICED BY HUSBAND AND WIFE. -- While Lena Price was the owner of a tenement house at 220 Madison Street she contracted, through her husband, as agent, with one Multz for certain carpenter work. This was in March, 1899, and before the 1st of August following the work was finished.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Some of the first families of Metuchen interested themselves lately in establishing an inn in the village which would be an improvement on the present village hotels and give them the opportunity to entertain visitors to Metuchen on a little better scale.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Schley court of inquiry tells us that Schley did not proceed with all possible dispatch from Cienfuegos to Santiago, that he should have proceeded without regard to the Eagle and the other "lame ducks" of his squadron, and that, generally and specifically, he was no good.
George L. Rives, who will be Corporation Counsel after New Year's, gave out the following statement last night:

The four-story dwelling at the northeast cotner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eight Street, originally owned by the elder Jame Gordon Bennett and subsequently the residence of the late Austin Corbin, has changed hands again, the new owner being the New York Realty Corporation. About a year and a half ago the property was sold by the Corbin heirs, through Richard M. Montgomery, to a syndicate headed by Charles T. Barney.

Those who believe, as many do, that all that is needed to build up a nation as a great maritime power is a sufficiently liberal system of bounties to shipbuilders and shipowners, would do well to study with some care the history of shipping bounties in France during recent years.

For three years the clothing house of Herbert Ansorge, a wholesale manufacturer at 406 West Third Street, has Seen robbed systematically, $25,000 worth of goods being stolen. Although the police and private detectives have been constantly on the watch for the culprits, it was not until last night that an arrest was made by two detectives of the Mercer Street Station.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A.G. Spalding, who was elected President-Secretary-Treasurer of the National Baseball League by a faction of that organization at its last meeting in New York, had a conference today with Edward B. Talcott, one of the former stockholders in the New York club, the object of which was to induce Mr. Talcott to resume his connection with the latter organization and to endeavor, if possible, to purchase the interests of President Freedman.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 25 -- In addition to the election of himself as United States Senator, Arthur Pue German has imported political schemes to carry through the Legislature, which meets Jan. 1, at Annapolis.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 24 -- At the attempted sale of the old Mint a few days ago a man in the crowd hinted at alleged crookedness in the sale of the New York Custom House, Secretary Gage was said to have called the man "a liar," and in an interview a few days later stated that he would have thrashed the man had he presented himself.

It was a picturesque scene last night at the Seamen's Church of the Holy Comforter, 341 West Street, when 300 followers of the sea -- mild-eyed Swedes, swarthy Spaniards and Italians, and ruddy Britons -- gathered there for a Christmas Eve song service, and to receive gifts donated by friends of the church.

Important developments will probably occur within the next month in regard to the plan proposed recently by the Automobile Club of America, to make that club the National organization of America, and all other automobile clubs affiliated members of the National body. The rough draft of the plan has been sent to all the leading clubs in the country, but considerable opposition has been encountered.

MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Dec. 24 -- Charles H. Patton died at his residence, in this city, last night, at the age of sixty-seven years. He was one of the most prominent members of the legal profession in the State, ranked high in fraternal circles, and at the last State convention of Roval Arch Masona was elected Grand High Priest of the order for Illinois.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 24 -- Four favorites won to-aay. Sevoy, in the fourth race, lowered the six furlongs track record to 1:12 1/2. B. Rice, who rode Hayward Hunter in the second race, had his leg crushed by being crowded into the fence. The boy hung on gamely, and, after receiving permision to dismount, was removed to the hospital.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 24 -- The Book of Ohio Company of Bowling Green, Ohio, was chartered at Dover to-day to purchase the publication of The Book of Ohio. Capital, $50,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- There are a large and ever-increasing number of thoughtful and well informed people in Great Britain, who express the serious belief that if radical changes do not come about in the near future, the United Kingdom will be relegated to the third position in the ranks of the world's trade and commerce."

It is evident that the general views of Secretary GAGE as explained in his report, and as advocated at the bankers' dinner and discussed at the Metropolitan Club on Saturday, have aroused great interest in banking circles in this city. It is exceedingly desirable that they should be carefully considered and thoroughly debated.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 24 -- After slumbering for two years Andrew Carnegie's offer to establish a library in Louisville has been revived and may be accepted. His offer, made to the Polytechnic Society of Kentucky in 1899, was to give to the city $125,000 for a library, provided the city would provide $12,500 annually for its maintenance.

War is and of right ought to be abherred. Yet those who most sincerely deplore the armed strifes of nations must admit that they are an effective force in bringing the races of mankind to new adjustments.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- At a special meeting of the General Managers' Association held here to-day a movement was started which may result in a general increase in the wages of trainmen, enginemen, firemen, and switchmen on all big railroad systems east of Chicago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me, as one of your regular constituents, to express (with the diffidence becoming to one not a banker) my dissent from so much of Secretary Gage's recent proposition, viz., that the substantive commodity, quoted habitually in the loan market as "money," is not "money," but "credit."

Many plans had been laid by some of the younger members of the Stock Exchange for a football game and general jollification on the floor of the Exchange after the close of trading yesterday, but somehow the plans fell through. When the gong rang at 3 o'clock a majority of the traders hurried out of the building as though glad to escape from it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I for one cannot agree with the argument or conclusions reached in your editorial of this date on the Schley controversy. You say that the testimony, decision of the court, and the exceptions are before the people, and that they can judge for themselves. If they are capable of judging for themselves, why do you judge for them?

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Money was much wanted in the market this afternoon, in connection with Christmas and the settlement. Discounts, influenced by Continental bill-buying, were relatively easy, pending short-loan developments. A. greater case of money is anticipated early in January. Apart from the arrangement of the mining settlement, business on the Stock Exchange consisted mostly in closing up commitments, in preparation for the general settlement.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Are we to have a "Dreyfus case" in this country, with Admiral Schley for the victim?

Mrs. Josephine Rodgers, sixty years old, of Savannah, Ga., who had come to New York to Spend the Christmas holidays, died suddenly last night in the apartment of Mrs. Helena E. Messinger, at 123 West Ninetieth Street, after being: stricken with apoplexy at Mrs. Messinger's doorstep.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- There is probably no more important information in the report of the Philippine Commission, which has just been submitted to the Secretary of War, than the statement that, according to the present outlook, the United States Government need not ever be called upon to support the Insular Government.

The faculty point of view in regard to the control of undergraduate athletics at colleges and comments on the courses open to the authorities in regard to student eligibility are interestingly outlined in the following article in the Columbia University Quarterly by James Furman Kemp, Chairman of the Columbia Faculty Committee on Athletics:

It required only a few minutes yesterday for the Customs Inspectors to examine all the baggage that was in the hold of the Atlas Line steamship Andes, which got in from Santa Marta in the afternoon. One lone passenger, named Fairbanks, was aboard, and what little baggage there was to examine belonged to him.

The indictment of three of the police witnesses in the Glennon trial for the same offense of which he was found guilty, the willful neglect of duty, and the prompt trials that are sure to follow, will still further affect the morale of the police force, and will affect it for good.

Charles P. Chipp, the ex-Assistant Collector of Arrears, appeared before Magistrate Brann yesterday morning to answer to the charge of defrauding the city out of large sums of money, the technical complaint being the larceny of $270 of the city's money. His wife had visited him in the Tombs and had assured him that she had forgiven him for his confessed sins against her.

Charles Buddensiek, whose name had become a synonym for flimsily and illegally constructed tenement houses and buildings, and who served six and one-half years in Sing Sing Prison on a conviction of manslaughter in the second degree as a result of the killing of a man in the collapse of one of his structures, died at Plainfield, N. J., yesterday.

By the jumping from the tracks of a heavily laden baggage car in the yards of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, adjoining the Grand Central Station, shortly after 8 o'clock last evening, traffic was delayed through the tunnels of the road for more than an hour and several thousand passengers who were coming to and going from the city were detained.

It was stated at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday that the Navy Department had decided to abandon homing pigeons for wireless telegraphy. Orders have been issued directing that the pigeons kept at the various navy yards be sold. The fifty-five birds at the Brooklyn yard will be sold on Monday next to the highest bidder.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The War Department has received from the Philippines the records of the court-martial by which three natives were tried for implication in the murder of five American soldier prisoners. One of the Filipinos was Timoteo Dahlan, a commandante of the insurgent forces, who ordered Man Gonzales, a Lieutenant of insurgents, to kill the Presidente of the pueblo of San Miguel de Mayumo, Province of Bulacan.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- One of the longest and most exhaustive State reports ever made in New Jersey was that submitted to Gov. Voorhees to-day by the commission appointed to investigate the condition of the Passaic River Valley from the falls at Paterson to the mouth of the river at Bayonne and to devise some means of disposing of the sewage of the valley.

Sea gulls to the number of thousands are making their Winter home upon the city's reservoirs in Central Park. This is not unusual, except in the increased numbers which are on hand this year. As a consequence, those most familiar with conditions in the reservoirs have protested that some means should be employed to get rid of these gulls at the earliest possible moment.

It was announced at the headquarters of the Citizens' Union yesterday afternoon that after Jan. 1 a strenuous effort will be made to secure the conviction of a number of persons, some of whom are members of the Police Department, who violated the elections law or attempted crimes against the franchise on election day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit me to express dissent with a statement in your editorial of this morning (Friday) with reference to the Schley case? Your statement is that "it would be well for the gentlemen of the Navy Department to understand clearly that the final court in this case is the people of the United States."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Robert P. Ballantine, Vice President of the Howard Savings Institution, and a member of the firm of P. Ballantine Sons, was to-day appointed by Chief Justice Gummere to the unexpired term of Governor-elect Franklin Murphy as member of the Essex County Park Commission.

A mad goat by its butting proclivities caused a panic among the Christmas shoppers on Sixth Avenue, near Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon, and a number of persons received shocks that arnica and time only will remove.

A mad goat by its butting proclivities caused a panic among the Christmas shoppers on Sixth Avenue, near Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon, and a number of persons received shocks that arnica and time only will remove.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Secretary Long has discharged Edgar Stanton Maclay from his position as a special laborer in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, Maclay having refused to resign when requested to do so.

The shining career in statesmanship of Mr. JOSEPH F. O'GRADY of Staten Island and the Common Council certifies to a degree of fitness for Congressional service which it was probably presumptuous and impertinent for Mr. PERRY BELMONT to dispute. Mr. CROKER, deluding Mr. BELMONT with promises of his support, has all the time intended the nomination of O'GRADY.

Columbia's Trustees are said to be contemplating a novelty in regard to the election of the President of the university to succeed Seth Low. Instead of only one Executive, it is said that they may have two; one an educator of ability, and the other a man of administrative powers.

During the past week several conferences have been held between Mayor-elect Low and Dr. John McGaw Woodbury, whom he has named as Commissioner of Street Cleaning. Dr. Woodbury has been carefully studying the workings of the department, and has informed Mr. Low, it is said, that he will have his plans for the cleaning of New York's streets well in hand when he takes office on Jan. 1.

Three firemen were injured last night in a collision between a Sixth Avenue trolley car and Fire Insurance Patrol No. 1. at West Broadway and Thomas Street. A call was sent in to the Leonard Street Police Station, and an ambulance from the Hudson Street Hospital, with Dr. Beckwith, was hurried to the scene.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A great deal of importance is attached by persons connected with the Immigration Bureau to Section 9 of the Immigration bill, pending in the House.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 24 -- The improvement in Cotton Duck shares was the most favorable feature of to-day's local market, and that because it is to the Cotton Duck group that the recent sharp decline was due. The common was a full point higher, and there was a firmer feeling manifest all through the group.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- The Board of Aldermen has accepted the resignation of City Treasurer Philip Gerst, whose accounts are now undergoing an investigation. Gerst has publicly admitted a shortage in his accounts of over $50,000, but claims it has been made good.

The taste for stained glass in windows is no longer confined to those who think of memorials as part of church decoration alone, but seems turning to secular buildings as well. As decorations for churches the fashion is firmly established, and our glassmakers easily lead the world in the richness of their glass.

DES MOINES, Dec. 25 -- Owing to the positive statements that the appointment of Shaw does not mean the retirement of Secretary Wilson, the friends of the latter are live statements that the appointment of Gov. State, especially in the agricultural districts, and the farmers would not receive his retirement with good grace even to secure for the State a higher place in the Cabinet.
To the Editor of The yew York Times: In to-day's issue of your paper I read, with interest, a letter from Augusta, Ga., signed "Justice."

There was no truce in the Seventh Congressional District fight yesterday. Soon after leaving his breakfast table at the Democratic Club Mr. Croker once more broke his rule not to speak for publication, and talked about Mr. Belmont. Mr. Belmont was just leaving his headauarters at the Astor House to take luncheon when Mr. Croker's interview was shown to him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- A.G. Spalding left here this evening for South Carolina, but before leaving gave out a statement in answer to the communication given out by Andrew Freedman's attorney regarding Mr. Spaldlng's announcement that he would not act further as President-Secretary-Treasurer of the National Baseball League.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25 -- When the Hot Air Pleasure Club of this city invited the Gaiety Boys of New York, a club founded for similar purposes, to come over and join them in celebrating Christmas Eve with a ball in Lyric Hall, cards were issued announcing that a "warm time" might be confidently expected.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 25 -- There was the usual distribution of gifts to the children of the Cove School to-day, but the familiar figure of President Roosevelt was missing. The President made it a point to make the distribution every year, no matter what else his attention was called for.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The President of the United States played Santa Claus last night. The library had been designated as the place which, would be visited by Santa Claus, and when, after all the children were safe in bed, the President stole into the library, he found a large and varied collection of stockings a waiting the saints visit.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 25 -- Assisted by her husband and Mr. and Mrs. Kirkpatrick, her guests, Mrs. Howard Gould to-day for the second Christmas played Lady Bountiful to the public school children of Port Washington. The affair today surpassed Mrs. Gould's first attempt last year.

Mrs. Ann H. Smith which she died, four years after her husband's death, was seventy-eight years old. Mr. Smith left her a farm in Tompkins County, this State, where she continued to reside after his death, and also $20,000 in securities. She kept growing feeble, but was able, until just before her death, to go to church and do her own housework.

The weather to-day and Friday will be fair in all districts except the upper lake region and along the West Gulf Coast. In the first named snow or rain is indicated for Friday, and rain in the last named to-night or Friday. The temperature will-fall in the South Atlantic States, the lower Mississippi Valley, and in Southern. Texas. Elsewhere the changes, will be unimportant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent "G.F.Y." in today's paper asserts that the gin palaces in London are open on Sundays from "1 o'clock to 3 in the afternoon." I am under a strong impression that in recent years they have been closed during those hours, and this same statement was made the other day in The Evening Post.

Secretary Vorhies of the National Bowling League has Issued the records of the tournament of 1901, which was completed last week. The averages of both the teams and the Individual members are, as a whole, unusually high and very creditable.

At the Irving Place Theatre yesterday afternoon over one hundred children belonging to the society Klein Edelweiss, presented a revival of an old fairy play entitled "Aladdin, or the Magic Lamp," being a German version in dramatic form of the famous story from the Arabian Nights.

Christmas cheer was yesterday carried to the thousands of inmates of the prisons and hospitals of New York. For once the prisoners were made to feel that the City was taking a kindly interest in them.
