From early morning the Wardens and turnkeys were cheerful and encouraging, and they exchanged Christmas greetings with the men and women who were locked behind bars.

Of course it is satisfactory to be assured that there is no danger of a conflict between Argentina and Chile. That is more credible than that the dispute should be "serious," as we are semi-officially assured from Washington that it is. The proposition to refer it to the Commissioners now delimiting the boundary indicates that the main question in dispute is territorial.

The bill for the formation of a National naval reserve, introduced in the House by Mr. Foss, does not appear on its face to be a practical measure. The bill provides for the enrollment in the first formation of all the members of the existing naval militia who served in the war with Spain and of ex-naval officers and others specially qualified for the service.

Disheartened and melancholy because she was away from her home in Kingston on Christmas Day, Annie Davenport, a pretty eighteen-year-old girl, attempted to end her life in her apartments at 331 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street last night by drinking carbolic acid. Only two months ago she was at school in Kingston, where her people are well to do.

"Darktown," as One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, between Amsterdam Avenue, and Broadway, is known on account of its colony of negroes, was the scene of a fierce free fight between negroes and whites yesterday afternoon, in which one man was shot, two were cut and slashed with razors, and a score or more had their heads battered with clubs and bale sticks.

Nature scarcely ever strikes without warning. In so far as disease is concerned it gives clear signs of what is impending days, weeks, months, and even years before the attack. If people looked for these signs and took warning from them they would escape much serious illness and live many years longer than they do.

The home of James Lewey, a mechanic who lives with his wife and five children at 625 Greenwich Street, was ringing with cries of delight last night as the little ones played around the Christmas tree in the little front parlor. The tree was lighted with candles, and many of the children who live in the five story tenement had been invited to take part in the festivities.

The remarkable series of articles appearing in The London Times on the crisis in British industry show very clearly that the most serious menace to the prosperity of Great Britain and to the retention of her position as a manufacturing nation is found in the policy of the trade unions.

An attack on the constitutionality of the Goddard amendment to Section 344 of the Penal Code, relating to policy playing, was made yesterday morning in Centre Street Court, before Magistrate Brann, by Cantwell Moore, counsel for John and Charles Wilson, father and son, arrested last Thursday in a raid by agents of Capt. F. Norton Goddard's Anti-Policy Society, on an alleged policy shop in Coenties Slip.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Nov. 28 -- The last few weeks have been characterized in Australasia by heavy gales, devastating stories, and, in this colony, by one of the heaviest shocks of earthquake experienced for many years. The earthquake, fortunately, injured no person, but the damage to property is very severe.

Whatever else can be said of the stock market, the one thing that stands out very prominently is that in the face of the sixty-point break in Amalgamated Copper, succeeded by a twenty-point decline in Sugar Trust stock-both "blind pools," and both with Standard Oil affiliations -- the general market, and more especially the railroad list, has held up wonderfully well.

Local skaters being deprived of the privilege of taking part in the races scheduled for Verona Lake, Montclalr, N.J., yesterday availed themselves of the opportunity offered by the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, and some rare sport resulted. A. Y. Sarony of the New York Athletic Club won the mile handicap from the forty-yard mark in the fast-time of 3:03 3-5.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- The society colony at Tuxedo passed a very quiet Christmas. The weather being cloudy and rainy, kept many in town. During the day luncheons were given by J. Henry Smith, Mr. and Mrs. James Brown Lord, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Munroe, Mr. and Mrs, T.G. Condon, and others.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 25 -- Nellie Waddell, who galloped away with the first race to-day, hung up a new track record for five furlongs -- 1:00 1/2. Nitrate, who got the verdict by a short-head in the second race, reduced the track record for a mile and 20 yards to 1:41. The race of the day was the Christmas Handicap, worth $1,800 to the winner.

It is something over thirty years ago that I first knew William McKinley, a young practicing attorney at Canton, Ohio. Strange as it may seem, I cannot recall the exact time or place when I first met him. I know that it was early in the seventies, and I have a recollection of being strangely attracted to the quiet and methodical lawyer.

One of those mysterious messages which are never discussed by policemen swept through the Tenderloin district yesterday afternoon, and the nine finest gambling houses in New York, with the exception of Canfield's place, closed their doors to all comers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Italian Government has been renewing its efforts of late with the authorities in Washington to have this country's statutes so extended as to protect foreigners in cases arising within the jurisdiction of States, thus giving a Federal remedy for lynchings and like affrays directed against Italians, such as have occurred in Louisiana, Colorado, and Mississippi.

A Christmas surprise was sprung on the friends of J. Harvey Ladew, the wealthy and well-known yachtsman, when it was published yesterday that on Nov. 27 Mr. Ladew had been married to Miss Jennie Bennett House of Rochester, N.Y. Mr. Ladew, who was the partner of the late Daniel Fayerweather, is a member of many prominent clubs, among them the Union League and the New York and Larchmont Yacht Clubs.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Dec. 25 -- The third annual Christmas tree festival of the crew of the Pennsylvania Railroad's train 273-289, which runs between this place and Jersey City, was held here to-day, and the crew entertained about thirty guests.

Eugene Sullivan, the proprietor of a saloon at 189 Pavonia Avenue, Jersey City, and the thirteen men who were arrested with him in the raid made on the saloon Tuesday, were discharged by Acting Justice John P. McCormick in the Gregory Street Court yesterday.

Horace C. Vandenberg, who asserts that he is a lawyer, physician, chemist, and a man of real talent, notwithstanding the fact that He is according to the police measurement, less than five feet four inches in height, and weighs under one hundred and twenty-five pounds, celebrated Christmas by being arrested and held in, the Mulberry Street Police Station.
Dime novels are thought to have been responsible for a youthful escapade involving the loss of $400 in cash yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The weather to-day was fine, and the boulevards were thronged all day by animated crowds of promenaders visiting the Toy Fair.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- One of the potent agencies relied upon by the United States Philippine Commission to Americanize the natives of those islands is a system of distinctly American public school education. Very interesting information as to what has already been accomplished is supplied in the report of the commission just submitted to the Secretary of War.

PRETORIA, Dec. 25 -- The formation of a new Burgher Corps, to be known as National Scouts, has aroused great interest among the surrendered burghers. In view of numerous meetings and applications, Lord Kitchener has authorized the creation of fresh wings to operate in the Southern and Eastern Transvaal, under prominent Boer leaders elected by the burghers themselves.

An interesting decision governing the relations between dentistry and dental boards in Wisconsin was rendered by Judge "Williams in the suit of Dentist F.C. Moloy against John Heffron, brought to collect a dentist's bill. The court held that while a dentist is prevented by law from practicing until he has a license from the State Board of Dental Examiners, he may recover for services performed without a license.
POTTSTOWN, Penn., Dec. 25 -- Henry Kramer, aged sixty-two years, was accidentally shot and killed in his home here to-day, after a dispute with his sons, Henry A. and Fred Kramer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Gov. Leslie M. Shaw has accepted the President's of offer to make him Secretary of the Treasury. This announcement was made at the White House to-night, and with it came the statement that the selection of an Iowa man for the office did not mean that Secretary Wilson's position would be interfered with.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the Sampson-Schley controversy which, according to the latest reports, seems to have had the immediate effect of almost disrupting the Cabinet, may I give an incident in my own experience, and allow you and your intelligent body of readers to draw your own conclusions, and answer or not, as you, or they, deem best.

The focal point of the gradually increasing coal famine, resulting from the inability of the railroads to move the freight offered them, seems to be in Central Ohio. In that State the important manufacturing industries are closing down for lack of fuel, and the losses and inconvenience therefrom resulting are very serious.
HAVANA, Dec. 25 -- According to telegrams printed in Senor, Estrada Palma's official organs, Gen. Gomez is faring badly on his political tour in favor of Palma.

-- Without pretending to be deeply grieved over the ugly and inconvenient Christmas present which Mr. EDGAR STANTON MACLAY, special laborer, has received from his official chief, we do regard as entirely natural, and lo that extent sympathize with, the surprise he manifests at finding himself, a lonely victim among the Sampsonian cohorts, selected for reproval and punishment.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 26 -- The Yale basket ball team left this afternoon for the longest Western trip a Yale team has ever taken. The team will go as far as Milwaukee and Minneapolis and return, playing eight games in the ten days of the trip. The team is made up of Capt. Lockwood, Finch, Pease, Hall, Hyatt, Church, Smith, Moorehead, Colton, and Weymouth, the last named being this year's 'Varsity full back.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Dec. 26 -- Thomas J. Hickey to-day made a denial of the dispatches sent out to the effect that the American Association will place a club in Louisville or Chicago.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 -- It is generally believed that unless the Detroit and Cleveland and the Cleveland and Buffalo Steamboat Companies form a close business alliance for next year's traffic, there is likely to be a fight for business between them. Added to that situation is the rumor that a direct lake line between Toledo and Buffalo, to be a part of the Clover Leaf Railroad, is probable.

With Christmas over, society is slowly recovering its-equilibrium, so to speak, and is beginning to entertain again. Last evening there was a fancy dress dance for the Misses Quackenbush, and this evening there is a meeting of the dancing classes. However, there will be nothing very notable for the week end, as there are so many people in the country.

The North American Indian was saved from annihilation yesterday just in the nick of time. Armed to the teeth and with enough ammunition about them to make sure that not a single skulking red varmint escaped Harrison Tiffany and Bert Fenwick, the two Brooklyn lads who ran away from their homes on Christmas Day, were caught yesterday afternoon just as they were about to board a train at New Milford, N.J., bound for the West.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Argentine Minister, Dr. Garcia-Merou, to-day received the following dispatch from the Minister of Foreign Affairs at Buenos Ayres:

A.G. Spalding, the enjoined National Baseball League President, and "Nick" Young, the former President, and who is not exactly sure whether he holds the office or not, had a friendly chat on baseball matters the other day, when Mr. Spalding stopped over in Washington on his way to South Carolina from Chicago.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 26 -- The troubles of the Wills family have become public property again and promise to involve the men of the village within the next few days.

The very considerable expansions which have been brought about in the English furniture trades during the past few years may be specially commended to the consideration of those workmen who are disposed to regard labor-saving machinery as necessarily inimical to their own interests.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 26 -- Fire broke out in Denlinger Brothers' oil refinery on Smallman Street about 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, and on account of the inflammable material the flames spread rapidly. The building was filled with barrels and tanks of oil, and the heat caused many of them to explode.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The following dispatch has been received from Lord Kitchener, dated Johannesburg:
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Sir Joseph Noel Paton, the painter, was found dead in his bed at Edinburgh to-day.

James Kinney of Queens County enlivened the proceeding's of the Republican City Committee at Murray Hill Lyceum last night by registering a decided protest against the selection, in advance, of the officers of the organization by the Executive Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- Charles A. Alden, private secretary to Commissioner Keller and acting Treasurer of the Charities Fund in the Department at New York, who is reported as missing since last Saturday, registered at the Hotel Walton, in this city, Saturday, left his valise as security and went out.

The Insurance Press -- which, we regret to learn, has itself just suffered a heavy loss, and perhaps even more serious inconvenience, from the destruction of its mechanical plant in the recent Reade Street fire -- publishes in its current issue a series of tables showing that within the past twenty-five years the fire loss in the United States has exceeded $2,800,000,000.

A movement of considerable strength is being carried on to secure radical amendments to the Inter-State Commerce act extending and modifying the powers of the commission. We publish in another column a letter from Mr. WALKER D. HINES, First Vice President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, which, we suppose, may fairly be taken as representing the views of the larger railroad interests.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 26 -- The State Department made public to-day extracts from the first annual report of United States Consul Norton at Harput, Armenia.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Announcement was matte here to-day that the new constitution of the Methodist Episcopal Church, adopted at the General Conference last May and referred to the various conferences throughout the country, had been approved by the three-quarters vote required. The vote was as follows: Ayes, 8,196; nays, 2,513.

John Fox, Jr., the son of John Fox, the President of the Democratic Club, yesterday filed objections to the probate of the will of his mother, Mrs. Ellen Fox, in which he was cut off in a clause which said: "I do not mention my erring and misguided son, but I know that his father will not only treat him justly but mercifully."

His Holiness Pope Leo XIII., on the testimony of the Archbishop of New York, has by a mandate dated at the Vatican, Oct. 11, 1901, appointed John D. Crimmins a Knight Commander of the Order of St. Gregory the Great of the civil class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much is now said about enlarging the powers of the Inter-State Commerce Commission. The agitation of this question will likely become more and more active. The importance and effect of the proposed legislation cannot be exaggerated. Widespread misconception exists on the subject.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- William L. Sloat, a man older than most men live to be, and Mary Elizabeth Vanderhoff, a young woman, had the record of their marriage filed, in Goshen to-day with the Registrar of Vital Statistics. The bridegroom is seventy-seven years old, with halting step and white hair.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 26 -- It is announced that the seven-day walking match scheduled to open to-night at the Coliseum, has been declared off. Prominent walkers from different parts of the country had already come here to participate. Among them are George Tracey, champion of the United States; George Cartwright, champion of England, and George Noremac, former American champion.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 26 -- A dispatch from Richmond, Ind., says that Tod Sloan sends word to his Indiana relatives that he has applied for a license to ride in England and America next year. He is now in Paris engaged in the manufacture of automobiles.

Charles A. Alden, private secretary to Commissioner John W. Keller of the Department of Charities, and also Acting Treasurer of the department, and Trustee of the Court Fund of the Out-Door Poor Department, has been missing from the city since Saturday noon last. Expert accountants, under direction of Commissioner Keller, began examining his books yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Edgar S. Maclay, the historian recently employed in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was notified today by the Civil Service Commission that his removal from his position was not in violation of the civil service act. This notification is contained in a letter written to Mr. Maclay by President Procter of the commission in reply to an inquiry from him.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks was in good supply at 3 per cent. New York funds cold at par, and 5 cents premium for cash. Exchanges, $22,232,907. Balances, $1,163,295. Money on call rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Time money is nominally 5 per cent, for four to six months.

Alfred Steckler was appointed Justice of the Supreme Court by Gov. Odell yesterday to fill a vacancy caused by the death of Justice David McAdam. Justice Steckler will serve for a year. Under the law, candidates for the place must be nominated for the general election to be held in November, 1902.
OLYMPIA, Washington, Dec. 26 -- Gov. Rogers died here at 8 o'clock to-night.

Col. E.A. Gilon, under whose control of the Bureau for the Collection of Assessments and Arrears of the Finance Department there has been defalcations estimated at from $30,000 to $75,000, was before Controller Coler yesterday afternoon on formal charges. Col. Gilon's resignation was requested by Controller Coler some time ago and refused.

Justice William C. Holbrook yesterday, in the Court of Special Sessions, First Division, dismissed the charges of oppression brought against Deputy Police Commissioner William S. Devery by ex-Policeman Edward O'Neill. In his memorandum Justice Holbrook refers to the Deputy Commissioner's language as "indecorous and of- fensive," but says that no conviction of neglect of official duty, based upon this charge alone, would legally stand.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- An Interview which M. Lagarde gave on his return from Jibuti to the Marseilles correspondent of the Francais is quoted by the Paris correspondent of The Times.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- The protest by the Methodist Ministers' Association against the student gatherings of the Massachusetts Institute of Technalogy at which beer is served, calls forth a letter from President Pritchett, in which he says:

Yesterday's remarkable upward movement in prices on the Stock Exchange may best be described as an incipient bear panic, as a result of which the "shorts" who had gone home on Tuesday pleased with their stock market Christmas presents were treated to a most unwelcome dessert.

KEYPORT, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The families of Patrick Kearney and Peter Lewis of this place spent a sad Christmas Day yesterday. They received word early yesterday morning that both men had been drowned off Rockaway Beach by the capsizing of a small sailboat. Kearney and Lewis were oystermen, and left Keyport for several days at a time to work in the oyster beds at Rockaway.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- Except in the last hour the Philadelphia market suffered from Inertia, though prices held fairly firm. At 2 o'clock, under the influence of the spurt in New York, Reading was lifted in a spirited fashion and the whole list began to harden. Improvement was shown in Cambria Steel, Electric Company of America, Consolidated Traction of Pittsburg, Marsden, Philadelphia Company, and Lehigh Valley.

It is much to be wished that there might be prepared, under the auspices of the State Department, say, a "Primer of the Monroe Doctrine," for use in the newspaper offices of the Continent of Europe. In the Chancelleries of the Continent it is not needed, nor any longer in the newspaper offices of Great Britain.

One of the saddest and still one of the most comforting Christmas celebrations took place yesterday afternoon when nearly 200 little cripples, under the care of the New York Society for the Relief of Ruptured and Crippled Children, were made happy about a splendid Christmas tree stationed in the play hall of the hospital at 135 East Forty-second Street.

The ferocious reprimand addressed, by direction of the President, to the Lieutenant General commanding the United States Army by the Secretary of War for publicly expressing opinions different from those at which a naval court of inquiry had arrived, has been promptly followed by the peremptory discharge, also by direction of the President, through the Secretary of the Navy, of a "special laborer" in the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Secretary of the Navy has felt it his duty to censure Admiral Dewey for a public utterance ou an opinion which he was perhaps better entitled than any of his fellow-citizens, either lay or official, to formulate, an opinion which is participated in by a majority of the Nation.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 26. -- Edward Corrigan, the prominent Kansas City turfman, who is to sail for England early in the year, arrived here to-night from Kansas City on his journey from Sacramento to New York. He has about twenty-five racers in England, and he intends to race them again next season.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The present interest in the Isthmian Canal makes the following words of Goethe worthy of notice. They are found in his Conversations with Eckermann in 1827.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 26 -- The Presbyterian Creed Revision Committee has issued the following statement through its Secretary, the Rev. Dr. William Henry Roberts:
Hugh McLaughlin, the Democratic leader of Kings County, was moved yesterday to answer published statements attributed to Controller-elect Edward M. Grout concerning Democratic reorganization.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 26 -- An interesting athletic decision has just been made by the Central Association of the Amateur Athletic Union. It stipulates the order of events to be followed in all athletic meets held under the auspices of the Central Association. This plan will aid trainers and team managers to make up their teams and arrange the placing of their men.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Ex-Prof. Herve, says the Paris correspondent of The Times, is again to be prosecuted, this time for a new article denouncing barrack life, especially addressed to conscripts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 16 I find an article on the State canals, which in some respects shows your appreciation of the fact that even with the very small increase in tonnage for the past year they have diminished to an almost insignificant factor in the commerce of the State.

Frank Farrell, known as the poolroom king, purchased the Empire City track at a foreclosure sale in Yonkers yesterday for $218,000. James M. Hunt, representing the creditors of the estate, was the only one to bid against him. Bankson T. Morgan, the referee, acted as the auctioneer. Immediately after the sale Farrell left for New York.

The Seventh District Congressional fight became more bitter yesterday. From Tammany sources the information was given out that Edward Muller, the son of Nicholas Muller, the Democratic leader of Richmond, had received a valuable oil painting from Perry Belmont. Nicholas Muller was largely instrumental in bringing about the nomination of Mr. Belmont.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 26 -- Judge Alfred Steckler was seen to-night at the Lakewood Hotel, where he is stopping with his family. To THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent he said:

Upon the resumption of business in the outside market yesterday prices showed considerable strength and transactions were larger than on, the first two days of the week. Practically all the active issues ended the day at prices at least fractionally higher than those of Tuesday's close, and in a number of instances the advances amounted to a point or more.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
Details will be found in another column regarding two trades involving properties valued at $4,000,000, owned by the Rev. Dr. E.A. Hoffman, Hoffman Brothers, and Henry Corn.

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Coroner Lisk continued to-day the inquest in the case of Peter A. Hallenbeck of Greenport, who was murdered at his home last Tuesday. The four young men under arrest on suspicion of being implicated in the murder are Willis. Burton, and Frederick Van Wormer and Harvey Bruce.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Ollie Atherton, the fourteen-year-old daughter of Robert Atherton, was drowned this afternoon while attempting to rescue her sister, Susie and Ira Balsley, both aged eleven.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The gathering of German warships in the vicinity of Venezuela and the presence in the same locality of many American, British, French, and other foreign warships is directing attention to the probable imminence of a German naval demonstration against Venezuela.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The account, recently published in THE NEW YORK TIMES'S SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS, of Mr. Dana's success in reducing the circulation of fiction 24 per cent., has interested rne greatly. In response to your inquiry as to the means by which such results can be accomplished.

A COMFORTABLE distance back from a shady West End strret in Atlanta, Ga., a frame cottage that seems mainly roof, and veranda, and the impression of quit sufficiency as to the life of its inmates, shelters the family of Joel Chandler Harris.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Stock values in the Philadelphia market were lifted in sympathy with New York, as well as because of cheerful local influences. There were large transactions in Reading common for New York account, and all the Readings crossed their high-record marks. Union Traction was an active feature, advancing nearly a point upon the report that the company had acquired the Foerderer Mack rapid transit franchises.

"SHAKESPEARE as a Dramatic Artist, with an Acat count, of His Reputation Various Periods," by Prof. Thomas R. Lounsof Yale, is being published by Charles Scribner's Sons. This is a history both of the attitude taken at different periods by English playwrights and the English public toward the rules governing the classical stage, and also of the opinions held about Shakespeare and his art from the time of the Restoration to the nineteenth century.

Gymnastic directors from prominent universities convened at Columbia University yesterday in the annual meeting of the Society of College Gymnasium Directors. The object of the organization is the advancement of physical education in institutions of higher learning and to discuss the theoretical and practical questions pertaining to gymnastics in these institutions.

With festoons of lace, Point de Venise, if you please, Mr. Arthur Symons decorates Henry Murger. The Briton who can appreciate this particular kind of a Frenchman is of the rarest, but certainly Mr. Symons understands the Murger characteristics. Murger found his Bohemia, and made it his own.

Some interesting information in regard to the Controller's Office was brought out yesterday in the trial of Col. Edward Gilon before Controller Coler for carelessness in the management of the Bureau for the Collection of Assessments and Arrears. This proceeding was the result of the $30,000 defalcation of Charles P. Chipp, the Deputy Collector.

There will be a line-up of the factions in the Seventh District Congressional fight before the Board of Elections this morning. On the outcome of this contest depends in a great measure the manner in which the fight between the Croker and Belmont factions will be carried on.

Brayton Ives, banker and sometime bibliophile, but now a purchaser of highclass trotters, has just gained his celebrated suit brought against Gilbert I. Ellis to determine the genuineness of an alleged Columbus letter which he bought in March, 1890, believing it to be the only copy of the Naples edition of April, 1493, which existed outside of the Ambrosian Library, at Milan.

Henry Stokes, twenty-three years old, colored, 6 feet 5 inches in height, weighing 210 pounds, is the description of a prisoner whom two Central Office detectives and three policemen captured and restrained with difficulty last evening in the shopping district. There was a chase, during which four shots were fired, a policeman's club thrown, and at the end a struggle.

William E. Dodge, the President, and the Rev. Dr. L.T. Chamberlain, the General Secretary, of the Evangelical Alliance for the United States, issued yesterday the invitation of the Evangelical Alliances of the world for the week of united and universal prayer, Jan. 5-13, 1902. It follows:

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- After ,Christmas, calendare, and one of the fruits of what might be called the new art, of printing, the devices by which inks or many colors may be used at small expense, is the appearance of many privately issued calendars, sometimes intended for the general buyer, sometimes, but more rarely, for special classes.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The time is long passed in which a librarian is to be considered as simply a custodian of books in his charge -- to keep them from getting down off the shelves and going off on a vacation. The pendulum swung, naturally enough, to the other end of the arc -- the librarian as a public servant, as a tempter of the young and the old.
Volume I. of the new edition of "Social England" will be ready in January lor publication in Amer- ica by G.P. Putnam Sons. This edition is illustrated, revised, and partly rewritten.

The six days' sale of Important books, which was concluded at Sotheby's Dec. 7, realized a total of L6,216 11s. 6d. for 1,475 lots, and brought forward a notable Byron item -- "Poems on Various Occasions" -- which was secured for an American customer at L120 by Denham Co., this fact causing much regret on the part of the English press.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Harvey Ladew, whose marriage was announced as a surprise to their friends on Christmas Day, sailed Thursday on Mr. Ladew's new steam yacht Columbia on a long honeymoon tour to the West Indies and the Mediterranean. The principal ports at which the yacht will touch are the Bermudas, Azores Islands, Gibraltar, and at a number of the Italian ports and other resorts on the Mediterranean.

BY invitation from the Committee on Public Art of the Reform Club, of which Charles R. Lamb is Chairman, Brooks Adams on Dec. 12 made a striking address before the club on the need for greater art sense in American municipalities.

Eleven basket ball teams in the metropolitan district were suspended yesterday after a joint committee meeting between the Basket Ball Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union and the Registration Committee of the Metropolitan Association. Their offense was playing under false colors and technical violations of rules.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you allow me space to explain some of the misconceptions and misstatements of your writer under "Topics of the Times," regarding the College of Forestry?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Navy Department this morning received the following telegram from Admiral Mortimer L. Johnson, commanding the Boston Navy Yard, dated to-day:

Readers scarcely need to have their attention directed to the letters from librarians, printed elsewhere in this issue, on the subject of restricting the circulation of fiction. What is most notable and most encouraging is the importance which the subject already has assumed in the minds of librarians.

George Nantell, forty years old, a painter, who lived at 540 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, was run down and instantly killed at 6:30 o'clock last night by a big unmanageable motor vehicle at Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. John McCluskey, twenty-seven years old, also a painter, of 115 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, a companion of Nantell's, was knocked down and received injuries that necessitated his removal to Bellevue Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Rumor-mongers were busy this morning with the story sent out from Omaha last night to the effect that a Kansas man soon would be a member of President Roosevelt's Cabinet. According to this story, Secretary Wilson of the Agricultural Department was to retire and F.D. Coburn, who is serving his fourth term as Secretary of the Kansas State Board of Agriculture, was to be invited to fill the vacancy.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Your question assumes that a showing on the face of the library statistics that a smaller percentage of fiction has been circulated than in some previous year is conclusive evidence that the readers have derived more benefit from the library than in that previous year.

How "The Cavalier" Was Written. Some recent reviews of George W. Cable's "The Cavalier" have nothesitated to state or to imply that the author broke away from his old-time style and atmosphere in order to catch public approval rather than the approbation of that not over large, yet particular public, which highly approved of Mr. Cable's earlier work.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 27 -- United States Senator William J. Sewell died at his home here at 9:30 A.M. He suffered from diabetes complicated with stomach and heart trouble. Senator Sewell's illness had extended over a period of two years, but his condition was not considered serious until about a year ago. His constant attention to the duties devolving upon him in his official capacity resulted, in 1899, in a collapse.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,300 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Dr. Garnett's volume, is signal proof that busy people often find abundant leisure for work outside their regular vocations. The twelve essays were written in the leisure hours of a hard-working librarian during the last fourteen years -- a period of time in which Dr. Garnett's duties at the British Museum must have been sufficiently oncrous.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- The report that Wagner left a voluminous autobiography in a sealed packet only to be opened and published thirty years after his death -- that is to say, in 1913 -- is believed to be either entirely without foundation or merely an advertising prelude to the appearance of some new collection of Wagner's reminiscences or letters.

According to the report of Major Gen. Charles F. Roe. commanding the New York National Guard, made public yesterday, the guard of the State is in excellent condition and larger than it has been in some years. Its present strength is 859 commissioned officers and 13,551 enlisted men, total 14,410, divided as follows:

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- Money at the local Clearing House to-day was quoted at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at par, 5 and 10 cents discount. Exchanges, $21,370,815; balances, $2,511,171. Money on call rules generally from 4 to 5 per cent. Time money is nominally 5 per cent. for four to six months.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- For his four score years and his title of "Nestor of the Jewish Church Reform in the Northwest," Dr. Bernhard Felsenthal, who will be eighty years old next Thursday. is to be honored to-morrow morning at the Isaiah Temple. The services for 10 o'clock have been arranged by the Chicago Rabbinical Association, and they will be repeated Sunday at the Sinai Temple.

A meeting of the Tammany Hall Executive Committee was held last evening and Richard Croker was present. He did not resign from the leadership, as it was stated he would do soon after the election. Instead Mr. Croker indicated that he intended to continue at the helm and he issued an invitation to all the discontented members of Tammany Hall to come "out in the open and make their kicks."

Mr. North has here prepared for a series of English and American classics a volume of selections from Lamb's Essays, with a long introductory essay and copious explanatory notes. The latter are particularly well-arranged, marginal numbers referring readers to explanatory notes forming a separate section at the end of the volume.

The mental mental digestion of young readers -- like their physical -- is capable of feats at which their elders can only look with amazed awe. The same boys who find no pabulum in Scott and Cooper will devour mediocre tales of adventure, singly or in neverending courses, with an avidity worthy of a better object.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Two members of the President's Cabinet and several bureau chiefs of the Navy Department, guests of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, left here for Newport News, Va., at 10 o'clock this evening by special train, to attend the launching of the battleship Missouri at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning, C.B. Orcutt, President of the company, was in the party.

Some of our readers will doubtless remember the mild excitement that pervaded the select literary circles of England, and extended within like limits to this country, a few years ago over the "style" of the late Walter Pater, not only the standard he undertook to set up, but the effort he made to apply it in his own writing.
After a delay of several months the longexpected annual report of the Union Pacific Railroad was made public yesterday.

Whatever Mr. Merriman lacks, we must concede his versatility in the matters of motive and scene, his power to interest both in character and plot, capacity for observation and an agreeable style. Why, with all these marks to his score, he invariably falls out before the end of the game, it is not easy to say.

The New York County Medical Society is now offered an opportunity to correct the impression that the physicians have manifested a singular and unaccountable apathy respecting the popular distrust of vaccine virus and the serums. The following resolution has been referred to the appropriate committee of that body and will come up for consideration and action at its next meeting:

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- Details of a plan for the reorganization of the Erie Telegraph and Telephone Company, with a capital of $32,000,000, involving a transfer of control to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, are made public in a circular to the shareholders of the former company. Kidder, Peabody Co., bankers, will carry out the plan if it is accepted by the shareholders.

WE have received from the Public library Committee of Connecticut, of which Miss Hewins of Hartford is Secretary, the selected list printed below or books for 1901, exclusive of those published in November and December.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Dec. 27 -- Five weeks of mystery and speculation as to the fate of Miss Ella M. Cropsey terminated to-day at 10 o'clock, when the body of the missing girt was found floating in the river opposite her father's home. The body was discovered by J.D. Stillman, a fisherman, who immediately notified the committee.

The members of the Board of Aldermen became excited at the meeting yesterday over franchise matters. Charges were made that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was maintaining a lobby in the City Hall, and that many members of the Board of Aldermen were "owned by the Metropolitan." Sergeant at Arms Coakley had to be called several times by President Thomas F. Woods, whose efforts were ineffectual in quelling the disorder.

MR. JOHN COTTON DANA'S success in restricting the circulation of fiction in the City Library of Springfield, Mass., 24 per cent. in four years was commented on in an editorial article printed in this paper two weeks ago.

IN 1896, while working in the city department of a New York paper, the writer hereof was detailed to collect the facts and write an article on the book market, keeping in view especially the sales of the popular books of the previous year or two -- such as "Tri by" and "Ben-Hur."
Rosa Delmonico has sold, through Robert Potter and William Dodd, to Henry Gucker the dwelling 220 West Fourteenth Street, 25 by 120.

By defeating Princeton in the second round in the intercollegiate tournament yesterday, Columbia forged to the front with half a point the better of Princeton. Harvard is still last, although she broke even with Yale yesterday. The contest is an unusually open one, and today's play may furnish some surprises.

READERS will find printed below lists of the contents of the principal American magazines for January. The lists are restricted to periodicals which appear once a month and, while the contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions relate mainly to regular and familiar departments and some of the minor contributions.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The reported decrease of 24 per cent, in fiction reading in the Springfield City Library in four years is what Lord Dundreary would have called a "staggerer." If, however, Mr. Dana says it's so, it is so; though it is a wonderful result, even from so exceptionally favorable a combination as the culture of Springfield and the ingenuity and resources and earnestness of Mr. Dana.

"John Forsyth's Aunts" is a series of episodes in each of which some of the same people reappear rather than one story or a collection of stories Except A Taste or Freedom," which is also a taste of Boston, they take place in the little New England village of Eppingham, and have to do with the trivial incidents and interests of provincial life centring around three maiden ladies.

The sentence pronounced yesterday upon the wardman GLENNON, like that previously passed and now in course of execution upon the wardman BISSERT, is calculated to improve the efficiency of the police force and to facilitate the labors of its new Chief. We can hardly say so much of the sentence in the case of Capt. DIAMOND.

The "Memoirs of an American Lady" has now been out of print for many years. The book was first published in London in 1808, and reprinted the following year. The first American edition appeared in 1809), at New York. The succeeding issues were rapidly exhausted, and for a long time it has been impossible to obtain them, except by chance, for excessive prices.

LONDON Dec. 10 -- Mr. Leslie Stephen, in his article in the last number of The National Review, counters pleasantly on the Baconians by asserting that Shakespeare was really the author of most of the works which have hitherto been attributed to Bacon.

It is a well-known fact that ever since Felix Mendelssohn lived and reigned musically in London his name has been worshipped with a great reverence by Englishmen. Admirable as Mendelssohn's music is in many respects, it is not to an Englishman that we should turn for a temperate and judicious estimate of his place in the world of art.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 27 -- Dispatches from Salonika report that W.W. Peet (Treasurer of the Missionary Society in Constantinople) has established communication with the brigands who hold Miss Ellen M. Stone captive and hopes that the release of Miss Stone will be accomplished within a fortnight.

The remonstrance of the Danes in Denmark against the sale of the Danish West Indies without a popular vote in the mother country shows with how much patriotic pride possessions are regarded which certainly do not add much to the material resources of the distant owner.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 -- Brewer Schorr and Annie, Thompson were the winning favorites to-day. In the steeplechase Butler, who rode Harve B., was unseated, but remounted and finished the race. In the fifth race Donna Seay was caught in a jam at the start and fell. The mare and rider escaped serious injury. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 27 -- J.H Bridges, President of the Uvalde Asphalt Company, has received a cablegram announcing that his company has been awarded the contract for laying pavements and sewers in the City of Havana, Cuba.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- Henry T. Coates Co. report the glowing success of "By the Higher Law," a novel of the New York" smart set," by Julia Helen Twells, Jr. Miss Twells, who now lives in New York, and who is conversant with the society of which she writes, was formerly a Philadelphian, and is still well known here.

A certain author of literary works once removed from a comfortable but unpretentious residence in a down-town street to a spacious and gracious mansion in one of the new avenues up town. His friends were at a loss to account for this sudden demonstration of solvency, for they had heard of no windfall of fortune which dropped upon this author.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The best way to reduce the circulation of fiction in a library is to have as many open shelves as possible ana give every reader two cards, one for all classes of books, the other for non-fiction, including bound magazines and music. There are stories in magazines, to be sure, but the reader has the benefit of the doubt.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 27 -- Through a decoy message Reuben Wallman of Oak Street was arrested by Secret Service agents at the Post Office here to-day. The prisoner was taken immediately to the railroad station, where, in custody of the officers, he boarded a train for New York. The officers declined to say on what charge the arrest was made.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Gov. Voorhees and Adjt. Gen. Oliphant left at noon to-day for Camden to confer with the family of Senator Sewell in reference to having a military funeral. It is expected that the Third Regiment, the Camden battery, and the Newark troop will be ordered but for the ceremonies.

Mayor Low's Police Commissioner, yesterday announced the appointment of Lieut. Col. Nathaniel B. Thurston to be Deputy Police Commissioner for Manhattan and Major Frederick H.E. Ebstein to be Deputy Police Commissioner for Brooklyn. Lieut. Col. Thurston is Inspector of Small Arms for the New York State Militia and a member of Major Gen. Roe's staff.

In calling Gov. SHAW of Iowa to the Treasury Department President ROOSEVELT not only gets a man whose record gives promise of an excellent administration of the office, but also recognizes in proper and wholesome manner the legitimate claims of the great section of the middle Northwest.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day, and the supplies were inconsiderable. Little relief is expected, until the release of the January dividends on funds. Discounts were firmer.

Few things are more deplorable in modern American life than the loss of the home longing and love, which were wont to be distinctively marked traits of the AngloSaxon. No sacrifice of the household gods is now considered too great if only one may hang on by the eyelids, as it were, to metropolitan excitements.

The editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS is trying to induce book advertisers to abandon sensational display, believing that quiet announcements will not only improve the appearance of his supplement, but further the interests of his advertisers as well.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- A brief official story of the ambush of a detachment of Company E, Ninth Infantry, by bolomen in the Island of Samar, has reached the War Department. Out of a total force of nineteen only six seem to have escaped unhurt. Seven were killed and six wounded.

It has been well said that hospitals measure the philanthropy of a nation, their support by the public being the purest form of unrewarded giving and heartfelt altruism. To-morrow, the last Sunday in the year, is "Hospital Sunday," and it behooves the good people of New York to thrust their hands deep down in their pockets for the maintenance of our hospitals.

The report of the Committee on Railroads and Transportation of the Pittsburg Chamber of Commerce on the freight congestion and the causes which have led to it seems to us to blame the railroads somewhat unjustly for conditions due to causes for which they can scarcely be held responsible.

Following is a statement of books which have sold beat in regular book and department stores in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, Washington, Cincinnati, Chicago, Minneapolis, Baltimore, and San Francisco between Nov. 25 and Dec. 25 of this year. The statement is based on reports received from the regular correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in those cities, personal inquiries having been made for the information sent to us.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Your editorial under the caption "Sensational Typography" has evidently appealed effectively to the common sense as well as the good taste of not a few of your readers. Claptrap advertising belongs so peculiarly to yellow journalism that a newspaper of the character of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS does the public a great service in disparaging and discouraging the affront.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In the other days of literature and literary production the matter at style, that is to say, the matter of the individuality of the writer, was or such distinction that it required no great effort to say what was Homeric, Virgilian, Shakespearean, Miltonian, Addisonian, Scottian, Thackerayan, Dickensian, and so on through the list, if the reader were but permitted to read a few passages by any writer.

William Harris Arnold's recent "Record of Books and Letters," which gives the cost and selling prices of the books in his second sale, is more interesting than the "Record" of his first auction. The importance of the first "Record" is great, however, in relation to the increasing value of American first editions, and with the final part commemorates in lasting form a most remarkable sale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Many of the publishers of the country have been informed that the Post Office Department has made a ruling which permits the mailing as second-class matter only of publications the subscription to which has been paid in advance. As such a ruling would injuriously affect many publishers, the department has received a number of protests from different parts of the country.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: While the wonder of Mr. Henley's article in The Pall Mall Magazine is fresh in our minds, it seems only fitting that sonic word should be said of Robert Louis Stevenson from the standpoint of his reader.

For a while it seemed as if there were to be a close match at the St. Nicholas Rink last night in the international hockey game between the Victoria Club of Montreal and the St. Nicholas seven of this city. But the local team after a temporary lead suddenly went to pieces, and was defeated in easy fashion by the visitors by a score of, 8 -- 3.

One of the branches under the present city administration may have its methods investigated by the Grand Jury. District Attorney Philbin announced yesterday afternoon that sufficient information had been gathered to warrant laying the management of The City Record before the jury. From the information which he has the District Attorney believes that there has been neglect of duty in the advertising for bids, particularly those for stationery and printing.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Dec. 27 -- Constable Jesse Woodruff took up a position to-day in the Wills homestead here to prevent any breach of the peace and the settting of Judge Wills's personal effects upon the sidewalk by his wife and daughter in advance of the time when, if the writ is not withdrawn or stayed by appeal to a higher court, the Sheriff's men must eject the Judge from the residence.

NICE, Dec 28. -- The marriage of Senator Chauncey M. Depew to Miss May Palmer took place at noon to-day at the American Church here. This ceremony followed the celebration of the Catholic marriage service at Notre Dame.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of the 24th inst, is a valuable summing up of the whole Schley controversy, which is not quite so cruel as the Dreyfus case. As you so well imply, the people or mass of the whole world are on Schley's side, and only two members of the court out of three, and a few stragglers, including a laborer, are against him.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 28 -- In the presence of 15,000 people, including many Government officials and distinguished guests, the new battleship Missouri was successfully launched to-day. The champagne poured over her bow by Miss Marian Cockrell daughter of the United States Senator from Missouri, was the product of that State's vineyards.

WILLEMSTED, Island of Curacao, Dec. 28 -- Reports received here to-day from Caracas are to the effect that the relations between Germany and Venezuela become more strained every day. The Venezuelan Government suspended traffic on the German railroad because the company, in view of the threats of the insurgents, refused to transport troops unless the Government guaranteed it against losses that might be sustained by the destruction of its road and equipment.
BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- From a close and long-time friend of Miss Mary E. Wilkins it is learned definitely that the much-discussed wedding of the novelist is to be solemnized on New Year's Day.

Controller Coler will to-morrow announce his decision in the matter of Col. Edward Gilon, who has been on trial before him on the charge of neglecting his duties as Collector of Assessments and Arrears. Several officials of the Controller's office stated yesterday that Col. Gilon would be promptly dismissed because Controller Coler was anxious to settle the matter and get it out of the way before Controller Grout takes office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That you should be fair and open minded as to Admiral Schley is characteristic of your policy, but to some of your readers it appears that you are gradually shifting into the position of a violent partisan of that officer who was unquestionably in personal command of the American naval forces during the battle of Santiago.

Gov. Odell was in the city yesterday and had two interviews with Senator Platt. He also conferred with Chairman Dunn of the State Republican Committee. Senator Platt said last night that he had read the Governor's message which will be sent to the Legislature nest Wednesday and that he was pleased with it.

BERLIN, Dec. 28. -- ''American diplomacy in Berlin, so far as it relates to commercial controversies, is hampered by the interference of the private interests concerned. The force of the representations of the State Department has been continually impaired by American business men, acting independently of diplomatic channels."
THE man didn't look very much like a spider, and the woman didn't look very fly: nevertheless, he blandly asked her to step into his parlor.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The financial week has been broken by two full holidays, while the accustomed crowds in the City were perceptibly smaller yesterday and to-day. Yet, as the last Stock Exchange settlement ended this afternoon, it may safely be said that the dismal year ends with a wonderful return of cheerfulness.

What can the Governor of Minnesota do about the Northern Securities Company? Can the Governor of Minnesota or any other State, or anybody else, prevent the completion of the plans of the Northern Securities Company in their present form or some other effecting the same results?

M.E. INGALLS, the railroad magnate of the Middle West, whose interests are more or less allied with the Vanderbilt system, is no exception to prominent men of business, inasmuch as he maintains an anteroom where callers are required to state their errands before being admitted to the official stronghold.

As soon as the holidays are over the amateur billiard players will start their tournament work. The first of these tourney's to get under way is to be the one under the auspices of the New York Billiard Club, which was recently organized, with the object of fostering the game of billard's among gentlemen amateurs and the conserving of the rights and interests of its members.
ONE of the absurdities of social life in the country districts mystifies an ex-salesman of this city.

The Rev. Charles A. Alden, who was private secretary to Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller, Acting Treasurer of the Charities Department, and Acting Trustee of the court funds of the Out-Door Poor Bureau, was yesterday reported to Mayor Van Wyck by the Commissioners of Accounts, John C. Hertle and Edward Owen, as having to account for at least $3,187.61, which was designated as a shortage.

James Russell Lowell said: "There's a deal o'solid kicking in the meekest-tooking mule" If the statement had been. There's a good deal of obstinacy covered by apparent amiability, the remark might have passed without a moments notice; but attached to such a figure as the poet used, it will be difficult for the mind ever to get rid of it.
SINCE the announcement of Marconi's sensational feat in spanning the Atlantic with his wireless signals there have been a host of suggestions as to possible future developments of this new art.

The group of explorers and writers who comprise the Arctic Club heartily applauded every mention of the name of Admiral Schley, who is a member of the organization, at their eighth annual dinner at the Hotel Marlborough last evening. Amos Bonsall of Philadelphia, who is the only survivor of the Kane (1853-55) expedition to the north, had this to say about the Admiral :

To the Editor of The New York Times: If not transgressing too much on your columns, will you kindly publish for the benefit of your readers a list of the battles fought and victories won by our two naval heroes, Admirals Benham and Ramsay?

WHEN a commission from Porto Rico visited New York about the beginning of this year, several of the members were placed on the visiting list of the New York Athletic Club. One evening one of the Porto Ricans, Mr. Vicente Balbas, who is now residing in Washington, surprised those who had gathered in the gymnasium by his prowess with the foils.

EDEN MUSEE -- One of the most expensive and elaborate wax groups ever made has just been received from Paris and placed on exhibition. It represents a scene in a Paris cafe. There will be many other extra attractions at the Musee during the holiday season.

THE swell uptown caterers have this season gone into the business of providing ready prepared food for their customers on a big scale. They will furnish any thing from a fifteen-course dinner to a teaspoon, or from terrapin and canvasback duck to consomme and ice cream.

Detective Allen Goldsmith of the Siegel-Cooper Company arrested last evening at Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, on the charge of grand larceny, a boy giving his name as John Bacon, but in whose pocket was found a letter from the Rev. Dr. John G. Fagg of the Collegiate Middle Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, recommending one Gustav Danwitz as a member of his church.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue to-day I note a certain article by one styling himself "A Loyal Legioner" in reference to the reprimand to Gen. Miles. The writer's language is: "The force of present National administrative power of the country * * * used to smother all freedom of speech,"

TO DAVID BELASCO and Mrs. Leslie Carter credit must be given for having relieved from the stigma of almost absolute barrenness the first half of the theatrical season of 1901-02. And to the chronicler of dramatic events it is more than a passing satisfaction to be able to point to an achievement that does much to make up for the vapidness of some five months of the theatrical year.

SOME one has described heraldry as the amusement of fools with long memories. Possibly he had looked in vain through the cyclopaedia and records for some blazonry or erest that appertained to him, some motto he might claim as his own, and his failure resulted in a soured disposition.

The measures of discipline which the President is now applying with so much rigor in his attempt to put a stop to the discussion of the Sehley-Sampson affair in the Army and Navy should have been applied By Secretary LONG three years ago to suppress the quarrel in its very beginning.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Crowds of visitors have come from all parts of the country to spend the Christmas and New Year's holidays at this fashionable resort in the Jersey pines. Society folks from such widely distant points as San Francisco, Chicago, Montreal, and New Orleans are numbered among the throng of holiday arrivals.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 -- All movements in the Philadelphia market were overshadowed by the activity in Reading securities, all of which extended their advance to a point that established new high records, the general mortgage 4s participating, touching par for the first time in their history.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Until within a few years there has always been free and open competition in all professions, employments, trades, and business enterprises; and so important was such competition deemed to be to the interests of the community and to the State that all laws and all private contracts in restraint of trade were regarded as against public policy and invalid and void.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 28. -- Suits in quo warranto were brought late this afternoon in the Circuit Courts of Crawford and Logan Counties to revoke the charters of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway Company, the Ohio Central Railway Company, the Kanawha and Michigan Railway Company, the Buckeye Coal and Railway Company, and the Sunday Creek Coal Company.

IT may be truly said that, like the human body, New York changes in all its parts once in so many years. All sorts of persons note the transformations wrought in great thoroughfares. The rebuilding of Broadway goes on year after year beneath the eyes of millions. Trade's steady, stealthy progress northward along Fifth Avenue is a thing that everybody has been talking about for twenty years or more.
SILAS LARRABEE is of the opinion that the bulk of President Roosevelt's time is taken up with miserable little things which never should be brought to his attention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the Custom House exactions felt by aliens to be most vexatious is the charging of duty and war tax upon trifling Christmas presents sent by relatives abroad. I refer especially to those charges on books, as they are the medium generally chosen by my relatives as tokens of good will to send to members of my family at this season.

It will occasion some surprise among thoughtful readers that so generally intelligent a journal as The London Saturday Review -- although, to be frank, its reputation for general intelligence was somewhat better deserved ten or twenty years ago than it is now -- should voice without qualification or protest the absurd agrarian demand of the country land-owning interest for protective duties on imports.

SIR ROBERT ANDERSON, who has been for many years Assistant Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis. (London.) Head of Criminal Investigation Department, and Registrar of Habitual Criminals in England, must be considered as an authority in relation to penology, and by penology is meant the study of punishment for crime, both in its deterrent and reformatory aspects.

On Jan. 4, 1899, the reorganization plan of the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway Company was issued. It was a comprehensive and carefully prepared document, and in the light of present developments presents an interesting exhibit of conservative financial readjustment.

Arthur Ambrose Maginnis. Arthur Ambrose Maginnis of New Orleans died at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon. Mr. Maginnis arrived at the hotel on Nov. 27, and a few days later was afflicted with throat trouble. An operation was performed and the patient seemed well on the road to recovery when kidney troubles, followed by other complications, set in.

OSCAR, the gastronomic authority and compiler of menus at the Waldorf-Astoria has a snug fortune, which is estimated at from $200,000 to $500,000. Like ail in his class of eminent "ministres de la bouche," he speculates in Wall Street.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- It was decided at a meeting of the Board of Managers of the Hudson River State Hospital, held to-day, to protest against the new ration allowance for patients established by the State Commission in Lunacy, to take effect Jan. 1. 1902.

DON'T forget to save the Christmas greens. Every scrap of a Christmas tree, of the wreaths, of decoration of all kinds in evergreen will be delightful a little later, when dry, for open fires. They are not only charming when they are burning, but they have an attractive appearance in the grate or open fireplace as they lie ready for the first cold day or the desire for extra cheer which an open fire gives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cause of Admiral Schley is agitating the heart of the Nation. The American people cannot be disposed of by autocratic measures unheard of in tone and substance. A more undignified example of this kind than the new Administration's letter to our chief commanding officer of the army it would be difficult to detect.
The National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America, which are better known as the Asphalt Trust, yesterday passed into the hands of receivers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In trying to take off the keen edge of Dr. Cuyler's remarks, "G.F.Y." has recourse to a rather contemptible kind of quibbling in regard to the exact Sunday hours of the London saloons. Notwithstanding "G. F. Y.'s" boasted wide-range knowledge of that city, the fact as to the saloon crowd is just as Dr. Cuyler describes, only rather more so.

WITHOUT question the opening of the opera, season at the Metropolitan Opera House last Monday evening was the dullest and most uninteresting that has ever been known in the checkered history of that institution. In the first place, Christmas week was not a happy time for, the opening.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that the "powers that be have handled the so-called ''Schley-Sampson controversy" very, veey badly.

Though the Christmas holiday has broken Wall Street's week, the result -- quotation wise -- has not been disagreeable. Ordinarily markets that are either featureless or ragged attend upon midweek adjournments, and tradition warrants Stock Exchange traders in expecting, if not disturbance, at least little that can be pleasant on such occasions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The State Department has received from United States Consular Agent Harris, at Eibenstock, an interesting report on the subject of German colonial enterprises, dated Nov. 28. Mr. Harris quotes from a speech delivered by Dr. Vosberg-Rekow, Director of the German Bureau for the Preparation of Commercial Treaties, before the merchants of Leipsic, as follows:
ONE of the Aquarium guards was telling a man and woman about the trigger fish, considered by many people the handsomest fish in the New York Aquarium.

Commissioner Murphy said yesterday that he is considering appointing thirty-five more Detective Sergeants during the few remaining hours of his official tenure and had been discussing the necessity for them with Capt, Titus, Chief of the Detective Bureau.

MME. POMPADOUR, the quasi-Queen of France, had done her work and fallen. She died at last or heart disease, after she had done as much harm to the Kingdom of France as it has ever been the lot of a single woman to do to any nation. It may not be true, though many historians declare that it is so, that she lost for France the whole of her American possessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The American Economic Association devoted its morning session to-day to a discussion of international trade and the afternoon session to economics. Brooks Adams of Quincy, Mass., in interpreting the recent expansion of the foreign trade of the United States, entered a plea of justification for commercial and even military warfare to maintain the commercial supremacy of a country.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- In spite of the active demand for money in the market to-day there was a short supply. Discounts were easy especially for bills to arrive early in January. Great pressure is likely to be felt Monday and Tuesday, after which considerable relief is probable.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 28. -- The wedding of Miss Pauline Fowler Humphrey of this city and the Rev. Ernest Louis Walz, Jr., of New York, took place here to-night. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Humphrey, formerly of Chicago. The bridegroom has been associate pastor of the old Prebyterian Church of the Sea and Land in Manhattan.

Charleston, S.C., is just now enjoying the benefits of an Exposition. Economists, however, differ as to whether expositions may be said to confer any real benefit upon the communities in the midst of which they are situated, owing to the disturbances they cause preliminary to their opening and to the reaction which follows their closing.
Three news plays, two revivals, the opening of a new theatre, and the production of a new burlesque by Weber Fields are the offering for the New Year's week in theatricals.

As a result of the spiritualistic faith of Thomas Hopkins of 128 Collard Street, Jersey City, which precludes the engaging of a physician in any kind of disease, an epidemic of smallpox has broken out in that section of the city which has caused a panic in the neighborhood and which the health authorities of Jersey City are endeavoring their utmost to stem.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 28. -- Gov. Shaw denied to-night that he had given out an interview regarding Secretary Gage's Treasury policy. On the contrary, he has positively refused to give any such interviews. He has, however, expressed in most cordial terms his approval of Mr. Gage's administration of the department.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 28. -- A prize competitition, open to the world, for a symbol or emblem for the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, to be held in St. Louis in 1903, has been set on foot by the exposition company. The symbol is to be used for the seal for the stationary and for publicity material of all sorts.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. -- Baltimore society has literally danced itself through the present week, the holidays giving an additional spirit to the gayest season it has ever known. On Christmas Eve Mrs. William S. Powell gave a delightful dance at Colonial Hall in honor of Miss Ellen Powell, the debutante daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Harrison Powell.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Dec. 28. -- Hundreds of men listened to the reading of the verdict of the Coroner's jury upon the death of Miss Ella M. Cropsey, whose body was found in the Pasquotank River yesterday. The verdict was read to-day in front of the Coroner's office, the publication of the jury's deliberations having been withheld because of the feeling against James Wilcox, the girl's sweetheart, who is still confined in the county jail.

In the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association yesterday evening, the Parke, Davis Co. team won two games, and as the Dodge Olcott team won and lost, the houses are now tied for the first two places in the tournament. The General Chemical Company team also won two games.

THE stars that shine in the January sky when the centre of Orion is on the meridian are more gorgeous than those of any other month in the year. Two constellations take the precedence for the grandeur and magnificence with which they irradiate the celestial expanse. They are the Great Bear, familiarly known as the Dipper, and Orion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Serious trouble between the United States and Germany is said to be possible because of the movement Germany is making to coerce Venezuela into paying a debt. It is not even hinted that the circumstances now surrounding the movement indicate a disagreement between this country and the Kaiser's Government, but that Germany may do something to cause friction is regarded as by no means impossible.
The December assessment for Philadelphia shows 342,890 citizens entitled to vote, this being an increase of 8,801 over the assessment in 1900.

Members of the Society of College Gymnasium Directors held their second and concluding day's session at Columbia University yesterday. While there were some papers read, the most important business was the election of officers. The choices occasioned some little surprise, as not a single one of this year's officers was reelected.

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany on Friday evening Mr. CROKER calmly and confidently invites first criticism and then suggestions. Neither being forthcoming routine business was transacted, and the General Committee met, Mr. LEWIS NIXON being assigned to the very prominent posts of Temporary and Permanent Chairman.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28 -- The Beralta Handicap, at a mile and a sixteenth, was the feature of the racing at Oakland today. It resulted in an upset, Position, a 15 to 1 shot; winning by a neck from Water Cure, the favorite. Afghan regained his speed and beat Herculean a neck in the first race.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- State Controller Erastus C. Knight resigned his office to-day. His resignation was sent to the Legislature through the Secretary of State, to take effect to-day. He requested the Secretary to inform Gov. Odell of the filing.

There are fifteen young men somewhere in this broad land who will not soon forget Gen. John R. Brooke, United States Army, commanding General of the Department of the East. A week ago they were all prisoners in Castle Williams on Governors Island. On Christmas Gen. Brooke, as a present as well as a reward for the small amount of trouble they had given the authorities during their confinement, gave them their liberty.

FROM the Bronx to the South Ferry the sisterhoods of Jewish women have the city districted. These sisterhoods carry on a work among the poor immigrants of their own race which is hardly to be paralleled in the annals of volunteer philanthropic effort. It is a combination of Settlement work with the outdoor relief organized charity.

Julius M. Mayer, the head of the Law Committee of the Republican County Committee, it was learned last night from men close to Mr. Low, is now first in Mr. Low's consideration for appointment as Judge of Special Sessions to succeed Justice Jerome, and his appointment may be said to be more than probable.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 28. -- The Republican factional contest for the organization of the Legislature has assumed an aspect that looks bad for Mr. Hanna. The Foraker-Kurtz combine has come out into the open and the Hanna, contingent has been forced to meet them. The situation to-night is decidedly it, favor of the Foraker side, and the friends of Mr. Hanna are in grave doubt as to the final outcome.

Nearly 500 city employes, including all the heads of bureaus in the Department of Finance, joined in the presentation of a magnificent silver service and album to Controller Coler yesterday, as the result of a spontaneous effort by his subordinates to give him something which should ever recall the pleasantest memories of his term as the first Controller of the new City of New York.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- It is said that the King's abolition of the old-fashioned drawing rooms in favor of the Court at Buckingham Palace this Winter is generally approved by persons most interested.

Seldom has there been a larger or more enthusiastic crowd of spectators to a hockey game than gathered last evening in the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, to witness the contest between the redoubtable hockey team of the Victoria Club, Canada, and that of the New York Athletic Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a constant reader of and subscriber to THE TIMES, and have felt that you have not followed your usual intelligent policy of thoughtful fairness to the treatment of the Schley controversy. I wish therefore to put on record a protest against the clamor sought to be raised in the matter.

The Christmas holidays are naturally very dull and given over almost entirely to house parties in the country, family parties at home, and parties for the children and the younger members of the family. There is no expression which fits so well this season as the old-fashioned word "party."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement in the grass that Judge McAdam was never late nor absent from court duties a single day during an unbroken record of nearly thirty consecutive years of judicial service recalls to my mind a visit by me to his residence on that memorable Monday morning of March 12, 1888, when our city awakened from its slumber to find itself in the grasp of a blizzard.
"Doc." a big, gray ambulance horse of Flower Hospital, met with a serious accident last night at Forty-Street and Third Avenue.
THIS is not to say that she forsakes them permanently. That would be an impossibility, for the shopping instinct is ingrained in woman's nature and it is her pleasure to shop.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The War Office this afternoon issued a list of the British casualties at Zeefontein Dec. 24, when Col. Firman's camp, consisting of three companies of Yeomanry and two guns, was successfully rushed by a Boer force under the command of Gen. De Wet. The length of the list demonstrates the entire success of De Wet's attack.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The able and scholarly letter from the Rev. W: Dallmann in THE TIMES of Dec. 22, upon the religious aspect of the Sunday question, and in favor of a rational observance of the day, is a striking and effective protest against Sabbatarian bigotry, and will convince all who are not absolutely hidebound in their prejudices and beliefs.

From The Fortnigtly Review. The Fillpinos are a weak nation, but they have kept a large American army locked up in the Philippines for the best part of three years. The legitimacy of guerrilla, cr partisan warfare cannot be seriously questioned -- it is the natural refuge of the weaker side.

The War Department has just officially decided, on an application by an officer for reimbursement for property lost in transit off Luzon, that he is not entitled to reimbursement "through military channels," and this for the reason that "there is a condition of war in the archipelago."

ANOTHER new "clipping bureau" started up in business in New York last week.
