At the present time there are nearly a dozen of these concerns in the metropolis, and all, apparently, doing what is called out West "a land-office business." The business is largely based upon the vanity of "prominent citizens" or of their wives.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the interview with Justice Jerome, as reported in Monday's TIMES, he says: "For my part I would vote to close the saloons every day in the week, if it could be done effectively. But I believe a great city, having half the population of the State, is entitled to relief from laws which cannot be enforced."

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- Harvey Bruce, aged twenty-one, to-day, in the form of a statement to his mother and aunt, witnessed by Mayor Charles S. Harvey and County Treasurer George M. Macy, confessed that the murder of Peter A. Hallenbeck, the wealthy farmer of Greenport, was committed by himself and Willis, Burton, and Fred Van Wormer.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 2 1/2 to 5 per cent. premium. Exchanges, $21,776,756; balances, $2,096,591. On call, money rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Trust companies are generally asking 5 per cent., and that is the minimum rate of several of the larger National banks.
COLON, Colombia, Dec. 28. -- Baranquilla papers, dated Dec. 24, which came to hand this morning, contain further details of the battle fought near Honda.

A large crowd saw the final struggle of the tenth annual intercollegiate championship at Columbia Grammar School yesterday afternoon and evening. The battle order was: Columbia vs. Harvard and Yale vs. Princeton, the players being pitted against each other as follows:

IT is a very well-known fact that the average Wall Street speculator takes defeat gracefully. Seldom in any office is there to be found a "kicker." ever though Dame Fortune be never so unkind. Which suggests a little incident that happened last week in an office not far distant from where James R. Keene makes his headquarters.

After an all-day hearing and an executive session lasting until 9 o'clock last ntght, the Municipal Bureau of Elections decided in the Belmont-O'Grady fight that Perry Belmont is the regularly nominated candidate of the Democratic Party in the Seventh Congressional District. The decision was made by a vote of 3 to 1.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 28. -- The marriage of Miss Nellie Reeder of New York and John Ernest Blandy of Funchal, Island of Madeira, which took place in Baltimore to-day, was one of widespread interest. The bride is a daughter of Capt. William H. Reeder, United States Navy, and a granddaughter of the late Admiral Clark H. Wells, United States Navy.

No changes of importance were made in the standing of the clubs in the principal local bowling leagues by the games of the past week, as on account of the omission of games on both Christmas Eve and Christmas evening only three games, at the most, were decided in any series, while in most of the tournaments a smaller number was the rule.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Rear Admiral Francis Asbury Roe, United States Navy, retired, died hero to-night. He was born in New York, and was placed on the retired list Oct. 4, 1885, after thirty-four years of active service.
THE young graduate and the middle-aged, experienced practitioner came out of the hospital and walked down the street together.

A few years ago a good deal was heard about Bleeding Kansas -- more, perhaps, than conditions called for -- while at the same time comparatively little was heard of the impoverishment of the rather considerable army of people who had been induced in the palmy days of the eighties to put their capital into the State, then being boomed to the limit.

THE average man, it is perhaps usually believed by all men, is not very difficult to discover. Possibly no man would admit that he could not easily Identify him. He is supposed to represent like any other average, a proportionate equality to the sum total of the whole. In personal appearance he looks quite like the majority.

MRS. GEORGE CROCKER, at the Bagby musical morning was in one of the many velvet gowns of the season. The skirt was long and sweeping, and had not that excessive tightness seen in many of the velvet shirts. Around the bottom, and running up perhaps six or eight inches, were applications of black silk braid in scroll design.

As a result of conferences held between Perez M. Stewart, who is to be Building Commissioner under the new administration of the Borough of Manhattan, and Lawrence Veillier, the Secretary of the Tenement House Commission, twelve men will be transferred from the Building Department to the Tenement House Commission.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- M. Lampre, Secretary General of the Panama Canal Company, sailed for New York this morning from Havre on the French Line, steamer L'Aquitaine. He will confer on his arrival in the United States with a number of the Panama Company's American representatives, and overtures for the sale of the canal property to the United States will then be renewed.

We note with interest the divergent and indeed incompatible views expressed, upon the question of the "policy" of the Police Department with respect to the Sunday laws, of the Deputy Chiefs of Police for the Boroughs of Manhattan and of Brooklyn. Col. THURSTON personally disapproves of the Sunday laws, in the rigor with which they stand on the statute book and as they are not really enforced in any county of the State.

In two stalls, capable of accommodating eighteen horses, William C. Whitney's Derby candidate, Nasturtium, and a two-year-old stable companion sailed yesterday on the Atlantic Transport liner Minnehaha. Aboard the vessel were ninety other horses, including some polo ponies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Illinois being about to lose her representation in the Cabinet through the retirement of Secretary Gage, it is said that she is looking longingly toward the Navy Department, with a view to having Representative George Edmund Foss succeed Mr. Long when the latter comes to what he considers an opportune time for resigning.

WITHIN a few days the City Hall will welcome a new master and add another event to the many interesting and important occasions that have figured in its history, covering a period of nearly a hundred years.
IF one wants to observe science in all her incompleteness, let him look for scientific facts about birds.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Senator and Mrs. Hanna have issued invitations to a large dinner party on New Year's Day, when they will entertain the President and Cabinet officers.
Charles F. Gammon, superintendent of colporteurs for the American Bible Society in Northern China, writes thus to the society concerning the present situation in the Chinese Empire:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not long ago your paper published editorials decrying the "barbarous practice of killing trapped pigeons." It is not the purpose or this letter to defend that sport, whatever my private opinion may be, but to call your attention to what you must consider an equally barbarous and cruel sport, though no voice is raised against it.

No games will be rolled in any of the local bowling leagues to-morrow or Wednesday evenings on account of the alleys being needed for public games, and the regular schedule in several of the tournaments will not be resumed until next week. The schedule for the remainder of the week in the principal local leagues is as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial entitled "The Practical Side of Fire Insurance" in to-day's issue, betrays (pardon me) a certain ignorance of prevailing conditions. You assume that the fire insurance companies have some control over their underwriting transactions, in other words that they themselves can discriminate as to the kinds of risks which they will accept, and can regulate rates of premium.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 29 -- It has been decided by the officials of the South Orange Field Club to keep the golf links open all Winter. Though the number of enthusiasts who frequent the links has fallen off somewhat since the cold weather set in, there are still plenty of golfers to be found on the course every clear day.

The Real Estate Record and Guide has compiled some interesting figures showing the marked shrinkage in the number of individual dwelling houses in New York -- or, to be more exact, in the Borough of Manhattan. Brooklyn, Queens, and Richmond have scarcely reached the point of development where the small house for the single family is being displaced by the multiple apartment house, but in Manhattan and the Bronx this tendency is very pronounced.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The announcement by The Railway Age that a larger addition has been made to the railway mileage of the United States in 1901 than in any preceding year since 1890 lends special interest to some figures just published by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics regarding the railways of this country and of the world.

A mass meeting of about 500 members of the Order B'rith Abraham, which has 18,000 city members, was held yesterday in the Grand Central Palace, 96 Clinton Street. It lasted from 2 o'clock until 4 o'clock, when the lights were turned out, and was a continuous wrangle between factions in the order.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 29. -- The brick wall which has been built around the Harvard College campus is not altogether lovely. It has, in fact, been severely criticised. But it seems that "the structural monstrosity," as Dr. Abbott calls it in a recently published communication, is but a part of a magnificent whole.

If the steel rail is as good a barometer of the general business situation and outlook as it is popularly credited with being, what it now records may be confidently regarded as an extremely favorable weather prognosis. The output of steel rails by the American mills in 1900 was 2,385,682 tons, which represented their capacity at that time.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Dec. 29 -- A plot more desperate than any before discovered here was unearthed yesterday at the Federal Penitentiary. Warden McClaughry learned through one of the prisoners of a plan concocted by five prisoners to seize one of the guards and the Deputy Warden, and, with them as shields, to force their way into the prison armory and then escape.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the offering for sale of the United States Mint property in Philadelphia the other day, some person (Secretary Gage being present) took occasion to remark upon the disgraceful and almost criminal proceeding in connection with the disposal of the Custom House property in New York a year or two ago.
To the Editor of The New York Times: That republics are ungrateful has been asserted so persistently that even its untruth does not avail to put it to rout.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 29 -- Congressman Frank M. Eddy of the Seventh Minnesota District makes the statement that not a dozen members of Congress could earn the salaries paid them by the Government. This assertion was made last night, while he was addressing the postal clerks' convention.

The morning service yesterday at the Lenox Presbyterian Church, on One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, west of Eighth Avenue, was conducted almost completely by Chinamen. The Rev. N.G. Poon Chew, who, owing to a lack of material support of his church was compelled to take the position of managing editor of the Chung Sai Yat Po, a Chinese daily paper in San Francisco, preached the sermon.

Whatever the rank and file in Wall Street, bearish almost to a man, may say, close market observers are of the opinion that the upward movement in prices begun in the latter part of last week marks the "turn" in the market toward betterment and a higher range of values.

Morris Moss, fifteen years old, of 44 Nostrand Avenue, Brooklyn, was found unconscious in the street at Flushing and Nostrand Avenues last evening slowly bleeding to death from two stab wounds, made, it is said, by Henry Frelius, twelve years old, of 8 Hopkins Street. Moss was removed to the Williamsburg Hospital, where his condition late last-night was said to be critical, owing to the loss of blood.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Superintendent of Banks Frederick O. Kilburn recommends in his annual report, which will be transmitted to the Legislature on Wednesday, that power be given to him to inspect and supervise personal loan associations, or that they be removed entirely from connection with the State Banking Department.

The purpose of the three years' warfare against Rear Admiral SCHLEY having been triumphantly accomplished, the very weapons with which that war was waged have now been turned upon Admiral DEWEY. In an editorial article published by our neighbor The Sun on Saturday morning we find this paragraph:

A pleasing entertainment was that given last night at Tony Pastor's Theatre by the little children of the stage, twelve of whom appeared in a varied and excellent performance. The audience was wholly professional, if that term will include 200 or more children of theatrical people who packed the balcony, and the actors and actresses themselves who filled the boxes and orchestra with an array of wonderful hats and white waistcoats.

Those French woven tapestries which they call Gobelin, and which are reasonable in price and attractive in appearance, are worth talking about. One does not have to be a millionaire to get a bit or the tapestry which will fill in a small wall space in the corner of a room with delightful effect.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The reason John F. Shanly, President of the local gas company, was appointed one of the three receivers of the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America yesterday, was because Judge Kirkpatrick, to whom the application was made, told the lawyers representing the interests involved, that there would have to be one receiver who is within the jurisdiction of his district.

Central Office Detectives Day and Deering last night arrested William Ashton, forty-two years old, at 125 West Eighty-fourth Street, where he was living. He was arrested at the request of the Chief of Police of Boston, who charged that he forged a check for $50 purporting to be signed by Louis Busiere, Treasurer of the Anaconda Mining Company of Boston.

Dr. Nicholas M. Butler, Acting President of Columbia University, has received from United States Minister Conger in Peking a letter saying that the Chinese Government is preparing to present to Columbia University for its Chair of Chinese a collection of maps, official papers, illustrations, books on Chinese literature, and other material, which will be of use to the university.

For the third time within a few weeks a big water main of the city's supply system burst last night. The break occurred at the northwest corner of West Broadway and Chambers Street and the pipe was forty-eight inches in diameter.

The Amateur Athletic Union is showing a determined disposition in all of its local associations to regulate basket ball thoroughly this year. The eleven clubs in the metropolitan district that were suspended last week are by no means exceptional cases, for similar legislation has been meted out to delinquent teams in the New England and the Central Associations.

Out of the ingenious mind or Mr. OxNARD, President of the American Beet Sugar Company, there issues the protocol of a modus vivendi in the Cuban sugar tariff controversy. Having a human soul and a kind heart, Mr. OXNARD recognizes the necessity of giving immediate help to the prostrate sugar industry and the impoverished sugar planters of Cuba.

ELIZABETH CITY, N.C., Dec. 29 -- The funeral of Miss Ella M. Cropsey, whose body was discovered in the Pasquotank River after a search of several weeks, was held in the Methodist Church here to-day. The church was crowded to suffocation, and the street leading to it was lined with people who uncovered as the hearse drove past. The body wlll be taken by Andrew G. Cropsey, uncle of the girl, to Brooklyn for interment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- It is expected that efforts will be renewed before long for the settlement of the numerous controversies which have long existed between the United States and Great Britain, growing out of relations along the Canadian border, the Atlantic fisheries, warships on the great lakes, the Alaskan boundary, and other questions.

Beginning with to-night there will be ten days of red-hot political campaigning in the Seventh Congressional District. Last night it was promised that there will be more oratory and red fire than during the Mayoralty contest and that Staten Island and the lower New York Assembly districts will resound nightly until Jan. 7 with the blare of brass bands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is something more in the discussion of the Sunday opening question than a mere proposition to take away some of the safeguards the law has been trying to place about some of the weakest and most tempted of its citizens, more than a mere proposition to legalize the desecration of a day regarded as holy by most real Christians.

The announcement that the New York Central management will meet the increasingly sharp competition of the interurban electric railways which are gradually paralleling its system by cutting its passenger rates between points also connected by trolley, is surprising only because it shows how completely the gentlemen in control of that great property fail to realize the situation with which they are confronted.

It was learned at Police Headquarters late last night that Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Thebaud of 158 Madison Avenue had been robbed of jewelry worth $50,000. This was corroborated by Mr. Thebaud himself, who was at headquarters at 1 o'clock this morning, where, in company with a member of the firm from whom most of the jewelry had been purchased, he gave to the police a partial list of the jewels taken.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst in his sermon at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning touched upon what he considers the faults of present-day journalism.

THE FATE OF ARMENIAN REFUGEES IN RUSSIA -- The St. Petersburg papers confirm recent cable dispatches which conveyed the intelligence that the Governor of Transcaucasia had been instructed "to assist those Armenians who have sought asylum within the domain of the Russian Empire." Details, however, are added.

The International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association has a big task on its hands between this time and Jan. 1. If by the time the gongs and whistles announce that 1902 has arrived $275,000 has not been raised, $725,000 which has already been pledged for carrying on the general work of the association will be almost entirely, if not entirely, lost to them.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- In three days the legislative machinery of the State of New York will be set in motion for the one hundred arid twenty-fifth time in her history. Although the date for the opening of the Senate and Assembly is a legal holiday, next Wednesday, nevertheless, will witness the convening of both houses.

For the sole purpose of gaining notoriety, according, to his own statement and the belief of his family, John Samuel Pinover jumped off the Brooklyn Bridge at 12:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had often told his family that it required only a large amount of nerve for a man to Jump from the bridge successfully.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- In the latest Consular reports there appears a letter from Charles L. Cole, Consul General at Dresden, describing an invention by Eugene C. Schrottky of Dresden for the making of malt from rice. The process, which is now being perfected, has already proved successful and promises to cheapen the cost of producing malt liquors in Europe.
"Though she hasn't a mark on her, or a twisted rail, to show what a tempestuous voyage she has had, it was, nevertheless, among the roughest experiences I have ever had during my maritime career."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly allow me space to ask a question or two bearing upon the late Schley investigation? I have never seen any reference whatever made to a small book issued by the Naval Intelligence Office, Washington, being a translation from the Spanish of letters and reports of Admiral Cervera.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Dec. 29 -- While the friends of W.C. Wakefield, the young man who is in the Middlesex County Jail on charges of obtaining money by illegal means from several persons in this town, still deny that it was he who sought to lease Ditton Park, Windsor, for the coronation exercises.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Dr. James Snyder Mackie, litterateur, linguist, and financier, died at 1 o'clock this morning at his home in this city, as a result of a stroke of apoplexy Saturday.

Another soldier escaped from the guardhouse at Fort Totten, Willets Point, Queens, yesterday morning. Only a week ago Private Monfort of the Eighty seventh Company Coast Artillery picked the lock of the guardhouse and escaped. Yesterday morning about 2 o'clock John Linden of the One Hundred and First Company followed his example and succeeded in getting away.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- Reports from all parts of Eastern Pennsylvania to-night show that the rivers avid creeks, which became greatly swollen as a result of Saturday night and Sunday's continuous rain, are steadily falling. There is one exception, however, the lower part of the Susquehanua River being reported to be still rising and close to the danger mark.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Who was it that originated the term "the majesty of the law"? "Whoever he was, he must have lived in the primitive days of legislation -- somewhere in that dim and distant period when those who made the laws had some sense of responsibility, some sense of the eternal fitness of things, and, perchance, the saving quality of humor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Maryland councils of the Junior Order of United American Mechanics to-night presented to Rear Admiral Winfield S. Schley a magnificent medal studded with diamonds, as an evidence of their personal esteem and admiration and of his services to the country.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Francis Wilson and his company in George Edwardes's "Toreador" scored a decided hit at the new National Theatre to-night. After the first of the two acts the curtain went up seven times, after which each member of the company was called before the curtain in turn.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The basket ball team representing the Twenty-third Street Young Men's Christian Association, New York, was defeated here to-night by St. Peter's Lyceum of this city by a score of 18 to 16.
ROME, Dec. 30 -- The production of Gabriele D'Annunzio's tragedy, "Francesca da Rimini," has been prohibited on grounds of morality.

Baseball rumors of every description continue to fill the air, but it seems that the Spalding element is working in a systematic manner to undermine the opposition of the four clubs opposed to it. That this has borne fruit is demonstrated in a measure by the apparent weakening of the Boston Club.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- New York exchange rates to-day were 25c premium. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent. Local stock values were well held, although the trading was only moderately active. Biscuit seems to have displaced Tin Can as the leader of the market. Further strength was shown by that stock to-day, the common advancing to 45 and the preferred being firmly held at 104.

All day yesterday Chief of Detectives Titus and a dozen of his best men were at work trying to run down Edward Kern, the principal in the $50,000 Thebaud diamond robbery. Capt. Titus said last night that he hoped before another twenty-four hours to have Kern lodged in jail. Several important clues developed during the day.

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The announcement this afternoon that Garry Brinckerhoff was ineligible for the office of Road Commissioner, to which he was elected last November, came as a great surprise to the young man's friends. He himself attributes the condition of affairs which exist in this case to carelessness.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 30 -- The signed contracts of Outfielder Harley, who was with Cincinnati last year and First Baseman Frank Dillon were received to-day by Secretary McNamara of the Detroit Baseball Club. Negotiations with Outfielder Lange are off. Lange wired that Detroit would have "to do better than $6.000."
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Gov. Odell today appointed Nathan L. Miller of Cortland County as State Controller to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Erastus C. Knight of Buffalo.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 30 -- Judge Elliott of the District Court of Hennepin County to-day granted a temporary order restraining the officers of the Northern Pacific Railroad Company from retiring the preferred stock of that company. The order was issued on the application of Peter Power of New York, who holds a hundred shares of the common stock and who came on from New York with his attorneys for the purpose of beginning the action.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 30 -- C. Aylett Ashby, one of the most prominent young attorneys in this city, shot and fatally wounded City Engineer E.A. Marye, son of State Auditor Morton Marye, this afternoon. Marye lies in the hospital with a 32-calibre bullet imbedded in his back. The ball entered the stomach just below the breastbone, tearing entirely through the liver along its longest diameter.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The new calendar of the Court of Appeals is the smallest of any made up in sixteen years. The calendar of 1885 contained 338 causes, that made up for 1902 has 389 causes. Twice in the past decade and a hall the work or the court has accumulated to such an extent that relief has had to be given it.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Money was in strong demand in the market to-day in connection with the settlement and the repayment of loans to the Bank of England. Discounts were easy and transactions were almost at a standstill.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 30 -- Miss Elizabeth Wetmore Hunter, daughter of Mrs. Thomas R. Hunter, was married to William Rogers Morgan this afternoon at the residence of her mother, in Rhode Island Avenue. Only a few relatives and intimate friends witnessed the ceremony, which was performed by the Rev. Henry Morgan Stone, rector of Trinity Church.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's TIMES I read an account of the usual accident which is of almost daily occurrence, and to which no one seems to object. I refer to the running away of horses left standing untied and unguarded by their drivers, and who, startled by anything unusual, dash down the thoroughfares of our city, often killing and wounding people and overturning other carriages in their wild career.

The opening games in the fourth annual tournament of the Morning Newspaper Bowling League will be rolled on McLaughlin's alleys, 272 Washington Street, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon, and thereafter on every Wednesday and Friday afternoon until March 28. There will be six team prices, ranging from $50 to $10 in value, and a silver cub the latter to be held for one year by the team winning first place.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 30 -- Sentiment in opposition to the St. Louis Transit Company, which controls four-fifths of the street railway mileage of the city, is rapidly crystallizing. Pressure upon the Mayor, Municipal Assembly, and the company is being daily increased by business organizations in every part of the city.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The funeral of United States Senator William J. Sewell will occur at 12 o'clock noon to-morrow, and will be a military one.

The Cunarder Umbria from Liverpool, due Saturday, and the French liner La Champagne, due Sunday from Havre, got in yesterday after a hard tussle with wind and sea. Both of the vessels bore much outward evidence of the fury of the elements, especially the Umbria, which was considerably bruised owing to the heavy onslaught received from the terrific waves that she had to plow her way through on practically every day of the passage.
Watch-night services will be held in many churches to-night and from a number of steeples the chimes will speed the dying year and welcome the new one with solemn and joyous clanging.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 30 -- The complicated condition of New Jersey politics caused by the death of State Treasurer Swain and United States Senator Sewell was the reason for an important conference of Republican leaders held here tonight.
COLON, Dec. 30 -- Gen. Herrera's expedition landed at Tonosi on Dec. 24 from the Liberal steamers Ibis, Darien, and Gaitan.

CHICAGO, Dec 30 -- Frank Hutchinson Peavey of Minneapolis, said to be the leading grain elevator owner in the world and insured for $1,376,000, died of pneumonia shortly after 3:30 A.M. to-day in suite 1,410 of the Auditorium Annex, after an illness of little more than a week. He was fifty-two years of age.

At the Democratic Club last night. Richard Croker reiterated with added emphasis a declaration made earlier in the day that if the courts should recognize Perry Belmont as regularly nominated for Congress in the Seventh District he will receive the loyal support of Tammany Hall. This was just after a four hours' conference between Mr. Croker and James Shevlin, the deputy and spokesman of Hugh McLaughlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Hugh J. Bonner of New York has accepted the tender of an appointment as Chief of the Fire Department of Manila. It is purposed to reorganize the Manila fire-fighting service on modern American lines, and Mr. Bonner was selected because of his fine record in New York City.

Senator MCLAURIN of South Carolina sends us a statement prepared for his information relative to the growth of manufactures in that State, which is of statistical interests and, incidentally, of political significance. The results of the industrial census of South Carolina in 1900, as compared with those of a similar census in 1890, present the following comparisons:

Before the Board of Public Improvements adjourned sine die yesterday resolutions were put through reducing by the score the assessments for street-opening improvements. All the requests for reductions were made by lawyers who during the last four years have been going to property owners and offering to have the legal percentages supposed to be paid for improvements reduced and added burdens placed on the city at large.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- The great bulk of the trading in the local market today was in the Reading securities. Though the price here ranged from 1/8 to 1/4 below that in New York nearly all day, the whole Reading group established the highest prices yet recorded, and the volume of trading was the largest seen in a long time.

The fourteenth annual Christmas ride at the new Riding Academy of the Durland Company occurred last evening in the new building, in Sixty-eighth Street, just off Central Park West. The occasion was a success in every particular. The riding and other exhibitions were of a high class, and the audience was a large, representative, and appreciative one.

Two women were injured by jumping from a second-story window at a fire which, starting from some unknown cause at 12:40 o'clock this morning, caused a panic among the occupants of the three-story brick tenement house 345 Baltic Street, Brooklyn. The fire was first seen in an apartment formerly occupied by Mrs. Mary Quinn, on the ground floor.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The Commissioner of Agriculture in his annual report to the Legislature states that comparatively little oleomargarine was sold within the State during the past year and that in all probability nearly all that was exposed for sale was detected by the men working in his department.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 -- Chairman Van Diver of the Democratic State Committee gave a dinner to the Democratic members of both Houses of the Legislature here tonight. Mr. Gorman, Gov. Smith, and all the party managers were present. There having been rumors of some dissension in the ranks Mr. Van Diver, when the dinner was drawing to a close, arose and said:
COPENHAGEN, Dec. 30 -- Royal honors will be paid to the body of Dr. Allanro Read, the American dentist, who had resided here since 1860, and who died last night.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says the attitude of a section of the New York press in regard to the threatened conflict between Germany and Venezuela is not taken very seriously in Berlin, as it is understood that the United States Government long ago received satisfactory assurances from Ambassador von Holleben.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Census statistics on industrial combinations show a total authorized capitalization of $3,607,539,200 for the 183 corporations reported May 31, 1900. The capital stock issued was $3,085,200,868. Of this total the authorized capital includes $270,127,250 in bonds, $1,259,540,900 in preferred stock, and $2,077,871,050 in common stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The State Department received dispatches from the City of Mexico making clear for the first time what is to be expected on the subject of arbitration, which has been the most important and the most difficult problem before the Congress of American Republics. The advices came from Mr. Buchanan, the United States delegate, who was assigned to look after this particular question.

The publication in THE TIMES on Sunday of a foolish and unwarrantable dispatch concerning the possibility of trouble between the United States and Germany over the attempt of the Germans to collect with warships money owing them by Venezuela has called forth the following comment from our neighbor The New York Journal:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Germany is said to have made a distinct promise to the United States Government that in her debtcollecting operations against Venezuela she will scrupulously respect the Monroe doctrine. A short time ago Herr von Holleben, the German Ambassador, held conferences with the President and Secretary Hay, in which he ascertained their views as to how far Germany might proceed against Venezuela in the attempt to force her to settle her obligations.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- John Henry Bogart, who died Friday in this city at the advanced age of ninety-two years, was a member of an old Dutch family, representatives of which settled in Albany in 1642. He was educated at the Albany Academy, and for several years before his death he had been the oldest living alumnus of that institution.

Gaston de Marsac had committed wholesale slaughter; one villain, pierced by the keen blade of "A Gentleman of France," had tumbled headlong down a flight of stairs, a second had pitched head foremost from a high balcony, and about the stage no less than six others, who had sought to prevent the brave gentleman from rescuing the beautiful Mile. De La Vire, writhed in the agony of death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- For the first time in the history of the Port of Rouen, France, a vessel direct from Philadelphia unloaded a cargo of coal there two weeks ago, says Consul Haynes in a report to the State Department from Rouen on Nov. 28. The reports deals with the prospects of American coal in France.

Hoboken had a smallpox panic yesterday. It began on a trolley car, and was afterward transferred to a big five-story tenement house at 514 Perry Street, occupied by twenty-six families. It was occasioned by William Witte, a smallpox patient who escaped from the hospital for contagious diseases at Snake Hill.

The Lincoln League of the Eighth Assembly District and their friends, about 500 in number, paid homage to the two Republican leaders of the district, Charles H. Murray and Assemblyman Charles S. Adler, at a dinner, which was tendered at the Broadway Central Hotel last evening, and at which Mr. Murray was presented with a silver loving cup and Mr. Adler with a gold watch.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- Money was in good supply to-day at Clearing House at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5, 8, and 10 cents premium. On call, money rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Four to six months' money is quoted from 4 1/2 @ 5 per cent., according to the character of the collateral.

Members of the "Big Five" basket ball team of Newark are considerably perturbed over their suspension by the Basket Ball Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union last week. This team, which contends that it is the strongest team in Newark, was one of the eleven teams suspended last Friday.

It seems that, in the pursuance of her policy in Manchuria, Russia has found it necessary to "secure control" of the cables and telegraphs at Niu-Chwang. The policy in question has been repeatedly defined by Russia as the occupation of Manchuria "provisionally and for the purpose of pacification only."

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The Senate of the University of Berlin, says the correspondent of The Times in the German capital, has punished several students concerned in the recent demonstration against Prof. Schiemann.

The surrender of the National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America to receivers is an instructive and impressive incident in the history of industrial consolidations. The merger of these companies was organized on lines inviting failure, because its sole object was to create a monopoly and subject Municipal Governments to the disadvantage of the extinction of competition in bids for street pavements.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were relatively small. The market was also narrower than it had been within the last few days, fewer issues being traded in. As a whole prices were fairly well maintained, although here and there sharp reactions from the closing prices of last week were noted.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Burglars this morning broke into Joseph Hinchman's barn, near the Denville Hotel, about six miles from here, at 3 o'clock this morning, and then, hitching one of his horses to a wagon at the hotel, they backed it up against the side of the house, and, forcing an entrance, removed the hotel safe, weighing 1,500 pounds, and made away with it.

It is evidently the intention of the revisers of the charter greatly to increase the powers, and consequently the responsibilities, of the Presidents of the boroughs. And this not only at the expense of the Mayor and of the general Municipal Government, but also at the expense of those subordinates whom they are authorized to appoint.

That the National Asphalt Company, in which is absorbed the Asphalt Company of America, the combination being known as the Asphalt Trust, is in a badly wreeket state, is indicated by the figures showing the condition of that corporation. These figures were set forth in the bill of complaint asking for the appointment of a receiver on Saturday before Judge Kilpatrick of the United States Circuit Court in Newark.

The holiday season being still in full force, there is not the greatest amount of gayety in town. The dance at Mr. Alfred Wagstaff's last evening was the most notable event. The day opened with the Bagby musicale and a meeting of skaters at the St. Nicholas Rink and a few luncheons and dinners and the gathering of several minor dancing classes brought the day to an end.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- For the first time in years the Republican legislative caucus tonight, in the Senate and Assembly Chambars, were open to the public. The lack of interest in them was remarkable. Politicians who have been coming to Albany for years said they had never witnessed anything like the apathy in the proceedings in their experience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A remarkable scheme is under way, and seems to be on the verge of success, by which the mining privileges of the Uintah reservation, in Utah, are to be turned over to a New Jersey company. This concern is to have a monopoly of privileges which have hitherto been denied to all white men, but the reservation is not to be opened for settlement.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 31 -- The Paterson Children's Day Nursery received from Mrs. Jennie T. Hobart, widow of Vice President Hobart, a New Year's gift in the form of a plot of land 100 by 125 feet at the northeast corner of Grand and Hamilton Streets. In addition to the land Mrs. Hobart also gives $25,000 with which to erect and furnish completely a modern building adopted to the needs of the nursery.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 31 -- The report that the Pennsylvania is planning to invade the upper peninsula of Michigan, together with the Cleveland Iron Cliffs Railway properties, has been revived, and deals that are said to be in prospect for various short lines of railroad tend to confirm the rumor, mor.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- "Bishop Potter, Dr. Rainsford, the saloon and dive keeper, and municipal or State officials who wink at violations of the liquor laws are in the same class, as far as we are concerned."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31 -- While the friends of both Senator Foraker and Senator Hanna are each now claiming that they have the votes to organize the Legislature, the truth is that neither side has sufficient, though neither is short more than four votes of having a majority of the caucus.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- Until Dr. O. SchmidtLeda, the German Minister to Venezuela, arrives at Caracas, which will be about Jan. 5, nothing will be done by the German Charge d'Affaires there, Herr von Pilgrim-Baltazzi, to press President Castro further.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The demand for money in the market to-day was keen, owing to year-end requirements. The Bank rate was freely paid. Heavy borrowings from the Bank of England relieved the pressure. Discounts were inactive and easier, in anticipation of a monetary case after the first of the year.

Suit was begun in the Supreme Court yesterday by Jeannette L. Smith to get $50,000 damages for the alienation of the affections of her husband, who is Sidney H. Smith, Vice President of the New York Last Company of 82 Beekman Street. The persons whom she accuses of having conspired to get her husband's affections away from her are Oscar A. Woodruff, the President of the New York Last Company; Genevra Hogan, and Kathryn Noble.
JAMES S. VAN ANTWERP, a widely known newspaper correspondent, died yesterday at his home in Washington. His death was due to physical and nervous collapse, superinduced by overwork.
HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Two important witnesses were examined by the Coroner to-day in the inquest over the death of Peter Hallenbeck, the farmer who was murdered at Greenport on Christmas Eve.

Physicians in this city, especially those whose practice is largely confined to nervous diseases, were yesterday much interested in the discovery reported from Chicago of the underlying principles of nerve action. This discovery is described as taking the form of the enunciation of a general law, many of whose manifestations have been known hitherto, but which are now for the first time grouped logically together, with the addition of new acts disclosed by recent experiment.

David R. Francis as the leading spirit of the St. Louis World's Fair, will be invested with a degree of distinction which has never before come to any person in a similar position. It was Francis who pushed the scheme to the front and was instrumental in causing the people of St. Louis to take hold of it with zeal and enthusias a feeling which has been followed by a great wave of municipal reform.

OAKLAND, Cal., Dec. 31 -- The will of John J. Valentine, late President of Wells, Fargo Co., who died on Dec. 21, leaving an estate valued at upward of $400,000, has been presented for probate by the Union Trust Company, which is named to act as executor.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- After four postponements, due to the fact that Jean de Reszke was suffering from a slight attack of influenza, the full-dress rehearsal of "Siegfried," which was looked forward to as the great event of the operatic season, was given here to-night and received by a crowded house with every indication of a success.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Treasury is in a condition of unexampled strength," said Secretary Gage to-day, when asked to review briefly the Treasury situation at the close of the year.

New York welcomed the advent of the second year of the twentieth century in characteristic manner. The most demonstrative part of the welcome, as usual, was manifested in the district around Trinity Church, on Broadway, facing Wall Street. Tens of thousands journeyed down to hear the chimes of Old Trinity, and then, in the same old way, blew horns so numerously and vigorously that they could hear nothing but the din of the blowing.
Unless Barnard College gets $80,000 within the twenty-four hours ending to-night, that institution will lose gifts which, with this needed $80,000, amount to $400,000.

Odd blues and browns are to be seen in the new foulards, those that are now out -- queer light shades of brown and many of the pretty and also light shades of blue, although there are some of the deeper shades of the latter color, as deep as the Yale blue.

New Year's Day, as far as social functions are concerned, is even duller than Christmas. The calendar is barren of any notable event. Every one who can has gone to the country, and those who have remained in New York are having family dinners, and in many cases going to the play or the opera.

Two important championship events are now giving the Amateur Athletic Union considerable study, as it is necessary to secure places in which to hold them, so that they may come off between now and the 1st of April. These are the boxing and wrestling championships and the indoor gymnastic championship.

Martin Mager. Jr., was appointed yesterday by the Board of Coroners of Queens County to succeed Charles J. Sohneller as Chief Clerk of the Coroners' office. Schneller resigned this morning while the Board of Coroners was in session, and Mager's appointment followed.
With the retirement of Controller COLER from office, the City of New York loses a brave and faithful financial officer.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 31. -- Among the decisions handed down by the Appellate Division, Third Department, to-day were the following:
Col. Michael C. Murphy put it out of the power of Mayor Low to remove him to-duy by sending shortly after noon yesterday the following communication to Mayor Van Wyck:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Marshal Halstead, United States Consul at Birmingham, England, writes to the State Department:

The Monroe doctrine will before long be a hundred years of age. It owes its genesis to the author of the Declaration of Independence, of which it may be regarded as a corollary; only its promulgation to the President whose name it bears. It is as curious as gratifying that, at the beginning of the twentieth century, it should have won one of the most remarkable of its triumphs.

A close game of hockey was played last night in the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink, Brooklyn, between the Second Naval Battalion and the Bedford Athletic Club. The latter team won by two goals, while the naval men failed to score. The match is the second game won by the Bedford hockey men in the series of games in the Intermediate Hockey League, and they have not yet encountered a defeat.

As THE TIMES was among those who could not at the time approve of the removal of District Attorney GARDINER for the reasons assigned, and as it was forced to describe the appointment of Mr. PHILBIN as something of an experiment, it takes particular pleasure in saying that the experiment has been extremely successful.

Mark M. Pagan, Jersey City's new Republican Mayor, will enter upon his duties at noon to-day, when he and Edward Hoos, the retiring Mayor, who is a Democrat, will receive calls together in the Mayor's office at the City Hull. Mayor Fagan announced his appointments yesterday. T are taken from both parties and are as lows:

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, heard the application of the "ex-wardman," Edward G. Glennon, who was convicted in New York County of neglect of duty in failing to suppress a disorderly house, for a certificate of reasonable doubt, pending his appeal to the Court of Appeals.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 3 and 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges were $25,650,090, and balances $2,752,754. Money on call rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent., new money being largely quoted at 5 per cent. Time money is quoted and nominally 5 per cent. for four to six months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- At the meeting of the Cabinet to-day it was decided to make the International Banking Corporation, organized in New York to do business in Shanghai, the agent of the United States Government for the receipt of the payments to this Government on account of the Chinese indemnity.

Fannie Rayne McComb yesterday risked the loss of millions for love's sake and became the wife of Lewis Herzog. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, in the presence of a few of the young people's friends.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- There was a general shrinkage in the Philadelphia stock market, except for a group of prominent stocks, including the Readings, Lehigh Valley, the Choctaws, American Railways, and Lehigh Navigation. The losses were chiefly in the industrials, with the Asphalt securities lending in the downward course.

In the history of the twentieth century the events of the year 1901 will fill no space. We do not know that the is to be apologized for on that act. A great part of the people of the h have been prosperous and coned, and most departments of human eavor will beg leave to report prog.

WASHINGTON Dec. 31 -- Miss Minna Cromwell, daughter of Rear Admiral Cromwell, was married at noon to-day to Ensign Needham Lee Jones. The ceremony took place in the Church of the Ascension. Bishop Satterlee officiated. The ushers, best man, and bridegroom all wore fulldress uniform, and so did the father of the bride, who returned from Europe to give his daughter's hand in marriage.

The report on the New York City vital statistics for 1901 were given out by Dr. Guilfoyle yesterday afternoon. Dr. Guilfoyle slates that the births are lower than last year, and he claims that this is probably due to the negligence of some doctors and midwives who, he says, have failed to report births.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was dull and presented very li of especial interest. The few stocks th were at all active were the same as have been most prominent in recent trading, and even in these issues price movements were for the most part unimportant. Net changes were about evenly divided between losses and gains, so that no special importance could be attached to the course of prices.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- The Keystone Telephone Company, the rival of the Bell in this city, will answer its first "Hello!" to-morrow morning shortly before noon. An invitation to be present on the occasion of the first official message to be sent over its lines from the main central office.

The last day of Controller Coler's term was marked by great excitement in and around his office. Maurice Featherson, the Tammany leader of the Twenty-eighth Assembly District, got into an altercation with Deputy Collector Edward A. Slattery, and the two men came to blows. There are varying accounts as to just what happened after the fight started, and the accounts also differ as to what was the cause of the row.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 31 -- In anticipation of the Republican caucus at Columbus next Saturday, previous to the organization of the Legislature on Monday, many members and others have recently been visiting Senator Foraker and George B. Cox, the Hamilton County leader at Cincinnati.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 31 -- The Board of Assessors of the town completed their work in figuring up the taxable property to-night and placed their book on file. Although the totals are not figured up, it is estimated that they have increased the grand list half a million dollars at least, to nearly $10,000,000.

DENVER, Dec. 31 -- Final details have been arranged for the organization of the United Rico Mines Company, with $3,600,000 capital, which will absorb the Enterprise, Rico, Aspen, and all the other principal mines, mills, and smelters in the Rico (Col.) district. The majority of the mines are silver properties.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 31 -- Judge William Lochren of the United States Circuit Court to-day dissolved the temporary injunction issued in the case of Peter Power against the Northern Pacific Railway Company by Judge Elliott of the District Court of Hennepin County on Monday.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- The New Year's Eve ball, one of the principal events of the Tuxedo colony, took place tonight at the Tuxedo Club. For over a week the clubhouses have been crowded with guests, and every room has been occupied. Many who own cottages opened them for the holidays and had house parties for the purpose of enjoying the excellent skating, tobogganing, and coasting on Tuxedo Lake.

Mr. GUGGENHEIMER, late President of the Council of this municipality, is one of a few members of the outgoing City Government -- to be exact, one of two -- who take out of office more and better reputations than they took in. Mr. GUGGENHEIMER was very little known to the majority of his fellow-citizens when he took office.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- For the first time in the history of the New York Legislature the annual appropriation bill was introduced in the Assembly during the first day's session. For several weeks Chairman Allds of the Ways and Means Committee has been striving to attain this object, and the bill was finally completed last night.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

The police are still searching for Valet Kern, the principal in the $50,000 Thebad robbery. At Police Headquarters last night it was said that Kern was no nearer prison than he had been since Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Senor Palma's election as first President of Cuba is the occasion of much satisfaction here. No official connected with the Administration will consent to be interviewed on the subject because of the well-known sensitiveness of the Cubans about anything which looks in the least like siding with one party or the other, but unofficially there are many expressions of pleasure over the triumph of the island's conservative elements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- President Roosevelt held his first New Year's reception at the White House to-day, and, surrounded by members of the Presidential and Cabinet circle, he greeted officials in every branch of the Government service of this and other countries, as well as a great concourse of people from private life.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 1. -- By the decisive score of 49 to 0 the Michigan University football team to-day defeated Stanford University. The score is quite in proportion to the general superiority of the Eastern men at the game of football. It does not, however, tell the story of Stanford's desperate but futile efforts against defeat.

Controller Edward M. Grout, who took charge of his office promptly at noon yesterday, signalized his entrance into the Department of Finance by reducing the salaries of clerks and other officials to the amount of $20,000. Several employes were discharged, and Controller Grout announced that the office hours would be from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., instead of 4 P.M., as had been the custom.

Over $170,000,000 worth of property in the United States and Canada was destroyed by fire in 1901, so far as the amount may be approximated before the data for the month of December have been collated properly.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- More interest was manifested at the Capitol to-day in the play of politics preparatory to the next State election than in the prospective legislation for this session, and evidence was plentiful that plans for the next campaign had already received much consideration.

At least one of the public functionaries authorized to marry people under the new law which went into operation yesterday was on hand early in the day with an advertisement of the goods he was prepared to deliver, and he waited in his shop ready to marry all who camp.

The first performance of a Mozart opera this season, namely, "Le Nozze di Figaro," took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. This is not an astonishing fact, because it is very early in the season, and furthermore Mozart is not performed so often as to annoy the less Serious attendants at the vocal exhibitions in upper Broadway.

When the members of the Garden City Golf Club assembled yesterday on their links they found much severer conditions awaiting them for the second Cross Country Cup given by Bruce Price than was the case on Christmas day. A fierce wind blew across the wide stretches of meadow, and the cold atmosphere made it difficult to keep the hanos warm enough to hold a club properly.

-- Buffalo naturally takes a special interest in the source and amount of remuneration to be received by the doctors and surgeons who attended President Mc-KINLEY in his last illness, but the Buffalo papers discuss the questions involved without any apparent regard for local interests, and some of them show a curious tendency to reduce the case to its simplest and most businesslike terms.

Street Cleaning Commissioner Percival E. Nagle turned his office over to the new head of the department. Dr. John McGaw Woodbury, yesterday afternoon. Dr. Woodbury was cordially received by the outgoing Commissioner, and there was a striking contrast presented in physical proportions when the two men shook hands. Mr. Nagle is over 6 feet 3 inches in height and weighs more than 300 pounds. Dr. Woodbury is much smaller.

MANILA, Jan. 1. -- Lieut. Charles D. Rhodes of the Sixth Cavalry, accompanied by two orderlies, when within six miles of Manila to-day came across twenty armed insurgents in a cunrtel or barracks. The insurgents shouted "Americanos," and Lieut. Rhodes feigned a retreat. But in reality he took the cuartel in flank, and drove out the insurgents, capturing two rifles, three revolvers, and some ammunition.

It was very dull, or rather it was quiet, in town yesterday. The entertainments were confined chiefly to family reunions. There was a great deal of theatre going, and the opera had a representative Wednesday audience. Nearly all the house parties will break up this morning, and the hosts, hostesses, and guests will come back to town.

Fire was discovered early this morning in the engine room of Keith's Theatre, on Fourteenth Street, between Fourth Avenue and Broadway. The fire was discovered by Joseph Burns, the engineer of the Morton House, which adjoins the theatre. He rushed into the hotel and notified the clerk, who sent in an alarm from the box in the hotel.

Col. John N. Partridge succeeded Col. Michael C. Murphy as Commissioner and chief of Police at 2:25 P.M. yesterday. Five minutes later First Deputy Commissioner William S. Devery was removed by the new Commissioner despite Mr. Devery's protest that he was a member of the uniformed police force of the city and Chief of Police.
LONDON, Jan. 1. -- Bar silver quiet at 25 3/4 d, per ounce. Money, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent. The rate of discount in the open market for short bills was 3 1/4 and for three months 3 1/8 to 3 1/4 per cent.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- "Arthur Fullerton," who, it is reported, succeeds M. de Blowitz as Paris correspondent of The London Times, is William Morton Fullerton, a Massachusetts man who has been for about ten years associated with M. de Blowitz, attending to all The Times's work in Paris except international politics and diplomacy.

The assumption of his high office by Mr. SETH Low will make every rightminded citizen of New York hold his head a little higher and walk a little more erect than he felt disposed to do on Tuesday, or at any time since the 1st of January, 1898. There is such a thing as civic pride, and the average New Yorker has it.

Recent reports of the large number of unemployed persons in Germany and of the increasing difficulties of the business situation in that country give especial interest to a blue book just issued by the British Foreign Office embodying data collected by Dr. FREDERICK ROSE, British Consul at Stuttgart.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 1. -- "All this talk about the line of policy I am going to pursue as Postmaster General is nonsense," said Henry C. Payne to-day. "It would be exceedingly foolish for me to express an opinion on the practical workings of the department without having a more practical knowledge than I have at this time.

It is certainly a remarkable sign of the times when two such distinguished clergymen as Bishop POTTER and Dr. RAINSFORD can speak in public of the question of the saloon as they spoke at the meeting of the Church Club on Monday evening.

New York City with the incoming of the reform administration yesterday, was officially without any prosecuting branch of its Government, although William Travers Jerome received from ex-District Attorney Philbin the insignia of his office, the keys to his room and desk. District Attorney-elect Jerome, a half hour after the Tammany Mayor had legally lost his power to appoint his successor as a Justice, presented to Mayor Low his resignation of that office.

Bird S. Coler called on Perry Beimont at his Astor House headquarters again yesterday afternoon. It was announced when Mr. Coler left after a half hour's conference that he had offered to make one or two speeches in Mr. Beimont's behalf before Jan. 7, and that the meetings would be arranged for to-day.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1. -- Lord Quex outclassed his field in the New Year Handicap, worth $1,485 to the winner, this afternoon, set his own pace, and won out by three lengths very easily. The Morris pair -- Serpent and The Hoyden -- met early interference, and were never prominent. Kaloma and Eva Rice were the only other winning favorites, though Moroni, who won the fifth race, was heavily backed.
"Lucky pigs" in solid silver, with a ring in the back to attach the charm to a chain for wearing, are selling for fifteen cents each.

The Academy of Design, whose seventy-seventh annual show opens this evening at the Fine Arts Building, in Fifty-seventh Street, has secured one of the best months for its exhibits, when the whirl of city life is at its fiercest and the greatest number of New Yorkers and Winter visitors are here.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 2. -- Differences between the firm of Wichert Gardiner, shoe manufacturers of Brooklyn, and their employes are to be settled by arbitration. Depending on the decision of the interested parties is $10,000, which was deposited one year ago to insure that each should live up to the provisions of an arbitration agreement decided on by employers and employed.

Physicians gathered last night in the large assembly room of the New York Academy of Medicine, 17-19-21 "West Forty-third Street, to discuss tuberculosis, the need of sanitaria, and the action of the Treasury Department in prohibiting the entrance of consumptives into this country. It was declared that the proposed State Sanitarium for Tuberculosis is endangered by the action of the Government in creating an unreasonable dread of consumptives.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- New York exchange was at par to-day. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Local stocks sympathized to a considerable extent with the strength and activity shown by the Wall Street market. Biscuit common and Tin Can were the leaders of the list, and both moved up somewhat from Tuesday's level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- It is expected that the Senate will amend the Philippines Tariff bill passed by the House before the holiday recess. In support of the proposition to amend the measure it is urged that, as it now stands, it is unfair toward products of the Philippines coming to this country.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2. -- The weather at the Oakland track to-day was threatening and the track was slow, Summary:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Responding to the confidence generally felt in the promises of the New Year, the outside market yesterday shared the strength shown by prices on the Stock Exchange. Although the number of issues traded in was not unusually large, nearly all the issues that did show activity made net gains for the day.

The sessions of the Harlem High School for Women, at 241 East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, will be resumed on Monday evening, Jan. 6, and will continue through the first week of April. Free tuition is given in the following subjects: English grammar and composition, literature, bookkeeping, business arithmetic, algebra, geometry, stenography, Latin, German, French, and Spanish.

Sweeping reductions were made in various branches at the initial meeting of the new Health Board yesterday afternoon, for after a session of several hours it was announced that 157 persons had been dropped from the payrolls.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 2. -- Gov. Van Sant and Attorney General Douglas reached home this afternoon. Both went immediately to the Capitol, and went to work on the railroad merger suits.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 2. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission will conduct another investigation concerning the alleged manipulation of grain rates by railroad lines running out of Kansas City. Subpoenas have been issued on grain men and a number of freight agents, representing Kansas City railroads, to appear before the commission in this city on Jan. 9 and explain their rates on grain to the Atlantic seaboard.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 2. -- Figures based upon the reports to the Secretary of State show the profits and losses of Fall River corporations during the year just ended. Eight concerns have not yet reported. Nine increased their indebtedness in a year and five increased their surplus. Three decreased their indebtedness and six decreased their surplus.

The Chamber of Commerce passed yesterday by a large majority the resolutions submitted by Gustav H. Schwab, George Frederick Vietor, Isidor Straus, and Silas D. Webb, condemning the action of the Reciprocity Convention held in Washington last month for its " resolution recommending reciprocity through tariff modifications only where it can be done without injury to any of our home interests of manufacturing, commerce, or farming, thereby rendering any application of reciprocal tariff concession impracticable."

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Money was easy and abundant in the market to-day, and the demand slackened. Discounts were weak. The opinion was expressed that money will be much cheaper after the forthcoming release of the dividends on funds.

-- It is reported from Albany that the "osteopaths " are hopeful of securing the passage by the present legislature of a bill legalizing and regularizing themselves as a part of the medical profession, their confidence being based, it is said, on the fact that Speaker NIXON has recently been treated by one of the bone jugglers, with results likely to make him exert his influence in their behalf.

BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- Before a convention of both branches of the Legislature and in the presence of several hundred invited guests, including State dignitaries, members of the judiciary, and prominent citizens, W. Murray Crane of Dalton, at noon to-day took the oath of office for the third time as the Governor of Massachusetts.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 2. -- Nearly thirty golfers appeared on the links of the Lakewood Country Club this morning to take part in the mixed foursome oven tournament, for which the first set of prizes has been given by Mrs. George J. Gould. The air had an unmistakable touch of wintry snap, although it grew noticeably warmer toward the close of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- W. B. Matchett of this city, representing the Government of Liberia, to-day made a formal request of Secretary Long that the action of Congress, as embodied in the act of April 17, 1866, providing for the relief of Liberia, be carried into effect.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey ferryboat Lakewood last night at 9 o'clock crashed into her slip at the foot of Liberty Street, wrecked the northern side of the ferry station, tore up the street outside the station for a distance of several feet, injured one man and scared nearly out of their wits several score of people who were either on the boat or in the ferry station or on the street.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 2. -- A warrant has been secured from the District Court here charging perjury against William C. Wakefield, the young promoter of large financial enterprises, who is now in jail at Cambridge, and whose name was mentioned in connection with the recent lease of Ditton Park, an English country estate, for the coronation ceremonies.
Mayer S. Auerbach has bought through Leopold Well, four dwellings, 206 to 212 West Thirty-sixth Street, covering a plot 68.6 by 100 on the south side of the street, 95 feet west of Seventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The monthly comparative statement of the Government receipts and expenditures shows that for the month of December, 1901, the total receipts were $47,001,004, an increase of $215,430 as compared with December, 1900. The expenditures for the month amounted to $37,318,998, leaving a surplus of $9,742,966 for the month.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2. -- The market to-day was held in check by the maintenance of call money on a rather high level, though the prevailing bull sentiment managed to lift it a shade above the ante-New Year's prices. The firmer tone of the Seaboard group was accepted as an indication of the recrudescene of a speculative spirit which will become more and more manifest as the month proceeds.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Two hundred thousand pounds have been placed at King Edward's disposal for charitable or utilitarian purposes. According to The Daily Mail the donor is Sir Ernest Cassel, a merchant and financier who has been prominent in Egyptian finance, and who was made a Knight Commander of St. Michael and St. George for his services in that field.

PEKING, Jan. 2. -- Several recent occurrences tend to discourage the hope that the Dowager Empress learned a lesson from the events of the past year. Foreigners are disposed to take a pessimistic view of the outlook.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- The State Civil Service Commission has sent back to the Civil Service Board of New York for explanation the list of places which the local board requested to have exempted from the application of the civil service rules. When Willlam M. Collier, head of the State Commission, was asked to-day what objection had been found to the list, he said:

PORT-DE-FRANCE, Martinique, Jan. 2. -- The British steamer Ban Righ, recently renamed the Libertador, has left this port for the Venezuelan coast. She carries among her passengers Manuel A. Matos, who is now referred to as Gen. Matos. and several Generals and other important personages of Venezuela who joined Gen. Matos here.

The Governor seems to be consciously on his defense in that part of his message which relates to " Home Rule for Cities." No wonder. He knows, as an intelligent citizen and politician, that the strict enforcement of the Sunday laws in the greater city will tend to bring back Tammany and to make worse the moral and social conditions of life in New York.

The fight between Perry Belmont and Joseph F. O'Grady over the Democratic nomination for Congressman of the Seventh Congressional District was ended yesterday by the decision of Justice Scott, in the Supreme Court, refusing to Mr. O'Grady a writ of certiorari to review the action of the Board of Elections in issuing a certificate of nomination to Mr. Heimont, and at the same time upholding the action of the board in indorsing the nomination.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 2. -- The financial affairs of the Everett-Moore syndicate, owning or controlling a number of urban and inter-urban electric railways and an extensive system of local and long-distance telephone lines in Ohio and Michigan, passed into the control of a committee composed of seven prominent bankers of this city to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- The stock market here to-day was active and prices were better. Reading predominated in the trading and made a new high record. Cambria Steel, after a period of dullness, was in spirited demand and rose a full point. Lehigh Valley continued Tuesday's advance, rising to 38 1/2, while Lehigh Navigation touched 79, the highest point recorded since last April.

During the past score of years there has been a good deal of talk of the need of banking facilities in this country to aid in the carrying on of international business, and ever since Mr. BLAINE started his dream of a federation of American republics the organization of an international bank has figured largely in the schemes bred of that grandiose vision.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Capt. Guy Burrows, who has just retired from the employ of the Congo Free State Government, after six years' service, declared in an interview to-day that the conditions prevailing in the Congo Free State were a disgrace to civilization, and far worse than ever before.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 2 -- Ex-Secretary of the Navy Hilary A. Herbert thoroughly approves of the suggestion that ex-President Cleveland be sent to England to represent the United States at the coronation of Edward VII. Speaking of the matter to-day Mr. Herbert said:

BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $26,395,974; balances, $2,687,172. Money on call rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. New money mostly 5 per cent. Time money is quiet and normally at 5 per cent, for all dates up to six months.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- A bill will be introduced in the Legislature at an early date to carry out the recommendation of Gov. Odell for the relief of the overcrowded condition of the calendars in the First and Second Judicial Departments. The recommendation was that a constitutional amendment providing for the temporary designation of County Judges to trial terms, either within or without their own judicial departments, be submitted to the people.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- A telegram from Dublin to The Times says that John E. Redmond, M. P., the Nationalist leader, in speaking at Sligo, denied that the power of the Irish in America was diminished. The Irish vote, he said, was as powerful as ever. He declared that it was calumnious to say that American sympathy for Ireland was based on the vote.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 2. -- Cadet, in the third race, was the only beaten favorite to-day, Hugh Kane, the Texas turfman, received a dispatch to-day confirming the report of the death of the horse George Arnold. Weather clear, track good. Summary:

Police Commissioner Partridge's time was so taken up yesterday with his duties as ex-officio member of the Health Board, a meeting of which he attended, and the perfecting of his bonds as Treasurer of the Police Pension Fund at the Controller's office, that he did very little at Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Miss Alice Roosevelt's "coming-out" ball, which will take place at the White House to-morrow night, is naturally an all-absorbing topic of interest to the younger people of fashionable society, but is by no means to be the great official function some persons seem to imagine.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- President O. C. Barber of the Diamond Match Company came to Chicago to-day to attend a meeting of the Board of Directors and report the results of his recent foreign trip. In speaking of the conclusions of the Directors upon his report, he announced that the surplus earnings of the company will be used from year to year hereafter in extending a foreign trade.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times says he has received from Dr. Ular, the well-known authority on Chinese affairs, an important communication, based on confidential documents. These give evidence that the events in China during the last few years were not only foreseen, but even prepared, with a view to the execution of a great political scheme for the establishment of Russia's preponderancy in the Far East.
SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Jan. 2. -- Gov. Hunt's message to the Legislature of Porto Rico was read at 11 o'clock this morning before a joint session of that body held in the theatre of San Juan.

Plans have recently been made by the Regatta Committee of the American Yacht Club, near Milton Point, Long Island Sound, for two new class raceabouts to add to the list of club regattas during the coming season. Both of these classes will be somewhat larger than the one-design class raced by the members of the club so successfully last year.

Policeman William E. Murphy, who watches over the safety of pedestrians at Liberty Street and Broadway, made his first appearance as an after-dinner speaker last evening. The occasion was the annual dinner at the Hotel Marlborough of the New York Law School class of 1903, of which Officer Murphy is a member.

The keynote of Mayor Low's administration was struck sharply yesterday on his first working day in office. There was a conference late in the afternoon between the Mayor and Controller Grout. For over an hour these two officials, who will have the shaping of the financial policy of the administration, discussed future plans.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 2. -- Mrs. Annie Guthrie of Boston, who arrived in town yesterday, announced to-day that she will take steps at once to have set aside a dec ee of divorce obtained last May by her husband. Peter M. Guthrie, who was married last night to Elizabeth Fryling of Roseville.

William Tsavers Jerome is now District Attorney. He took the oath of office yesterday morning before Justice David Leventritt of the Supreme Court, Mr. Jerome arrived at his office in the Criminal Court Building at 9 o'clock and at once began his work, opening a large mail. He then signed the oath formula and went to the County Court House.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 2. -- Richard Croker arrived at Lakewood this afternoon on the Atlantic City Express from New York. Andrew Freedman accompanied him. They drove to the Lakewood Hotel, where Mr. Freedman registered for both.

SALT LAKE, Jan. 2. -- The Board of Directors of the San Pedro, Los Angeles and Salt Lake Railroad Company has just called upon the members of the company for an additional $1,000,000 to push the work of construction on the line that is to run from this city to the coast. This money is to be paid at once, and makes $6,000,000 already advanced by the promoters.

Mr. Strutt prepares his reader for a more or less biographic method of treatment in this study of Filippo Lippi.
