"I confess," he says in his preface, "that I was attracted almost as much by the human in- terest attaching to the theme as by its un- deniable artistic importance, an importance hitherto overlooked for some incomprehen- sible reason by most writers on art."

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- Money at the Clearing House was in increased supply and loaned at 3 per cent. New York funds sold at 5 and 8 cents premium. Exchange, $27,565,025: balances, $2,648,181. Money is loaning on call mostly at 5 per cent., although there are still some loans outstanding at per cent.

Mayor Low issued his first official statement yesterday. It was a warning to the press and public that attempts were being made by bribery to win ever enough members elected to the Board of Aldermen on the Fusion ticket to give the opponents of the administration the power to organize the legislative body of the city.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In connection with recent research bearing upon the correct spelling of an explorer's name appearing on the new ten-dollar bills of the United States Govern- ment, the following may be not without interest and value:

The Hudson County Grand Jury yesterday considered the case of Mrs. Elizabeth Howe Dale, charged with the murder of her daughter Emeline at Busch's Hotel, in Hoboken, on Nov. 19. The Grand Jury subsequently reported to Justice Gilbert Collins that they had decided not to return an indictment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 3 -- An unknown iron bark, supposedly of French origin, smashed into the steamship Walla Walla early Thursday morning off Cape Mendocino, on the California coast. While the steamship sank to the bottom of the sea and her passengers and crew took to the lifeboats for their lives, the bark crept off in the darkness, and nothing has been heard of her since.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Consols settlement to-day enhanced the demand for money. The ordinary supplies were supplemented by large borrowings from the Bank of England, causing an abundance.

As a result or the cold rain of early yesterday morning, which was later frozen by the changing weather, New York awoke with slippery streets and sidewalks, and during the forenoon ambulances from the hospitals and the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were kept busy attending to injured persons and horses.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- The Readings and United States Steel raced for first place in activity and strength in the local market. In Reading the first check to the recent aggressive advancing movement was applied, but it quickly rallied and regained most or the loss. United States Steel stocks were frequently one-eighth, and sometimes one-quarter, higher here than in New York, the common selling at 45 in Philadelphia, but the difference was quickly adjusted.

At Sotheby's on Dec. 16, 117 books, bound by the Guild of Women Bookbinders and at the Hamstead Bindery, realized a total at a little over L1,293, against L720 for 100 similarly bound volumes on Dec. 10, 1900. Five of the lots were purchased by the King.

In Mr. Adams's memoir of William Hamilton Gibason we have what is a rare thing now, a sympathetic study which is not fulsome in its praises of a character and a life really worth studying. Such a combination of happy subjects and happy treatment is remarkable, more so, perhaps, to-day than it would have been some time ago.

Three interesting Wordsworth items recently appeared in the English auction market, fetching prices that seemed to show an awakeninig of bibliographical intrerest in the poet. All three occurred for sale in Hodghson Co.'s auction rooms, in Chancery Lane, London, the first on Nov. 9, 1901, the other two on Nov. 20, 1901.

Potter Brother have bought from the various owners, 218 to 226 West Forty-third Street, old dwellings on a plot $3.4 by 100.5, together with an abutting parcel, 213 West Forty-second Street, 20 by 100.5.

This rather fragmentary little volume follows quite naturally the Poe movement which recently found expression among the students and professors of the University of Virginia. With appropriate exercises in the library of the university the Zolney bust of the poet was unveiled and an al- cove was dedicated to Poe literature.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- H.R. Newcombe, Chairman of the committee of bankers chosen to take charge of the financial affairs of the Everett-Moore Syndicate, stated to-day that telegrams were being received from many out-of-town creditors, who approved of the steps taken and agreed to the proposition to give an extension of eighteen months on the paper of the syndicate.
PITTSBURG, Jan. 3 -- The Yale hockey team was defeated in the second game of the series to-night at Duquesne Garden by the Keystones. Score, 6 to 2.

Booth Tarking- ton, who wrote "A Gentleman from Indiana," "Monsieur Beau- caire," , and Edwin S. Wildman, author of "Aguinaldo," were friends and schoolmates at Phillips Exeter Academy in 1888, Mr. Tarkington preparing for Princeton and Mr. Wildman for Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Panama Canal Company's proposition to sell its property to the United States has reached Washington, and it is understood at the State Department that as soon as the Secretary of the company arrives here the offer will be presented formally to the President.

THE more one examines the career of President Roosevelt in the light of the books he has produced, the more difficult it becomes to talk about him as a man of letters, even though repeated readings of his works awaken a growing enthusiasm for their themes and a more profound respect for the vitality, the range of knowledge, and the mode of thought of the brain which has produced them.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 8 -- One of the most important acquisitions of the Pittsburg Coal Company during the past year was secured to-day when final papers were signed for the transfer of all the properties and interests of the Shaw Coal Company to the big corporation.

Housebreaking and assault charges, a warrant of arrest, an irate young brother-in-law with a big horse pistol, which, however, wouldn't shoot: a front door battered in at dead of night, were some of the uproarious accompaniments of the marriage of Harry Wunder, paymaster at Wauamaker's and twenty-four years old to Miss Elsie Lohr, nineteen years old, of 126 East One Hundred and First Street.

AMONG the early fiction announced for the new year by the Macmillan Company we notice a new novel by the author of "When Knighthood was in Flower," which it is said, will be illustrated in an unusually elaborate way for a piece of popularly-dressed fiction.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- The so-called Foraker-Hanna contest over the organization of the Ohio Legislature closed its last day before results will be known with neither Price nor McKinnon assured of the necessary thirty-five votes for the Republican nomination for Speaker. Sacrifices on both sides are being made to get votes for McKinnon and Price, and to-night it is conceded that only the ballot in caucus tomorrow aftornoon will decide the contest.

The Civil Service Board of Greater New York was excited yesterday by the statement given out by members of the State Civil Service Board in Albany that the list sent to Albany by the local board had been returned because it contained too many exemptions.

TO say that every book that needs an index ought to have an Index may seem superfluous, but that it is not so is shown by the frequent publication by some of our best publishers of works which are almost useless from the absence of a proper key to their treasury of facts.

With the meeting of several dancing classes and the dinner at Mrs. I. Townsend Burden's and the opera, it was very say last evening. To-day there will be a number of receptions and musicales. The ball at the White House for Miss Roosevelt last evening took many to Washington, especially those connected with the Roosevelt family.

The name of the Count of TURENNE, and his position as a Minister Plenipotentiary in the French Diplomatic Corps, give more weight to his suggestions for the ending of the war in South Africa than is to be attached to such propositions from volunteer humanitarians.
Commissioner Partridge adhered yesterday to his policy of attending closely to police business and refusing to talk about it.

THE present memoir, prepared by Mary E. Palgrave, is one of the series of "Saintly Lives" edited by Robert F. Horton. In his introduction, Mr. Horton quotes a saying of Jowett's, that a greater amount of good can be done by writing the lives of good men and women than by set treatises of theology and morals.
Forget not, brother singer! that though Prose Can never be too truthful or too wise. Song is not Truth, not Wisdom, but the rose Upon Truth's lips, the light in Wisdom's eyes.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In my opinion, there are many readers and reviewers who will look on the list of "Best Books of 1901," as recommended by the Literary Committee of Connecticut and printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS as far from complete in several instances.

In order to protect the good name of Columbia University Seth Low while President of the university last year loaned $10,000 to the undergraduate football association with which to pay outstanding debts on the rent of Manhattan Field and various other bills. At the time it was said that graduates had been the lenders and nothing was mentioned in regard to Mr. Low's connection with the matter.

Puzzling elements enter into an attempt to defraud Mrs. J.P. Knapp of the Hotel Marie Antoinette, at Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, out of $50 for which Frederick Belleck of 378 Second Avenue, who says he is the son of a master plumber, is held pending further examination in the West Side Court.

Most readers of fiction doubtless still-remember vividly the thrill of pleasure they experienced, not so very many years ago, when they chanced upon Stanley Weyman's first notable success. "The House of the Wolf." The historical atmosphere, the engrossing narrative, the dramatic episodes, and the style, which, if not distinguished, was yet characterized by verve and nervous energy, marked this brief tale as something unique at the time of its appearance.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Gov. Odell gave a hearing to-day on the charges preferred against Sheriff Samuel Caldwell of Erie County by the Rev. Dr. O.P. Gifford of Buffalo. The charges are that he failed to close the Illinois Club, an alleged poolroom on Broadway, outside the city line of Buffalo.

John Muir's latest book contains ten chapters on the parks and forest reservations within the United States, and is furnished with a few photographic illustrations and a map. In his preface the author tells us that much of the material was originally published in the pages of The Atlantic Monthly.

A story by Mrs. Poultney Bigelow, "While Charlie Was Away," (D. Appleton Co.,) is in the form of letters purporting to have passed between Mrs. March, a lady of thirty-eight, whose husband was away in the British naval service on the west coast of Africa, and Lord Darraway, her cousin, living in Ireland, who had always loved her.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Saturday Review prints a remarkably free-spoken editorial, in which it strongly advises Great Britain to form a working alliance with Germany in order to check the "continued and apparently inevitable advance of the United States into South America."

-- A writer in Our Animal Friends, the paper issued by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, announces that another vigorous effort will be made while the present legislature is in session to remove from the statute book of this State that utterly indefensible law which exempts trap-shooters from the restrictions and penalties imposed Upon everybody else by the general statute protecting the lower forms of life from brutal treatment.

The New York Time Saturday Review of Books: I have been wasting time and money (fortunately little of either) on the book entitled "The Story of Manhattan," recently published by a local house (Scribner's.) The author, Charles Hemstreet, in his preface, tells us that " The effort has been to make it accurate and interesting.

John J. Dixon, Secretary of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, sent out yesterday to the fifty- two clubs in the local association a list of the amendments to the constitution which were submitted to the annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union and favorably granted subject to the final action of the local associations themselves.

The resolutions adopted on Thursday by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York on the subject of reciprocity must be accepted clearly as a long-deferred expression of impatience and resentment at the outrageous opposition of the protected interests to anything that will really aid foreign trade.

Elsewhere in the present issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS Mr. John Dennison Champlin, a gentleman whose experience as an encyclopaedist entitles him to respectful consideration, descants upon the importance of indexes in books of fact and of the inability of the authors of the books to make them in a satisfactory manner.

In the opinion of real estate men, whatever may be the merits of the proposed mortgage-tax legislation, Senator Stranahan's measure will not be met with very much united opposition from the real estate interests of this city, as has been brought forth by previous bills bearing upon this subject.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The new battleship Maine is 78 per cent, completed, according to a report received to-day at the Navy Department. This is such a rapid advance on the new ship that naval officials are satisfied that she can be placed in commission by February 15, 1903, which will be the fifth anniversary of the sinking of the former battleship Maine in Havana Harbor.

In "the Gospels" we have an account of the birth and the work of Jesus Christ, the Son of God. In "the Acts of the Aposties" we have an account of the birth and the work of Christ's Church. When He finished His work for the Church He returned to the Father. When the Church began its work for Him it must be baptized with the Holy Ghost from the Father.

When Mr. S.R. Crockett brought out "The Silver Skull" last Spring, many who had read his earlier books with pleasure wished that he bad not wandered so far afield. The Mr. Crockett who wrote of Scotland did work of a far more personal character than the Mr. Crockett who wrote historical romances of Italy.

Mr. and Mrs. Constant Lejeune, who live in the Judson apartments, 63 Washington Square South, last nignt surrendered to Special Treasury Agent William H. Theobald jewels valued at $25,000. It is claimed that the jewels were brought into this country without duty having been paid for them.

In the first part of the second annual chess match between Columbia and Cornell, played yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club. Columbia won by 5 1/2 points to 1/2. The drawing for first move resulted in Cornell having the attack on the oddnumbered boards and Columbia on the even numbered.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 3 -- Mr. Slason Thompson's "Life of Eugene Field," which the Scribners brought out, has attracted an unusual amount of attention here where so many of the people concerned still live. The demand was very good during the holidays. Mr. Thompson is an editorial writer on The Record-Herald.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 3 -- The better tone evidenced by the Cotton Duck group was the nearest approach to a feature to-day. It was rumored on the street that the promoters of the United States Cotton Duck Company are at work on a plan by which they hope to remove all underlying securities of the constituent companies, leaving nothing whatever ahead of the preferred stock.

The Rev. Ng Poon Chew lectured in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church last night on the subject, "The Chinese Crisis as Viewed from the Point of View of a Chinaman." Mr. Chew is the managing editor of the San Francisco Chinese dally paper, "Chung Sai Vat Po."

There are so many cheap lmitations -- on paper -- of what used to be called Bohemia, of what is really as conventional and comfortable a place and habitation, both, in space and manner, as conditions of purse and work make practicable, that it is delightful to get an-inside view of the real thing -- to see how that large body of workers broadly classed as artists lives.
EUREKA, Cal., Jan. 3 -- Capt. A.L. Hall of the wrecked steamship gives a graphic account of the disaster. He pays:

On no subject connected with literature is more nonsense indulged in than on that of the value of a literary reputation to its possessor. "It is simply because I haven't a name that editors send back my stuff," wails the struggling, unappreciated novice; while, with the self-satisfied optimism born of success, his more fortunate rival contends that merit alone decides the acceptance or rejection of proffered manuscripts.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was again fairly active and prices continued to show strength. Notwithstanding the irregular close of the Stock Exchange market, quotations for most of the active outside stocks ended the day above Thursday's figures. The places of most prominence were held by the same stocks which had been most active the previous day, but the number of issues traded in was probably larger than Thursday.

FOR the preparation of the volume entitled "The French People," Mr. Arthur HasSall, in dealing with this most extended subject, shows how numerous were the authorities consulted. The list is a large one, and comprises the names not only of the contributors to French history in the past, but includes the authorities of to-day.

EVEN at the risk of adding another pediment (or impediment) to your crowded columns, I cannot refrain from getting on my feet to say a few words to one whom Mr. Thomas B. Connery endeavors to bring into popular disrepute by publicly calling his friend.
In "St. Nazarius," the author, Mrs. Farquharson, adds the question of a priesthood to the familiar one of a man's love for a woman and his loyalty to his friend.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Max Pemberton's novel, "The House Under the Sea," which is now running as a serial in The Strand Magazine, has been secured for book publication by D. Appleton Co., and will be presented by them next October. The same house has also purchased for publication later in the year another novel by Mr. Pemberton which has as yet received no title.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- A verdict of suicide while temporarily Insane was returned by a Coroner's jury this morning in the case of Baron Charles Cauldre Boilleau, who was found dead from a bullet wound in a railroad car at Loughborough Junction last Sunday.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The insufferable girl has been a factor in fiction before and since Henry Esmond teased us by his inexplicable affection for Beatrice. But Beatrice (and Rosamond Vincy, for another example.) served a further literary purpose than to indicate the extreme limit of willfulness, and seldom outside of The Duchess's volumes were we supposed to admire the pert heroine who boxed the ears or her lover.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 3 -- Favorites fared badly in to-day's racing, Monos being the only one to score. Most of the winners, however, were fairly well supported. T. Walsh's ill-judged ride spoiled a plunge on Samivel in the second race. The gelding was backed from 8 to 1 to 3 to 1, but had nothing left when the pinch came.

The views of the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst on journalism and history are, necessarily interesting. He has had a good deal to do with furnishing material for the former and he is a student of the latter. We quite agree with him that journalism is not history, and we shall not in the least dispute his high estimate of what history is when it is at its best.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Some of the main features of the protocol between the United States and Nicaragua have been made known in recent press dispatches from Managua, but there are many other important features which have not yet been disclosed, one of these being the complete American jurisdiction and the establishment of American courts, civil and criminal, throughout a zone six miles wide and extending from ocean to ocean, and including the proposed termini.

The chief objection to Senator STRANAHAN'S bill providing for a stamp tax of one-half of 1 per cent, to be affixed to mortgages at the time of filing lies against its title. Gov. ODELL in his message described it as a bill for the taxation of mortgages, and Senator STRANAHAN evidently understands that to be its object.

Fritz Lindinger, the banner bearer of the Fritz Lindinger Club, drew out of the Seventh Congressional District fight yesterday, but in doing so he omitted to inform his lieutenants of the fact, at least for many hours after the Perry Belmont campaigners had his declination properly signed and witnessed in their possession, and were circulating it as the day's most important bit of campaign literature.

The Rev. Dr. F. De Sola Mendes has now been with Shaarai Tefillah Congregation twenty-five successful years, and the anniversary is to be celebrated Jan. 10 and 11. The West End Synagogue is in Eighty-second Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Its name means "Gates of Prayer," and it used to stand in West Forty-fourth Street, having been organized as a congregation in 1869, under the leadership of the Rev. Samuel S. Isaacs.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Why might not George Cary Eggleston, in defense of his views as to the spelling of "honor," use the examples and arguments of men who from the dates at which they passed away from this world may be fairly assumed to have escaped the imputation of "Americanism" which is so handily thrown at the use of many an old and perhaps forgotten spelling.

In view of all that has been said of Mr. Henley's recent criticism of Stevenson, it is interesting to note, in glancing over the volumes of Stevenson's letters, the great number that passed between them and the warm note of affection they contain. That Henley could be severe in criticism as well as fulsome in praise of the living Stevenson's work is shown by two letters.

Women who do not use them constantly are apt to forget the value ou embroidery or crewel needles. They are to be found in the different numbers of ordinary needles, with the long eye which is so valuable in using many kinds of embroidery materials. These needles are useful also for fine darning.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- No end of guide books have been written about Italy, but they all resolve themselves into one or another of three classes. There is the dry, statistical guide book of which Baedeker is the type.

Formal announcement will be made within a few days of the amalgamation of the principal natural cement companies of the country. This is the result of the rate-cutting war which began between these companies about two months ago, and which has brought about a cut of nearly 33 1-3 per cent. in the price of cement.

The general reading public, which did not know or know of the late Clarence King, may well have road with surprise the eulogies upon him of his friends and acquaintances. The literary work by which he was most widely known consisted of technical studies and reports in the line of his occupation as a geologist and explorer.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The appreciative critique of Capt. Mahan's." Types of Naval Offcers," prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY RE- VIEW OF BOOKS of Dec. 21, by Col. Prout, reminded me once more of the incidents peculiar to the growth of that author's lit- erary career.

Plans for Philadelphia's proponed elevated railway have been practically completed by George H. Thomson, Chief Engineer of the American Elevated Railroad Company, which has offices in the Broad-Exchange Building, and which, it is said, will be given the contract for the construction of the road.

The mooting of The American Historical Association at Washington during the holidays was a notable affair, not only in point of the National character -- indeed international -- of some of those in attendance, but also in that it indicates a widening interest in history in the United States, an interest which bids fair to call forth a splendid output of works by American students.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 3 -- Elkwood Park, the home of the Gentlemen's Driving and Field Club of Monmouth County, has closed its doors, and there is little likelihood of its attempting another year's existence. Mrs. Philip Daly, who leased the place to the club, has taken charge. She has secured $1,500 of the year's rental, half the stipulated amount, and the lease does not expire until next month.

Winston Churchill on the English Tougue. Winston Churchill was "taken down" at the Savage Club in London recently for delivering a fifth-form lecture on the study of English." It is considered in English neither new nor true that more attention should be paid to English classics and less to those of antiquity.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 3 -- Changes in the service rules for the Police Department are demanded to-day by Chief O'Neill. The Chief would shift the location of a policeman's revolver from his right hip pocket where it is housed in by several wraps of clothing, to the inside of the overcoat, just below the first button, in Winter, and a corresponding place in Summer.

There is nothing intrinsically improbable in the report, which comes to us from Paris through London, that Russia and China struck a bargain, before the invasion of China by the Powers, according to which Russia, was to protect China from the other Western Powers and to have in return whatever she required for herself.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 3 -- When the men and women who qualified on the previous day for the cups given by Mrs. George J. Gould for the mixed foursome tournament at the Lake-wood Country Club arrived on the links this morning they found a light fall of snow covering the greens.
Brooklyn this morning promises to be the scene of a fierce Magisterial war, when the rival claimants for seats on the police court bench of the borough come together in the several courts.

Few people have done more than Lilian Whiting in spreading the love of beauty; not only her books, but her weekly news letters from Boston have carried with them the appreciation of beauty in all forms and have given a moment's breathing space and uplift to people living under sordid conditions.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- The Youngstown Telephone Company, controlled by Everett and Moore, will not be affected by the financial embarrassment of the syndicate. The company, it is stated, is on a paying basis and amply able to meet all its obligations.

The gold output of the world in 1901 has been slightly greatly than in 1900, but the gain is iunimportant. The United States and Canada have together made a gain of perhaps twelve millions. The Nome output was about $4,300,000, not far from its yield in 1900. The miners there labored against a very backward and unfavorable season.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- The Rev. Dr. Hiram W. Thomas, recently pastor of the People's Church of Chicago, has announced in a letter to Peter Van Vilssingen, treasurer of the Chicago branch of the American Transvaal League, the willingness of himself and his wife to go to South Africa in the interest of non-combatants gathered at the reconcentrado camps.

OTTAWA, Jan. 4. -- The Canadian Government has had under consideration for some time past the question of granting provincial autonomy to the Canadian Northwest. So far the Legislatures of the Territories have had only limited powers, and a delegation of the Territorial Government visited Ottawa several weeks ago.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Saturday. -- The holiday crowds have come and gone and Lakewood society is resting from the pleasures of what was undoubtedly the gayest holiday season this fashionable resort has ever enjoyed. Never before were there so many visitors at this time, and never before were such elaborate plans made for their entertainment, the hotels and the cottagers offering unbounded hospitality to all who came.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- The rapidity with which the Chinese are becoming accustomed in the use of the food supplies and commodities of civilization is fast disproving the off-repeated assertion of a few years ago that they cherished their antiquated habits of life closely and would never adopt modern memoes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of the Governor as to a stamp tax on real estate mortgages seems to "hit the nail on the head," and presents a practical solution of a vexed problem.

The average crop yield of the United States during the past year has been satisfactory. The corn crop was short, but the prices range higher and the producers made more money than they would have made with a larger crop and the ordinary prices. The cotton crop was short also, but higher prices brought good returns to the cotton growers.

CINClNNATl, Ohio. Jan. 4. -- A company is being formed by local capitalists with a capital stock of about $.5,000,000 to buy the Everest-Moore holdings in the Detroit United Railway. The movement is being engineered by a local brokerage firm, and considerable Eastern and Detroit capital has been pledged.

At the best Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, New York, Chicago, and other large cities, the best of wines are served to Chinese as well as American customers, together with the finest and most expensive foods. In the average Chinese restaurant in those cities good board can be had by the Chinese for from $15 to $20 a month, and these restaurants are largely patronized.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- When King Edward opens Parliament on January 16, which will be an occasion of even greater pomp and ceremony than was his last appearance in the House of Lords, one of the most interesting sessions of recent years will be commenced.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 4. -- The season in Baltimore continues with unabated gayety, each succeeding event rivaling the former ones in beauty and lavishness. On New Year's Eve the Bachelors' Cotillion Club gave at Lehmann's Hall the handsomest ball in its history to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization in its present form.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 4. -- State Civil Service Commissioners William M. Collier of Auburn, Cuthbert W. Pound of Ithaca, and John E. Kraft of Kingston, met here to-day and at the request of the Municipal Civil Service Commission of New York City exempted from competitive examination forty-three positions there.

SYDNEY, Dec. 4. -- The past year will prove one of the most remarkable in Australian commercial history, the accomplishment of federation having necessitated many fiscal changes, most of which have yet to be accomplished, creating a period of business transition, during which mercantile affairs generally throughout the Commonwealth must remain in a more or less unsettled condition.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- A formal proposition to sell the Panama Canal properties to the United States Government for $40,000,000 was submitted to-day to the authorities here. It was made by M. Boeufve, representing the company, to Admiral Walker, as Chairman of the Isthmian Canal Commission.
THIS is the story as Crane told it to me on a West Indian diner recently.

The decision of the new administration to require the employes of the city to add another hour to those they have been in the habit of giving to their work hitherto is significant of the change that has taken place in more ways than one.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 4. -- Tayon's defeat in the Audubon Handicap, worth $1,230 to the winner, was a blow to the talent to-day. The horse was a heavy favorite in the betting, and, off in the lead, made all of the running. There was a desperate drive in the stretch, and when the pinch came, Alard nosed the favorite out.
THE "youngerrson" industry is in a flourshing condition in California this Winter, with branches in Florida, Oklahoma, and Colorado, all doing a "land-office" business.

JOHANNESSBURG, Nov. 2. -- The territories upon which the forecast is called for are the theatre of the Anglo-Boer war. When hostilities broke out in October, 1899, hundreds of business houses in both territories immediately closed down, and those that remained open were it liable to maintain even a show of doing business, except at great loss.

Speaking from a commercial stantpoint, I am glad to be able to say that the general conditions in the commercial and mercantile world are good. The outlook for the Spring buying season is favorable, and I expect to see merchants from all over the country purchase freely in this market for the Spring and Summer trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most roundabout method is sometimes the most effective, and perhaps it may happen that the helpless prospectors of Utah may be able to reach the conscience of the Department of the Interior through the distant medium of your valuable newspaper.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Twelve stakes for the Spring and Summer meetings of the Harlem Jockey Club were announced by Secretary Nathanson to-day. They are all on the cash system, and the added money ranges from $1,500 to $5,000 each. Entries for these stakes will close on Monday, Feb. 10. The Twentieth Century handicap, worth $7,500, remains the leader, and the M. Lewis Clark Stake is retained.

One is templed to say that the railroads of the United States have now fairly entered on the most important epoch in their history. But, having in mind the danger of superlatives, and looking back at various other railroad epochs which have been seen since the civil war, we will only say that this is a very important epoch.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read your editorial in this morning's TIMES entitled "Legalizing Building Law Violations" with surprise, because THE TIMES editorials are usually the result of a careful and painstaking inquiry into facts.

A set of questions relative to currency and banking conditions was prepared and submitted to Controller of the Currency William Barrett Ridgely, who answered each of the questions specifically. The questions together with the Controller's replies follow:

PROCTOR'S THEATRES. -- The Twenty-third Street theatre will offer another week's bill of continuous vaudeville. The Ten-Ichi troupe of Japanese magicians and the Cycle Whirl again will be the features. Two-one-act plays. "Grif" and "Waldorf Cab No. 93," will also be produced. The Five Nosses, George W. Day, Belle Stewart, and Fields and Ward will be other entertainers.
SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 4. -- The French bark Max reports being in collision with the steamship Walla Walla.

The most important development of the year 1901 in its effect upon the export trade of the United States in manufactured merchandise has been the unexampled prosperity of the country. Every mine, mill, and factory was taxed to its utmost to supply what was urgently called for. Every transportation company has been in the greatest straits to move merchandise within the limits of the Republic from the points of production to the points of consumption.

Manufactories of every kind exist in Lyons. After silk, which is the principal industry, ranks metallurgy. The number of metallurgical establishments is placed at 400. Everything is made, from a pin to a locomotive. The annual product of the metallurgical establishments in Lyons is valued at $15,440,000.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The action of Sir Ernest Cassel in placing u200,000 at the disposal of King Edward, for charitable or utilitarian purposes, which sum will be devoted to the establishment of a sanitarium for consumptives, has brought prominently before public notice one of the most interesting characters in England.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- Negotiations for the sale of the buildings and grounds of the Woman's College of Medicine, with a view to abandoning that institution, are being carried on by the business agent of the Northwestern University.

One cannot look over the range of prices established in the daily markets for the different metals during the year of 1001 without being impressed by the remarkable lack of price fluctuation in most of them.

VALPARAISO, Chile, Dec. 2. -- The year 1901 showed a marked increase in trade between the United States and Chile over any previous year in the last decade. And the prospects for the future are brighter and better than at any time in the history of the two Republics.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- The Western turf war is over, as every race track in this section will be under the control of the Western Jockey Club after next Monday. This was decided upon here last night after a conference between Messrs. Palmer and Hendrie, who control the Highland Park track of Detroit, the Fort Erie, Canada, and Douglas Park, Louisville, and R. C. Chambers, who controls the Windsor track.

A new musical comedy at the Knickerbocker Theatre, a new drama at Daly's, both of English origin; a new German play at the Irving Place Theatre, and a curtain raiser -- a selection from Edmond Rostand's "The Romancers" to precede the comedy "Sweet and Twenty" at the Madison Square Theatre, is the coming week's addition to the theatrical programme.

In the history of St. Paul there has been no more prosperous business year than that of 1901. After the panic of 1893 there was a depression for several years here, as in other parts of the country, and then gradually a recuperation. The year 1900 was counted by our business men as the banner year, but 1901 has far eclipsed its predecessor.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4. -- The easing of the money rate and the abundance of funds at the 5 per cent, rate were the only semblance to a feature in to-day's market. The easing tendency in money was a helping cause in stiffening a bullish sentiment. Interest centred around the report that a six-tickets-for-a-quarter bill would be introduced in the Legislature against the United Railway Company.

Four of the Brooklyn Police Magistrates slept last night in their courtrooms, attended by friends and by court officials who were prepared to resist all intruders, and they propose to open court this morning. They are Magistrates Higginbotham, Dooley. Turlong, and Devoy.

In the future no more society men, not even those possessing millions of dollars, can obtain a commission in the Twelfth Regiment of the National Guard of this city without enlisting first as a private, and shouldering a rifle like any other ordinary enlisted man. Col. Dyer, who commands the regiment, determined upon this course yesterday, and the rule will be followed strictly in all applications for commissions from civil life.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Catherine Bowden, eighty-five years old, the youngest of three distinguished sisters whose father, Jaboz Rockwell, was a soldier of the Revolutionary War, died at the home of her niece, Mrs. Phoebe Bunnell, of Matamoras, Penn., this morning. The two other sisters, living at the same place, are Mrs. Lucinda Valentine, eighty-nine years old, late of Brooklyn, and Mrs. Phoebe Gainford, ninety-six years old.

BARCELONA, Spain, Dec. 10. -- A brief glance at the official statistics for the first six months of the year, as given in The Madrid Gazette, will give a general idea of the position of Spanish trade during that time, as compared with the corresponding period of 1900.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The second Wagner festival at the new Prinzregenten Theater in Munich next August will be a pecuniary success iF much advertising can make it so. There will be twenty performances of four works: " Tristan und Isolde," " Die Meistersinger," "Tannhiluser," and " Lohengrin," arranged in eight cycles, and the singers will include Nordica, Temina, Anna Mildenburg, Staudigl, Fritzi Scheff, Bertram Knote, Anthes, and many others.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- As a contrast to the magnificent results of the past year's commerce in the United States there is a general depression sweeping over the Old World at the present time that omens ill for the coming year, and is causing anxiety to many who are closely connected with European trade.

Two cotton crops aggregating in value $850,000,000 during the past two years have brought to the South greater prosperity than has been known since the war. Thus at the commencement of the current season farmers and merchants generally were in an easy and comfortable position.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Washington Post will print to-morrow an interesting and important article by ex-Senator William E. Chandler, President of the Spanish Claims Commission, entitled, "Wanted by the United States, a President." The article is a strong argument for a reform in the present methods of conducting executive business.

From Chamber's Journal. The famous basket trick depends mainly upon the construction of the basket. This in plan is oval, its longest diameter being about 4 feet and its shortest about 2 feet 6 inches. In elevation it is dome shaped, with a flat top represented by the lid, which measures about 2 feet 6 inches wide by 1 foot 6 inches; but the exact shape and dimensions of the basket vary in different localities.

Wherever the American goods are introduced they speedily become popular.
The large increase of exchanges for the year 1901, as shown in the report of Clearing House transactions is a striking proof of the increase of business the past year.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Rudyard Kipling begins the New year by warning his compatriots that if they wish to continue great and prosperous they must think less of trade and grouse shooting and look to it that their army is up to the mark, their powder always dry, and their martial spirit undiminished.

A MELANCHOLY interest attaches itself to the last historical incident in the life of the old Illinois town, Kaskaskia, in the recent decision of the Post Office Department to wipe its name from the official map of the United States.

This has occasioned much comment, and has even produced an uneasy feeling in some quarters.

In the battle of Navarino the shell suns of the allies set on fire and destroyed many of the Egyptian ships. When iron and steel vessels came into fashion much woodwork was retained.

Capt. J. W. Miller of the New York State Naval Militia has submitted his annual roport to Adjt. Gen. Henry. Capt. Miller says that, notwithstanding the fact that many causes, both National and local, militated against the progress of the Naval Militia during the past year, its development has been most satisfactory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not care to rush into print on every provocation, but the letter inserted in THE TIMES from R. B. Roosevelt on Dec. 30 is more than I can pass unanswered. His whole letter is simply calumny! He seeks to slander one man personally and a nation generally.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 4. -- The campaign against trusts in Texas was renewed with vigor hero to-day. The State filed four suits against, corporations which are alleged so have violated the Anti-Trust act, and the penalties sought to be recovered aggregate 2,870,000. WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The War Department has received from the Philippines copies of a remarkable proclamation signed with the names of nine Americans -- seven of them said to be in the United States military service -- inviting American soldiers to desert and join the ranks of the Filipino soldiery.

Plans for Speyer Co.'s new banking house to be erected on the north side of Pine Street, just east of Nassau Street, which were filed at the Building Department yesterday, show a structure that will be in many respects unique.

The number of National banks reporting to the Controller of the Currency on Oct. 31 was 279 greater than the year previous. The aggregate capital increased during the year $30,721,800, and the aggregate resources reached the enormous total of $5,695,347,294.96. The number of banks increased very largely in the smaller towns and the more sparsely settled portions of the country.

To the Editor of The New york Times: The splendid argument of Gov. Odell against the Sunday opening of saloons should make some of the clerical advocates of a Continental Sunday blush for shame. It Is a consolation to the Christian men of this State to know that the Governor is sound on this vital question, which affects not only-New York City, but every part of the State.

YOKOHAMA, Nov. 15. -- The United States takes each year from Japan three-fourths of the tea, nearly all the floor matting, more than half the raw silk, and a large proportion of some kinds of silk tissues. The United States is the largest purchaser of Japanese porcelain, and only Great Britain takes more of straw plaits, while, for the first time, in 1900 we took more of Japan's rice and camphor than any other nation.

Her exports and imports amount to about fourteen hundred millions of dollars annually, or three-quarters of those of the United States, reaching nearly the volume of tnose of France, and falling short of those of Germany by only $300,000,000 or $100,000,000.

The Crude Rubber Company, organized by Charles R. Flint and incorporated under the laws of Virginia in 1897. passed into the hands of a receiver yesterday. The liabilities of the Crude Rubber Company are, according to the statement of counsel, about $2,000,000 in excess of the assets.

Not in a good many weeks has the trading in the outside market been as active on Saturday as it was yesterday. A number of issues were traded in to a considerable amount, and in the cases of a few prominent stocks the morning's trading was as large as the recent average for a full session.

After the holidays the season promises to be extremely gay. It is on the principle of the life depicted by the old poet, a short and a merry one. From now on there will be many dances and balls and entertainments of all kinds. The great house parties which lasted through the holidays have broken up and the guests have returned to town.

MRS. CLARENCE MACKAY, at the opera on Monday night, was gowned in a fashion that suggested mediaeval times. The sleeves and bodice were shaped like those of several centuries ago, but the material was distinctively modern. The sown was of soft black stuff, evidently lace small tulle, spangled in curving lines with small circular green and jet circles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ultimate results of the present crisis in Venezuela cannot be at present foreseen. Whether serious or not, however, the incident is, in one respect, very important, for it is putting to a practical test the intrinsic efficacy of that very sweeping but rather vague policy called the Monroe doctrine.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Whatever may be said by Bishop Potter and Dr. Rainsford, the fact remains that if the question of permitting the liquor saloons to open on Sunday was left to a popular vote in New York City it would be answered in the negative by an overwhelming majority.

The City of St. Louis is a typical American city; the population is uniquely cosmopolitan; there is a happy combination of Eastern thrift, of Northern energy, of Western enterprise, and of Southern hospitality. It is the commercial capital of the State of Missouri, and is one of the most important business centres of the country.

Mr. T. P. O'CONNOR has just reminded us anew, in a very interesting article on Lord SALISBURY, that he was once, as Lord ROBERT CECIL, the leading political writer of The Saturday Review. That was the time when WALTER BAGEHOT took occasion to say that he was the only one of the great hereditary nobles of Great Britain who had proved his capacity to earn his own living.

SUPERIOR, Wis., Jan. 1. -- It is so unusual for the chief officer of the leading financial institution of an important municipality to advise the "readjustment " of the city's debt that the letter addressed this week by President William B. Banks of the First National Bank of Superior to the Taxpayers' League is considered very remarkable.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- Speaking broadly, the year just closed has been for Great Britain one of the worst ever known for financial enterprises of every sort, but it has been by no means a bad year in many branches of trade, while the outlook at the opening of the second year of the new century presents some encouraging features.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4. -- The dispute with Chile is again aggravated owing to the alleged unfairness of the Chilean diplomats during the negotiations.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- The year closes in Chicago and the Northwest with general business conditions absolutely sound and a promise of continuance throughout 1902. The progress which has been made during the twelve months has been of a most substantial character in every line of trade and manufacturing.

The second matinee of the Season of opera in French, German, and Italian took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The musical delights of the occasion were to be sought in Gounod's "Faust." The audience was a large one, though there have been times when the same opera has caused the walls of the building to distend, which they cannot be said to have done yesterday.

Hies on the powers of the Inter-State Commerce Commission and your editorial comment thereon published in a recent issue of your paper, and would esteem it a privilege to be allowed to say a few words not exactly on the other side, but from the shipper's point of view.

Old Jeremy Bentham kept himself up to his work for eighty years by his regular "postjentacular circumgyrations."

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Kipling's new poem, " The Islanders," which was printed in full in The London Times this morning, is copyrighted both in Great Britain and the United States, and therefore cannot be published in extenso in either country except by the owners of the copyright. In brief, it is a rebuke to Englishmen for not having a larger, more formidable, and more enthusiastic army.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ever-increasing postal business of New York City has become so far of public notoriety that a radical change in the facilities for the transaction of that business is not only demanded by the necessities of the case, but will be sanctioned by general approval.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- In a fist fight which became general for a few minutes the six-day bicycle race at Park Square Garden ended to-night with McFarland and Maya the winners. The six leading teams were on even terms in distance traveled for the week, the winning places being taken in the last sprint.

Odell in his message for a system of bonding for such game as may remain in the possession of a dealer at the end of the open season, but they do not share the Governor's belief that the adoption of such a system would result in a voluntary recognition of the game laws.

The charge that the books of the Park Department were kept improperly was discussed by ex-President George C. Clausen yesterday. He declared that William Hepburn Russell, the new Commissioner of Accounts, spoke without proper investigation, and was talking of things of which he knew nothing.

THE local archaeological exploration or the American Museum of Natural History, conducted for the past two years in the vicinity of New York City by M. R. Harrington, is now complete, and the exhibits illustrating it can be seen in the museum. The field work of the past Summer continued that of the first season, but included certain interesting new finds.

"WIDOWERS are much nicer than bachelors," said the man who has been married three times. "I know this is a fact, because widows think so, and if there is anybody on earth who knows a good thing when she sees it, it is a widow.

Ex-Congressman John J. Adams, counsel for Mrs. William H. Clark, widow of ex-Corporation Counsel Clark, will to-morrow apply in the Supreme Court for an injunction restraining Referee Bankson Morgan from giving to Frank Farrell a deed to the Empire City racetrack, purchased recently by the latter and associates under foreclosure proceedings.

SENATOR QUAY of Pennsylvania is not a laughing man. He rarely lets anything move him beyond the twinkle in his eye, but a Florida farmer's impression regarding him made him "let loose." The Senator, returning from a fishing trip to his bungalow, at St. Lucie, Fla., rode in an accommodation train, and the farmer sat beside him and questioned him.

"IT was to one of the "prohibition counties of North Carolina, where prohibition counties abound," said a nomadic New Yorker, "and I had, been there but a few hours, when I discovered that many sharp eyes were on the lookout to detect the presence anywhere at a surreptitious jug, and particularly a surreptitious jug with 'moonshine' in it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Secretary Hay and a number of men interested in the Carnegie project of a National University met at the State Department to-day and formed a corporation known as the "Carnegie Institution." It is understood that Mr. Carnegie has removed the obstacles that existed to the acceptance of his gift of $10,000,000 to the cause of education, and to-day's action was the first step toward giving legal form to the proposition.

ODESSA, Dec. 4. -- The grain trade of Odessa for the year 1900 shows an almost unprecedented depression. Only wheat and rye show an increase, and this increase is very slight. The failure of the crops in 1899 and 1900 affected Odessa more that other places in Russia, because Odessa is the outlet of the principal grain growing territories.

We are paying off our indebtedness to other nations at the rate of $350,000,000 a year. We still owe some $1,7,000,000,000. Five years more of our present prosperity and productiveness would Square the account and prepare the way for us to become, what we have not yet become, a creditor Nation, a lending Nation, not a borrowing one.

Mrs. Mabel McKinley Baer, the favorite niece of the late President, and a number of other ladies gratified the hearts of some 700 "Little Mothers" yesterday afternoon when they sang and entertained the children on the occasion of their annual Christmas entertainment, which took place at Webster Hall, Eleventh Street, near Third Avenue.

Superintendent John Thatcher of the Department of Sewers in Brooklyn continued yesterday his work of weeding out employes in his department whose services he felt wore not needed. He found many more men in the department who had been drawing pay regularly for doing little or no work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- At the close of the fiscal year the imports into the Philippine islands exceeded the exports by over $6,000,000. The imports were $32,818,411 and the exports $26,431,262. For the fiscal year of 1900 the imports amounted to $23,043,836, and the exports to $21,766,440, the imports thus exceeding the exports by $1,277,416

BARMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 4. -- Alabama coal miners ascertained to-day from an inspection of the sale books of the leading iron producers for last month that the average price of pig iron on all grades is between $10 and $11 per ton.

Complications beset the love affairs of Edward Bourne, a young man employed as a cashier in Altman's Sixth Avenue store, and Mattie Dunelay, a lawyer's stenographer from Providence, R. I., in Harlem, last night; but when all seemed darkest Police Capt. Hogan of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station smoothed the difficulties and saw them well started on their journey.

HENRY B. IRVING and Lily Brayton are credited with personal successes in Louis Parker's English version of Ludwig Fuldaa's drama. "The Twin Sister," which has just been produced at the Duke of York's Theatre, in London. The play was cordially received.

Three men were injured in an elevator accident in Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon. The men were Samuel Franks, twenty-nine years old, of 39 Front Street; John Smith, thirty-five years old, of 25 York Street, and Henry Miller of 65 Nassau Street, all employed at the Union Lead and Oil Works, at 81 Front Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In yesterday's (Wednesday's) TIMES I note under the heading of "Butchers' Shops on Sunday," that Assemblyman Adler of the Eighth Assembly District of the Borough of Manhattan is getting ready to present a bill which will repeal or amend the Sunday closing law of the butchers.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 4. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $25,610,353. Balances, $1,853,322. Money on call rules from 4 1/2, to 5 per cent. Time money is quiet. Quotations range from 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent., according to collateral.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- While it seems that the Stale dues all it can, or ought to do, in existing circumstances, to encourage the agriculturist, and the urban taxpayer has just cause for complaint in consequence, the British farmer continues to grumble.

A word of friendly caution to the gentlemen who on Wednesday assumed office by election or appointment may not be out of place. Ever since the election returns established the fact that Tammany had been repudiated by the people those who knew that their days of official life were numbered have been busily engaged in planting mines and placing torpedoes for the undoing of their successors.
As a maker of Wall Street records, 1901 stands unapproached. Some of these records -- most of them -- are inspiriting; but others there are of very different import.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Bishop Potter and Dr. Rainsford have drawn down the wrath of the ladies of Chicago with a vengeance, but their remarks are just what might be expected. The ladies cannot argue, but abuse an antagonist who may attack any pet theory. But, as I object as a man of true temperance to some of their remarks, I will name them.

LAST Sunday night. Outside, a persistent and most depressing downpour of rain; inside, a disgruntled detachment of "supers," called for a final rehearsal which has been delayed owing to the late arrival of the scenery, dim shadows cast by the many-pronged gas jet, which serves in lieu of footlights, and a vague vision of a sea of brown holland, which drowns all prospect of hilarity.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- It was a very dull day in the Philadelphia stock market, and price variations were in harmony with the commonplace character of the dealings. The only changes of note were in the Asphalt bonds and the arbitrage stocks, the exclusively local shares showing small net losses for the day.

The total value of imports into Peru for the year 1900 was $33,121,631, an increase of $9,093,634 over 1899. The ecrcase in the importations of coal during the past year may be accounted for by the fact, that petroleum, which is very plentiful in Peru and which is brought to Callao at moderate cost, is superseding coal as a fuel, owing to the very high price of the latter.

PEKING, Jan. 4. -- The Dowager Empress has issued another edict displaying a desire to conciliate foreigners. She says that friendly relations with the Ministers should be resumed immediately on the court's return to Peking, wherefore it is desirable that the Emperor grant an audience, and she orders an early date to be fixed for the reception of the Ministers.
WOMEN who travel without the protection of man, useful in engaging passage, seeing about baggage, and in paying of bills, are not without compensation.

It is many years since the tanners, manufacturers, hide brokers, and leather men have had the same volume of business that they have had in the past twelve months. Since the early part of May tanners have had to refuse orders: and it is doubtful if you can pick out half a dozen leather men in the whole United States who have accepted orders for immediate delivery since that date.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- In to-night's Republican caucuses for the organization of the General Assembly the Hanna men secured control of the House and the Foraker men of the Senate. Some of the nominations for the latter were made without opposition, but in the House caucus there was a fight to a finish, and especially for the Speakership.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The preliminary estimate of Mr. Roberts, the Director of the Mint, on the production of gold and silver in the United States during the calendar year 1901, indicates only a slight gain over the production of the preceding year. The yield of Alaska fell off by about $1,000,000, Colorado made a slight gain in gold, and the other producers were nearly stationary.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 1. For the year 1901 total from ore shipments out of the Lake Superior region were 20,737,340 gross tons, or nearly 1,700,000 tons more than the year before, which had broken all prceeding records. In other words, the business of iron mining on Lake Superior was in the year just closed equal to all the life of the industry up to 1883, a period of twenty-eight long and eventful years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The success attending efforts of societies friendly to seamen in placing comfortable reading rooms along and near the water front has received public recognition and commendation from ex-District Attorney Philbin. Bishop Potter, Jacob Riis, and others familiar with their work.
LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Public feeling here has been deeply stirred by the alleged libels on British soldiers in South Africa, circulated on the Continent.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- One of the interesting pieces of gossip in military circles is that the Fourth Brigade is to be disbanded and the companies forming it are to be added to those of the Third Brigade. This would divide the State into three brigades, two in Greater New York and one for the rest of the State, the territory of the latter extending from Yonkers to Lake Erie.

CAIRO, Nov. 2. -- The passing year was on the whole a moderately prosperous one for Egypt. For the last few years there has been a steady progress in trade and commerce. The competing nations in the Egyptian market are chiefly England, the United States Germany, and France. The trade of the other European nationalities do not come up to anything like dangerous competition.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 5. -- In spite of the general decrease in trade, I am of the opinion that, aside from cotton goods, more merchandise was imported into China from the United States in the year 1900 than in 1899. It is impossible to give exact figures on this subject, as the publications of the imperial maritime customs, so far as regards the trade of the United States with China, are misleading.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Jan. 4. -- Because the only town clock in this place -- a timepiece with a reputation for Veracity -- has gone wrong, about half the population of Lockport is transacting business a half hour ahead of standard time. The big clock that has begun to lead a fast life is in the Post Office Arcade, opposite the general delivery window.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- The Third Signal Corps of this city and the Fourth Signal Corps of Buffalo were to-day disbanded by Adjt. Gen. Nelson F. Henry, under direction of Gov. Odell. This is in line with the policy of economy that Gov. Odell has begun for the current year.

United States Consul at Copenhagen. COPENHAGEN, Dec. 16. -- The chief interests of Denmark are agricultural and maritime. The chief exports, in order of value, are as follows: Butter, pork, eggs, beef, horses, hides, and skins. None of these, except the last, can be exported to the United States, as the latter is itself a large exporter of the same products.

HANKOW, China, Nov. 11. -- Hankow, China, is located 600 miles from the coast, on the north bank of the Yang-tse-Kiang River, at its junction with the Han River. It is called the mart of the eight provinces. It has nine regular lines of steamers running between this port and Shanghai, consisting of twenty-eight steamships.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having seen no reply to A. E. Lewis's letter from Milford, Penn., of Dec. 23. 1901, published in your paper, I believe that I may be able to answer, in part, some of his questions.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- An effort will soon be made to have a practical asphalt man elected to the Cuyler investigation committee now probing the affairs of the Asphalt Company of America. The resignation of Henry Tatnall has created a vacancy in the company. At an informal meeting to-day, several men representing large interests agreed to propose the name of A. L,. S. Shields as a successor to Mr. Tatnall.

To the Editor Of The New York Times: Accept my thanks for the assistance you are almost dally lending the anti-Boer cause by the publication of pro-Boer letters from many of your readers. A careful perusal of these epistles is hardly necessary to prove the entire lack of prejudice against the cruel English.
PEKING, Jan. 5. -- The Chinese capital, on the eve of the return of the Court, presents an animated and gaudy scene, probably not before equalled in its history.
Archbishop Corrigan, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, yesterday morning delivered the third of the series of sermons on Socialism which be commenced in October last.
Dr. Louis Albert Banks, at Grace Methodist Church, last night replied to the remarks concerning the prohibition movement made by Bishop Potter and Dr. Rainsford on Monday last at the Church Club.

There was no truce in the Seventh Congressional District fight yesterday. Mr. Belmont's headquarters were open from early in the forenoon until midnight and hundreds of political workers called and reported to Mr. Belmont or to Judge Daniel E. Finn. Montague Lessler, the Republican candidate, put in a hard day's campaigning on Staten Island, where he will also spend to-day.

Fire damaged the Tabernacle Methodist Episcopal Church in Greenpoint to the extent of about $20,000 last night, and incidentally threw into a panic about 100 men and women who were attending an Epworth League meeting in the basement of the edifice.

So far as can be judged by the record of the first Sunday under the new police administration, its policy in regard to the sale of drink on the Sabbath is to be substantially that of Mr. Low when he was Mayor of Brooklyn. Notorious resorts, and those that harbor the disorderly and the vicious, were strictly closed at midnight on Saturday night, and were not opened during the day.
To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to a letter in your columns on the canals of this State.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- During the eleven months ending with last November the course of the domestic trade of the United States was generally satisfactory.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 5. -- Illuminating gas caused the death of four persons here this morning, and sixteen others had narrow escapes. The dead are Anton C. Cheves, aged twenty-nine, a machinist; Mrs. cheves, aged twenty-one; their baby, and Mary Devida, aged eighteen.

The Fusion members of the Board of Aldermen will meet at 11:30 o'clock today to complete their caucus. At noon the Board of Aldermen will meet for the purpose of organization. When seen at his home last night, President Fornes said:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 5. -- Four thousand people attended a pro-Boer meeting in Gray's Armory this afternoon. There was enthusiastic applause for every expression of sympathy and encouragement for the Boers. An unexpected incident was the appearance of William Jennings Bryan, who was here for the day as the guest of Mayor Johnson.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a member of the S.P.C.A. and one deeply interested in the welfare of animals, may I be permitted to reply to the article in to-day's TIMES headed "Slippery Streets Cause Many Accidents"?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Senator Gallinger of New Hampshire is a strong supporter of the Administration's scheme of reciprocity with Cuba. Notwithstanding the fact that he is one of the most uncompromising protectionists in Congress, he favour tariff concessions to the Cubans. In stating his position this evening, he said:

Apart from seeming inadequacies in the Navy Department bill for the establishment of a National Naval Reserve, there is a sad fault to be found in it by all those interested in the splendid organizations of State Naval Militia. If Congress passes the bill without alteration, the Naval Militia will be ushered, out of existence -- indirectly, but none the less surely, "requested to resign."

Anybody who desired a drink, no matter in what portion of Manhattan and the Bronx and Brooklyn he happened to be, had no trouble in setting it yesterday, the first Sunday under the administration of Mayor Low and Police Commissioner Partridge. Paloons, east side, west side, and all over town, did the usual Sunday side-door business.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 5. -- Because his child was being weaned from the church of his faith David Leonard, a shoe merchant of Cutchogue, got a writ of habeas corpus to obtain possession of her. The writ was argued before Justice Wilmot Smith in a Special Term of the Supreme Court yesterday.

Particular attention was centred upon the German Emperor's new sailing yacht a short time ago, when it became known that an American firm or naval architects, Cary Smith Barbey of 35 Nassau Street, had been selected to design the imperial craft and to superintend its building in this country.

The recent expression of a well-defined business sentiment against everything resembling the "blind pool" and in favor of the fullest publicity in corporate management, and especially in the management of mergers, trusts, and consolidations, is bearing fruit. Papers of incorporation have just been filed in New Jersey for a corporation to own and operate the combined plants of an important industry which contains some new and interesting requirements.

The magisterial situation in Brooklyn was devoid of excitement yesterday, any trouble which might have arisen over the arraignment of prisoners having been avoided by an order issued by Commissioner Partridge to the police on Saturday, directing them to take all of their prisoners to the three local courts not involved in the squabble.

Columbia's preliminary work in rowing, cycling, track athletics, and lacrosse will be started this afternoon in the gymnasium. On account of Columbia's splendid showing at Poughkeepsie last year, rowing is attracting the greatest interest. For the present only the inexperienced men will be set to work learning the principles of Coach Hanlan's stroke on the rowing machines.

With Jan Kubelik as the star the concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with the prices raised to meet the financial demands of the violinist's manager, drew a crowd that compelled the ticket sellers to retire from business. Whatever may be said of Kubelik as a violinist, as a drawing card he is a wonder.

METUCHEN, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The marriage of Miss Margaret Evelyn Herron to Dr. Charles Venner Berghall, which was to have taken place next month, has been indefinitely postponed. Miss Herron is a sister of Prof. George D. Herron and the fact that she is not to be married as Planned is due indirectly to the assassination of President William McKinley.

MANILA, Jan. 5. -- Gen. J. Franklin Bell is conducting a vigorous campaign in Batangas Province. Every available soldier is in the field. The columns under the command of Cols. Wint and Dougherty are doing excellent work and driving the Filipinos in all directions. A number of the latter are fleeing to Tayabas Province, where the native constabulary is rendering valuable assistance in capturing men and rifles.

Though last week was a broken week -- business being interrupted by the New Year's holiday -- the developments in the stock market were clearly and decidedly along the lines of advancing prices. This, however, is only regarded as natural in view of the clearing away of the Northern Pacific difficulty and the certainty of ease in money for the next few months at least, now that the year has so happily been turned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to an article in your esteemed paper of this date on the above subject, your correspondent Mr. Herman Hauser seems to be well posted on some of the reasons that make the shortage of cars, but he does not refer to or mention any practical solution of the matter.

Chicago sportsmen have been roused to an unusual pitch of indignation over the sweeping condemnations made by Mayor Harrison upon the honesty of sports in general. Baseball, horse racing, and boxing came in for his particulat condemnation, and the Chicago sports have not had so great a bomb hurled into their midst in years.

Down on the lower east side among the crowded tenements there is a humorist who during the past few days has kept people guessing as to his identity. He has produced and freely circulated a strange circular reporting the existence of a water famine, and his printed words are a queer medley of Biblical lore, sociology, and National and municipal politics.

The view taken in our Annual Financial Supplement of our trade with China by the various well-informed writers who discuss it is at once hopeful and conservative. The actual trade for the past five years has shown a healthy growth, except so far as it was interrupted by the disturbances of last year.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- So strenuous has grown the competition between the Standard Oil Company and the many independent concerns now battling for the export trade, that the contestants are employing measures which closely resemble those used by the navies of the world in time of war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The William McKinley National Memorial Arch Association has drafted the following bill, which will be introduced in Congress this week, and supported by a petition signed by the members and also the members of the McKinley National Memorial Association.

The odor of illuminating gas which was perceptible throughout the entire building 358 West Forty-seventh Street during the morning hours of yesterday finally led to the discovery that one person in the flat occupied by Peter A Lynch was dead -- a baby -- that Lynch himself was dying, and that two other persons were in a very critical condition.

It was in the early hours of the morning yesterday that resolutions were adopted by the Gloucester Naval Command, No. 17, Spanish War Veterans, requesting the resignation of Harry Hauck, Quartermaster General of the State, in the order. The command met at 17 Court Street, Brooklyn. Hauck, about a year ago, got together some members and had resolutions adopted derogatory to Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment, who was a member.

How much or little blame attaches to the railroads for the present condition of congestion on all the important freight carrying lines is a question which admits of a good deal of discussion without promising to lead to very definite conclusions. When a marching column suddenly falls into confusion and becomes a mob, it is often difficult to say just who is at fault.

Deputy Police Commissioner Thurston established a precedent yesterday when he attended a fire in Walker Street. The fire was on the top floor of the seven-story building 88 to 90 Walker Street, occupied by Ruben Brothers, manufacturers of suspenders. Twenty-five persons, who were at work at the time, rushed down the six flights of stairs to the street when the alarm was given.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan 5. -- The people of Meridian, Miss., last night proved to Charles F. Ceilley of St. Louis, one of the organizers of the American Federation of Labor, that negro unions were not in keeping with Southern ideas. Ceilley has been in Meridian for several clays organizing all branches of trade into unions.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- State Controller Knight's annual report will go to the Assembly to-morrow evening. Its principal features are the following:...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- After a recess of almost three weeks, both houses of Congress will reconvene to-morrow. The principal item on the House programme for the Week is the Hepburn Isthmian Canal bill, which is the special order for Tuesday. No limit has been fixed as to the time for debate, but Mr. Hepburn (Rep., Iowa,) does not contemplate a prolonged discussion of it.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The atmosphere on the London Stock Exchange has been more cheerful since the beginning of the year than for a long while past. The activity which developed with the resumption of business Jan. 2 was greatly aided by the abundance of money with which a stringout market has recently and suddenly become flooded.

Arthur T. Hillebrand, the former Princeton athlete, has been selected as the successor of Phil King, as head football coach at the University of Wisconsin. Hillebrand was for two years Captain of both the baseball and the football teams at Princeton, and his selection was made at the instance of the retiring coach.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Impetus to the movement to establish the Jewish nice once more in Palestine was given to-night at a mass meeting of Zionists in the Medinah Temple Theatre. Two thousand Jews, most of them supporters of the plan to open again the "promised land," crowded the hall.

The third week of the season of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House began last night with one of those combinations which excite the masses to large outpourings of their savings. Mme. Sembrich and Mme. Calve appeared -- not together, for two operas were needed to furnish them opportu- nities -- but still in the same evening and for the same price of admission.

If the Democratic Senators intend to oppose Senator STRANAHAN'S bill in relation to the tax on mortgages they ought to read the measure. Senator DONNELLY, representing the minority, shows by this comment upon the bill that he is unfamiliar with its provisions:

A lively session of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union was held last night at the headquarters, 34 Union Square, at which those who had charge of dispensing patronage were attacked by representatives of districts that had not been cared for.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Senators and Representatives of the Pacific Coast who have been considering a bill for Chinese exclusion have perfected a measure which will be introduced in both Houses in a few days. It contains forty-five pages, and does not limit itself to any term of years, as did the Geary act.

The message of Mayor Low to the Board of Aldermen is practically an appeal to the people of the city to aid his administration in the work it has undertaken to do, by dealing in a frank and honest way with the mischievous practices that have grown up in the past and have been reduced to a system.

The first meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment under Mayor Low's administration was held yesterday in the Council Chamber in the City Hall. The first appropriation was $149,030 to purchase a school site at Essex and Norfolk Streets.

There will be no annual police dinner this year -- the last was at the Waldorf-Astoria in 1900, under the auspices of Chief William S. Devery -- and Col. John N. Partridge will not follow the example of Col. Michael C. Murphy and sanction his enrollment as an honorary member of the Police Endowment Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The United States Supreme Court to-day refused to interfere in the case of Capt. Oberlin M. Carter. The decision was rendered in the proceedings instituted by ex-Capt. Carter for the purpose of securing a writ of habeas corpus that would release him from prison at Leavenworth, Kan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Record-breaking prices in wheat set all grain jumping to-day.
