May wheat registered a net gain for the day of 1 1/4 cents, having made a new record for the crop, of $4 3/4, 1 cent above the previous record. May corn closed three-eighths to half a cent up, and May oats one-eighth to one-quarter of a cent higher.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The following correspondence was made public at the White House to-day:

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The prosperity and growth of the Alliance Francaise, which were expected to develop largely within a short time as a result of an announced gift of $1,000,000 from Robert Le Baudy, a Frenchman, are not likely to materialize to the extent supposed.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff was prevented by engagements in New York City from presiding at to-night's session of the Senate, and President pro tern. Timothy E. Ellsworth took his place. The Senators presented a large number of bills which introduced the measures recommended by the Governor.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Democrats in the Legislature came face to face with a Sunday opening bill to-night, and decided not to commit themselves definitely.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col., Jan. 6 -- The Colorado, State Bank, one of the oldest institutions in Grand Junction, has closed its doors. Some time ago the bank secured a loan of $30,000 from the Hanover National Bank of New York for the Colorado Sugar Company of this city. The New York bank recently forced the collection of the loan, thus compelling the local bank to suspend.

Sentiment in Wall Street was adversely affected at the commencement of business yesterday by suggestions of the likelihood of a resumption of gold exports at an early date, and of the continuing effect of Saturday's disappointing bank statement. As a result professional selling appeared in the general market at the opening and was continued uninterruptedly almost all day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Without consulting Secretary Long, President Roosevelt summoned Rear Admiral Schley to the White House to-day and held a conference with him for more than an hour. Immediately after the conference Admiral Schley sent for his counsel, Mr. Rayner, who will arrive in Washington to-morrow.

The Citizens' Insurance Company of this city, after being engaged in the fire insurance business for nearly sixty-five years, is now to be placed in voluntary liquidation. Its risks have been reinsured in the Phenix Insurance Company of Brooklyn.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Assemblyman McCullough to-night introduced a bill to regulate the price of illuminating gas in New York City. The measure provided that
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 6 -- Melbourne MacDowell, the actor who ended an engagement here yesterday, signed a sensational deposition to-day in Kansas City, Kan., in his suit against Clarence M. Brune, a theatrical manager who last season starred his wife, Minnie Tittel Brune, and MacDowell in Sardou's play, "Theodora."

"The Toreador," announced on the programme as "an entirely new and original musical play," was produced for the first time in New York at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, and it may be said that if it is not original it at least ought to be so, for no less than six collaborators assisted in putting it together.

The Coney Island Jockey Club has received fifty-seven entries for the Suburban Handicap, which is to be run on Saturday, June 14 next, which is six entries more than were received for the event last year. The number of entries for the various other stakes, with a comparison of the entries of last year, have also been made public, as has also the number of nominations received for the Futurity of 1904.

We greatly hope that Senator LODGE will suceeed in securing the enactment of the bill he has introduced for the reform of the Consular Service. It Is sound in principle. It is sorely needed. It is supported earnestly by the representatives of the most influential and authoritative commercial bodies in the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- The Philadel- phia market sagged and was dull until the coal stocks spurt began in New York, and then, influenced also by the declaration of the Jersey Central dividend, a better feeling was manifested. A heavy demand arose for the entire Reading group. The common after falling in the forenoon rallied 3/4 and the second preferred went up 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Lodge, (Rep., Mass.,) Chairman of the Committee on the Philippines, will introduce to-morrow a bill for a temporary government of the Philippines. The bill does not attempt to establish a new form of government in the islands, but confirms the action of President McKinley in creating a commission and ratifies the acts of that commission under the instructions of the President.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Senator John Raines to-night introduced a bill to provide for the discovery and taxation of interest-bearing or dividend-bearing evidence of indebtedness and securities. The bill provides for un annual tax of one-fifth of 1 per centum of the principal or par value of all such evidence of indebtedness or securities.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Money was in moderately good demand to-day and very large amounts changed hands in connection with the distribution of dividends and repayments of loans to the Bank of England. The supplies, however, were plentiful. Discounts were easier.

Secretary William Leary of the Fire Department established a new record in municipal affairs yesterday. He got Mayor Low to write an urgency message to the Board of Aldermen, and then he obtained from the board a unanimous vote putting through a resolution appropriating $19,000 for the use of the Fire Department without public letting.
Although some more or less important changes in the situation developed yesterday, the Magisterial snarl in Brooklyn was quite as tangled as ever last night.

The Trustees of Columbia University at their regular monthly meeting held yesterday afternoon in the library unanimously elected Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler President of the university. Dr. Butler has been Acting President since the resignation of Seth Low last October.

No argument was heard yesterday in the Supreme Court on the motion made by attorneys for A.G. Spalding to compel the Freedman faction in the National Baseball League to give security for costs on the ground that three of the clubs allied with Mr. Freedman were foreign corporations and could not be proceeded against in the event of their defeat.

PEKING, Jan. 6 -- The Chinese officials have requested the Ministers of the powers to keep the legation guards within their quarters to-morrow, in order to prevent the possibility of a collision between the Chinese and foreign troops. The Ministers will comply with the request.

Although the general course of prices in the outside market yesterday was upward, declines were more numerous than recently. This irregularity was accompanied by considerable activity, a number of the stocks being traded in and a few issues showing large totals. In a general way the outside market reflected the conditions prevailing on the board, and in few cases were the day's movements attributed to any specific cause.

The remarkable proclamation signed by nine American soldiers who are or were prisoners of war in the hands of the Filipinos shows us move vividly than anything that has happened before with what sort of enemies we are contending. It is lucky that the vanity of the Filipino brigand defeats his malice and his perfidy.

The block front on the east side of Broadway, between Eighty-fifth and Eighty-sixth Streets, will be transferred shortly to a corporation organized recently by W.J. Merritt. A twelve-story apartment hotel will be erected on the site. Title to the property is now held by Le Grand K. Pettit, who acquired it last February from Charles T. Barney.

Yesterday was the brave beginning of a very gay week. Mrs. Astor's ball was the notable event, and the dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Marshall C. Lefferts was a delightful affair. The morning was occupied with the Bagby musicale at the Waldorf-Astoria and with a number of receptions. There were dinners in the evening, and the opera presented a most brilliant spectacle.

The West End Association, at its monthly meeting held last night in the Hotel Endicott, indorsed the scheme of the Municipal Art Society for the improvement of the Columbus Circle at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. This scheme, which has already been described in the newspapers, contemplates the removal of the tracks from the centre of the area and throwing them into a circle.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The old fight over prohibition of pigeon shooting in this State for sporting purposes is to be revived.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Word was received in this city to-day from Philadelphia to the effect that representatives of the Asphalt Company of America favored the appointment of George M. Barnes of this city, Vice President of the Commercial Bank, an automobile manufacturer, and a man of varied business in- terests in Syracuse, to fill the vacancy on the Cuyler Investigating Committee caused by the resignation of Henry Tatnall.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent and New York funds sold at 5 and 16 cents' premium. On call, money rules from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent.; time, 4 1/2 to 5 1/2 per cent. In business paper the best names still sell at 5 per cent., and corporation paper at 4 1/2 per cent.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- The Times, in an editorial article to-day, says that wonder, not unmixed with alarm, is aroused by the results of the energy and capacity displayed by the people of the United States during the last two or three years. The impression appears to have been created in many quarters that Europe is in the presence of a new and irresistible economic force, before which other economic organisms are helpless.

With one minute to spare, ex-Congressman John J. Adams yesterday secured a stay from Supreme Court Justice Maddox in Brooklyn which prevented Referee Bankson T. Morgan from delivering the deed of the Empire City Race Track, the property of the late ex-Corporation Counsel William H. Clark, to Frank Farrell and associates, who on Dec. 26 purchased the property for $218,000 under foreclosure proceedings.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- As the agent in London who has been remitting half the pay of the crew of the steamer Ban Righ (recently renamed the Libertador) to relatives of the men, has received orders from Martinique to stop the payments, it is presumed here that the British crew are no longer aboard the vessel.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6 -- The market to-day extended itself over a wide range of securities, and, with very few exceptions, tended upward. United Railways improved on reports of a defeat of the ordinance in the City Council for the creation of an opposition company. International Trust advanced three points on anticipation of the beginning of dividend on the stock during the present month.

Ferdinand Poggenburg and Mark Muldaur were the contestants last night in the second game of the Amateur Billiard Club's tourney, held in Daly's Broadway Billiard Rooms. Poggenburg conceded 50 points to Muldaur, playing 300 points at 14-inch balk-line, two shots in, and ran out the limit in an excellent game in thirtytwo innings.

The annual dinner of the New York Association of Williams College Alumni was held, last night at Delmonico's, about 130 graduates of the college being present. The dining hall was handsomely decorated with flags and royal purple, the college colors, and a Hungarian band furnished the music.

The argument for trade reciprocity with Cuba rests first of all upon moral obligation. The President and the Secretary of War give prominence and emphasis to this consideration in recommending that action be taken. "Elsewhere," says the President in his message, "I have discussed the question of reciprocity.
The second of Mr. Samuel Franko's matinee concerts of eighteenth century music took place yesterday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre. The programme was as follows:

The meeting of the City Committee of the Citizens' Union on Monday evening was marked by proceedings which must have left a very disagreeable impression upon most readers of the reports of it, including, we suppose, a majority of the members of the Union.

The difficulty which the statisticians are experiencing in accounting for the fact that the farmers of the corn belt are finding so little apparent inconvenience from the shortage of their important crop would seem to indicate that they are not as much injured as it was expected they would be.

There is a bill now being debated, though very scantily, in Congress, entitled "An Act Temporarily to Provide Revenue for the Philippine Islands, and for Other Purposes." The "other purposes" are obvious and they are not nice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Census Bureau to-day issued a report announcing that the population of the entire United States, including all outlying possessions, was 84,233,069 in the census year 1900. This is itemized as follows:

London Comedy by Sydney Grundy Provokes Laughter and Aids Digestion. The ideal toward which managers of theatres yearn with a passionate intensity worthy of a better cause is a play that will compel an audience to laugh just enough to promote digestion and make them tell their friends next day that they were amused.
The Armory Board held a session yesterday. Several bills for architects' fees were offered by Messrs. Horgan Slattery, the Tammany architects. After two or three had been passed Mayor Low said:

-- Dr. G.A. SOPER of this city, writing in The Medical News, supplements the report of the Isthmian Canal Commission by an exhaustive comparison of health conditions along the Panama and the Nicaragua routes, as they affect both the building and the maintenance of an interoceanic canal.

The appointment of John E. Eustis as Park Commissioner for the Borough of the Bronx has been welcomed by the Harlem River oarsmen, who now have hopes of obtaining the improvement of the water front of McComb's Dam Park, in front of which a number of the local, clubs have their houses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A serious clash has occurred between American sailors of the United States gunboat Vicksburg and the Russian soldiery at Niu-Chwang, China. There have been three fights, and as a result one Russian soldier is reported wounded.

Gov. Odell has answered the appeal of the Riverside and Morningside Heights Association from the refusal of State Excise Commissioner Cullinan to consent to the bringing of actions for the revocation of the licenses of certain "Little Coney Island" saloons, upon evidence obtained by the association's detectives.

A. G. Spalding, the enjoined President of the National Baseball League, made the interesting and somewhat startling announcement yesterday that he was willing to retire permanently from baseball and its annoying controversies. So radical a move from the predominating factor in the present baseball warfare was not made without some qualifying considerations.

Those who are in the habit of observing musical affairs needed only the sudden outbreak of bad weather yesterday to inform them that the Kneisel Quartet was somewhere near. That such a conclusion would have been justified was proved by the fact that the organization gave its second evening concert at Mendelssohn Hall last night.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 7. -- The dissatisfaction of many of the stockholders in the Banta-Hill Consolidated Mines Company with the way the promoters have been handling the affairs the past year was vehemently expressed at a meeting held in Room 16, at 100 Broadway, the office of Andrew Foster Higgins, a railroad President, yesterday afternoon.

The stock market yesterday was distinctly heavy throughout the day as the result of pressure brought to bear upon it by a number of the leading professional operators who were loud in their predictions that the earnings of the United States Steel Corporation for the quarter ended Dec. 31 would be decidedly disappointing, and much below general expectations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The object of Admiral Schley's visit to the White House yesterday was to request the President to entertain and consider an appeal for the reversal of the action of Secretary Long and the disapproval of the majority judgment of the court of inquiry. The interview was satisfactory, the President granting the Admiral's request.

ST. LOUIS. Jan. 7. -- Six masked men entered the National Stock Yards Bank, north of East St. Louis, III., last night, and after capturing and gagging the two night watchmen and firemen at the plant and blowing open the vaults with dynamite, obtained $3,000 in coin and currency, with which they fled.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- The battle between the old and new schools of healing which enlivened the Legislature last session is about to be renewed. This morning Senator Brackett of Saratoga County introduced a bill to legalize the practice of osteopathy. Doctors of prominence all over the United States took part in the discussion, either 1.1 person or by communication.

Four hundred lawyers, bankers, merchants, politicians, and clergymen were present at the dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night to R. Fulton Cutting President of the Citizens Union, and Dr. Elgin R. L. Gould, the new City Chamberlain and Treasurer of the Citizens' Union during the recent campaign.

PEKING, Jan. 7. -- The entry of the Emperor and Empress Dowager into Peking to-day was the most remarkable episode in the annals of Kwang-Su's reign, save the fright of the Court when Peking was bombarded by the allied forces.

Hedwig Lange, the leading lady of the Irving Place Theatre, had her benefit last night. She had chosen for this occasion a new play in four acts by Hermann Katsch, entitled, "The Colleague." The programme designated this piece as a drama. It was really a tragedy a la Sudermann, with a little more comedy, a little more light and shade instead of a continuous gloom.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- It is announced in a dispatch from Peking that an Imperial edict has been issued, conferring yellow jackets on Viceroy Yuan-Shi-Kai and on Tsen-Chun-Hsuan, Governor of Shen-Si. who protected the Chinese rulers in their flight from Peking.

William H. Rose, who owns a saloon at the Hackensack Bridge on the Paterson Plank Road, Secauous, was standing behind his bar on Monday afternoon when the door was opened and a strange man came in and asked for some whisky and a cigar. Rose produced the articles and the stranger helped himself to a generous drink and took a good ciger.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Congressman Cooper of Wisconsin, Chairman of the House Committee on Insular Affairs, today introduced a bill giving a complete form of civil governmont for the Philippines to begin Jan. 1, 1904, with a Governor appointed by the President, a Legislature of two houses, and with two Philippine Commissioners to represent the Filipino people at Washington.

For the first time since he became Police Commissioner of Greater New York Col. John N. Partridge yesterday presided at the trials of delinquent policemen at Brooklyn Police Headquarters. As a trial judge he very favorably impressed the erring bluecoats who came before him. There was an entire absence of bullying or badgering, and the utmost fairness was observed in disposing of the cases.

Assistant District Attorney Schurman yesterday had scarcely opened the case of the People against Thomas McGurk, accused of the murder of Gottlieb Saehr on July 17 last, when he was interrupted by the second of the jurymen. McGurk, seventy years of age, the oldest man, according to the authorities in the Criminal Court Biulding who had ever been tried for murder, ashen-faced, with his eyes wildly staring through his glasses, gasped as the juryman spoke.

Earnings of $84,779,298 for the first nine months of the United States Steel Corporation's existence were announced at the quarterly meeting of the Board of Directors yesterday afternoon. The earnings for the last quarter were $20,751,615, the largest earnings for three months in the history of the corporation.
ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- A counter move to the action of the excise conference in New York yesterday was made here to-day by Assemblyman Phipps of Orleans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- When a member of the Ways and Means Committee of the House was asked to-day how the fight for reciprocity with Cuba was progressing, he said:

Yesterday there were musicales, dinners, and dances. The dinners were principally those which preceded the Junior Cotillion, and the guests of which went afterward to the dance. The Fortnightly also had its regular meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria. This evening the Wednesday Cotillon has its meeting, and there are also many dinners.

In NICHOLAS MURRAY BUTLER Columbia University gets a President with whose character, ability, and tendencies the Trustees are entirely familiar. So far as these are known to the public they justify the choice.

For many months past jobbers and wholesale merchants in various parts of the commercial district have been receiving complaints from their out-of-town customers regarding shortages in shipments. The country merchants kept sending word that various cases of merchandise invoiced as containing so many pieces of goods were upon arrival short from one to three parcels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Attorney General Wallace B. Douglas of Minnesota filed to-day in the United States Supreme Court the bill of complaint in the case of the State of Minnesota, complainant, against the Northern Securities Company, defendant. It is a long document, about 10,000 words, covering 32 pages of printed matter.
Montague Lessler yesterday defeated Perry Belmont for Congress by 394 plurality at the special election held in the Seventh Congressional District to choose a successor to Nicholas Muller, resigned.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7. -- There was a general revival of interest in the Philadelphia market to-day, and the range of trading was the widest in over a month. In the face of the weakness of the Reading group, nearly everything was higher. A remarkable demand arose for long-neglected Cambria Steel.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- With the addition of six millions in Government dividends the supplies of money in the market to-day were abundant, in spite of further heavy repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts had an easier tendency and were expected to continue the ease. Business on the Stock Exchange began with a fairly good tone, but the transactions were inconsiderable.

It is a pity, and not a credit, that the charter should have made no provision whatever for municipal embellishment. We do not forget the Art Commission. But the functions of that body are purely negative. It has power to reject any work of art, including public buildings, of which it deems the design unworthy.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Assemblyman Balnbridge Colby of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District of New York will to-morrow Introduce a bill providing for an appropriation of $300,000 for a New York building at the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, to be held in St. Louis in 1903. In accordance with the recommendation of Gov. Odell the bill will also give authority for the appointment of a commission to take charge of the State's exhibits.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The House is handling the canal question just as everybody expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a reception at the White House to-night in honor of the Diplomatic Corps. It was the first formal evening levee of the season, and the first at which President and Mrs. Roosevelt have been the host and hostess. A full representation of the Diplomatic Corps made the affair notably brilliant.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- Prosecutions against all the big packing house concerns in the West for violations of the provision of the inter-State commerce law against receiving preferential rates are contemplated by the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- Assemblyman John P. Ahern of Troy, who yesterday introduced a bill providing for a State board of censors for actors and plays, to-day announced that in a few days he would send out a circular calling upon prominent peo-people interested in the stage to come to Albany and give their opinions upon his measure.

Something like order was brought out of chaos yesterday in the Magisterial situation in Brooklyn. The legal phase of the matter remained unsettled, but definite steps looking toward a final determination of the questions at issue were taken late in the afternoon, when lawyers representing both sides got together and discussed ways and means of ending the trouble.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7. -- For three months Yale has had a Dean of her Divinity School who was not an ordained minister.

Fencing begins its season of activity this month, and besides a number of informal club competitions, which will be held in the Fencers' Club and the New York Athletic Club, the first event under the auspices of the Amateur Fencers' League of America will be given on Jan. 21 in the New York Athletic Club.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- Splendid learn work and excellent ability at throwing goals from all parts of the court gave the basket ball team of the Fifteenth Separate Company a hard-won victory tonight over the Columbia University five. For the first ten minutes Columbia kept ahead by the score of 6 to 5, but there the collegians let up, and the half closed with the score 22 to 5.

It is very easy for the light-minded to make fun of Mr. BELMONT'S defeat in the Seventh District. Yet the result of the voting at the special election for Congress held in that District on Tuesday has a serious meaning for those Democrats who still take an interest in the welfare of their party and cherish hopes of its regeneration.

It now looks as if the Brooklyn Magistrates' muddle would be settled amicably. Several conferences were held by the contending men and their numerous lawyers, and it was decided finally to leave the matter entirely in the hands of the Supreme Court.

In pursuit of its endeavor to open new fields of work for the artists, the National Arts Club has brought together a collection of works of art and other objects relating to the church which will remain to the end of the month.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 8. -- John J. McGraw, manager of the Baltimore Baseball Club, and Miss M. Blanche Sindall of Baltimore were married in this city this evening.
The New York Board of Trade and Transportation held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon in its rooms at 203 Broadway. This Board of Directors was elected to serve until January, 1905:...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- President Roosevelt and party occupied a box at the Columbia Theatre to-night to witness Stuart Robson in "The Henrietta." Accompanying the President were Mrs. Roosevelt, Mrs. Hanna, and Miss Carew, Mrs. Roosevelt's sister.

Thomas McGurk, feeble and scared, sat in the witness chair yesterday in Part I., Criminal Division, of the Supreme Court, to tell the story of his killing Gottlieb Saehr on July 17 last. His thin hands trembled and his voice was weak until he began to tell the exact circumstances of the murder, when he gathered himself together and earnestly stated in a clear voice:

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Gov. Odell's recommendation that some method be devised whereby the country school districts shall receive more support from the State was acted on by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee to-day.

The entire block front on Central Park West, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, extending 225 feet on the formel and 200 feet on the latter, has been sold. The nine lots on the Sixty-second Street side of the plot are sold by Justice P. Henry Dugro. On the Sixty-third Street side, the seller of the 150 feet frontage, beginning at the Central Park West corner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the proceedings of the Academy of Medicine a few nights ago are correctly reported, the public should feel grateful to be informed ex cathedra that the disease which killed 9,396 people in Greater New York last year is not such a serious matter after all, and that "phthisiophobia" is the stigma of ignorance or the result of a disordered imagination.

Snow that at 5 o'clock in the afternoon had reached a depth of 1 1/4 inches fell in New York yesterday. The fall was at times almost blinding, but it was nevertheless what might be termed a pleasant storm, as it was not accompanied by low temperature. The electric car service was not hindered to any great extent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- The National bowling tournament, which will be held here during the week beginning Jan. 20, promises to be one of the biggest affairs of the kind ever held. While the entries are not all in, there are at the present time over fifty five-men teams, about 100 two-men teams entered, and individual entries will reach the 200 mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- Bennie Monroe of Memphis, Tenn., defeated "Charlie" Turville of Philadelphia in a fifteen-mile motor-paced race at the Second Regiment Armory to-night by 2 1/2 laps. Monroe's time was 26:54 3-5.

A very agreeable bit of entertainment was provided at the Madison Square Theatre last evening in the production of the first act of Edmond Rostand's comedy, "The Romanesques," which preceded the regular bill, "Sweet and Twenty."

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 8. -- Stephen M. Ga Nun of the firm of Ga Nun Parsons, opticians, of New York, was in the second car from the rear, along with his son, Wilbur, aged sixteen, and his daughter, Marybelle, aged fifteen. They were sitting in the middle of the car on the west side. Mr. Ga Nun lives in Greenwich. He said last night:

Prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday moved uniformly downward in the morning, under the lead of the United States Steel stocks, and just as uniformly upward in the afternoon following upon aggressive buying in Union Pacific and Sugar, which advanced the former stock nearly three points from the low for the day and the latter over four points.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- Money was quoted at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent. and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $26,485,968; balances, $2,133,417. On call money rules from 4 1/2, to 5 per cent. for four to six months, though the very choicest loans would probably find buyers under 4 1/2 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Mr. Shackleford (Dem., Mo.) opened the second day's debate on the Nicaraguan Canal bill in the House. He spoke in advocacy of its passage.
BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- In the Reichstag to-day Count von Stolberg-Wernigerode (Conservative) denounced the recent references of Mr. Chamberlain, the British Colonial Secretary, to the Germany Army.
ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Assemblyman Blackwell of Kings County to-day introduced a bill which provides that the City of New York shall supply the members of the police force with uniforms and insignia.

Stricken at the council table in the performance of deliberative and advisory duties for which his long experience and remarkable powers of sound judgment gave him so high a degree of fitness, MARCELLUS HARTLEY may be said to have died as the wise man might wish to die; not after a period of pain and in weakness, but with the harness on, in the fullness of his powers, and in attendance upon his daily tasks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- In the Senate this morning, Mr. Elisworth again presided in the absence of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, who is still in Brooklyn. Senator Higgins, Chairman of the Finance Committee, reported favorably on a number of the recess appointments by Gov. Odell. All the appointments were confirmed.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- The State Board of Charities met here to-day. The board had under consideration the Governor's recommendation to abolish the existing Boards of Managers of State insane asylums, and the substitution of Visiting Boards for each district, to be appointed by the Governor annually.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 8. -- The Queen's University hockey team from Kingston. Ontario, met its first defeat in the United States to-night at Daquesne Garden in one of the fastest and cleanest games seen here for a long time. The All Stars of Pittsburg, who had retired from regular playing, were responsible for the visitors' downfall. The score was 2 to 1, all made in the second half.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- When Henry Villard died he left, in addition to the bequests to his children and friends, a number of gifts to various charitable institutions of New York City. Under the old laws these institutions were exempt from taxation, but under the laws of 1900, however, bequests to all institutions are taxable.
The Trustees of the New York Public Library held their regular monthly meeting yesterday afternoon at the Astor Building in Lafayette Place. John Bigelow presided.

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The speech from the throne, read by the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, at the opening of the Prussian Diet to-day, took a gloomy view of the economic situation. It pointed cut that the revenue from the State railroads in 1901 fell considerably short of the estimates, and that the whole results of the financial year were disappointing.

Andrew Freedman gave no indication yesterday that he was going to retire from baseball, and thereby be one of the three men whose retirement from the game would meet Spalding's proposition half way, and thus bring about Spalding's voluntary retirement from active participation in the National League.

DETROIT, Jan. 8. -- On petition of Henry A. Everett, which was filed in the United States Circuit Court of this district, Judge Swan to-day appointed Manager A.F. Edwards of the Detroit and Toledo Shore Line Electric Railroad receiver of that road.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before writing upon the subject in mind I must commend your paper in the highest terms for opening to the public its columns for the free discussion of subjects of public interest. These subjects are read by us (pro bono publico) with unusual interest, and through them thoughtful public opinion is crystallized.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Frank Brainard, representing the New York Produce Exchange, and Henry B. Hebert, President of the Canal Association of Greater New York, had a conference with Gov. Odell to-day about his recommendations for canal legislation. When seen after the conference Mr. Brainard said:

Fifteen persons were killed and two score severely injured as a result of a rear-end collision in the Park Avenue railroad tunnel, at Fifty-sixth Street, yesterday morning at 8:20 o'clock. Unaccountable blunders of an engineer, who disregarded signals, which he says he did not see, are held to be responsible for the accident -- the worst railroad disaster that ever occurred on Manhattan Island.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- Money was abundant to-day, and the indebtedness to the Bank of England was practically liquidated. The demand was good. Discounts were quiet. There was some uncertainty regarding the future, as the heavy collection of revenues for the last quarter of the year will possibly materially affect the money market.

The mantle of the versatile and industrious HARBURGER has fallen upon the shoulders of more than one member of the present Legislature, and the first of the annual crop of cheap gas bills has already blossomed in Mr. MCCULLOUGH'S bill, introduced into the Assembly, making 65 cents the maximum price for illuminating gas sold in any of the boroughs of New York.

PEKING, Jan. 8. -- While the casualties in the fighting at Niu-Chwang between American sailors and Russian soldiers are trifling up to date, the matter has resulted in unpleasantly strained relations between the American, Russian, and British authorities there. The Washington and St. Petersburg Governments are now endeavoring to arrange matters so that there may be no further friction at Niu-Chwang.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- Senator Slater to-day introduced an employers' liability bill. The bill was drafted by a committee appointed by the State convention of labor organizations. Senator Slater said, and was in accordance with the ideas of the Federation of Labor on the subject.

At a few minutes before 11 o'clock the bodies of the dead taken from the wreck began to arrive at the East Fifty-first Street Station. Several trips were made by two patrol wagons, and when all were there it was found that fourteen men and one woman were numbered on the roster of the dead.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- A wealthy Mauritian resident of Paris, says the correspondent of The Times at that place, has just died, leaving to the Louvre an important collection of pictures by Corot, Delacroix, Vroyon, Millet, Diaz, and other modern artists, and a number of bronzes by Barye.

Isidor Straus, President of the Educational Alliance, was the chief speaker at the annual meeting of the Both Israel Hospital Association, which was held in the auditorium of the Alliance last night, and was devoted chiefly to the new Both Israel Hospital at Jefferson and Cherry Streets, which has been erected at a cost exceeding $200,000, and now only lacks furnishing.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 8. -- Invitations have been sent out by Dr. C. Elsom, Director of the Wisconsin Gymnasium, to the large Western universities asking them to send teams to participate in a gymnastic meet at Madison on March 22. The institutions expected to compete are Minnesota, Chicago, Michigan, Illinois, Iowa, and Beloit.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Senator Hobart Krum, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, this morning expressed the opinion that the tax measure introduced by Senator Raines, which contemplated the taxation of all interest-bearing securities, including bonds, mortgages, notes, certificates or indebtedness, and in fact every conceivable form of paper bearing interest, would meet the fate it met a year ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note with interest that the question of one-cent postage for letters, which has been agitated for some few years past, has now been practically abandoned for the very good reason that the adoption of such a plan would create a large deficit in the revenues of the Post Office Department, which I see has been estimated at not less than $35,000,000.

PEKING, Jan. 8. -- All the evidence indicates that the Emperor is now more completely under the domination of the Dowager Empress than he was before the Court went into exile. Several high officials were received in audience to-day, and at these audiences the Emperor filled the role of a figurehead.

Upon the order of Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court subpoenas were issued yesterday calling for an examination of the Directors of the Amalgamated Copper Company who reside in New York. Those who fall under the order of the court are Henry H. Rogers, P.J. McIntosh, William G. Rockefeller, Frederic P. Olcott, Robert Bacon, James Stillman, Anson R. Flower, and Leonard Lewisohn.

Activity in the outside market yesterday was confined to a very few stocks, and the total for the day was the smallest since the beginning of the year. As a whole the market was weaker than it has been, and, although here and there a net gain showed at the close, quotations as a rule were fractionally lower.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 8. -- Arthur P. Gorman and Chairman Murray Vandiver of the Democratic State Central Committee were selected as the Democratic nominees for United States Senator and State Treasurer, respectively, at the Democratic caucus held to-night. Senator German's selection was unanimous and enthusiastic.

THE NEW YORK TIMES'S Sunday edition was a wonderful publication. In addition to the usual news pages and magazine supplement, there was the annual financial review, forty-eight large pages, crowded with interesting articles on financial and industrial topics from the pens of men who are recognized as authorities upon the subjects on which they wrote.

The killing of fifteen human beings and the maiming of many more in the Park Avenue tunnel of the New York Central Railroad yesterday awakens both the public horror and the public indignation. That men and women should be ground to pieces in this way in the very heart of the city while going about their daily vocations passes understanding and tolerance.

Probably there never was before, in the history of the world, so melancholy a "triumphal return" of a ruler to his capital as that which has just been executed by the majesty of China. Whether we take the majesty to be incarnated in the Emperor or the Empress Dowager, the humiliation of the dynasty was not to be disguised from any individual of the kneeling crowd of Pekingese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Senate did not meet to-day until 2 o'clock, an adjournment having been taken yesterday until that hour in order that Senators might have an opportunity to attend the wedding of Mr. Foraker's daughter.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- Perhaps after all the greatest suffering occasioned by the tragedy in the Central tunnel was borne to-day in this little town where live the friends and loved ones of almost every victim. There is scarcely a street in the place on which at least one family is not either mourning for its dead or ministering to the wants of the injured.
Graphic accounts of their sensations and experiences and of incidents to which the disaster in the Park Avenue tunnel gave rise were recounted by survivors and those who went to their assistance.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League on the Harlem Republican Club alleys last night the home team won two of three games with the West Side Republican Club bowlers. The match between the Century Wheelmen and the Harlem Wheelmen in the same series was postponed because the former team was scheduled to bowl in the Columbia League also.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Bernard Stark, State Mediator of Industrial Disputes, agreed upon as arbiter in the long-pending dispute between Wichert Gardiner, shoe manufacturers of Brooklyn and 500 of their employes, has decided in favor of the employers.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Boston is still sending large quantities of rum to the natives of Africa. The schooner Alice J. Crabtree was off Nantasket outward bound for the Dark Continent to-day, heavily laden with a liquid cargo. The Lillian Woodruff, which had previously cleared from this port with a similar cargo and with a like destination, was reported yesterday morning as having arrived in distress at St. Vincent, Cape Verde Islands.
ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Controller Miller gave a hearing to-day in a test case growing out of the law passed by the Legislature of 1901 taxing the surplus of savings banks.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The stinging rebuke administered to Mr. Chamberlain by Chancellor von Bulow in the Reichstag on Wednesday as a result of Mr. Chamberlain's references to the conduct of the German Army in the war with France has caused intense and widespread irritation here, and has markedly increased the bitterness of Anglo-German relations.

At a recent meeting of the Board of Directors of the Consolidated Railway, Electric Lighting and Refrigerating Company a motion was carried calling for the resignation of Isaac L. Rice, President of the company, and, it is said, for that of other officials of the company as well.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 9. -- Gen. Funston returned on the Warren to-day. When asked to give his impressions of the condition of the Philippine Islands, he said he could not do so, as he had been three months in a hospital. Besides, he was familiar only with his own district.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- The will of William P. Cochran of Yonkers, the carpet manufacturer, was filed here to-day. The testator leaves to his wife all his household goods, horses, and carriages, the family residence in Yonkers, and a life estate in the family residence at 5 East Forty-fifth Street, New York.

A six-car elevated train, propelled by electricity, with Edwin and Howard Gould and a large number of distinguished engineers and railroad men aboard, was run yesterday afternoon over the tracks of the Second Avenue Elevated Railroad from South Ferry to One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street.

It is quite probable that the Directors of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad feel much aggrieved at the outburst of popular indignation against themselves occasioned by the slaughter of passengers in the Park Avenue tunnel. No doubt they are greatly shocked and regret the incident exceedingly.

Senator AMBLER -- Fixing standard of measure for buying small fruits as the quart, which shall contain, when even full, sixty-seven cubic inches; the pint, which when even full, shall contain thirty-three and one-half cubic inches, and the hair pint, which, when even full, shall contain sixteen and three-quarters cubic inches.

A dinner for the special consideration of the excise law and the question of Sunday opening was given last evening at the Reform Club. The large banquet hall, where the dinner was held, was crowded to the doors by members and their friends, and as soon as the speaking began members crowded into the gallery and listened attentively to the speaking.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Senator Dietrich (Rep.) of Nebraska made a proposition to-day concerning tariff concessions to the Cubans. This, very likely, will be accepted by the various interests which are regarded as entitled to consideration in the settlement of the questions involved. Mr. Dietrich comes from a beet sugar State, and speaks as a representative of beet raisers and beet sugar manufacturers.

Some of the leading financial interests of this city, Chicago, and Boston are reported to be large holders of the stock of the Sovereign Hank of Canada, now in process of organization, with a capital of $2,000,000. The Standard Trust Company and Wilson Stephens are among those interested.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The Street Cleaning Department of the new municipal administration had its first chance yesterday to perform one of its most important functions, that of the removal of snow. The fall of Wednesday, though continuing for ten hours, piled up but two inches on the city streets, an inch less than the measure which calls for the aid of the contractor for snow removal.

Yesterday was crowded with good things for society. These included the dinner and musicale at Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt's, the dinner at Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs's, the dinner dance at Mrs. George Crocker's, the dance for Miss May Haddan, and dinners given by Mrs. Daniel S. Lament at the Metropolitan Club annex, by Mrs. Howland Pell, by Mrs. D. Henry Knowlton, and others, and an afternoon reception by Mrs. Frederick J. de Peyster.

The second notable private entertainment of the week was given last evening by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at her residence, 608 Fifth Avenue. It was a dinner, followed by, a musicale. The list of guests comprised the names of the majority of the most fashionable set in New York, and the artists who played and sang for the musicale were the most noted stars of the musical season.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The Quaker member of the Senate, William Willets Cocks of Old Westbury, Suffolk County, is after the Vanderbilts, Goulds, Whitneys, and other equally well-known automobilists and will endeavor to have a law passed regulating the speed of automobiles and making it a misdemeanor, punishable by both fine and imprisonment, to operate the machines faster than the rate provided by law.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- Heavy profit taking in the Readings forced the common and second preferred down to-day, and the stocks' transactions made three-quarters of the market. The weakness was not felt to any serious extent in other departments, and the greater part of the list maintained the strength acquired yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Henry H. Savage of Trenton, N.J., a sophomore in the university, has smallpox. The cause of his illness was discovered last night. The house was immediately quarantined. Eleven students who roomed in the building are confined, and every precaution is being taken to prevent the spread of the disease.

Perez M. Stewart, the new Superintendent of Buildings, and John B. McDonald, the rapid transit contractor, were the guests of honor at the second annual dinner of the Contractors' Protective Association, which was held at Shanley's last night.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Admitting that his picture was in the Rogues' Gallery, and that at one time in his life he had been familiar with the "lowest depths of New York opium joints." yet pleading for mercy from the court, Franklin J. Moses, ex-Governor of South Carolina, received sentence in the Municipal Court here to-day for the larceny of an overcoat.

At the annual meeting of the Saratoga Racing Association, held at the office, Windsor Arcade, Forty-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon, the old Board of Directors was re-elected for the ensuing year, as follows: William C. Whitney, F.R. Hitchock, H.K. Knapp, Andrew Miller, R.T. Wilson, Jr., W.W. Worden, Perry Belmont, J.R. Alexandra, T. Hitchoek, Jr., Philip J. Dwyer, J.G. Follansbec, J.H. Bradford, and J.G. Heckscher.

The dispute between the Brooklyn Magistrates over title to office is to be settled speedily and orderly through the courts. This was definitely determined upon late yesterday afternoon when word was received from Attorney General Davies at Albany consenting to the bringing of a quo warranto proceeding in the case.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 9. -- The removal of two vans of furniture from the barn on the country seat of the late Frederick H. Benedict, at Cove Neck, near the residence of President Roosevelt, is probably the beginning of a long legal battle. Mr. Benedict was killed in an automobile accident in October last.

More fuel was thrown upon the controversial fires of baseball yeaterday, and as a result the flames flared up with greater energy in various sections of the wordy bonfire that continues to hold the gaze of all baseball enthusiasts interested in the future of the National League. The fire of words still keeps warm, but thus far hardly anything has been produced but ashes.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5c premium. Exchanges, $32.883.563: balances, $1,184,211. Call money still rules at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent., mostly at the latter figure. There is a good demand for loans from country banks, and trustees amd private lenders are particularly rich in funds.
ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The conflict between the State Board of Charities and Gov. Odell has now become an open one and interesting developments are promised.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The public press has suggested that President Roosevelt request ex-President Cleveland to represent this Government at the approaching coronation of his Majesty Edward VII., King of Great Britain and Ireland, Emperor of India, Australasia, South Africa, Egypt, and all parts adjacent.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Messrs. Fletehel (Rep., Minn.,) and Lassiter (Dem., Va.,) were the two members of the House who voted against the Hepburn Canal bill.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Money was in fair demand in the market to-day. The canceling of indebtedness to the Bank of England materially lessened the supplies and made rates firmer. Discounts were steadier and there was less disposition to allow quotations to fall.

In the course of the trial yesterday of four young men charged with assault in the second degree, Recorder Goff turned the case into one of investigating the policemen who had brought charges against the prisoners.

Ralph Cohen of 12 East Ninety-fifth Street, Manhattan, and Mrs. Ellen Dingelstedt of 614 River Street, Hoboken, who were arrested in Jersey City on Tuesday charged with conspiring to defraud the Title Guarantee and Trust Company by securing a loan, on property at 242 Ogden Avenue, were yesterday arraigned before Police Justice Hoos.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- Herr Richter, who is regarded even by the Ministers as knowing as much about economic Questions as any statesman in Germany, entertained the Reichstag several hours to-day with ridicule of Germany's colonial policy. While, he said, the simplest and most necessary home needs were neglected, anything demanded on behalf of the colonies was voted enthusiastically, under the illusion that such action increased the greatness of the empire abroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Senate confirmed the nominations of Leslie M. Shaw for Secretary of the Treasury and Henry C. Payne for Postmaster General in to-day's executive session. Before the latter's name was passed upon favorably there was considerable discussion of his connection with the various schemes in which Government officials had been interested for getting a monopoly of mining privileges on the Uintah Reservation in Utah.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Secretary Root gave an interesting exposition of the condition of affairs in the Philippines, together with the outlook for replacing military with civil rule, before the House Committee on Military Affairs to-day. The hearing was on the Army Appropriation bill. No exact statement of Mr. Root's remarks was given out, but the following is understood to embody the more essential features:

The first practical result of the conference recently held at the New York Board of Trade and Transportation under the auspices of the National Civic Federation between representatives of the labor and capital interests of the country was the virtual settlement yesterday of the bitter controversy that for many months has been waged between the garment cutters and the clothing manufacturers of the United States.

The twenty-third annual banquet of the New York City Hotel Association took place last evening at Delmonico's. About 400 guests were present, representing prominent men of all branches of trades and professions, the City Government beingconspicuously represented in numbers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A delegation representing the National Association of Hide and Leather Dealers saw the Chairman and some other members of the Ways and Means Committee to-day and urged that the committee make an effort to take the duty off hides. Ex-Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn was one of the delegation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs unanimously agreed to-day upon a report on the case making charges against Lieut. Col. H.O. S. Heistand of the army.

That a party of man-o'-war's-men ashore should get to fighting with a party of sailors -- or, for that matter, of soldiers -- of another nationality is not an unprecedented incident, and would not of itself constitute an international "question." If that were all that had happened at Niu-Chwang the incident would be closed as soon as the contusions of combat had subsided.

There seems to be a misunderstanding in the minds of a good many newspapers writers in regard to the true nature of the work that Mr. CARNEGIE'S latest splendid gift for education is intended to accomplish. The aim has been referred to in a number of instances as a university.
BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- In the course of Chancellor von Billow's speech in the Reichstag yesterday he said:

A robbery effected in broad daylight on Sixth Avenue, and in a sensational manner, startled the crowds passing along that thoroughfare in the vicinity of Twentyeighth Street at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Official announcement was made to-day of the Board of Trustees of the Carnegie Institution, which has been incorporated here under the $10,000,000 gift of Andrew Carnegie. The only indication as to the form of the gift is that it will be in "5 per cent. bonds."

Three hundred and fifty members and guests of the New York Chamber of Commerce met Ambassador Joseph H. Choate yesterday afternoon at a reception given to him at the hall of the Chamber before his departure for England. Mr. Choate intends to sail next Wednesday on the steamship St. Louis.

Capt. George S. Chapman of the Mercer Street Police Station engaged in a fierce encounter last night on a Broadway car with a drink-crazed patrolman whom, aided by his wardman, Wesley Hall, he was trying to take to the station house. During the struggle the patrolman drew his revolver and made frantic efforts to shoot his superior officer, according to the latter's account of the occurrence.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- Money was in good request to-day, and the supplies were fairly large. Discounts were steady. With the approach of the first settlement of the year there is a disposition to curtail speculation, and prices dwindled in the absence of support. The foreign selling of consols has caused weakness; besides, the market argues that whatever form the Government's finance proposals take, consols will not benefit.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Commissioner of Agriculture, Charles A. Wieting has discovered an infected herd of cows at a point about two and a half miles from Peekskill, and as a result two cows which have been proved to have had tuberculosis have been killed, and the entire herd quarantined, in order to prevent the sale and distribution of infected cattle throughout the State.

It should be extremely instructive to the officers and Directors of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad that the calamity of Wednesday last has given rise to a more or less intelligent popular clamor for their indictment. In the case of a great many railroads such an accident could have occurred without raising a question of criminal liability on the part of the Directors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The real question with reference to the Cubans is not what shall be given to them in the shape of tariff concessions, but rather whether anything will be given. The Administration is not at all sure that any measure of relief will be granted, hopes something will be done, almost expects something will be done, but fears nothing will be done.

In a portion of his annual message, to which little attention has been paid, Gov. ODELL strikes at the independence of the judiciary and recommends legislation that would enable him to attach the Judges of the State courts to the Republican Party machine, subject to his control and devoted to the furtherance of his ambitions.

Goaded into action yesterday over the report from Andrew Freedman's office on the previous day that A.H. Soden of Boston had practically written Spalding that he was not with him in his position in the National League fight, and was perfectly willing to await the decision of the courts, Mr. Spalding yesterday made public Mr. Soden's letter and considerable other correspondence.
The fourth public rehearsal of the sixtieth season of the Philharmonic Society of New York took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The programme was as follows:

Twenty-four of the most valuable and thoroughly tried-out polo ponies to be found in the United States will sail early this morning for England on the steamship Minneapolis. They represent the string which, with the addition of Foxhall Keene's ponies, already in England, will be used by the American players in the coming international match with the crack players of the Hurlingham Club.

The Bachelors' ball last evening absorbed the general attention of society. The opera was also very brilliant. Among those who gave dinners before the ball were Mrs. I. Townsend Burden and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The real difficulty involved in the Park Avenue tunnel arises from the immense traffic thrown through this narrow channel and the consequent short headway upon which trains are operated. This involves no criticism of the railway. The only wonder is that a system so perfect as to pass such innumerable trains through the tunnel could ever have been devised.

W.W. Swan of the Woodbridge School won both senior events in the New York interscholastic speed skating races last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink in Brooklyn. Heretofore these events have been held at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink in this city, but this year it was decided to hold them in Brooklyn.

The Bachelors' ball, which took place last evening at Sherry's, was a brilliant ending to a week of sulendid entertainments. There have been few affairs which have been the subject of such discussion for so long a time previous to the date of their happening as the ball of last evening.

Army. The following recent appointments of officers of the Porto Rico Provisional Regiment of Infantry are announced: Edwin J. Griffith. Captain: William D. Pritchard and George A. Derbyshire, Second Lieutenants. Capt. Griffith will report to the commanding officer at Columbus Barracks for temporary duty.

In the American National tournament last night the Fidelia defeated the Orchard and the Monarch teams, making an average of 990 in the two games. The Grand Central team won two games in the New York League, and all three teams tied in the Columbia and the Harlem tournaments. Thp scores:

FARGO, N.D., Jan. 10. -- James J. Hill, President of the Northern Securities Company, addressed the Tri-State Association of Grain and Cattle Growers this afternoon. The crowd was very large, and included farmers and business men from all parts of Minnesota and both Dakotas, special delegates having come to-day from Duluth and the twin cities to hear Mr. Hill.

LONDON, Jan, 11. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times wonders whether the speech in the Reichstag on Wednesday by Count von Billow, the German Imperial Chancellor, was the funeral oration of the Triple Alliance.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The State Board of Charities to-day threw down the gauntlet to Gov. Odell by sending him a respectful but vigorous protest against the carrying out of his plan to do away with the Boards of Managers, and vest the power now exercised by these boards in a Superintendent, to be appointed by the State Board, with the approval of the Governor.

Twenty-four of the most valuable and thoroughly tried-out polo ponies to be found in the United States will sail early this morning for England on the steamship Minneapolis. They represent the string which, with the addition of Foxhall Keene's ponies, already in England, will be used by the American players in the coming international match with the crack players of the Hurlingham Club.

J.B.C. McKee won the game last night in the amateur fourteen-inch bolk line billiard tournament at Maurice Daly's Academy. Ferdinand Poggenburg was unable to concede him 50 points, the score being 250 to 288. McKee Secured the lead at the start and kept it, Poggenburg playing rather poorly in the middle stages of the contest.

They are only 75 cents and $1 apiece, and all this time New York girls have been going without them. They have had silver pieces of different kinds, but it is only the occasional girl who has had a silverhandled powder puff. The seventy-five-cent ones have slender, pointed handles, and those for $1 have a silver button in a French gray finish.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- A resolution brought out by the recent disaster in the New York Central tunnel in New York City was offered in the Assembly this morning by Assemblyman Wainwright of the Westchester district, which includes New Rochelle. Under a rule of the House, the resolution was objected to, and will come up again on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The statistician of the Department of Agriculture estimates the average yield of an acre of wheat in the United States in 1901 at 14.8 bushels, as compared with 12.3 bushels in 1900, 12.3 in 1899, 15.3 in 1898, and 13.3 bushels as the mean of the average of the last ten years.

A judgment for $1,586 was entered yesterday against Thomas E. Corcoran. James Conners, John Daly, and Charles Davis, as co-partners in the firm of Thomas E. Corcoran Co. of S Barclay Street, and against Charles Davis. individually, in favor of Leopold Samuels, for money alleged to have been lost by Max H. Raubitschek in playing faro at S Barclay Street.

It should be extremely instructive to the officers and Directors of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad that the calamity of Wednesday last has given rise to a more or less intelligent popular clamor for their indictment. In the case of a great many railroads such an accident could have occurred without raising a question of criminal liability on the part of the Directors.

The New York Central Railroad's plans for a change in the motive power to be used for hauling trains through the Park Avenue tunnel have been completed, and it is probable that announcement of the exact nature of the plans will be made within a week, or as soon as the result of the investigations into the conditions in the tunnel has been announced.

The Bachelors' ball, which took place last evening at Sherry's, was a brilliant ending to a week of sulendid entertainments. There have been few affairs which have been the subject of such discussion for so long a time previous to the date of their happening as the ball of last evening.

In the banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last evening fifty-eight separate dining tables were required to accommodate the members of the West Side Republican Club and their guests and friends, numbering over six hundred, at the fourth annual dinner of that organization. The hall was profusely decorated, principally with American flags.

The bill which has been reported from the Committee of Coinage, and which was introduced by Mr. HILL of Connecticut, is a step in the direction of completing the establishment of the gold standard, which is generally represented in all Republican platforms as established, but which in fact is not.

The Bachelors' ball last evening absorbed the general attention of society. The opera was also very brilliant. Among those who gave dinners before the ball were Mrs. I. Townsend Burden and Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks.

The stock market yesterday was dull, irregular, and hesitating, and, as has been the case now for some time, reflected little more than the operations of the professionals, who for the moment seem to be in control of the situation. In the early dealings there was heaviness, following upon reports of rate cutting in the West.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 10. -- Henry B. Kummell was to-day elected State Geologist to succeed John C. Smock, who resigned some months ago. Prof. Kummell was Professor Smock's assistant, and has been acting as State Geologist since the resignation of his chief.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- Loans at the Clearing House to-day were made at 3 and 4 per cent, mostly at the latter figure. The advance was due chiefly to the shifting of balances by reason of the payment of the $9,000,000 of Erie Telephone notes which matured to-day. One large bank called in a portion of its outstanding call loans and marked up all others to 4 per cent.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The Times says that Edgar Speyer of Speyer Brothers has given $125,000 to King Edward's Hospital Fund for London.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- The First Assembly Ball was held to-night in the foyer of the Academy of Music, which was elaborately decorated. At one end the six patronesses, Mrs. John G. Johnson, Mrs. George Meade, Mrs. John Thompson Spencer, Mrs. John K. Mitchell, 3d, Mrs. Charlton Yarnall, and Mrs. J. Conyngham Stevens, received in front of a solid bank of flowers and plants.

Business in the outside market yesterday showed practically no change from the previous day's conditions. Prices again showed irregularity, the most marked weakness being in Standard Oil, which sold down 20 points, while several less important issues made substantial sains. There was little or no disposition shown to extend transactions beyond the somewhat narrow limits to which they had been confined for the past few days.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10. -- The market experienced another day of dullness, with a slight downward tendency. The chief incident of the day was the advance of a full point in West Virginia Central 6s. which was the first local reflection of the various rumors about the sale of that company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The real difficulty involved in the Park Avenue tunnel arises from the immense traffic thrown through this narrow channel and the consequent short headway upon which trains are operated. This involves no criticism of the railway. The only wonder is that a system so perfect as to pass such innumerable trains through the tunnel could ever have been devised.

DUBLIN, Jan. 10. -- At a private meeting of the Irish Parliamentary Party in the Mansion House here to-day John E. Redmond was unanimously re-elected Chairman. The other officers and committeemen were also re-elected. Resolutions were adopted condemning the coercion methods of the Chief Secretary for Ireland, George Wyndham.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Improvements to be made on the Baltimore and Ohio system during 1902 will cost fully $50,000,000, according to a statement made here to-day. A large part of this sum is to be expended on the lines west of Pittsburg to Chicago.

Columbia's football report was published yesterday by Francis S. Bangs, graduate Treasurer of the football association. It shows a balance of $2,407.26, including $208.62 by subscription, with total receipts of $34,584.16. Besides the surplus, the guarantee fund of $2,500 demanded last year by former President Low is still intact with which to start next season's work.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- A correspondent of The Times, wiring from Johannesburg, says Lord Milner's speech at the banquet given in his honor on Thursday evening has been received with the greatest enthusiasm, and criticism is silent in the presence of the general approval of the tone and substance of the High Commissioner's remarks.

Our congratulations to the managers of the Manhattan Elevated system upon the successful installation of the electrical plant which is to furnish power for the Second Avenue line are not intended to include any complimentary references to the suddenness of their accomplishment.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 10. -- Mary Kelly, five years of age, was mans led by a bulldog belonging to her brother this morning. It is feared that her injuries may prove fatal.

BERLIN, Jan. 10. -- In the course of the debate on the estimates in the Reichstag today references were made to Mr. Chamberlain's remarks concerning the German Army in his famous speech at Edinburgh. Herr Sonnenberg, Radical Anti-Semite, made a long and violent speech, in which he used the most bitter invective against Mr. Chamberlain and the British Army ever heard in the Reichstag.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- District Attorney Jerome's address at the Reform Club on the subject of excise was read with great interest by members of the Legislature today. When Senator John Raines, the author of the Raines law, was asked what he had to say in reply to Mr. Jerome, he answered that he had nothing to add to the interview which he gave out a fortnight ago, which, he thought, covered the subject completely.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The real question with reference to the Cubans is not what shall be given to them in the shape of tariff concessions, but rather whether anything will be given. The Administration is not at all sure that any measure of relief will be granted, hopes something will be done, almost expects something will be done, but fears nothing will be done.

-- It is more than a little pathetic that the game of pelota should come to us as a Cuban sport -- not because a sport is necessarily or even probably of little account because it is Cuban, but because to credit pelota to the Cubans is to deprive a most interesting and mysterious people who are not even Spanish of one of their few belongings.

EDOUARD DE RESZKE is telling a story which he seems to relish mightily, even though the joke is upon himself and his distinguished brother. It was during their last season in Paris together. In their apartments at a certain hotel the brothers often practiced singing together of mornings.

BIT by bit archaeologists and ethnologists are scientifically revealing the sort of people the aborigines were who built the wonderful stone and adobe homes, perched, like human martin's nests, on the ledges of precipitous canon walls of this region away back in prehistoric ages.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- A sudden outbreak of weakness in Philadelphia Electric 4 per cent, bonds was the feature in Philadelphia to-day. Their close last night was at 62 1/2; they closed to-day at 55 3/4, the lowest ever recorded. The bonds were under persistent pressure all day. The fall is from 64 1/2 on last Monday.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, speaking at Birmingham to-night, took occasion to notice, without entering into a controversial rejoinder, the criticisms showered upon him in the Reichstag during the past week, especially Count von Bulow's castigation. Referring to the animosity of foreign nations, he said he was well aware that he was in some quarters attributed to the "indiscreet oratory of the Colonial Secretary."

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- The hearing in the attempt being made to have Emma L. Hendricks removed as co-executrix of the estate of Rachel A. Cartwright, widow of Benjamin Cartwright, was concluded before Judge Skinner, in the Orphans Court, to-day. The application was made by Rachel A. Lynch of Lakewood, daughter of the testatrix and niece of Miss Hendricks.

Many pathetic incidents occur within the white walls of the Presbyterian Hospital, but the attendants say that it has been many a long day since so sad a scene has been enacted as one of yesterday. A young man who has faced death for a week and who to-day must undergo a serious operation, was married yesterday afternoon in one of the wards to the woman who had plighted her troth to him in health.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The State Railroad Commission expects to have before it for consideration before long a novel and an unprecedented ease in the history of the commission. The Long Island Railroad Company is to ask the State Railroad Commission to compel the United States Government to pay it an adequate amount for carrying the mails.

TOLEDO, Jan. 11. -- George B. Ketcham, owner and driver of the trotter Cresceus, announced to-day that during the year he received more than $70,000 in purses and for exhibitions given in various parts of the country by Cresceus. The horse was today taken to the Ketcham farm, where he will remain during the remainder of the Winter.

The city scored a victory in the Supreme Court yesterday in a test suit which was one of 140 suits brought against it to recover damages growing out of the flooding of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards on July 5 and Aug. 24 of last year. The suits involve claims for damages amounting to $500,000.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- One of the most important deals involving the investment of American capital in Europe has just been completed here. It consists in the securing of all-water routes for American cargoes of grain and other commodities from inland ports in the United States to inland ports in Europe, and embraces the purchase by American capital of several British and other canals.

From The City of Mexico Herald. Western agriculturists in the United States are talking of uniting to secure reciprocal trade agreements with this country and with all tropical Latin America, so that American farm products shall secure free entry into these countries in exchange for a similar letting down of the tariff bars by the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With several others of my acquaintance I should like to enter a protest against the fuss and muss, , which is made nowadays over a man in our army and navy when he does a good and a creditable job exactly in the line of his duty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- An increase of almost 192 per cent, in the capital invested in the turpentine and resin industry and of 152 per cent, in the value of the products therefrom is shown in the census report issued to-day on the manufacture of those products in the United States. A total capital of $11,847,495 was invested in the 1,503 establishments reporting.

A DISPATCH to THE TIMES a few days since announced the death at Matamoras, Pike County, Penn., of Catherine Bowden, in her ninetieth year. The two sisters who survive Mrs. Bowdon, one older and one younger than she, are the last members of a most remarkable family.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring briefly to the letter of a Belleville, N.J., correspondent which appeared conspicuously on your editorial page in today's issue, will you permit me to say that the dignity of the United States would no more be lowered by the fact of a special representative of this Government attending the coronation of Edward VII, than by the fact of the presence of its Ambassador at that ceremony.

The Danish West Indies. According to well-informed persons in Copenhagen, two elements have of late disturbed the Danish-American negotiations for the sale of the Danish West Indies, the influence of which the Danish Government has all alone miscalculated.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 11. -- A somewhat painful impression has been created in interested circles by the dissensions which brought to an end the Russo-American gold mining enterprise on the Russian shore of Bering Sea last year. The following account comes from Russian sources:

The Board of Managers and the Ladies' Committee of the New York Infant Asylum held a reception yesterday afternoon to celebrate the opening of the new asylum building, at Sixty-first Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The reception hall was crowded by those interested in the institution.

A big entry list in every event forced the officials for the annual indoor games of the Hospital Corps of the Eighth Regiment and St. Bartholomew's Athletic Club, held last night in the Eighth Regiment Armory, to run nearly every race in from three to eight heats. The sixty-yard handicap had the largest number, and that took eight heats to weed out the men for the final struggle, while the sixty-yard novice had seven heats.
CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 11. -- Ban Johnson made public for the first time to-day the details of his famous conference with A. G. Spalding at Atlantic City last June.

It hag long been customary for Postmasters in all parts of the world to exchange greetings with each recurring New Year. All last week Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott's personal mall contained many of these missives. Some of them are unique, while the very large majority are handsome and replete with original ideas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dun's Review for Jan. 4, 1902, contains tables based upon quotations for 350 articles, with due allowance for the relative importance of each, showing that the cost of living is now greater in this country than ever before. The following are the "index" figures for Jan. 1, 1890; July 1, 1897; Jan. 1, 1900, and Jan. 1, 1902:
