A PART from the more pretentious openings --" Frocks and Frills " at Daly's and " The Toreador " at the Knickerbocker Theatre -- the last week is to be credited with two interesting offering. One of these must have been largely experimental and the other, oddly enough, was the work of those who as yet have all their laurels to win on the professional stage.

It is a long way from the drama of dress, which characterized the chief effort in New York theatres last week, to the drama of ideas, which will find a representative in Mrs. Patrick Campbell at the Republic Theatre to-morrow night. But in a great city of so many varied tastes as this, there must of necessity exist a large class of patrons for each of varied forms of entertainment.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 11. -- The traffic of Lake Superior for the year just passed has been about three times that of the Suez Canal for the latest period of which there are reports. The Lake Superior business, aside from coastwise inside the lake, was 28,403,003 tons of freight, while the Suez is about 9,000,000 tons.

Apropos of the situation in pig iron, Archer Brown, discussing the matter, declares that the troubles surrounding the situation are by no means lessened. "The transportation problem has improved slightly at some points and grown worse at others. A large number of furnaces in the aggregate are still banked for lack of fuel.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Last evening Mrs. George Daly, Miss Louise Daly and Miss Mae Bellis of Bound Brook came to this city to see the performance of "The Eleventh Hour" at a local theatre. They thought that the last car home left at midnight, but the car, like the play, was scheduled for the eleventh hour.
The Ladies Auxiliary of St. Vincent's Hospital will give a reception at the Waldorf-Astoria on next Wednesday evening in aid of the destitute sick.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- There will be a Cabinet meeting here on Monday which bids fair to be most fateful to the history of the West Indies, and may be of great importance to the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am sure you would have the gratitude of a host of readers if you should do or suggest anything to curb the Metropolitan Street Railway Company's insolent disregard of the rights of the people at whose expense highways are maintained for its immensely lucrative and exclusive traffic in passengers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Norman E. Mack, National Democratic Committeeman for the State of New York, gave out the following interview to-night, in connection with the resignation of Richard Croker as leader of Tammany Hall, and the election of Lewis Nixon as his successor:

From The Portland Oregonian. Worry, it is said, was a prominent factor in the illness which terminated the life of Gov. Rogers. This is not improbable. The debilitating effects of anxiety are well known. In the years of financial and industrial depression they caused many a man to succumb to disease who would otherwise have been able to throw it off.

Subscriptions to the issue of $30,000,000 4 per cent, serial debenture bonds of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company are being received by J.P. Morsan Co. The proceeds of these debentures are to be used partly for the purchase of equipment to meet the road's growing traffic, the construction and acquisition of additional branch lines, and the purchase of outstanding bonds and stocks of branch line companies, and other improvements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in yesterday's TIMES on " Municipal Embellishment " quite accords with my own ideas, for the general appearance of this city, largely from the effects of the four years of the last inefficient administration, is truly deplorable.
BUFFALO, Jan. 11. -- The entries for the National bowling tournament which will begin here on Jan. 20, and continue during the week, have closed, and have filled beyond expectations.

According to the preliminary returns of the Inter-State Commerce Commission the railroads of the United States gained another $100,000,000 in gross earnings for the fiscal year 1901, comparing results with those for 1900, the amount for the first time on record exceeding $1,500,000,000.

The second annual international chess tournament, to be played under the auspices of the Club des Etrangers of Monte Carlo, promises to become the most interesting tournament ever held. The entry Mst is large and includes three Americans, Pillsbury, Marshall, and Napier, and the German champion.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 11. -- With Lake Carasaljo a field of smooth, clear ice, Lakewood is now at the height or her Winter glory. Skating is the popular out-of-door pastime with the Winter colony, and since the word was given that the ice was thick enough. Lake Carasaljo's broad surface has been crowded with skaters.

How is the making of those famous old Navajo blankets for a lad? It is one which a couple of bright New York girls have taken up recently. So there is absolutely something new in the way of accomlishments in the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a resident of Mount Vernon, I have commuted on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad for the past seven years. I believe engineers are usually careful men, fully alive to the trust and confidence placed in them. No one could make me believe that an engineer deliberately ignored a signal.

A very attractive programme has been arranged by Mr. F.X. Arens, conductor of the People's Symphony Concerts, for the second of the series at Cooper Union Hall on Friday, Jan. 17, 1902. The orchestral numbers, for which an orchestra of nearly fifty carefully selected musicians is engaged, will be Beethoven's "Egmont" overture, Haydn's symphony in E flat major, Tschaikowsky's "Andante Cantabile" from the string quartet. Opus 11, and the Wagner overture "Rienzi."

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- If A.G. Spalding wants the Boston Baseball Club, its good- will, or its support he can have it by paying $250,000. This in brief is the substance of a statement made by A.H. Soden, the controlling: owner, to-day with his partners. Conant and Billings. He is willing to sell, providing he gets what, is right.

The Corinthian Bowling Club had a run of ill-luck last week, and moved down one place in the American National. Columbia, and Harlem Leagues. They still have two more games to play in the American National series, and with good luck may tie the Metropolitan teams for first place, but at present they stand third in that series, with the Metropolitans first and the Fidelias second.

In a large room in the New York Aquarium, the doors of which are conspicuously marked " No Admittance," are to be found a lot of interesting-looking fish that the public, except by special permission, seldom get a chance to view. Of all these fish the most peculiar as well as interesting is one known as the axolotl, or " fish with legs."

IT Is a great treat to have something new in a mushroom recipe. So some folks think. As a matter of fact. It not a necessity to nave anything new, though tomany people it is a satisfaction. Any one who knows anything about mushrooms knows that the more simply they are cooked the better they are, and the more the gourmet's experience grows the more certain he is of this fact.

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and Kew York funds were at 8 to 10 cents' discount. Exchanges, $29,515,132; balances, $4,444,808. Locally, money on call rules from 4 1/2 to 3 per cent. Time money is quoted all the way from 4 to 5 per cent., according to dates and collateral, probably 4 1/2 per cent, is the general rule for six months.

IT IS interesting, as the time for the coronation of King Edward VII, approaches, to know what will be worn by the nobility, among whom several American women will appear as peeresses of the realm. English papers are publish ing many things concerning the coronation robes and facts bearing upon the event which are generally interesting.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Articles incorporating the Consolidated Rosendale Cement Company of Binnewater, Ulster County, have been filed with the Secretary of State. The capital stock is to be $1,500,000, of which the sum of $1,000,000 is to be in 7 per cent. non-cumulative preferred stock, and the sum of $300,000 in common stock.

The funeral services of Marcellus Hartley, the millionaire philanthropist, who died suddenly in the Directors' room of the American Surety Company last Wednesday, took place yesterday morning in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. Friends of the dead financier, including Andrew Carnegie, Russell Sage, J. Pierpont Morgan, and many others prominent throughout the country, filled the pews of the church and the galleries.

Richard Croker abdicated as the leader of Tammany Hall yesterday and named Lewis Nixon as his successor. The first announcement of the new head of the Wigwam was that he was no "figurehead." Mr. Croker is going to sail for Europe on or about Feb. 15, and the time of his return to this country is entirely problematical.
BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- In connection with the proposed trip of the German Emperor's yacht Sohenzollern to New York, Emperor William telegraphed as follows, in English, to President Roosevelt:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the largest and most prosperous city in one of the largest and most prosperous countries of the world, has just occurred a railroad accident that will make the whole civilized race shudder at its heartbreaking details.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The selection of an ex-President of the United States, whose distinction is that he was fairly elected to his august office by the free suffrages of millions of his fellowcitizens, for our representative at the coronation pageant of King Edward VII. is, on the face of it, so illogical and inconsistent that it hardly seems possible that it can be seriously entertained.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The irrepressible tendency of human nature is to rebel at the enforcement of irrational, Puritanical, otherwise ancient, sumptuary laws, most of which are obso- lete. In a world city like ours the above question in its adaptation is purely local where the conditions are entirely dissimilar from those of any other American mu- nicipality, and consequently must be dealt with on its merits.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 11. -- Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Premier, received a cable this afternoon stating that R.R. Dobell, a member of the Dominion Cabinet without portfolio, had been killed at Folkestone, England.

SHAS LARRABEE is back in Washington with a rather remarkable story of a trip he took to Indiana, in the company of a detective from that State. " Surprised to see me, ain't ye?" Mr. Larrabee demanded, as he entered my room last night.

Three small children, Louisa, Arthur, and George Hans, respectively, twelve, eleven, and nine years old, whose rather, William a cabinetmaker, they said, had turned them adrift late on Friday night from their home at 66 Myrtle Avenue, Ridgewood, were found last night crying on a stoop at Broadway and Berry Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "O tempora, O mores"! The saloon has become the most important factor in the great temple of modern civilization. It has grown to such gigantic proportions and has accomplished such magnificent achievements that the brains of our leading thinkers, both in State and Church, are taxed to the utmost in arranging its programme for the future.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The British War Office is confronted with a most serious state of affairs. Its call for volunteers to relieve the regiments at the front has so far met with absolutely no response, and has served to intensify the widespread indignation existing among all the volunteer regiments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial commending Senator Stranahan's bill exempting mortgages from all taxation, except a small tax of one-half of 1 per cent., to be paid only once, at the time of filing, is very encouraging to all good citizens who ore opposed to the methods now pursued by the Government of taxing anything and everything in sight.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 11. -- The snow- covered golf links made the red ball a necessity in the open handicap of the Country Club of Lakewood to-day. There were eight entries, and six cards were returned. F.N. Doubleday of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club won first prize with a net score of 91.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the question of legalizing the opening of the saloons on Sundays is being agitated, on the ground, partly, that a large element in this city in particular, and in all large cities in general, must have some meeting place other than their crowded tenement homes or lonely quarters in boarding houses, is it not an opportune time to agitate the opening of public libraries on Sundays?

PARIS, Jan. 1. -- All Paris is occupied today with paying its respects to its special set. Indeed, these functions, so far as the Government is concerned, began several days ago, in order that there should be time for every one to go the rounds.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Nearly 2,000 people crowded Metropolitan Hall here to-night at the mass meeting called to express public opinion in regard to the New York Central tunnel disaster, and the meeting was attended by representative men from many parts of WestChester County, who had come to extend their sympathy with the people of New Rochelle and to act with them in remedying the tunnel dangers.

LISBON, Dec. 16. -- In a country of the size of Portugal, under 35,000 square miles in extent, and with a population of a little over 5,000,000 inhabitants, not blessed with much wealth, one must not expect to find figures of large dimensions in its foreign trade returns.

Society at present is in the very midst of its busiest season. Every evening is taken up with dinners and dances and balls and the opera and entertainments of all kinds, while luncheons and days home and other similar affairs are in progress during the afternoons. Last week was opened by Mrs. Astor's ball, one of the notable entertainments of the year.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Now that William C. Whitney's Derby candidate, Nasturtium, and his stable companion are safe at New-market, and the English experts have had a chance to see him, Nasturtium has become a prime favorite for the Derby, sharing with Duke of Westminster the top price, 6 to 1 against.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is an old, old story related in your columns to-day in a dispatch from Chicago pertaining to witnesses that it is desired to have before the meeting there Jan. 7 of the Inter-State Commerce Commission. The object stated is to " probe the entire matter of 'community of interest' between great railways," the specific investigation being aimed at the Northwestern railways.

Jewelry worth thousands of dollars and valued far more as heirlooms was stolen from the home of Mrs. Edward Fuller, 35 East Thirty-sixth Street, a four-story dwelling, while she and her sister, Miss Easton, who occupy the house alone with their servants, were at dinner last evening. The robbery was the work of an expert porch-climbing thief, who may have had one or more confederates for all the police know.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- While the first financial week of the year has scarcely borne out the good promise of the closing one of the old year, the City is by no means discouraged, but quite the reverse.

IT is a long cry from 1648 to 1902, and for just that length of time the premises located on Fourteenth Street, adjoining the Fourteenth Street Presbyterian Church, at Second Avenue, and watch have been recently sold to Mandelbaum Lewine, were in the possession of the Stuyvesant family.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- A stadium which will seat 75,000 persons and which, in point of size, elegance, and excellence of arrangement, will probably excel any other building ever erected for a similar purpose, is outlined in a set of preliminary plans just placed in the hands of Harry J. Furber, Jr., President of the Olympian Games Association.

In the new volume of " Las Annales du Theatre," which has made a rather tardy appearance this year, M. Lucien Muhifeld, who has been chosen to write the introduction, discusses the subject of the feeling of uneasiness which is said to characterize the present condition of theatrical affairs in France.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am now enjoying a delicious treat which I desire to share with you -- don't hurry me -- wait! I am just going to tell you.

Defenders of our duties on objects of the fine arts are prone to picture the lamentable case of the United States, once the customs bars down, when we shall be flooded by masses of inferior art works and our artists driven to desperation by underpaid and State-assisted rivals.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.y., Jan. 11. -- Receiver of Taxes John Koellmer of this city was placed under arrest to-day after confessing a shortage in his accounts amounting to between $5,000 and $7,000. He was arraigned and held for the action of the Grand Jury.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The Earl of Dysart has offered u10,000 toward the erection of a national opera house in London, provided the balance of the u500,000, which lie believes is needed, is raised in six months.

BREACH OF WARRANTY. -- Robert P. Staats bought a pair of cob horses from Moses G. Byers in January, 1897, which the latter "warranted sound, kind, and gentle on delivery." The day after the horses were delivered Mr. Staats decided to take them to Long Branch by boat. They were driven singly.

THESE winter days the visitor to Birdland expects to find but few of his feathered friends at home. All the sweet songs of Summer and early Autumn he knows are ringing now in the glades and goves of Florida: the brilliant, flashing fellows who once were a delight and a charm are disporting themselves in alien woods away down by the Gulf, and only the hardy, careless Winter birds are left to entertain their callers.

BERLIN, Jan. 11. -- The Prince of Wales's visit to Emperor William on the occasion of the letter's birthday will be only for a day. Those who see in this visit a desire on the part of the British Government to show good will toward Germany are quite mistaken. It is intended simply as a token of Kng: Edward's personal regard for Emperor William.

John M. Wisker, the engineer of the White Plains train which on Wednesday crashed into the Danbury train in the Central tunnel with tragic results, obtained freedom yesterday by giving bail for his appearance when required in $10,000. Great interest was manifested in his behalf before he was released.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11. -- Harvard received a hard blow this morning when statements were given out by Oliver F. Cutts, Harvard's star football tackle, and by Prof. Hollis, Chairman of the Athletic Committee, stating that Cutts was ineligible, and should not have played against Yale last November.

DOGS are the most widely disseminated creatures known to man. Compared with him, the mosquito may be said to flock alone. The dog has doubtless penetrated from pole to pole and infests all that region that lies between. He is the practical sewer of the Orient and is pretty much the only sewer it knows.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is one important fact in relation to the slaughter in the tunnel, which has not received any consideration. The car yard or approach to the Grand Central Station extends from Forty-fifth to Forty-ninth Street. It is filled with an intricate network of tracks and switches.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 11. -- Horace Elisha Scudder, author and a former editor of The Atlantic Monthly, died at his residence, here, to-night in the sixty-fourth year of his age. Death resulted from a complication of diseases with which he had been suffering for nearly a year, heart trouble being the ultimate cause of his death.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- Amos C. Hall, President of the Forestport Lumber Company of Hinkley, N.Y., died at the Ten Eycke Hotel in this city last night. Mr. Hall was considered the best living authority upon the lands, values, and titles in the Adirondacks.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 11. -- Miss Helen Miller Gould arrived here this afternoon in a special car from the East. She wan accompanied by Mrs. Patten, Miss Patten, and Mrs. Gilbert Patten of Germantown, Penn., and Misses Stephenson, Hartshorn, and Coots of New York.

Yesterday was another day of irregular price movements on the Stock Exchange. In the early dealings decided strength developed under the lead of Union Pacific, St. Paul, Baltimore and Ohio, Manhattan, and Sugar. This strength was well maintained until the publication of the regular weekly bank statement, which was decidedly favorable in every respect, surplus reserves increasing over $5,400,000, while loans were decreased $5,300,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 11. -- To a committee of women representing the Lexington Chapter of Daughters of the Confederacy, who petitioned Charles Scott, a local opera house manager, to refrain from booking any more " Uncle Tom's Cabin" shows here, he replied to-day as follows:

W. Wickham Smith, of the law firm of Curie, Smith Maxwell, at 22 William Street, attorney for the Merchants' Association, made yesterday afternoon what he said would be his first and last statement concerning the investigation which he is to make into the reported frauds in the customs department in this city.

The stock market of the week just passed was altogether dominated by the professional element who, bearish almost to a man, were most industrious in their endeavors to bring about a lower range of prices. Demonstrations against market values were made persistently and aggressively: yet at the end of the week there appears no general shrinkage in prices that alarms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Wireless telegraphy's effect on the future of the submarine cable was developed to some extent today by the House Commerce Committee's hearing on the proposed Pacific cable. The hearing was largely attended, and Vice President Ward of the Pacific Commercial Cable Company continued his statement of yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The joint committee of the Senate and House of Representatives appointed to make arrangements for a memorial meeting in honor of President McKinley decided to-day that the meeting should be held in the hall of the House of Representatives at noon on Feb. 27.

The officers of the Canal Association of Greater New York expressed themselves as much pleased with Mayor Low's advocacy of the improvement of the Erie Canal along the lines recommended in Gov. Odell's message. A meeting of the Canal Association will be held Tuesday evening, and an effort will be made to have Mayor Low attend.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The manager of one of the largest transatlantic lines, when asked to-day if he expected an unusual number of Americans to be present in London at the time of the coronation of King Edward, said:
British railway managers are far from composing a happy family, as may be surmised from the following editorial protest of The London Railway News:

We remember being once mildly chidden by our London homonym, for resenting, " with some degree of verbal asperity," the remarks of the Berlin press, what time Admiral DEWEY was in charge of the harbor of Manila, and his control of it was ignored by the commander of a squadron larger than his own, and, on paper, more formidable, which with friendly tact Germany had sent to supervise his operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Edouard Lampre, representing the Panama Canal Company, appeared before the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals to-day, in obedience to the summons of that committee, to testify concerning the affairs of his company and its proffer to sell its property and franchises to the United States.

The second interscholastic hockey game of the championship series was played last night at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, and Cutler School, victorious in the opening game of the association last Tuesday night, won again from Dwight School. Huzleton of Dwight School, who contested in the Interscholastic speed contests Friday night, winning places in both the senior events, was hurt five minutes after play commenced and had to retire from the game.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg that you will give me space for a few words about the accident in the New York Central tunnel.

If all the wild turkeys in the Mogolion Mountains from Turkey Creek to the Mexico line could be killed or trapped there would be dinner material for half the families of the Nation. They are big birds, too.

This is the season of annual golf meetings, and the members of a number of local clubs are making plans for coming events. Chief interest, of course, centres in the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, which has just been announced for Thursday evening, Feb. 27, at Delmonico's.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The frequency and nature of railroad ac- cidents in this country point to Government ownership as the only radical remedy. Had the railroads of this country been originally surveyed and built by the General Government the recent hideous barbecue in Michigan could never have occurred.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 4. -- Cope Whitehouse, having been shown the account of an interview with M. Lagarde, printed in The London Times and NEW YORK TIMES, on Dec. 27, in reference to the storage of Nile water, said that it was impossible to exaggerate the importance of any effort on the part of the Abyssinians to control the Blue Nile.

There is no more remarkable sight on the east side of this city than that now to be observed nightly at the Boys' Club, at the corner of Second Avenue and Tenth Street. The magnificent new building of the club has just been opened for use, and the boys of the neighborhood are flooding the institution for membership.

Last week the representatives of two great industries appeared before the mighty Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee of the House to praythat their industries might set from the majority an adjustment of tariff taxes that would powerfully promote their interests and would inflict no injury on any one.

Justice William J. Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, early last evening handed down a decision granting a motion made by counsel for the wardman, Edward G. Glennon, convicted in New York County of neglect of duty for failing to suppress an alleged disorderly house, for a certificate of reasonable doubt whether the judgment of conviction of a misdemeanor should stand.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 11. -- Because non-residents are not entitled to free education in the public schools of Baltimore, Senor Rafael Janer and fifteen Porto Rican children, whom he brought here last July to educate, will leave this city. Senor Janer said to-night that he would take the children either to New York, Boston, or Philadelphia, where free tuition is promised them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read the letter of "A.M.E." in THE TIMES of the 6th inst., I feel impelled to answer it, because I have heard Prof. Adler's lecture on this subject of Sunday opening and have also met a few persons who reason from the same standpoint as your correspondent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The little skirmish between a TIMES writer and a TIMES reader as to the propriety of using the word " aleatory," reminds me of a story. A sailor being examined in a lawsuit about something: that happened aboard ship, was bothered by the words plaintiff and defendant, which he did not understand.

IT is just a dozen years since " Yaller " became a member of the New York police force. This is how it all came about: Doorman Frank Goodrich of the Eldridge Street Police Station, " Yaller's " best friend, tells the story:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent the apparently needless and awful loss of life and the maiming of limbs and bodies in the Harlem tunnel wreck, has it occurred to the public that the despair- ing cry of the engineer, "It was up to me to make up lost time," has more behind it than at first appears?

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 11. -- Dr. Daniel C. Gilman, President Emeritus of the Johns Hopkins University, who will be the executive head of the Board of Trustees of the Carnegie Institution at Washington, gave important information concerning the scope of the institution in an address to-day to the Faculty and students of the Hopkins.

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- The Park Theatre reopened to-night with the first performance in this country of "Morocco Bound." The play is in the hands of A.H. Chamberlyn, who was the originator of it in England. The book is by Arthur Branscombe, the lyrics are the product of Adrian Ross, and the music is composed by Dr. Osmond Carr.

PEKING, Jan. 11. -- The indications point to a satisfactory settlement of the French claims against China in time to permit M. Beau, the French Minister here, to present his credentials in company with his colleagues, at the first audience, a few days hence.

If there is any secret which Uncle Sam jealously guards it is the process of manufacturing the fibre paper upon which his money notes are printed. He pays a Massachusetts firm 43 cents a pound for it, and this firm does its work under the surveillance of a Government agent. The paper is manufactured of the finest rags, cleaned, boiled, and mashed into pulp.

Capt. Max Schmittberger of the West One Hundredth Street Station last night arrested a young man on a charge of attempted highway robbery and assault, and the story told by the police of the young desperado's daring attempts at robbery in broad daylight places him, they say, in the first ranks of criminals.

MUCH is written at the present time of notorious criminals, their startling records, and the number of cities in which their photographs figure conspicuously in the Rogues' Gallery -- but the public takes only passing notice. With our present police system and our vast population there is little or no personal fear of these chronic offenders against the law.

BARON MIKOSCH of Budapest is one of those unfortunate individuals who are constantly saying and doing funny things without intention, and usually jat their own expense. Convinced of the worfh-leftsness of all doctors save those of Hungary, the Baron makes it a rule to take his own physician with him wherever he goes; but on a recent occasion he was unfortunate enough to fall and break his leg when in Vienna without this useful functionary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Pierre de Coubertin, Chairman of the International Olympian Committee, in a letter to the President of the American Olympian Games Association, which has charge of the preparations for 1904, says that he has recently conferred with the King of Belgium regarding the athletic congress to be held at Brussels in anticipation of the International Olympian games to be hold in America in 1904.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Five funerals were held here to-day of victims of the tunnel disaster, and many of the shops and offices of the city were closed to permit employes to attend the services. The streets here bear many of the evidences of public mourning, and at the funerals to-day there was every indication of widespread public sympathy.

THE wedding gown of Miss Margaret Mark -- who married William Ogden Harrison a few days since -- was different from any other wedding frock yet seen this season. The trained skirt was conventional, although an applied flounce with lace stitching is unusual, but the bodice was original.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Secretary of War and Mrs. Root gave the first of a series of Cabinet dinners to-night, entertaining President and Mrs. Roosevelt, Attorney General and Mrs. Knox, Postmaster General and Mrs. Smith, Secretary and Mrs. Hitchcock. Secretary and Miss Wilson, Assistant Secretary of War and Mrs. Sanger, Justice and Mrs. White.

By his discovery of the Oa, a kind of gibbon, Prof. Haeckel claims to have upset the Darwinian theory that man is descended from the monkey, and to have proved that, on the contrary, the monkey has descended from man. -- Morning Leader.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacoa, Jan. 11. -- Dispatches received here from Caracas, Venezuela, announce that a bomb was exploded on Tuesday last before the house of Senor Tello Mendoza, the Minister of Finance, and that other bombs were exploded in different parts of Caracas.
THAT caustically witty gentleman, Ernest van Dyck, once said that Jean de Reszke was the last of the prima donnas. A very keen and cutting observation, and not without foundation.

DETROIT, Midi., Jan. 11. -- Prof. Lombard of Ann Arbor, Instructor of Physiology in the University of Michigan, believes that he has located the dwelling place of the soul in the spinal column. He has arrived at this conclusion after many months of experiments with frogs.

It is a trite theme of our Consular reports that American exporters do not show enough regard for the habits and the tastes of their foreign customers, or of the foreigners whom they desire to become their customers. Perhaps in part this may be only a way of speaking, into which the Consuls have fallen.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J, Jan. 11. -- "No marriage for ten years" is the motto of an association which has been formed by a number of young women who are connected with a well-known church of this city. Why the limit of single blessedness has been put at ten years is as yet a mystery to all except the young women concerned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The accident, if it may be so termed, which has shocked the city and surround- ing towns and brought agony to many fam- ilies, will be of benefit in that it draws or concentrates the public mind upon railroad corporations and their responsibilities.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Independently of the State game protectors and the commissions which have in charge the departments of fish and game and forests, the guides of the Brown's Tract Guides' Association carry on a system of protection fully as effective as the efforts of the machinery of the State.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The announcement from Cambridge of the action of the Harvard Athletic Committee in declaring Cutts a professional was hailed in Yale undergraduate circles as a substantiation of the view of the Harvard's right tackle's standing that has been held here all along.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Probably the tempest in a teapot which has been raging since Mr. Chamberlain at Edinburgh said that if the British troops in South Africa resorted to more severe measures than had as yet been employed they would have ample precedent in the doings of the Germans in the FrancoPrussian war will now gradually subside.

It is always gratifying when legislators turn from the vain things of politics and give their attention to practical matters. In this respect Mr. LEGGETT, who represents Niagara in the Assembly, has set his colleagues a good example. He has introduced a bill to expel the unprofitable daisy from the State of New York.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Supplies of money were more plentiful to-day, and the large Government disbursements eased rates. Discounts were firm.

John H. Dolph, the well-known artist, famous on both sides of the Atlantic for his pictures of cats and dogs and other animal subjects, recently discovered that his studio in the Sherwood Studio Building, 58 West Fifty-seventh Street, had been robbed of fourteen unframed on paintings valued at about $3,500.

The National Rifle Association of America will send a team to Canada next Summer to compete for the Palma Trophy, which the Canadians won at the meeting at Seabright last year, in order to bring that trophy back to this country.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., Dec. 19. -- So far as the Legislature is concerned, " white Australia " is provided for already, both the Immigration Restriction bill and the Pacific Island Laborers' bill having passed both houses of the Commonwealth Parliament. The former has, of course, been reserved for the King's assent, as it deals with a question of foreign relations and may concern the foreign policy of the empire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I understand it, the proposed recording tax of one-half of 1 per cent. on mortgages is intended to compel the money lender to bear a part of the burden upon real estate.

Turquoises are the favorite stones of all the Mongol racea, and are generally worn in their original state, except by the Chinese women, who have them roughly cut, and wear them mixed with pearls and coral. Both the Tibetan men and women ornament themselves with lump turquoises, the men wearing them attached to their single gold earrings, which are worn in the right ear only.
A BABY of two years, absolutely without the sense of hearing, learning to talk.

ALTHOUGH most of the greatest actors left their own names as their only heritage to the stage, there is a larger proportion of our conspicuous players who are descendants of well-known players than one would suppose.

WALDO SHERMAN, Educational Director of the Twenty-third Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association has been conducting a course on American Citizenship at the Twenty-third Street and Bowery branches, which has Attracted considerable attention among educators, and which may result, it is thought, in a reconstruction of collegiate methods of teaching civil government.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 11. -- The plans for improvements to be carried out by the Union Pacific Road during 1902 were given out officially to-day. They will result in the expenditure of from $125,000,000 to $30,000,000 in betterments and extensions.

BUFFALO, Jan. It. -- At a meeting of the Common Council to-day to elect a City Treasurer to fill the vacancy caused by the removal of Philip Gerst, charged with misconduct in office, the first ballot resulted in sixteen votes for Henry C. Steul, (Rep.,) eleven for James N. Adam, (Dem.,) six for John G. Wicksher, and one for Walter J. Shepard.

Slippery asphalt prevented an express wagon crossing Broadway at Eighty-first Street from getting out of the way of a north-bound electric car which James Seeter, the driver, saw bearing down upon him at full speed as he reached the rails yesterday afternoon. The collision demolished the front end of the wagon and upset what was left.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 11. -- The new Japanese Government iron foundry at Wakamatsu is now in full operation, and since Dec. 2 has been turning out 100 feet of sixty-pound steel rails daily. The foundry has cost several times more than the original estimates. It is expected that it will eventually pass into private hands, which car operate it much more cheaply than the Government.

BOSTON, Jan. 11. -- Inter-city bouts between Boston and New York furnished the principal attraction in the boxing at the B.A.A.'s games to-night. The Boston boys carried off the honors by winning three out of four contests.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- Concerted action will be taken by the Boards of Managers of the State Hospitals for the Insane to defeat the bill abolishing them, creating to succeed them Boards of Visitation, and extending the powers and duties of the State Commission in Lunacy.
IT was no day to be out of doom. The fashionable American woman sat chatting with her friend of school days long past, and the talk turned on the expense of living.

-- A certain woman whose emotional resources are highly developed was recently thrown into the depths of grief by the death of an ancient and estimable cat. Much and vehement affection had been centred upon this animal, and for its sake all other cats and all dogs as well, had been banished from the house.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Miss Marion Balgrie, a nurse in the employ of the famil of Sidney M. Colgate, 363 Central Street, a daughter of City Councilman Andrew W. Baigrie of East Orange, was accidentally burned this morning and died in the Memorial Hospital several hours after she was taken there.

Ewald Balthasar, a well-known financier and silk manufacturer, who retired from active business life three years ago, committed suicide yesterday at his home in the Hotel Beresford, Eighty-first Street and Central Park West. His act is attributed by members of his family to ill-health, which induced despondency.

In spite of the cold weather there was a good attendance of members at all the Harlem River boat clubs, while at the Friendship Boat Club the large meeting room was thronged with oarsmen, including a number from other clubs, who had gathered to witness a rehearsal of the minstrel entertainment which the club is to give at the Harlem Casino, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, on Thursday evening.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The speech of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, at Birmingham on Saturday is naturally commented upon from the party standpoint.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 12 -- The genealogical fad which has taken hold of society here received a severe shock when it was announced that the Rev. Dr. Nichols of New York, a descendant of Robert II. of Scotland, had compiled a directory of the families of the United States privileged to be members of society.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12 -- John T. Brush to-day issued an elaborate and corroborative statement, in which he discusses A.G. Spalding's proposed baseball trust, which was blocked by himself and Frank De Haas Robison. The documents in evidence are copies of letters and telegrams passing between Messrs. Spalding, Robison and himself, and conversations which are proved by letters.

The action of the Central Federated Union a week ago in sending the statement of Samuel Compers, President of the American Federation of Labor, regarding the work of the National Civic Federation to the affiliated unions for action proved a surprise to Mr. Gompers. A letter was read from him at yesterday's meeting of the Central body, in which he said he had not sent the matter in shape to be ready for such action.

MANCHESTER, Jan. 12 -- The cloth market during the past week was generally firm. There was fair business in some directions, while in others there was difficulty in arranging for the decline of cotton in the early part of the week. Heavy port receipts caused an abstention from buying. The recent improvement in tone has enabled sellers to regain their lost ground.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Four of the eight boys who escaped from the State Reform School at Jamesburg on Friday were captured here this evening. They are John Klein of Paterson, Eugene Sloane of Belvidere, and Edward Jacobs and Willis Dickerson of Trenton. The boys allege brutal treatment at the school and charge some of the keepers with being almost inhuman in their actions toward them.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 12 -- The Rev. Dr. C.H. Parkhurst, who is ill with lumbago at Lakehurst, was much improved today. He read with great interest this afternoon the news that Mr. Croker had retired from the leadership of Tammany Hall, and expressed the belief that it was not a bona fide retirement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One very evident fact which has been brought to the front in the present controversy as to the proper methods of dealing with vice and the Sunday laws is that few people seem to apprehend the vital point at issue or the proper attitude and responsibility of the Government toward the community.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Burglars entered the residence of Simon Rothschild, at 348 Palisade Avenue, this city, early this morning and stole about $1,000 worth of loot. Eutrance was effected by means of a skylight. "It is supposed that one of the burglars climbed one of the ornamental pillars in front of the house to the roof and opened the skylight.

John Hills, for thirty years an active figure in commercial life in this city, died yesterday of Bright's disease at his home, 715 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn. He was a member of the Hills Brothers Company, one of the largest wholesale dealers in fruit in the country.
Thomas C. Hall lectured before the Peopie's Institute at Cooper Union last evening on the subject "Duty and Pleasure." The speaker said, in part:

GOSHEN, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Luther Marsh talked at the morning and evening services in Christ Church, Universalist, Middletown. His subject was "Some Thoughts of Jesus, the Christ." In the evening address he made the following references to Spiritualism:

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- Notwithstanding the unfavorable view of the condition of business given by the speech from the throne, read by Count von Bulow at the opening of the Prussian Diet Jan. 8, and the pessimistic survey of the finances of the empire by Baron von Thielmann, Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, the Boerse had another strong week.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The length of electric lnes of railroads in New York State was ncreased 117.83 miles, 34 new street railroad companies were incorporated, with an aggregate length of proposed railroad of 530 3/4 miles, and steam surface railroads increased their mileage from 28,843.30 miles in 1900 to 32,119.42 miles in 1901. The main lines of railroads were increased from 15,664,23 to 17,518,05.

Church fair methods, Wall Street and society gambling were dealt with by the Rev. Dr. Alinot J. Savage in his sermon on "The Ethics of Gambling," in the Church of the Messiah yesterday morning. He said in part:

Major Gen. O.O. Howard was the principal speaker yesterday at the Sunday afternoon meeting in the West Side Auditorium of the Young Men's Christian Association on West Fifty-seventh Street. He was announced to make only a short introductory speech in the opening services, but it became known that he would make some remarks upon the Chinese question, and a large number of people was in attendance, completely filling the auditorium and its galleries.

Dr. Burch, pastor of the Mott Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, of which John M. Wisker. who is held responsible for the recent disaster in Park Avenue tunnel, offered prayer yesterday morning on behalf of the engineer. Wisker was not present. After the service Dr. Burch said:

The resolutions introduced in the Assembly by Mr. WAINWRIGHT, representing the district in which New Rochelle is situated, requesting the Railroad Commissioners to take action in regard to the tunnel, ought not to be necessary, but their passage may stimulate the Commissioners to more prompt and effective measures.
ST. ETIENNE, France, Jan. 12 -- Favored by cold, fine weather, the opening of the Ministerial electoral campaign here to-day proved an unqualified success.

A young woman who said she was Mrs. Emily C. Tarbocs, twenty-four years old, of 713 Cortlandt Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested at One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street and Third Avenue last night because she had on a uniform which belongs to her husband as a conductor of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Not a word of comment, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, appeared in yesterday's Vienna newspapers regarding the speech in the Reichstag on Friday by Count von Biilow, the German Imperial Chancellor.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Legislature concluded its first week of actual business on Friday last and up to that time 200 new bills had been introduced. Many of the new measures have excellent prospects of passing both houses, but it is predicted that 75 per cent. of them never will get out of committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In the House of Representatives Monday will be given to measures affecting the District of Columbia. After that the Pension Appropriation bill will be passed. Although this measure carries about $139,000,000, it follows the department estimates, and does not involve any serious issues, so that after a brief explanation it will probably have a prompt passage.

The success of American manufactures in the markets of the world has had the effect of turning the attention of Europeans to means for counteracting the ascendency of the United States. To shrewd observers in Europe the situation comes with no surprise; they foresaw it a decade or more ago, and even then began to devise methods of defense.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The Fire Department of this village was called twice to-day to fight the same fire. As it was Sunday and as each alarm was sounded at meal time there was a full turnout. The department did excellent work, for, while the building in which the fire started was gutted, the big frame building next to it was saved.

It will not profit much to discuss what may or may not be the immediate future of the stock market, for the reason that so long as the professional element is in control --as at present it is -- the movement of prices will to a large extent depend upon the operations of that element.

Soon after ex-Senator David B. Hill learned that Richard Croker had abdicated as leader of Tammany Hall he left Saturday night for his home, at Albany. Among those with whom Mr. Hill talked before leaving the city were Perry Belmont and John C. Sheehan.

Lewis Nixon will be at Tammany Hall at 10 o'clock this morning to actively take up the duties of leadership. He spent several hours yesterday with his private secretary. Thomas F. Smith, outlining his detailed plans for building up the Tammany organization in every Assembly district of the city along new lines.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 12 -- When the United States collier Leonidas sails from here to-morrow morning at 9 o'clock she will have aboard a detachment of marines bound first to Culebra Island and then to St. Thomas and other islands or the Danish West Indies. These marines will be joined by others.

BUFFALO, Jan. 12 -- Henry Pearlstein, his wife and five children, ranging in age from one and a half to twelve years, were burned to death early this morning in a fire that destroyed a two-story frame building at 1,047 Broadway. Joseph Supowski, who owned the building and kept a shoe store on the ground floor, has been placed under arrest pending an investigation as to whether the fire was of incendiary origin.

MANILA, Jan. 12 -- Medical authorities here assert that a considerable amount of the breaking down in health among American residents of the Philippine Islands is due to their nostalgia. The newspapers of Manila are urging the Philippine Commission to make an appropriation for a daily cable news service from the United States, thus bringing Americans here into closer touch with their home life.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 12 -- The Michigan Telephone Company, with the other telephone concerns controlled by the Erie, has formally passed into the control of the Bell combination, known as the American Telegraph and Telephone Company. It is announced that the scheme of reorganization of the Erie has been carried through, and that by means of this the $9,000,000 of indebtedness, which has been carried along for a year, will be wiped out.

We took occasion some time since to point out that if Mr. CROKER should fix on Mr. NIXON to be either his successor in the leadership of Tammany or the nominee of Tammany for Mayor, it would be a policy which the friends of good government in this city could not afford to regard with indifference.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Ptomaine poisoning last night nearly killed Thomas O'Neill and his wife and two sons, John, four years old, and Michael, seven. Yesterday the older boy bought 25 cents worth of meat from a butcher's shop. Mrs. O'Neill did not like the looks of it, but as she had been buying meat from the same shop for years.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- Speaking on the subject "Chinese Exclusion -- Is It in Harmony With the Moral Principles of the Single Tax?" William Lloyd Garrison of Boston argued before the Henry George Club to-night that the barring of Orientals from this country was contrary to the principles of free government and "a link in the chain of imperial aggrandizement."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The announcement that Prince Henry of Prussia, brother of Emperor William, will come to the United States has caused much interesting speculation as to the details of his reception. The programme for his entertainment will be an elaborate one, appropriate for his high station.

Only the capable and economical woman knows how to take advantage of these days in the shops. A woman who makes, or at least can make, over and alter her clothes and clean them can save a fortune in her purchases this month. There are charming things in waists which during the season, have become soiled and slightly shopworn, and which are perhaps in "out" sizes, which are sold at marvelous reductions.

ROME, Ga., Jan. 12 -- As a result of a collision between a passenger and a freight train on the Southern Railway twenty miles north of here early this morning Mme, Lillian Nordica, the singer, was injured, and her accompanist, E. Romaine Simmons, sustained a bruised hand. Engineer Frank Tracey was killed, and three other employes of the road were hurt.

If Mr. OXNARD will not get out of the road he must be run over. His attitude is not only perfectly selfish and unreasonable, but the consequences of his obstruction, should he prevent the granting of any tariff concessions on Cuban sugar, would come perilously near to putting him in the position of a public enemy.

At a meeting of the Board of Manages of the State Charities Aid Association, held last Friday, a statement was adopted with reference to the recommendations contained in the annual message of the Governor, and already embodied in bills introduced in the Legislature, regarding the State hospitals for the insane.

Ex-Gov. and Mrs. Levi P. Morton announced yesterday the engagement of their fourth daughter, Miss Alice Morton, to Winthrop Rutherfurd of this city. Miss Alice Morton has only recently returned with her family from Europe, where this Autumn Miss Helen Morton was married to the Count Boson Tallyrand Perigord.
PARIS, Jan. 13 -- According to the Presse, the battleship Massena is fitting out at Brest, in order to take President Loubet to St. Petersburg to return the visit to France of the Czar.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Col. John N. Partridge, ex-Superintendent of Public Works, has prepared that department's annual report, which will be submitted to the Legislature to-morrow night by his successor, Charles S. Boyd.

"I have observed a curious thing about distances," said a thoughtful citizen," and I have heard many persons comment on the same thing; but I have never seen any satisfactory explanation of it. In fact, I suppose nearly every person who has had an opportunity to contrast conditions as they exist in cities with the more open conditions in rural sections has observed the same thing.

About 100 men and women interested in the work which the Hebrew Technical Institute is doing for the Jewish boys of New York, met yesterday morning in the Hebrew Charities Building, at Second Avenue and Twenty-first Street, to hear how the work had progressed during the past year, and to learn of the plans for the future.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for David Rothschild to an investor the seven-story apartment house known as the Lauriston, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, 85 by 100. The structure was only recently completed, and while the exact selling price could not be learned yesterday, it is known that the property has been held at about $400,000.

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- Upon the resumption of the hearings on the postal fraud charges this afternoon E.G. Rathbone was unexpectedly called by the Government. The court told Rathbone he had the right to refuse to testify if he so desired. He replied that he was glad of this opportunity to testify.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 13. -- Mme. Nordica arrived here to-day, and her appearance at the Masonic Theatre to-night was a triumph. There was not the slightest indication of physical ill-effects from yesterday's accident, and she sang in splendid voice. A large audience accorded her an ovation.

The American people have within the past week read with surprise, and, we hope, with incredulity, news reports from Monte Carlo of the general tenor of the following dispatch which appeared in the columns of our neighbor The Sun on Monday morning:

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- A span of horses attached to the sleigh of B.P. Cheney, in which Mr. Cheney and his wife, formerly Julia Arthur, were riding, ran away in one of the most crowded streets of Boston today, and brought up against a store window. An electric car struck the sleigh, and Mr. and Mrs. Cheney were thrown out and somewhat hurt, but it is thought no serious injuries were sustained.

Practically every important active stock dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday showed a decline at the close of the day, as the result of a continuation of the seiling movement which set in on Saturday following the publication of the bank statement, though the statement itself was altogether favorable.

Without the least warning, so the officials of the company claim, thirty-three men comprising the day force at the power house of the New York and Staten Island Electric Company at Livingston, S.I., quit work yesterday at 3:30 o'clock. They had shut down the engines, drawn the fires, drawn out the plugs from the boards, and left the power house perfectly "dead."

The fight for the control of the American District Telegraph Company has reached a very critical stage. Edwin Gould, the largest individual shareholder in the company, said yesterday that in case the Western Union interests in the District Telegraph did not prevail at the annual meeting the last of the month, the Western Union Company would establish a messenger service of its own.

Bellevue Hospital received a shock yesterday which for a few hours caused almost as much uneasiness among the officials as the scandal made public a little over a year ago, resulting in the retirement of the head of that institution and the indictment of two nurses charged with having caused by brutal treatment the death of a patient in the insane pavilion.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The Politische Correspondenz, quoted by the Vienna correspondent of The Times, says public discussion at Constantinople of the Franco-Italian agreement in regard to the Mediterranean has caused intense annoyance, though no surprise. The publication is particularly unwelcome, yet it is not certain that a formal protest will be issued.
Theodore Douglas Robinson, son of Douglas Robinson, and President Roosevelt's favorite nephew, is to be operated upon today for appendicitis. Dr. Bull is to perform the operation.

We note with much satisfaction that the Schoolmasters' Association of New York is giving serious attention to the subject of declamation in schools. To Prof. THOMPSON belongs the credit of having told the professional pedagogues some plain truths on this subject, which have been known for generations to every one but themselves, and especially to all thoughtful persons not too old to remember the incidents of their own school days.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Coquelin Aine, with his own company, began a week's engagement to-night at the Royal Theatre. The French actor was most cordially received. Tickets for the performance sold at twenty marks ($4.76) each, which is an extraordinary price for Berlin.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- A rather lively debate was precipitated at the opening of the Assembly to-night, when Mr. Davis's bill adding four members to the Board of Trustees of the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Libraries, was called up. Mr. McKean of Kings moved an amendment, adding all elective officers to the board.

At a largely attended dinner of the Phi Delta Phi Club of the City of New York last night at the Hotel Marlborough, Mayor Low and Police Commissioner Partridge were criticised and the Bar Association of the City of New York was attacked and defended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Justice Gray of the United States Supreme Court delivered an opinion to-day in the case of Nutting against the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, involving the constitutionality of the law of that State prescribing penalties upon brokers or others who negotiate or make contracts in Massachusetts with insurance companies which are not admitted to do business in the State.

A large number of saloons in this city were open all day on Sunday. Beer and liquors were freely sold and consumed. In some places the device of the sandwich served with the drink in a rear room was employed to give the business the color and seeming of a compliance with the law; in others the barroom itself was filled with customers and the law was frankly violated without subter-fuge.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day announced that it will conduct a formal investigation of the tunnel disaster in New York City. The investigation will open on Monday, Jan. 20, and will be conducted at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, New York. The investigation which Commissioner Baker and Inspector Schultz have been conducting has been in the nature of an informal inquiry upon which the board will base its formal investigation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Representative Hill (Rep.) of Connecticut presented to-day the majority report from the House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures in favor of the bill providing for the exchangeability of gold and silver coins. The report largely follows that of the last year on the same bill, although Mr. Hill has added much new information as to the world's supply of the precious metals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Republican members of the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals apologized to-day to M. Lampre, the representative of the Panama Canal Company, for the treatment he had received from Chairman Morgan, (Dem., Ala.) They told him they disclaimed all responsibility for Mr. Morgan's actions, which, they said, they regarded as insulting and discourteous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Nothing has yet been decided definitely about the programme for the reception and entertainment of Prince Henry of Prussia. The President has talked about the matter to members of his Cabinet, but has neither made nor received any suggestions about the form which the reception will take.

Mrs. Patrick Campbell found a very appreciative audience at the new Theatre Republic last night, though not a wildly enthusiastic one. It was an intelligent assemblage of theatre-goers and actors and actresses, who watched for each situation and weighed it against the same scene as it has been played by the foremost women of the boards, by Eleanora Duse, by Modjeska, and others.

The fashionable season is at its zenith. Besides the larger dances, there are a number of smaller affairs going on, and many are giving a series of dinners. The cotillion last evening for the Misses Mills, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills, given by Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, was the most notable entertainment.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The bill for the abolishment of the Boards of Managers of the State charities did not go in to-night. It may not be ready for a couple of days.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- There will be a hearing to-morrow before the Taxation and Retrenchment Committees of the two houses on the Stranahan mortgage tax bill. Delegations from New York are expected to attend the hearing.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The announcement made by Senator Platt in Washington that he would be a candidate for re-election to the Senate aroused considerable interest among the Republican politicians here.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 13. -- Dagmar, Mr. Phinizey, and El Ghor were the winning favorites, Dagmar's win in the steeple-chase is a new record for the track. George Odom arrived to-day and will ride during the meeting. Weather clear and cool; track fast, Summary:

Christopher Donnelly, a Brooklyn policeman, nearly lost his life early yesterday morning while saving Edward Barrie, 185 Park Row, Manhattan, who had fallen into the East River. Donnelly succeeded in getting ashore with Barrie only after a desperate struggle in the darkness to find a landing place.
A bright-eyed boy, neatly clad, and apparently about fourteen years old, entered Tammany Hall at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and inquired of half a dozen men sitting in the outer room:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 13. -- As the result at a conference between the interested parties to the Detroit and Toledo Shore Line receivership held in this city to-day, all differences are practically settled and the tangle has been straightened out. The claim of Contractor Strang of New York will be paid, the road will be financed and completed, and in a short time the State Court litigation will be dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Indications were given to-day that the people of the Pacific Coast were highly displeased over the Philippine Tariff bill. Senators and Representatives from that region have been hearing from their constituents, and they report that public sentiment against the bill is rising.

OLNEY, III., Jan. 13. -- Wickliff Higgins, who was arrested in New York a few days ago to be returned to Olney on the charge of misappropriating public funds, was a politician of prominence in Richland County ten years ago. While he was High Sheriff an old man named Cornell was in the jail. He gave Higgins his history and showed him papers to make good his claim to a large English estate.

The popular uneasiness in Great Britain concerning the present condition and possible duration of the domestic coal supply has resulted in the appointment of a royal commission to go over again and correct or verify the conclusions of the commission of 1871, which gave five years to the investigation of this subject and made a report of exceptional thoroughness and value.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- The slump in Philadelphia Electric, the lighting combination of this city, was the overshadowing feature of the local market to-day. Bonds and stocks were thrown on the market in extravagant amounts. The scare started on Saturday with a raid on the 4 per cent. bonds.

The annual election of the New York Athletic Club will be held this evening. But one independent nomination in opposition to the regular ticket has been made, James H. Haslin being nominated for the Board of Governors. Against which regular nominee this independent nomination is directed or course will not be known until the election takes place.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 13. -- It was stated at the headquarters of the McKinley National Memorial Association to-day that the issuance of several additional proclamations by Governors had stirred up the public throughout the country to make McKinley Day a splendid success.

Lewis Nixon reached Tammany Hall at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning and took the historic chair and desk from which William M. Tweed, John Kelly, and Richard Croker dominated in turn the affairs of the organization. Before going to the Wigwam Mr. Nixon went to the Democratic Club, where he had a talk with Richard Croker.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Senator Ambler of Columbia, a leading anti-canal legislator, introduced in the Senate to-night a concurrent resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution, that Section S of the Constitution, which forbids the sale of canals, be eliminated. This will allow the State to lease, rent, or sell the canals.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Resolutions calling upon Congress to reopen the Schley case and make its own decision as to who was in command at the battle of Santiago were passed by the Board of Trade at its annual meeting to-day. The vote was not unanimous, but the roar of "Yeas" was much louder than that of the "Nays," and the vocal vote went unchallenged as expressing the feeling of the board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- M. Lampre, Secretary of the Panama Canal Company, appeared before the Senate Committee on Inteloceanic Canals again to-day. Senator Morgan (Dem., Ala.) questioned him closely, especially concerning the interest of the stockholders of the old Panama Canal Company in the pending transaction.

-- A reader whose letter we published on Sunday seems to have derived much satisfaction with what he calls our "little skirmish" over the word "aleatory," but then he went ahead on his own account and indulged in some criticism of our vocabulary -- criticism which, despite its good nature, was not on that account the less likely to start another skirmish, this time with himself.

A form of complaint to submit to the Attorney General for use in the Institution of quo warranto proceedings was agreed upon yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the lawyers representing both sets of City Magistrates who are claiming title to office in Brooklyn. The quo warranto proceedings are planned to end the dispute.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and supplies were ample. Discounts were quiet. On the Stock Exchange operators were largely occupied with the settlement in mines and preparations to carry over in other sections to-morrow. The tone was generally cheerful. First-class securities were firm, but consols declined at the close, owing to the belief that the German loan will interfere with the success of the expected British loan.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13. -- Traders refused to follow the selling movement in Wall Street, which refusal steadied the list, reduced the number of declines, and made possible the scoring of some good gains. The losses were mostly fractional, and were chiefly among the speculative issues. On the other hand, the advances range from 1/8 to 5 points.
BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- Prince Henry of Prussia will be attended on his visit to the United States by Capts. Schmidt, von Schwindt, and von Egidy, and by several high marine officers not yet selected.

We have already noted the general plan of the reform of the system of selecting Consuls proposed by Senator LODGE. In response to inquiries by correspondents, we submit the specific features of the plan in some detail.

The Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company has been ordered by Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal to place an additional man on the front platform of every train crossing the Brooklyn Bridge during the so-called "rush" hours of the day. The idea of having two motormen instead of one on the front platform of each train is to prevent any possibility of accident when the trains follow each other so closely.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 13. -- The will of Ernest F. Walton, the young member of the New York Stock Exchange who was killed in the tunnel disaster last week, filed in the Surrogate's Court to-day, leaves his estate, valued at $60,000, to his widow. Edward J. Coppet and Robert P. Doremus, Mr. Walton's partners in Wall Street, are named as executors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial contained in your Saturday's edition on Gov. Odell and his proposition regarding the designation of County Judges to hold court as Supreme Court Justices was timely and should be read and considered by every voter in this State.

Guglielmo Marconi, the inventor of the wireless telegraph, as the guest of honor at the annual dinner of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers at the Waldorf-Astoria last night described to a gathering of his co-workers in the field of electricity how he sent his already world-famous message across the Atlantic Ocean.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- The inaugural meeting of the London Liberal Association at St. James's Hall last evening had been awaited with great interest, principally because it was probable that light would be thrown upon the future relations of Lord Rosebery and the Liberal Party. Lord Rosebery was not present at the meeting at which Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, Liberal leader in the House of Commons, and Earl Spencer were the principal speakers.

Steps were taken in the Surrogates' Court yesterday which showed that the various parties involved in litigation over the estate and wills of the millionaire William Marsh Rice had entered into an agreement not to dispute the validity of the will of 1896, and to unite in contesting the will of 1900, known as the Albert T. Patrick will.

One of the most disquieting rumors floating about this city yesterday had to do with a corner on eggs. It was vaguely reported about the Produce Exchange that somebody had quietly gathered in the product of nearly every hen engaged in working for New York, and that for a time every table except those of the very rich throughout the greater city would be barren of this article of sustenance.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was more active than at the close of last week, but with this increase of activity the irregularity of the past few days was succeeded by a decided downward tendency. Practically all the active issues closed lower for the day, and in a few the net losses were substantial.

BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, replied in the lower house of the Diet to-day to interpellations relative to the Polish question in Prussia. The National Liberals desired to known how Germanism was to be upheld, while the Polish members bitterly criticised the events at Wreschen declaring that the sentences of the courts "must have caused Justice to veil her face in shame."

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- A remarkable article appears in The Times to-day under the caption "Literature of German Anglophobia," describing the character of the anti-British cartoons which have appeared in the German newspapers. The Times says these cartoons "in coarseness, obscenity, and venom are without a parallel in modern times."

The personal tax assessments for 1902 are now open to inspection, and the "swearing off" process will start at once and continue until the books close on March 31. The assessments levied this year represent the work of the old Tax Commissioners, and several billions of personal assessments on residents, non-residents, resident corporations, and non-resident corporations have been placed on the books.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 14 -- Grave apprehension is felt among naval officers at Esquimault over failure of H.B.M. ship Condor, one of the vessels of the North Pacific Squadron, to arrive at Honolulu, for which port she sailed Dec. 2. On Saturday word was received from the British Consul at the Hawaiian capital that the vessel, then considerably overdue at Honolulu, had not arrived.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- In the Senate to-day Senator McCabe of Brooklyn asked that the reference of the bill regulating and legalizing the practice of osteopathy be changed from the Committee on Judiciary to the Committee on Public Health. The osteopathic bill was introduced by Senator Brackett of Saratoga, who asked its reference to the Judiciary Committee, of which he is the Chairman.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Caught in an alleged gambling joint and worried because he would be one of the witnesses, Harry B. Sharp killed himself this morning by putting a bullet in his brain. Sharp was until recently one of the best-known and most popular business men in this city.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The hearing on the Stranahan mortgage tax bill before the Senate and House Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment developed little serious opposition to the bill. Senator Stranahan said to-night that two amendments offered by Lawson Purdy, Secretary of the New York Tax Reform Association, would probably be accepted by the Senate Committee, and with these changes he thought the bill would pass.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- A chicken coop has been the home of William H. Pugsley, the wealthy landscape artist for almost two months. He will be able to move back into his house in a day or two if the orders of City Judge Bennett are obeyed by Mrs. Alice Brown, a sister of Mrs. Pugsley.

Andrew Carnegie was the chief speaker last night at the celebration of the twenty-sixth anniversary of the Railroad Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, 361 Madison Avenue. Chauncey M. Depew for the first time in twenty-six years was absent Edward V.W. Rossiter presided. The hall on the second floor of the building was filled to overflowing with railroad men.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being a constant reader of your valuable paper, and being an ex-railroad man of twelve years' experience, I have taken a deep interest in your editorials and also letters bearing on the frightful disaster which occurred in the tunnel last week. I would most respectfully request a short space of your valuable paper to make reply to the letter of "Non-Expert" in your issue of even date.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- While the Republican members of the Philippine Committee have not arrived at any definite agreement to amend the Philippine Tariff bill, it is given out as altogether probable that the rate of duty on Philippine products coming to this country will be 75 per cent. of the Dingley rates, with a reduction on goods upon which an export tax is charged in the Philippines, equal to such tax.
LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The Paris correspondent of The Times quotes an article on the Isthmian Canal which Victor Berard contributes to to-day's Revue de Paris.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Senator Platt of New York has introduced a bill to authorize the issue of circulating notes by State banks. It provides that banks may deliver to the United States Treasurer State, city, or county stocks or bonds and receive from the Controller of the Currency circulating notes not to exceed 80 per cent, of the market value of the stocks or bonds so delivered.

-- Quite the most remarkable document, in some ways, that ever came into this office is a thin pamphlet, issued, according to the title page, by "the Pan-German League," whatever that may be. The author is the Rev. DIEDRICH VON SLOOTEN, "late a Predikant in the South African Republic," and "co-laborer in the Lord and fellow-refugee of the Rev. HERMAN D. VAN BROEKHUIZEN."

A large number of the members of the Nineteenth Century Club assembled at Sherry's last night to listen to a discussion by well-known speakers on the subject of "What Shall We Do With Anarchy and Anarchists?" The speakers were Recorder John W. Goff, the Rev. Lyman W. Abbott, and Edmund Wetmore.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Assembly Committee on Judiciary to-night reported the bill introduced on the recommendation of the Governor for the abolishment of the Boards of Managers for the eleven State Asylums for the Insane and the appointment of a Superintendent by the Governor, on the recommendation of the State Commission in Lunacy, to perform the duties now discharged by these boards.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- William Fife of Fairlie, on the Clyde, is to build Sir Thomas Lipton's next challenger for the America's Cup. At a conference just held between Sir Thomas and his advisers definite arrangements were made for the construction of the Shamrock III. and an order for the new yacht was given to and accepted by Mr. Fife.

Signor MARCONI, who sails to-day for Europe is not a stranger to the representative men of his profession in the United States, but it may be truthfully said that he leaves our shores with the respect and good wishes of every electrical engineer and the confidence of every one financially interested in the telegraph business.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Times says one of the principal reasons for Mr. Chamberlain's unpopularity on the Continent is the fact that he has done more than any other living Englishman to further the cause of imperialism in the British Empire. He has largely contributed to inspiring the British people with confidence in their own strength and resources, which confidence naturally makes them feel more independent of Continental alliances.
