The principal speakers at the third annual banquet of the Jewelers' Association and Board of Trade, held last night at Sherry's, were James B. Dill and John Sparhawk, Jr., of the Philadelphia bar. Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, who was to speak on "The American at Home and Abroad," was through illness unable to attend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few days ago Congressman Charles Grosvenor of Southern Ohio, in an interview with The Herald's Washington correspondent, said with reference to the irrigation bill in Congress: "My constituents are farmers, and I don't believe in taxing the farmers of Ohio just to benefit the farmers of the West."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Oscar S. Straus of New York, ex-United States Minister to Turkey, was to-day appointed a permanent member of the Committee of Arbitration at The Hague.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- The certificate of incorporation of the New York-New Jersey Trust Company was presented to the Department of Banking and Insurance to-day, and an application made under the statute for its approval and for leave to organize the corporation.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors of the New York Central, which was held yesterday morning at the Grand Central Station, the plans of the engineering department for the improvement of the service through the Park Avenue tunnel were considered, and it was decided to submit them to the full Board of Directors, which is to meet this morning.

The Verein Deutscher Eisen and Stahl Industrielle has just published some interesting figures compiled by its eminent statistician. Dr. H. RENTZSCH, showing the distribution of iron and steel production throughout the world. The tables are full of material for interesting and instructive comparisons.

ALGIERS, Jan. 14 -- Max Regis, the ex-Mayor of Algiers and Anti-Semite leader, was arrested here this morning and imprisoned, on account of his failure to pay damages obtained against him in various libel suits. In default of payment, M. Regis was sentenced to terms of imprisonment aggregating three years.

The annual award of three first prizes, given by the Century Road Club Association, to its leaders in mileage, century riding, and securing new members, has just been announced. Three solid gold medals and other honors are evenly distributed, New York, Brooklyn, and New Jersey sharing the first prizes, and Watervilet N.Y., and Far Rockaway, L.I., with New York, the second honors.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Gov. Voorhees to-day transmitted his third and last annual message to the Legislature. As he is soon to turn over his office to his successor the message was largely in the nature of a valedictory.
Members and the friends of the New York Zoological Society met at the Waldorf-Astoria last night to attend the sixth annual meeting of the society and two lantern slide lectures.

With the exception of the Hoyt dance, there were not any very notable entertaintments yesterday evening. Tuesday is generally reserved for dinners, and there were quite a number of them. One of the largest was given by Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Mills for their twin daughters, who made their debuts Monday evening at the ball given for them by Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid.

Mr. NORMAN E. MACK bespeaks for Mr. NIXON in his new office of leader of Tammany Hall the cordial welcome and support of the Democratic press. It has been the misfortune of Democratic leaders in New York, says Mr. MACK, to encounter the opposition of the newspapers of their own party.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- The examination of Estes G. Rathbone, ex-Director General of Posts of Cuba, was continued this afternoon, when the trial of the charges growing out of the Cuban Post Office frauds was resumed. Private correspondence between Rathbone and ex-Postmaster General Smith was introduced.

Plans for coming races and runs were made yesterday by the Board of Governors of the Automobile Club of America. It was decided to hold a one hundred mile run, without stop, on Decoration Day, May 30. The start will be made from the clubhouse, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, and the run will be fifty miles out and back.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday handed down a decision upholding the constitutionality of the Percy-Gray racing law of this State, the effect of which was to permit bets to be made at the race track, while they may not be made in poolrooms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The House devoted much time to-day to the proposition advanced by Mr. Rixey (Dem., Va.) yesterday to open the doors of the soldiers homes to ex-Confederate veterans. Two notable, speeches were made in support of the proposition, one by Mr. Gardner, (Rep., Mich.,) and the other by Mr. De Armond (Dem., Mo.)

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- Jules Martin Cambon, Ambassador of the French Republic, to the United States, has been secured by William B. Hornblower, President of the State Bar Association, to deliver the annual address before that organization at its convention, to be held in this city on Tuesday. Jan. 21.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I ask the privilege of responding to the communication of Jan. 1 of Mr. E.P. Bacon, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Law Convention, and the communication of Dec. 28, from Mr. Robert W. Higbie, member of the Committee on Legislation of the National Wholesale Lumber Dealers' Association.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 14 -- The most noteworthy incident of to-day's trading was the weakness of the trust companies group, with Mercantile leading. It broke 4 points in consequence of the reduction in the semi-annual dividend from 8 to 6 per cent. Maryland Casualty was also 1 point lower and International declined 1 1/4 points.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 14 -- The sessions of the New Jersey Legislature for 1902 opened at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The two houses organized with the election of the officers agreed upon in the Republican caucuses some time ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- The subsidence of the scare over Philadelphia Electric bonds gave the market a cheerful tone in the earlier trading to-day. In the Electrics there was a marked recovery, the 4s rallying 2 3/4 and the 5s 2 3/8. The stock closed 1/8 better. An unconfirmed rumor was to the effect that the company would declare a dividend to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Cabinet meeting to-day was devoted largely to considering the appointment of representatives of this country at the coronation of King Edward VII. At the conclusion of the meeting the following designations were announced by the Secretary of State:

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Court of Appeals to-day reversed the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Second Department, granting a new trial to William F. Miller, of the Franklin Syndicate, and has affirmed the judgment of the Trial Court convicting him of larceny.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 14 -- As was generally expected, ex-United States Senator Arthur Pue Gorman was to-day re-elected to that position by the solid Democratic vote of both branches of the General Assembly. His opponent, Congressman William H. Jackson, received the straight Republican support in both houses, the combined vote standing Gorman, 6S; Jackson, 52.
The annual meeting of the members of the Merchants' Association was held at the rooms of the association yesterday afternoon. De Le Roy Dresser, President of the association, was in the chair.

The present system of conducting the institutions for the care of the insane is certainly far from ideal, but we are not able to see in what it would be improved by the changes urged by the Governor, while there are risks in that change of rather a serious sort.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The demand for money increased to-day in connection with Stock Exchange requirements, but the supply was plentiful, owing to the release of dividend and interest payments. Discounts were easy. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet. Prices were irregular, but the changes were trifling.

Two full halves and a short extra period were required last night to decide the hockey contest between the New York Athletic Club and the Crescent Athletic Club, at the Clermont Avenue Rink, the former team winning by a score of 5 to 1. The contest was about the fastest ever played between local teams, as neither seven seemed to care to act upon the defensive.

An application for alimony and counsel fees was made before Justice Dugro, in the Supreme Court, yesterday in the suit for separation, on the ground of cruelty, brought by Mrs. Mina Larre Smith Duryea against her husband, Chester Burnell Duryea, son of Gen. Hiram Duryea, organizer of the Starch Trust, which was capitalized at $30,000,000.
Frederick Zittel has sold for Elisha P.S. Wright to a client the two five-story American basement dwellings, with extensions, 312 and 314 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, each 20 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Mr. Young said to-night that he expected to send to the printer to-morrow the stenographer's notes of the last meeting of the League, and soon will be in a position to furnish a copy of the report to those desiring it. Heretofore it has not been the practice of the President to have the reports of the League meeting printed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Gov. Durbin of Indiana, Senator Fairbanks. Attorney General Taylor, and State Audtior Hart called at the White House to-day and invited the President to attend the dedication of the Soldiers Monument at Indianapolis on May 15.

HONGKONG, Jan. 14 -- The British steamer Nanning (belonging to the Hongkong, Canton and Macao Steam Coal Company, Limited,) of Hongkong, has been fired on by Chinese soldiers in the Tam-Chau Channel, West River.

Controller Grout, in compliance with many requests, recently set a corps of expert accountants to work to ascertain the exact nature and extent of the work of Horgan Slattery, the Tammany official architects of the city. Yesterday the following data were made public in regard to the fees paid to the firm each year during the Van Wyck administration and claims now pending by them against the city.
BERLIN, Jan. 14 -- Baron Heyl zu Herrnsheim (National Liberal) proposed an amendment to the Tariff bill in committee to-day which was aimed at the United States.

LONG BRANCH, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Light and flighty winds cut short the sport of the ice yachtsmen of the South Shrewsbury and Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Clubs this afternoon. A keen interest was manifested in the match race between the Leroy, which holds the championship of the North and South Shrewsbury Rivers, and Commodore Morris's Mildred.

Further declines occurred in a number of outside, stacks yesterday, but to a greater extent than on Monday. These losses were offset by advances in other parts of the list. In one or two issues trading was more active than on any day recently, but the total transactions of the day were not unusually larg.

The engagement was announced yesterday of Miss Marion Mason, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. Lawrence Mason of Boston, to Richard Wilson, Jr., the youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Wilson, and a brother of Mrs. Ogden Goelet, the Hon. Mrs. Michael Herbert, Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, and M. Orme Wilson, who married Miss Carrie Astor.

By an arrangement with Oscar Hammerstein yesterday, David Belasco consummated a long cherished desire to secure a theatre for his own productions in New York. Negotiations were completed at the office of ex-Judge A.J. Dittenhoefer, whereby the Theatre Republic is leased to Mr. Belasco for ten years from May 1.

In the blue and white banqueting hall of the Hotel Savoy last evening, the Alumni of the New York University Law School sat down to their eighteenth annual dinner. Many distinguished members of the bench and bar were present. Criticisms were freely made of the proposition to give the Governor power to delegate Judges of the Supreme Court in the country districts to hear cases in New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- There was tumult to-day in the grain pits. For a time a panic of depression threatened everything. All other news was subordinated to the failure of George H. Phillips to advance margins on his deals and the consequent unloading of many million bushels of cereals on the already weakening markets.

"Bank Day," the annual meeting occasion of most of the banks of this city, brought about a number of important changes yesterday in the directorates of New York financial institutions. The most important of these changes was in the First National, the institution which recently increased its capital stock from $500,000 to $10,000,000, and which has become allied with the Chase National.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15. -- George I, Kline of St. Louis and Robert L. West of Cincinnati were arrested across the river this morning, charged with robbing the trunk of T. E. Manners of Chicago of about $2,500 worth of jewelry. The two men are alleged to have represented themselves last night as Manners and another guest at the St. Charles, to have? paid the bills, and to have gone away with the baggage.

The Coffee Exchange holds its annual election to-day. Two tickets have been put in nomination, and the main point at issue is the quqestion of a clearing house. The opposition claims that the men now in control have persistently opposed any attempt made for the creation of a clearing house, notwithstanding the fact that the majority of the coffee trade are in favor of such a plan.

An Increased attendance was noticeable yesterday in the Madison Square Garden, where the hens, roosters, turkeys, pigeons, ducks, geese, and ganders continued to make just as much noise as ever and seemed perfectly contented to look their prettiest and be admired by hundreds of pairs of eyes.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 15. -- Senator Foraker had practically no opposition for reelection before the General Assembly today, the partisan division being purely formal. The Democrats supported Charles H. Baker of Cincinnati. Every Republican member voted for Mr. Foraker. There were no addresses, except that of the Senator, and no demonstration except the applause which followed his introduction.

The obvious uneasiness which exists in the inner recesses of the Grand Central Station, and for which it must be admitted no little warrant exists at the moment, is doubtless tempered and mitigated by the thought that every day gained removes something of the danger which menaces.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Dr. von Holleben, the German Ambassador, to-day received a cablegram from Berlin giving the dates of the arrival and departure of Prince Henry, and a list of the party who will accompany him to the United States.

The bill introduced by Senator Platt in the Senate at Washington on Tuesday, giving authority for the issuing of State bank notes, was quite generally discussed by bankers yesterday. A synopsis of the provisions of the measure was given in these columns yesterday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J, Jan. 15. -- Vice Chancellor Pitney of the New Jersey Court of Chancery yesterday afternoon handed down a decision holding the President and Directors of the Middlesex County Bank of Perth Ambdy liable for the losses of that institution, amounting to about $219,000. These losses were occasioned by the defalcation of George M. Valentine, the cashier.

Black Beauty, the Van Cortlandt Park buffalo, who managed to resist all efforts at capturing him and transporting him to the Central Park Menagerie on Tuesday, remained in possession of the field all day yesterday, and, as far as can be ascertained, has not the least intention of joining the Central Park animals.

Yale defeated Princeton in the opening hockey game of the intercollegiate championship series at the St. Nicholas Rink last night. After two halves, in which exciting incidents were few, the wearers of the blue won without difficulty by the score of 7 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the effort of the New York legislator to eradicate the daisy is to me very interesting. It brings up afresh in these cold barren Winter days an old problem that has often puzzled me as I have walked out in June and seen the fields -- not white and ready for harvest, but white and destructive of the harvest.

The schedules of the Brooklyn Royal Arcanum and the Columbia Bowling Leagues were completed last night, though some ties remain to be decided in the former series and some postponed games in the latter. In the Royal Arcanum tournament De Forest Council won first place, with Bedford second and De Long third, in Class A, while in Class B, Empire State, Lefferts, and Gramercy Councils are tied for the first three places.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- On the day following New Year's Day the fact was reported that detectives had been stationed in the Executive Chamber to watch the crowd at Gov. Odell's reception, and it was stated that Superintendent Bendor was fearful, because of President McKinley's assassination at Buffalo, that an attempt might be made on Gov. Odell's life.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- Judge Grosscup of the United States Court has decided that the, city has the right to regulate the price of gas. The question came up in the case wherein the People's Gas, Light and Coke Company sought to have the city enjoined from enforcing its seventy-flve-cent gas ordinance.

The letter of Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE, which we print elsewhere in this issue, on the dangers of electrical power installations, especially in tunnels, is undoubtedly of interest, but it will be read with surprise, and even with consternation, by electrical engineers. Mr. WESTINGHOUSE undoubtedly has the right to hold the views he expresses, but why he should hold them is likely to be the subject of no little speculation.

M. LAMPRE, in behalf of the New Panama Canal Company, now offers to transfer to the United States all the rights and property of the company in the unfinished canal for $40,000,000, which is the estimate of value placed upon it by the Walker Canal Commission.

In German ears "Polenthum" is a word of scorn that includes irritation at a people who can prefer their own plastic and difficult language full of hissingsounds and triple consonants to good sound German, and contempt at the poverty and shiftlessness of the Poles of the novel and stage, who are represented for the most part as brainless worshippers of rank and title, charlatans and vulgarians, boastful and uncultured.

It was stated by an official of the Amalgamated Copper Company yesterday that the company had on Monday of this week begun the operation of the latest form of smelter, the plant having cost about $5,000,000. It was said that the use of this machine would make it possible to produce copper at a greatly reduced cost.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- At a meeting of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee today the clerk was directed to send communications to the heads of the various departments asking them to get their items for the annual supply bill in at once. It is expected that the committee will have all the estimates ready by the latter part of the week and that the bill will be reported some time next week.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- It is announced that the Government decided this morning that Prince Henry of Prussia is to sail for the United States on the Kronprinz Wilhelm of the North German Lloyd Line on Feb. 15. Cabins have been engaged for a suite of fifteen persons.

Policeman Barker of the West Thirtieth Street Station, a new man on the force, made his first arrest last night, and as a result a man said to be a nephew of the late Judge Fulton and a woman, who declares she is a relative of Police Captain Westervelt, were locked up. The man is charged with intoxication, and the woman with interfering with an officer.

Pinero's play, "Iris," which has occasioned much comment in London, where it has been running for four months at the Garrick Theatre, is to be presented here next season, with Virginia Harned in the title role.

A call to the pastorate of the Fifth Ave- nue Presbyterian Church has been extended to the Rev. Dr. J. Ross Stevenson, Professor of Ecclesiastical History in the McCormick Theological Seminary of Chicago. It was unanimously indorsed at a large congregational meeting of the church last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Gov. Odell's State Committee in Lunacy bill, providing for the abolishment of the Board of Managers at the eleven State asylums and the appointment of a general Superintendent, may be recommitted to the Assembly Committee on Judiciary, which reported it favorably last evening.

Curlers were out in considerable force yesterday on Van Cortlandt Lake, and the scene was the merriest that has been witnessed on the ice there this season. The curlers have had little opportunity thus far to enjoy their favorite sport, and the match that was played yesterday has twice been postponed on account of the vagaries of the weather.

The second meeting of the present Board of Aldermen was held yesterday. President Fornes announced the standing committees for 1902 and 1903. Alderman Herbert Parsons was named as Chairman of the Finance Committee, the most important assignment, as this appointment entitles him to vote as a member of the Sinking Fund Commission.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 15. -- For the second time in six months the safe of the Post Office at Spring Lake was robbed this morning. A. Cazda, living opposite the Post Office, saw the robbers, but a revolver at his head kept him quiet and the burglars escaped with their booty.

-- Our confident expectation that Mr. CHARLES M. SCHWAB would speedily realize the Injury done to himself and others by the reports of his doings at Monte Carlo, and that he would hasten to deny the accuracy of the stories, was justified by the dispatch from him which we published yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It may prove useful at this moment to direct the attention of the press to certain features incident to the use of electricity for the operation of trains or cars.

With all the impressive dignity of the ritual of the Protestant Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Frederick Burgess was consecrated Bishop of the Diocese of Long Island in Grace Church, on the Heights, Hicks Street, near Remsen, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. Sixteen Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States and two from Canada were present, besides more than 200 of the clergy of the diocese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- A certain amount of seriousness was contributed to the report that Secretary Gage had Senatorial aspirations by the circulation here this evening of an advance proof of an article that is to appear in The American Economist to-morrow. The article reads as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Controller Miller today appointed the following Tax Appraisers: Charles D. Lockwood of Troy, for Rensselaer County, salary $1,000. Charles H. Lovett of Mount Vernon, for Westchester County, salary $1,800; I.H. Loughran of Walden, for Orange County, salary $1,000; Gilbert T. Lofee of Patchogue, for Suffolk County, salary $1,000.

For several months complaints have been made to Capt. Schmlttberger that a young man has been presenting telegrams and notes to women in flathouses on the upper west side addressed to their husbands, signed with a woman's name and making an appointment. The bearer of the message each time extorted 25 to 50 cents from the wives and would then hurry away.

BERLIN, Jan. 15. -- Emperor William has occasionally told Americans that he would like to visit the United States, and it is said that he still desires to do so. But it is declared, there is not the least probability of his gratifying this desire, as reasons of State forbid his leaving Germany for the period of time required for a journey to the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15. -- All but a few minor stocks ended the day with advances. The only notable exception was in Cambria Steel, which stock fell 3/4 after the announcement of the dividend, but hardened toward the close. The restoration of confidence over the Philadelphia Electric situation was more manifest to-day than at any time since the depression set in.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 15. -- Both houses of the General Assembly met in joint convention at noon to-day and formally ratified the election to the United States Senate of Arthur P. Gorman in succession to George L. Wellington.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 15. -- The mysterious fight to secure control of the Western Maryland Railroad continues. Mayor Hayes declares that no action by the city will be taken until the parties come out in the open and say whom they represent. Their simple assertions that they do not represent the Pennsylvania Railroad, he says, are not sufficient, they must tell the public whom they do represent.

One is constantly seeing the confusion which prevails in fashions, and Summer things are worn in Winter and Winter things in Summer, and nothing but an almanac will keep us straight as to time. Velvet flowers are on all those pretty light Summer hats which are being shown just now.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The supplies of money were large to-day and discounts were easy. Business on the Stock Exchange opened quiet. Prices were firm, except in the case of Americans. Peace rumors helped Kafirs and strengthened consols. First-class securities were not especially active.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your timely editorial on a "College of Arts and Crafts" is a good and wise suggestion. It only needs one conversant with the methods and workings of the European guilds to organize such a society right here in the midst of a big manufacturing city like New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Hearings on the Cuban reciprocity question began today before the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.

Wednesday is usually set for weddings, and there were several yesterday, among the most notable of which was that of Miss Belknap and Dr. Deas Murphy. There were also many receptions and days at home, but no notable dance. This evening Mrs. H. McK. Twombly will give a dinner dance.

PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 15. -- The Board of Aldermen met again this evening, but failed to break the deadlock over the election of a President. Up to a late hour the board had taken to-night 160 ballots without reaching a conclusion. During the day Alderman Winters gave out a statement to the effect that a money consideration had been tendered him if he would break the deadlock.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- Bird S. Color, ex-Controller of New York City, was the principal speaker at the fourth annual banquet of the Rochester Credit Men's Association this evening. His subject was "The City and the State." and he spoke in part as follows:
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Dowling today introduced a bill which provides for the election of eight additional Supreme Court Judges for the First Department.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator McCabe was defeated to-day in his effort to have the reference of the Osteopath bill changed from the Committee on Judiciary to the Committee on Public Health. When Senator McCabe called up his motion an interesting debate ensued between him and Senator Brackett, during which Senator Brackett denied that he had received the bill from Senator Platt.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16. -- The decline in Seaboard issues was the feature of today's market. The decline was ascribed to the decrease of $18,185 in net earnings for the week ending Jan. 8. The preferred suffered a severer loss than the common, though both were fractional. The bad showing for the week was singularly effective, owing to the excessively limited orders now found in the market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- When the Isthmian Canal Commission met to-day the offer of the Panama Canal Company to sell its property to this country for $40,000,000 was considered. The expectation is that before the week closes the action of the commission with reference to the offer will have been determined.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- When the calendar of the Assembly was taken up this morning Speaker Nixon called Assemblyman Kelsey to the chair in order that he might speak upon the annual appropriation bill, on the order of final passage. Mr. Nixon spoke at length with reference to the provisions of the bill for the State Free School Fund.

Light fines and frequent threats of dismissal should offenders persist in their infractions of the regulations were again the rule at the trials of delinquent policement at Headquarters yesterday. Deputy Commissioner Thurston first presided, but was succeeded later by Commisioner Partridge There were about forty cases, and all were patiently heard.

Manager Joseph H. Franklin of the Grand Central Station and Harlem Line was put through a searching examination by District Attorney Jerome concerning the signal lights and method of operating trains in the New York Central tunnel, at the inquest before Coroner Scholer yesterday into the deaths of the seventeen victims of the recent tunnel disaster.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Gen. and Mrs. Gillespie entertained at dinner this evening at their home, in Rhode Island Avenue, in honor of Gen. and Mrs. Corbin. The additional guests were the Secretary of War and Mrs. Root, the ex-Surgeon General of the army and Mrs. Moore, Rear Admiral Walker, Mr. and Mrs. R. McM. Gillespie of New York, and Miss E.W. Brown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Cuban reciprocity was again under consideration by the Ways and Means Committee to-day. A large representation of Cubans and of the various sugar and tobacco Interests was in attendance. A delegation from the New York Produce Exchange, favorable to reciprocity and several delegations from the beet growing sections, opposed to reciprocity, arrived this morning.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- More than usual interest was attached to the opening of the debate on the King's speech in the House of Lords yesterday, Lord Rosebery, of course, being the most prominent figure because of his recent utterances.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- The allegation made at yesterday's hearing before Judge Marean of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, that the bills making the offices of County Clerk, Sheriff, and Register, salaried instead of fee offices, were unconstitutional, has caused much comment here in Albany.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The House of Lords was well filled when business was resumed after the royal ceremony yesterday. The Prince of Wales occupied the seat formerly used by his father. Many Peeresses were in the gallery.

The annual banquet of the Merchant Tailors' Society was held at the Hotel Savoy last night. There was not one of the members of the organization whose dress suit actually matehed that of any other one. As any harmony can be made in two octaves, with the possibility of numberless differing combinations, so in various details of make and fashion the assembled merchant tailors were shown to believe in no single style.

John Van Schaick Oddie, long prominent as an operator on Wall Street, and for many years secretary of the New York Yacht Club, died yesterday afternoon of Bright's disease, at his home, 39 West Forty-eighth Street.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra gave its third evening concert of the present season at Carnegie Hall last night. The programme was as follows:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16. -- Alexander Cameron of New York has been invited to become head coach of the Yale Boat crew. Mr. Cameron was stroke of the Varsity crew last year and the year before.

A certain number of our fellow-citizens, editors of newspapers and writers of letters thereto, are just now indulging in complaints against the President because he has appointed a Special Ambassador and special officers of the Army and Navy to represent this Government at the coronation of the King of England.
The majority of the members of the House of Representatives are apparently bent on stocking all the departments, as far as possible, with their favorites now in the Census Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Rear Admiral Rebley D. Evans, who has been charged with the preparation and execution of the naval programme for the reception of Prince Henry of Prussia, called upon Dr. von Holleben, the German Ambassador, at the embassy to-day, and consulted with him regarding the arrangements for the welcome to the royal visitor.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- Settlement payments increased the demand for money to-day and the plenitude weakened discounts. Business on the Stock Exchange opened cheerfully, but there were few transactions. It was the busiest settlement pay day for the past three years, owing to the Kafir revival.

There will be brought up before the Board of Aldermen within a few days a measure to prohibit the use of upper Fifth Avenue as a thoroughfare for trucks, delivery wagons, between the hours of 2 and 7 P.M. throughout the year, except the three Summer months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Senator Gallinger (Rep.) of New Hampshire thinks members of Congress should hear from the country on the proposition for commercial reciprocity with Cuba. He believes the country favors the proposition, and wants it to say so to Representatives and Senators, who find it hard to decide how they should vote.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- King Edward opened Parliament yesterday afternoon with a ceremonial in all essential respects similar to that of last February. The procession to the House of Lords was of the same character as that witnessed on the occasion of the opening of the first Parliament of King Edward's reign, while within the Upper House were seen the same State pageantry, the same historic dresses, and the same revival of ancient forms.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Gov. Odell said this evening that no charges against Sheriff Guden had been brought to his attention. If such charges should be brought, the Governor said he would give them proper consideration. Register J.K. Neal and County Clerk Hartzheim of Brooklyn were here to-day, accompanied by their attorney, Judge Neu, and Judge Brenner, the Chairman of the Kings County Republican Executive Committee.

It is interesting to know that the plan approved by the Directors of the New York Central for the improvement of their New York terminal was the one of three plans prepared for their consideration which the engineers of their corporation considered least meritorious.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- A reduction in the tax proposed to be levied by the Krum bill upon foreign corporations has been practically agreed upon by Gov. Odell and leaders in the Legislature. The Krum bill was framed upon the lines of Gov. Odell's recommendation to make corporations incorporated in other States, but doing business in New York, pay a tax proportionate to their privileges.
LONDON, Jan. 17. -- There was only a meagre attendance of members when the House of Commons met at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon to begin the work of the session.

Commissioner Homer Foiks of the Charities Department, yesterday attacked the time-honored custom of the great hospitals of this city which are supported, in part at least, by private charity. These institutions, to keep down their death rates, hurry patients to Bellevue as soon as it is seen that they are dying.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 16. -- Every marine engineer in its employ was ordered to-day by the United States Steel Corporation to report on shipboard ready for duty next Monday morning. This is about ten weeks before there is anything for the men to do, except to draw their pay.

The security market yesterday had little of interest in it. Few stocks were traded in to the extent of 10,000 shares apiece, total transactions for the entire list falling short of 400,000 shares. Commission house transactions were insignificant. The professional talent of the Stock Exchange had the market much to themselves the room trader and the scalper being responsible for most of the volume of business.

Mr. J.H. EHREHART, who is described as "the tax expert of the State Board of Commissioners," need not be cast down. He may take courage and hold up his head among the rest, for his plan of mortgage taxation is not a whit more idiotic than a dozen of twenty other plans that have been excogitated during the last five years in the great Albany school of economic learning.

Colin Barrett, a designer living with his mother and two brothers in a fine homo at 920 Morris Avenue, in the Borough of the Bronx, was shot twice at midnight in a fight with revolvers with two burglars, one of whom was a masked man and the other a woman, while his brothers, with their pistols also detonating as fast as they could pull the triggers, stood by his side.

Statistics on the growth of the churches of the United States in 1901, and the order of denominational rank in 1890 and 1901, have been completed by the Rev. Dr. H.K. Carroll, who was in charge of the religious statistics of the United States census of 1890.

Chief of Detectives Titus received the following telegram last evening concerning "T.K. Manners," who was arrested Tuesday in New Orleans, and who is supposed to be Valet Kern, the principal in the fifty-thousand-dollar Thebaud diamond robbery:

Collector George R. Bidwell yesterday announced his decision on the detention of the jewels belonging to Mr. and Mrs. Constant Lejeune. which were seized by Special Treasury Agent William H. Theobald at the Judson Apartments a short time ago. Mr. Bidwell ordered the lewels returned to their owners and ordered that duty be collected on the furniture.
S. Osgood, Pell Co. have sold for I. Herman to a client the four-story brown-stone-front dwelling 128 East Sixty-second Street, 20 by 100.3.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Assemblyman Fitzpatrick to-day introduced a bill which seeks to amend the Weekes marriage law by providing that the marriage contract shall be filed by the person before whom executed within six months after the date of marriage. The law as it stands places the responsibility for filing the contract upon the parties to the marriage.

At Delmonico's last night 200 lawyers sat down at a dinner tendered to ex-Justice Abraham R. Lawrence, upon his retirement from the Supreme Court bench after twenty-eight years of service, as a compliment to him on behalf of the members of the bar.

The seventeenth annual dinner of the Holland Society, held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was attended by more than 400 members, who were for the most art willing to forego the achievements of the present day and laud for the one night the sterling character and worth of their Dutch ancestry.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Assemblyman Weekes to-day introduced a bill to carry into effect Gov. Odell's recommendations with regard to the suppression of anarchy. The Weekes bill provides that if the crime attempted, if committed, is punishable by death of the offender, or by imprisonment for life, the person convicted of the attempt shall be punishable by imprisonment for not more than twenty-five years. The maximum punishment for such crimes at present is ten years.

Sheriff Charles A. Guden of Kings County declined when seen last night to discuss the statement of Bert Reiss concerning an alleged ante-election promise made by Guden to Col. Michael J. Dady with regard to the receipts of the Sheriffs office. Sheriff Guden said that he was preparing a statement relative to the matter, which he would give out to-day.

Such nice little things as they are. They look like sad irons, a very small edition of them, but in these the lower part is of pumice stone, and the handle of nickel. They are exceedingly attractive, in convenient shape for scrubbing the hands when pumice is needed, and cost only 10 cents.

There were a large number of dinners last evening, and among the hostesses who entertained were Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry and Mrs. Lucius K. Wilmerding. Receptions were given by Mrs. Everett Mallory Culver, Mrs. George N. Gardiner, and Mrs. Marshall C. Lufferts, Miss Llewellyn Parsons was the guest of honor at a large luncheon at Delmonico's, and the first meeting of the musical salon was held at the Waldorf-Astoria.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 16. -- A price war in the window-glass trade has practically begun. The effort to reconcile the differences existing between the three combines -- the American, the Co-operatives, and the independents -- was to all appearances irredeemably defeated to-day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Senate discussed to-day the bill creating a department of commerce, and the debate tended to show that the measure would have to be amended in many particulars before it could pass. Serious objections were raised to the transfer of several important bureaus now a part of other departments to the proposed new branch of the Government.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Hudson M. Taylor, the counsel for the Hudson River State Hospital, has been succeeded by J. A. Williams. The appointment of Williams was made by the State Board of Lunacy. The charge Is made that Williams owes his appointment to Louis F. Payn.

-- An elaborate pamphlet issued by the Michigan Sugar Manufacturers' Association presents in detail so minute as to be more than a little impressive and bewildering, to the layman, figures showing exactly what it costs to make beet sugar in that State and what returns the industry brings to everybody connected with it.
Andrew B. Neweombe has been appointed Brooklyn agent of the Aachen and Munich Insurance Company of Germany.
ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Gov. Odell to-day issued a proclamation urging that Jan. 29, the birthday of the late President McKinley, be observed in this State.

Although the thirteenth annual exhibition of the New York Poultry, Pigeon, and Pet Stock Association, now in progress at the Madison Square Garden, does not attract the large crowds which some of the Garden attractions do, the attendance is very good, and is said to be the largest in the history of the association.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- The grain pits went margin mail to-day. Ever since the raid on Phillips last Monday brokers have been demanding margins to the limit. Rumors that several firms were in straights were circulated late yesterday on the curb. The bears seized these to-day as cudgels to beat down the weaklings and succeeded in raiding prices.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- A delegation of citizens from New Rochelle called upon Gov. Odell to-day to bespeak his interest in remedying conditions in the New York Central tunnel. The delegation consisted of S.W. Marvin, Chairman; Augustus Thomas. District Attorney; J. Addison Young, and ex-Assemblyman Carlyle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The preliminary census report on the manufacturing industries of New Jersey shows a total capital of $503,824,082, an increase of almost 101 per cent., and value of products in 1900 of $611,728,933, an increase of almost 73 per cent. There are 13,481 establishments, increase, 68 per cent.; 241,581 wage earners, increase, 101 per cent.; total wages of $110,088,605, an increase of almost 33 per cent.

Commissioner of Bridges Lindenthal has considered another method of reducing the crush on the Brooklyn Bridge during the rush hours, and has written to Dock Commissioner Hawkes on the matter. He proposes that the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company and the ferry companies operating lines between New York and Brooklyn enter into an arrangement whereby they will transfer passengers between the boats and cars, fur one five-cent fare.

BOSTON, Jan. 16. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $29,000,690; balances, $1,321,475. Call money is loaning generally at 4 1/2 per cent., although a few special loans as low as 4 per cent. are reported as having been made. Time loans are being made freely, with the bulk of the business done at 4 1/2 and 5 per cent.

Those members of the Coffee Exchange who have been urging the establishment of a clearing house, for that institution were defeated in the annual election held yesterday. Henry Hentz of the "anti-clearing house party" was elected Vice President by 152 votes against 120 for Henry W. Banks, Jr.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- The demand for money slackened to-day. Discounts were weak. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet. Prices occasionally were irregular, and there were some fractional declines owing to the peace talk being less prominent. Gilt-edged securities were easier.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Baron von Richthofen, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, will give a dinner to-morrow to Prince and Princess Henry of Prussia, Andrew D. White, United States Ambassador to Germany, and Mrs. White, John B. Jackson, Secretary of the United States Embassy, and Mrs. Jackson, and a number of other distinguished persons in anticipation of Prince Henry's visit to the United States.

-- That young woman of New Castle, Penn., who has sued for breach of contract the mistress of the boarding house in which she has been trying to live, claiming that though she pays regularly the sum agreed upon she is not getting either the amount or the quality of food requisite for health and happiness, has taken a step the consequences of which cannot be anything less than momentous.

The charges made by Bert Reiss, a Brooklyn lawyer and Republican politician, that Elections Commissioner Michael J. Dady made a corrupt ante-election bargain with Sheriff Charles J. Guden of Kings County, whereby Col. Dady was to receive all the emoluments of the Sheriffs office in excess of $12,000 annually, are to be investigated in court.
STRANGE as it may seem, although the existence of these memoirs was well known, having been re- peatedly and authentically affirmed, it was not until 1878 that they first saw the light in print.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The senate Committee on Commerce has authorized a favorable report on the Ship Subsidy bill. The report will be made by Senator Frye, (Rep., Me.,) the author of the bill. The Democratic members of the commitee voted against reporting the measure. They also voted solidly for a motion offered by Senator Mallory (Dem., Fla.,) to strike out the general subsidy provision of the bill.

Lewis Nixon, the newly chosen leader of Tammany Hall, paid a visit to the rooms of the Timothy D. Sullivan Association last night, at 207 Bowery. It was the occasion of the regular monthly " stag " instituted by Alderman Sullivan. Of course there was a crowd, one that filled the entire building to overflowing.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Without meaning in any way to revive or continue the discussion of the intrusive French "u" in such words as "honor," "color" and the like, I ask space in which to relate a bit of history which seems to me interesting, and which is not generally known.

BOSTON, Jan. 17. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $26,244,933; balances, $2,334,973. Call money is in indifferent demand and shows a tendency to decline toward 4 per cent., although 4 1/2 per cent, is the usual going rate to borrowers of good credit.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- The Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New York City has served notices on a large number of lumbermen living in the vicinity of Ellenville that they must vacate the land which they have been occupying for several years and that actions of ejectment to obtain possession and suits for damages for the cutting of timber are about to be commenced.

HELENA, Mont., Jan. 17. -- A dispatch from Lewistown, Mont., says that a reliable report reached there to-day of the discovery of an immense diamond field in the northeastern part of Fergus County, which has driven all the prospectors of Spotted Horse and Maiden wild with excitement.

Everybody knows how simple it is to secure a copyright for published mate- rial and to have that copyright perfect- ed, but probably few persons are aware of the extremely slight obligation they have imposed upon the Government. The popular interpretation of a copyright is that it secures to the owner the monop- oly of the thing copyrighted, which monopoly the Government is prepared to defend against all comers.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Twenty-four of the trust companies of New York City which have made their annual reports to the State Superintendent of Banking for the year 1901 show an increase in resources for twelve months of nearly $100,000,000. Their profits over those of the previous year are greater by $6,500,000, and their dividends larger by $350,000.

The cover of the romance indicates the character of Mr. Hamilton Aide's romance. You see a spider, a butterfly, and a common fly. In " The Snares of the World," it is the Hon. Moyra O'Connell who is the fly. The spiders are many, and they belong to both sexes. Moyra's temptations are endless.

LONDON, Jan. 17. -- Justin McCarthy is busy with the proofs of his history of Queen Anne, which Harper Brothers are putting through the press. He is also at work on the third volume of his personal reminiscences, relating chiefly to Ireland and the Irish.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Proctor (Rep.,) of Vermont, discussing this evening the question of Cuban reciprocity, said:

One of the strongest reasons for a new building and larger quarters for the New York Historical Society was found in the Librarian's report at the recent annual meeting of the society, held in the old building, Second Avenue and Eleventh Street. The additions during the year 1901 to the library were close to 5,000 volumes, while pamphlets exceeded that number by a few hundred.

Maclay Davies have sold for the estate of Henry W. Miller to William F. Havemeyer the three-story brick building at the northeast corner of Exchange Place and New Street, on a lot 24.5 by 26.10. This property has been in the possession of the Miller family for over fifty years.

Although to the student of the aesthetlic and Historical departments of architecture, Volume III. of Mr. Sturgis's book may not prove so attractive as the other volumes, for it embraces only those subjects which fall between the letters O and Z, and, with the exception of articles on "Roman," "Romanesque," "Spanish," "The United States," "Russian," "Scandinavian," "Scottish," "South American," c., is chiefly given over to the definition of technicalities.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: A young woman, in a discussion regarding Shakespeare, recently said to me that she had never seen Ben Jonson's saying of Shakespeare, "thou hadst small Latin and less Greek," quoted except in a way to give the inference that Jonson was censuring Shakespeare for his ignorance of the classical tongues.

IN this volume are soon the best qualities of an autobio- graphy. It is John McCauley Palmer's wife who tells us that to her husband "The writing of these re- collections was as a labor of love. * * * It was hard to select from such a vast treasure house that which might interest all.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 17. -- News of the unanimous election of Dr. Henry Hopkins as President of Williams College, at the meeting of the Trustees at the Hotel Manhattan, in New York, to-day, was received here by the undergraduates with many expressions of approval.

BOSTON, Jan. 16. -- Messrs. L.C. Page Co. refuse to reveal the name of the author of "Laurlel," but permit the feminine pronoun to escape in the course of refusal. They admit that the author is "not unknown" to the reading public, and there they pause and gloat upon the sufferings of their victims.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- A blue book, issued yesterday on the subject of the concentration camps in South Africa, contains further detailed explanations from Lord Milner, the British High Commissioner, and Lord Kitchener, as to the causes of the excessive death rate in the camps and refutations of the charges of cruelty.

The St. Nicholas Skating Club defeated the Brooklyn Skating Club in an Amateur Hockey League championship game last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, by a score of 4 to 3. The contest was fairly clean, the St. Nicholas players doing the bulk of the aggressive work, Stoddard excelling in individual play.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 17. -- On the docket of the Common Pleas Division of the Supreme Court, which meets in Newport next Monday, are four petitions under the head of cases in which jury trial is waived, in which New York will doubtless be interested. They are petitions for declaration of citizenship in Rhode Island and brought under a law passed by the Rhode Island Legislature in 1898.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me, through the medium of your paper, to call the attention of the municipal authorities to a few facts that appear to have been overlooked in the hasty action on the proposed Mortgage Tax bill.

The letter of Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE which appeared in THE TIMES of Thursday, pointing out that the movement of the traffic of the Park Avenue tunnel by electricity would greatly increase rather than diminish the dangers due to the use of steam locomotives, would seem to mean either a good deal more or a good deal less than the writer intended.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- J.G. Henderson writes to The Times offering to pay u10,000 if the charges of inhumanity on the part of British troops in the South African war are proved within six months.

Whatever may have been the shock to tradition and the interruption to the stately order of procedure in the House of Lords on Thursday, King EDWARD would have been untrue to the best blood in his veins had he not been thrilled by the applause that greeted the very modest reference in the speech from the throne to the humanity of his troops.

ALBANY, Ga., Jan. 17. -- An application for a temporary receiver has been filed by the Directors of the Commercial Bank of Albany. The bank did not open for business to-day, and a posted notice stated that the bank had suspended payment pending the action of the State authorities. The liabilities of the bank are estimated at $128,000, with assets of $191,000 in bills receivable and real estate.

The February number of The world's Work will contain the complete poem, entitled "The Islanders," by Rudyard Kipling, a part of which has been reprinted in the newspapers. Another part is given below by permission of Doubleday, Page Co.:

Yvette Guilbert as a Novelist. Yvette Guilbert has written a novel entitled "La Vedette," which will soon be published in Paris. It is believed to be more or less autobiographical. According to the singer's account, the book reveals side lights of music hall life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The time of the Cabinet at the meeting to-day was largely occupied by the discussion of formalities to be followed upon the occasion of the visit of Prince Henry of Prussia. It is the desire of the President to show his Royal Highness every honor befitting him as a Prince of the royal blood and as the personal representative and kinsman of the German Emperor.

The Rosedale bowlers completed their schedule last night in the Columbia Bowling League tournament by defeating the Landwurster and Enterprise teams, which gives them second prize in the series. The Corinthians won two games in the Harlem League, and the Century Wheelmen defeated the Caledonian Club in three games in the New York Inter-Club League series.

Officials of the New York Central Railroad Company were subjected to further extended cross-examination regarding train operations and conditions in the Park Avenue tunnel at yesterday's session of the recent tunnel disaster inquest.

The rarity of John Dryden's autograph, which has long been well known to a number of collectors, is attracting much attention in these modern days when the poet's writings are sought for with cagerness and his name is becoming a mighty one in the auction room. The current catalogue of of Messrs. Sotheran of London contains one of the last letters written by Dryden, which is priced at u33.

It is in every way gratifying to observe the symptoms that Mr. OXNARD has already shot his bolt, and indeed exhausted the whole quiverful of his arguments. It would have been a National scandal if the endeavor had been successful to prevent us from carrying out the implied pledge of the whole country to give the impoverished Cubans fair access to our market.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Jan. 17. -- The Beth- lehem Steel Company's new gun shields were tested to-day at the proving grounds near here, in the presence of Gen. Miles and officers of the Bureau of Ordnance and Fortifications of the War Department. The shields were subjected to severe tests and scored a splendid success.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Assemblyman Jean Burnett of Ontario would not admit to-day that the bill which he will prepare to amend the Raines excise law would have for its purpose the abolishment of the side doors. Mr. Burnett is a member of the Assembly Committee on Excise and comes from Senator Raines's district.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Cuneo d'Ornano interpellated the Government regarding alleged violations of the military laws and regulations governing the promotion of officers, by Gen. de Galliffet, the ex-Minister of War, and Gen. Andre, the present Minister of War.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Jan. 17. -- One of the most terrible catastrophes ever recorded in the State of Guerrero occurred late yesterday afternoon. A very violent earth- quake visited Chilpancingo, causing a great loss of life and injuring many persons. De- tails from the district are very meagre, but scattering reports indicate that probably 300 persons were killed and as many more injured.

Some time ago there appeared in Longman's Magazine an article on the wellworn topic of dreams. The treatment of the subject, though not novel, was an intelligent one, and not over serious. There was no attempt to force conclusions, for the author declared his ignorance "on the writings of the learned on the subject of dreams generally."

A flood of light, that is to say, as far as books are luminous, has been cast on China of late -- and still we are of the opinion that we know very little about the Chinese. The individual Chinaman differs so much from ourselves that it is difficult to comprehend him. For our further enlightenment, Mr. E.H. Parker, formerly one of H.M. Consuls, presents his "John Chinaman, and a Few Others."

Among the many categories into which men are divided for the nonce in this ka- leidoscopic world, none is pleasanter than that of comrades in sport. Campaigners who remain together must necessarily be chums, and the recounting of their advent- ures is tremendously interesting to themselves because every story relates a case of pars quorum fuit.

In "The Library of Literary Criticism," the first volume of which covers the years 680 to 1638, and the second from 1639 to 1786, the aim is to present every significant piece of exposition or criticism that has ever been written about English authors. The authors themselves are arranged in chronological order, while their critics are introduced in a similar manner.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17. -- The atmosphere of the Pan-American conference was suddenly cleared to-day, and, with the most excellent feeling on all sides, both the plan of compulsory arbitration and The Hague agreement passed the conference.

The cold-storage system or car heating employed on the lines of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is being examined into by the Department of Health. In the interests of science the health authorities are seeking to learn what it is that keeps the passengers on the Brooklyn trolley cars from freezing to death.

Meredith Townsend, associate editor of The London Spectator, and who is known as a writer on Indo-European politics, calls these papers "studies," but a careful examination of them indicates a more pro- nounced treatment of the subjects under discussion than this characterization would imply.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: DESIROUS of beginning a course of reading in biogra- phy and not knowing how to begin, it occurred to me that perhaps you would assist me through the columns of your paper.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 17. -- One of the most elaborate patriotic entertainments which has ever taken place here, was given this afternoon by the Baltimore Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, in honor of Mrs. Charles W. Fairbanks, President General of the National society, and to celebrate the one hundred and forty-third anniversary of George Washington's wedding day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- New York exchange was quoted at 30 cents discount to-day. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2 to 6 per cent. Fractional advances were scored by some of the active stocks on the local Exchange, but the character of the trading did not indicate any increase in the outside interest.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Tom Sharkey and Peter Maher, the pugilists, and James H. McFarland, an official of the Industrial Athletic Club, under the auspices of which the Sharkey-Maher fight was presumed to take place to-night, were arrested late this afternoon on warrants charging them with conspiracy to commit a breach of the peace.

PECULIARLY interesting are these letters, not only because the writer of them, Lady Sarah Lennox, lived through romantic historical scenes, had at one time every prospect of becoming Queen of England, and preserves the memory of many noteworthy persons in her graphic, intimate, descriptions, but also because she united to a warm heart and buoyant disposition a truly excellent mind and a judgment whose discretion was only surpassed by its indiscretion.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Jan. 17. -- The Pere Marquette Railway Company's Steamboat No. 3 struck the bar at the mouth of the harbor early to-day while attempting to enter in a high southwest gale, and was scuttled in nine feet of water. The nine passengers and the crew of thirty-five were taken off by the life saving crew with their breeches buoy apparatus.

Kyrle Bellew's matinee of "A Gentleman of France" at Wallace's yesterday for the High School boys was a "screaming" success. That word is used advisedly, and perhaps the occasion ought to be further qualified as a "whistling" one. To say that the youths made the welkin ring at every exhibition of the doughty hero's valor is a mild description of what actuality took place.

At the Hotel Savoy last night the New York Typothetae, comprising many of the master printers of the city, came together as disciples of Benjamin Franklin to celebrate with a dinner the one hundred and ninety-sixth anniversary of the birth of their patron saint, Franklin, and to honor Theodore L. De Vinne, who, as a master printer, received degrees last June from Yale and Columbia University.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I have been interested in recent contributions to your columns, relative to "payment for verse." Bear with me while, as the Methodists say, I "tell my experience" in two instances.

HAVANA, Jan. 17. -- The cross-examination of Estes G. Rathbone, ex-Director General of Posts of Cuba, in to-day's session of the Cuban postal frauds trial brought out no new facts. Counsel for W.H. Reeves, ex-Deputy Auditor for Cuba, who is also on trial, endeavored to place on Rathbone the responsibility for the neglect on the part of Cuban Postmasters to render monthly statements.

The shock caused by the sudden death of Mr. Azarlah Smith of Messrs. Houghton, Mifflin Co., the day after Mr. Scudder's funeral, at first was incredulity more than sorrow. It hardly seemed possible that one so perfectly poised, so absolutely self-possessed, could be surprised even by Azrael himself.

Following the course of the Stock Exchange market, prices in the outside market yesterday were strong. Transactions were not large, except in half a dozen stocks, the balance of the list being firm and dull. It is true that some net declines occurred, but the market as a whole showed considerable improvement over that of two days ago.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 17. -- A.G. Spalding, the enjoined President of the National Baseball League, arrived in Chicago to-day and arranged for a conference at the Auditorium Annex to-morrow morning with President Johnson of the American League, at which a beginning of the end of the present baseball tangle may be made.

Every new year is in some sort, a beginning all over again; or, at least, we love to fancy that it is so, and to think that, by some magic of the calendar, upon every first of January "all our life Is newly ours to live."

Perhaps the most interesting portion of the late Horace E. Scudder's "Biography of James Russell Lowell" is that which refers to Lowell's great poem consecrated to the memory of Abraham Lincoln -- the "Ode Recited at the Commemoration of the Living and Dead Soldiers of Harvard University, July 21, 1865."

Fritz, the driver, dubbed him "Rubber." But he never thought when he gave it to him that this name would be so applicable in the course of events. "Rubber" is a big horse and shares with his mate the responsibility of dragging a heavy wagon through the city streets, delivering beer for the H. Clausen Son Brewing Company, at First Avenue and East Forty-seventh Street.

With a vigor which is surprising, the authors of "Karadac. Count of Gersey," lead the reader backward to the age of chivalry. The romance is descriptive of the blind love, the unquenchable passions of those who lived a thousand years ago. Through "mullioned windows," there troop the Knights "mailed and sworded," and grand ladies in glorious array, Karadac, Goyault, Algitha, and Gundred, are the heroes and heroines.

The white flag with a red ball painted upon it, indicating that there was skating on the big lake in Central Park, was hoisted over the Arsenal and at the top of the Belvidere Observatory, in the Park, yesterday morning. It was either seen or heard of by several thousand young men, young women, boys, and girls, who were not slow to take advantage of the opportunity it gave them.

ONE of the few obviously sincere poeins penned by Publius Statlus has some lines celebrating the delights of a Surrentine villa owned by his friend Pollius Felix. Modern Sorrento has the same occupation and offers the same delights as did the Surrentum of the Augustan age.

Here we have a new and handsome edition of what is accredited with being the best historical novel in French literature, Alfred de Vigny's "Cinq-Mars. A Conspiracy Under Louis XIII.," as translated by William Hazlitt. The book is divided into two parts. Part I. contains a biography of the author, an essay by himself, "Thoughts on Truth in Art" -- the novel contents, and the "Notes and Historical Documents."

Patrons of the Plaza Hotel had a lively quarter of an hour, starting at 3:20 o'clock P.M. yesterday, when a fire, which suddenly assumed serious proportions, was discovered on the seventh floor in a suite facing Central Park, which is occupied by Ernest Staples and his family. Mr. Staples was conversing with a friend in his room when he saw the smoke, and at once notified Clerk Herbert Hodgdon, who sounded an alarm.

There always is in the romance work of the late Grant Allen a certain directness. The tawdry he had no liking for, nor was he given to retrospection. His road in the highway of romance was the straightforward one. He never wandered off or indulged in the overspeculative. It may be true that, finding there was neither bread nor butter in scientific writing, he sought for the necessities of life in story writing.

A rumor was started yesterday that Dr. John McGaw Woodbury might be asked to resign as Commissioner of the Street Cleaning Department. The story was printed in a Brooklyn newspaper, and was based on the assertion that Commissioner Woodbury had reappointed Patrick H. Quinn, the Democratic Deputy in Brooklyn, and that Mayor Low had secured the rescinding of the appointment.
Controller Grout made a statement yesterday on the Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill. It is in part as follows:

The gas companies are experiencing an unforeseen trouble with their new mechanical collector, the prepayment meter. It gave promise of vast utility, and seemed destined to give the gas companies infinite satisfaction. Such tendency to mendacity as it might develop in obedience to the law of its being was reasonably sure to escape notice.

Mr. W.A. Penn's history of tobacco in an attractive binding and bearing the suggestive and fanciful title. "The Soverane Herbe," contains apparently all the information and all the commendation concerning this most famous of American plants which it is possible to compress within the limits of 300 and more octavo pages.

We are indebted to Marco Polo for the information that in the times of Genghis Khan there was a mounted express and that a distance of 300 miles a day was oc- cusionally covered by the messengers. Meth- ods of transmitting news by means of rid- ers must have existed in remote times. Many centuries, however, elapsed before that remarkable enterprise, the pony express, had its origin in the United States.

The cotillion given by Mr, and Mrs. Ogden Mills last evening for their twin daughters, the Misses Mills; the ball of the Columbia Juniors at Sherry's; the dance for Miss Katharine Schley, and other entertainments made yesterday a red-letter day. The event of this evening will be the dance given at Delmonico's by Robert Hargous.

It has been gratifying to note the edi- torial articles which prominent news- papers have devoted to our recent symposium on the needs for controlling the circulation of fiction in public libraries. There seems to be a quite general agreement with the views of librarians, as expressed in these columns, that, while the best kinds of fiction should in no way be restricted, unworthy and ephemeral novels ought to have far fewer readers.

Among the many books on scultpure in general, and on individual sculptors and on the exhaustively be written period of the Renaissance, this admirable volume has an individual and important place. It is addressed chiefly to the aesthetic sense although it follows more or less closely a chronological and historical plan.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is rather late for me to acknowledge my indebtedness to Mr. Shirley Prescott for his contribution to the John Pierpont discussion. But I am glad lo find through him that Thomas Campbell did write "The Rainbow," copied into Pierpont's "American First Class Book."

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 17. -- Walter Miller Potts, engineer of the Poutiloft Works Company of St. Petersburg, Russia, accompanied by Alexander Strekhnine, a draughtsman connected with the company, arrived in this city to-day.

"OLD English Plate, Ecclesiastical Decorative, and Domestic; Its Makers and Marks," by Wilfred Joseph Cripps is being published in this country in a large and illustrated edition by Charles Scribner's Sons and in England by Jonn Murray.

Over 500,000 shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, and a substantial list of advances was recorded; but there was little extension of commission brokerage house business, little new suggestion of any public interest. Many pools are at work, many clever devices are engaged to help along activity and make quotations strong; but in almost every quarter professionalism dominates.

HISTORIANS do not generally refer to the great Cardinal as a reformer, Scholar, courtier, statesman, soldier, diplomat, ecclesiastic, and patron of learning he certainly was. His efforts at reforming the church and the clergy, which he made at one time in his career, have been thrown into the shade by the splendor of his statecraft and the ambitious struggies and intrigues into which he plunged in the Court of Henry VIII.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- The meeting of the Board of Trustees of the State hospital for the care of persons suffering from incipient tuberculosis will be held in the Hotel Ten Eyck next Wednesday, when plans for the hospital buildings to be erected on the site at Raybrook, between Lakes Placid and Saranac, in the Adirondack region, will be passed on and probably approved.

A work in German on "The Museums of the Eastern Part of the United States" tells of the museums and universities of the seven largest cities of the Eastern States of the Union. The work is compiled and written by Dr. A.B. Meyer, Director of the Zoological Museum in Dresden, and is based on his visits to the eastern section of our country from August to October, 1900.

Mr. Scudder may congratulate himself that his biography of Lowell has worked a mild miracle in the pages of The London Saturday Review. It has inspired one of the writers for that venerable and acidulous oracle to a fairly appreciative notice of the book and of American authors, of whom Lowell was the best known in London.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 17. -- Favorable conditions furnished rare sport for the ice yachtsmen of the South Shrewsbury River this afternoon. A large number of enthusiasts saw Commodore B.P. Morris's Mildred lower the colors of B.E. Taber's Leroy, present holder of the championship pennant of the Shrewsbury River.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The attention of the Navy Department has been called to the fact that in 1898 a report appeared indicating friction between Admiral Dewey and Prince Henry of Prussia. According to this story, which was widely published at the time, Prince Henry, while at Hongkong, gave a banquet to the commanding officers of foreign warships and squadrons at that port.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- When the Isth- mian Canal Commission met to-day, it was with the understanding that the session should continue until a majority at least had reached a definite conclusion respect- ing the nature of the recommendation to be made to the President. It is learned on the highest authority that the commission is not united on any one of the propositions which have been submitted.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: "Lift the stone, and thou shall find me; cleave the wood, and there am I." This is not a conundrum, as Frederick Dwight of Brooklyn suggests, but a saying of Jesus, not authenticated, however.

In covers of imperial purple and with letter press of a similar hue, Mrs. Annah Robinson Watson of Memphis, Tenn., proves by genealogical tables which he who runs may read that there are at this moment living in America no less than 100 persons through whose veins courses the blood of Alfred the Great and other sovereigns.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- The recent happening of greatest literary interest here is the publication in the January Era of the first installment of Joel Chandler Harris's new story "Gabriel Tolliver." The time of the novel is the reconstruction period, but, as in "The Kidnapping of Abraham Lincoln," the line has been sharply drawn between sectional feeling and sectional bitterness.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in yesterday's issue, deservedly rebuking Mr. Westinghouse for his pessimistic and ill-advised letter, is in error in stating that it will be read with consternation, or even with surprise, by electrical engineers, notwithstanding Mr. Prout's indorsement.

Railroad development in Manhattan Borough has created a flurry in religious property. Among churches vitally affected are the North and Christ Presbyterian, the First United Presbyterian, Thirty-third Street Baptist, Thirty-fourth Street Reformed, Chelsea and Swedish Methodist, St. Michael's Roman Catholic, Ahawath Chesed Hebrew, St. Peter's Lutheran, and Holy Apostles' and Heavenly Rest Chapel, Episcopal.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Jan. 17. -- The Anawan Mill here has been sold by John S. Brayton and family to a mill broker acting for another party. In mill circles the understanding is that M.C.D. Borden of New York is the purchaser. He recently bought the controlling interest in the Meta Comet mills.

In the intervals in his war correspondence Mr. Davis has found time to run off a charming little storiette. Though it repre- sents that class of fiction known as de- tective stories, it bears no resemblance to the marvelous experiences of the peerless Sherlock Holmes. It is a detective story without the bloody details which usually characterize that style of fiction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Mrs. Roosevelt gave a small reception this afternoon. One hundred friends were invited to the White House from 5 to 6 o'clock to hear the Dutch pianist, Zeldenrust, who is now being entertained by the Minister from the Netherlands, Baron Gevers. The piano was placed in the East Room, where the beautiful decorations of the dinner party of Thursday evening were still in place.

THE array of notable persons with whom the late John Ruesell Young came into relations more or less intimate and confidential was perhaps not exceeded in the experience of any man of his generation. His active life began early, at an age when most youth are still at the preparatory school, "like young bears with all their troubles before them."
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Reuter's Telegram Company has received the following dispatch from Amsterdam:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17. -- Substantial improvement and lively trading in the arbitrage stocks helped the local issues to-day, and the market was hotter throughout in activity and in tone. The greatest change was a three-point rise in Choctaw common, but the two Lehighs and Cambria Steel were to 25, hardy.

The present police treatment of Sunday liquor selling in violation of law can hardly be called a policy since it has not been formulated or proclaimed. It is a condition rather, and it must inevitably re-establish another condition, the old evil condition of bribery of the police by the saloon keepers and the blackmailing of the saloon keepers by the police.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 17. -- Ex-Gov. Leslie M. Shaw, the new Secretary of the Treasury, while admitting that in two years he had released three times as many convicts as had been released by his predecessors in ten years, or 473 in all, said today that he believed he was doing the noblest work in the power of Christian man.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorials on the subject of taxation of mortgages, which have appeared since the publication of the Governor's message, deserve to be kept standing while the Legislature continues in session for the benefit of those members who are studying the question.

From The Worcester (Mass.) Spy. A small herd of deer are reported to be roaming in the vicinity of Worcester, and the buck that strayed into the city Thursday may have been one of the drove that became separated from his companions and came to his death in an effort to regain the woods and pastures of the open country.

IT seems somewhat strange to one who knows the real nature of the game of pelota to hear the proposition, seriously made, to attempt to introduce it as a part of American athletics. One hears it called vaguely a Cuban, or, a trifle more accurately, a Spanish game, and the idea seems to be that it can be Americanized and made universal, as the Scotch golf or French tennis has been.

A new feature was added to the serious Reiss-Guden-Dady political controversy in Brooklyn yesterday when Bert Relss, under oath and threatened with commitment for contempt of court, after making several appeals for immunity, declared that ex-Senator Jacob Worth, once the Republican boss of Kings County, knew of the existence of the alleged Guden-Dady written compact and had condemned it and censured its makers.
