Considerable attention has been given during the past weak to the steady decline in Standard Oil stock, following as it did upon a heavy drop in the price of the stock during the preceding week. Perhaps to the movement of no outside the stock is more importance attached than to the course of Standard Oil.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have followed with interest, mixed often with astonishment, the discussions on the Sunday opening of saloons that have appeared in your paper, which I read daily and esteem highly, except for its stand on this question.

There will be opened at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, on Monday, Jan. 27, a midwinter fete which will differ in many expects from anything of the kind hitherto een and upon which some of the best own artists of Greater New York are ow at work. It is to be for the benefit of the Church Charity Foundation, with its homes for the aged, orphans, and the lind.

TRENTON, Jan. 18 -- The Executive succession in New Jersey on Tuesday next at the inaugural ceremnoies turns on an ancient custom, one of the several relics that has come down from the misty past which New Jersey is not willing to give up.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 18. -- Chilpancingo, capital of the State of Guerrero, has been in a panic because of yesterday's repetition of the earthquake. This last disturbance razed to the ground many houses which had been spared in the first shock.

Manhattan in its rise above 140 and its subsquentdrop below 133, (through this has in part been recovered.) occasioned much theorizing. The advance resulted from purchases by Gould and outside interests. By the former the buying was in the belief tliat under electrical operation the economies to result will be very material, (estimated in some quarters as equivalent to 2 per cent, on the stock.) and that stockholders therefore will be substantially benefited.

The greatest baggage station on the face of the earth is situated in the Harbor of New York. It is on Ellis Island, where is located the United States Immigration Station of this port, and occupies the greater portion of the ground floor of the main structure of the bureau.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 18 -- What is said to be the largest single contract for conduits ever awarded in this country was let here to-day to a contractor of Cincinnati and New York by the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company. It includes the laying of underground wires for the entire arc-light system of the city.

WHEN Diderot uttered his now famous paradox that "to move others one must be himself unmoved " he threw a brand into the fire of dramatic discussion which has emitted sparks at intermittent intervals ever since.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit a reply to the letter of your correspondent "K. G.," in which" the Republicans [are] warned." In the first place, I am never impressed with the advice given to the Republican Party by Democrats and reformers.

WHEN the little boy and his mother and the young man with the umbrella stumbled over the box the woman didn't mind their discomfiture very much, but when the fat man fell over it and said impolite things she picked it up and went out on the front platform.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It will not be disputed by attentive Observers that the opening of saloons on Sunday is the greatest issue of the day. There is nothing in politics, whether municipal, State, or National, which matches it, and because it is an old and trite subject does not change its nature or minify its importance.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Second Judicial Department, has handed down a decision bearing on the construction of the tenement house law and its amendments, which, if upheld by the Court of Appeals, will affect many builders now being sued by the city for evasion of the new law.

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 18. -- That althletics at Dartmouth will be above reproach was shown by the action of the Athletic Council this afternoon in disqualifying L. D. Varney, Captain and pitcher of the Varsity nine, and T. V. Uniac, the second baseman. This summary decision is due to the participation under contract of both players in the New York State League last Summer.

Letter from Rome to Chicago Record-Herald. Cardinal Rampolla, the Papal Secretary of State, and, next to the Pope, the greatest man in the Catholic Church to-day, lives at the top of the Vatican, and his visitors are required to climb 403 marble stairs. There are no elevators in that venerable building, although it has recently been fitted with electric lights at a cost of $45,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial article which, under the caption "A College for the Arts and Crafts," appeared in your esteemed journal upon the 13th inst., is in my humble judgment worthy of more attention than anything which has within my memory been put forward in connection with the artistic and industrial interests of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- It will surprise the German-Americans of the country when they learn that the Kaiser has intimated his desire for as little as possible of German-Americanism in the reception of Prince Henry. The Kaiser desires that Whatever is done in the way of entertaining his brother be done by Americans rather than by any distinctive class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see by a letter printed in to-day's TIMES that Bishop Potter's remarks about the use of alcoholic beverages in the hard-drinking temperance States of Maine, New Hampshire, and Vermont have met with adverse criticism. I have no "statistics" to go by, but I believe that what Bishop Potter said was in the main true.

From The Washington Post. "The female conductor experiment in Chillicothe is proving a great success," said Mr. Alexander O. Stevens of Columbus, Ohio. "I know of no other city in the world which has a street-car line upon which 'Fare, please,' is spoken by a woman. The history of the custom is rather interesting.

In his speech at the completion of the sculptures in the Sieges-Allee at Berlin, full report of which is now at hand, the German Emperor shows that he is the victim of his surroundings by his attack on modern art. In science and militarism WILHELM II. hails whatever is promising and new, but art seems to him too much akin to religion to permit of experiments.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:
Capt. Stevenson of the Mulberry Street Station, and Capt. Walsh of the Eldridge Street Station, raided two alleged gambling houses last night in their precincts and in each ten prisoners were taken.

On Wednesday afternoon, at 3 o'clock, in Mendelssohn Hall, Mr. George Hamlin will repeat the recital of songs by Richard Strauss given by him last month in Mendelssohn Hall. The repetition will arouse much interest on the part of lovers, of modern development of the song. Mr. Hamlm's programme will include the following songs of Strauss:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Orders were issued to-day by Lieut. Gen. Miles involving an extensive movement of troops between the United States and the Philippines. Troops to the number of about 5,233, stationed in the United States, are ordered to service in the Division of the Philippines, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Isthmian Canal Commission concluded Us labors today and its report was taken by Admiral Walker, President of the commission, to Secretary Hay, who turned it over to the President late this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is an easy matter to find living, concrete proofs of the falsity of our Southern 'friends' claim that there are no people of one-sixteenth part negro blood. And we can find them in France, a country where people of any degree of African descent are relatively rare.

"How doth the little busy bee, improve each shining hour, By bustling round for something sweet, Avoiding all that's sour." -- Mr. Watts. THE bee deserves to be poetically chronicled in a better way than this, but since the above is beyond all doubt the best that has been done for him, it is well to mention it.

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Jan. 18. -- A large crowd of ice yachting enthusiasts saw Commodore D. P. Morris's yacht Mildred score a second triumph in a sharp contest for the challenge pennant of the South Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club this afternoon. The big event on the afternoon's card was a three-cornered match race between the Commodore's boat, E. E. Tabor's Leroy, holder of the championship, and Charles Gibbon's Baby Ruth.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to earnestly protest against the conclusion implied in your editorial of the 14th on "School Oratory," viz.: that declamation in the public schools should be abandoned. It seems to me that you are virtually encouraging the acknowledged decline of oratory among the American people.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- Oscar Hammerstein, the New York theatre promoter, is said to have decided to purchase properties at 1,016 and 1,018 Chestnut Street, this city, for a site for a new theatre. This site is directly opposite the Chestnut Street Opera House.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read in yesterday's TIMES a telegraphic item from Nice, France, announcing that the chief astronomer of the Nice Observatory reports that on the evening of Jan. 11 the light of Venus was so intense as to cast shadows on the walls, with the questionable assertion, "This is the first time this phenomenon has been observed."

The testimony brought out in the Coroner's inquest into the fatal casualty in the Park Avenue tunnel is so startling and disquieting as to warrant the gravest public uneasiness. Those who use the tunnel route daily will be made very uncomfortable by the realization that the overrunning of signals is habitual and that the conditions in the tunnel are frequently such that the train engineers cannot see the signals.

BERLIN, Jan. 18. -- The announcement that Director Ballin of the Hamburg-American Steamship Line, and Director Wiegand of the North German Lloyd Line intend going to New York together at the end of January, causes much conjecture as to the object of their trip. It is supposed in some Quarters that it refers to pooling arrangement with the United States lines, though both Herr Ballin and Herr Wiegand are reticent on the subject.

Emperor William's new Meteor, which Miss Roosevelt is to christen, will, when launched, be the largest schooner yacht afloat, and probably one of the fastest ever built. There are very few schooner yachts now in existence which approach her in size. None of the schooners which are celebrated in yachting history, such as the Dauntless and the Sappho, were as large as the Emperor's new yacht either in water line length or tonnage displacement.

From The London Mail. This week witnesses the completion of the superstructure of the Westinghouse Company's marvelous works near Manchester, upon which nearly a million and a half pounds sterling have been spent, and the installation of machinery will proceed forthwith.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to thank you for the prominence you have given to my letter of the 11th and the discussions thereon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Whatever concerns the capital concerns the Nation. And the exhibition which was to-day opened to the public in the Corcoran Art Gallery, of the plans for what modestly calls itself the improvement of the park system in the District of Columbia," is of National importance and should be even of international interest.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 18. -- Cornell defeated Harvard at basket ball to-night by the score of 34 to 26. The game was exciting from start to finish, the score running up so evenly as to make the result in doubt up to the very last. Cornell's men were much heavier than Harvard's, but this was equally offset at the beginning of the contest by the speed of the Crimson players.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18. -- The Readings, common and second preferred, made the Philadelphia market to-day. Over 23,000 shares of the first named changed hands, and over 11,000 of the common. At times the price of the common was 1/8 higher here than in New York, Choctaw was the erratic stock of the day.

From The London Chronicle's Paris Message. As a necessary pendant to the census. The Journal Officiel of to-morrow will publish the statistics of the foreign population distributed over every French department. The figures as they stand are highly interesting. For certain reasons connected in a general way with naturalization and with inhabitants of Alsace and Lorraine, who would be more correctly classified as Germans pure and_simple, the total of 1,037,778 aliens is not strictly reliable.
The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston has given up its projected trip to Charleston, S.C., which it intended to take in February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A delegation of beet sugar manufacturers from Michigan, headed by W.L. Churchill, President of the Michigan Sugar Manufacturers' Association, and F.R. Hathaway, Secretary, appeared before the President to-day and protested against the proposed reduction of the duty on Cuban sugar.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 18. -- The ice yacht racing conditions to-day are far from being favorable, although the sport furnshed excitement for hundreds of spectators on both the river and shore. Under the influence of a warm southwest breeze, which at times blew with no more force than that of a zephyr, the ice became soft and greatly hindered the speed of the yachts.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 18. -- A check for $1,000,000 has been received here in payment of the policy on the life of Prank H. Peavey, the Minneapolis millionaire.

MRS. JAMES SPEYER was dining at Sherry's the other evening in a superb gown of black and gold. The material was black lace. The bodice had a yoke and epaulets of golden sequins overlapping each other like fish scales. From these epaulets the sleeves of unlined black lace extended to the wrists.

Disagreements in the Board of Managers of the New York Produce Exchange, have caused the resignation from the Law Committee of two of the three members. The counsel for the Exchange resigned also, but subsequently withdrew the resignation.

Some time on Wednesday night the handsome home of John M. Dillon, at 9 East Ninth Street, was pilfered of a quantity of Jewelry. Since then Capt. Chapman has four detectives assigned to the Mercer Street Station and the private detectives of the United States Fidelity Company have been hard at work on the case.

The Governor and his friends, it seems to us, are rather overworking the argument that the concentration of power in the State Commission in Lunacy and the abolition of the local boards of managers of the hospitals for the insane will tend to increased responsibility.
Senator PROCTOR has for the second time rendered a signal service to the cause of Cuba. The service is not less to the reputation of our country and to the cause of American civilization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your comments on Mr. Westinghouse and his letter, as far as they go, are very fitting, for of course, it is not in your province to give a technical discussion of his points. His position and that of Mr. Pennock, however, are deserving of vigorous comment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Attorney General and Mrs. Knox entertained at their first Cabinet dinner to-night in honor of President and Mrs. Roosevelt. The other guests were Secretary and Mrs. Root, Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne, Secretary and Mrs. Hitchcock, Secretary and Miss Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Wayne MacVeagh, Mr. and Mrs. John Dalsoll, Miss Knox and Reed Knox.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I "understand it, the New York Central Railroad Company propose to settle the tunnel problem " by building a loop tunnel tinder the present depot, and sending through this tunnel all local trains, the motive power for the local trains through the main and loop tunnel to be electricity.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Jan. 18. -- Mrs. Oscar W. Young was astounded yesterday when her daughter Edna came down stairs in street attire and remarked that she was going to take a train for Brooklyn to meet her husband. This was the mother's first intimation that her daughter was married, and she was greatly overcome by the news.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 18. -- The Transcontinental Freight Bureau has issued a call to its seventeen lines for a session in Portland on Feb. 18. More than 1,000 questions will be discussed. There is a possibility that the bureau may decide upon important reductions in transcontinental rates.

Wall Street's security market has been exhibiting disappointing features. Commission house transactions are small; the old lament is heard that "the public is not in." Indeed, it is showing scant sign of any disposition soon to come in. A variety of reasons exist to explain this attitude.

We have already commented upon a curious defect in our charter, which answers to a defect in our general notions of civic duty and opportunity. That is the omission of any provision for the aspect of the city as concerns its attractiveness. We fail to find any compulsion put upon any municipal officer to employ expert artists for any purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The census report on cottonseed manufacture in 1900 shows that there were 357 establishments engaged in the extraction of cottonseed oil in the United States, using 2,479,386 tons of cottonseed, the cost of which was $28,632,616, an average cost of $11.55 per ton.

From The Spectator. The genesis of the impresario may be traced bark logically enough to the inherent necessities of the operatic environment. Opera came to its birth in Italy, the land of song, of the "bel canto," where the ingrained tendency of the people is (or was) to prefer charm to character, beauty of sound to dramatic intensity of expression.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 18. -- Society is much interested in the marriage of Miss Mary E. Wilson, only daughter of Col. John F. Wilson of Tunlaw, North Plainfield, and ex-Mayor of that town, to Joseph P. Truitt of Philadelphia, which is to take place on Saturday, Feb. 8. Only the immediate relatives of the contracting parties have been invited to witness the ceremony, because of a death that recently occurred in Mr. Truitt's family.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in to-day's issue of THE TIMES on the need of a college of arts and crafts is admirable. In connection with the same may I use a little of your space to present an outline of my experience as Director and teacher in an institute which, for ten or more years, fought its way into public favor and then practically perished for lack of funds?

Copyright, 1902. Via French Telegraph Cable Company. LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Shares of the American Steel Company continued in some sort of demand most of the week, the tip mentioned last week having been amplified and repeated, but otherwise there have been few incidents of importance in that branch of the market which the City popularly terms American Rails.

HAVANA, Jan. 18. -- When the trial of the cases arising from the Cuban Post Office frauds was resumed in the Audiencia Court to-day the cross-examination of ex-Chief of the Bureau of Finance, C.P.W. Neely, was continued.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., Jan. 18. -- These pleasant days in the pines at Lakewood afford great opportunities for the enjoyment of almost every form of outdoor sport. Lake Carasaljo is still covered with ice, and the skaters are happy. The links of both golf clubs are free from snow, and the golfers can now play under perfect conditions.

The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, which was started last May through a gift of $200,000 made by John D. Rockefeller, and which has nineteen workers in this city. Philadelphia, Boston, and in Europe on various investigations, has prepared for the public a report of the main facts which have been ascertained in reference to the way in which milk delivered in New York City is produced and handled.

A larger number of special and regular prizes has been offered this year than ever before for the twenty-sixth annual dog Show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which will be one of the big February features in the Madison Square Garden. The entries will close on Feb. 3, with James Mortimer, Superintendent, at 1,123 Broadway.

Discordant cacklings kept the Madison, Square Garden noisy all day yesterday while a large delegation of school children in the afternoon imparted a scene of lively animation to the vast arena, which has been the temporary home of over four thousand varieties of poultry and pigeons during the past week.

As the year begins it would seem that there develop misgivings as to the course of the country's foreign trade, economic conditions at home and abroad being brought under close scrutiny, and the results of such examinations serve as a basis for theories that further contraction is probable rather than recovery and expansion.

From The London St. Martin's-le-Grand. A telegraph messenger was assaulted while on duty and was laid up in consequence. The following is taken from his letter of explanation: "One of them threw the core of an apple at me which hit me in the ear; I took no notice of that, and walked on, and then they threw their hats at me.

From The American Israelite, (Cincinnati.) The following from the editorial columns of The London Jewish Chronicle contains a suggestion that may well be carefully considered by those Americans who are inclined to regard Zionism as at worst a bit of harmless idealism. The editor of The Chronicle says:

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Gov. Odell announced to-day that after considering the charge against Sheriff Caldwell of Buffalo he had decided to remove him from office. Frank T. Coppins is appointed to succeed Mr. Caldwell. In removing Sheriff Caldwell the following reasons were given by Gov. Odell:

LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 18. -- After a desperate struggle with a pack of wolves, Olaf Halesrud, a well-known farmer, who lives about ten miles north of here, lies in a critical condition, with the flesh literally torn from his body in many places. Physicians say he cannot live.
AIKEN, S. C., Jan. 19. -- The season at Aiken has opened early. Every day brings new arrivals, and an unusually large number of the Winter colony celebrated Christmas here.

HE WAS "only a merchant," as the professional politician put it; a New Yorker by birth, with an exceptionally high rating in the commercial agencies, neither a liquor dealer nor a firm of liquor dealers or liquor dealing, temperate in life as well as principle, and not a politician. But he was a student of public affairs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 18 -- The application of Mrs. Mary. S. Clark, widow of William H. Clark, to set aside the sale of the Empire City Racetrack to Frank Farrell, on the ground that the price paid $218,000, was not sufficient, came up before Judge Keogh in the Supreme Court to-day. Mrs. Clark and her sons, William Grant aged eleven, and Edmund, aged nine, were in court.

Lieut. Thorwald Fritsche, son of Etatsraad Fritsche, the President of the Copenhagen Chamber of Commerce, and the head of one of the most prominent families in Denmark, is dead here at the Presbyterian Hospital. He was about thirty-five years old. He was an officer in the Danish Navy, and some years ago served for twelve months in the American Navy.

IT is evident that the Rev. Ng Poon Chew, who is the managing editor of a San Francisco paper, is not up in fashions. Even a masculine being who is supposed in China to know so much more than his countrywomen may not know, always know what they wear. This is what Mr. Chew said in a recent lecture in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church:

Arthur Townsend lost the championship of the National Associatibn of Amateur Billiard Players to Edward Gardner of the Acquackanonk Club, Passaic, N.J., last night in the final game of the tournament at 14.2 at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn. Gardner played with good judgment all during the contest and had Townsend practically beaten from the start.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorials are always interesting; but the one in to-day's issue upon " Manners Among Nations " is so able that I am tempted to request a small space to say a word or two thereon. Of course, there is no necessity for the United States to fall in line with the ceremonial performance of certain foreign functions.

From The London Standard. CONSTANTINOPLE, Dec. 29. -- Some hundred yards outside the terminus of the Oriental Railway at Stamboul stands a bridge, crossing the line. Beyond this the line is single, and to avoid accidents a somewhat complicated system of signals has been established, working by electricity.
LONDON, Jan. 18. -- George Edwardes has scarcely found another "San Toy" in "A Country Girl," which he produced at Daly's to-night with a very strong cast and beautiful costumes and scenery.

Street Lamps and Street "Kids." THE policeman was so mad, that he fairly blubbered. "Now, just look here," he said. "If here ain't another street lamp broke. That makes the third in this block in two days. And not a kid in sight, either. The damage ain't been done long enough to get cold, or they'd have got over their scare and come out again."

Two thousand women, who are members of the Brotherhood of Cloakmakers, have been organized as a women's branch of the union and will hold a general meeting next Tuesday evening in the University Settlement Building, Rivington and Eldridge Streets. Miss Sarah Goldstein has been elected President and Miss Lena Levene Secretary of the new organization, and a general Executive Board will be formed next Tuesday evening.

SYDNEY, Dec. 15 -- New South Wales is closely following New Zealand in the attempt to substitute a compulsory system of arbitration for strikes and lockouts, and thus assist in preventing a repetition of the disastrous conflicts between employers and employed which have been so frequently, as in other countries, productive of injury to the mutual interests of capital and labor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We look forward with pleasure to the introduction of the Pennsylvania Railroad into New York City as bringing in the new life of science and civilization in railroad management.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18. -- The Yale crew season began this week, with the call for candidates for the freshman boat by Capt. Kunzig of the 'Varsity. Ninety-four men responded, and work commenced at once in the gymnasium tanks. The 'Varsity crew candidates will not begin work until the end of the week, when a general call will be sent out.

THE success of "Siegfried" at the National Opera goes to prove how Paris has changed since the stormy reception of "Tannhauser," and lo emphasize the prophetic remark made by Wagner in the days when he lived here-in a sumptuous hotel in the Rue Newton, near the Arc de Triomphe -- "I am not at all anxious in regard to the French -- they will end by interpreting me even better than ihe Germans."

NOT much field for extended comment is offered by the principal musical entertainments of the week which has just come to an end. Last Sunday the only incident of importance was the appearance of Mr. Eduard Zeldenrust, the Dutch pianist. The usual concert at the Opera House was one of the routine sort, without a single item on which to base intelligent remark.

The legitimate business of almost any week would appear insignificant in the face of realty, purchases by a railroad corporation aggregating $3,500,000, and it is quite natural that the buying by the New York Central, both on account of its magnitude and because its announcement came as a complete surprise, should divert attention temporarily from all dealing of ordinary character.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 18. -- Wilmington is becoming the Gretna Green of the smart set of Baltimore. The fourth couple to quietly slip away from this city to the town on the Delaware to have the marriage knot tied are Miss Minnie Vogeler, daughter of the late Charles A. Vogeler, and Lester Bresee, son of the late Edward L. Bresee, whose widow married Robert Goldsborough Keene.

The second letter of Mr. GEORGE WESTINGHOUSE on the dangers of electric traction for passenger cars, which appears elsewhere in this issue, makes his first letter more intelligible than most of those for whom it had especial interest probably found it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 18. -- Ban B. Johnson and A. G. Spalding held a conference to-day, at which the baseball situation was discussed at considerable length. Mr. Johnson and Mr. Spalding agreed that it was inadvisable to consider amalgamation of the two stated that the American League circuit leagues on any kind of basis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Probably the item of most current interest in the Urgent Deficiency bill, in view of the coming of Prince Henry, is one appropriating $10,000 for the coming in expenses of the State Department. It has long been the custom of the department to hold a small found of this character for the entertainment of visitors and to meet other diplomatic emergencies which may arise.

Ignace Jan Faderewski, the famous pianist, will sail for this city on Wednesday and will arrive here about Jan. 29. His visit at this time has a twofold purpose. He comes chiefly to supervise the preparations for the production of his opera " Manru " at the Metropolitan Opera House. These preparations are well under way under the general direction of Walter Damrosch, who is to conduct the work.

Commissioner WOODBURY will command approval for the interest he is showing in securing the powers necessary to permit his department to deal with the cleaning of the sidewalks and gutters in front of vacant lots and unoccupied building's. The statutes relative to the removal of ice and snow from sidewalks and the opening of gutters in front of private property are regularly, and sometimes rather rudely, enforced against householders and tenants.
Actors and other persons in the theatrical world continue to wonder what members of the profession will receive coronation honors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As we notice by the newspapers that it is now proposed to reduce the present rates of duty on shipments from the Philippines to this country by 23 per cent., plus the export duty, if any, paid in the Philippines at time of shipment, it is evident the Senate is commencing to realize that we should show some justice to these islands.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $23,946,460; balances, $2,695,186. Call money is in very light request, with loans generally being made at 4 1/2 per cent., and with 4 per cent, quoted to favorable borrowers.

From The London Pall Mall Gazette. ROME, Jan. 6. -- Those great ones who a generation ago made the name of Italy resound throughout the world, are becoming very few, and, say the pessimists, they are not being replaced. One of the best known and greatest of these was the Marchioness del Grillo -- nee Adelaide Ristori -- who on Jan. 28 will be eighty years of age.

From The Nineteenth Century. During the last twelve years the population of the great province of Buenos Ayres and of its capital has nearly doubled, and vast extensions and improvements have been made in the city, which now contains a population of over 800,000. Accounts published of it twelve years ago state that its houses, with few exceptions, were then single storied, that its streets were ill-paved and very rough to travel on.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- If the weather holds good there is a prospect of getting off the race for the championship pennant of America at Roosevelt's Point on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- There appears to be a better chance at this session for the passage of a bill creating a Department of Commerce than ever before. The indifference of past years has been succeeded by active support or opposition on the part of many Senators and Representatives.

Harvard's hockey team made its first appearance in the intercollegiate championship series at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening, and pleased its supporters by defeating Columbia's 'Varsity team by a score of 4 to 3. Columbia, though defeated, was well pleased with the showing of its team, for reports of Harvard's prowess had given rise to the fear that the Cambridge collegians would win by a much larger score.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The money market was quieter to-day, and the demand during the coming week is expected to be small. Discounts were easy. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet and tolerably cheerful. The attendance was small. The renewed hopes of peace in South Africa hardened consols.

OF those who read this, some may perchance recall various stories which appeared in certain daily papers at the time anent the purchase in Philadelphia of a torpedo boat by the agents of a Haitlen revolutionary party. Her trip down the coast was noted and gave rise to some speculation as to her exact destination, but after leaving a Southern port she disappeared from view, and public curiosity about her subsided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Numerous articles and letters have appeared in your columns relative to the New York Central tunnel accident, but with one exception these letters and articles have had to do with abstract questions. The true situation, however, is exemplified by a remark recently made to the writer relative to the action of an individual brought face to face with sudden danger.

In the early part of the past week the Atehison, Topeka and Santa Fe Board of Directors made application to the investing public for $30,000,000 for new capital, proposing to issue in exchange therefor 4 per cent, serial debenture bonds, $2,500,000 of the principal payable on Feb. 1, 1903 and $2,000,000 annually thereafter to February, 1914.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- Yale literally swamped the Columbia basket tall team in the Yale gymnasium before a large crowd to-night, winning by a score of 48 to 3. Yale's work from start to finish was entirely in a class by itself, Columbia not being able to put Yale's goal in danger more than a dozen times in the two halves.

Mrs. Patrick Campbell enters upon her second week at the Republic to-morrow evening, the bill for the occasion being Pinero's play, "The Notorious Mrs. Ebbsmith." Like most of the other plays thus far disclosed by this actress in New York, the present work is not unfamiliar. It was presented here with John Hare in the character of the Duke of St. Olpherts, and Julia Neilson as Mrs. Ebbsmith.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- "Great Canals of the World" is the title of a study prepared by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics for publication in the forthcoming volume of The Monthly Summary of Commerce and Finance. It shows the commerce, cost, and dimensions of the great canals of the world, especially those connecting great bodies of water, and which may be properly termed ship canals.

President Bernard N. Baker of the Atlantic Transport Line was one of the most active supporters of the Ship Subsidy bill introduced in the last Congress. It was suggested to Mr. Baker by THE NEW YORK TIMES that his views upon the pending Subsidy bill would be of interest to the public, and Mr. Baker has prepared the following statement upon this subject.

THAT the habit of cigar smoking is conducive to longevity is the firm belief of two physicians of the Eastern District of Brooklyn. Their faith in so peculiar theory is born of the fact that they owe their continued existence to the fondness of one of them for smoking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is apparent from reading the statement issued by the President of the New York Central on behalf of the Directors that the old brutal policy is to be continued, for under cover of providing a plan to protect travelers they are really endeavoring to acquire for their own benefit the people's properly in the streets and avenues of this city.

At the annual banquet of the New York Press Club, which was held last night at Delmonico's, Lewis Nixon, Tammany Hall's new leader, goaded by the good-natured raillery of Col. Abraham Gruber and Job E. Hedges, retorted in an impromptu speech, wherein he said some things which silenced his opponents.

Funeral services of John Van Schaick Oddie, Secretary of the New York Yacht Club, who died on Thursday, held yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, were attended by a congregation of fully 200, among whom were many men prominent in Wall Street.

Van Cortlandt Lake was alive with skaters yesterday, for, despite the warm change in the weather, the ice was in excellent condition, and the lake was fairly black with young people late in the afternoon. One section of the lake was reserved for the curiers, and quite a large delegation from various clubs in the local world were out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The many solutions of the tunnel question published in your paper in the past have been as interesting as amusing, and in most instances showed a lack of knowledge of the true conditions, as well as the engineering difficulties involved.

Price movements on the Stock Exchange yesterday were very irregular, strength showing in the early trading and heaviness later in the day, when, following the publication of the bank statement showing an increase of over $6,000,000 in surplus reserves, professional operators who had bought on the day previous undertook to secure their profits, while the operators, bearishly inclined, offered down prices.

From The Catholic world. A short time ago I heard at a cathedral Wagner's "Pilgrims" Chorus" as an operatic " "Tantum Ergo." What would the artist think of this treatment of his whole life's effort to teach men that "nothing is good without respect? "The cathedral is less inartistic, though more profane, that gives us a benediction scena from Donizetti -- very well sung.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 18. -- A string of eleven two-year-olds faced Starter Fitzgerald in the third race this afternoon, making their debut on the turf. Based on trials the Morris-Walden pair. Merry Sister and Offset, were favorites and coupled. Merry Sister's race was much the better. She was on the outside all the way, and was carried wide on the turns, but came very fast at the end and finished strong.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Confirmation of the report that the visit of Dr. Kuyper, the Dutch Premier, to London this week was connected with the proposed reopening of the peace negotiations between the Boers and the English seems positive in spite of the craftily qualified denials of Dr. Kuyper to the journalists at The Hague and of Lord Salisbury to Lord Rosebery in the House of Lords.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $.3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $300 of consideration over $3,000.

GRAND STREET? That is a high-sounding name for a street, though our own well-known Now York thoroughfare richly deserves its appellation. There are many Grand Streets in the cities of the United States, and it is quite possible that the future founders of great centres of population will christen streets yet to come as "Grand" Celebrated highways do not, however, always keep up their dignity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that a week has passed since the New York Central tunnel disaster, and we can with evidence before us from the newspaper reports realize the cause of such an accident, will you allow a business man to make a practical suggestion how to avoid such wholesale murder in the future?

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is apparent from reading the statement issued by the President of the New York Central on behalf of the Directors that the old brutal policy is to be continued, for under cover of providing a plan to protect travelers they are really endeavoring to acquire for their own benefit the people's properly in the streets and avenues of this city.

At the annual banquet of the New York Press Club, which was held last night at Delmonico's, Lewis Nixon, Tammany Hall's new leader, goaded by the good-natured raillery of Col. Abraham Gruber and Job E. Hedges, retorted in an impromptu speech, wherein he said some things which silenced his opponents.

MY friend Bethany, having learned that I was to pass through New York City on the way from Washington to Ogunquit, sent me a telegram in which he insisted that I must make him a visit. I accented the invitation, and on arriving in New York proceeded at once to Mr. Bethany's house.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 18. -- If the Government insists that the Indians in its change shall cut off their long hair, abstain from use of paint and gaudy habiliments of savagery, the aborigines will, they say, dig up their hatchet and shed their blood in resisting so sudden a wiping out of their racial characteristics.
From The Lonodn Mail. PARIS, Jan. 7. -- The last Paris Exposition has been blamed for many thing's, but few people suspected that it has earned a grudge on the part of the undertakers.

A DOZEN or more men were standing around one of the up-town shafts that leads down into the rapid transit subway, when one gave expression to an idea that from the remarks which followed had evidently been uppermost in the minds of aiL He said:

The American liner Philadelphia, which arrived yesterday from Southampton, had on board a mysterious passenger, whose presence excited the curiosity of all those who made the trip in the first cabin. On reaching the pier, his identity was learned by most of his fellow passengers for the first time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the article by Nathaniel T. Bacon on "Why the United States Is Not a Creditor Sunday's TIMES -- which every one interested in finance must have read with great interest -- find statements that deserve to be challenged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Secretary Root talked about the friar lands in the Philippines before the House Committee on insular Affairs to-day. He said these land holdings constituted one of the chief causes of discontent among the people; that they were the hotbeds of insurrection, and had furnished Aguinaldo his chief appeal to popular prejudice.

There were fully 5,000 skaters on the big lake of Central Park yesterday afternoon, which is located in the valley just east of the West Seventy-second Street entrance. It was Saturday afternoon, a holiday for the schoolboy and schoolgirl, a holiday for the down-town clerk and the stenographer, and for the children of the neighborhood.

PARIS, Jan. 18. -- Patriotic sentiment and warm sympathy with France were the keynotes of to-night's annual banquet and meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in Paris. Francis Kimbel, President of the Chamber, emphasized the former in his opening speech, proposing a toast to President Roosevelt and President Loubet, and saying that Americans abroad all took pride in declaring, after the manner of the ancient Romans, "Civis Americanus sum."

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 18. -- Yale Junior Promenade Week begins to-morrow with the annual crowding of Battell Chapel in the morning with the guests of the undergraduates. Prom. Sunday is annually the most brilliant of all Yale chapel functions, and this year bids fair to eclipse previous occasions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your admirable editorial on "The Panama Canal Offer " In to-day's issue of your paper which I commend to every thinking man who has not read it -- I beg to indorse all that you say as to the "influences " at work to defeat any canal across the isthmus.

The week which has passed was distinguished for the number of very handsome dances which were given at private houses. Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid gave a beautiful cotillion on Monday evening, and Mrs. Ogden Mills a very large and charming ball on Friday. Both of these entertainments were for the Misses Mills, who are making their debut this Winter.

Some prowling wagon thief gave the Right Rev. William Andrew Leonard, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Ohio, an anxious time at 192 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, last evening, and came near marring the service to-day in the Church of the Redeemer, at Pacific Street and Fourth Avenue, where the Bishop is to preach.

PORTSMOUTH, N. H., Jan. 18. -- Frank Jones, the millionaire brewer, railway man, and "the uncrowned King of New Hampshire "is dying of Bright's disease of the kidneys. His end, it is said, is a matter of but a few days.

Copyright, 1902. LONDON, Jan. 18. -- John S. Sargent has been painting many portrait's this Winter, including several more of the Wertheimer family, to whom his canvases have already given worldwide fame, and a group of three young women named Hunter, which is proclaimed to be veritably his masterpiece by those who have seen it in his studio.

Stories to the effect that the relations between Mayor Low and Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury are strained and will probably end in the resignation of the Commissioner were emphatically denied yesterday by the Mayor. He said: "The story Is pure fiction and imagination. There is not a shadow of truth in the statement, and you cannot make my denial too strong."

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, President of the Society for the Prevention of , Crime, yesterday gave out the following letter to Mayor Seth Low. The letter was adopted at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the society on Friday and sent to Mr. Low on Saturday by special messenger. It reads as follows:

Messrs. Boussod, Valadon Co. of Paris retired some months ago from the London market, and have followed this up by closing their New York branch, which has been managed hitherto by Mr. Eugene Glaenzer. Their paintings, water colors, and pastels will be sold next month, and Mr. Glaenzer will continue under his own name at the same address, 303 Fifth Avenue.

Delegates from all the German-American societies in New York and vicinity, representing about 250,000 of their countrymen, organized in Terrace Garden yesterday afternoon to receive fn some fitting manner Prince Henry of Prussia when he arrives. Fully 800 men, some of them deputized to act for several societies, many of which are singing societies, turn vereins, literary societies, and various kinds of social clubs, were present.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- Tiring of the play, three men in evening dress, who occupied a balcony box at the South Broad Street Theatre last night, turned their backs upon the stage and started a game of cards. Although they drew back into the shadow of the box and passed the cards circumspectly to each other, a keen-eyed "gallery god" soon took in the situation.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 19. -- A suit of much interest is in progress here. It involves the validity of a mortgage for $24,000 given by Albert Van Saun to Abram Leipziger of New York on property on Van Houten Street known as Apollo Hall. Early in August proceedings were instituted looking to the foreclosure of the mortgage owing to the default of the owner in the payment of the semi-annual interest.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- Bela E. Brown, aged sixty-five, a prominent dealer in diamonds and manufacturer of jewelry, was found murdered in his store, 24 State Street, to-night. Watchman John Raquet, while making his accustomed rounds, entered the jeweler's salesrooms as usual and found the owner dead.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 19. -- Miss Hilda Harris of 63 New Street is recovering from a severe attack of lockjaw, and it is said antitoxin is responsible for the cure.

Joseph Henry, a Councilman of the town of Harrison, N.J., and a member of the Police Committee of the board, was arrested at his saloon, 108 First Street, on Saturday night charged with maintaining a resort for gambling. The raid was headed by Prosecutor James S. Erwin and Assistant Prosecutor George T. Vickers, assisted by Detectives McCormick and Rielay, James Clark, clerk of the Grand Jury, and three deputies sworn in for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- When the Senate Committee on the Philippines, which has had the House Philippine Tariff bill under consideration, reports the measure to-morrow, the bill and the committee amendments will be sent to the printer, and Senator Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) Chairman of the committee, will give notice of his intention to call it up on the following day and ask for its continued consideration until finally disposed of.

In the very temperate and candid statement of Mr. BAKER of the American Transport Line on the subject of the Ship Subsidy bill now before Congress, which we published yesterday morning, we think that most of our readers missed, as we did, any mention of the possible alternative of building up our merchant marine, as other nations have done, by permitting our citizens to buy vessels where they can buy them best and cheapest.

The second handicap amateur billiard tournament under the auspices of the recently organized New York Billiard Club will start this afternoon at Maurice Daly's Academy, and continue throughout the week. The scratch men in the tourney are Charles Roder, T.E. Lewis, and W.S. Bash, and they to win must score 200 points.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 19. -- John T. Brush, President of the Cincinnati Baseball Club, grave out to-day a copy of a letter which he has mailed to A.G. Spalding in reply to a letter of Mr. Spalding's about the National Leagne troubles. Mr. Brush in this letter says in part:

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Jan. 19. -- The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Dr. Melville R. Skidmore of Centre Moriches continues to excite the entire town of Brookhaven, He left home ten days ago supposedly to make a professional call at West Hampton.

Ex-Congressman John De Witt Warner spoke last night at the usual Sunday night meeting of the Women's Henry George League at Civic Hall, 128 West Twenty-eighth Street. The meeting was presided over by Mrs. John S. Crosby, and Mr. Warner, who said he had strong objection to the existence of trusts, said he was in favor of the Government supplanting them in ownership.

ITALY AND ABYSSINIA. -- Of late there has been much printed in the European press concerning the relative influences possessed by France and Great Britain at the Court of the Negus Menelek of Abyssinia, and now the Italo-Abyssinian question, which has lain dormant since the Italian war in East Africa six years ago, is about to be revived.

One of the pioneer banks of New York will this week close its doors. To-morrow the Directors of the National Bank of North America will meet and elect new Directors, increase its capital stock, choose new officers, and formally absorb the Bank of the State of New York, established in 1836, and which for so many years has done business in the building at William Street and Exchange Place.

The sentiments of the Navy Department -- not necessarily the facts of the case -- were set forth by Senator HALE when he said, in introducing in the Senate the bills for the establishment of a National Naval Reserve, that the continued existence of the militia organizations would only be supported in a halfhearted way.

Secretary ROOT explained to the Congressional committee on Saturday, with his usual clearness, the situation as to the lands of the friars in the Philippines. He in effect advocated the plan proposed by the Philippine Commission. This is to purchase the lands and rent or sell them to actual cultivators.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- On Oct. 1, 1901, the total prison population of the State, according to the annual report of the State Prison Commission to the Legislature, was 11,157 of which 3,323 were in State prisons, 1,610 in reformatories, 359 in houses of refuge for women, 2,206 in the penitentiaries, and 3,528 in jails.

The sixth annual special service for students and college men at the Calvary Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, was held last night. The Rev. J. Lewis Parks conducted the service, and President Arthur T. Hadley of Yale and Bishop Potter made addresses on the subject. "The Modern View of Life's Purposes."

This is the period of the year when, according to the many prophets of evil in Wall Street, railroad earnings were to begin to show decreases, substantial and significant. The corn crop damage and the "turn" in the tide of business prosperity were to be the chief influencing factors in the lower level of earnings predicted.

Col. De Lancey Floyd-Jones, a well-known veteran of the Mexican and civil wars, died of pneumonia at 4 o'clock yesterday morning at the Park Avenue Hotel, where he had been living for some time. He had been ill for about ten days.

MANILA, Jan. 19. -- Gen. Chaffee, in the annual report which has just been issued, sums up the situation from the military point of view by saying that the Provinces of Batangas and Lagua, in Southern Luzon, and the Islands of Samar, Mindoro, and Cebu constitute the disturbed area in which bodies of insurgents in force are to be found.

The Tribune prints in another column an editorial from THE NEW YORK TIMES on Signer Marconi and his achievements. What is said in that editorial reflects truly the opinion of the whole country. It is with the confidence and with the best wishes of the American people that Signor Marconi returns to Europe.

LINCOLN, New Jan. 19. -- The large number of claims coming into the State Auditor's office for bounties on wolves and coyotes has led that official to make an investigation, and he has arrived at the conclusion that the farmers and ranchers in the western part of the State have gone into the business of breeding these animals for the bounty market.

BERLIN, Jan. 19. -- The Boerse has had another very strong week. The first half of the week showed light transactions, but values were well maintained. The latter half of the week exhibited uncommon strength, and there were sharp advances in prices.

TRENTON, N.J. Jan. 19. -- This city will be the centre of interest in the State during the coming week, and the capital city will see one of the busiest and most interesting periods in its history. On Tuesday there will be one of the largest parades of military and other organizations ever held in the State.

Valentines are out. The last of the calendars are not yet gone, and the preparations for St. Valentine's Day are begun. There are many dainty things this year among the valentines. Many of the cards are in floral designs, which, like the laces and dress ornaments, are cut out instead of being upon a solid card, and are much more effective for this reason.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- The feeling on the Stock Exchange at the close of the past week was decidedly happy. Whether or not this was merely the upward end of the financial see-saw is hard to say, but unless some unexpectedly discouraging news arrives from South Africa there is a good prospect for a continued upward movement.

Census Bulletin No. 122 contains some information relative to industrial combinations in the United States as they existed during the census year ended with May, 1900, which is of general interest as showing to what extent the tendency to combine plants formerly competitive has been carried and, by inference, what may be expected to be the progress in this direction during the next few years.

MANILA, Jan. 19. -- A report has been received here that a dugout canoe bearing eleven men of Company L, Second Infantry, is missing and probably lost. It is believed the men either perished or were captured.

Thirteen firemen were seriously overcome last night by smoke, and two were shocked by electricity in a fire which gutted the flower and feather establishment of Blumenthal Stiner, occupying the ground floor, basement, and subcellar of the five-story building at 686 Broadway, near Great Jones Street, and blocked the Broadway electric cars for more than six hours.

Further developments of an interesting character in the Reiss-Guden-Dady political controversy in Brooklyn are looked for to-day, when the examination of witnesses in the police court proceedings will be resumed before Magistrate Higginbotham in the Lee Avenue Court. Bert Reiss, the young lawyer, will be cross-examined as a witness to-day.

The Harlem River was free of ice yesterday, and a number of oarsmen ventured a spin on the river. A strong northwest breeze retarded their progress going north, but enabled them to get back in record-breaking time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 20. -- The horses ran over a muddy track at Oakland to-day, but favorites and well-played horses were successful in the majority of events. Winnie O'Connor and L. Jackson divided the riding honors, each landing three winners. Summary:
PARIS, Jan. 20. -- To-day's session of the Chamber of Deputies was devoted to interpellations concerning the attitude of France on the Boer war and the Armenian question.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- Prince Henry of Prussia, while in the United States, will visit Chicago, Milwaukee, Niagara Falls, and Boston. These points are embraced in theitinerary which has been cabled here by Dr. von Holleben, the German Ambassador at Washington. This programme was submitted to Emperor William and Prince Henry to-day, and has been approved by them.
To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of a recent date contains the following paragraph:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senate Committee on Pensions to-day ordered a favorable report upon Senator Hanna's bill to grant a pension of $3,000 a year to Mrs. Ida S. MeKinley, widow of the late President McKinley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Philippine war is not over -- not even in Luzon. On the contrary, it is now entering upon its sternest phase. This is shown in Gen. J. Franklin Bell's orders for the prosecution of the war in the Province of Batangas, which is in Southern Luzon. The main features of it are a declaration that the innocent must suffer with the guilty for the sake of speedily ending the war.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- Prince Henry of Prussia, while in the United States, will visit Chicago, Milwaukee, Niagara Falls, and Boston. These points are embraced in theitinerary which has been cabled here by Dr. von Holleben, the German Ambassador at Washington. This programme was submitted to Emperor William and Prince Henry to-day, and has been approved by them.
PARIS, Jan. 20. -- To-day's session of the Chamber of Deputies was devoted to interpellations concerning the attitude of France on the Boer war and the Armenian question.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The communication sent to Gov. Odell by the State Board of Charities in answer to the recommendations in his message with regard to the management of the State's charities still reposes in one of the pigeon holes of the Governor's desk. The Governor has refused to give it out, and the State Board has declined to make public its contents for fear of offending the Governor's dignity.

Wallace Downey, President of the Townsend Downey Shipbuilding Company, who has been in Washington consulting with President Roosevelt, Rear Admiral Evans, Assistant Secretary of State Hill, Ambassador von Holleben, and others, in regard to the launching of Emperor William of Germany's schooner yacht' Meteor, returned to New York yesterday morning.

Mr. RIXEY of Virginia has again introduced the bill originally proposed by him in 1898 to admit Confederates into the soldiers' homes established by the United States on the same terms as Union soldiers and also to extend to the States maintaining Confederate Soldiers' Homes the same aid that is extended to those maintaining homes for Union soldiers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- Invitations are out for the wedding of Miss Ethel Jackson and J. Frederick Zimmerman, Jr., which will take place Feb. 3 in St. James's Episcopal Church, Walnut and Twenty-second Streets. Miss Jackson has but recently retired from the stage, after having earned an emviable reputation as an actress and vocalist.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The communication sent to Gov. Odell by the State Board of Charities in answer to the recommendations in his message with regard to the management of the State's charities still reposes in one of the pigeon holes of the Governor's desk. The Governor has refused to give it out, and the State Board has declined to make public its contents for fear of offending the Governor's dignity.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Amid an absolute silence that was a striking tribute to the deep interest felt in the matter. Lord Cranborne, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Commons yesterday, made the first official statement which has ever emanated from the British Government regarding its private attitude toward the United States in the war with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee to-day decided to begin consideration of the bill reducing war revenue taxes, and after a conference attended by all of the Republican members or the committee. Chairman Payne gave out the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Imperialism is to be one of the issues of the Congressional and Presidential campaigns. This was made clear by the action of the Democrats in the House to-day.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20. -- Dr. Hart and Ecome were the winning favorites to-day. Andes reduced the six and a half furlong track record to 1:19 1/2.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The bill designed for the improvement of the canals and the Constitutional amendment authorizing a bond issue for that purpose was introduced to-night by Senator G.A. Davis. It provides for a bond issue of $28,800,000, to become due in 17 years, and to be sold in lots of not more than $9,000,000 at a time.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20. -- Dr. Hart and Ecome were the winning favorites to-day. Andes reduced the six and a half furlong track record to 1:19 1/2.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacoa, Jan. 20. -- It is now known that the insurgents who attempted to capture Maracaibo on Saturday were adherents of Gen. Hernandez, "El Mocho," (who is still kept in prison by President Castro.) The revolutionists attacked the police post situated in the main street, where a fight, which ended in the defeat of the revolutionists, took place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Only meagre official details of the fighting in Panama Bay were received here to-day. They consisted of a dispatch from Consul General Gudger at Panama and another from Capt. Mead, the commander of the cruiser Philadelphia. The dispatch from Mr. Gudger was as follows:

Wallace Downey, President of the Townsend Downey Shipbuilding Company, who has been in Washington consulting with President Roosevelt, Rear Admiral Evans, Assistant Secretary of State Hill, Ambassador von Holleben, and others, in regard to the launching of Emperor William of Germany's schooner yacht' Meteor, returned to New York yesterday morning.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The National Cycling Association, under whose auspices all of the recent six-day bicycle races have been held, desires the law prohibiting any contestant in a race remaining on the track more than twelve hours amended. Assemblyman Brooks to-night introduced at their request a bill designed to allow contestants to remain on the track the first twenty-four hours and thereafter not more than eighteen hours per day.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Amid an absolute silence that was a striking tribute to the deep interest felt in the matter. Lord Cranborne, Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Commons yesterday, made the first official statement which has ever emanated from the British Government regarding its private attitude toward the United States in the war with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Isthmian Canal Commission reports that in its opinton "the most practicable and feasible route" for an isthmian canal to be "under the control, management, and ownership of the United States " is that known as the Panama route. To this opinion every member of the commission has subscribed, all of their names being appended to the report transmitted to Congress to-day from the White House.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- Invitations are out for the wedding of Miss Ethel Jackson and J. Frederick Zimmerman, Jr., which will take place Feb. 3 in St. James's Episcopal Church, Walnut and Twenty-second Streets. Miss Jackson has but recently retired from the stage, after having earned an emviable reputation as an actress and vocalist.

Three matches were rolled in the New York Inter-Club Bowling League series last night, the Knickerbocker A.C. winning three games from the Harlem Wheelmen, the Harlem Republican winning three from the Caledonian Club, and the Century Wheelmen obtaining two of three games with the New York Athletic Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The scientists, led by the astronomers, teach us that certain fixed stars are at such an immense distance from our earth that it requires twenty years for light to reach us from them; and 200 years from others, This has been told so often that the mass of mankind in this enlightened age take it as gospel truth.

Franklin Bell's orders for the prosecution of the war in the Province of Batangas, which is in Southern Luzon. The main features of it are a declaration that the innocent must suffer with the guilty for the sake of speedily ending the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The proposed lease of Indian lands, except in Utah, have attracted very little attention as yet, and this is clue chiefly to the sudden and rapid manner in which they have been carried through, and also to the fact that the Congressional delegations of the States interested have offered no opposition.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacoa, Jan. 20. -- It is now known that the insurgents who attempted to capture Maracaibo on Saturday were adherents of Gen. Hernandez, "El Mocho," (who is still kept in prison by President Castro.) The revolutionists attacked the police post situated in the main street, where a fight, which ended in the defeat of the revolutionists, took place.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The National Cycling Association, under whose auspices all of the recent six-day bicycle races have been held, desires the law prohibiting any contestant in a race remaining on the track more than twelve hours amended. Assemblyman Brooks to-night introduced at their request a bill designed to allow contestants to remain on the track the first twenty-four hours and thereafter not more than eighteen hours per day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The proposed lease of Indian lands, except in Utah, have attracted very little attention as yet, and this is clue chiefly to the sudden and rapid manner in which they have been carried through, and also to the fact that the Congressional delegations of the States interested have offered no opposition.

John B. Day, the former owner and one time manager of the New York Baseball Club, made a proposition yesterday which he hopes will aid in clearing the atmos- phere of the present baseball difficulty and giving the clubs an opportunity to enjoy an excellent season of play. Mr. Day's offer seems almost too good to be believed for it is somewhat unique in baseball.
ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Gov. Odell was asked to-night whether he contemplated calling Mayor Low and Commissioner Partridge to account for permitting violations of the excise law in New York City.

John B. Day, the former owner and one time manager of the New York Baseball Club, made a proposition yesterday which he hopes will aid in clearing the atmos- phere of the present baseball difficulty and giving the clubs an opportunity to enjoy an excellent season of play. Mr. Day's offer seems almost too good to be believed for it is somewhat unique in baseball.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The first important debate of the session began in the House of Commons last evening, on an amendment, moved by Frederick Cawley, (Liberal,) to the address in reply to the speech from the throne. While the amendment constituted a recognized part of the opposition programme, strangely enough it was not supported by a single front bencher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The scientists, led by the astronomers, teach us that certain fixed stars are at such an immense distance from our earth that it requires twenty years for light to reach us from them; and 200 years from others, This has been told so often that the mass of mankind in this enlightened age take it as gospel truth.

The unanimous report submitted by the Isthmian Canal Commission in favor of a return to the Panama route for the canal will of course carry great weight, with Congress and with the country. For the signers are our experts upon the question. They were chosen because among them they comprised familiarity with all the phases of it.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The bill designed for the improvement of the canals and the Constitutional amendment authorizing a bond issue for that purpose was introduced to-night by Senator G.A. Davis. It provides for a bond issue of $28,800,000, to become due in 17 years, and to be sold in lots of not more than $9,000,000 at a time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Isthmian Canal Commission reports that in its opinton "the most practicable and feasible route" for an isthmian canal to be "under the control, management, and ownership of the United States " is that known as the Panama route. To this opinion every member of the commission has subscribed, all of their names being appended to the report transmitted to Congress to-day from the White House.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 20. -- Counsel for John I. Hambleton Co., bankers, of Baltimore, supposed to be representing the West Virginia Central Railroad Company, and probably the Gould interests, had introduced in the City Council to-night an ordinance directing the Mayor and the finance officers to set a price upon the Western Maryland property and to decide the method of sale.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20. -- P.G. Thebaud of New York to-day fully identified "T.E. Manners." the prisoner in the jail at Gretna, as Edcuard Kern. Jr., his late valet, who robbed the Thebaud mansion, in New York, of $60,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The State Civil Service Commission gave out the following statement to-day:

According to the statement of Mr. LODGE in bringing the Philippine Tariff bill before the Senate, one-fourth of the Dingley rates is to be deducted from the taxes levied on imports from the islands. He added that a reduction in the export duties levied in the islands would bring the total concession up to 35 per cent.

A perusal of the recent correspondence between Sir ROBERT HART, the Inspector General of Chinese Customs, and the Chinese Plenipotentiaries, concerning the provision to be made for the payment of the indemnity sheds a very instructive light upon Chinese official methods. The 5 per cent. ad valorem tariff upon all goods entering Chinese ports was imposed to raise part of the revenue needed for this purpose, and went into effect Nov. 11.
Mayor Low last evening issued the following statement as to the arrangement for the reception to be tendered by the City of New York to Prince Henry of Prussia on his arrival next month:

Richard Croker will sail for Europe on the Philadelphia this morning. He will go to his home at Wantage, Berks, England, for an extended stay. Last night at one of the most notable dinners ever given in the Democratic Club Mr. Croker announced his permanent retirement from active politics.

Nine of the jurymen who are to try Albert T. Patrick for the murder of William Marsh Rice were selected yesterday after a panel of 200 talesmen was nearly exhausted. Counsel for the defense in the two days consumed in trying to get a jury entered twelve peremptory challenges and the prosecution nine.

The French ball opened last night at the Madison Square Garden with everything indicating that before the morning the merriment would be all that was anticipated. The crowd was there, the costumes and decorations were brighter and gayer than usual, but as is the wont of this revel, the proceedings started with the solemnity that might be expected at a staid family function.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 -- Valet Edward Kern, who is wanted in New York for the Thebaud jewel robbery, was removed from Gretna to-day to the New Orleans prison. Klein and West, the men charged with stealing the jewelry which Kern himself stole, were placed on trial in the Criminal Court, but their case was postponed to Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the special information of your correspondent, Mr. Ellis, allow me to say that I have carefully read most of the letters of Bismarck, which were lately published, as well as those published some time ago, and since I read them in the German language have been unable to find in any of them, whether written or received by Bismarck, any trace of untruthfulness on his part.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill is almost certain to be amended. The country members have found out that it will hurt. Speaker Nixon is said to have made the discovery that it would reduce the assessment value of Westfield no less than $300,000. Other up-State members have been making similar discoveries, and to-day deep concern about the bill was manifested by the rural legislators.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Senator Wagner will probably introduce the excise bill which Mr. Jerome is to bring to Albany. The following corespondence on the subject has passed between the Senator and the District Attorney:
First Lieut. Walter Cox, Assistant Surgeon, is relieved from duty in the Philippines, and will proceed to San Francisco and report for instructions.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Much bitterness developed at the convention of the American Bowling Congress to-day and the struggle for supremacy between the Eastern and Western delegates may lead to a split and the formation of two distinct bodies. The convention was called to order by President Langhenry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- William Barret Ridgely. Controller of the Currency, has made the following statement in regard to the condition of National banks as shown by the latest reports:

As the weary baseball war drags along, with no clear indication of a peacemaking settlement, notwithstanding the offer of John B. Day to act as mediator between the rival factions, the view is gaining ground in the minds of many lovers of the sport that the coming season will undoubtedly witness a four-club schedule.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- During the debate on the foreign estimates in the Chamber of Deputies to-day Count Boni de Castellane (Republican) asked for explanations of the Government's policy. He complained that the French policy in China denoted that it was doubtful whether France had a comprehensive plan of foreign policy as in the case of Russia, Germany, and Great Britain.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21 -- It is understood at Cambridge that the proposed plans for another five years' agreement between Harvard and Tale are not progressing smoothly. The unofficial story is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 21 -- A fresh hit was scored by Henrietta Crosman at the Auditorium to-night in her new role of "Joan o' the Shoals." This latest footlight creation is unique, with a quaint, odd atmosphere and color of its own. Mrs. Sutherland's characters throughout the play are almost all of them promising studies, sacrificed in the long run to the imperative exigencies of a melodrama full of exciting situations.

District Attorney William Travers Jerome announced last night that the intention he had formed during the recent political campaign to live on the lower east side had not been forgotten, and that now, when he had his office in systematic shape and running safely, he meant to go and live among the people he championed on the stump, among whom he placed his campaign headquarters and his trust of being elected.

Much surprise was caused yesterday to the friends of Signer Guglielmo Marconi, the inventor of the Marconi wireless telegrap system, and Josephine Bowen Holman by the announcement that the marriage engagement of the young couple had been suddenly terminated.
MONEY AND EXCHANGE. Money on call, 3 @ 4 per cent., closing at 3 per cent. Majority of the day's loans at 3 1/2 per cent.

A junior fencing tournament of more than ordinary interest was held last evening in the New York Athletic Club. The competition practically ushered in the fencing season, for it was the first actual contest held in this city and inaugurated the series of events arranged for the year by the Amateur Fencers' League of America.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was very light, except in two or three stocks. The dullness of the Stock Exchange market naturally had its effect upon trading in outside securities, and resulted in a dull, irregular market. Of the day's events the most interesting was the transfer to the outside market of trading in the stock of the American Tobacco Company, the continued advance in which has recently drawn wide attention.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Fourteenth Street Bank of New York City has filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of increase of Directors from twelve to fifteen. The increase was approved by the State Superintendent of Banks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Roosevelt has issued cards for a musicale Jan. 28. The guests will be selected from her personal friends, and be largely of the younger contingent in society. The invitations are quite informal. They come in Mrs. Roosevelt's name, with the date and hour written in pen and ink and the single word "music."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- For nearly three hours to-day the Senate had under consideration the Philippine tariff bill. The measure was made the unfinished business, and will probably hold that position of preference until it shall" have been voted on finally. The debate was opened by Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts, Chairman of the Committee on Philippines.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- The correspondent of The Times, cabling from Peking, says that a son of Prince Ching will represent China at the coronation of King Edward. He is twenty-six years of age and personally is undistinguished.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 21 -- The declines in Cotton Duck issues and Seaboard stocks were the nearest approach to features in to-day's trading. Cotton Duck was easier, as the result of yesterday's failure on the part of the Directors to take final and positive action on the payment of January interest on the income bonds.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 21 -- Tobacco raisers and tobacco manufacturers were before the Ways and Means Committee today protesting against lower tariff rates on Cuban tobacco. There could be no reduction in those rates, they told the committee, without accompanying injury to the interests they represented.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 21 -- Yale's junior promenade was held in the Second Regiment Armory to-night and was attended by over 500 couples, representing society in all the large cities and from all over the country. As usual, the Yale "Prom" was to-night an elaborate and beautiful affair. The immense hall was towered and festooned with color and greenery.
