Prospects for the proposed New York and Port Chester Railroad, which promises safety and comfort hitherto unknown to a large proportion of daily travelers now bound to pass through the Park Avenue tunnel, became much brighter at a hearing before the State Railroad Commission at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday morning, when the Union Railway Company, which operates the trolley lines of the Bronx, surprised all present by withdrawing its objection.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Executive Committee of the Regents met to-day to consider among other matters their estimates for maintenance of the departments of the university for the next fiscal year. Whitelaw Reid, St. Clair McKelway, Bishop Doane, William H. Watson, and Albert Vanderveer attended the meeting.
Two sketches new to vaudeville are being presented in the continuous houses this week, and promise to become popular with those who enjoy variety in entertainment.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The inauguration of Franklin Murphy as Governor of New Jersey took place at Taylor's Opera House at noon to-day in the presence of an audience which filled the building. The members of the two houses of the Legislature occupied seats on the stage. Among those in the boxes were members of Mr. Murphy's family.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- A bill to license all fire insurance brokers has been introduced by Assemblyman Sulzberger. It provides for the payment of a fee of $25 for a certificate of authority, the certificate to remain in force one year unless revoked by the Superintendent of Insurance for cause.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The indications are that the Ship Subsidy bill has been made a party measure and that it will pass both Senate and House. Its passage in the House, it is thought, easily can be arranged by the Republican leaders, and there is no reason to expect obstructive tactics against the measure in the Senate.

Yesterday was rather quiet, and there is no very notable event on the list for today. The musicale given by Mr. and Mrs. William Douglas Sloane was the largest affair. Mrs. Frederic J. de Peyster gave the second and last of her receptions, and the fifth Fortnightly took place at the Waldorf-Astoria.

STEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21 -- El Ghor and Ernest Parham were the beaten favorites to-day. Merry Sisters ran three furlongrs in 0.35 3/4, which is a new record for the track. Weaffier clear: track fast Summary:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Continued heavy buying of Union Traction was the feature of the local market, and the stock advanced 1 1/8, reaching the highest recorded for many months. The buying brought out a report that arrangements had been made for a merger with a new company, but this was not confirmed.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Senate and House Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment were astonished to-day by the apparent remarkable lack of interest shown in the hearing on the Krum Corporation Tax bill. Although the fact that the hearing was to be held to-day had been extensively advertised, only two persons appeared in opposition to the bill.

At the annual dinner of the first panel Sheriff's jury, which was held at Delmonico's last evening, ex-Gov. Frank Black and District Attorney William Travers Jerome opposed one another in their toasts, both on the excise question. The District Attorney spoke warmly of the lack of interest which the up-State politicians were showing in the excise question, and several times in his address referred to them as "hay seeds."

BERLIN, Jan. 21 -- The Foreign Office denies that Germany desired to or did associate itself with any other Government that may have sought to bring about European intervention in the Spanish-American war.

The land beneath which the Bronx branch of the Rapid Transit tunnel will pass, immediately after crossing the Harlem River and before it reaches One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street, has been bought by the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company, through Douglas Robinson, Charles S. Brown Co.

Annie Thoms, seventeen years old, and her sister, Lizzie, thirteen years old, of 600 Park Avenue, Hoboken, were arraigned before Recorder Stanton yesterday charged with conspiracy to poison their mother, Mrs. Thoms, whose husband, John Thoms, is at St. Mary's Hospital suffering from a broken leg.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- The first ice yacht race for the challenge pennant of America between the Scud and Dreadnaught of the Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club and the Icicle and Jack Frost of the Hudson River Ice Yacht Club will be held Thursday morning. The race was to have been held to-day, but the conditions where not favorable.

PANAMA, Colombia, Jan. 21 -- All is quiet here to-day. Gen. Herrera, the revolutionary leader, informed Capt. Mead of the United States cruiser Philadelphia that he came here to prevent the Colombian Government using the steamer Lautaro against the Liberals. He had accomplished this, and therefore retired.

Swits Conde, one of the most prominent business men of this State, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. George B. Thorne, 34 West Seventy-second Street. He had been ill nearly a month with Bright's disease, complicated by heart trouble.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 21 -- The legal forms necessary to make Mrs. William Astor or Caroline W. Astor, as her petition is signed, a domiciled resident of Newport were completed in the Common Pleas division of the Supreme Court in session here to-day. The formalities were of a very simple character.

Less than half a score of railroad stocks and only four industrials were traded in yesterday to the extent of 10,000 shares apiece, the entire Stock Exchange list aggregating transactions of about 400,000 shares. Fluctuations were inconsequential, with very few exceptions being confined to fractions.

All possibility of a "corner" or serious complications in the trading on the Stock Exchange in the common stock of the American Tobacco Company was nipped in the bud yesterday by the Listing Committee of the Exchange, which struck these shares from the Exchange list. This followed the sensational rise in value of these shares, which in a few weeks have gone from 140 to 300.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- There will be a fight over the Employers' Liability bill, introduced by Senator Slater in accordance with the recommendations of Gov. Odell, unless certain desired concessions are made. Some of the railway employes' organizations, after consulting counsel, have become convinced that the bill in its present form affords them no protection.
Asked what he thought about the excise situation in the City of New York, Gov. ODELL replied; "I haven't thought about it. I don't go around with that load on my shoulders all the time."

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21 -- Governor General Taft, who arrived from Manila last night, landed this afternoon, and expects to start for Washington to-morrow. He will stop at Cincinnati, his home, on the way. Discussing conditions in the Philippines, Gov. Taft said to-day:

GOSHEN, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- As a result of the will left by the late Clarissa J. Huyler, wholesale litigation is under way, which involves the executors in defending the provisions of the will. The following have retained counsel; John J. Huyler, the husband; May Huyler, the daughter; Luther R. Marsh, R.H. Dolson, E.E. Conkling, and I.W. Robertson, the executors.

Commissioner DOUGHERTY felicitates himself and congratulates the public that, owing to favorable weather conditions during the past few months, the city has "plenty of water." This is undoubtedly a cause for satisfaction. It is also gratifying that Commissioner DOUGHERTY is considering measures for increasing the storage capacity of the old reservoirs and planning new ones where needed to conserve the supply and effect a more equable distribution.

Persons visiting the Department of Buildings on business have now the unusual experience of finding in charge an officer who believes that his first duty is to enforce the law, and to exercise his discretionary powers only when there is a reason for so doing which is not in conflict with the public interest.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 21 -- Admiral Schley's appeal from the majority report of the court of inquiry was taken to the White House to-day by M.A. Teague, assistant to his counsel. Attorney General Rayner. Mr. Rayner and Mr. Teague arrived in Washington at 11 o'clock to-day, and held a conference of several hours with Admiral Schley.

Dr. Carlos Henriquez and his two brothers, Dr. George and Richard, formerly residents in the United States of Colombia, were at luncheon yesterday afternoon in their home at the southeast corner of Ninety-eighth Street and West End Avenue, when a heritage in the shape of a Colombian parrot made so much noise that it was ordered up to its cage on the third floor of the house.

The deal by which the National Bank of North America absorbed the Bank of the State of New York was consummated yesterday at the annual meeting of the shareholders of the North America Bank. The capital stock was increased to $2,000,000, and the surplus to $2,100,000.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stumps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25- cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 21 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 5 dents premium. Exchanges, $24,721,127; balances, $1,949,021. On call, money is in abundant supply at 4 per cent. Several trust companies, generally quoting the highest rates, have marked down to 4 per cent.

-- "How about Achin?" is a question of extreme neatness, addressed, as it has been at last, by the badgered Britishers to the Dutchmen who are so horrified by recent events in South Africa, and who find, in the duration of Boer resistance to the armies of a nation claiming vastly superior strength, excuse for contemptuous denial of the claim.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Mr. Wainwright's bill designed to prohibit the use of steam in the Park Avenue tunnel in New York City, reads as follows:

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- An authoritative Statement has been secured regarding the rumored shipping deals, which, while confuting the reports of the amalgamation of several lines, reveals the fact that negotiations toward a trade agreement are being conducted on a larger scale than hitherto hinted at.
Stone, Matthews Co. have been appointed Philadelphia agents of the Aachen and Munich Insurance Company.

The Central of New Jersey's two new screw ferryboats Lakewood and Bound Brook crashed in the North River a little before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the fog, which was very thick. Both boats had left their slips at 1:30 P.M., the Lakewood from the New York side and the Bound Brook from Communipaw.

The production of a new opera at the Metropolitan Opera House may fairly be described as an "event." To those concerned in the preparations it certainly seems to be, for obstacles which would be regarded as insuperable in any foreign opera house have to be overcome. The schedule of appearances of principal singers is the prime factor in all arrangements.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The State Department has received a cablegram from United States Consul Malmros, at Colon, stating that an insurgent attack upon that place is momentarily expected.

It seems, from the tone of the inters view with Gov. TAFT cabled from San Francisco, that he is proceeding to Washington with very different views of the situation in the islands from those set forth in the almost simultaneous publication of the order of Gen. BELL concerning the necessity of a sharper prosecution of the campaign against the insurgents in the district of Batangas.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Several days ago Gov. Odell removed Sheriff Caldwell of Erie County because he permitted gambling in Buffalo. To-day the Senate Committee on Internal Affairs favorably reported a bill the purpose of which is generally understood to be to afford protection to the gamblers of Saratoga.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Ex-President Cleveland left here this evening for a two weeks' hunting and fishing trip in the South. The rest of the party, which consists of Rear Admiral R.D. Evans, Gen. Anson G. McCook, E.C. Benedict, and Herman May. will meet Mr. Cleveland at Jersey City, from which point they will start for Georgetown, S.C., to be the guests of Col. Alexander of that place.

The report of the committee of the County Medical Association appointed to examine into and report upon the quality of the sera and virus supplied to the New York market is a disappointment. If satisfactory to the profession, we are forced to conclude that they are easily satisfied.

Among the passengers who sailed on the American liner Philadelphia for England yesterday morning was Signer Guglielmo Marconi. The inventor was among the first of the passengers to reach the pier and went immediately to his stateroom after he boarded the liner. He was asked if he had anything further to say about the breaking off of his engagement to Miss Josephine Holman of Indiana, which fact was announced Tuesday.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Contractor J.B. McDonald may be allowed to dispose of his contract to operate the rapid transit lines in New York City if a bill, introduced by Assemblyman Kelsey to-day, becomes a law. The measure authorizes the contractor, now building the subways and installing the equipment, if he so desires, to dispose of his contract to operate the road.

The meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday lasted nearly four hours, during which there was hardly a minute of quietness for the orderly transaction of business. Members called each other "cowards," and President Fornes made so many threats to use force and to put members out of the Aldermanic Chamber if they did not come to order that both the Fusion members and the Democrats became involved in the uproar.

The P. Divver Association held a special meeting last night at its clubrooms, 59 Madison Street, and a resolution was adopted to form an independent Democratic organization in the Second Assembly District. More than 500 of the members who attended the meeting signed the following:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- This was beet sugar day with the Committee on Ways and Means. Mr. Oxnard and his friends were at the hearing, stoutly protesting against any tariff concessions whatever.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 22 -- The Harvard University crew management to-day received a challenge from Annapolis proposing a five-cornered race between Harvard, Yale, Pennsylvania, Georgetown, and Annapolis, to be rowed in May on the Severn, at Annapolis. Prominent rowing men who were consulted to-night said that probably the challenge will not be accepted.

Gov. ODELL'S plan for relieving the congestion of the calendar of the Supreme Court in this department by empowering him to detail County Judges selected by himself as Supreme Court Judges and send them to Manhattan to try cases and get the pay of their brevet rank is one thing.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 to 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $21,070,718; balances, $1,314,484. On call money is in good supply to the best borrowers at 4 per cent., and it is said there are exceptions as low as 3 1/2 per cent.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- In speaking of the Philippines, Gov. Taft said:

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- In view of the statement made by Lord Cranborne, the British Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in the House of Commons, Monday, on the subject of representations made to Great Britain before and after the outbreak of the Spanish-American war, inquiries were made in an authoritative quarter, to which were received the following explanations, which throw a somewhat different light on the question.

Public School No. 70, at Macon Street and Patchen Avenue, Brooklyn, was closed up on Tuesday afternoon, when it was discovered that the mother of four of the pupils of the school was a victim of smallpox. This is the third school in Brooklyn to be closed up because of the prevalence of the disease in that borough.

Beginning with the month of February the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, until further notice, will guarantee Brooklyn Union Elevated 4-5 per cent, bonds and Kings County Elevated 4 per cent, bonds on three flays in each month. Bonds will be guaranteed on Feb. 4, 14, and 24; March7, 17, and 28; April 4, 14 and 23; May 2, 12, and 23; June 3, 13, and 23, and July 1, 11, and 21.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- The split in the American Bowling Congress which had been threatening since the body convened here in annual session came this afternoon, when the Eastern delegates left the hall in a body and declined to take any part in the consideration of matters before the convention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The monthly statement of the collections of internal revenue show that in December, 1901, the total receipts were $22,812,915, a decrease as compared with the corresponding month in 1900 of $2,399,231. The receipts from the several sources of revenue are given as follows:

Among the various clauses contained in the will of Wolf Dazian, the theatrical costumer, which was filed for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday, was a provision to set aside $5,000 for "my son Meyer Dazian, who left this city many years ago and from whom I have not heard in twenty years."

MANILA, Jan. 22 -- A new phase of the currency question in the Philippine Islands has arisen with the refusal of the banks here to receive deposits in Mexican silver. The banks claim there is no more room in their vaults for such deposits.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- President A. J. Cassatt of the Pennsylvania Railroad has selected the following engineers as a commission of experts to supervise and approve all the plans for the proposed tunnels under New York Harbor for the Pennsylvania Railroad before the actual work of construction begins Col. Charles W. Raymond, Chairman; Charles M. Jacobs, Alfred Gustav Lindenthal, and W.H. Brown.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- The heavy rain of yesterday afternoon and last night has caused the Schuylkill River to overflow its banks, and from various nearby points reports were received to-day that the water is steadily rising. At Manayunk, a suburb of this city, the river is 20 feet above normal, and many manufacturing establishments at that place have suffered serious damage.

YORK, Penn., Jan. 22 -- In a letter received by A.B. Farquhar of this place, exPresident Grover Cleveland announces convalescence from his recent illness, and denounces in strong terms the opposition to the appeal of Cuba for tariff concessions. The letter is as follows:

Two days and a half having been spent in the examination of talesmen, the jury box was filled yesterday for the trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with the murder of William Marsh Rice. The prisoner looked the jurors over carefully and expressed satisfaction to his attorneys. After the recess he listened earnestly to every word uttered by Assistant District Attorney Osborne in his opening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Four hundred guests attended the Bachelors' Ball to-night at the National Rifles' Armory. Mrs. Richard Townsend received for the committee, which consisted of Jesse Brown, P. Lee Phillips, Capt. J.C. Gilmore, Jr., Major Charles L. McCawley, Richard T. Merrick, John Van Ness Phillip, and Lieut. Commander Thomas S. Rodgers.

An American Eagle of the largest size, erect, superb, proclaiming his confident purposes with ample voice, perched upon the right shoulder of our townsman, Mr. CHARLES A. GARDINER, as he penned the glowing words which we take for publication this morning from his speech to the New York Credit Men's Association and the rest of mankind.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The Western Telephone and Telegraph Company, capital stock of $32,000,000, was incorporated here to-day, to construct and operate lines of electric telegraph and telephone in all pans of the world. Incorporators -- Chandler Hovey, G.E. Perrin, and A.B. Mason, Boston; Clarence M. Walker and E.H. Green, Guttenberg, N.J.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Judge Peter S. Grosscup and John M. Clark were appointed by Judge Tuley this morning as the Trustees of the fund left by John Crerar for the erection of a colossal statue of Abraham Lincoln. The appointment of these Trustees was made in consequence of the death of Norman Williams and Huntlngton W. Jackson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Some of the old partisan fire was injected into the proceedings of the House to-day when the item in the Urgent Deficiency bill appropriating $500,000 for a military post at Manila, which the Democrats have been using as a text for speeches in opposition to the Philippine policy of the Administration for the last three days, was reached.

The proceedings in the Board of Aldermen yesterday were a disgrace to the city and a shame to those who took part in the disturbance. The Tammany members started in to make all the trouble possible, and the Fusion representatives, lacking organization and not quite sure of themselves, were inadvertently involved in a wrangle in which public business was subordinated to blackguardism and buffoonery.

Yesterday's stock market lapsed into extreme dullness. Barely 300,000 shares were dealt in throughout the day, which approximates within a few thousand shares the dullest day in all 1901, namely, Oct. 21, when the total dealings registered some 297,000 shares. So dull was the market that only nine securities were traded in to the extent of more than 10,000 shares each, with Metropolitan Street Railway stock alone furnishing one-fifth of the entire market transactions.

-- That malignant sprite, silent and invisible, to whom has been assigned the task of causing impossible accidents to happen in newspaper offices, dropped in upon us Tuesday night. Though nobody had even a suspicion of his presence, he performed his allotted work, and in yesterday's TIMES, clearly printed in the list of guests at the farewell dinner to Mr. RICHARD CROKER, was the name of -- Mr. HERMAN RIDDER!

The International Banking Corporation, a new financial institution, will not have exSecretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage as President, to succeed the late Marcellus Hartley. That was the statement made by Edward F. Cragin, a member of the Executive Committee, to reporters at his office in the Empire Building, 71 Broadway, yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 22 -- John T. Milliken, the wealthy chemist, mine owner, and capitalist, of this city, who is a brother-in-law of Albert T. Patrick, the lawyer who is now on trial in New York on the charge of murdering Millionaire William Marsh Rice, to-day made a statement in regard to the report that he had been offered a bribe to have Patrick compromise the will of 1900. He said:

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Dispatches from New York received here to-day state that "the First National Bank crowd of this city has acquired an important interest in the Commercial National Bank of Chicago. This means that the latter institution will become an important link in the chain of great banks being welded together on the community of interest plan through the efforts of J.P. Morgan and his allies.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- At to-day's meeting of the State Bar Association the following papers were read: "Some Legal Aspects of Hypnotism," by Dr. George Trumbull Ladd, Professor of Philosophy, Yale University; "Deliberate Legislation," by Carman F. Randolph of New York City; "The Supreme Court and the Present Bankruptcy Law," by William Horace Hotchkiss of Buffalo; "Anarchism," by Joseph A. Kellogg of Glens Falls, and "Legislation and Judicial Desiderata," by James MacC. Mitchell of Buffalo.

Capt. William A. Mercer, Seventh Cavalry, upon the transfer to his successor as Acting Indian Agent at Leech Lake Agency of the property and funds in his charge, and upon the rendition of his final accounts as Acting Indian Agent, will join his troop in Cuba.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- The French Ambassador, M. Jules Cambon, held receptions to-day in both the Senate and Assembly Chambers, the proceedings in both houses being suspended to give the Senators and Assemblymen an opportunity to shake hands with the distinguished diplomat.

Opponents of the great abattoir which Swift Co., proposed to erect, to cover the entire block front in First Avenue, between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets, won their fight at the regular meeting of the Board or Health, when Dr. Lederle, the President; Health Oficer Doty, and Police Commissioner Partridge, sitting as the board, denied the application of the meatpacking firm for permission to establish its plant.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 22 -- The local market to-day was a little backward and easy as a result of the uncertainties surrounding the Cotton Duck issues. The common stock sold off 1/2, and the first mortgage fives yielded 1/2. These losses were due to uneasiness growing out of the persistent refusal on the part of the present management to publish any facts upon which to base a judgment.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Money was wanted to-day in connection with lodging tenders for L2,000,000 of new local loans. The supply was fairly large. Discounts were weak on continuous German bill buying. Business on the Stock Exchange opened more cheerful. Kafirs were very active, and hardened on home and Continental buying.

At the annual meeting of the members of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association yesterday a recommendation that the concern reincorporate as a legal reserve life Insurance company was approved unanimously. The recommendation, which was presented by Vice President George D. Eldridge, was made by the Executive Committee of the Board of Directors.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 22 -- Trading in Union Traction continued to be the most interesting feature of the local market. Rather free selling orders caused a reaction to 35, but the buying was good. Welsbach dropped another point to-day, making a new low record. The Welsbaeh 5s, however, advanced to 64.

The German Emperor could not easily find among the Princes of his own house, or the Wittelsbach line of Bavaria, an envoy who would be more likely to represent him well than his brother HEINRICH. If the latter has had any political ambitions, or even thoughts, he has managed to keep them hidden.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 22 -- The Journal to-day quoted Lemuel D. Cummins, a former member of the Twentieth Kansas Regiment, admitting that he and Maurice Cohen, deceased, shot and killed two Filipino prisoners at the battle of Caloocan, and exonerating Gen. Wilder S. Metcalfe from all blame.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Presidents of Western railroads and of all the big packinghouse interests west of Chicago to the Missouri River have joined hands with a view of assisting each other to obey the provisions of the Inter-State Commerce law. The alliance was completed at a meeting held here to-day.

We wish the advocates of Cuban reciprocity were possessed of one-half of the cheek and hardihood of OXNARD. He told the Ways and Means Committee yesterday that the vast beet-sugar industry had been brought into existence by the laws of Congress. Its enactments had invited and induced capitalists to invest their money in beet-sugar production.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- It is said here that the International Sugar Conference at Brussels is practically certain to end in a disagreement between the powers concerned therein, with the result that France and Great Britain will take aggressive steps against the Austrian and German bounty systems.

Through the arraignment yesterday in the Ewen Street Police Court, Williamsburg, of Louis Anton, the seventeen-year-old son of a widow, of 27 Withers Street, Williamsburg, a story of a boy's opposition to his mother's second matrimonial venture was disclosed. Mrs. Anton is a woman weighing nearly 300 pounds and is thirty-eight years old.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- During the debate on the estimates of the Chancellor's Department in the Reichstag to-day, the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, referred to the pleasant relations between Germany and the United States and to the approaching visit of Prince Henry of Prussia. The Chancellor found his opportunity in the remarks of Dr. Barth, leader of the Freisinnige party, who, in discussing the budget, said:

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The Assembly Committee on internal Affairs to-day favorably reported a bill, the purpose of which is to give Louis F. Payn control of the Board of Equalization in and for the County of Columbia. This latter bill was introduced by Assemblyman Payne, who owes his nomination to Louis F. Payn, but is no relative of that Republican leader.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23. -- El Ghor and Scarlet Lily were the winning favorites today. Princess Tulane, Lizzie Brooks, and Lady Matchless were the debutantes in the two-year-old scramble, Lizzie Brooks being a strong favorite in the betting. The filly was practically left at the post. The Stewards have decided to allow Otis, the suspended jockey, to ride, but only for James Arthur, after Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Consideration of the Department of Commerce bill was resumed in the Senate to-day, the pending amendment being that offered by Mr. Pettus (Dem., Ala.,) that the Department of Labor be not transferred. He made a brief argument in support of his amendment.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 23. -- A bill was introduced in the House of Delegates to-day which, if passed, will effectually prevent the purchase of the Western Maryland Railroad by any corporation controlling a railroad in this State competing with the Western Maryland.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Lady Stanley, wife of Sir Henry M. Stanley, has caused a sensation by asserting that she has high authority for the statement that the Italian legal difficulties have been overcome, and that negotiations are well advanced for the transfer of the entire Borghese Gallery to the United States.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23. -- John F. Dryden, who was to-day made the Republican caucus choice for United States Senator, was born in Farmingdale, Me., on Aug. 7, 1839. He comes from an old New England family. He obtained an ordinary common school education and then entered Yale University with the intention of studying law.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Assemblyman Fitzgerald dropped into the Assembly box late this afternoon a bill repealing Chapter 353 of the Laws of 1882 entitled "An act to create a Board of Railroad Commissioners and to define and regulate its powers and duties." Mr. Fitzgerald's bill also repeals all acts and parts of acts amending the Railroad Commissioners act.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Guest, Keen Co. of Dowlais and Cardiff, who recently absorbed the Cyfarthfa Iron Works and collieries, have, it is announced, completed arrangements to acquire the business of the Nettlefolds, big screw wire manufacturers of Birmingham, for about $2,000,000.

Investigation of the collision in the New York Central tunnel, on Jan. 8, in which seventeen persons lost their lives, was begun yesterday by the State Railroad Commissioners at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, Chairman Ashley W. Cole presided. Commissioners Baker and Dunn sat with him. There were present in the room the representatives of numerous organizations of suburban towns, with recommendations for the improvement of the conditions prevailing in the tunnel.

The National Championship Committee of the Amateur Athletic Union, consisting of J.E. Sullivan, Chairman, Bartow S. Weeks, Dr. B. Merrill Hopkinson, Harry McMillan. W.H. Liginger, and Thomas F. Riley, yesterday made final arrangements with the Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia for holding the Amateur Athletic boxing and wrestling championships.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The State, Forest, Fish and Game Commission gave a hearing to-day on are application to have declared void the purchase of 30,000 acres of land in Franklin County, near Upper Saranac and Tupper Lakes, by the School of Forestry of Cornell University. This application was made by Eric P. Swenson, representing an association of residents and property owners of Upper Saranac Lake.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The debate on the address in reply to the speech from the throne was resumed in the House of Commons yesterday by John E. Redmond, the Irish Nationalist leader, who moved an amendment raising the whole question of Irish grievances.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23. -- Plunger H. Lewis took about $20,000 out of the ring at Oakland to-day and created a sensation. He beat the fifth race, betting $10,000 on Muresca alone. He also won $5,000 on Nilgar in the first race. Lewis came here from New York and bought Pompino and other horses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Mrs. Depew held her first reception this afternoon. She was assisted in welcoming several hundred visitors by Miss Paulding, who stood with her in the second drawing room. The Senator also was present throughout the receiving hours. Mrs. Depew wore a beautiful grown of white silk, embroidered in silver and let in with white lace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Consideration of the Urgent Deficiency bill, which has been under debate in the House since Monday, was completed to-day, but owing to the lateness of the hour the passage of the bill was postponed until to-morrow.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 23. -- Attorneys of Milton L. Bouden and Sophia Barth Chapman filed a petition to-day for an injunction in the State District Court against the Great Northern Railway and its Directors, to prevent the transfer of its stock to the Northern Securities Company. Bouden holds 400 and Mrs. Chapman 100 shares of Great Northern stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- It is promised for the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals that it will make a searching investigation before it determines its attitude with respect to route. This assurance comes not from Chairman Morgan, (Dem., La.,) but from "privates" in the committee.

PEKING, Jan. 23. -- The foreign Ministers here have attained the goal which has been their aim since intercourse between China and the powers began. They have been received as representatives of sovereigns equal in rank to the Chinese Emperor.

The detailed plans of the engineering department of the New York Central Railroad for the proposed tunnel loop were made public yesterday. It appears from these plans that the loop will turn off to the right from the present line of the road, and will at its extreme westerly end run underneath Madison Avenue for nearly two blocks, between Forty-fourth and Forty-sixth Streets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- A delegation of New York and Chicago bankers had a conference with Commissioner Yerkes of the Internal Revenue Bureau to-day and requested him to suspend the operation of his ruling to the effect that undivided bank profits should be taxed like other bank surplus.
ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Mayor Low's letter to the Rev. Charles II. Purkhurst was shown to Gov. Odell this evening, and his opinion of it asked.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 23. -- The Cereal Sugar Company of Peoria, through an old German vinegar maker, has discovered a process whereby one gallon of hydrol, a by-product in the refining of sugar, can be manufactured into one gallon of excellent crude spirits and about three gallons of good vinegar.

Some improvement showed in yesterday's stock market, there being developments which in some quarters were construed as indicative of the early coming of new activity. A number of conspicuous issues displayed strength, two or three making notable advances.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- Interest in the stock market to-day was chiefly centred in Union Traction, Philadelphia Company, and Consolidated Lake Superior. Other issues were dull and without remarkable change. Nearly half the trading was in Union Traction, the activity being in the last two hours.

The annual meeting of the Consumers' League of the City of New York was held yesterday afternoon in the assembly hall of the Presbyterian Building, 156 Fifth Avenue. The meeting was well attended. Mrs. Frederick Nathan, who was re-elected President for 1902, presided. Mrs. Nathan read her annual report, in which she told of the progress and work of the league.

Mayor Low yesterday sent to the officers of the Society for the Prevention of Crime the following answer to their communicauon of the 17th inst., in which it was charged that the excise law was not enforced:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- Petitions against the shooting of live pigeons were handed in by a number of Senators at the session this morning. Senator Slater has a bill in the Judiciary Committee prohibiting the shooting of live pigeons in this State. He announced to-day that he would push the bill next week, for there was an annual slaughter of 20,000 birds at one tournament alone.

The Rev. Dr. Ernest M. Stires, rector of St. Thomas's Church, talking to Protestant Episcopal clergy and laymen about the Sunday opening question last night, attacked the Continental Sunday and told his hearers that If any of the barriers here are taken down, the entire responsibility should rest upon the State, upon the politicians -- and none of it upon the Church.

Recent information as to the status of the experiments on the Berlin-Zossen railway, by which it was expected to demonstrate the practicability of speeds of 100 to 125 miles an hour for passenger trains, show that they have led just where it might have been expected they would.

BUFFALO, Jan. 23. -- According to Forecaster Cuthbertson of the United States Weather Bureau, the fall of snow, which begun on Tuesday morning and ended last night, amounted to 22 1/2 inches, the greatest this city has ever experienced.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- In the fifteenth annual report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, made public to-day, the paying of unlawful rebates to packing houses by railroad officials is deplored. That well-known business men at the head of those houses receive such rebates is commented upon as too strange a state of affairs to be described except by a plain statement of the facts in the case.

The week has been rather quiet. The first day began brilliantly, but the lead has not been followed. Last evening there were a few meetings of dancing classes, a large dinner given by Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor for thirty guests, and a number of receptions. The principal event of this evening is the cotillion to be given by Heber R. Bishop.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Money was in fair demand to-day, and the supplies were lessened. Considerable sums were locked up in large applications for local loans stock. Discounts eased, after the lowering of the bank rate. Business on the Stock Exchange opened quiet. There was renewed activity in Kafirs, especially East Rands.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The Assembly Committee on Judiciary to-day reported on the State Commission in Lunacy bill with a number of important amendments to the Governor's plan. To conciliate the sentiment antagonistic to the abolishment of the Boards of Managers, it is proposed to continue these boards, but to reduce their membership to five.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The visit to the United States of Prince Henry of Prussia, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, continues to interest political circles in the Austrian capital. Austria has for years past not been on sufciently cordial terms with the United States to seek a rapprochement such as Germany is now bent on effecting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The anti-imperialistic propaganda is on at both ends of the Capitol. Apparently the Democrats in Congress fancy they are shaping the absorbing issue of the next Congressional campaign and maybe of the next Presidential campaign. It seems to be the general impression with those who have watched the Congressional proceedings this session that the minority is interested in practically nothing but anti-imperialism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Louisiana cane sugar men made their protest to-day against Cuban reciprocity. They told the Ways and Means Committee a story similar to that which had been told the day before by the beet sugar men. The admission or Cuban sugar free or at a reduced rate of duty would be death to their industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Industrial Commission, after several years spent in investigating the industrial condition of the country, with the view of making recommendations calculated to assist in the solution of the problems of the times, has completed and sent to the printer its final report.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission in its annual report makes some sensible suggestions for amendment of the law, some that are not likely to improve the law, and some admissions that seriously affect the whole system of the law.

John Herbst, thirteen years old, of 158 Nassau Avenue, Brooklyn, is confined in an eye and ear infirmary in Manhattan in a critical condition. While acting as mentor of the Seventh Grammar Class of Public School No. 34, in Norman Avenue, Wednesday, he was struck in the eyes by missiles thrown by other boys of the class.

One way to deal with smallpox patients was invented by Michael Kelly in Hudson County, N.J., yesterday afternoon. His way of doing things was to drive several patients around the streets for hours while he satisfied his desire for drink.

The statesmen who, in committee, listened to the arguments submitted on Wednesday against the Governor's scheme to do away with the local boards of the State Hospitals for the Insane were a sorely puzzled lot. They could not understand why the large number of men and women engaged in this work should object to having an unpaid job taken away from them.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23. -- The Republican caucus to name a candidate for United States Senator to be supported during the present session of the Legislature to succeed the late Gen. Sewell selected on the nineteenth ballot John F. Dryden of Newark, President of the Prudential Insurance Company.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 23. -- The Cotton Duck issues, which were wavering yesterday, were better to-day. The common stock and 5 per cent. bonds advanced fractionally, while the income bonds sold 3 points higher than yesterday's bid price. The uneasiness seemed to be more or less allayed and more confidence developed.

The lot at the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Seventieth Street, title to which is held by the City Real Estate Company, and the adjoining plot, 50 by 100, owned by J. Harsen Rhoades, have been sold. The transaction, it is believed, also includes a fourth lot on the avenue, owned by Anthony H. Creagh, making in all a plot 100.5 by 100.

In an address lately delivered before the Railroad Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE said a great many practical and sensible things which doubtless gave his hearers much pleasure. He also said some things which have set them thinking, and which have given rise to much discussion.

The first step was taken yesterday by the city officials to take away from the Tammany architects, Horgan Slattery, the monopoly they have had during the past four years of all city work which could be voted to the firm. Mayor Low took up the matter at the meeting of the Armory Board, and he declared that it was his intention to have open bidding and competition for plans for armories in the future.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- Money loaned to-day at the Clearing House at 3 and 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5c premium. Exchanges, $20,264,973; balances, $2,006,097. Call money is in good supply at 4 per cent., and offerings are a little freer at 3 1/2 per cent. Time money is more plentiful.
The Crescent Athletic Club hockey team scored a signal victory over the seven of the St. Nicholas Skating Club, in the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink, Brooklyn, last night, the score being 8 to 2.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The town here was thoroughly aroused to-day over a murder which was discovered shortly after noon, when the body of Mrs. Isabella Allen, forty-four years old and the mother of five children, was found with the skull crushed beside the roadway in Cottage Avenue, not 300 feet from the door of her own home.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 23. -- The American Bowling Congress met to-day, and after a conference between committees from the Eastern and Western delegates, it was decided that the action of yesterday's convention should be rescinded, after which matters will stand as they did before the convention met. The convention will meet this afternoon, with President Langhenry presiding.

The taking of testimony in the trial of Albert T. Patrick for the murder of William Marsh Rice will commence before Recorder Goft this morning, when some of the most important witnesses of the prosecution will be put upon the stand. Yesterday's session was taken up with the opening address to the jury of Assistant District Attorney Osborne.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24. -- Lord Minto, Canada's Governor General, has received a memorial from the Yukon Council, setting forth that the interests of Canada as well as of the Yukon Territory require that representation be given the Territory both in the House of Commons and the Senate of Canada.

At a dinner last night of the Republican District Committee of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, Mayor Low, who is a resident of the district and who attended as one of the guests of honor, was presented with a souvenir of the occasion in the form of an elephant labeled " G.O.P." standing on a prostrate Tammany Tiger.

There was no more disappointed town on the map last night than Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and it was all because the Ramsden-Powell goat trial did not take place in Pioneer Hall. With the consent of James A. Morgan, the Justice of the Peace, the goat was to have been taken to court and introduced as evidence, and the local sports were betting on how long it would take that goat to clear the court.

That a collection numbering a half-dozen old masters of the Netherlands and a haifscore excellent paintings by the Rpmanti cists of the last century in France should have existed in Chicago, hardly known to the collectors and the press, seems at first blush surprising, but it is only an incident like many others.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24. -- Only two favorites won at Oakland to-day. Plunger Lewis dropped some of his winnings, as he bet on four horses that failed to land, among them Greyfeld and Dunblane. Meehanus was a favorite for the third race, but he did not have his usual speed, and was beaten by Matt Hogan and Captivate.

President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan has decided that the order of Commissioner Livingston to remove the Pabst portico on Forty-second Street, near Broadway, shall be carried out. A letter was written yesterday to the attorney for James B. Regan, the lessee and owner of the restauram to this effect.

At a meeting of the Road Drivers' Association of the City of New York, held at the Rossmore Hotel last night, Fred Gerken's The Monk was recognzed as the champion trotter of the Speedway for 1901 and the Secretary was directed to obtain a suitably engrossed certificate to that effect for presentation to the owner of the champion.

Inquiry of the several foreign banking houses authorized to receive subscriptions to the imperial German loan -- which the cables report as having been fifteen times oversubscribed -- discloses the fact that the American subscriptions aggregate the entire issue, which will be 300,000,000 marks.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In connection with the review of "A Royal Lineage," by Mrs. Watson, that appeared in your columns Jan. 18 under the heading of " American Descendants of Alfred the Great," it may be of interest to call attention to an article by Henry Kendall that appeared in The Nineteenth Century some years ago.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your last week's editorial anent a Smollett revival find the new edition of his works edited by Mr. Henley, you suggested some doubts as to whether the editor himself had read these books through. It would not be surprising if he had not. Their interminable length, if nothing else, makes them the despair of all but the most patient delver in literary mines.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: THE late Artemus Ward used to say: "U kan most allwuz Phind phun at a phuneral iph U no whare 2 look!"

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The Committee on Coinage has reported to the House a bill introduced by Mr. HILL of Connecticut the passage of which will finally settle the silver question in the United States and establish the gold standard on a perfectly sound and steady basis. It will at the same time make provision for the sorely felt and constantly Increasing need of small change.

A remonstrance bearing 200 signatures has been sent to Bishop Potter protesting against the sale of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, Seventy-fourth Street, near Park Avenue, the abandonment of the parish, and the turning over of the property to the Church of the Archangel, St. Nicholas Avenue, Harlem.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Every one of the 800 locomotive engineers on the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway is to be given a material increase in wages. The advance in pay was agreed upon at a meeting of a committee representing the engineers and officers of the road in Chi- cago to-day, and is the result of meetings that have been held almost daily since Oct. 26.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress ended to-night. It has been one of the most successful meets held by the organization, both as regards the number of entries and the management of the tournament. The newly-elected officers of the Congress were installed to-night at National Hall, and the best of feeling now prevails among the delegates from every section of the country.

MISS SICHEL has given an unusually vivid and lifelike series of character sketches. It has been difficult, she says, to find "a title modest enough for a book which in no way claims to be a chronicle of events, political or military. It is merely a personal history -- an effort to recall a few of the less-known figures that moved and had their being in France in the first half of the sixteenth century."

THIS volume is the second in the series of old New York wills Published by the Historical Society, the first having been issued less than a year ago. It is the twenty -- sixth volume in the series of publications the society has issued.

A correspondent, who evidently has had some experience in the struggle toward Parnassus, writes to say that, though he thinks we are right in the main in regard to the value of a literary reputation, in many cases -- or at any rate in his -- we are wrong. He believes that without friends at court the chances of an unknown writer are still very poor.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The Assembly Committee on Judiciary to-day reported the Brackett-Rogers State Commission in Lunacy bill, with the amendments made by the committee yesterday, and the bill went to a third reading. Being on the order of third reading, it can be called up in three days, and the programme of the majority leaders is to call it up and put it through.

Ed. Gardner, who won the billiard cham- pionship at the Montauk Club recently, was defeated in a handicap match at the Knickerbocker Billiard Academy, Brooklyn, last night by Dr. H.D. Jennings of the Crescent Athletic Club. Dr. Jennings was required to make 225 at the 14.2 game while Gardiner was to have made 300 to win.

In the past year, which brought forward such a wealth of printed books, the sales of manuscripts and autographs were astonishingly rich. The feature of the year was the sale of the magnificent Ashburnham-Barrois collection of ancient manuscripts, 628 items realizing the large total of u33,217 6s. 6d., but a number of the other auctions of 1901 included many fine things.

In preparation for the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Golf Association on Friday night at the Metropolitan Club, the Nominating Committee submitted its report yesterday. Several changes are made, due to a desire to give more equable representation to the different sections of the organization.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In the recent discussion started by Mr. Findlay Sackett, he quotes from your review of Mr. Hapgood's "Washington": " In spite of an unusually high sense of hurnor, he advised," Here " honor," not " humor," is evidently the word which was written, but set up wrong by the printer.

ST. LOUIS. Jan. 24. -- Two distinct shocks of earthquake were felt in St. Louis and in many of the adjoining towns a few minutes before 5 o'clock this morning. The first shock was light. The second was more severe. Persons who had slept through the first disturbance were awakened by the second.

There have been few greater changes in the last twenty-five years than that which has taken place in the attitude of religion toward science, and this change is well shown in Dr. Cunningham Geikie's new book, "The Vicar and His Friends." It is a discursive volume, purporting to record the conversations of Dr. Manly, the vicar of Battiscombe, with some of his parish- ioners, and with neighboring clergymen.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- The rush to buy Union Traction was somewhat checked to-day by a flood of rumors regarding deals affecting the company, but the buying was still large and the price was steady at 35 3/8. A general opinion on the Street is that a guaranteed rental on Union Traction stock will be a feature of any merger plan that may be executed.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Benjamin Kidd's second work, "The Principles of Western Civilization," which will be published next month, although complete in itself, serves as the first volume to a system of evolutionary social philosophy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- W.H. Barnes, a Director of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company and also of the International Navigation Company, to-day denied the reports that the visit of the representatives of the English steamship companies who are now in this country was for the purpose of bringing about a combination of those lines with the International Navigation Company.

The first witnesses in the Patrick trial were put upon the stand yesterday. Recorder Goff's court was crowded with persons intently listening to the evidence, which disclosed the actions of Patrick on the day following the murder of William Marsh Rice, and the efforts of Patrick to collect the moneys which the aged millionaire had on deposit in this city.

PEKING, Jan. 24. -- The Dowager Empress and her Councillors are seriously discussing the engagement of foreign advisers to reorganize the Government. Yuan-Shi-Kai, Viceroy of Pe-chi-Li, is the inspiration of the movement. He returns to Pao-ting-Foo to-morrow, having devoted several days to impressing the importance of real reforms upon the court, and to urging the necessity for adopting foreign methods, as being the only practical measures.

Books for Prince Henry to Read. All the world apparently has visit on Prince Henry over the visit of Prince Henry of Germany to the United States. It is said that he is keenly posting himself in the outline of his prospective travels.

There were a number of meetings of dancing classes last night. Mrs. William Brookfield's, which is for a young set, met at Sherry's, the third Knickerbocker dance at Delmonico's, and several others at other places. Then there was the cotillion at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Heber R. Bishop.
A cablegram was received by the Merchants Association yesterday morning from Cuba as follows:

Yesterday's developments went far toward clearing up the somewhat complex situation involving the properties on Broad and New Streets and Exchange Place, immediately south of the Commercial Cable Building. The holdings of the Adee estate, an irregular parcel containing about 6,300 square feet, with frontages at 24 Broad Street.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 3 and 2 1/2 per cent, and New York funds sold at 5 cents premium. Exchanges, $20,560,467; balances, $11,027,911. Money on call is very easy at 4 per cent., and to the strongest borrowers is becoming easier at 3 1/2 per cent. Time money is offered more freely.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- State Senator John Raines spoke at the annual banquet of the Railway Men's Sound Money Association here this evening. Discussing "Rights of Citizens," he touched upon many points raised by District Attorney Jerome of New York in a speech in this city a short time ago.

"Journalist, author, musician." Thus was described for "Who's Who in America," doubleness by himself, Edward Howard House, who died in Tokio on Dec. 18, in his sixty-sixth year. He is entitled to be remembered and celebrated in all three capacities. His early advantages were not unusual.

-- As practical recognition of a lamentable fact, and as tending to call general attention to that fact, much and grateful commendation is deserved by the two ladies of this city who have established a fund from the proceeds of which prizes are to be paid for essays suggesting means of preventing the extermination in the woods and fields near New York of all flowering plants, shrubs, and trees.

That there has been a need for a good study in English of the life and writings of Schiller will probably not be denied by any one in a position to know the facts of the case. This need Prof. Calvin Thomas has aimed to supply, and it is with that end in view that he has produced the present volume.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- James J. Hill, President of the Northern Securities Company and of the Great Northern Railway, testified for more than three hours before the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day. In answer to questions tending to show the effect of the community-of-interest plan on rates he declared that competition did not lower rates, but advanced them.

The earnest disclaimers of the Continental powers in respect to their reported intention to apply unfriendly pressure to us just before the outbreak of the Spanish war are both flattering and Inopportune. We are naturally pleased to receive these assurances that the great Continental powers so much desire to enjoy our good-will that they are striving to remove from our minds the impression created by reports of their former action hostile to our interests.

The new Sinking Fund Commission held its first meeting in the Council Chamber yesterday. Mayor Low presided, and all the members were present. President Fornes of the Board of Aldermen and Alderman Parsons were appointed as a committee to examine and report on the securities in the hands of the board.

In a little shop window in the heart of a busy district in this city there is a display of fabrics suitable for the clothing of men, and on each piece there is a large placard announcing a "Gigantic Clearing Sale." Beyond the window, which holds the entire front with the exception of a modest door, there is apparently only a single room of small dimensions.

The New, York Times Saturtday Review of Books: Being a great lover of biography I see with a thrill of pleasure " E.R.'s " request for suggestions on that particular line of reading. Your article in reply is all that it should be; but sometimes something personal is interesting. May I name the following list of books as some which have given me the greatest amount of enjoyment:

The death this week of Aubrey Thomas de Vere, the third son of Sir Aubrey de Vere, who filed in 1816, and was himself a poet of note as well as a prose writer, removes a distinguished and patriarchal author. The elder de Vere was a contemporary of Byron and Peel at Hurrow, and Wordsworth soid of his sonnets that they were " the most perfect of our age."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Mrs. Roosevelt held her usual weekly reception for a specially invited company of 200 guests from 4 to 6 o'clock to-day. She and Miss Roosevelt welcomed the company in the Blue Room, while Miss Root, the Misses Hitchcock, Miss Jones, and Miss Wilson served tea in the adjoining Green Room.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- T.P. O'Connor, (Irish Nationalist) made a strong fighting speech in the House of Commons yesterday in support of John E. Redmond's amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne. He was frequently cheered.

The State Railroad Commission continued at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday its investigation of the recent disaster in the Park Avenue tunnel. Having copies of all the evidence taken before District Attorney Jerome and at the Coroner's inquest, the Commissioners hope to expedite matters by confining their efforts, in the main, to finding means of improving conditions in the tunnel.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24. -- The market was again interested in Cotton Duck issues, owing to the prospective measures likely to be taken to force the management to give a full accounting of the past income bondholders. The likelihood of some important information coming to the surface made the tone of the group firmer, and resulted in an advance of the income and first 5 per cent, bonds also in the common stock.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Rabbi Emil G. Hirsch of Chicago was cheered enthusiastically at the Outlook Club to-night at the conclusion of an address on "Israel Among the Nations." Men and women rose to their feet to cheer and the demonstration was led by the Rev. Dr. Bradford, one of the best known Protestant ministers in this city.

EMINENT surgeons there have been whose biographies would scarcely be of interest to any one outside their own profession. Sir James Paget, on the contrary, though in the front rank of medical science, was of such a type that the strongest impression left by his memoir is not so much that of his skill as a surgeon as of his quality as a man.

The new city administration has acted none too soon, and with none too much severity, in the cases of those two "devouring absurdities," HORGAN SLATTERY. Two self-respecting men in their places -- but that is unimaginable. Two self-respecting men could never occupy their places.
George H. Mendell, Jr., has been chosen Assistant Secretary of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company.

Mr. John Kendrick Bangs, chronicling a series of interviews purported to be received over the telephone from Baron Munchausen, entirely refutes the statement made by the Baron, in Hades, to Ananias of The Gehenna Gazette, to the effect that lying is a lost art. The lies in "Mr. Munchausen" are unsurpassed in history.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Democratic members of the House of Representatives held a caucus in the hall of the House at 8 o'clock this evening. After a short and spirited contest they adopted resolutions declaring that they were without power to promulgate a platform of principles for the party, owing to the binding character of the party platform heretofore regularly made at a National Convention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If not too late, I desire to add a word to the discussion of Mr. Westinghouse's letter. That letter is to be commended, in so far as it may be taken as a protest against the prevailing idea that electric traction is a panacea for all the dangers and difficulties of railroading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As much is written to the papers these days on the matter of taxation, I have a word or two to say on what looks to me to be a loose, careless, and unbusinesslike way of doing things in the Tax Commissioner's office in this city. I note one or two instances of which I have personal knowledge.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- The National Asphalt Company and the Asphalt Company of America to-day confessed two judgments, each for $301,000, to the Land Title and Trust Company of Philadelphia, trustee.

It was reported in this city yesterday that the St. Lawrence and Adirondack Railroad, through A.L. Meyer, its Vice President, had concluded negotiations for the acquisition of the Canada Atlantic Railway on terms declared to be advantageous to the purchasing Company. It was said that the Dominion Securities Company would finance the consolidation.

Readers scarcely need to have their attention called to the notice printed elsewhere of the New York Historical Society's second volume of abstracts of old wills. Here will be found interesting and suggestive reading. Nearly 200 years have passed since the dates of these wills.

OSKALOOSA, Iowa, Jan. 24. -- As the result of a terrible mine explosion at Lost Creek this afternoon twenty-one dead are in an improvised morgue, and eight injured persons are in a temporary hospital. The disaster occurred at noon and was what is known as a "dust" explosion.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- The February Atlantic, which appears on Saturday, might with small impropriety be called a New York number, for nearly forty pages are given to topics especially concerning New Yorkers, and seventeen of these to Mr. Edward M. Shepard's liberation of mind on " The Second Mayoralty Election in Greater New York."

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Money was in fair re- quest to-day. The gathering in of revenue will contract the supplies of money and the collections until the end of the financial year, and will tend to sweep the market bare. Besides the strong foreign demand for gold in the open market, the condition of Continental exchange is against a further decline of rates.

Jessie Milward has decided to produce " In the Palace of the King " in London. Just what theatre has been selected is not yet known, but the play will be produced about Easter. Several well-known American actors have been approached with offers of parts in the London cast.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The treaty of cession of the Danish West Indies was signed at the State Department to-day by Secretary Hay and Constantin Brun, the Danish Minister. The treaty will be submitted to the Senate for ratification immediately.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Some variety was lent to the hearings on Cuban reciprocity before the Ways and Means Committee at to-day's session. It was furnished by two sugar men who declared in favor of granting some concessions to Cuba. One was H.H. Post of the National Sugar Company, and the other was R.B. Hawley of Texas, who is interested in cane sugar, both in Louisiana and Cuba.

Improvement in the copper trade situation is suggested by the tendency of copper shares in the security market. Both here and in Boston there has lately been evident absorption of the more prominent issues on a substantial scale. Over 65,000 shares of Amalgamated were dealt in on the Stock Exchange yesterday and a two-point advance in the quotation was scored.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 24. -- Capt. Alfred Hicks of Pittsburg and Thomas K. Maher of Philadelphia closed a deal to-day for 8,000 acres of coal land situated in Belmont County, Ohio, for a sum close to $1,000,000. The property adjoins the De Armit Coal Company's workings, and has three mines now in operation.

WHEN James A. Roberts, the State Controller in 1895, wanted more room for the extension of his office, he came across many valuable papers relating to the Revotionary War, "showing the important position occupied by the State in that momentous struggle."

Sometime there should be told the stories of the lives of the women -- mothers, sisters, and wives -- who by courage, insight, and foresight have brought to perfect fruition the literary labors of the men who have stood nearest to their hearts. How many have been these rare and gifted souls is betrayed in the dedication of volumes which now could ill be spared from the world's best literature.

RECOLLECTIONS." by Aubrey de Vere, is being published by John Lane. Besides its autobiographical interest it deals with the many friendships which the dead poet formed and conserved during his many years of literary work.

From Last Saturday's Mail and Express. The publishers of "The Right of Way" have discovered, as a result of an investigation conducted by them, that of 1,486 readers of the book willing to talk on the subject, 711 "had heard it favorably spoken of by friends," 468 had seen it advertised and reviewed, while 114 more had read reviews without seeing the advertisement.

IMPRESSIONS of a combatant in great and epoch-making wars are always worth reading, but when the recorder is a Geueral who is able to oversee the greater part of engagements that may cover miles of territory and has the means of directing or helping to direct the movement of armies, then a double interest attaches to what he has to say.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- It is reported that the State Department, at the instance of the Navy Department, has made a complaint to Lord Pauncefote against the British Naval Attache, Capt. Lewis Bayly. The report is accepted as true by naval officers and others, although no authoritative confirmation of it can be obtained.

We confess that we do not quite understand the statement from Albany that the amendments proposed to the Brackett-Rogers bill as to the hospitals for the insane is in the nature of a compromise. It is in effect the compromise proposed in the time-honored offer of "Heads I win, tails you lose."

A New biography on a wellworn subject must usually justify its appearance either by presenting new material by offering a subtle and intensive character analysis, or by radically new generalizations and conclusions on well-known facts.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 24. -- Old Fox, who lowered the short course steeplechase track record two seconds, was the only winning favorite to-day. Weather cloudy; track fast. Summary:

Borough, President Cantor gave a hearing yesterday to a committee representing the Automobile Club of America, the Road Drivers' Association, and the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York appointed to urge the necessity for better roads in the northern part of Manhattan. A.R. Shattuck, from the Automobile Club, was the spokesman, the other members being Dave H. Morris, George C. Wheeler, and S.S. Toman.

Business in the outside market yesterday was fairly large and prices again showed a number of net gains. A few stocks declined as a result of the day's transactions, but these cases were exceptional. The increased interest that has appeared for the past few days was sustained and a number of stocks figured more or less prominently in the dealings.

The Bowery underwent a change last night. By a well-planned, strategic campaign, wholesale raids were made on more than half a dozen notorious resorts on the thoroughfare by nearly one hundred policemen under Inspector Cross and Capt. Walsh, and thirty-two prisoners were taken.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: I am a humble borrower and my opinion may not have much weight with the "great" in the library world, but I use the library extensively, coming there every Sunday and at least two nights in the week. We have a kind of a reading and discussion club, consisting of five members, for all of whom I select and borrow the books.

SOME homes are mushrooms, pleasant and useful, but rootless; others are oaks, drawing strength from deep-buried growths of the past, their branches widespreading on every side to take the winds of distant lands.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- The Pegasus Club, which is one of the distinctive feattures of literary Philadelphia, is soon to issue a year-book similar in general plan to that which it printed several years ago, though more comprehensive in Its scope and contents. The idea is to incorporate in the volume all of the poems submitted by its members in the regular course of the club's work.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Elbert H. Gary, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the United States Steel Corporation, has been elected Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Allis-Chalmers Company, the largest machinery concern in the world, capitalized at $25,000,000. The announcement it is said, has caused a sensation in commercial and financial circles, as it means that the Steel Trust intends reaching out into another line of business.

The Hon. J. B. Frazier, who will be the next Governor of Tennessee, spoke in response to the toast "James K. Polk" before the Tennessee Society at St. Louis on Jackson Day. His peroration was as follows:

THE artistic and popular failure in Rome of Gabriele d'Annunzio's drama, "Francesca da Rimini." illustrates in an interesting manner the risk that a playwright runs in seeking to present an elemental historical story freed from the traditions and legends that have accumulated around it.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25. -- The projected consolidation of four big bituminous coal properties owned by Marylanders, with the New Somerset Company, controlling mines in the Meyersdale region of Pennsylvania, is for the purpose of producing a mixed bituminous coal that will more effectively compete with the English coal for foreign trade.
ROME, Jan. 25. -- J. P. Farrelly of Nashville, Tenn., Secretary of the American College here, has been appointed Privy Chamberlain to the Pope.

Letter from Home, Italy, to Chicago RecordHerald. At noon on the day before Christmas Leo XIII. formally received the Cardinals, Archbishops, Bishops, and Monsignori of the Catholic Church who were in Rome in order that they might present their Christmas congratulations and salutations to him.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- Mrs. Langtry returned to the Imperial Theatre this evening in " Mademoiselle Mars," a gorgeously mounted and costumed comedy, in which Mrs. Langtry dominated, as usual, with her feminine charms, for which the play gives ample opportunity. The emotional triumph of Lewis Waller's Napoleon was the feature of the play, the dramatic possibilities of which were appreciated by the large audience in attendance.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25. -- Sevoy cantered off with the Cotton Selling Stakes, worth $1,485 to the winner, to-day, and incidentally lowered the seven furlongs track record to 1:26. Light showers fell during the forenoon, but the track was fast. The Stewards have suspended George Land Co., their trainer and horses, pending an investigation of the performances of the horse Judge Steadman.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a lawyer, I have been watching your columns to see whether the excellent and timely letter of J. U. H. in regard to trials before referees, recently published by you, would call forth any other communications on the subject. To my surprise it has not.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Jan. 25. -- In the second regular session of the first legislative Assembly of Porto Rico, both houses are working as harmoniously as could be expected, and by the time the session adjourns they will have accomplished much toward the "Americanizing" of Porto Rico.

JUST after midnignt a motor vehicle puffed and snorted, as it waited outside the Staten Island Ferry gates to regain the power of self-propulsion lost because the gasoline tank had to be emptied before the trip over the bay, and refilled on this side, under rules of maritime insurance.

A great crowd thronged Madison Square Garden last night, the occasion being the sixth annual entertainment, concert, and ball of the Siegel-Cooper Company's Employes' Association. The entertainment consisted of a programme of the foremost acrobats and sensational feature performers. It included trick and fancy bicycle riding, and a polo game by fifteen cyclists.

IT was the former County Clerk who was talking: "I remember -- 't was long in the sixties," said he, "and traveling wasn't as pleasant then us now, that the Montreal sleeper was over an hour late out of Troy one night, and a party of us was waiting at Eagle Bridge, up in Rens -- selaer County, thinking she'd never come along.

The discussion that has been going on for several weeks over the plan of the Governor to abolish the local Boards of Managers for the State hospitals for the insane, or to strip them of all real influence in the hospitals, has brought up the whole theory of the relation of official administration to this peculiar class of institutions.

The Colonnade Hotel, at 728 Broadway, running through to Astor Place, together with the adjoining property, best known to New Yorkers as the " Old London Street," has been sold by the Hilton estate to William E. Finn. Mr. Finn confirmed last evening reports that he was the purchaser of this large parcel and talked freely in regard to the transaction.

We doubt whether the officials responsible for the management of any great railroad system have ever before been placed in a position so serious as that now occupied by the officers and managing staff of the New York Central Railroad. They have repeatedly been called to the bar of public opinion, but in that tribunal the formality of entering a plea is often contemptuously ignored and time quashes the proceedings.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 25. -- There is considerable excitement here over the case of David Sandman, who, with his son Samuel, is accused of violating the excise law.

Boston is the centre of the shoe trade, and it is not by chance that there are located all about this city such large industries, or is our pre-eminence of sudden growth. It has been steady, gradual, and sure, from the days when the merchants of old Salem brought home the hides and skins from foreign lands to be tanned and curried by the tanneries about that town.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the letter from M., published in Tuesday's TIMES, permit me to say, that M. is probably not aware of the fact that by questioning the accepted theory of the velocity of light through space, he is monkeying with the keystone of the arch which supports the Copernican system.
In his Majesty the King motoring possesses one of its keenest supporters.

Charles M. Schwab; who signed contracts last Summer for the purchase of the block now occupied by the Orphan Asylum of the City of New York, West End Avenue, Riverside Drive, and Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets, took title yesterday to the West End Avenue front of the property.

IT is a peculiar time to look for visitors at the seashore these months, when the north wind is the ruling factor in the weather, and when the waves come rolling in go cold and fierce and all repellent in their aspect, yet down by the sea are many guests who scorn the delights of New York in Summer and prefer to visit there at just such times as these.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Jan. 25. -- Fine mid-winter conditions have prevailed in Virginia during the past week, and outdoor sports and pastimes have been much in vogue. Duck hunting continues to be popular and many parties have been organized at the Chamberlin for hunting trips in launches and sailing craft on the bay.

ONE of the rarest volumes of early newspapers in the possession of the New York Historical Society is the first volume of The Boston News Letter, the initial number of which was published on April 17, 1704, being the first regular newspaper published in the Colonies. Besides this fact, sufficiently interesting in itself, is the autograph presentation on the fly leaf, reading: "To the New York Historical Society, from George Bruce, Printer. New York. 1805."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Believing that your paper is always ready to champion that which is essential for the welfare of the people, I would like to suggest that which has not been advocated before, viz., National legislation compelling the railroad companies of the country to adopt block signals.
