LONDON, Jan. 25. -- This week has seen Edward VII. dutifully and with unaffected sorrow observing the anniversary of his mother's death and also the abandonment of the trappings of woe by the Court. The period of mourning is now over, and the feeling of the entire nation seems to be that Edward is a fitting successor to the beloved and respected Queen.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 25. -- Theatre parties continue to be the fad of the Winter in Baltimore, and three particularly charming ones occurred on Monday evening. Two to see Mr. Willard in "The Cardinal" were given by Mrs. Daniel C. Howell and Miss Howell in honor of Hiss Louise Symington, and by Mrs. Ferdinand C. Latrobe in honor of her debutante daughter.

The public schools of this city will observe the fifty-eighth anniversary of the birth of William McKinley next Wednesday, and in each school in the Borough of Manhattan there will then be unveiled a colossal bust of George Washington, presented by Frank Tilford. State Superintendent Charles R. Skinner, in His letter regarding the observance of McKinley's birthday, says:

By winning first place in the pole vault at the monthly games of St. Bartholomew's Athletic Club, held in the clubhouse, in East Forty-second Street, last night, Otto Sauer maintained his lead in the competition for the club trophy for the present indoor season, though with the narrow margin of a single point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe there is not the slightest reason to doubt that, with a proper degree of foresight in design, reasonable care in installation, and systematic inspection and test after installation, electricity is a safer agent than steam in the operation of elevated or underground railways.

District Attorney William Travers Jerome will meet with a greater welcome on the lower east side than he, perhaps, anticipated when he decided to make his home at 8 Rutgers Street. His neighbors watch with keen interest the preparation of the old parochial school of St. Teresa's Church. Three new bathtubs are to be placed in the upper floors and as many needle baths.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present excise law takes from New York City approximately $5,000,000. This amount is controlled and largely applied by the State in reduction of tax levies outside the City of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Two five-mile motor-paced bicycle races tooK place to-night on the indoor track at the Second Regiment Armory. The contestants were "Jimmy" Michael, Jean Gougoltz of Paris, Archie McEachern of Canada, and Howard Freeman of Portland, Ore. McEachern broke the world's indoor five-mile record, covering the distance in 7:52 2-5.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- When the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House resumed its Chinese exclusion hearings today it was informed that, if it had not been understood fully by the people of the Pacific Coast in the last National campaign that the Chinese would be excluded by a Republican administration and by a Republican Congress, California's electoral vote would have been cast for Mr. Bryan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals at its meeting Monday will decide whether it shall report immediately to the Senate in favor of constructing the Isthmian Canal or recommend the adoption of the Nicaragua route. The alternative proposition is to enter on an investigation of the several proposed routes before making a report.
Announcement was made yesterday that Andrew Carnegie within the last few days has given a second gift of $300,000 to Cooper Union.

It is no wonder that a zealous British Naval Attache should have got himself into trouble at Washington through excess of zeal. There is no nation the Naval and Military Attache's of which have not got themselves into like trouble. Our own country has been quite as unfortunate in this respect as any other.

The proposition of the State Entomologist of New Jersey that a legislative appropriation of $10,000 be made for the extermination of the mosquito in that State has brought to the front a large and industrious contingent of the friends of that insect, who, until attacked, probably did not know that he had any friends.

Some exciting finishes marked the events last evening in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory in the annual Fall games of the Seventy-first Regiment Athletic Association. There was an excellent entry list in nearly all the competitions, and as they were all closed, the inter-company feeling ran high.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- There has been a great misapprehension of the attitude of the President toward what are known as the machine and reform elements of Pennsylvania. This misapprehension may have arisen from an imperfect understanding on the part of Representative Young of Pennsylvania in a White House conversation relating to the Internal Revenue Collectorship at Philadelphia.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Jan. 25. -- Two cases of smallpox have developed in Netcong, Morris County. The first victim to succumb to the dread disease is Mrs. A. S. Butler, who became ill last Monday. Two days later Dr. Miller, who was attending her, announced that she had smallpox, and yesterday the eighteen-months-old child of Charles Hammell was stricken.

One night about two weeks ago Isabel Evans departed from the home of her husband, Dr. Paul W. Evans, a wealthy dentist, at 1,722 S Street, Washington. She left behind a little note, scribbled with a pencil, saying that he need not watch for her return, as she had gone forever and expected to find her future fame and happiness on the stage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Again our eminent legislators at Albany are framing a mortgage tax bill. Think of it! A bill to tax an obligation and indebtedness. This matter has been so thoroughly thrashed over that it may well be said that anything new in the premises will be a work of supererogation.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 25. -- All the Directors of the wrecked Middlesex County Bank of Perth Amboy, excepting Robert N. Valentine, uncle of George M. Valentine, the defaulting cashier of the institution, have served on Receiver Edward S. Campbell notices of appeal from the recent decision of Vice Chancellor Pitney, holding them responsible for $219,533, the losses estimated to have been suffered through the collapse of the bank.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the last acts of kindness of the Tammany Mayor and its friends in the Tax Board was to decrease or cut clown the taxation of the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company. This act of kindness was no more than should have been suspected, when you remember that the last administration owed its existence to the kindly efforts of the magnates who finance the street railroad company.

The block front on the west side of Seventh Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-fifth and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Streets, purchased recently from the Schubarth estate by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company, has been resold by the latter corporation to the Hudson Realty Company, of which Maximilian Morgenthau is President.
LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The Irish Party has begun another campaign against the Government in Parliament, in the usual manner, and with, the anticipated setback.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25. -- A number of society women of Baltimore have become interested in the vigorous crusade by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals against "docking" horses. These ladies have ordered the practice stopped on their own horses.

Trade facilities between England and America are about to be still further increased. A powerful British-American syndicate, represented in London by Mr. Howard Crosby Cooke, 9 and 11 Fenchurch Avenue, and in America by persons looking after the interests of the Gould family, is planning to build a large fleet of refrigerator steamers.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I have long wanted to write a letter to Mr. Vreeland, but Mr. Vreeland is a busy man, and I feared he might not read it, but it came to my mind that Mr. Vreeland, being a smart man, surely read THE TIMES, and that if you would publish the letter it would certainly reach him.

HOW can the entire absence of great dancers to-day be accounted for? Why are there no Taglionis, no Ellslers? It may be asserted that there are no real artists no whose graceful, poses are enhanting and who are the embodiment of poetic movement.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "Barkis is willin." Was there ever such a farce as we have now on our hands?

OWNERSHIP of fine table linen is a matter of honest and pardonable pride to every woman. It is a pity that its durability and its beauty are at the mercy of her servants. From the moment the damask is removed from the table to the time when it is returned to the linen closet, presumably not always actually, glossy, spotless, and accurately folded, it is constantly exposed to harmful mishandling by careless or ignorant maids.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- There was a sort of rally in American securities at the latter end of the week, and there was, too, some fitful buying all the week from the Continent, but financial interest was not centred in this branch of the market, as the Kafir boom continues in spite of the slight setback in the middle of the week.

SILAS LARRABEE was moved to mirth to-day by a paragraph in The Social Mirror, the society paper of Ogunquit. "Read that," he said, handing the paper to me and pointing to the amusing paragraph, which ran as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- When the second day's inquiry by the Inter-State Commerce Commission into the "community of interest" combination of the great railroads opened to-day, great interest was manifested in E. H. Harriman's testimony. The United Stales court's room, where the investigation was held, was crowded with well-known railway men from all over the country.

A new complication developed yesterday in this Brooklyn Magistrates' case, when Supreme Court Justice Maddox, on the application of appointed Magistrate E. Gaston Higginbotham, granted an order directing Assistant Corporation Counsel McKeen to show cause why the proceedings in the case before Justice Keogh should not be reopened.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Hear Admiral Schley declared three times to-day that he had no intention of entering politics. He said that no office, however high, would tempt him to jeopardize the love which the people of this country had expressed for him.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel, Corporation, arrived here Thursday, and has had two busy days, seeing, acquaintances and receiving a procession of bankers and manufacturers Who wanted to meet the man who is directing five milliards of capital.

Up to within the closing fifteen minutes of business yesterday the stock market was dull and almost featureless with trading so inactive that the tape on a number of occasions failed to record any transactions for several minutes at a time. In the final quarter of an, hour however, the market took on more activity -- but at the expense of values.

The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals will again during the present session of the State Legislature put forth every effort in trying to have repealed the law which allows trap shooting where live birds are used in this State. A hearing will be given on Wednesday next at Albany before the Fisheries and Game Committee, at which the society will be strongly represented.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With all deference to our brave legislators, who are endeavoring to eliminate from our country various political and social evils, together with other obnoxious things, allow me, a native-born American woman, to put in a plea for the daisy, that it shall not be entirely exterminated.

BERLIN, Jan. 25. -- The newspapers say that Herr Ballin, a Director of the Hamburg-American Line, and Dr. Wiegand of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company, before entering into negotiations with Mr. Morgan, will demand a pledge that the American capitalists will Abstain from buying more of the shares of the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd companies.

With the exception of the sale of the Adee estate holdings, on Broad and New Streets and Exchange Place, last week witnessed no transactions of great size or importance. An increased number of small dealings, however, went far toward sustaining a volume of business well up to recent standards, and showed, if anything, a greater variety in the properties involved.
A GROUP of reporters awaited the coming of Signor Marconi at the Hoffman House Monday night. It was near midnight when he came in and said in answer to their queries:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Analyzing the published statement of the Michigan beet sugar manufacturers, it shows the following results:

Vanderbilt shares moved somewhat irregularly. New York Central has been depressed by the numerous damage suits brought against it as a result of the deplorable tunnel accident. On the other hand, the so-called junior issues have been steadily bought by Vanderbilt brokers, this being in large measure due to the improving dividend positions of these properties, as illustrated by the recent increase of 1 per cent. in the dividend on Nickel Plate second preferred.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two letters in THE TIMES yesterday appear to me to be worthy of special attention. One, on the subject of "Heat, Light and Electricity," suggests an error as great as the Ptolemaic theory of astronomy; the other, "A Phase of the Saloon Question," appeals to the experience of residents as well as visitors in our large cities.

NATURALLY, there is great repugnance against all frivolity in matters of such solemn moment as a funeral-naturally so, and rightly so -- but just as grief is grief, so mirth is mirth, and, incidentally, there are both funerals and funerals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. "L. W.," from sinless Brooklyn, rose up in wrath at my suggestions for adopting a practical way that may persuade the powers in Albany to grant New York the much-needed reform in excise matters, and by impressing upon them the fact that by being obstinate they may lose the power given the Republican Party by the help of independent Democrats, and independent Republicans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on "The Art of City Making" is highly suggestive. What would you say, for instance, to the assertion that New York can easily be made to look, like a fairy city, both from the waters off the Battery and from the high grounds north and west of Central Park? Of course I am speaking particularly of Manhattan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Mr. Westinghouse in your issue of Jan. 16 sounds a bit startling, and seems to the writer somewhat overdrawn, but it certainly gives a note of warning that should not pass unheeded. In the rapid development of electric traction there has been a tendency to take chances which from the standpoint of public safety should be suppressed.

Henry Sehreiner,twenty-eight years old, of 326 Hamburg Avenue, Brooklyn, was arraigned before Police Justice Hoos, in Jersey City, yesterday charged with grand larceny by George Ponsby. Ponsby, whose home is in Holyoke; Mass., started from there on Friday to visit relatives in New Jersey.

WASHlNGTON, Jan. 25. -- The black and white flag of the Gridiron Club floated over the Arlington Hotel all day, and tonight the Washington correspondents composing that organization assembled for the seventeenth annual dinner. More than 20 members and guests gathered in the banquet hall, and for four, hours were entertained with the interesting and unique features of a Gridiron dinner.

First-nighters will have plenty to interest them at the theatres this week. Indeed, those persons who make it a rule not to miss opening performances of new plays will be obliged to do so this week, lor tomorrow night three attractions entirely new to this city will make their bid for favor. And on Tuesday and Wednesday both in the afternoon and evening novelties will be offered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you be so kind as to allow me sufficient space in your columns to call your attention to your misconception of the field of inquiry of the Committee of Public Health of the New York County Medical Association as evinced by your editorial of this date?

When you take the Winter as a standard or any-one week, you will find that the past seven days were dull. The week, it is true, opened brilliantly. The ball given by Mr. and Mrs. William F. Douglas for Miss Douglas and Miss Randolph was a very handsome affair, and Dr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb on the same night entertained in honor of Senator Chauncey M. Depew and his bride.

The most successful target breaker at the Crescent Athletic Club's Bay Ridge traps yesterday was Brigham, one of the scratch men. He contested two matches with Skelly, and won each by one target, while he was the winner in four of the seven shoots for trophies. Marshall and Bedford tied in one of the others, and Bedford won the shoot-off and another trophy by beating Marshall out in a handicap twenty-five target event.

PHELADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Business on the Exchange to-day fell away to the lowest proportions of the year and price variations were slight. The only semblance of life was in Union Traction and Reading common, the latter becoming weak in the last half hour, on New York selling. Danville Bessemer, after a long period of drowsiness, was unusually active.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 14. -- The commission which has been revising the Criminal Code during the last fifteen years has made its report to the Council of the Empire. The new code, if adopted, will replace the Code of 1845, and will naturally contain numerous vital changes.
IT is in a woman's dormitory near Columbia University, and the elevator carries some 400 different college girls up and down every day.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The rates for money and discount rates were firm to-day. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet, pending the settlement, which commences Monday. Consols weakened, owing to the condition of the money market and the talk of further issues of colonial loans. Americans were neglected, and most of the changes were to lower prices.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- Ex-Postmaster General Wilson S. Bissell in an address before the Men's Glub here to-night roundly scored the plan for the Government ownership of the telegraph. He said there are many reasons why the Government should not own the wire.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- The first two matches of a series of home-and-home games between the New York Racquet Club and the Philadelphia Racquet Club were played here to-day, and the local teams won both contests. In the first match B. H. Warburton and Edgar Scott of this city, defeated W. B. Dinsmore. Jr., and Ford Huntington of New York in four straight sets.

HERE is one of those street-car problems which come up once in a while, Most people, particularly those who were standing in the car at the time, would decide against the woman and the dog. The woman was out with a good-sized dog, a dog too large to hold in the lap, and boarded the car with him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It was with great pleasure I read the letter in a recent issue of THE TIMES signed "A Chiel's Amang Ye Takin' Notes" on this subject. I have lacked courage to write you upon the question of refuges of public comfort, but I Trill follow your correspondent's brave example.

The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst was one of the guests invited to address the members of the Independent Club of the Twenty-first Assembly District, who held their annual dinner last night at the Bingiiam, Broadway and 94th Street. The subject was "Excise," and in view of Mayor Low's letter and Dr. Parkhurst's recent utterances on the question, a large attendance was present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This latest message of Gov. Odell to the Legislature concerning the judiciary, even more than his first message, stamps him as inexcusably ignorant for a man in his place. He opens by saying that in his regular annual message he called attention to the "matter of the speedy disposition of the large trial calendar in the City of New York."

NOVELTIES in the week of music just ended were not unusually numerous. We had "Messaline," at the opera, Victor Herbert's new suite at the consert of the Pitsburg, Orchestra, Chadwick's quintet at the kneisel Quartet concert, and some Strauss songs (heard only once before) at Mr. Hamlin's interesting recital on Wednesday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25. -- The tone of the whole market was better to-day, due partially to the improved feeling in the Cotton Duck group. The disclosure of important news with reference to those issues created more confidence among holders and thus put the whole list in a less apprehensive mood.

IN the matter of economic house heating, America is easily first. Take a modern moderate-sized apartment flat. The heating of the building is usually in the hands of the janitor. Properly located in the basement is the steam or hot air or hot water apparatus, and this is as a rule so efficient that an independent fire maintained in any of the apartments up stairs is a rarity.

MRS. ROBERT McALLISTER LLOYD was frocked the other afternoon in a charming pale-blue costume. It was a smooth-finished cloth and was embroidered in the same color and had touches of white lace and black velvet. The trailing skirt had fine vines ebroidered in blue silk cord all about the bottom and the top of the simulated flounce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It will greatly interest your readers and the passengers who suffer from colds contracted from open-front doors of surface cars to know that the Board of Health, to whom I wrote, replied that "there is no provision of the sanitary code in reference to this matter."

Roer Pence Rumors. The recent statement made by the British Government that it had received no overtures of peace from any one authorized to represent the Roer leaders was on Thursday supplemented by a more extended declaration to the same effect by the Government leader in the House of Commons.

It seems to us that the more the proposition of Representative Rixey of Virginia, namely, that the doors of soldiers' homes be opened to ex-Confederates, is discussed the greater the chances will be that it will meet the approval of the Southern people. There may be reasons for rejecting it, but those in favor of it are a great deal stronger.
Now that Columbia has been admitted to the intercollegiate basket ball league, considerable local interest has manifested itself in the sport.

Whenever a number of young people come together in Russia during New Year's Eve and Tewlfth Night, whether it be for dancing, playing games, or just spending a pleasant evening together, some one of the party is sure to propose "fate-reading,' or "gadat," as it is called in Russian.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The public is to be congratulated that Mr. George Westinghouse's letter, published in yours of the 16th, happened among others in a medium that would grant the subject the space its agitation warrants.

Peter Martin recently purchased a piebald horse with eyes that should have belonged to a circus "calico" steed. He tried the animal for the first time in his hansom cab yesterday and picked up near Trinity Church late in the evening three fares, who evidently had feared the excise law might be put into operation to-day and had over-fortified against Sabbath thirstiness.

The extreme quiet of speculation leaves little to discuss in current market movement -- the more notable feature being the dull resistance which renders bear attack upon value abortive. This directs attention anew to the conditions back of the market, for it is certain that without those strong conditions dullness must have resulted in depression.

Unless the unexpected happens, one section of the rapid transit subway will be entirely finished by the end of the present year. It is No. 5B, the sub-contractors of which are Naughton Co. A division engineer of the rapid transit subway is authority for the statement that about 50 per cent, of the work on the section, which extends from Forty-seventh to Sixtieth Street, along Broadway, has been completed already.

CONCORD, N. H., Jan. 25. -- Michael J. Fanning, Superintendent of the New Hampshire Anti-Saloon League, who has been very active during the last few years in bringing about the enforcement of the prohibitory liquor laws in this State, has received a tempting offer from the National Anti-Saloon League to do three months' special work in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Judge Advocate General Lemly of the navy and E. P. Hanna, the solicitor of his office, are busily at work preparing their "comment" on Rear Admiral Schley's appeal to the President. " Comment " is the technical name for what will be a reply to the paper filed by Admiral Schley, showing why the relief sought by him should be denied.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 25. -- William Strother, the negro attendant at the Vista Turkish Bathhouse here, confessed to-day to the murder on Wednesday night in the bathhouse of Alexander Dean Cooper, the millionaire.
FEW persons realize the work that is exacted of a gymnasium instructor or physical director, as he is sometimes called.

The City Council and business men of Springfield, Mass., are trying to devise some unique way of celebrating on the 25th of May next the fiftieth anniversary of the incorporation of Springfield as a city.

Nothing of course, would have been done it Senator TELLER'S resolution concerning the case of the Boer Commandant SCHEBPERS had been pushed to a vote in the Senate. Senator TELLER introduced it in the belief that the Boer officer in question was simply under sentence of death, and withdrew it, after freeing his mind upon the subject, upon learning that the sentence had actually been executed.

The effort of this city to beautify itself and increase its lung capacity by the provision of parks as breathing places for the dwellers in crowded neighborhoods is a movement which appeals to right-minded citizens of all classes. But to be useful and attractive, parks must be something more than barren stretches of mangy grass and hot asphalt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Dec. 29 I was sorry to read an editorial expression of opinion placing Chile at fault for the questions at that time pending between her and the Argentine Republic, but now happily settled. You indicated that the trouble was due to a misconstruction by Chile of the boundary treaty of 1893.

The usual six games were rolled in the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association yesterday evening, the Johnson Johnson and the Church Dwight Company teams each winning two games. Matches were also rolled in the Bank Clerks' and Custom House Leagues. The scores:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent correspondence in your columns as to the English daisy recalls a similar discussion a few months ago in The London Athenaeum. It was stated that the "wee, modest, crimson-tippet" flowers did not flourish on American soil, whereupon a correspondent wrote to say that he had seen them growing wild somewhere in California.

If any one had a curiosity, as to what attitude the operagoing public would take toward Mr. Isidore de Lara's " Messaline," he might have learned something by going to the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The second performance of the Work was then given, and an opportunity Was afforded a matinee audience, which, as every one knows, is composed of ladies and young persons, to show how it would receive such an opera.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 25. -- Some excellent athletic work was done by the students of Williams College at the annual Winter indoor meet of the Williams College Athletic Association this afternoon. The events resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Col. Tasker Bliss, the United States Army, officer detailed as Collector of Customs at Havana, was before the Ways, and Means Committee to-day concerning Cuban reciprocity. In opening his statement he disclaimed authority as a sugar expert, and said his knowledge was confined to that of an observer for three years in an official position dealing with the trade of Cuba.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,778,665; balances, $2,465,103, On call, money rules from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent. The strongest borrower has little difficulty in supplying his wants at 3 1/2 per cent., although some of the largest banks are not quoting under 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The postal clerks of the country are again renewing the attempt which they make with every new Congress to get a bill passed which will raise their salaries automatically, year after year, until a certain maximum is reached. This bill, or something like it, has been before Congress for many years, but without success, and the outlook for it this year is no better than usual.
Miss Mary Helen Howe's concert will take place at the Waldorf-Astorla on Wednesday at 3:30. The programme:

Yale's hockey team gained a very easy victory over the seven of Brown University in an intercollegiate championship match at the St. Nicholas Rink last night. The score was 11 to 1. Yale outclassed Brown in every department of play. The "Ell" forwards were very last, and almost constantly kept the puck among themselves.

Business in the outside market yesterday was very quiet. A few stocks showed fair activity, but these were principally the issues which for some time past have been most prominent, so that the day presented practically no new features. Although in the majority of cases prices were fairly strong the day's movements showed somewhat more irregularity than on any day since the early, part of last week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Princeton won her second intercollegiate basket ball game to-day from Columbia University by a score of 44 to 12. Poor team work and inaccurate goal shooting were responsible for Columbia's defeat. On the other hand, Princeton showed a decided improvement in team play, and in nearly every try for goal was successful.

In spite of the injunction sought in Boston on Friday prohibiting the sale of the Erie Telegraph and Telephone Company to Bell Telephone Interests, stockholders of the company representing more than 96,000 shares met in this city yesterday and voted to accpet a proposition to sell the franchises and property of the company to the Occidental and Oriental Telephone and Telegraph Company for $1,594,426.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of "W. L. C.," in Saturday's TIMES, that the hours for jury trials should be from 10 to 1 and 2 to 5, and the "call" calendar to be on Saturday morning instead of Friday afternoon, is a step in the right direction.

Great in Theatre Parlanee. That one word in the vocabulary of theatre-goers which seems capable of most elasticity in application is "great" There was a time, perhaps, when its use was confined to those artists will really deserved it.
The third concert of the Mendelssohn Trio Club will take place at the Hotel Majestic on Tuesday at 3 P. M. Trios by Mozart and Jadassohn will be heard.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I venture to ask your indulgence for an opportunity to lay before your readers a reply to the questions asked by Mr. Walker D. Hines in his second communication concerning the Inter-State Commerce act and published in your issue of Jan. 16, 1902.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow, me the privilege of replying through your columns to the second communication of Mr. Hines of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, in relation to the proposed amendment of the Inter-State Commerce act, which appeared in your issue of, the 15th inst.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Wall Street's fit of the blues is something more than a fit; it is progressing toward the chronic stage, even if it may not he said to have arrived there already. It is in the dumps and refuses comfort, the latter for the plain reason that it cannot get the kind of comfort it deems essential for its health.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- There has been a good deal of talk this session about the Weekes common marriage law, which was passed at the last legislative session. In the early days of this year's session some of the Senators and Assemblymen were in favor of amending it, but they have now given up that notion in deference to the plea of Mr. Weekes that the law should be given a fair trial.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- There was considerable talk about the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in St. Louis in the House last week, and after credit had several times been given to Jefferson for the purchase, Representative Alexander of New York became restive. Presently he got up and in a vehement speech declared that history as made in Congress and elsewhere was wrong in giving the credit of the purchase to a Virginian.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Senate will devote its attention this week principally to the Philippine Tariff bill. It is the purpose of Senator Lodge, (Rep., Mass.,) who is in charge of the measure, to press its consideration until it is disposed of, but he does not expect final action for some time.

Although a number of arrests were made yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx for violations of the excise law, thirsty men had no trouble in getting drinks on the east side or the west side, from the Battery to the point where the Bronx merges into Westchester. Even the frayed and ancient Raines law sandwich was little in evidence.

The Socialists were handled without gloves at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union for their attacks on labor leaders and the arbitration plans of the National Civic Federation at the anti-industrial peace conference at 64 East Fourth Street last week.

Acting Capt. Joseph Cobb of the Eightieth Precinct, West Brighton, with a Sergeant, a Roundsman, and a patrolman, raided a dog fight late on Saturday night, and captured twenty-two men, one dog, and the pit. There were about a hundred men in the room when the police entered, and most of them got away by dropping from the rear windows to an extension, and thence to the ground.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- William H. Taft, civil Governor of the Philippine Islands, arrived in Chicago this afternoon from San Francisco. He was met at the station by President S.M. Felton or the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company and went at once to the latter's residence, where he spent the day.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The Vossische Zeitung, in an article quoted by the Berlin correspondent of The Times, referring to the North German Gazette's announcement of the visit of the Prince of Wales to Berlin, says it is evidently an inspired utterance. The article holds, says the Vossische Zeitung, a mid-course between enthusiasm and indifference.

The Slater bill, now before the Legislature, is admittedly an effort on the part of the representatives of labor to correct a grievance which the workingmen have against the law as it stands, as interpreted by the Court of Appeals in its enunciation of the doctrine of "assumed risk."

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- In order to stamp out smallpox, which is semi-epidemic here, the Board of Health started compulsory vaccination to-day. The work was begun in East Boston, where 125 surgeons, each accompanied by a policeman, made a house-to-house canvass, vaccinating all who had not been recently inoculated.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- When the Legislature meets to-morrow the Senate and Assembly will be ready for the first time this session to begin a solid week's work. Up to now only minor propositions have been dealt with, but the calendars of both chambers, as well as the books of the various committees, show that the close of the first month of the session will be a busy one.

Prof. George F. Canfield, President of the State Charities Aid Association, yesterday made the following statement concerning the amendments to the bill relating to the State Hospitals for the Insane.

-- There is many a slip between the signing of such a treaty as that for the transfer of the Danish Islands and the final ratification of it, but the present indications that St. Thomas, St. Croix, and St. John will soon fly the American flag are certainly strong enough to warrant discussion as to what benefits we are to derive from their possession other than those connected with the Harbor of Charlotte Amalia.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- The Boerse during the past week was characterized by great strength in all Government funds and fixed interest bearers. The tendency in industrials was mixed, irons remaining strong, while coal shares and most of the other industrials lost several points. Coal shares were depressed by the continued warm weather and the difficulty of disposing of the output.

The Merchants' Association has sent out thousands of circulars to merchants throughout the State, in opposition to the bill of Assemblyman Moran of Seneca County, now before the Legislature, providing for reduction of the legal interest rate to 5 per cent. The circular declares that the business machinery of this State is threatened with destruction by the attempt to limit the rate arbitrarily to 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- "The Progress of the United States in Its Material Industries" is the title of a monograph issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, which contains a series of statements which show the rapid development during the last century of the important factors in the present prosperity of the country.
DJUMALA, Turkey, Jan. 20. -- Miss Stone, the captive American missionary, and her companion, Mme. Tslika, have been located near Yapyak, in the vicinity of the frontier.

MANCHESTER, Jan. 26. -- Business on the cloth market during the past week was poor, but grew firmer toward the close of the week, in sympathy with the improved tone of the New York market, although the active volume of business done was not marked by an increase and cloth sellers found it dificult to secure business.

LAKE GENEVA, Wis., Jan. 26. -- John E. Burton of this village has shipped his entire library of 12,000 volumes to New York, where it will be sold at auction. This library is the largest private collection of books in the Northwest.

Mr. CARNEGIE has made another graceful gift in memory of PETER COOPER to the admirable charity which the latter founded. His donation is now $600,000, and makes it possible for Mr. HEWITT and his daughters to carry out their plans for the improvement of the schools of the Cooper Union in many ways.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the election of John F. Dryden to the United States Senate, New Jersey for several years will enjoy the distinction of being represented in the Senate by two no-bodies from the standpoint of statesman-ship.

Abram S. Hewitt, Secretary of Cooper Union, announces that the descendants of Peter Cooper -- ex-Mayor Edward S. Cooper, his sister Miss Sarah Amelia Cooper, and ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt and family -- have given to Cooper Union $300,000, being a sum equal to that given by Andrew Carnegie last week.

There was gloom and dejection in the Gates Avenue Police Station last night. Jacko, the pet monkey, had died suddenly. Sad to relate, he had drank himself to death. Jacko was the property of Sergt. O'Reilly. He joined the department about a year ago, and was one of the best-known members of the police force in Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 26. -- The National Liberal Party was organized here to-day by representatives from all parts of the country. The preamble declares for the separation of Church and State to the extent of abolishing Chaplains in the army and navy, legislative bodies, and all public institutions; the taxation of Church property, and the abandonment of Sunday observances.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Cabling from Vienna, a correspondent of The Daily Chronicle says that the newspapers of Athens report that the celebrated Saint Paul Monastery, on Mount Athos, was partially burned last Thursday night, and that the Prior and nine monks perished, while twenty others were seriously injured.

A mass meeting of Methodist Sunday school scholars was held at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon in the interests of the Twentieth Century Thank Offering Fund. It was one of the largest demonstrations of its kind seen in the city for a number of years. Applications for over seven thousand tickets were received by the committee and a large number of them could not be granted.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26. -- Mayor Hayes will clash with the Gorman managers at Annapolis this week, it is predicted. The managers of the regular party organization are bent on revenge for the Mayor's coldness toward the Gorman campaign last Fall and there has been talk of curtailing some of his powers under the new city charter and of cutting short his term of office.

The annual meeting of Mount Sinai Hospital, the last to take place in the present quarters of the institution, was held yesterday morning in the Dispensary Building, at 149 East Sixty-seventh Street. The hospital is soon to be moved to its newer and much more spacious group of buildings, at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and First Street.

Rabbi Emit G. Hirsch of Mount Sinal Temple, in Chicago, preached yesterday to congregation that occupied every seat am crowded the aisles of Temple Beth-El, at Seventy-sixth Street and Fifth Avenue. The subject of his address was, "Is Judaism a Memory or a Message?"

PHILADELPHIA. Jan. 26. -- Samuel Rea, Fourth Vice President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, who will have direct executive charge of the construction of the road's tunnels under the North and East Rivers and Manhattan Island, discussed today the reports that the company would be forced to pay exorbitant prices for terminal property in New York because speculators had obtained possession of much of the needed land.

Senator FRYE'S revised and amended ship subsidy scheme still fails to convince those best informed regarding the interests of American commerce that it is intended in good faith to encourage American shipbuilding.

OGDEN, Utah, Jan. 26. -- Mayor William Glasmann is preparing to turn the firemen of Ogden into truck gardeners as soon as the Spring season opens. The Mayor is of the opinion that the firemen might just as well put in their time to good advantage while they are waiting for some conflagration to demand their attention, and he has formulated this plan to keep them from idleness.

The Harlem Navy Bowling League, which proved a great success last season, has been reorganized, with fifteen boat clubs on the roll. Only twelve clubs were in the league last year and nine the year previous. Robert J. Maher of the Wyanoke Boat Club has been re-elected President and the tournament will begin on Monday evening, Feb. 3, and end Monday evening, March 24.

AN ECHO OF THE DREYFUS CASE. -- The decision of the French Government to postpone the consideration of the long-pending petition of Joseph Reinach for rein-statement as an officer in the French territorial army, or militia, until after the May elections shows how anxious the WaldeckRousseau Ministry is to prevent political capital from being made out of the Dreyfus case at the present time.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- A member of the University of Pennsylvania's Baseball Committee is authority for the statement that Pennsylvania's baseball schedule has been completed, and that there is no Yale date on it. The schedule has been sent to the Faculty Committee for approval, and will be taken up and, it is expected, approved at the next meeting of the committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The St. Louis American League baseball franchise was sold to-day by "Matt" and Henry Killilea or Milwaukee to R.L. Hedges, who represents a number of St. Louis capitalists. The price paid was not made public. The new owners of the club will hold a meeting in St. Louis Wednesday to form a permanent organization and elect officers.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- The Prince of Wales, who is to represent King Edward at the celebration of the birthday of Emperor William to-morrow, visited the Prussian Princes, Count von Bulow, (the Imperial Chancellor,) the various Ambassadors, and other distinguished personages this morning.

Wall Street will watch with much interest the developments at Washington to-day in connection with the litigation growing out of the formation of the Northern Securities Company. The Supreme Court will hear arguments as to the question of the court's jurisdiction in the premises, and, while no decision is expected for a week at least, the arguments will nevertheless engage not a little attention.

Additional prizes continue to be offered for different classes in the coming dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club. The prize list as published last week was larger than ever before in the history of the Westminster's bench shows, and competition for them promises to be fully up to the standard of the prize list.

-- Much as we regret to revive a controversy which on innumerable occasions has led to an enormous waste of paper, ink, and postage stamps -- and to no other results -- stern duty compels us to condemn the Secretary of State for misspelling, or allowing to be misspelled, the word "honor" on the invitations to his daughter's wedding which he has just sent out.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Money was in good demand to-day, and the supplies were considerably reduced, chiefly due to revenue collection. Discounts were sympathetically firm. Business on the Stock Exchange was not brisk, but the tendency was good. Attention centred in the mining settlement, which was described as the most exciting experience in years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial on Messrs. HORGAN and SLATTERY in this morning's issue, is it not rather bad taste to gloat over the defeat of those who for the time being may have lost in the battle of life? Is not your editorial inspired by the fact that their names happen to be HORGAN and SLATTERY?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Attorney General Douglass of Minnesota to-day made his argument in the United States Supreme Court for leave to file the bill of complaint of the State against the Northern Securities Company in the matter of the merger of the Northern Pacific with other railroads.

A conference to consider means for the redemption of the City of New York, called by the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations, was opened yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, open sessions being held in the morning, the afternoon, and the evening.

Dynamite cartridges in a frail shanty on a platform over the west shaft of Section 4 of the subway tunnel in Park Avenue just south of Forty-first Street exploded through a fire which started among paper in the shanty just after noon yesterday with fatal, maiming, and injuring results and wide destruction of property.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- On the resumption to-day in the Bankruptcy Court of the inquiry into the affairs of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, the official Receiver read a letter from the Marquis of Dufferin denying that he had been a party to Whitaker Wright's speculations, which resulted in losses amounting to L1,700,000.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- Emperor William, who was Born on Jan. 27, 1859, signalized his birthday to-day by conferring territorial titles on all the regiments which have hitherto borne no distinctive names. In an army order on the subject His Majesty says:

Undoubtedly it would "encourage the others," could a prominent officer of the New York Central Railroad be imprisoned, if found guilty of criminal conduct in the management of the road. It would thereafter be more difficult to secure a man for the place the prisoner had occupied who would take the risks attaching to it.

The Executive Committee of the Society for the Prevention of Crime met in their rooms in the United Charities Building yesterday to take action on Mayor Low's reply to the society's letter to the Mayor relative to the enforcement of the excise laws. A letter, of which the following is a copy, was prepared and sent to Mr. Low by special messenger:

The strong common sense and sound judgment that characterized the remarks of the Mayor to the Citizens' Committee on Excise yesterday will secure for the plan of liquor law reform which he suggests the candid consideration of all reasonable men in this community and the approval of a great part of them, we think.

Yesterday's trading in the outside market resulted in relatively few changes of any importance. Within a narrow range prices showed considerable irregularity, a number of stocks closing fractionally better, while elsewhere in the list declines were noted at the close. Not a single one of the stocks most active recently showed a total as large as the average of last week, and none of the less prominent issues attracted very much attention.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 27 -- The case of John C. Gray vs. J.S. Tracey, in which the plaintiff, a professor in the Harvard Law School, had previously obtained a preliminary injunction against the defendant selling without his permission typewritten copies of notes on his lectures, came up to-day before Justice Braley in the Equity Session of the Superior Court, and was disposed of by a decree continuing the injunction.
There are reports in local fire insurance circles of two more reinsurance deals now pending, but the officers of the companies in question deny that there is any substantial basis for the reports.

While the stock market halts and is irregular, doing little to encourage traders upon either side, evidences accumulate of plans under way whose accomplishment will mean much that is good. Though on the surface it may be politic for yet a further time to disguise the fact, there has none the less come into the Western railway situation a material improvement.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- The Conservative journals here have been singularly silent in regard to the approaching visit of Prince Henry of Prussia to America, which the old aristocracy looks upon coldly. These newspapers do not see how any special German object can be served by the visit, and fear in some vague way that a warm friendship between the United States and Germany will render more difficult the passage of the German Tariff bill.

The Sunday opening question was the topic of discussion at the Methodist Preach- ers' meeting at 150 Fifth Avenue yesterday. The Rev. R.S. Pardington presided. The Rev. Thomas L. Poulton of Lawrence, R. I., during the reading of a paper on "The Duty of Christians and Citizens Toward the Sabbath and the Ballot," said, referring to the recent utterances of Bishop Potter and the Rev. Dr. Rainsford:

BRANCHVILLE, S.C., Jan. 27 -- A carefully planned and audacious express robbery took place about 7 o'clock this evening on the Southern Railway, when the passenger train from Charleston reached nearly the exact site of the successful robbery of two years ago, five miles from Branchville.

Troop 2 of Squadron A won the annual five-man carbine shooting match last Saturday night for the third year. The contest was held in the armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street, and the winners led the headquarters contingent by ten points, and Troop 3 was a close third. The best individual shooting, however, was done by Private Geer of Troop 3, who scored 63.

The facts recited in our news columns this morning as to the immediate circumstances attending the terrible explosion in the subway are plainly such as make necessary a searching investigation. This there is no reason to doubt the proper authorities will undertake and conduct with entire impartiality.

For the first day of the week yesterday was only moderately gay. It was the first time since the season began that the week has not opened with a large ball or entertainment. The dance for Miss Winters was the only event of the kind. There was the musical morning at the Waldorf-Astoria and a number of minor events.

At the annual meeting of the Board of pity Magistrates held last night President Deuel read a report prepared by him of the work of the courts for the past year. In the course of his report he has this to say of the enforcement of the excise law:

ALBANY Jan. 27 -- The Judiciary Committee of the Senate met this evening and decided to report favorably the State Commission in Lunacy bill as amended by the Assembly Judiciary Committee. The vote in the committee stood 7 to 5. Those voting in favor of reporting the bill favorably were: Senators Brackett, Krum, Davis, Mills, Thoraton, Ellsworth, and McKinney.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Another splendid billiard run was made last night by W.H. Sigourney, the San Francisco expert, in a game with M.D. Brown at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. The contenst was played at the 14.2 game, and Sigourney allowed his opponent 200 points in a 400-point game. When Sigourney began his twenty-sixth inning Mr. Brown needed but 14 points to complete his string, while Sigourney, with 106 to go, seemed to be beaten.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Discussion of the Government's policy in the Philippines and a sharp argument on that question occupied much of the time of the Senate today. The subject was introduced by Senator Lodge, Chairman of the Philippine Committee, who reported favorably a resolution authorizing that committee, to make an investigation of the Philippine question, and for that purpose to sit during the sessions of the Senate.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 -- All pits on the Board of Trade went wild to-day. A stampede in May oats forcing liquidations in all markets pressed prices downward in a panicky fashion, and within half an hour from the opening May oats had dropped 5 1/8, May wheat 1 3/8, and May corn 1 3/4. Provisions also were sore hit.

Here are the dearest little things in the way of ferns ever seen, tiny plants in small flower pots, and they cost only 10 cents each. The plants must be kept in a saucer in which there is a little water, and one man who has kept one of them for a month says it is still in good condition.
CASINO -- Anna Held began the last week but one with " The Little Duchess."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Carmack to-day submitted a minority report from the Committee on Philippines on the Philippine Tariff bill. It says that opposition to the measure is not based on any mere question of revenue or any theory concerning forms and principles of taxation, but because the bill violates constitutional rights and transcends the limits of constitutional power.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- C.W. Jacobs, an English engineer, who is consulting engineer for the Carnegie Company and for the American Bridge Company, sailed from Liverpool for New York on Jan. 22 on the White Star liner Oceanic in order to take charge of the construction of the Pennsylvania Railroad's tunnel.

In the Spring of 1900, near the end of the regular season of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House, Mr. Grau brought forward Mozart's "H. Flauto Magico" and gave five performances of it in rapid succession. Previous to that the work had been once given for a charity in 1897, and before that it had been heard since 1897.

The trial of Albert T. Patrick for the murder of Millionaire Rice, yesterday developed some surprising features. The first of these to be made apparent was the fact that the defense intends to insist that Mr. Rice died a natural death. Until yesterday there had been no evidence introduced tending to show what caused the death of Mr. Rice.

Mayor Low announed fully yesterday his views on the excise questions. A committee of the Citizens' Excise Committee, consisting of the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, Willis L. Ogden, Wheeler H. Peckham, and Wiliiam R. Corwine, called at the Mayor's office and presented to him a letter announc- ing the results of the conferences held of late on the excise problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Senator Morgan was overruled in the meeting to-day of the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals. The committee refused to order a report favorable to the Nicaragua route for the Isthmian canal and decided it would investigate thoroughly the Panama route before it would make any recommendations with respect to the construction of the canal.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Chairman Brackett of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate to-day introduced a bill empowering the State Board of Railroad Commissioners in its discretion to set a date when the New York Central Railroad Company shall substitute electricity for steam in the Park Avenue tunnel.

There was a wild scene in the Coroners' Court yesterday afternoon, when the war between the District Attorney and the Coroners reached open hostilities, where hard blows were struck and around the witness box men fought, swore, and yelled in a confused mass, and every one seemed to have forgotten that he was in a courtroom.

The annual meeting of the Westchester Golf Club will not be held in the Murray Hill Hotel, as had been expected; but the meeting will probably be held to-night if news can be sent to the members in time. Secretary Redfield said yesterday that he hoped a convenient place would be obtained, but it was impossible to send out notices of a definite meeting place yesterday.

The New York Realty Corporation has bought from M. Orme Wilson and the United States Trust Company, as trustees, the Wilson residence, 414 Fifth Avenue, together with the three four-story dwellings 8,10, and 12 West Thirty-eighth Street. These parcels form an "L," the Filth Avenut part being 32.6 by 145, and that fronting on Thirty-eighth Street 50 by 98.0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Miss Alice Roosevelt was the guest of honor at a luncheon given to-day by Mrs. Joy, wife of Congressman Joy of Missouri. The guests were Mrs. Payne. Mrs. Dalzell, Mrs. Steele, Mrs. William Alden Smith, Mrs. Grosvenor, Mrs. Hepburn, Mrs. Littlefield, Mrs. Sibley, Mrs. Bonnell, Mrs. Morris, Mrs. Hopkins, Mrs. Foster, Mrs. Montell, Mrs. McCall, Miss Cannon, Miss Quay, Miss Morris, Miss Fletcher, and Miss Corlis.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27 -- The advance in Cotton Duck incomes and 5 per cent, bonds reflected the favorable impression created by the proposed reduction of the capital stock of the United States Cotton Duck Company from $50,000,000 to $20,000,000. United States Fidelity was better by reason of the good, reports concerning the company's business.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Gov. Odell received to-day a transcript of the evidence in the case of Sheriff Charles Guden of Kings County, charged with entering into an agreement prior to the election to turn over to Col. Michael J. Dady all of the earnings of his office in excess of his salary of $12,000.
In accordance with the terms of the previous announcement, the three stories from the "Man in the Street" department of THE TIMES'S Sunday Magazine of Jan. 26 are here republished:

BOSTON, Jan. 27 -- Money loaned, at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par and 5 cents discount. Exchanges, $22,991,945; balances, $2,110,874. On call money rules largely from 3 1/2 to 4 per-cent. Loans are reported as low as 3 per cent, though such loans are not a fair measure of market conditions.

A three-cornered women's team match between the women's, golf associations of Philadelphia, Boston, and this city, will probably be one of the new features of the coming golf season. This possibility formed the most important matter of business for discussion yesterday at the annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, which was held at the home of the Secretary, Miss Ruth Underhill, 6 East Ninth Street.

Counsel representing forty-seven corporations affected by the special franchise tax imposed in Chapter 712 of the Laws of 1899 have during the last two weeks appeared before Judge EARL, the referee appointed by the Supreme Court at Albany, to present arguments against the assessment and collection of the tax.

MANILA, Jan. 28. -- Gen. Chaffee curtailed his trip and returned here this morning. He says he found the conditions apparently satisfactory everywhere, except at Samar, where continuous rain in the past two months, has retarded the campaign, especially against such an elusive enemy.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday was served with a summons to appear before Magistrate Brann to-day at 10 o'clock, in the Centre Street Police Court, to answer to the charges of assault brought against him by Coroner's Clerk John Murray. A meeting of the Coroners was also held, at which the tumultuous proceedings of Monday were reviewed, and it was finally decided that the District Attorney should still be admitted, though his actions were deprecated.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- "Send to Flanagan, at Canandaigua, and buy oysters for $1 per gallon."
Abram S. Hewitt last night made public the following letter sent by him yesterday to Gov. Odell relative to the proposed State Charities legislation:

Moses Epps, the colored man who had charge of the cartridges in the powder house over the west shaft of Section 4 of the subway tunnel, when the fatal and disastrous explosion occurred on Monday, is likely to figure prominently in investigations and lawsuits which will result from it.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- Archie McEachern, the Canadian cyclist, added another victory to his record in this city by defeating Bennie Monroe of Memphis and Otto Maya of Erie, Penn., in a fifteen-mile motor-paced bicycle race at the Second Regiment Armory to-night. His victory was a hollow one in that his competitors met accidents which compelled them to leave the track.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- For several hours this afternoon the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment deliberated on the two principal tax measures now pending the Legislature, the Krum bill, taxing foreign corporations, and the Stranahan mortgage tax bill. The Krum bill was amended in so many important particulars that little remains of the original measure.

John Huggins, trainer for William C. Whitney, received a cablegram from Newmarket, England, yesterday, afternoon which brought, the unwelcome intelligence that Mr. Whitney's Derby candidate Nasturtium had had a chill and that with the chill had quite a temperature, which is supposed to mean that the temperature of the famous two-year-old is much above the normal.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- The two houses of the Legislature met separately at noon to-day and voted on the United States Senatorship. The name of John F. Dryden of Newark, the Republican caueus nominee, was presented in the Senate by Senator McCarter, and in the House by Mr. Bacheller.
Peter J. Mettler has been appointed Toledo agent of the Commonwealth Insurance Company.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 28. -- M. Santos-Dumont made a trial ascent in his airship this morning. Everything worked smoothly. The vessel readily answered her helm in the light breeze prevailing. After a tour of the harbor M. Santos-Dumont steered his craft back to her shed, amid the cheers of the assembled crowds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- It is said at the War Department that if Gen. Wheaton said nothing worse than he is reported to have said there is no danger of his being, reprimanded. It is admitted that he made some sharp criticisms on Dr. Schurman, according to the newspapers' reports. But the War Department fails to find any evidence that he made any reflections upon the Senate or its members.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The annual Winter carnival and race meet opened here to-day, with a good attendance. The trotting races on the ice, though won in straight heats, were well contested. Summary:

Edward F. McSweency, Assistant Commisisoner of Immigration, presided at the morning session of the conference of the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations, which was resumed yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle, at Thirty-fourth Street and Sixth Avenue, and the forenoon was devoted to a consideration of methods of dealing with the immense foreign population of New York City.

The movement now making by a number of shippers and shippers organizations to "strengthen" the Inter-State Commerce Commission by an increase of its powers and more direct enforcement of them has undoubtedly, a purpose with which all business men can agree. It is not denied by any one familiar with the transportation situation that there are evils connected with it.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- The Government of the Netherlands has offered in the most frienaiy terms to help in bringing about peace in South Africa. In a communication to the British Government, the Dutch Government suggests that it be permitted to act as a sort of diplomatic agent for the Boer delegates, but expressly disavows any attempt at intervention, and does not mention, any terms.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 28. -- Yale mid-Winter athletics are now begun in earnest, and the gymnasium is daily filled with the hundreds of candidates for the various Varsity teams. Capt. Hargrave opened the track team season this week, the crews are now well started, and baseball will begin immediately. With the hockey and basket ball teams in the midst of their championship series.

One thing may very safely be said of the war in South Africa, and that is that both parties to it are very heartily sick of it. The Boers, in fact, must be very close to the point of exhauation. And, while Great Britain could keep it up indefinitely at the present rate of expenditure of men and money and of progress, Englishmen must be very ready to make peace on reasonable terms.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- The New Orleans Railway Company, capital $5,000,000, to operate and construct street railways, was incorporated here to-day. Incorporators: Walter R.H. Hardingham, Charles F. Gehrman, Malcolm N. Butler, and Henry B. Pogfon, all of Jersey City.

The prosecution, in the trial of Albert T. Patrick for the murder of Millionaire Rice put one of its most important witnesses on the stand yesterday in the person of Capt. James A. Baker of Houston, Texas. For hours the jurymen, the prisoner, and the spectators listened with breathless attention as he related his conversations with Patrick immediately following the murder.
Nero, for many years the police dog of the Tenderloin Station, lost his life yesterday afternoon while attempting to save that of a little girl. Rena Savoretti, of 1-9 West Thirtieth Street.

LONDON, Jan. 28 -- The revenue collections to-day denuded the market of supplies of money, the Government disbursements were small, and the Bank of England was apparently borrowing. These conditions, with the state of foreign exchange, strengthened discounts, in spite of the Continental inquiry for bills.

Devastation and ruin on every hand marked the scene at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street yesterday morning as the result of the explosion of dynamite in the rapid transit tunnel the day before. Looking southward down Park Avenue from the Grand Central Station, it appeared as if an earthquake or a terrible hurricane had struck the city and laid it waste.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment today gave a hearing upon the bill introduced by Assemblyman Fitzgerald taxing membership or seats in any stock or mercantile exchange. President Rudolph Keppler of the Now York Stock Exchange and Lewis Cass Ledyard appeared in opposition to the bill.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The Union Terminal Company of New York was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day with a capital of $100,000, to construct and operate an electrical tunnel road between nine and ten miles long between New York and Kings Counties.

PEKING, Jan. 28. -- The Dowager Empress made her formal debut before the foreign Ministers to-day at the diplomatic reception. She occupied the throne in the main audience chamber, while the Emperor sat behind a table on a low dias before the throne. The fiction of recognizing the Emperor as the Sovereign was maintained, but the Dowager Empress was the personage of chief interest and importance.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 28. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5 and 10 cents' discount. Exchanges, $23,703,613; balances, $2,658,534; on call, money is more freely offered at 3 3/4 per cent. Some National banks as well as some trust companies are not yet quoting under 4 per cent.

If to look always picturesque and sometimes rarely beautiful is enough for an actress, and if the sight of that loveliness in the chief performer is enough to make a play, then were Mrs. Patrick Campbell and "Felleas and Melisande" combined one of the most successful performances known to boards.
WINDSOR, Jan. 28. -- Queen Alexandra is again slightly indisposed, owing to a co: which has caused the postponement of King Edward's return to London.

Brig. Gen. McCoskry Butt called up THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday afternoon from the New York Yacht Club, and, after saying that he had some opinions to express regarding Police Commissioner Partridge on which he asked to be quoted, declared with some excitement:

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The ninety-sixth annual convention of the New York State Medical Society opened in this city today. Dr. H.L. Elsner of Syracuse, President of the association, in an address, recommended that the President be empowered to appoint a committee of five to confer with a similar committee representing the State Medical Association, witn a view of bringing the two organizations together.

Activity and strength both increased in yesterday's stock market. The day's transactions mounted beyond 580,000 shares, and practically every important stock on the list advanced, some of them substantially.

Two matches in the New York Interclub Bowling League were decided last night, the New York Athletic Club bowlers winning three games from the Catholic Club team and the Harlem Wheelmen winning two of three games with the Harlem Republican Club. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The patient work of Senator Nelson of Minnesota in support of his bill to establish a Department of Commerce came to a successful issue in the Senate to-day. The bill passed without a disserting vote and without an important amendment. Three of the bureaus which, the original bill contemplated taking into the department are to stay where they now are.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 28. -- The strength of the Cotton Duck issues to-day was a primary influence in infusing strength into the whole local list. So general was the improvement that the record closed without a single decline being scored against it. The whole Cotton, Duck group was higher.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The programme for the reception and entertainment of Prince Henry of Prussia here and in New York was finally completed to-day. The arrangements now agreed upon differ somewhat from those previously tentatively made, and permit the Prince and his party to spend more time in New York City.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mort- gage and "P.S." for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,000 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $.500 of consideration over $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The White House was the scene of another large private entertainment this evening. The President and Mrs. Roosevelt entertained at a musicale, preceded by a dinner party for young people. The only married people invited were Mr. and Mrs. George C. Lee, Jr., of Boston, cousins of Miss Roosevelt.

The dinner dance given by James Stillman for Miss Ethel Rockefeller was a notable event of yesterday. Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave a large dinner. A number of New Yorkers were in Boston to attend the wedding of Miss Marjorle Robbing and Albert J. Milbank. Among these were Mr. and Mrs. Henry Asher Robblns, Mrs. Harry McVickar, and Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Bliss, and Miss Bliss.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Senator Spooner (Rep., Wis.,) entered the field to-day in support of the Philippine Tariff bill against such of the minority as might choose to accept his challenge. Messrs. Clay of Georgia, Rawlins of Utah. Teller of Colorado, and Tillman of South Carolina took up the gage on the floor of the Senate, and a lively tilt of two hours resulted.
ROME, Jan. 29. -- Cardinal Lucido Maria Parocchi, Bishop of Porto and Santa Rufina, who has been dangerously ill for some weeks, is dying.
Randolph Guggenheimer and Isaac Untermyer have sold to Bernhard Levin Co. the six-story apartment house at the southWest corner of Columbus Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, 50.8 1/2 by 100.

With such fierceness did a fire rage in the two upper floors of the seven-story brick building at the southwest corner of Bleecker and Mott Streets last night that four alarms were turned in and a small army of firemen tested to their utmost for more than two hours before they got the blaze under control.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Sheriff Guden of Kings County must stand trial before Gov. Odell. The Governor to-day served notice upon Guden that he appear in Albany next Tuesday for a hearing of the charges against him. The official notice sent by the Governor to Guden was as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The Brackett bill, to regulate the practice of osteopathy, is dead. Its fate was decided at the hearing this afternoon before the joint Committee on Judiciary. At the executive session of the committee, held directly afterward, the measure was dropped. The sentiment was practically unanimous against the measure and it was buried beneath an avalanche of protest.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29. -- This afternoon Judge Wood issued a bench warrant for the arrest of Ellis Wainwright, President of the St. Louis Brewing Company and Director of the St. Louis and Suburban Company. A Deputy Sheriff who took the warrant for service returned to the office of the Circuit Attorney stating that the arrest could not be made because Mr. Wainwright was in New York, where he makes his home.

The State Railroad Commission at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday continued the investigation of the Park Avenue tunnel disaster and some interesting evidence was taken. Much of it tended to show that the use of electricity is feasible in the tunnel and the obscurity there, in the main, is caused by steam and not by smoke.

Yesterday's Stock Exchange transactions passed the 600,000 share mark, and again Copper Trust was far and away the most active of the issues, approximately 120,000 shares (one-fifth of the day's total transactions) being quoted. Further advance in the price of the trust's product was reported, but the stock fell a couple of points.

This is moving day for "Collier's Weekly," And more. It is a day of extension, of spreading put. The plant of P.F. Collier Son was long ago outgrown. In the old building, its ground floor covering twenty-six building lots, there was not enough room. So a new structure covering fourteen building lots was built to order.

The inevitable has happened, and though not yet announced by the manager, it is a fact that Charles Frohman has secured a dramatization of "Tom Sawyer." The play has been made from Mr. Clemens's book by Paul Kester, the American dramatist, who wrote "Mlle. Mars," which Mrs. Langtry produced at the Imperial Theatre, London, last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) insisted that consideration of the Philippine measure should continue in the Senate to-day. He refused to yield the floor to Mr. Bacon, (Dem., Ga.,) who wanted to join in a Revolutionary War discussion begun by Messrs. Hoar (Rep., Mass.,) and Money (Dem., Miss.) Mr. Lodge's action irritated Mr. Tillman, (Dem., S.C.,) who said:

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Dispatches from Vienna report that in a duel fought at Cattaro, Dalmatia, between the hereditary Prince of Montenegro, Danilo-Alexander, and his brother, Prince Mirko, because Prince Mirko ridiculed the wife of Prince Danilo-Alexander, the latter was slightly wounded, but has since gone with his wife to visit the Italian Court.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 29. -- Henry C. Spinks of Newport, Ky., to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court a bill charging the officers of the Asphalt Company of America and of the National Asphalt Company with fraud and collusion in having those companies declared insolvent and placed in receivers' hands.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 29. -- Alfred Hennen Morris denied to-day the statement that has been published that the Morris Park track, at Westchester, N.Y., would be cut up and sold. Mr. Morris said another lease for two years has been arranged with the Westchester Racing Association.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29. -- The strength of Cotton Duck incomes and of Third National Bank was the most notable feature in today's trading. Opinion on the Cotton Duck income bonds has shifted from the bear side and is now running as strongly in favor of the securities that all purchases are likely to produce better prices.

Frank Moss, the Rev. Dr. Charles Cuthbert Hall, and the Rev. Dr. Thomas R. Slicer were the principal speakers at yesterday's session of the conference of the Federation of Churches and Christian Organizations which is being held in the Broadway Tabernacle at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- Count von Pasadowsky-Wehner, Imperial Secretary of State for the Interior, speaking to-day before the Tariff Committee on behalf of the Government, said that if the members of the committee forced into the Tariff bill amendments designed to provoke retaliation abroad the bill would be rejected, as the Government could not support it.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 29. -- Mayor Hayes to day received a telegram from President George F. Baer of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway, stating that none of the syndicates offering to buy the Western Maryland Railroad is acting in the interests of the Reading Company or the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Board of Trustees of the Carnegie Institution met to-day in Secretary Hay's office, received Mr. Carnegie's deed of gift, and elected officers. Dr. Daniel C. Gilman of Baltimore was chosen President and Abram S. Hewitt of New York Chairman of the Board of Trustees.

BUFFALO, Jan. 29. -- The anniversary of the birthday of William McKinley was celebrated here to-day. Exercises were held in all of the public schools. At noon the Rev. Charles Edward Locke made an address at the Merchants' Exchange.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29. -- Tony Licalzi more than won the price he paid for the filly Wilton to-day. Recently he bought her from Felix Carr, representing Barney Schreiber, for $800, and this afternoon she landed the Orleans Railroad Company Stake at three furlongs and worth $965 to the winner by a nose in a driving finish.
The dispatch from Peking to The London Times which we printed on Monday gives an additional interest to some disclosures made in that journal on Jan. 3.

The modern and enlightened spirit which characterizes the management of the United States Steel Corporation is nowhere better exhibited than in this passage from the preliminary report to the stockholders issued yesterday in advance of the annual meeting on Feb. 17:
