There were only two witnesses in the Patrick trial yesterday, but their testimony was so interesting as to keep the courtroom crowded up to a late hour with spectators, eagerly listening to every word bearing upon the guilt or innocence of the prisoner, on the charge of conspiring to murder Millionaire William M. Rice.

The four-story building at the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, 60 by 115, has been sold by Alfred D. Pell to the Alliance Realty Company. The property will probably be resold By the flatter corporation to a builder, although negotiations to that end are not yet sufficiently advanced to admit of any announcement.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- In the absence of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, who is in New York City, President Pro Tem. Ellsworth presided at this morning's session of the Senate. The Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment reported favorably the Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill and the Foreign Corporation Tax bill with the amendments outlined in the dispatches published this morning.

A rather remarkable story of domestic complications was told before Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, when Mrs. Clara Peart Bruce, through her lawyer. David May, applied for permanent alimony from her husband, Thomas Bruce, a mineralogist and mining expert of this city.

ROME, Jan. 29. -- The eightieth birthday of the Marchesa Del Grille (Adelaide Ristori) was made the occasion for many celebrations to-day. King Victor Emmanuel, accompanied by a large suite, visited and felicitated the actress, who held a kind of court, the Mayors and other dignitaries of a number of towns paying their respects to her.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- Assemblyman Bennet introduced to-day an excise bill which was drawn by the New York Anti-Saloon League. The measure proposes to abolish the Raines law hotels and provides for local option on the question of license or no license for election districts in cities and for cities as a whole.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- The Senate Committee on Codes to-day favorably reported the Automobile bill introduced by Senator Cocks. The bill was amended so as to make the speed limit of automobiles on highways twenty miles an hour, eight miles an hour in cities, and four miles an hour over bridges and viaducts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- There seems to be no hope that the Ways and Means Committee will report a bill to grant tariff concessions to the Cubans. The committee has ceased to be sphinx-like, and it has come to be understood that its present attitude is strongly against favorable action on the Administration's appeal in Cuba's behalf.

The American Advertisers' Association held their first annual banquet last night in Delmonlco's. Prominent among the 125 advertisers and publishers who sat down to dinner were Robert C. Ogden, lucien C. Warner, Edward P. Call, C.W. Post, Artemas Ward, E.C. DeWitt, Charles T. Root, "Walter H. Page, and George P. Rowell.

Yale's 'Varsity hockey team defeated the seven composed of Yale graduates in an exhibition game at the St. Nicholas Rink last night. The score was, after two desperate halves, 4 to 3. Considering the fact that the game was a friendly one, it was highly exciting and at times exceedingly rough, both teams tripping and body checking to a great extent.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- Former Village President Caleb W. Mitchell committed suicide by shooting himself here to-day. Before killing himself Mitchell called at the office of State Senator Edgar Brackett, who happened to be out. He seemed disappointed at not finding Senator Brackett, and showed great excitement.

The preliminary report to stockholders of the United States Steel Corporation to be submitted at the first annual meeting on Feb. 17 next, was made public yesterday. Inasmuch as it is the first report made by the company -- other than the bare statement of earnings published each quarter -- the facts as presented are of peculiar interest.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The rates for money were very firm to-day, and the demand was active. Discounts were easier. The reported South African peacs proposals had a dominating influence on the Stock Exchange. Prices in all departments were firm, and operators were cheerful. Kafirs were especially animated, and induced large transactions.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The Hague correspondent of The Daily Mail says he is able to announce on authority that The Netherlands note to Great Britain, after rehearsing the earnest concern of the Dutch Government at the prolongation of hostilities in South Africa, offered its good offices in bringing them to a close.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- Louis E. Whicher, partner of Lane B. Schofield, who committed suicide at Newtonville, to-day in an interview admitted that Mr. Schofield had experienced financial reverses due to unfortunate ventures, and said: "The affairs of Schofield, Whicher Co. are ail right at this moment.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- There was much amusement to-day at the hearing before the Assembly General Laws Committee on the bill introduced by Assemblyman Ahern of Troy to license actors and provide for a board of stage censors. "We will hear the opposition to the bill first," said Chairman Burnett.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Navy Department has made public Admiral Schley's appeal, delivered to the President about a week ago. The department's comment will be published in a day or two.

All precautionary rules and regulations adopted for the government of traffic on the Brooklyn Bridge as a result of the ominous happenings of last Summer, when seventeen suspenders parted one after another during a slight blockade at the highest point of the north roadway, were thrown to the winds during the heavy hours of travel last evening.

A special meeting of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners was convened yesterday to discuss the Park Avenue dynamite explosion at Forty-first Street on Monday. The session lasted an hour and a half, and at the instance of Mayor Low these resolutions were passed:

Apart from the trading in three or four stocks, the business transacted in the outside market yesterday was small. Notwithstanding the declines in the Stock Exchange, market during the afternoon outside Stocks remained fairly strong, some of them showing noteworthy gains. The largest loss of the day occurred in International Salt certificates, which on Tuesday had been bid up from 30 practically without sales, and the bid for which yesterday dropped back to 22.

Reciprocal tariffs with foreign nations and the growing mutual understanding of labor and capital -- these were the keynotes of the speeches at the twenty-ninth annual dinner of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria in special commemoration of the fifty-ninth birthday of the late President McKinley.

The stones for the walls of the dungeon in which Senator DUBOIS would confine Gen. WHEATON have not been hewed, nor has the Constitutional amendment been adopted under which President SCHURMAN is to be compelled to stop talking about Philippine independence. Nobody is to stop talking, not even Senator DUBOIS, not even Senator TELLER, whose talk was with perfect accuracy described by Senator LODGE as "silly."

No better choice could have been made for President of the Carnegie Institution than that of Dr. DANIEL COIT GILMAN. By character and career, by his personal gifts and the training of a long and fruitful experience, and especially by his keen and enlightened interest in precisely the kind of work to which Mr. CARNEGIE'S mind has turned in this latest benefaction, Dr. GILMAN is extraordinarily fitted for the task he has assumed.
Deputy Police Commissioner Thurston presided over the trials of fifty policemen charged with various delinquencies at Headquarters yesterday.

There was no meeting yesterday of the Board of Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners. The Secretary said that the Park Avenue explosion would next be considered at a special meeting yet to be called or on Feb. 6. Chief Engineer William Barclay Parsons is preparing a detailed report on last Monday's accident to supplement the preliminary report he made on Wednesday.

A delegation of 100 members of the Business Men's League called last evening at Tammany Hall and assured Lewis Nixon that they had confidence in his ability to make the political organization of which he is now the leader a factor for clean and good politics. The address on behalf of the league was made by Walter H. Bunn, ex-Appraiser of the Port of New York.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- A frightful coasting accident occurred at Keeseville this evening, in which one young man was killed and two young women fatally injured. A large party was coasting on Academy Hill, using a large bobsled, holding ten persons.

Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal declared again yesterday that the only means of relieving crushes on the Brooklyn Bridge was to establish more interborough transit facilities. The Commissioner made this statement, when asked regarding the crush Wednesday afternoon during the snow storm.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners in its annual report to the Legislature says that it is probable that in the current year it may be unnecessary to prepare an equalization table, as it is anticipated that the constitutional requirements of a small exaction for canal bonded indebtedness may be satisfactorily provided for without any direct tax levy.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- It having been brought to Gov. Odell's attention to-day that under the law creating the Board of Election Commissioners the power of removal was vested in him and not in Mayor Low, he was asked whether he contemplated taking action against Michael J. Dady, the second party to the alleged unlawful contract asserted to have been entered into by Dady and Sheriff Guden of Kings County prior to Guden's election.

The Charity Ball, which for nearly half a century has been a time-honored institution of New York, took place last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball differed but little from those which have been given in former years, except that the attendance was larger and there were among the guests more well-known people in the world of fashion than have been present for some seasons past.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Cocks Automobile bill was recommitted to the Committee on Codes after a spirited fight in the Senate to-day. The vote in favor of recommitting the bill was 22 to 17. The bill, as reported by the Codes Committee, provided for a maximum speed of twenty miles an hour on highways.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Senator Mills to-day introduced a bill which provides that for each increase of population to the extent of 80,000 in any judicial department there shall be allowed an additional Supreme Court Justice. The bill also authorizes the Legislature to divide the Second Judicial Department into two departments, each of which shall have a Supreme Court Justice for every 60,000 of its population.

HELENA, Mon., Jan. 30. --The Montana Ore Purchasing Company to-day provided the bond, with capable sureties, which the Supreme Court has exacted before it will permit the $350,000 cash bond to be surrendered in the Pennsylvania controversy with the Amalgamated Copper Company.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30. -- Sand Flea, Echodale, and Lady Alberta were the winning favorites to-day. Weather cloudy; track heavy. Summary:

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- It is certain, says the Vienna correspondent of The Times, that in influential quarters, where the international situation is best known, the end of the South African war would be welcome, more particularly because Great Britain's hands would be free and she would be able to make her voice heard more effectually in the councils of Europe.

President Fornes of the Board of Aldermen ruled the board with an iron hand yesterday. The word was passed around among the Democratic members that the Fusion majority would take drastic action in case the scenes of disorder which took place at the last meeting of the board were repeated.

Oakland Baron, 2;09 1/4, Baron Wilkes's great trotting son and the star of the big Fasig-Tipton midwinter sale at the Madison Square Garden, was sold yesterday morning to Congressman Jacob Ruppert for $15,700, and was sent at once to the Ruppert stock farm at Poughkeepsie. He will be used in the stud and raced also.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 30. -- The late easing in the tone of the Seaboard group was the most notable feature of to-day's trading. The decline was due to the decrease of $26,947 in the earnings for the third week in January. The Brewing issues again figured prominently in the demand, the common stock advancing 1 point, the first bonds 1 4/8 points, and the income bonds three-quarters of a point.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Secretary Long received to-day the following cablegrams from Rear Admiral Rodgers, who is at Cavite:

More life was displayed by the outside market yesterday than was shown on the earlier days of the week, and trading was somewhat more diversified. Transactions in several new issues were added to the business done in the stocks which heretofore have been the most prominent, and one or two of these received special attention.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- In view of the contention of Senator Cullom, (Rep., Ill.,) that reciprocity treaties affecting the revenues could be negotiated without Congressional action, Mr. Tawney (Rep., Minn.,) has introduced in the House the following:

Heavy blasting for the Rapid Transit tunnel before the institution of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society, in Broadway between One Hundred and Fiftieth and One Hundred and Fifty-first Streets, has so terrified the 800 children who are cared for there that progress with their lessons is next to an impossibility.

LA CROSSE, Wis., Jan. 30. -- As Jefferson de Angelis was about to go on the stage in "The Royal Rogue" last night he received a telegram announcing his son's sudden death in New York. He went through the play, however, and at midnight left for the East.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,000 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The rates for money were firm to-day, as settlement requirements increased the pressure and large sums were locked up in heavy applications for the London County Council loan issue. Continental inquiry, with the firmness of French exchange, weakened discounts. Business on the Stock Exchange was somewhat irregular.

There was peace yesterday in the Criminal Courts Building. The District Attorney did not disturb the Coroners greatly, and they made no hostile move against the public prosecutor. Coroner's Clerk John Murray, however, who was about the building, was in a belligerent frame of mind. He has a statement, which he says he will soon give in full for publication.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The "comment" of Judge Advocate General Lemly and Solicitor Hanna upon the appeal of Admiral Schley, as submitted to the President by Secretary Long, is less than a third as long as the appeal itself, a fact accounted for by the comparatively few quotations from the court's testimony.

Our Washington dispatches yesterday indicated that the Committee of Ways and Means has determined to defy not only "our plain duty" toward Cuba, but the urgent appeal of a Republican Administration to perform that duty. Such a defiance can certainly not be addressed to men like Messrs. ROOSEVELT and ROOT without having serious political consequences.

The new Street Cleaning administration had its first serious tussle with snow yesterday, and all things considered acquitted itself fairly well. This was the opinion expressed by business men and pedestrians generally, particularly those on Broadway and others of the more important downtown thoroughfares, where Commissioner Woodbury's contractors and department men had succeeded in making way with the accumulation during the day.

PARIS, Jan. 30. -- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, was seen here to-day in connection with the Wall Street rumor that he had resigned the Presidency of that concern, Mr. Schwab refused to confirm or deny this report. "I won't say anything," he declared, emphatically.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- The general list was inactive to-day, but prices were generally firm. Some stocks, not often quoted, participated in the trading, among them being Warwick Iron, with a half point rise and sales amounting to 2,000 shares. The minor steel issues reflected the encouraging condition of trade shown by the United States Steel Corporation, Susquehanna holding at 2 and Cambria at 24 3/4.
With approximately half a million shares dealt in, yesterday's stock market was irregular, though the changes shown in final quotations were largely on the side of advance.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The annual report of the Forest, Fish, and Game Commission, which was sent to the Legislature to-day, says in part:

The New York Athletic Club hockey team won an easy victory from the Brooklyn Skating Club at the St. Nicholas Rink last night, scoring 7 goals to the visitors' 1. The Brooklyn team was quite outclassed by the Now Yorkers, and but for the excellent defense of McMasters, the Brooklyn goalkeeper, the score would have been even more onesided.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League on the West Side Republican Club alleys last night, the home team won three games from the Century Wheelmen. The Manhattan Council team won two games in the New York Royal Arcanum League series. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- When the Philippine Tariff bill was taken up at 2 o'clock Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C.,) took the floor. He announced that he would not talk much about the Philippine tariff, but would discuss the part South Carolina took in the War of the Revolution. He arraigned Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) for attempting to prevent a discussion on the Revolutionary theme and for trying to parcel out the time of the Senate."
Friends and relatives of the fourteenth class of the Baron de Hirsch Trade School filled the building at 222 East Sixty-fourth Street last night. There were eighty graduates.
PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Judge Senior arrested a man after an exciting battle of several minutes at his own home this morning.

Some interesting features of the 1901 racing season are mentioned in the annual report of the State Racing Commission which was presented to the Legislature at Albany yesterday. The Commissioners signing the report are August Belmont, E.D. Morgan, and John Sanford. The opening sentence states that the racing year just closed has been successful beyond expectations, and continuing in this vein, the report says:

PITTSBURG, Jan. 30. -- Edward and John Biddle, awaiting execution in the county jail for the murder of Grocer Thomas D. Kahney of Mount Washington, overpowered the guards at 4 o'clock this morning and escaped. The prisoners had been provided with saws with which they cut the bars in their cells until ready at any moment to make an opening sufficiently large to pass through.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Committee on Arrangements for the reception of Prince Henry held another meeting to-day and completed the itinerary of the Prince's Western and Southern trip.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The British reply to the Dutch note in regard to the war in South Africa was dispatched on Thursday to The Hague. Consequently, the meeting of the British Cabinet yesterday had nothing to do with the terms of the note, the contents of which are kept strictly secret, as it is intimated that the first publication of the text shall be made in Parliament on Monday.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Selections from The Page fill the current Cornhill Booklet, and an introduction by Mr. Edwin Osgood Crover, called "Foreword," describes the periodical as "an amusing and interesting expression of the artistic spirit and originality of Mr. Gordon Craig." Nearly all its contents are acknowledged as his, and Mr. Grover suspects him of more than he acknowledges.

There has long been a crying need for a short, unprejudiced, scholarly political history of the United States. That cry is still unsatisfied, for Mrs. Conklin's "American Political History," popularly told, fills successfully but one of the requirements -- the first.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The investigation into conditions in the Philippine archipelago was begun by the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day. Gov. W.H. Taft was the first witness. There was a full attendance, and Senator Lodge, (Rep., Mass.,) Chairman, explained that the committee desired not only the fullest information concerning the islands, but any advice that the Governor might offer.

Gov. ODELL'S control of the Republican majority in the Assembly is not absolute, but it is effective. His bill to abolish the local Boards of Managers of the State hospitals and concentrate their powers in his own hands passed the Assembly on Thursday by a vote of 97 to 45.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: The letter of Mr. William Abbatt in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Jan. 25 places me under the necessity of once more asking the indulgence of your columns. To Mr. Abbatt I am also under obligations for his excerpt from the memoirs of Gen. Heath.

The amount realized by the sale of Mrs. P.C. Hanford's collection of paintings by the American Art Association at Mendelssohn Hall on Thursday evening was $124,133. The appearance of a Rembrandt. "The Accountant," and the price which it fetched, $23,000, gave rise to some surprise. A dealer bought the picture.

BUTLER, Penn., Jan. 31 -- Edward Biddle is in jail here dying; John Biddle, riddled with buckshot, is in a precarious condition, and Mrs. Peter K. Soffel is in the hospital with a self-inflicted bullet wound in the breast, as the outcome of the sensational escape of the Biddle brothers from the Allegheny County Jail, aided by Mrs. Soffel, the wife of the jail warden, on Thursday morning.

Illustrated Edition of "Social England." A new edition of the well-known illustrated work "Social England," which will be in six volumes, is to be called the King Edward Edition. It will contain 2,500 illustrations and numerous colored plates, reproduced from authentic sources, and edited by H.D. Traill, D.C.L. sometime Fellow of St. John's College, Oxford, and J.S. Mann, M.A., sometime Fellow of Trinity College, Oxford.

THE present day method of writing history, based as it is upon a careful study of all public records, including the dispatches of Ambassadors and other contemporary documents preserved in record offices, with such further light as can be gathered from original manuscripts and private letters in the archives of well-known families, has led to the reversal or modification of many long-established verdicts.

HE is a disagreeable man. I shall never cross his path again." Such was Mr. O'Brien's first impression of the man whose biographer he was to be nearly thirty years later. Possibly in biography, as well as in matrimony, it is safest to begin with a little aversion.

Burglars forced the Fifth Avenue entrance of the store of the Meriden Britannia Company at 1,128-1,130 Broadway some time Thursday night and are believed to have carried away a whole carriage load of carefully selected silverware from the counters of the establishment, which is one of the largest of its kind in the country.

Two inches of snow had fallen between 7:40 o'clock A.M. and 9 o'clock P.M. yesterday, according to the local Weather Bureau. There were sprinkles of snow from 7:40 to 7:50 o'clock and from 8:12 until 10:40 o'clock, and then a continuous fall, very light in quantity, except between 5:20 and 6:30 o'clock.

Peter Sinnirud proved himself a championship skater well worthy of the name yesterday in the first day's contests at Verona Lake, near Montclair, N.J., for the championship of the United States and Canada. He won the five-mile championship, after a beautiful race, by scarcely a foot from M. Wood, both representing the Verona Lake Club, and the only Canadian to set a place was W. Coldwell, who was only a few inches behind Wood.

ON Monday and Tuesday, Feb. 17 and 18, 1902, John Anderson, Jr., will sell in four sessions in his new auction room, in West Thirtieth Street, the fifth-portion of the library of the late Thomas J. McKee. The four preceding sales, held respectively in December, 1900, and in January, April, and December, 1901, brought forward a notable array of rareties that eloquently appealed to specialists in four departments of literature.

Every American, we should suppose, must feel a thrill of patriotic pride in reading the list of gifts and benefactions for public purposes made in the United States during 1901, which we owe, as usual in such cases, to the courtesy of the editor of Appletons' Annual Cyclopaedia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Some of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee have apparently become alarmed at the manner in which their attitude toward Cuban reciprocity is received. They have had abundant evidence that they are regarded generally as being in direct opposition to the Administration in respect to a project to which the Administration attaches very great importance.

The pool tournament which has been in progress for the last few weeks at The Strollers for the championship of the club will be brought to a conclusion to-day. There will be a match between Maximilian B. Ziegler and Eugene Van Schaick in the semi-finals in the afternoon at 3 o'clock. The winner of this match will play against Howard A. Colby in the finals at 9 o'clock in the evening.

One hundred of old Dartmouth's alumni gathered around the board last night at the annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association of New York at Delmonico's. President William Jewett Tucker of the college was the guest of honor, and made a plea for the use of the best methods by men of wealth of to-day who are seeking a way to further the cause of higher education in this country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Before Secretary Gage retired he carried out his intention of removing J.D. O'Connell, financial clerk of the Bureau of Statistics. As stated yesterday. Mr. O'Connell was accused of making charges against the management of the bureau. He gave to Representative Cannon of Illinois a statement charging Chief O.P. Austin with using the information obtained by the bureau for private gain.

The Ways and Means Committee have just determined to repeal internal revenue taxes to the amount of $68,000,000, and the tax on tea, some $9,000,000 more, while refusing the slightest reduction of the purely protective and discriminating tax on sugar and on tobacco for the products of Cuba.

The most important book sale held this season by Bangs Co. brought forward Jan. 22 and 23 in their Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms a large number of choice and desirable books. The highest price of the sale was the $500 given by Mr. Elliott for a copy of the Kelmscott Press edition of Chaucer's "Works," 1896.

Although the accompanying correspondence speaks for itself, there are two phases of it to which we desire particularly to call attention -- the attempt to bribe librarians to indorse a certain publication and the character of the publication itself. We have received letters from two librarians who are among the most eminent in their profession.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Secretary of State for War, the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, introduced the supplementary army estimates of L5,000,000 in the House of Commons yesterday. He said that on Jan. 1 there were still 237,800 British troops in South Africa. The cost of the war had now been reduced to about L4,500,000 a month.

The dinner of the Municipal Art Society, which we reported yesterday, with the discussion that followed it, was a noteworthy occasion. We have pointed out the entirely inadequate provision made by the charter for entertaining or executing projects of municipal embellishment.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Referring to the discussion recently raised by Judge Dykman regarding Washington's reasons for declining the aid of cavalrymen, the occurrence took place in July, 1776, at a time when the headquarters were at New York, and when the locality likely to be the first subject of attack by the British Army and fleet was a matter of much conjecture.

This volume is deservedly designated a revision and enlargement of the original imprint, which appeared in 1896. The revision has involved so large an amount of labor and the additions have been so generously made that the volume now in hand invites attention with almost the force of an original performance.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 -- The joint conference of miners and operators settled down to business this afternoon, and by evening proceedings were well under way. The miners, through President Mitchell, presented their demands for an increase in pay and for correcting abuses, and they were discussed at some length in open convention.
George W. Jones has been appointed Brooklyn agent of the Glens Palls Fire Insurance Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the West Jersey and Seashore Railroad Company today, A.J. Cassatt, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, was elected President and Director, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Senator William J. Sewell.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The exposition of a historical fact must be my excuse for a last trespass upon your valuable space and time.

Detonating caps were stored next to the dynamite in the magazine before the Murray Hill Hotel, according to the story told to the assembled reporters in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning by Andrew Murray, the powder man, just after he was held in $10,000 bail for examination on Monday on account of his connection with the disaster.
Transactions in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange for the month of January were the smallest since last August, and were much less than half those of the corresponding month last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Democrats in the Senate were greatly disconcerted today when Mr. Morgan of Alabama started upon a speech designed to show that there was no sense nor reason in the opposition the minority had been making to the passage of the Philippine tariff bill. The speech was based on Mr. Morgan's amendment proposing that the bill shall be made to recognize certain constitutional provisions.

The civil list supposed to show the officials and employes of the departments and bureaus and offices of the City of New York was published yesterday as a supplement to The City Record. Section 1,528 of the charter requires that the full list of city officials, with their salaries, length of service, and other details must be printed in the month of January and July of each year.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: During the last few months several congratulatory dinners and receptions have been given in honor of silver-haired poets and literary men who could have said with truth, as did one of our great Generals on a like occasion, "I thank you for the tremendous furore with which you have received me, for I know it is as heartfelt on your side as it is well-deserved on mine."

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 31 -- In the presence of a large congregation the funeral of Rear Admiral Lewis Kimberly, who died Tuesday, was held to-day in the First Unitarian Church of West Newton. The honorary pall bearers were Rear Admirals Belknap and Dyer, retired; Rear Admiral Johnson, commandant of the Charlestown Navy Yard; Charles A. Luce, Capts. George H. Wadleigh and Henry W. Lyons, Commander E.K. Moore, and James Parker.

Frederick A. Carll has sold for the Provident Real Estate Company, for about $115,000, the six-story apartment house 6 and 8 West Ninety-second Street, 45 by 88 by 100. The same broker has also sold for Meyer Auerbach, for $35,000, the four-story dwelling 965 Lexington Avenue, 20 by 50 by 70.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Jan 31 -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, sitting in Monroe County, has dismissed the appeal in the celebrated case of Dole against Dole, in which an uncle deeded to his nephew a large fortune consisting of Chicago real estate while under the influence of liquor.

Mr. Dole has just brought out a privately printed edition of the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam which is strictly limited in its issue to 150 numbered copies on hand-made paper and twenty-five on Japanese veilum.

IN a prefatory note the publishers of this volume announce their intention to publish a short series of books having a general resemblance to certain obsolescent manuals which once had a considerable vogue, their purpose being to shape the ideals and purposes of young men and women on the threshold of their active life.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 31 -- The Atlantic Hotel, the Columbia Office Building, which adjoined the hotel, the Albemarle Flats and a block of stores in the centre of the city were destroyed early this morning by the most destructive fire that Norfolk has had in thirty years. The damage is estimated at $900,000.

Parading in grey coats and white duck trousers, the Seventh Regiment, in command of Col. Daniel Appleton, was reviewed at its armory last night by Brig. Gen. William A. Kobbe, United States Army, a former member of the Seventh Regiment, who, during the evening was presented with a sword by the members of the regiment.

In "The Wisdom of the Wise," played by students of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts at the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon, John Oliver Hobbes has written an exceedingly entertaining comedy, punctuated from first to last with original and witty lines, and containing a number of well-defined and thoroughly interesting characters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Committee on Arrangements for Prince Henry's reception to-day made public the itinerary for the Prince's Eastern, Western, and Southern trips as it stands finally approved by the railroad authorities. This itinerary governs only the movements of the party by rail.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day heard applications for changes in the schedule of classifications in New York City, Syracuse, and Erie County. There was a large delegation present, representing the cities where the exemptions from examination and other changes in the classifications are requested.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Chairman Kelscy of the Assembly Committee on Cities, to-day introduced two bills which were sent to him by Dock Commissioner McDougal Hawkes of New York City. The first bill provides that the Dock Commissioner shall have the right to acquire by condemnation any property needed for docks and wharves on the North River front between Bloomfield Street and the northerly side of Twenty-third Street.
Capt. Charles B, Wheeler will proceed to the Sandy Hook Proving Ground, Sandy Hook, on business pertaining to the manufacture of gun carriages.

AFTER stating that prefaces to books can be of but two sorts, explanatory and apologetic, and that one of the second variety may generally be considered by experienced readers as a trustworthy warning to pass by the book to which it is prefixed, Mr. Seymour Van Santvoord proceeds to indulge in somewhat profuse apologies for the publication of "The House of Caesar and the Imperial Disease."

DR. FITCHETT has written a dramatic and eloquent story of the Sepoy Rebellion from the English point of view. He carries his readers so thoroughly along with him that their emotions even overleap his own, and they are ready to justify every act of English vengeance, even the blowing of the Sepoy prisoners from the muzzles of the cannon, and the shooting of the Princes of the House of Timour.

Belloc's "Robespierre." What Hilaire Belloc, the author of a trust worthy monograph on Danton, attempts to accomplish in his "Robespierre," just published by Charles Scribner's Sons, is explained in his own words in the preface of his book.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The Mortgage Tax bill is in danger. The opposition to it from the country districts is growing serious. This week several County Treasurers have been in Albany to see the Senators and Assemblymen of their districts, and to inform them as to the effect the bill would have upon the taxable valuation of their respective localities.

The tone of yesterday's market was distinctly strong, few noteworthy declines being recorded, only one or two of as much as a whole point, while many conspicuous issues rose substantially. A few hundred shares of Lake Erie and Western preferred lifted the quotation 5 points, and 9 points were added to Lackawanna by transactions aggregating less than 2,000 full shares.

When the auctioneer banged his hammer, disposing of the last horse for the day's allotment in the big Fasig-Tipton horse sale in Madison Square Garden last night, nearly 500 head of horses were recorded as a result of this annual auction. The big consignment from the Philadelphia Brewing Company was disposed of.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Senate adopted to-day Mr. Rawlins's resolution for an investigation into the Uintah mining leases in Utah. The investigation is to be conducted by the Committee on Indian Affairs, which will inquire into two subjects -- the authority of the Interior Department to approve such leases, and the connection of Government officials with the making of the leases.

The statement of the Commissioner of Bridges about methods for relieving the congestion of the Brooklyn Bridge corresponds to the result of the observation of every observant user of that structure. It is, of course, very absurd that a horse falling on a slippery roadway should for the time paralyze the communication between two boroughs which, of themselves, would be the first and the fourth of American cities.

FULL and authentic text of President Jacob Gould Schurman's address. "Philippine Affairs; a Retrospect and an Outlook," is being published this week by Charles Scribner's Sons. In this text of President Schurman's much-lauded and abused address is given a full survey of the situation with regard to Philippine affairs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Judge Tulcy has ordered a receivership for the Zion Lace Industries, and on Monday he will enter a decree appointing Elmer Washburn receiver under a bond of $700,000. In a lengthy decision of the case, which was instituted by Samuel Stevenson, a brother-in-law of John Alexander Dowie, the court declared that Dowie's Christian Catholic Church was a curious mixture of religion and business.

And who might Thomas Dongan be Such, no doubt, were the thoughts which arose in many minds, on learning a few days ago that a public dinner had taken place in this city in honor of Dongan's memory, and that one of the speakers insisted that a monument to Dongan should be erected in New York.

ONLY at the end of a 3,000mile chase, extending over many months, did the writer at last succeed in having an interview with Mr. Parker. The game, however, all interviewers will agree, was large enough to repay one for the pursuit.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value, exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- T. Fisher Unwin will shortly bring out in book form H.G. Wells's recent address before the Royal Institution on "The Discoveries of the Future," which is full of thought and fancy.

In the case of CHRISTIANSEN vs. CRUM the Indiana courts have reached a conclusion of much interest, involving the declaration of the principle that the death of one of the parties to a marriage engagement constitutes a breach of promise, entitling the surviving party to the unfulfilled contract to receive compensatory damages in such amount as may be shown to be just and equitable in the circumstances.

Last month ex-Justice of the Supreme Court Henry W. Bookstaver, at present a member of the law firm of Bookstaver Norton of 257 Broadway; Lawyer Louis B. Hasbrouck of the firm of Straley, Hasbrouck Schloeder, and Dr. Egbert Le Fevre, a well-known physician of 52 West Fifty-sixth Street, were persuaded by Charles M. Dobson, a mining expert, to invest $1,800 in a Cuban manganese mining enterprise.

An agreement has been signed by all of the principal Tranatlantic steamship lines whereby rates between this country and England on three of the most important articles of export from the United States -- grain, flour, and produce -- will be advanced about 50 per cent. The new rate will go into effect this morning, but will not apply to vessels sailing to-day, as these are loaded.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Money was in active demand to-day, in view of the month-end requirements, and rates were very firm. Discounts were quiet. The attraction on the Stock Exchange continued to centre on Kafirs. Their advance was maintained, and there were several further slight rises. The dealings were large.

Practically every Christian Endeavor society in this city and vicinity, of which there are nearly 500, will to-morrow observe the coming of age of the Christian Endeavor movement. These societies are for the most part in Presbyterian and Congregational churches with some in churches of smaller religious bodies, and are junior, intermediate, and senior.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the contemplated visit of Prince Henry to the United States, it is much to be hoped that our people will remain level-headed and not "slop over" or otherwise make fools of themselves.

Many, when they hear that a new book by Mr. Birrell is about to appear, live in expectation. For they have already entered into bonds of friendship with him. The personal element in his books has thrown its influence around them, and they have felt its charm. He has drawn them "with cords of a man."

Wise observers of things bibliographical have found the history of American bibliomania interesting to study. While historians have entertainingly chronicled our growth in many directions, the story of American book collecting is still a tale untold. Despite the unusual fascination that it possesses, it remains an untouched subject.

This edition of the love letters of Keats appears to be most appropriate in form and letters press. It may be recalled that the letters of the poet to Fanny Brawne were first published for private circulation by Mr. Buxton-Forman in 1878, and were later on incorporated in a complete edition of Keats's letters brought out in 1895.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is strange by what psychological process or poetical chemical analysis two persons, in all respects as far apart as the poles and working on entirely dissimilar materials, can arrive at the same conclusions. This thought was suggested to me on reading the last stanza of Anna H. Branch's poem in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS.

General absence of auditors from the foyers of the various theatres of the city indicated last night a prompt observance by managers of the order from Fire Commissioner Sturgis, issued on Thursday, for the enforcement of the old law against loitering in the aisles and spaces at the rear of seats.

At about 6 o'clock last night, in the blinding snowstorm, the British steamship Cavour of Liverpool, belonging to the Lamport Holt Line, in command of Capt. Kelly, went ashore at Long Beach, a point on the southern Long Island coast, eighteen miles east of Sandy Hook.

Dr. SIMON NEWCOMB -- he is "Doctor" by the decrees of half a dozen universities in nearly as many countries -- has a sombre article in the current number of The North American Review, on "The Conditions Which Discourage Scientific Work in America." It is written with full knowledge, and, of course, in entire good faith.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 31 -- A number of trolley cars of the North Jersey Street Railway Company are snow-bound on the Orange Mountains to-night.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 and 2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $23,131,644; balances, $1,371,175. Boston brokers are borrowing call money in New York as low as 2 1/2 per cent., while here the banks are still quoting 3 1/2 to 4 per cent., though there are a few exceptions at 3 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A representative of the Neue Freie Presse, whose statement is quoted by the Vienna correspondent of The Times, says he was informed by Dr. Leyds that the Boers had applied to the Dutch and other Governments to use their good offices to end the horrors of the war.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- The local market was dull in the early trading, most of the business being in Union Traction, but in the last hour the strength in New York was responded to and the market took on a cheerful appearance, the arbitrage stocks, especially Reading, becoming very active.

Gov. Odell was the principal guest and speaker at the eleventh annual dinner of the Alumni of Syracuse University, which was held last evening at the Hotel Savoy. Other guests of honor, most of whom were called upon to respond to toasts, were J. R. Day, the Chancellor of the University: John D. Archbold, Dean Frank Smalley, Dean Ensign McChesney, State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles R. Skinner.

ALBANY, Jan. 31-- Assemblyman George M. Palmer of Schoharie, the minority leader, has written an open letter in which he says that more radical amendments should be made to the judiciary article of the Constitution than are proposed by the Legislature.

We are not advised concerning the specific merits of the controversy between the Japanese Government and the foreigners resident in Yokohama, but it is pretty plainly in continuation of the controversy which lasted for a generation about the international status of Japan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Saturday, Jan. 25, I was surprised to see your statement quoted from Mr. William Barclay Parsons's testimony before the State Railroad Commission during its investigation of the recent accident in the New York Central Railroad tunnel.

Living portraiture is now the fashion. It has special advantages. Every professional camerist will tell you that nervous sitters are most difficult to please; their likenesses so seldom do them justice, as they say, and some people are such bad subjects that even the most skilled retouching cannot make their photographs satisfactory.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Doulos," in his brief communication to your columns in to-day's issue, has no trouble in convicting Dr. Parkhurst of unscripturalness in his sermon of last Sabbath, in which he took the ground that only good men are immortal. The text of the sermon in question proves nothing, being a simple question, "If a man die, shall he live again?"

BUTLER, Penn., Feb. 1. --The death of both the Biddle brothers, condemned murderers and jail breakers, closed a day of intense excitement here to-day. John Biddle, who, until late this afternoon, was considered as likely to escape present death, succumbed at 7:35 P.M. His death was followed at 11 o'clock by the death of Ed. Biddle.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Andrew Carnegie contends that the condition of the workingman is better now than in former times, if the cost of living is taken into consideration. This, I think, needs an answer from some one more intimately familiar with the everyday life of the wage earner as it was a half century ago and as it now is.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- With the month-turn the supplies of cash are temporarily relatively good. The market having borrowed from the Bank of England, the demand has been active, but the large repayments to be made to the Bank next week render the position very uncertain.

Copies of the voluminous report of the Municipal Civil Service Commission for 1901, which was sent to the State Commission last week, were made public yesterday. It shows a total of 11,797 persons examined during the year, of whom 1,362 competed for promotions. There were 357 examinations.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 .-- A better general tone was noted in the market to-day, and in some instances high-record prices were established. Union Traction was carried up to 33 1/4 or close to its record figure for the present movement. Further advances were attained by Warwick Iron, Philadelphia Electric, and Cambria Steel, while United Power and Transportation reached the highest in its history, selling equivalent to 51.

APPRECIATION of a scientific subject differs widely. A general public is prone to assimilate one portion, as often as not that of minor importance, and entirely overlook that other part, which is the major one. Not long ago all zymotic diseases were classed as dirt diseases.
ABOUT three days south of Java by ship is the smallest and most unique civilization on earth. At the same time it furnishes an illustration of one of the methods of extending the British Empire.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- A sensational dispute between a wealthy mother and daughter over the custody of the latter's children was aired in the courts this week. The parties were Mrs. Naylor-Leyland and her daughter, the Hon. Mrs. Chetwynd, a sister-in-law of Lady Naylor-Leyland, who who was Miss Jennie Chamberlain of Cleveland.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Unless the Central Railroad of New Jersey takes down a fence which it has erected at the West Eighth Street station here it is likely that there will be trouble between the health officials and the commuters on the one side and the railroad men on the other.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Gen. Chaffee has cabled to the War Department a report of the expedition of Major Waller and his marines across Samar. It is the first full account of the march and tells a tale of terrible suffering and hardship. The story is told in the following dispatch:
To the Editor of The New York Times: There are some points in the discussion of the sugar tax which do not yet appear to have attracted the attention which ought to be given to them.
PEKING, Feb. 1. -- The Dowager Empress, the Emperor, and the Empress this afternoon received the ladies and children of the members of the Diplomatic Corps in the private apartments of the palace.

TACOMA, Washington, Feb. 1. -- The land sales of the Northern Pacific Railway in Washington, Oregon, and Idaho in the past year are stated in the annual report of the road to amount to 1,118,401 acres, or more than six times as great as the land sales in 1891, which was considered a year of unusual activity in locating new settlers in the West.
One of the features of railroad progress has been the relatively tardy recovery in passenger business -- that record, compared with freight results, being in striking contrast.

William Chicelli's ancestors used the scalping knife on the white invaders. Chicelli makes his living in the employ of dime museums, where the elasticity of his bronzered skin makes him one of the "rubber-men," well known to the employers of freaks. Incidentally Chicelli has inherited the gift of telling the future -- at least he says be has inherited this mystic power from his forefathers.

Frank White, Governor of North Dakota, is at the home of his father-in-law, Artemus Hadley, 2,032 Ashland Avenue, for a few days' visit. Gov. White is a clean-cut sort of a man, broad-shouldered, erect in carriage, and pleasant-faced. Except when the merits of North Dakota are brought into question he does not believe the English language was invented altogether for purposes of conversation, but on that topic he is not reserved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Gov. Taft continued his statement concerning conditions in the Philippine archipelago before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day. He said that, next to Manila. Cebu came nearer to being a city in point of population and manner of improvement than any other place in the islands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the greatest scholars and preachers of American Judaism, and one of the best-known in Christian circles, is Rabbi Emil G. Hirsch of Chicago, but even so great a man as he may be hurried by the inspiration of the hour into statements which need to be challenged in the interests of truth and fairness.

Wall Street has ceased to worry over money-market possibilities, and even the professional calamity howler can find nothing in the local monetary situation to solace him or afford opportunity for complaint. Ease -- genuine and beyond cavil -- is here, and the indications are not only that it will be continuing in its nature, but that it will grow more pronounced as the days develop.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1. -- Nutt's skillful riding gave Prince Blazes the verdict by a head in the Merchants' Handicap, worth $1,920 to the winner, this afternoon. Ida Ledford, Malay, and Menace, all at fives, were equal favorites in the betting. The Morris castoff, Choice, set a hot pace for six furlongs and then died out, yielding first place to Jessie Jarboe, who had been in close attendance all the way.

IN many ways there are queer happenings that may have a hearing on the coalmining industry and now and then they form features of interest. Here are a few incidents which recently came under my notice:

To the Editor of The New York Times: From the numerous articles in your paper and others, together with the expression of the sentiment of the mass of the people, the fact is apparent that the proposed Stranahan mortgage tax is not wanted by the people, and is regarded by them as an injustice, a double tax on real estate, a disposition to make rents higher and living higher -- for what purpose?

The effort now making to interest Congress in certain necessary reforms in the drawback system should not be attended with very great difficulty. The existing law requires the user of imported materials on which duty has been paid to establish the "identity" of such materials before he can make good his claim to the rebate of duties which it is the intention of the law to allow him when his products are exported.

Amalgamated Copper was strong throughout the week, any recessions that appeared being merely of a temporary nature. If abundant reports be true the management of the company (which persists in its sphinx-like silence) has made another colossal blunder in respect to the metal market.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Monday night the Rogers bill abolishing the Boards of Managers of the State insane asylums and vesting their powers in a Superintendent, to be appointed by the State Commission in Lunacy, will come to the Senate. The pro- gramme is to substitute it for the Brackett bill and pass it.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- While the Eisberg bill with regard to the salaries of mechanics in the State Gas Meter Inspector's office was under consideration yesterday, Senators Stranahan and Donnelly became involved in a civil service argument.

Gov. Odell breakfasted with Senator Thomas C. Platt yesterday morning, and last evening went to his home at Newburg. Gov. Odell, before leaving the city, complained of not feeling in good physical condition. He said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been so popular to rate "Old Probabilities" a cheat, a fraud, a prevaricator of colossal magnitude that I have kept tab for a time on the weather forecasts to see if the alleged meteorological turpitude of the old gentleman could be shown by the facts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The refunding law, which was intended to furnish for many years an adequate banknote currency, is not meeting the entire expectations of its authors. This result is due to the high price of the " per cent, bonds, which have been ranging for some months from 108 to 109.

Americans scored heavily over the Canadians yesterday in the finals of the championship skating races of Canada and the United States at Verona Lake, near Montclair, N.J. The competition, which began on Friday, was concluded by skating off the finals of the half mile and mile events, which had been run in heats on the previous day, while the three-mile and ten-mile races were the additional attractions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Knowing the great care that your valuable paper has always taken to safeguard the best interests of this great city, especially in behalf of its humbler denizens, by whom I am importuned to voice their views at this time regarding a matter of vital interest to all, I write you this letter with a note of warning.

The wedding of Miss Josephine Bissell Roe, daughter of Gen. Charles F. Roe, and Prescott Slade is to be celebrated on Saturday afternoon in St. Thomas's Church, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. Mrs. Adams Batcheller is to be the matron of honor, and the maid of honor will be Miss Florence Waring.

True, the glory of China has been darkened; but the eclipse passes and the sun remains. True, the armies of China have been scattered; but the crowds which scatter before a "must" elephant are still in the scale of creation the beast's superiors, and will live when he has fallen into the river.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On my return from a short trip away I find a letter from Mr. Henry E. Chapman, which appeared in your issue of Jan. 19, criticising my article in your paper two weeks earlier. His suggestion that my figures want revision is one which is always in point.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- In a report to the State Department on "Sugar Production in Europe," Henry W. Diederich, United States Consul at Bremen, has submitted the following:

Copyright, 1902. LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Even now, when peace negotiations of some sort or other are known to be in progress, the ma- jority of practical Englishmen believe that Lord Kitchener will still be a most useful factor in the restoration of peace in South Africa.

DYNAMITE is so little understood by the general public that it may be pertinent, in view of recent events in New York, to say that it is a mechanical mixture of a high explosive, nitro-glycerine, and a transporting medium, such as a siliceous infusorial earth. Nitro-glycerine was found to be too highly explosive for general practical use, and its discoverer, Nobel, invented dynamite as a safer form.

The new system of taking tickets during the rush hours on the bridge was not thoroughly tested yesterday and no actual comparison could be made with the old system for the reason that Saturday is always a quiet day and the rush is well distributed over the afternoon. The new system went into effect yesterday at 4:10 P.M. and was observed until 7:30 P.M., as these hours are believed to be the heaviest.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 1. -- Consul General F.H. Mason, at Berlin, has made the following report to the State Department:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of this morning, "Oxnard vs. Plain Duty," occurs the following: "Men employed in one of the departments make bold to appear as experts before a committee of Congress and oppose the policy of the Administration of which they are the subordinates."

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have devoted considerable space, in the last few months, to local architects, and have tried, it seems to me, to convey the impression that, with the exception which you have stated so often, the architects, whose names are seen on plans for important structures, are artists and men of honor.

HUSBAND'S LIABILITY FOR WIFE'S NECES- SARIES. -- In an action brought in the Mu- nicipal Court by Agnes Ogle against Will- iam Dershem to recover for board furnished the latter's wife, the defendant set up as a bar a judgment dismissing the complaint in an action brought by his wife against him for separate maintenance.

Mrs. Ann Nixon, who for several years had been a quaint figure in the thorough- fares of the Borough of the Bronx, where she picked rags, washed clothes, and did anything else at which she could make an honest penny, was found dead in her fur-nished room in the cottage of John Roden-feld at 4,177 Park Avenue yesterday morning.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Three hundred of the most prominent men of Syracuse met at the University Block Assembly Halt this evening and for three hours argued the demerits of the Brackett-Rogers bill to revise the system of managing State institutions for the insane. State Senator Horace White and Erastus Pellenz, a prominent Socialist, stood alone in defending the measure.

ONE little arbutus plant blossomed in Bronx Park last Spring, but it will never blossom again. Mrs. N.L. Britton, wife of Dr. Britton, Director in Chief of the Botanical Garden, had taken it under her especial care, and tended it as if it were a human. It grew dangerously near a footpath, and she had it sufficiently covered with leaves, she thought, to hide it away from the most observing eyes.

If the sovereign State of New York bad possessed as many self-satisfied fellows as Massachusetts, her place in history would have been higher. She has always been modest in her claims, with the result that New England, which has always claimed everything, has forged ahead and left New York far behind as a centre of historical interest.

Yesterday's stock market was dull, but, on the whole, distinctly strong, considering the persistent bear pressure put upon it, together with the realizing sales made by room traders and others who make it a habit never to go home long of stocks over Sunday. Greatest strength was shown in Amalgamated, Anaconda, Sugar, Southern Pacific, Rock Island, and St. Paul, the buying of all these issues being by some of the largest interests in the Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Scene: New York City. Time: 1902. Mr. Primrose suddenly finds himself forced by nature to seek a retiring place, enters one of the shops in the vicinity, and is very courteously directed to the cafe on the corner.

At first you will find it difficult to decide by what name to call any one of the year's phases. The familiar terms seem to fit them but ill, for the seasons of the tropics have many strange features. If you bear in mind what the Malay Peninsula is like, you will see how this can hardly fail to be as it is.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The first perform- ance of "Ulysses" at Her Majesty's Theatre this evening was vehemently applauded by a crowded audience, in- cluding many persons distinguished in art, letters, and social life. As a spectacle alone the production is almost sure to have a long run, because the pictures have scarcely been surpassed in the history of the English stage.

THE "Better Days" crowd had finally secured seats all in a bunch in the eastern court, and after the Major related as many of his "hayfoot, strawfoot" stories of life in the Shenandoah Valley during war days as the crowd would permit, the County Clerk mentioned that he had seen an excellent portrait of the late Gov. Flower in a saloon on Houston Street while getting a drink early in the evening.

WHEN Johnson wrote his "Happy Valley" he had no idea that such a place existed. His Utopia was an ideal never to be realized even in his book. But over here in Mexico, in a country of which the great Englishman knew almost nothing, that valley existed, had existed for generations, and still exists.

Next Saturday night a concert of some importance to music lovers will be given at Carnegie Hall by C.L. Graft in honor of Mme. Lilli Lehmann's last appearance in New York this season. The artists who will appear with Mme. Lehmann are Mmes. Gadski and Blauvelt, and Kubelik, the vio- linist.

The annual dinner of the Italian Chamber of Commerce, which was held at the Hotel Savoy last night, was enlivened by an incident at the door of the banquet hall. It was occasioned by the attitude II Progresso has taken toward Antonio Zucca, the ex-Coroner, and Giovanni Branchi, the Italian Consul General in this city, for some time past.
R. Fulton Cutting, President of the New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, has issued an appeal in which he says, in part:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this day of excise agitation and milliondollar donations, would it not be well to consider means for offsetting the saloon? Any one not a theorist knows that decent working men go to the saloon. Some of our ministers ridicule the idea that the saloon is the " poor man's club."

The bill for a gallery of American art at Washington introduced by Senator PENROSE in the Senate calls for half a million dollars to buy land and erect a building. It is to be in charge of a commission composed of the Secretary of the Interior, the architect of the Capitol Extension, and the Librarian of Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Following the late discussion relative to our judiciary, the statistical information given herewith may be of passing interest, although I cannot see that it "points a moral," but it does emphasize the fact that the law is far from being an exact science, and that the highly trained legal mind is far from being an exact machine.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I take issue with one point in Mr. Hewitt's letter to Gov. Odell, published this morning in THE TIMES. Mr. Hewitt said: "The State cannot by any possibility prevent the advance of poverty which in the end undermines the security of liberty and property, and ultimately compels a change in the form of government from freedom to despotism."

TO hundreds of visitors who go each Summer to the Adirondacks, Paul Smith is a familiar and interesting character. His keen wit, his shrewd observations, and his quaint phraseology make his stories unique and entertaining. Here is one, as he told it last Summer:

Sherrill Babcock, who has just returned from abroad, told yesterday of his visit and examination of the Boer prisoners' camp at Diyatalawa, Island of Ceylon, during the Summer of the past year. The three camps so far established by the British Government are at St. Helena, Ceylon, and in the Bermudas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tour gentle sarcasm of the efforts of the Tree Planting Association has a charm even for those who know you are dead wrong. It is worth something to see a man holding his ground so cheerfully against both facts and men.

I ACCOMPANIED my friend Silas Larrabee to-day on his quarterly inspection tour of the Ogunquit Zoological Garden, of which he is one of the Trustees. Stopping in front of a bear cage Mr. Larrabee remarked: "That's the Widder Marcot bear."

LAST WEEK I had a boil -- a regular old-fashioned Job's comforter. While I had it I kept a record of all the boil cures that were urged upon me by sympathizing friends, and the publication thereof I hope will result in the speedy cure of all boils in this part of the universe.

President Vernon M. Davis of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children has made public the twenty-seventh annual report of the society's officers. The President in his report states that during the society's twenty-seven years of existence it has given careful attention to 147,085 complaints, in which the welfare of children under the age of sixteen years became the subject of individual investigation.

Even Russia can scarcely afford to disregard the formal protest of the three great Powers over her performances in Manchuria. Yet that protest has now been lodged at Peking against the conclusion of the treaty with China, upon which Russia has been relying as an act of indemnity for her past performances, and for leave to continue them in the future.

"Apropos of the contemplated visit of Prince HENRY to the United States," says a correspondent of THE TIMES, "it is much to be hoped that our people will remain level-headed and not 'slop over' or otherwise make fools of themselves."

Commander B. Whitehouse, Noyal Navy, has lately returned to England on completion of a detailed survey of the British portion of the Victoria Nyanza, undertaken by the Uganda Railway Committee in view of the completion of the railway from Mombasa, and of the consequently enhanced value of the lake and its navigation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As one of the obligations of true hospital- ity consists in making one's guests comfortable in body as well as amused, it behooves the committee in charge of the reception of Prince Henry to see that he is physically well cared for, as well as entertained in mind.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 1. -- Never before in the annals of Baltimore has there been such a continual round of dinner giving as dur- ing the past week. On Monday, before the Bachelor Cotillons, the number of dinners was unusually large, among the handsomest being those given by Mrs. Garrett, Mrs. Joseph Rieman in honor of Miss Helen Christian of Richmond, by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Shoemaker, by Mrs. Inglis, and by Mrs. Albert Shriver.

"You haven't had such a dressing down for years," said Mr. John Burns in a conversational parenthesis to the great audience of workingmen who in Memorial Buildings, Roscoe Street, Bunhill Row, listened with delight to, and cheered with vigor, the long, powerful, and outspoken address to which he treated them.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 1. -- During the first half of the present meeting at Oaklaud, (seventy-five days,) the new California Jockey Club has distributed $207,000 among the horsemen. The smallest purse has been $400, with handicaps of $600 and $700.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Feb. 1. -- The tide of tourist travel has set in from the North and a steady influx of arrivals may be expected at Old Point from now on. On Sunday the number of guests at the palatial Chamberlin was largely in excess of the number of those sojourning here a year ago at this time.

Local steamship men were much interested yesterday over the tentative agreement entered into by the principal lines carrying grain, flour, and provisions from American to English ports to advance rates of freight on these articles and fixing a minimum rate, which enables them to handle such cargoes on a profitable basis.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 1. -- Brook Curry, through the local trotting association, has issued a challenge to the stallion owners of the country for a stallion representative sweepstake race, three years olds, $300 per entry, three heats in five, to meet a get of Silent Brook by Dark Night during the October meeting here.

SALEM, Mass., Feb. 1. -- The manner in which Mayor John F. Hurley of Salem took upon himself the additional duties of City Marshal this afternoon was characteristic of the man. At the special meeting of Aldermen on Friday a motion to reconsider the order removing Col. John W. Hart as City Marshal was defeated, and a second order, empowering Mayor Hurley to act until the appointment of a new Marshal, was instantly passed.

Superintendent Stewart of the Bureau of Buildings made an informal report to President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan yesterday on the contests he has had with the skyscraper contructors to compel observance of the Building Code. President Cantor backed up Superintendent Stewart, and said:

Not in some time has the outside market shown as much activity on Saturday as it did yesterday. A number of stocks showed totals of a thousand shares or more, and many stocks were traded in in smaller amounts. For the most part the day's transactions were made at advancing prices, the net gains in several prominent stocks being substantial.

BOSTON, Feb. 1. -- Money at the Clearing House loaned to-day at 2 1/2 and 2 per cent, and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $24,267,197; balances, $3,187,347. On call, money rules from 3 to 4 per cent., mostly 3 1/2 per cent. Time money is in good supply. Six months collateral loans are passing as low as 3 2/4 per cent., though the quick rate is still 4 per cent.

The Amateur Athletic Union tourney for the billiard championship of America, Class A, commences to-morrow evening in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, the scene of former contests for the championship. This is the most important annual event in billiards, and this year practically every part of the United States is represented by skilled players at the 14.2 game, the rules of which will govern in the present tourney.

This feature of recent railroad progress is exceptionally encouraging, and it would seem to be this character of policy that is now governing operations in the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis -- the Big Four -- railroad, another of the Vanderbilt group, on whose stock has lately attracted attention owing to statements that the New York Central is seeking more direct control of the property.

THE February sky is alive with stars and clustering constellations, including some of the most superb that adorn the whole heavens. The group of stars that forms the Northern Cross, that Constantine hailed as the emblem of Christianity, is situated so far north as to be visible most of the year at some time during the night.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Assemblyman Bennet of New York expresses the opinion, after sounding the sentiment of the Assembly, that his bill providing for local option by election districts for New York and taking from hotels the right to sell liquor on sunday will pass. He estimates that the rural members will be only too glad to do this service for New York City.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The enormous cost and number of wedding presents now showered on society brides have brought out a vigorous protest against what is termed the "unbearable social tax." The Daily Mail declares that "since the advent of American and South African millionaires the tendency toward reckless expense and ostentatious display in wedding presents has steadily grown until now it is nothing less than a social evil."

"Yankees make me tired. I've lived among them for thirty-five years. I forsook my own schoolmates and joined their armies during the war of the rebellion. I've made two fortunes of more than $1,000,000 each, and the thieves have gotten it back again. I've come to Mexico with nothing but brain for assets, and I'm going to make another fortune bigger than any of them."

WACO, Texas, Feb. 1. -- In the midwinter shoot of the Waco Gun Club, now in progress in this city, Rollo O. Heikes of Toledo, Ohio, champion clay pigeon shot, broke the world's record Friday afternoon for clay pigeon shooting. Shooting from the nineteen-yard mark he broke 90 out of 100 and made a straight run of 89. TROTTERS AND PACERS SOLD.

J. Dunton Corr, six feet tall, well built, and good looking, notwithstanding his very red hair, who has lived at 239 West Seventieth Street, was arrested yesterday morning by County Detective Cuff as he was taking a farewell drink in a saloon opposite the pier of the Anchor Line. Detective McNutt was waiting for him at the gangway of the steamer Anchoria, on which Corr was to sail at noon.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 1. -- A dispatch from San Antonio, Texas, says:

According to cabled extracts from leading London newspapers, England is on the verge of a beef famine. It is said that during the past week not a single bullock ar- rived at Deptford Market from the United States, and The London Mail calls for the reopening of the cattle trade with Argen- tina under proper restrictions.
A Bostonian pleads that a new bridge across the Charles River be called the Longfellow Bridge.

On the first day of June next the Polson Iron and Shipbuilding Works of Toronto will deliver to Mr. J. Poupore, a Montreal contractor, the largest dipper dredge in the world. It will cost $62,000 to build.

Although marked by only one or two transactions of the first magnitude, last week's dealings showed that same diversity which, all things considered, has been the most gratifying feature of the market's aspect for some time past.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club's carnival of sports at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night promises to be the biggest indoor meet that has ever been held in this country. Athletic circles in this and other cities are interested in the various contests scheduled to take place, and the entry list is the largest that has ever been received for indoor games.
The letter which we print below may be taken as the view of one of the greatest experts in the wine trade.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mayor Low has doubtless little time to give to open letters, but there are many citizens who, like myself, wish to uphold his hands and very much need some information. We are well aware that many voted for him not because they wanted him in, but because they wanted Tammany out; we are very anxious lest he should lead many to wish to be done with him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading "Topics of the Times" you referred a few days ago to the hypocrisy of the Dutch in respect to their solicitude for freedom and independence, and, furthermore, ask the question, "What about the Achinese?"

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- It begins to look as though Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee regarded the President as a sort of Davy Crockett. Having arrayed themselves against the Administration with respect to the Cuban Reciprocity bill, it was taken for granted they would yield only after a long and severe struggle, but now there seems a probability of an unconditional surrender.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 31. -- The pines are shrouded in white after the snowfall of Wednesday, and Lakewood has taken on a wintry appearance. There is not enough snow on the ground for sleighing, however, and this is a great disappointment to many.

The Indians called rock crystal an "unripe diamond," and until the beginning of the eighteenth century India, was thought to be the only land which produced that precious stone. It was not, therefore, until the discovery of India that the diamond was known to us.

Six Harlem River rowing clubs have organized a handball league, and will begin a tournament on Feb. 16. They are the Metropolitan Rowing Club, Lone Star Boat Club, Wyanoke Boat Club, Union Boat Club, Dauntless Rowing Club, and the Harlem Rowing Club. All have expert handball players among their members, and a lively contest is looked for.

Honors are even in the inter-city racquet contests between New York and Philadelphia. The return meeting between the racquet clubs of the two cities was held yesterday in the Racquet and Tennis Club of this city, and the two home teams won both of their sets. As both of the Philadelphia teams won last Saturday in their city, honors, therefore, ended in a tie.

Officials of the Department of Street Cleaning expressed satisfaction last night with the progress made during the day in the removal of snow from the principal thoroughfares. The aggregate of the number of loads dumped was largely in excess of that of Friday.
