Peter Zimmer, a foreman in the employ of the New York Popcorn and Candy Works, at 20 Desbrosses Street, was taken to Hudson Street Hospital last night suffering from a fractured skull and ten scalp wounds, inflicted with a hatchet found on the scene of the assault. Three of the blows penetrated the skull, but the physicians say he may recover.

District Attorney Jerome has systematized his office so that at the beginning of each day he knows exactly where he stands. He receives daily reports of the work done and the work on hand. This is in charge of Assistant Clerk Thomas Goggins, who furnishes the District Attorney with tabulated reports.

HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- Early to-day the old Anson Wood mansion on Main Street was ruined by fire. Alvah Harrison Webster, the owner, was carrying a lamp through the kitchen, when he stepped on a kitten that was lying near the stove. This startled Mr. Webster, who dropped the lamp, which exploded.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the days to come, when the next generation knows something of the events that followed the birth of the present generation, MacMonnies's statue of Gen. Henry W. Slocum will come in for as much deserved criticism as many of the other atrocities we have in our parks and public places in bronze.

AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 1. -- The third feather- bed hunt of the season was run on Wednes- day behind the Hitchcock hounds. A deer having been turned loose near the new race track, the dogs soon struck the trail, and after a run of four or five miles chased the animal into the paddock at Robinson's Pond.

Members of the alumni of Lehigh University living in and about this city had an enthusiastic meeting on Friday evening, when the Lehigh Club was reorganized under the name of the Lehigh University Club of Greater Now York.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 17. -- Capt. P.R. Kozioff, the explorer of Thibet, who recently reached Irkutsk, made a detailed report of his expedition on arriving at that city. From local papers the following points are taken:

A set of swimming races in the tank of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Fortyfifth Street and Madison Avenue, last night attracted a large entry list from Yale, Columbia, the New York Athletic Club, and the home club, and some interesting competitions resulted. Despite the large attendance of well-known outside swimmers the home club won most of the prizes.

The weekly Clearing House statement yesterday was distinctly favorable except in respect to the loan account, which, because an increase was shown, was by the speculative element regarded as disappointing. Surplus reserves increased $1,290,950, loans increased $19,580,100, specie increased $6,924,000, legal tenders increased $949,500, and deposits increased $26,330,200.

Prof. Lewis Swift, the astronomer, who from the roof of Duffy's cider mill and the tower of the Warner Observatory made himself and Rochester famous, is in the city the guest of his niece, Mrs. A.D. Mott. He came from Marathon, Cortland County, to be a guest at the anniversary supper of the Third Presbyterian Church on Thursday night.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 1. -- Preparations are being made for the troops of this State to be represented in the annual international rifle contest to be held at Sea Girt, N.J, next Summer. A team consisting of twelve men, to be selected from the sharpshooters' ranks of the Governor's Horse Guard, will be entered in the shoot.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 1. -- All the mills of the American Woolen Company, situated in Olneyville, were to-day closed for an indefinite period because of the policy of the weavers in the Weybosset and Riverside Mills pursued in antagonizing the double loom system by endeavoring to precipitate general strike.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- There has been a won- derful change in the aspect of theatrical affairs here, and the majority of the the- atres are now at the flood tide of success. Old favorites like "Kitty Grey," "Sher- lock Holmes," and "Frocks and Frills" continue to draw overflowing audiences, while every one of this week's productions has been successful.

Bellevue and the allied hospitals, Harlem, Gouverneur, and Fordham, yesterday passed from the control of the Charities Department to that of the recently appointed Board of Trustees, under the provisions of the revised charter. The members are Dr. John W. Brannon, President; James K. Paulding, Secretary; Morris Tierney, Samuel Fachs, Martin Stine, Theodore E. Tack, Howard Townsend, and Commissioner of Charities Homer Folks, ex officio.

There have been all sorts and conditions of wagers made since men began to differ in opinion, and the latest worthy of record is unique. Mr. Gard and Mr. Percy Smith were of different opinions as to whether Canadian scholars are better informed on American geography and form of government than American scholars are on Canadian geography and form of government.

Adelaide Ristori. A contrast not without elements inspiring regret in those who take a personal interest in the mimic kings and queens, is suggested by the new honors that have come to Adelaide Ristori. It has already been told in the news how King Victor Emmanuel, with his suite, visited the great Italian actress on the occasion of her eightieth birthday last Wednesday, and how Queen Helena hastened to do her honor.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter's answer in the civil proceedings begun some months ago for the purpose of impounding certain property said to have been secreted by his relatives was filed today in the United States Circuit Court. Other answers were filed by Stanton Carter and Lorenzo D. Carter, his brother and uncle, who deny generally and in detail the charges that they have conspired to conceal the funds.
"I wish to impress on you that I am insured only against total loss. If anything happens, then, please see that it happens in deep water."

The body of a woman was found by two Central Office detectives last night in a room in the rear of the basement at 127 Chrystie Street. There was a deep gash two inches long in her throat and an open penknife was clutched tightly in her right hand, but in such a position that it would have been almost impossible for her to have inflicted the death wound herself.

ILLUSTRATIVE of the gigantic proportions financial dealings in Wall Street have attained within the last few years was the experience of a Western man suddenly grown rich who came to New York and wished to invest his money. While still a poor man in a Western town he became acquainted with a newspaper correspondent whose headquarters were in New York.

SOME modern writers would have us believe that the life of a bird is a life of constant fear; that not only it is all work and no play, but that it is passed in deadly terror. To a bird lover this idea is intolerable, and if accepted would take away all pleasure in making their acquaintance.

Bank stocks generally increased in value in 1901. But nowhere else in this country, probably nowhere else in the world, did this accretion bear so large a proportion to the par value as in the City of New York. Never before in the history of the city banks has there been so great an addition in market value as from Dec. 31. 1900, to Dec. 31, 1901.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It will be found meet, I think, if you will yield up sufficient space for that purpose, that a word be said at this time in behalf of Edward O'Neill, the policeman so ruthlessly and, as it seems to me, so unjustly dismissed, and that some comment be made on the way the new administration has treated him.

THE revival of two of the large-cast operas at the Metropolitan Opera House was the only feature of the musical week calling for special discussion at this time. Mozart's "Il Flauto Magico" was made known once more in special splendor on Monday evening, while on Wednesday night "Les Huguenots" was brought forward again.

A SHORT time ago, in looking over my library, I found stowed away in a corner among ponderous tomes a little book -- little in comparison with its neighbors -- which I recalled having read with absorbing interest during the concluding years of the war with the South, but which in its obscure hiding place during the intervening time had quite passed out of my recollection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read the editorials on the New York Central tunnel in your paper and New York City contemporaries, voicing the conditions of said tunnel, I would like to offer, through your paper as a medium, a suggestion which has occurred to me.

Charles Mosher, fifteen years of age, according to his own statement, gave himself up to the police in the City Hall Station Friday night. He announced that he was lost, helpless, and without money in a storm-swept city. Charles is a handsome and very well dressed boy. The police were impressed with his appearance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The article in THE TIMES Saturday, 18th inst., in reference to the payment of personal taxes by Mr. Richard Croker, on Friday, Jan. 17, and also the payment made on the same day by Mr. John Claflin, eleven minutes prior to the closing of the receiver's office, prompts me to write and ask you to publish the following facts:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 1. -- Rolling Bingham, a member of one of the first families of Missouri, has surrendered to the police of Dallas, Texas, and has asked to be returned here to stand trial on the charge of forging deeds to property in this city twelve years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The man who occupies a seat in a street car while a lady in his presence hangs to a strap presents an interesting study in sociology. Barring the fact that he may be aged or infirm, it will generally be admitted that a well-bred person would yield his seat to the lady.

WOMEN who are up-to-date should have their kitchens finished with teakwood. It is expensive, to be sure, but it has wearing qualities which are ideal. It is teakwood which is used to finish the galleys on fine yachts, because it will not warp. It takes a man always to have everything that is ideal in domestic arrangements.

Helen M. De Long, forty-five years old, who says she is in the real estate business, was arrested in her apartments, at 317 West Fifty-eighth Street, last night and locked up in the West Forty-seventh Street Station. She is charged with selling bogus tickets for fashionable entertainments and musicales which she said were to be held at Carnegie Lyceum and the Waldorf-Astoria.

PARIS, Feb. 1. -- Col. Picquart, the French officer who was prominent in the defense of Capt. Dreyfus, is publishing, in the Grande Revue, a series of articles on the military position of France. He says France has come to the end of her military resources, whereas Germany has ample resources with which to increase her strength.
The War Office has at last decided upon the new military uniforms in detail, and the transformation of the soldier is expected to commence about the middle of the year.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me call the attention of your readers to one view of this question that I have not seen presented.
LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The city's all-absorbing topic this week has been the Kafir boom, which has now extended to the public and is taking on the semblance of genuine speculative reawakening.

With its annual meeting Monday afternoon and a dinner in the evening the oldest business corporation in Philadelphia celebrated the one hundred and forty-third year of its existence. What is now the Presbyterian Ministers' Fund for life insurance was chartered in 1759, and it has been doing business continuously ever since, thus ranking in age by more than eighty years any life insurance company in the country.

Most of those who have watched the course of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee will be agreeably surprised at the signs given by Messrs. GROSVENOR and PAYNE that they really are beginning to understand the public sentiment in regard to our clear duty toward Cuba and our own substantial interests.

The immediate course of the stock market will in all probability be shaped by the decision to be handed down by the Supreme Court in the case of the Northern Securities Company. That decision is expected to-day, and while it will be only on the question of jurisdiction, having nothing to do with the merits of the case, it will be awaited with much interest.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Taxes, the speed of automobiles, and employers' liability are among the subjects that will have the attention of the State Senate this week. The Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill and the Krum foreign corporation measure, which has been so much amended that it is now practically a new bill, are side by side in general orders, and will probably be taken up Tuesday morning.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The newspaper Vortland, says the Copenhagen correspondent of The Times, publishes sensational disclosures in regard to the sale of the Danish West Indies. It asserts that the project was initiated by private capitalists, including "Senator H. Rogers," who frankly declared to the secret agent for Danish capitalists and the late Premier Horring, "For me the whole question is a business matter.

The annual memorial service for the deceased members of the association of the veterans of the Seventh Regiment was held yesterday afternoon at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The front of the church was reserved for the members of the association, but there was no other formality, as the members were in civilian costume, and they assembled without military ceremonial.

With the evident co-operation of some persons outside, two burglars under indictment in the Queens County Jail, in Long Island City, escaped from it last evening. They are William Travis, alias William O'Neill, and William Watson, one of his pals. They apparently had the matter well planned, at least one of them having been busy during the afternoon perfecting the plan of escape.

THE BAGDAD RAILWAY CONCESSION -- The so-called Bagdad Railway convention, which has just been signed in Constantinople by representatives of the German Anatolia Railway Company and the Turkish Government has apparently been imparted to Berlin in an entirely different form from the way it was imparted to the rest of the world.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 2 -- That the Inter-State Commerce Commission is itself to blame for the rate cutting which it condemns in its latest annual report is the assertion made by Walker D. Hines, First Vice President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company, in a pamphlet which he has just issued.

The Central Federated Union yesterday look up the question of re-enactment of the Chinese exclusion law, which expires next May, and which is agitating the labor unions all over the country. The Central Federated Union is now attached to the American Federation of Labor, which has forwarded a red-letter circular to all labor organizations, asking them to unite in supporting two bills now before Congress, known as Senate bill 2,960 and House bill 330.

James Reid, an English soldier, who was seventy-two years old, who had served through the Crimean campaign with the Royal Artillery, and had distinguished himself for bravery at Sebastopol and Balaklava, succumbed to asphyxiation by gas yesterday morning in his home at the rear of his store, at 926 Amsterdam Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thank you, Mr. Carnegie, for helping to keep green the memory of Peter Cooper, St. Peter, as Dr. Collier affectionately and rightly styled him. Dollar for dollar and foot for foot, no institution in New York is as useful as Cooper Union. It gives the right aid to people who want to help themselves and who do not want charity.

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The heaviest snowstorm yet experienced this Winter began here early this afternoon and continued until dark, covering the streets of the city to a depth of several inches, seriously impeding traffic and forcing the electric street cars to suspend service.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Opponents of tariff reductions for Cuba's benefit apparently are not satisfied with the easy victory they won in the Ways and Means Committee. They fear the determination of the President to push to success his original plan, and accordingly a compromise proposition has been laid before him.

The northern borough of the City of New York, which takes in a large part of Westchester County, is not yet made familiar to the citizens of the country at large which contributes to the great city, and they do not see its position or its character very clearly in their minds, while especially the origin of the name is the subject of frequent queries.

It was easy yesterday for those so inclined to get drinks in any part of the City of New York. A side-door business was done everywhere. As on the four prior Sundays of the year, no orders were sent out to "close things up," and saloon proprietors attended to their Sunday trade as usual.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The bad odor into which Tammany has fallen in the last few years, and which is scarcely less bad than in the time of Tweed and Barnard, ought to be availed of to make an end once for all of the organization as political marplot and general nuisance in civic affairs.

W.H. Sigourney, the champion amateur billiard player of the Pacific Coast, who is to play C.S. Schmitt, the champion of New England, in the opening game to-night in the 14.2 tourney for the championship of Class A at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, played two practice matches in that clubhouse yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 2 -- Despite the recent conferences between William Keeler and the Baltimore baseball management and the reported offer to the famous player of an interest with his friend "Joe" Keliey in the club ownership. "Ned" Hanlon said to-day that he was almost certain Keeler would wear a Brooklyn uniform the coming season.
Can a man who knows himself to be at the point of death use a vulgar slang expression? Would a dying man gasp, as almost his last words: "You bet your life ! "

Marston T. Bogert, the Controller of Sports at Columbia, has issued an open letter to the students defining his position and powers, and explaining to the students the present status of affairs, together with an outline of the rules to be in force for the remainder of the year. The communication is as follows:

CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 2 -- Policeman Mark Allen was shot and killed at mid-night last night by Albert Vest, a negro whom he had placed under arrest for quarreling on the street with a negro woman. The negro shot Allen in the leg, and as the officer fell to the sidewalk Vest fired two more shots into his body, death resulting shortly after.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As to your article, "More Bridges Necessary," in to-day's issue, in which you quote Bridge Commissioner Lindenthal at length, may I inquire as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The monthly summary of internal commerce, issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics, shows that there have been extraordinary gains in the trade movements of most of the country's staple commodities and losses in a few, but on the whole there were in 1901 conspicuous gains over the preceding year.
With the junior foils competition finished, the season of fencing is well started, and for the next three months many events have been arranged.
"The Spiritual Life of the Poor" was the Subject of Prof. Felix Adler's address before the Society of Ethical Culture at the Carnegie Lyceum yesterday morning. He said, in part:

DANVERS, Mass., Feb. 2 -- Inquiry here throws no light upon the supposed connection of Harry A. Macomber with the woman who was found apparently murdered in a Chrystse Street house in New York last night, although the letter of recommendation found at the time in a dresser in the room was easily traced.

BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 2 -- In this section yachting people regard the appointment of Capt. Charlie Barr as skipper of the 70-foot Mineola for next season as a step toward placing the same skipper at the wheel of the Constitution, if she is selected as a candidate to defend the cup in 1903. August Belmont, the owner of the Mineola, is the head of the syndicate that had Constitution built.`

It had been hoped by Commissioner Woodbury of the Street Cleaning Department and his aids that the work of removing the snow from the streets of Manhattan would have been Practically completed yesterday, and great headway made in the streets of the Brooklyn business district.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 2 -- The International Chess Congress opened here this morning, when a meeting of all the competitors and the committee was held for the purpose of adopting a code of rules to govern the tournament, which begins tomorrow. The committee announced that the following twenty-two players would enter the contest: ...

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 3 -- The most disastrous fire in the history of Waterbury is now, 2 o'clock A.M., raging in the business centre of the city. All the fire-fighting apparatus that Hartford, New Haven, Bridgeport, Torrington, and Naugatuck could spare is here aiding the local department, but the combined efforts of the fire fighters seem unable to check the progress of the flames.

Athletic champions past and present are to comnete to-night in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club's carnival of sports at Madison Square Garden. The event which seems to be the most interesting is the two-mile relay race between college teams. Yale, Columbia, Georgetown, and the University of Pennsylvania all have crack teams to represent them, and the record for the distance, 8.08, stands for a good chance of being supplanted.

NORWICH, Conn., Feb. 2 -- As a result of a disagreement about working on Sunday Peter Long, a gardener, shot his employer, Mrs. Abraham Plaut, a wealthy resident of West Thames Street, to-day. Her wound is not thought to be dangerous.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- If the plan indorsed at the Good Roads Convention in this city is carried into execution, this State will be called upon to issue bonds amounting to $20,000,000 for the immediate installation of a system of road improvement, which means the construction of up-to-date highways that will connect every city of the State.

The Imperial German Government has just ridden to a fall in the Reichstag on a matter the relation of which to the United States may not have been obvious to many who read the cable dispatch. The Agrarians defeated the Government by insisting that foreign exporters who send goods to Germany shall legalize their bills of lading before the German Consul in such countries as demand similar legislation from German exporters.

"Scientific batters are rare, but batting can be taught, and any player who will conscientiously apply himself can learn just as he can learn anything else," said an old-time baseball player recently, who at the same time was deploring the miserable outlook the National game has in this city for the coming season.
LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The recent gales have been succeeded by heavy snowstorms in Western Europe, and shipping along the coast of Spain has suffered considerable damage.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Many women are expected to be in court to-morrow to attend the trial of Mrs. Mabel Maines, who will probably be called upon to answer to an indictment charging her with murder, the alleged victim being her little stepdaughter, Gwendolin, aged two years.

We have no desire to be exacting toward the new administration in the matter of street cleaning. We quite appreciate the difficulties with which the Commissioner has to deal. They are numerous and varied, and it is entirely possible that they are at present insuperable.

Nearly 1,300 men have applied to the Municipal Civil Service Commission for examination for appointment as Sanitary Inspectors and Inspectors of Light and Ventilation in the new Tenement House Department. So unprecedented is the number to be examined that the Grand Central Palace has been leased for next Friday, when the examinations will be held.
An earnest and timely plea for school declamation is made by a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who has noted the increasing tendency of the public schools to abandon elocutionary training.

The identity of the woman found dead on Saturday in the basement of 127 Chrystie Street was established last night by the police of the Eldridge Street Station. She was Minnie Clark, thirty-three years old, and came here from St. Cloud, Minn., some time ago in company with her husband, William B. Clark, and her daughter.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 2 -- An abstract of the nineteenth annual report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for 1901, transmitted to the Legislature by Commissioner of Labor John McMackin as part of his first annual report, shows a uniform growth of labor organizations, both in number and membership; during the past five years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the proper authorities are sifting the evidence, or endeavoring to find it, with reference to the awful explosion at the Park Avenue tunnel, may it not be pertinent to inquire the necessity of using such heavy charges of explosives, which now and then seem to shake up old Mother Earth in a very disagreeable -- and with this latest example -- stupendously dangerous manner?

MANILA, Feb. 2 -- Manila is intensely interested as to what action Congress will take concerning the Philippine Islands. Ordinary local politics have been forgotten, and two parties have been formed -- the optimists and the pessimists. Some think that life and property are unsafe outside the towns of the islands, while others ridicule such ideas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Gov. Taft continued his statement before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day regarding the conditions existing in those islands.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Feb. 1 is a letter from a correspondent at New Rochelle signed "B." on "overstudy in public schools," "B.'s" idea is absurd, I think; in fact, it appears to me additional evidence of commercialism in the public school system -- advocating a reduction of service while continually calling for larger appropriations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- It is understood to be the purpose of the State Department to make the cession of proper coaling stations on the isthmus a condition of the undertaking to build an isthmian canal. This is one of the factors that will be taken into consideration in making the final choice of routes.

-- A correspondent of The Electrical World and Engineer, himself an experienced electrician who was once made unconscious for several hours by a shock from a two-thousand-volt alternator, and has seen several others revived after experiences which left them apparently dead, raises anew the disquieting question whether the criminals executed in this State are killed in "the chair" or later by the doctors who perform the autopsy.

The Board of City Record met yesterday. Mayor Low presided. Supervisor Cowen of The City Record suggested that a supplemental edition of the civil list containing the names and facts about city officials be printed so that the typographical errors in the list printed on Jan. 31 could be corrected.

A panic was averted narrowly in the Waldorf-Astoria, several runaways were caused, and two men were injured seriously yesterday afternoon by a blast in a new cellar at the northwest corner of Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, where Clarence L. Smith Co. are excavating on the site of the old Stewart mansion, directly opposite the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- Money was in good demand to-day, owing to the heavy repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were quiet. There was little business transacted on the Stock Exchange. Kafirs opened firm, with some advances. Later the activity relaxed, and they became easier, partly in consequence of the lack of Continental Bourse advices, owing to the prostration of telegraph and telephone wires by the storm.

At the February meeting of the Trustees of Columbia University, held yesterday afternoon, the final plans for the installation of President Butler were adopted. The committee set apart April 18th and 19th as holidays in their programme, and those days will be given up entirely to the celebration.

From 8 o'clock last night until midnight from 500 to 600 athletes competed for honor and trophies in the Madison Square Garden. The great indoor meet under the auspices of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club met with unqualified success and the management developed an alacrity that never allowed the interest to flag for an instant.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Owing to objection by the Faculty, the baseball team of Columbia University will not be allowed to have the services of E. M. Lewis as coach this season. Mr. Lewis is now an instructor in elocution at the university, and it is on the ground that it would not be compatible with his position as a member of the Faculty to be a professional coach that the objection is raised.

Mme. Marcella Sembrich gave at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon the song recital which was originally announced for Jan. 23. It will be recalled that at that time the entertainment had to be given up because the famous artist had sneezed too hard and ruptured a small blood vessel in a vocal chord.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Assemblyman Palmer (Dem.) has introduced a concurrent resolution providing for a number of important changes in Article VI. of the Constitution. It provides for six additional Justices who shall reside in and be chosen by the electors of the First and Second Judicial Districts, three in the First District and three in the Second District.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 3 -- A revised list of the heaviest losers by the fire and the insurance carried is as follows. This does not include the losses to scores of families of whom no accurate estimate can be made:

The opening games of the Harlem Navy Bowling League were rolled last night on Thum Kablsdorf's Harlem Palace alleys between the teams of the Friendship and the Waverley Boat Clubs and the Dauntless Rowing Club. The Friendship team, the champions of the past two years, won both their games, the Waverleys won one and lost one, and the Dauntless team lost two games.

Fire Commissioner Thomas Sturgis yesterday sent to a number of theatres which had been reported to him as having disregarded the law against allowing persons to stand a circular letter in which he informed them that if the violation was repeated it was his duty to take steps to prevent its recurrence.

The West End Association decided by resolution last evening to request the Manhattan Railway Company as well as the Metropolitan Street Railway Company to provide some relief to the residents of the west side from the crush they are compelled to endure during the rush hours.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 3 -- The American full-rigged ship L. Schepp drove ashore at Point Lookout, Long Beach, this morning, and is hard and fast aground about two miles from the point where the British steamship Cavour lies in her bed of sand, into which she plunged on Saturday night during the snowstorm.
What, it is said, will be the fastest oceangoing yacht in the world, will be launched next Tuesday from the works of the Burlee Dry Dock Company, at Port Richmond, S.I.

The Rev. Dr. George C. Lorimer, who reebently came from the Berkeley Temple in Boston to take charge of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church in this city, and the Rev. Dr. Robert McKenzie, the new pastor of the Rutgers Riverside Presbyterian Church, were the guests of honor and principal speakers at a reception given last evening at the Hotel Savoy by the Presbyterian Union.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were large, and unusual interest was centred in the trading on account of the unusually large sales of Northern Securities. Prices showed considerable irregularity, although at the end of the day quotations were in most cases somewhat above the final figures of Saturday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 3 -- The City of Waterbury stands to-day devastated by fire. The loss, according to the estimates of the most conservative business and insurance men, will run close to $2,5000,000. With all this great property loss there has been, strange to say, no loss of life, and but few accidents have been recorded.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Senator Ahearn of New York to-night introduced, in the Senate a bill to compel all gas companies in cities of the first class to place on all gas meters automatic valves to prevent the escape of gas in case of fire. In commenting on his bill, Senator Ahearn said:

The property 4 to 10 West Thirty-first Street, 97 by 100, which was purchased from the Alvord estate several weeks ago by the New York Realty Corporation, has been resold by the latter to William C. Dewey of Springfield, Mass. Negotiations were conducted through Broker Leopold Weil.

The announcements of Mr. ROBERT W. DE FOREST, Commissioner of the Tenement House Department, relative to the filling of the original vacancies in the inspection staff of his department, are an instructive object lesson in practical civil service reform which may be studied with advantage by those having similar responsibilities.

May Edouin, assisted by Fred Roberts, Leads the bill of continuous vaudeville at Proctor's Twenty-third Street, presenting "All in the Family." Shean and Warren were second features, their travesty being "Kidding the Captain." Kitamura's Japs, the Powers brothers, and Mr. and Mrs. Jimmie Barry are among the other numerous entertainers.

Professional Wall Street devoted most of its attention yesterday morning to forecasting a favorable decision from the United States Supreme Court in the Northern Securities case, and market prices were made measurably buoyant. When at noon postponement of the decision was announced, quotations forthwith fell sharply -- the price of Northern Securities stock itself dropping 4 or 5 points in the curb market, from which it has not yet graduated.

Coroner Goldenkranz and a jury at 10 o'clock this morning will begin the inquest into the explosion of dynamite in Park Avenue a week ago. Coroner Goldenkranz will rely on the assistance of Assistant Corporation Counsel Hart for legal advice in his conduct of the inquest. Major Ira A. Shaler, the contractor, who is out under $10,000 bail, will be called upon to testily, as will be Joseph Bracken.

Miss Rachael Martense, who is probably the oldest woman in Brooklyn, yesterday celebrated the one hundred and first anniversary of her birth at her home. Linden Boulevard and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. She had many callers during the day, a number of whom brought her flowers. Miss Martense, despite her great age, continues physically active, and her mental faculties remain unimpaired.

Whether William Marsh Rice, the octogenarian millionaire, with whose murder Albert T. Patrick is charged, was chloroformed to death, as the prosecution claims, or whether he died of heart disease, as the defense maintains, was the question opposing counsel contended over before Recorder Goff and the jury at the beginning yesterday of the third week of Patrick's trial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The work to which the Democrats in Congress have devoted themselves -- that of making the Philippine question the paramount issue in the Congressional elections -- was materially accelerated by this afternoon's debate in the Senate. The speeches on both sides had the ring of stump speeches, and there was much talk about the willingness of each speaker to "go to the people on this issue."

Two of the largest, stanchest, and most powerful sea-going tugs of tills port -- the Edward J. Berwind, 133 tons, and the E.S. Atwood, a 04-tonner -- were caught in the gale that swept over the New Jersey and Long Island coasts on Sunday afternoon. Within an hour the seas had battered them to pieces and sent them to the bottom three miles east of the Sandy Hook Lightship.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 -- A renewal of demand for Union Traction was one of the points of interest in the local stock market to-day. Good buying of Philadelphia Electric 4s was another. It is believed that a considerable part of the money realized from the assessment on the stock will be used to retire some of the securities in order to reduce fixed charges.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- At the Adelphi Theatre last night "Arizona," by Augustus Thomas, had a most enthusiastic reception. There seems to be little doubt that it will be a success. The stalls and dress circle were filled with patriotic Americans, but a significant and important fact was that the loudest applause came from the gallery and pit.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 3 -- Continued strength and activity in the G.B.S. Brewing issues and in the United Railways group formed the backbone of to-day's trading. The whole list was in sympathy with their strength. Persistent bullish talk on both groups has stimulated confident buying and the bonds and stocks both are advancing on the ready absorption.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 3. -- The Gould interests are believed to be behind a bill to incorporate the Baltimore, Pittsburg and Western Railroad which was introduced in both Houses to-night. It provides for the construction of a railroad from Baltimore City, at tidewater, to the Maryland and Pennsylvania boundry near Kmmittsburg, and grants permission for the line to run southwesterly from Baltimore to a point on the Chesapeake Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A situation that would have been vastly embarrassing to the Republicans of the Ways and Means Committee of the House, and that was wholly unexpected, was saved to-day by a single vote, when by seven against six the majority barely checked an attempt to attach as a rider to the War Tax Reduction bill the provisions of the Babeock bill for a reduction in the tariff rates on steel and iron.
The stories printed on Sunday in the "Man in the Street portion" of the Magazine Supplement, to which the prizes were awarded are as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The first officer of the French ship Chanaral was landed at Falmouth yestecday. He is the sole survivor of the crew of twenty-two men of the vessel, which was capsized off Ushant, (off the coast of Brittany.)

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- A bill increasing the power of the State Racing Commission was introduced to-night by Senator Elsberg. The measure provides that when an association intending to establish a race track shall file its certificate it shall specify whether it is proposed to conduct trotting or running, or steeplechase race meetings.

Gun metal hat pins, perfectly plain, but in different styles, round ball heads, long slender pointed heads, and various others, can be found for 95 cents apiece. There is nothing more satisfactory in the long run than these pins. They are strong and wear well and they are always in good taste.

The last week of the season has not much promise of great gayety, as far as large entertainments go. There were last evening only a few dinners and the opera. Among the afternoon receptions were those of Mrs. Gouverneur Morris Carnochan and Mrs. D. Eugene Parsons.
Judge Cowing in Part I. of General Sessions yesterday delivered this charge to the February Grand Jury when he swore them in, after defining the laws under which they must act:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A circular letter has been received by members of the Senate from Gen. Wood, Military Governor of Cuba, urging concessions on Cuban sugar coming into the United States. It is dated at Havana Jan. 30. Gen. Wood says:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The United States Supreme Court adjourned to-day until Feb. 24. The court did not announce a decision in the Northern Pacific merger case, and that case now necessarily goes over until after the reconvening of the court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Republican members of the House of Representatives held a caucus in the hall of the House to-night to consider a line of policy to be adopted concerning the alleged disfranchisement of voters in the South. The caucus lasted from 8 o'clock until about 11, when it was determined to adjourn for one week to consider more fully the different propositions brought forward.

The elite of the First Assembly District to the number of 400 attended the annual theatre party, banquet and ball of the Daniel E. Finn Association last night. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont came especially from Washington to attend. From the boxes and best seats in the American Theatre the guests of the association witnessed a special performance of "Cyrano de Bergerac."

Nothing in recent history is of a keener psychological interest than the demeanor of the Empress Dowager of China since her return to her capital. Most Occidental readers may be inclined to believe that those were crocodile tears with which she bedewed Mrs. CONGER, upon the occasion, unprecedented in Chinese history, upon which she received foreign women as guests and social equals.

The attempts of Gov. ODELL to usurp control of the judiciary constitute an assault upon the fundamental principles of the State Government, and are manifestly contrary to the spirit of the Constitution. A complete separation of the Executive and the judicial departments is one of the familiar principles of the American system of government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to contribute a fact or two to the discussion on the relative cost of living suggested by Mr. Carnegie's remarks. The question is one of fact, not of theories, and it ought not to be difficult to decide it. But, unfortunately, with many persons, when facts do not harmonize with their theories -- so much the worse for the facts!

Governor Odell was commended and the leaders of the Kings County Republican organization was severely criticised at a meeting of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club held last night in the Johnston Building, at Nevins Street and Flatbush Avenue. The Guden-Dady controversy, the proposed reappointment of Naval Officer Robert A. Sharkey, and other matters affecting the party in the county engaged the attention of the meeting.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- The subject of Christian Science was debated in the Reichstag to-day.

W.H. Sigourney won the opening game in the Amateur Athletic Union's Class A 14.2 billiard tournament last night in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Opposed to Sigourney was C.S. Schmitt, the New England champion. Sigourney is the undisputed leader of the amateurs on the Pacific Coast.

The Finance Committee of the Prince Henry Executive Committee will meet at the Chamber of Commerce to-day to discuss and settle upon some method of raising by private subscription the funds for defraying the expenses of receiving and entertaining the Prussian Prince. Practically nothing has so far been determined in regard to finances yet, except that the Board of Aldermen will probably not be asked to vote any appropriation for this purpose.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senate Bill No. 372, in relation to the payment of State fees and taxes by corporations, has been reported to the Senate without opportunity being given for a public hearing. It is a complete change from the law, which, substantially in its present form, has been in force for nearly twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Fifteen votes were mustered in the Senate to-day for Mr. Stewart's amendment to the bill to increase the salaries of Federal Judges. The amendment was to increase the salaries of Senators and Representatives to $7,500 a year, beginning March 4, 1903. These fifteen were the men who favored the plan and were not afraid to say so.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- The trial of the charges against Sheriff Guden will begin before Gov. Odell to-morrow. A large delegation from Brooklyn is expected here. Gov. Odell said this evening that no subpoena had yet been issued for Michael J. Dady. Col. Dady is expected to arrive in New York from Havana on Feb. 7.

It would be curious, if it were not so familiar, to notice how soon a "burning question" may cease to burn, or even to smolder. During the first two Sundays of Mayor Low's administration, every eye was fixed, so to speak, on the side door. Last Sunday most eyes were turned in other directions.

A genuine surprise awaited the lovers of hockey who gathered in the Clermont Skating Rink, Brooklyn, last night to see the teams of the Crescent Athletic Club and the Short Hills Club line up in opposition. The match was hotly fought and was close and interesting from start to finish, and the surprise was furnished when the Short Hills players triumphed over the home team by 5 to 3.

District Attorney Jerome stood before Magistrate Cornell yesterday morning to answer to the charge brought by Coroner's Clerk John Murray of felonious assault The Magistrate waited until after 10 o'clock, the hour of opening, and then Murray's name was called. There was no answer, and the court waited a few minutes.

Flower brokers took all the People's Gas stock offered yesterday, and continued to express their confidence in the property as a 6 per cent, dividend investment security. Levy Mayer, general counsel of the Ogden Gas Company, who was in the city Yesterday, said, apropos of the situation in Chicago:
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Montagu White, representative of the Boer republics in America, in commenting upon the reply of the British Government to the Dutch note, said to-day:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2.500 and Is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 4 -- From 9 to 12 o'clock to-day the bodies of John and Edward Biddle were exposed to public view at an undertaking establishment on the South Side, and several thousand curious persons passed before the coffins. As early as 8 o'clock crowds began to gather, and despite the cold they awaited patiently the opening of the doors.

The human sense of proportion is often woefully wrong. Things accounted of minor importance are at length discovered to be of serious moment to everybody, and then, late but earnestly, we attend to them.

With a view to establishing another outlet from the bridge for trolley cars, the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company is planning to lay tracks across the so-called Brooklyn Bridge Plaza, in Brooklyn. This plaza, as it is officially described, cost the old City of Brooklyn something like $3,000,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 4 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at par. Exchanges, $35,031,319; balances, $3,701,412. Money on call is loaning freely at from 2 1/2 to 4 per cent. Time loans range from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent., mostly at the latter figure.

It is impossible, we should say, for even the most hardened pro-Boer to read the correspondence between the British and Dutch Governments without admitting that the overtures made from The Hague were predestined to futility and that the British Government could not, with dignity or with intelligence, have taken any other course than it has taken.

The first statement to which Secretary SHAW has to affix his signature is a very different one from that which Mr. GAGE was obliged to sign on his entry into the department, now nearly five years ago.

A large number of American women whose circumstances permit them now and then to travel in foreign countries have signed petitions praying for relief from the annoyance, indignities, and insults of passenger baggage examination as now conducted under the American protective system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- It is said a number of the members of the Ways and Means Committee are extremely anxious that the President shall "let them down easy," and that, with this desire in their hearts, they have asked him to send a special message to Congress urging the passage of a Cuban relief measure.
Fully 350 members of the General Alumni Society of the New York University met together at the Savoy Hotel last night for their first triennial dinner.

The dancing classes are having their last meetings before Lent, and last evening the last Junior Cotililon was danced. Tuesday seems to be a favorite day for dinners. Among those entertaining last evening were Mrs. Astor, James Henry Smith, Mrs. Pembroke Jones, and Mrs. James B. Martin. There will be among other entertainments to-day a reception to be given by Mrs. Liester del Garcia.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The trial of Sheriff Guden of Kings County was begun to-day before Gov. Odell. The Executive Chamber was crowded. All of the spectators were Brooklynites, save the few State officials and members of the Legislature who dropped in out of curiosity.
W.E. F.B. Taylor have sold for the estate of Effingham H. Nichols, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 620 Fifth Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets, 25 by 100.

Unusually heavy shipments of gold were engaged by a number of banking houses yesterday for transportation on the steamship L'Aquitaine, leaving this port to-morrow. The total shipment so far announced will amount to $3,750,000, and the destination will be Paris. This will make a total of $5,210,000 shipped since the first of the year.

When Prince Henry of Prussia reaches this port on the steamship Kronprinz Wilhelm, the new pier at West Thirty-fourth Street, on which he will land, will be elaborately equipped with electric lights and the interior of the pier shed will be converted into a palm garden. Dock Commissioner Hawkes gave his sanction yesterday to the desired alterations in the pier.

There is a combination which is very pretty to be seen in some of the gowns just now, pale blue with pale gray, blue chiffon with frocks of silk or crepe de chine. One gown of this kind has the vest of the blue chiffon and deep puffs in the lower edges of the elbow sleeves. This is a pretty gown in every way.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- The North American will say to-morrow:

The occupants of the five-story private apartment house at 69 East Fifty-fourth Street are greatly frightened over what appears to be a determined plan to burn them out. Two fires have been discovered in the house within the past two weeks, both of which, it is claimed, are of incendiary origin.

The first case to reach the courts in the present movement to enforce regulations for safety in playhouses win be that of the American Theatre. This morning the management of this house will appear at the Tenth Municipal District Court, Fifty-fourth Street, near Eighth Avenue, to answer to the charge of disregarding the safety ordinance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Secretary Shaw's first communication on financial legislation is contained in a letter to Representative Sulzer (Dem.) of New York concerning the latter's bill to deposit Government funds at interest in National banks throughout the country.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The Assembly Excise Committee gave a hearing this afternoon on the bill of Assemblyman Phipps amending the excise law, to prohibit side doors to saloons and the transfer or assignment of licenses in second-class cities, and to increasing the license fee in New York City from $800 to $1,000 per year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President Roosevelt is giving a much larger share of his attention to the Schley appeal than is generally realized. He recently asked Secretary Long for a copy of the proceedings at the court of inquiry, and is now engaged in reading it carefully page by page.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Babcock (Rep.) of Wisconsin is greatly exhilarated by the closeness of the vote in the Ways and Means Committee when an attempt to make his tariff reduction scheme a rider on the war tax reduction bill was defeated by only one vote. He is in an uncompromising mood, and is determined to succeed in getting his proposition for the reduction of the tariff rates on steel and iron reported.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- State Commissioner of Excise Cullinan to-day reported that an order has been granted by the Supreme Court revoking the liquor tax certificate issued to Max Micha of Coney Island, upon the ground that he trafficked in liquor on Sunday in violation of the liquor tax law.
Mr. Samuel Franko's series of three concerts of early music came to an end yesterday afternoon at the Lyceum Theatre. The programme was as follows:

The Board of Aldermen approved important matters at the session yesterday. Street Cleaning Commissioner Woodbury appeared before the board and made a speech. When he concluded his argument all the members were convinced that the city would be constantly menaced if the Commissioner's ideas were not carried out.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 -- When the local market to-day received news from New York to the effect that more gold had been engaged for export, the bull momentum gathered together in the past few days naturally broke into profit taking at different points. The group that most keenly felt this realizing was the G.B.S. Brewing issues.

Borough President Cantor received last evening a report from Building Superintendent Perez M. Stewart, inclosing a report from the Building Inspectors concerning the condition of the buildings surrounding the scene of the Park Avenue explosion. The report of the Inspectors is as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- In the House of Commons' on Monday evening Major Arthur Hamilton Lee (Conservative, British Attache with the United States Army during the Spanish-American war and later British Military Attache at Washington,) said that Great Britain had received the offer of the services of the chief horse expert of the United States Army as adviser in the purchase of American horses for the British Army.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The communications between the British and Dutch Governments in regard to the South African war were made public yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 4 -- The schooner Edith L. Allen, which was ashore on Brigantine Shoal, was floated this afternoon and started for New York in tow of a tug.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- At the opening of to-day's session of the Senate Mr. Kean (Rep., N.J.,) presented the credentials of John F. Dryden, elected to succeed the late Senator Sewell of New Jersy for the unexpired term of six years, beginning on March 4, 1901. Mr. Dryden was escorted to the desk of the President pro tem., who administered to him the oath of office.

When the three barges that were in tow of the Chesapeake and Ohio Coal Company's tug Richmond broke away from that craft in the gale of Sunday night it marked the termination of the earthly existence of certainly nine and probably thirteen persons, twelve of whom composed the crews of the barges, while the last and thirteenth was a woman, Mrs. Miller, the wife of the Captain of the Antelope, one of the barges.

Alderman John J. Dietz of the Thirty-fifth Aldermanic District, James J. Frawley, Tammany leader of the Thirty-second Assembly District, and a man known as "Schemer" Ryan, were yesterday charged by State Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh with bribery and aiding and abetting false registration and illegal voting.

-- More trouble! One of our readers, "as a Swiss," resents our recent reference in this column to the Swiss mercenaries who before and long after the beginning of the last century habitually took the pay of Europe's big and little despots, including the most despicable of them, and thus delayed the dawn of liberty for many years.

Business in the outside market yesterday although not as active as on Monday, continued to attract attention and presented several interesting features. The sharp movements in Standard Oil, following the announcement of an unexpectedly large dividend, were naturally closely watched, and interest in Northern Securities was also large.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Gov. Taft continued his narrative before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day. Referring to his testimony of yesterday, he said he reared he had given a wrong impression concerning the part the army had played in bringing the Philippine insurrection to an end, but if so, this was due to the fact that he could not present a correct impression of the whole situation from one point of view.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4 -- At least six men were killed and as many more injured in a fire which broke out to-night in the fivestory stone and brick building located at 314 Chestnut Street, occupied by the American Tent and Awning Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is avowed by those actively engaged in organizing the Greater New York Democracy that it is their purpose to supplant Tammany Hall as the regular Democratic organization of the City of New York. This is desirable. Tammany is not a Democratic organization --" on the contrary, quite the reverse."

Lewis Nixon, the new leader of Tammany Hall, was introduced to a large crowd of his supporters last night in the Tammany burger, leader of the Tenth Assembly District, 94 Second Avenue. Mr. Nixon received a hearty welcome from 2,000 members of the organization, and at the close of his brief speech a line was formed and he shook hands with all in turn.

Albert Lewis, a colored man, who disappeared from the Queens County Jail at the same time that the burglars Travis and Watson escaped last Sunday, was captured in Seigel's saloon, in the Bowery, near First Street, last night by Under Sheriff Bennett and Keeper McGowan, who was suspended as a result of the jail delivery.

Yesterday's security market was distinctly strong, in the face of a variety of rumors and developments which ordinarily might have exerted depressing influence. A recession in the price of crude copper and downward manipulation of Copper Trust quotations, the announcement of Great Britain's rejection of the Netherlands peace proposals, and an unexpected engagement of approximately $4,000,000 of gold for export induced no general liquidation.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The Times prints a letter from Count Adalbert Sternberg, who took part in the Boer campaign, and who declares that the treatment he has received from the British press and official and non-official Englishmen leaves him no cause to be an Anglophile.

There was very serious business yesterday in the Coroners' Court, but an element of mirthfulness and cheerful disregard of ordinary legal procedure. District Attorney Jerome was absent, having sent his regrets, saying that he believed the Grand Jury would scrupulously avoid any conflict with the Coroner.

The more the question of the purchase of remounts for the British Army in South Africa is gone into, the graver does the scandal appear. It is the more significant because no attempt seems to have been made in the House of Commons to "make political capital" out of the business.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The vote on the Lunacy bill will be taken to-morrow. At the conclusion of the debate on the bill to-day the friends of the measure announced that they had 29 votes in its favor, not counting absentees. This is 3 votes more than the required number. Only three Republican Senators are expected to vote against the bill.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The one hundred and fifth convocation of the Grand Chapter of Royal Arch Masons was held in the Masonic Temple this morning. In his address M.E.J. Harris Balston, Grand High Priest, spoke of the deaths of members that have occurred in the year, dwelling particularly on the death of Companion William McKinley.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- It was common talk among members of the House to-day that there was small danger of attributing undue significance to the strong demand for tariff revision made yesterday in the Ways and Means Committee by those who voted for the Babcock rider reducing the rates in the iron and steel schedule.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Senator Sullivan to-day introduced a bill which provides that every passenger on a street railroad car shall be entitled to a seat, which shall he not less than fourteen inches in width. No fare shall be demanded or collected of a passenger who has not been provided with such a seat.

The New York Court of Appeals has rendered a decision as wise as it is righteous in the case of one SARAH C. SMITH against the Kingston Street Railway Company. Mrs. SMITH was alighting from one of the cars of the defendant corporation when the bottom of her skirt caught on what is described in the argument of counsel as a "plunger."

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- District Attorney Jerome arrived here to-night with his excise bill, and registered at the Ten Eyck. Shortly after he started for the Fort Orange Club in company with Assemblyman Julius Seymour. As they went through the grillroom of the Ten Eyck they almost ran into Senator John Raines.

A match in the Athletic Bowling League tournament was rolled on the Knickerbocker Athletic Club alleys last night between the home team and that of the Newark Athletic Club, the home bowlers winning two of the three games. In the Commercial League series the team of Joseph Wild Co. made a new high team score of 956.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 4 -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pittsburg Plate Glass Company was held to-day, and the old Board of Directors, with six members, was re-elected, together with one additional member. The Directors are John Pitcairn, E.A. Hitchcock, Artemus Pitcairn, W.W. Heroy, W.L. Clause, W. D. Hartupee, and C.W. Brown, the new member being Mr. Hitchcock of St. Louis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Secretary Long received a visit to-day from Capt. Joshua Slocum, who made the famous trip around the world on the little sailing vessel Spray. In the course of the conversation the talk turned to Capt. Clark, who has recently been in Washington, and Slocum told of meeting the Oregon when Clark was making his great trip up the South American coast to join the North Atlantic Squadron during the Spanish war.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 5. -- Two burglars who invaded the handsome home of Julius C. Hocke, at 669 Avenue C at 2:30 A.M. to-day, could hardly have shown more politeness and consideration had they come as invited guests. About the only detail of deportment in which they failed was that they wore their black derby hats and masks while in the presence of the startled household.

IN THE ASSEMBLY. Mr. COLBY -- That no action against a city of the first class for salary, wages, or other compensation shall be maintained unless commenced within one year after the cause, of action shall have accrued, and then not unless notice of such action shall have been filed with the Corporation Counsel within six months.

There was an angry protest filed yesterday morning in Justice O'Gorman's court by the jury in the case of Kate Hickey against the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company, which, after being out all night, reported they had been unable to agree. The statements made to Justice O'Gorman will be investigated by his order.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- With the exceptions of mild activity in Union Traction, Reading, and the Philadelphia Electric securities, the local market was practically lifeless. Union Traction remained stationary at 33 1/2 until the close, when it went to 33 3/4. Reading common was slightly higher than last night.

The Associated Press has been put in possession of the following dispatches, which have never heretofore been published, and which are unquestionably authentic. They comprise the circular telegram of the Spanish Government to its representatives at several of the European Courts and excerpts from telegrams from Spanish Ambassadors:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Throughout today's session the Senate had under consideration the Urgent Deficiency Appropriation bill, and just before adjournment it was passed substantially in the shape in which it was reported.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter appeared in last Saturday's issue of THE TIMES entitled "Overstudy in the Public Schools," and signed "B." Some of the statements made in this letter I believe to be exaggerated. I am myself a teacher in the public schools, and the majority of my pupils are twelve or thirteen -- the age mentioned by " B."

BOSTON, Feb. 5. -- The will of the late Charles F. Sprague bequeaths his entire estate, amounting to about $10,000,000, to his widow. Mr. Sprague died on Thursday at the Butler Sanitarium, where he had been undergoing treatment for mental disorder since last July.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 5. -- The upward movement in Seaboards and United Railways issues was the feature in to-day's trading. Seaboard stocks and bonds all advanced as the result of the favorable annual statement showing a large net increase. United Railways continue to improve by reason, of the steady investment buying, aided by some speculative dealings, the effort being to carry it back to its ante-Summer level.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 5. -- The first race for the world's challenge ice yacht pennant between yachts of the Hudson River Club and the North Shrewsbury (N.J.) Club will take place on the Hudson River to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock, if the conditions of the ice and weather continue as they are to-night.

Discussing the condition of the iron and steel trades. The Iron Age notes that the situation is becoming more and more strained and perplexing, owing entirely to the phenomenal demand which is now dealing with the tonnage of the second half of the year, the capacity for the first six months being taken up in the principal lines.

The ball to be given by Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry this evening will be the last of the great social functions of the season. There will be a double cotillion, and the leaders will dance with the Misses Gerry. The afternoon subscription concert at the Metropolitan Club Annex, at which Calve will sing, will be the afternoon function.

"The Social Evil, with Special Reference to Conditions Existing in the City of New York," is the title of a volume of 188 pages which will be published within the next few days by G.P. Putnam's Sons for the Committee of Fifteen, which was constituted as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- In his statement before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day Gov. Taft dealt especially with the question of the relationship of the civil and military authorities, and his explanation was received with much interest. The day's session began with the understanding that there should be no interruption by members of the committee until the presentation of this entire branch of the subject was completed.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Sheriff Guden of Kings County was heard to-day in his own behalf before the Governor. For three hours he was subjected to a searching cross-examination, which will be continued to-morrow. It was after 6 o'clock, when Gov. Odell called a halt and asked Mr. Shearn, attorney for the complainant, how much more time he wanted.

A fairly large number of stocks were traded in in the outside market yesterday, but total transactions were considerably smaller than those of Tuesday. In the matter of prices there was considerable irregularity, but very few of the day's net changes were important. Standard Oil and a few other stocks succeeded in making large advances, which were retained until the close, but these were exceptions.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Money was wanted in the market to-day in connection with the Consols settlement and the payment of the West Australian loan. There was less pressure, however, and the tendency was toward easier rates. Discounts were weak. The possibility of a reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount, to-morrow, was much discussed, the condition of the Paris rate of exchange providing an uncertain factor.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- With resources of nearly $800,000,000, the savings banks of New York City handled over their tellers' counters, in deposits and payments, during the year 1901, the enormous aggregate of $360,234,083. Of this sum the greater amount by $22,702,019 was deposits. The story of the year's operations compared with those of 1900 is best told in these figures, showing their condition on Jan. 1:

Mr. Paolo Gallico, a local pianist of excellent repute, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall. His programme consisted of the following numbers: Weber's sonata, opus 24; Beethoven's A major variations; Schumann's "Papillons," a Schumann caprice on a Paganini theme; two preludes, and the fantasia, opus 49, of Chopin; Louis Saar's ballade, opus 18, No. 1, D minor; his own "Suite Mignonne," an etude by Nowakowsky, and Rubinstein's "Valse Allemagne."

Judge Leventritt of the Supreme Court has appointed Estelle B. Winslow receiver for the copartnership composed of herself and Kate Dignan, who keep a boarding house at 415 Madison Avenue, on the application of Thomas E. Rush in a suit brought by Estelle B. Winslow against Kate Dignan for a dissolution of the copartnership, which was formed on Nov. 1 last to continue for a year.
Daniel Frohman announces that Daly's Theatre will be reopened next season with "The Country Girl," the musical comedy recently produced by George Edwardes in London.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- The Presbyterian Committee on Creed Revision met here to-day to continue the work of preparing a report to be presented to the General Assembly in New York next May. The committee will meet daily during the remainder of this week and part of next week, and the members expect these sessions to be all they will hold.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The Railroad Commission this morning issued, an order increasing the rate of speed at which trains of the New York Central and the New York. New Haven and Hartford Railroads may run through the tunnel from Ninety-sixth to Fifty-sixth Street, New York City, from eighteen miles an hour to twenty-four miles an hour.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Lord Salisbury unveiled a life-size marble statue of Queen Victoria at the Junior Constitutional Club last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5. -- Thomas F. Ryan of New York, a representative of the Directorate of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, came to this city to-day and spent several hours in conference with P.A. B. Widener in the latter's private office. It is understood that they were discussing a prospective corporation to become possessed of all the surface lines in Manhattan Borough.

"If you don't see what you want -- don't ask for it; for you'll get it by and by" ought to be posted up in big red letters at the New York Theatre. In the "Hall of Fame," produced there last night, there is something for everybody, except, perhaps, the very serious-minded person who wants a minute to think.

The amount of gold engaged for export was somewhat increased yesterday, but no influence was thereby exerted upon market prices. Quotations were firm throughout the list, some substantial advances being scored. The Vanderbilt issues reflected investment favor and there was renewal of reports semi-officially authenticated a month ago touching development plans whereby there will be more concentration in the direction of the lesser properties.

A work for boys and young men is to be established on the west side below Twenty-third Street and west of Fifth Avenue. The nucleus of the fund for the same approximates $100,000, and is in hand, and there has just come to New York from Lincoln House, Boston, William A. Clark, to take charge of the project.

-- While in theory there is little or no objection to the changes which Assemblyman DAVIS'S concurrent resolution proposes to make in that clause of the State Constitution relating to the forest preserve, there is, we think, a strong feeling among those best informed on the subject -- and with no private interests to serve -- that the law would better be left as it is.

A tug started from New York for Boston Sunday afternoon at 3:30 with three barges in tow. Within three hours thereafter the wind was blowing so violent a gale as hardly comes once a year. The barges, helpless hulks even in fine weather, were swamped and thirteen lives were probably lost.

The 320 men comprising the First Battalion, Naval Militia of New York, were entered in the review and competitive drill which took place last night in the Seventyfirst Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Three bills now before Congress, providing for public statues in Washington, illustrate the hopelessly haphazard and random way in which we go about to commemorate our famous men. All three of these measures are joint resolutions introduced into the Senate. One has passed that body and gone to the House, where it has been referred to the Committee on the Library.

It is very cold weather, but this is the temperature in which the very best kinds of wash goods make their debut for the season. In fact, it is the best kind of weather in which to stay in the house and sew it there are yet women who do their own sewing, and one does come across one now and then who makes at least her own shirtwaists.

The annual report of the Diamond Match Company for the year ended Dec. 31, made public yesterday, shows net earnings of $2,021,072, an increase over the preceding year of $6,233, and a total surplus of $1,736919, as compared with $636,919 in the previous year.

The Chamber of Commerce will hold its regular monthly meeting to-day. The Chamber will define its attitude upon the recommendation of Gov. Odell to spend $28,000,000 for the improvement of the canals. An elaborate report favoring the recommendation is to be presented by the Committee on Internal Trade and Improvement, of which A. Barton Hepburn is Chairman.
In pursuance of the recently adopted policy of the management. President S.M. Rice of the Distilling Company of America yesterday made public the first semi-annual statement of the company's affairs.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- The Foreign Office confirms the substantial accuracy of a statement in regard to Germany's course toward the United States at the time of the war with Spain, which the Kreuz Zietung points to-day. It is understood that the article was prepared by Prof. Schiemann, Professor of History at Berlin University, who enjoys special official sources of information.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25 cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 5. -- By the explosion of the boilers on the towboat John W. Ailes, owned by the Monongahela River Consolidated Coal and Coke Company, one man was killed outright and four probably fatally injured early this morning. Several are still missing, and six were rescued from the icy waters.
Two phases of the Biddle tragedy merit passing notice, since both present psychological phenomena which are difficult of comprehension toy people of average sanity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- A bill to designate governmental despositories for surplus funds of the United States Treasury was introduced in the House to-day by Representative Cornelius A. Pugsley of the Sixteenth District of New York. Mr. Pugsley is the President of the Westchester County National Bank, one of the oldest institutions in New York State.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial yesterday under the title "Reforms in the Drawback System" you say.

Ex-Senator William E. Chandler has written an open letter entitled. "Would Spain Have Yielded Independence to Cuba to Avoid War?" In it he says that all the correspondence from Washington to the Minister to Spain during the time previous to the war was directed toward the maintenance of peace, and that Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, who was then the Minister, was told to demand more than he did demand.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- District Attorney Jerome had a rather discouraging experience with his excise bill to-day. Mr. Jerome reached the capital at 10 o'clock and went straight to the executive chamber, where he had a short conference with Gov. Odell. He would not discuss what passed between him and the Governor, but when the Governor was asked about their interview he said:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to reply to the communications of Jan. 18 from Mr. Robert W. Higbie and Mr. E.P. Bacon, published in your issue of Jan. 26.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club made a good showing in the Amateur Athletic Union/billiard tournament for the Class A amateur billiard championship of America in the club theatre yesterday, as two of the club's players were the winners in the games of the day.

Fire Commissioner Sturgis announced yesterday that he had sent letters to the proprietors of all theatres in the city calling attention to the violations of the law, and notifying them that the reports received from the firemen detailed at the theatres had been forwarded to the Corporation Counsel.

The Hockey Club of New York won an easy victory from the Brooklyn Skating Club last night at the St. Nicholas Rink by the score of 10 to 0. Despite the fact that the game was one-sided it abounded in brilliant plays and furnished plenty of excitement for the spectators, especially in the second half, when the Brooklyn boys made many desperate attempts to score.

Members of the City Club of New York met in unusual numbers last night in the clubrooms, 19 West Thirty-fourth Street, it having been announced that a new Board of Trustees was to be chosen and the constitution of the club so amended that it should be in effect a general grant of power to the board to manage the affairs of the club, both social and political.
LONDON, Feb. 6. -- At the annual meeting yesterday of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom several matters interesting to the United States were discussed.

New York is becoming more and more the Mecca for portrait painters of all nations. Time was when traveling American had his portrait painted in one of the capitals of Europe during a trip abroad, but the growth of American art supplied the home cities with good workmen, and it was more convenient to givo sittings in America than waste in that fashion the time for an outing which might be devoted to the sights.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The perennial Deceased Wife's Sister bill, which has been before Parliament for the last half-century, reappeared yesterday in a form identical with that of last year. On fourteen occasions the House of Commons has affirmed the principle of the bill, which, however, has always met with insurmountable obstruction, generally from the Bishops, in the Lords.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- The first witness examined to-day in the Guden inquiry was David M. Stone, who assisted in the conduct of the Sheriffs campaign. He was called, by the defense, and swore that no promise had been made to him about appointments and that he had made no promises.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- "I think," said Senator Orville H. Platt of Connecticut tonight, "that the cause of protection is now in far more danger of being wounded in the house of its friends than it ever was in danger of being injured by its enemies."
PARIS, Feb. 5. -- The following statement is made by an official who held a very high position during the early days of the Spanish-American war, and it is undoubtedly authentic:
