BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 5. -- The existence of a subterranean river rising in the White Mountains and emptying into Narragansett Bay is to be proven or disproven by the Superior Court now sitting at Dedham.

ELIZABETHPORT, N.J., Feb. 5. -- About 2 o'clock this morning four masked men entered the office of George Hill, at this place, who is constructing car shops for the Central Railroad, near the Singer Sewing Machine Works, and, after tying and gagging the watchman, carried off $2,500 in money.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5. -- Barney Saal, Beana, and Garter Ban were the winning favorites to-day. In the last race Syncopated Sandy ran away a mile in his preliminary, and the Stewards decided to refuse the horse's entry in the future. Weather cloudy and cool; track slow. Summary:

Superintendent of Elections John McCullagh declared late yesterday afternoon that he had instructed his deputies to look for Alderman John J. Dietz, James J. Frawley, Tammany leader of the Thirty-second Assembly District, and one "Schemer" Ryan and arrest them on sight.
Columbia's basket ball team was defeated in a hard game at the Grand Central Palace last night by the Silent Five of the Fanwood Athletic Club. The score was 25 to 13.

J.E. Johnson and J.L. Van Sant have sold for Samuel Kempner, 22 East Twenty-first Street, 25 by 92, to a client, who will erect on the lot an eight-story mercantile building. The buyer gives in exchange a six-story building in the neighborhood of Bleecker and Wooster Streets, the exact location of which, however, is withheld for the present.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As an illustration of the inequity, injustice, and oppression of the proposed and the existing law on New York State taxation, the following is submitted:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Senate passed to-day the bill appropriating $2,500,000 for a new Post Office Building in New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest your editorial in THE TIMES of Dec. 31 last on "Manufacturing in the South." I note particularly the statement in the last paragraph of the article, "We are strongly of the opinion, however, that the best interests of the South will be found in the development of its agricultural resources."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- "Let us alone," was the burden of Representative Talbert's speech in the House to-day. Mr. Talbert, who conies from South Carolina, and is a Democrat, gained the floor to speak in opposition to the Crumpacker proposition to reduce the representation of those Southern States in which the negroes were denied the right to a vote.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- After a week of comparative lagging and dullness, there was an all-round betterment in the Philadelphia market to-day, nearly everything showing gains. Most of the activity was in Union Traction. United Gas Improvement. Reading, and Philadelphia Electric. This group was influenced by specific causes, but the strength thus developed extended to other branches.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- The Anti-Pigeon Shooting bill was reported favorably to the Senate to-day by the Committee on Judiciary. Senator McCarren tried to have it recommitted. He advanced a new proposition, maintaining that the bill ought to be amended so as to allow gun clubs licensed by the Fish, Forest and Game Commission to shoot live pigeons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Industrial Commission has submitted its final report to Congress. It is a document of more than 1,000 printed pages. The first part, which has been made public, deals with the progress of the Nation, agriculture, mining, and transportation. Recommendations are made on the subjects of transportation and agriculture.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The New Jersey Subway Company to-day filed articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State. The capital is fixed at $100,000. The incorporators are Robert A. Montgomery, the local representative of the Asphalt Trust; Frank H. Leonard, and Alfred M. Worstal.

The entire day of Justice Steckler and a jury in the Supreme Court was taken up yesterday in listening to the intricacies of the ballet master's profession from several points of view. The case on trial was a suit brought against the Metropolitan Railway Company by Filiberto Marcheti, a ballet master, to recover $20,000 damages for injuries he received in a collision with a trolley car in 1899.

The feature of yesterday's stock market was its strength. Activity extended, and the volume of the day's transactions was larger than has lately been the average, but the increase was largely in a few of the conspicuous issues. The local traction shares, three or four of the mercurial trust stocks of the sugar and copper sort, with some of the older railway shares, monopolized most of the day's prominence.

Prospect of a discussion upon the sub- ject of the Cuban tariff and the promise of considering other important issues drew an unusually large attendance to the regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. The debate on the Cuban question was precipitated at once by the report of the Committee on Foreign Commerce and the Revenue Laws, of which Gustav H. Schwab is Chairman.

William Raymond Morley, ex-Captain of Columbia's football team, will be the head coach of Columbia's football team next season, and George Foster Sanford, coach for the last three years, will not be at the university in any capacity this Fall. Harold Weekes, Captain of the 1902 football team, gave the first official information of Morley's appointment yesterday afternoon, when he made public this statement:

The Macbeth Gallery, 237 Fifth Avenue, has an exhibition of a small private col- lection of paintings for the coming fortnight, one which was made apparently during the eighties, one which offers many charming works in landscape and figure by American colorists. Some of the painters are no longer living.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Representative Jones (Dem.) of Virginia has introduced a bill to appropriate $50,000 for the erection of a monument to Gen. Hugh Mercer at Fredericksburg, Va. The monument was authorized by an act passed on April 8, 1777.

Mr. and Mrs. Elbridgre T. Gerry gave their annual cotillion last night at their town house, in upper Fifth Avenue. The Gerry house is one of the largest and most admirably adapted for large entertainments of any in the city. It is one that requires little floral decoration, and aside from large growing ferns and palms but little was attemped last night in the matter of flowers.

Thomas J. Ford, a Deputy Tax Commissioner for the Borough of the Bronx, will have an examination before Magistrate Cornell in the Centre Street Police Court at 2 o'clock this afternoon on a charge of accepting a bribe. The chief witness for the District Attorney's office is J. Bowie Dash, President of the Holland Coffee Company, Limited, of 61 Water Street, who has extensive properly interests in the Bronx.
Major Gen. Roe and Mayor Low decided yesterday that Squadron A and Troop C of the National Guard shall act as the escort for the Prince while he is the guest of the city.

Trading in the outside market yesterday developed considerable irregularity in prices, and at the same time there was some falling off in transactions. Several stocks, which recently had advanced substantially on small transactions, reacted sharply and closed considerably below Wednesday's final figures.

Three matches were rolled in the New York Inter-Club Bowling League tournament last night, the New York Athletic Club winning three games from the Caledonian Club on the New York A.C. alleys, the Knickerbocker Athletic Club winning three games from the Catholic Club on the Knickerbocker alleys, and the Harlem Wheelmen winning two of three games with the West Side Republican Club on the latter club's alleys.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Consideration of the Philippine Tariff bill was resumed in the Senate to-day, and Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) expressed a desire to perfect it by the addition of some amendments to the phraseology. He proposed verbal modifications to the first amendment. These were agreed to, and the amendment then was adopted.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- It was announced today that bowlers of the whole world will be invited to participate in the Olympian games of 1904 in Chicago. An effort will also be made to secure the annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress of that year for the games.

The precocious boys of Columbia University are not behaving very nicely to the equally meritorious and altogether more interesting girls of Barnard College in making a fuss about the new rule granting the latter the use of the gymnasium swimming tank one evening in the week.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The official British denial of the statement that Lord Pauncefote, the British Ambassador at Washington, on April 14, 1898, made a second proposal to the powers to remonstrate with the United States, was laid to-day before a high German official, whose position gave him absolute first-hand knowledge of everything just as it occurred.

Plans for the proposed tunnel of the Union Terminal Company, which was incorporated in Albany last week, with a capital of $100,000, were filed with the County Clerk yesterday. The project was described by Appleton D. Palmer of 100 Broadway, who is attorney for the conceren, Francis H. Leggett, the wholesale grocer, being the President.
CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- With the announcement of Adam Worth's death to-day all the details of the recovery of the celebrated Gainsborough painting were made public here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I heartily agree with Mr. Hugh Hastings in his criticism of MacMonnies's statue of Gen. Slocum, and can't understand who of the General's friends could have accepted the design of that statue before it was cast. It certainly ought not to be placed in any public place as depicting Gen. Slocum.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Money was harder to day and the supplies were materially reduced. Discounts were somewhat adversely affected, owing to New York's large shipment of gold to-morrow. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet and the tone was fairly cheerful on the reduction of the Bank of England's rate of discount and the war news.

A collision in which an engineer and one passenger were injured occurred on the Lackawanna Railroad at Hoboken yesterday. The Orange accommodation train, drawn by locomotive No. 932, due at the Hoboken station at 2:30 o'clock P.M., had passed through the tunnel and just crossed the Jersey City line.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few words in reply to the letter of J. M. Bishop in THE TIMES of Feb. 2. As a woman, and a Southern woman, moreover, I have a decided opinion of the men who do not surrender their seats in crowded street cars to women. They are perfectly right to remain seated.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- One of the results of the dinner given last night by P.A.B. Widener to J.P. Morgan is that the latter is expected to finance he new securities company which will reorganize the Metropolitan Street Railway Company in New York and also the proposed merger of transit companies in Philadelphia.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Robert C. Morris and William H. Ten Eyck of the Republican County Committee came to Albany to-day to attend a dinner given by Gov. Odell tonight at the Executive Mansion. Superintendent of Elections McCullagh is also here. He is urging the adoption of the item in the appropriation bill giving him $127,000 for the running of his office.

Fifty-three paintings from the collection of the late Edward Moran, N.A., the well- known marine artist, were sold at auc- tion last evening at 366 Fifth Avenue by order of the executor of his estate.

PEKING, Feb. 6. -- The British, United States, and Japanese Ministers here have renewed their opposition to the Manchurian arrangements between China and Russia. It is probable that this action will result in the further postponement of the consummation of the treaty.

DUBLIN, Feb. 6. -- The Parliamentary election in the East Division of County Down, the member for which constituency, Dr. J.A. Rentoul, (Conservative, elected without opposition in 1900.) was recently appointed Judge of the City of London Court, has resulted as follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. G. -- Blue Ridge, Navasota, and Parnassus were the winning favorites to-day. Weidmann stumbled soon after the fourth race and threw W. Waldo. Rider and horse both escaped injury. Weather cloudy, track heavy, Summary:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- At the conclusion of the routine business in the Senate to-day, Mr. Scott (Rep., West Va.,) called up and had read a resolution which he offered several days ago providing for the appointment of a commission of experts to examine what is known as the San Blas, or Mandingo Bay, route for an isthmian waterway and to report to the Senate the cost of constructing an interoceanic canal by that route.
Bar silver was quoted in London at 25 1/2d per ounce and in New York at 55 1/4c per ounce. Mexican dollars were quoted at 43 1/4c.

It is curious that Washington should be imposing a limit on the height of buildings just as Chicago is taking it off. In Washington the motive of the restriction is to preserve the beauty of the city. The restriction itself is said to go no further than to prevent any commercial building or apartment house from overtopping any public building in its immediate neighborhood.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Assemblyman Bennet of New York to-day introduced another excise bill. Mr. Bennet's new bill provides merely for amending the Raines lay by striking out the provision under which hotels and clubs are privileged to dispense liquors on Sunday.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 6. -- Play in the International Chess Tournament was resumed this morning, when the third round of the contest was governed by Round 6 of the Berger schedule, bringing the players together in the following order:

"The Climbers," in which Amelia Bing- ham scored her first success as an actressmanager last season, is to succeed her present production of "Lady Margaret" at the Bijou Theatre on Feb. 24. This will come as a surprise, but it was learned yes- terday that efforts are being made to have the scenery and other requirements for his play in readiness, and the fashion play will therefore have only two more weeks to run.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Feb. 6. -- The Sultan's brother-in-law. Damad Mahmud Pasha, has been sentenced to death.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Following is the full test of the treaty between the United States and Denmark for the cession of the Danish West Indian Islands recently negotiated by Secretary Hay and Minister Brun of Denmark.

There was a departure from the ordinary routine scene in the opening proceedings of the Park Avenue explosion inquest yester- day in the Coroner's court. There was a climax when Peter Wessels, Juror No. 9, arose as Coroner Goldenkranz announced the inquest adjourned. Shaking his finger at the Corener, the juror said:

There was an exciting scene in Hahn's restaurant on Park Row last night about 9 o'clock when an elderly man who had been dining rather heavily rose to his feet in the middle of a discussion with the occupants of a neighboring table and exclaimed in heated tones:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The fishing sloop Dart, Capt. David Calhoun, with a crew of two, which has been missins since Tuesday, returned this afternoon and reports having lost the two seamen, Thomas Peck and a Japanese named Sitra.

The venerable no-seat-no-fare bill has made its annual appearance at Albany. Senator SULLIVAN introduced it in the Senate on Tuesday. It provides that street railway companies shall not demand or collect fare of a passenger unless a seat, not less than fourteen inches in width, is provided for him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A proposition is pending before Congress to pension the widow of one of the martyrs to science who have died as a result of experimenting on themselves in the effort to discover the cause of yellow fever. This case is somewhat different from the others, in that the victim did not offer himself to experimenting doctors to be operated upon, but conceived the idea himself and was his own victim.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- Because Thomas Chalmers of the firm of Fraser Chalmers made a mistake in his age a life insurance company has canceled a policy issued more than fifty years ago. Mr. Chalmers has brought suit in the Superior Court to have the company's action annulled.

The three-platoon police patrol system, which Aug. 13 last went into effect under Police Commissioner Murphy, will Monday next at 8 o'clock A.M., by order of Commissioner Partridge, be changed back to the old two-platoon system, which was in force for thirty-five years prior to last August.

After a delay of three weeks the official minutes of the annual meeting of the National League and American Association of Baseball Clubs, held at the Fifth Ave- nue Hotel during December, were made public yesterday, and the statement recently made by A.G. Spalding that the delay in the publication of the minutes was being utilized to edit and alter the records is now said by persons present at the meeting to be well founded.

With an injured Captain, and every man on board suffering from frost-bitten feet and hands, and other ills due to extreme cold, the schooner Charles Noble Simmons was towed into New York Harbor by the steamship Indian yesterday morning. The Indian, when she sighted the craft, was making for Philadelphia from Boston, and when she stopped to investigate the condition of the men aboard the Simmons.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- New England, through her delegation in Congress, flatly condemns the recent attitude of the Ways and Means Committee with respect to Cuba and unequivocally declares for tariff concessions to the island both as a matter of right and as a matter of policy. There is not a Senator from a New England State who is not an outspoken and ardent advocate of the Administration's scheme for helping the Cubans.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 6. -- District At- torney William Travers Jerome of New York was the guest of greatest interest at the college men's dinner here to-night. About thirty colleges were represented.

SIGNS are not lacking which reveal that there is considerable interest shown in England over some recent books that have appeared on this side dealing with the North American Indian as he was when the early English and Dutch colonists were successfully striving to establish homes in this country, notably in Central New York.

The noteworthy series of "Yale Bicentennial Publications" has just been augmented by Prof. Lounsbury's "Shakespeare as a Dramatic Artist." To show the exact phase of Shakespearean study which is undertaken here, we must reproduce some sentences from the preface in general introduction.

READERS will perhaps remember our response a few weeks ago to a correspondent who had grown tired of reading the ephemeral novels of the day, and wished to be advised as to biography. We gave a list of recent books in this class adapted to those who had not already become familiar with biographical literature.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- For the seventh time the yachts of the Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club of Red Bank, N.J., were defeated in a race for the challenge pennant of America held over the Hyde Park course this afternoon. The winner of the first series of three events was Commodore Archibald Rogers's first-class yacht Jack Frost, of the Hudson River Club.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7 -- While coasting on Rose Street last night a bobsled on which fourteen boys were riding, crashed into the curbs scattering the boys over the sidewalk. Frank Idler's nose was broken. Edward Mack wounded his arm and back. Fred Maurer received a bad scalp wound. The wounded were attended at a nearby drug store and left for home.
Discussing the movement of currency during the week Messrs. Dow, Jones Co. say:

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 8 -- In a secret session which was begun last evening and ended after midnight the delegates of the United Mine Workers, acting finally upon the advice of each of their National officers, adopted the report of the joint Scale Committee, reaffirming the scale of 1901 as a whole.

Bangs Co. have now in preparation the catalogue of the library of early American books collected by William R. Weeks, and the sale will probably take place at an early date. The collection contains much rare Americana -- Smith's "New Jersey," in uncut condition; Horsmanden's "Negro Plot," printed by James Parker in New York in 1744,

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, had half an hour's audience with King Edward at Marlborough House this afternoon. Mr. Schwab was accompanied by Sir Thomas Lipton, who introduced him to his Majesty. The King greeted Mr. Schwab in the most cordial manner and chatted freely with him, mainly on the friendship between the United States and Great Britain.

Last night was one of dances. There was quite a number of last meetings of dancing classes, including the first Friday cotillions, the Friday evening dances, and other minor classes. There was also a cotillion at the residence of Dr. and Mrs. Seward Webb. This evening there will be the last meeting before Lent of the Saturday evening class.

At a meeting of the Bar Association held last night the Judiciary Committee and the Committee on the Amendment of the Law submitted a report, pursuant to a resolution adopted at the annual meeting that the suggestion of the Governor that County Judges be assigned to sit as Justices of the Supreme Court be referred to those committees.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 7 -- The improvement in the feeling about Cotton Duck shares was the item of chief interest in to-day's trading. The common stock lifted three-qauarters of a point, and the income bonds advanced three-eighths. This was due to more optimistic views as to the successes following the progress in the company's plans, which, it is thought, will add value to the income bonds.

This large volume, without preface or index, does not purport to be a diplomatic history of the United States, but merely undertakes to discuss, in five long chapters, some of the most important questions that have arisen in the course of our dealings with foreign powers during the last century and a quarter.

IT is impossible that any am- bilious young man should read the biographical sketch of Henry Baldwin Hyde without making confession that his soul had been filled from it with new courage, stimulus, and inspiration.

THE memoirs of Dean Lake of Durham Cathedral remind us of the passing of the men who lent peculiar glory to English educational and religious life half a century ago. When Dean Lake was a student at Oxford Dr. Arnold was at Rugby and Keble was singing his way into the religious heart of England.

The drop in the price of copper, doing away with some of the recent advance, and a decline in the market quotations of Amalgamated stock made interesting topics for Wall Street discussion yesterday, but did not much disturb Stock Exchange sentiment or general values. As a speculative or investment influence the ups and downs that may attend Copper Trust manipulation can be fairly regarded now as cut loose from the general market.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7 -- It is announced that Columbia and Yale will not play football next Fall. The presence of Lancon and Kindgen on the Columbia team in the game with Yale last season is declared to have created an unpleasantness on account of the belief of Yale men that they were ineligible to play as bona fide students.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Secretary Long made public to-day the following letter to Rear Admiral Sampson regarding the latter's retirement:

That he might save Mrs. John Vanderpoel of 36 West Thirty-ninth Street, who is very old, the disagreeable and possibly dangerous experience of venturing into the offensive atmosphere of a police court, Magistrate Pool, in the West Side Court, yesterday, adjourned court to the sidewalk for her benefit.

The annual masquerade ball or the Arion Society was held last night in Madison Square Garden. An immense throng filled the boxes and stalls and every available bit of standing room, so that the carnival procession had scarcely room enough to pick its way around the Garden.

DIVIDED COURT ON QUESTION OF NEGLIGENCE -- Benjamin Saletzky was riding with another lad on the 14th of May, 1898, on a truck being driven in a northerly direction on Third Avenue, in this city, on the easterly track of the Third Avenue Railroad. He was sitting on the rear of the truck, with his legs hanging down.
The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Something struck me hard just now, away up here in the Tarheel mountains, and you "done it," or let that other fellow, which is just as had.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Senator and Mrs. Hanna were hosts this evening at the largest private reception ever given in Washington, their guests being entertained at the Arlington Hotel, where a suite of three parlors and the ballroom had been reserved for the occasion. The Senator and his wife received alone in the first of the three parlors, where the decorations consisted almost entirely of Spring blossoms, yellow tulips, narcissus, white hyacinths, and lilacs.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The Krum bill amending the tax law in relation to the payment of State fees and taxes by both foreign and domestic corporations will come up for passage in the Senate next week unless there should be a demand of sufficient urgency for a further hearing upon the measure

A further opportunity to study the creation of Mr. Isidore de Lara's fancy was afforded at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, when a small and reflective audience assembled to hear "Messaline" and to observe Mme. Calve in her impersonation of an antique voluptuary of noisome memory.

A little book by Susan Chenery has just been added to the recently accumulated literature on the mural education of children, and, while there is much good sense in it, one cannot help wondering, as one reads it, if a little bit of plain, un-selfconscious humanity in parents and teachers would not go quite as far as so many rules of action.

Police Captain Walsh of the Eldridge Street Station, at the head of a squad of detectives, shortly before 1 o'clock this morning, raided life First Morning Glory Club at 225 Chrystie Street. Nine prisoners who were captured were bundled into a patrol wagon and taken to the Eldridge Street Station, where two of them were charged with keeping and maintaining a gambling house, and the others with being common gamblers.

It looked for a time yesterday morning as if a large percentage of the population of Greater New York desired to become Sanitary Inspectors and Inspectors of Light and Ventilation in the Tenement House Department. There are 120 Inspectors needed by the department, and about 1,600 persons gathered outside the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, to take the required civil Service examination for the positions, which pay $1,200 a year.

Coroner Goldenkranz made an effort yesterday to continue his investigation of the Park Avenue tunnel explosion, but with the more important witnesses subpoenaed by the District Attorney to appear before the Grand Jury, the Coroner was forced to adjourn his court at 12:30. There was another outbreak on the part of the jurymen, who insisted that they were business men and that the delay was ruinous to them.

It is difficult sometimes to estimate accurately the worth or certain books of verse, from the fact that they are not feeble enough to be condemned and yet are not striking enough to deserve particular praise. The power to make verse is now so nearly a universal endowment of cultivated minds that almost everybody who can write at all tries, first or last, his hand at poetry.

Liebler Co. contemplate an elaborate revival of D'Ennery's melodrama "The Two Orphans," to follow Kyrle Bellew's run at Wallack's Theatre in May. The idea is to have an all-star cast, Mr. Bellew and Otis Skinner having signified their willingness to play, and other actors, such as James O'Neill and Clara Morris, being considered.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- To a newspaper correspondent who wished the Chinese Minister a happy New Year to-day Mr. Wu said:

Miss Winston is the author of the painful but strong story. "Waters That Pass Away," which excited interest two years ago. Her new novel. "The Grace of Orders." is no less sincere and thoughtful, and shows growth of power, and a clearer vision for "things as they are." She gives an accurate picture of life and character developed by the influences of Virginia as it was before the great cataclysm, and as it is now.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: One of the beat services THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS has done is to reveal the sham underlying the reported enormous circulation of the popular novels of to-day. Considering the jockey arts employed by those interested to foist upon the public the belief that this circulation implies that these books are read -- this is the point, are they read?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The recent favorable report by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on the treaty for the cession of the Islands of the Danish West Indies was accompanied by a written statement made by that committee to the Senate. This report contains a small diagram showing the location of the three islands and their positions relative to Porto Rico, and states numerous interesting facts concerning the Islands.

The Appellate Division yesterday gave a decision holding that the elevated railroad had no right to construct a third track on Ninth Avenue. The case before the appellate tribunal was an appeal taken by Henry B. Auchincloss from a decision of the Special Term of the Supreme Court dismissing the complaint in his action to recover damages for the taking of his easements by the railroad, and to restrain the construction of the third track.

Bernard Smyth Sons have sold to Sonn Brothers for the estate of the late Daniel F. Tiemann, who was Mayor of this city from 1858 to 1860, the plot of about thirty-two lots having frontages of 276 feet on Broadway, 200 feet on One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, 399.8 feet on Claremont Avenue, and 28 feet on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Gov. Odell will confer with the leaders of the Senate Monday about the Charities bill. The conference will be as to the form of the bill. The existing draft provides for a reduction of the present board to three members, who are to be salaried, the same as the members of the Lunacy Board.

EVIDENTLY inspired by Lord Rosebery's scholarly and enlightening sketch of Napoleon at St. Helena, Henry Foljambe Hall has gone far toward clearing up the varied and conflicting estimates that have been given concerning the domestic phase of Napoleon's life. In the third decade of the nineteenth century, when reaction had gently set in against the Bonapartes, there appeared in Paris a volume entitled "Memoires et Correspondance de I'Imperatrice Josephine," by Regnault Varin.
MONTE CARLO, Feb. 7 -- The fourth round of the International Chess Tournament was played according to Round 1 of the Berger schedule, and the players were therefore paired as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Admiral John G. Walker, Chairman of the Isthmian Canal Commission, testified before the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals to-day. He went over much of the ground covered by the reports of the commission, and in reply to numerous questions explained the reasons for the recent recommendation for the acceptance of the offer of the Panama Canal Company.

Thaddeus D. Kenneson, Secretary of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, yesterday made public two letters on the excise question, one of which was sent to Gov. Odell and the other to George Hilliard, Deputy Commissioner of Excise, by the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst, President of the society.

We hope that Mr. CARNEGIE will not have use for an epitaph for a long time to come, but when he does we doubt if those who have to select it will be impressed by the appropriateness of that suggested by him in his remarks at the dedication of the new Laboratory of Engineering at Stevens Institute: "Here lies a man who knew how to get around him men much cleverer than he."

The score of 9 to 2, by which the hockey team of the Crescent Athletic Club defeated Yale University at the Clermont Avenue Rink last evening, is not a fair indication of the relative merits of the opposing sevens, for the majority of the points obtained by the Brooklyn representatives were obtained within the space of ten minutes.

PANAMA, Feb. 7 -- Col. Julien Del Castillo, an envoy from Gen. Herrera, the insurgent commander, arrived here last night, escorted by police, and left Panama two hours later. Gov. Arjona received important papers from Col. Del Castillo for himself and the Consuls here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Census Bureau has issued a preliminary report on the manufacturing industries at Pennsylvania in 1900. The figures for the State, with the increase for the decade, follow:

LONDON, Jan. 25 -- The controversy over Mr. Kipling's "Islanders" shows no signs of diminishing. As was to have been expected, the thousands of men who are interested in cricket and football are extremely indignant at the epithets "flanneled fools" and "muddied oafs," and the indignation of those who indulge in fox hunting and other athletic sports is scarcely less than that of the ball players.

Alumni of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute of Troy held their twenty-fourth annual dinner and mid-winter reunion at Sherry's last night. About one hundred graduates of the institution were seated at the numerous tables. Charles Macdonald, President of the Alumni Association, presided.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- The annual Junior Promenade was held here this evening in the Casino, which had been decorated in the college colors. The upper class club boxes encircled the dancing floor and gave the chaperons and visitors an excellent opportunity to view the dancing. The attendance was the largest of any previous midwinter function: Dancing was kept up to an early hour this morning.

The librarian of the Carnegie Library at Pittsburg has done a public service by preparing the list of a hundred entertaining biographies for which we gladly make room. Among the million devotees of "light reading" who read only for amusement, and who find amusement only in fiction, it is much to be feared that the majority find it only in trash.

Next Wednesday is the birthday of Abraham Lincoln. A tentative movement on the part of local clergy to set aside tomorrow (Sunday) as a Lincoln Memorial Day tends to substantiate the hold the immortal "rail splitter" continues to have upon a Generation sprung since his passing, and recalls the prediction made shortly after his death, nearly forty years ago, by M. Edouard Grenier, the last poet of the idealistic school of France.

EVERY one knows how loath George the Elector was to leave his palace of Herren-hausen after he had been announced King of Great Britain. His behavior, we remember, reminded Mr. Justin McCarthy of the convict in Prior's poem, who, when the cart was ready and the halter adjusted, "often took leave, but seemed loath to depart."

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- Chickadee, who finished third in the first race to-day, was disqualified for fouling Dolce Far Niente. The stewards to-day announced their decision in the case of George Land Co., owners, and the horse Judge Steadman, whose inconsistent performance led to the inquiry.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 7 -- After three days of discussion, the Harvard Debating Club to-day sent the following question for the annual debate to Princeton: "Resolved, That Mayor Low should strictly enforce the excise law in New York City."

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Papers were filed in the office of the Clerk in Chancery to-day showing the appoinment at Newark yesterday by Vice Chancellor Slevens of a receiver for the Automobile Company of America. The appointment is made temporary and a rule to show cause is granted returnable before the Vice Chancellor at Newark on Tuesday next.

A syndicate headed by David G. Legget is seeking to secure control of the Brooklyn Bank, at Fulton and Clinton Streets. Yesterday the stockholders of the bank received a circular letter from the Long Island Trust Company stating that the owners of two-thirds of the stock of the Kings County Bank had deposited with the trust company money sufficient to purchase the capital stock of the Brooklyn Bank, which it was sought to obtain.

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 7 -- Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., son of President Roosevelt, is ill of pneumonia at the Groton school. He was reported at 9 o'clock to-night to be "as comfortable as could be expected." Those in attendance at his bedside declined to give any more definite information, but it was understood at the school that the patient showed some improvement during the afternoon and early evening.

"PRINCIPLES OF WESTERN CIVILIZATION," by Benjamin Kidd, will be published about the middle of this month by The Macmillan Company. The main thesis of this new work embodies a fundamental conception, the shifting of the centre of significance in the modern evolutionary hypothesis out of the present into the future.

That is at least a modest homeopath over in Brooklyn who thinks he can be of more service to science dead than alive, and who has pretended to offer his body to be vivisected instead of operating upon the bodies of his fellow-beings. It would be sad if his patients should believe him.

One night at the Authors Club Charles F. Russell ventured the opinion that the dominant characteristic of our modern poetry is the genuineness of its impure and inspiration. It would be hard to find or frame a fitter phrase with which to characterize Mr. Russell's own poems, now for the first time collected in a volume called "Such Stuff as Dreams," (Bowen-Merrill Company, Indianapolis.)

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The Secretary of the Admiralty, Admiral von Tirpitz, opened the debate on the naval estimates in the Reichstag to-day. He said the Government hoped it would not have to ask for further credits to meet this year's expenditure.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Gov. Taft appeared before the Senate Committee on Philippines again to-day and talked about the question of the revenue of the islands. He began his statement with an explanation of his previous statement that sentiment was the main reason for asking a substantial reduction of the rates of the Dingley law so far as they applied to the Philippines, saying he feared the statement might be misunderstood.

In the current number of The Independent Mr. Upton Sinclair tells an interesting story of his experience with a book. He says that he should be loath to make the announcement to the critics that he has caught them in a trap, but apparently that was his purpose, and, apparently again, he thinks that he has succeeded.

The Chicago Daily News for Jan. 24 contains an account of an interview with Mrs. Eugene Field in regard to her position as to the life of her husband recently published by Slason Thompson. This book has been widely discussed in Chicago literary circles, and especially among Field's friends; the impression gaining ground that Mrs. Field was far from satisfied with the "study" as a whole.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- T. Fisher Unwin's forthcoming volume in the climber's Guide Series describes mountaineering in the Dolomite Alps. The author is Mme. Narman Neruda.

W.C. Brown, the recently elected Third Vice President and General Manager of the New York Central, and A.H. Smith, the new General Superintendent of the same road, arrived in this city yesterday morning in order to confer with President Newman and the others officials of the Central preliminary to entering on the administration of their new offices.

The Era for February has two pages devoted to an interesting collection of extracts from some of the latest books. They touch upon many subjects and range over unlimited fields. Following are a few of the wittiest:

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Thirty cents premium was charged to-day for New York ex- change. Interest rates on time and call loans 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. With the exception of Tin Can and Metropolitan Elevated, in both of which special influences operated in the direction of a lower level of prices, the local market to-day was firm, and in some stocks considerable strength was shown.

The story which we published yesterday from Peking is of a nature to impair the usefulness of a diplomatist of any other country than Russia. Russian diplomatists are supposed in all the Chancelleries to the the most complete exemplifications still extant of Sir HENRY WOTTON'S famous definition of an Ambassador.

Elsewhere we print a notice of the final volumes of "The Jesuit Relations and Allied Documents," as edited by Reuben Gold Thwaites. They are Volumes 72 and 73 of the set, and are entirely given up to an index. During recent weeks some remarks, intended to be insistent, have been made in these columns concerning indexes -- the lack of them in many books, the need of better ones in books that already have them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Roosevelt left Washington at 4:50 o'clock this afternoon, for Groton, Mass. She is traveling in a drawing room car on the regular Pennsylvania Railroad train, which goes through to Boston without change, arriving there to-morrow morning at 7 o'clock. From Boston the first available train will reach Groton at 10:33 A.M.

If women who go shopping would, consider their own comfort and convenience by getting home before the rush of uptown travel begins they would contribute materially to the public convenience. This is especially noticeable on the west side elevated trains between the hours of 5:30 and 6:30.

C.F. Conklin of Chicago and Charles Threshie of Boston were the winners yesterday in the Amateur Athletic Union's 14.2 billiard tournament for the championship of Class A. Threshie was in fine form in the afternoon contest, and completed the 400 points necessary to win in 42 innings, his average being 9 22-44.

Some interesting comments on the employment of Hessians by the English Government as an aid in suppressing the rebellion in the thirteen Colonies in the latter's s struggle for freedom were made by Hugh Hastings, the New York State historian, in a recent address before the Sons of the Revolution in this city.

WITH the issue of the two final volumes of the "Jesuit Relations" there is completed the most notable recent undertaking in the field of American historical literature -- the presentation in scholarly and definitive form of the mass of material, the letters, journals, chronicles, and like documents concerning the Jesuit mission in New France, which for nearly three centuries strove to carry "the faith" ever further into the wilderness.

WRITING is a trade, and, like any other trade, it must be learned. We must serve our apprenticeship; but we must work it out alone. There are no teachers. We must learn by failure and by repeated effort how the thing should be done."

There is at present being shown at the Grolier Club a fine exhibition of mosaic bindings, carefully classified and arranged, which will remain open until Feb. 22, tea being served on Saturday afternoons. The catalogue which accompanies the exhibition is particularly valuable. Besides the description of books shown, which include specimens of all ages and countries, it contains an unusual amount of fine descriptive text.

After a conference with President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan, Mayor Low announced yesterday that at the request of Secretary of State Hay the date on which the ceremony of giving Prince Henry of Prussia the freedom of the city has been changed from Feb. 23 to Feb. 22.

The bill introduced by Mr. PUGSLEY of this State, permitting the deposit of pub- lic funds in banks having a capital of only $100,000, undoubtedly meets the views of a very considerable class of bankers. The conditions imposed are substantially the same as those of the bill of Mr. SULZRR, with the exception of the capital of the banks, which was in the latter case required to be $500,000.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- Money was in good demand to-day; rates were firm and the supplies were materially curtailed. The market was largely indebted to the Bank of England. Discounts had a hardening tendency. Prices on the Stock Exchange opened generally firm. The Kafir section was the only one which had a semblance of activity, the nearness of the settlement restricting dealings.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as follows: Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, par; call loans, 3 to 3 1/2; time money, 4 to 4 1/2. Clearing House exchanges, $23,941,640; balances, $1,671,469. The general stock market was very active and strong in spots, while the coppers were generally quiet.

The Science of Religion is a phrase which would have been practically meaningless a quarter of a century ago, but which is well understood to-day as the name of an important branch of study, namely, what is known as Comparative Religion, Comparative Mythology; or, as the Germans call it, "Religionswissenschaft."

MOUNT VERNON, Ky., Feb. 7 -- While Judge Durham, Magistrate in the Wildie district, was in town on business he was called up over the telephone by Constable Harry Jones, who said he had in charge Dan Dickerson, charged with breach of the peace. Dickerson asked an immediate trial, and it was agreed to conduct the trial over the telenhone wires.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- E.S. Theall, representing counsel for Rear Admiral Sampson, filed with President Roosevelt to-day the following brief, protesting against the claim set up in Admiral Schley's appeal that he was in supreme command during the battle off Santiago:

The present issue of the Beacon Biographies, the story of Alexander Hamilton, should prove of unusual interest to Americans, for the reason that aside from the story of Hamilton's remarkable career the book gives an unusually clear picture of the early political and constitutional history of our country, and the firm establishment of its financial credit, the latter being almost entirely due to Hamilton's unaided efforts, and largely through his plan for a National bank.

The war revenue law as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

Although this little anthology of poems upon themes suggested by nature would be welcome were it issued anonymously, yet it derives special and singular interest from the fact that the selection represents the individual choice of a man whose opinion and taste in such a field are of great weight and interest.

The letter of a correspondent which appeared in our issue of Tuesday last on the relative cost of living at the present time and at previous periods within his recollection was of unusual interest. This comment, however, does not imply conviction on our part that our correspondent is correct in his view of past or preseut conditions, for we think him wholly mistaken.

The dead, no less than the quick, seem to have their destinies. Although the name of Mary Rich, Countess of Warwick, has come down faintly to the modern reader as that of a saintly recluse, little was written, and less was definitely known, about one of the most illuminating figures of the seventeenth century.

PROF. HERBERT L. OSGOOD of Columbia University has performed a valuable service in directing attention afresh to the value of State, county, and town records. He has just prepared, on behalf of the American Historical Association, a report which is undoubtedly the most exhaustive ever presented on the archies and public records of the State and City of New York.

THE good people of Wilkesbarre, Penn., will celebrate on Feb. 11 what they term "the centennial of anthracite." Probably because there were other centennial affairs on hand a quarter of a century ago, the real occasion passed unnoticed, for it was considerably over a hundred years ago that the use of anthracite coal was known even in the beautiful spot beside the Susquehanna whereon is now located Wilkesbarre.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The reserve with Which all measures affecting the judiciary of the State have been treated heretofore by the Legislature will be broken when the bill introduced by Senator White to increase the allowances of the Trial Judges comes up for debate. Republican leaders in the Senate and in the Assembly will make a strong effort to defeat this bill.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a seeker after truth, I desire to have the true inwardness of certain popular expressions explained to me. Such expressions are "Cheap Chinese labor," "Underselling American labor," and others of a kindred nature. To one who lives in the Far West they read rather like strange shibboleths for the confusion of the unwary, or as mere war cries, filled with sound and nothingness.

The State civil service law was repeatedly and violently assaulted last night by the speakers at the complimentary dinner given by the Republican Club of the Twenty-second District to the district leader, Charles K. Lexow, and Park Commissioner William R. Willcox at the Marlborough Hotel, in appreciation of their services during and since the recent municipal campaign.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The burghers of the Transvaal being either our prisoners or in the field, and their women and children on the farms being surrounded by vast numbers of blacks, and blacks violently hostile because of frequent ill-treatment, it had always seemed to me that the collection of their women in camps was inevitable if horrors were to be avoided.

AN ingenious crook has of late been reaping a harvest in the up-town apartment house district. One day last week a lady who lives in Ninety-seventh Street was called to the kitchen of her flat during the absence of her maid by the ringing of her dumb-waiter bell. A voice from the depths informed her that a package had been sent to her address from a Broadway shop where men's belongings are sold.

For the past three months Capt. Gannon of the East Eights-eighth Street Station has received numerous complaints of burglaries in the flat-house districts in his precinct, and, although his detectives have been watching closely to apprehend the culprits, it was not until last night that any success was attained.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Gov. Odell gave a dinner at the Executive Mansion Thursday night, to which the leaders in the Senate and Assembly, Democrats as well as Republicans, were invited. After the dinner the guests were entertained by a slight-of hand man engaged from one of the vaudeville theatres.

The decoration of Holy Trinity, Boston, the finest church edifice in that city, was intrusted to John La Farge, who superintended the general color scheme and painted a number of figures on various walls. Several series of stained glass windows were also from his workshops, so that the interior bade fair to be exclusively under the control of the famous colorlst.

It is popularly supposed that with the advent of Ash Wednesday all worldly pleasures cease, and that from that day until the dawn of Easter New York will be, socially, a desert. It only means that the dances have come to an end, and that nominally the Winter season has passed into history.

Great interest was shown by the Judges of the Court of Claims in their inspection of the silver sceptre or mace which is to be carried by the Lord Mayor, subject to the King's approval, at the coronation of Edward VII. This emblem of the Lord Mayor's authority was borne in the coronation of George IV., since which the Lord Mayor has taken no part in the procession.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wonder if the average reader realizes the importance, influence, and effect of the scholarly opinions frequently handed down by Justice William J. Gaynor of Brooklyn. The last, I believe, was in the Glennon case, in which this Judge wrote an opinion which has been reproduced by law journals, magazines, and periodicals all over the country.

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Suits aggregating more than half a million dollars have been begun or are about to be begun against New York City by lawyers representing land owners' interests in the Croton watershed in Putnam County. The suits arose from the building of the middle and west branch reservoirs and the Mahopac improvement.

VESTED RICHTS OF BENEFICIARY. -- Rosa Feirstein, who failed in her suit in the Supreme Court to recover of the Supreme Lodge, Knights of Honor, upon a benefit certificate in which she, as the wife of Morris Feirstein, was named as beneficiary to the extent of $1,000, has been granted a new trial by the Appellate Division on payment by her of the costs of the first trial and of the appeal.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- The week closed with the money market in the same easy position that it has held now for some time past. Money is in plentiful supply, and demand is very light. The best opinion in banking circles still inclines to the belief that the present conditions are likely to continue for some time to come.

WHEN the splendid marble palace in which the New York Stock Exchange is to be housed is finally completed, the members of that organization will have for the locality of their business transactions the most ingenlously and expensively equipped building in the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your paper of Feb. 4 was published an article by Mr. J.R. Griffing, entitled "Relative Cost of Living." "While I do not care to argue the cost of living nowadays, I desire to express my opinion on a young man's chances to-day to climb to the top of the ladder of success.

"The responsibility for our present deplorable condition devolves upon yourself," says Dr. PARKHURST in his awakening letter to Gov. ODELL in regard to violation of the excise law in Raines law hotels. This is not a question of Sunday opening or of amendments to the law, as to which the Governor can plead that he is bound to inaction by his respect for an overwhelming public opinion up the State.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Feb. 8. -- The Dominion Cabinet is holding sessions daily preparing for the opening of Parliament on Thursday of next week. Although the Government does not intend to present a very lengthy programme, much work has to be done in preparing estimates and providing for new undertakings as well as in continuing all the works now under way.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 8. -- The joint conference of the miners and operators to-day unanimously ratified the old wage scale agreement. The admission of Iowa and Michigan to the next joint conference was denied because of the opposition of the operators from Illinois and Ohio.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to thank the Southern lady, "J.H.M.," whose letter you published in your to-day's issue, for the liberal views expressed therein, and for the courage to publish them. Certainly every man who read this letter felt pleasure and satisfaction.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- During to-day's session of the lower House of the Diet, the Minister of Commerce, Herr Moeller, made the interesting announcement that the Prussian Government would shortly submit a bill authorizing a credit of 58,000,000 marks for the purchase of the Westphalian coal fields.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From a recent announcement by our daily press, the Nineteenth Ward of the Borough of Manhattan it seems is to have another hospital and dispensary added to its already large number of similar institutions. The Manhattan Maternity Hospital and Dispensary is to be located on the plot of ground made up of 327,320,331, and 333 East Sixtieth Street.

Folks with a fondness for pessimism will be attracted by George Alfred Townsend's chapter of National canal promotion reminiscence -- the writer being hopeless apparently that any good can come out of the Nicaragua. This is his representation:

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Greenwich is stirred up over the question of the morality or immorality of certain entertainments which have been held in Ray's Opera House, and it is charged by some that the effect of these productions on the minds of the young has been pernicious. The effect is supposed to have been accomplished through colored posters.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 8. -- Continuing his narrative before the Senate Committee on the Philippines, Gov. Taft reverted to-day to his former testimony for the purpose of introducing a cablegram he had received from Acting Governor Wright urging a reduction in the tariff on Philippine articles imported into the United States.

WHILE all New York was looking expectantly toward the new Street Cleaning Commissioner to see how "Reform" would hustic a first-class snowstorm from the streets into the rivers, an experiment which may result eventually in the revolutionizing of removing snow from the streets of big cities was being tried under the personal supervision of the man of whom so much was expected.
PANAMA, Feb. 8. -- The foreign Consuls here have agreed to send to the insurgent Gen. Herrera the following answer to his note addressed to the American, French, British, and German Consuls:

Judge William E. Werner was the guest of honor at the fourth annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee, which was held last night in the ball room of the Waldorf-Astoria. His presence, supplemented by that of several other well-known Justices and lawyers, lent a legal aspect to the dinner, and this flavor of the law was carried out in all the minor details of the affair.
Electric tram cars of American build are about to invade the land of the Czar.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 8. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb was asked to-day about his candidacy for the Governorship and about rumors to the effect that a political bargain was attached to his candidacy.

The weekly Clearing House statement yesterday was regarded by speculative Wall Street as distinctly unfavorable, in that it showed a loss of $8,727,125 in surplus reserves, and the rather extraordinary increase in loans of $28,974,300, the largest single week increase save one in the history of the Clearing House.

"Please say to the people of New Rochelle that I shall be glad when I am back there again, and that I thank all my friends there for the kind interest they have taken in me since I have been here and that I feel stronger every day. And you might also say that the entire staff of Bellevue Hospital has done everything to bring about my recovery."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Women are said to look at things in the concrete. That way of looking at the saloon, question has just been forced upon me anew. Last Wednesday night, as we all remember, was cold and snowy, so when my proper little housemaid staid out till all hours.

There was the greatest mystery about the Criminal Courts Building yesterday and more activity about the office of the District Attorney than there has been since William Travers Jerome took office. The District Attorney was again on the trail of the mysterious "John Doe," who figured so prominently in the gambling exposures that preceded the last municipal election.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8. -- Lannep's victory in the Clubhouse Handicap, worth $1,250 to the winner, was a surprise to the talent to-day. The aged mare was crowded out in the first quarter, but under Gormley's vigorous ride worked her way through, caught Sevoy, a strong second choice, in the backstretch, where he was tiring badly, and beat him out very cleverly.

The hockey enthusiasts who crowded the St. Nicholas Rink last evening to witness the league game between the teams of the New York Athletic Club and the St. Nicholas Skating Club were treated to a fine exhibition of hockey, and to a genuine surprise, for the St. Nicholas players left the ice winners by a score of 3 goals to 2 after an extra period of play had been ordered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thomas Sturgis, Fire Commissioner, evidently has in him the fibre of which successful administrators are made. He is mindful of the oath to which he solemnly subscribed Jan. 1, and he proceeds to enforce the law as he finds it; a novel departure in this community perhaps, but one to which the city under its present rulers will gradually become accustomed.

Advancing quotations were quite generally the rule to the stock market yesterday until the appearance of the bank statement, showing a decrease in surplus reserves of over $8,000,000 and an increase in loans of nearly $29,000,000 -- the second largest single week loan increase ever reported, the largest having been on Feb. 2, 1901, when the expansion was $30,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is talk that the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company will try to lease the rapid transit subway road. This plan should be blocked, for reasons which have been long obvious.

The old saying is no longer true that while England has colonists and colonies, France has colonies but no colonists, and Germany colonists but no colonies. True, France has no colonists, nor is likely to have so long as her population remains stationary. But Germany has colonies.

The 360 Government shops in St. Petersburg where vodka is sold are meant to supersede almost entirely the old traktirs, taverns, or saloons, which formerly adorned the thoroughfares of Russian cities and towns, just as they do in our own blessed land. In these traktirs the workman and the peasant could sit and sip their vodka by the hour, the day, or the night, and find in jovial companionships encouragement to further excesses.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The apparent incompetence and it is claimed, possible dishonesty, which permeate the purchasing departments of the British Army, as revealed this week in Parliament, have caused a public agitation that augurs badly for the War Office. Judging from recent and promised disclosures, scarcely any of the supplies for the army in South Africa were secured on business principles.

Copyright, 1802. LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The British reply to the Dutch note having satisfied everybody worth trying to satisfy, news from the seat of war being distinctly encouraging, the smallpox scare having, for the time being, considerably abated, and that "Hardy Annual," as The London Times calls it, the Deceased Wife's Sister bill, having probably been shelved for another session,all England ought to be reason -- ably happy at the end of this week.

The Rev. Edgar Gardner Murphy of Montgomery, Ala., Chairman of the Alabama State Committee, which seeks to abolish the labor of young children in that State, is at the Hotel St. Denis, where he said yesterday that New England capitalists were largely to blame for the conditions under which it has been conservatively estimated that in some sections of the South more than 20 per cent, of the employes are less than fourteen years old.

THE recently published returns of the British Board of Trade, which showed that within twelve months 65,000 to 75,000 British citizens had emigrated to the United States as against only 12,000 or 13,000 who went to Canada, taken in conjunction with the disappointing figures of the last Canadian census, nave caused the Dominion Government to send the Deputy Minister of the Interior to London for the purpose of creating additional interest in the British colony.

THOSE who have read the charming work of Thomas Hughes entitled "Tom Brown at Oxford" will remember that at certain intervals the story is carried forward by the publication of the contents of certain letters. The author speaks of these chapters as the "Interrupted Mail Bag."

The sales reported in the outside market yesterday were small even for a Saturday. The volume of business was so limited that there were few changes of importance in quotations. Even in the stocks which recently had been quite actively traded in the day's total was small, and with the single exception of corn products common none of the stocks which recently have been added to the list was dealt in to any considerable extent.

Mr. and Mrs. Ludovic Breitner and Leo Schulz will give chamber music recitals at Knabe Hall on Feb. 13 at 8:15, and on March 6. The programme of the first will consist of Dvorak's "Dumky" trio, Schumann's piano and violin sonata, opus 121, and Brahms's trio, opus 101.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The various newspaper reports of the sentence by Judge Warren W. Foster of our Court of General Sessions of G. Arthur Hill, alias Walter Curtis, who was recently pardoned by President Roosevelt, to six months' imprisonment in the penitentiary would convey the impression that Judge Foster had acted with undue severity and in disregard of the probably fatal nature of Hill's illness.

MEXICO as a land of fiestas ceases to exist this week. With the ushering in of Lent next week the whole country elves up the dances and almost daily celebrations of some sort or another to which it is accustomed and goes into mourning.

CARNIVAL MONTH, the merriest at the year in Porto Rico, opens today, although the actual festivities begin at noon to-morrow. To-morrow morning every lady in San Juan is expected to provide herself with a bag filled with confetti, and at exactly noon the carnival season will be opened with the first confetti battle, while a band plays through the principal streets of the city.
An empire flag! At last an ensign which shall adequately represent Great Britain both at home and beyond seas seems assured.

The Charity Organiation Society asks for a monthly pension to support the aged widow of a physician. She has been placed in a home, where, by the payment of $20 a month, she can be cared for during the remainder of her life. Money for this case may be sent to the Charity Organization Society, 105 East Twepty-second Street.

During the sojourn of the Wagners in Paris, from 1839 to 1842, they often had to face actual want. At these crises his wife, Minna, always tried to help her husband to the best of her ability. Once, when it seemed utterly impossible to him to procure even the amount necessary for their daily food, he suggested to Minna to pawn her few trinkets.

HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Sportsmen of this section are circulating a petition urging the Legislature to pass a bill allowing the shooting season of grouse, quail, and woodcock to open in October, 1902, for Rensselaer County. Shooting of this game has been prohibited for three years.

At Argonia, Kan., the remark is often made of a public gathering that "it was nearly as large as Charley Cox's temperance meeting," and thereby hangs a tale. Some thirteen years ago a woman temperance lecturer was billed to speak at Argonia.

WITHIN the past few months there has been established at 27-29 West Sixteenth Street a primary of books for the blind. It was founded and is controlled by Father Joseph Stadelman, a member of the St. Francis Navier Jesuit foundation in West Sixteenth Street. Its purpose is to furnish religious books to the blind of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Census Bureau has issued a preliminary report on the cotton manufactures of the United States. The following is a summary of the figures for the manufactures, exclusive of the small, wares: ...

How the earnings of the Chicago. Milwankee and St. Paul Railway Company have been stimulated by the exceptional Spring wheat crop harvested in its territory last year, how general conditions were effective in multifying the results of the shortage of 1900, and to what extent the tendency has been toward improvement in average resulsts during the past three years.

There are as many vagaries in the waters as in the winds. Why, for instance, should three great ocean currents send their warm waters across the wide Pacific, Atlantic, and across the Cape of Good Hope? There have been many theories advanced to solve the problem of their origin, but all have proved fallacious.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- The management of the Santa Fe Railroad has decided not to renew its contract with the Armour fruit car lines when it expires next Spring. The railroad company has been busily engaged for several months in building fruit cars, and by the time of the expiration of the contract it will have between 4,000 and 4,500 cars ready for service.

LAST February, as the 14th of the month drew near, not a few youths in New York were secretly wishing that valentines were not so awfully out of fashion. One of them suggested that while poems and cards were no longer to be thought of a valentine of flowers would be altogether novel.
Park Benjamin, the writer on naval topics, yesterday attacked the protest against Rear Admiral Schley's petition to the President as presented for Rear Admiral Sampson.

The frightful gas explosion in Chicago on the evening of Feb. 5, much more fatal than the explosion in the subway in this city a few days before, and attended with injury to a very much greater number of people, calls attention to the increasing menace to life and property which attends the distribution of gas in cities.

Copyright, 1902. LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The Southern Pacific tip, rather persistently circulated in the city this week, did not have much effect, as its exact meaning was mysterious, and English operators are always inclined to look on the dark side of Amercan tips in such circumstances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to Mr. Griffing's note in your issue of Feb. 4, in which he claims that the cost of living has increased more rapidly than the purchasing power of the dollar and the rate of wages, and also that the opportunity for employment and promotion in that employment has lessened greatly during the past fifty years, my observation and experience are directly opposite.
The third of the Kneisel Quartet's evening series of concerts will be given on Tuesday, at Mendelssohn Hall, at 8:15 o'clock. The programme will be as follows:
A Peep Here and There. For the jaded theatregoer who sees each new play as it is produced and who signs for more of novelty, one night's rounds with the theatrical reporter might prove entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Admiral Walker concluded his testimony before the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals to-day, and Col. Haupt, another member of the Isthmian Commission, is to be heard on Monday.

The formal opening of Earl Hall, the new $100,000 building presented to Columbia University by William Earl Dodge, will take place on March 8. On the afternoon of the day of dedication Mr. Dodge will receive his friends and the members of the Faculty in the reception room on the first floor, and in the evening the students will be welcomed to the new building.

There was much excitement yesterday afternoon in the aristocratic neighborhood of Clinton and Willoughby Avenues, Brooklyn, as a result of a fire which badly damaged the handsome residence of Edward T. Bedford of the Standard Oil Company, at 181 Clinton Avenue, between Willoughby and Myrtle Avenues.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 8. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners have just approved the plans for the new station and tracks of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at Bridgeport. The big roller lift bridge over the harbor will contain four main tracks, which will enter the station area by a long curve.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The controversy recently begun over the relative cost of living by Mr. Andrew Carnegie has brought out a number of mis-statements and erroneous ideas that should not be allowed to go unchallenged.

The two fish within the Aquarium that are the objects of the most admiration on the part of visitors are the angel and queen triggers from Bermuda. The angel fish, which are kept in two separate tanks, are more graceful than the queen triggers, but if it should come to a question as to which is the more lavishly colored it would take an expert to render an intelligent opinion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Consul General Barlow of Mexico City has made his annual report to the State Department. This will be published in full in Commercial Relations, 1901. The report deals with much that is of interest to the United States. Extracts from the report follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see from a recent issue of your paper that at a meeting of the Medical Association of the County of New York the Committee of Public Health, through its Chairman; Dr. N.E. Brill, made a report of its investigation into the antitoxin and vaccine virus products of the laboratories of the Department of Health.

To the country visitor who views the Houses of Parliament for the first time few things are more surprising than the undignified and easy-going attitudes in which he discovers our prominent politicians.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is seldom, indeed, that I "rush into print," but I cannot let the remarkable assertions of "J.H.M.," published in THE TIMES of Feb. 7, pass unchallenged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is announced from Albany that the Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill will come up in regular order next week in the Senate. This bill in its present form contains the Purely amendments, which were accepted by the Senate Committee on Taxation and incorporated in the bill.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8. -- Harvard's museums have been extremely fortunate this year in the number and value of the collections that have fallen into their hands. Excluding the magnificent gift which the German Emperor has made to the university, there remain a number of collections which have added greatly to the scientific possessions of Harvard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Representative Lanham of Texas, Democratic member of the House Judiciary Committee, presented to-day a minority report on the bill for the protection of the President against assault and conspiracy. While agreeing with the idea that the United States should not be made an asylum for Anarchists, he dissents from giving the President protection not accorded to other citizens.

THE society woman of to-day is the "new woman" in the true sense of that term. She spends her waking hours abroad in the land, going to and fro, driving or riding over the earth. The "claims" upon her time, invited or succumbed to by herself, are varied and manifold.

TO a reader of the newspapers who has followed with any cure the course of events in China, recent dispatches from Peking must have presented a puzzling problem. One day the news comes that the Chinese army and navy are to be reorganized under the direction of foreign experts; the next that China has given way to Russia on every point connected with the Manchuria, negotiations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The papers of this morning report that Senator Sullivan has introduced a bill at Albany which provides that "every passenger in a street railroad car shall be entitled to a seat and that no fare shall be demanded or collected of a passenger who has not been provided with a seat."

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 8. -- The last series of games in the Union-Middlesex League was rolled last night on the alleys of the Ilderan Club of Rahway, between the two leaders, the Ilderans and the Christ Church Club of this city, the former club winning by one game. Sperling's fine bowling won for him the high individual average prize and the prize for highest number of spares.
Money on call, 2 1/2 per cent. Time money, 3 1/2 per cent. for thirty to sixty days; 4 per cent. for ninety days. 4@ 4 1/4 per cent. for four months, 4@4 1/2 per cent. for five to six months.

The coming week at the Metropolitan Opera House will be somewhat irregular in programme, owing to the intrusion of Ash Wednesday. The regular subscription performance of Wednesday night will be transferred to Tuesday, and on Wednesday evening an extra entertainment will take place. The programme is as follows:

If the story of Helen Keller's life was not irrefutably established it would be regarded as pure romance and the creation of the wildest imagination; certainly, the story is as startling as it is unprecedented. For, although Miss Keller was blind and deaf and dumb, and has always been so, still patience and love have brought out of the darkness a soul so sweetly spiritual that she seems angelic rather than earthly.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- Money was not plentiful in the market to-day, but there was a good demand. Discounts were firm. Business on the Stock Exchange opened cheerfully, and with a general appearance of strength. Dealings, however, were restricted. High-class securities were firm on dear money.
IT was Alexandre Dumas who, coming from a representation of Myrrba, met a friend and asked:

To the Editor of The New York Times: A paragraph in "Topics of the Times" in your issue of this morning, in dealing with the crowding of trains on the Manhattan Elevated, practically admits the contention that the company" is doing its best" during rush hours. If that is interpreted to mean that trains cannot be run on less headway, it is probably true.

And now it is for the merry minstrel -- he of the black face and the snowy, rufffled shirt bosom, the singer of tearful ballads and the teller of ancient jokes. Who cares for the protestations of the press agent that every thins is new -- that the old-time methods of minstrelsy have been discarded. It's "the minstrels" -- that's enough.

It may not seem possible, but the fact is nevertheless borne out by trade statistics which can be relied upon for their accuracy that the consumption of pig iron in the United States during the late calendar year exceeded by more than 20 per cent, the volume which went into use in 1900, rising by an almost similar proportion over the result for 1899, when the previous high record was made.

BISHOP CONATY, rector of the Catholic University at Washington, while on a visit to Brooklyn recently, told of a priest's experience in a small New England town. The clergyman was just about to retire for the Light when he heard a knock at his door.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer, who is in no way either directly or indirectly interested in the stock of the United Stales Steel Corporation, would like to have some intelligent explanation to show why the preferred stock of this corporation does not commmand a higher price.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 8. -- One of the most brilliant racquet matches ever witnessed in this city was played in the court of the Philadelphia Racquet Club this afternoon. It was the deciding match in the inter-city series between New York and Philadelphia, and the latter team, consisting of Hugh D. Scott and George Brooke, defeated Clarence Mackay and Morton S. Patton after five exciting games.

The annual return of shipbuilding at home and abroad, issued by Lloyd's Register, shows that, not counting warships, 639 vessels, of 1,524,739 tons, of which 591, of 1,501,078 tons, were steamers, were launched in the United Kingdom during 1901. Including the forty-one warships launched at the Government and private yards, the total output amounts to 680 vessels, of 1,736,708 tons.

Before this week is passed there will be an unobstructed sulterranean passageway beneath the northwest corner of Central Park.
