The drills of the two shafts, one coining from Central Park West and the other from Lenox Avenue, are now within hearing distance of each other, and through less than 100 feet of solid rock the miners are signaling from the west to the east heading.

Six firemen were injured, three it is feared, fatally, in a fire which started shortly before midnight last night from some unexplained cause in the four-story building at Cumberland Street and Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, occupied by the wheelwright shop and truck manufactory of John Shadboldt and by J. K. Parker, manufacturer of women's waists.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- To-day's market in Philadelphia continued active and cheerful. United Gas surpassed yesterday's high range, rising 2 3/8 to 126, but fell back to 123 1/4.

RS. E.J. BERWIND'S gown for the Charity Ball was a finely ribbed deep rose pink silk. It was a moire in effect, with silver threads woven in it. The skirt was trained and perfectly plain. The low-cut bodice had wide shoulder straps -- or, rather, folds of black tulle, plaited, and with fine lines of silver sequins striping them.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- A sensation was caused to-night by the announcement by the Board of Health that Dr. Immanuel Pfeiffer, who voluntarily exposed himself to smallpox at the hospital of Galloupes Island about two weeks ago, is ill with smallpox in its worst form at his home in Bedford, and probably cannot live.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reference to your article the other day about the coming examination for the position of Sanitary Inspector in the recently created Tenement House Department, it may interest your readers to learn of my experience as one of the thousands of candidates to-day.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 8. -- The weather man's conscience must have bothered him about the snow, wind, and rain he sent to Lakewood last week, for he has been moved to make reparation, and as a result this resort is just now enjoying most glorious weather. The days are clear and sunny and just cold enough to make it a pleasure to be out of doors.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Vice Chancellor Emery to-day refused to grant an injunction to restrain the East Orange authorities from maintaining a smallpox hospital in South Clinton Street in that place. Father McManus and others asked for the injunction two weeks ago. The authorities secured affidavits from many physicians, who expressed the opinion that the presence of the hospital was not dangerous to the neighborhood.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The Excise Department to-day announced that it had not as yet received the letter which the Society for the Prevention of Crime is said to have sent to George Hilliard, Special Deputy Commissioner of Excise for the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx. It was stated that if the letter contains reports of specific violations of the law the department will take such action as may be deemed necessary.
IN the Museum of Natural History there is now to be seen an exhibit of rare minerals found on the Island of Manhattan.

The cold weather and high winds of yesterday proved a deterrent to the shooting at the Crescent Athletic Club's Bay Ridge traps. But few of the experts cared to shoot, and the scores made were not up to the usual average. Palmer, with a grand total of 44, led in the shoot of the February Cup, and he also shared with Marshall the honor of first place in the shoot for the Sylces Cup.

Vanderbilt issues have been among the features of the week, a number of new high records being scored as a result of the steady demand for the shares. Chicago and Northwest common being notably conspicuous. The Nickel Plate shares, Big Four, and Lake Erie and Western were little behind in point of activity and strength, the buying being largely for Vanderbilt interests.
PANAMA, Feb. 8. -- An accident in the Church of Borencitos, in Chiripui, resulted in the death of thirteen persons and the severe wounding of thirty others.

Rarely has the Columbia gymnasium held a larger or more enthusiastic crowd than that which witnessed the double victory scored by Columbia last night at basketball over teams representing Harvard and Yale. The more important game, the Intercollegiate League contest, between the Varsity and Harvard, was won rather easily by Columbia's team, which scored 28 points to Harvard's 11.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest practically everything you have printed on the New York Central question, but I do not think you or any of them have struck the practical solution. As long as a tunnel is necessary, first make it right, regardless of the power used.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- Emperor William is so incensed at the Spiritualist movement that he has issued a notification, through the North German Gazette, that all persons in any way connected with Spiritualists, faith healers, Christian Scientists, or kindred culls will hereafter be rigidly excluded from the imperial Court.

SILAS LARRABEE is not an excitable person, and seldom indulges in fits of impatience. I was astonished therefore when I saw him bound out of his chair last night, fling his newspaper on the floor, and kick the family hassock half way across the sitting room. His daughter opened her eyes in wonder.

Copyright, 1902. LONDON, Feb. 8. -- Our English friends all insist that the attempted baiting of "Arizona," which began almost with the rise of the curtain at the first performance at the Adelphi, is not due to hostile feeling of any part of the public toward American plays and actors.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 8. -- The better feeling in Cotton Duck continued to be the chief item of interest in the local market. The bullish attitude of cotten men generally toward the company has led the public to believe that the future holds out better possibilities. The report will be published next week, and that is counted on for information which will better the market position of the securities.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in this morning's paper entitled "Shoppers in Rush Hours," was certainly a very timely and humane one, and we think, intended to be entirely fair.
Major Carver Howland will be relieved from duty at Fort McDowell in time to enable him to join his regiment upon its arrival at San Francisco and to proceed with it to the Philippines.

LONG-CHERISHED landmarks in the Bronx region and historic spots of Revolutionary and romantic interest are now in grave peril of utter extinction by the resistless tide of modern improvements. Some are already doomed; others will follow them to oblivion, unless saved by sentimental and patriotic persons or societies who have the means to buy the land upon which they are located.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "J.H.M.," in Friday's TIMES, combats the proposition that the best conception of manhood and gallantry in America demands of a man that he should resign his seat to a lady rather than allow her to remain standing in his presence while he remains seated.

Buying has continued in all of those localities which hold out favorable prospects for building operations in the near future, and with a new field of speculative interest opened up by the announcements relative to the completion of the old North River tunnel, the week certainly has not been lacking in interesting developments.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 8 -- The annual indoor handicap games of the Boston Athletic Association were held to-night in Mechanics' Hall, with a big entry list and before an immense crowd of enthusiastic rooters. Many stars of the athletic world took part, and there were surprises in most of the events, when veterans were obliged to give way to younger blood.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is very encouraging to those who are looking for spiritual truth and willing to accept it to find a man so prominent as Dr. Parkhurst take the position he has taken regarding the immortality of the soul. That souls are not immortal is plainly taught in the Scriptures.

LANCASTER, Penn., Feb. 8. -- An attempt was made to rob the Gap National Bank of Gap, Penn., sixteen miles east of this city, early this morning. It ended in a lively exchange of shots between the town's watchman, David Stamix, and the burglars. Btamix heard an explosion in the direction of the bank, and found three or four men standing in front of the building.

-- A new note now sounds through the dispatches from South Africa. Hitherto there came in almost unbroken series story after story of Britons surprised by Boers. It was lamentably monotonous, and in some degree inexplicable, even by those of us who have read of the days when BRADDOCK, that gallantest of wooden heads, was a fair type of the British officer, and WOLFE a not more gallant exception.

After reading the report of the State Railroad Commission upon the causes of the collision in the Park Avenue tunnel no officer of the New York Central Railroad will venture to say that the criticisms of the press and public upon its management have been unreasonable, unintelligent, or heedless of the necessary relation of what ought to be done to what can be done.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Notwithstanding the fact that the Boerse was greatly disappointed at Great Britain's answer to the Dutch note, the general tone of the market during the week remained firm. Special interest during the week was attached to bank stocks. This was induced by the forthcoming loans and the conversion of the Hungarian 4 1/2 per cents to 3 per cents.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The Krum bill, amending the tax law in relation to the payment of State fees and taxes by foreign and domestic corporations, is on the order of their reading in the Senate, and may be moved for final passage on Tuesday or Wednesday of this week. There is a chance, however, that the bill may be laid aside for a week or recommitted for another hearing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- "Commercial Opportunities and Commercial Methods in Siberia" is the subject of a recent publi- cation in The Bulletin Commercial, published at Brussels, a copy of which has just reached the Treasury Department of Statistics. The Siberian merchant, it says, is even more intelligent, energetic, and en- terprising that the merchant of Russia, and his average capital is probably larger than that of the average Russian merchant.

Sixty men and sixty-five women, who were converted during the colored Baptist revival meetings in January at the Mount Olivet Baptist Church, at 161 West Fifty-third Street, were baptized yesterday morning at the rate of three a minute in the church amid scenes of great excitement and religious exaltation.

Mrs. Warren D. Hanford, who was robbed of $5,000 worth of jewelry at the San Remo oh Saturday morning, has recovered the greater part of the lost property. Mabel Hyman, twenty-four years old, of 271 West Fifty-second Street, and George Marvin of 233 West Fifty-fourth Street, were arrested yesterday afternoon charged with complicity in the theft.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- According to the estimates of the city authorities the number of persons burned out of house and home is 1,500, constituting about 300 families.

An entirely novel exhibition is one of the attractions for February. The National Arts Club, 37 West Thirty-fourth Street, has given hospitality in its galleries to an exhibition of things relating to streets and public buildings under the auspices of the Municipal Art Society. Such materials as can be brought together, relating to a matter so novel as civic art, are exposed in the pretty galleries of the club.

An elaborate dinner was given last night at the Hotel Majestic, Central Park West and Seventy-second Street, by Jacob Rothschild, one of the proprietors, to artists of the Metropolitan Opera Company and several dramatic artists and their friends who are staying at the Majestic. There were twenty-five guests present, and the cost of the dinner was $2,000.

Magistrate Crane, sitting in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday morning, took occasion when three ticket speculators were arraigned before him, to denounce the practice in general, and collusion between the speculators and theatre proprietors in particular. He said he understood the latter condition existed in some places.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- The activity on the Stock Exchange continues, and with the prospect of easy money for a considerable time to come there is a reasonable chance of prices going higher, in spite of the failure of the peace overtures and the lack of any considerable military success in South Africa.

Attempts to butter the parsnip of rec- iprocity with fine words from the pro- tectionist's dictionary of cant must al- ways fail. Senator HALE shows true insight and understanding when he says that "reciprocity is something which implies an injury to protection, in which I am a thorough believer."

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- One of the most remarkable features of the fire was the strangely curious way it had of jumping over certain buildings and destroying others. The most phenomenal jump made was from the public library building, near the stricken business section, to the Sandy Hill district, across the Erie Railroad tracks, and skipping fully a third of a mile of territory and leaving it absolutely unscathed.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9. -- Eleven persons lost their lives in an early morning fire, which destroyed the Empire Hotel, a three-story men's lodging house, at 2,700 Olive Street. The victims were ten men and one woman, and eight others were dangerously hurt. Ten or more who had narrow escapes from death were more or less injured by being frost-bitten.
It would be interesting to know the exact impressions that Mr. SHEPARD and Mr. NIXON made on each other at the big reception to the latter at the Democratic Club on Saturday night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Brooklyn Bridge presents a serious municipal problem. During the rush hours of the evening the trolley cars are over- taxed, but the cable car system is not used to its capacity. The growth of traffic in the last three years has been substantially as great as the present trolley traffic, and it is probable that within the next two years there will be a proportionate increase.

In the realization of the discomfort of the subway excavation, which is a matter of daily experience for every citi- zen of New York, we are apt to overlook the fact that the contractor has not only kept his promises in the matter of conforming to his schedule, but is materially ahead of it.

Indications point to fairly good golfing weather during the coming week, and as the first of February's holidays falls on Wednesday, Lincoln's Birthday, there will be considerable competitive activity on several links. The women's committee of the Lakewood Country Club has announced a kicker's handicap, open to all women players.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Seven full city blocks that once contained the chief business portion of the city are guarded in their complete darkness to-night by troops of the National Guard, and only smoldering ruins, from which now and then little blazes start up and silhouette a gaunt wall or a lone pier against the sky, remain of what was last night Paterson's proudest buildings.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Paterson has been under martial law since 7 o'clock tonight. About 400 National Guardsmen are patrolling all the streets bordering and touching upon the burned waste, which is lighted at intervals by sheets of flames and showers of sparks, the final ripples of the billows of fire that laid the business part of the city in ashes.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- The university observed the day of prayer for colleges here to-day. Several services were held, and the students manifested a great interest in all of them.
The Rev. Dr. Donald Sage Mackay in the morning service yesterday at the Collegiate Church, Forty-eighth Street and Fifth Avenue, preached a sermon entitled "A Plea for Christian Unity."

Maurice Grau announced yesterday after- noon that all of the arrangements for the visit of Prince Henry of Prussia to the opera on the night of Feb. 25, which have been in process of perfection by him and the Prince Henry Committee on Opera jointly, are practically settled.

The Rev. John Birkett is dead in Jackson County, Kan., and the story of his life forms a striking example of how misfortunes may pursue even a good man from the cradle to the grave. Mr. Birkett was born in England in 1818. He was a preacher there, but on coming to America in 1842 he became a merchant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The Executive Committee of what is known as the Justice Party has decided to call a National convention to meet in Washington April 19, 1902. One of the chief demands of this party is that aged and decrepit ex-slaves shall be the wards of the entire Nation and be provided for as public pensioners.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Among the first to respond to the alarm of fire were Mayor Hinchcliffe and Sheriff Sturr. When the Library Building was burning both were watching it. They noticed a man who seemed to be a little slow in leaving the burning structure. They found that he was the janitor and went into the building to tell him to come out on the street.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Two of the most daring burglars that ever operated in this city or vicinity visited East Orange early this morning. They entered the home of Mrs. W.H. Arrowsmith, at 24 Hawthorne Avenue, East Orange. She is a widow, and lives with her fifteen-year-old son and a four-year-old child.

Two children, one eight and one mix years old, the daughters of Dr. R. Berlinger, died from suffocation at 9:05 o'clock yesterday morning while a fire was in progress on the top floor of the doctor's residence at 131 East Seventy-fourth, Street. Heroic efforts on the part of the children's parents, their nurse, a policeman, and a citizen, to save the children resulted in failure.

Ben Tillett, the English Socialist, who came here some time ago to attend the convention of the American Federation of Labor as a fraternal delegate of the British Trades Union Congress, was censured severely at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union.

The transatlantic liners Lucania and Philadelphia, that were due on Saturday, but which were delayed by strong winds and high seas, reached their piers on the North River yesterday morning, apparently none the worse for their rough experience.

The cross-country runners had a big day of it yesterday. Five runs were held over the Jerome Avenue course, in the Bronx, while the Star Athletic Club, in Long Island City, lengthened its usual Sunday run to six and one-half miles, in preparation for the big handicap run of the Pastimes next Sunday.

The loss by the fire which destroyed the big plant of the Shadbolt Manufacturing Company, at Flushing Avenue and Cumberland Street. Brooklyn, early yesterday morning according to what is given as a conservative estimate, is not less than $300,000. The Shadbolt factory, which was a four-story brick structure, with a frontage of 123 feet on Flushing Avenue, and extending back 150 feet on Cumberland Street, is a complete ruin.
LONDON, Feb. 10. -- From Wolvehoek Lord Kitchener yesterday telegraphed a long description of a combined movement of numerous British columns with the ob- ject of securing Gen. De Wet.

Gen. Stewart L. Woodford presided over the mass meeting for men held yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at which Dr. Lyman Abbott made a plea for local option in an address on "The Saloon Question in New York."

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9 -- Late this afternoon Under Sheriff Townsend received word from President Underwood of the Erie Railroad, through a personal representative, that the Erie was ready to assist with money and in any other way in caring for the homeless and destitute of Paterson. President Underwood said that he would have as many Pullman palace cars run on to the side tracks here as was necessary to accommodate all who were homeless.

ACWORTH, Ga., Feb. 9. -- Safe blowers j forced the vaults of the Lemon Banking Company here early this morning, securing $5,000 in gold, a Georgia State bond for $5,000, and a large number of stock certificates. Between $45,000 and $50,000 in notes, stock certificates, and bonds were hopelessly mutilated by the explosion, and much currency and small bills destroyed.

The Paterson conflagration with its property loss, which is at present roughly estimated at $8,000,000, is likely to rank as one of the great conflagrations during the last hundred years in the United States and Canada.
PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Some idea of the destruction wrought by the fire may be gathered from the following description:

Jersey City was visited yesterday by the most disastrous fire, it has suffered in several years. Fortunately it was outside the residential part of the city and was confined entirely to the water front of the South Cove and the freight yard of the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Gov. Murphy of the State arrived in Paterson late this afternoon. He was accompanied by three members of his staff, and went at once to the Court House, where he met Mayor Hinchcliffe and Sheriff Sturr. He preferred the sympathy of the State to the citizens of Paterson and promised all the relief the State could afford.

The efforts of the regular police force and private detectives to find Mrs. Char- lotte Hopkins Seixas of Brooklyn, who has been missing since Jan. 24 last, have thus far been unsuccessful. At the time of her disappearance Mrs. Seixas was living at the home of her stepfather, Elias T. Hopkins, a retired, business man, of 14 First Place, Brooklyn.

Wolves and coyotes have again descended on the fold in Nebraska. Scarcity of feed on the western ranges, owing to the short growth of grass and the consequent diminution of the herds and flocks, together with the unceasing warfare that has been waged against these outlaws of the West, has driven them nearer to civilization this Winter than they have come in many years.

A fire in Paterson, N.J., yesterday that laid waste the principal business portion of the city, destroying there about fifty buildings, and then jumped over more than a third of a mile and razed to the ground a hundred dwellings did damage that is conservatively estimated at about $8,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The second part of the report of the Industrial Commission was made public to-day. It covers manufactures and industrial combinations, and in its recommendations quotes from its report to Congress in 1900, when it then recommended that the promoters and organizers of corporations or industrial combinations looking to the public to purchase or deal in their stocks or securities should be required to furnish full details regarding the organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The third part of the Industrial Commission's final report was made public to-day. It treats of labor, immigration, taxation, and irrigation. Regarding labor, it is recommended that all engineers and switchmen should submit to an examination for color blindness; that it should be a misdemeanor for an engineer or switchman to be intoxicated while on duty.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Thirty laborers were set to work to-day to break ground for the new two-hundred-and-fifty-thousand-dollar gymnasium which will be erected on the south campus. The contractors already have received a large quantity of material, and will keep a large force of men employed to rush the construction as rapidly as possible.

DETROIT, Feb. 10 -- Vice President Frank C. Andrews of the City Savings Bank, which has been in the hands of State Banking Commissioner George L. Maltz since this morning, was arrested late this afternoon, and arraigned at 9:30 o'clock to-night on the charge of "willfully, fraudulently, and knowingly" securing from the bank, without security and without the knowledge of the other Directors, a sum exceeding $1,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- Assemblyman James A. Alien of the Ninth District of New York, which is Republican National Committeeman Gibbs's district, to-night introduced a bill designed to permit the removal from office of every Tammany official. In speaking of his bill, Mr. Alien said: "I am responsible for the bill and no one else.
There is something infinitely pitiful in the fate of the children who were burned, or, more probably, suffocated, in their home in East Seventy-fourth Street on Sunday morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Representatives of all the baseball leagues of the country met here to-day to revise and establish the playing rules on a uniform basis, and to have them so worded that they may be easily understood by amatours and professionals alike.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 10 -- The case of B.D. Greene, John F. Gaynor. E.T. Gaynor, and W.H. Gaynor, indicted jointly with O.M. Carter, formerly Captain of Engineers, United States Army, and Michael A. Connolly, Carter's secretary, will be called in the Federal District Court to-morrow.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 10 -- Clearing House rate to-day was 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5 cents discount. Call loans, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.; time money, 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $18,240,642; balances, $1,432,018. The weekly bank statement shows loans, $186,233,000, a decrease of $1,463,000; deposits, $157,022,000, a gain of $187,000; reserve excess, $1,749,280, a gain of $42,715.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The efforts of the German official and semi-official press to reopen the controversy concerning the attitude of the powers toward the United States prior to the Spanish-American war are rapidly leading to complications which at least will be entertaining, and which possibly may have important developments.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- State Controller Hancock to-night placed his resignation in the hands of Gov. Murphy, as the result of the election of ex-Mayor Briggs of Trenton to the office of State Treasurer. He opposed Mr. Briggs's election, and at the time he said to the Governor that if Mr. Briggs was elected he would resign as Controller.

BERLIN, Feb, 10 -- A dispatch announcing the gravity of the condition of President Roosevelt's son was communicated to Prince Henry this afternoon, and was communicated by him to the Emperor. Deep sympathy for Mr. Roosevelt was manifested at the Schloss. The Foreign Office expects to receive to-night from Dr. von Holleben, the German Ambassador at Washington, a report on the condition of the President's son.

Randolph Guggenheimer, ex-President of the Municipal Council, was entertained at a banquet at the Hotel Savoy last night by more than 100 of his friends, Republicans and Democrats, who wished him a speedy return into municipal politics.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- The great conflagration which burned its way through the heart of Paterson yesterday has at last completely spent its force, and its last embers are quickly dying out in the ashes broken brick, and twisted iron of its ruin Fanned by a strong wind last night it burned up fitfully in spots, but wherever the flames showed threatening strength that firemen beat them down.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with the payment of calls for colonial issues and tenders for a million in Treasury bills, the applications for the latter amounting to u6,729,000. Discounts hardened in sympathy. Attention on the Stock Exchange centred in Kafirs, which, were buoyant and in renewed demand, the war news being regarded as satisfactory.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Creed Committee of the Presbyterian Church, now sitting in this city, disposed of considerable work to-day, it coming to a definite decision on several vital points in the Confession of Faith. The work done is best summed up in the official statement given out by Dr. William H. Roberts of this city, the Stated Clerk of the General Assembly, and the Secretary of the committee.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 10 -- The Court of Appeals this morning rendered a decision which will cost the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company $300,000. In a decision by the Presiding Judge, Adair Wilson, the railroad company must pay the losses in the tire which swept a portion of Colorado Springs. Oct. 1, 1898.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is somewhat surprising that your editorial columns to-day contain no comment upon, the letter of Secretary Long to Admiral Sampson, notifying him of his retirement. It is difficult to see wherein Mr. Long's offense differs from that of Gen. Miles.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 10 -- A schooner with three masts, the name of which is unknown, was burned out at sea to-night. Her crew is believed to be in small boats about where she was, but they are caught in the ice. The tire broke out about 5 o'clock this afternoon, and soon could be seen from the shore.

The nightly congestion at the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge is dangerous. So long as the present system is maintained with a loop consisting of four tracks upon which cars of the different Brooklyn lines receive their passengers there will be delay, crowding, and infinite confusion.

It is gratifying to be assured that the new Secretary of the Treasury is going into a serious investigation of the complaints about the treatment of returning American travelers at this port. Nothing in Mr. GAGE'S administration less became him than the magazine article in which he maintained that there was nothing the matter with a system that seems to infuriate almost every man, and quite every woman, who is subjected to its operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read the different letters in THE TIMES, "touchin' on," , the amenities of the situation in a surface or elevated car, of a gentleman sitting and a lady standing, when all seats are occupied, prompts me to give my views. True courtesy requires the surrender of the seat to the lady -- who is a fellow-passenger -- on the part of the gentleman sitting.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 10 -- The most destructive fire in the history of Springfield was discovered in the Champion Chemical plant of the East Street shops to-day at 9 A.M. An hour and a half later twelve manufacturing plants were in total ruin. The latest estimated loss is $500,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- The Orpheum Theatre in Washington Street, opposite the City Hall, this morning suffered $30,000 damage by fire, believed to of incendiary origin. Three attaches of the theatre and two hotel tailors, who were in the building when the fire started, were overcome by smoke and severely burned before they could be rescued.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 10 -- The Rev. Oliver Hemstreet, a Presbyterian minister, caused a stir and no little indignation in the meeting of the Presbyterian ministers to-day by the harsh statement that "President McKinley was assassinated by an Anarchist, but he reaped only what he sowed."

The two-platoon system of police patrol was resumed in this city at 8 A.M. yesterday. It takes the place of the three-platoon system which police Commissioner Murphy adopted upon the recommendation of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, last August.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- The preliminary report of Expert Accountant Harvey S. Chase, employed by Mayor Collins to investigate the financial condition of the city departments, which shows that the Boston Municipal Government's total expenditures per capita of population exceed those of New York by 18 1/2 per cent. and exceed the average of ten other cities by 172 per cent. was sent to the Board of Aldermen to-day.

Two new points were brought out by the prosecution at the trial yesterday of Albert T. Patrick charged with the murder of the millionaire William M. Rice. One was made through the testimony of John R. Potts, Patrick's friend, that the latter, six days before Mr. Rice died, on Sept. 17, 1900, days blank checks, ostensibly signed by the aged millionaire, with the will, making film residuary legatee, and the assignments, in his possession.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- In continuing his statement concerning conditions in the Philippine Islands before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day, Gov. Taft said that the estimate for preliminary expenses in those islands must include a considerable outlay for school buildings.
The second part of the report of the Industrial Commission just published contains this recommendation:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- There was a sequel to-day to the recent "treason and sedition" talk in the Senate, in which Mr. Foraker, (Rep., Ohio,) had to repel single handed the attacks of a number of anti-imperialist Senators of both parties who wanted to convince him that the sedition laws of the Philippines were un-American.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 10 -- The following is a, list of the losses in the business section of the city, which was prepared late this afternoon by several well-known authorities on Paterson values, and is believed to be approximately correct. It does not, however, take into account the losses of the lawyers and other tenants in the office buildings, and the many smaller tenants:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 10 -- Commdore B.P. Morris's ice yacht Mildred of the South Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club won the race to-day for the Commodore's Silver Cup over a fifteen-mile triangular course. Of the three boats entered in the event, the Mildred was the only one to finish.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 10 -- The fire which visited Paterson did not spare merchants of this city in its far-reaching calamities. A number of local dealers, members of the New jersey Retail Merchants' Protective Association, will be called upon for heavy assessments. Connected with the association is a fire insurance auxiliary.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Another change has taken place in the proprietorship of The Daily News, George Cadbury having bought out his co-partners. A number of new departures are contemplated. A special feature will be made of social reform. Betting and turf news will be rigidly excluded from the paper, but the reporting of other sports will be continued.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 10 -- Miss Percy Haswell, the proprietor of the Percy Haswell Stock Company, which is established at Chase's Lyceum Theatre, will at the close of the current theatrical year cease to be a permanent factor in the amusement field here. Miss Haswell to-day concluded an agreement covering a long term of years, by the terms of which she will star under H.B. Harris's management, beginning next September.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10 -- The Philadelphia stock market to-day was vigorous in tone and in some respects more than ordinarily active. The features were United Gas, Union Traction, Steel, and the Readings. Everybody seemed to have buying orders, particularly for the second preferred and common Readings.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- In his opening prayer in the Assembly to-night the Rev. A.L. Love alluded feelingly to the affliction Gov. Odell had sustained in the death of his mother and invoked Divine consolation to assuage the grief of the stricken family. The Chaplain also prayed that President Roosevelt's son might speedly recover from his serious illness.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 10 -- In addition to an order placed with the Southern Car and Foundry Company of Birnmingham, Ala., last week by the Norfolk and Western Railway for 1,000 box cars and 75 coal cars, that road to-day announced its intention to place an order for 500 flat cars with the Roanoke Machine Works of this city.

Annual meetings of several express companies are to be held this week, and there was renewed talk in Wall Street yesterday of mergers between the large companies. Inquiry of President Fargo of the American Express Company, President Wier of the Adams, and Vice President Crosby of the United States, brought forth positive statements that no combination plans were in prospect.

Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, Chairman of the Committee on Entertainment of the Officers and Men of the Hohenzollern, which met at the Chamber or Commerce yesterday, announced after the meeting that all the proposed receptions in honor of the officers of the imperial yacht before the arrival of the Prince are off.

Hegleman and Cavanagh, the Irish-American team, managed to hold the lead all day yesterday in the six-day go-as-you-please pedestrian race in the Madison Square Garden. They were hard pressed, however, by the so-called Indian team. Davis and Carroll, both of the latter showing up very strong every hour while on the track, and they monopolized the lively sprints of the day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 10 -- The Faculty of Yale University will shortly be asked to sanction a plan to secure an undergraduate and graduate Advisory Council in athletic matters. At present the managers and Captains of the several teams act under the advice of Walter Camp, the athletic adviser of the Faculty, with final submission of all important matters affecting the university's policy in athletic matters to the undergraduate mass meetings.
Dr. LYMAN ABBOTT touches the very heart of the excise question when he declares that local option, applied at intervals of a few years, is the only possible way toward a solution.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- The opponents of the Anti-Pigeon Shooting bill have adopted a new plan of campaign. Realizing the improbability of defeating the measure in an open, fair fight, they are now scheming to have the measure amended in a manner which will render it impotent for the purpose intended.

Our news columns yesterday were almost wholly surrendered to stories of conflagrations, great and small, and the startling character of the calamities which have visited our own and neighboring cities may well set the reader to thinking whether the system of fire insurance which permits so many hazardous and extra hazardous risks to be underwritten is working to the public advantage.

Shrove Tuesday, the last day of the Carnival, will not be celebrated in New York with any particular observance. There are a few dinners this evening, and that is all. Among those who will entertain are Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lehr. Mr. and Mrs. Pembroke Jones, Mr. and Mrs. B. Rollins Morse, and Miss Leary.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Secretary of State for War, the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, confirmed the report that the Government had decided to withdraw the British troops at Wei-hai-Wei, on the Shan-Tung Peninsula, and to proceed no further with the building of fortifications at that place.
Officers for the coming year were elected as follows at the annual meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club, which was held in the banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria last night:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The Washington social season was brought to a close this evening by the Assembly ball at the Arlington Hotel, which annual function was participated in by 400 guests, mainly from resident circles, although nearly every State in the Union and most foreign powers with Embassies or Legations in Washington were also represented.

If the man who rents opera glasses at the Casino will put in a large supply of ear muffs and blue goggles he ought to feel reasonably sure of a thriving business during the next few weeks. Persons whose nerves have not been hardened in a boiler factory will certainly require the former for a full enjoyment of the so-called "operatic-comedy" "Miss Simplicity," produced by Frank Daniels and his company last night.

A short conference was held yesterday afternoon between President Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company and William McCarroll and James T. Hoile, respectively Chairman and Secretary of the Committee of Fifty of the Manufacturers' Association, at which plans for the relief of traffic conditions on the Brooklyn Bridge were discussed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- The second caucus of the Republicans of the House of Representatives to consider the question of action looking to reducing the Congressional representation of the Southern States which abridge the suffrage, was held in the Hall of Representatives to-night.

Yesterday was another dull day in the outside market, and very few stocks attracted special attention. Although in some parts of the list this dullness was accompanied by recessions in pripes, quotations for the most part remained firm. In some few instarices sharp advances over Saturday's 'figures were recorded.'

Speculators and others who affected at the close of last week to find reasons for nervousness in the "bad bank statement," and who were full of grave forecasts for the security market, did not figure yesterday in the light of prophets entitled to much credit. Instead of general weakness, the market was strong all day long, and the net changes of the day make a substantial list of advances.

An attempt to smuggle through an amendment to the Building Code was discovered yesterday, and the members of the Board of Aldermen who went to the City Hall spoke against the means used to obtain the proposed change in the method of constructing skyscrapers.

The plan to keep trucks and heavy vehicles off of Fifth Avenue between Twenty-fifth and Fifty-ninth Streets, from 2 to 7 o'clock in the afternoon from Oct. 1 to May 31, was discussed yesterday at a public hearing before the Aldermanic Committee on Streets and Highways.
BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- The official North German Gazette this evening joins in the controversy regarding the attitude of the powers previous to the outbreak of the Spanish-American war.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT of THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

Verdi's "Otello" was repeated last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. As is usually the case when this intensely dramatic and highly wrought work is presented, the audience was chiefly in the lower part of the house. The galleries were not filled, and there were many empty seats even in the dress circle.

Mr. Coleman is one of our American painters who have dwelt so long in the same special environment abroad that they have absorbed the local peculiarities like the natives. In the exhibition Mr. Coleman made several years ago the picture that found most favor in certain quarters was a view of the cliff of Anacapri and the central part of the island; it contained so much of the peculiar charm of the spot!

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Sir Thomas Lipton's third challenger for the America's cup will be tested against the Shamrock II. with an American skipper and crew on board the latter. This decision is the outcome of the statement that the Columbia was better handled during the cup races of last year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- During a fight with Winchester rifles between the followers of rival claimants to-property lying along the Lake Shore Drive, the most aristocratic boulevard in Chicago, Prank Kirk, a watchman for one of the claimants, was shot through the head this evening, sustaining a mortal wound.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Representative Samuel W. McCall, (Rep., Mass.,) who has introduced a bill to do away with the outrages committed in baggage inspection at the Port of New York, is of the opinion that the Inspectors have been unfairly charged with the responsibility for these outrages.

Ex-United States Attorney General John W. Griggs, at the dinner of the Silk Association of America last night, in a speech reaffirmed the Republican Party platform of protection and reciprocity, arraigned Congress for failing to ratify the reciprocity treaties negotiated with Cuba by President McKinley, and warned the Republican Party that it would be dangerous to disregard public sentiment on this subject.

The issue of veracity is so unpleasant when pushed to the extreme that in the interest of good understanding and friendship it may be suggested that the Berlin Foreign Office should re-examine the documentary basis for its charge that on April 14, 1898, the British Ambassador at Washington suggested to the other diplomatic representatives of foreign powers joint action of a nature unfriendly to us.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Frank H. Mason, United States Consul General in Berlin, sends the following report to the State Department on "Germany's Dependence on Imported Grains":

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 11 -- The Treasurer of the Kansas India Relief Committee has telegraphed $83.50 to those who suffered on account of the Paterson fire. This amount is all that remains of the committee's fund. It had come in since the last draft was sent to India to relieve the famine sufferers, and the Commissioners were awaiting a good opportunity for its use.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- A member of the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals said to-day that in his judgment the committee was in a "pretty fair shape" to consider the great question before it.

Compared with many London streets or with the chief boulevards of Paris, Fifth Avenue is not an overcrowded thoroughfare. Any observer who will take the time and trouble to study the currents of travel during the crowded hours will perceive that it is not the number of vehicles so much as marked variation in rates of speed that causes confusion, blockades, and delay.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Senator Krum's much amended foreign corporation tax bill was to have come up in the Senate this morning for a final vote, but at the last moment Senator Krum, who is Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, decided to join with the Assembly Committee on Taxation to give another hearing on the bill this afternoon.

That "the play's the thing" after all, the popularity of stars and actors generally notwithstanding has been emphasized in an unmistakable fashion recently in New York theatres. There is no necessity to individualize, for it must be patent to all persons familiar with what is current on the stage whence the inspiration for that conclusion comes.

That Germany should wish to live at peace with the United States is of good omen for the tranquillity of the world, or, rather, it will be so as soon as substantial evidence is forthcoming that we are not merely in presence of a tactical move prompted by the somewhat altered relations of Germany with certain European, great powers.

W.H. Sigourney, the Pacific Coast champion, won the evening game at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club in the 14.2 billiard tournament of the Amateur Athletic Union for the championship of Class A. from J.A. Hendrick. The afternoon game, a contest of fifty-two innings, resulted in favor of Dr. Mial, who beat Dr. Miller rather handily by a score of 400 to 257.

BUFFALO, Feb. 11 -- The members of the different baseball associations who are revising the playing rules resumed their work this morning. The text of Sections 3 and 4 of Rule 44, defining a strike, as finally adopted, is:

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- New York exchange to-day was at 30 cents premium. Time and call loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Interest in the local market continues to centre in the street railway stocks, and most of these are again strong to-day. Biscuit also was moved up somewhat on what appeared to be buying of an excellent character.

Superintendent York of the City Lodging House kept a telephone wire hot last night trying to find some one, or some institution, that would receive and take proper care of two small children who were suffering from whooping cough. He was unsuccessful, and in the end had to provide for the children as best he could himself.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday was fairly active, notwithstanding the approach of the holiday, and prices remained firm. In some parts of the list quotations were under selling pressure, but in few cases were any substantial declines brought about by the liquidation. There was very little news directly affecting the stocks dealt in on the curb, and all told the day was a very quiet one.

Very little, if anything, has been said in this country about the proposition of Chile to the Boers. It is, however, a serious proposition. As we learn from Paris, the general agent of the Chilean Government at that capital has communicated to the press the terms which he is empowered to offer to such of the Boers as desire to abandon South Africa when the British conquest of the country is completed.

Hugues Le Roux, the author, traveler, and lecturer, and a member of the Legion at Honor, who comes to America to lecture, beginning at Harvard to-day, was an arrival on the French liner La Gascogne yesterday morning. M. Le Roux on his arrival went to the residence of James H. Hyde, 9 East Fortieth Street, where during the day he consented to talk to reporters.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- King Edward's first levee since his accession to the throne was held in St. James's Palace at noon to-day, and was an exceptionally brilliant affair. The Prince of Wales, the Duke of Connaught, and other members of the royal family were present, and the gathering of members of the Diplomatic Corps, Cabinet Ministers, and naval and military officers was unprecedentedly large.

PHOENIX, Arizona, Feb. 11 -- In a desperate fight with a gigantic rattlesnake, G, Wharton James, famous as a Western author and scientist, was fatally bitten to-day. At a curiosity shop here is an immense rattlesnake, the largest ever in captivity, which had killed two men who had attempted to handle it.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 11 -- Lynde Harrison of New Haven, executor of the estate of the late Henry B. Plant, under the rulings of the Connecticut courts, came here to-day and paid into the State Treasury $8,834,832, as the succession tax. Yesterday he had reported to Judge Cleaveland, in the Probate Court in New Haven, that the value of the estate was $16,000,000, but some of it was not liable for the tax.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to an editorial article in your paper of last Sunday, in which I am quoted as having said that "I am through," relating to the crush at the New York and Brooklyn Bridge, and thereupon you pass a criticism upon me which I consider unjust.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Senator Carmack (Dem., Tenn.,) introduced to-day the following joint resolution:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- After several days of broadening the Philadelphia market narrowed to-day, and became inactive, and the local issues generally slightly lower. Reading was strong and active, the demand for the second preferred exceeding any single day's transactions this year. This strength helped all the steam roads.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 11 -- The local market developed a more generally bullish feeling, which attested itself in the broader range of securities dealt in and the larger proportion of issues which advanced. Consolidated Gas lifted 1 1/4 points on rumors that a securities company is forming which will buy the traction and illuminating companies in a number of the big cities.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Evidence that the Democrats in the Legislature have no recognized leadership and that they are seriously divided upon questions of policy accumulate daily. Senators Grady and Sullivan favor the Stranahan mortgage tax bill. Leader Nixon of Tammany Hall is said to be opposed to it.

Further activity and further strength marked yesterday's security market. Those issues which have recently been conspicuous were still the market's leaders. Developments in some variety, though none of striking character, figured in the news of the day which Wall Street discussed.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Viscount Cranborne, replied in the House of Commons yesterday to a question by Henry Norman (Liberal) regarding the Spanish-American war controversy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial headed "The Fire Record" in to-day's paper hits a big nail on the head. Have your readers ever considered that at least one-half, perhaps threequarters, of the waste by fire of life and property is due to the institution of fire insurance as at present organized and operated?

Application has been made to the Wisconsin Insurance Department for a license to do business in that State by the Chippewa Valley Casualty Company of Eau Claire, and the Consolidated Fire and Marine Insurance Company of Albert Lea, Minn.

The plumbers of at least two States are learning from disagreeable experience that to maintain a conspiracy in restraint of trade, with high-handed rules framed to drive from the business all who do not conform to the regulations prescribed by the National Association of Master Plumbers, is dangerous even if profitable.

The Tammany Hall organization of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District in mass meeting assembled last evening declared against Richard Croker ever resuming the leadership of Tammany Hall. When this announcement was made in a speech by the district leader, James J. Martin, the men present threw their hats in the air and shouted themselves hoarse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Mr. Teller, (Silver Rep., Col.,) who had the floor when the Senate adjourned yesterday, continued his speech on the Philippine tariff question to-day. He did not think the folding of the islands by this Government ever would be profitable. Nobody believed, he insisted, that the United States could force upon the Filipinos our Government or our civilization.

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 11 -- Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., who has been ill with pneumonia for five days at the Groton School infirmary, was pronounced better at 8 o'clock to-night than at the same time last night. The last sick room bulletin for the day was given out at 11 o'clock, when there was every indication for a favorable night.

The Buyers' Association of America gave an entertainment last night at Carnegie Hall in aid of the bulialng fund of the society. Judging from the size of the audience the entertainment must have been as successful from a financial point of view as it was in every other respect.

Friends of Clyde Fitch are considerably worried over a prolonged illness of the playwright, which confined him to his home, 113 East Fortieth Street, for over a week. Yesterday Mr. Fitch left for Atlantic City in the hope that the change might do him good.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 11 -- Julia Junkin, Ranco, and Sir Florian were the winning favorites to-day. In the handicap, Death, the favorite, was hemmed in by Andes and Lady Alberta and bumped first by one and then by the other all the way. Slack and Thompson finally came to blows with their whips, and both were set down for the remainder of the meeting.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 11 -- One of the most exciting ice yacht races ever sailed on the North Shrewsbury River took place this afternoon. The triangular course was sailed over four times, and the time -- 23 minutes -- was the fastest ever sailed for ten miles by the third-class boats. Most of the yachts carried reefed sails.

VIENNA, Feb. 11 -- The reports of the various committees appointed by the Minister of Commerce to consider the best means of meeting American competition will be handed in to-morrow. Forecasts of the reports obtained to-day show that the committees differ in regard to the efficiency of protective tariffs.

DETROIT, Feb. 11. -- A receiver will be appointed by Judge Donovan to-morrow morning for the wrecked City Savings Bank. At a hearing this afternoon in the Chancery Court, the county officers and the local Board of Education opposed the appointment of the Union Trust Company, which was the choice of Banking Commissioner Maltz and the Attorney General.

Archbishop Corrigan has accepted an invitation to attend the dinner to be given toy the New Yorker Staats-Zeitung to the American press in honor of Prince Henry of Prussia, and as the dinner will take place on the evening of Feb. 26, a Lenten fast day, the Archbishop, at the solicitation of Herman Ridder.

That Mr. E.F. Milliken is a Very discriminating person in his choice oil pictures one can see at a glance on entering the upper gallery of the American Art Association. From nearly every frame among the twenty-six comes a Hash of interest, ana from some the clear signs of genius beckon.
LONDON, Feb. 12 -- A Parliamentary paper was issued last night giving the terms of an alliance between Great Britain and Japan for the preservation of the integrity of China and Korea.

Handwriting expert testimony and the stubborn fight of the defense to keep out of the record all expert testimony prejudicial to Albert T. Patrick, marked yesterday's session of the trial of Patrick upon the charge of murdering Millionaire William Marsh Rice.

The incorporation of a company to complete the old Hudson River tunnel, with the avowed purpose of having trolley cars running through it within eighteen months, is gratifying evidence that the advantages of the "submerged bridge" are securing recognition and that capital and enterprise are actively enlisted in solving the problem of correcting the disadvantage which New York suffers from its insular position.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The Washington correspondent of The Times says the North German Gazette's statement in regard to Lord Pauncefote's alleged action at an Ambassadorial meeting on April 14, 1896, is known in Washington to be untrue. Telegraphing before the publication in America of Lord Comborne's statement in the House of Commons, says the correspondent, he does not hesitate to state, from information obtained from independent sources, what happened.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- At the Republican House caucus, held last night to coneider the matter of Southern representation, Representative Tayler (Rep.) of Ohio called attention to the Federal statute of June 23, 1868, fixing the terms upon which the Confederate States should be admitted to representation in Congress.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- The Senate Cities Committee gave hearings this afternoon on three bills of special interest to New York City. The first hearing was on the Marshall bill, providing that there shall be a municipal clubhouse for boys in each borough of Greater New York, and that the city shall appropriate the sum of $10,000 for each clubhouse.

Over 1,000 peddlers of fish of the east side of Manhattan stormed the citadel of the City Hall yesterday in an attempt to appear before Mayor Low and state their grievances. They formed in a solid mass, and marching through the streets of the east side, headed toward the City Hall, with Abraham Denowitz in the lead.

BRYN MAWR, Penn., Feb. 11 -- The Alumnae Association of Bryn Mawr College held its annual meeting here, and the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: Member of the Academic Committee, Mary B. Breed, '94, Ph. D., 1901, the Dean of Women of the Indiana University; President, Elizabeth B. Kirkbride, '96; Vice President, Martha G. Thomas, '90; Recording Secretary, Elizabeth Nields, '98; Corresponding Secretary, Edith C. Crane, 1900; Treasurer, Jane B. Haines, '91.

The Guden-Dady affair was the subject of stormy discussion last night at a meeting of the Kings County Republican General Committee. The war of words was precipitated by the introduction of a resolution repudiating the nomination of Sheriff Guden and placing the responsibility for all the unpleasantness that has grown out of the same upon the Executive Committee of the organization.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Leading bankers at this State are taking steps to bring about a conference of the banks of the State, with the idea of establishing a uniform rate for the State and municipal funds that may be deposited with them. There is a prospect of a rate war for the possession of the moneys.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Prince Henry of Prussia will sail for the United States on Saturday as arranged, even though Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., continues to be critically ill. Should his illness result fatally before Saturday, the Prince will probably continue his journey, unless it should appear to be President Roosevelt's desire that the visit be deferred or abandoned.
According to Toledo, Ohio, dispatches shipments of coal, while largely increased, have not kept up with the demand and a serious shortage is again threatened through the Middle States.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 11 -- Laborers are one of the greatest needs of this fire-swept city, and no able-bodied man to-day offered to work but that he found anxious bidders for his services. The demand for toilers will grow rapidly as the business men of the community recover from the paralyzing effects of the catastrophe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Ways and Means Committee is still "deliberating" over the Cuban tariff question.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Money was short today, and in brisk request. Discounts were steady. The dealings on the Stock Exchange were much interrupted by the adjustment of the account. The tendency was good, Gilt-edge securities were firm. Home rails were irregular, Americans, responding to the buoyancy in New York, opened above parity, especially Southern Pacifies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11 -- Harvard undergraduates are glad to learn that Yale entertains the idea of forming a stable athletic committee very similar to the one in existence at Harvard. The students at Cambridge believe that if Yale does form such a committee it will be a big step toward solving the difficulty which now keeps the two colleges from coming together and forming an athletic agreement.

LONDON, Feb. 11 -- Sir Thomas Lipton will accept the committee's invitation to be present at the Olympian games to be held in Chicago in 1904, and, if possible, will bring the new America's Cup challenger to sail on the Lakes. To a representative of The Associated Press, Sir Thomas said to-night:

On Dec. 24 last Gov. WILLIAM JENNINGS of Florida had occasion to fill out and sign a document directing the Sheriff of Putnam County, that State, to perform on Jan. 25 the unpleasant task of hanging up by the neck until he was dead one J.B. BROWN, a negro of Palatka, who had been convicted of murder.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 11 -- At 10 o'clock this morning the James Orr Overall Factory in this village temporarily suspended operation to allow the proprietor to announce to the one hundred female operators he employs that an advance of 25 per cent. in wages would be given to all employes on April 1.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 11 -- Surrogate Seabury to-day vacated the injunction restraining Elias C. Benedict from administering the estate of his son, F.H. Benedict, on the ground that the moving papers, petition, and affidavits being made wholly upon information and belief, were insufficient.

The Directors of the Brooklyn Rapid Rapid Transit Company have decided to recommend to stockholders of the company a plan to issue a general mortgage to secure bonds not to exceed $150,000,000, to be used, it is officially stated, "for the retirement of the outstanding bonds of the company and for the purpose of acquiring additional property and securities."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to call the attention of the many men and women of liberal means and broad views to the necessity for, and the benefits to be derived from, the endowment of medical schools, and more particularly of those schools which take charge of and endeavor to give thorough practical bedside and laboratory instruction to men and women who have already graduated in medicine.

Albert Ballin, Director General, and Gustax Tietgens, President of the Hamburg-American Steamship Line, and Dr. H. Wiegrand, Director General, and George Plate, President of the North German Lloyd Line, were among the notable passengers who arrived at New York on the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse from Bremen yesterday afternoon.
The latest tidings concerning the condition of the President's son are so distinctly reassuring that it would no longer be unfeeling for the losers by his illness to repine over what they have lost.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 11 -- This being the eighteenth birthday of Miss Alice Roosevelt, was the date selected last November for a cotillion to take place in the East Room of the White House and mark the close of the social season. On account of the illness of Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., the dance was abandoned.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 11 -- At the Clearing House balances between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 5 @ 10 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $24,450,013, against $28,647,265 a year ago to-day, a decrease of $4,191,252, or 14 per cent., and the balances were $2,440,012.

Ash Wednesday was celebrated at the Metropolitan Opera House by an extra performance, the regular subscription night having been transferred to Tuesday. For this special occasion Mr. Grau, out of consideration for the public, put forward Mme. Emma Calve in her familiar specialty, and gave her the capable support of Mme. Eames and Mr. Alvarez.

Ash Wednesday and Lincoln's Birthday falling on the same date combined to make a very quiet day of yesterday. There were no social functions whatsoever, and as the day was mild and fair, many went to the country. Baltusrol, Apawamis, Knollwood, and Ardsley all had good attendance, and there was a large house party at Chatsworth.

Three fencing teams appeared in the Fencers' Club, 37 West Twenty-second Street, last night, to compete in the second annual competition for the Fencers' Club Cup, which was offered last year. The home club won the trophy at that time and it succeeded in capturing it again last night.

Glenn Brown of Washington, Secretary of the American Institute of Architects of that city, and also Secretary of the National Art League, lectured last night at the National Arts Club, 37 West Thirtyfourth Street, on the proposed improvements in Washington between the Capitol and the Potomac.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- "Of course there is opposition to this bill. If the practice of placing people upon the rack and of torturring them with thumbscrews were up before the Legislature of New York to-day for consideration doubtless you would have the manufacturers of racks and thumbscrews here to protest against the enactment of any measure prejudicial to their Industry.

BOSTON, Feb. 12. -- As a fitting observance of the anniversary of Lincoln's birth the Middlesex Club gave a banquet at the Hotel Brunswick this evening. The guests who addressed them were Secretary of the Navy John D. Long, Major Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, Lieut. Gov. Bates, Capt. John Bordman, and Roscoe Conkling Bruce, a colored student and orator at Harvard College.

MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., Feb. 12 -- Six are dead and as many more are dying as the result of a battle between Middlesborough officers and mountaineers. The battle, one of the most desperate of its kind in the history of mountain warfare, occurred between 4 and 6 o'clock this afternoon at Lee Turner's saloon, three and a half miles from Middlesborough.

The sixteenth annual Lincoln dinner of the Republican Club of the City of New York was given at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The large banquet hall was handsomely decorated and a new departure to gathering's of this kind, was the fact that while the club members and their friends were being regaled with the good dings of this life the ladies were being Similarly entertained in adjoining apartments.

Enormous power in snug compass is shown in the sail plan of Kaiser Wilhelm's schooher yacht Meteor, now rapidly approaching completion at Shooters' Island. The plan looks like a very compact one, but the lower sails alone will contain 10,000 square feet of canvas, while, according to the designers, Cary, Smith Barbey of 35 Nassau Street, the yacht will spread no less than 22,049 square feet of sail when on a broad reach.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE'S letter on the subject of canal improvement exhibits the knowledge and the practical common sense of the experienced man of business. But it must not be misconstrued as an unequivocal indorsement of Gov. ODELL'S plan for increasing the traffic capacity of the State canal.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- August Belmont, Chairman of the State Racing Commission, and several other prominent racing men appeared to-day at the hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Elsberg bill proposing to amend the law by giving additional power to the State Racing Commission in the interest of clean sport and legitimate racing.

His imperial German Majesty's yacht Hohenzollern, from Kiel, Jan. 18, and St. Thomas, West Indies, Feb. 8, was docked yesterday at 4:30 P.M. at Pier 3 of the North German Lloyd's docks, in Hoboken, and her commander. Rear Admiral Count von Baudissin, reported an uneventful voyage and all well.

Two competitions were held yesterday on the links of the Westchester Golf Club, near West Farms, for despite the fact that considerable snow still clung to the links, the course was in fair playing condition and the greens were not as poor as might have been supposed. There Was a very good delegation of members on the course and many played who did not turn in cards for the tournaments.

It is not probable that the cultivation of the amenities of social intercourse will tend to make burglars popular with those selected for nocturnal visitation, or that there will be any disposition on the part of prosecuting officers to present apologetically the facts calling for indictment in the case of gentlemanly burglars as contrasted with the brutal ruffians who figure as housebreakers in romance and melodrama.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The memorial of the Federal Party of the Philippines, transmitted to the Senate this afternoon by the Secretary of War, sets forth that the insurrection in the islands is due to a misunderstanding and not to hatred of the American sovereignty. It further states that out of the sixty provinces war exists only in two, Batangas and Samar, and that the towns anxiously desire "a definitive civil rule."

WILLEMSTAD, Curacoa, Feb. 12 -- The report that the Venezuelan revolutionary steamer Libertador (formerly the Ban Righ) has sunk the Venezuelan gunboat General Crespo, is confirmed. The Libertador is now off this island. The following report of the engagement was obtained to-day:

WINSTED, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Twenty-one delegates, representing twelve States, met in attendance upon the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen, which held its opening session in Torrington to-day, and listened to anything but encouraging reports.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- In both houses of the Legislature to-day was introduced a new Employers' Liability bill, which emanated from ex-Senator John Laughlin of Buffalo and which was presented to the Senate by Senator Hill and to the Assembly by Assemblyman O'Malley. The bill differs in many particulars from the Slater bill and its supporters claim that it has greater merit and affords better protection to workingmen.

-- When one of our readers, on coming across the word "aleatory" in our columns a while ago, breathed hard, got red in the face, and took his pen in hand to write therewith a savage denunciation of men who use words other people don't understand, we held that he was unnecessarily excited and with unkindly levity told him so.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The official Reichsanzeiger this evening published the following:

WASHINGTON. Feb. 12 -- The alliance between Japan and Great Britain occasions no surprise at the State Department. In theory, of course, the American Government knew nothing about it until it was officially informed of it by Minister Takahira, who visited the State Department today and formally notified Secretary Hay of the existence of the treaty.

Although the publication of the agreement between Great Britain and Japan comes after the news of the practical abandonment by Great Britain of Weihai-Wei as a fortified strong place in the Far East, the event first announced is really the sequel and corollary of the treaty.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League, on the Century Wheelmen's alleys last night, the home team won three games from the Knickerbocker Athletic Club bowlers. The West Side Republican Club also won from the Caledonian Club on the latter club's alleys. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Full authority is given for the statement that the protocol now being prepared by Admiral Walker, Chairman of the Isthmian Canal Commission, and Dr. Silva, the Colombian Minister, will not contain any provision for the relinquishment of sovereignty over the isthmus.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 12 -- An answer has been served by the Great Northern Railway on the attorneys for Milton L. Bouden and Sophia Barth Chapman in their action to prevent the Northern Securities Company from securing the stock of the Great Northern. The suit was brought in the district court of Hennepin County on Jan. 22 and was transferred to Ramsay County last Monday.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- The demand for money was strong to-day. The market was entirely controlled by the Bank of England to which there was considerable indebtednes. Discounts were inclined to be easier, being affected by Continental bill buying. Business on the Stock Exchange was irregular.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Italian Ambassador has completed negotiations for the purchase of the residence of Mrs. Phoebe A. Hearst, 1,400 New Hampshire Avenue. Mrs. Hearst's house, built by its owner some ten years ago is one of the handsomest residences in Washington, and, with its furnishings, which it is understood are to be included in the sale, will make the Italian Embassy one of the finest official homes in America.

Morris Wood of Long Branch, N.J., the new champion skater at one and three miles, demonstrated his remarkable ability on the ice by easily defeating the principal local skaters in the two scratch skating races at Verona Lake, Montclair, N.J., yesterday afternoon.

Sales of paintings held to-night and Friday and Saturday nights at the Silo Galleries, 366 Fifth Avenue, will throw on the market a number of paintings by New York artists, notably by Charles H. Miller, N.A., whose pictures form part of the estate of Mrs. Jane Miller, and are to be sold by order of the executors.

Wall Street will resume business today, after its brief holiday, in an altogether hopeful frame of mind. It is a fact that in the past few days hesitancy and doubt in the financial district as to the future of the stock market have been replaced by confidence and hope. Marked improvement is now freely predicted -- not by small men, but by the greatest financial powers in the Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- United States Consul Hollis at Lorenzo Marques sends the following report to the State Department on the "Opening to Civil Traffic of the Lorenzo Marques Railway":

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 13 -- The business men of Baltimore are prepared to make a determined fight against an anti-Trust bill, constructed on the lines of the Texas law, now in the Maryland Legislature, and which may be passed through the efforts of the members from the counties. The bill is drastic in its provisions, prohibiting any combination whatever to fix the price or limit the manufacture of any article.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- One man was killed, several others were injured, one woman was hurt, and a man was shot as a result of a railroad collision in the Waverly yards of the Pennsylvania Railroad to-night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- Secretary Shaw gave a hearing to-day to four Washington women who protested against the obnoxious enforcement of the baggage regulations at the port of New York. They were Mrs. Hobson, Miss Gwynne, Mrs. Richard Townsend, and Miss Mabel Boardman. They were presented to the Secretary by John A. Kasson, who assisted them in explaining their objections to the treatment they have received.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 12 -- The Rev. Ralph B. Pomeroy of Nyack, N.Y., has accepted the curacy of Emmanuel Church of this city, and will enter upon his duties on the first Sunday in May. He was graduated from Columbia University in 1898, and later from the General Theological Seminary.

Discussion concerning the circumstances attending the severance of friendly relations between John C. Sheehan and Richard Croker was again rife yesterday as a result of the statement made by District Attorney Jerome at the Sheehan dinner on Tuesday night that at the meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall held after Mr. Croker's return from Europe in 1897, he challenged the district leaders to criticise him, but they would not do so.

Capt Charles G. Woodward, now sick at San Francisco, is detailed for general recruiting service and when fit for duty will report to the recruiting officer in Milwaukee to relieve Capt. Conway H. Arnold, Jr., who, upon being relieved will join his company at Havana, Cuba.

The energy and enterprise already shown in the rebuilding of Paterson are no more than were to be expected of such a community. But, in the eagerness to rebuild, there is danger that it may be forgotten that such a fire as has swept over the business part of the city constitutes not merely a calamity but also an opportunity.
LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The morning papers continue to discuss the question of the powers and the Spanish-American war.

Edward R. Thomas of 17 West Fifty-seventh Street, a broker and son of Gen. Samuel Thomas, railroad President and financier, while speeding his automobile with a party of friends aboard through Convent Avenue at 1:45 o'clock P.M. yesterday, ran over and Instantly killed Henry Theiss, seven years old, of 2,517 Eighth Avenue, who with some playmates were running across the street after looking at a schoolboys baseball game in the vacant lot at that point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Ways and Means Committee of the House gave a hearing this afternoon on the bill recently introduced by Chairman Payne, (Rep., N. Y.,) "to simplify the laws in relation to the collection of the revenues and to encourage the industries of the United States."

W.H. Sigourney and Dr. L.L. Mial won the games in the Amateur Athletic Union's Class A 14.2 billiard tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club yesterday. These victories caused a shifting about in the standing of the players. Sigourney drew up even with Dr. Mial, and Norris, the man he defeated, dropped back with them.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- The announcement of the conclusion of the Anglo-Japanese treaty has opened the floodgates of discussion and comment throughout the Continent. The London papers are full of interviews, opinions, and special articles describing Japan and her military and naval strength, and speculations as to the outcome of the alliance.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- There were two races on the card for the second day of the Saratoga Ice Racing Association's annual trotting meeting on Saratoga Lake, and both races were stubbornly disputed, but the honors passed to the credit of the favorites. Summary:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The War Revenue Reduction bill is to be carried through the House under close guard. Nobody is to be allowed to put a rider on it. Members may attack it in debate as bitterly as they like, but they will not be permitted to amend it. It is going to the Senate just as it came from the Ways and Means Committee.
