GROTON, Mass., Feb. 12 -- If Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., continues for the next twenty-four hours in his present condition his physicians have given the President and Mrs. Roosevelt reason to believe that their son's vitality will be sufficient for him to meet and pass successfully the crisis in his disease, which is looked for some time tomorrow, and on Friday morning he will be practically out of danger.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill is in grave danger of defeat. It has been well-known for some time that there were a number of Republican Senators opposed to it, but the hope of Senator Stranahan and the other defenders of the bill was that they would be able to induce a sufficient number of Democrats to vote for it to offset the Republican defection.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 12 -- M. Hugues Le Roux, the French lecturer, who is making an American tour, began his series of lectures before the Cercle Franchise of Harvard yesterday afternoon at Sanders's Theatre in the presence of a large and fashionable audience.

Rich and Harris have secured from Anson Pond, author of "Her Atonement," a new drama of New York City life, and have arranged with Charles Frohman to produce it at the Garden Theatre in the Spring, following the run of the Bostonians there. The new play is entitled "Life."

The anti-imperialism of Senator CARMACK of Tennessee is unconquerable. After he had denounced the Philippine Commission's treason law as "tyrannical and un-American," Senator FORAKER unfeelingly explained that the severest clause in the Philippine treason and sedition law was copied from the statutes of the State of Tennessee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- With the exception of a sharp clash between Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) and Mr. Patterson (Dem., Col.,) over the admission of representatives of the press to the investigation before the Philippines Committee, the discussion of the Philippine Tariff bill in the Senate to-day was quiet.

When seen last night President J.L. Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company said that he did not know anything of the effect that the proposal to issue $150,000,000 in bonds would have in Wall Street.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 12 -- The troops on duty here will be withdrawn at 6 o'clock to-morrow morning and the city will then be handled by the police alone. This was decided upon this evening by Mayor Hinchcliffe after a conference with Brig. Gen. Campbell. The change was partly decided upon last night.

Van Cortlandt Lake was alive with skaters and curlers yesterday. After several postponements, the lovers of the good old Scotch game on the ice were able to enjoy their fun, and eight rinks turned out for the first competition for the Dewar Cup. The match is one of the most important local contests, and the largest delegation of curlers was seen on the lake that has been at Van Cortlandt this season.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- The Times says today that the general body of Unionists approves the treaty between Great Britain and Japan, as well as some of the Liberal Imperialists, but some old Parliamentary hands are disposed to be noncommittal, on the ground that the treaty is a departure from the policy of isolation which this country has hitherto pursued.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 13 -- Favorable weather favored the ice, yacht races sailed this afternoon under the auspices of the Shrewsbury Club. Three races were sailed, including the contest for the Rice Cup, which was easily won by Vice Commodore W.A. Seaman's Harold. The summary:

Seven indictments were found yesterday by the Grand Jury in connection with the disastrous explosion of dynamite in the rapid transit tunnel at Forty-first Street and Park Avenue. Ira A. Shaler, the subcontractor, was indicted for manslaughter in the first degree and for misdemeanor. The charges against him were that he was culpably negligent and that he had stored dynamite contrary to the provisions of the law.
Gen. George Moore Smith, commanding the First Brigade of the National Buard, reviewed the Twelfth Regiment at its armory last night before one of the largest crowds of spectators ever in the armory.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I consider it my duty, in justice to my little son, Florizel, to deny some of the erroneous statements made by the press regarding him.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 13 -- The Central Coal and Coke Company of Kansas City has purchased all the properties and business of the Kansas and Texas Coal Company of St. Louis. The deal involves more than $3,000,000 and makes the Central Coal and Coke Company the largest concern of its kind west of Pennsylvania.

The trial of Albert T. Patrick, charged with murdering William Marsh Rice, the aged Texas millionaire, was resumed yesterday before Recorder Goff in the Court of General Session. The whole court day was taken up with hearing Albert S. Osborne's, (the handwriting expert,) reasons for believing that the disputed will and certain checks were forgeries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The House Committee on Labor held to-day the first of a series of hearings on the bill which limits all work on Government contracts to eight hours a day. This measure meets with strong opposition from the shipbuilders and manufacturers of high grades of iron and steel.

Mr. Henry James's play, "Mrs. Jasper," played yesterday afternoon for the first time by the pupils who gather together under the long-winded name of The American Academy of Dramatic Arts and the Empire Theatre Dramatic School, is called on the programme a comedy; but those who dropped into the Empire Theatre in the hope of seeing on the stage an example of Mr. James's realism suffered a grievous disappointment.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- King Edward and Queen Alexandra, the Prince and Princess of Wales, Prince and Princess Charles of Denmark, Princess Victoria, and a distinguished suite witnessed the finals in the world's figure-skating competition at the Niagara Rink this afternoon. U. Salchow of Stockholm retained the championship, Mrs. Edgar Syers of England won second, while M. Jordan of Berlin won third prize.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 13 -- Three St. Louis banks will pay interest on daily deposits hereafter.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Senator Sullivan in the Senate and Assembly Ullman in the Assembly to-day introduced a Three-Platoon Police bill for the City of New York. The bill gives evidence of being hastily drawn, and the general opinion was that it would never get out of the Cities Committees of the two houses in its present form, if reported at all.

There are two resolves which every intending keeper of a saddle horse would do well to make and firmly to keep. The first is not to employ the British War Office to buy the animal; the second is not to let the Police Department of New York, under a Tammany administration, look after his health.

We have little doubt that the present apparently irreconcilable conflict between the German Foreign Office and the British Foreign Office will be ended and the truth of history established by a conclusive statement from Lord PAUNCEFOTE or from Viscount CRANBORNE on his authority.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- New York exchange to-day was 10 and 15 cents premium. Call and time loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. There has been a decided improvement in the condition of the local market lately. The demand for Biscuit, both common and preferred, was strong to-day, and prices moved up to the highest points seen in several months, the common touching 47 and the preferred going to 108 1/2.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were fairly large, and as a whole prices were firm. Here and there in the list the final quotations disclosed some sharp recessions from Tuesday's prices, but this occurred principally in several stocks which thus far have been little traded in. The transactions in Northern Securities were quite large, and more interest was shown in the stock than on any day since the adjournment of the Supreme Court.

Andrew Carnegie received an enthusiastic reception last evening at the Authors Club, in Carnegie Hall, of which he is a member. The occasion was to commemorate Mr. Carnegie's gifts to education in general, and those for the New York libraries in particular, and to congratulate him upon his election as Lord Rector of St. Andrew's College, Aberdeen University.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Gov. Odell's attention was called to-night to the statement of Excise Commissioner Cullinan that the Excise Department, the Police Commissioner of New York, and the District Attorney of New York County were now working in harmony for the suppression of Raines law hotels, which were violating the excise law.

Rear Admiral Count von Baudissin, who commands the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, paid official visits yesterday to Rear Admiral Albert S. Barker, commandant of the navy yard: Major Gen. John R. Brooke, commanding the Department of the East, and Mayor Low, and received an official visit from the German Consul General, Karl Ruenz.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- It is being asserted here that the Republican County Committee of New York really is responsible for the Allen bill to amend the civil service law so as to give the new officials of New York City the right of removal and appointment for a period of six months. Chairman Morris and William H. Ten Eyck were here last week.

Bills for water made out by estimates based on the inaccuracies found in the meters have been made out and sent to the owners and lessees of the premises at 20 and 121 Bowery, with notice that if they are not paid within three days the water supply will be cut off. The bills amount to $1,450.70 and $497.20.

An active and irregular market, with more show of manipulation than recently appearing, resulted yesterday in few net changes of consequence. Copper Trust shares fell below 70, Manhattan receded a couple of points, and some of the standard railway stocks showed an inclination to decline, but as regards the latter group, the selling seemed to be for the short account rather than to reflect liquidation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Representative George W. Smith (Rep.) of Illinois is going to press his bill providing for penny postage, now that the Post Office Appropriation bill has been completed. When he goes before the sub-committee to which his measure has been referred he will be armed with a petition claimed to be the most representative that was ever presented to Congress.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- Money conditions are unchanged. Loanable funds are still in abundant supply, and rates are in many cases practically what borrowers offer. Business is light, and shows little prospect of growing, although the opinion prevails in some quarters that the numerous big bond issues now shaping up will soon have the effect of increasing the demand and strengthening the market.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Every employe of railroads entering Chicago, from the Presidents to the messenger boys, will be vaccinated between now and Monday or lose his position. Every car which arrives in the city from every direction will be subjected to fumigation for six hours, under the direction of the Health Department, before other passengers are allowed to enter it.

The coming exhibition of the Architectural League is said to be strong in cartoons and colored designs for stained glass windows. The decorations of the South Carolina and West Indies Exposition at Charleston will be prominent so far as models for the sculpture there shown are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The minority of the House no longer regards it as possible that it will be able to make a successful contest against the rule that is to be reported for the consideration of the War Tax Reduction bill. It did expect Republican help in fighting the rule, but that expectation has been abandoned.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 13. -- Before leaving for Chicago this evening Mr. Lazare Weiller and M. Maurice de Lagotellerie, in an interview, said they would recommend to the French Government that the school for educating French engineers be located in Pittsburg, and the school for political science be located in New York.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly give me space to reply to some of the criticisms on my letter in THE TIMES of last Tuesday on "The Relative Cost of Living"?

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- It is stated that President Ban Johnson of the American Baseball League, after consulting with Umpire "Jack" Sheridan and President Hickey of the American Association, the latter having returned from the East, authorized the announcement that the American League will not accept the new rules framed up at the Buffalo meeting.

Stock brokers in Wall Street were nonplussed yesterday by the announcement of the decision of Internal Revenue Commissioner Yerkes that a tax of 2 cents per $100 of par value would have to be made on all shares of stock deposited with bankers and others as security for loans.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 13 -- Vice Chancellor Stevenson to-day issued an order temporarily postponing the foreclosure sale of the various properties owned by the United States Flour Milling Company, and mortgaged for $15,000,000 to the Central Trust Company of New York. The sale was to have taken place in Jersey City tomorrow.

C.F. Conklin, the Chicago expert, who finished first in the Class A 14.2 billiard tourney last year and challenged Wilson P. Foss for the championship, won and lost yesterday in this year's tourney in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Opposed to him in the afternoon contest was Threshie, his opponent in the deciding game last year, which Conklin won by just one point.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 13 -- The schooner Frank Herbert, with a cargo of pine lumber from Opecoke, N.C., for New York, was abandoned in a sinking condition off here to-day, it being the second vessel to fall a victim this week off this coast to the great ice fields flowing out of Delaware Bay.
Money on call, 2 1/4@2 1/2 per cent, closing at 2 1/4 per cent. Majority of the day's loans at 2 1/2 per cent.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The Senate Cities Committee reported favorably the Rapid Transit Tunnel bill, which gives John B. McDonald, contractor, the privilege of disposing of operating the rapid transit tunnel railroad to a corporation. The bill was advanced.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Lake steamship lines and the railroads are engaged in a struggle over the payment of commissions, which is likely to rupture the friendly relations that have hitherto existed between them.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 -- Outsiders divided the honors with favorites here to-day. Jockey Dale has been suspended pending an investigation of his riding in recent races. Weather clear; track fast. Summary:
BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The Kreuz Zeitung, in an inspired note on the Spanish-American war controversy, says:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 13 -- The decling in Cotton Duck issues was the item of most interest in to-day's trading. The decline, however, was not accepted as of much significance, because the sales were few and were offered down by brokers who are known to represent the syndicate which is trying to depress them for obvious reasons.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Gov. Odell announced this evening that he would hold a conference with the leaders of the Senate and Assembly Tuesday in regard to the Charities bill and other important matters. The Charities bill has not yet been introduced. The conference announced is to determine the form in which the bill shall be presented.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 13 -- It was learned to-day that 176 acres of land in the northern suburbs of Baltimore had been unconditionally donated as a new site for Johns Hopkins University. Arrangements have been practically completed for the transfer of the land on Feb. 22, the date of the jubilee celebration of the university.

Hundreds of people were terror-stricken and a dozen or more slightly injured in a rear-end collision between two express trains during the height of the evening rush of travel on the Third Avenue elevated road near One Hundred and First Street last evening.

Those teams that have managed so far to survive the strain on mind and body of the six-day go-as-you-please pedestrian race in Madison Square Garden, yesterday gave another exhibition of how a faggedout man, physically and mentally, looks when he is plodding around a circle in a half-dazed and exhausted, condition.

Ill, and with her mind a blank as to her wanderings, Mrs. Charlotte Hopkins Seixas, stepdaughter of Elias T. Hopkins, a retired business man of 14 First Place, Brooklyn, who mysteriously disappeared on Jan. 24, was found yesterday at the Occidental Hotel, Bowery and Broomo Street, Manhattan.

The order of the new Postmaster General that no removals of fourth class Postmasters will be made except for cause duly presented in the form of charges, will come as a surprise to most of the Congressmen and politicians interested, and will give great satisfaction to those who care only for the good of the service and for honest politics.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- This metropolis bestowed its highest distinction on the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, yesterday, when, at the Guildhall, it conferred on him the freedom of the city, the document being inclosed in a gold casket.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Marquis of Lansdowne, replied to a question on the subject of the British-Japanese alliance.
No change in the Bank of England's rate of discount.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- While no definite agreement has been reached, a vote on the Philippine Tariff bill in the Senate seems to be in sight. It appears likely, judging from a discussion of the subject late in to-day's session, that the vote may be taken next week.

The Union League Club had a regular meeting last night at the club house. Cornelius N. Bliss presided for the first time since his election to the Presidency. He made an address, in which he referred to the history of the club, to his own thirty-five years of membership, and to the promises of the future.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 13 -- A few minutes after 6 o'clock this morning the last detail of soldiers was called in by Lieut. Dunphy, and at 7:30 the last file marched into the armory and lined up for final dismissal. They found the remainder of their comrades waiting.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 13. -- As a result of factional differences of recent growth, the Constitutional Convention, now in session here, was transformed into a veritable bedlam for a time to-day, and the President, ex-Gov. Charles B. Andrews, almost broke his gavel to pieces in trying to silence the introducer of a resolution of which he disapproved.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- Money was much wanted to-day for Stock Exchange payments, and the supply was very short. The Government, apparently, was disbursing little money. Discounts were weak. Operators on the Stock Exchange were occupied with the conclusion of the settlement, which was wound up satisfactorily, in spite of considerable forced closing.

sylvania's Rivalry. Andrew Carnegie takes the position that the formation of the large railroad combinations of the country militate against the pre-eminence of the Port of New York. He touches upon this subject in a letter to Henry B. Hebert, Chairman of the Canal Association of New York, in which he says:

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The Pennsylvania North River Tunnel bill came up in both the Senate and the Assembly to-day. In the Senate it was advanced to third reading without question. In the Assembly its progress was blocked by Messrs. Fitzgerald and McKeown. They both said it was a measure of too much importance to be rushed through.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Census Bureau has issued a preliminary report on manufacturing industries of New York State, showing a total capital of $1,679,966,515, an increase of 49 per cent. The total value of the products, including custom work and repairing in 1900, was $2,175,766,900, an increase of 27 per cent. since 1890.

Lenten amusements are beginning and the programme is quite well filled for the remainder of the season. There were several dinners given last evening, one by Mrs. James A. Burden. At Miss Leary's Father Pardow of the Society of Jesus gave the first of a course of lectures and there was a meeting of the Thursday Evening Club at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reld, and a ride at the Knickerbocker Riding Club.

As an acrobatic exhibition the hockey match, between Princeton and Brown which was played last evening at the St. Nicholas Rink and won by the former by a score of 3 to 0 was something well worth seeing. As a return to the boyhood delights of "shinny" it was a delightful reminiscence. As hockey it was scarcely modern enough to suit the patrons of the rink.

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 13 -- President Roosevelt left here for Washington late this afternoon. Just before his departure he verified the previous statements that his son, Theodore, Jr., was safely past the crisis of his attack of pneumonia.

Controller Grout announced yesterday that New York could issue $34,000,000 of corporate stock for improvements of all kinds before the debt limit is reached. The statement was the result of an examination of the city's finances.

The Century Realty Company has sold, through Richard M. Montgomery, the plot at the northeast corner of Broadway and Sixty-second Street, 116.3 by 108.7 by 100.4 by 164.11. Although the buyer's name is withheld, it was stated yesterday that this parcel has not been acquired by the same interests which made large purchases earlier in the week on the opposite side of Broadway at that point, through Mr. Montgomery.

A quiet conference of prominent independent Republicans of Brooklyn was held last evening in the Johnston Building, in Nevins Street, to devise means of effecting a change from the conditions which now obtain in the party in the borough. The conference was called chiefly as a result of the Guden-Dady controversy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- The Excise Committee of the Assembly, it was said by a member of the committee to-night, has decided to report favorably the bill introduced by Assemblyman Bennet of New York providing for local option by election districts in New York.

District Attorney Jerome's homicide bureau and the Coroner's office were again at loggerheads yesterday, this time over the case of the boy Henry Thies of 2,517 Eighth Avenue, who was run over and killed on Wednesday by the automobile of Broker Edward R. Thomas, son of Gen. Samuel Thomas.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- The ice yacht Jack Frost of the Hudson River Ice Yacht Club, owned by Commodore Archibald Rogers, won her second race in the contest with the yachts of the Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club for the challenge pennant of America to-day. The race was full of thrilling incidents.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Detailed accounts just received of Lord Kitchener's movement to capture the Boers within the block-house lines show that the conflict was very picturesque, and that it was one of the most exciting incidents of the whole campaign. Although apparently surrounded by an impenetrable ring of fire and steel, the Boers' dauntless bravery and dashing charges ultimately resulted in the majority of them escaping from the meshes of Lord Kitchener's close-drawn net.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- This was a brisk day in the Philadelphia stock market, and there were heavy dealings in the Reading stocks, conspicuously the second preferred, which sold at the highest to its history. Nearly all the buying was for New York accounts. In the rest of the market there was considerable hardening, but price changes were insignificant with a few exceptions.

By the lamented death of John Richard Green England has lost one of her most learned scholars and busy workers. His aim in life was constantly to be learning something new. During the course of his studies on historical subjects he kept producing minor articles and essays on many and varied topics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Commissioner Powderly and the immigration officials at Ellis Island, New York, are struggling with the proposition of what shall be done with four Italian children who are detained in the hospital of the Ellis Island immigration establishment. These children are Elizabeth, Maria, Salvatore, and Colagero Carolla, the youngest being three years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- One of the principal subjects discussed at the Cabinet meeting to-day was the forthcoming reply of the President to the appeal of Admiral Schley. Mr. Roosevelt has given much attention to the matter, and it is understood that in the course of a few days, probably by the middle of next week, he will be ready to announce his conclusions.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law as amended, provides that a, 25cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- The itinerary governing Prince Henry's visit to New York has been completed by the President's delegates up to the docking of the imperial yacht in New York. As now arranged, when the Prince, aboard the Kronprinz Wilheim, arrives at Quarantine he will be waited on by Roar Admiral Evans, who will go down the bay from Tompkinsville for that purpose on a naval tug.

The opinions printed elsewhere concerning the respective merits of English and American books in point of manufacture will interest, many readers. They are remarkable in that so many Englishmen commend the work done in America. This is notably true of the authors, of whom five out of ten condemn the books made in their own country.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 14 --The Vice President and General Manager of the Pecos Valley Railroad has semi-officially announced that the Santa Fe. owner of the Pecos Valley, will construct a one-hundred-mile line from Roswell, N.M., to El Paso, to compete with the newly completed Rock Island route, which made a cut of 222 miles over all lines now touching here.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14. -- Though the feeling was cheerful in the stock market to-day, the arbitrage issues, were about the only things traded in, the record of transactions for local stocks being the lowest for the week. Lehigh Valley was better, and so was Consolidated Lake Superior, but both United Gas Improvement and Union Traction were lower, while Choctaw common on a single sale went off a point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Some of the monotony of a private pension day in the House was enlivened to-day by a sensational speech from Mr. Wheeler (Dem., Ky.,) in denunciation of what he denominated "flunkeyism" to foreign countries. He took the recent statements emanating from Continental Cabinets regarding the attitude of Great Britain during the Spanish war as a text for an attack upon the trend of our recent diplomacy.

"SPINDLE AND PLOUGH." by Mrs. Henry Dudeney, author of "The Maternity of Harriott Wicken" and "Folly Corner." will be published early in the Spring by Dodd, Mead Co. Mrs. Dudeney is considered by some the equal of Thomas Hardy, as she is his literary congener.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- The Lackawanna Steel Company of West Seneca, Erie County, was incorporated to-day with a capital of $40,000,000. It proposes to manufacture iron, steel, and other metals; to operate mines and lumber lands; to erect and operate furnaces, forges, mills, foundries, and other manufacturing establishments; to construct and operate bridges, ships, engines, cars, slips, elevators, water-works, viaducts, aqueducts, and canals, and to transact such other business as may be incidental thereto.

Ready for a fight "to the finish," as he declared, Elections Commissioner Michael J. Dady returned yesterday from Cuba to face his political foes in Brooklyn. Col. Dady arrived on the Ward Line steamship Santiago. His arrival caused a flutter of excitement in Republican circles in Brooklyn, and developments in the situation in the party in the borough are looked for today.

The bowling team of the Nonpareil Rowing Club made its first appearance in the Harlem Navy Bowling League tournament last night and made a good beginning by winning both its matches and rolling the highest team score of the series to date. Its chances for first place are considered excellent.

Frank Du Puy Veiller and Miss Isabel Dominlck Lockwood were married yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's parents, 205 West Fifty-seventh Street, by the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer of St. Bartholomew's Church. The bride was given away by her father, Williston B. Lockwood. Her bridal gown was made of cloth of silver veiled with duchesse lace.
An honest and industrious seeker after truth writes to us as follows:

Our neighbor The Evening Post makes against the late President McKINLEY a Charge so serious in its nature that if made and substantiated during his term of office it would have afforded just cause for his impeachment, and if now supported by proofs would cover his name with infamy.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Feb. 14. -- Two closely contested races were sailed under the auspices of the Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club this afternoon. The trophies were the champion pennant and the twenty-four-hour pennant, and were won by Seaman's Harold and J.E. Green's Eagle, respectively.

Commission house transactions became yesterday one of the distinctive features of the stock market. Conservative firms not active for a long time were conspicuous buyers. This was notably so in a variety of the lower-priced railway issues, like Colorado Southern, Chicago Great Western, and the Wabashes.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS lately reviewed a recent work that relates to the interesting feature of early Oregon history, when Dr. Marcus Whitman, the missionary, made his midWinter Journey across the continent in the season of 1842-3, which his friends claimed saved Oregon to the United States.

Mr. J.W. Powell, the Director of the Bureau of American Ethnology, writes the preface for Mr. Frank Hamilton Cushing's "Zuni Folk Tales." Mr. Powell tells us that" mythology is the term used to designate the superstitions of the ancients, Folk-lore is the term used to designate the superstitions of the ignorant of to-day.

ANDREW CARNEGIE, last Thursday evening. was the honored guest of the Authors of which he is a member. For some time it had been the intention of the club to show their appreciation fittingly of Mr. Carnegie's gifts to libraries and for the promotion of culture and education.

IN ITS civic history and material development and in the character of its citizens Kansas has always been unique and attractive. Born in a whirlwind of political strife and cradled in a storm of National conflict, probably no State in the Union outside the original thirteen had more interesting beginnings or has kept a closer hold upon the attention of the country at large.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 14. -- The second and deciding race for a silver cup, open to third-class ice yachts, was sailed this afternoon. The triangular course was sailed in a moderate northwest breeze, the distance being ten miles. Ten yachts started, and the race was very interesting, because of the closeness of the leaders.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Gov. Taft of the Philippines to-day continued his statement before the Senate Committee on the Philippines concerning the conditions in that archipelago, with the intention of discussing the degree of tranquillity in the pacified provinces, which, he said, included all the provinces except Tayabas, Samar, and Batangas.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The Washington correspondent of The Times flatly contradicts the latest statement of Dr. von Holleben, (German Ambassador at Washington,) which the correspondent calls the Ambassador's third error.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Next Wednesday the Ways and Means Committee will enter upon consideration of Cuban reciprocity. The War Tax Reduction bill will be out of the House by that time, and the members of the committee will then have before them no important question except the Cuban problem.

Mr. De Vinne published about two years ago the first portion of his "Practice of Typography," which was devoted to plain printing types, with a few words on the composition of title pages -- a subject requiring an entire volume for adequate treatment. The present volume has for its subtitle "Correct Composition."

In the history of education there are few names more illustrious than that of Friedrich Frobel, and the Interest in the present volumes on the "Life of Baroness von Marenholtz-Bulow" lies chiefly in the fact that she, perhaps of all others, fell most under the influence of his teaching's, knew most of the man himself, his aims and ideas.

It seems rather unreasonable to complain of "Fables in Slang" as too slangy. But slang has its class distinctions, its aristocracy, and its "canal," as poor dear Lady Clavering was wont lo term the hoi polloi, and Mr. Ade does not always draw the line. He often gives one the feeling of rubbing shoulders with the wrong crowd, especially when associating with his young girls, who are too suggestive of the Sunday picnic maidens.

HERE is published the nutral volume of the first complete edition of the writings of William Hazlitt, a small limited edition for England and America. The set will consist of twelve large volumes of about 500 pages each and is under the editorship of A.R. Waller and Arnold Glover.
Al Adams and sixteen others, charged with violations of the anti-policy law, yesterday pleaded not guilty before Judge Cowing, in Part I. of General Sessions.

Those who study the anxious problems of the Brooklyn Bridge should not lose sight of the fact that these are divisible into two classes -- those which demand instant relief, by reason of the fact that the existing conditions are intolerable and should be modified in the interest of life and limb, and those which will increase the capacity of the bridge and adapt it to a still larger traffic than it can now accommodate.

Mrs. Catherine Voelpel, a widow, who lived at 129 Christopher Street, at the corner of Hudson Street, was murdered in the house at some time between the hours of 6 A.M. and 9:30 A.M. yesterday by some person whose identity is at present unknown to the police. She had been stabbed eighteen times with a dirk or broad-bladed butcher's knife, which the murderer carried away.

IN the discussion of juvenile fiction the children themselves are rarely heard. Yet they are the best authorities for the facts that lie at the basis of the discussion, namely, what authors they prefer and why they prefer them.

"We read that" the whole House was aroused " yesterday by the speech of the Hon. C. K., WHEELER of Paducah, Ky. Well it might have been. It was a style of oration which has fallen into innocuous desuetude in that body for the past ten or twenty years. The noble sport of tail-twisting has gone out of fashion.

Lord Dufferin, of whom most readers think only as of a man who had been very successful in administration and diplomacy, is also very worthy of remembrance as a man of letters. He is indeed a "man of one book." But so are some of the greatest and justest favorites in literature.

There was a time when lexicographers took Pope's adage about words and fashions to heart and sat as censors on the morals of language. The same spirit animated the editor of the first American edition of that valuable guide, "Roget's Thesaurus," published in Boston in 1854, for he wrote in his preface that much care had been taken to exclude "vulgar words and phrases," and those which had not firmly established themselves in the language.

-- There's no doubt of it -- no matter what problem may be presented, and whatever its difficulty, at least one of our readers will come forward, with a solution. Possibly not even the wisest of them knows everything, but their collective wisdom, like their generosity in distributing it, will stand any test.

Dr. Gray's "Mushiss" form a delightful addition to the nature books that are making a goodly and a restful row upon our shelves. These papers appeared from time to time in The Interior, of which their author was long the honored editor, and were selected for publication only a few months before his death.

A fairly large number of stocks was traded in in the outside market yesterday, but in only a few issues were the totals large. The net changes for the day showed considerable irregularity in the movement of prices, some of the declines as, well as some of the advances being large. All told, however, prices held fairly well and several stocks which recently have been weak showed signs of strengthening.

In this time of crowding formal criticism, and when books enter into human life as never before, and the swarm of readers are critics to an unprecedented degree, the want of the critic, par excellence, is still felt by many, and they think that it is just out of such conditions that we may look for him to come.

The new building of the Alexander Avenue Baptist Church will be formally dedicated on the afternoon of Sunday, Feb. 23. The last service in the old building, which stood on the same site as the one just completed, Alexander Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-first Street, was held in October, 1900.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 14. -- Flaubert was the French novelist whose motives and works were made the subject of a lecture by M. Hueues le Roux, delivered before the Cercle Franchise of Harvard University this afternoon, the address being the second of a series. M. le Roux when a boy paid a visit to Flaubert, and a description of this visit, which decided the lecturer's professional career, formed the prelude to his discussion.

The New York Realty Corporation has sold the three four-story dwellings 8, 10, and 12 West Thirty-eighth Street, on plot 50 by 98.9 to Mrs. George L. Rives, wife of Corporation Counsel Rives, who owns and occupies the adjoining house. No. 14. Douglas Robinson. Charles S. Brown Co. were the brokers in the transaction.

Parents and teachers will scarcely need to have their attention called to the article, printed elsewhere in this issue, on juvenile fiction as judged from the standpoint of those who are its devoted readers. Mr. Bostwick, who writes the article, has had ample opportunities for forming intelligent and interesting judgments on the subject.

John F. Clancy, politician and saloon keeper, of Long Island City, under indictment for murder in the first degree, who has been long out on bail, has married since the commission of the alleged crime. On June 21 last he shot and fatally wounded John Clark, a frequenter of race tracks, at First Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Capt. Joseph J.B. Ball, one of the doorkeepers of the United States Senate for nearly twenty-five years, died here to-day. He had a gallant war record, having won distinction on several occasions by valuable and hazardous work. Capt. Ball was born at Orange, Mass., June 13, 1828.

The New York Times Saturday Revies of Books: In regard to the value of a literary reputation. I would like to give you some personal reasons which I entertain for believing that" without friends at court the chances of an unknown writer are still very poor."
A bill is pending in the Senate which amends Section 666 of the Penal Code in such wise as to make that section declare that:

The conscience of the Union League Club has been aroused and its best intel- ligence awakened by the dull, narrow, hateful course of the party leaders in the House in regard to Cuba. There is the ring of old-time honesty and patriotism in the resolution adopted unanimously at the regular meeting of the club on Thursday evening:

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- Echoes of the recent violent revival of the Bacon-Shakespeare controversy still reverberate in the air, but the storm seems to have passed. Dr. Eduard Engel, the distinguished German student of English literature, writes of the folly in the Berliner-Tageblatt, uttering words of wisdom, which, however, have often been uttered before.

Copyright, 1902. THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Feb. 14. -- The Author will take up the subject of the newspapor copyright in its forthcoming number and proposes to discuss the question pro and con. The first contribution from the publishers' viewpoint will be by C.F. Moberly Bell, manager of The Times.

William Morris, who loved English Gothic art more perhaps than any other man of the century, so much, indeed, that it was very hard for him to see beauty in other styles, made from time to time the most eloquent and touching pleas for the preservation of its ancient examples from the mutilation of the so-called restorer.

St. Valentine's Day passed without any special observance. The one entertainment of the day was the St. Valentine's Kettledrum, and that at night was the dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Livingston for their daughter. Miss Lilias Livingston. At Delmonico's, the Valentine dance of the Knickerbocker series took place.

MR. ALLEN is one of the Shyest and most reticent of men, and he at the same time possesses an open mind and a generous attitude toward men and affairs. His nature shrinks from the curious gaze of those seeking for titbits of gossip served up to them by the ubiquitous and burrowing interviewer.

The ancient palaces in or around London are so closely associated with the Kings and Queens of England as to form a part of history. Such royal residences as Westminster, St. Jumes, Kensington, Richmond, Hampton Court, and Windsor Castle we are fairly familiar with, but we know little of Eltham Palace, or Crosby Hall, Savoy Palace, or Whitehall.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Gov. Odell has made assurances to those interested in the Champlain Canal improvement which cause them to count confidently upon the Governor's support of their bill. The Governor also has talked to Assemblyman Lewis, who has charge of the Oswego Feeder bill, in a manner which has inspired Mr. Lewis with hope that probably the Oswego Canal yet may be included in the Governor's plan of canal improvement.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 14. -- The Moscow Courier says Count Tolstoi's condition is hopeless.

Dennis Lahey, who was six feet tall, and who weighed 689 pounds, was buried in Calvary Cemetery yesterday. He was probably the heaviest man in Brooklyn. Lahey lived in the Laurel Hill section of Brooklyn. where for many years he carried on with a brother a florist's business. He was the son of Salvator P. Lahey, a wellknown Manhattan physician, who retired many years ago with a large fortune.
Best previous record for 121 hours, 545 miles.

The bill introduced in the Assembly by Mr. ALLEN of this city to authorize the heads of departments in so much of the city as lies in the County of New York to remove their subordinates at will within a period of six months is one that ought not to pass.

BOSTON, Feb. 14. -- The local Democracy, which for two years prior to Jan. I was bereft of the fees and emoluments of public office, is on the verge of disruption because of the manner in which patronage is being distributed. There are about twenty applicants for each place available, and the disappointed ones are complaining loudly.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 14. --The money situation is still very comfortable, and rates are, if anything, inclined to work slightly lower. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 102 1/2 and 105 discount. Call loans, 3 to 3 1/2; time money, 4 to 4 1/2. Clearing House exchanges, $22,713,772; balances, $1,751,957.
MONACO, Feb. 14. -- M. Santos-Dumont met with a disaster here to-day, and had a narrow escape from death. His airship is a tattered wreck, while its motor lies at the bottom of the Bay of Monaco.

The storm, which we considered last week, did not in any degree injure the young oak against which it beat, but only made it strike its roots deeper into the earth, and become more fully established in its place. When it had spent its fury -- like the storm on the Sea of Galileo which Jesus rebuked -- "the wind ceased, and there was a great calm."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Adjt. Gen. Corbin to-day made public the report of the Army Board, of which Gen. MacArthur was President, appointed to consider and report the names of officers and enlisted men of the Army who distinguished themselves during the recent campaigns in Cuba, China, and the Philippines, so as to entitle them to the award either of medals of honor or certificates of merit.

LONDON, Feb. 14. -- Though the demand slackened somewhat to-day money was much wanted for the end of the settlement. Discounts were easy. The feature of business on the Stock Exchange was a heavy fall in Grand Trunk seconds and thirds, in consequence of the disappointing dividend announcement.

"Manu," opera in three acts, the book by Alfred Nossig, the music by Ignace Jan Paderewski, the famous pianist, was performed for the first time in America last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The work was originally produced on May 29, 1901, at the Court Theatre, Dresden, under the baton of Ernest von Schuch, the distinguished conductor of the house.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Col. Michael J. Dady is to testify in the Guden case. Col. Dady is to be called at his own suggestion. A telegram was received to-day by Gov. Odell from Mr. Wernberg, one of Sheriff Guden's attorneys, stating that Col. Dady had returned home and asking whether his testimony was desired in the case.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 14. -- The Trimmer Building, in the centre of the business section of the city, was destroyed by fire to-day. Several women and children living in the building had narrow escapes, two of them getting out with, their clothing afire and one woman being taken from the window of her apartment.

Mr. E.F. Milliken's collection of twentysix paintings were sold at public auction last night at Mendelssohn Hall. The total receipts from the sale were $128,325. The highest price paid for a single picture was $42,000, which was bid by Durand-Ruel Sons for Titian's portrait of Giorgio Cornaro.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- A story published to-day to the effect that Prince Henry of Prussia lias sent a letter of apology to Admiral Dewey is generally discredited here. The apology alleged to have been made was for the acts of Admiral von Dicderichs at Manila when Dewey commanded the American squadron there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14. -- Alfred Noble, civil engineer and a member of the Isthmian Canal Commission, was before the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals to-day. He said it would be necessary to have absolute control of the Cities of Panama and Colon in order to control sanitation.

LIVERPOOL, Feb. 14. -- The Earl of Rosebery received a tremendous ovation at a great Liberal demonstration here this evening. His lengthy speech, the principal address of the evening, was attentively listened to and heartily applauded. He failed to throw any startling fresh light on the war situation, but he strongly emphasized his hostility to the Irish Party and his desire to utterly alienate it from the Liberal camp.
There will be a revision or sawmill fire insurance rates in Eastern Kentucky by the Kentucky and Tennessee Board of Fire Underwriters.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: There are occasions when it is inadvertently revealed to the vvorld how a man would himself have his name called (or written.) One such time was when the resonant, all-pervading dunce music at an assembly, by accident, stopped short off, as though a knife had severed the sound waves, with no timely warning to the dancers on the floor to apply brakes to conversation in progress.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb.14. -- J. B. Lippincott Co. have just issued the first of ten volumes which promise to be the most authoritative lists of the knowledge of physical and scientific geography which has been published. The books, all of which are being prepared under the direction of J. G. Bartholomew, undoubtedly the most distinguished cartographist of the day.

W.H. Sigourney of San Francisco and C. S. Norris of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club won the games in the Class A championship 14.2 billiard tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club yesterday. Sigourney's victory over Threshie in the afternoon gave him the lead in the tourney, while the game which the Knickerbocker Athletic Club champion won from a fellowplayer, Dr. Mial, gave him second place.

UTICA, Feb. 14. -- D.M. Johnson, proprietor of Baggs Hotel here, died this morning, aged fifty-seven years. Mr. Johnson had been the proprietor of Baggs Hotel for about fifteen years. Shortly after the civil war, through which he served with distinction, enlisting as a private and being mustered out as a Captain, Mr. Johnson became the manager of the Manhattan Club in New York.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 14. -- The Yale basket ball five to-night won from the Cornell team in easy manner. The final score was 42 to 16.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 14. -- The Russian official view of the British-Japanese treaty was to-day stated as follows:

Admiral Count von Baudissin, commanding the imperial yacht Hohenzollern, paid and received visits of courtesy yesterday, and in the early afternoon came to New York to call as an unofficial personage on several persons whose acquaintance he made while the yacht was at various yachting rendezvous, among them Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gould.

IN the January number of Caxton's Magazine appears an article by George Bernard Shaw, headed "A Criticism of Modern Book Printing," which is followed by a symposium on "Book Production as It Is," in which H.G. Wells, Gilbert Parker, Mrs. L.T. Meade, Eden Phillpotts, Morley Roberts, Ian Maclaren, Max Pemberton, John Oliver Hobbes, (Mrs. Craigie.) I. Zangwill, and S.R. Crockett give their views on the subject.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 14. -- Open-water work on the harbor will commence for the Yale 'Varsity crew in about three weeks, according to the present plans of the crew Captain and coaches. The first boat is now made up of the men who rowed last year against Harvard, and of the 'Varsity fouroared crew.

A GREAT sprawling book, 6 by 9 inches by 1 inch, the covers as bare of ornament or relief as a burned-over prairie, no more of invitingness about it than the mouth of a tunnel, and, on the back, "Rhymes of Ironquill."

Boston in particular and Massachusetts in general have many good things peculiar to themselves for which they are duly thankful, but perhaps the one thing in which the Commonwealth and its capital are favored far beyond any other section of the country is in the matter of boiler explosions.

President Jacob L. Greatsinger of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company yesterday exhibited plans and drawings showing to what extent the proposed elevated connection between the Manhattan terminals of the East River bridges can be used for the relief of conditions on the present bridge.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 15. -- "Absolute insolvency and suspension of the exercise of municipal functions" are predicted by Controller McGann in a letter sent to Chairman Mayor of the Council Finance Committee. While the Controller's estimate for 1902 was for a total of $9,207,108.81, Mr. McGann now points out that the cash available will be limited to $8,190,119.38.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- At a meeting of the Rabbinical Association at Sinai Temple today a committee from the Industrial Art League endeavored to interest the members in a proposition to establish a guild in connection with the Jewish Training School on the west side. The committee was composed of Prof. Gabriel Bamberger, Mrs. Marion Craig Wentworth, and E. P. Rosenthal.

Central Office detectives and the police of the Charles Street Station now expect an early solution of the mystery which surrounds the death of Mrs. Catherine Voelpel, who was found murdered in her flat, at the corner of Christopher and Hudson Streets, on Friday morning.

Andrew Raben, a jockey, twenty-six years old, died Friday at the home of his brother, Henry Raben, a grocer of 510 Evergreen Avenue. Williamsburg, of consumption, while his aged mother was hurrying front Germany to see her son before the end came. Mrs. Raben had sailed from Germany on the Graf WalQersee, which arrived on Friday, but too late to hear the last words of her son.

WITHIN the past few weeks there has been organized at the Twenty-third Street Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association a "Poor Men's Club," composed of ten young men, whose object is to pool their savings and invest the total in a manner which will insure them larger returns than if each acted singly.

Knowledge or culture, which of these is the proper object of the university? The two are not mutually exclusive. Culture of a certain kind goes with all high knowledge. Mental exercise, developing the faculties, goes with all acquisition of knowledge, indeed with all worthy use of the mind.

It is the pleasing theory of the present State Excise Commissioner and his deputies that his chief, and practically his sole, duty under the liquor tax law is to collect the taxes, leaving to the local authorities the business of enforcing the very stringent provisions of the law in other regards.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Manager Knox of the Phillips-Andover Academy baseball team has announced the baseball schedule. The only preparatory school game is that with the Phillips-Exeter Academy for the championship game. The list includes:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Panama canal protocol, which has been in course of preparation for several-weeks, is practically completed. It was drafted by Dr. Silva the Colombian Minister; Mr. Herran, first secretary of legation, and F. Mutis-Duran, special representative of the Department of Panama.

Michael J. Dady disappointed a lot of expectant Brooklyn Republicans yesterday by failing to unbosom himself further as to the Guden matter. It had been expected that Mr. Dady would supplement the brief statement of denial which he made to the newspaper reporters on Friday night with a detailed story of his side of Brooklyn's now quite celebrated political case.

EVER Since the remarkable achievements of the Ermak, the Russian ice breaker, which two years ago was tried successfully in smashing channels through ice in polar seas, shipping men about New York interestea in river navigation have discussed the advisability of keeping the Hudson open in Winter by means of similar ice breakers.

Our correspondent Mr. J. R. GRIFFING, whose letter, on the compensation of labor and the cost of living, which appeared in THE TIMES some two weeks ago, started so interesting a discussion, defends in a second letter what we believe to be a mistaken view of the matter under consideration.

Brigham, one of the scratch men of the Crescent Athletic Club, in shooting, made the highest scores at the club's Bay Ridge traps yesterday and won three of the six trophies. He also tied for first place in the shoot for the February Cup, and his lowest score in a twenty-five-target contest was better than 20.
I must confess that for the American woman I have the most profound respect and admiration.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- A charge made to a jury by County Judge Samuel A. Boman of Franklin County in a case involving he killing of a moose in violation of the game laws of the State has been exhibited in Albany recently by opponents of the bill which was advocated by the Governor to give him power to designate County Judges for service on the Supreme Court bench in the First and Second Departments.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In your valuable paper dated Feb. 10, 1902; I saw an article copied from The Omaha (Neb.) Bee on the subject of rounding up wolves which suggests some ideas in regard to similar animals that infest our great City of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Through the lakes to the seaboard " a funnel " is an adequate deep waterway as recommended by the United States Commission and Survey, uniting the United States navigation system of twenty-one feet on the lakes with the United States forty-foot system out from New York.

MR. CARNEGIE has established, within the past two years, more than 300 libraries in cities and towns in almost every state and territory in the Union, and is planning to establish many more in the future. At the same time there has been a great boom in the book trade, believed to be in a measure due to Mr.Carnegie's munificence.

RECENT dispatches which announce that the phenomenally rich gold deposits that have been discovered in the Sturgeon Lake district of Ontario are to be developed with American capital call attention to the large number of enterprises in Canada which are being largely financed and directed by citizens or former citizens of the United States.
OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Feb. 15. -- Mid-February at Old Point is one of the pleasantest periods of the season at this popular resort of Eastern Virginia.
A crucial change has come over the close companionship that used to appertain by all the laws of sentiment and proper feeling to husbands and wives of the good oldfashioned type.

FRAUD PRACTICED BY HUSBAND AND WIFE, -- Patrick J. Kennedy, while the owner of the saloon at 2,625 Eighth Avenue, borrowed $4,250 from H. Koehler Co., giving as security a chattel mortgage on the saloon together with an assignment of the lease of the place and the liquor tax certificate.

One of the conditions of the educational foundation provided for in the will of STEPHEN GIRARD, in Philadelphia, was that no newspapers, which he contemptuously characterized as " teachers of disjointed thinking," should be admitted within its inclosing wall. It may be that from the point of view of his time, GIRARD was right.

The removal to the Hudson Street Hospital yesterday morning of Walter S. Brooks, a commission merchant, of the firm of Brooks Wells of 17 Jay Street, who was found in the Glen Island Hotel, at Cortlandt and West Streets, with a bullet in his head, was followed several hours later by the arrest of Florence Burns, nineteen years old, at the home of her father, on Beverly Road.

Surrogate Fitzgerald has under consideration a motion made by Edward S. Clinch for his client, the Rev. Henry SI. Warren of the Central Park Baptist Church, who, under the will of Joseph Richardson, the millionaire who gained celebrity at one time by building a "spite house" seven feet wide on Lexington Avenue, is to receive a legacy of $17,500, for the payment of that legacy to his client.
As sponsor for the bill before the Legislature to require the licensing of cats, Representative Moody Kimball of Newburyport finds himself locally famous.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Ex-United States Senator Thurston of Nebraska argued before the Senate Committee on Immigration to-day against the proposed Chinese Exclusion bill. He said that the regulation of Chinese immigration should be left to diplomatic negotiation in order to prevent the irritation which was already such as to affect the Chinese Legation in the United States and possibly the Chinese Court itself.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The hearing before the Senate Committee on the Canal bill Wednesday developed a good deal of humor. As the various delegations interested in the bill were filing into the room, Senator Cocks of Suffolk County remarked to Senator Hill of Buffalo: "Hill, if you will tell me where Long Island comes in on this canal improvement I will be glad to vote for the bill."

To the Editor of The New York Times: That we are likely to set some hot-head legislation from Albany, under the initiative of our clever but impulsive Governor, has been evident for some time; but as indicative of the somewhat inexpert consideration such business is receiving from him and his coadjutors, I would like to call attention to three features of the current effort to amend the tax laws as affecting foreign corporations.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I confess to a feeling of joy at the present outcry of wealthy women returning from Europe with outfits for the year at the enforcement against them of the law imposing duties upon such articles, especially in view of the fact that these women are mostly wives of high protectionists.
TUESDAY, FEB. 18.-- By James L. Wells, executors' sale, 363 Fifth Avenue, east side, 99.3 feet north of Thirty-fourth Street, 17.6 by 125 and irregular, five-story brownstone-front building; also.

Over two thousand dogs will transform the big Madison Square Garden into a vast kennel of many breeds on Wednesday, when the annual bench shots of the Westminster Kennel Club will open, to continue for the remainder of the week. To be exact, the number of entries is 2,366, over 200 in excess of any previous show, so that this fact alone will make the coming show memorable as a record breaker.

WEST BROOKFIELD, Mass., Feb. 15. -- As the result of an explosion of illuminating gas, Mrs. Fanny Gould, wife of T. Elmer Gould, and Mrs. Mary Shaw Tomblen were killed, Mr. Gould was terribly injured: a servant of the Gould family, Miss Margaret Lahey, was so badly injured and burned that she probably cannot recover, and Mr. Gould's house was entirely wrecked about 6:30 o'clock to-night.

ONE of the most important developments of the club idea, and one which it now appears has come to stay, has taken place quite recently in this city, and is already reported to have spread to other large cities of the country. This is the organization of clubs representing geographical sections.

Democratic harmony was the slogan which was sounded by all the speakers at the Tilden banquet held under the auspices of the Brooklyn Democratic Club in Brooklyn last evening in the Germania Club. The speakers were men of National and local political power representing all factions.

BANGOR, Feb. 15. -- Logging operations on all Maine waters are now far advanced, chopping being nearly over and what remains of the crews being engaged now chiefly in hauling from the yards to the landings. On the Penobscot the cut amounts to somewhat more than 200,000,000 feet, as indicated by the latest returns from camps on all branches, the West Branch cut being very nearly 100,000,000 feet.

Sunday concerts will be given at the Victoria, New York, American, Dewey, Metropolis, and at all of the Proctor theatres: also at Hurtig Seamen's and the New York Winter Garden. Entertaining programmes have been arranged, and the concerts trill provide features that promise to be enjoyable.
THE future evolution of the conventional dress suit in America is just now exciting considerable speculation in certain fashionable circles.

No great excitement marked the close of the six-day go-as-you-please pedestrian race last night which has been in progress in the Madison Square Garden since a few minutes past midnight last Monday morning.

Not withstanding the gold exports of a week ago and the large loan expansion reported by the banks in the two weeks ending Feb. 8, it is a fact of no little consequence and significance that throughout the week just closed money rates not only showed no signs of hardening, but rather tended to greater ease.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- In to-day's debate on the permanent Census Bureau bill, Senator Lodge (Rep., Mass.) exposed an ingenious scheme to pack the civil service. The bill provides for transferring to the permanent Census Bureau such clerks in the present bureau as are needed, and the remainder of the clerks in the present bureau are to go upon the classified list, on the ground that they are experienced clerks.

In discussing the question of " issues," it is well to bear in mind exactly what is meant by the expression. The word issue has a very different meaning when employed by a Democrat from what it has when employed by a Republican.
The Journal is in receipt of a note from a Western Kansas map, now serving in an official capacity in the State House, which says:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15. -- St. Cuthbert, who has been gradually roumling into form, scored very cleverly in the De Solo Handicap, worth $1,645 to the winner, to-day. The gelding was always favorite in the betting, being backed from fours to 5 to 2. Sevoy who might have been a dangerous rival, was overweighted.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 15. -- The movement in Cotton Duct issues formed the leading feature in to-day's trading. Yesterday's report by the company, in which interest on the income bonds was passed, caused some selling in the morning, but when the report was analyzed sufficiently to observe its favorable side, the pressure to sell was checked and the bonds sold 3/4 above the lowest for the day.

BREMERHAVEN, Feb. 15. -- Admiral Prince Henry of Prussia sailed to-day for New York on the Kronprinz Wilhelm at 3:43 P.M. The big German liner passed the Hohenweg lighthouse at 5:25 P.M. The weather was magnificent and the sea calm.

MANY young men of Gaivesion are at the present moment exelled by stories of a pirate's treasure, said to have been buried on the island by Jean Lafitle, and told to them by an old sailor, one Andrew Straubue of Sixteenth Street and Avenue A. Galveston, employed on the strand there.
Judson Harmon, Attorney General in the second Cabinet of President Cleveland, wrote as follows:
BATONNE, N. J., Feb. 15. -- John Braden, whom the police have frequently but vainly tried to convict on the charge of arson, was again arrested last night.

MOST interesting of the plans to honor the memory of Victor Hugo in connection With the hundredth anniversary of his birth, which is to be celebrated in Paris on the 26th of this month, is the establishment of the Victor Hugo Museum in the house in the Place des Vosges, in which he resided for sixteen years -- from 1832 to 1848 -- and in which so many of his masterpieces wore written.

CHILPANCINGO, State of Guerrero, Mexico, Feb. 15. -- Great alarm prevails here, as well as in Chilapa and Tixtla, at the discovery of smoke issuing from the openings in the summit of Temalacatlaco on the roan between this city and Chilapa.

Copyright. 1902. LONDON, Feb. 15. -- One important feature of the financial week has been the development of a decidedly better feeling in regard to American rails, the market for which has become much steadier, although the volume of business continues to be small except for continental and New York buying.
In his letter of regret Richard Olney, ex-Attorney General and ex-Secretary of State under the Presidency of Grover Cleveland, wrote:

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- Money conditions continue unchanged. The end of the week finds the situation as easy as it has been all along of late and with the opinion general that low rates are to continue for some time to come. Demand is still very light, and the banks, on the other hand, are well supplied with loanable funds.

RECENT dispatches from Rome stated that Cardinal Lucido Maria Parocch was afflicted with a mortal disease, and it was declared that he was dying ton days ago. His death would remove a dignitary of the Catholic Church who was regarded by many students of the politics of the Holy see as the likeliest of all the candidates for the Papacy to succeed the venerable Leo XIII.

Market conditions show distinct improvement. With the removal of the issues that attend upon the Northern Securities litigation, it is the opinion of conservative authorities that the Stock Exchange will enjoy both activity and buoyancy.

Copper Trust stock gave another of its pyrotechnical exhibitions during the week, dropping a half dozen points as a result of what appeared to be a continuation of inside manipulation. Not satisfied with the slaughter of the innocents that already has taken place, these millionaire gamblers apparently are renewing their campaign of depression in order to shake out further stock-the lower and cheaper, the better.

As an illustration of Lord Dufferin's peculiar gift of diplomatic use of humor, some references to the United States may be cited. The question of the fisheries was under discussion. He solemnly declared that while in the United States he had beleaved as if there were no fisheries question indeed, as if fish had no existence.

ONE rainy day, like some of recent occurrence costs the New York theatres about a thousand dollars. If the morning is bright and it comes on to rain about 1 o'clock on a matinee day then the theatres reap a harvest, for the people are driven into, the places of amusement.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- George H. Raymond, who represents the interests of Buffalo in the pending canal legislation, when asked to-day whether Buffalo would antagonize the appropriation for the improvement of the Champlain Canal, said:

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 13. -- Work was started here this week on the new third-rail electric road between this city and Trenton. As the maps of the projectors show, the line will pass exclusively through farms, and will not touch a town or a village of any importance between New Brunswick and Trenton.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Edward S. Hall, Professor of Physics at Harvard, who made such a sensation at the Bowdoin Alumni dinner in Boston last week by saying that the collegiate athletic laws are too strict, is the leader of a quiet movement at Harvard which promises to do more than anything else to straighten out the present difficulties between Yale and Harvard.

FOR MORE than a generation there has been an old trapper and guide in the Adirondacks whose usual haunts were near Raquette Lake and the Fulton Chain. His name is Alvah Dunning, but he is better known to hunters and visitors in that region under the soubriquet of " Snake-Eye."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The German Ambassador entertained at dinner this evening. His guests were the French Ambassador, the Secretary of Agriculture and Miss Wilson, the Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Hill, Justice and Mrs. Gray, Judge and Mrs. Hagner, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Squires, the Argentine Minister and Mme. Garcia Merou, Col. and Mrs. Henry May, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Legare, Miss Merriam, the Naval Attache of the Embassy and Frau von Febuer-Pasehwitz.

WEDNESDAY, FEB. 19. -- By William M. Ryan, sale in partition of interests, West and Washington, Laight and Hubert Streets, the block, 179 by 225 try 178 by 229, brick structures of various heights, from three to ten stories, known as the old Appraisers' Stores.

"THE mysteries of the newspaper profession," remarked Assistant Secretary of State David J. Hill the other day. "have always had a deep fascination for me, and particularly that rule of the business which requires newspaper writers to assert that 'much excitement is felt in Washington,' or that 'the State Department is deeply gratified over the news,' or that 'much uneasiness is felt at the State Department.'

Superintendent Stewart of the Bureau of Buildings declared yesterday that he was opposed to any change in the law covering the construction of skyscrapers as proposed before the Board of Aldermen. The amendment, proposed by Alderman Seebeck, is to strike out parts of Section 105, which specifies the materials to be put in buildings over 100 feet in height.

WORKMEN digging on the tunnel near One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street unearthed two weeks ago numerous large fragments of enormous stone pillars which appeared to form part of an extensive ruin in a part of Manhattan Island where no building is known to have existed.

ST PETERSBURG, Jan. 30. -- This city is enjoying one of the gayest seasons ever known here. During the last fortnight an unwonted bustle of state and private carriages, with gorgeously liveried footmen, has announced daily a succession of dinners, receptions, and dances in the upper circles.

At the instance of Sir Albert Rollit, the Senate of the University of London yesterday resolved to appoint a committee to consider and report as to the expediency of establishing a degree in commerce.

Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted permission to the Church of the Epiphany to sell its property in Fortyseventh Street, west of Lexington Avenue, to the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad for $31,300, subject to an existing mortgage of $20,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg to inform you that I traveled north in a four-car train which left the Twenty-third Street station of the Second Avenue line at 6:20 P. M., and the manner in which it was packed was a disgrace, not alone to the City of New York, but to civilization.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The dispute over the attitude of the powers toward the United States prior to the Spanish-American war continues to take up columns of the London dailies. As pointed out when the Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Lord Cranborne, made his first statement, official opinion is much divided as to the advisability of that step.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was very glad to read your editorial on the importance of shipmasters heading the warnings of the United States Weather Bureau signals when they are about to leave this port, bound coastwise especially. I trust we shall see the subject brought up again in order to show further the advantages of what the Government is doing in warning the marines of approaching storms.

Intense excitement prevailed in front of the Criterion Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fourth Street, last night when Hugh McGarry, a Pinkerton detective, was attacked by a dozen ticket speculators, who punched and kicked him into unconsciousness.

VARIOUS magazine articles upon wireless telegraphy, written subsequent to the wonderful experiments of Marconi in Newfoundland in December, have intimated that the time was not remote when the cable equipments of the world would become practically valueless and the hundreds of millions of dollars invested in cables might as well he sold as scrap iron.
BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 15. -- The season just ended in Baltimore was remarkable in more ways than one. It was the most brilliant in the annals of the city.
Though certain of the Government are in favor of the militia ballot, the scheme does not recommend itself to the more Important members of that body.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 15. -- A party of officers of the imperial German yacht Hohenzollern, headed by Lieut. von Mantey, passed through Buffalo this evening for Niagara Falls, where they will spend Sunday. The party were at dinner in their private car when their train reached this city.

Only six officers, subordinates to Admiral von Baudissin. were left on the imperial yacht Hohenzollern yesterday. Six of them left the Grand Central Station for Niagara Falls at 8:45 A. M. on the fast mail which follows the Empire State Express, and will return to-morrow, when those who were left on duty will be entitled to furlough for the trip.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Rudolph Keppler, President of the New York Stock ExChange, and H. K. Pomeroy, Vice President, had a conference to-day with Commissioner Yerkes of the Internal Revenue Bureau on the subject of his recent decision to the effect that the memorandum which accompanies stock deposited as collateral security for loans is subject to stamp tax.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Money was in active demand to-day, and the supplies were poor. Discounts were firmer. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet and irregular. There was the usual week-end disinclination to do business. Consols were dull. Home rails generally were firm. Grand Trunk seconds hardened.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15. -- Robert M. Snyder, the millionaire promoter of Kansas City and New York, was indicted to-day for bribery in connection with the Central Traction bill. A bench warrant has been issued for his arrest and a Deputy Sheriff is trying to find him, but he reports that Mr. Snyder is not in the city.

SHE is a thirteen-months-old baby, and the other day she distinguished herself. She has done that before, but not in quite the same way. She first showed herself to be an unusually clever baby by suddenly rising upon her small feet, and, with no previous experience, walking over to her mamma to show her some of her small treasures.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Gov. Taft talked about the Philippine question before the Senate Committee on the Philippines again to-day. The hearing began with a series of questions by Senator Patterson (Dem., Col.,) in regard to the fitness of Fllipinos for jury duty. The Governor repeated what he had said before -- that the natives were not qualified for such duty.

SILAS LARRABEE expressed some rather contemptuous opinions concerning the Wars and Means Committee of the National House of Representatives in a lecture he delivered last night in the auditorium of the Ogunquit Board of Trade. He gave it as his deliberate Judgment that the committee was "short-sighted, narrerminded, and cold-blooded," and that it was "raising thunder with the Republican Party and the United States of Ameriky."

ANY one who takes a ferry trip to Brooklyn nowadays will get a superficial idea of the differences between the old and new suspension bridges over the East River, and may well be surprised at the rapidity with which the latter is being finished.

NOT long ago Judge Dickey of the Supreme Court, who hails from Newburg, was holding court in Brooklyn. The lawyer for the defendant in the case before him occupied the time of the court by asking practically the same question over and over again. Judge Dickey called his attention to this fact once or twice, and finally became provoked and said to the lawyer:

Agreement for a fight for the pugilistic championship of the world, to be held on or about May 15 next, was reached yesterday morning in the office of The New York Journal by James J. Jeffries, the present holder of the championship, and Robert Fitzsimmons, the ex-champion, whom Jeffries defeated for the title.

"With reference to the statement, ' Even families with Cromwell's blood are not likely to resent the omission of Cromwell's portraits from the New Gallery,' I was curious," writes a correspondent, " to find out how many descendants of his were of such prominence in the world as to give some value to their resentment, suppose they did resent, at the omission of his portrait from the New Gallery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems strange that our Bridge Commissioner cannot devise some way to relieve the bridge to accord at least with the common decencies of life. Surely there must be a way out of the difficulty. When loafers and roughs are to be dealt with, only the police can enforce order.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The absolute facts are that the present capitalization of the Standard Oil Trust is at least $202,233,700, instead of the reported $97,000,000, and that this month's declaratory quarterly dividend amounts to more than $40,000,000, instead of $20,000,000, and that the average market price of its trust certificates, 1901, was $763 per share, aggregating an investment value of $1,543,043,131.

Two records were broken and one established in the open swimming races held in the New York Athletic Club tank last night. Otto Wahle of the home club made the most notable performance, beating the former record in the 800-yard swim by fully 23 seconds and finishing 15 yards ahead of Fred Wenck of Tale and the New York Athletic Club.

A very curious case came to light from Chickasaw County, Miss. It seems that some time ago a man named Richardson, a well-to-do planter, was murdered. Before Richardson died he stated that he was murdered by Leroy Harper and his wife. They were arrested. Feeling against the Harpers was high.
