GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 15. -- Frederick Mead of New York recently put in a bill for $75,000 for three years' work as executor of the estate of Solomon Mead of Greenwich, and the claim is now being contested by the seven heirs and numerous legatees, most of them church missionary societies.

" Foxy Grandpa " will have its first performance in this city at the Fourteenth Street Theatre to-morrow night, whith Joseph Hart and Carrie De Mar as the stars, assisted by a large company of comedians and vocalists.

The accounts recently published in regard to the plans of the Southern Educational Conference may be premature, but the plans outlined are clearly within the scope of the purpose of the conference, and it is more than probable that the gentlemen named in these accounts will take an active part in carrying out this purpose.
BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The Cologne Gazette devotes a lengthy editorial to the departure of Prince Henry on his visit to the United States. It says:

BONES of murdered Revolutionary patriots, ancient coins, and perhaps half-decayed records of 125 years ago are waiting for the subway excavators to uproot them under the old Hall of Records, beneath which the diggers will begin to do their work in a week or two.

WHEN the five and ten cent stores were established and proved a success it was supposed that the lowest limit had been, readied. But the one-cent store has in the past few months become an established institution in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- Operations on the Stock Exchange to-day were largely in Reading second preferred, the dealings in that issue equaling the total in all other issues combined. A house identified with the Reading management bought the stock, but it did not respond more than 1/8 to this demand.

Changes in material comforts have so altered affairs among the middle classes of Germany, more especially in the large cities, that the women lack employment in their homes. Gradually the ideal of the German Hausfrau, with her well-stocked and well-guarded pantry, her bunch of keys, and her petty but constant occupations from morning to night is fading from the respectable burgher circles in cities.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 15. -- This city is filling with fashionable visitors who are coming here to spend the Lenten season, and the Boardwalk presents an animated scene every clear morning and afternoon.

The biggest raid that has startled the Bowery for some time took place late last night, when in the neighborhood of Chatham Square and Chinatown six disorderly houses were raided and forty-seven prisoners taken and brought to the Elizabeth Street Station. Two patrol wagons were employed and one of them made two trips.

C. S. Norris, the champion of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, succeeded in beating C. P. Conklin, the Chicago expert, last night in the final game at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of the Amateur Athletic Union 14.2 billiard tournament for the championship of Class A. His victory places him on even terms with the Pacific Coast champion, W. H. Sigourney, and therefore necessitates the playing of an extra game.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I understand that the bill now before the legislature will regulate the wild career of our city automobiles. Action cannot come too soon and cannot be too strictly enforced if we would not be in time as childless a city as Hamelin after the departure of the piper.
His Shereefian Majesty's Camp, Settat, Morocco, Dec. 1. By the invitation of his Majesty I am accompanying the Sultan on his march from Marakesh to Rabat.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I want very briefly to correct some misstatements that Mr. Walker D. Hines has unintentionally made in his letter to you as published in your issue of the 6th inst.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Consul General Robert P. Skinner has reported to the State Department from Marseilles "some facts respecting olive oil." He says:

The British Governmen has just published in the form of a "White Paper" a petition from the Boer prisoners in Bermuda, which shows that as far back as last September they desired lo help in ending the war in South Africa. The petition is addressed to "his Excellency the Military Governor, Bermuda," and dated "Tucker's Island, Sept. 24, 1901," and runs as follows:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with extreme interest the reports of Dr. Parkhurst's sermons on "Limits to the Soul's Life," as reported in THE TIMES.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 15. -- The rush of Lenten visitors to this sequestered spot in the heart of the New Jersey pines has begun and the village now presents an appearance of bustling activity that it did not have a week ago. The days are clear and sunny and just cold enough to make a walk or a drive an exhilarating pleasure.

Seven firemen were badly injured and narrowly escaped with their lives from the old Durland Riding Academy building, which was burned to the ground yesterday afternoon. The large Poillon apartment house, at the corner of Sixty-first Street and Central Park West, was at one time also on fire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An an elderly woman, who has suffered from sciatica and other ills. I feel that I must thank "A Man" for his brave and chivalrous words in THE TIMES of Feb. 11 in regard to the standing of women in the cars. It is refreshing to know that we have "A Man" with us yet who can thus make light of his sacrifices to my sex.
The Virginia State Constitutional Convention is still hammering away at the new instrument, and is not likely to have it finished under a month yet.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The King and Queen continue their unostentatious round of theatregoing, and presumably will visit every theatre of the first rank in turn. It is understood each time that there will be no special demonstration, although theatre managers are merely human, and they make all they can of the honor in the way of advertisement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15. -- Eonic, carrying the colors of Caesar Young and ridden by Lee Jackson, won the $10,000 Burns Handicap at Oakland to-day in the presence of more than 7,000 people. Nones was second and Corrigan third. The mile and a quarter were covered in 2:10 1/4.

This man knows more about locks and vaults than an the bank robbers in the country. He can open a safe in Boston by telephone in five minutes, ordinarily.

HAVANA, Feb. 15. -- Major W. C. Gorgas, Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana, says the principal work of the Sanitary Department for the past year has had for its object the extermination of yellow fever and that he has many reasons to believe that Havana has been actually purged from the disease.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- No change in grade was made by the tea experts, who have just completed their session. "One feature which was very prominently commented upon in the board," says Secretary Woodsworth, "was the fact that no really poor and undesirable teas were offered for the board's inspection.

There was a large gathering at Bermondsey Town Hall when the Mayor of the borough, Col. S. B. Bevington, opened the new electric lighting and dust destructor works which have lately been brought to completion by the Bermondsey Borough Council. The new works are situated in Spa Road, at the rear of the Town Hall and public baths, and they occupy an area of about 1 1/2 acres.

PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 15. -- Mrs. Catherine Boyle, an elderly woman, was arraigned before Recorder Senior to-day charged with setting fire to her home, 376 Straight Street. The woman did not seem to understand the seriousness of the charge preferred against her. The Recorder was unable to get any satisfactory answers from Mrs. Boyle, and committed her to jail until he can make an investigation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read in your issue of this morning the article headed "Fatal Automobile Ride." It is time to call a halt on these so-called "couldn't-help-it" automobile homicides. Within a few days two persons have lost their lives through the rapid driving of these too carelessly managed machines.

Although maintaining an undiminished volume, the last few days' dealings in real estate have followed more conventional lines. There has been no new tunnel project to infuse life into some hitherto inactive section, or any other influence to create a new centre of buying, and, indeed, the large purchases by Richard M. Montgomery's syndicate on Broadway, just north of the Circle, have been the week's only distinguishing feature.

The progress which Russia is making in laying down railways, not only of commercial but of strategic value, attracts much attention here. In two directions the network of Russia's railways has strikingly developed during the past year, in Central Asia and on the Russian and Austrian frontiers.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Gov. Odell to-day sent to Dr. C. H. Parkhurst an answer to the letter of one week ago in which Dr. Parkhurst charged the State administration with being responsible for the existence of the Raines law hotels in New York City. In his letter Gov. Odell says:

Yesterday the Matin published a real titbit from its London correspondent, who sent a long translation of an article that has appeared in a Venezuelan newspaper. The extract is to the effect that President Kruger has visited Caracas incognito. The South American newspaper says: -- "Yesterday the illustrious Kruger, President of the heroic Boers, arrived incognito at Caracas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am not a new woman, nor am I President or Chairman of any society for woman's rights. This preface suffices to explain that I have no ambition in a political line -- that I do not intend to "spring " myself on the people as a future candidate for President of the United States.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 15. -- The quarter contennial celebration of Johns Hopkins University or Feb. 22 will be a notable event in university circles. Presidents Eliot of Harvard, Hadley of Yale, Harper of Chicago, and Patton of Princeton will be among the distinguished guests. The programme includes a great mass meeting at Music Hall on Friday evening, Feb. 21.

The first week in Lent finds society in New York just settling down to realize the changed condition of affairs. With this week will come the first meetings of many of the Lenten club's and sewing classes. So far the O. N., Miss Leary's, and the Post Graduate have been the ones which have assembled.

APROPOS or Prince Henry's visit, and the attraction titled foreigners have for some New Yorkors, a matron, commenting on this paradoxical trait of a democratic people, recalled the other day an incident in her experience in the early eighties, when Sir Samuel and Lady Baker were the guests in this city of the late Dr. Thomas C. Durant.

The full effects of tobacco can only be experienced when they are assisted by the drinking of alcoholic liquors. The theory, however, is published not as an exhortation, but as a warning, although it is to be feared that the pleasant blending of poisons will not be greatly checked even by the most scientific argument.

Some centuries of experimentation in aeronautics have brought us, in the results obtained by M. SANTOS-DUMONT, back to the starting point. Icarus, flying from Crete on wings of wax, fell into the Aegean Sea and was drowned. SANTOS-DUMONT, with very much better, but apparently no more dirigible apparatus, has fallen into the Mediterranean.

Among prominent stocks which are depending for dividends upon further development in earnings there are many whose issues for large amounts, whose activity has at times been marked, and whose prices have made quite sharp advances, as traffic and traffic results have progressed and general business expansion has taken place.
The Rev. Jenkin Lloyd Jones preached at All Souls' Church on Sunday his annual sermon on Lincoln. His subject was "Lincoln in Story and Song." He said:

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 15. -- The latest reports from the sick rooms of the three Groton School students are most favorable. Mrs. Roosevelt stated late this afternoon that her son was improving rapidly, and the Potter and Gammell lads are also better, although their convalescence is not so rapid as young Roosevelt's.
ONE shoe store on Amsterdam Avenue has attracted a good deal of attention lately, and has incidentally increased its trade by displaying the following notice:

TRIESTE, Austria-Hungary, Feb. 15. -- Crowds throng the streets this morning but military patrols keep the strikers and public on the move. All the squares and public buildings are occupied by soldiers, and large contingents of the military forces are in readiness for immediate action. Business is suspended.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- In the unlovely district of St. Ouen lives an old ragpicker, well known to her neighbors on account of her aversion to cats. Her name is Louise Maritzman, but every one knows her as Mother Matou.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A revelation made by Gen. Grosvenor, (Rep., Ohio,) on the floor of the House yesterday attracted considerable attention in Washington today. It was to the effect that President Roosevelt had nothing to do with the selection of Whitelaw Reid as special Ambassador to the coronation of King Edward.

The programme of stake events for the Saratoga Racing Association meeting in August was announced yesterday by Secretary H. D. Mclntyre, with a list of seven events for three-year-olds and upward, four for three-year-olds, five for two-year-olds, and two for steeplechasers, all to close on March 10.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- In the unlovely district of St. Ouen lives an old ragpicker, well known to her neighbors on account of her aversion to cats. Her name is Louise Maritzman, but every one knows her as Mother Matou.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- A revelation made by Gen. Grosvenor, (Rep., Ohio,) on the floor of the House yesterday attracted considerable attention in Washington today. It was to the effect that President Roosevelt had nothing to do with the selection of Whitelaw Reid as special Ambassador to the coronation of King Edward.

The programme of stake events for the Saratoga Racing Association meeting in August was announced yesterday by Secretary H. D. Mclntyre, with a list of seven events for three-year-olds and upward, four for three-year-olds, five for two-year-olds, and two for steeplechasers, all to close on March 10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- An important conference was held in the Cabinet room of the Wite House this morning. At the President's request he was joined there shortly after 10 o'clock by Senators Allison, (Rep., Iowa,) Aldrich, (Rep., R. I.,) and Spooner, (Rep., Wis.,) Speaker Henderson, (Rep., Iowa,) and Representatives Cannon, (Rep., Ill.,) and Grosvenor, (Rep., Ohio,) and the conference last until a few minutes after 12.

Fire destroyed the ornamental iron works of Franz Meyer, on Franklin Street, Astoria, last night. Two men are missing, although they may have escaped and through fright have run away, as did a third-one. The fourth man who was in the building when the flames broke out is in St. John's Hospital, in Long Island City, severely injured.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly permit me to mention a coincidence which may be of interest. I was passing a high school one day last week where a group of young people stood chatting over the day's history lesson. One manly looking boy spoke out decidedly:

When Mr. ROOT first took office he announced what he conceived to be his official function by saying that the use of an army was to be ready for war. It was really a new notion in the War Department. Mr. ROOT'S predecessors had, at worst, looked upon the Secretaryship as an eligible place in which to "play politics."

Under the auspices of the Anti-Saloon League a mass meeting was held yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Temple, at which a memorial was adopted as the sense of those present favoring the passage of the Bennet-Ambler Local Option bill. Both the auditorium and the balcony of the church were well filled with persons interested in the Sunday saloon question.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in the editorial of your paper of the 11th inst. that you were again touching upon the question of our troublesome customs regulations as far as individuals entering this country are concerned, but I do not think you are taking this question from the right side.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Senator and Mrs. Depew entertained at dinner this evening. Their guests were invited to meet Mr. and Mrs. M.E. Ingalls of Cincinnati, who are on a brief visit to Washington. The company included Postmaster General and Mrs. Payne, Senator Fairbanks, Senator and Mrs. Scott, Senator Beveridge, Mr. and Mrs. Grosvenor, Mr. and Mrs. W.W. Rockhill, Mrs. Slater, and Miss Paulding.

LYONS, Feb. 7. -- In several places where French workingmen have been beaten in strikes recently, they returned to their work with the determination to get even with the employer by indulging in "sabottage," which means that they do not half do their work, and let material go to waste and machinery be injured.

Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation, arrived in New York yesterday on the American Line's steamship St. Paul, after an absence of six weeks on a visit to England and a short tour of the Continent, his trip having been a combination of business and pleasure.
SOUTHAMPTON, Feb. 16. -- The Kronprinz Wilhelm arrived here this morning. Prince Henry's voyage to England was uneventful.

The reply of Gov. ODELL to the letter of Dr. PARKHURST is disingenuous. In the light of the known facts it is also absurd. It is the plea of the Hibernian that for one witness who saw him commit an offense he could bring ten who did not see him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Once again, for after all it is the renewed attack, the "once again" that wins the day. Your good paper then to the fore in behalf of a better service for the homeless or injured animals of this city and Brooklyn.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 16. -- Cycle races on the new Atlanta Coliseum track will begin to-morrow night. This will mark the opening of the Winter cycle season here, to last three months. All of the crack professional riders of the country are now here and getting into racing shape. Lawson, the terrible Swede from Buffalo, to-day sent his motor cycle over the course at a 1:30 clip.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- "A picture on every page" is the term by which an enthusiastic student of statistics describes the Statistical Abstract of the United States, just issued by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics. While solid columns of figures are not looked upon by the average citizen as especially picturesque, an examination of the pages of this publication presents some interesting, if not absolutely picturesque, facts.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- A freight train crossing from the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg tracks to No. 3 track on the New York Central at Lincoln Park was struck and cut in two to-day by the West Shore's east-bound " Continental Limited." Both the engineer and fireman on the limited jumped before the collision, the former escaping injury, while the latter sustained a dislocated shoulder.

The agitation regarding the Sunday closing of saloons, and especially of violations of the excise law by Raines law hotels, has been vigorously renewed by the arrival in this city of thirty Excise Inspectors. They were sent by State Commissioner Cullinan to gather evidence against the Raines law hotels and will report to him at Albany the result of their investigation.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- When the Legislature convened the leaders announced that this would be a ten weeks' session, a record breaker. Plains were made to secure an adjournment on March 15, but events have already begun to work against an early adjournment, and now at the beginning of the seventh week it is announced that the session will probably continue until April.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Looking to the reduction of the "jam" at the New York end of the bridge, the following suggestions are submitted! That the roadway from Brooklyn be closed to wagons, , between 5 P.M. and 7 or 7:30 P.M. Passengers coming from Brooklyn during thess hours should be instructed to leave cars, say, at a point on the roadway about 400 feet from present loop.

With a somewhat shortened stride and a considerable want of breath, John Foy of the Star Athletic Club gamely crossed the finish line, the winner of the annual open handicap cross country run of the Pastime Athletic Club yesterday afternoon. Only fifteen yards behind was J.J. Farrell, also of the Star Athletic Club, while closely pursuing him was a Pastime runner.

There was good footing on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning for the first time in over a month, and as a result horsemen turned out in full force, glad of the opportunity to step their favorite trotters and pacers, who have been growing heavy and clumsy for want of proper exercise.

READMISSION OF JESUITS TO GERMANY. -- A curious sequel to the attempted theatrical expulsion of the Jesuits from England has been played in Berlin, in the Reichstag the other day Dr. Spahn of the Centre or Catholic Party interpellated the Government on its attitude toward the bill passed by the Reichstag in February, 1899, rescinding the Jesuit exclusion law of 1872.

Prof. C.E. Borchgrevink, the antarctic explorer, was a passenger on the Cunarder Etruria, which arrived yesterday. He is at the Everett House. Yesterday he said, in relation to his expedition in search of the south pole:

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Thousands of persons visited the scene of last Sunday's fire to-day, all from out of town. They were allowed to wander about the Streets in the burned district under police supervision. The streets now practically are cleared of debris, and the walls which menaced life have been leveled.

The market gardener near Paterson, N.J., who tapped the power cable of the trolley line and conveyed the current to his vegetable patches no doubt committed a technical offense against the property right of the railway company, but it begins to look as if he had made a discovery of such value that the company could well afford to condone the appropriation of its current and pay something for the knowledge it has gained.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times quotes an article on the British-Japanese alliance in The Exchange Gazette, which paper, he says he has reason to believe in this instance expresses with considerable fidelity the views held in authoritative quarters.

At the Democratic banquet in Brooklyn on Saturday evening Mr. SHEPARD thus defined one principle on which all Democrats must unite if they are to form an effective opposition in the present, and be able to apply a definite, conservative, and constructive policy in the future, should they secure power.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Rands were still the centre of interest, as well as the centre of anxiety, during the last week, for those who were inclined to take a pessimistic view of the outlook on the Stock Exchange. The settlement was an arduous task, especially in the mining section, where the accounts of several overrash speculators were suspended.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The Rev. George Carter Needham, well-known evangelist and writer, died suddenly of neuralgia of the heart to-day at his home in Narberth, a suberb of this city. He had just returned from an evangelistic tour of several weeks through Tennessee, and expected shortly to go to Chicago to preach.
VIENNA, Feb. 16. -- The riots at Trieste were the gravest which have occurred in Austria in many years. The original strike is supposed to be an outcome of Socialist or Anarchist agitation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 17. -- The detailed report of the Census Bureau of Agriculture in New Jersey pleases those interested in farming in this State. The total value of farm property by the census is $189,533,660, exclusive of live stock and implements. The live stock is worth $17,612,620, the implements nearly $10,000,000, and the buildings (included in farm values), $69,230,080.

-- Slightly unnecessary wonder is expressed by The New York Medical Journal because of the fact that, though the doctors agreed years ago that pneumonia is due to a specific micro-organism, the notion so often expressed by the words, "this is good weather for pneumonia," and based on the old idea that exposure to cold, per se, can produce the disease, still holds almost unquestioned sway among the people.

BERLIN, Feb. 5. -- Now that Prince Henry is preparing to sail for the United States, the anti-American sentiment in Germany looms up more luridly than before. There are only spasmodic and formal comments on the enthusiastic spirit manifested in the United States toward Prince Henry and the Kaiser.

A debate on the question, " Shall the Saloons Be Open on Sunday?" was held in Cooper Union last night, the Rev. Thomas H. Slicer speaking on the affirmative and Secretary Robert Graham of the Church Temperance Society on the negative, was decided in the affirmative by a vote of about 1,200 to 200 by the audience, which contained only a few women.

Lieut. Browning, the Adjutant at Governors Island, was asked the other day if he had any idea as to the number of dogs on that island. Before the Adjutant could form a reply about a dozen dogs scampered by his window, and, pointing to them, he laughingly said: "I hope you don't take me for a lightning calculator."

Cooper Institute has received another gift of $250,000 to its endowment fund, but the name of the giver at his own request will not be made public. Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt told of the gift yesterday at his home, 9 Lexington Avenue.

A woman was burned to death and two men were burned seriously last evening in the apartments of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Suret, at 265 West Thirty-ninth Street. The dead woman is Mrs. Virginia Suret, fifty years old. The men were her husband, Victor Suret, sixty years old, and Policeman Blessing of the West Forty-seventh Street Station.

The saloon of Joseph E. Winters, 300 yards from the main gate to Fort Totten, Willetts Point, is a wreek. For wrecking it twenty-one privates of the Eighty-second Company of Sea Coast Artillery are prisoners in the guardhouse at the fort. Winters, the proprietor, is a prisoner in the Flushing Hospital, while James Maloney, a private in the Eighty-second Company, lies in the hospital at the fort with a bullet wound in his left hip.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- The Times quotes the February report of the Boiler Makers' and Iron and Steel Ship Builders' Society, which says there is a greater dearth of orders booked than at any time during the last five years, but that hopes of improvement are not dead yet. The report adds:

Florence Burns, the nineteen-year-old girl of Flatbush, accused of the murder of Walter S. Brooks, in business as a commis- sion merchant at 17 Jay Street, had lost none of her self-possession after the night spent in a cell in the Church Street Station, when she appeared in the Centre Street Court yesterday morning.

To establish an Order of Paulist Fathers among the clergy of the Protestant Episcopal Church is the latest proposition of some of the members of that body. The suggestion emanates from the Middle West, where, it is said, the work of such an organization would be particularly useful at the present time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am pleased to see that you are still continuing in your columns the discussion of a subject which seems to have escaped the attention of the more sensational of the daily press. I refer to the editorials and letters which have appeared in THE TIMES regarding the actions of the New York City Board of Health.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- The financial report of the Boerse for the last week is characterized by great strength in most of the departments. The announcement of the Anglo-Japanese treaty had a favorable effect, particularly on Chinese loans, which were heavily bought on rising prices. German and Prussian 3 per cents weakened earlier, in the week, and the holders of these securities found it more profitable to sell them and invest in foreign rentes.

MANILA, Feb. 16. -- Gen. J. Franklin Bell has practically broken the insurrection in Batangas Province, the troops under his command having made a clean sweep of the district. It is not believed that all the insurgent arms have been captured or surrendered, but it is certain that a number of them have been taken to other provinces or safely hidden.

HELENA, Mont., Feb. 16. -- Harold M. Cole, formerly of New York, Assistant Superintendent at East Helena Smelter, is dead in an undertaker's establishment, and Olive Mayne Cole, his wife, is mortally wounded as the result of shots fired by the husband.

With the exception of a few clubs in Boston which have shown a commendable activity in announcing early days for big tournaments during the coming year, the Philadelphia Golf Association is the only regular organization that has thus far arranged and announced the dates of some of its most important competitions.

The general balance sheet of Manhattan -- which on Saturday put out the best quarterly statement ever published by it, showing for the period ended Dec. 31, 1901, an increase in net figures of $246,837 -- was made public yesterday. It is as of Dec. 31 and shows as follows:
The Mueller estate has sold the plot on the west side of Third Avenue, 25.11 feet north of One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, 50 by 100, now covered by old frame buildings.

Though the severity of yesterday's storm kept many brokers and their customers from business, the Stock Exchange's transactions still approximated half a million shares, and throughout the day strength prevailed. Practically all the notable price changes were advances. In this regard the market has very materially improved during the past fortnight, a result traceable largely to the fact that many conservative interests hitherto advising inactivity are now outspokenly bullish.

The snowstorm was a factor in social life yesterday. It kept numerous parties snowbound in the country, and it made it a very dull day for the impromptu entertainments which are a feature of metropolitan life. The Monday Evening Bowling Club did not have a very large attendance, and there was rather a small audience at the opera.

ALBANY, Feb. 17. -- Gov. Odell to-day made his defiance to those who have been opposing his policy with regard to the State charities. At the hearing on the Lunacy bill in the executive chamber, the Governor severely criticised the opponents of the measure for the methods which they have pursued.

Daniel Frohman has decided to present Paul Potter's new play, founded on Victor Hugo's romance of "Notre Dame," at Daly's Theatre, on Wednesday evening, Feb. 20. In presenting it then, Mr. Frohman observes the centenary of Victor Hugo's birthday, which is to be celebrated throughout Europe on that day.

There was not a great crush at the Brooklyn Bridge entrance yesterday, notwithstanding the heavy snowfall. In the first place the usual army of shoppers deferred their trip to Manhattan, awaiting more favorable weather conditions. Then large numbers of those who were bound to venture out expecting a terrific rush at the usual evening hour, sought to avoid it by taking the ferryboats.

There is a possibly castanean anecdote of a house owner and host descending a flight of newly polished stairs, "who slipped and fell half way down, and landed sprawling in the drawing room as if he had been shot out of a catapult. To sympathizing guests who rushed to his assistance he protested that he was not injured nor an object of sympathy:
Money on call, 2 1/4@3 per cent., closing at 3 per cent. Majority of the day's loans at 2 1/2 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate a message recommending the retirement of Naval Constructor Richmond P. Hobson, and in accordance with this recommendation Senator Gallinger immediately introduced a bill providing for Mr. Hobson's transfer to the retired list.

For a number of years New York has made a commendable effort to establish a reputation as a Winter resort. Those who remember the cold "Winters and deep snows of thirty or more year's ago, when the New York boy expected skating by Thanksgiving and good sledding, with exciting rides in the stage sleighs, from the first of December until the end of March, cannot resist the conclusion that our climate is growing milder.

Two matches were decided in the New York Interclub Bowling League tournament last night, the Century Wheelmen winning from the Catholic Club, and the Harlem Republican Club winning from the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

"Foxy Grandpa." the musical medley that opened last night at the Fourteenth Street Theatre, bears much the same relationship to the musical piece on Broadway which Hoyt's farces bear to the plays of the modern English school of comedy. The Broadway shows have more glamour, but the show on Fourtienth Street is homemade.

Testimony regarding William Marsh Rice's attitude toward Lawyer Albert T. Patrick was given yesterday for the first time since the lawyer was put on trial four weeks ago charged with murdering the aged Texas millionaire.

District Attorney Jerome was denounced yesterday morning before Justice Holbrook in Special Sessions by C.G.F. Wahle, counsel for Minnie Kurtz, the woman known as the "missing witness" in the Diamond and Bissert trials. Mr. Wahle appeared in court, announcing that he had received a "tip" that the case against Minnie Kurtz for keeping a disorderly house was to be called, although he had not been notified.

After being enticed into the rear of a long and dark hall Frank Gens, a jewelry peddler of the lower east side, was last night assaulted by two men who, after half blinding him with a handful of snuff, attempted to rob him.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17. -- The heavy snowstorm which began in this section at 10 o'clock last night ceased at 5 o'clock this afternoon, the fall of snow being the heaviest in three years. A high-wind accompanied the snow, but to-night the wind is rapidly diminishing. The greatest fall of snow occurred at Atlantic City, which was the centre of the storm this morning.

Florence Burns, nineteen years of age, the twenty-first of the prisoners now confined in the Tombs on the charge of homicide, is apparently the least concerned as to her fate. Albert T. Patrick and R.B. Molineux are more nervous than she. The girl did not have a visitor yesterday, and made no, complaint against the coarse prison food.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The War Revenue Reduction bill, which it was expected would be under discussion for two days, passed this afternoon without debate by unanimous vote. This outcome was due to a request proferred by the minority leader, Mr. Richardson, for unanimous consent for present consideration of the bill.

Means of relieving the traffic congestion at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge was discussed last night at a joint meeting of the Manufacturers' Association and the Committee of Fifty at the rooms of the association, 198 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 17. -- The whole market was strong and active. Cotton Duck took the lead in the point of bullish move, though United Railways were leaders in point of sales. Cotton Duck incomes were in good demand, being absorbed somewhat by insiders, and advanced 2 full points. The stock was 7/8 higher.

After early heaviness Copper Trust stock, which had sold down to 70 1/4, rallied to 71 5/8, and closed at 71 1/4, or a net gain of 5/8 on dealings in 37,000 shares. The movement in the stock, so far as could be learned, was due to nothing more than operations of professionals on the floor. One trader is credited with having covered a fairly considerable short line during the day.

The Holleben-Pauncefote controversy has driven our neighbor THE TIMES to excited investigation of newspaper files, whence it thinks it has derived evidence to confute our assertion that the "full significance" of the Spanish note of April 10, 1898, was not known to Congress. We used the word "full" advisedly, being aware of all the facts which THE TIMES now triumphantly disinters.

Seventy-six per cent. of the capitalization of the United States Steel Corporation was represented at the first annual meeting of the shareholders of that institution yesterday. The meeting was held in the small unpretentious Directors' room of the Hudson Trust Company, in Hoboken, and not more than two score persons were present, many of them being newspaper reporters.

Only on one occasion since the great blizzard of March, 1888, has this city been visited by a more severe snowstorm than was experienced yesterday. During Feb. 12, 13, and 14, 1899, there was a paralyzing storm here which smothered traffic in fifteen and a hair inches of snow. On the memorable Sunday night of March 11, 1888, and on the Monday following there was a fall of 30.9 inches of snow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- With the passage of the War Revenue Reduction bill in the House to-day informal plans are being discussed on both sides of the chamber for the consideration of the Cuban reciprocity question now pending before the Ways and Means Committee. Chairman Payne said to-night that no definite plan had yet been matured for taking up the Question either by the Republican members or by the committee as a whole.

Since the doctrine was asserted that the seals in Alaskan waters are domestic animals which our Government has the right to protect against Canadian marauders, no point of law has been stretched so far, we think, as by Representative CORLISS of Michigan, who maintains in his committee report urging Government ownership of the Pacific cable that "the right to construct and operate the Pacific cable is a public utility or franchise held by the people.

Second Lieut. William S. Martin, who was assigned Jan. 6 to temporary duty in the Military Information Division in the office of the Adjutant General, will be relieved March 25, and will then join his proper station.
According to New Orleans dispatches a syndicate with $1,000,000 capital will develop the coal mines at Tuscaloosa, Ala.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The Republican members of the House of Representatives held a third caucus to-night to consider the question of Southern elections. The attendance was not as numerous as at former gatherings. Speaker Henderson not attending, and only 86 Republicans out of a total of 199 being present.

Chinatown celebrated its New Year last night with two dinners, one given by the Chinese Merchant Association and the other by the Oriental Club. Both were well attended, and a number of prominent guests were entertained at each board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- To-day, after a little more than an hour's consideration, the Senate ratified tlie treaty with Denmark ceding to the United States for a consideration of $5,000,000 the islands of St. Thomas, St. John, and St. Croix, composing the group of the Antilles known as the Danish West Indies, and lying just east of Porto Rico.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

After two days devoted to the study of the circular issued on Friday last by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, and containing the outlines of a certain plan, of finance, Wall Street bankers and lawyers have decided that it does not contain particular information which any one financially interested in that company would be entitled to have.
MONTE CARLO, Feb. 17. -- The ninth round of the International Chess Tournament was played to-day according to Round 2 of the Berger schedule, and the men were therefore paired as follows:

The most prominent and most active issue in the outside market yesterday was Metropolitan Street Railway rights, which were first traded in on Saturday. In other parts of the list some few stocks supplied a fair amount of business, but the total in these was somewhat below the recent average. Prices were irregular, but more net gains appeared at the end of the day than declines.

The President of the United States Steel Corporation is the last person one would suppose would be an advocate of "protection" and subsidies for manufactures of steel. The spectacle of this giant corporation, full-grown, if not, indeed, overgrown, whining and puling in its nurse's arms, begging for sustenance at the expense of the public would be ludicrous if it were not revolting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Gov. Taft, in his testimony before the Senate Committee on the Philippines to-day, stated more succinctly than heretofore his theory, which is also, he said, the theory of the Philippine Commission, as to what Congress should do in the way of supplying the Philippine people with a form of government.

BAKU, Feb. 17. -- Details which are slowly reaching Baku from Shemakha, which is about seventy miles from here, show that 2,000 persons, mostly women and children, perished as a result of the earthquake last week, and that 4,000 houses were destroyed.

C.S. Norris, the champion of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, defeated W.H. Sigourney, the Pacific Coast champion, in the deciding game of the Amateur Athletic Union Class A, 14.2 billiard tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club last night, and, therefore, won the right to challenge Wilson P. Foss, the holder of the trophy emblematic of the billiard championship of the United States.

BOSTON, Feb. 17. -- In his third lecture at Harvard this afternoon M. Hugues Le Roux discussed Daudet, devoting himself in great part to life in Southern France. "The Northern man, the Englishman, and the Scandinavian," he said, "works so hard during the day that he is physically exhausted at night, and he prefers to sit down speechless at the fireside.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Dr. Hill, for the President's delegates, to-day made public the general programme and itinerary of the visit of Prince Henry of Prussia, covering the period of time from Feb. 22 to March 11. From time to time publication has been made of parts of the itinerary, but there has been more or less change in the original programme, and new features have been added.

LONDON, Feb. 17. -- Money was scarce and in brisk demand to-day. Rates were firm, Apart from considerable repayments due to the Bank of England this week, calls, amounting to millions, on recent new issues of stock, must be met. On the other hand, the release of over four millions in dividends, together with half a million received from India, will relieve the market, Discounts were quiet.

Puccini's lyric version of Sardou's "Tosca" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The effects of the weather were seen in the number of unoccupied seats in the auditorium, but not in the performance, which moved with spirit and earnestness. Repeated hearings of the opera do not change the convictions which were reached after its first performance here, but they do serve to bring out more clearly the excellences of the score.

For the woman who likes an all-black gown, one of the most serviceable for warm weather and for many other purposes as well is a silk called a tourist foulard, made by one of the most reliable of silk manufacturers. It has a glace surface, is very light, but strong and durable, and is made up by many women into traveling frocks.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- A futile attempt was made in the House of Lords yesterday to obtain an earnest hearing for a bill abolishing the "conscientious objector" clause in the vaccination law, but, even with a grave smallpox epidemic threatened, the Government is determined not to retreat from its present position, intimating that the foolish clause will be abolished when the time-limit expires next year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 17. -- Snow has been falling here since 1 o'clock last night. The storm has been accompanied by a variable north wind, fitful in force, but of sufficient strength to give the disturbance the aspect of a blizzard. To-night the wind has shifted into the northwest, whence it blows steadily with biting force.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 17. -- Mr. Isham was born in Bennington, Vt., Jan. 15, 1836. His father, Pierpont Isham, was a Justice of the Supreme Court of Vermont. He completed his college preparation at Lawrence Academy, Groton, and then entered Williams College, where he was graduated in 1857.

As a preliminary to their game with Yale on Friday night in the Columbia gymnasium, Columbia's basketball team will play the Fourteenth Separate Company at Kingston to-night. The team has a considerable list of cripples. Tyler in practice yesterday strained his ankle so badly that he cannot play.

The advance in National Biscuit common stock yesterday, seldom traded in on the Exchange, was on buying by Western houses, apparently in connection with the showing made by the company in its annual report for the year ended Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- The minority report on the Pacific Cable bill, filed today, dissents from the view that the Government should build the cable, and states that a private organization, the Commercial Pacific Cable Company, already has contracted for a cable to Hawaii, to be completed by Nov. 1 next, intending to extend the line to the Philippines within two years thereafter.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18. -- The chestnut horse The Huguenot, brother to the sensational Henry of Navarre, now in the stud at the Nursery Stud of August Belmont, will again race. His owner, the noted Eastern trainer. "Jimmy" Rowe, has ordered him shipped from the McGrathiana Stud, where he has been quartered since his three-year-old form.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- The Executive Chamber was crowded to-day by members of the Legislature and the general public, anxious to hear Col. Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn testify in the case of Sheriff Guden of Kings County. Col. Dady's denial of the charge that he had made any agreement with Sheriff Guden by which he was to receive from Guden all of the earnings of the Sheriff's office above $12,000 a year was positive.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Gov. Odell filed a memorandum with the bill, passed by both houses of the Assembly, substituting control by a State Board on Lunacy for the former management of asylums for the insane by local managing boards and signed by him to-day. Gov. Odell makes a long defense of the change. This, in part, is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The speech of Mr. Wheeler of Kentucky in the House last Friday, when he bitterly assailed Secretary Hay and Lord Pauncefote, and criticised the official preparations for the reception of Prince Henry, had a sequel in the House to-day during the debate on the Indian Appropriation bill.

Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage has accepted the Presidency of the United States Trust Company of 45 Wall Street, this city, and will assume the duties of the office about the 1st of April. He succeeds John A. Stewart, who has been connected with the company since its organization in 1853.

Mayor Low attended at the rooms of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday a meeting of the full committee appointed by him to receive Prince Henry of Prussia. He listened to reports from each of the sub-committees. From the Finance Committee he received a statement of its progress in raising a large guarantee expense fund.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 18. -- The Canadian interests in the Dominion Iron and Steel Company and the Dominion Coal Company in Cape Breton have been able to force an exposure of the plans of the H. M. Whitney interest in those companies and to prevent the threatened "Americanization" of the enterprises.

Madison Square Garden will be thoroughly alive with dogs to-day, for the largest number of canines ever received as entries for a show of the Westminster Kennel Club has been received for the present bench exhibit. The Garden presented a busy sight all day yesterday, for the long rows of benches were being placed in position, and many of the prospective prize-winners were put in their places.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Democratic leaders in the House put small reliance in the profession Mr. Babcock of Wisconsin makes that he is a tariff reformer. They do not believe he is any more a tariff reformer than is Chairman Payne of the Ways and Means Committee, or Mr. Dalzell of Pennsylvania, or Gen. Grosvenor of Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The decision of President Roosevelt on Rear Admiral Schley's appeal from the majority opinion of the court of inquiry is to be published in the newspapers on Thursday morning, and is said to contain about 2,300 words.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Just what will happen to the War Revenue Reduction bill passed by the House yesterday and sent to the Senate to-day, nobody can state with any degree of certainty. There are at least two opinions about the bill among the Senators likely to have something to say as to the form it will ultimately assume.

It is, of course, understood that the Democratic Party, as represented by its National Convention, now nearly two years in the past, is committed to the repeal of war taxes. That fact explains, though it does not justify, the unanimous vote in the House of Representatives for the Republican repeal bill.

The ratification by the Senate of the treaty buying the Danish Islands without a division, and virtually without debate, must be gratifying to the State Department, which negotiated the treaty. Senator BACOX, while reserving the "ex proprio vigore" point, upon which the Supreme Court has already had the misfortune to differ from him and his party, patriotically explained the reason of the unanimity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The important document entitled "Review of the Foreign Commerce of the United States in 1901," showing the progress which this country made during the last year in the great race for supremacy in trade in the world's markets, has just been made public.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 18. -- Owing to the snow on the ice, the skating races on the North Shrewsbury were not held this afternoon. The races have been postponed indefinitely. It is likely, however, should conditions be favorable, that they will take place on Washington's Birthday.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 18. -- Owing to the recent advance in spot cotton the mills of North Carolina will be compelled to close unless there is a corresponding rise in cotton yarns. Dr. James A. McAden, than whom there is no bigger mill owner in the South, to-day said:

Winthrop Rutherfurd and Miss Alice Morton, the fourth daughter of ex-Gov. and Mrs. Levi P. Morton, were married yesterday at noon in Grace Church. The wedding was extremely simple. As it was Lent, there were no floral decorations, except two large bunches of lilies on the altar. Neither were there bridesmaids nor maid of honor, and the invitations to the church were limited to intimate friends and relatives.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 18. -- Gov. Odell today conferred with the Republican Senators and the Republican Assemblymen who are Chairmen of committees upon pending legislation. Lieut. Gov. Woodruff and Speaker Nixon also attended the conference. Frank Platt was in the city, but he was not invited to be present.

From early morning until late last night the merry jingle of sleigh bells was heard throughout the city. They began to tinkle at daylight, when the milkmen and bakers made their rounds in clumsy rigs, and died away about midnight, as the last jolly party, muffled in furs, sped down Seventh Avenue, and through the moonlit Park.

The ratification by the Senate of the treaty buying the Danish Islands without a division, and virtually without debate, must be gratifying to the State Department, which negotiated the treaty. Senator BACOX, while reserving the "ex proprio vigore" point, upon which the Supreme Court has already had the misfortune to differ from him and his party, patriotically explained the reason of the unanimity.

Neither the eloquence of Mr. COCKRAN nor the sincerity of Mr. SHEPARD can put living efficacy into the sterile and forsaken doctrines they preached to an unheeding party upon the occasion of the Tilden dinner. Demoralized and broken, without leaders, without issues, without policies, its character destroyed and the confidence of the people forfeited, the Democratic Party's desperate condition reveals a need which these gentlemen either do not realize or are incompetent to meet.

ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Assemblyman Uhlmann went before the Assembly Committee on Cities this afternoon and submitted a substitute for the Three-Platoon Police bill, which he introduced last week. The substitute was accepted by the committee and put in the same place as the original bill. Mr. Uhlmann's new bill was drawn to meet the objections which were urged against the original measure.

Ex-Deputy Commissioner of Police William S. Devery and one John J. Byrne, who is said to be related to Devery, attended the auction sale of properties belonging to the estate of Josephine L. Peyton in the New York Real Estate Salesroom yesterday afternoon, and before they left Byrne had been the successful bidder for twelve parcels, the prices of which amounted to $377,800.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 18. -- Albert Crane of Strawberry Hill, a reputed millionaire and well Known in New York, where he has been an attorney at law, and Miss Fanny Starkey, daughter of the late George Lyman Starkey of Boston, were married in Boston on Feb. 10 by the Rev. Samuel E. Herrick of the Mount Vernon Church.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The "Rev. Tsilka," who, according to the Constantinople correspondent of the Paris Temps, has been arrested on the charge of complicity in the kidnapping of Miss Stone, is the husband of Mme. Tsilka, Miss Stone's companion.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 18. -- The Canadian interests in the Dominion Iron and Steel Company and the Dominion Coal Company in Cape Breton have been able to force an exposure of the plans of the H. M. Whitney interest in those companies and to prevent the threatened "Americanization" of the enterprises.

That fact explains, though it does not justify, the unanimous vote in the House of Representatives for the Republican repeal bill.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Rear Admiral Schley to-day was refused the courtesy of an introduction to the State Senate. He was introduced in the Assembly by Speaker Nixon and was received with applause. He expressed his appreciation of the honor done him in a few formal words.

The championship hockey match between the St. Nicholas Skating Club and the Hockey Club of New York, which was played last evening at the St. Nicholas Rink, resulted in a victory for the latter by a score of 6 goals to 0. This result was due as much to the excellent work of Ellison in goal as to the efforts of the forward line of the Hockey Club team.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 18. -- When the players taking part in the international chess tournament assembled at the Casino this morning it was announced that Round No. 21 of the Berger system would guide the pairing for the tenth round of the contest, scheduled for to-day. The contestants, therefore, faced each other in the following order:

The belated house parties in the country are beginning to come into town, but those who were snowbound were quite late in arriving. The only very notable occurrence in society was the wedding of Miss Alice Morton and Winthrop Rutherfurd, described elsewhere. This afternoon there will be a meeting of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club.
ALBANY, Feb. 18. -- Senator Raines to- day introduced an amendment to the hotel provision of the liquor tax law, commonly known as the Raines law. Regarding it he gave out the following statement:

Bids for $3,000,000 worth of 3 1/2 per cent, corporate stock of the City of New York were opened and read yesterday in the Controller's office. It was the first bond sale under the new administration, and attracted a larger number of persons than usual.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama, in referring to-day to Mr. Carnegie's letter, which speaks of the Senator's eager pursuit of the Nicaragua Canal route, said that he had never talked with Mr. Carnegie about his reasons for favoring Nicaragua. If he had, he said, Mr. Carnegie would have learned that his purpose was to get the best possible route.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18. -- Admiral Count von Baudissin, commander of the Hobenzollern, who is in this city as the guest of Lawrence Johnson, was the guest of honor at an informal luncheon this afternoon at the University Club. This evening a reception was given in his honor by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Johnson at their home.

Mayor Low yesterday appointed a commission to draft an ordinance dealing with the use and care of explosives within the City limits. The following is the personnel of the commission as announced by the Mayor:

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 18. -- Hartford lawyers are up in arms over the appointment of Judge James P. Platt of Meriden by President Roosevelt for the vacant United States Court Judgeship. The Hartford bar has consistently backed Judge Hungerford of New Britain and Judge Case of Hartford.

The Garden presented a busy sight all day yesterday, for the long rows of benches were being placed in position, and many of the prospective prize-winners were put in their places.

His owner, the noted Eastern trainer. "Jimmy" Rowe, has ordered him shipped from the McGrathiana Stud, where he has been quartered since his three-year-old form.

If he had, he said, Mr. Carnegie would have learned that his purpose was to get the best possible route.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 18. -- Owing to the snow on the ice, the skating races on the North Shrewsbury were not held this afternoon. The races have been postponed indefinitely. It is likely, however, should conditions be favorable, that they will take place on Washington's Birthday.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Feb. 18. -- The Kellogg; or Seventh Day Adventist, Sanitarium here was destroyed by fire early to-day, and the property loss is estimated at from $300,000 to $400,000, on which there is an insurance of $148,500.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The speech of Mr. Wheeler of Kentucky in the House last Friday, when he bitterly assailed Secretary Hay and Lord Pauncefote, and criticised the official preparations for the reception of Prince Henry, had a sequel in the House to-day during the debate on the Indian Appropriation bill.

Bids for $3,000,000 worth of 3 1/2 per cent, corporate stock of the City of New York were opened and read yesterday in the Controller's office. It was the first bond sale under the new administration, and attracted a larger number of persons than usual.

OTTAWA, Feb. 19 -- The attitude of Great Britain toward Canada in connection with a number of questions affecting Canada and the United States was severely criticised in the House to-day. The discussion arose on a motion of Henri Bourassa, for the production of the correspondence regarding the Alaskan boundary and the Clayton-Bulwer treaty.

ALBANY, Feb. 10 -- The Stranahan Mort- gage Tax bill and the Krum Corporation Tax bill are dead. The Mortgage Tax bill received its death blow this afternoon at the Republican conference held in the Executive chambers, with Gov. Odell presiding. In view of its distinguished parentage, the Mortgage Tax bill is to be interred with a show of honors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- What is voted one of the most interesting speeches delivered in the House this session was made to-day by Mr. Hamilton (Republican) of Michigan upon the subject of trusts. He argued that combinations were inevitable; that they existed everywhere in Europe, and that only combinations here could meet them.

The International Woman Suffrage Conference at Washington has undoubtedly stimulated interest in the movement in this country. That it has increased the strength of the movement would be as yet a rash opinion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The President's delegates charged with the arrangements for the reception and entertainment of Prince Henry of Prussia held a final meeting at the State Department to-day and disposed of several details that were not included in the official programme issued a few days ago.

Those are shrewd questions which the Secretary of the Treasury has been putting to every individual signer of the women's protest against the inquisition into the baggage of passengers at this port. The questions are admirably framed in order to get at the facts. It is possible that some of them may give to some signers some of the pain which they have suffered at the hands of the Inspectors.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 -- The actions of a party of twelve Princeton freshmen who last night painted a number of residences in Trenton and defaced the memorial column in that city are looked upon with the utmost displeasure by the upper-class men, and a great deal of just condemnation has been heaped on the heads of the guilty ones.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Capt. James W. Palmer, seventy years of age, of the Cove Road, broke through the ice on the pond near the Stamford Manufacturing Company's Works this afternoon, and but for the timely and effectual aid of Joseph Paight and other men at the mills who witnessed the accident, he would probably not have come out alive.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- At the conclusion of routine business Mr. Burrows (Rep., Mich.,) addressed the Senate upon the Philippine Tariff bill. He said that it was not his purpose to discuss fully the Philippine question, but to show simply how the United States was in the Philippines, and why it should remain there.

The first regular meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Civic Federation, known as the Arbitration Committee of Thirty-six, was held in the Mission Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, yesterday forenoon.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 19 -- The News to- day says: Negotiations which have been pending for some time involving the sale of the Denver City Tramway Company to the Morgan-Ryan-Wldener-Elkins syndicate of Eastern investors, for $8,500,000, are said to have been completed practically.

A meeting of the Stewards of the Jockey Club was held yesterday at 571 Fifth Avenue. August Belmont, F.K. Hitchcock, H. K. Knapp, Andrew Miller, and F.K. Sturgls being present. The following racing officials were appointed: Starter -- C.J. Fitz Gerald; Judges -- Clarence McDowell and C. H. Pettingill; Clerk of Scales -- H.G. Crickmore; Handicapper and Forfeit Clerk -- W. S. Vosburgh; Timer -- W.H. Barretto; Paddock and Patrol Judge -- J.L. Hall.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The Senate Committee on Judiciary to-day listened to arguments upon the bill introduced by Senator Cocks to enable the Montauk tribe of Indians (so called) in the name of their chief to maintain action in the courts of the State to establish and protect their rights in real and personal property.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 -- The preliminary agreement which is announced between Yale and Harvard and the definite prospect of later and more careful study of Yale-Harvard relations is a most satisfactory piece of news to Yale men. Baseball, track, and crew meets are now assured for the coming Spring, and football for next Fall, at least.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 19 -- The strength in United Railways stock and income bonds at the saime time that Consolidated Gas, as well as the electric light company's issues were higher, has revived the rumors about some pending deal. The Stret hears it reported that the United Railways is to part with its controlling interest in the electric light company, and that the latter, together with Consolidated Gas, will pass into other hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee consulted for more than two hours today about the Cuban relief question. When the consultation was over for the day, nothing had been settled with reference to the form in which the proposed relief should be granted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- After England, Germany is the most formidable competitor of the United States in the iron markets of the world, according to a report of United States Consular Agent Harris at Eibenstock, dated Jan. 25, which was made public at the State Department today.

Efforts to equalize the salaries of Associate City Superintendents of Schools at $6,000 and District Superintendents at $5,000 caused lively discussion at the adjourned meeting of the Board of Education yesterday afternoon, but final action on the matter was deferred. Ex-President Miles M. O'Brien called upon Superintendent Maxwell to explain the reason for the change and how much it would cost the taxpayers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In August, 1900, I pointed out the danger of promiscuous expectoration in public places, which you have kindly published, and which has been followed by other writers until the former Commissioner of Health, Mr. Sexton, gave orders for the enforcement of the anti-expectoration law.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- M. Hugues Le Roux confessed to his audience in Sanders Theatre at Harvard this afternoon that he was not at ease in speaking of M. de Maupassant to an American audience, because in him was to be found a particular and peculiar disposition to conceive life that was not only French, but also "Gaulois."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- President Roosevelt has decided that Rear Admiral Schley was not in command of the American fleet at the battle of Santiago. In his decision on the Schley appeal, published to-day, he says Sampson's blockade, foresight, and directions made possible the victory, but declares that the question of which was in command is merely of nominal character.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 -- Official announcement was made by the Bankers' Committee of the Everett-Moore syndicate to-day concerning the sale of the Canton-Akron and Canton-Massillon Urban and Inter-Urban Traction lines. The deal has been closed formally, and the properties will be transferred to Tucker, Anthony Co. of Boston, within a few days.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 19 -- The attempt made by E.C. Benedict, the New York banker, to obtain a permanent injunction restraining his daughter-in-law, Mrs. F. H. Benedict, as administratrix from disposing of the assets of her late husband's estate, ended in failure to-day, so far, at least, as the Surrogate's Court is concerned.

Wilson P. Foss of Haverstraw won for the third time the National Amateur billiard championship at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club last night, thereby coming into permanent possession of the $1,000 trophy, emblematic of the leading amateur billiard honors in America. His opponent was Charles S. Norris, who became his challenger by winning the Class A 14.2 tournament at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

The Advisory Committee of the Greater New York Democracy held yesterday the first regular meeting since its reorganization. All the members were present, except President Cantor of the Borough of Manhattan. A set of resolutions were introduced by Matthew P. Breen, of which the following are extracts:
According to London cables, the applications for shares in the Imperial Tobacco Company were much in excess of the amount offered.

MADRID, Feb. 20 -- The newspapers here comment on the situation at Barcelona in a tone of suppressed anxiety. While confessing that the warnings have been frequent and persistent for several years past, they say that hitherto the lack of funds and organization have compelled the trades unions to yield, especially as the employers, enriched by protection, were willing to grant the concessions suggested by the authorities to avert greater difficulties.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Senator Humphrey has introduced a bill to extend the provisions of the General Banking law to the Manhattan Company of New York City. The Manhattan Company operates under a charter which was obtained in 1799 by Aaron Burr. The charter was to enable the company to construct a reservoir, sell water, and do other business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much has been said and written about the water supply of this city, and with your permission I would be pleased to add my mite. There is no subject that is as interesting to the writer as that of "water supplies," and consequently I have made it a special study for the past fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The annual banquet of the Department of the Potomac, Commandery of the Grand Army of the Republic, was held at the New Willard Hotel to-night. President Roosevelt, Secretary Wilson, and Gen. Torrence, Commander in Chief of the Grand Army, were among the guests.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- A resumption of the advance movement in Consolidated Lake Superior issues and heaviness of Union Traction were the chief points of interest in the Philadelphia market. The reported disagreement among the political powers allied with the Union Traction merger had a depressing influence on the stock of that corporation, the price at one time declining 3/4.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "P.S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3.000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.

The stock market is listless. On every side more and more crowds the theory that the market's future depends largely upon what may be the action of the United States Supreme Court in the Northern Securities case. With a decision scheduled in Wall Street expectation for Monday next, there is much calculation, as to what can be the market effect of a judgment that the case is not properly before the court.

A match in the Athletic Bowling League tournament was decided on the New York Athletic Club alleys last night between the teams of the home club and the Knicker-bocker Athletic Club, and resulted in a victory for the home team, which won all three games, the first by a single pin. The scores:

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 19 -- No regular round was played in the International Chess Masters' Tournament here to-day, but adjourned and drawn games from previous rounds were concluded and replayed, respectively. There was one adjourned game, between Tschigorin and Marooczy, and there were drawn games between Teichmann and Pillsbury, Albin and Tarrasch, and Eisenberg and Mieses.

-- A correspondent who writes to us from Sidney, this State, over the signature, "A Friend of Both Parties " -- meaning, as we gather from his letter, that he likes both THE TIMES and the Society of Psychical Research -- seems to be much grieved because a recent reference in this column to the society's annual meeting lacked seriousness and respect.

Valet Charles F. Jones, still cool and collected, continued yesterday on the witness stand his recital of the details of the formation and execution of what the State contends was the conspiracy between himself and Albert T. Patrick, now on trial, to gain possession by forgery and murder of the millions of William Marsh Rice. Patrick, charged with being the master mind in the plot, sat nervously tugging at his blonde beard as Jones testified.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- There were several important developments with regard to canal legislation to-day. It was decided that the Canal bill should not be taken up for discussion in the Republican conference, as it was desirable in the interest of canal improvement that no impression should be given out that Republicans looked upon the pending bill as a party measure.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 -- Money is in abundant supply, and the demand still light, with rates very easy. The slightly firmer tone for exchange in that it suggests the possibility of gold shipments has created a little questioning, but not enough to make itself felt on the general market temper. The best opinion is that the present comfortable conditions will continue for some time to come.

District Attorney Jerome yesterday morning, in the case of Florence Burns, held under the charge of having murdered Walter S. Brooks, violated all precedent in criminal procedure, amazed Magistrate Cornell, before whom the hearing was held, and at the same time earned the approval of the Magistrate and received the thanks of the counsel for the defense.

Discussion of labor matters occupied a large part of the second day of the sixteenth annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Charles H. Taylor of Boston presided in place of President S.H. Kauffmann of Washington, who was confined to his room by a cold.

Prince Henry of Prussia is to be protected from the public view by unprecedented precautions. Such efforts as will be made to prevent crowds from congregating in his immediate vicinity are a novelty in this country and city, and it is at the request of the German Ambassador in Washington, Dr. von Holleben, who paid his first visit to the Hohenzollern late yesterday, that the undue vigilance is to be manifested.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In a Consular report on the passenger traffic between Europe and the United States Frank H. Mason, the United States Consul General at Berlin, says in part:

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- The hearing before the Assembly Committee on Railroads today upon the Wainwright bill affecting the New York Central tunnel disclosed a square issue between the advocates of the bill and the counsel of the New York Central Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Another echo of Mr. Wheeler's anti-royalty speech was heard in the House to-day. While the Indian Appropriation bill was under consideration Representative Bromwell (Rep., Ohio,) secured the floor to reply to Mr. Wheeler's remarks. Mr. Bromwell represents one of the Cincinnati districts and a large German constituency.

Rapid progress was made in the indoor championship lawn tennis tournament of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association in the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon. The preliminary and the first rounds were completed, and one match played in the second round. Today play will be begun in the doubles and continued in the singles, and it is expected that the finals in both series will be reached on Saturday.

Brooklyn politicians discussed with much interest last night a story which came from Albany yesterday to the effect that Col. Michael J. Dady, the "deputy Republican leader" of Kings County, while at the capital on Tuesday, had expressed a determination to retire from politics. According to the Albany story, Col. Dady had decided to resign as executive member from the First Assembly District and also as Commissioner of Elections.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- There was to have been a hearing this afternoon before the Senate Committee on Judiciary on the bill introduced by Senator Raines which amends the election law by the insertion of a provision that the names and addresses of all signers of independent petitions shall be printed in two newspapers of the county within ten days after the last day for filing independent certificates of nomination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you permit a word of criticism of "Manru" from one who loves music without pretending to be a connoisseur? Modern grand opera is one of the finest flowers of civilization. It should combine the most beautiful music with a fine melodrama or tragedy; and it is only when the drama that unfolds itself to our delighted senses is noble and soul-stirring that the opera lives.

Chinatown in short silk overcoats, lined with rabbit's fur, gathered yesterday in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, many of the celestials having been subpoenaed there to testify in the case of Mock Duck, charged with participation in the killing of Ah Fee, who was persona non grata to the Highbinders and a Mason of high degree in the organization opposed to them.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The tightness of money was not relieves to-day. Considerable amounts in loans due to the Bank of England have been renewed daily. Relief is doubtful until the turn of the financial year. Consequently discounts, were disposed to harden. Business on the Stock Exchange opened irregular and inanimate.

Carnegie Hall rang last night with the cheers of fifteen hundred men and women, belonging to all classes and representing all parties, who had gathered to voice their protest against any further delay in granting reciprocity to Cuba and to emphasize their demand that the efforts of the President and of the Secretary of War to save Cuba from ruin be supported by Congress.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 4 -- The predictions that the present social season here would prove the gayest in years seems to have been correct. The second Court ball was given to-night. It is described as being even more splendid than the opening ball. The great palms of the Winter Palace palm house were removed to the supper room, and the tables were built around them.

Conferences have begun among the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee preparatory to reporting a bill lowering the duties on the products of Cuba. Where men honestly desire to do what justice and duty demand the way can be found with small loss of time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Responding to an inquiry from Senator Lodge, the Secretary of War to-day sent to him a large number of papers bearing upon the charge that cruelty is practiced by the American troops on the natives of the Philippines. Senator Lodge presented the documents in the Senate.

Though entirely respectful in tone, the warning of the United States to the Governments of China and Russia, in regard to exclusive rights and privileges in the Chinese Empire, is very clear and firm.

The sixteenth annual dinner of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association took place at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. It followed the business meeting in the afternoon, and many ladies graced the occasion with their presence. Every portion of the Astor Gallery and Myrtle Room was occupied.

President Swanstrom of the Borough of Brooklyn sent a letter yesterday to the Rapid Transit Commissioners urging a change in the plans for the extension of the tunnel to Brooklyn under the East River. He claims that the two-track tunnel would be dangerous, and in addition would not accommodate enough passengers to relieve the congestion of traffic at the New York end of the bridge.
Capt. Thaddeus P. Varney, Paymaster, having reported his arrival at San Francisco, will proceed to San Antonio for duty.

Through the efforts of the Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York York the co-operation of all the local organizations of riders and drivers toward the betterment of the highways has been secured, and the attainment of the reforms for which the Associated Cycling Clubs have been working for the past five or six years now seems likely to be secured.
Following is the text of the Sherman antitrust law of 1890 under which Attor- ney General Knox is to institute his test. The sections cited cover all the essential provisions of the law:

Wall Street experienced a startling surprise yesterday. The instruction of President Roosevelt to Attorney General Knox to begin proceedings looking to a dissolution of the Northern Securities Company was not anticipated.
