It was expected that the Supreme Court would render a decision on the case now pending before that body on Monday and no other action in the matter was looked for before then.

ROME, Feb. 20 -- King Victor Emmanuel opened Parliament to-day with considerable ceremonial. Queen Helena accompanied him. In the speech from the throne the King referred to the tranquilizing effect on the country of the Government's liberal policy and to the excellent relations existing between Italy and all the powers.
MADRID, Feb. 20 -- Premier Sagasta is preparing a decree establishing martial law throughout Spain. The signing of the decree, it is believed, will be followed by an extreme national crisis.

About 200 residents of the Borough of Richmond, headed by Gugy A.E. Irving, President of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, held a long conference with Dock Commissioner Hawkes at his office, at Pier A, yesterday morning, in regard to the service of the Staten Island Rapid transit Company, which has given rise to much bitter complaint.

BOSTON, Feb. 20 -- The money situation is still unchanged. Demand either for continuous or speculative purchases is ex- tremely light. Rates are easy, and in many cases nominal. Indeed, money is being freely offered by outside lenders, and borrowers are getting concessions on the going bank rates.

With unerring judgment President ROOSEVELT puts his finger upon the origin and provoking cause of the Schley-Sampson controversy; and earnestly desiring to put an end to the dispute he has dealt the enemies of SCHLEY a blow calculated to fill them with rage and bitterness which not all of them will be able to dissemble.

The Hotel Bayard property, at the southwest corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, has been sold, through Bullowa Bullowa, as attorneys, to W.H.P. Oliver of Morristown, N.J., for about $300,000. The plot has frontages of 75.10 feet on Broadway, and 101.3 feet on the street. It is understood that the new owner will erect an apartment hotel on the site.
PEKING, Feb. 19 -- Mr. John Hay, the American Secretary of State, has sent the following note to the Russian and Chinese Governments:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- The new steamship Kroonland was launched at Cramps' Shipyard this afternoon. The tallow on the ways had frozen, and the Kroonland stuck to such an extent that it was necessary to use powerful hydraulic jacks in order to slide her into the water. The launching of the Kroonland was of an informal character.

Fire which started in the repair shops and car yards of the Fifth Avenue elevated division of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, at Thirty-sixth Street on the west side of the avenue, shortly after 11 o'clock last night, brilliantly illuminated the waterfront close by, destroyed much valuable property, including ten of the elevated cars, many of them equipped with costly motors, and the great switch tower rising forty feet above the structure.

Not so long ago it was announced that Clyde Fitch was engaged in writing a new play, in which Charles Frohman had arranged to present Ethel Barrymore next season. The publication here that the play in question is not an original one, but an adaptation of Alfred Capus's "La Petite Fonctionnaire," will surprise a good many persons, including the playwright, for the exact nature of the work has been a guarded secret.
The sixteenth annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association was continued at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday. Among many resolutions unanimously adopted was the following:

ALBANY, Feb. 20 -- The Automobile bill went through the Senate to-day with the speed of a "White Ghost" When the opponents of the bill recovered their wits sufficiently to take in what had passed they became as indignant as a crowd on a North Hempstead highway after narrowly escaping being mowed down by one of the electric fliers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Gov. Taft continued to discuss the climatic conditions in the Philippines to-day before the Senate Philippine Commission. Reverting to what he had said yesterday concerning the health of the American troops in the Philippines, Gov. Taft said that much of the sickness which does exist is due to exposure, and incidentally he made an appeal for liberal appropriations for the construction of barracks, and for the protection of officers and men.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- During the debate in the House to-day on the Indian Appropriation bill, Mr. Smith, the Delegate from Arizona, moved to strike put the appropriation for the Carlisle Indian School. He declared that experience showed these schools, distant from the Indian reservations, had done more harm than good.
The most striking feature of the "Arbitration Committee of the National Civic Federation," which met in this city on Wednesday, is the complete "recognition" it secures for organized labor.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20 -- Two entirely different suits were heard at once by Vice Chancellor Pitney in the Chancery Court here to-day. One action involves $1,155,000 and the other $800,000. The law points were exactly similar in each case, so the Vice Chancellor directed that both go on at once.

The North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm, on board of which Prince Henry is coming to America, will, if the expectations of the American management of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company are realized, steam past the Sandy Hook Lightship between 8 and 9 o'clock to-morrow morning.

ROME, Feb. 20 -- The Pope to-day entered on the twenty-fifth year of his Pontificate. Although the main celebration of the Jubilee is postponed until March 3, when the anniversaries of his Holiness's birth and coronation will be observed, to-day was marked by the singing of a Te Deum in St. Peter's and other observances.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- It is reported to-night on what seems to be good authority, that the Republicans of the Ways and Means Committee are falling into line with the Administration in their views as to the Cuban tariff question. According to the report Mr. Payne of New York, Chairman of the committee, has decided that there must be a reduction in the tariff rates on Cuban products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Senator Bacon to-day gave notice of his intention to offer an amendment to the Philippine Tariff bill, declaring it to be the intention of the United States, when order shall be restored in the Philippine Islands, to allow the formation of a government for and by the Philippine people, and to guarantee to them the same degree of liberty and independence that this country has pledged to the Cuban people.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- Arrangements for the reception of Prince Henry here have been practically completed, and were outlined to-day by Mayor Ashbridge when he named a committee of twenty-four prominent citizens to entertain the Prince. The committee includes Col. A. Loudon Snowden, Chairman: Henry Tatnall, John Cadwalader, John H. Converse, A.J. Cassatt, George F. Baer, Senator Penrose, Charles H. Cramp, Theodore C. Search, and Clement A. Griscom.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 -- The opinion of Attorney General Knox regarding the legality of the merger of Western railroads was felt here as it was in New York, most of the slump, however, being in the arbitrage stocks. The Readings were freely offered, the common falling from 29 1-16 to 28 1-16, and the second preferred from 34 3/4 to 33 1/2.

Florence Burns, who is held in the Tombs for the murder of Walter S. Brooks, arose at 6 o'clock yesterday morning after sleeping soundly for eight hours. Her parents visited her during the day and brought her a bundle of clothing and magazines.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 20 -- Announcement was officially made to-day of the organization here of the Southern Trust and Banking Company, a million-dollar corporation. Many prominent capitalists of the city are represented. The plans of the corporation include the erection of a twelve-story building on Carondalet Street.

Yesterday's session of the outside market was the most active in many weeks. The unexpected announcement of the Government's intended action in regard to the Northern Securities matter resulted in very heavy trading in that stock at declining prices, and this activity was shared by a number of other stocks.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 -- A party of St. Louis business men will leave here next Saturday to visit the Legislatures of New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, and Massachusetts to explain the plans and purpoes of the coming Louisiana Purchase Exposition. The party will be headed by ex-Gov. David R. Francis, President of the exposition; Gov. A.M. Dockery of Missouri, Mayor Rolla Wells of St. Louis, ex-Mayor C.P. Walbridge.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20 -- The local market was affected comparatively little by the break in New York. The reduction in the volume of business was the chief ill effect felt. This reduction checked the recently started advances. Cotton Duck issues were higher. The incomes reached 50 and closed with a net gain of 3/8.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and in under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3,000.
The will of Marcellus Hartley, which was executed on March 23, 1881, was filed yesterday for probate in the office of the Surrogate. The will reads:

For forty-eight hours after the mysterious death of James McAuliffe on Sunday evening last in Roosevelt Hospital the police of the West Forty-seventh Street Station concealed the fact that the man had been a prisoner in that station during all the night previous to the time he was found dying on the sidewalk near Sixth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 20 -- James J. Hill was taken ill to-night and is confined to his bed. It was announced that his indisposition is nothing more than a severe cold. This afternoon Mr. Hill refused to submit to an interview, but in a conversation he expressed himself as being surprised at the action of the President and Attorney General Knox.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 20 -- Speaking of President Roosevelt's action in directing Attorney General Knox to investigate the merging of railways, John S. Miller, a prominent attorney, said: "The litigation has got to take place some time, so long as there is serious question about the validity of an organization of that nature, and it would better come before a lot of innocent investors become interested.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- At a general meeting of the Marconi Company yesterday, Signor Marconi, referring to the transatlantic experiments, announced that the next series of tests would include the transmission of words and messages. He added that there was nothing to prevent the company from undertaking commercial communication with ships at sea.

Albert E. Whyland, for many years a partner in the now dissolved grocery firm of Thurber, Whyland Co., died at his home, 629 West One Hundred and Forty-second Street, yesterday, from heart disease, after an illness lasting four days. Since the firm went out of business he had been living a retired life.

The paintings belonging to the estate of James M. Hart, the landscape and cattle painter, which include pictures by himself and those which he collected, came under the auctioner's hammer last night at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries. Although there had gathered an unusually large assemblage, of prospective buyers, many of the pictures went at prices much below their real value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- After conferences between State Department officials and members of the Senate and House of Representatives arrangements have been completed for the reception of Prince Henry when he comes, to the Capitol next Monday afternoon.

LONDON, Feb., 20 -- The condition of the money market here was practically unchanged to-day, except that discounts were a shade harder. Most sections of the Stock Exchange were quiet, the degression in Americans monopolizing attention. Heavy selling began early, both for local and New York account, on the opinioin of Attorney General Knox in regard to the merger of the Northern Pacific and Great Northern Railways, through the medium of the Northern Securities Company.

MISS WARD has lately trans lated from the French of Georges Berlin a historical sketch ot Mme. de Lamballe, the materials for which were largely drawn from unpublished documents and articles found in the newspapers of the end of the eighteenth century.

LONDON Feb. 21 -- Henry Savage Landor's new book is receiving splendid advertising this week through his letter from "Darkest Asia" announcing his recent illness and his discoveries near the Persian-Afghan frontier, the news of which has been widely circulated.

READERS will find printed below lists of the contents of the principal American magazines for March. The lists are restricted to periodicals which appear once a month, and, while the contents are not absolutely complete, the omissions relate mainly to regular and familiar departments and some of the minor contributions.

The Princeton freshmen who defaced the battle monument at Five Points by painting "05" on it in red, doubtless thought they were doing a very clever thing and having a great deal of fun. Probably'subsequent reflection will convince them that the incident is one which does not seem as amusing by daylight as it did over night.

The extra-illustrator of books, when he has stalked abroad in modern days, has been a pathetic figure. Some of the most beautiful of all books having extra illustrations, volumes which even the most bitter enemy of Grangerism would have found interesting, were brought forward in the Cox and Wright sales of 1890, and in the Daly sale of the following year.

"NOTHING succeeds like success" is up to a certain point a true saying. Beyond that point, failure itself is scarcely as fatal. It is hard for any one -- hardest of all for a writer -- to live down a triumph too absolute.

Over the clothesline of fancy there hangs many a romantic wash. In "The Giants' Gate" there are numberless French Generals, some semblances of Esterhazy; the superb English amazon, Lady Kathleen, daughter of the port-absorbing Earl; the Baroness Pauline, who runs a salon in Paris; Borgia, the Russian; Lucien, the crazy inventor; the impossible Zephyrin, Mercier, Marchand, Bedotte the spy, and an assassin or two, all dangling from the same cord.

Lalor Beringer have sold for Jeremiah C. Lyons the twelve-story fire-proof store and loft building 394 and 396 Broadway, running through to 124 to 130 Crosby Street, between Prince and Houston Streets. The structure has frontages of 83 feet on Broadway and 90 feet on Crosby Street, and is 199 feet in depth.

The rapid conversion of the British Lloyds, once an organization of marine underwriters, into a gambling institution is calculated to alarm all who are connected with or interested in legitimate insurance. In fire under-writing a great deal of business is now done without a company organization or capital behind it, after the plan of individual guarantees which obtained for a time in this country, but quickly fell into disfavor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Final ratifications of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty were exchanged at the State Department this afternoon. There was very little ceremony about the exchange. Copies of the treaty had been prepared, precisely similar, except in the fact that the signatures were inverted in one copy, and these were formally exchanged between Lord Pauncefote and Secretary Hay, a protocol being signed, formally attesting to that fact, which will form part of the record.

It is curious that most books about James McNeill Whistler have so little that is new or interesting about the man. The trouble probably lies with the man himself, for it is quite apparent that, in the face of an interviewer or biographer, Mr. Whistler declines to permit himself to be taken seriously, while his disdain of encyclopedists is notorious.

District Attorney Jerome still holds to his theory that James McAuliffe, the Glennon witness, met his death last Sunday by accident. Yet he admits that the possibility of homicide is by no means remote.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 21 -- The week finishes with the money market in the same comfortable condition that has been in evidence for some time past. Demand is light and rates are now showing little change from day to day. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent; New York funds, 10c discount; call loans, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent.; time money, 3 3/4 to 4 1/2 per cent.

Vice President A.B. Hepburn of the Chase National Bank announced yesterday that the Leather Manufacturers' National Bank of this city had been designated by the Committee on Taxation of the American Bankers' Association to test the ruling of Commissioner of Internal Revenue John W. Yerkes on the subject of the internal revenue tax on the undivided profits of banks.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 21 -- According to the Tidhingen, the United States Steel Corporation has purchased nearly all the shares of the Gellivare Ore Company, at the nominal price of 6,000,000 kronen, ($1,608,000.) The paper adds that the Steel Corporation will take over the working of the North Swedish mines in the Autumn.

ON Monday and Tuesday of this week George D. Morse sold in John Anderson, Jr.'s auction room in west Thirtieth Street the fifth part of the library of Thomas Jefferson McKee. This part of the collection included a selection only from Mr. McKee's autographs and prints.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The Parliamentary Secretary to the Admiralty, H.O. Arnold-Forster, introduced the naval estimates for 1902-3 in the House of Comomns yesterday. They show a total of L31,255,000, as compared with L30,875,000 last year.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 21 -- Isaac N. Henderson of West Lafayette, Ohio, was found dying at a lonely spot on George Street, on the outskirts of the city, at an early hour this morning. A revolver, one chamber of which was empty, was lying by his side. He was found by a party of young people who were returning home from a straw ride.

The position of American newspapers in respect to the duty on wood pulp is the same as that of any manufacturer whose business is hampered and injured by the Dingley impost on his raw material. In advocating the abolition of the duties on the materials out of which news print paper is made, a newspaper is obviously speaking in its own interest.

Methodists of this city and vicinity will utilize the three annual meetings of their ministers in conference to further their undertaking to pay off church debts, increase income of conference claimant funds, and more firmly establish educational interests. A big meeting is planned for Carnegie Hall, at which one of the speakers will be R.W. Perks, the member of Parliament who suggested to English Wesleyans that they raise 1,000,000 guineas.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: Will you allow me a few words of comment on the letter of Mr. S.A. Clarke of Washington on "The Story of Marcus Whitman''? Mr. Clarke's statements are apparently based upon what he has heard in Oregon, for he gives no printed authority for his assertions.

This little book is written from a very modest standpoint. The author hopes to interest young readers in art by showing them pictures painted by the great men of the past, and telling them stories that lay no claim to authenticity, but serve perhaps "as a peg on which to hang a definite piece of knowledge."

"The Colonials" is a historical novel of the great lakes and of the Colony of Massachusetts Bay at the beginning of the American Revolution. Opening with adventure in the forest about Lake Huron, the scene soon shifts to Boston -- the Boston of the Tea Party and the siege.

Notwithstanding the bad weather, there was the liveliest sort of a ball last night at the German Liederkranz. The rule that every one must be masked on entering the hall was enforced rigidly. Those who dared to disobey were confined to a prison cell with real bars. When they paid the price, a bottle of champagne, they were released.

Although it was well known that Lord Dufferin, who died a few days ago, was one of the most cordial friends which Lord Tennyson possessed in the British diplomatic service, it is not generally known what particular circumstances or events brought the two men, in many ways so dissimilar, together.

The storm last night paralyzed the efforts of Street cleaning Commissioner Woodbury. More than 2,000 men went to work on the night shift at 6 o'clock to remove snow and slush. One hour later not a wheel turned, nor was there a sweeper or shoveler to be found at work. They refused to stay out in the gale for the stipend allowed by the City Government.

The Civil Service Reform Association has resolved to present to the Mayor objections to certain exemptions from competition proposed by the Municipal Civil Service Commission. As these propositions require the approval of the Mayor, the action of the City Commission is very properly made the subject of discussion with him by the Reform Association.

By those who know his "South Sea Idylls," or his "Summer Cruising in the Southern Seas," a new book by Charles Warren Stoddard will be welcomed. Though better Known in California, perhaps, than in other parts of America, Mr. Stoddard's vivid and poetic charm has long been recognized by lovers of description or of books of travel.

M. Hugues Le Roux brings us the usual plaint that we English-speaking peoples form an incorrect and unfair notion of French life from the stories of it that are most read in this country and in England.

A New Life of Napoleon I. John Holland Rose, the author of "A Life of Nopoleon I.," and well-known English historian, is a man whose historical perspective has heretofore been satisfactorily proved, and he has here given us a scholarly work resting upon the most recent contributions to the subject.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Commissioner of Excise Cullinan has made the discovery that wholesale violations of the excise law have been committed by druggists throughout the State. For several weeks the Commissioner has been collecting evidence, and he says he is now ready to begin prosecutions against 200 druggists.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Supplies of money were scarce to-day, and the market was anxiously waiting for a Government distribution of funds. Discounts were inclined to be easier, in consequence of the decline of money rates abroad. Business on the Stock Exchange was less depressed, though there was an indisposition to enter into fresh engagements, in view of the nearness of the settlement.

Wall Street yesterday was much less disturbed over the purposed action of President Roosevelt to test the standing of the Northern Securities Company under the Sherman anti-trust law. While as on the day before the same disinclination to talk was shown by those most concerned, what talk there was showed less resentment toward the President.

Manuals of the floras of various countries have changed much in appearance since the days of Gerarde's "Herbal." Rafinesque's little "Flora of the United States," written almost a century ago, looked like any other book, having heavy type only for the specific names which headed paragraphs in which the analytical description of the plant was succeeded by economic notes.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Mr. Wells, in his tecture on the "Discovery of the Future," did not make any distinct prophcies. He played the part of a theoretical prophet, which somehow reminds one of the theoretical barber, who is postulated by the familiar sign, "Practical Barber."

A little of the good brown earth of Indiana, and some of the air above it, have made, if not a Shakespeare, yet certainly a group, or succession, of poets and prose-writers entirely disproportionate in fame and numbers to the size and population of the State. The phenomenon is one to excite curiosity.

Words suffer the fate of things. Per- haps no one should quarrel with the fact that "villa" in the old Florentine sense, designated something very different from those suburban seats of economical respectability attached to a time table which the term at once presents to the modern vision.

The appointment of Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans to take charge of the navy's participation in the reception to Prince Henry, who will arrive in New York Feb. 22, is an appropriate honor, and it is probable that Admiral Evans was selected because he is a personal friend, of the Emperor and the Prince.

Of the three best-known English texts of Balzac's 'Comedie Humaine," two have now been completed in small 16mo volumes. The relative and comparative excellencies of the translations made by Miss Wormeley and those selected by Mr. Salntsbury have already been noted in these columns. The first volume of the Temple Edition contains a general introduction and classification of the novels, while each book has its special preparatory essay.

The Harvard Club of this city gave its thirty-sixth annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and despite the weather there were between four and five hundred Harvard graduates present. The chief, speakers of the evening were Charles W. Eliot, President of Harvard University; Carroll D. Wright, United States Labor Commissioner; Frederick P. Fish, and Dr. George B. Shattuck, Charles S. Fairchild, former Secretary of the Treasury and President of the club, presided.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: It is a foolhardy task to try to supplement your somewhat caustic words of advice to an aspirant for poetic honors and emoluments; but admitting the value of rules and scientific precision in most lines of knowledge, in poetry they are hardly entitled to priority, if at all worthy of place.

The preliminary hearing of Florence Burns, who is held for killing Walter S. Brooks, will take place at 10 o'clock to-day before Justice Mayer, in the Court of Special Sessions. District Attorney Jerome and his assistant, Mr. Schurman, will conduct the prosecution, while Foster L. Backus of Kings County will defend the prisoner and try to establish an alibi.

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 21.--Theodore Roosevelt, Jr., who has been ill with pneumonia for two weeks in the Groton School infirmary, is bound for Washington tonight. Bundled to his eyes with blankets, he was taken in a covered sleigh from the infirmary to the special train, which had been in readiness at the Groton station for several days.

The arrival here yesterday of the White Star steamers Teutonic and Georgic brought information which, taken together, indicates that the Leyland Line steamer Philadelphian, from Liverpool for Boston, has been disabled in midocean and is being towed by the North German Lloyd Line steamer Neckar.

Mrs. Tuttle's sketch of Queen Louise of Prussia, which was recently published under the title of "The Mother of an Emperor," has now been presented in a second edition in a book which also includes other pen pictures by the author dealing with Prussian life, together with some pen-and-ink drawings and half-tone reproductions of paintings, notably that of "The Kaiser Wilhelm I.," by W. Camphausen.
MADRID, Feb. 21 -- Official dispatches received here assert that calm has been restored at Barcelona, Saragossa and Valencia, but newspaper telegrams report that the situation is still serious.
SOME days ago the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society adopted the following memorial to Congress:

This lesson is simply a continuation of that of last week. Then Stephen had been arrested as he was preaching in one of the Hellenistic synagogues of Jerusalem. Those who listened to him, being unable to answer his arguments, and unwilling to accept his conclusions, were filled with anger.
LONDON, Feb. 22 -- The weekly reviews make the impending arrival of Prince Henry of Prussia at New York the occasion of more discussion regarding the Spanish-American war and the European powers.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The invitation which has been extended by Gov. Odell and the Committee of Five appointed by the Repub- lican conference to the members of the State Board of Charities to confer with the committee and offer suggestions for the framing of a bill to change the system of management of the State charities has its significance.

Wall Street's hysteria was modified yesterday. Some liquidation had the appearance of being enforced during the earlier hours of business, but the later movements of the day had favorable aspects. Some lines of short contracts were covered. Buying on a substantial scale came from important commission houses.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" has had a period of rest, during which Mme. Ernestine Schumann-Heink, the Brangane of the cast, has been careering around the country singing in concerts for the delectation of thousands. As those thousands do not have the felicity of hearing Wagner's wonderful embodiment of the passion of love, we may not grudge them their opportunities of listening to Mme. Schumann-Heink in the act of singing the brindisi from "Lucretia Borgia."

One of the most spectacular fires the city has seen in years destroyed the varnish works of Emil Calman Co. in Long Island City yesterday. For a time the flames threatened to sweep through a large section, and but for the fact that Chief Croker mustered four fireboats, all the engines in Long Island City, and many from Brooklyn, the fire might have spread disastrously.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- Andrew D. White, the United States Ambassador here, presiding to-night at an assemblage of 300 Americans, who celebrated Washington's Birthday at the Kaiserhof by a musical entertainment, followed by supper and a dance, said in an address:

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The appeal of Capt. John D. Herlihy, formerly of the Twelfth Police Precinct, New York City, from a decision of the Appellate Division, First Department, overruling a decision made by Recorder Golf in sustaining his demurrer to an indictment charging him with willful neglect of duty as Police Captain in not suppressing disorderly houses, was argued in the Court of Appeals to-day.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- Lord Rosebery's announcement of his final separation from Sir Henry Campbell -- Bannerman's section of the Liberal Party forms a fruitful topic for editorials and for discussion in all quarters.

There seems unfortunately no reason to doubt that at the New Year's audience granted by the Empress Dowager and the Emperor of China to the foreign representatives, the manners of the latter and of those in their suites, for whom they were responsible, were very bad.

The conversion of W. Augustine Birrell is too important an event to be thought lightly of. The place he fills in literature is his own, and honorable. Admiration of his style and his fine discrimination induces an apprehension as to the effect of the event upon his future flights in criticism.

An article elsewhere printed in this issue in regard to the rights of editors in dealing with the manuscripts of authors is interesting chiefly because it reveals the existence of an uncertainty in this delicate matter. The question of how far an editor may go in editing is a pretty one, and it ought to be thoroughly discussed.

Notwithstanding the miserable weather yesterday, everything was serene and comfortable inside the Madison Square Garden, where the dogs continued to bark just as lively as though the conditions outside the Garden were more conducive to human animation. The attendance, especially in the afternoon and evening, was large, and it was easy to see by the numerous groups gathered in front of certain pens where the interest in dogs was divided.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House Committee on Territories to-day unanimously voted to report bills for the admission of the Territories of New Mexico, Arizona, and Oklahoma. The vote was taken upon a motion made by Mr. Moon of Tennessee declaring it to be the opinion of the committee that the three Territories were entitled to Statehood and that sub-committees be appointed to prepare the bills.

The New York Times Saturday Review of Books: In your interesting and valuable review of the new edition of Hazlitt's works in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS of Feb. 15 I was just a little startled by the statement, taken from Mr. Henley's introduction, that Hazlitt's father established the first Unitarian Church in America.

-- Good evidence that the Londoners think the Boer war is practically over -- if it isn't evidence that they have resigned themselves to the thought that the war is to go on forever -- is supplied by the fact that the correspondents of the London papers are showing just now an intense interest in hens, as objects, grateful or ungrateful, profitable or unprofitable, of urban and suburban care.

There was some very brisk bidding last night at the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries when the remainder of the collection of the paintings belonging to the estate of the late James M. Hart, the landscape and cattle painter, were offered at auction. Although, because of the inclement weather, there was only a small gathering of art lovers and dealers, some pretty good prices were realized.
From The Evening Post of yesterday. The American Newspaper Publishers' Association, at its annual meeting yesterday, passed the subjoined resolution:

There were those who, after reading Mr. Phillips's "Paolo and Francesca." preferred Dante's brief account of those unhappy lovers to Mr. Phillips's drama, for all its moments of exquisite tenderness and beauty. His "Herod" forced on us no comparison between it and a preceding literary form of great renown.
The imports of dry goods and general merchandise for the week were valued at $10,878,824. The imports of specie amounted to $210,174 and the exports of specie to $688,466.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- New York exchange to-day was 15c discount. Time and call loans, 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. On the local Exchange Tin Can again made up the bulk of the day's business. As was the case yesterday, New York made the market for this stock, quotations from there, particularly for the common, coming decidedly strong.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Tunnel bill met with a setback in the Senate to-day. Senator Stranahan attempted to advance the bill from general orders to third reading, but because of objection made by Senator Donnelly, the bill remained in general orders and will not be advanced until next Tuesday.

One of the many subjects which constantly arise among authors, and, in a secondary sense fully as important, among readers, is the extent to which an editor may properly exercise his right of revision. That he has and must maintain that right, within reasonable limitations, cannot be gainsaid: the heart of the problem is in determining what are "reasonable" and what are unreasonable limitations.

VICTOR HUGO, whose centenary comes on Feb. 26, was one of the most striking personalities of the nineteenth century; many-sided, versatile, ardent in his political and social beliefs, touching life at many points, and getting so close to humanity that its very heartbeats could be heard.

MRS. EDITH WHARTON'S first long novel. "The Valley of Decision." being published this week by Charles Scribner's Sons. The story is in the time when, the small principalities of Italy were breaking up, at the end of the eighteenth century.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- When the Senate met at 11 o'clock to-day it at once entered upon the consideration of the Philippine Tariff bill. Mr. Bate (Dem., Tenn.,) spoke in opposition to the measure. He covered pretty fully the general Philippine question. Few things had occurred in the Senate chamber, he said, more fateful or involving more delicate issues and greater results than the ratification of the Treaty of Paris.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- "A newspaper in a small city is not a legitimate business enterprise." This is the prelude to the "Confessions of a Provincial Editor," in the coming number of The Atlantic Monthly. He bases his statement, not only upon his experience of six years, but upon his knowledge of other papers in small cities.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Emma Fischer, a Hungarian servant girl employed by William J. Simons of 90 Bruce Avenue, this city, attempted to kill her employer's little daughter and herself this afternoon. The child, whose name is Georgiana and who is four and a half years old, lies critically ill to-night, although the physicians, who discovered that two bullets had passed through her body, hold out hope for her recovery.

A telephone message was received at Police Headquarters early this morning from John McLaughlin, the gateman at the Thirty-fourth Street Fery, to the effect that a boat is drifting helplessly down the East River off Thirty-second Street. The boat, McLaughlin said, is loaded with dynamite.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21 -- In answer to the widespread and rapidly growing movement for the more thorough and at the same time more natural education of children, the firm of Henry T. Coates Co. has announced for early publication the first volume in a series for "The Children's Library."

Florence Burns, the Brooklyn girl who is charged with the murder of Walter S. Brooks at the Glen Island Hotel, was arraigned for preliminary examination before Justice Mayer in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday. District Attorney Jerome reiterated his statement that he was as anxious to establish her innocence as her guilt.

Through the Fire Marshal, Coroner Goldenkranz, and the District Attorney's office, a rigid investigation into the deaths of seventeen persons and the severe injury of many others was begun yesterday. The fact that a fatal and disastrous hotel fire had again occurred in New York brought the various department together.
MEN'S fashion plates for the coming Spring and Summer and the independent suggestions of the leading tailors of Fifth Avenue show several new departures.

The expansion of our trade and commerce is the great problem of the day. We must in the near future find markets for our surplus products abroad or expect disaster at home. The commercial intercourse of the great nations of the world is rapidly approaching the character of the business relations that exists between individuals in trade.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22. -- The notable exercises which mark the quarter century in the history of Johns Hopkins University and the installation of Ira Remsen as President of that institution were attended today by fully 4,000 persons from all parts of the country.

It is given out from New York that Mr. John D. Rockefeller and his son have determined to invest large sums of money in the promotion of Southern education, and that President Baldwin of the Long Island Railroad is to be the head of the organization formed for the purpose.

In the large banquet room at Delmonico's last night the Sons of the Revolution, in the State of New York celebrated the one hundred and seventieth anniversary of the birth of George Washington. The hall was decorated handsomely with groups of silk flags, banners of the society, and roses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "E.R. Thomas Exonerated." So reads the headline in your issue of this morning in its notice of a recent verdict by the Coroner's jury. No one could be more sincerely glad than I that Mr. Thomas, if innocent, should be thus cleared. There are, however, some points in the case which have not been satisfactorily explained in the published reports.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Standing without the Campbell-Bannerman tabernacle, yet not in solitude. Lord Rosebery has sounded his horn, and many influential Liberals are flocking to his standard. Herbert Asquith, Sir Henry Fowler, Sir Edward Grey, and Richard Haldane feel that they have no longer common intertests with the hard working, but inept and unfortunate leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 22. -- A "sweet Spring" bird chirruped blithely from the boughs of a pine tree in front of the Presbyterian Church last Sunday morning, and the churchgoers who heard the bird's cheery warble took it as a sure omen that Spring was near at hand. The bird proved to be a false prophet.

Miss Etta H. Maddox of Baltimore, who recently graduated at the Maryland University Law School and was refused admission to the bar on account of her sex, made a strong appeal to the Senate Judiciary Committee in Annapolis on Thursday afternoon. A bill making legal the admission of women to the bar has been introduced in the Senate and is now in the hands of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, who have been considering the question of concessions to Cuba at several meaning this week, finally reached an agreement this afternoon, which is considered a victory for those who have favored tariff concessions to that island.

The following pastoral letter by Archbishop Corrisan has been issued to the clergy and laity of the archdiocese on the occasion of the twenty-fourth anniversary t the election to the pontificate of Pope Leo XIII., which occurred on Thursday last:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22, (by mail.) -- The customary celebration of Washington's Birthday by the University of Pennsylvania took place to-day in the Acartemy of Music. The most impressive feature of the occasion was the conferring of eight honorary degrees upon seven distinguished men and one woman.

Herbert Kelcey and Effie Shannon have in "Her Lord and Master." it is said, an exceptionally dainty play. It is to be produced at the Manhattan Theatre to-morrow night. Miss Martha Morion, the authoress, claims that the play is founded upon actual occurrences. It deals with an international marriage.

The Argument. A writer on stage matters, in an effort to prove that acting was not an art once asserted that without an audience there could be no such thing as acting. The conclusion was fallacious. One might assert with equal reason that Raphael's "Madonna," if locked in a dark cellar where no one could see it, had therefore ceased to be a work of art.

Steel Trust stocks were strong throughout the week, failing to show any material recession even on Thursday, when the whole market declined sharply as a result Of the unexpected developments concerning the Northern Securities Company. On that day, indeed, while other stocks broke three, four, and five points, Steel common and preferred held up remarkably well, each showing only a fractional decline at the close of the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's paper Mr. Volkhardt complains that the rate for water measured by meters is too high. I am sure that if the Department of Water Supply had a meter put in every place where water is used for commercial purposes the city easily could reduce the rate one-half, without losing anything thereby.

The scene in the Senate chamber is the culmination of a contest for supremacy between two politicians from the same State, which has been conducted with much bitterness and the exchange of many personalities.

ONE Summer day in 1890 a New Yorker visiting Berlin strolled to the Lustgarten, and sitting on one of the benches, contemplated the various fine buildings around him. He did not know his bearings well, and, in halting German, asked some questions of a young man who had sat down beside him.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- Chicago paid fitting tribute to-day to the memory of Washington. All the banks, the Stock Exchange, and the Board of Trade were closed, and many of the large business houses observed the holiday. In the morning an audience of nearly 5,000 school children were present at a union celebration at the Auditorium given under the auspices of the Union League Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--Two Senators fought to-day on the floor of the Senate and drew blood each from the other. The persons in conflict were the Senators from South Carolina. Benjamin Ryan Tillman and John Lowndes McLaurin. The fight took place while the Senate was in session considering the Philippine Tariff bill.

The beginning of lead mining in Wisconsin territory was about the year 1824, or thirty-six years before the coming of the pioneers who sought for farms in the new country. The pioneers came in by way of Galena, where the lead deposits had been worked two years, the product being taken out down the Mississippi River.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The Irish Party attaches great significance to the evictions of the tenants of forty farms on Lord De Freyne's estate in Roscommon County, Ireland, for refusal to pay rent, and intends to make a fierce Parliamentary struggle over the matter.
Where the minister's name is announced he is mentioned for the service or services at which he will officiate.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 22. -- The meeting of the League baseball officials which was scheduled for 11 o'clock this morning did not get under way until 2 o'clock this afternoon on account of the trains from the East being late because of the storm. The officials present were Charles H. Ebbets and Edward Hanlon of Brooklyn, Col. John I. Rogers of Philadelphia, J.A. Hart of Chicago, Barney Dreyfuss of Pittsburg, and Harry Pulliam.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Georgiana Simons, the four-year-old child of William J. Simons, who was yesterday shot twice near the heart by Emma Fischer. a young Hungarian servant in the household, was reported to be better to-day, with every prospect for her recovery.

FOUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- The roads are blocked, trolley lines tied up, and traffic on railroads interrupted by the heaviest snowfall which has occurred in this vicinity since 1888. It began snowing yesterday morning and continued until lote this afternoon. Between eighteen inches arid two feet of snow fell.

The discovery of dozens of violations of the new tenement house law in the construction of east side houses has aroused Superintendent Stewart and Commissioner De Forest of the Tenement House Commission to drastic measures to correct the evils. Many builders of east side tenements who have been putting up "jerry structures" during the four years of the Tammany administration of the Building Department have been compelled to comply with the new law.

Society is pretty well en villagitura Just at present There is much more news from Palm Beach, and Aiken and other resorts than there is from the court end of town. Sewing classes go on with mild monotony, and some or them are tempered with music. Miss Leary has Heath Gregory and others once a week, and there are bowling and badminton and ping pong bly bridge clubs.

The worst weather of the season was experienced yesterday at the Bay Ridge traps of the Crescent Athletic Club. Despite the unfavorable conditions, however, a successful day's shooting was held, the scores in nearly every instance being up to the average.

Cazenovia, N.Y., Feb. 17, 1902. WASHINGTON, The defender of his country. The founder of Liberty. The friend of man. History and tradition are explored in vain For a parallel to his character. In the annals of modern greatness he stands alone.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22. -- The present dearth of private entertainments has afforded an opportunity for the different woman's clubs and patriotic societies to assume their customary importance in Baltimore. On Tuesday morning Mr. Marshall Darraeh of New York gave a recital of the "Merchant of Venice" at the Arundell Club before one of the most exclusive audiences of the Winter.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- During the debate on the Cocks Automobile bill in the Senate Thursday a State official who is known to be interested in the manufacture of automobiles was an interested listener. There were also present some representatives of street railway interests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The common law of this enlightened country has descended from "the bosom, of God," wherein is the seat of the law, "whose voice is the harmony of the world." The efforts of good men and true are now being made to have the infamous pigeonshooting law repealed, so that the law of the State may not conflict with the axiom above mentioned.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Residents and visitors alike are now enjoying for the third time this Winter the pleasure of sleighing, and the six-mile stretch of speedway between aristocratic Chelsea and Longport is the scene of gayety and life. Every sort of a vehicle on runners has been pressed into service, and the chic sleigh of modern times runs side by side with high, back affairs that have seen better days.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent heavy snowstorm has demonstrated the fact that the elevated railroad is the last to succumb to elementary disturbances. While Flatbush and other outlying sections dependent upon the trolley roads were early left to their fate during the storm, people living in the vicinity of the city line traveled to and from the bridge on the Fulton Street elevated without discomfort.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22, -- The whole list was better on the local Stock Exchange yesterday. Union Traction being the particularly bright spot. There was a revival of animation and strength in American Asphalt fives, over $200,000 of the bonds being bought at advancing figures, the price touching 34 1/2, against 33 Thursday night.

To the Editor of The York Times: The alliterative story in the Magazine Supplement of THE TIMES on Sunday last told by the late Pierre Lorillard of his Cockney coachman at Rancocas Farm was published in London Punch about fifty years ago, and in much bettor form, in connection with a large cartoon showing four figures in a London street -- two horses and two cabbies.

BERLIN, Feb. 22.--Advices received here from St. Petersburg attribute the excitement among the students in part to a false report on Feb. 20 that Count Tolstoi was dead. It was asserted that the authorities had suppressed the news, because the Holy Synod was undecided whether to proceed with the annual excommunication of the author.

Not since 1894, when the great contralto Mme. Patey expired on the concert platform at Sheffield, has a popular audience been so shocked ns the crowd in the Lyceum Theatre, Birmingham, were on Wednesday night. The sensation had brief notice in The Express yesterday.

TEA drinking in America and the use of the afternoon tea table is increasing constantly. There were innumerable afternoon tea tables sold for Christmas presents the past holiday season. They say at the furniture shops, a sign of good times, for such things are more or less luxuries. Muffin stands are in so much demand that it is difficult 10 keep a supply in the shops.

LIKE the bankrupt merchant who before offering his assets at public auction attempts, to see what advantageous bargains he can personally make with those who might derive special benefit from a private sale, so Alexander of Servia is entering into negotiations with Russia to discover if he can drive a private bargain before circumstances shall force him to make an assignment to his own people, who are his natural and moral creditors.

To those who believe that England's extremity is America's opportunity, it begins to look as if the adoption of our machinery and methods in the industries of that country would rapidly and permanently equalize conditions and put British manufacturers in a position to recover control of markets in which our manufactures have become of controlling commercial importance.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22. -- The favorites were beaten in rapid succession to-day. Prince Blazes, who, though a winner, is always classed as an outsider in the stakes, scored a clever victory in the George Washington Handicap, worth $1,793 to the winner. Piederich and Banish coupled were hot favorites.

EVERY YEAR the number of Americans who do not wait until they die to so to Paris is increasing at a rate that once would have been considered truly extraordinary, but which in these days of luxurious and rapid transit across the Atlantic -- a mere ferry trip to the average long-distance traveler -- is the most natural thing in the world.

IT is a true tale of what might have been a Southern tragedy. Husband and wife had been spending the evening at the house of a friend, where there had been a small social gathering, and after several hours of pleasure returned home. The house, after the fashion of many places in the South, had been left not only unlocked but open.

At the London Institution "Company Promoters in Theory and Practice" was the subject of a paper by Mr. G.F. Emery, who suggested that a promoter was practically the parent of the company. In just the same way as a father had to look after his child a promoter should look after his company, until it was working.

The upward course of the current market was again shown last week both in increased amount of miscellaneous business and in a large number of transactions involving high valued properties and fore-shadowing extensive improvements.

Little improvement in the terrible condition of the slush-covered streets was apparnet yesterday. The hapless pedestrians waded ankle deep in the chilly, dirty mire as they crossed from sidewalk to sidewalk. or ventured into the roadway to board slow-moving or belated cars, the while they shrank under their wind-beaten umbrellas from the snow, sleer, and rain that alternated until late in the evening, when the weather showed signs of clearing up.

SANTOS-DUMONT'S recent accident, which came very near ending his life in the waters of the Mediterranean, will lend added interest to the prospective visit to this country of the daring navigator of the air next Summer. It is regarded as likely that Santos-Dumont will construct an entirely new balloon, and make a special effort to impress Americans with its dirigibility.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: Why not try to settle this whole liquor question by removing every restriction from the sale and consumption of liquor, by permiiting every one who wishes to sell liquor as much freedom as is now extended to those who sell candy or potatoes, thus removing the saloon, with all its alleged corrupting influences from the field of politics?

THE fashions in hats as seen in the milliners' windows and those actually worn by women of fashion are often widely divergent. It is not uninteresting to note certain examples worn at dinners in leading restaurants where people of fashion -- as also some of those who make no pretensions thereto -- congregate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Since the election of the Fusion administration discussion as to the attitude of the various reform forces on excise, gambling, and the social evil has shown that those who aim to bring about better conditions are hopelessly antagonistic as to practical steps.

Silas Larrabee received by mail this morning a communication purporting to come from the "National Anti-Expletive Society.'' The President of the society in this communication invited Mr. Larrabee to place before the public his views upon the use of "profane and other shocking ejaculatory expressions."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I should esteem it a favor If THE TIMES would chronicle my deep disgust at the speech on Trusts and the tariff made in the House on Wednesday by Congressman Hamilton of Michigan. The sophistry and buncombe that speech contained will recoil on the Republican Party with damaging force.

As a result of an investigation made by engineers and architects in the employ of the city, the Brooklyn Borough Hall, which occupies the centre of the triangular plaza bounded by Fulton, Court, and Joralemon Streets, was yesterday declared to be unsafe. The entire second floor of the building, built many years ago for use as the City Hall of Brooklyn will be condemned.

There was only one thing lacking to make the gala performance in honor of Prince Henry at the Irving Place Theatre last night a complete success, and that was the presence of the Prince. But while he was held back by the storms the gala performance went merrily on with a few variations.

Every one who pays attention to such matters is aware that the pre-eminence in the production of iron has passed from the United Kingdom to the United States. Furthermore, every such person knows that in the neutral markets we have to meet a keen competition, not only from the United States, but likewise from Germany and Belgium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that the President's loyalty to President McKinley and his love of the thickest of the fight have influenced him in the Schley decision rather than his usual strong common sense.

Eminent surgeons have long endeavored to find out precisely what parts of the brain control the various muscles and limbs of the body, with a view to ascertaining therefrom new ways of treating diseases of the nervous system.

The Purim Association announces its forty-second annual ball, to be held at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday evening, March 20. The proceeds will be devoted to the United Hebrew Charities. The committeemen intend that the ball this year shall be the most successful socially and financially ever given under their management.

THE man who writes for a living regards with speechless wonder those who write long letters to the editor. The idea that any one is willing to do all that writing for no pay is astonishing to him. On the other hand, the people who write the gratuitous letters to the editor have a certain contempt for the man who uses his pen only to earn money.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 22. -- "Terry" McGovern of Brooklyn defeated Dave Sullivan to-night in the arena of the Southern Athletic Club after fifteen rounds of as desperate fighting as were ever seen in any ring. From the first tap of the gong until the end it was slam bang, hammer and tongs nearly every second, both men working away with all the energy they possessed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 -- (By Mail.) -- Cut off from the world, in darkness, and swept bys a terrific storm of rain and sleet, falling upon streets already six inches deep in muddy slush, this has been the condition of Philadelphia for the past forty hours. To the discomfort of the storm and darkness, was added the terror of live electric wires strewn about the streets.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- The journals of the capital appear to have reserved their editorial pages to-day for America. The subject of domestic politics is dropped and the relations of all other countries for the moment are forgotten in long, kindly comments upon the United States and Prince Henry's visit.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22. -- Every indication points to the belief that a biff railroad and financial deal is on tap, by which George J. Gould's Missouri Pacific will grain an entrance into San Francisco. Prince Ponlatowskl, P.S. Bullock, One of his partners in several enterprises, and Senator Clark of Montana are represented as being connected with Mr. Gould in his scheme to extend the Gould railroad system west from Salt Lake to San Francisco.

THURSDAY, FEB. 27. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., public auction sale, by order of the heirs, 1,204 to 1,210 Broadway, east side, 64.5 feet north or Twenty-ninth Street, 67.7 by 121.4 and irregular, four-story brick buildings.

ACTON, NORMAN, of Colorado Springs, 32 years of age. He was a member of the Hawkins-Acton Investment Company, and since June had been managing the branch office of the firm at 100 Broadway. He was also the principal stockholder in the Cochiz Mining and Milling Company, and a Director of the Orocobre Mining and Milling company, for which he was the Eastern manager.

MADRID, Feb. 22. -- Agitators are actively urging the declaration of a great strike to take place here on Feb. 24 in support of the strikers in Barcelona. The Socialists were greatly excited by reports that several workmen at Barcelona had been tried by court-martial and shot. This, however, was denied officially.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some weeks ago you editorially congratulated the Manhattan on its installation of electricity as a motive power instead of the antiquated locomotives they are now using, but I am very much afraid that you were too premature as to time and too sanguine in your expectation that the company would at last do their duty toward the public.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- This week will develop definitely the chances of canal legislation. The canal bill carrying an appropriation of $31,500,000 will be reported to the Assembly. This includes the appropriation for the Champlain Canal, which was not included in the original plan of improvement recommended by the Governor, but for which he has now consented that provision be made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer is a rock-ribbed protectionist. He believes that protection has been and is for the "greatest good of the greatest number": that upon not other theory has it a right to its being; that present conditions, the relative position we hold to-day as workers doing the world's work, is irrefragable evidence of the correctness of our theory and practice.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- So far the effect of the Attorney General's opinion in the Northern Securities matter on prices of American shares in the London market this week, has merely reflected New York. Much has been printed here in regard to the situation, but little has been said that is worth repeating to New York readers.

SOMETHING very like homelessness last week came to the little colony of artists, newspaper men, and kindred bohemlans, who, despite changing conditions, the northern movement of the city's centre, have clung tenaciously to the old haunts near where the Washington Arch rears its graceful outline.

THE bridal gown of Miss Alice Morton, who on Tuesday became Mrs. Winthrop Rutherfurd, was simple but rich. The material was a heavy, creamy white satin. The bodice was surplice in its fashioning, but a modified surplice -- the plaits slanting only slightly and forming a narrow V at the top in the back and one somewhat wider in front.

At the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, Donizetti's "La Fille du Regiment" and Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana" were performed. The house had been sold out for several days, and despite the difficulty which many holders of seats must have had in reaching their destination, the auditorium was crowded.

Many Important changes to the constitution were adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America held in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The meeting was well attended, all the leading colleges having delegates, and most of the amendments that were proposed by the Executive Committee about a month ago were ratified without opposition. Officers for the coming year were elected as follows:

An increase of nearly $20,000,000 in the loans of the New York banks, following an increase of $19,500,000 the week before, was calculated to make people stop and think, comments The United States Investor, which proceeds:

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The other day Journal Clerk Fay of the Senate called one of the page boys and said to him: "Here, boy, take this bill to Senator White." In a moment the boy came back to the desk. "Sennior Brown is not in his seat," he said.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The annual same of football, played under association rules, between Oxford and Cambridge, took place to-day at the Queen's Club, here, and was won by Oxford, with a score of 2 to 0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you please answer the following, and no doubt many other daily readers of your financial columns will be interested in the answer: Why is it that a "phenomenally successful" corporation, like the United States Steel Corporation, paying regularly 4 per cent, on its common stock and 7 per cent. on the preferred, has its shares quoted so low on the Exchanges?

Very few Americans, we suppose, are likely to share the assumption of Mr. WHEELER of the First District of Kentucky that we are about to entertain at our best the reputedly amiable and cultivated German gentleman who is about to arrive upon our shores, upon his individual account, or merely because he happens to have an imposing handle to his name.

IF the plans for the regulation of the street traffic of New York as proposed by William Phelps Eno, the well-known yachtsman, clubman, and Tale graduates are put into execution, a veritable revolution in the method of regulating vehicles in this city win be effected. Mr. Eno has published an elaborate pamphlet setting forth some of his views.
The flag, the Stars and Stripes, was named "Old Glory" in 1851 by a Salem (Mass.) skipper named William Driver. He was at that time Captain of the brig Charles Doggett.

A SUBSCRIPTION is to be taken up today in many Episcopal churches throughout the country in aid of the old Pohick Church, where George Washington used to worship. The Trustees of the Pohick Church Fund have been making efforts for several years to raise $12,000 to put the historic little edifice in repair, as it was badly damaged during the civil war.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A bill to support parochial and sectarian schools in this city from the funds in the public treasury has been introduced into the Legislature at Albany by Senator Bernard F. Martin of Mew York City. This measure is in direct antagonism to the spirit of American institutions.

The mourners of old-fashioned Winters ought to be satisfied with the current edition, writes Frederick E. Saward in his Coal Trade Journal. For about four months there has been necessity for burning coal, and there have been many and strong Demands therefor; the output has been kept up far beyond what is usually the case during the Winter months, and yet there is no surplus anywhere.

It is now an open secret that an expedition is being fitted out to search for the buried treasure which escaped Mr. E.F. Knight and his fellow-adventurers of the Alerte, in their voyage undertaken a dozen years ago. The treasure consists of gold and silver, largely in the form of church plate and candlesticks, carried away from Peru by revolutionists and buried in a lonely Island.

THERE is now under way a revival in dancing in this city. One of the causes of his among the younger members of society is attributed to the prompt action of a New York woman who gave a fashionable dance this Winter. It was patronized by a large number of young men who did not dance.

QUITE lately important additions have been made to the known pictures of animals of the past. MM. Captain and Breuil have sent to the Paris Academy of Sciences drawings of many animals found by then: in a cave at Combarelles. On the rock sides of the cave no less than 109 etchings have been brought to light.

Opening of the Italian Parliament. If the speech from the throne at the opening of the Italian Parliament last Thursday contained no outline of foreign policy it was because the subject had already been exhausted in the exchange of sentiments last month between the French Ambassador in Rome, the Italian Government, and the German Cltancellor.

OTTAWA, Feb. 22.--The annual report of the Minister of Railways, which has just been issued, shows that there are in Canada 18,294 miles of railway, which is an increase of 658 miles over the previous year. In addition to this there are 2,710 miles of sidings. The number of miles laid with steel rails is 18,184, and the number of miles in operation is 18,140.

Bank checks are of two kinds -- city and out of town. In collecting city checks New York has no superior, but it is behind the ago in collecting out-of-town checks. Reform is needed. And since free collection will result, all persons receiving out-of-town checks are interested in the adoption of improved methods.
The Kronprinz Wilhelm with Prince Henry of Germany on board was sighted at 1 o'clock this morning off Nantucket Lightship. She will arrive off Sandy Hook at 10 o'clock this morning.

TUESDAY, FEB. 25. -- By William M. Ryan, foreclosure sale, Austin E. Pressinger, referee, 1,584 Lexington Avenue, west side, 36.3 feet south of One Hundred and First Street, 16.2 by 75.5, three-story brick dwelling. Due on judgment, $9,454.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- When routine matters had been disposed of after the opening, Mr. Tillman resumed his speech on the Philippine bill, which he began yesterday. He declared that no revenues were needed by the insular Government in the Philippines, as it had ample funds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If Commissioner Sturgis will visit the gallery of Carnegie Hall he will find under the seats a condition of affairs far more dangerous in my opinion than any overcrowded aisles could be. For some reason, perhaps for purposes of ventilation, the architect or builder has left under and at the back of each row of seats, an opening several inches wide, running along the floor.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Snow commenced falling here on Friday at daybreak and ceased this afternoon. The country roads are badly drifted and the snow on the level is three feet deep. All railroad traffic is delayed from one to seven hours.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Charles Clark Peck, who died in this city on the 16th inst., at the advanced age of ninety-two years, had been a subscriber to THE NEW YORK TIMES since the year of its first issue, a fact which, I think, you should know, and also that he was an intimate friend of the late George Jones of your paper.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 22. -- The text of the treaty between the United States and Denmark for the sale of the Danish West Indies was distributed this afternoon in Danish and English to the members of the Rigsdag. A bill dealing with the sale of the islands probably will be submitted to the Rigsdas at the end of next week.

After the fire in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, had raged for more than an hour early yesterday morning, flames were communicated to the Park Avenue Hotel, across the street, and, trapped in a swirling cone of flame and smoke, which swept almost unheralded up through the building, Seventeen guests of the hotel were suffocated or burned to death, and some two-score more or less seriously injured.

ONE of the most grotesque blunders concerning the United States is the habitual use by certain people in Europe of the word "Anglo-Saxon" to designate Americans. There are millions of people in England who always speak of Americans as members of "the Anglo-Saxon race" and believe them to be such.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 22. -- Robert Fulton Cutting of New York has rented of Robert M. Gushing his villa on Ocean Avenue and the rocks, known as "The Ledges." The villa, which is now rented for the first time since Mr. Gushing has owned it, is in a fashionable neighborhood, being in close vicinity to the villas of Henry Clews, Stuyvesant Fish, G.H. Warren, and W. Starr Miller.

President Roosevelt's announcement that the Federal Government will project a judicial inquiry into the legitimacy of the Northern Securities Company has given Wall Street a sensation with which no experience of recent years is comparable. Nervousness has been created.

Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff, speaking last, night at the annual dinner of the Hamilton Club of Brooklyn, held at the clubhouse, Remsen and Clinton Streets, criticised the element in the Republican Party in the borough which has declared for a general reformation in the local organization.

Nine years ago, 1893, occurred the first of those auspicious occasions known in the history of Stetson University, at De Land, Fla., as "Presentation Day." The first occasion was signalized by the gift, on the part of Mr. John B. Stetson of Philadelphia. Penn., of cash and real estate valued at over $125,000.

Two things will strike the public with amazement and apprehension in the history of the disastrous fire of yesterday morning. One is that a massive and costly public structure like the armory of the Seventy-first Regiment could have been so swiftly destroyed by fire, and the other is that the lives of the inmates of a supposedly fireproof hotel could have been sacrificed in a manner apparently so needless.

A DISTINGUISHED French ecclesiastic, on his first visit to Canada, recently made a speech at a dinner in Montreal. He was politely though not enthusiastically received. After the dinner he remarked to his neighbor, the editor of a Montreal paper:

At the beginning of last week those interests in Wall Street who are bearishly inclined professed to be very solicitous over the immediate future of the money market, not alone because of the continued expansion in the loan account, but also because of what was then declared to be the certainty of a resumption of the gold export movement on a larfge scale.

"Poor Things, but Our Own." The only plays that have been added during the last fortnight to the permanent theatrical attractions in New York are Primrose Dockstader's minstrel show at the Victoria and Joseph Hart's "Foxy Grandpa" at the Fourteenth Street Theatre.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The pressure Gov. Odell has brought to bear on pushing through the State Lunacy bill with the avowed intention of reducing institutional expenses brings a serious question before the public: How far may economy be carried without degenerating into parsimony?

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Friday, under the head of "Tenement Bill Hearing," I have read the proceedings before the Assembly Cities Committee in relation to certain proposed amendments to the tenement house law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You are right in disapproving the practices of the Inspectors of the Customs. I have had some experience with these men myself. My experience convinces me that as a class they have become the most uncivil and dastardly set of scoundrels to be found in the "customs" of the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice in to-day's issue of THE TIMES Mr. Bernard Kiernan's letter to you about "Reform Mayors." I will give you my experience in the matter, and you can form your own opinion as to whether the Mayor is responsible, or whether he is handicapped by laws which leave him powerless.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a humble Bible student, it seems to me what stands very much in our way when approaching the subject of "immortality" and other deep teachings of Scripture comes from our indistinct conception of the values of certain terms and words. "Immortality" as it stands as an English word means exemption from dying.

Shortly after the docking of the Kronprinz Wilhelm at the foot of West Thirtyfourth Street yesterday afternoon, Special Treasury Agent Theobald arrested Michael Leinkram, a second cabin passenger, twenty-one years of age, of 32 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, on a charge of attempting to smuggle to this country diamonds worth between $25,000 and $40,000.

The Rev. Edward Niles, pastor of the Bushwick Avenue Reformed Church, at Himrod Street and Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, in a sermon last night made an appeal for the return of the three-platoon system in order that the policemen, when off duty, could attend church.
ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- George M. Palmer of Schoharie, Democratic leader in the Assembly, will offer the following resolution to-morrow night:

Prince Henry of Prussia, representative of his brother the Emperor of Germany at the launching of the latter's American-built yacht, landed here yesterday, and the representatives of the Republic, the State, and the city united with nature in giving this, the third member of European royalty ever to set foot on American soil, a truly royal welcome.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Feb. 23. -- Yesterday's Senatorial fracas is the topic of the day among Senators and discussion is rife concerning its probable outcome. Although the Senate yesterday ordered the reference of the matter to the Committee on Privileges and Elections, it has not yet reached that committe, and no action is probable for some time after it does.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of last Sunday Mr. George B. McClellan sets forth the tariff as an issue to be presented to the people. In support of this he cites the fact that the late President McKinley, "in his last public speech, came out boldly in favor of the Democratic doctrine of commercial treaties."

Golfers from many parts of the country will assemble at Delmonico's on Thursday evening for the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association. The meeting promises to be of far-reaching importance, and a number of radical changes may be adopted for the future government of the National body.

The voyage across the storm-racked Atlantic of the North German Lloyd liner Kronprinz Wilhelm was a pleasant one so far as one passenger was concerned. That particular passenger was Prince Henry of Prussia, and for him at least the combination of wind, rain, and sea that made the voyage an exceedingly disagreeable experience for nearly every one else on board, had no terrors whatever.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Twelve stakes of the Harlem Jockey Club have closed and Secretary Nathanson has announced that a total of 1,309 entries had been received. For stakes having cash entrance fees of $10 and upward each, this average of 109 per stake makes a record. The events and the number of nominations for each are:
BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- Secretary Barton of the American Board has received the following unsigned cablegram, dated Salonika:

Lieut. Commander Alfred B. Fry, Superintendent of Federal Repairs in this city, has had in charge the drafting of a chart of Shooter's Island, where the Kaiser's yacht Meteor will be launched to-morrow morning. The accompanying cut shows the result of this work, and the Lieutenant Commander announced the plans for the launching yesterday afternoon in his office in the Post Office Building.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church from John, xii., 5:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why not solve the bridge question in the following manner: The city should grant the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company a franchise to lay tracks and operate cars on such streets of Manhattan as will seem necessary in the eyes of the Railroad Commission to the relief of the present crush on the bridge.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 23. -- This city at 7:35 to-night got in direct telegraphic touch with the country at large for the first time since 4:10 P.M. Friday. This was accomplished through herculean efforts of the mechanical force of the Western Union Telegraph Company in restoring to working condition a number of wires between Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del., which had been prostrated by the fierce sleet storm of Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our present economic conditions (about which so much -- good and bad -- has been written of late) are the result of nineteenth century changes on the part of capital and labor. Living is not cheap, if your conditions approximately preclude the purchase; neither is it dear, if conditions are favorable.

All of the injured taken from the Park Avenue Hotel during the fire Saturday morning were reported at the various hospitals at a late hour last night to be resting comfortably. All, it was said, had good chances of speedy recovery. The injured are:

Yesterday 'and the day before demonstrated with a force unequaled, perhaps, within the memory of this generation of New Yorkers, the need of keeping the gutters of city streets free of snow, and the enormous amount of inconvenience that is always a possible penalty for neglecting this duty.
