ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 23. -- Commander Richard Wainwright, Superintendent of the Naval Academy, has received the official order from Secretary Long of the navy that the first class of naval graduates are to be prepared to be graduated May 1, something over a month ahead of the prescribed, time.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- An abstract of the fifteenth annual report of the New York State Board of Mediation and Arbitration for nine months ended Sept. 30, 1901, will be transmitted to the Legislature to-morrow by Labor Commissioner John McKin as a part of the first annual, report of the Department of Labor.

For a couple of tours before noon yesterday there was good sleighing in the Park, along Seventh Avenue, and on the Speedway, but as the sun rose higher it turned the snow that had frozen over night into slush, in which the horses floundered and slipped, while the steel-shod runners cut through to the dirt and macadam.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The act of 1899 relating to the civil service of the State of New York provides (Sec. 12) that the exempt class shall consist of the following:

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The conferences of Senators and Assemblymen with Gov. Odell during the past week have done much toward clearing the legislative atmosphere, and there now exists among the members of the dominant party a general understanding relative to the disposition of the more important measures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The solution of the carrying capacity of the Brooklyn Bridge has thus far, it seems to me been wide of the mark. All of the schemes simply beg the question, and at best could only be a makeshift. A larger field of action is absolutely necessary, and this can only be obtained by radical or heroic measures.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Various events during the past week concurred to dampen the temper of the Boerse. Besides the publication of several reports of banks and industrial companies, the weakness of the London Kaffir market and the opinion of Attorney General Knox as to the illegality of the Northern Securities Company merger, gave speculators a warning of caution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to thank you for your editorial this morning in regard to baggage examination, and to add a line on the subject. Having had, as a traveler, considerable experience with the customs authorities in various countries, I think it is safe to say that all baggage examination is disagreeable, or liable to be made so by many little things connected with the actual examination.

From The London Telegraph. An opportunity for the inventor presents itself in Australia. A remedy is wanted for the prickly pear, which has invaded various parts of the island continent, rendering them useless and impenetrable. A Government prize of u5,000 is therefore offered to the person of persons who shall devise means, practipable, within reasonable limits of expense, to extirpate this pest.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Frederick D. Kilburn, State Superintendent of Banks, has completed his annual report on institutions subject to the supervision of the Banking Department, and on Tuesday will submit it to the Legislature. The report in part follows:
Joseph J. Willett of Alabama, in his speech at the sixteenth annual dinner of the Southern Society of the City of New York, held at the Waldorf-Astoria Saturday night, said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recently certain clergymen, in expressing their dissent from the views or Bishop Potter and Dr. Rainsford on the saloon question, have taken occasion to emphasize and give point to their dissent by insinuating, in terms more or less direct, that those two gentlemen belong to the class of bon vivants who are addicted to their cups.

WASHINGTON, Eeb. 23. -- The McKinley memorial exercises in the Halt of Representatives on Thursday overshadow the programme in the House this week. When Prince Henry visits, the Capitol to-morrow to look down on the two houses of Congress he will witness probably an uninteresting spectacle, so far as the popular, branch is concerned, as the House will be working on District of Columbia, business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Medicus" has indeed called attention to a few things which disgrace the civilization of New York City in the eyes of those who have sojourned in English cities. He omits, however, to mention one fertile source of contagion and constant irritation to frequenters of the down-town district.

Day dawned bright and clear yesterday, and until evening the sun poured floods of warm, golden light over the snow-clogged city, bringing some relief from the gloomy days of the past week. Despite the slush from the thawing snow and the splashing from passing street cars and other vehicles great numbers of people ventured out to enJoy the beauty of the day and to greet Prince Henry of Prussia.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Princeton's basket-ball team defeated the Harvard five here last evening in a fast and well-played game by the score of 22 to 14. The work of both teams was unusually full of snap, and at times seemed bordering on rough play.

At last a Democrat has risen to his feet to speak to his party words worth its while to hear and heed. With sure judgment and insight, ex-Senator HILL defines the true issue for his party and points out the path it must follow -- the only issue and the only path that possess the supreme virtue of leading toward victory, not away from it.
We think that the Senate would be Justified in expelling Mr. TILLMAN of South Carolina.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would seem that the gods have willed the destruction of the Democratic Party, for madness is rife among its "leaders" (?) The first stage was reached when Bryan, with his pernicious doctrines, caused thousands of Democrats to vote with the Republicans.

GOV. ODELL, having succeeded in securing the passage bf his bill with, reference to the hospitals for the insane, is new turning his energies to the remodeling of the general system of charities along the same lines.

Interesting discoveries which may have an important bearing upon the origin of the peculiar fire in the Park Avenue Hotel, at the time the Seventy-first Regiment Armory burned, in which eighteen lives were lost and scores injured, were made yesterday by District Attorney Jerome and Fire Chief Croker, during a personal examination of the building.

Prince Henry, after the luncheon on board the Hohenzollern, made a trip to the navy yard, Governors Island, and the battleship Illinois to return the visits of Admiral Barker, Gen. Brooke, and Admiral Evans.

In the untimely death of Mrs. REBECCA SALOME FOSTER, who was numbered among the victims of the hotel fire in, this city on Saturday morning there passed to rest one whose place can never quite be filled. Mrs. FOSTER was one of those good women whose unselfish happiness is derived wholly from kindly and gentle ministrations to souls in trouble.

Help given to those who are suffering and in peril should be prompt and unconditional. These qualities are the very essence of benevolent action. The Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee have carefully excluded them from their plan of Cuban reciprocity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The Senate this evening, after an exciting all-day debate, in which there were echoes of the fight on Saturday between the two South Carolina Senators and indications of another out-break and personal encounter between the two Maryland Senators, passed the Philippine Tariff bill by a strict party vote -- 46 to 26, Messrs.

The man who grave the name of Michael Leinkram when he was arrested at the West Thirty-fourth Street pier on Sunday, after he had disembarked from the Kronprinz Wilhelm, the ocean liner upon which Prince Henry arrived, was arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday morning.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 24 -- Raritan has a nice new jail, with clean furniture, comfortable cots, and steam-heating apparatus, and its fame has spread among the Knights of the Road so that the tramps are going there in droves. The coziness of the place became known to a weary member of the tribe on Saturday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 24 -- The baseball season was begun here this afternoon, when Capt. Steinwender called out the freshmen candidates for preliminary work in the 'Varsity cage. Forty-three men appeared and were given a short hour's work in picking up grounders and in sprinting around the floor.

The general trend of Miss Marina Morton's play, "Her Lord and Master," produced last night at the Manhattan Theatre, would lead one to suppose that it was intended to read a lesson in deportment to American wives and husbands. Miss Indiana Stillwater, (Miss Effei Shannon,) an American heiress, marries Thurster Viscount Canning for his title and position, and goes to live with him in London.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 24 -- Judge Sterling B. Toney of the Circuit Court to-day gave judgment of $232,551 in favor of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad against the Louisville Bridge Company and the Pittsburg, Chicago, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad. On account, however, of the loss of certain papers the Louisville and Nashville loses more than $500,000.

BAYONNE, N.J., Feb. 24 -- Robert Gray, the lighthouse keeper at Bergen Point, is still missing. He left his post for shore in a rowboat nine days ago. He was seeking supplies. Gray's aunt and her three boys waited several days for his return. They were absolutely without food for two days. They hoisted a flag, upside down, in token of their distress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest the letters which are daily printed in your columns regarding the shortcomings of the managers of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company; but not one of your correspondents has noticed or complained of the high-handed action of the officials of the company in regard to its transfer system.

We have already published the letter of the Secretary of War transmitting to the Senate the information in his possession concerning the charges of cruelty, including torture, made against our troops in the Philippines. But the "documents" which the Secretary transmits are worth the serious study of anybody who is inclined to believe in these charges.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The Peking correspondent of The Times (Dr. Morrison) sends word that he has been visiting Niu-Chwang. He was detained en route two days, awaiting a passport from the Russian Admiral permitting him to travel on the Chinese railway.

An audience which filled every part of the spacious Temple Rodeph Sholom, at Sixty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, last night, attended the entertainment of the Young Men's and Women's Culture Society connected with the temple. An address by Bishop Potter was the feature.

Considerable activity was shown in the outside market yesterday, and as a whole prices showed an upward tendency. The few net declines of importance were considerably outnumbered by substantial gains in various parts of the list. Naturally, much attention was directed to Northern Securities because of the expectation that the Supreme Court would hand down its decision in the case of the State of Minnesota against the Northern Securities Company.

Pitch and hitch is a new game which is acquiring considerable popularity in Brooklyn, and a tournament is now in progress between twelve clubs. The game may be called something like indoor quoits. The player has twelve disks which he throws into a receiver, a round rubber cup placed on the floor from eight to ten feet from the player.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- The American Board of Foreign Missions late this afternoon received the following cablegram from its representative, W.W. Peet, dated at Yenidjani, Bulgaria:

Florence Burns was not arraigned yesterday before Justice Mayer in Special Sessions for the continuance of her examination on the charge of causing the death of Walter S Brooks. Her counsel, Foster L. Backus, telephoned to District Attorney Jerome early in the morning that he had an important case on trial in Brooklyn, and that it would be impossible for him to come to Manhattan.

Three horsese were instantly killed and half a dozen more made frantic by electric shocks, totally demoralizing a funeral on the way to Holy Cross Cemetery, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. Several persons were shocked, too, but none seriously enough to need a physician's attention.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 24 -- The announcement of the United States Supreme Court's decision against the application of the State of Minnesota for leave to file a suit against the Northern Securities Company was received in this city to-day without surprise. President Hill of the Northern Securities Company refused to discuss the opinion of the court, contenting himself with the remark that it was no more than he had anticipated several weeks ago.

MONTE CARLO, Feb. 24 -- Play in the International Chess Masters' Tournament was resumed this morning, when the thirteenth round of the contest was governed by Round 8 of the Berger schedule, bringing the players together in the following order:

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 -- The continued strength of the Consolidated Gas issues and of the United Electric Light and Power Company's preferred stock was the feature of the trading, and caused a renewal of the rumor that a deal between the two is pending. This merger, if it occurs, will inure to the benefit of the United Railways, because the last-named company owns the controlling interest in the Electric Light Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The TillmanMcLaurin incident in the Senate Saturday figured as conspicuously at the White House to-day as in the Senate. Three phases of the problem that grew out of Mr. Tillman's assault on Mr. McLaurin attracted considerable attention.
ORDER OF TO-DAY'S EVENTS. S.A.M. -- With the President, and their attending suites, the Prince will leave the Pennsylvania Railroad Station in Jersey City for Shooter Island.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Gov. Odell and the Republican leaders in the Legislature are on the way to reach an amicable understanding with the State Board of Charities with regard to legislation to bring about a change in the management of the State's charitable institutions.
BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- Hugues le Roux discussed Zola in his lecture before the Cercle Francais this afternoon.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- The Supreme Court to-day construed the Voorhees Two Per Cent. Franchise Tax act of last year to exempt from its operation those public utility companies that hold special charters granted to them by the Legislature before the passage of general laws for the incorporation of such companies.

The recommendation of Mr. SWANSTROM, President of the Borough of Brooklyn, that the tunnel under the East River be built for four tracks' instead of two, as proposed by the Rapid Transit Commission, at least merits consideration before the work has gone too far to permit a change of plan.

The prosecution in the case of Albert T. Patrick, accused of the murder of the millionaire, William Marsh Rice, expect within the next few days to put on the witness stand a person not heretofore mentioned in the course of the trial. The testimony of this witness, the prosecution believes, will tend greatly to corroborate Valet Jones's story.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The United States Supreme Court to-day delivered its opinion in the case of Minnesota versus the Northern Securities Company in the application of the State to file a bill of complaint in that court. The opinion was read by Justice Shiras, and the motion for leave to file the bill was denied, on the ground that this court is without jurisdiction.

It is a cause for sincere regret that the lawlessness which so often characterizes the conduct of undergraduates, and of which we found occasion to speak somewhat plainly in the case of the Princeton students who defaced a cherished historical monument, is not always confined to mischief perpetrated upon public and private property.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The German mania raging at present, not perhaps so much among the American people as in the American press, causes not only our "nursery" journals, but also papers possessed of so much sound sense as THE NEW YORK TIMES, to perform the most erratic antics in view of the visit of a German Prince.

The status of the portico of the Pabst Hotel, which in Forty-second Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue squats on public property worth $40,000, was settled Nov. 18 last by the late Supreme Court Justice David McAdam, in the suit to compel the taking down of the obstruction, brought by the city against Charles Thorley and James B. Regan.

President E.R. Thomas of the Evansville and Terre Haute Railroad yesterday confirmed the report that he is to resign his office and that he is to retire from the Board of Directors of that road. Gen. Samuel Thomas and H.M. Work will also resign.

The features yesterday in connection with the condition of the streets were the admission by Commissioner Woodbury's department that many of the thoroughfares are in bad shape and the announcement that a wholesale attempt is being made to defraud Contractor Maillie by the use of counterfeit tickets.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- The supplies of money were increased to-day through Government disbursements, but tenders for u3,000,000 in twelve months' Treasury bills (the applications amounting to u7,899,000) increases the demand. Discounts were firm. The Bank of England advanced the buying price of German gold coin to 76s 4 1/2d.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Assemblyman Josiah G. Newcomb of the Twenty-third District of New York introduced in the Assembly to-night the Excise bill drafted by the Citizens' Committee formed in New York six weeks ago to consider the question of Sunday opening. This committee consisted of Col. Willis L. Ogden, Dr. Felix Adler, Wheeler H. Peckham, John G. Agar, and William R. Corwine.

Whether it would have been right for the President to withdraw the invitation to meet Prince HENRY at dinner extended to Senator TILLMAN of South Carolina as a member of the Naval Committee of that body, simply by reason of the rowdyish behavior of that statesman on the floor of the Senate, is a question of social casuistry upon which people may differ.

Investigation of the Park Avenue Hotel disaster yesterday resulted in a disagreement between the Fire Marshal and the Building Department officials. The dispute arose over the question of responsibility for the equipment of hotels and places of public resort with fire-escapes, appliances for fighting fire, and all other safeguards to prevent the loss of life and property.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- The narratives of the reception of Prince Henry at New York take up from one to two pages in to-day's issues of the principal German newspapers. No foreign event has ever been reported in the German press with such detail as is the welcome of New York to the brother of the Emperor.

It is worth noting, though, of course, it is not at all necessary to call to it the attention of our State Department, that the reported attempt of Germany to obtain exclusive mining privileges in ShanTung is clearly opposed to the rights of all the Powers as defined in treaties and as interpreted in the recent letter of Secretary HAY.

BOSTON, Feb. 24 -- The money market shows little or no change, so far as rates are concerned, although there is slightly firmer tone in evidence. Money rates, bank clearances, balances and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as follows: Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 5, 8, and 10 cents discount.
X.B. Drexilius has been appointed Cincinnati agent of the Union Assurance Society of London.

The usual Lenten entertainments Prevailed yesterday. There was the meeting of the Monday Evening Bowling Club, and there were also meetings of various sewing classes. In the afternoon Mrs. Dunlap Hopkins gave a large musicale. The matinee performance of the "Rheingold" was very well attended, and the audience at "Les Huguenots" in the evening was also a good one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- The dinner given to Prince Henry by President Roosevelt at the White House tonight closed the honors bestowed to-day on the royal visitor by official Washington. The affair was on an elaborate scale, and brought together a distinguished company.

The Hon. Mr. GROSVENOR of Ohio is indulging in very just and proper denunciation of the shoddy makers, who oppose the bill to compel them to stamp all goods made of their product with the name of the material.

As Wall Street had confidently anticipated, the United States Supreme Court decision in the Minnesota Northern Securities case was handed down yesterday in favor of the corporation. But there was in the market no such jubilation as had been popularly forecast -- prior to President Roosevelt's announcement that the Government would proceed against this same corporation on an independent basis, alleging infraction of the National anti-trust law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not want to add to the troubles of the Democracy brought on it by the vagaries of the Populistic National Conventions which have twice presumed to speak in its name, but I wishe to point out one of the errors left in the minds of some of its representative men by those unfortunate Populistic utterances.

Immediately after the conference of the four baseball clubs loyal to A.J. Spalding at Pittsburg on Saturday a telegram was sent to Mr. Spalding apprising him of the stand taken. The following is Mr. Spalding's answer:

The properties 202 to 210 West Thirtyfourth Street, south side, 60 feet west of Seventh Avenue, have been sold by the various owners. The combined frontages amount to 91 feet, the rear lines being irregular. The purchaser's name could not be learned yesterday.

There was nothing symbolic, though for a half hour or more a problem was involved in a new version of "Lost in New York," played by Mrs. Patrick Campbell yesterday morning. The English actress arrived from Toronto at an early hour on a West Shore train. The company, attendants, and a retinue of no less than three managerial functionaries immediately boarded a Twenty-third Street ferry and arrived safely on this side of the river.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 24 -- A strong and significant buying movement in Union Traction was the feature of the local market. Under the sharp demand the stock made a new high record price on its present movement, advancing strongly to 38 3/8 by noon and making a further gain in the later trading.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial, "For a General Staff," and was not wholly unprepared for the views expressed, though I cannot agree with them.
THE SUNDAY MAGAZINE SUPPLEMENT OF THE NEW YORK TIMES has, as one of its features, a Series of anecdotes by or about well-known men grouped under the caption of "The Man in the Street."

VICTOR, Col., Feb. 24 -- Cripple Creek is in a state of terror owing to a preconcerted attack upon all the leading assay offices doing business in the district, beginning at 3 o'clock this morning and following in rapid succession six explosions wrecked as many assay offices in the centers, ranging from Victor to Cripple Creek, and up to Gold Field.

In the tournament of the Harlem Navy Bowling League last night, the Metropolitan Rowing Club bowlers defeated the teams of the Atalanta Boat Club and the Dauntless Rowing Club. The Atalantas also defeated the Dauntless five.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 25. -- Young Corbett," "William H. Rothwell, and Terry McGovern were matched here to-night for a twenty-five-round boxing contest, to take place before the club offering the best inducements, on or before Oct. 15, 1902. Both men agreed to weigh not more than 127 pounds at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of the contest.

The launch yesterday was the visible occasion and incentive of the visit of Prince HENRY of Prussia. And so, on every account, it was particularly desirable that it should pass off very well. It is curious how sensitive we all feel on an occasion of that kind, when our own country is evidently on show and undergoing criticism from other countries.

The Will of Charles L. Tiffany, the head of the house of Tiffany Co., who died Feb. 18 at an advanced age, wag filed yesterday for probate in the office of the Surrogate. By this will, which was executed on June 30, 1886, Mr. Tiffany divided his entire estate between his Widow and his four children.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Court of Appeals to-day ordered that "The" Allen, Charles Bennett, William Lewis, Arthur Moore, William Campbell, and Robert Allen, who were arrested on April 9, 1901, on the charge of conducting a poolroom at 80 Sixth Avenue, New York City, be discharged.

A case which some lawyers say is without parallel in the legal history of the New York State courts was made known yesterday, when Justice MacLean of the Supreme Court signed the order to allow William Harkness, seventy years old, to adopt as his daughter Elizabeth Holland Richardson, forty-seven years old, his housekeeper.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- The Landon bill, which imposes a tax of 1 cent for two square feet or fraction thereof on the surface of every poster exposed to public view upon any land or attached to any building or other structure erected in the State, was up for a hearing to-day before the Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment.

The valet, Charles F. Jones, who charges Albert T. Patrick, now on trial, with instigating his self-confessed murder of the millionaire, William Marsh Rice, declared yesterday on the witness stand that Patrick agreed in the Tombs to commit suicide with him, and then illustrated how he endeavored to keep his part of the agreement by plunging a knife, given to him by Patrick, into his throat.

Joseph Wilfred Blondin, otherwise, Joseph Morrau and Joseph Barnard, the French-Canadian, who last June, when his wife's dismembered body was found near Chelmsford, not far from Boston, Mass., fled and has been looked for by the police of the United States and Canada, was arrested yesterday morning in the main corridor of Police Headquarters.

The annual report of the Lackawanna Railroad for the year ended Dec. 31. 1901, was made public after the company's annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. At this meeting the old Board of Managers was re-elected, and the board in turn re-elected the old officials.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law, as amended, provides that a 25-cent stamp shall be placed on all conveyances where the consideration or value exceeds $2,500 and is under $3,000. Twenty-five cents additional is required for each $500 of consideration over $3.000.

In making the date of the one hundredth centenary of Victor Hugo's birth the occasion for the production of Paul Potter's version of "Notre Dame" at Daly's tonight, Daniel Frohman's company will provide an opportunity for mellow reminiscence to those few playgoers whose experience dates back as far as the old Bowery Theatre.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- The first message from Miss Ellen M. Stone, the missionary, to her family and friends since her release was received to-night by her brother, Charles A. Stone. Prior to the receipt of this message Mr. Stone received a dispatch dated Salonika, from M. Gargiulo, as follows:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 25. -- William Hoey, fifty-nine years old, committed suicide at his home here Sunday, but the fact did not become known until yesterday. Mr. Hoey was a son of Mrs. John Hoey, the widow of John Hoey, one of the founders of the Adams Express Company. Mrs. Hoey was twice married.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Col. Abraham Gruber appeared before the Assembly Excise Committee to-day in opposition to the excise bill introduced by Assemblyman Bennet, the Representative of the Twenty-first Assembly District, of which Col. Gruber is the Republican leader. Mr. Bennet's bill provides for local option by election districts, and also for the repeal of the provision of the Raines law which gives to hotels the right to dispense liquor on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Republican Senators to-day got out of what they considered a decidedly ticklish position by resorting to what the Democrats characterize as a very "cheap expedient." The Democratic Senators intended to confront the Senate again to-day with the question of the status of the two South Carolina Senators who had been declared to be in contempt because of their fight on the floor of the Senate last Saturday.

Probably one of the most remarkable gatherings that was ever collected in a church of this city crowded into Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, yesterday morning, to attend the funeral services for Mrs. Rebecca Salome Foster, who has been known for many years as the "Tombs Angel."

History would give a good deal to know which particular lunatic it was who started the dancing craze which affected whole communities in Europe during the later Middle Ages. But the lunacy that bids persons ascribe the works of SHAKESPEARE to any one except WILLIAM can be traced to the late IGNATIUS DONNELLY, and concerning him opinions differ, whether he was moved by belief or a thirst for notoriety.

LIABILITY FOR HARBORING VICIOUS DOGS. -- As Mrs. Lena G. Austin, with her mother, was driving past the house of Rush Bartlett in a one-horse cart, a dog ran out and attacked the horse, frightening him and causing him to run away. Mrs. Austin was thrown out of the cart and received severe injuries.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read on the second page of to-day's TIMES "For the first time the freedom of the city will be bestowed upon a European of royal rank. The last to receive this freedom was the Marquis de Lafayette in 1824."
CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- The Lake Shore Railroad proposes to elevate every mile of track that it has within the limits of Chicago. Right down to and beyond the Calumet River the tracks will go up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Republican members of the House of Representatives met in conference at 8:15 o'clock to-night to consider the question of Cuban reciprocity, the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee having reached an agreement to grant reciprocity concessions of about 20 per cent.

LONDON, Feb. 25. -- Money was in brisk demand to-day, in connection with the settlement, and rates were firm. Discounts were quiet. Business on the Stock Exchange was quiet and practically featureless. Operators were watching the outcome of the settlement. The predominance of bull accounts in Kafirs, some of them risky, having been held over from last account, formed an element of uneasiness.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- While the Senate was acting as a Committee of the Whole this, morning, the Stranahan bill, permitting the City of New York to grant a franchise to the Pennsylvania Railroad to tunnel the Hudson River from New Jersey and to maintain terminals on Manhattan and Long Island, was moved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25. -- The Controller of the Currency to-day appointed National Bank Examiner J.W. Delay receiver or the First National Bank of Belmont, Ohio, upon telegraphic advice from the Directors of the bank that they had closed the doors.

ALBANY, Feb. 25. -- Senator Trainor today introduced a bill designed to compel the placing of alarm bells throughout hotels, lodging houses, , by which all occupants may be given immediate warning of fire in the buildings.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Government was defeated in the House of Commons last night.

M. L. Hess have sold to Josef Steiner the irregular plot at the northeast corner of University Place and Eleventh Street, having frontages of 114 feet on the former and 58 feet on the latter, and containing about 3,100 square feet. By this purchase Mr. Steiner has rounded out a plot of about 20,000 square feet, various parts of which he has acquired from time to time through the same brokers.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 25. -- The strength of International Trust to-day was one of the most striking features of the day's trading. It jumped 3 1/2 points, and closed strong at that figure. The advance is proceeding on merit, being more in the nature of a recovery to normal value than to a new advance.

In the tournament, of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League last night the New York Athletic Club won from the Century Wheelmen and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club won from the Catholic Club. In the Harlem Navy League Capt. Wagner's team of the Wyanoke Boat Club won two games, and are now tied with the Harlem Rowing Club for second place. The scores:

The men who inscribed the "strange symbols" on the Democratic banner at Chicago and Kansas City will fight hard against the restoration of the old party legends. Mr. BRYAN frankly, openly and squarely sets up the principles of the platforms on which he went to defeat against the platform of tariff reform which ex-Senator DAVID B. HILL commended to the Democracy in his Manhattan Club speech.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 25. -- Although it has been known for two weeks that Prince Henry would visit the United States Naval Academy next Friday, no action yet has teen taken by the Legislature or State authorities toward inviting him to visit the historic State Capitol, in which George Washington resigned his commission in the American Army.

Prince Henry was the guest of honor at a dinner given by Mayor Low at the Metropolitan Club last evening. The clubhouse was elaborately decorated. Eight thousand American Beauty roses were used in the table display alone, and there were many other features which made the banquet one of the most notable ever given in this city:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 25. -- A coalition has been formed between Isaac Lobe Straus, the anti-organization Democratic fighter, with his four friends of Anne Arundel County, and all the Republicans in the House by which they absolutely control the Situation and can dead-lock or defeat the "gerrymander" or any other political legislation desired by the Gorman managers.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were smaller than they had been recently, and in very few stocks did the day's trading develop price movements of importance. The market was inclined to drift along the lines which it had been following for some days, and there was little evidence or outside interest in the market.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 25. -- Winthrop Rutherfurd, who recently married Miss Helen Morton, has rented of Dr. Clement Cleveland, the cottage on Catherine Street for the coming Summer. The cottage is located in a quiet neighborhood, rather apart from the fashionable thoroughfares. But last Summer a considerable number of the cottages there were occupied by members of the fashionable set. Mr. and Mrs. Rutherfurd will be very popular to Newport society.

In specialties yesterday's market was strong; various stocks moved in groups. The local tractions, led by Brooklyn Rapid Transit, had increased activity. The group of steel stocks made better showing. A variety of specially situated industrials were conspicuous and improved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So the great American Republic is dead and we have instead an empire devoted to financial ends merely! At least, I infer as much from a telegraphic item in respect to our present status: "Millions for the trusts, but not one cent for honor."

It will not introduce a discordant note into the agreeable harmony of international relations to consider whether, in the recount of our obligations to Germany, we are not likely to overlook the fact that Germany's obligation to one who may be almost entitled to rank as the cleverest of Americans is greater than that which this country owes to any individual German or citizen of German parentage.

Coroner Goldenkranz yesterday afternoon continued his investigation into the deaths through the fire in the Park Avenue Hotel. Among those who gave sworn statements were Fire Chief George Ross of the Eighth Battalion of the Fire Department, Superintendent of Buildings Stewart, Inspectors Miller, O'Connor, Sanderson, and Louis of the Department of Buildings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would it not be work of great benefit for a paper with the standing and progressiveness of THE NEW YORK TIMES to urge and demand the adoption of proper heating and ventilating systems for our surface cars? I note with satisfaction that a bill is before the Legislature compelling the inclosing of platforms, but it should go further and compel companies to heat their cars.

BERLIN, Feb. 25. -- All day long to-day crowds stared at portraits of President Roosevelt and Prince Henry which hung side by side in front of a newspaper office on Unter den Linden. Part of the time the crowd was so dense that the police had to clear a way for traffic.

That the United States is now receiving a considerable and increasing number of undesirable immigrants is generally conceded. That this class of immigration should in some effective manner be restricted is unquestionably the general sentiment of the country without distinction of class.

In the schedule of Columbia outdoor track contests announced yesterday by Marcellus H. Dodge, manager of the team, no dual meet with Princeton appears. This will be the first time in many years that these two teams have not met on the track. The ostensible reason for the failure to arrange the usual contests is because of inability to come to a satisfactory agreement for dates.

The freedom of the City of New York was conferred upon Prince Henry yesterday afternoon by Mayor Low in the City Hall. For the first time in the history of New York a visitor of royal blood was welcomed within the portals of the seat of the City Government and the hand of fellowship extended by the civic officials.

BOSTON, Feb. 25. -- The arrest of Blondin, the suspected wife murderer, ends one of the most persistent searches ever made by police authorities, especially those of New York and this city. The man has been a fugitive since last June, when the body of his wife was found.

The Prince and his suite left Sherry's about 3:30 o'clock, a flourish of umpets serving to give notice to the police to clear the thoroughfare. This the did will and quickly. Preceded by mounted police and troopers, the Prince and his party hastened down Fifth Avenue to Thirty-fourth Street, and thence to the North River pier, where the Prince and his suite boarded the Hohenzollern.

Policy and policy players figured largely yesterday in the proceedings in the Criminal Courts Building. There was a serious difference of opinion between the District Attorney's office and Judge Warren W. Foster. In addition the light sentences imposed by Judge Newburger upon the men who had pleaded guilty under the antipolicy law angered the officers of the Anti-Policy League.

The banquet given to the press of the United States by the New York Staats-Zeitung in honor of Prince Henry of Prussia last night at the Waldorf-Astoria was attended by more than 1,200 editors and publishers from every part of the country, and gave the royal guest a favorable opportunity of getting in touch with one of the principal bulwarks of a republic.

MANILA, Feb. 26. -- Gen. Smith, in command of the United States troops on the Island of Samar, cables that Lieut, Strebler's scouts have captured Gen. Lucban, the notorious leader of the Samar rebels, and taken him to Laguan, capital of a small island of that name, north of and adjoining Samar.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was somewhat more varied than it Had been on Tuesday, and at the same time there was a considerable increase in activity. The copper group, in particular, showed considerable animation and most of the issues were more active than they had been on any day recently.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Prince Henry of Prussia will be the guest of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt at dinner to-morrow evening. The party to meet him will be an exceedingly small one, and the occasion as informal as the rank of the imperial visitor and dignity of his host will permit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections was in session on the Tillman-McLaurin case practically all day. The committee met at 10:30 this morning, and when it was found that an agreement was impossible, the Senate decided to adjourn immediately after meeting.

Stock Exchange business was dull and quotations for most of the list soft yesterday. Announcement of the engagement of $1,500,000 gold for export was much paraded by the pessimists who are never done worrying over an apprehension that the United States may be completely drained of its resources.

One of the most notable incidents in the history of New York occurred yesterday at Sherry's, where Prince Henry of Prussia sat down at luncheon with more than a hundred of the leaders in finance, commerce, and industry in the New World. The Prince entered thoroughly into the spirit of the luncheon, and contributed largely to the success of the function.

-- Our good -- we are tempted to say "unco' guid," but will refrain -- neighbor, The Evening Post, joins, as is its right, in the chorus of rejoicing over the abolition of pigeon slaughters that is ascending from every part of the State where common decency has an abiding place. "The Evening Post," it says, "takes leave to congratulate itself, upon the occasion of this victory, that it has consistently opposed that barbarous business.

The interior of the Arion Clubhouse, at Fifty-ninth Street and Park Avenue, was a veritable conservatory, prepared for a reception to Prince Henry last evening. In the main halls leading from the Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street entrances were banks of palms, ferns, and flowers, here and there the American flag and German colors appearing.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Senate to-day passed the bill introduced by Senator Stranahan giving the Pennsylvania Railroad Company the right to tunnel under the Hudson River and the East River and across the Island of Manhattan. A bill, similar in every respect, introduced by Mr. Kelsey, also passed the Assembly.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 26. -- The jury in the case of Henry A. Taylor, charged with conspiracy to bribe in connection with the water scandal, returned a verdict of guilty to-night as charged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have never heretofore availed myself of the newspapers to express my views upon any subject, but present conditions in my neighborhood at the present moment are so exasperating that I cannot avoid making the attempt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The Department of Justice has completed the bill which is to be filed in the suit against the Northern Securities Company. It will be filed on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week, either in Minnesota or New Jersey, but probably in New Jersey.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 -- St. Cuthbert and Kafir were the winning favorites to-day. The Stewards have reinstated the horses Divertissement, Miss Ransom, and Falella. Weather clear, track good. Summary:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 26. -- The make-up of the committee which will represent Yale in the coming negotiations with Harvard was announced to-night. There will be four graduates on the committee, Walter Camp, Anson Phelps Stokes, H. B. Sargent, and Prof. T. D. Woolsey. Mr. Camp is Yale's athletic adviser.
SALONIKA, Feb. 26. -- Miss Stone and Mme. Tsilka and her baby arrived here last night, well and cheerful. They received the members of the Anglo-American community in the railway carriage.

The day after the entertainment at the Opera House did not present many special features. The Knickerbocker Bowling Club met in the afternoon at its hall and the Knickerbocker Sewing Class at the residence of Miss Lee in Gramercy Park. The Wednesday Evening Amusement Club met at the house of Stewart Woodford Eames.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A. B. Colburn's suggestion in this morning's TIMES, that hotel proprietors hang up in each room a diagram showing the means of egress, , is already embodied in law. Section 762 of the Greater New York charter provides that:

The torchlight procession of about 8,500 men belonging to 320 German societies which marched past the Arion Society's Clubhouse last evening was without a hitch and distinctly spectacular, but was under circumstances that militated against the paraders and Prince Henry. The line of march was Park Avenue, from Seventy-second to Fifty-seventn Street, to Fifth Avenue, to Twenty-sixth Street.

Joseph Gachet, seventy years old, who for the last forty years had served the Winthrop family as butler, shot himself through the head in his room at the home of Mrs. Mary J. Winthrop, the widow of Henry R. Winthrop, at 35 West Twentieth Street, yesterday morning. The old servant had been sick with a painful malady for a long time, and was under the care of Dr. Francis Delafield of 12 West Thirty-second Street.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 26. -- Indications at midnight are that the big ice gorge in the Allegheny River may let go early to-morrow morning or some time during the day. The first sign of a general break-up in the gorge occurred about noon to-day just below Kittaning. The ice cracked in a number of places at this point, making cracks that extended from bank to bank.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 26. -- The G. B. S. Brewing issues were in large demand today, resulting in good fractional gains all through the group. The buying was based upon good business results, and was little affected by the late profit-taking. The first mortgage bonds gained 3/4, the income bonds 3/4, and the common stock 7/8.

The death of Mr. MARQUAND, following so closely upon that of Mr. TIFFANY, recalls freshly and strongly our municipal obligations to our rich merchants. Both were public benefactors in the artistic way, but Mr. TIFFANY benefited the community by setting the artistic standard by setting and maintaining which he made his fortune, Mr. MARQUAND by the manner in which he dispersed his.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Mortgage Tax bill now being considered by the State Legislature does not seem to be attracting the attention worthy so important a measure, and it is feared by many that the proposed law will not be enacted unless more demand therefor is shown.

The general collapse of the telephone and telegraph communication over a large part of the country, and notably between New York and Philadelphia, as the result of the recent storms, again calls attention to the lack of enterprise on the part of the corporations enjoying these valuable franchises in failing to make their systems storm-proof.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Money was in strong demand to-day, but its scarcity provoked an indisposition to discount freely. On the Stock Exchange the tone was fairly good, though there was an absence, of business, beyond the settlement. Consols were easier. Americans were helped by New York over-night advices and opened slightly above parity.

The effort of Mr. W. H. SAYWARD, Secretary of the National Association of Builders, to provide a practical method of settling the ever recurring difficulties between employers and workmen in the building trades without the interruption of strikes has now reached a stage in which it needs only the assent of the labor unions immediately interested to become operative as an interesting and promising experiment.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 26. -- Senator McCarter's bill to have the State money on deposit in banks draw interest was opposed when it came up on third reading in the Senate to-day. After much debate Senator McCarter consented to have the bill go over until next week in order that the amendments might be prepared to meet the objections that had been made against the measure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: South Carolina, like poor Kansas, is subject to attacks of political spino-menigitls. During these periods of lunacy it can raise more merry hallelujah than all the other States combined. Not very many years ago, during one of its spasms of idiocy, it put aside that splendid type of the gallant Southern soldier and chivalrous gentleman.

The White Star steamship Oceanic arrived from Liverpool yesterday in the good time of 6 days 6 hours and 13 minutes. Among the cabin passengers were Sir W. Martin Conway, the well-known mountain climber; Sir Philip Burne-Jones, the British artist, who is a cousin of Rudyard Kipling; Gerald Duckworth, the London publisher; C. J. Catto of Toronto, and E. K. Spinney of Nova Scotia.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- Prominent German merchants, sociologists, and educators will be among the members of the American-German League for the preservation and promotion of mutual understanding and friendly relations between Germany and the United States. Steps have already been taken for the formation of the league.

But two witnesses were examined yesterday at the hearing of Florence Burns, accused of the murder of Walter S. Brooks, held before Justice Mayer of the Court of Special Sessions. They were George Washington, the colored bellboy of the Glen Island Hotel, and Arthur C. Weibles, the guardman on the Brooklyn elevated train.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill was advanced to third reading in the Senate to-day. An amendment offered by Senator Hennessy to exempt building and loan associations from the provisions of the measure was defeated, and the motion of Senator Foley to strike out the enacting clause was voted down by 27 to 15.

The report of the committee of the British Board of Trade to investigate the vibration induced in adjacent buildings by trains running through the tunnel of the Central London Railway has interest in view of the fact that unless our subway engineers have builded better than they knew, we are likely to have a similar problem to investigate, and deal with in parts of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26. -- Irregular reports from New York, due to interruption of telegraphic service, kept the local market still in a state of uncertainty regarding the arbitrage stocks to-day. The ticker service, however, was better than yesterday, and there was acorresponding improvement in the trading.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A. dispatch received to-day at the State Department from Minister Leishman at Constantinople announced that Miss Stone was free and at Strumitsa; that she was much fatigued and worn out, and would have to rest awhile, but that she would start on her return journey to-day or to-morrow.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Senator Stranahan in the Senate and Assemblyman Kelsey in the Assembly to-day introduced two bills amending the revised charter of New York City with regard to the salaries and classification of city employes. Mayor Low, in a letter addressed to Assistant Corporation Counsel Whitman, who is stationed here, says the bills are of vital importance to the City Administration.

Columbia's novice track athletes held the last of their weekly series of games open to men who have never represented the University in public competition in the gymnasium yesterday afternoon. On the basis of the winners in these contests, and taking into consideration the records made in the previous sets of games, the university championships for novices were awarded.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- Prices opened firm on the Boerse to-day, but later eased somewhat owing to the absence of transactions. The undertone remained good. The unconfirmed rumor on the Boerse that the King of Servia had been assassinated made little impression on business.

BOSTON, Feb. 26. -- Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as below: Clearing House rate,2 1/2 per cent. New York funds, 10 cents discount. Call funds, 3 to 3 1/2 per cent. Time money, 3 3/4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Clearing House exchanges, $24,666,189; balances, $2,200,885.

Mrs. William Faversham, wife of the actor, has brought suit for absolute divorce, through her attorneys, Howe Hummel. Application will be made to Justice Henry Bischoff, in the Supreme Court, to-morrow, for the appointment of a referee to hear testimony in the case. The plea is brought on statutory grounds.

John Doyle was signed yesterday to play first base and Captain the New York baseball team, and John Ganzel was released. Doyle obtained his release from the Chicago National League team Tuesday, and immediately came to this city to open negotiations with the New York Club. After signing the contract he left for his home in Holyoke, Mass.

The Kingston Avenue Hospital for contagious diseases in Brooklyn has been inundated, and although three engines supplied by the Fire Department have been at work since yesterday afternoon pumping out the water, it is not believed that communication will be established between the institution and the outer world until Saturday, except by boat.
J. N. Kalley Son have sold for Lucy Buhler to H. Liebmann, the four-story buildings at the southeast corner of William and Duane Streets, on a plot about 51 by 38.

The visit of Prince Henry to the box of Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt on Tuesday evening at the gala opera performance and his marked attention to her have, been matters of current discussion since that event. The recognition was so marked and the signaling out of this young matron so obvious that it took many by surprise.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 26. -- A large business deal was accomplished to-day by Attorney John De Witt of Senator Foraker's law firm. Mr. De Witt sold to J. W. Reed, a New York capitalist, the interest of Herman Bartels in the Fairmont Brewing Company. Mr. Bartels held all but four shares of the $300,000 capital stock.

In the tournament of the Athletic 'Bowling League on the New York Athletic Club alleys last night, the home team won three games from the Jersey City Club. The Friendship Boat Club won their seventh and eighth consecutive victories in the Harlem Navy League series, and made a new high team score of 985.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The recall of the Kelsey bill is taken here as indicating that the effort to place the designation of Supreme Court Judges within the power of the Governor is to be abandoned. When this bill was passed, it was denounced by its opponents as a bold attempt to give the Governor control over the judiciary.
NEWPORT, Feb. 26. -- Col. and Mrs. Reginald Norman and Mr. and Mrs. Bradford Norman have gone to Europe.

The Heffley School boys triumphed over Princeton University at hockey last night after a dull, uninteresting game at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn. The Brooklyn lads scored five goals in the first half and added as many more to these in the second half, while Princeton was unable to do any scoring during the entire contest.

BERLIN, Feb. 26. -- At a meeting of the Kiel Yacht Club, held to-day, at which Admiral von Senden-Bibran, Chief of the Imperial Marine Cabinet, represented Emperor William, it was decided to increase the number and value of the racing trophies to be competed for at the Kiel regatta next Summer.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Speaking upon a question of personal privilege. Assemblyman McKeown of Kings County to-day made an announcement in the Assembly which was at once taken up by the politicians as having much political significance. Mr. McKeown's. objection to the consideration of a political resolution introduced by minority leader Palmer, Monday night, had led to the impression that there was lack of harmony among the Democratic members.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Times says the recent student troubles at Kieff began in a theatre, where leaflets announcing a student demonstration were scattered among the audience. The demonstration commenced in the streets on the signal of a student, who was joined by fifty students and workingmen armed with clubs and other weapons.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Senate to-day, by a vote of 34 to 15, selected William Nottingham Republican for the vacancy in the State Board of Regents. The Assembly chose the same candidate by a vote of 100 to 29. The Democratic candidate in both houses was John Jasper Superintendent of Schools in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Nobody undertakes to predict with certainty the outcome of the struggle that is going on in the House over the Cuban question. One difficulty the forecasters run up against is their inability to say just who are the parties to the contest that opened last night in the conference of the Republican members of the House.

Golf matters of National interest will be discussed and determined this evening at Delmonico's, when the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association convenes there shortly after 8 o'clock. The election of officers for the coming year is one of the least important things that will claim the attention of the delegates.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- The Raines bill, to compel the publication of petitions for independent nominations, came up for a hearing to-day before the Senate Committee of Judiciary W. A. Shortt and Horace E. Deming appeared on behalf of the City Club and the Citizens' Union, to protest against the passage of the bill.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Oscar Hammerstein of New York was to-day fined $3 by Justice Maddox of the Supreme Court, for having failed to obey a subpoena, served on him to testify in a suit here. Mr. Hammerstein's excuse, when arrested a few days ago, was that he was compelled on the same day as the hearing here to be in the United States Court in New York.

Controller Grout yesterday made public a statement showing the financial standing of the City of New York on Jan. 1, 1902, and also many important facts about the debt limit and the condition at the public improvements planned or in course of completion.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 27. -- The G.B.S. Brewing issues were once again the bull leaders in to-day's market. Investment and speculative crowds were both buyers, and pushed the bonds and stock higher. Interest centred around the common stock chiefly, which scored an advance of 1 1/8 points.

The Society for Instruction in First Aid to the Injured held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at the United Charities Building, 287 Fourth Avenue. Charles H. Marshall presided, and presented a report regarding the work of the past year which he considered very encouraging. Instruction had been given to forty-five classes, the students numbering 650 men and 256 women and girls.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Most of the prizes awarded to-day in the annual bench show of the New Jersey Kennel Association were in the beagle classes. Several Newark and Jersey City dogs also received awards in the terrier classes.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Assembly Committee on Canals this afternoon favorably reported a bill introduced by Mr. Lewis of Oswego this morning, providing an appropriation of $37,200,000 for canal improvement. The Lewis bill is exactly similar to the bill introduced by Senator Davis in the Senate and by Assemblyman Weekes in the Assembly except that it contains an appropriation of $5,400,000, for the Oswego feeder.

George W. Schurman, who is acting as District Attorney in the absence of William Travers Jerome, who is in Washington, said yesterday that the rumor that Mr. and Mrs. Burns, father and mother of Florence Burns, are in New Brunswick, N.J., to avoid answering subpoenas issued by the District Attorney, had not been investigated.

The old home of the Shawnee Club, the Tammany Hall organization of the Twenty-ninth. Assembly District, at 121 East Eighty-third Street, was formally converted into the Greater New York Democracy clubhouse of this district last night, in the presence of Mayor Low, Borough President Cantor, Deputy Controller N. Taylor Phillips, and other city officials.

Details will be found in another column relative to the sale of the northwest cornel of Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street by the Century Realty Company to the New York Ophthalmic and Aural Institute.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Feb. 27. -- O'Donovan Rossa, the celebrated Fenian agitator, is dying at St. Francis's Hospital of blood poisoning. At noon an operation was performed, taking off the large toe of the left foot.

The two bills introduced in the Legislature at the request of Mayor Low were the subject of discussion among the politicians yesterday. The bills, if they become laws, will so amend the Greater New York Charter as to take away from the Board of Aldermen the control and regulation of the salaries of city officials.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Secretary of the Treasury Shaw was the principal speaker at the banquet of the National Business League held to-night at the Auditorium and his speech was received with much attention, it being one of the first public addresses made by him since his appointment to his present office.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The bill introduced by Senator Stranahah amending the present tenement house law, and which has the approval of Mayor Low and the city authorities of New York, was vigorously attacked by the representatives of Brooklyn building interests and as forcibly defended by Tenement House Commissioner Robert W. De Forest at the hearing to-day in the Senate Chamber before the Cities Committees of the Senate and the Assembly.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- George Standing of the New York Racquet Club to-day won the first of his matches against Harry Boakes, the Chicago Athletic Association professional, taking three out of the four games played. The exhibition was one of the best ever seen in the courts of the Michigan Avenue Club.

Lawyer Robert M. Moore finished yesterday his two days of cross-examination of valet Charles F. Jones, the accuser of Albert T. Patrick on trial charged with the murder of William Marsh Rice. Assistant District Attorney Osborne began the redirect examination just before adjournment.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The proprietors of the Baldwin Locomotive Works celebrated the seventieth anniversary of the founding of the works and the completion of the twenty thousandth locomotive by a dinner given at the Union League this evening, at which 250 prominent men were guests.

The February meeting of the Legal Aid Society was held yesterday at the office of the President, Arthur Von Briesen, 49 Wall Street. These officers were elected, for the ensuing year: President -- Arthur Von Briesen; Treasurer -- Robert Behr; Secretary -- Walter M. Taussig. Miss Rosalie Loew, the attorney of the society, was also re-elected.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Feb. 27. -- It is understood that the United States will shortly take steps to obtain the reimbursement of the $72.500 paid to the brigands as ransom for Miss Stone, holding Turkey responsible, inasmuch as the capture of the missionaries was effected on Turkish soil.

Among the things which Prince HEINRICH will not have time to notice in the rush, of visiting are the German words which have become adoptive citizens in America. While we are summing up all that we owe the Fatherland, why should these humble additions to our copious tongue be overlooked?

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the letter of your esteemed correspondent concerning Jamestown Island in last Sunday's issue, let me say that Jamestown Island contains approximately 1,600 acres. Of this, the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, (of which I am a member as well as your correspondent,) owns 22 1/2 acres, having received the property by gift from its patriotic owners, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Everett Barney.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The local market was dominated by Union Traction. The persistent rise in these shares brought out a fresh supply of profit-taking sales this morning, but after these had been cleared up the price began to rise again, and in the last hour the stock was taken in large lots, one block going at 40.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27. -- O'Hagen and Tragedy were the beaten favorites to-day. Odom rode three winners. In the second race May Alien clipped a second off the track record. Weather cloudy; track good. Summary:

The only painter in France who still attracts American artists is Claude Monet, for we hear no more of pupils of Gerome and Bonnat and Carolus Duran, and the cold and smooth drawing of Bouguereau is anathema on the lips of the rising generation of foreigners who are faithful to Paris and her schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The special train carrying Prince Henry of Prussia, his suite, and the American escort made its second trip from New York to Washington on schedule time. It left Jersey City at 1:30 o'clock this morning, and at 9 o'clock rolled into the Pennsylvania station here. There was no delay in the flooded districts of New Jersey, but the train was slowed down whenever there was a possibility of danger.

The hockey players of the St. Nicholas Skating Club won an easy victory from the Brooklyn Skating Club seven in an amateur league championship hockey game at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The score was 5 to 2, and could have been larger if the home players had tried harder. St. Nicholas's chief merit was in the strength of her defense, which again and again rendered unavailing the efforts of the Brooklyn forwards.

Glenview, near Chicago, won the honor last night for the amateur golf championship of the United States for the present year. Twenty-one of the twenty-six associated clubs in the United States Golf Association voted on the question of giving the leading golf tournament of the year to the West or the East, and the West won by 27 ballots to 14.
PARIS, Feb. 27. -- A splendid gift has been made for the benefit of the American colony here and American visitors to Paris by Edward Tuck, who, has for many years resided in this city.

For a Lenten Thursday it was a busy day. There were several sewing class meetings and a number of dinners. Mrs. William Schermerhorn gave a musicale in the afternoon. The largest dinner in the evening was given by Mr. and Mrs. George Vanderbilt.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- There is trouble in the First Brigade, National Guard, over the election of a brigade commander to succeed Gen. Wanser, promoted to be division commander. Under the law of 1900 Captains of Artillery and troops are given a right to vote for brigade commander.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- The resumption of gold exports has as yet made little or no impression upon the tone of the money market. The situation is still extremely comfortable, and demand is still very light. Clearing House rate, 2 1/2 per cent.; New York funds, 10 cents discount; call loans, 3 to 3 1/2; time money, 4 to 4 1/2; Clearing House exchanges, $22,336,252.

On the French line steamship La Champagne, which sailed for Havre yesterday, $3,500,000 in bold was shipped. This was the largest shipment sent to Europe in a month of February or March since 1894. The total shipment for February now amounts to $7,800,000 against $416,812 for February of last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- When under special order the Senate convened this morning at 11:45, in order that it might attend the McKinley memorial service, Mr. Frye, President pro tem., said after the call to order that by his direction on last Monday the clerk had not called the names of the two Senators from South Carolina, they being in contempt of the body.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- The rule to show cause recently granted by Vice Chancellor Stevenson why the Central Trust Company of New York should not be permanently restrained from selling at foreclosure sale the properties and mills of the United States Flour Milling Company of New York, came up before Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day, when the defendant, the Central Trust Company, through Lindabury, Depue Foulks, presented its answer.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- "One of the most beautiful pages in our international relations is the record of these festivities," says the Cologne Gazette, referring to Prince Henry's visit to the United States. It adds:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Central Office detectives were here to-day trying to locate Mrs. Fred Burns of Brooklyn, mother of Florence Burns, who is wanted as a witness in the Brooks murder case. They visited all the families by the name of Burns in this city and vicinity, but got no clue to the Brooklyn women.

Though dullness continues and the market is without features of exciting interest, quotations maintained firmness and the market's undertone is undisturbed by any of the petty bear inventions that from day to day cause more or less noisiness.
